17/10/17, 8:18‚ÄØam
A (fairly longish!) account of the marvelous murals of Hampi at: http://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/entrancing-murals-of-hampi
They are the last remaining examples of the Vijayanagar style of paintings.
Do have a look at them in the google photos link. If you click on the i link on the right hand corner, details of the paintings will be visible.
Would appreciate if you could post your comments in the weebly blog.
Thanks!

2018

Blog & posts

08/01/18, 10:41‚ÄØam
Ahalya and myself were in Siem Reap recently, exploring the rich heritage of the Angkor region.
Over a period of time, I will be posting experiences (and images!) of our sojourn!
The jewel of Khmer architecture is Banteay Srei.
We spent a whole morning savoring the beauty of this wonderful little temple and our account is at: http://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/splendors-of-banteay-srei.
I look forward to your comments and suggestions and would appreciate if you post them in the weebly website rather than at the google photos!
Warmly
Ragu & Ahalya

It was a nostalgic reunion last week, fifty years after we entered the medical school at JIPMER.
As we shared our memories of years gone by, I was also reminiscing about my rite of passage to the medical school.
Do have a look at: http://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/down-the-memory-lane
And feel free to post your comments in the blog!

15/02/18, 3:27‚ÄØpm
Sir this is with reference to a patient Ranjini,32yrs referred by Dr. Satish Girimaji. She was seen by Dr. NJR, between 2010 to 2015, on medication for psychosis, Oleanz stopped in 2015. She did her BSc and later MSc in biotech though with difficulty. After graduation on the advice of some Counsellor got her married, but she ran back to her parent's place the very next day of marriage and later divorced. She tried but failed to continue with 3 to 4 jobs. Her daily routine was mainly sleeping, doing petty errands till she got married again to Srinivas who is coming to see you. He was taken to DR NJR before marriage who told him about her thought process. Right now over the past 2mths after marriage, husband complains about her negative symptoms slow to do work, dies not know cooking, value of things, not talking to people, withdrawn, preoccupied, asking 'silly' questions, not being romantic, may not be able to rear children etc. He appears to be forceful wants categorical answer how long she will take to become normal and that he finds it difficult to go on as he is already 40yrs old. Off late he accuses her of having taken 10, 000, from Cupboard. Her father is a prof of National law school. He would like to meet you later.

During first yr of degree was ditched by boy friend and was depressed. Currently continues to have low confidence, difficult to cope up with problems, prefers to be at home, not motivated to do anything, at times even the regular household duties, tends to oversleep, feels rejected, lonely, scared to take up new tasks, hopelessness, helplessness. It is with a sense of deep dismay I have to share the sad news of the passing away of Dr GG Prabhu at Mysore. A person of exceptional importance and a colossus who shaped the discipline of clinical psychology in India. He was Ahalya's Phd guide and made it a point to attend the festschrift that was organized by the department on the occasion of her superannuation, in spite of his infirmities. We cherish our long association with this giant and warmly recollect the evening we spent with him in Mysore before we left for US. An irreplaceable loss personally and for the profession at large
10/07/19, 8:32‚ÄØam

10/07/19, 9:46‚ÄØam
It triggered off lot of conflicting feelings. Lot of things didn't fall into their places in my life. But a strong passion to continue in the field of Psychology made me go against family members when I kicked the Gov job and joined M.Phil was realised and I am so greatful to Prof. Could not share the hurt which was hurled in the dept. because it was my decision. Previous night when Aditya passed away I had mentally felt hatred towards Prof as I used to be extremely anxious during his pregnancy. I felt like that probably it was a premonition and after all I am his mother. Aditya passed away on July 30th. It is important to work on the meaning of life and our 'selves' though it is like taking a 360 degree turn. Have been doing it. Sorry to bother you Sir. I felt like sharing which I don't usually do.

Festivals

15/01/20, 10:33‚ÄØam
Thank you Sir. Wish you all a very happy and auspicious Pongal.
22/08/20, 7:57‚ÄØam
In the words of Adi Shankara Lord Ganesha is 'Ajam Nirvikalpam Niraakaaramekam.' He is Ajam (unborn), he is Nirvikalpa (attributeless), he is Niraakaar (formless) and he symbolizes the consciousness which is omnipresent.The formless divinity finds a beautiful expression in this delicate carving at Khajuraho
24/10/20, 8:27‚ÄØam
DAY 8
One of the most unusual Mahishasuramardini sculptures in India is this iconic Pallava creation at the Kailasanathar Temple at Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu. Constructed over a 20-year period from 685 to 705 CE, the Kailasanathar Temple is the first structural temple built by the Pallavas, after their earlier experiments with rock-cut temples at Mahabalipuram. The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and named after his abode on Mount Kailash. There are two Mahishasuramardini sculptures: a larger one on the outer wall of the sanctum and a smaller one sculpted within one of the 58 miniature shrines that are built into the niches of the surrounding wall. Though smaller in size compared to other, it is exquisite.
Unlike the other Mahishasurmardini panels which we have seen so far, this one has no Mahishasura in the frame. Instead we see a triumphant Durga posing in the aftermath of her victory in a strikingly confident posture. Her left leg is placed on the back of the lion which is vividly sculpted. Her left hand is rests casually on the raised left knee. Her right hand is gripping her hip, and there is a noticeable bend at the waist which gives grace and movement to the whole sculpture. Notice the long bow held by her, which is taller than she is! These sculptures in the smaller shrines were once painted with vegetable dyes. One can notice the remnants of it on the wall behind. How resplendent she would have been at that time!
24/10/20, 10:45‚ÄØam
Oh what a beauty Sir and your description of the same leaves me speechless as there is nothing to add on. Fingers are exquisitely sculpted and the smile goes with her triumphant posture. It is a feast to the eyes. Wish you all a very happy Durgashtami.
25/10/20, 7:34‚ÄØam
DAY 9
After some fabulous birding at Mangalajodi in Orissa, I enquired at the place where I was staying as to whether they could arrange a vehicle for me to visit Dakhya Prajapati temple at Banapur. They were surprised at my interests extending beyond the feathered friends and said ‚ÄúWhy do you want to go there doctor? There is just an old temple there!‚Äù Undeterred, I asked for a taxi and after a journey of one and a half hours we reached the small dusty town of Banapur.
When I got down from the car, I was surrounded by a group of boys who were playing cricket outside the temple. They were curious as to why I was visiting the place and kept following me as I went around the temple which was totally deserted.
Dakhya Prajapati temple is one of the relatively well preserved monuments of the Ganga period. It is dated to the Eastern Ganga dynasty which ruled in the early part of 13th century. It was during this period that temple architecture reached its pinnacle in Orissa. The temple is carved out of khondolite stone, which is named after the khond tribe, in whose terrain it is often sourced. Most of the temples in Orissa, including the Sun Temple at Konarak are built with this type of stone, which unfortunately is easily eroded by weather.
The temple tower is in the Nagara style and is intricately carved with many beautiful figures. These figures were interspersed with delicate scroll work. Among them was a small sculpture of Mahishasuramardini which was enclosed by a stunning border. Durga‚Äôs encounter with Mahisha has been a popular subject among artists for centuries. Most often she is depicted either serenely or victoriously, standing on the decapitated head of the buffalo or in the act of killing a buffalo headed figure from whose cut neck the demon emerges. The focus of the depiction here was not on the combat between the goddess and the demon, but on the goddess herself. She is seated here with wearing the karanda mukuta crown resembling a basket. Though her face was eroded, she seemed to be looking directly at the observer, offering her blessings. Mahishasura is usually represented in three forms: in his zoomorphic form he is shown as a buffalo, in the theriomorphic form he is supposed to have the body of a buffalo and the head of a man, and in the anthropomorphic form. Mahishasura can be seen at the bottom in the human form here. The iconography of Mahishasuramardini has never been a stagnant one and has undergone changes over time as the image was incorporated and depicted in different regions of India. As time progressed, the images also became more ornate.
After having a good look at the sculptures, I entered the sanctum and was warmly welcomed by a young man who spoke English. After offering the arathi to the main deity, he narrated the mythology associated with the temple. Dakhya is the son of Brahma and the father of Sati. Dakhya means ‚Äúable‚Äù and Prajapati is the Lord of all creatures. Here he is worshipped in the form of Lord Siva as Dakhyeswar. Hence it is also referred to as Dakhyeswar Siva temple.
As I was leaving, I asked him as to how he spoke such good English! He told me that he worked as a laborer in Whitefield, but grew tired of the urban chaos and returned home. He said ‚ÄúI come here every day and offer puja to the deity‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt earn much but I find immense peace in serving him..it is a labor of love‚Äù I was deeply touched by his words.
In his own quiet way he was conveying that fulfillment through exalted work is the highest form of virtue in life.
Traveling in not just about discovering places. There is something undeniably magical in these small moments when you meet people who open up new vistas and enrich your understanding of life.
Aren‚Äôt we all stones
Dreaming of shapes
That we might become
Awaiting the chisel
Of the Creator?
18/11/20, 6:58‚ÄØpm

22/10/20, 8:44‚ÄØam
DAY 6
I relish discovering places and temples that are off the tourist radar.
Udaipur is not just about lakes and palaces. When I was there sometime back for a CME, after finishing my talk I enquired about a (unusually named) temple referred as Saasbahu temple. With some effort I found a local taxi driver who seemed to know the place, which was just an hour‚Äôs drive from Udaipur.
Located in the lap of the Aravalli mountain range, it was a charming structure by the side of a lake, surrounded by mustard fields. There was an aged guard who opened the gates and let me in. The early morning sun was playing hide and seek with the richly carved exterior of the temple
Built in the late 10th century, the larger temple (referred to as Saas) is surrounded by ten subsidiary shrines and is more profusely decorated than the smaller (Bahu) temple which has four shrines and an octagonal ceiling. The story goes that king Mahipala married a queen who was a devotee of Lord Vishnu and he constructed a temple dedicated to Vishnu for his wife to offer prayers. Years later, the king‚Äôs son married a princess who was devotee of Lord Shiva so he constructed another temple nearby for his daughter in law. Since the Vishnu temple was constructed first it was known as Sahastrabaahu temple meaning the lord with thousand arms though it included the Shiva temple as well. The name however got corrupted over a period of time to be called ‚ÄúSaas Bahu temple‚Äù much before the TV serial!
Made of granite, the carvings are quite remarkable and among them, this one of Mahishasuramardini caught my attention. Even though details of her face have been lost with the passage of time, the flowing lines enhance her graceful poise which is embellished with rich ornamentation. She is portrayed with a sword in her hand after killing the demon whose head is clearly seen on the ground. Though on a pragmatic level decapitation represents the loss of power, perhaps it is also a liberative act indicating that human pride and ego must be severed in order to attain salvation.
22/10/20, 10:33‚ÄØam
Thank you Sir for the rare journey into centuries old temples, which definitely have their own pure dedication to sculpture and vibrations. Yes, symbolic representation shouldn't be missed out.
23/10/20, 7:37‚ÄØam
DAY 7
Sometimes travelling in India is like a leap in the dark. One starts exploring destinations and discovering places which open up an entirely different world of experiences. My visit to Bhoramdeo was one such. While in Raipur for the Annual Conference of the Indian Psychiatric Society, I suddenly decided on a whim, to visit the place about which I had read a long while ago.
At first view, the temple stunned me. Set amidst a thick canopy of tall trees it was serenely beautiful. Soft morning rays of the winter sun dappled their way over the sal and bija leaves, setting the temple aglow with a golden lustre. The central tower composed of receding rows of exquisitely carved sculptures tapering upwards, seemed to replicate the receding hills of the Makali range in the background.
Dating back to the 7th century, it was Alexander Cunningham who discovered this temple which was engulfed by a dense forest, overgrown with vegetation. Taken aback by the sheer artistry of the temple he is said to have commented that ‚Äòit is one of the most beautifully decorated temple seen by him.‚Äô He also contended that it was originally dedicated to Vishnu and subsequently during the period of Gond supremacy in the region, the Vishnu idol was replaced with a Shivalinga in the sanctum. As the Gond tribals of the area worship Lord Shiva as Bhoramdeo, the temple was also named Bhoramdeo.
The outer walls of the temple were embellished with panel upon panel of delicate sculptures, covering a wide range of themes from the religious, the symbolic to the erotic. Because of the profusion of erotic sculptures and its structural similarity, it is often referred to as the ‚ÄúKhajuraho of Chattisgarh‚Äù. High up on the tower is a sculpture of Mahishasuramardini. Since it has been carved in chlorite stone, there has been considerable damage to the sculpture. In spite of it her face is serene and the ornamentation is exquisite.
Chipped, battered, broken, and yet elegant, its radiant beauty transcends its imperfection...
23/10/20, 10:04‚ÄØam
Sir thanks for giving us a chance to take a glimpse of the hidden treasure.
24/10/20, 10:45‚ÄØam
Oh what a beauty Sir and your description of the same leaves me speechless as there is nothing to add on. Fingers are exquisitely sculpted and the smile goes with her triumphant posture. It is a feast to the eyes. Wish you all a very happy Durgashtami.
25/10/20, 7:34‚ÄØam
DAY 9
After some fabulous birding at Mangalajodi in Orissa, I enquired at the place where I was staying as to whether they could arrange a vehicle for me to visit Dakhya Prajapati temple at Banapur. They were surprised at my interests extending beyond the feathered friends and said ‚ÄúWhy do you want to go there doctor? There is just an old temple there!‚Äù Undeterred, I asked for a taxi and after a journey of one and a half hours we reached the small dusty town of Banapur.
When I got down from the car, I was surrounded by a group of boys who were playing cricket outside the temple. They were curious as to why I was visiting the place and kept following me as I went around the temple which was totally deserted.
Dakhya Prajapati temple is one of the relatively well preserved monuments of the Ganga period. It is dated to the Eastern Ganga dynasty which ruled in the early part of 13th century. It was during this period that temple architecture reached its pinnacle in Orissa. The temple is carved out of khondolite stone, which is named after the khond tribe, in whose terrain it is often sourced. Most of the temples in Orissa, including the Sun Temple at Konarak are built with this type of stone, which unfortunately is easily eroded by weather.
The temple tower is in the Nagara style and is intricately carved with many beautiful figures. These figures were interspersed with delicate scroll work. Among them was a small sculpture of Mahishasuramardini which was enclosed by a stunning border. Durga‚Äôs encounter with Mahisha has been a popular subject among artists for centuries. Most often she is depicted either serenely or victoriously, standing on the decapitated head of the buffalo or in the act of killing a buffalo headed figure from whose cut neck the demon emerges. The focus of the depiction here was not on the combat between the goddess and the demon, but on the goddess herself. She is seated here with wearing the karanda mukuta crown resembling a basket. Though her face was eroded, she seemed to be looking directly at the observer, offering her blessings. Mahishasura is usually represented in three forms: in his zoomorphic form he is shown as a buffalo, in the theriomorphic form he is supposed to have the body of a buffalo and the head of a man, and in the anthropomorphic form. Mahishasura can be seen at the bottom in the human form here. The iconography of Mahishasuramardini has never been a stagnant one and has undergone changes over time as the image was incorporated and depicted in different regions of India. As time progressed, the images also became more ornate.
After having a good look at the sculptures, I entered the sanctum and was warmly welcomed by a young man who spoke English. After offering the arathi to the main deity, he narrated the mythology associated with the temple. Dakhya is the son of Brahma and the father of Sati. Dakhya means ‚Äúable‚Äù and Prajapati is the Lord of all creatures. Here he is worshipped in the form of Lord Siva as Dakhyeswar. Hence it is also referred to as Dakhyeswar Siva temple.
As I was leaving, I asked him as to how he spoke such good English! He told me that he worked as a laborer in Whitefield, but grew tired of the urban chaos and returned home. He said ‚ÄúI come here every day and offer puja to the deity‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt earn much but I find immense peace in serving him..it is a labor of love‚Äù I was deeply touched by his words.
In his own quiet way he was conveying that fulfillment through exalted work is the highest form of virtue in life.
Traveling in not just about discovering places. There is something undeniably magical in these small moments when you meet people who open up new vistas and enrich your understanding of life.
Aren‚Äôt we all stones
Dreaming of shapes
That we might become
Awaiting the chisel
Of the Creator?
25/10/20, 10:39‚ÄØam
We are so deeply steeped in the materialistic world not giving credence to the the small things which may not give money or name. Very moving but validates the thoughts. Thanks Sir for a holistic trip!
26/10/20, 7:47‚ÄØam
DAY 10
Over the last nine days, I had posted various sculptural depictions of Mahishasuramardini across India‚Ä¶each one of them distinctly different and impressive. On this tenth day of Vijayadashami let me take you down south to Tirunelveli district of Tamil Nadu.
When the Vijayanagara Empire fell, it splintered into several smaller kingdoms controlled by Nayakas, Telugu-speaking warriors from the Andhra region. The greatest period of temple construction in Tamil Nadu after the famed Chola temples of the 11th-13th centuries occurred during their rule.
The ancient temple at Thirukurungudi, situated an hour‚Äôs drive from Tirunelveli is one such gem. As per the Vaishnava tradition, Thirukkurungudi is one among the 108 Vaishnava shrines and is said to be the ‚ÄòSouthern Home‚Äô of Lord Vishnu and is hence called ‚ÄòDakshina Badri‚Äô.
The main deity is Azhagiya Nambi Rayar also referred to as ‚ÄúSundara Paripoornam‚Äù, meaning ‚ÄúPerfect and complete beauty‚Äù. True to its name, it is one of the most beautiful portrayals of Vishnu. Not just the main deity, the entire temple complex is replete with some stunningly gorgeous sculptures.
The Chitra Gopuram of the temple is one of the most beautiful structures I have ever seen. Every inch of its fa√ßade is richly carved with panels depicting scenes from various epics. Each one of them demonstrates the sculptors' careful attention to detail and depict many mythological themes which are found nowhere else.
The most attractive section in the Chitra Gopuram depicts the slaying of the demon Mahishasura. In one of the smallest of panels in the tower, the talented sculptor has carved the scene in intricate detail. Devi is seen with eighteen hands, each one of them holding a different weapon and objects. Even the folds of her dress have been engraved with much care; every fold and every crease is visible. Her right leg is firmly in position on Mahisha‚Äôs neck, while piercing him with a sharp trident. As the Asura warriors watch the scene, the lion is also sinking its teeth into the demon. The victorious smile on her face is unmistakable!
As her arrow
Rests in the quiver
Let us recall these lines . . .

‚ÄúWhenever trouble arises due to the advent of the demons, I shall incarnate and destroy the foes. ‚Äú
(Markandeypurana, 91.51: Eleventh Chapter of the Devi Mahatmya)

As I explored the dark confines of the temple gopuram of Thiruppudaimaruthur, I was surrounded by exquisitely carved small wooden sculptures that adorned every inch of the space, blending seamlessly with the murals on the wall. The light from my mobile as I was shining on them was like a magical lantern bringing them alive

25/06/20, 4:26‚ÄØpm

11/08/20, 11:19‚ÄØam
One of the commonest representations of Lord Krishna is Venugopala.
Perhaps the finest depictions I have ever seen and that too in terracotta medium was in Bishnupur. The temples walls of Bishnupur are extensively embellished with carved and molded terracotta decorations made from the locally available laterite clay. These temples are associated with the Gaudiya Vaishnava faith, dating back to seventeenth century. Understandably then the temple walls are covered with terracotta panels recounting the life and exploits of Krishna.
Among them is this exquisitely carved depiction of Krishna playing the flute in the classic tribhanga pose, with gentle bends at the neck, waist and knee. He is surrounded by gopis who are entranced by his music, with peacocks and deer keeping them company. Do notice the finely chiseled carpet-like patterning of the terracotta facade of the entire fa√ßade of the temple.
What does the flute really signify? Hollow and empty, it does not produce any sound of its own. Travails we experience in life are like holes in the flute. We have to breathe life into it and let the melodious notes unfold‚Ä¶
22/08/20, 7:57‚ÄØam
In the words of Adi Shankara Lord Ganesha is 'Ajam Nirvikalpam Niraakaaramekam.' He is Ajam (unborn), he is Nirvikalpa (attributeless), he is Niraakaar (formless) and he symbolizes the consciousness which is omnipresent.The formless divinity finds a beautiful expression in this delicate carving at Khajuraho
18/09/20, 8:14‚ÄØpm
https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/at-the-threshold-of-farther-shores
18/09/20, 8:14‚ÄØpm
This post is close to my heart...Do take sometime and share your refections in the website...would value your comments there in preference to WhatsApp!
17/10/20, 9:50‚ÄØam
Over the course of next few days I will be posting various depictions of Devi. Chalukyas were the forbears of South Indian sculptures traditions and were the first to
introduce the rock cut architectural tradition in South India. The Chalukyan artists were also the first in conceiving and depicting Mahishasuramardini in sculpturar form in South India.Here Mahishasuramardini is seen with four hands. Her lower left hand is holding the tail of the buffalo and with the trident on her lower right hand, she is piercing its head. One can clearly notice the spear going through the head of the buffalo. She is neither riding a tiger and nor is the asura depicted in human form. This is the sculptuea in Cave 1 at Badami
17/10/20, 10:34‚ÄØam
Yes Sir. And Lord Vishnu's Shanka and Chakra in two hands! Very nice. Will look forward to the other depictions.
18/10/20, 9:59‚ÄØam
Ravana Phadi cave temple was conceived at the same time like that of the cave temples of Badami. But here, the artisans have excelled themselves in creating a prototype of a regular temple by carving it into a huge sandstone boulder. There is a large plain field in front with a nandi facing the temple. Two pillared halls are on either side of the entrance. Once you ascend the steps and enter the cave one notices that the interiors are much larger than any other cave in Badami. All the walls of the cave have exquisite carvings and one among them is Mahishasuramardini.
Here the goddess is portrayed with eight arms. With the weight of her left leg she is holding the buffalo demon Mahisha down, while spearing it with the trishula. On one of her left hands she is holding the head of the buffalo. She is also carrying a sword and a bow and is seen wearing an elaborate, conical crown. On her left one can spot a lion. Compared to the sculpture of Mahishasuramardini in Badami, here the goddess is more energetic and graceful.
Unfortunately ravages of time and vagaries of neglect have left their impact on this beautiful sculpture. An earlier sketch by an unknown draughtsman in 1853 will give an idea as to how gorgeous it would have been when it was sculpted. . .
18/10/20, 12:08‚ÄØpm
Very sad to see the distorted sculpture but the draftman's work helps us to go back to the time, imagine and appreciate the gracefulness of the sculpture.
20/10/20, 7:16‚ÄØam
Mahishasuramardini is often depicted standing on a decapitated buffalo head or in the act of killing it, from whose head a demon in the form of a man emerges. But the most vibrant depiction of the goddess is in an exquisite bas relief in a small cave in Mahabalipuram which depicts her in battle scene with Mahishasura. She is shown riding a prancing lion and holding various weapons in her eight hands, attacking the demon who is retreating from her onslaught, accepting his defeat. It is the finest depiction of the epic battle scene. I kept wondering as to what could have been the source of inspiration for this majestic creative art.
As I was exploring the Mallikarjuna temple in Pattadakkal, I was struck by a small panel, worn out with years, in a dark corner. In its miniature form it seemed to be a prototype for the grand battle scene at Mahabalipuram! The spirit of experimentation patronized by the Early Chalukya dynasty perhaps has been the source of inspiration for the sculptors to create a majestic, larger version at Mahabalipuram!
Though the Pallavas and Chalukyas have been known for their incessant rivalry, the wars between the two dynasties never came in-between the growth of rich cultural heritage. Their mutual exchange and influence of architectural styles can be seen in the beauty, rhythm and vigor captured in stone by their masterful craftsmen. The Mahishasuramardini panel in Pattadakkal and Mahabalipuram is the perfect example of this remarkable confluence.
21/10/20, 8:07‚ÄØam
DAY FIVE
The shore temple at Mahabalipuram dates back to 8th century and it is generally believed that it is actually a small part of a temple complex which existed eons ago. It demonstrates the progression of Pallava temple architecture from rock cut structures to free standing structural shrines. Though years of wind and erosion from sea water have worn away the details of many carvings, there is a strikingly large free standing sculpture of a lion on the southern side of the temple. It is actually a miniature temple! A carved alcove in its heart serves as the sanctum, within which is a carving of Mahishasuramardini. The goddess is shown sitting astride triumphantly on the severed head of the buffalo demon. Two dwaraphalakis are carved on either side of the lion, clasping it. Mahishasuramardini is often portrayed riding a lion or a tiger. Here she has found a place in a lion‚Äôs heart! The Upanishadic concept that likens the heart to a cave within which resides a hidden self is emphasized here. Perhaps in portraying Mahshasuramardini in this form, the sculptors are conveying that within each of us is a heart of a lion where courage and power resides to vanquish negative forces!
21/10/20, 12:42‚ÄØpm
Sir you have a fantastic eye for details. The sculpture is so beautiful and the hands and legs are so slender and shapely! And the discovery you have made!
21/10/20, 12:48‚ÄØpm
Yes. Instead of just hailing the beauty of the sculpture, the interpretation that you have given is very apt. It boosts the spirit to fight.
22/10/20, 8:44‚ÄØam
DAY 6
I relish discovering places and temples that are off the tourist radar.
Udaipur is not just about lakes and palaces. When I was there sometime back for a CME, after finishing my talk I enquired about a (unusually named) temple referred as Saasbahu temple. With some effort I found a local taxi driver who seemed to know the place, which was just an hour‚Äôs drive from Udaipur.
Located in the lap of the Aravalli mountain range, it was a charming structure by the side of a lake, surrounded by mustard fields. There was an aged guard who opened the gates and let me in. The early morning sun was playing hide and seek with the richly carved exterior of the temple
Built in the late 10th century, the larger temple (referred to as Saas) is surrounded by ten subsidiary shrines and is more profusely decorated than the smaller (Bahu) temple which has four shrines and an octagonal ceiling. The story goes that king Mahipala married a queen who was a devotee of Lord Vishnu and he constructed a temple dedicated to Vishnu for his wife to offer prayers. Years later, the king‚Äôs son married a princess who was devotee of Lord Shiva so he constructed another temple nearby for his daughter in law. Since the Vishnu temple was constructed first it was known as Sahastrabaahu temple meaning the lord with thousand arms though it included the Shiva temple as well. The name however got corrupted over a period of time to be called ‚ÄúSaas Bahu temple‚Äù much before the TV serial!
Made of granite, the carvings are quite remarkable and among them, this one of Mahishasuramardini caught my attention. Even though details of her face have been lost with the passage of time, the flowing lines enhance her graceful poise which is embellished with rich ornamentation. She is portrayed with a sword in her hand after killing the demon whose head is clearly seen on the ground. Though on a pragmatic level decapitation represents the loss of power, perhaps it is also a liberative act indicating that human pride and ego must be severed in order to attain salvation.
22/10/20, 10:33‚ÄØam
Thank you Sir for the rare journey into centuries old temples, which definitely have their own pure dedication to sculpture and vibrations. Yes, symbolic representation shouldn't be missed out.
23/10/20, 7:37‚ÄØam
DAY 7
Sometimes travelling in India is like a leap in the dark. One starts exploring destinations and discovering places which open up an entirely different world of experiences. My visit to Bhoramdeo was one such. While in Raipur for the Annual Conference of the Indian Psychiatric Society, I suddenly decided on a whim, to visit the place about which I had read a long while ago.
At first view, the temple stunned me. Set amidst a thick canopy of tall trees it was serenely beautiful. Soft morning rays of the winter sun dappled their way over the sal and bija leaves, setting the temple aglow with a golden lustre. The central tower composed of receding rows of exquisitely carved sculptures tapering upwards, seemed to replicate the receding hills of the Makali range in the background.
Dating back to the 7th century, it was Alexander Cunningham who discovered this temple which was engulfed by a dense forest, overgrown with vegetation. Taken aback by the sheer artistry of the temple he is said to have commented that ‚Äòit is one of the most beautifully decorated temple seen by him.‚Äô He also contended that it was originally dedicated to Vishnu and subsequently during the period of Gond supremacy in the region, the Vishnu idol was replaced with a Shivalinga in the sanctum. As the Gond tribals of the area worship Lord Shiva as Bhoramdeo, the temple was also named Bhoramdeo.
The outer walls of the temple were embellished with panel upon panel of delicate sculptures, covering a wide range of themes from the religious, the symbolic to the erotic. Because of the profusion of erotic sculptures and its structural similarity, it is often referred to as the ‚ÄúKhajuraho of Chattisgarh‚Äù. High up on the tower is a sculpture of Mahishasuramardini. Since it has been carved in chlorite stone, there has been considerable damage to the sculpture. In spite of it her face is serene and the ornamentation is exquisite.
Chipped, battered, broken, and yet elegant, its radiant beauty transcends its imperfection...
24/10/20, 8:27‚ÄØam
DAY 8
One of the most unusual Mahishasuramardini sculptures in India is this iconic Pallava creation at the Kailasanathar Temple at Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu. Constructed over a 20-year period from 685 to 705 CE, the Kailasanathar Temple is the first structural temple built by the Pallavas, after their earlier experiments with rock-cut temples at Mahabalipuram. The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and named after his abode on Mount Kailash. There are two Mahishasuramardini sculptures: a larger one on the outer wall of the sanctum and a smaller one sculpted within one of the 58 miniature shrines that are built into the niches of the surrounding wall. Though smaller in size compared to other, it is exquisite.
Unlike the other Mahishasurmardini panels which we have seen so far, this one has no Mahishasura in the frame. Instead we see a triumphant Durga posing in the aftermath of her victory in a strikingly confident posture. Her left leg is placed on the back of the lion which is vividly sculpted. Her left hand is rests casually on the raised left knee. Her right hand is gripping her hip, and there is a noticeable bend at the waist which gives grace and movement to the whole sculpture. Notice the long bow held by her, which is taller than she is! These sculptures in the smaller shrines were once painted with vegetable dyes. One can notice the remnants of it on the wall behind. How resplendent she would have been at that time!
24/10/20, 10:45‚ÄØam
Oh what a beauty Sir and your description of the same leaves me speechless as there is nothing to add on. Fingers are exquisitely sculpted and the smile goes with her triumphant posture. It is a feast to the eyes. Wish you all a very happy Durgashtami.
25/10/20, 7:34‚ÄØam
DAY 9
After some fabulous birding at Mangalajodi in Orissa, I enquired at the place where I was staying as to whether they could arrange a vehicle for me to visit Dakhya Prajapati temple at Banapur. They were surprised at my interests extending beyond the feathered friends and said ‚ÄúWhy do you want to go there doctor? There is just an old temple there!‚Äù Undeterred, I asked for a taxi and after a journey of one and a half hours we reached the small dusty town of Banapur.
When I got down from the car, I was surrounded by a group of boys who were playing cricket outside the temple. They were curious as to why I was visiting the place and kept following me as I went around the temple which was totally deserted.
Dakhya Prajapati temple is one of the relatively well preserved monuments of the Ganga period. It is dated to the Eastern Ganga dynasty which ruled in the early part of 13th century. It was during this period that temple architecture reached its pinnacle in Orissa. The temple is carved out of khondolite stone, which is named after the khond tribe, in whose terrain it is often sourced. Most of the temples in Orissa, including the Sun Temple at Konarak are built with this type of stone, which unfortunately is easily eroded by weather.
The temple tower is in the Nagara style and is intricately carved with many beautiful figures. These figures were interspersed with delicate scroll work. Among them was a small sculpture of Mahishasuramardini which was enclosed by a stunning border. Durga‚Äôs encounter with Mahisha has been a popular subject among artists for centuries. Most often she is depicted either serenely or victoriously, standing on the decapitated head of the buffalo or in the act of killing a buffalo headed figure from whose cut neck the demon emerges. The focus of the depiction here was not on the combat between the goddess and the demon, but on the goddess herself. She is seated here with wearing the karanda mukuta crown resembling a basket. Though her face was eroded, she seemed to be looking directly at the observer, offering her blessings. Mahishasura is usually represented in three forms: in his zoomorphic form he is shown as a buffalo, in the theriomorphic form he is supposed to have the body of a buffalo and the head of a man, and in the anthropomorphic form. Mahishasura can be seen at the bottom in the human form here. The iconography of Mahishasuramardini has never been a stagnant one and has undergone changes over time as the image was incorporated and depicted in different regions of India. As time progressed, the images also became more ornate.
After having a good look at the sculptures, I entered the sanctum and was warmly welcomed by a young man who spoke English. After offering the arathi to the main deity, he narrated the mythology associated with the temple. Dakhya is the son of Brahma and the father of Sati. Dakhya means ‚Äúable‚Äù and Prajapati is the Lord of all creatures. Here he is worshipped in the form of Lord Siva as Dakhyeswar. Hence it is also referred to as Dakhyeswar Siva temple.
As I was leaving, I asked him as to how he spoke such good English! He told me that he worked as a laborer in Whitefield, but grew tired of the urban chaos and returned home. He said ‚ÄúI come here every day and offer puja to the deity‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt earn much but I find immense peace in serving him..it is a labor of love‚Äù I was deeply touched by his words.
In his own quiet way he was conveying that fulfillment through exalted work is the highest form of virtue in life.
Traveling in not just about discovering places. There is something undeniably magical in these small moments when you meet people who open up new vistas and enrich your understanding of life.
Aren‚Äôt we all stones
Dreaming of shapes
That we might become
Awaiting the chisel
Of the Creator?
26/10/20, 7:47‚ÄØam
DAY 10
Over the last nine days, I had posted various sculptural depictions of Mahishasuramardini across India‚Ä¶each one of them distinctly different and impressive. On this tenth day of Vijayadashami let me take you down south to Tirunelveli district of Tamil Nadu.
When the Vijayanagara Empire fell, it splintered into several smaller kingdoms controlled by Nayakas, Telugu-speaking warriors from the Andhra region. The greatest period of temple construction in Tamil Nadu after the famed Chola temples of the 11th-13th centuries occurred during their rule.
The ancient temple at Thirukurungudi, situated an hour‚Äôs drive from Tirunelveli is one such gem. As per the Vaishnava tradition, Thirukkurungudi is one among the 108 Vaishnava shrines and is said to be the ‚ÄòSouthern Home‚Äô of Lord Vishnu and is hence called ‚ÄòDakshina Badri‚Äô.
The main deity is Azhagiya Nambi Rayar also referred to as ‚ÄúSundara Paripoornam‚Äù, meaning ‚ÄúPerfect and complete beauty‚Äù. True to its name, it is one of the most beautiful portrayals of Vishnu. Not just the main deity, the entire temple complex is replete with some stunningly gorgeous sculptures.
The Chitra Gopuram of the temple is one of the most beautiful structures I have ever seen. Every inch of its fa√ßade is richly carved with panels depicting scenes from various epics. Each one of them demonstrates the sculptors' careful attention to detail and depict many mythological themes which are found nowhere else.
The most attractive section in the Chitra Gopuram depicts the slaying of the demon Mahishasura. In one of the smallest of panels in the tower, the talented sculptor has carved the scene in intricate detail. Devi is seen with eighteen hands, each one of them holding a different weapon and objects. Even the folds of her dress have been engraved with much care; every fold and every crease is visible. Her right leg is firmly in position on Mahisha‚Äôs neck, while piercing him with a sharp trident. As the Asura warriors watch the scene, the lion is also sinking its teeth into the demon. The victorious smile on her face is unmistakable!
As her arrow
Rests in the quiver
Let us recall these lines . . .
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ω‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§‡•§
‚ÄúWhenever trouble arises due to the advent of the demons, I shall incarnate and destroy the foes. ‚Äú
(Markandeypurana, 91.51: Eleventh Chapter of the Devi Mahatmya)
26/10/20, 1:53‚ÄØpm
Oh. Fantastic Sir. Though we can't compare with other sculptures, this appears to be very appealing, energetic and there is a contagious feeling of triumphüôè Hope some day I will be able to go that temple!
27/10/20, 9:22‚ÄØam
Sir I have to thank you for taking on a tour which was worth being a part of. Yes they have to connect deep within us. Otherwise it will be a futile picnic for fun.
28/10/20, 12:42‚ÄØpm
Probably the only idol in the world that was made using three metals: silver, copper and brass.üôèüèº Here the face of the Goddess is made of silver, the rest of the body is made of copper and the cloth is made of brass. The melting points of these three metals are different. There is no welding anywhere on this idol, it is an unbroken idol. The same feature is of the lion below the goddess, the whole body is of copper and the ayal is of brass. Even today, attempts to make such idols have failed.
üôèüèºüåü‚ú®üåüüôèüèºüõïüö©
The *Shri Ambabai (Mahalaxmi) Temple of Kolhapur in Maharashtra.*
(Photo from Temples of India.)
02/11/20, 9:22‚ÄØam
This is the illustrated talk I gave on the temple architecture of early chalukyas in Essex Indians forum. *Essex Indians* is a registered charity and association of Indian diaspora in the UK. The association has been very active in keeping the Indian community connected during the current Covid-19 pandemic. It has organised several online cultural programmes One of its flagship programmes is the *‚ÄòUnity in Diversity‚Äô* series in which each episode is showcasing one state of India. It aims to educate, inform and entertain the audience about the culture and heritage of that state.

As I explored the dark confines of the temple gopuram of Thiruppudaimaruthur, I was surrounded by exquisitely carved small wooden sculptures that adorned every inch of the space, blending seamlessly with the murals on the wall. The light from my mobile as I was shining on them was like a magical lantern bringing them alive

03/10/20, 12:55‚ÄØpm
Sir, will there be a difference in the approach taken, between the person who is tired but has done whatever could be, is satisfied and a person who has gone through turbulent times, is tired and wants to seek real nature of self.
20/10/20, 7:16‚ÄØam
Mahishasuramardini is often depicted standing on a decapitated buffalo head or in the act of killing it, from whose head a demon in the form of a man emerges. But the most vibrant depiction of the goddess is in an exquisite bas relief in a small cave in Mahabalipuram which depicts her in battle scene with Mahishasura. She is shown riding a prancing lion and holding various weapons in her eight hands, attacking the demon who is retreating from her onslaught, accepting his defeat. It is the finest depiction of the epic battle scene. I kept wondering as to what could have been the source of inspiration for this majestic creative art.
As I was exploring the Mallikarjuna temple in Pattadakkal, I was struck by a small panel, worn out with years, in a dark corner. In its miniature form it seemed to be a prototype for the grand battle scene at Mahabalipuram! The spirit of experimentation patronized by the Early Chalukya dynasty perhaps has been the source of inspiration for the sculptors to create a majestic, larger version at Mahabalipuram!
Though the Pallavas and Chalukyas have been known for their incessant rivalry, the wars between the two dynasties never came in-between the growth of rich cultural heritage. Their mutual exchange and influence of architectural styles can be seen in the beauty, rhythm and vigor captured in stone by their masterful craftsmen. The Mahishasuramardini panel in Pattadakkal and Mahabalipuram is the perfect example of this remarkable confluence.
21/10/20, 12:48‚ÄØpm
Yes. Instead of just hailing the beauty of the sculpture, the interpretation that you have given is very apt. It boosts the spirit to fight.
23/10/20, 7:37‚ÄØam
DAY 7
Sometimes travelling in India is like a leap in the dark. One starts exploring destinations and discovering places which open up an entirely different world of experiences. My visit to Bhoramdeo was one such. While in Raipur for the Annual Conference of the Indian Psychiatric Society, I suddenly decided on a whim, to visit the place about which I had read a long while ago.
At first view, the temple stunned me. Set amidst a thick canopy of tall trees it was serenely beautiful. Soft morning rays of the winter sun dappled their way over the sal and bija leaves, setting the temple aglow with a golden lustre. The central tower composed of receding rows of exquisitely carved sculptures tapering upwards, seemed to replicate the receding hills of the Makali range in the background.
Dating back to the 7th century, it was Alexander Cunningham who discovered this temple which was engulfed by a dense forest, overgrown with vegetation. Taken aback by the sheer artistry of the temple he is said to have commented that ‚Äòit is one of the most beautifully decorated temple seen by him.‚Äô He also contended that it was originally dedicated to Vishnu and subsequently during the period of Gond supremacy in the region, the Vishnu idol was replaced with a Shivalinga in the sanctum. As the Gond tribals of the area worship Lord Shiva as Bhoramdeo, the temple was also named Bhoramdeo.
The outer walls of the temple were embellished with panel upon panel of delicate sculptures, covering a wide range of themes from the religious, the symbolic to the erotic. Because of the profusion of erotic sculptures and its structural similarity, it is often referred to as the ‚ÄúKhajuraho of Chattisgarh‚Äù. High up on the tower is a sculpture of Mahishasuramardini. Since it has been carved in chlorite stone, there has been considerable damage to the sculpture. In spite of it her face is serene and the ornamentation is exquisite.
Chipped, battered, broken, and yet elegant, its radiant beauty transcends its imperfection...

DAY 8
One of the most unusual Mahishasuramardini sculptures in India is this iconic Pallava creation at the Kailasanathar Temple at Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu. Constructed over a 20-year period from 685 to 705 CE, the Kailasanathar Temple is the first structural temple built by the Pallavas, after their earlier experiments with rock-cut temples at Mahabalipuram. The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and named after his abode on Mount Kailash. Though smaller in size compared to other, it is exquisite.

Instead we see a triumphant Durga posing in the aftermath of her victory in a strikingly confident posture. Her left leg is placed on the back of the lion which is vividly sculpted. Her left hand is rests casually on the raised left knee. Her right hand is gripping her hip, and there is a noticeable bend at the waist which gives grace and movement to the whole sculpture. Notice the long bow held by her, which is taller than she is! These sculptures in the smaller shrines were once painted with vegetable dyes. One can notice the remnants of it on the wall behind. How resplendent she would have been at that time!

DAY 9
After some fabulous birding at Mangalajodi in Orissa, I enquired at the place where I was staying as to whether they could arrange a vehicle for me to visit Dakhya Prajapati temple at Banapur. They were surprised at my interests extending beyond the feathered friends and said ‚ÄúWhy do you want to go there doctor? There is just an old temple there!‚Äù Undeterred, I asked for a taxi and after a journey of one and a half hours we reached the small dusty town of Banapur.
When I got down from the car, I was surrounded by a group of boys who were playing cricket outside the temple. They were curious as to why I was visiting the place and kept following me as I went around the temple which was totally deserted.
Dakhya Prajapati temple is one of the relatively well preserved monuments of the Ganga period. It is dated to the Eastern Ganga dynasty which ruled in the early part of 13th century. It was during this period that temple architecture reached its pinnacle in Orissa. The temple is carved out of khondolite stone, which is named after the khond tribe, in whose terrain it is often sourced. Most of the temples in Orissa, including the Sun Temple at Konarak are built with this type of stone, which unfortunately is easily eroded by weather.
The temple tower is in the Nagara style and is intricately carved with many beautiful figures. These figures were interspersed with delicate scroll work. Among them was a small sculpture of Mahishasuramardini which was enclosed by a stunning border. Durga‚Äôs encounter with Mahisha has been a popular subject among artists for centuries. Most often she is depicted either serenely or victoriously, standing on the decapitated head of the buffalo or in the act of killing a buffalo headed figure from whose cut neck the demon emerges. The focus of the depiction here was not on the combat between the goddess and the demon, but on the goddess herself. She is seated here with wearing the karanda mukuta crown resembling a basket. Though her face was eroded, she seemed to be looking directly at the observer, offering her blessings. Mahishasura is usually represented in three forms: in his zoomorphic form he is shown as a buffalo, in the theriomorphic form he is supposed to have the body of a buffalo and the head of a man, and in the anthropomorphic form. Mahishasura can be seen at the bottom in the human form here. The iconography of Mahishasuramardini has never been a stagnant one and has undergone changes over time as the image was incorporated and depicted in different regions of India. As time progressed, the images also became more ornate.
After having a good look at the sculptures, I entered the sanctum and was warmly welcomed by a young man who spoke English. After offering the arathi to the main deity, he narrated the mythology associated with the temple. Dakhya is the son of Brahma and the father of Sati. Dakhya means ‚Äúable‚Äù and Prajapati is the Lord of all creatures. Here he is worshipped in the form of Lord Siva as Dakhyeswar. Hence it is also referred to as Dakhyeswar Siva temple.
As I was leaving, I asked him as to how he spoke such good English! He told me that he worked as a laborer in Whitefield, but grew tired of the urban chaos and returned home. He said ‚ÄúI come here every day and offer puja to the deity‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt earn much but I find immense peace in serving him..it is a labor of love‚Äù I was deeply touched by his words.
In his own quiet way he was conveying that fulfillment through exalted work is the highest form of virtue in life.
Traveling in not just about discovering places. There is something undeniably magical in these small moments when you meet people who open up new vistas and enrich your understanding of life.
Aren‚Äôt we all stones

That we might become
Awaiting the chisel
Of the Creator?
26/10/20, 7:47‚ÄØam
DAY 10
Over the last nine days, I had posted various sculptural depictions of Mahishasuramardini across India‚Ä¶each one of them distinctly different and impressive. On this tenth day of Vijayadashami let me take you down south to Tirunelveli district of Tamil Nadu.
When the Vijayanagara Empire fell, it splintered into several smaller kingdoms controlled by Nayakas, Telugu-speaking warriors from the Andhra region. The greatest period of temple construction in Tamil Nadu after the famed Chola temples of the 11th-13th centuries occurred during their rule.
The ancient temple at Thirukurungudi, situated an hour‚Äôs drive from Tirunelveli is one such gem. As per the Vaishnava tradition, Thirukkurungudi is one among the 108 Vaishnava shrines and is said to be the ‚ÄòSouthern Home‚Äô of Lord Vishnu and is hence called ‚ÄòDakshina Badri‚Äô.
The main deity is Azhagiya Nambi Rayar also referred to as ‚ÄúSundara Paripoornam‚Äù, meaning ‚ÄúPerfect and complete beauty‚Äù. True to its name, it is one of the most beautiful portrayals of Vishnu. Not just the main deity, the entire temple complex is replete with some stunningly gorgeous sculptures.
The Chitra Gopuram of the temple is one of the most beautiful structures I have ever seen. Every inch of its fa√ßade is richly carved with panels depicting scenes from various epics. Each one of them demonstrates the sculptors' careful attention to detail and depict many mythological themes which are found nowhere else.
The most attractive section in the Chitra Gopuram depicts the slaying of the demon Mahishasura. In one of the smallest of panels in the tower, the talented sculptor has carved the scene in intricate detail. Devi is seen with eighteen hands, each one of them holding a different weapon and objects. Even the folds of her dress have been engraved with much care; every fold and every crease is visible. Her right leg is firmly in position on Mahisha‚Äôs neck, while piercing him with a sharp trident. As the Asura warriors watch the scene, the lion is also sinking its teeth into the demon. The victorious smile on her face is unmistakable!
As her arrow
Rests in the quiver
Let us recall these lines . . .

‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ω‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§‡•§
‚ÄúWhenever trouble arises due to the advent of the demons, I shall incarnate and destroy the foes. ‚Äú
(Markandeypurana, 91.51: Eleventh Chapter of the Devi Mahatmya)
28/10/20, 12:42‚ÄØpm
Probably the only idol in the world that was made using three metals: silver, copper and brass.üôèüèº Here the face of the Goddess is made of silver, the rest of the body is made of copper and the cloth is made of brass. The melting points of these three metals are different. There is no welding anywhere on this idol, it is an unbroken idol. The same feature is of the lion below the goddess, the whole body is of copper and the ayal is of brass. Even today, attempts to make such idols have failed.
üôèüèºüåü‚ú®üåüüôèüèºüõïüö©

https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/a-beguiling-beauty
02/06/20, 11:19‚ÄØam

22/08/20, 7:57‚ÄØam
In the words of Adi Shankara Lord Ganesha is 'Ajam Nirvikalpam Niraakaaramekam.' He is Ajam (unborn), he is Nirvikalpa (attributeless), he is Niraakaar (formless) and he symbolizes the consciousness which is omnipresent.The formless divinity finds a beautiful expression in this delicate carving at Khajuraho
18/09/20, 8:14‚ÄØpm
https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/at-the-threshold-of-farther-shores
21/10/20, 8:07‚ÄØam
DAY FIVE
The shore temple at Mahabalipuram dates back to 8th century and it is generally believed that it is actually a small part of a temple complex which existed eons ago. It demonstrates the progression of Pallava temple architecture from rock cut structures to free standing structural shrines. Though years of wind and erosion from sea water have worn away the details of many carvings, there is a strikingly large free standing sculpture of a lion on the southern side of the temple. It is actually a miniature temple! A carved alcove in its heart serves as the sanctum, within which is a carving of Mahishasuramardini. The goddess is shown sitting astride triumphantly on the severed head of the buffalo demon. Two dwaraphalakis are carved on either side of the lion, clasping it. Mahishasuramardini is often portrayed riding a lion or a tiger. Here she has found a place in a lion‚Äôs heart! The Upanishadic concept that likens the heart to a cave within which resides a hidden self is emphasized here. Perhaps in portraying Mahshasuramardini in this form, the sculptors are conveying that within each of us is a heart of a lion where courage and power resides to vanquish negative forces!
22/10/20, 8:44‚ÄØam
DAY 6
I relish discovering places and temples that are off the tourist radar.
Udaipur is not just about lakes and palaces. When I was there sometime back for a CME, after finishing my talk I enquired about a (unusually named) temple referred as Saasbahu temple. With some effort I found a local taxi driver who seemed to know the place, which was just an hour‚Äôs drive from Udaipur.
Located in the lap of the Aravalli mountain range, it was a charming structure by the side of a lake, surrounded by mustard fields. There was an aged guard who opened the gates and let me in. The early morning sun was playing hide and seek with the richly carved exterior of the temple
Built in the late 10th century, the larger temple (referred to as Saas) is surrounded by ten subsidiary shrines and is more profusely decorated than the smaller (Bahu) temple which has four shrines and an octagonal ceiling. The story goes that king Mahipala married a queen who was a devotee of Lord Vishnu and he constructed a temple dedicated to Vishnu for his wife to offer prayers. Years later, the king‚Äôs son married a princess who was devotee of Lord Shiva so he constructed another temple nearby for his daughter in law. Since the Vishnu temple was constructed first it was known as Sahastrabaahu temple meaning the lord with thousand arms though it included the Shiva temple as well. The name however got corrupted over a period of time to be called ‚ÄúSaas Bahu temple‚Äù much before the TV serial!
Made of granite, the carvings are quite remarkable and among them, this one of Mahishasuramardini caught my attention. Even though details of her face have been lost with the passage of time, the flowing lines enhance her graceful poise which is embellished with rich ornamentation. She is portrayed with a sword in her hand after killing the demon whose head is clearly seen on the ground. Though on a pragmatic level decapitation represents the loss of power, perhaps it is also a liberative act indicating that human pride and ego must be severed in order to attain salvation.
23/10/20, 7:37‚ÄØam
DAY 7
Sometimes travelling in India is like a leap in the dark. One starts exploring destinations and discovering places which open up an entirely different world of experiences. My visit to Bhoramdeo was one such. While in Raipur for the Annual Conference of the Indian Psychiatric Society, I suddenly decided on a whim, to visit the place about which I had read a long while ago.
At first view, the temple stunned me. Set amidst a thick canopy of tall trees it was serenely beautiful. Soft morning rays of the winter sun dappled their way over the sal and bija leaves, setting the temple aglow with a golden lustre. The central tower composed of receding rows of exquisitely carved sculptures tapering upwards, seemed to replicate the receding hills of the Makali range in the background.
Dating back to the 7th century, it was Alexander Cunningham who discovered this temple which was engulfed by a dense forest, overgrown with vegetation. Taken aback by the sheer artistry of the temple he is said to have commented that ‚Äòit is one of the most beautifully decorated temple seen by him.‚Äô He also contended that it was originally dedicated to Vishnu and subsequently during the period of Gond supremacy in the region, the Vishnu idol was replaced with a Shivalinga in the sanctum. As the Gond tribals of the area worship Lord Shiva as Bhoramdeo, the temple was also named Bhoramdeo.
The outer walls of the temple were embellished with panel upon panel of delicate sculptures, covering a wide range of themes from the religious, the symbolic to the erotic. Because of the profusion of erotic sculptures and its structural similarity, it is often referred to as the ‚ÄúKhajuraho of Chattisgarh‚Äù. High up on the tower is a sculpture of Mahishasuramardini. Since it has been carved in chlorite stone, there has been considerable damage to the sculpture. In spite of it her face is serene and the ornamentation is exquisite.
Chipped, battered, broken, and yet elegant, its radiant beauty transcends its imperfection...
24/10/20, 8:27‚ÄØam
DAY 8
One of the most unusual Mahishasuramardini sculptures in India is this iconic Pallava creation at the Kailasanathar Temple at Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu. Constructed over a 20-year period from 685 to 705 CE, the Kailasanathar Temple is the first structural temple built by the Pallavas, after their earlier experiments with rock-cut temples at Mahabalipuram. The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and named after his abode on Mount Kailash. There are two Mahishasuramardini sculptures: a larger one on the outer wall of the sanctum and a smaller one sculpted within one of the 58 miniature shrines that are built into the niches of the surrounding wall. Though smaller in size compared to other, it is exquisite.
Unlike the other Mahishasurmardini panels which we have seen so far, this one has no Mahishasura in the frame. Instead we see a triumphant Durga posing in the aftermath of her victory in a strikingly confident posture. Her left leg is placed on the back of the lion which is vividly sculpted. Her left hand is rests casually on the raised left knee. Her right hand is gripping her hip, and there is a noticeable bend at the waist which gives grace and movement to the whole sculpture. Notice the long bow held by her, which is taller than she is! These sculptures in the smaller shrines were once painted with vegetable dyes. One can notice the remnants of it on the wall behind. How resplendent she would have been at that time!
25/10/20, 7:34‚ÄØam
DAY 9
After some fabulous birding at Mangalajodi in Orissa, I enquired at the place where I was staying as to whether they could arrange a vehicle for me to visit Dakhya Prajapati temple at Banapur. They were surprised at my interests extending beyond the feathered friends and said ‚ÄúWhy do you want to go there doctor? There is just an old temple there!‚Äù Undeterred, I asked for a taxi and after a journey of one and a half hours we reached the small dusty town of Banapur.
When I got down from the car, I was surrounded by a group of boys who were playing cricket outside the temple. They were curious as to why I was visiting the place and kept following me as I went around the temple which was totally deserted.
Dakhya Prajapati temple is one of the relatively well preserved monuments of the Ganga period. It is dated to the Eastern Ganga dynasty which ruled in the early part of 13th century. It was during this period that temple architecture reached its pinnacle in Orissa. The temple is carved out of khondolite stone, which is named after the khond tribe, in whose terrain it is often sourced. Most of the temples in Orissa, including the Sun Temple at Konarak are built with this type of stone, which unfortunately is easily eroded by weather.
The temple tower is in the Nagara style and is intricately carved with many beautiful figures. These figures were interspersed with delicate scroll work. Among them was a small sculpture of Mahishasuramardini which was enclosed by a stunning border. Durga‚Äôs encounter with Mahisha has been a popular subject among artists for centuries. Most often she is depicted either serenely or victoriously, standing on the decapitated head of the buffalo or in the act of killing a buffalo headed figure from whose cut neck the demon emerges. The focus of the depiction here was not on the combat between the goddess and the demon, but on the goddess herself. She is seated here with wearing the karanda mukuta crown resembling a basket. Though her face was eroded, she seemed to be looking directly at the observer, offering her blessings. Mahishasura is usually represented in three forms: in his zoomorphic form he is shown as a buffalo, in the theriomorphic form he is supposed to have the body of a buffalo and the head of a man, and in the anthropomorphic form. Mahishasura can be seen at the bottom in the human form here. The iconography of Mahishasuramardini has never been a stagnant one and has undergone changes over time as the image was incorporated and depicted in different regions of India. As time progressed, the images also became more ornate.
After having a good look at the sculptures, I entered the sanctum and was warmly welcomed by a young man who spoke English. After offering the arathi to the main deity, he narrated the mythology associated with the temple. Dakhya is the son of Brahma and the father of Sati. Dakhya means ‚Äúable‚Äù and Prajapati is the Lord of all creatures. Here he is worshipped in the form of Lord Siva as Dakhyeswar. Hence it is also referred to as Dakhyeswar Siva temple.
As I was leaving, I asked him as to how he spoke such good English! He told me that he worked as a laborer in Whitefield, but grew tired of the urban chaos and returned home. He said ‚ÄúI come here every day and offer puja to the deity‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt earn much but I find immense peace in serving him..it is a labor of love‚Äù I was deeply touched by his words.
In his own quiet way he was conveying that fulfillment through exalted work is the highest form of virtue in life.
Traveling in not just about discovering places. There is something undeniably magical in these small moments when you meet people who open up new vistas and enrich your understanding of life.
Aren‚Äôt we all stones
Dreaming of shapes
That we might become
Awaiting the chisel
Of the Creator?
27/10/20, 9:22‚ÄØam
Sir I have to thank you for taking on a tour which was worth being a part of. Yes they have to connect deep within us. Otherwise it will be a futile picnic for fun.

The narrative draws us towards seeking light within. Thank you Sir, for the same!

Art & culture

01/01/21, 12:23‚ÄØam

14/01/21, 7:57‚ÄØam
Pongal (like other harvest festivals in India), is a day to worship and express gratitude to the Sun God for helping the crops to flourish by providing energy for their growth. It marks the beginning of Uttarayan, the sun‚Äôs transition northwards for a six-month period.
There are numerous depictions of Hari-Hara (a combined form of Shiva and Vishnu) but it is relatively rare to see a combined form of Surya and Shiva. One such unusual depiction is at Khajuraho. On the right half of this sculpture is Surya, the Sun God. He is holding lotuses: a fully bloomed one in one hand and a bud in the other. The left half is Shiva and he is holding a snake and a water pot.

The Sun God, a manifestation of Lord Hari, resides in the Soul of everyone in this world
Bhagavata Purana, 12.11.30:

13/05/21, 8:45‚ÄØam
There are moments of reprieve in these gloomy times.
The sky is getting darker and a billowy wind is blowing across. As the raindrops start caressing the leaves, the chirping birds search for shelter. An interesting medley sounds softly floats in the air.
I keep wondering whether the bird calls are sounding different in these times. There seems to be a discernibly upbeat quality in their songs. Or perhaps given the lack of noise due to the lockdown their calls are heard more vividly.
The soundscape replete with mellifluous calls of birds soothens the angst of isolation.
There is an intricate, ineffable relationship between the landscape outside of us and that within.
In the words of Rumi, ‚ÄúBirdsongs brings relief to my longing‚Äù and I retreat into the silence within‚Ä¶
22/05/21, 12:29‚ÄØpm
Sir your caption magnifies the beauty and significance of the heart warming photograph!
25/05/21, 2:13‚ÄØpm
Today is Narasimha Jayanti.
Narasimha is one of the ten incarnations of Vishnu. He has often been depicted in nine different forms, Nava Narasimha which can be seen in the temple at Ahobilam.
Sculptors from the Hoysala period depicted some of these forms in intricate detail. This one from Halebeedu depicts him seated with the demon Hiranyakashipu in his lap. He is portrayed with six arms; two upper hands hold the shanku and chakra, the bottom two hands are grasping the demon in a tight grip while the two arms in the middle are tearing his entrails apart. Even the intestines have been depicted in detail! Prahlada can be seen in the bottom left offering obeisance.
As Ananda Coomaraswamy commented, sculptures in Indian temples are not patterned after any ‚Äòliving model.‚Äô They represent an unending array of imagery, steeped in symbolism. What could be the symbolism behind the sculpture?
To me he is an iconic symbol of intensive resistance to unjust things, hope against odds, triumph of the good over persecution and evil. He is the annihilator of maleficent forces within and outside of us.
25/05/21, 10:39‚ÄØpm
Fantastic sculpture. Your description forces us to scan the picture carefully!
26/05/21, 7:46‚ÄØam
On the occasion of Buddha Jayanthi today, I was recollecting my sojourn to the Mahabodhi temple.
It had rained the previous evening and the cool breeze of the morning kept me company as I slowly made my way to the temple. Since I was keen to reach the place early, there was hardly anyone at that time. A group of Buddhist monks were walking and chanting melodiously at a distance. I went around the temple and sat in front of the Bodhi tree. Early morning sun was peeping through its leaves.
For more than a month, Siddhartha (as Buddha was earlier called) meditated beneath it and attained enlightenment. It is said that emperor Ashoka's daughter, Sanghamitta took a branch from the original Bodhi tree to Sri Lanka and planted it in Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka. That Bodhi tree is still alive there and is supposedly one of the oldest continually documented trees in the world. The tree I was sitting in front has been grown from a sapling brought from the one in Sri Lanka.
Forest and trees are intimately associated with Buddha. He was reportedly born under the ashoka tree(though some say it was a mango tree), attained enlightenment under the papal tree and entered into mahaparinirvana under the sala tree. Further, four trees are associated with the enlightenment of the Buddha. He sat under a pipal tree for the first seven days, in the bliss of his enlightenment; then he arose and sat under a nyagrodha, the banyan tree for another seven days, in the bliss of his illumination; then he sat beneath a muchalinda (Indian oak) for another seven days, in the bliss of his calm; and, finally, he sat beneath a rajayatana (wild mango) for seven days, in the bliss of his emancipation. The four trees are known as the Tree of Enlightenment, the Tree of the Goatherd, the Tree of Muchalinda, and the Tree of Emancipation, respectively.
There has been a strong association with spirituality and sacred trees in Indian history and I was sitting under one of them to savor a fleeting glimpse of the infinite.
With the chants echoing in the distance, I slowly immersed myself in the experience of feeling His presence. As I lost myself amidst the canopy in front of me, I felt that He was whispering in my ears, ‚ÄúAny tree could be your Bodhi tree‚Ä¶‚Äù
08/06/21, 8:35‚ÄØpm

09/07/21, 10:13‚ÄØam
https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/bewitching-murals-of-bodinayakanur
18/07/21, 10:51‚ÄØam
A few years ago we visited Omi International Arts Center in Ghent, off the beaten path in the gorgeous Hudson Valley countryside. It is a vast open space of over 100 acres studded with nearly 80 sculptures which blend into the landscape. We spent several hours exploring the magical space and savoring large-scale works of contemporary and modern artists. As I made my way amidst the rolling farmland and undulating meadows, I felt that I was in ‚ÄúConstable Country!‚Äù
John Constable was largely responsible for reviving the landscape painting in 19th century. He began painting canvases in the open air, with striking results. Using finely executed brushwork, he synthesized elements of light and shade to convey the radiance of the Suffolk countryside.
I was not carrying my camera and this image of the radiant landscape of the OMI Center was taken with the iPhone.
20/07/21, 8:01‚ÄØpm
Whenever I see this small statuette on my desk I am reminded of Francis of Assisi, who abandoned a life of luxury and embraced the vow of poverty.
He had a deep love of nature and animals and is known as the patron saint of ecology.
These lines from Prayer of St Francis are extraordinarily evocative:
O divine Master
grant that I may not so much seek
to be consoled as to console,
to be understood as to understand,
to be loved as to love.
For it is in giving that we receive‚Ä¶
20/07/21, 10:22‚ÄØpm

22/07/21, 12:17‚ÄØpm
The Jataka tales are an important part of Buddhist art and literature. They describe the previous births of the Buddha in both human and non-human forms. The tales were often delicately sculpted in stupas. One such depiction of the Mahakapi Jataka appears on the western gateway of the Great Stupa at Sanchi.
The king is shown with a parasol over his head travelling with an entourage. To the right of the king an archer appears with bow and arrow aiming at the monkeys. Realizing that their lives are in peril, they appeal to the Great Monkey (Bodhisattva) who climbs onto the mango tree, grabbing the branch firmly, stretching himself across the river. The relief show the Bodhisattva as the bridge by which monkeys escape to join the rest of the troop in the forest. Notice the depiction of the river with crocodile and fishes!
In the tale, when the king asked the Great Monkey as to why he risked his life to protect the monkeys he replies, "Great king, I guard the herd. I am their lord and chief. When they were filled with fear of your archers, I leapt a great distance to save them. I managed to hold the branch of the mango tree so that my monkeys could pass over my back and reach safety. Because I could save them, I have no fear of death. Like a righteous king, I could guarantee the happiness of those over whom I reign. Sir, understand this truth! If you wish to be a righteous ruler, the happiness of your kingdom, your cities, and your people must be dear to you. It must be dearer than your life."
A timely reminder these days, especially on this World Mango Day!!
24/07/21, 8:21‚ÄØam
The thirst for knowledge is an eternal quest which requires the help of a Guru. On this Guru Purnima day let us pay obeisance to Shri Dakshinamurthy, the Adi Guru. He is the personification of spiritual wisdom and knowledge. His teaching is through the subtlest form of speech called para vak, which can be felt in the vibrations of silence.
There are many depictions of Dakshinamurthy in sculptural form. The most beautiful of them is in Kailasanathar Kovil in Kancheepuram. Here you can see him seatped under a tree, giving a sermon. So much so, even the snake that adorns his neck has crawled down to sit and listen to him! There are two antelopes below him. They are a metaphor for a quick thinking human mind. His stance is also quite unusual. With his left foot crossed over his right knee he is gracefully turning towards us. The immaculate attention to the finer aspects is visible in the sole of the left foot, with the arches and instep sculpted in exquisite detail. On top on either side are the Kanakadi Rishis; Sanaka, Sanandana, Sanatana and Sanat Kumara. They are the four sons of Brahma who are considered as the greatest of gyanis. Though old in years due to their exemplary spiritual attainments, they maintained themselves eternally as small children.
‡•ê ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡••‡•´‡••
Salutations to the embodiment of Pranava (Om)
Salutations to the personification of the Pure, Non-Dual Knowledge,
Salutations to the Pure and Tranquil Sri Dakshinamurthy.
29/07/21, 10:28‚ÄØam
Nature has always been a source of inspiration for poets.
Mahakavi Bharathiyar wrote a series of Vachana Kavithai (Prose Poems) titled Kaatchi (Vision). It is a work of immense literary and spiritual significance. In its style and imagination, they are unique in the history of Tamil literature. Some of these verses are akin to verses from the Rig Vediv hymns which laid emphasis on the worship of nature in its most sublime aspects.
It is believed that Mahakavi Bharathiyar studied the Rig Veda under the tutelage of Sri Aurobindo.
This particular verse about the setting sun is redolent with sublime imagery‚Ä¶.
‡Æû‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ±‡Øá,‡Æá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Øà ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ© ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç?
‡Æì‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ©‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Ææ? ‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Ææ? ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ¥‡ØÅ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Ææ?
‡Æï‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ÆÆ‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æï‡Æ≥‡Ææ‡Æï‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æï‡Øà‡Æï‡Æ≥‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ±‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Ææ?
‡Æá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æï‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Ææ?
‡Æá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æ£‡Æµ‡ØÅ‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Ææ?
‡ÆÖ‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Ææ?
‡Æá‡Æ∞‡Æµ‡ØÜ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ£‡Ææ‡Æ§ ‡ÆÆ‡ÆØ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ§‡Ææ?
‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Æµ‡ØÅ‡Æü‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Øä‡Æ≥‡Æø ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ≤‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡Æ§‡Ææ?

‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æï ‡Æµ‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡Æâ‡Æ≤‡Æï‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Øà‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æü‡Æø ‡Æâ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æè‡Æµ‡Æø ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ±‡Ææ‡Æ≥‡Ææ?

These verses resonate deeply whenever I watch a gorgeous sunset‚Ä¶.
