10/09/21, 7:48‚ÄØam
Ganesha, as we know him today, appears as a distinct deity during the Gupta period. With the advent of the Puranic tradition, he emerged as a major God with a sect of his own called Ganapatyas. By the seventh century CE, Adi Shankara included the worship of Ganapati as one of the six systems (shanmata) of the Hindu religion.
There are 32 forms of Ganesha and he continues to be depicted in various pleomorphic forms inspired by the creative spirits of the artists!
One of the magnificent images of Ganesha is in Hampi, often referred to as Sasivekalu Ganesha. This monolithic statue is carved out of a single block of granite rock and is housed in an open pavilion.
Ganesha holds an axe in the upper right hand and a noose in the upper left hand. He holds the axe urging the devotee to destroy unwanted, evil thoughts that can lead one into Adharma. The noose or pasha in Ganesha's left hand is an implement to capture all difficulties. The noose conveys that worldly attachments are a noose around man‚Äôs neck. In order to attain spiritual perfection, one should cut the worldly attachments and attain spiritual enlightenment. In his lower left hand he is holding his favourite sweet the
‚Äúmodak‚Äù. ‚ÄòMod (‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶)‚Äô means Anand and ‚Äòka (‡§ï)‚Äô means a small portion. Therefore, modak is a small portion of Anand. He is holding a broken tusk in the right lower hand which he used as a writing tool for the Mahabharata epic.
A snake is tied around his prominent belly (which incidentally resembles a mustard seed and hence the name!). The popular tale is that once Ganesha ate lots of food and his stomach was almost bursting. In order to hold it back, he tied a snake around it!
However, the surprise element in this sculpture is at the back when one notices Devi Parvathi holding Ganesha in her lap! This is a very unusual and unique depiction of Ganesha!
As with other Hindu Gods the story of Ganesha is embedded in varying mythological narratives which are replete with multiple symbolic interpretations. It also interweaves with folk elements reflecting a community‚Äôs understanding and interpretation of the God in relation to their lifeworld‚Äôs.
16/09/21, 10:13‚ÄØam
https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/balpandia-silent-sentinel
21/09/21, 5:35‚ÄØpm
Today is Alzheimer's Day
The most poignant aspect of dementia is whether it is more painful to forget, or to be forgotten...
A very perceptive reflection on forgetfulness is a poem by my favorite poet, Billy Collins.
FORGETFULNESS
The name of the author is the first to go
Followed obediently by the title, the plot,
The heartbreaking conclusion, the entire novel
Which suddenly becomes one you have never read,
Never even heard of,
As if, one by one, the memories you used to harbor
Decided to retire to the southern hemisphere of the brain,
To a little fishing village where there are no phones.
Long ago you kissed the names of the nine Muses goodbye
And watched the quadratic equation pack its bag,
And even now as you memorize the order of the planets,
Something else is slipping away, a state flower perhaps,
The address of an uncle, the capital of Paraguay.
Whatever it is you are struggling to remember
It is not poised on the tip of your tongue,
Not even lurking in some obscure corner of your spleen.
It has floated away down a dark mythological river
Whose name begins with an L as far as you can recall,
Well on your own way to oblivion where you will join those
Who have even forgotten how to swim and how to ride a bicycle.
No wonder you rise in the middle of the night
To look up the date of a famous battle in a book on war.
No wonder the moon in the window seems to have drifted
Out of a love poem that you used to know by heart.
10/10/21, 8:52‚ÄØpm
For those who were unable to log in....here is a recording. Looking forward to your reflections and thoughts
13/10/21, 10:03‚ÄØam
Among the many depictions of Goddess Durga slaying the demon Mahishasura, this sculpture at Halebidu is distinctive. Exquisitely chiselled it depicts the story in a narrative form. Goddess Durga is standing triumphantly with her left leg over Mahishasura, the buffalo that has fallen on the ground. Mahishashura is seen emerging from the body of the buffalo in a human form and a trident is piercing him. Seated next to the buffalo is lion, Durga‚Äôs vehicle. Goddess Durga has ten arms (some of which are missing or broken), each holding different weapons and objects given to her by various gods.
The word Mashishasurmardini consists of three Sanskrit words: Mahisha (buffalo), asura (demon), and mardini (slayer). Mahishasura's legend is told in the major text of the Shaktism, Devi Mahatmya, a part of Markandeya Purana. His transformation through various forms represents the never ending chain of desires within us. When one desire is fulfilled another springs and takes control. The conquest of Mahishasura is also symbolic of conquering and winning over such tendencies in us. The story is also told in the Sikh text Chandi di Var, also calledVar Durga di, which many in Sikh tradition believe was included in the Dasam Granth by Guru Gobind Singh.
Durga appears serene, calm and collected after vanquishing the demon in the sculpture.
Her graceful demeanour is described eloquently in Mahishasuramardini Stotram which was composed by the great sage Adi Shankaracharya around 810 AD.
‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤‡§≤‡§§‡•á
‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§ø‡§ö‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•á ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤ ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•á
‡§ú‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§Ø ‡§π‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•ß‡•™ ‡••
The Goddess who is with the radiance like that of the lotus petals, whose forehead is like that of a clear moon
O the one who is skilled in all the arts, and surrounded with attendants, whose steps are followed by dancing swans
O the one whose is with lotuses and Pogada flowers, which are attracting the bees, O the one with beautiful hair
Victory to you, victory to you, the destroyer of Mahishasura, the one with beautiful-braided hair, the daughter of the mountain.
14/10/21, 9:52‚ÄØam
Today is Saraswathi Pooja. I had seen many sculptural depictions of Saraswathi during my travels. Personally I would rate the portrayal of the goddess at Gangaikondacholapuram as the most beautiful one. It was by sheer chance and through close observation, I had a glimpse of one of the smallest representation of Saraswathi and it was at Khajuraho.
Khajuraho temples represent the exquisite architectural heritage of the Chandellas. The Varaha temple is among the oldest in the western group of temples and is believed to have been constructed around 900 ‚Äì 925 A.D. Comparatively small in comparison to its neighbours, its grandeur overwhelms you as you ascend the stairs and enter the little pavilion. Directly under the pyramidal roof which is carved with lotus flower, stands an enormous monolithic image of the boar Varaha, the third incarnation of Vishnu. The image is made out of a single block of sandstone that measures 2.6 metres long and 1.7 metres high. The stone shines like burnished metal and on its surface are 675 miniature figures, carved in twelve well-ordered rows. These figures represent many of the important Gods and Goddesses of the Hindu pantheon. These include ganesha, the seven mothers, the seven sages, the eight guardians of space, the nine planetary divinities, the river goddesses, the seas, the Rudras, and the different forms of Vishnu.
A low parapet wall surrounds the massive figure of Varaha and as I sat on the soft smoothened stone, my attention was drawn to a small figure carved between the nose and mouth of Varaha.
I was totally surprised to see a diminutive sculpture of Saraswathi with Veena in her arms!
Though small in size, the sculpture powerfully conveys all the essence of the goddess, much like beej mantras.
Literally the word ‚Äòbeej‚Äô means ‚Äòseed‚Äô. In the seed are inherent all the characteristics of the tree. The most important thing about beej mantra is pronunciation and the sound associate with it, as each beej is associated with its own frequency. The more accurate the recitation of the beej mantra, easier it is for one to focus on meditation. ‚ÄúMantra‚Äù in Sanskrit is made up of two syllables: ‚Äúman‚Äù (mind) and ‚Äútra‚Äù (liberate). Thus in its most literal translation the word ‚Äúmantra‚Äù means ‚Äúto liberate one‚Äôs mind‚Äù. Essentially beej mantras are tools for expansion of consciousness utilizing the power of sound vibrations.
The beej is ‚ÄúAing‚Äù for Saraswati and is chanted along with name of the goddess and is prefixed with ‚ÄúOm‚Äù, the primordial vedic beej mantra.
‡•ê ‡§ê‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ||
Om Aing Mahasaraswatyai Namah |
Meaning: I meditate and bow to Maha Saraswati Devi.

10/11/21, 9:08‚ÄØam
Akka Mahadevi was a twelfth century Kannada poet, saint and mystic of the Virashaiva Bhakti movement. She was the first woman to have written vachanas in Kannada which are free verse hymns. Her vachanas end with her ‚Äòankita‚Äô (signature) calling Shiva as Chennamallikarjuna or as poetically translated by A. K. Ramanujan, ‚ÄúLord as White as Jasmine‚Äù. Over time, Akka‚Äôs concept of Chenna Mallikarjuna changed from that of the Puranic Shiva to a formless Divine which finds expression in this vachana, superbly translated by my favourite poet AK Ramanujan.
I was reminded of this vachana when I saw this landscape enveloped in early morning mist‚Ä¶
YOU ARE THE FOREST
you are all the great trees
in the forest
you are bird and beast
playing in and out
of all the trees
O lord white as jasmine
filling and filled by all
why don't you
show me your face?
12/11/21, 4:59‚ÄØpm
This year, Ragu reaches a milestone on 21st Nov when he turns 70! Yes, it's kind of hard to believe that!
Many of you, dear family and friends were with us to celebrate his 60th birthday. However given the current uncertain situation, we have shelved the idea of an in-person gathering this time, though it would have given us immense joy to have you all with us on the occasion.
Instead, we have created a special Facebook page for you to share your reflections, anecdotes, memories (including photographs!) and anything else that you may like to, about your association with him over these years. Ragu will deeply cherish this. Kindly click on the above link, join the group and delve into your memories!
24/11/21, 1:50‚ÄØpm
My interest in the field of psychiatry started quite early during my undergraduate period at JIPMER. I did quite well in ophthalmology and my professor felt that I had the makings of a good ophthalmologist, in spite of my myopia! Undeterred, I pursued my interest and was privileged to have had exceptional teachers who furthered my passion‚Ä¶which over decades I have tried to pass onto my students.
The field of mental health necessitate providing space for people to share their stories which they are unable to, in their real lives. I have strived to adopt a narrative approach (influenced by the literary legacy‚Ä¶thanks to my mother) in facilitating emergence of untold, unshared tales of suffering. I personally feel that psychiatry cannot be abstracted merely at a molecular level and has to transcend beyond, to incorporate the contexts and life worlds of people. That I have been able to instil this orientation in my students is my greatest satisfaction.
I am filled with gratitude that many of you who have been my co-travellers have taken time to share your thought, feelings, memories and photographs too!
I feel overwhelmed by the depth of affection expressed by all of you‚Ä¶
In the midst of all the demands in life, there is one person who has been beside me all through, for whom I am deeply indebted‚Ä¶ and our journey began together in 1978‚Ä¶
18/12/21, 9:49‚ÄØam
Sacred trees form an important part of the cultural heritage of India. Most temples are associated with trees and each one of them has a sacred Sthala Vriksha.
This particular tree is called audumbara or cluster fig (Ficus racemose). It is easy to spot with copious bunches of fruits growing from its trunk. Each and every part of this plant has medicinal properties and has been used extensively in Ayurveda.
Audumbara tree is most commonly associated with the Adi Guru Lord Dattatreya, a deity believed to embody Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma. He is considered to reside at the base of the Audumbara tree in a subtle form. Throughout India, adumbara trees are planted in temples dedicated to Dattatreya. Because of this association, cutting it is considered a sin. If an audumbara tree grows in a house, it is deemed to be a blessing as it signifies the presence of Lord Dattatreya in the household.
Incidentally today is Datta Jayanti‚Ä¶
20/12/21, 8:33‚ÄØam
Today is Arudra Darisanam‚Ä¶
It is believed that on this holy day (Arudra or Thiruvadirai), Shiva performed the cosmic dance as Nataraja. Legend has it that Lord Shiva performed the cosmic dance as Nataraja at Chidambaram for his devotees Adi Shesha and Vyagrapaadar. Adishesha, the seven-hooded serpent on whom Lord Vishnu rests in milky ocean, wanted to witness this divine dance of creation after hearing about it as also Vyagrapaadar who performed penance and tapas to witness the Ananda Tandavam of Nataraja. Lord Shiva granted their request and performed the cosmic dance at Chidambaram. The Ananda Thandavam is said to symbolize the five divine aspects (pancha krityas) of creation, sustenance, dissolution, concealment, and bestowment of grace.
Although the occasion is associated with Chidambaram, it is celebrated with equal fervour and joy at other temples too. One such shrine is at Uthirakosa Mangai in Ramanathapurm district. The temple houses a 6 feet tall idol of Nataraja which is carved out of emerald, referred to as Maragatha Nataraja. The idol is covered with sandal paste all around the year and no puja is offered to the deity. On the eve of arudra darisanam the sandal paste is removed for a few hours for devotees to have a glimpse of the Lord.
Ahalya and myself visited this temple early this year and found this beautiful mural of Nataraja on the ceiling of the mandapa leading onto the garbagriha of the Nataraja shrine. There were a few other murals too, but almost all of them had faded over the years due to neglect except this remarkable one.
In almost all depictions of dancing Nataraja, the lord is seen lifting his left foot while balancing over apasmara (or muyalagan) with his right foot. In this painting he is lifting his right foot while balancing on his left one. The only other place where he is depicted similarly is at Madurai Meenakshi temple. The legend has it the Lord danced with his right foot raised on the request of Pandya King by the name of Rajasekhara, a great devotee of Shiva. The king was very much concerned that dancing with permanently grounded right foot that might cause the Lord pain. Responding to his fervent prayers, the lord himself made the shift from left foot to right foot, which is referred to as ‚ÄúKaal maari aadiya patalam.''
The metaphor of the cosmic dance unifies ancient mythology, religious art and spirituality seamlessly.
As the Dhyaana Shloka in praise if Lord Shiva, the Lord of Dance states:
‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø
‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ
‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø
‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§É (‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç
Angikam Bhuvanam Yasya
Vachikam Sarva Vangmayam
Aaharyam Chandra Taradi
Tam Numah ( Vande) Saattvikam Shivam
Whose bodily movement is the entire Universe
Whose speech is the language (of the Universe)
Whose ornaments are the moon and the stars
Him, we worship the pure (serene) Lord Shiva!
25/12/21, 8:00‚ÄØam
The Vatican Museum is a treasure trove. It has 54 galleries with amazing works of art.
As I walked into the Raphael Rooms, I was overwhelmed with the sheer beauty of its frescoes.
Prominent among them was The Disputation over the Blessed Sacrament or the Triumph of Religion which was painted by the artist when he was just 27 year old. It was probably first fresco that Raphael painted at the Vatican.
In the top most realm is featured God the Father, the Creator of all things visible and invisible. He is depicted holding the world in His hands along with a host of angels by his side. At the centre is God the Son. Seated on a throne of clouds, He gazes benevolently at the viewer. An august aureole encompasses His divine aura. To Christ‚Äôs left is seated John the Baptist. He is identified by his traditional iconography, pointing out to Christ as the path to salvation. To Christ‚Äôs right Blessed Virgin Mary is seated the with hands pressed at her chest. On either side of them are various saints and prophets. Below Christ‚Äôs feet is the Holy Spirit, to whose sides are books of the four Gospels held open. At the bottom is the monstrance which is flanked by groups of theologians in lively debate.
I spent several minutes, unmindful of scores of people passing by, looking at this incredible work of art brimming with life. The clarity, rich colours, harmonious composition and grandeur of this fresco left a lasting impression on me.
It is said that Raphael won the commission to paint the four rooms after stiff competition with both Michelangelo, who was working on the Sistine Chapel and Leonardo da Vinci. This incensed Michelangelo who accused Raphael of plagiarism, spreading rumours that Raphael had sneaked into the Sistine Chapel to have a preview of his work and copied the techniques!
(BTW this is just one section of the mural!)

26/05/21, 7:46‚ÄØam
On the occasion of Buddha Jayanthi today, I was recollecting my sojourn to the Mahabodhi temple.
It had rained the previous evening and the cool breeze of the morning kept me company as I slowly made my way to the temple. Since I was keen to reach the place early, there was hardly anyone at that time. A group of Buddhist monks were walking and chanting melodiously at a distance. I went around the temple and sat in front of the Bodhi tree. Early morning sun was peeping through its leaves.
For more than a month, Siddhartha (as Buddha was earlier called) meditated beneath it and attained enlightenment. It is said that emperor Ashoka's daughter, Sanghamitta took a branch from the original Bodhi tree to Sri Lanka and planted it in Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka. That Bodhi tree is still alive there and is supposedly one of the oldest continually documented trees in the world. The tree I was sitting in front has been grown from a sapling brought from the one in Sri Lanka.
Forest and trees are intimately associated with Buddha. He was reportedly born under the ashoka tree(though some say it was a mango tree), attained enlightenment under the papal tree and entered into mahaparinirvana under the sala tree. Further, four trees are associated with the enlightenment of the Buddha. He sat under a pipal tree for the first seven days, in the bliss of his enlightenment; then he arose and sat under a nyagrodha, the banyan tree for another seven days, in the bliss of his illumination; then he sat beneath a muchalinda (Indian oak) for another seven days, in the bliss of his calm; and, finally, he sat beneath a rajayatana (wild mango) for seven days, in the bliss of his emancipation. The four trees are known as the Tree of Enlightenment, the Tree of the Goatherd, the Tree of Muchalinda, and the Tree of Emancipation, respectively.
There has been a strong association with spirituality and sacred trees in Indian history and I was sitting under one of them to savor a fleeting glimpse of the infinite.
With the chants echoing in the distance, I slowly immersed myself in the experience of feeling His presence. As I lost myself amidst the canopy in front of me, I felt that He was whispering in my ears, ‚ÄúAny tree could be your Bodhi tree‚Ä¶‚Äù
26/05/21, 12:02‚ÄØpm

22/07/21, 12:17‚ÄØpm
The Jataka tales are an important part of Buddhist art and literature. They describe the previous births of the Buddha in both human and non-human forms. The tales were often delicately sculpted in stupas. One such depiction of the Mahakapi Jataka appears on the western gateway of the Great Stupa at Sanchi.
The king is shown with a parasol over his head travelling with an entourage. To the right of the king an archer appears with bow and arrow aiming at the monkeys. Realizing that their lives are in peril, they appeal to the Great Monkey (Bodhisattva) who climbs onto the mango tree, grabbing the branch firmly, stretching himself across the river. The relief show the Bodhisattva as the bridge by which monkeys escape to join the rest of the troop in the forest. Notice the depiction of the river with crocodile and fishes!
In the tale, when the king asked the Great Monkey as to why he risked his life to protect the monkeys he replies, "Great king, I guard the herd. I am their lord and chief. When they were filled with fear of your archers, I leapt a great distance to save them. I managed to hold the branch of the mango tree so that my monkeys could pass over my back and reach safety. Because I could save them, I have no fear of death. Like a righteous king, I could guarantee the happiness of those over whom I reign. Sir, understand this truth! If you wish to be a righteous ruler, the happiness of your kingdom, your cities, and your people must be dear to you. It must be dearer than your life."
A timely reminder these days, especially on this World Mango Day!!

Today is the International Vulture Awareness Day to draw attention to the importance of preservation of this often reviled bird for the yeomen service they do in keeping the ecosystem in balance. My dear friend Bharathidasan has been doing exemplary work in their conservation through his organization Arulagam.
Often seen alone, this majestic Red Headed Vulture is a timid bird in spite of its size. It usually refrains from fighting with other birds at a carcass. Instead, it waits patiently before hurriedly making a foray and withdrawing with a bite of flesh.

10/09/21, 7:48‚ÄØam
Ganesha, as we know him today, appears as a distinct deity during the Gupta period. With the advent of the Puranic tradition, he emerged as a major God with a sect of his own called Ganapatyas. By the seventh century CE, Adi Shankara included the worship of Ganapati as one of the six systems (shanmata) of the Hindu religion.
There are 32 forms of Ganesha and he continues to be depicted in various pleomorphic forms inspired by the creative spirits of the artists!
One of the magnificent images of Ganesha is in Hampi, often referred to as Sasivekalu Ganesha. This monolithic statue is carved out of a single block of granite rock and is housed in an open pavilion.
Ganesha holds an axe in the upper right hand and a noose in the upper left hand. He holds the axe urging the devotee to destroy unwanted, evil thoughts that can lead one into Adharma. The noose or pasha in Ganesha's left hand is an implement to capture all difficulties. The noose conveys that worldly attachments are a noose around man‚Äôs neck. In order to attain spiritual perfection, one should cut the worldly attachments and attain spiritual enlightenment. In his lower left hand he is holding his favourite sweet the
‚Äúmodak‚Äù. ‚ÄòMod (‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶)‚Äô means Anand and ‚Äòka (‡§ï)‚Äô means a small portion. Therefore, modak is a small portion of Anand. He is holding a broken tusk in the right lower hand which he used as a writing tool for the Mahabharata epic.
A snake is tied around his prominent belly (which incidentally resembles a mustard seed and hence the name!). The popular tale is that once Ganesha ate lots of food and his stomach was almost bursting. In order to hold it back, he tied a snake around it!
However, the surprise element in this sculpture is at the back when one notices Devi Parvathi holding Ganesha in her lap! This is a very unusual and unique depiction of Ganesha!
As with other Hindu Gods the story of Ganesha is embedded in varying mythological narratives which are replete with multiple symbolic interpretations. It also interweaves with folk elements reflecting a community‚Äôs understanding and interpretation of the God in relation to their lifeworld‚Äôs.
10/09/21, 4:30‚ÄØpm

Wis≈Çawa Szymborska the Nobel laureate from Poland is often referred to as the ‚ÄòMozart of Poetry‚Äô. In her works which are deceptively simple, she draws attention to the extraordinary in the ordinary like this observation about a tree sprouting amidst rocks.
The little tree that springs up
In some inexplicable fashion
On the side of a cliff
Where are its roots, what does it feed on
What miracle produces those green leaves?

26/09/21, 10:28‚ÄØam
Today is the birthday of the poet TS Eliot, someone whom I like immensely. He concludes his magnum opus, Waste Land with these lines of hope;
Datta. Dayadhvam. Damyata.
Shantih Shantih Shantih.
Interestingly, Datta, Dayadhvam and Damyata have their origin in the fifth chapter of the Brihdaranyaka Upanishad. Prajapati, the creator is asked by devas, men and demons for advice. Then the thunder said Da.. Da.. Da‚Ä¶ Prajapathi asked them whether they understood the message. All the three groups nodded their heads saying ‚ÄòYes, Master, we understood it very well‚Äô. Devas understood Da as Damyata, self-control. Da meant Datta, give, donate for humans. While for the demons Da meant Dayatva, compassion.
Kanchi Paramacharya highlighted the importance of these three in his song Maithreem Bhajatha, made popular by MS Subbalakshmi
An English translation of this song I found on the web reads:
Serve with friendship and humility
Which will conquer the hearts of everyone.
Look upon others similar to yourself.
Renounce war
Renounce unnecessary competition for power
Give up aggression on others‚Äô properties
Mother Earth is broad enough to give us all we desire
God is compassionate to all
Daamyata ‚Äì So, Restrain yourself
Datta ‚Äì So, Donate your wealth to others
Dayathvam ‚Äì So, Be Kind to others
May all people of this world be happy and prosperous.
May all people of this world be happy and prosperous.
May all people of this world be happy and prosperous.

13/10/21, 10:03‚ÄØam
Among the many depictions of Goddess Durga slaying the demon Mahishasura, this sculpture at Halebidu is distinctive. Exquisitely chiselled it depicts the story in a narrative form. Goddess Durga is standing triumphantly with her left leg over Mahishasura, the buffalo that has fallen on the ground. Mahishashura is seen emerging from the body of the buffalo in a human form and a trident is piercing him. Seated next to the buffalo is lion, Durga‚Äôs vehicle. Goddess Durga has ten arms (some of which are missing or broken), each holding different weapons and objects given to her by various gods.
The word Mashishasurmardini consists of three Sanskrit words: Mahisha (buffalo), asura (demon), and mardini (slayer). Mahishasura's legend is told in the major text of the Shaktism, Devi Mahatmya, a part of Markandeya Purana. His transformation through various forms represents the never ending chain of desires within us. When one desire is fulfilled another springs and takes control. The conquest of Mahishasura is also symbolic of conquering and winning over such tendencies in us. The story is also told in the Sikh text Chandi di Var, also calledVar Durga di, which many in Sikh tradition believe was included in the Dasam Granth by Guru Gobind Singh.
Durga appears serene, calm and collected after vanquishing the demon in the sculpture.
Her graceful demeanour is described eloquently in Mahishasuramardini Stotram which was composed by the great sage Adi Shankaracharya around 810 AD.
‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤‡§≤‡§§‡•á

‡§ú‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§Ø ‡§π‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•ß‡•™ ‡••
The Goddess who is with the radiance like that of the lotus petals, whose forehead is like that of a clear moon
O the one who is skilled in all the arts, and surrounded with attendants, whose steps are followed by dancing swans
O the one whose is with lotuses and Pogada flowers, which are attracting the bees, O the one with beautiful hair
Victory to you, victory to you, the destroyer of Mahishasura, the one with beautiful-braided hair, the daughter of the mountain.

11/11/21, 2:55‚ÄØpm
If you are wondering what this hole amidst the rocks is‚Ä¶ it has a chequered past in the annals of history‚Ä¶
During the 18th century, Chitradurga Fort was under the rule of Madakari Nayaka IV. Hyder Ali, one of the most powerful military leaders of the times, was on a conquering spree and he decided to attack this fort. He tried everything possible to conquer the fort often referred to as Elusuttina Kote (meaning the fort of seven circles). which was one of the most impregnable forts of the time. Finally, he found that there was a small hole (also known as kindi) in one of the walls of the fort. The hole could easily fit one person in it. He also found out that the guard watching this hole goes to his house during lunch hours to have a meal. So he hatched a plan to attack the fort by sending the soldiers one by one through the kindi. One day, Kalanayak, husband of Obavva was guarding the tower as usual. He decided to go home for lunch. While having his meal he asked for water. Since there was no water at home Obavva went to the pond near the kindi, to collect water in a pot. While filling water she heard sounds approaching. She realized that enemy was lined up and was trying to enter into the fort through that hole. Using her presence of mind, she hid behind the hole and waited for the enemy. She just had an ‚ÄòOnake‚Äô a long wooden pestle used to pound paddy in the fields, as her weapon. The moment she saw the first soldier coming out of the hole, she hit his head so hard that he died in a single stroke. Similarly, she kept killing all the soldiers who came inside the fort through that tiny hole. The lone women bravely killed all the enemies who tried entering the fort that day.
With the only resource she had, she fought the enemy fiercely and the hole that she guarded is now known as Obavvana Kindi.
The government of Karnataka was planning to honour this women on this day as Onake Obavva Jayanti. This has been held back due to the model code of conduct being in place due to elections to the legislative council.
Obavva has an enduring presence in the history (irrespective of these issues) and do try and find your way down that hole!
11/11/21, 5:04‚ÄØpm

20/12/21, 8:33‚ÄØam
Today is Arudra Darisanam‚Ä¶
It is believed that on this holy day (Arudra or Thiruvadirai), Shiva performed the cosmic dance as Nataraja. Legend has it that Lord Shiva performed the cosmic dance as Nataraja at Chidambaram for his devotees Adi Shesha and Vyagrapaadar. Adishesha, the seven-hooded serpent on whom Lord Vishnu rests in milky ocean, wanted to witness this divine dance of creation after hearing about it as also Vyagrapaadar who performed penance and tapas to witness the Ananda Tandavam of Nataraja. Lord Shiva granted their request and performed the cosmic dance at Chidambaram. The Ananda Thandavam is said to symbolize the five divine aspects (pancha krityas) of creation, sustenance, dissolution, concealment, and bestowment of grace.
Although the occasion is associated with Chidambaram, it is celebrated with equal fervour and joy at other temples too. One such shrine is at Uthirakosa Mangai in Ramanathapurm district. The temple houses a 6 feet tall idol of Nataraja which is carved out of emerald, referred to as Maragatha Nataraja. The idol is covered with sandal paste all around the year and no puja is offered to the deity. On the eve of arudra darisanam the sandal paste is removed for a few hours for devotees to have a glimpse of the Lord.
Ahalya and myself visited this temple early this year and found this beautiful mural of Nataraja on the ceiling of the mandapa leading onto the garbagriha of the Nataraja shrine. There were a few other murals too, but almost all of them had faded over the years due to neglect except this remarkable one.
In almost all depictions of dancing Nataraja, the lord is seen lifting his left foot while balancing over apasmara (or muyalagan) with his right foot. In this painting he is lifting his right foot while balancing on his left one. The only other place where he is depicted similarly is at Madurai Meenakshi temple. The legend has it the Lord danced with his right foot raised on the request of Pandya King by the name of Rajasekhara, a great devotee of Shiva. The king was very much concerned that dancing with permanently grounded right foot that might cause the Lord pain. Responding to his fervent prayers, the lord himself made the shift from left foot to right foot, which is referred to as ‚ÄúKaal maari aadiya patalam.''
The metaphor of the cosmic dance unifies ancient mythology, religious art and spirituality seamlessly.
As the Dhyaana Shloka in praise if Lord Shiva, the Lord of Dance states:
‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø
‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ
‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø
‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§É (‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç
Angikam Bhuvanam Yasya
Vachikam Sarva Vangmayam
Aaharyam Chandra Taradi
Tam Numah ( Vande) Saattvikam Shivam
Whose bodily movement is the entire Universe
Whose speech is the language (of the Universe)
Whose ornaments are the moon and the stars
Him, we worship the pure (serene) Lord Shiva!

12/05/21, 10:50‚ÄØam
Once in the city of Vesali there was widespread famine and spreading disease. There were many dead bodies as the conditions overwhelmed the ability to properly dispose of bodies. The local citizens sought out the Buddha‚Äôs help, who was nearby in Rajagaha. The Buddha arrived in Vesali a short time later with a large number of monks, including Ananda. Just before the Buddha‚Äôs arrival, torrential rains helped the situation somewhat by cleansing the landscape of rotting corpses and clearing the air and water.
Prior to his presenting this discourse, he instructed his attending monks to walk through the city and do what they could to ease the physical suffering of the citizens and to individually present this teaching. At the formal teaching the Buddha then presented a way to bring true refuge from the stress and suffering of the world and to put an end to all dukkha... https://youtu.be/Dte6qZarSks
13/05/21, 8:45‚ÄØam
There are moments of reprieve in these gloomy times.
The sky is getting darker and a billowy wind is blowing across. As the raindrops start caressing the leaves, the chirping birds search for shelter. An interesting medley sounds softly floats in the air.
I keep wondering whether the bird calls are sounding different in these times. There seems to be a discernibly upbeat quality in their songs. Or perhaps given the lack of noise due to the lockdown their calls are heard more vividly.
The soundscape replete with mellifluous calls of birds soothens the angst of isolation.
There is an intricate, ineffable relationship between the landscape outside of us and that within.
In the words of Rumi, ‚ÄúBirdsongs brings relief to my longing‚Äù and I retreat into the silence within‚Ä¶
13/05/21, 12:21‚ÄØpm

On this Shankara Jayanthi, I was reminded of these lines from his Pratah Smarana Stotram, the Morning Prayer.
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç

22/05/21, 12:29‚ÄØpm

25/05/21, 2:13‚ÄØpm
Today is Narasimha Jayanti.
Narasimha is one of the ten incarnations of Vishnu. He has often been depicted in nine different forms, Nava Narasimha which can be seen in the temple at Ahobilam.
Sculptors from the Hoysala period depicted some of these forms in intricate detail. This one from Halebeedu depicts him seated with the demon Hiranyakashipu in his lap. He is portrayed with six arms; two upper hands hold the shanku and chakra, the bottom two hands are grasping the demon in a tight grip while the two arms in the middle are tearing his entrails apart. Even the intestines have been depicted in detail! Prahlada can be seen in the bottom left offering obeisance.
As Ananda Coomaraswamy commented, sculptures in Indian temples are not patterned after any ‚Äòliving model.‚Äô They represent an unending array of imagery, steeped in symbolism. What could be the symbolism behind the sculpture?
To me he is an iconic symbol of intensive resistance to unjust things, hope against odds, triumph of the good over persecution and evil. He is the annihilator of maleficent forces within and outside of us.
25/05/21, 10:39‚ÄØpm
Fantastic sculpture. Your description forces us to scan the picture carefully!
26/05/21, 7:46‚ÄØam
On the occasion of Buddha Jayanthi today, I was recollecting my sojourn to the Mahabodhi temple.
It had rained the previous evening and the cool breeze of the morning kept me company as I slowly made my way to the temple. Since I was keen to reach the place early, there was hardly anyone at that time. A group of Buddhist monks were walking and chanting melodiously at a distance. I went around the temple and sat in front of the Bodhi tree. Early morning sun was peeping through its leaves.
For more than a month, Siddhartha (as Buddha was earlier called) meditated beneath it and attained enlightenment. It is said that emperor Ashoka's daughter, Sanghamitta took a branch from the original Bodhi tree to Sri Lanka and planted it in Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka. That Bodhi tree is still alive there and is supposedly one of the oldest continually documented trees in the world. The tree I was sitting in front has been grown from a sapling brought from the one in Sri Lanka.
Forest and trees are intimately associated with Buddha. He was reportedly born under the ashoka tree(though some say it was a mango tree), attained enlightenment under the papal tree and entered into mahaparinirvana under the sala tree. Further, four trees are associated with the enlightenment of the Buddha. He sat under a pipal tree for the first seven days, in the bliss of his enlightenment; then he arose and sat under a nyagrodha, the banyan tree for another seven days, in the bliss of his illumination; then he sat beneath a muchalinda (Indian oak) for another seven days, in the bliss of his calm; and, finally, he sat beneath a rajayatana (wild mango) for seven days, in the bliss of his emancipation. The four trees are known as the Tree of Enlightenment, the Tree of the Goatherd, the Tree of Muchalinda, and the Tree of Emancipation, respectively.
There has been a strong association with spirituality and sacred trees in Indian history and I was sitting under one of them to savor a fleeting glimpse of the infinite.
With the chants echoing in the distance, I slowly immersed myself in the experience of feeling His presence. As I lost myself amidst the canopy in front of me, I felt that He was whispering in my ears, ‚ÄúAny tree could be your Bodhi tree‚Ä¶‚Äù
26/05/21, 12:02‚ÄØpm

18/07/21, 10:51‚ÄØam
A few years ago we visited Omi International Arts Center in Ghent, off the beaten path in the gorgeous Hudson Valley countryside. It is a vast open space of over 100 acres studded with nearly 80 sculptures which blend into the landscape. We spent several hours exploring the magical space and savoring large-scale works of contemporary and modern artists. As I made my way amidst the rolling farmland and undulating meadows, I felt that I was in ‚ÄúConstable Country!‚Äù
John Constable was largely responsible for reviving the landscape painting in 19th century. He began painting canvases in the open air, with striking results. Using finely executed brushwork, he synthesized elements of light and shade to convey the radiance of the Suffolk countryside.
I was not carrying my camera and this image of the radiant landscape of the OMI Center was taken with the iPhone.

20/07/21, 8:01‚ÄØpm
Whenever I see this small statuette on my desk I am reminded of Francis of Assisi, who abandoned a life of luxury and embraced the vow of poverty.
He had a deep love of nature and animals and is known as the patron saint of ecology.
These lines from Prayer of St Francis are extraordinarily evocative:
O divine Master
grant that I may not so much seek
to be consoled as to console,
to be understood as to understand,
to be loved as to love.
For it is in giving that we receive‚Ä¶

29/07/21, 10:28‚ÄØam
Nature has always been a source of inspiration for poets.
Mahakavi Bharathiyar wrote a series of Vachana Kavithai (Prose Poems) titled Kaatchi (Vision). It is a work of immense literary and spiritual significance. In its style and imagination, they are unique in the history of Tamil literature. Some of these verses are akin to verses from the Rig Vediv hymns which laid emphasis on the worship of nature in its most sublime aspects.
It is believed that Mahakavi Bharathiyar studied the Rig Veda under the tutelage of Sri Aurobindo.
This particular verse about the setting sun is redolent with sublime imagery‚Ä¶.

Yes Sir, which is very unique. The caption coincided with the smell I was getting from watering a plant which I hadn't üôÑ The droplets of rain are also visible in the photograph!
12/08/21, 11:10‚ÄØam
World Elephant Day, observed every year on August 12, draws attention to their importance in our ecosystem and emphasizes the need for their conservation and protection.
At one time in history elephants played a crucial part in warfare. They had a huge psychological impact in wars because their majestic sight and destructive potential. Their sheer size and ability to get rid of a number of enemy foot soldiers at one sweep created panic in the battlefield. Monarchs from different ruling dynasties like Magadha, Maurya, Gupta, and Chola enlisted these doe-eyed gigantic creatures in the army and they continued to be used by Indian warriors, right unto the seventeenth century.
Thankfully, the use of war elephants gradually declined at the end of medieval era after the advent of gunpowder.
This depiction of the war elephant is from a 16th century Nayak era mural at Thiruppudaimaruthur temple
12/08/21, 5:25‚ÄØpm

It is difficult to convey the grim reality on the ground in Afghanistan, especially its impact on the women.
Some years ago, on an early morning in the sand dunes of Khuri, I saw this woman trudging alone the vast landscape, delicately balancing a pot on her head.
I was wondering where she was heading to, treading on this harsh terrain, as the nearest human habitat was several miles ahead.
Will memories of her home guide her or will it always be away?

19/08/21, 8:40‚ÄØam
The movement of light and shadows formed by the interplay of trees, wind and sunlight on the landscape is always quite entrancing.
The Japanese have a unique word for this occurrence: komorebi, which is made up of the kanji characters for tree, shine through and sun.
It is quite an untranslatable, poetic word. The closest in English might be dappled sunlight!
More than a word, it is an awe-filled feeling‚Ä¶
A glimpse of that ephemeral moment on this World Photography Day‚Ä¶

02/09/21, 8:55‚ÄØam
Hampi has an enduring presence in spite of ravages of wars and time.
The melancholic beauty of the ruins has an irresistible charm.
Amidst the vast landscape, giant boulders of various sizes and hues reach out to the sky. These were once part of gigantic granite monoliths of the Dharwar Craton which date back to 2.5 billion years.
Nature has sculpted these rocks in amazing shapes, many of them balancing precariously on the craggy hills.
04/09/21, 11:09‚ÄØam
Today is the International Vulture Awareness Day to draw attention to the importance of preservation of this often reviled bird for the yeomen service they do in keeping the ecosystem in balance. My dear friend Bharathidasan has been doing exemplary work in their conservation through his organization Arulagam.
Often seen alone, this majestic Red Headed Vulture is a timid bird in spite of its size. It usually refrains from fighting with other birds at a carcass. Instead, it waits patiently before hurriedly making a foray and withdrawing with a bite of flesh.
04/09/21, 12:37‚ÄØpm
As humans with a developed brain, we should learn from it. Such a beautiful photograph Sir!
07/09/21, 8:48‚ÄØam
Anagalis Moneli orBlue Pimpernel has one of the brightest blue petals in nature and is named after French horticulturist Jean Monelle.
It is also called ‚Äòpoor man‚Äôs barometer‚Äô as the blue blossoms remain closed in dusky, cold weather and open when the sun comes up.
It is quite a charmer with its pink eye and yellow anthers in the midst of silky blue petals!
07/09/21, 10:28‚ÄØpm
Beautiful blue flower, Sir. The photograph has made the colour striking, because of hazy green background.
10/09/21, 7:48‚ÄØam
Ganesha, as we know him today, appears as a distinct deity during the Gupta period. With the advent of the Puranic tradition, he emerged as a major God with a sect of his own called Ganapatyas. By the seventh century CE, Adi Shankara included the worship of Ganapati as one of the six systems (shanmata) of the Hindu religion.
There are 32 forms of Ganesha and he continues to be depicted in various pleomorphic forms inspired by the creative spirits of the artists!
One of the magnificent images of Ganesha is in Hampi, often referred to as Sasivekalu Ganesha. This monolithic statue is carved out of a single block of granite rock and is housed in an open pavilion.
Ganesha holds an axe in the upper right hand and a noose in the upper left hand. He holds the axe urging the devotee to destroy unwanted, evil thoughts that can lead one into Adharma. The noose or pasha in Ganesha's left hand is an implement to capture all difficulties. The noose conveys that worldly attachments are a noose around man‚Äôs neck. In order to attain spiritual perfection, one should cut the worldly attachments and attain spiritual enlightenment. In his lower left hand he is holding his favourite sweet the
‚Äúmodak‚Äù. ‚ÄòMod (‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶)‚Äô means Anand and ‚Äòka (‡§ï)‚Äô means a small portion. Therefore, modak is a small portion of Anand. He is holding a broken tusk in the right lower hand which he used as a writing tool for the Mahabharata epic.
A snake is tied around his prominent belly (which incidentally resembles a mustard seed and hence the name!). The popular tale is that once Ganesha ate lots of food and his stomach was almost bursting. In order to hold it back, he tied a snake around it!
However, the surprise element in this sculpture is at the back when one notices Devi Parvathi holding Ganesha in her lap! This is a very unusual and unique depiction of Ganesha!
As with other Hindu Gods the story of Ganesha is embedded in varying mythological narratives which are replete with multiple symbolic interpretations. It also interweaves with folk elements reflecting a community‚Äôs understanding and interpretation of the God in relation to their lifeworld‚Äôs.
21/09/21, 8:52‚ÄØam
Written by the Singaporean poet Anne Lee Tzu Pheng, this remarkable poem dwells on the nature of time and the relationship humans share. It invites the reader to be present in the moment rather than losing oneself in regret and guilt about the incontrovertible nature of time and lost opportunities. This poem is to remind us to take our time to live life and appreciate the value of life and memories that lives on beyond time and death.

Beautiful photograph Sir. Yes, when will I be able to maintain silence in the mind üôÑ
26/09/21, 10:28‚ÄØam
Today is the birthday of the poet TS Eliot, someone whom I like immensely. He concludes his magnum opus, Waste Land with these lines of hope;
Datta. Dayadhvam. Damyata.
Shantih Shantih Shantih.
Interestingly, Datta, Dayadhvam and Damyata have their origin in the fifth chapter of the Brihdaranyaka Upanishad. Prajapati, the creator is asked by devas, men and demons for advice. Then the thunder said Da.. Da.. Da‚Ä¶ Prajapathi asked them whether they understood the message. All the three groups nodded their heads saying ‚ÄòYes, Master, we understood it very well‚Äô. Devas understood Da as Damyata, self-control. Da meant Datta, give, donate for humans. While for the demons Da meant Dayatva, compassion.
Kanchi Paramacharya highlighted the importance of these three in his song Maithreem Bhajatha, made popular by MS Subbalakshmi
An English translation of this song I found on the web reads:
Serve with friendship and humility
Which will conquer the hearts of everyone.
Look upon others similar to yourself.
Renounce war
Renounce unnecessary competition for power
Give up aggression on others‚Äô properties
Mother Earth is broad enough to give us all we desire
God is compassionate to all
Daamyata ‚Äì So, Restrain yourself
Datta ‚Äì So, Donate your wealth to others
Dayathvam ‚Äì So, Be Kind to others
May all people of this world be happy and prosperous.
May all people of this world be happy and prosperous.
May all people of this world be happy and prosperous.
29/09/21, 7:50‚ÄØam
Early in the morning, in the jungle, our attention was drawn to an extraordinarily wide range of loud calls ‚Äì whistles, wails, screeches, and gurgles. Soon enough, we spotted the origin of these sounds; a flock of noisy birds with striking orange beaks and yellow markings in it neck and nape. Their glossy black feathers shimmered in the light. Interestingly, they were hopping sideways in the tree trunk actively looking for insects.
The Hill Mynah has been described as the best talking bird in the world, indeed the champion of mimics! Unlike some other birds, such as the racket tailed drongo, they do not imitate other birds in the wild. In captivity, they can learn to reproduce a range of sounds, including the human voice, with astonishing accuracy and clarity.
As we were watching, it flung its wings and flew away, scattering the medley of calls into the air‚Ä¶
10/10/21, 10:02‚ÄØam
The purpose of the World Mental Health Day is to shine light on the ubiquitous impact of emotional distress and offer hope to emerge with greater resilience
14/10/21, 9:52‚ÄØam
Today is Saraswathi Pooja. I had seen many sculptural depictions of Saraswathi during my travels. Personally I would rate the portrayal of the goddess at Gangaikondacholapuram as the most beautiful one. It was by sheer chance and through close observation, I had a glimpse of one of the smallest representation of Saraswathi and it was at Khajuraho.
Khajuraho temples represent the exquisite architectural heritage of the Chandellas. The Varaha temple is among the oldest in the western group of temples and is believed to have been constructed around 900 ‚Äì 925 A.D. Comparatively small in comparison to its neighbours, its grandeur overwhelms you as you ascend the stairs and enter the little pavilion. Directly under the pyramidal roof which is carved with lotus flower, stands an enormous monolithic image of the boar Varaha, the third incarnation of Vishnu. The image is made out of a single block of sandstone that measures 2.6 metres long and 1.7 metres high. The stone shines like burnished metal and on its surface are 675 miniature figures, carved in twelve well-ordered rows. These figures represent many of the important Gods and Goddesses of the Hindu pantheon. These include ganesha, the seven mothers, the seven sages, the eight guardians of space, the nine planetary divinities, the river goddesses, the seas, the Rudras, and the different forms of Vishnu.
A low parapet wall surrounds the massive figure of Varaha and as I sat on the soft smoothened stone, my attention was drawn to a small figure carved between the nose and mouth of Varaha.
I was totally surprised to see a diminutive sculpture of Saraswathi with Veena in her arms!
Though small in size, the sculpture powerfully conveys all the essence of the goddess, much like beej mantras.
Literally the word ‚Äòbeej‚Äô means ‚Äòseed‚Äô. In the seed are inherent all the characteristics of the tree. The most important thing about beej mantra is pronunciation and the sound associate with it, as each beej is associated with its own frequency. The more accurate the recitation of the beej mantra, easier it is for one to focus on meditation. ‚ÄúMantra‚Äù in Sanskrit is made up of two syllables: ‚Äúman‚Äù (mind) and ‚Äútra‚Äù (liberate). Thus in its most literal translation the word ‚Äúmantra‚Äù means ‚Äúto liberate one‚Äôs mind‚Äù. Essentially beej mantras are tools for expansion of consciousness utilizing the power of sound vibrations.
The beej is ‚ÄúAing‚Äù for Saraswati and is chanted along with name of the goddess and is prefixed with ‚ÄúOm‚Äù, the primordial vedic beej mantra.
‡•ê ‡§ê‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ||
Om Aing Mahasaraswatyai Namah |
Meaning: I meditate and bow to Maha Saraswati Devi.
14/10/21, 5:19‚ÄØpm
Wonderful image Sir. And so very rich in depiction. Hail their patience to carve them and yours to have captured so beautifully and it appears to be an apt justification for their patience. The narration is so informative.
15/10/21, 9:46‚ÄØam
Dussehra denotes victory of good over evil and there are two stories that are associated with the festival in India. It is said that it was on this day that goddess Durga defeated Mahishasura after a fierce battle lasting for more than nine days. It is also celebrated to mark the victory of Lord Rama over ten-headed demon king of Lanka, Ravana.
One of the most vivid depictions of this battle scene is in the western gallery of Angkor Wat. Extensive, detailed, carefully chiselled bas reliefs depicting various scenes from Ramayana adorn the gallery. The craftsmanship on the sandstone carvings is quite extraordinary.
The first photo depicts Rama waging the battle with his army and the second one portrays Ravana in his chariot. The stylized portrayal of Ravana is quite distinctive from usual depictions and is reflective of Khmer influence. The dynamism in the rendering of the battle scene is truly outstanding.
Ramayana is a living tradition in Cambodia and the epic is called the Reamker. The story is broadly that of the Ramayana, with a few changes. Rama is known as Phreah Ream, Sita as Neang Seda, Laxman as Preah Leak. The three are sent into exile with one of Rama‚Äôs stepmothers seeking to get her son crowned as King. Neang Seda is abducted in the forest and the two brothers ally with Sukreep (Sugreeva) to defeat the demon army of Lanka to get her back. Ravana is Krong Reap, the ten-headed king of Lanka. There is an interesting twist in the tale about Hanuman. In India, Hanuman is revered and regarded as the epitome of celibacy. In the Reamker, Hanuman was directing his monkey army to build a bridge of stones to Lanka. He realized that mermaids were stealing the stones. He decides to capture the mermaid princess, Sovanna Maccha, and teach her a lesson. In the process, Hanuman falls in love with the mermaid princess and marries her, later having a son called Mudchanu!
21/10/21, 9:53‚ÄØam

Heavy rain accompanied by thunder and lightning has been an unwavering feature on most days.
On one such evening I spotted this lone bird flying amidst dark, gloomy monsoon clouds‚Ä¶

04/11/21, 7:33‚ÄØam
Deepavali demonstrates how ancient tales in various epics can vary across the country. There are many narratives around Deepavali. One of them which we grew up with, commemorates the vanquishing of the demon Narakasura by Lord Krishna. As kids we would be woken up at an unearthly hour before sunrise and after an oil bath (which I detest!), wearing the new clothes, we would offer obeisance to the elders and rush to light the fire crackers. Sumptuous lunch with Deepavali sweets will be topped with a special lehiyam (a digestive) prepared for the occasion.
In other accounts it also marks the day that Lord Rama triumphantly returns to Ayodhya with Sita after a prolonged exile of 14yeas and defeating Ravana in the battle. It is said that Ayodhya‚Äôs citizens welcomed their prince home with thousands of glowing oil lamps on a moonless night. The word Deepavali has its origins from the Sanskrit word deep (lamp) and avali (row).
This painting is from Ram Gopal Poddar Chhatri in Ramgarh, Rajasthan which Ahalya and myself visited sometime back. Ramgarh is a sleepy little town surrounded by sand dunes in the Shekhawati region and was once amongst the richest towns in India. It was considered as a centre of learning and was known as Doosra Kashi. It is now a treasure trove of painted havelis and chhatris. Chhatris are basically cenotaphs built to commemorate the memory of the rich and the royalty. Though they look unremarkable from outside, their interiors are full of resplendent paintings. The Ram Gopal Poddar Chhatri , built by the Poddar family in 1872, has exquisite murals depicting scenes from the Ramayana, the life of Lord Krishna, and Ragmalas. This impressive painting on the ceiling in particular depicts the arrival of Lord Rama and Sita to Ayodhya and the celebratory manner with which they were received. The luminous quality of the mural conveys the mood of the occasion wonderfully.
May the light of the diyas spread joy and happiness‚Ä¶
In the words of Rumi, ‚ÄúIf everything around seems dark‚Ä¶.look again You May Be The Light!‚Äù
Warm Deepavali Wishes From Ragu & Ahalya
10/11/21, 9:08‚ÄØam
Akka Mahadevi was a twelfth century Kannada poet, saint and mystic of the Virashaiva Bhakti movement. She was the first woman to have written vachanas in Kannada which are free verse hymns. Her vachanas end with her ‚Äòankita‚Äô (signature) calling Shiva as Chennamallikarjuna or as poetically translated by A. K. Ramanujan, ‚ÄúLord as White as Jasmine‚Äù. Over time, Akka‚Äôs concept of Chenna Mallikarjuna changed from that of the Puranic Shiva to a formless Divine which finds expression in this vachana, superbly translated by my favourite poet AK Ramanujan.
I was reminded of this vachana when I saw this landscape enveloped in early morning mist‚Ä¶
YOU ARE THE FOREST
you are all the great trees
in the forest
you are bird and beast
playing in and out
of all the trees
O lord white as jasmine
filling and filled by all
why don't you
show me your face?

This year, Ragu reaches a milestone on 21st Nov when he turns 70! Yes, it's kind of hard to believe that!
Many of you, dear family and friends were with us to celebrate his 60th birthday. However given the current uncertain situation, we have shelved the idea of an in-person gathering this time, though it would have given us immense joy to have you all with us on the occasion.
Instead, we have created a special Facebook page for you to share your reflections, anecdotes, memories (including photographs!) and anything else that you may like to, about your association with him over these years. Ragu will deeply cherish this. Kindly click on the above link, join the group and delve into your memories!

24/11/21, 1:50‚ÄØpm
My interest in the field of psychiatry started quite early during my undergraduate period at JIPMER. I did quite well in ophthalmology and my professor felt that I had the makings of a good ophthalmologist, in spite of my myopia! Undeterred, I pursued my interest and was privileged to have had exceptional teachers who furthered my passion‚Ä¶which over decades I have tried to pass onto my students.
The field of mental health necessitate providing space for people to share their stories which they are unable to, in their real lives. I have strived to adopt a narrative approach (influenced by the literary legacy‚Ä¶thanks to my mother) in facilitating emergence of untold, unshared tales of suffering. I personally feel that psychiatry cannot be abstracted merely at a molecular level and has to transcend beyond, to incorporate the contexts and life worlds of people. That I have been able to instil this orientation in my students is my greatest satisfaction.
I am filled with gratitude that many of you who have been my co-travellers have taken time to share your thought, feelings, memories and photographs too!
I feel overwhelmed by the depth of affection expressed by all of you‚Ä¶
In the midst of all the demands in life, there is one person who has been beside me all through, for whom I am deeply indebted‚Ä¶ and our journey began together in 1978‚Ä¶

25/12/21, 8:00‚ÄØam
The Vatican Museum is a treasure trove. It has 54 galleries with amazing works of art.
As I walked into the Raphael Rooms, I was overwhelmed with the sheer beauty of its frescoes.
Prominent among them was The Disputation over the Blessed Sacrament or the Triumph of Religion which was painted by the artist when he was just 27 year old. It was probably first fresco that Raphael painted at the Vatican.
In the top most realm is featured God the Father, the Creator of all things visible and invisible. He is depicted holding the world in His hands along with a host of angels by his side. At the centre is God the Son. Seated on a throne of clouds, He gazes benevolently at the viewer. An august aureole encompasses His divine aura. To Christ‚Äôs left is seated John the Baptist. He is identified by his traditional iconography, pointing out to Christ as the path to salvation. To Christ‚Äôs right Blessed Virgin Mary is seated the with hands pressed at her chest. On either side of them are various saints and prophets. Below Christ‚Äôs feet is the Holy Spirit, to whose sides are books of the four Gospels held open. At the bottom is the monstrance which is flanked by groups of theologians in lively debate.
I spent several minutes, unmindful of scores of people passing by, looking at this incredible work of art brimming with life. The clarity, rich colours, harmonious composition and grandeur of this fresco left a lasting impression on me.
It is said that Raphael won the commission to paint the four rooms after stiff competition with both Michelangelo, who was working on the Sistine Chapel and Leonardo da Vinci. This incensed Michelangelo who accused Raphael of plagiarism, spreading rumours that Raphael had sneaked into the Sistine Chapel to have a preview of his work and copied the techniques!
(BTW this is just one section of the mural!)

01/05/21, 11:49‚ÄØam
On this Labor Day, let us focus attention on the Worker Bee!
They are born sterile and their sole purpose is to continue to work during their entire lifespan.
Worker bees are essentially the lifeblood of the hive. Without worker bees, there would be no one to care for the ever important queen, produce honey or pollinate plants and flowers.
The job for the worker bee changes through their life-span.
Younger ones handle cell cleaning and foraging outside is for the older bees. When the older ones return to the hive they leave packets on nectar for the house bound worker bees who then deposit them in the marked cells.
Worker bees live for about five weeks and then die.
They literally work themselves to death to help the survival of the hive‚Ä¶

22/09/21, 12:25‚ÄØpm
The greater one-horned rhino is the largest of the rhino species. Its greyish brown hide with skin folds gives it an armour plated appearance. It can deposit as much as 25 kg of dung in a single defecation. The dung piles contain seeds which have been ingested by the rhino which germinate in the nutrient-rich dung. During the day, rhinos spend a lot of time in water or wallowing in mud in order to keep cool. They are known to make about 10 sounds, including snorts, honks and roars!
On the World Rhino Day let us recollect this verse from the Khaggavisana Sutta, a Buddhist Pali text‚Ä¶
Without resistance in all four directions,
content with whatever you get,
enduring troubles with no dismay,
wander alone
like a rhinoceros.

04/01/22, 9:15‚ÄØam
Last year was a demanding one for all of us and there doesn't seem to be a respite around too, with the steady inroads of the new variant of the virus in the New Year.
Some reflections on the year that has gone by at: https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/unmasked-reflections.
Feel free to share your reminiscences about this post and that of the year too!
21/02/22, 12:07‚ÄØpm
I love Bar Headed Geese! They are amazing travellers! They breed in massive colonies near mountain lakes in Mongolia and when the cold starts to overcome them, fly thousands of miles to winter in South Asia and come down to South India too in large numbers. As someone suggested these dainty birds are able achieve what the fearsome Genghis Khan was unable to do!
When we heard that they are back in Hadinaru Lake near Mysore, myself and Ahalya took a much needed break after a year of prolonged stay at home and headed there. We were welcomed by their chorus of clucks as we went near the lake and it was such a wonderful sight to see hundreds of them resting and frolicking in the water. A sight to behold‚Ä¶
I had written a detailed account about these birds‚Ä¶do have a look at: https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/soaring-high-on-graceful-wings
17/03/22, 9:33‚ÄØam

https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/amidst-the-hallowed-precints-of-a-sacred-forest
10/04/22, 5:54‚ÄØam
https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/avani
India has many interesting places associated with Ramayana where the legend comes alive.
On the occasion of Ramanavami, let me take you to Avani, a small town in Kolar, Karnataka.
Soaked in antiquity the 10th century Ramalingeshwara temple at Avani and the looming hill behind it is the site of Uttara Ramayana and has incredible stories associated with it.
Read on and savor the rich architectural heritage of the place.
Kindly post your comments in the blog and not in Facebook!
18/04/22, 8:30‚ÄØam
Today is the World Heritage Day and the theme this year is ‚ÄúHeritage and Climate‚Äù.
On this occasion let me introduce you to Ashtadikpalakas, divine guardians of eight directions of the universe.
The ceiling near the sanctum of a temple is often considered to symbolically represent the sky and Ashtadikpalakas are sculpted in it.
One of most exquisite depictions of them is at Ramalingeshwara temple at Avani.
Do read on, have a glimpse of these guardians and feel free to post your comments in the blog! https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/ashtadikpalakas

Festivals

04/01/22, 9:15‚ÄØam

14/01/22, 3:37‚ÄØpm
