Sir I have always been drawn towards Gautham Buddha's teachings and it is heartening to know from the above the connectedness to the nature. It is so important to start walking in the path with a still focus. Thank you Sir for your attempts to bring our focus back to the long spiritual journey.
24/05/22, 8:37‚ÄØam
The day began with this beautiful song, Dwaitamu Sukhama, Advaitamu Sukhama, wherein Saint Thyagaraja expresses the dilemma faced by many seekers.
Dwaita and advaita offer two very different answers for the fundamental question of all philosophy: what is the nature of the world and that of the internal self? Dwaita claims that there are fundamentally two entities, jIvAtma and paramAtma, with the internal self being jIvAtma and the external world being a multi-faceted manifestation of paramAtma. Advaita posits that there is but only the paramAtma and the internal self is also a manifestation of the paramAtma.
They are often positioned as two different, dissimilar paths.
An elegant, insightful perspective is provided in a verse from Ashtavakra Gita.
kva dharmahÃ£ kva ca vƒÅ kƒÅmahÃ£ kva cƒÅrthahÃ£ kva vivƒìkatƒÅ |
kva dvaitamÃ£ kva ca vƒÅ(a)dvaitamÃ£ svamahimni sthitasya mƒì || 19-2 ||
For me, established in my own glory, there is no religion,
sensuality, possessions, philosophy, duality or even non-duality.
30/05/22, 9:57‚ÄØam
Matsuo Basho was a 17th century Haiku master. His singularly simple, beautiful poems are sublime catalysts for a Zen like reflective state like this one.
31/05/22, 9:02‚ÄØam
https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/the-lure-of-the-parrots
08/06/22, 8:39‚ÄØam
On the World Ocean Day, let us recall that life on earth probably began in hydrothermal vents in the depths of the oceans. But it was not the ocean we know today. It was warmer, more acidic and rich in iron. As life evolved, the oceans continued to provide home to many living things. In fact, a greater number of organisms live in the oceans than on land. Covering more than 70 per cent of the earth‚Äôs surface, they are humanity‚Äôs most important natural resource. Oceans feed us, regulate our climate and generate most of the oxygen we breathe.
Unfortunately, they also face major threats: global climate change, pollution, habitat destruction, invasive species, and a dramatic decrease in ocean fish stocks. These threats to the ocean are so extensive that more than 40 percent of the ocean has already been severely affected and no area has been left untouched.
The World Ocean Day is a timely reminder to develop a shared vision of a sustainable use of oceans.
As for me, the ocean with its enormity and mystery, has always been a continuing source of enchantment. There is no music more relaxing than the rolling of ocean waves.
My most memorable trip along the ocean was in California highway 1. It is perhaps one of the most astoundingly scenic roads in the world. Smelling the salty and briny sea breeze of the Pacific Ocean, seeing its vastness and feeling so small in the middle of its quiet stillness‚Ä¶these are emotions only the ocean can stir.
Poets capture these moments beautifully, like in these words of Meena Alexander, ‚ÄúSometimes the syllables of poetry well up, waves on the surface of the sea, and they burst as flying fish might, struck by light.‚Äù
As TS Eliot wrote in Four Quartets, ‚ÄúThe river is within us, the sea is all about us, ‚Äù and we have to tend to both with sensitivity and concern‚Ä¶
12/06/22, 9:14‚ÄØam
Today is Vaikasi Visakam which is celebrated as the birthday of Lord Muruga. Worship of Lord Muruga is interwoven with folk myths, personal and cultural histories. He has an unbounded and immortal presence across Tamil Nadu, inspiring intense devotion. A god who fosters multiple narratives, each and every community, has a story about their own divine ancestry featuring Lord Muruga.
Some of the earliest sculptural depictions of young Lord Muruga is in the Somaskandamurthy panels
which can be seen in the first freestanding temple in Tamil Nadu, the Kailasanatha Temple in Kanchipuram.
As we walk around the temple precincts, we can see many of these panels which portray Siva and Parvati with Skanda sitting on Parvati‚Äôs lap. In a larger depiction, (photgraph 1) Vishnu can also be seen in the back, in addition to Siva, Parvati and Skanda. Many of the small shrines that dot the inner wall of the courtyard have Somaskanda panels. One of them which attracted my attention was a striking portrayal with the remnants of vibrant hues adorning the back wall. Unfortunately, the face of Skanda has worn out with time. But its beauty and allure hasn‚Äôt faded‚Ä¶
17/06/22, 7:04‚ÄØam
‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Øà ‡Æö‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øá ‡Æ®‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Ææ
‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ∞‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ±‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Øã‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Øá ‡Æ®‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Ææ
In the black colours of the crow
I have a glimpse you Nanda (Krishna)
These are the opening lines of ‚ÄúKaakai Siraginile,‚Äù one of the most beautiful poems of Mahakavi Bharathiyar. It is a simple octet with references to a crow‚Äôs feather and a tryst with fire in the quest of Nandalala, the young Krishna. As with most poems, a direct translation doesn‚Äôt do justice to the nuances of the song itself.
Why did the poet choose the crow?
Crows are generally considered scavengers and generally not portrayed in good light. As someone known for raising his voice against social injustice, was Bharathiyar implying that even in such creatures, he sees the divine nature of Krishna. Was he also indicating that people can see Him everywhere in nature?
The poem embodies the eternal truth that the seeker can perceive the presence of the formless in all its forms.
18/06/22, 8:29‚ÄØam
Paul McCartney who is turning 80 today is a favourite singer of mine.
Shortly after returning from India where he was learning the art of Transcendental Meditation, he wrote "Blackbird" which was featured in the ‚ÄòWhite Album.‚Äô I keep listening to this tranquil guitar ballad often. This song was written solely by Paul McCartney. However, he acknowledged the role of John Lennon and hence the song goes under the name Lennon-McCartney.
Paul wrote this song on the background of the civil rights movement in US. The black bird in the song refers to a group of black students who faced racial discrimination in Little Rock Central High School Arkansas. As he said later, ‚ÄúThis was really a song from me to a black woman, experiencing these problems in the States. Let me encourage you to keep trying, to keep your faith; there is hope.‚Äô‚Äù
It is a song of empowerment, reflecting the singer‚Äôs longing for change.
No matter how dark our circumstances may be, there is always a glimmer of hope to be found..
Blackbird fly, blackbird fly
Into the light of a dark black night
21/06/22, 7:46‚ÄØam
Among all yoga asanas Vrksasana or tree pose is one of the most beautiful and serene one imbued with symbolic significance. It is also one of the oldest known yoga poses and is depicted in ancient sculptures.
An earliest representations is in ‚ÄúBhagiratha‚Äôs Penance‚Äù or ‚ÄúThe Descent of the Ganges‚Äù in Mahabalipuram which is dated to the 7th century. Bhagiratha stood in Vrksasana for one thousand years which persuaded Brahma and Shiva to create the Ganges.
In the first photograph one can notice a man standing on top left in the Vrksasana pose. Interestingly on the bottom right is a cat with a similar pose. Probably the cat is pretending to be a peaceful yogi fooling the mice (seen at its feet) before it eats them!
The second photo which portrays the asana in detail is from a pillar in the Thirukurungudi temple. It is slightly different from the former with one leg in Ardha Padmasana (Half-Lotus) and hands in Anjali Mudra (prayer position).
Symbolically, the tree is said to be strong and well grounded. It grows both upwards and downwards, ensuring stability. The grounding action of the standing leg represents the roots of a tree, and the stretching of the arms overhead represents the branches reaching upwards. It is believed that when one holds the pose, prana (life force) goes up facilitating the release of a transformative energy.
Dualities vanish
If, for a moment
We become a tree‚Ä¶
04/07/22, 8:21‚ÄØam
As humans we have the privilege to express ourselves through our speech. On many occasions we find that a simple gesture of the hand can express our thoughts equally well and perhaps much better.
Specific hand gestures that symbolize and convey various meanings are referred to as Mudras. Mudra Vidhanam, written by Anna and published by Ramakrishna Mutt lists at least 137 mudras. When a sculptor creates a deity, he adds various mudras to express the idea symbolized by it.
For instance look at these images. First one is from Gangaikondacholapuram and the second from the bronze gallery from Chennai museum. You will notice the gesture of the right hand, where the forefinger is joined with the thumb and the other three fingers remain separate. This is often referred to as Chinmudra.
The thumb represents Brahman because without the thumb the hand cannot function. The middle, ring and the small finger represents the body, mind and intellect respectively. Index finger represents the ego because it keeps pointing at others most of the times! When we hold our hand normally the index finger is attached to the other three fingers and is far away from the thumb. This indicates that we normally think of ourselves as the body, mind and intellect, separate from the Brahman. As long as we have this notion, we will have a beginning and an end. When the index finer (ego) separates itself from the body/mind/ intellect and unites with the thumb (representing the Brahman), it forms a circle, which has no beginning and end. It symbolizes the union of the jivatma with the Paramatma, which is the essence of all realisation.
Some symbols convey the deeper meanings with sublime simplicity‚Ä¶
12/07/22, 8:26‚ÄØam
The mango season is on the wane and having savoured it, sweet memories linger on..
Absence of simplicity in life is akin to a mango without its sweetness.
All too often, we fritter away our lives in pursuit of the tangible. Simplicity is about minimizing our needs and maximizing the meaningful aspects of life. When a mathematician tries solve a difficult problem, he first frees the equation of all impediments and reduces it to its simplest terms. Like wise to simplify our lives we need to distinguish the necessary and the real from the clutters of the material world in which we are immersed.
Many illustrious people have explored the terrain of simplicity, the most prominent of them being Henry Thoreau. He went to the Walden Pond to learn what were the ‚Äútrue necessaries of life‚Äù. He recorded his experiences spread over a decade in journals which were later compiled in the book Walden.
Often Thoreau sat on the banks of the Walden Pond reading Charles Wilkin‚Äôs 1785 translation of the Bhagvat Gita. In his own words, ‚ÄúIn the morning I bathe my intellect in the stupendous and cosmogonal philosophy of the Bhagvat Gita‚Ä¶‚Äù This particular verse from Chapter 17 draws attention to the significance of simplicity.
‡§Æ‡§®: ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶: ‡§∏‡•å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•å‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π: |
‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á || 16||
Serenity of thought, simplicity, silence, self-control, and purity of purpose are the austerities of the mind.
Today is also the birth anniversary of Thoreau which is celebrated as the World Simplicity Day.
It is probably a perfect day to pick up Walden and remind ourselves that pursuit of simplicity in life need not be a distant dream.
13/07/22, 9:39‚ÄØam
A true Guru would never tell the seeker or the student what to do.
On the contrary, he/she would give them the knowledge with which they could decide what would be best path for them to venture. When he/she points a finger towards the path of discovery the students attention is often fixed on the finger and not the path.
Thich Nhat puts this succinctly "just as a finger pointing at the moon is not the moon itself. A thinking person makes use of the finger to see the moon. A person who only looks at the finger and mistakes it for the moon will never see the real moon."
I hail from a family of teachers and have been blessed with Gurus who inspired and guided me ‚Äòto see the moon‚Äô in my professional journey. This quest remains unabated as I continue to learn from my multitudinous talented students.
The letter ‚Äògu‚Äô refers to darkness, the letter ‚Äòru‚Äô means he who dispels such darkness, ‚ÄòGuru‚Äô is called so because of his ability to dispel darkness of ignorance.
In Indian spiritual traditions, Dakshinamurthy is perceived as the First Guru, Adi Guru.
Iconographically, he is depicted in various forms and this beautiful carving is from Amirthagadeswarar temple at Melakadambur which was built by the Chola King Kulothunga-I in 1113 AD
14/07/22, 9:36‚ÄØam
Yesterday was Guru Purnima and it is not mere coincidence that it was also the day in 6th century BCE when Buddha delivered his first sermon after his enlightenment at Bodhgaya. It is recorded as the Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta, which means "The Setting in Motion of the Wheel of Dharma." It took place in the Deer Park at Varanasi to the group of five ascetics, namely Konda√±√±a, Assaji, Bhaddiya, Vappa, and MahƒÅnƒÅma.
In this sermon, the Buddha outlined the core conceptual framework of Buddhism. He began with the doctrine of the Middle Way, which emphasizes that the path to enlightenment lies between extremes of self-indulgence and self-denial. Then Buddha explained the Four Noble Truths, which are: Life is dukkha, dukkha is driven by craving, there is a way to be liberated from both and that way is the Eightfold Path. Eightfold Path encompasses: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration.
Dukkha is a Pali word is often translated as unhappiness, pain or suffering. Suffering is inevitable in our lives, it is part of our human condition. By learning to be still and coming face to face with our pain and disappointments we have the opportunity to transform ourselves.
An ancient tribal saying states it succinctly, ‚ÄúBefore we can see properly we must first shed our tears to clear the way.‚Äù
14/07/22, 8:04‚ÄØpm
Yes Sir. Nowadays people want to turn to spirituality as an escape. Going through the vagaries of life, facing the hardships is the only way to become strong and think beyond. Thank you for letting me revise and ponder over the teachings.
16/07/22, 9:42‚ÄØam
Much like meditation, observing nature is an act of mindfulness. In the process, a deep connection emerges which is infinitely soothing.
It was early morning and we were the first few in the hallowed precincts of Muir Woods. As I was watching the sun streaming through the leafy branches of trees, I was reminded of the words of John Muir ‚Äúbetween every two pine trees there is a door leading to a new way of life.‚Äù Yet at the same time it was a reminder as to how fragile our world has become. I was wondering whether there is a term that encapsulates this experience and I stumbled upon this word Ambedo.
‚ÄúAmbedo is a kind of melancholic trance in which you become completely observed in vivid sensory details, briefly soaking in the experience of being alive, an act that is done purely for its own sake.‚Äù
01/08/22, 5:39‚ÄØam
Moby Dick is a multi-layered novel in which Herman Melville (whose birthday is today) handles several themes. One salient refrain is the story of man's attempt to defeat nature. Nature itself is personified through the white whale, one of the sea‚Äôs greatest marvels. They are a part of nature themselves. Any act of violence against them becomes an act of violence against nature as well. If nature is a thing of wonder that should be treated with great respect, its creatures should be treated in the same manner.
Finally, the sea takes down the men aboard the ship and the elusive Moby Dick slips away. Nature continues to carry on as it has for the past several thousand years, regardless of those who attempt to control or destroy it and the final sentence of the novel resonates with this message: ‚ÄúNow small fowls flew screaming over the yet yawning gulf; a sullen white surf beat against its steep sides; then all collapsed, and the great shroud of the sea rolled on as it rolled five thousand years ago.‚Äù
William Turner was a sublime artist of the sea and painted a series of seascapes. Herman Melville was fascinated by his paintings. It is said that shortly before writing his maritime masterpiece, he travelled to England and saw some of Turner‚Äôs paintings. Aspects of Moby Dick are strikingly evocative of Turner‚Äôs style.
02/08/22, 11:04‚ÄØam
It was Aadi pooram yesterday which is considered to be the birthday of Andal. She is one of the most extraordinary personalities in religious history and is the only female among the 12 Alvars. Alvars were poet-saints of South India who expressed their devotion to Lord Vishnu in their songs resplendent with longing and bhakti.
Andal‚Äôs Nachiyar Thirmozhi matches and even surpasses Sangam love poetry.
For instance she writes‚Ä¶.
‡ÆÆ‡Æ¥‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Øá ‡ÆÆ‡Æ¥‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Øá ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ±‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÇ‡Æö‡Æø ‡Æâ‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æ≥‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ
‡ÆÆ‡ØÜ‡Æ¥‡ØÅ‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡Æä‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æ©‡Ææ‡Æ±‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æä‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æü‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æâ‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±
‡ÆÖ‡Æ¥‡Æï‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æ§‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡ÆÆ‡Øà ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ®‡ØÜ‡Æû‡Øç‡Æö‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æï‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æü‡Æ§‡Øç
‡Æ§‡Æ¥‡ØÅ‡Æµ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æ§‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æä‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æµ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Øá?
Rain, pouring rain
My dazzling lord
Lives encased in clay
Molten wax within.
Can you rain down
And wash away the clay?
To melt my heart
With his radiant embrace
(A rather ‚Äòamateurish‚Äô translation of the original!)
In Nachiyar Thirumozhi, Andal writes about her dream of holding the hands of Lord Vishnu under a pearl studded canopy. In this painting, musician S Rajam who was also painter extraordinary, has depicted the scene vividly with vibrant hues.
03/08/22, 8:43‚ÄØam
Once James Baldwin (whose birthday was yesterday) wrote ‚ÄúYou think your pain and your heartbreak are unprecedented in the history of the world, but then you read.‚Äù
Reading his book, The Fire Next Time, which was published more than five decades ago, widens our gaze and perspective about the dreadful legacy of racism. It is an intensely personal, passionate document.
He writes, "The White man's unadmitted - and apparently to him, unspeakable - private fears and longings are projected onto the Negro. The only way he can be released from the Negro's tyrannical power over him is to consent, in effect, to become black himself, to become part of the suffering and dancing country that he now watches wistfully from the heights of his lonely power and, armed with spiritual traveller's cheques, visits surreptitiously after dark‚Ä¶..try to remember that what they believe, as well as what they do and cause you to endure, does not testify to your inferiority but to their inhumanity and fear. " It is an insightful comment about understanding the lives and tribulations of the marginalized ‚Äòother‚Äô, who continue to face discrimination and oppression across various structural inequalities.
Words that are as relevant today as he wrote them more than fifty years ago.
That said, I often wonder why it is so difficult for us to recognize inhumanity and the pain of the ‚Äòother‚Äô. Perhaps as James Baldwin reflects, ‚ÄúI imagine one of the reasons people cling to their hates so stubbornly is because they sense, once hate is gone, they will be forced to deal with pain.‚Äù
06/08/22, 11:14‚ÄØam
Flowers have a habit of blooming in the most unexpected of places‚Ä¶which we may not even notice.
Sometimes a poet pauses, observes and reflects on it as Alfred Tennyson (whose birthday falls today) does in his poem ‚ÄòFlower In A Crannied Wall.‚Äô
It is a short six line poem in which he muses on the connection between man, god and the cosmos. He visualizes man as flower, god as the root of the flower and the wall as cosmos. He wonders whether by plucking the flower from the wall, one can fathom its roots and understand all of its deep connections.
The poet suggests that even the tiniest creations of the universe, those that could be found anywhere, are part of the whole of creation. Through honing the ability to understand every aspect of it, one can unravel the mystery of our connection to the divine and the cosmos.
Essentially anything , any object, no matter however mundane it may be, when truly and mindfully experienced, opens up a doorway to enlightenment.
07/08/22, 9:09‚ÄØam
Yesterday I had posted about Tennyson‚Äôs quest to ‚Äòunderstand‚Äô the connection between man, god and the cosmos through plucking a flower in the roadside and exploring its roots.
Can one experience that connectivity merely by ‚Äòlooking‚Äô at a flower?
Basho who is revered as the greatest of Japan‚Äôs haiku poets observes a nazuna flower (sheperd‚Äôs purse) blooming by the wayside on a hedge and writes:
When I look carefully
I see the nazuna blooming
By the hedge!
He is content merely to "look" to sense the deep mystery of the flower. Immersing oneself through contemplative observation of an ordinary flower and pondering over its beauty, one could unravel the mystery of creation. In the process, the distinction between ourselves and nature breaks down. We become one with the universe and a reassuring sense of harmony and connection with the world permeates our consciousness. A state often referred to Eutierria.
British naturalist and environmental writer Michael McCarthy wrote eloquently about such experiences, ‚ÄúThere can be occasions when we suddenly and involuntarily find ourselves loving the natural world with a startling intensity, in a burst of emotion which we may not fully understand, and the only word that seems to me to be appropriate for this feeling is Joy.‚Äù
Let us reclaim and discover our joyous belonging to the natural world . . .
08/08/22, 10:55‚ÄØam
Ardez is a small, quaint village located on the southern slope of the Silvretta alps, in the midst of lush meadows. It is an outstandingly well preserved village with typical Engadine houses. These houses have massive walls with deep set windows and archways. What makes them unique are their playfully decorated facades. These are referred to as Sgraffiti, which is derived from the Italian ‚Äúsgraffiare‚Äù (to scratch). Beautiful patterns, drawings are engraved on the walls and many of them are exquisitely painted too. We spent several hours savouring each nook and corner of this charming village.
And on a corner of an old house was this cat staring straight at us.
Cats have provided the inspiration for an incredible range of fiction, memoir and poetry. TS Elitot for examples, was a ‚Äòcat man‚Äô. He owned many during his life and gave them various funny and outlandish names. He wrote ‚ÄòOld Possum‚Äôs Book of Practical Cats‚Äô which outsold his magnum opus ‚ÄòThe Waste Land‚Äô! This excerpt is from the poem "The Naming of Cats" from the book.
When you notice a cat in profound meditation,
The reason, I tell you, is always the same:
His mind is engaged in a rapt contemplation
(Incidentally today is International Cat Day!)
09/08/22, 11:09‚ÄØpm
A beautiful photograph Sir and the poem! When we connect with nature and contemplate we can understand about life and inculcate its natural ways.
10/08/22, 1:39‚ÄØpm
World Lion Day, which is today is to create awareness about one of the most majestic species to walk the earth and celebrate the animal kingdom's most beautiful and fearsome creature.
Lions have been an important symbol in various kingdoms for thousands of years and appear as a theme in all cultures across the world. As the ‚ÄúKing of the beasts," it is a symbol of majesty, strength, courage, justice, and confidence.
Artists have been depicting lions for millennia and the list of lions in art is endless.
In temple architecture in India, lions figure all through history and prominently during the regime of the Pallavas.
The structural temples of the Pallavas belong to two groups: Rajasimha group (A.D. 690-c.800) and the Nandivarman group (800-c.900 A.D.). The famous ‚ÄòKailasanatha Temple‚Äô, considered as the largest sandstone temple in the world, is the best representation of the Rajasimha group of temples, while the ‚ÄòVaikuntha Perumal Temple‚Äô is an example of the Nandivarman group. Lion motifs started appearing under Rajasimha, marking the beginning of a pillar design in Kailasanatha temple and it reached the zenith in the Vaikuntha Perumal Temple in Kanchipuram. This temple is a masterpiece of Pallava architecture. Most impressive and unique feature of the temple are the pillars. Each one of them has a meticulously carved lion on it. They support the enclosed passage inside the temple which have a wealth of weathered but extremely detailed wall panels.
Lions have particularly caught the public attention of late, thanks to their representation over the new parliament building. The lion represents the Buddha, formerly Shakyamuni, a member of the Shakya (lion) clan. With their mouths open, the lions seem to convey the message of dharma and the Four Noble Truths.
A timely reminder in these times‚Ä¶
profraguram.com
16/08/22, 1:32‚ÄØpm
As we celebrated 75 years of India‚Äôs independence yesterday, another exceptional event escaped our attention. It was also the 150th birth anniversary of Sri Aurobindo, the revolutionary turned mystic.
The decisive moment in his life was when he was incarcerated in the Alipore bomb case. Spending a year in solitary confinement, he experienced a series of spiritual awakenings. Deeply influenced by these, his life‚Äôs trajectory changed. On the strength of an 'Adesh' (Divine command) from above, he moved to Pondicherry. In his words, ‚ÄúPondicherry is my place of retreat, my cave of tapasya‚Äù. Yoga that strived for personal salvation was not for him. He sought the unity with the outer along with the exploration of the inner through his ‚Äòintegral yoga‚Äô
The core of Sri Aurobindo‚Äôs political philosophy is that the state exists for the individual and not the individual for the state. He commented, ‚ÄúThe government is for the people. It must provide for stability as well as progress. Stability may be achieved by unity and co-operative action, and progress by free individual growth. The government should be run by people who are selfless, unegoistic, scrupulously honest and capable. Their allegiance should be to the whole country; they should serve the interests of the whole country and not of any party.
A timely reminder!
01/09/22, 7:12‚ÄØam
The way to truth lies through the destruction of the false.
To destroy the false,
you must question your most inveterate beliefs. Of these the idea that you are the body is the worst.
With the body comes the world,
with the world
-- God,
who is supposed to have created the world and thus it starts --
fears, religions, prayers, sacrifices, all sorts of systems --
all to protect and support the child-man, frightened out of his wits by monsters of his own making.
Realize that what you are cannot be born nor die, and with the fear gone,
all suffering ends.
- Sri Nisaraghatta Maharaj.
04/09/22, 7:31‚ÄØam
Krishna Janmashtami is closely followed two weeks later by the birthday of Radha, which is celebrated today.
The inseparable love and affection between Radha and Krishna is symbolic of the eternal striving of a devout mortal for the Divine.
‚ÄúAtma To Radhika Tasya‚Äù: She is the soul and energy that resides in Krishna.
The love between Radha and Krishna has been immortalised by poets, musicians, painters and writers.
Jayadeva‚Äôs Gita Govinda is an important text that describes their relationship in exquisite detail.
For instance in act seven song fourteen verse 17, he narrates the feeling of Radha when Krishna casts a glance on her:
dayita-vilokita-lajjita-hasit√§
bahu-vidha-k√ºjita-rati-rasa-rasit√§
k√§pi madhuripu√´√§
‚ÄúThe glance of her beloved incites a bashful laughter in her, Tasting the ambrosia of love, she murmurs like a cuckoo, voicing her pleasure with a sudden surge of ecstatic euphoria‚Äù.
Very many schools of painting have rendered such scenes with stylistic variations.
Thousand of Radhakrishna paintings adorn galleries and museums across the world.
Each one of them is sheer visual poetry.
This particular mural is from the Ram Gopal Poddar Chhatri in Ramgarh in the Shekhawati region of Rajasthan.
07/09/22, 12:34‚ÄØam
There are times in one‚Äôs life when the desire to know the essence of thing has an irresistible appeal. ‚ÄòZen And The Art Of Motorcycle Maintenance‚Äô fulfilled that need early in my life. It was the personal quest of the author, Pirsig in throes of intense suffering (he had 28 ECTs), to explore that realm through weaving together eastern and western philosophical thoughts in a fascinating manner. The motorcycle is a symbol of a soul in search. Reading the book is a transformational experience.
6th September was Pirsig‚Äôs birthday
09/09/22, 7:20‚ÄØam
Queen Elizabeth II died ‚Äúpeacefully‚Äù at her home at Balmoral Castle yesterday. Human mortality is a poignant moment.
Tolstoy took up the challenge of exploring it in his novella ‚ÄòThe Death Of Ivan Ilyich‚Äù.
It is a lyrical account of a man in the throes of impending death. Tolstoy narrates the fear, the denial, the pain, the pity, and the inevitability of death with much sensitivity. Ivan Ilyich finally looks death in the eye and that direct confrontation destroys the terrible fear which had tormented him all along.
‚ÄúWhere was death? What death? There was no fear, because there was no death.
Instead of death there was light.
‚ÄúSo that‚Äôs it!‚Äù he suddenly said aloud. ‚ÄúSuch joy!‚Äù
‚ÄòThe Death Of Ivan Ilyich‚Äô is one of the most profound meditative works of literature ever written about the end of life.
The story of Ivan Ilyich is deeply relevant for insightful palliative care.
Incidentally today is Tolstoy‚Äôs birthday
11/09/22, 8:45‚ÄØpm
Today is the death anniversary of one of the greatest Tamil poets, Mahakavi Bharathiyar.
The first All India Writers Conference took place in Madras in the 1960s. My mother was a key member of the organizing committee. As a young boy I moved around the venue, taking autographs of all the writers from across the country. Among them was the historian RA Padmanabhan, who was solely responsible for documenting Bharathiyar‚Äôs life and works. He took the autograph book from me and wrote in his beautiful handwriting, ‚ÄúBharathiyai Padi‚Äù, meaning Read Bharathi. I was totally inspired by this and began savouring and discovering the remarkable writings of this great poet, over the years.
Though subject to tremendous inner tribulations, Bharathi sought and perceived harmony in all his life experiences. Nature in all her manifestations was an abiding source of inspiration for him which he narrated in many of his works.
For Bharathi, not only human beings, but even common birds like crows and sparrows were representatives of Cosmic Consciousness. He wrote:
Kakkai Kuruvi engal jaathi - neel
Kadalum malaiyum engal koottam
Nokkum thisaiyellam naam andri vaerillai
Nokka nokka kaliyaattam
(Crows and sparrows are our fellows,
The sea and the hills are our kinsmen.
Wherever I look, I find none but myself,
Mere looking around brings boundless joy)
My quest to fathom the vast creative outpourings of this remarkable poet continues unabated‚Ä¶
12/09/22, 4:45‚ÄØpm
Yesterday I wrote about how Mahakavi Bharathiyar sought to glimpse the cosmic consciousness through a crow in his poems.
Ikkyu was a beloved figure in Japanese Buddhism. On one occasion when he was meditating in a boat, he heard the call of a crow and realized the ever elusive enlightenment.
He was a renegade Zen monk, much ahead of his time. Once he was walking in a town‚Äôs streets in his monk‚Äôs robes, carrying a long red sword. He was an incongruous sight. When asked what he meant by his act, he responded, ‚ÄúThis is a wooden sword; it cannot cut. The priests that run rampant in this world are like my wooden sword here‚Ä¶handsome fakes that are utterly useless‚Äù.
If only we realise that wisdom‚Ä¶
15/09/22, 8:30‚ÄØam
Today is the birthday of the talented Nigerian writer Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
Last year I chanced upon a slender book of hers, ‚ÄòNotes on Grief‚Äú. Her father died suddenly when the COVID-19 pandemic was raging across the world. It is a searing, reflective account by the author as she struggles through the most unsettling of human experiences, grief.
Often we find it difficult to say the right words and express our feelings to offer succour to those in throes of grief. As the author comments evocatively, ‚Äúyou learn how much grief is about language, the failure of language and the grasping for language‚Äù.
Grieving is both a public as well as private act and there have been many poignant personal memoirs about it. These have created spaces where people can share their experiences freely and openly. They are not accounts of ‚Äúthe stages of grief ‚Äú which professionals are accustomed to, but intimate, organic responses to loss. Grief is a kinetic mixture of love and pain. The process of mapping the contours of these experiences can often be therapeutic. It is a passage to another state of ‚Äòbeing‚Äô in the journey of life.
That said, grief doesn‚Äôt disappear‚Ä¶it reverberates deeply within, all through our lives.
As WS Mervin wrote:
Your absence has gone through me
Like thread through a needle.
Everything I do is stitched with its color.

21/09/22, 8:38‚ÄØam
Today is the birthday of Leonard Cohen, one of the most passionate songwriter and musicians.
His was an extraordinarily turbulent life. Depression was his lifelong nemesis. Treatments were of little help. After reading Balsekar‚Äôs book, ‚ÄòConsciousness Speaks‚Äô he came down to Bombay and stayed on for a year, meeting him everyday. At the end of his stay, the depression lifted miraculously and in his own words, ‚ÄúThere is a crack in everything. That‚Äôs how the light gets in‚Äù
Though I like many of his songs (who can forget Suzanne!‚Äù, ‚ÄòBird On The Wire‚Äô has a particular appeal for me. It was written during his early years, while he was staying on the Greek island of Hydra. During this period, he fell in love with Marianne Ihlen and theirs was a tempestuous relationship. It was not easy living and the town had no electricity amongst other problems. When the government finally installed the necessary infrastructure, the wires stretched across Leonard Cohen‚Äôs windows. As Marianne Ihlen recounted, ‚ÄúWhile we‚Äôre sitting there, birds were landing on the wire like notes on a music sheet.‚Äù She brought Cohen his guitar and he began to compose the song that became one of his greatest successes.
After they‚Äôd been together for eight years, the relationship came apart, bit by bit, ‚Äúlike falling ashes,‚Äù as Cohen put it. Later in her life Marianne was diagnosed to have cancer.
Hearing about it, Leonard Cohen wrote a poignant letter:
‚ÄúWell Marianne, it‚Äôs come to this time when we are really so old and our bodies are falling apart and I think I will follow you very soon. Know that I am so close behind you that if you stretch out your hand, I think you can reach mine. And you know that I‚Äôve always loved you for your beauty and your wisdom, but I don‚Äôt need to say anything more about that because you know all about that. But now, I just want to wish you a very good journey. Goodbye old friend. Endless love, see you down the road‚Äù.
In her last hour her friend held Marianne‚Äôs hand and hummed ‚ÄúBird on the Wire,‚Äù as her life slowly ebbed away‚Ä¶
21/09/22, 10:26‚ÄØpm
Very moving Sir
And good to note that he found solace in our interpretation of consciousness. As usual very apt photograph and will listen to the song.
25/09/22, 8:12‚ÄØam
Colour is all around us and plays a crucial role in paintings. In figurative art where the subject matter is recognizable from the real world, they are employed to complement and enhance their representation. What if there‚Äôs no element of figures in a painting?
Decades ago when I was strolling through the National Gallery of Art in London, I walked into a room where there was a large painting of rectangles in brilliant hues, alternatingly radiant. A woman was sitting, totally engrossed in the painting with tears rolling from her eyes. I gingerly stepped out of the room without disturbing her.
Several days later, I went again to the museum and sat in front of the painting. The large canvas was suffused with a delicate yet powerful luminosity. Slowly my eyes soaked in the colours which seemed to percolate deeply within. It was an experience beyond words, beyond language. It was akin to a meditative state when the chatter of the mind quietens and there‚Äôs an inexplicable stillness.
In the words of Sogyal Rinpoche, ‚ÄúOur true nature could be compared to the sky, and the confusion of the ordinary mind to clouds. Some days the sky is completely obscured by clouds. When we are down on the ground, looking up, it is very difficult to believe there is anything else there but clouds. Yet we only have to fly in a plane to discover a limitless expanse of clear blue sky. From up there the clouds we assumed were everything seem so small and so far away down below‚Äù
Sharing a painting of Rothko on his birthday‚Ä¶
30/09/22, 7:29‚ÄØam
The poet WS Merwin whose birthday is today, had a spiritual connection with nature, especially in his later years. He went to Hawaii to study with the Zen master Robert Aitken and remained there, purchasing land on a place aptly called Haiku. He painstakingly restored depleted flora, including hundreds of species of palms, creating in the process one of the largest collections of palms in the world.
And the foliage started to bloom in his poems‚Ä¶
In the poem ‚ÄòPlace‚Äô he wrote:
On the last day of the world
I would want to plant a tree
what for
not the fruit
the tree that bears the fruit
is not the one that was planted
I want the tree that stands
in the earth for the first time
with the sun already
going down
and the water
touching its roots
in the earth full of the dead
and the clouds passing
one by one
over its leaves
When I was watching the migratory Bar Headed Geese which fly across several thousand miles to reach the lake Hadinaru Kere near Mysore, I was reminded of his poem, ‚ÄòMigration‚Äô:
Prayers of many summers come
to roost on a moment
until it sinks under them
and they resume their journey
flying by night
with the sound
of blood rushing in an ear
30/09/22, 1:43‚ÄØpm
The more we are closer to nature the more we grow spiritually. When I was reading Ramayana, the description of the Great Ganges, Yamuna, Chitrakoota mountain and the description of nature gave the virtual treat. The contribution of people like the poet you have mentioned goes a long way to protect our earth Sir. And the poem!
05/10/22, 8:13‚ÄØam
The salient myth associated with Vijayadasami is that of the Goddess vanquishing the demon Mahishasura. It is interesting to note that Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva combined their powers to trounce the demon who had been granted his wish that he would not be annihilated by a male of any species. However he never thought that a woman would be capable of defeating him. But this underestimation of the power of women turned out to be his downfall.
This myth is a pointer to the inherent, underestimated and unacknowledged energy of the feminine spirit. Moreover it draws attention to the fact that the ‚Äòevil‚Äô often resides within us and it is imperative to address and annihilate it.
This sculpture is from the temple at Gangaikondacholapuram. In contrast to many fierce depictions of the Goddess, one can perceive the tranquil expression on her face after she subjugates and decimates the demon.
07/10/22, 7:56‚ÄØam
Considered as the ‚Äògreat voice of Victorian England,‚Äô Tennyson had a troubled legacy. He was subjected to trenchant denunciations by literary critics during his lifetime. It impacted his mental health and ailing from depression, he lamented:
‚ÄúWhen in my youth the growls!
In mine age the owls!
After death the ghouls!‚Äù
But his works had considerable public appeal. When he died on October 6th 1892, scores of people applied for tickets to his funeral in Westminster Abbey.
Tennyson built upon the foundations of Romantic poets and shared their reverence for nature. He commented ,‚ÄúWords, like nature, half reveal and half conceal the soul within.‚Äù
Artists often use Tennyson‚Äôs poetry to inspire their works. I found my muse in a corner of a garden which aptly embodies these words of his‚Ä¶
‚ÄúFlower in the crannied wall,
I pluck you out of the crannies,
I hold you here, root and all, in my hand,
Little flower‚Äîbut if I could understand
What you are, root and all, all in all,
I should know what God and man is.‚Äù
09/10/22, 7:04‚ÄØam
There is something magical about being in nature. You cannot put it in words, but you feel it deep within‚Ä¶it touches your spirit. Just a few minutes of being in nature can make us feel healed and restored. When we walk amidst the trees and reconnect with nature, an indescribable stillness will inescapably pervade within.
John Muir observed this perceptively, ‚ÄúNature‚Äôs peace will flow into you as sunshine flows into trees. The winds will blow their own freshness into you, and the storms their energy, while cares will drop away from you like the leaves of Autumn.‚Äù
As we usher in another World Mental Health Day, let us strive to discover the healing power of nature‚Ä¶
In Rache Carlson‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúThose who dwell among the beauties and mysteries of the earth are never alone or weary of life.‚Äù
12/10/22, 10:24‚ÄØam
Sometimes in the morning I sit on the deck, looking at this Buddha, listening to the sonorous rendering of Mahaparinibbana Sutta which describes the last days of Buddha. Though the recitation is in Pali, an all pervading sense of peace transcends the lyrics.
In his teachings Buddha emphasised the concept of NibbƒÅna, a Pali word for the extinguishing of a fire. A burning fire clings onto its fuel. When it extinguishes, it lets go of it, merging into the cosmos, reaching a state of unbounded freedom.
Buddha elaborated this analogy further in his Addittapariyaya Sutta, commonly known as the Fire Sermon, when he addressed his disciples:
‚ÄúAnd what is all that is burning? Bhikkhus, the eye is burning, visible forms are burning, visual consciousness is burning, visual impression is burning, also whatever sensation, pleasant or painful or neither-painful, nor pleasant, arises on account of the visual impression, that too is burning. Burning with what? Burning with the fire of craving, with the fire of hate, with the fire of delusion; I say it is burning with birth, ageing and death, with sorrows, with lamentations, with pains, with griefs, with despairs.‚Äù
Though the imagery is stark, Buddha draws attention to how suffering is caused by these sensory inputs which fill our minds and hearts with simmering fires of desire and hatred. The quest in life is to quell these fires and find peace within.
13/10/22, 7:47‚ÄØam
My tryst with Buddhist thought and teaching continues‚Ä¶
Over the years, I have been drawn to the teachings of Thich Nhat Hanh.
Caught in the throes of the Vietnam war, he was in a dilemma. Should he confine himself to the monastery and practice meditation or go out and help people? He decided to venture outside and assist people in distress and also be mindful in doing so. This transition from introspection to action laid the foundation for the practice of ‚ÄòEngaged Buddhism‚Äô.
He outlined fourteen precepts of Engaged Buddhism. Two of them in particular have made a deep impression on me. To begin with, truth has to be found in life and not through conceptual knowledge. It is important to engage and learn throughout life by observing within and becoming aware of oneself. The other one is to be cognizant of the existence of suffering in the world and explore ways of attending and redressing it. He articulated his thoughts about the reality of suffering perceptively in his book, No Mud No Lotus, ‚Äú‚ÄúIf you know how to make good use of the mud, you can grow beautiful lotuses.‚Äù
Thich Nhat Hanh also drew attention to how mindfulness can increase our awareness about Mother Earth. ‚ÄúPeople usually consider walking on water or in thin air a miracle. But I think the real miracle is not to walk either on water or in thin air, but to walk on earth. Every day we are engaged in a miracle which we don't even recognize: a blue sky, white clouds, green leaves, the black, curious eyes of a child‚Äîour own two eyes. All is a miracle.‚Äù
These words resonate within whenever I take a stroll and observe the beauty and mystery around me.
Thich Nhat Hanh (whose birthday was on 11th October), opened a vivid personal window of awareness for me‚Ä¶
18/10/22, 7:49‚ÄØam
There are many schools of thought and myriad interpretations concerning Zen.
I first read the book, ‚ÄòIntroduction to Zen Buddhism‚Äô by DT Suzuki (whose birthday is today), decades ago. This edition had a wonderful foreward by CG Jung.
Zen differs from all other philosophical and religious meditative practices in staying clear of conjectures and presuppositions. Even focusing attention on Buddha has to be avoided as he too is an image. On the other hand, the emphasis is on the immediacy of experience that is beyond words, spontaneous and not premeditated.
As Suzuki commented, ‚ÄúNo amount of wordy explanations will ever lead us into the nature of our own selves. The more you explain, the further it runs away from you. It is like trying to get hold of your own shadow. You run after it and it runs with you at the identical rate of speed.‚Äù
Often such illuminating experiences emerge from nature itself‚Ä¶
25/10/22, 9:19‚ÄØam
Narakasura who figures prominently in the Deepavali legend has many stories associated with him. He was deemed to have been born from the union of Bhudevi and Varaha. This is a beautiful relief sculpture of Varaha and Bhudevi in the second cave at Badami.
According to the narratives from the North east of India, he was a king who ruled over Pragjyotishapura, which is modern day Assam. He was besotted with the beauty of Devi Kamakhya and wanted to marry her. The Goddess playfully put a condition on him that if he was able to build a staircase from the bottom of Nilachal hills to the temple within one night before the cock crowed to indicate dawn, then she would marry him. Narakasura accepted the condition and worked with all his might and was about to accomplish the task before dawn. When Kamakhya Devi got this news she made a cock to crow to convey the impression that it was already dawn. Angered by this, Narakasura chased the rooster, slew it and then entered into a battle with the Devi. During the course of the battle, Kamakhya Devi revealed herself as Maa Kali. Realising his mistake, Narakasura fell at her feet and requested that he be remembered as a devotee and not as a demon after his death. Maa Kamakhya granted the same and killed Narakasura with her trident on the Chaturdasi day. The incomplete staircase is known as the Mekhela Ujua Path and is used by devotees even today, to walk to the Kamakhya temple.
When I was reading about this, I was reminded of Led Zeppelin‚Äôs ‚ÄòStairway To Heaven‚Äô.
And as we wind on down the road
Our shadows taller than our soul
There walks a lady we all know
Who shines white light and wants to show
How everything still turns to gold
And if you listen very hard
The tune will come to you at last
When all are one and one is all, yeah‚Ä¶
27/10/22, 7:50‚ÄØam
During my Commonwealth fellowship (decades ago!)I used to explore various parts of the United Kingdom almost every weekend, thanks to the student's pass in the British Rail. The beautiful, untamed Welsh landscape had a special allure for me. During one such visit, I requested my student who was working in Carmarthen to take me to Dylan Thomas‚Äô writing shed. We made our way along Dylan's Walk to a simple, small structure perched on the edge of a cliff. When I peered through the window, I could see some cigarette butts, empty beer bottles and paper strewn on the floor in that sparsely furnished room. The setting sun cast its light through the window, which offered a lovely glimpse of the estuary. I could imagine Dylan sitting there, looking at the landscape which he loved dearly,writing his poems. It was the place where he completed his ‚ÄòUnder Milk Wood‚Äô.
Dylan died young at the age of 39 after a heavy drinking bout complicated by pneumonia. His life and works have had a lasting impact on many. Bob Dylan changed his last name from Zimmerman in homage to the poet. One can spot Dylan Thomas (just above Marlon Brando) on the iconic cover of the Beatles‚Äô album Sgt. Pepper‚Äôs Lonely Hearts Club Band.
Poetry opens our inner world and that is particularly true about Dylan‚Äôs powerfully articulated poem, ‚ÄòDo Not Go Gentle Into That Night‚Äô written on the background of his father‚Äôs ailment. It set off cascades of inner conversations within me when I was tending to the elderly in our family during their final days. I was caught in a conundrum: as a physician should I facilitate ‚Äòrage, rage against the dying of light‚Äô or quietly observe a life gently ebbing away. This is a predicament for everyone involved in end of life care.
On his birthday today I also wonder whether these lines have a larger canvas and ambit of impact. In the throes of unrelenting climate change, we realise that the earth we live in has a fragile existence and an uncertain future. Dylan was perhaps encouraging us to rage, rage against that dying light.
Of course there's a lot more to rage about, these days‚Ä¶

Read on and post your thoughts here: https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/throught-the-lens-of-a-poet-keats-psychotherapy
11/11/22, 7:40‚ÄØam
Along with His Holiness the Dalai Lama, Thich Nhat Hanh has had a deep impact on me, personally as well as in my therapeutic work. I was also drawn to his teaching wherein he emphasized the interconnectedness of the Buddhist way of being and love of nature. According to him, even a simple act of walking mindfully can be a meditative practice. In his words:
Look again, you will see me in you and in every leaf and flower bud.
Walk and touch peace every moment.
Walk and touch happiness every moment.
Each step brings a fresh breeze.
Each step makes a flower bloom.
Kiss the Earth with your feet.
Bring the Earth your love and happiness.
The Earth will be safe
when we feel safe in ourselves.
(11th November was Thich Nhah Hanh‚Äôs birthday)

29/11/22, 7:25‚ÄØam
Both Ahalya and myself are Beatles aficionados. We have a good collection of their music (as LPs!) and listen to them often.
George Harrison was the most spiritual of all the Beatles. His tryst with Eastern music and religion was kindled by Ravi Shankar. The first time he used a sitar riff was in ‚ÄòNorwegian Wood‚Äô. He read extensively. In his own words, "I had read enough from the Vivekenandas and Yoganandas, to comprehend how to see God: by using the Yogic system of transcending through the relative states of consciousness to get to the most subtle level of pure consciousness. It is at that level that the individual experiences pure awareness, pure consciousness, the source of all being‚Ä¶‚Äù
His engagement and involvement in spiritual pursuits finds reflection in many of his songs. I particularly like ‚ÄòThe Inner Light‚Äô. The lyrics are inspired by a section of the Tao Te Ching, written by Lao Tsu, a contemporary of Confucius. There are 81 short chapters of Tao Te Ching. "Inner Light" is the title of Chapter 47, which in translation reads as:
Without going outside, you may know the whole world
Without looking through the window, you may see the ways of heaven
The farther you go, the less you know
Thus the sage knows without travelling
He sees without looking
He works without doing
Harrison's tweaked theses lines a bit, yet essentially conveying its inherent meaning:
Without going outside of your door
You can know all things on earth
Without looking out of your window
You could know the ways of heaven
The farther one travels
The less one knows
The less one really knows
Arrive without travelling
See all without looking
Do all without doing
When George died on 29th November 2001, Ravi Shankar was by his side as verses from the Bhagavad Gita were chanted. His ashes were later immersed in the Ganges as per his wish.

14/02/22, 8:23‚ÄØam
As John Paul Young sang, ‚ÄúLove is in the air, everywhere I look around, Love is in the air, every sight and every sound.‚Äù It is also the time when love turns into serious business in the guise of Valentine‚Äôs Day. But what is the real story behind Valentine?
While Valentine‚Äôs Day might be associated with romantic love, the real story behind its namesake, Valentine, is full of bloodshed and heart break. He was reported to have had healing powers, especially for those ailing from epilepsy. According to one legend, Valentine signed a letter ‚Äúfrom your Valentine‚Äù to his jailer‚Äôs daughter, whom he had befriended and healed her from blindness. Another legend states that he defied the emperor‚Äôs orders and secretly married couples to spare the husbands from war. Unhappy with his actions, Emperor Claudius ordered that he be put to death and he was beheaded. Neither written nor material evidence from the pre-medieval period associates Valentine with love or lovers. Scholars credit Geoffrey Chaucer for turning Valentine into the patron of love. In his Parlement of Foules he wrote, ‚Äúseynt Volantynys day/ Whan euery bryd comyth there to chese his make. (Saint Valentine‚Äôs day, when every bird comes there to choose his mate.) Chaucer was a major influencer in his day ‚Äì after him, everyone began calling their beloved ‚ÄúValentine‚Äù and writing love poems on 14 February.
Closer home there is a more suitable mythological character, Kamadeva. He has many names: he is called ‚ÄúRagavrunt‚Äù, ‚ÄúAnanga‚Äù, ‚ÄúKandarp‚Äù, ‚ÄúManmath‚Äù, ‚ÄúMansija‚Äù, ‚ÄúMadana‚Äù, ‚ÄúRatikant‚Äù, ‚ÄúPushpvan‚Äù and ‚ÄúPushpdhanv‚Äù. Kama has a variety of meanings, ranging from sensuality to aesthetic enjoyment, although its overtones are predominantly sexual in the popular imagination. It is also a misconception that kama means love, kama literally means trishNa(Sanskrit), desire or thirst.
There are striking parallels between the depiction of Kamadeva and Cupid. Both carry a bow and a quiver of arrows. Kamadeva‚Äôs bow is made of sugarcane and is sugar coated with the bowstring soaked in honey. Arrows are decorated with flowers and the flowers on his arrows are: Aravinda(White Lotus), Ashoka, Cuta (Mango Flower), Navamalika (Jasmine), and Nilotpala (Blue Lotus). Kamadeva carries five kind of arrows with him: Maran, Stambhan, Jrumbhan, Shoshan and Ummadan. Kamadeva‚Äôs five arrows are associated with five effects. The first arrow is aimed at the heart and it causes initial excitement and a youthful cheerfulness. The second arrow is aimed at the lips and it causes one to cry out of this excitement. The third arrow is aimed at the head/brain and it makes one lose their mind / go crazy with love. The fourth arrow is aimed at the eyes which makes one see things. The fifth arrow is basically designed to hit anywhere causing the person to totally be absorbed with love.
There are no temples solely dedicated to Kamadeva in India. However, in Assam there is a shrine for him called Madana-Kamadeva temple. Situated in a dense forest, this temple has some marvellous sculptures but unfortunately the structure is quite dilapidated.
This particular sculpture of Kamadeva is from a small temple at Krishnapuram in Tirunelveli district. It is an astounding sculpture crafted out of a single stone and is exquisitely carved. He is holding the bow made of sugarcane, which is so well hewn that if one drops a pin into the hole on top of the bow, it comes out at the bottom! Unfortunately, in the process of testing this out, people have broken part of the bow, the bane of many a sculpture in India. The sculpture now is encircled within a steel enclosure to prevent further damage to it.
There is a mantra dedicated to Kamadeva which reads:
Aum Kamadevaye Vidmahe
Pushpa banaye dhimahi
Tanno Ananga Prachodayat
Oh let me meditate to the God of Love
He who carries an arrow made of flowers
May that Ananga (who is without a body) bestow upon me higher intellect and illuminate my mind.
Purusartha is a key concept in Hinduism and refers to the four important goals of human life. They are Dharma (righteousness, moral values); Artha (prosperity, economic values); Kama (pleasure, love) and Moksha (liberation, spiritual values). The path to enlightenment or Moksha is facilitated by the harmonious interaction of Dharma, Artha, and Kama.
Ultimately, the highest Kama is the longing for Oneness with the Divine.
14/02/22, 6:18‚ÄØpm

Our culture has more angles to the concept of love and it is one of the goals, in the limits of Dharma. Thank you Sir for throwing light on the details and the sculpture which is so bright and glowing!

16/02/22, 4:04‚ÄØpm
Siva is worshipped in various anthropomorphic forms. His facial depiction usually encompasses five different representations: Satyojatam, Vamadevam, Tatpurusham, Esanam and Agoram. The last one in turn has five forms, one of which is Gajasamharamurti. He is also worshipped as Ayurdevata, which is mentioned in Ayush suktam of Rig Veda which also mentions Him by the Sanskrit name Krithivasa.
According to legend, once 30,000 sages, who were meditating at Tarukavanam, challenged the omnipotence of Lord Siva. They created many wild creatures through sacrificial fire to kill Siva, but in vain. Finally, they sent an elephant demon (Gajasura). But Siva, dwarfing Himself entered the elephant‚Äôs body and then assumed his original form only to slay the demon and emerged wearing its skin. Sages who saw this divine event shed their pride and arrogance and took refuge in Siva. Symbolically the mad elephant represents, anger, ignorance and pride. When we take refuge in Siva, he slays all these demons within us.
There is also a reference to Gajasamharamurti in Kalidasa‚Äôs ‚ÄòKumarasambhavam.‚Äô According to it was demon Nila who came in the form of an elephant to kill Siva. Learning about it, Nandi ordered Veerabadra to slay Nila. Veerabadra killed the demon and presented the skin (charma) to Siva, who wore it while on his way to vanquish Antakasura. Hence he is also referred to as Gajacharmambara.
The only temple dedicated to Gajasamharamurti is at Vazhuvoor in Mayiladuthurai district, Tamil Nadu and it is believed to be the site where Lord Siva killed Gajasura, the elephant demon, and wore his hide around him.
There are many sculptural depictions of Gajasamharamurti. The most attractive one is at the Hoysaleswara temple at Halebid. He is depicted in a dancing posture with his right foot on the demon Gajasura. The lifted left leg is so delicately carved that one can even see the arch of the heel! The two hands on the top are positioned high, holding the elephant‚Äôs skin which is surrounding the God like a Prabavalli. He is holding trishul, damaru, kapala and Khadaga amongst others. He is wearing a tall crown with several small skulls inscribed on it. Several rings can be seen on his fingers. A highly ornate belt called Mekhala is adoring his midriff. As he dances inside the elephant his jewellery is swinging too! Nandi is on his right hand side, looking out. On the left are various Ganas playing the drums. One of them is even adjusting the ropes of the drum to tune it! To his right is Nandi and to the left two ganas playing mrudanga can be seen in the lower part of the carvings. The entire sculpture is suffused with elegance conveying a delicate sense of balance.
Today is Masi magam and among the many legends associated with it, is that of Gajasamharam, reminding us to destroy our ego and surrender ourselves at the feet of the divine.
16/02/22, 4:40‚ÄØpm
I will read again in detail Sir.

No words to express the deftness of the sculpture.

01/03/22, 8:58‚ÄØam
According to one of the legends, Mahashivaratri is the day Lord Shiva got married to Parvati.
Goddess Sati took birth as Parvati, the daughter of Himavan to marry Lord Shiva. She practised intense penance to win over Lord Shiva's heart. After years of Tapasya at the Gauri Kund, Parvati finally succeeded in convincing Lord Shiva to accept her as his wife. Shiva reportedly proposed to Parvati at Guptakashi and then tied the nuptial knot at Triyuginarayan. The celestial marriage of Lord Shiva and Parvati took place in the presence of Lord Brahma, who turned a priest to conduct the ceremony and Lord Vishnu, who performed the duties of the bride's brother. The Agni that was witness to the wedding ceremony still exists in the form of an eternal flame, Akhand Dhuni, near the temple.
This 17th century mural at Veerabadra temple at Lepakshi depicts the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. Shiva is shown wearing the characteristic tiger skin, carrying the deer and axe in the upper hands. Parvati, escorted by attendants stands in front of Shiva, her head slightly bent. She is seen carrying a lotus in her left hand while offering the right hand to Shiva. Do not fail to notice a diminutive Nandi jumping joyfully between the couple! To the left of Paravati is her father Himavan who is carrying a kamandala in his raised hand and is about to solemnize the wedding by pouring water on the hands of the couple. Brahma is seen sitting in front of the sacred fire performing various rituals.
When I first visited the temple, the murals covered with years of dirt and soot were hardly visible in the dark interiors of the place. Thankfully a careful restoration has brought them alive now, even though some details have been lost. Unquestionably they are the finest examples of mural paintings of the Vijayanagar period.
04/03/22, 6:51‚ÄØpm

15/03/22, 7:42‚ÄØpm

17/03/22, 4:50‚ÄØpm
Happy holi Sir!
18/03/22, 11:58‚ÄØam
Colours play an important role in the festival of Holi. They add vitality to the festival, making it one of the most vibrant of celebrations. Each of the colours is deemed to have a symbolic significance. Blue for instance is the colour of Krishna's complexion and also of the sky and the oceans.
And colours are the smiles of nature.
Birds are beautiful jewels in the sky. There are many brightly coloured birds in the world, and the most flamboyant ones are the parrots. During our birding sojourn in Australia, Ahalya and myself saw some of the most multihued parrots, prominent among them being the Rainbow Lorikeet.
Rainbow Lorikeet, definitely deserves its name! True to its name, one can see all the colour palettes of rainbow in its feathers. Its head is deep blue with a greenish-yellow nuchal collar, and the rest of the upper parts (wings, back, and tail) are green. The chest is orange/yellow in colour. The belly is deep blue, and the thighs and rump are green. Their species name, haematodus, comes from the Latin word for blood, and is a reference to the rich red found on its breast.
The colour of the feathers of birds serves various functions; thermoregulation, climatic adaptation and a fine balance between sexual signalling and camouflage. Birds need to balance being attractive to potential mates while having some kind of camouflage against potential predators. When hunted from above, the Rainbow Lorikeet blends with the foliage of the trees with its green back. It has been suggested that the colourful patches confer evolutionary advantage in courtship and mate recognition.
Rainbow lorikeets have two unique features. They possess a tongue with brush-type tissues helping them to collect nectar and pollen. The other distinctive feature is their agile legs which help them to hang upside-down and feed on bottlebrush flowers. It is a dazzling sight when flocks of them fly with the rays of the sun streaming through their gorgeous plumage!
On the occasion of Holi, in the words of Maya Angelou, let us ‚ÄúTry to be a rainbow in someone‚Äôs cloud.‚Äù
18/03/22, 1:17‚ÄØpm
Oh. Beautiful Sir. Real feast for the eyes and mind. Thanks for letting us know about this parrot. God's creation is unimaginable. Our duty is to turn our eyes and tune our mind to it. And what a saying üëç

02/04/22, 10:09‚ÄØam

07/04/22, 11:02‚ÄØam
Each of the lecture theatres in JIPMER were named after a historical medical luminary and their portrait used to be displayed outside. Every time I entered theatre Bernard I used to be fascinated by a painting which depicted him in a deeply reflective mood. Claude Bernard was an exceptional man. He posited that there is a delicate balance between physiological processes within the human body and the environment outside of it. He termed them as ‚Äòmilieu interior‚Äô and ‚Äòmilieu exterior‚Äô. He drew attention to how physiological mechanisms are crucial in maintaining constancy of the internal environment to sustain a status of health in response to changes in the external environment.
Understandably over the years medical professionals have focused their attention on the internal environment to preserve individual health. Unfortunately, in the process, the crucial role of the environment in which we are immersed everyday in our lives and its vital role in modulating individual health has been lost sight of.
On the occasion of the World Health today and on the background of looming climate changes, it is imperative to remind ourselves that climate crisis is health crisis. Our health is intricately related to health of the planet and we should strive to make every effort to conserve and protect the Mother Earth.
07/04/22, 7:24‚ÄØpm
Oh. Yes Sir. It is something which all of us should focus on. I think we are already in the downward trend and contributed heavily to the extremes in the climate. Man has become extremely self centered and doesn't know he is destroying himself by showing a callous attitude to our mother earthü§î
09/04/22, 11:36‚ÄØam
Navratri is celebrated in different seasons, five times a year across our country. They are Chaitra Navratri, Ashadha Navratri, the Sharada Navratri, and the Paush/Magha Navratri. Of these, the Sharada Navratri heralds the onset of autumn and the Chaitra Navratri the season of spring. Today is the date of Shukla Paksha Ashtami of Chaitra month, also referred to as Maha Ashtami, dedicated to Goddess Durga.
One of the outstanding depictions of Goddess Durga slaying the demon Mahishasura is at the 13th century Hoysala temple at Somanathapura. The Devi is seen triumphantly standing on top of the he buffalo that appears to have fallen on the ground. Mahishasura is seen emerging from the body of the buffalo. If you look carefully, you can notice Mahisha‚Äôs intestines coming out of his stomach! Standing to the left of the Goddess is her vehicle, a partly broken lion, which is seen killing an asura. Even though some of the arms Goddess Durga are missing or broken, the vigour and vitality in depiction is a tribute to the sculptor Mallithamma, who sculptures adorn many Hoysala temples.

Indian Coral Tree is among the earliest flowering trees in spring and is extremely colourful and picturesque. It adds colour to the skyline with its conspicuous vibrant red coloured flowers. When in bloom the coral tree is like an aviary, attracting numerous bird species like this Golden Fronted Leaf Bird here.
Referred to as a Mandara tree it is one of the five heavenly trees, Panchavriksha in Indira‚Äôs garden in Swarga. After Krishna had brought the Parijata Tree from heaven for Satyabhama, Rukminin insisted that he should bring the Mandara tree for her!

24/05/22, 8:37‚ÄØam
The day began with this beautiful song, Dwaitamu Sukhama, Advaitamu Sukhama, wherein Saint Thyagaraja expresses the dilemma faced by many seekers.
Dwaita and advaita offer two very different answers for the fundamental question of all philosophy: what is the nature of the world and that of the internal self? Dwaita claims that there are fundamentally two entities, jIvAtma and paramAtma, with the internal self being jIvAtma and the external world being a multi-faceted manifestation of paramAtma. Advaita posits that there is but only the paramAtma and the internal self is also a manifestation of the paramAtma.
They are often positioned as two different, dissimilar paths.
An elegant, insightful perspective is provided in a verse from Ashtavakra Gita.
kva dharmahÃ£ kva ca vƒÅ kƒÅmahÃ£ kva cƒÅrthahÃ£ kva vivƒìkatƒÅ |
kva dvaitamÃ£ kva ca vƒÅ(a)dvaitamÃ£ svamahimni sthitasya mƒì || 19-2 ||
For me, established in my own glory, there is no religion,
sensuality, possessions, philosophy, duality or even non-duality.

25/05/22, 8:31‚ÄØam
On this World Otter Day, I recollect my first sighting of the smooth coated otters in the backwaters of Chimmony. It was a glorious evening with the setting sun framing the backwaters with brilliant hues and as we were cruising along in a boat, suddenly I noticed a group of otters, just in front of us. They were barking like dogs at us with khar kharr sounds. Neer-nai as they are often referred to as, might appear drab brown at a casual glance. But these sleek little water-wanderers were graceful as they ambled along the crevices of the rocks. Some were coming out of the water with their snouts just visible, making waves of whirls in the calm water. A group of them swiftly emerged out of the crevices and were staring at us, upright! We spent a few minutes watching them before they quietly slinked away.
These Smooth Coated Otters are closely related to the Giant Otters of South America and are Asia‚Äôs largest otters. They are highly social and are often seen in packs. They mostly feed on fish (more than 90% of their diet is fish) and that makes them quite unpopular among fishermen. However, trained smooth-coated otters are often used by fisherman to herd fish into nets. Unfortunately, their population is threatened by loss of wetland habitats, poaching, and contamination of waterways by pesticides.
Otters
Glide amidst the rocks
Straight into my heart‚Ä¶

‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Øà ‡Æö‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øá ‡Æ®‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Ææ
‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ∞‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ±‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Øã‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Øá ‡Æ®‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Ææ
In the black colours of the crow
I have a glimpse you Nanda (Krishna)
These are the opening lines of ‚ÄúKaakai Siraginile,‚Äù one of the most beautiful poems of Mahakavi Bharathiyar. It is a simple octet with references to a crow‚Äôs feather and a tryst with fire in the quest of Nandalala, the young Krishna. As with most poems, a direct translation doesn‚Äôt do justice to the nuances of the song itself.
Why did the poet choose the crow?
Crows are generally considered scavengers and generally not portrayed in good light. As someone known for raising his voice against social injustice, was Bharathiyar implying that even in such creatures, he sees the divine nature of Krishna. Was he also indicating that people can see Him everywhere in nature?
The poem embodies the eternal truth that the seeker can perceive the presence of the formless in all its forms.

18/06/22, 8:29‚ÄØam
Paul McCartney who is turning 80 today is a favourite singer of mine.
Shortly after returning from India where he was learning the art of Transcendental Meditation, he wrote "Blackbird" which was featured in the ‚ÄòWhite Album.‚Äô I keep listening to this tranquil guitar ballad often. This song was written solely by Paul McCartney. However, he acknowledged the role of John Lennon and hence the song goes under the name Lennon-McCartney.
Paul wrote this song on the background of the civil rights movement in US. The black bird in the song refers to a group of black students who faced racial discrimination in Little Rock Central High School Arkansas. As he said later, ‚ÄúThis was really a song from me to a black woman, experiencing these problems in the States. Let me encourage you to keep trying, to keep your faith; there is hope.‚Äô‚Äù
It is a song of empowerment, reflecting the singer‚Äôs longing for change.
No matter how dark our circumstances may be, there is always a glimmer of hope to be found..
Blackbird fly, blackbird fly
Into the light of a dark black night

04/07/22, 8:21‚ÄØam
As humans we have the privilege to express ourselves through our speech. On many occasions we find that a simple gesture of the hand can express our thoughts equally well and perhaps much better.
Specific hand gestures that symbolize and convey various meanings are referred to as Mudras. Mudra Vidhanam, written by Anna and published by Ramakrishna Mutt lists at least 137 mudras. When a sculptor creates a deity, he adds various mudras to express the idea symbolized by it.
For instance look at these images. First one is from Gangaikondacholapuram and the second from the bronze gallery from Chennai museum. You will notice the gesture of the right hand, where the forefinger is joined with the thumb and the other three fingers remain separate. This is often referred to as Chinmudra.
The thumb represents Brahman because without the thumb the hand cannot function. The middle, ring and the small finger represents the body, mind and intellect respectively. Index finger represents the ego because it keeps pointing at others most of the times! When we hold our hand normally the index finger is attached to the other three fingers and is far away from the thumb. This indicates that we normally think of ourselves as the body, mind and intellect, separate from the Brahman. As long as we have this notion, we will have a beginning and an end. When the index finer (ego) separates itself from the body/mind/ intellect and unites with the thumb (representing the Brahman), it forms a circle, which has no beginning and end. It symbolizes the union of the jivatma with the Paramatma, which is the essence of all realisation.
Some symbols convey the deeper meanings with sublime simplicity‚Ä¶

13/07/22, 9:39‚ÄØam
A true Guru would never tell the seeker or the student what to do.
On the contrary, he/she would give them the knowledge with which they could decide what would be best path for them to venture. When he/she points a finger towards the path of discovery the students attention is often fixed on the finger and not the path.
Thich Nhat puts this succinctly "just as a finger pointing at the moon is not the moon itself. A thinking person makes use of the finger to see the moon. A person who only looks at the finger and mistakes it for the moon will never see the real moon."
I hail from a family of teachers and have been blessed with Gurus who inspired and guided me ‚Äòto see the moon‚Äô in my professional journey. This quest remains unabated as I continue to learn from my multitudinous talented students.
The letter ‚Äògu‚Äô refers to darkness, the letter ‚Äòru‚Äô means he who dispels such darkness, ‚ÄòGuru‚Äô is called so because of his ability to dispel darkness of ignorance.
In Indian spiritual traditions, Dakshinamurthy is perceived as the First Guru, Adi Guru.
Iconographically, he is depicted in various forms and this beautiful carving is from Amirthagadeswarar temple at Melakadambur which was built by the Chola King Kulothunga-I in 1113 AD

Hunter Thompson whose birthday is today was a hugely talented maverick.
He developed a style of journalism which is often referred to as gonzo journalism. It is a type of journalism where the writer becomes part of the story, portraying events through their own experience. His ‚ÄòFear and Loathing in Las Vegas: A Savage Journey to the Heart of the American Dream‚Äô is a compelling read.
He led a troubled life, often experiencing periods of low mood, articulating it in these poignant words‚Ä¶
