25/07/22, 9:09‚ÄØam
The landscape of Corbett is quite magical. One can spend hours amidst the vast grasslands, gently undulating hills, marshy depressions and riverine belts. It is the oldest national park in the country and is named after Jim Corbett whose birthday is today.
Corbett was a hunter with a heart. He tracked and killed 19 tigers and 14 leopards which were responsible for slaying around 1,200 people, without suffering even a scratch! He would mostly work alone, venturing into the jungles with his faithful dog Robin by his side. He also wrote six books which offer fascinating accounts of his trysts with the wildlife. His ‚ÄòMan eating leopard of Rudraprayag‚Äô is exciting narrative of a leopard that spread terror killing more than hundred people. Apart from being an account of the relentless pursuit of animal for more than a year, it also offers rich insights into lives in the Garhwal region. It is an ode to the people who inhabit the terrain and the resilience with which they face the hardships that assail them. On the highway to the town, there is a tree by the side of the road where one can find a notice which reads: ‚ÄúThis was the tree on which Jim Corbett sat and shot dead the Man Eating Leopard of Rudraprayag in 1926.‚Äù
Corbett died on April 19, 1955, days after finishing his sixth book, Tree Tops. A year later, the state of Uttarakhand renamed the national park he helped found as Jim Corbett National Park. In addition to the national park that bears his name, there‚Äôs a species of endangered Indochinese tiger, Panthera tigris corbetti, that bears his name.
In spite of his prowess as a hunter, Corbett was a naturalist at heart and voiced the need for wildlife conservation in India long before it became a popular refrain.
A child of the Kumaon region, its forests inspired his lifelong effort to protect animals and people alike.
In his own words, ‚ÄúThe book of nature has no beginning, as it has no end. Open this book where you will, and at any period of your life, and if you have the desire to acquire knowledge you will find it of intense interest, and no matter how long or how intently you study the pages, your interest will not flag, for in nature there is no finality.‚Äù
25/07/22, 8:51‚ÄØpm
So nice to read through but with a heavy heart as I feel we have come so far away from nature. Man is encroaching the natural habitat and believes he can thrive without wildlife and forests. In for trouble üòí Thanks Sir for the info.
27/07/22, 10:13‚ÄØpm
Such life like sculptures, what magic was there in their fingers! Thanks Sir for taking us into the past, for a change not the negative but something to cherish.
29/07/22, 7:51‚ÄØam
There is always a surprise element in spotting a tiger.
One early morning, we were tumbling along the dust tracks in Corbett. On hearing the alarm calls of the langurs the vehicles in front of us speeded ahead. Our driver avoided the rush and took a side road.
A brown fish owl caught my attention and when I turned my gaze away from it, there it was, sauntering nearby, ignoring our presence. The tiger sat on the ground, with the dappled sunlight on its golden coat. Slowly it lifted its head, growled, got up and bolted into the thicket. I was in a daze. Those few minutes are etched in my memory forever.
Over the years during all our visits in the jungle, invariably we had a glimpse of the Lord of the Jungle.
The last one was at Panna. We were at Sarai at Torria and had the privilege of spending time with our host Raghu Chundawat. Raghu has been documenting and researching the lives of the big cats in Panna for decades. In 2009, the national park made headlines when it lost every single tiger due to poaching. Raghu raised the alarm, compiled a report titled ‚ÄúMissing tigers of Panna‚Äù and sent it to the Ministry of Environment & Forests. He had to pay a heavy price for drawing attention to the sordid state of affairs at Panna. His research permits were cancelled and he was denied entry to the Park, even as a tourist. He was accused of running a ‚Äòhidden agenda‚Äô by the head of Project Tiger and was probed about his possible role in poaching! The intimidation and harassment continued till a Special Investigation Team set up by the National Tiger Conservation Authority confirmed that there are no tigers left in Panna. A scientist who should have recognized for daring to speak up for the tigers of Panna found himself being systematically intimidated and harassed. Unfortunately, this is the bane of tiger conservation efforts in the country which is to a large extent bureaucratized.
Just as the tiger returns to Panna, the reserve itself is up against a new threat: Ken-Betwa river-linking project. If implemented, it will submerge prime forest spread over 4,000 hectares and destroy 11 lakh trees. Moreover, the tiger reserve itself will be bifurcated, leaving even less forest space for the beleaguered tigers.
It was our privilege to receive the autographed copy of Raghu‚Äôs book, ‚ÄòThe Rise and Fall of the Emerald Tigers‚Äô which is based on his decade-long research in Panna National Park. It covers a vast canvas highlighting the importance of investigating and understanding the ecological needs of tigers and also drawing attention to the dark side of conservation practices in the country.
Redolent with these memories, we made our way back from Panna, fervently hoping for a larger vision about conservation of tigers which is sensitive to inspiring efforts by committed individuals and informed by research inputs.
01/08/22, 12:56‚ÄØpm
We have been destroying nature like nobody's business and reaping now. Thanks once again Sir for the write up.
03/08/22, 1:00‚ÄØpm
Yes Sir. We celebrate Thiruvadippooram on that day and Andal Thiruppavai is sung during the month of Marghazi masam. Thanks for sharing the beautiful painting.
04/08/22, 8:41‚ÄØam
Shelley whose birthday is today was not merely a talented poet. He was much ahead of the time in championing the cause of vegan diet for a sound mind and healthy body. He was also the man who first propounded the idea of massive, non-violent protest as the most appropriate and effective response to authoritarian oppression.
In his short life, he wrote some of the most dazzling lyrical poems. I am particularly fond of the poem, ‚ÄúTo a Skylark‚Äù. One day while walking in Italian countryside with his wife Mary, Shelley heard the melodious notes of the skylark. In the poem consisting of 24 stanzas, he describes the grace and beauty of the skylark's birdsong. He addresses the bird directly and praises the purity of its music, which is later contrasted with sad, hollow human communication. It is quintessentially an ode to the unmatched splendours of the natural world. Interestingly, Shelley uses the phrase "harmonious madness" referring to the beauty of the song of the skylark. He asks the bird to teach him ‚Äúhalf the gladness / That thy brain must know,‚Äù for then he would overflow with ‚Äúharmonious madness,‚Äù and his song would be so beautiful that the world would listen to him, even as he is now listening to the skylark.
This photograph is of a graceful Rufous Tailed Lark with a stanza from the poem.
04/08/22, 5:11‚ÄØpm
What a wonderful photograph Sir. The details on the wings are also visible in the sunlight. And the poet. So beautifully the poet is able to communicate what he feels and thinks. No wonder terms it as hollow communication. Great thinker's thought process and communication is so unique but so valuable.

07/08/22, 9:09‚ÄØam
Yesterday I had posted about Tennyson‚Äôs quest to ‚Äòunderstand‚Äô the connection between man, god and the cosmos through plucking a flower in the roadside and exploring its roots.
Can one experience that connectivity merely by ‚Äòlooking‚Äô at a flower?
Basho who is revered as the greatest of Japan‚Äôs haiku poets observes a nazuna flower (sheperd‚Äôs purse) blooming by the wayside on a hedge and writes:
When I look carefully
I see the nazuna blooming
By the hedge!
He is content merely to "look" to sense the deep mystery of the flower. Immersing oneself through contemplative observation of an ordinary flower and pondering over its beauty, one could unravel the mystery of creation. In the process, the distinction between ourselves and nature breaks down. We become one with the universe and a reassuring sense of harmony and connection with the world permeates our consciousness. A state often referred to Eutierria.
British naturalist and environmental writer Michael McCarthy wrote eloquently about such experiences, ‚ÄúThere can be occasions when we suddenly and involuntarily find ourselves loving the natural world with a startling intensity, in a burst of emotion which we may not fully understand, and the only word that seems to me to be appropriate for this feeling is Joy.‚Äù
Let us reclaim and discover our joyous belonging to the natural world . . .
08/08/22, 7:20‚ÄØam

08/08/22, 10:55‚ÄØam
Ardez is a small, quaint village located on the southern slope of the Silvretta alps, in the midst of lush meadows. It is an outstandingly well preserved village with typical Engadine houses. These houses have massive walls with deep set windows and archways. What makes them unique are their playfully decorated facades. These are referred to as Sgraffiti, which is derived from the Italian ‚Äúsgraffiare‚Äù (to scratch). Beautiful patterns, drawings are engraved on the walls and many of them are exquisitely painted too. We spent several hours savouring each nook and corner of this charming village.
And on a corner of an old house was this cat staring straight at us.
Cats have provided the inspiration for an incredible range of fiction, memoir and poetry. TS Elitot for examples, was a ‚Äòcat man‚Äô. He owned many during his life and gave them various funny and outlandish names. He wrote ‚ÄòOld Possum‚Äôs Book of Practical Cats‚Äô which outsold his magnum opus ‚ÄòThe Waste Land‚Äô! This excerpt is from the poem "The Naming of Cats" from the book.
When you notice a cat in profound meditation,
The reason, I tell you, is always the same:
His mind is engaged in a rapt contemplation
(Incidentally today is International Cat Day!)

Thought it was a bulb and carried carefully to open it in the kitchen and to my mother's horror it was a kitten. It was a day old and we named it Deepali. She became one in the family understood tamil very well and the attachment was beyond human. Died after eating poisoned rat dragged herself to my brother's feet whom she adored. 12/08/22, 8:01‚ÄØam
Elephants played a crucial role in military, political and cultural history of India.
On this World Elephant Day, let us recall their role in warfare.
The Mahabharata mentions the use of elephants in battle, though chariots were the preferred vehicle of the elite warriors. Almost every ruler in India had an army of elephants and used them effectively in battles. There are vivid descriptions of their role in the battle field. Arthashastra of Kautilya provides plenty of information on elephants, their training and conduct in wars.
With heavy armour to protect them, elephants were trained to trample the enemy and stab soldiers with their tusks which were armed with special blades, called elephant swords. Sometimes these elephant swords were coated with poison to make them even deadlier. During a charge, elephants would slash to pieces whomever they came in contact with. In some instances, the war elephants had an iron chain with an iron ball at the end attached to their trunk to kill enemy soldiers.
At one sweep elephants could get rid of enemy foot soldiers, scare away horses, and trample chariots. There was also the practice of intoxicating elephants as inebriated elephants could cause much more panic and break enemy formations with ease. The Chalukyas of Vatapi were well known for their use of drunken elephants to wreak destruction on the enemy troops. Only males, especially if they were sixty years old were used in the battle. The armies didn‚Äôt raise war elephants, they hunted them in the wild, tamed and trained them.
Innovative methods were employed to scare the elephants in the battle. It was found out that the elephants were afraid of the high-pitched squealing of the pigs. To make sure that they squealed louder, they were coated with tar, resin, or oil, set on fire and despatched towards the enemy elephants!
With the advent of artillery and muskets on a larger scale, the use of war elephants decreased over time. However, they continued to be used to carry the royalty and commanders into battle.
This mural in Thiruppudaimaruthur portrays war elephants in the 'Tamirabarani battle' which took place in 1532 at Aralvaimozhi Pass, near Thovalai in Kanyakumari district between the King of Travancore, Bhoothala Veera Udaya Marthanda Varma and Emperor of Vijayanagara, Achyutadeva Raya.
12/08/22, 6:42‚ÄØpm

There are times in one‚Äôs life when the desire to know the essence of thing has an irresistible appeal. ‚ÄòZen And The Art Of Motorcycle Maintenance‚Äô fulfilled that need early in my life. It was the personal quest of the author, Pirsig in throes of intense suffering (he had 28 ECTs), to explore that realm through weaving together eastern and western philosophical thoughts in a fascinating manner. The motorcycle is a symbol of a soul in search. Reading the book is a transformational experience.

17/09/22, 8:10‚ÄØam
Today is Ken Kessey‚Äôs birthday. He was a maverick who was adept in donning various hats. He was a wrestler, a set designer, writer and an enthusiastic propagator of psychedelics.
His forays into the interior landscapes of the mind began when he volunteered at a hospital to be a subject of experiments with psychomimetic drugs. There was a dramatic change in his explorations when he took a job as a night attendant in a psychiatric ward of a big hospital. Watching the patients there convinced him that they were locked into a system that was the very opposite of therapeutic, and it provided the raw material for his magnum opus ,''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.''
It is a truly remarkable novel which offered insightful accounts of institutionalisation and its psychological impact. It was later made into a popular movie that won many Oscars. However Kessey was not happy with the production and refused to watch the film.
I am particularly drawn to this passage in the novel:
‚ÄúYou got to understand that as soon as a man goes to help someone, he leaves himself wide open.‚Äù
The encounter between a client and the therapist is not a one way process. Invariably the tumultuous emotional turmoil of the client leaves its footprints on the therapist too. In order not to feel overwhelmed and helpless, the therapist has to acknowledge and be aware of it as the impact might play out in their personal lives and in therapy too. In order to be helpful, the therapist must acquire the capacity to locate himself/herself in two parallel realities: the personal and the professional lives and their demands.
Therein lies the necessity and importance of personal supervision for the therapists‚Ä¶
17/09/22, 10:51‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for the write up about the author. And the importance of maintaining a balance between the client and therapist world. The therapeutic process should be able to enhance and empower the therapist.
17/09/22, 10:51‚ÄØpm
Yes Sir. I will.
21/09/22, 8:38‚ÄØam
Today is the birthday of Leonard Cohen, one of the most passionate songwriter and musicians.
His was an extraordinarily turbulent life. Depression was his lifelong nemesis. Treatments were of little help. After reading Balsekar‚Äôs book, ‚ÄòConsciousness Speaks‚Äô he came down to Bombay and stayed on for a year, meeting him everyday. At the end of his stay, the depression lifted miraculously and in his own words, ‚ÄúThere is a crack in everything. That‚Äôs how the light gets in‚Äù
Though I like many of his songs (who can forget Suzanne!‚Äù, ‚ÄòBird On The Wire‚Äô has a particular appeal for me. It was written during his early years, while he was staying on the Greek island of Hydra. During this period, he fell in love with Marianne Ihlen and theirs was a tempestuous relationship. It was not easy living and the town had no electricity amongst other problems. When the government finally installed the necessary infrastructure, the wires stretched across Leonard Cohen‚Äôs windows. As Marianne Ihlen recounted, ‚ÄúWhile we‚Äôre sitting there, birds were landing on the wire like notes on a music sheet.‚Äù She brought Cohen his guitar and he began to compose the song that became one of his greatest successes.
After they‚Äôd been together for eight years, the relationship came apart, bit by bit, ‚Äúlike falling ashes,‚Äù as Cohen put it. Later in her life Marianne was diagnosed to have cancer.
Hearing about it, Leonard Cohen wrote a poignant letter:
‚ÄúWell Marianne, it‚Äôs come to this time when we are really so old and our bodies are falling apart and I think I will follow you very soon. Know that I am so close behind you that if you stretch out your hand, I think you can reach mine. And you know that I‚Äôve always loved you for your beauty and your wisdom, but I don‚Äôt need to say anything more about that because you know all about that. But now, I just want to wish you a very good journey. Goodbye old friend. Endless love, see you down the road‚Äù.
In her last hour her friend held Marianne‚Äôs hand and hummed ‚ÄúBird on the Wire,‚Äù as her life slowly ebbed away‚Ä¶

04/10/22, 6:08‚ÄØam
During Navarathri, Shakti is worshipped in her three manifestations. The first three days are for the worship of Mahakali (power of performing activities), Lakshmi is venerated during the next three days and the last three days are dedicated to Saraswathi, who symbolises the power of knowledge. Saraswathi, supreme icon of wisdom and the arts, is often depicted seated, holding a veena in her hands. Raja Ravi Varma‚Äôs painting of a seated Saraswathi can invariably be found in many Indian homes.
Sculptural representations of Saraswathi dancing are comparatively infrequent and are often found in the temples of the Hoysala period. This particular one is from Chennakesava temple at Somanathapura. Intricately chiseled, it exudes innate beauty and grace. The Goddess is seen dancing with one leg planted on the ground while raising the other one, bent at the knee. This is referred to as the urdhvajanuchari pose. She is holding an eka tantri veena in her hands and the ornamentation is detailed and exquisite. She is dancing to the beats of the drummer who can be seen in the lower right corner. Since the material used was soft chloritic schist stone, some of the details have been lost with vagaries of time, made worse by uncaring visitors who rub their hands over it with sheer disdain.
Dynamic, creative energy seems to flow from every inch of this visual interpretation of Goddess Saraswathi.
In the words of Mahakavi Bharathiyar‚Ä¶
‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ≤‡Æµ‡ØÅ ‡Æö‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øá‡Ææ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øá‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç
‡Æà‡Æ§‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æé‡Æ¥‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æø‡Æü‡Øà‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Ææ‡Æ≥‡Øç

In beauteous paintings, temple towers
She manifests
As an epitome of joyful grace

10/10/22, 7:33‚ÄØam
Libraries figured prominently during my formative years. I accompanied my writer mother whenever she visited them (which was quite often), for her reference work. I used to enjoy climbing up the ladders just to feel the leather bound old books stacked in tall shelves in the cavernous Connemara Library.
RK Narayan (whose birthday is today10th October), captured that experience quite eloquently. He wrote ‚Äúfaint aroma of gum and calico that hangs about a library is as the fragrance of incense to me. I think the most beautiful sight is the gilt-edged backs of a row of books on a shelf. The alley between two well-stocked shelves in a hall fills me with the same delight as passing through a silent avenue of trees. The colour of a binding-cloth and its smooth texture gives me the same pleasure as touching a flower on its stalk.‚Äù
During my school days, the stern looking librarian would silently hand over RK Narayan‚Äôs books which I used to read and reread many times. Swami and friends kept me company on many afternoons.
Later in life, RK Narayan commented on issues of topical interest. For instance, he remarked, ‚ÄúIf someone should ask, ‚Äòhow should an Opposition function?‚Äô, the best answer would be, ‚Äòin the manner of a traditional mother-in-law who watches the performance of household work by a daughter-in-law and follows her about with her comments.‚Äù
That kind of mother-in-law seems elusive now!

12/10/22, 10:24‚ÄØam
Sometimes in the morning I sit on the deck, looking at this Buddha, listening to the sonorous rendering of Mahaparinibbana Sutta which describes the last days of Buddha. Though the recitation is in Pali, an all pervading sense of peace transcends the lyrics.
In his teachings Buddha emphasised the concept of NibbƒÅna, a Pali word for the extinguishing of a fire. A burning fire clings onto its fuel. When it extinguishes, it lets go of it, merging into the cosmos, reaching a state of unbounded freedom.
Buddha elaborated this analogy further in his Addittapariyaya Sutta, commonly known as the Fire Sermon, when he addressed his disciples:
‚ÄúAnd what is all that is burning? Bhikkhus, the eye is burning, visible forms are burning, visual consciousness is burning, visual impression is burning, also whatever sensation, pleasant or painful or neither-painful, nor pleasant, arises on account of the visual impression, that too is burning. Burning with what? Burning with the fire of craving, with the fire of hate, with the fire of delusion; I say it is burning with birth, ageing and death, with sorrows, with lamentations, with pains, with griefs, with despairs.‚Äù
Though the imagery is stark, Buddha draws attention to how suffering is caused by these sensory inputs which fill our minds and hearts with simmering fires of desire and hatred. The quest in life is to quell these fires and find peace within.

19/10/22, 7:26‚ÄØam
Brown Pelican is an interesting bird to watch, especially when it engages in the ‚Äòhead throw‚Äô behaviour. It throws its head into the air while arching its back to stretch its neck and gular pouch. The pouch measures from six to ten inches in depth and is capable of holding several gallons of water. This manoeuvre is reportedly a means to maintain the health and elasticity of pouch skin, But the ‚Äòhead throw‚Äô becomes handy when it attempts to catch a fish. Pelicans are plunge divers and dive into the water with force. Once they catch a fish and come upto the surface, they engage in ‚Äòhead throw‚Äô action to swallow the fish head first.
It was wonderful to observe the ‚Äòhead throw‚Äô behaviour which lasts for just a few seconds.
As the American humorist Dixon Lanier Merrit wrote in 1913
A wonderful bird is the pelican
His bill can hold more than his belican
(This is often misattributed to Ogden Nash!)
19/10/22, 10:45‚ÄØpm

In our everyday lives, preoccupied with our internal monologues, we stand on the banks of the river of awareness and watch it pass by as if it is ‚Äòout there.‚Äô
There is a wonderful anecdote about the Zen master Gensha, referred to as the ‚ÄúGreat Master Of One Doctrine‚Äô. A monk once went to him and wanted to learn where the entrance to the path of truth was. Gensha asked him, "Do you hear the murmuring of the brook?" "Yes, I hear it," answered the monk. "There is the entrance," the master told him.

20/12/22, 8:20‚ÄØam
After birding around the Coyote hills, when we ventured into the Arastradero Preserve, in Santa Clara county, the call of the acorn woodpecker welcomed us. Its call was reportedly the inspiration for the cartoon character, Woody Woodpecker! The story goes that Walter Lantz, the creator of the cartoon character and his new bride, Grace, were on their honeymoon in a cabin in California. They were disturbed by a loud sound as if someone was laughing. When they went out to check, they spotted an Acorn Woodpecker, pounding away at the roof nonchalantly and Woody was born!
The terrain of the preserve was largely grassland with great old oak trees. When I saw this magnificent tree with its bare branches, I was struck by its resemblance to mysterious neural networks in our brain.
There is always something of an unknown presence embedded in such knotty tangles‚Ä¶
20/12/22, 10:20‚ÄØpm
Absolutely eye catching Sir. And what a comparison. There is a saying in Kannada, what Sun can't see a poet sees!

09/01/22, 6:01‚ÄØpm
It is curfew time‚Ä¶.all noises have ceased..
Amidst the silence, a red vented bulbul announces its presence through its unmistakable call.
As I watch, it raises its head and lets out a quiet phrase of a song. Starting as a whistle the song soon turns melodious, enlivening the still ambience.
Its cheery call alleviates the angst of isolation..
Towards the end of his life, the last Mughal emperor Bahadur Shah Zafar had to face similar seclusion when he was incarcerated by the British and he wrote a beautiful poem about the bulbul:
Bulbul ko bƒÅƒ°hbƒÅ√± se na sayyƒÅd se gila
qismat me√± qaid likkhƒ´ thƒ´ fasl-e-bahƒÅr me√±
The bulbul has no complaints from the gardener, or the bird-catcher.
It knows that it is destiny to get caged, even if it is springtime.
Such prescient observation about travails of life during pandemic!
22/01/22, 6:30‚ÄØpm
He might have left his body but the guiding light lives for ever. We seem to have become blind to what we need to focus on. The photograph is so enchanting Sir.
23/01/22, 3:09‚ÄØpm
Oh...so powerful and a positive saying. We should be greatful to have had (will be) such a realised being during our life time. And what an apt fantastic photograph üëç
02/02/22, 11:35‚ÄØam
Wetlands play a crucial role in absorbing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and locking it away in plants, root systems and soil. They are also a vibrant biologically diverse ecosystem that sustain a large number of birds, fish and other small creatures which live in harmony.
For many of us, water simply flows from a tap and we hardly reflect about it beyond this point of contact and consumption. In the process, we have lost a sense of respect for the complex workings of a wetland and the intricate web of life that this simple waterbody supports.
On this World Wetland Day it is imperative that we commit ourselves to conserve and protect this invaluable, precious ecosystem‚Ä¶
02/02/22, 12:06‚ÄØpm
What a photograph üëç
05/02/22, 9:22‚ÄØam
Basant Panchami which is being celebrated today heralds the arrival of spring and is imbued with many legends. The most popular association is with Saraswati, the goddess of knowledge, language and music who is deemed to have been born on this day.
Amongst the many legends concerning Basant Panchami, there is one which revolves around Kama and his role in bringing Lord Shiva and Parvati together. Shiva, mourning the death of his wife Sati/Uma, retreated to the Himalayas and became a reclusive ascetic. Parvati, a reincarnation of Sati, told her father King Himavat that she would marry only Shiva. When informed of this, Shiva declined and walked away without even a glance at Parvati. Undaunted, she waited for many years but couldn‚Äôt win him over. The Gods intervened and approached Kamadeva to wake Shiva from his deep meditation and make him fall in love with Parvati. Heeding to their request, Kamadeva shot his five arrows of love, one of which distracted Shiva, who got bewitched by Paravati‚Äôs beauty. But as soon as he realized it was Kamadeva‚Äôs ruse, he opened the third eye and reduced him to ashes. Deeply distressed by this, Rati undertook an austere penance for 40 days to Shiva. Shiva finally relented and brought Kamadeva back to life on the day of Basant Panchami. On this day Kamadeva and Rati descend on earth ushering in the first fragrant breeze of spring, a season or rebirth and renewal. This is one of the reasons as to why Basant Panchami is also associated with Shringara Rasam.
This beautifully carved sculpture of Kamadeva and Rati is from the western groups of temples at Khajuraho.
It is not a so well-known fact that the Muslim community has been celebrating Basant Panchami since the 12th century A.D. According to legend, Delhi's Chishti Saint Nizamuddin Aulia's young nephew Taqiuddin Nooh died in this month. Stricken with grief, he withdrew himself. The famous court poet, Amir Khusrau, tried to think of ways to brighten the Saint's mood. Then Khusrau noticed some young women dressed in yellow clothes, adorned with yellow flowers of marigold who were celebrating Basant Utsav. Seeing this, an idea struck Khusrau, who immediately donned a yellow ghaagra, covered his face with a chunni, hung garlands of yellow marigold around his neck, went to the Saint and began dancing and singing, ‚ÄúAaj Basant Manaaley Suhagan‚Ä¶Aaj Basant Manaaley Suhagan‚Äù. Seeing this spectacle and knowing it was Khusrau under the woman‚Äôs garb who was singing and dancing with gay abandon, Nizamuddin Aulia burst out laughing and his spell of gloom was swiftly lifted. He then went to the grave of his nephew and sang: ‚ÄòAshq rayz ameedan abro bahar‚Äô (‚ÄòShed tears of joy at the coming of spring and the clouds‚Äô). Since then, Basant Panchami is being celebrated at the dargah of Nizamuddin Aulia in Delhi and all dargah's of the Chishti order.
Basant, the season of spring, has also inspired many ragas in Indian music. In the north, there are Basant, Basant Bahar and Basant Mukhari and in the south, Vasantam, Hindola Vasantam, Shuddha Vasantam, Vasanta Varali, and Vasanta Bhairavi. Each one of them embodies the spirit of spring.
On this day let us celebrate the cultural syncretism associated with this festival in the subcontinent and spend the day savouring and immersing ourselves in these ragas!
05/02/22, 12:21‚ÄØpm
Time to rejuvenate ourselves. Nature offers therapy. We should be open to it. A very informative blend of Basant Panchami. Thank you Sir.
07/02/22, 8:33‚ÄØam
Rathasapthamai which is being celebrated today marks the movement of sun (Surya) turning his ‚Äúratham‚Äù (chariot) drawn by Saptha (seven) horses from winter solstice to (Dakshinayanam) to the summer solstice (Uttarayanam).
The worship of Surya is deep rooted in antiquity. Sun has been an object of reverence and worship from the start of human settlements and has been represented symbolically in the pottery and seals of ancient civilizations. The transformation of Surya from a symbolic form to an anthropomorphic figure occurred during the Rig Vedic period. In the process of providing a form to the formless an iconic tradition started and Surya was represented in various human forms across different parts of India. The Agama tradition further specified details of depiction of the sun god. One of the most beautiful representation of Surya according to the Suprabhedagama tradition is in at the Virupaksha temple in Pattadakkal. This temple was built by Queen Loka Mahadevi after the successful military campaign of King Vikramaditya II against the Pallavas. Within the dark interiors of the temple, the inner ceiling in the east has this intricately carved image of Surya.
At the center of this intricately carved bas-relief is Surya, the sun god, riding a seven-horse chariot. He is standing majestically in the chariot holding a lotus flower with each hand, and surrounding his head is a halo of rays emanating outwards. Behind him are the two-headed mythical creatures (Makaras), disgorging yakshas. Accompanying him are his consorts Ushas (Goddess of Dawn) and Chhaya (Goddess of Shadow). Both Ushas and Chhaya are pointing their bows upwards, indicating that they are fighting the darkness. At the bottom of the panel is Aruna, Surya‚Äôs charioteer, holding the reins of seven horses, representing the days of the week. The seven horses are named as Gayatri, Brihati, Ushnih, Jagati, Trishtubha, Anushtubha and Pankti.
Perhaps one of the most exquisite delineation of the attributes of the sun god is in the composition of Muthiswamy Dikshitar ‚ÄòSurya Murte Namostute‚Äô set to raga Sourashtram.
The spiritual connotations of the Sun have been brought out vividly by Rabindranath Tagore: ‚ÄúOne day while I stood watching at early dawn the Sun sending out its rays from behind the trees, I suddenly felt as if some ancient mist had in a moment lifted from my sight and the morning light on the face of the world revealed an inner radiance of joy. The invisible screen of the commonplace was removed from all things and all of mankind and this ultimate significance was intensified in my mind and this is the definition of beauty.‚Äù
08/02/22, 9:34‚ÄØam
Bhishma or Bhishma Pitamaha was one of the most charismatic characters in Mahabharata and was respected by both the Kauravas and the Pandavaas. His original name was Devavrata and he was the son of King Shantanu and Ganga. His father wanted to marry a fisherwoman, Stayavati, who insisted that only sons born to her should succeed Shantanu to the throne. To facilitate this, Devavrata took a vow of celibacy for life and also pledged to serve anyone who ascended the throne of Hastinapura.
In the battle of Mahabharata, the Pandavas were unable to make any headway even after many days mainly due to the skill and valour of Bhishma. At this point, Shikhandi, who was born a woman, positioned herself in front of Arjuna to fight against Bhishma. Bhishma knew that Shikhandi was born a woman, who had a grudge against Bhishma because he had interfered in her marriage. Seeing Shikhandi, Bhishma refused to fight and was felled by Arjuna‚Äôs arrow. It is believed that Bhishma himself had hinted at this ploy while Arjuna and Krishna met him the previous night.
Arjuna‚Äôs arrows had already formed a bed and Bhishma did not fall to the ground. Arjuna used more arrows to form a pillow. As the battle raged, Bhishma held on till Uttarayana to die as he had the boon of ‚ÄòIchcha Mrityu‚Äô, the ability to choose one‚Äôs time of death.
It is believed that Bhishma revealed the Vishnu Sahasranama Stotram to the Pandavas in the presence of Lord Krishna, an incarnation of Lord Vishnu, on this day which is celebrated as Bhishma Ashtami.
The battle of Kurukshetra is carved into the southern section of the west gallery, which is located on the perimeter of the lower level of the Angkor Wat. This is a depiction of Bhishma on a bed of arrows. Interestingly it is said that a beam of sunrays falls on this image during the winter solstice
10/02/22, 10:19‚ÄØam
Absolutely blissful and carefree! Or does it look like because we are tired of human life? It's a beautiful photograph Sir!
14/02/22, 8:23‚ÄØam
As John Paul Young sang, ‚ÄúLove is in the air, everywhere I look around, Love is in the air, every sight and every sound.‚Äù It is also the time when love turns into serious business in the guise of Valentine‚Äôs Day. But what is the real story behind Valentine?
While Valentine‚Äôs Day might be associated with romantic love, the real story behind its namesake, Valentine, is full of bloodshed and heart break. He was reported to have had healing powers, especially for those ailing from epilepsy. According to one legend, Valentine signed a letter ‚Äúfrom your Valentine‚Äù to his jailer‚Äôs daughter, whom he had befriended and healed her from blindness. Another legend states that he defied the emperor‚Äôs orders and secretly married couples to spare the husbands from war. Unhappy with his actions, Emperor Claudius ordered that he be put to death and he was beheaded. Neither written nor material evidence from the pre-medieval period associates Valentine with love or lovers. Scholars credit Geoffrey Chaucer for turning Valentine into the patron of love. In his Parlement of Foules he wrote, ‚Äúseynt Volantynys day/ Whan euery bryd comyth there to chese his make. (Saint Valentine‚Äôs day, when every bird comes there to choose his mate.) Chaucer was a major influencer in his day ‚Äì after him, everyone began calling their beloved ‚ÄúValentine‚Äù and writing love poems on 14 February.
Closer home there is a more suitable mythological character, Kamadeva. He has many names: he is called ‚ÄúRagavrunt‚Äù, ‚ÄúAnanga‚Äù, ‚ÄúKandarp‚Äù, ‚ÄúManmath‚Äù, ‚ÄúMansija‚Äù, ‚ÄúMadana‚Äù, ‚ÄúRatikant‚Äù, ‚ÄúPushpvan‚Äù and ‚ÄúPushpdhanv‚Äù. Kama has a variety of meanings, ranging from sensuality to aesthetic enjoyment, although its overtones are predominantly sexual in the popular imagination. It is also a misconception that kama means love, kama literally means trishNa(Sanskrit), desire or thirst.
There are striking parallels between the depiction of Kamadeva and Cupid. Both carry a bow and a quiver of arrows. Kamadeva‚Äôs bow is made of sugarcane and is sugar coated with the bowstring soaked in honey. Arrows are decorated with flowers and the flowers on his arrows are: Aravinda(White Lotus), Ashoka, Cuta (Mango Flower), Navamalika (Jasmine), and Nilotpala (Blue Lotus). Kamadeva carries five kind of arrows with him: Maran, Stambhan, Jrumbhan, Shoshan and Ummadan. Kamadeva‚Äôs five arrows are associated with five effects. The first arrow is aimed at the heart and it causes initial excitement and a youthful cheerfulness. The second arrow is aimed at the lips and it causes one to cry out of this excitement. The third arrow is aimed at the head/brain and it makes one lose their mind / go crazy with love. The fourth arrow is aimed at the eyes which makes one see things. The fifth arrow is basically designed to hit anywhere causing the person to totally be absorbed with love.
There are no temples solely dedicated to Kamadeva in India. However, in Assam there is a shrine for him called Madana-Kamadeva temple. Situated in a dense forest, this temple has some marvellous sculptures but unfortunately the structure is quite dilapidated.
This particular sculpture of Kamadeva is from a small temple at Krishnapuram in Tirunelveli district. It is an astounding sculpture crafted out of a single stone and is exquisitely carved. He is holding the bow made of sugarcane, which is so well hewn that if one drops a pin into the hole on top of the bow, it comes out at the bottom! Unfortunately, in the process of testing this out, people have broken part of the bow, the bane of many a sculpture in India. The sculpture now is encircled within a steel enclosure to prevent further damage to it.
There is a mantra dedicated to Kamadeva which reads:
Aum Kamadevaye Vidmahe
Pushpa banaye dhimahi
Tanno Ananga Prachodayat
Oh let me meditate to the God of Love
He who carries an arrow made of flowers
May that Ananga (who is without a body) bestow upon me higher intellect and illuminate my mind.
Purusartha is a key concept in Hinduism and refers to the four important goals of human life. They are Dharma (righteousness, moral values); Artha (prosperity, economic values); Kama (pleasure, love) and Moksha (liberation, spiritual values). The path to enlightenment or Moksha is facilitated by the harmonious interaction of Dharma, Artha, and Kama.
Ultimately, the highest Kama is the longing for Oneness with the Divine.
14/02/22, 6:18‚ÄØpm
Oh. What a detailed description Sir. But the story behind Valentine's day leaves one with bitter taste in mouth. Our culture has more angles to the concept of love and it is one of the goals, in the limits of Dharma. Thank you Sir for throwing light on the details and the sculpture which is so bright and glowing!
16/02/22, 9:53‚ÄØpm
Such a beautiful rendering Sir. I didn't know this. I think all the Puranas Vedas Upanishads talk about the same, the jist that you have highlighted in the end. We need to keep reminding ourselves the same and sampoorna sharanagathi helps in destroying our ahankara. I took time to read the above and observing the sculpture. No words to express the deftness of the sculpture.
21/02/22, 12:07‚ÄØpm
I love Bar Headed Geese! They are amazing travellers! They breed in massive colonies near mountain lakes in Mongolia and when the cold starts to overcome them, fly thousands of miles to winter in South Asia and come down to South India too in large numbers. As someone suggested these dainty birds are able achieve what the fearsome Genghis Khan was unable to do!
When we heard that they are back in Hadinaru Lake near Mysore, myself and Ahalya took a much needed break after a year of prolonged stay at home and headed there. We were welcomed by their chorus of clucks as we went near the lake and it was such a wonderful sight to see hundreds of them resting and frolicking in the water. A sight to behold‚Ä¶
I had written a detailed account about these birds‚Ä¶do have a look at: https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/soaring-high-on-graceful-wings

01/03/22, 8:58‚ÄØam
According to one of the legends, Mahashivaratri is the day Lord Shiva got married to Parvati.
Goddess Sati took birth as Parvati, the daughter of Himavan to marry Lord Shiva. She practised intense penance to win over Lord Shiva's heart. After years of Tapasya at the Gauri Kund, Parvati finally succeeded in convincing Lord Shiva to accept her as his wife. Shiva reportedly proposed to Parvati at Guptakashi and then tied the nuptial knot at Triyuginarayan. The celestial marriage of Lord Shiva and Parvati took place in the presence of Lord Brahma, who turned a priest to conduct the ceremony and Lord Vishnu, who performed the duties of the bride's brother. The Agni that was witness to the wedding ceremony still exists in the form of an eternal flame, Akhand Dhuni, near the temple.
This 17th century mural at Veerabadra temple at Lepakshi depicts the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. Shiva is shown wearing the characteristic tiger skin, carrying the deer and axe in the upper hands. Parvati, escorted by attendants stands in front of Shiva, her head slightly bent. She is seen carrying a lotus in her left hand while offering the right hand to Shiva. Do not fail to notice a diminutive Nandi jumping joyfully between the couple! To the left of Paravati is her father Himavan who is carrying a kamandala in his raised hand and is about to solemnize the wedding by pouring water on the hands of the couple. Brahma is seen sitting in front of the sacred fire performing various rituals.
When I first visited the temple, the murals covered with years of dirt and soot were hardly visible in the dark interiors of the place. Thankfully a careful restoration has brought them alive now, even though some details have been lost. Unquestionably they are the finest examples of mural paintings of the Vijayanagar period.
18/03/22, 11:58‚ÄØam
Colours play an important role in the festival of Holi. They add vitality to the festival, making it one of the most vibrant of celebrations. Each of the colours is deemed to have a symbolic significance. Blue for instance is the colour of Krishna's complexion and also of the sky and the oceans.
And colours are the smiles of nature.
Birds are beautiful jewels in the sky. There are many brightly coloured birds in the world, and the most flamboyant ones are the parrots. During our birding sojourn in Australia, Ahalya and myself saw some of the most multihued parrots, prominent among them being the Rainbow Lorikeet.
Rainbow Lorikeet, definitely deserves its name! True to its name, one can see all the colour palettes of rainbow in its feathers. Its head is deep blue with a greenish-yellow nuchal collar, and the rest of the upper parts (wings, back, and tail) are green. The chest is orange/yellow in colour. The belly is deep blue, and the thighs and rump are green. Their species name, haematodus, comes from the Latin word for blood, and is a reference to the rich red found on its breast.
The colour of the feathers of birds serves various functions; thermoregulation, climatic adaptation and a fine balance between sexual signalling and camouflage. Birds need to balance being attractive to potential mates while having some kind of camouflage against potential predators. When hunted from above, the Rainbow Lorikeet blends with the foliage of the trees with its green back. It has been suggested that the colourful patches confer evolutionary advantage in courtship and mate recognition.
Rainbow lorikeets have two unique features. They possess a tongue with brush-type tissues helping them to collect nectar and pollen. The other distinctive feature is their agile legs which help them to hang upside-down and feed on bottlebrush flowers. It is a dazzling sight when flocks of them fly with the rays of the sun streaming through their gorgeous plumage!
On the occasion of Holi, in the words of Maya Angelou, let us ‚ÄúTry to be a rainbow in someone‚Äôs cloud.‚Äù
22/03/22, 1:24‚ÄØpm
Wonderful photograph Sir. Each one of us should take the responsibility to save drops of üí¶
07/04/22, 11:02‚ÄØam
Each of the lecture theatres in JIPMER were named after a historical medical luminary and their portrait used to be displayed outside. Every time I entered theatre Bernard I used to be fascinated by a painting which depicted him in a deeply reflective mood. Claude Bernard was an exceptional man. He posited that there is a delicate balance between physiological processes within the human body and the environment outside of it. He termed them as ‚Äòmilieu interior‚Äô and ‚Äòmilieu exterior‚Äô. He drew attention to how physiological mechanisms are crucial in maintaining constancy of the internal environment to sustain a status of health in response to changes in the external environment.
Understandably over the years medical professionals have focused their attention on the internal environment to preserve individual health. Unfortunately, in the process, the crucial role of the environment in which we are immersed everyday in our lives and its vital role in modulating individual health has been lost sight of.
On the occasion of the World Health today and on the background of looming climate changes, it is imperative to remind ourselves that climate crisis is health crisis. Our health is intricately related to health of the planet and we should strive to make every effort to conserve and protect the Mother Earth.
18/04/22, 1:31‚ÄØpm
Enlightening Sir. Not gone into so many details!!
22/04/22, 9:37‚ÄØam
Forests are the lungs of our land.
On this World Earth Day, let us strive to cherish Mother Nature and resolve to conserve and protect it...

Oh what a photograph. It literally takes us there and the caption makes us experience our presence there. Thank you Sir for the breatherüôÇ
23/04/22, 9:58‚ÄØam
Indian Coral Tree is among the earliest flowering trees in spring and is extremely colourful and picturesque. It adds colour to the skyline with its conspicuous vibrant red coloured flowers. When in bloom the coral tree is like an aviary, attracting numerous bird species like this Golden Fronted Leaf Bird here.
Referred to as a Mandara tree it is one of the five heavenly trees, Panchavriksha in Indira‚Äôs garden in Swarga. After Krishna had brought the Parijata Tree from heaven for Satyabhama, Rukminin insisted that he should bring the Mandara tree for her!
29/04/22, 1:09‚ÄØpm
Fantastic sculpture Sir. Such an apt example which highlights out heritage giving a divine touch to the art.
03/05/22, 10:26‚ÄØam
Basavanna whose birthday is today, was a revolutionary saint and an ardent social reformer. He composed vachanas in simple language, which are very thought provoking. This particular one translated by AK Ramanujan is my favourite.
He outlines as to how various parts of a temple are analogous to several body parts and a temple is the primordial template of the human body. Though the rich may construct temples to show their wealth and power, Basavanna highlights that our body is itself is a temple which houses the immortal god.
The last lines: things standing shall fall, but the moving will ever stay, is so prescient. A temple built with stones and mortar might fall but the immortal spirit will move on, not confined to the physical space.
Words from a thousand years ago never ring more true now‚Ä¶.
06/05/22, 9:34‚ÄØam
Yesterday was Ramanuja Jayanthi and today is 1234th birth anniversary of Adi Shankaracharya. While Ramanjua strove to make spirituality more religious, Shankara was motivated by the desire to make religion more spiritual. One catered to human vulnerability and fulfilment in the life lived now, the other focused on the search for ultimate truths.
Though Shankara acknowledged the innate human need for religious practices, he also urged that these should not impede the quest for exploring one‚Äôs divine nature and that of the Supreme Self, as this verse from his magnum opus, Vivekachudamani illustrates‚Ä¶
07/05/22, 10:47‚ÄØam
On his birthday I was re-reading Tagore‚Äôs Stray Birds. It is a collection of some 300 short poems, each one of them a sparkling gem! They are deeply meditative reflections on myriad manifestations of nature‚Ä¶be it birds, flowers, sun, moon‚Ä¶this one is about clouds..
07/05/22, 5:41‚ÄØpm
Oh what a photograph Sir. No words. But words from a writer, poet, artist like Rabindranth Tagore apt for the photograph!
14/05/22, 9:14‚ÄØam

16/05/22, 8:19‚ÄØam
On the Buddha Purnima day, it is interesting to note that all the important events in his life were associated with trees. He was born under a sal tree and he experienced his first deep meditation under a rose-apple tree. Years later, his enlightenment took place under a Bodhi tree and he attained Mahaparinirvana lying between two mighty sal trees. Buddha considered a kind person to be like a banyan tree, growing along road side offering respite and succour to the tired traveller with its cool shade.
This panel in Sanchi portrays a banyan (Nyagrodha) tree with a throne beneath (representing Buddha). For several weeks after attaining the enlightenment, Buddha was hesitant and diffident to make known The Truth to the world. Then Brahma, Indra, the four Lokapalas (Regents of the Four Quarters) and the archangels of the heavens approached him and implored him to expound his revelations. The four figures side by side in the foreground are the four Lokapalas. The nyagrodha tree symbolizes the principle that a seemingly insignificant cause can produce a great effect, just as the tiny seed of the nyagrodha develops into an sprawling tree.
Nyagrodha also figures in an interesting narrative in the Chandogya Upanishad. Uddalaka a great saint sent his son Svetaketu when he was twelve, to the ashram of a renowned teacher for studies. Svetaketu was a bright boy and in twelve years, he mastered all scriptures that could be taught. Seeing a man proud of his knowledge, his father asked him, ‚ÄúDo you know that by knowing which all can be known? That which cannot be taught but can only be known?‚Äù He asked the boy to get a fruit of the Nyagrodha tree, cut it open, and remove a seed. He then asked him what he saw. ‚ÄúNothing‚Äù the boy replied. ‚ÄúThat is the subtlest essence of all. That essence that you do not perceive, from that arises the big tree. That essence is the reality. That essence is the Spirit of whole universe. That which cannot be explained or taught but by knowing which you know all there is to know.‚Äù. Then the Sage took his son in to his arms and whispered this great truth in to his ear, ‚ÄúYou are THAT, Svetaketu. Tat Tvam Asi
Religious orientations and teachings may differ but the search for ultimate reality stems from the underlying interconnectedness of individual and universal consciousness.
As Thich Nhat Hanh commented perceptively about this quest, ‚ÄúThe mind can go in a thousand directions, but on this beautiful path, I walk in peace. With each step, the wind blows. With each step, a flower blooms.‚Äù
16/05/22, 8:29‚ÄØam
On the Buddha Purnima day, it is interesting to note that all the important events in his life were associated with trees. He was born under a sal tree and he experienced his first deep meditation under a rose-apple tree. Years later, his enlightenment took place under a Bodhi tree and he attained Mahaparinirvana lying between two mighty sal trees. Buddha considered a kind person to be like a banyan tree, growing along road side offering respite and succour to the tired traveller with its cool shade.
This panel in Sanchi portrays a banyan (Nyagrodha) tree with a throne beneath (representing Buddha). Then Brahma, Indra, the four Lokapalas (Regents of the Four Quarters) and the archangels of the heavens approached him and implored him to expound his revelations. The four figures side by side in the foreground are the four Lokapalas. The nyagrodha tree symbolizes the principle that a seemingly insignificant cause can produce a great effect, just as the tiny seed of the nyagrodha develops into an sprawling tree.

That essence is the reality. That essence is the Spirit of whole universe. That which cannot be explained or taught but by knowing which you know all there is to know.‚Äù. As Thich Nhat Hanh commented perceptively about this quest, ‚ÄúThe mind can go in a thousand directions, but on this beautiful path, I walk in peace. With each step, the wind blows. With each step, a flower blooms.‚Äù

Sir I have always been drawn towards Gautham Buddha's teachings and it is heartening to know from the above the connectedness to the nature. It is so important to start walking in the path with a still focus. Thank you Sir for your attempts to bring our focus back to the long spiritual journey.
18/05/22, 6:24‚ÄØam
I lose myself in a museum!
Whenever we trave,l we make it a point to savor the museums of the place, leisurely.
As you stroll through a museum, it becomes part of your, somehow.
Museums are places of discovery and learning. Visit to a museum often is a part of a student‚Äôs life from early days, abroad. It is a wonderful sight to see children milling around the exhibits curiously, while being briefed about them by their teachers.
Less said about the status of museums in India, the better. There is an overwhelming sense of neglect in many of them, with some notable exceptions. The exhibits are often displayed haphazardly with poor lighting with little information about them. Gallery walks are a rarity in most.
Madhya Pradesh Tribal Museum at Bhopal is an outstanding example of how a museum should be! Designed by Revathi Kamath, pioneer of mud architecture in India, it is a series of aesthetically designed colorful galleries that offer interesting and informative insights into the rich cultural heritage of various tribes of the region. One can spend hours amidst the beautifully lit artifacts and exhibits.
Take a walk through this museum at: https://photos.app.goo.gl/eh4ChAvfXt72BMRJ7
Incidentally today is the International Museum Day!
20/05/22, 7:20‚ÄØam
The third friday in May is considered as the Endangered Species Day, to draw attention to threatened species and the importance of protecting them. It was established by David Robinson and the Endangered Species Coalition in 2006.
One of the critically endangered bird species in India is the Great Indian Bustard. Once in the running to become India‚Äôs national bird, it is literally fluttering for survival. Its prime habitat, the grasslands are being slowly denuded due to various industrial projects. The Great Indian Bustard is considered among the largest flying birds in the world and because of its large size they usually take low flights which often bring them fatally in touch with overhead power lines. Even though the Supreme Court had stipulated that the power lines need to be taken underground, the progress has been very slow as companies continue to violate the order. The situation is not helped by the presence of feral dogs which eat the bustard‚Äôs eggs and also attack the young ones. Earlier found across several states of India, the numbers have dramatically declined over the years, especially in peninsular India.
It was a most privileged moment for me, sometime ago, to see a male strolling across, with its held high, in a grassland. As I was watching it intently, I failed to notice the female, who sauntered across gently. Soon both of them disappeared in the vast grassland and to my great surprise and joy they mated! That moment continues to remain alive in my memory.
Sadly when I visited that habitat again, not a single GIB was there.
With less than hundred Great Indian Bustards in the country and their alarming decline over the years, it is real possibility that they may become extinct in the future.
As we ravage their habitat
And let the grasslands dwindle
This gracious bird
Will just cease to be‚Ä¶
22/05/22, 1:51‚ÄØpm
There is profound beauty in the vast, arid landscape of The Little Rann of Kutch. Its incredible biodiversity supports an astonishing range of flora and fauna, many of them unique to the region. The International Biodiversity Day today, draws attention to the crucial role of biodiversity in maintaining a healthy ecosystem.
An important native member of the ecosystem of the Little Rann of Kutch is the Indian wild ass. In Kutchi language, the Indian wild ass is called ghorkhar. It is the only region in India where they live in the wild, one of the main reasons being that unlike donkeys and horses, it was never successfully domesticated. Groups of them graze nonchalantly unmindful of the scorching heat amidst patches of grasslands. They are notoriously shy and quickly bolt with amazing speed, once they spot an inquisitive human observer! Seeing herds of these majestic creatures sprinting across the parched land with streaks of dust in their wake is an unforgettable sight!
24/05/22, 8:37‚ÄØam
The day began with this beautiful song, Dwaitamu Sukhama, Advaitamu Sukhama, wherein Saint Thyagaraja expresses the dilemma faced by many seekers.
Dwaita and advaita offer two very different answers for the fundamental question of all philosophy: what is the nature of the world and that of the internal self? Dwaita claims that there are fundamentally two entities, jIvAtma and paramAtma, with the internal self being jIvAtma and the external world being a multi-faceted manifestation of paramAtma. Advaita posits that there is but only the paramAtma and the internal self is also a manifestation of the paramAtma.
They are often positioned as two different, dissimilar paths.
An elegant, insightful perspective is provided in a verse from Ashtavakra Gita.
kva dharmahÃ£ kva ca vƒÅ kƒÅmahÃ£ kva cƒÅrthahÃ£ kva vivƒìkatƒÅ |
kva dvaitamÃ£ kva ca vƒÅ(a)dvaitamÃ£ svamahimni sthitasya mƒì || 19-2 ||
For me, established in my own glory, there is no religion,
sensuality, possessions, philosophy, duality or even non-duality.

05/06/22, 8:22‚ÄØam
As we usher in another World Environment Day, it is a sad and stark fact that the health of our environment is not in good shape. A slew of factors ranging from global warming to deforestation have left their impact on an already fragile planet.
The campaign this year focuses on "Living Sustainably in Harmony with Nature."
A little bird has been practising this quietly, for centuries‚Ä¶the Barn Swallow!
Barn swallows have always been linked to people, even adapting former nesting grounds in caves and cliff faces for manmade structures and living harmoniously with the humans. In many parts of the world, having Barn Swallows nesting on one's property is considered a sign of good fortune. Unfortunately, scores of them were slaughtered for their feathers in the Victorian era for decorating ladies‚Äô hats. Concerned with this practice and the decimation of the birds, George Bird Grinnell wrote his famous editorial in ‚ÄòForest and Stream‚Äô in 1886 opposing it. That editorial led to the formation of the Audubon Society and the advent of the conservation movement in the United States.
These twittery, flittery birds love to eat the insects that we consider pesky. They consume 60 insects in an hour which can even go up to 850 per day. That's how much each bird eats. Working efficiently as effective pest control agents they do their bit silently to maintain the environment.
Let this diminutive bird inspire us on this day!
As Shakespeare wrote, ‚ÄúTrue hope is swift and flies with swallow‚Äôs wings.‚Äù
08/06/22, 8:39‚ÄØam
On the World Ocean Day, let us recall that life on earth probably began in hydrothermal vents in the depths of the oceans. But it was not the ocean we know today. It was warmer, more acidic and rich in iron. As life evolved, the oceans continued to provide home to many living things. In fact, a greater number of organisms live in the oceans than on land. Covering more than 70 per cent of the earth‚Äôs surface, they are humanity‚Äôs most important natural resource. Oceans feed us, regulate our climate and generate most of the oxygen we breathe.
Unfortunately, they also face major threats: global climate change, pollution, habitat destruction, invasive species, and a dramatic decrease in ocean fish stocks. These threats to the ocean are so extensive that more than 40 percent of the ocean has already been severely affected and no area has been left untouched.
The World Ocean Day is a timely reminder to develop a shared vision of a sustainable use of oceans.
As for me, the ocean with its enormity and mystery, has always been a continuing source of enchantment. There is no music more relaxing than the rolling of ocean waves.
My most memorable trip along the ocean was in California highway 1. It is perhaps one of the most astoundingly scenic roads in the world. Smelling the salty and briny sea breeze of the Pacific Ocean, seeing its vastness and feeling so small in the middle of its quiet stillness‚Ä¶these are emotions only the ocean can stir.
Poets capture these moments beautifully, like in these words of Meena Alexander, ‚ÄúSometimes the syllables of poetry well up, waves on the surface of the sea, and they burst as flying fish might, struck by light.‚Äù
As TS Eliot wrote in Four Quartets, ‚ÄúThe river is within us, the sea is all about us, ‚Äù and we have to tend to both with sensitivity and concern‚Ä¶
08/06/22, 2:57‚ÄØpm
Oh what a beauty. The photograph conveys a lot! It really soars the spiritüôÇ
09/06/22, 8:28‚ÄØam
Sunset has always inspired poets.
Poets of the Sangam era (300 BCE to 300 CE) were no exception. Sangam literature contains 2381 poems in Tamil composed by 473 poets, It includes Tolkappiyam, Ettuthogai, Pattuppattu, Pathinenkilkanakku, and two epics, Silappathikaram and Manimegalai.
Kalithogai is part of the eight anthologies (Ettuthogai), It contains one hundred and fifty poems which were written by various authors. This particular one was written by the poet Nallanthuvan.
‡ÆÖ‡Æï‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æû‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ≥‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡ÆÜ‡Æï‡Æ™‡Øç

And joins the mountains
As if it swallowed the day

12/06/22, 9:14‚ÄØam
Today is Vaikasi Visakam which is celebrated as the birthday of Lord Muruga. Worship of Lord Muruga is interwoven with folk myths, personal and cultural histories. He has an unbounded and immortal presence across Tamil Nadu, inspiring intense devotion. A god who fosters multiple narratives, each and every community, has a story about their own divine ancestry featuring Lord Muruga.
Some of the earliest sculptural depictions of young Lord Muruga is in the Somaskandamurthy panels
which can be seen in the first freestanding temple in Tamil Nadu, the Kailasanatha Temple in Kanchipuram.
As we walk around the temple precincts, we can see many of these panels which portray Siva and Parvati with Skanda sitting on Parvati‚Äôs lap. In a larger depiction, (photgraph 1) Vishnu can also be seen in the back, in addition to Siva, Parvati and Skanda. Many of the small shrines that dot the inner wall of the courtyard have Somaskanda panels. One of them which attracted my attention was a striking portrayal with the remnants of vibrant hues adorning the back wall. Unfortunately, the face of Skanda has worn out with time. But its beauty and allure hasn‚Äôt faded‚Ä¶

Today is the birthday of WB Yeats. He wrote the poem ‚ÄúThe White Birds‚Äù the day after Maude Gonne, ‚Äúhis great unrequited love,‚Äù rejected his first marriage proposal. She had expressed the feeling that she would rather be a ‚Äúseagull‚Äù than any other bird. Yeats went along with this image and wrote this poem. Though never formalized by marriage vows their love did achieve literary immortality with this poem.

17/06/22, 7:04‚ÄØam
‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Øà ‡Æö‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øá ‡Æ®‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Ææ
‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ∞‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ±‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Øã‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Øá ‡Æ®‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Ææ
In the black colours of the crow
I have a glimpse you Nanda (Krishna)
These are the opening lines of ‚ÄúKaakai Siraginile,‚Äù one of the most beautiful poems of Mahakavi Bharathiyar. It is a simple octet with references to a crow‚Äôs feather and a tryst with fire in the quest of Nandalala, the young Krishna. As with most poems, a direct translation doesn‚Äôt do justice to the nuances of the song itself.
Why did the poet choose the crow?
Crows are generally considered scavengers and generally not portrayed in good light. As someone known for raising his voice against social injustice, was Bharathiyar implying that even in such creatures, he sees the divine nature of Krishna. Was he also indicating that people can see Him everywhere in nature?
The poem embodies the eternal truth that the seeker can perceive the presence of the formless in all its forms.
17/06/22, 4:11‚ÄØpm
Really food for thought Sir. It is very true that we detest crows and many have superstitions about sighting a crow. What a way to accept every creation in the universe and once again reinforcing the fact that focus should be Atman and not limited to body mind. And what a photograph because we rarely come across a crow being the subjectüëçüèª
18/06/22, 8:29‚ÄØam
Paul McCartney who is turning 80 today is a favourite singer of mine.
Shortly after returning from India where he was learning the art of Transcendental Meditation, he wrote "Blackbird" which was featured in the ‚ÄòWhite Album.‚Äô I keep listening to this tranquil guitar ballad often. This song was written solely by Paul McCartney. However, he acknowledged the role of John Lennon and hence the song goes under the name Lennon-McCartney.
Paul wrote this song on the background of the civil rights movement in US. The black bird in the song refers to a group of black students who faced racial discrimination in Little Rock Central High School Arkansas. As he said later, ‚ÄúThis was really a song from me to a black woman, experiencing these problems in the States. Let me encourage you to keep trying, to keep your faith; there is hope.‚Äô‚Äù
It is a song of empowerment, reflecting the singer‚Äôs longing for change.
No matter how dark our circumstances may be, there is always a glimmer of hope to be found..
Blackbird fly, blackbird fly
Into the light of a dark black night
21/06/22, 7:46‚ÄØam
Among all yoga asanas Vrksasana or tree pose is one of the most beautiful and serene one imbued with symbolic significance. It is also one of the oldest known yoga poses and is depicted in ancient sculptures.
An earliest representations is in ‚ÄúBhagiratha‚Äôs Penance‚Äù or ‚ÄúThe Descent of the Ganges‚Äù in Mahabalipuram which is dated to the 7th century. Bhagiratha stood in Vrksasana for one thousand years which persuaded Brahma and Shiva to create the Ganges.
In the first photograph one can notice a man standing on top left in the Vrksasana pose. Interestingly on the bottom right is a cat with a similar pose. Probably the cat is pretending to be a peaceful yogi fooling the mice (seen at its feet) before it eats them!
The second photo which portrays the asana in detail is from a pillar in the Thirukurungudi temple. It is slightly different from the former with one leg in Ardha Padmasana (Half-Lotus) and hands in Anjali Mudra (prayer position).
Symbolically, the tree is said to be strong and well grounded. It grows both upwards and downwards, ensuring stability. The grounding action of the standing leg represents the roots of a tree, and the stretching of the arms overhead represents the branches reaching upwards. It is believed that when one holds the pose, prana (life force) goes up facilitating the release of a transformative energy.
Dualities vanish
If, for a moment
We become a tree‚Ä¶
22/06/22, 11:24‚ÄØam
As I was listening to the enchanting pallavi of Oothukadu Venkata Subbaier krithi,
‚Äúkuzhaloodhi manamellaam kollaikondapinnum
kuraiyaedhum enakkaedhadi sakiyae
When he plays his flute and takes hold of my heart
Will I ever be discontented my friend? (my translation)
I remembered that yesterday was the World Music Day.
Lord Krishna is inseparable from his flute and the lure of his music is irresistible.
One of the most beautiful depiction of this is in the Chitra Gopuram of Thirukurungudi temple in Tirunelveli district.
Carved with exquisite detail, it portrays Lord Krishna holding the flute with his two hands with shanku and chakra on the other two hands. The sages, devatas, cowherds, people, animals and birds are totally entranced by the mellifluous music emanating from the flute. The snake at his feet is no exception. The sculptor animates the scene by portraying a mischievous monkey stealing butter from the cowherd!
There is a beautiful story about how Radha is jealous of the flute because it is always with the Lord. Once she asks the flute, ‚Äúwhat is it that you have which I lack, that he is always with you?" The flute replies: "Perhaps he likes me because I am empty."
When we empty ourselves, the lord enters and fills that space.
22/06/22, 10:51‚ÄØpm

25/06/22, 7:48‚ÄØam
Sand dunes have an irresistible charm, especially in the desert landscape.
Several years ago we ventured onto the sand dunes of Khuri and spent the night there.
It was an unforgettable experience.
Lying down on the sand I saw nothing but a vast expanse of dark, nocturnal sky, radiant with sparkling, shimmering stars. It was a starry night straight out of Vincent van Gogh‚Äôs palette and I took his suggestion, ‚ÄúIt often seems to me that the night is even more richly coloured than the day‚Ä¶if you look carefully, you‚Äôll see that some stars are lemony, others have a pink, green, forget-me-not blue glow.‚Äù
The wind was sculpting millions of fine sand particles to form tantalizing shapes with remarkable patterns.
Every sand particle brushing against my hands was an experience.
As Rachel Carson commented ‚Äúin every grain of sand there is the story of the earth.‚Äù
I can still feel those grains of sand in the hour glass of my memory‚Ä¶.
(On the occasion of the World Sand Dune Day!)

04/07/22, 8:21‚ÄØam
As humans we have the privilege to express ourselves through our speech. On many occasions we find that a simple gesture of the hand can express our thoughts equally well and perhaps much better.
Specific hand gestures that symbolize and convey various meanings are referred to as Mudras. Mudra Vidhanam, written by Anna and published by Ramakrishna Mutt lists at least 137 mudras. When a sculptor creates a deity, he adds various mudras to express the idea symbolized by it.
For instance look at these images. First one is from Gangaikondacholapuram and the second from the bronze gallery from Chennai museum. You will notice the gesture of the right hand, where the forefinger is joined with the thumb and the other three fingers remain separate. This is often referred to as Chinmudra.
The thumb represents Brahman because without the thumb the hand cannot function. The middle, ring and the small finger represents the body, mind and intellect respectively. Index finger represents the ego because it keeps pointing at others most of the times! When we hold our hand normally the index finger is attached to the other three fingers and is far away from the thumb. This indicates that we normally think of ourselves as the body, mind and intellect, separate from the Brahman. As long as we have this notion, we will have a beginning and an end. When the index finer (ego) separates itself from the body/mind/ intellect and unites with the thumb (representing the Brahman), it forms a circle, which has no beginning and end. It symbolizes the union of the jivatma with the Paramatma, which is the essence of all realisation.
Some symbols convey the deeper meanings with sublime simplicity‚Ä¶
04/07/22, 1:13‚ÄØpm
Very enlightening Sir!!
06/07/22, 10:08‚ÄØam
Dalai Lama whose birthday is today has an enduring, deep impact on me.
When I met him several years ago, I was enveloped in his ‚Äòbeing‚Äô which emanates love and immense kindness‚Ä¶it seemed to flow from a profound, unending source.
His way of analyzing conflict through the lens of compassion and resilience continues to guide me in my personal and professional life.
07/07/22, 4:30‚ÄØpm
