22/01/22, 9:58‚ÄØam
Thich Nhat Hanh passed away today‚Ä¶
Over the years, he had a significant impact on me personally and professionally, through his teachings on mindfulness and compassion.
As he remarked, ‚ÄúThe Buddha taught that there is no birth; there is no death; there is no coming; there is no going; there is no same; there is no different; there is no permanent self; there is no annihilation. We only think there is.‚Äù
He did not want his followers to build a stupa, but if they did build one, he told them they should add three signs on it: ‚ÄúI am not in here.‚Äù ‚ÄúI am not out there either.‚Äù ‚ÄúIf I am anywhere, it is in your mindful breathing and in your peaceful steps.‚Äù
He was a ‚Äòspiritual exemplar‚Äô and a source of inspiration for the environmental movement.
When I took a walk a few years ago in the woods behind Angkor Wat, I was reminded of his words‚Ä¶
05/02/22, 9:22‚ÄØam
Basant Panchami which is being celebrated today heralds the arrival of spring and is imbued with many legends. The most popular association is with Saraswati, the goddess of knowledge, language and music who is deemed to have been born on this day.
Amongst the many legends concerning Basant Panchami, there is one which revolves around Kama and his role in bringing Lord Shiva and Parvati together. Shiva, mourning the death of his wife Sati/Uma, retreated to the Himalayas and became a reclusive ascetic. Parvati, a reincarnation of Sati, told her father King Himavat that she would marry only Shiva. When informed of this, Shiva declined and walked away without even a glance at Parvati. Undaunted, she waited for many years but couldn‚Äôt win him over. The Gods intervened and approached Kamadeva to wake Shiva from his deep meditation and make him fall in love with Parvati. Heeding to their request, Kamadeva shot his five arrows of love, one of which distracted Shiva, who got bewitched by Paravati‚Äôs beauty. But as soon as he realized it was Kamadeva‚Äôs ruse, he opened the third eye and reduced him to ashes. Deeply distressed by this, Rati undertook an austere penance for 40 days to Shiva. Shiva finally relented and brought Kamadeva back to life on the day of Basant Panchami. On this day Kamadeva and Rati descend on earth ushering in the first fragrant breeze of spring, a season or rebirth and renewal. This is one of the reasons as to why Basant Panchami is also associated with Shringara Rasam.
This beautifully carved sculpture of Kamadeva and Rati is from the western groups of temples at Khajuraho.
It is not a so well-known fact that the Muslim community has been celebrating Basant Panchami since the 12th century A.D. According to legend, Delhi's Chishti Saint Nizamuddin Aulia's young nephew Taqiuddin Nooh died in this month. Stricken with grief, he withdrew himself. The famous court poet, Amir Khusrau, tried to think of ways to brighten the Saint's mood. Then Khusrau noticed some young women dressed in yellow clothes, adorned with yellow flowers of marigold who were celebrating Basant Utsav. Seeing this, an idea struck Khusrau, who immediately donned a yellow ghaagra, covered his face with a chunni, hung garlands of yellow marigold around his neck, went to the Saint and began dancing and singing, ‚ÄúAaj Basant Manaaley Suhagan‚Ä¶Aaj Basant Manaaley Suhagan‚Äù. Seeing this spectacle and knowing it was Khusrau under the woman‚Äôs garb who was singing and dancing with gay abandon, Nizamuddin Aulia burst out laughing and his spell of gloom was swiftly lifted. He then went to the grave of his nephew and sang: ‚ÄòAshq rayz ameedan abro bahar‚Äô (‚ÄòShed tears of joy at the coming of spring and the clouds‚Äô). Since then, Basant Panchami is being celebrated at the dargah of Nizamuddin Aulia in Delhi and all dargah's of the Chishti order.
Basant, the season of spring, has also inspired many ragas in Indian music. In the north, there are Basant, Basant Bahar and Basant Mukhari and in the south, Vasantam, Hindola Vasantam, Shuddha Vasantam, Vasanta Varali, and Vasanta Bhairavi. Each one of them embodies the spirit of spring.
On this day let us celebrate the cultural syncretism associated with this festival in the subcontinent and spend the day savouring and immersing ourselves in these ragas!
07/02/22, 8:33‚ÄØam
Rathasapthamai which is being celebrated today marks the movement of sun (Surya) turning his ‚Äúratham‚Äù (chariot) drawn by Saptha (seven) horses from winter solstice to (Dakshinayanam) to the summer solstice (Uttarayanam).
The worship of Surya is deep rooted in antiquity. Sun has been an object of reverence and worship from the start of human settlements and has been represented symbolically in the pottery and seals of ancient civilizations. The transformation of Surya from a symbolic form to an anthropomorphic figure occurred during the Rig Vedic period. In the process of providing a form to the formless an iconic tradition started and Surya was represented in various human forms across different parts of India. The Agama tradition further specified details of depiction of the sun god. One of the most beautiful representation of Surya according to the Suprabhedagama tradition is in at the Virupaksha temple in Pattadakkal. This temple was built by Queen Loka Mahadevi after the successful military campaign of King Vikramaditya II against the Pallavas. Within the dark interiors of the temple, the inner ceiling in the east has this intricately carved image of Surya.
At the center of this intricately carved bas-relief is Surya, the sun god, riding a seven-horse chariot. He is standing majestically in the chariot holding a lotus flower with each hand, and surrounding his head is a halo of rays emanating outwards. Behind him are the two-headed mythical creatures (Makaras), disgorging yakshas. Accompanying him are his consorts Ushas (Goddess of Dawn) and Chhaya (Goddess of Shadow). Both Ushas and Chhaya are pointing their bows upwards, indicating that they are fighting the darkness. At the bottom of the panel is Aruna, Surya‚Äôs charioteer, holding the reins of seven horses, representing the days of the week. The seven horses are named as Gayatri, Brihati, Ushnih, Jagati, Trishtubha, Anushtubha and Pankti.
Perhaps one of the most exquisite delineation of the attributes of the sun god is in the composition of Muthiswamy Dikshitar ‚ÄòSurya Murte Namostute‚Äô set to raga Sourashtram.
The spiritual connotations of the Sun have been brought out vividly by Rabindranath Tagore: ‚ÄúOne day while I stood watching at early dawn the Sun sending out its rays from behind the trees, I suddenly felt as if some ancient mist had in a moment lifted from my sight and the morning light on the face of the world revealed an inner radiance of joy. The invisible screen of the commonplace was removed from all things and all of mankind and this ultimate significance was intensified in my mind and this is the definition of beauty.‚Äù
08/02/22, 9:34‚ÄØam
Bhishma or Bhishma Pitamaha was one of the most charismatic characters in Mahabharata and was respected by both the Kauravas and the Pandavaas. His original name was Devavrata and he was the son of King Shantanu and Ganga. His father wanted to marry a fisherwoman, Stayavati, who insisted that only sons born to her should succeed Shantanu to the throne. To facilitate this, Devavrata took a vow of celibacy for life and also pledged to serve anyone who ascended the throne of Hastinapura.
In the battle of Mahabharata, the Pandavas were unable to make any headway even after many days mainly due to the skill and valour of Bhishma. At this point, Shikhandi, who was born a woman, positioned herself in front of Arjuna to fight against Bhishma. Bhishma knew that Shikhandi was born a woman, who had a grudge against Bhishma because he had interfered in her marriage. Seeing Shikhandi, Bhishma refused to fight and was felled by Arjuna‚Äôs arrow. It is believed that Bhishma himself had hinted at this ploy while Arjuna and Krishna met him the previous night.
Arjuna‚Äôs arrows had already formed a bed and Bhishma did not fall to the ground. Arjuna used more arrows to form a pillow. As the battle raged, Bhishma held on till Uttarayana to die as he had the boon of ‚ÄòIchcha Mrityu‚Äô, the ability to choose one‚Äôs time of death.
It is believed that Bhishma revealed the Vishnu Sahasranama Stotram to the Pandavas in the presence of Lord Krishna, an incarnation of Lord Vishnu, on this day which is celebrated as Bhishma Ashtami.
The battle of Kurukshetra is carved into the southern section of the west gallery, which is located on the perimeter of the lower level of the Angkor Wat. This is a depiction of Bhishma on a bed of arrows. Interestingly it is said that a beam of sunrays falls on this image during the winter solstice
08/02/22, 12:27‚ÄØpm
Yes Sir. He waited till Uttarayana Punyakala. The carving of Bhishmacharya is beautiful and rare. In fact we celebrate Ratha saptami today. Thanks again for the reminder of the event in Mahabharata.
14/02/22, 8:23‚ÄØam
As John Paul Young sang, ‚ÄúLove is in the air, everywhere I look around, Love is in the air, every sight and every sound.‚Äù It is also the time when love turns into serious business in the guise of Valentine‚Äôs Day. But what is the real story behind Valentine?
While Valentine‚Äôs Day might be associated with romantic love, the real story behind its namesake, Valentine, is full of bloodshed and heart break. He was reported to have had healing powers, especially for those ailing from epilepsy. According to one legend, Valentine signed a letter ‚Äúfrom your Valentine‚Äù to his jailer‚Äôs daughter, whom he had befriended and healed her from blindness. Another legend states that he defied the emperor‚Äôs orders and secretly married couples to spare the husbands from war. Unhappy with his actions, Emperor Claudius ordered that he be put to death and he was beheaded. Neither written nor material evidence from the pre-medieval period associates Valentine with love or lovers. Scholars credit Geoffrey Chaucer for turning Valentine into the patron of love. In his Parlement of Foules he wrote, ‚Äúseynt Volantynys day/ Whan euery bryd comyth there to chese his make. (Saint Valentine‚Äôs day, when every bird comes there to choose his mate.) Chaucer was a major influencer in his day ‚Äì after him, everyone began calling their beloved ‚ÄúValentine‚Äù and writing love poems on 14 February.
Closer home there is a more suitable mythological character, Kamadeva. He has many names: he is called ‚ÄúRagavrunt‚Äù, ‚ÄúAnanga‚Äù, ‚ÄúKandarp‚Äù, ‚ÄúManmath‚Äù, ‚ÄúMansija‚Äù, ‚ÄúMadana‚Äù, ‚ÄúRatikant‚Äù, ‚ÄúPushpvan‚Äù and ‚ÄúPushpdhanv‚Äù. Kama has a variety of meanings, ranging from sensuality to aesthetic enjoyment, although its overtones are predominantly sexual in the popular imagination. It is also a misconception that kama means love, kama literally means trishNa(Sanskrit), desire or thirst.
There are striking parallels between the depiction of Kamadeva and Cupid. Both carry a bow and a quiver of arrows. Kamadeva‚Äôs bow is made of sugarcane and is sugar coated with the bowstring soaked in honey. Arrows are decorated with flowers and the flowers on his arrows are: Aravinda(White Lotus), Ashoka, Cuta (Mango Flower), Navamalika (Jasmine), and Nilotpala (Blue Lotus). Kamadeva carries five kind of arrows with him: Maran, Stambhan, Jrumbhan, Shoshan and Ummadan. Kamadeva‚Äôs five arrows are associated with five effects. The first arrow is aimed at the heart and it causes initial excitement and a youthful cheerfulness. The second arrow is aimed at the lips and it causes one to cry out of this excitement. The third arrow is aimed at the head/brain and it makes one lose their mind / go crazy with love. The fourth arrow is aimed at the eyes which makes one see things. The fifth arrow is basically designed to hit anywhere causing the person to totally be absorbed with love.
There are no temples solely dedicated to Kamadeva in India. However, in Assam there is a shrine for him called Madana-Kamadeva temple. Situated in a dense forest, this temple has some marvellous sculptures but unfortunately the structure is quite dilapidated.
This particular sculpture of Kamadeva is from a small temple at Krishnapuram in Tirunelveli district. It is an astounding sculpture crafted out of a single stone and is exquisitely carved. He is holding the bow made of sugarcane, which is so well hewn that if one drops a pin into the hole on top of the bow, it comes out at the bottom! Unfortunately, in the process of testing this out, people have broken part of the bow, the bane of many a sculpture in India. The sculpture now is encircled within a steel enclosure to prevent further damage to it.
There is a mantra dedicated to Kamadeva which reads:
Aum Kamadevaye Vidmahe
Pushpa banaye dhimahi
Tanno Ananga Prachodayat
Oh let me meditate to the God of Love
He who carries an arrow made of flowers
May that Ananga (who is without a body) bestow upon me higher intellect and illuminate my mind.
Purusartha is a key concept in Hinduism and refers to the four important goals of human life. They are Dharma (righteousness, moral values); Artha (prosperity, economic values); Kama (pleasure, love) and Moksha (liberation, spiritual values). The path to enlightenment or Moksha is facilitated by the harmonious interaction of Dharma, Artha, and Kama.
Ultimately, the highest Kama is the longing for Oneness with the Divine.
14/02/22, 6:18‚ÄØpm
Oh. What a detailed description Sir. But the story behind Valentine's day leaves one with bitter taste in mouth. Our culture has more angles to the concept of love and it is one of the goals, in the limits of Dharma. Thank you Sir for throwing light on the details and the sculpture which is so bright and glowing!
16/02/22, 4:04‚ÄØpm
Siva is worshipped in various anthropomorphic forms. His facial depiction usually encompasses five different representations: Satyojatam, Vamadevam, Tatpurusham, Esanam and Agoram. The last one in turn has five forms, one of which is Gajasamharamurti. He is also worshipped as Ayurdevata, which is mentioned in Ayush suktam of Rig Veda which also mentions Him by the Sanskrit name Krithivasa.
According to legend, once 30,000 sages, who were meditating at Tarukavanam, challenged the omnipotence of Lord Siva. They created many wild creatures through sacrificial fire to kill Siva, but in vain. Finally, they sent an elephant demon (Gajasura). But Siva, dwarfing Himself entered the elephant‚Äôs body and then assumed his original form only to slay the demon and emerged wearing its skin. Sages who saw this divine event shed their pride and arrogance and took refuge in Siva. Symbolically the mad elephant represents, anger, ignorance and pride. When we take refuge in Siva, he slays all these demons within us.
There is also a reference to Gajasamharamurti in Kalidasa‚Äôs ‚ÄòKumarasambhavam.‚Äô According to it was demon Nila who came in the form of an elephant to kill Siva. Learning about it, Nandi ordered Veerabadra to slay Nila. Veerabadra killed the demon and presented the skin (charma) to Siva, who wore it while on his way to vanquish Antakasura. Hence he is also referred to as Gajacharmambara.
The only temple dedicated to Gajasamharamurti is at Vazhuvoor in Mayiladuthurai district, Tamil Nadu and it is believed to be the site where Lord Siva killed Gajasura, the elephant demon, and wore his hide around him.
There are many sculptural depictions of Gajasamharamurti. The most attractive one is at the Hoysaleswara temple at Halebid. He is depicted in a dancing posture with his right foot on the demon Gajasura. The lifted left leg is so delicately carved that one can even see the arch of the heel! The two hands on the top are positioned high, holding the elephant‚Äôs skin which is surrounding the God like a Prabavalli. He is holding trishul, damaru, kapala and Khadaga amongst others. He is wearing a tall crown with several small skulls inscribed on it. Several rings can be seen on his fingers. A highly ornate belt called Mekhala is adoring his midriff. As he dances inside the elephant his jewellery is swinging too! Nandi is on his right hand side, looking out. On the left are various Ganas playing the drums. One of them is even adjusting the ropes of the drum to tune it! To his right is Nandi and to the left two ganas playing mrudanga can be seen in the lower part of the carvings. The entire sculpture is suffused with elegance conveying a delicate sense of balance.
Today is Masi magam and among the many legends associated with it, is that of Gajasamharam, reminding us to destroy our ego and surrender ourselves at the feet of the divine.
16/02/22, 9:53‚ÄØpm
Such a beautiful rendering Sir. I didn't know this. I think all the Puranas Vedas Upanishads talk about the same, the jist that you have highlighted in the end. We need to keep reminding ourselves the same and sampoorna sharanagathi helps in destroying our ahankara. I took time to read the above and observing the sculpture. No words to express the deftness of the sculpture.
17/02/22, 12:58‚ÄØpm
Yesterday while detailing about Gajasamharamurti I had mentioned that the event took place in Tharukavanam. The rishis living in the forest became very arrogant as they had mastered all the 'Vedas', 'Agamas' and 'Shastras' and could raise powerful creatures from the sacrificial fires to do their bidding. Lord Siva wished to show these rishis their limitations and appeared as a handsome mendicant. This created chaos in 'Tharukavanam' as the wives of the rishis fell under the spell of this charming, handsome mendicant. The rishis became very angry, raised an elephant to destroy Siva, which he eventually destroyed.
This very small frieze in Sri Vanamamalai Perumal temple at Nanguneri dating back to 13th century, depicts Siva dancing as a mendicant in the middle with ganas at his feet surrounded by rishipatnis.
17/02/22, 1:09‚ÄØpm
Oh...when 'I know everything' gets into head this is what happens. Whether it is a Rishi or mortals like us üôÑ We have forgotten what our culture has given us, the message given by scriptures and sculptures.
21/02/22, 12:07‚ÄØpm
I love Bar Headed Geese! They are amazing travellers! They breed in massive colonies near mountain lakes in Mongolia and when the cold starts to overcome them, fly thousands of miles to winter in South Asia and come down to South India too in large numbers. As someone suggested these dainty birds are able achieve what the fearsome Genghis Khan was unable to do!
When we heard that they are back in Hadinaru Lake near Mysore, myself and Ahalya took a much needed break after a year of prolonged stay at home and headed there. We were welcomed by their chorus of clucks as we went near the lake and it was such a wonderful sight to see hundreds of them resting and frolicking in the water. A sight to behold‚Ä¶
I had written a detailed account about these birds‚Ä¶do have a look at: https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/soaring-high-on-graceful-wings
24/02/22, 9:08‚ÄØam
The formidable looking dwarapalaka are the door-keepers of temples. The name dwarapalaka is a combination of two words Dwaram and Palakas: Dwaram stands for door or entrance and the Palakas for guardians. Carved in pairs, they are the protectors of the main deity and are typically depicted as huge and robust warriors. One can find them at the entrance to the temple and also at the doorway to the sanctum. Their iconography differs according to whether they are in a Shiva or Vaishnava shrines.
One of the outstanding representations of dwaraplakas is at the 14th century vaidyanatheshwara temple at talakadu. Here he is seen holding trishula in his top right hand and a damaru entwined by a snake is in his top left hand. His right hand at the front holds gada (mace) and his left hand at the front is in abhaya mudra. He is wearing a Kirita, and the entire body is adorned with exquisitely chiselled jewellery.
This dwarapalaka is quite distinctive from any others! Look carefully at his chest and abdomen and you can recognize the face of nandi, the vahana of Shiva!
I stood there for some time, totally mesmerized by this marvellous sculpture by an unknown artisan who seems to have dipped his chisel in his soul to create this masterpiece.
01/03/22, 8:58‚ÄØam
According to one of the legends, Mahashivaratri is the day Lord Shiva got married to Parvati.
Goddess Sati took birth as Parvati, the daughter of Himavan to marry Lord Shiva. She practised intense penance to win over Lord Shiva's heart. After years of Tapasya at the Gauri Kund, Parvati finally succeeded in convincing Lord Shiva to accept her as his wife. Shiva reportedly proposed to Parvati at Guptakashi and then tied the nuptial knot at Triyuginarayan. The celestial marriage of Lord Shiva and Parvati took place in the presence of Lord Brahma, who turned a priest to conduct the ceremony and Lord Vishnu, who performed the duties of the bride's brother. The Agni that was witness to the wedding ceremony still exists in the form of an eternal flame, Akhand Dhuni, near the temple.
This 17th century mural at Veerabadra temple at Lepakshi depicts the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. Shiva is shown wearing the characteristic tiger skin, carrying the deer and axe in the upper hands. Parvati, escorted by attendants stands in front of Shiva, her head slightly bent. She is seen carrying a lotus in her left hand while offering the right hand to Shiva. Do not fail to notice a diminutive Nandi jumping joyfully between the couple! To the left of Paravati is her father Himavan who is carrying a kamandala in his raised hand and is about to solemnize the wedding by pouring water on the hands of the couple. Brahma is seen sitting in front of the sacred fire performing various rituals.
When I first visited the temple, the murals covered with years of dirt and soot were hardly visible in the dark interiors of the place. Thankfully a careful restoration has brought them alive now, even though some details have been lost. Unquestionably they are the finest examples of mural paintings of the Vijayanagar period.
08/03/22, 10:38‚ÄØam
Feminity was not viewed as a weak trait in Hindu mythology. The greatest example is Goddess Durga. She transformed herself into many different avatars, depending on the situation she had to confront, much like a woman in modern times deftly negotiating many different, demanding roles. This dexterity and resolve needs to be recognised, appreciated and celebrated‚Ä¶not just on this International Woman‚Äôs Day!
This exquisite sculpture of Durga is from Bhoganandeeswara temple.
08/03/22, 11:56‚ÄØam
Very true Sir. Parents play an important role in nurturing the above and partners to be aware of it. Wonderful sculpture, not just to be idolized!
18/03/22, 11:58‚ÄØam
Colours play an important role in the festival of Holi. They add vitality to the festival, making it one of the most vibrant of celebrations. Each of the colours is deemed to have a symbolic significance. Blue for instance is the colour of Krishna's complexion and also of the sky and the oceans.
And colours are the smiles of nature.
Birds are beautiful jewels in the sky. There are many brightly coloured birds in the world, and the most flamboyant ones are the parrots. During our birding sojourn in Australia, Ahalya and myself saw some of the most multihued parrots, prominent among them being the Rainbow Lorikeet.
Rainbow Lorikeet, definitely deserves its name! True to its name, one can see all the colour palettes of rainbow in its feathers. Its head is deep blue with a greenish-yellow nuchal collar, and the rest of the upper parts (wings, back, and tail) are green. The chest is orange/yellow in colour. The belly is deep blue, and the thighs and rump are green. Their species name, haematodus, comes from the Latin word for blood, and is a reference to the rich red found on its breast.
The colour of the feathers of birds serves various functions; thermoregulation, climatic adaptation and a fine balance between sexual signalling and camouflage. Birds need to balance being attractive to potential mates while having some kind of camouflage against potential predators. When hunted from above, the Rainbow Lorikeet blends with the foliage of the trees with its green back. It has been suggested that the colourful patches confer evolutionary advantage in courtship and mate recognition.
Rainbow lorikeets have two unique features. They possess a tongue with brush-type tissues helping them to collect nectar and pollen. The other distinctive feature is their agile legs which help them to hang upside-down and feed on bottlebrush flowers. It is a dazzling sight when flocks of them fly with the rays of the sun streaming through their gorgeous plumage!
On the occasion of Holi, in the words of Maya Angelou, let us ‚ÄúTry to be a rainbow in someone‚Äôs cloud.‚Äù
28/03/22, 1:01‚ÄØpm
Search for the infinite starts from the stillness within!
07/04/22, 11:02‚ÄØam
Each of the lecture theatres in JIPMER were named after a historical medical luminary and their portrait used to be displayed outside. Every time I entered theatre Bernard I used to be fascinated by a painting which depicted him in a deeply reflective mood. Claude Bernard was an exceptional man. He posited that there is a delicate balance between physiological processes within the human body and the environment outside of it. He termed them as ‚Äòmilieu interior‚Äô and ‚Äòmilieu exterior‚Äô. He drew attention to how physiological mechanisms are crucial in maintaining constancy of the internal environment to sustain a status of health in response to changes in the external environment.
Understandably over the years medical professionals have focused their attention on the internal environment to preserve individual health. Unfortunately, in the process, the crucial role of the environment in which we are immersed everyday in our lives and its vital role in modulating individual health has been lost sight of.
On the occasion of the World Health today and on the background of looming climate changes, it is imperative to remind ourselves that climate crisis is health crisis. Our health is intricately related to health of the planet and we should strive to make every effort to conserve and protect the Mother Earth.
07/04/22, 7:24‚ÄØpm
Oh. Yes Sir. It is something which all of us should focus on. I think we are already in the downward trend and contributed heavily to the extremes in the climate. Man has become extremely self centered and doesn't know he is destroying himself by showing a callous attitude to our mother earthü§î
09/04/22, 11:36‚ÄØam
Navratri is celebrated in different seasons, five times a year across our country. They are Chaitra Navratri, Ashadha Navratri, the Sharada Navratri, and the Paush/Magha Navratri. Of these, the Sharada Navratri heralds the onset of autumn and the Chaitra Navratri the season of spring. Today is the date of Shukla Paksha Ashtami of Chaitra month, also referred to as Maha Ashtami, dedicated to Goddess Durga.
One of the outstanding depictions of Goddess Durga slaying the demon Mahishasura is at the 13th century Hoysala temple at Somanathapura. The Devi is seen triumphantly standing on top of the he buffalo that appears to have fallen on the ground. Mahishasura is seen emerging from the body of the buffalo. If you look carefully, you can notice Mahisha‚Äôs intestines coming out of his stomach! Standing to the left of the Goddess is her vehicle, a partly broken lion, which is seen killing an asura. Even though some of the arms Goddess Durga are missing or broken, the vigour and vitality in depiction is a tribute to the sculptor Mallithamma, who sculptures adorn many Hoysala temples.
10/04/22, 5:54‚ÄØam
https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/avani
India has many interesting places associated with Ramayana where the legend comes alive.
On the occasion of Ramanavami, let me take you to Avani, a small town in Kolar, Karnataka.
Soaked in antiquity the 10th century Ramalingeshwara temple at Avani and the looming hill behind it is the site of Uttara Ramayana and has incredible stories associated with it.
Read on and savor the rich architectural heritage of the place.
Kindly post your comments in the blog and not in Facebook!

18/04/22, 8:30‚ÄØam
Today is the World Heritage Day and the theme this year is ‚ÄúHeritage and Climate‚Äù.
On this occasion let me introduce you to Ashtadikpalakas, divine guardians of eight directions of the universe.
The ceiling near the sanctum of a temple is often considered to symbolically represent the sky and Ashtadikpalakas are sculpted in it.
One of most exquisite depictions of them is at Ramalingeshwara temple at Avani.
Do read on, have a glimpse of these guardians and feel free to post your comments in the blog! https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/ashtadikpalakas

01/05/22, 8:59‚ÄØam
Balmy Alley in the Mission District of San Francisco has some of the finest murals and street art that I have ever seen.
On the occasion of the May Day, let me draw attention to one of the most iconic murals of the alley, Naya Bihana or A New Dawn. It depicts three generations of Nepalese women toiling in the fields beneath the Himalayas. To the right, one determined-looking woman breaks the chains of oppression while others stand with their fists in the air. It is a persuasive visual narration of empowerment of a community collectively resisting injustice and regaining leverage to effect change.
03/05/22, 10:26‚ÄØam
Basavanna whose birthday is today, was a revolutionary saint and an ardent social reformer. He composed vachanas in simple language, which are very thought provoking. This particular one translated by AK Ramanujan is my favourite.
He outlines as to how various parts of a temple are analogous to several body parts and a temple is the primordial template of the human body. Though the rich may construct temples to show their wealth and power, Basavanna highlights that our body is itself is a temple which houses the immortal god.
The last lines: things standing shall fall, but the moving will ever stay, is so prescient. A temple built with stones and mortar might fall but the immortal spirit will move on, not confined to the physical space.
Words from a thousand years ago never ring more true now‚Ä¶.
05/05/22, 7:58‚ÄØam
Dedicated to Lord Cheluvanarayana Swamy or Thirunarayana, Melukote is a small but beautiful temple in Mandya district, Karnataka. On the occasion of 1005th birth anniversary of Sri Ramanujacharya, let us explore his association to this place.
Sri Ramanujacharya was one of the most important exponents of the Sri Vaishnavism tradition and spent major part of his life at Srirangam. To avoid persecution, Sri Ramanujacharya had to leave the place and after travelling along the course of Cauvery, he reached Thondanur, a flourishing centre of Jain theology, ruled then by the Hoysala king Bitti Deva. Bittideva, a Jain king of the region became his ardent disciple and in the process, changed his own name to Vishnuvardhana. According to the legend one day Sri Ramanujacharya was running short of the white sand to put a holy mark on his forehead. That night, Lord Tirunarayana came in his dream and instructed Sri Ramanujacharya to go to Melukote where he would find the white sand as also a deity of Lord Tirunarayana. After intense search, the deity of the Lord Tirunarayana was found near an anthill and a temple was erected over the it, over time.
Prior to this, there was an old temple in Melukote which was destroyed by invaders who plundered its wealth and also took away the Utsavamurthy, ‚ÄòCheluva Pillai‚Äô to Delhi. Lord Tirunarayana once again appeared in Sri Ramanujacharya‚Äôs dream and instructed him to bring the deity back to Melukote. He travelled to Delhi and found that the idol was with the king‚Äôs daughter who was treating the deity as her spouse. When she came to know that the idol was about to be taken away from her, she could not bear the separation and travelled back to Melukote along with it. After reaching Melukote, she started meditating in front of the temple as she was not allowed inside. Noticing her intense devotion and dedication, Sri Ramanujacharya allowed her inside and she merged with the Lord. Sri Ramanujacharya installed an idol of Bibi Nachiyar which is worshipped along with the main deity, even today.
This legend is remarkably parallel to that of Tulukka Nachiyar in Srirangam.
These narratives inform us that in spite of instances of intense interfaith crises, there have always been moments of remarkable synergy in our history.
07/05/22, 5:41‚ÄØpm
Oh what a photograph Sir. No words. But words from a writer, poet, artist like Rabindranth Tagore apt for the photograph!

11/05/22, 1:48‚ÄØpm
Another initiatve from Wayanad Girijana Seva Trust which we support. "SRI SARDA SEVA MEDICAL CLINIC" under Wayanad Girijana Seva Trust has started functioning at Niravilpuzha town Wayanad from 1st May 2022 onwards with medical consultation & Lab/ pharmacy etc.in full fledge everyday from 07.30 morning to 4.30 evening except Sunday. The service to tribals & poors is free whereas the others are charged with reasonable fees. Tele-medicine service is also rendered by a prominent doctor in Wayanad Dr. Jithendranath Krishnan through the clinic.
Moreover, in order to extend medical care to those poor tribes who are bedriddren due to prolonged illness and are unable to reach this unit, care will be made available to them.
16/05/22, 8:19‚ÄØam
On the Buddha Purnima day, it is interesting to note that all the important events in his life were associated with trees. He was born under a sal tree and he experienced his first deep meditation under a rose-apple tree. Years later, his enlightenment took place under a Bodhi tree and he attained Mahaparinirvana lying between two mighty sal trees. Buddha considered a kind person to be like a banyan tree, growing along road side offering respite and succour to the tired traveller with its cool shade.
This panel in Sanchi portrays a banyan (Nyagrodha) tree with a throne beneath (representing Buddha). For several weeks after attaining the enlightenment, Buddha was hesitant and diffident to make known The Truth to the world. Then Brahma, Indra, the four Lokapalas (Regents of the Four Quarters) and the archangels of the heavens approached him and implored him to expound his revelations. The four figures side by side in the foreground are the four Lokapalas. The nyagrodha tree symbolizes the principle that a seemingly insignificant cause can produce a great effect, just as the tiny seed of the nyagrodha develops into an sprawling tree.
Nyagrodha also figures in an interesting narrative in the Chandogya Upanishad. Uddalaka a great saint sent his son Svetaketu when he was twelve, to the ashram of a renowned teacher for studies. Svetaketu was a bright boy and in twelve years, he mastered all scriptures that could be taught. Seeing a man proud of his knowledge, his father asked him, ‚ÄúDo you know that by knowing which all can be known? That which cannot be taught but can only be known?‚Äù He asked the boy to get a fruit of the Nyagrodha tree, cut it open, and remove a seed. He then asked him what he saw. ‚ÄúNothing‚Äù the boy replied. ‚ÄúThat is the subtlest essence of all. That essence that you do not perceive, from that arises the big tree. That essence is the reality. That essence is the Spirit of whole universe. That which cannot be explained or taught but by knowing which you know all there is to know.‚Äù. Then the Sage took his son in to his arms and whispered this great truth in to his ear, ‚ÄúYou are THAT, Svetaketu. Tat Tvam Asi
Religious orientations and teachings may differ but the search for ultimate reality stems from the underlying interconnectedness of individual and universal consciousness.
As Thich Nhat Hanh commented perceptively about this quest, ‚ÄúThe mind can go in a thousand directions, but on this beautiful path, I walk in peace. With each step, the wind blows. With each step, a flower blooms.‚Äù
16/05/22, 8:29‚ÄØam
On the Buddha Purnima day, it is interesting to note that all the important events in his life were associated with trees. He was born under a sal tree and he experienced his first deep meditation under a rose-apple tree. Years later, his enlightenment took place under a Bodhi tree and he attained Mahaparinirvana lying between two mighty sal trees. Buddha considered a kind person to be like a banyan tree, growing along road side offering respite and succour to the tired traveller with its cool shade.
This panel in Sanchi portrays a banyan (Nyagrodha) tree with a throne beneath (representing Buddha). For several weeks after attaining the enlightenment, Buddha was hesitant and diffident to make known The Truth to the world. Then Brahma, Indra, the four Lokapalas (Regents of the Four Quarters) and the archangels of the heavens approached him and implored him to expound his revelations. The four figures side by side in the foreground are the four Lokapalas. The nyagrodha tree symbolizes the principle that a seemingly insignificant cause can produce a great effect, just as the tiny seed of the nyagrodha develops into an sprawling tree.

That which cannot be taught but can only be known?‚Äù He asked the boy to get a fruit of the Nyagrodha tree, cut it open, and remove a seed. He then asked him what he saw. ‚ÄúNothing‚Äù the boy replied. ‚ÄúThat is the subtlest essence of all. That essence that you do not perceive, from that arises the big tree. That essence is the reality. That essence is the Spirit of whole universe. That which cannot be explained or taught but by knowing which you know all there is to know.‚Äù. 18/05/22, 6:24‚ÄØam
I lose myself in a museum!
Whenever we trave,l we make it a point to savor the museums of the place, leisurely.
As you stroll through a museum, it becomes part of your, somehow.
Museums are places of discovery and learning. Visit to a museum often is a part of a student‚Äôs life from early days, abroad. It is a wonderful sight to see children milling around the exhibits curiously, while being briefed about them by their teachers.
Less said about the status of museums in India, the better. There is an overwhelming sense of neglect in many of them, with some notable exceptions. The exhibits are often displayed haphazardly with poor lighting with little information about them. Gallery walks are a rarity in most.
Madhya Pradesh Tribal Museum at Bhopal is an outstanding example of how a museum should be! Designed by Revathi Kamath, pioneer of mud architecture in India, it is a series of aesthetically designed colorful galleries that offer interesting and informative insights into the rich cultural heritage of various tribes of the region. One can spend hours amidst the beautifully lit artifacts and exhibits.
Take a walk through this museum at: https://photos.app.goo.gl/eh4ChAvfXt72BMRJ7
Incidentally today is the International Museum Day!
25/05/22, 8:31‚ÄØam
On this World Otter Day, I recollect my first sighting of the smooth coated otters in the backwaters of Chimmony. It was a glorious evening with the setting sun framing the backwaters with brilliant hues and as we were cruising along in a boat, suddenly I noticed a group of otters, just in front of us. They were barking like dogs at us with khar kharr sounds. Neer-nai as they are often referred to as, might appear drab brown at a casual glance. But these sleek little water-wanderers were graceful as they ambled along the crevices of the rocks. Some were coming out of the water with their snouts just visible, making waves of whirls in the calm water. A group of them swiftly emerged out of the crevices and were staring at us, upright! We spent a few minutes watching them before they quietly slinked away.
These Smooth Coated Otters are closely related to the Giant Otters of South America and are Asia‚Äôs largest otters. They are highly social and are often seen in packs. They mostly feed on fish (more than 90% of their diet is fish) and that makes them quite unpopular among fishermen. However, trained smooth-coated otters are often used by fisherman to herd fish into nets. Unfortunately, their population is threatened by loss of wetland habitats, poaching, and contamination of waterways by pesticides.
Otters
Glide amidst the rocks
Straight into my heart‚Ä¶
05/06/22, 8:22‚ÄØam
As we usher in another World Environment Day, it is a sad and stark fact that the health of our environment is not in good shape. A slew of factors ranging from global warming to deforestation have left their impact on an already fragile planet.
The campaign this year focuses on "Living Sustainably in Harmony with Nature."
A little bird has been practising this quietly, for centuries‚Ä¶the Barn Swallow!
Barn swallows have always been linked to people, even adapting former nesting grounds in caves and cliff faces for manmade structures and living harmoniously with the humans. In many parts of the world, having Barn Swallows nesting on one's property is considered a sign of good fortune. Unfortunately, scores of them were slaughtered for their feathers in the Victorian era for decorating ladies‚Äô hats. Concerned with this practice and the decimation of the birds, George Bird Grinnell wrote his famous editorial in ‚ÄòForest and Stream‚Äô in 1886 opposing it. That editorial led to the formation of the Audubon Society and the advent of the conservation movement in the United States.
These twittery, flittery birds love to eat the insects that we consider pesky. They consume 60 insects in an hour which can even go up to 850 per day. That's how much each bird eats. Working efficiently as effective pest control agents they do their bit silently to maintain the environment.
Let this diminutive bird inspire us on this day!
As Shakespeare wrote, ‚ÄúTrue hope is swift and flies with swallow‚Äôs wings.‚Äù
08/06/22, 8:39‚ÄØam
On the World Ocean Day, let us recall that life on earth probably began in hydrothermal vents in the depths of the oceans. But it was not the ocean we know today. It was warmer, more acidic and rich in iron. As life evolved, the oceans continued to provide home to many living things. In fact, a greater number of organisms live in the oceans than on land. Covering more than 70 per cent of the earth‚Äôs surface, they are humanity‚Äôs most important natural resource. Oceans feed us, regulate our climate and generate most of the oxygen we breathe.
Unfortunately, they also face major threats: global climate change, pollution, habitat destruction, invasive species, and a dramatic decrease in ocean fish stocks. These threats to the ocean are so extensive that more than 40 percent of the ocean has already been severely affected and no area has been left untouched.
The World Ocean Day is a timely reminder to develop a shared vision of a sustainable use of oceans.
As for me, the ocean with its enormity and mystery, has always been a continuing source of enchantment. There is no music more relaxing than the rolling of ocean waves.
My most memorable trip along the ocean was in California highway 1. It is perhaps one of the most astoundingly scenic roads in the world. Smelling the salty and briny sea breeze of the Pacific Ocean, seeing its vastness and feeling so small in the middle of its quiet stillness‚Ä¶these are emotions only the ocean can stir.
Poets capture these moments beautifully, like in these words of Meena Alexander, ‚ÄúSometimes the syllables of poetry well up, waves on the surface of the sea, and they burst as flying fish might, struck by light.‚Äù
As TS Eliot wrote in Four Quartets, ‚ÄúThe river is within us, the sea is all about us, ‚Äù and we have to tend to both with sensitivity and concern‚Ä¶
09/06/22, 8:28‚ÄØam
Sunset has always inspired poets.
Poets of the Sangam era (300 BCE to 300 CE) were no exception. Sangam literature contains 2381 poems in Tamil composed by 473 poets, It includes Tolkappiyam, Ettuthogai, Pattuppattu, Pathinenkilkanakku, and two epics, Silappathikaram and Manimegalai.
Kalithogai is part of the eight anthologies (Ettuthogai), It contains one hundred and fifty poems which were written by various authors. This particular one was written by the poet Nallanthuvan.
‡ÆÖ‡Æï‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æû‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ≥‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡ÆÜ‡Æï‡Æ™‡Øç
‡Æ™‡Æï‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ®‡ØÅ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æü‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æö‡Øá‡Æ∞
The sun that lights the wide world
Unfurls its many rays
And joins the mountains
As if it swallowed the day
There are occasions when photography and poetry can come together and this is once such moment‚Ä¶
12/06/22, 9:14‚ÄØam
Today is Vaikasi Visakam which is celebrated as the birthday of Lord Muruga. Worship of Lord Muruga is interwoven with folk myths, personal and cultural histories. He has an unbounded and immortal presence across Tamil Nadu, inspiring intense devotion. A god who fosters multiple narratives, each and every community, has a story about their own divine ancestry featuring Lord Muruga.
Some of the earliest sculptural depictions of young Lord Muruga is in the Somaskandamurthy panels
which can be seen in the first freestanding temple in Tamil Nadu, the Kailasanatha Temple in Kanchipuram.
As we walk around the temple precincts, we can see many of these panels which portray Siva and Parvati with Skanda sitting on Parvati‚Äôs lap. In a larger depiction, (photgraph 1) Vishnu can also be seen in the back, in addition to Siva, Parvati and Skanda. Many of the small shrines that dot the inner wall of the courtyard have Somaskanda panels. One of them which attracted my attention was a striking portrayal with the remnants of vibrant hues adorning the back wall. Unfortunately, the face of Skanda has worn out with time. But its beauty and allure hasn‚Äôt faded‚Ä¶
12/06/22, 7:01‚ÄØpm
I didn't know about this. Wonderful sculptures and the sunlight which is falling on them and the eye catching colours is adding on the beauty.
18/06/22, 8:29‚ÄØam
Paul McCartney who is turning 80 today is a favourite singer of mine.
Shortly after returning from India where he was learning the art of Transcendental Meditation, he wrote "Blackbird" which was featured in the ‚ÄòWhite Album.‚Äô I keep listening to this tranquil guitar ballad often. This song was written solely by Paul McCartney. However, he acknowledged the role of John Lennon and hence the song goes under the name Lennon-McCartney.
Paul wrote this song on the background of the civil rights movement in US. The black bird in the song refers to a group of black students who faced racial discrimination in Little Rock Central High School Arkansas. As he said later, ‚ÄúThis was really a song from me to a black woman, experiencing these problems in the States. Let me encourage you to keep trying, to keep your faith; there is hope.‚Äô‚Äù
It is a song of empowerment, reflecting the singer‚Äôs longing for change.
No matter how dark our circumstances may be, there is always a glimmer of hope to be found..
Blackbird fly, blackbird fly
Into the light of a dark black night
21/06/22, 7:46‚ÄØam
Among all yoga asanas Vrksasana or tree pose is one of the most beautiful and serene one imbued with symbolic significance. It is also one of the oldest known yoga poses and is depicted in ancient sculptures.
An earliest representations is in ‚ÄúBhagiratha‚Äôs Penance‚Äù or ‚ÄúThe Descent of the Ganges‚Äù in Mahabalipuram which is dated to the 7th century. Bhagiratha stood in Vrksasana for one thousand years which persuaded Brahma and Shiva to create the Ganges.
In the first photograph one can notice a man standing on top left in the Vrksasana pose. Interestingly on the bottom right is a cat with a similar pose. Probably the cat is pretending to be a peaceful yogi fooling the mice (seen at its feet) before it eats them!
The second photo which portrays the asana in detail is from a pillar in the Thirukurungudi temple. It is slightly different from the former with one leg in Ardha Padmasana (Half-Lotus) and hands in Anjali Mudra (prayer position).
Symbolically, the tree is said to be strong and well grounded. It grows both upwards and downwards, ensuring stability. The grounding action of the standing leg represents the roots of a tree, and the stretching of the arms overhead represents the branches reaching upwards. It is believed that when one holds the pose, prana (life force) goes up facilitating the release of a transformative energy.
Dualities vanish
If, for a moment
We become a tree‚Ä¶
21/06/22, 5:50‚ÄØpm
Such wonderful sculptures Sir. It is so difficult to chisel these postures!
22/06/22, 11:24‚ÄØam
As I was listening to the enchanting pallavi of Oothukadu Venkata Subbaier krithi,
‚Äúkuzhaloodhi manamellaam kollaikondapinnum
kuraiyaedhum enakkaedhadi sakiyae
When he plays his flute and takes hold of my heart
Will I ever be discontented my friend? (my translation)
I remembered that yesterday was the World Music Day.
Lord Krishna is inseparable from his flute and the lure of his music is irresistible.
One of the most beautiful depiction of this is in the Chitra Gopuram of Thirukurungudi temple in Tirunelveli district.
Carved with exquisite detail, it portrays Lord Krishna holding the flute with his two hands with shanku and chakra on the other two hands. The sages, devatas, cowherds, people, animals and birds are totally entranced by the mellifluous music emanating from the flute. The snake at his feet is no exception. The sculptor animates the scene by portraying a mischievous monkey stealing butter from the cowherd!
There is a beautiful story about how Radha is jealous of the flute because it is always with the Lord. Once she asks the flute, ‚Äúwhat is it that you have which I lack, that he is always with you?" The flute replies: "Perhaps he likes me because I am empty."
When we empty ourselves, the lord enters and fills that space.
22/06/22, 10:51‚ÄØpm
Wow.. Such a pleasing beautiful sculpture Sir. Blessed are the sculptors and thanks for the photograph. The very sight of it brings a smile on our face and the atmosphere so serene. And your narrative.... Too good....
25/06/22, 7:48‚ÄØam
Sand dunes have an irresistible charm, especially in the desert landscape.
Several years ago we ventured onto the sand dunes of Khuri and spent the night there.
It was an unforgettable experience.
Lying down on the sand I saw nothing but a vast expanse of dark, nocturnal sky, radiant with sparkling, shimmering stars. It was a starry night straight out of Vincent van Gogh‚Äôs palette and I took his suggestion, ‚ÄúIt often seems to me that the night is even more richly coloured than the day‚Ä¶if you look carefully, you‚Äôll see that some stars are lemony, others have a pink, green, forget-me-not blue glow.‚Äù
The wind was sculpting millions of fine sand particles to form tantalizing shapes with remarkable patterns.
Every sand particle brushing against my hands was an experience.
As Rachel Carson commented ‚Äúin every grain of sand there is the story of the earth.‚Äù
I can still feel those grains of sand in the hour glass of my memory‚Ä¶.
(On the occasion of the World Sand Dune Day!)
26/06/22, 8:10‚ÄØpm
We feel inspired by these talented youngsters. While supporting their educational expenses all through their medical career, we were keen that both of them are kept in the dark about it. It is such an ennobling experience to be part of their journey
04/07/22, 8:21‚ÄØam
As humans we have the privilege to express ourselves through our speech. On many occasions we find that a simple gesture of the hand can express our thoughts equally well and perhaps much better.
Specific hand gestures that symbolize and convey various meanings are referred to as Mudras. Mudra Vidhanam, written by Anna and published by Ramakrishna Mutt lists at least 137 mudras. When a sculptor creates a deity, he adds various mudras to express the idea symbolized by it.
For instance look at these images. First one is from Gangaikondacholapuram and the second from the bronze gallery from Chennai museum. You will notice the gesture of the right hand, where the forefinger is joined with the thumb and the other three fingers remain separate. This is often referred to as Chinmudra.
The thumb represents Brahman because without the thumb the hand cannot function. The middle, ring and the small finger represents the body, mind and intellect respectively. Index finger represents the ego because it keeps pointing at others most of the times! When we hold our hand normally the index finger is attached to the other three fingers and is far away from the thumb. This indicates that we normally think of ourselves as the body, mind and intellect, separate from the Brahman. As long as we have this notion, we will have a beginning and an end. When the index finer (ego) separates itself from the body/mind/ intellect and unites with the thumb (representing the Brahman), it forms a circle, which has no beginning and end. It symbolizes the union of the jivatma with the Paramatma, which is the essence of all realisation.
Some symbols convey the deeper meanings with sublime simplicity‚Ä¶
08/07/22, 4:42‚ÄØpm
This is a sculpture found in recent excavation in Harihareshwar temple at a place called Kundal near Sangli (Maharashtra)
Uniqueness about it is- There is only one
face of Krishna but five bodies in
different positions.
Lookat each body and you will feel
the face is of that body.
Incredible India and its rich culture!!
