12/07/22, 8:26‚ÄØam
The mango season is on the wane and having savoured it, sweet memories linger on..
Absence of simplicity in life is akin to a mango without its sweetness.
All too often, we fritter away our lives in pursuit of the tangible. Simplicity is about minimizing our needs and maximizing the meaningful aspects of life. When a mathematician tries solve a difficult problem, he first frees the equation of all impediments and reduces it to its simplest terms. Like wise to simplify our lives we need to distinguish the necessary and the real from the clutters of the material world in which we are immersed.
Many illustrious people have explored the terrain of simplicity, the most prominent of them being Henry Thoreau. He went to the Walden Pond to learn what were the ‚Äútrue necessaries of life‚Äù. He recorded his experiences spread over a decade in journals which were later compiled in the book Walden.
Often Thoreau sat on the banks of the Walden Pond reading Charles Wilkin‚Äôs 1785 translation of the Bhagvat Gita. In his own words, ‚ÄúIn the morning I bathe my intellect in the stupendous and cosmogonal philosophy of the Bhagvat Gita‚Ä¶‚Äù This particular verse from Chapter 17 draws attention to the significance of simplicity.
‡§Æ‡§®: ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶: ‡§∏‡•å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•å‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π: |
‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á || 16||
Serenity of thought, simplicity, silence, self-control, and purity of purpose are the austerities of the mind.
Today is also the birth anniversary of Thoreau which is celebrated as the World Simplicity Day.
It is probably a perfect day to pick up Walden and remind ourselves that pursuit of simplicity in life need not be a distant dream.
13/07/22, 9:39‚ÄØam
A true Guru would never tell the seeker or the student what to do.
On the contrary, he/she would give them the knowledge with which they could decide what would be best path for them to venture. When he/she points a finger towards the path of discovery the students attention is often fixed on the finger and not the path.
Thich Nhat puts this succinctly "just as a finger pointing at the moon is not the moon itself. A thinking person makes use of the finger to see the moon. A person who only looks at the finger and mistakes it for the moon will never see the real moon."
I hail from a family of teachers and have been blessed with Gurus who inspired and guided me ‚Äòto see the moon‚Äô in my professional journey. This quest remains unabated as I continue to learn from my multitudinous talented students.
The letter ‚Äògu‚Äô refers to darkness, the letter ‚Äòru‚Äô means he who dispels such darkness, ‚ÄòGuru‚Äô is called so because of his ability to dispel darkness of ignorance.
In Indian spiritual traditions, Dakshinamurthy is perceived as the First Guru, Adi Guru.
Iconographically, he is depicted in various forms and this beautiful carving is from Amirthagadeswarar temple at Melakadambur which was built by the Chola King Kulothunga-I in 1113 AD
13/07/22, 10:48‚ÄØpm
A fantastic carving, even the fine carving of the leg is so conspicuous.
14/07/22, 9:36‚ÄØam
Yesterday was Guru Purnima and it is not mere coincidence that it was also the day in 6th century BCE when Buddha delivered his first sermon after his enlightenment at Bodhgaya. It is recorded as the Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta, which means "The Setting in Motion of the Wheel of Dharma." It took place in the Deer Park at Varanasi to the group of five ascetics, namely Konda√±√±a, Assaji, Bhaddiya, Vappa, and MahƒÅnƒÅma.
In this sermon, the Buddha outlined the core conceptual framework of Buddhism. He began with the doctrine of the Middle Way, which emphasizes that the path to enlightenment lies between extremes of self-indulgence and self-denial. Then Buddha explained the Four Noble Truths, which are: Life is dukkha, dukkha is driven by craving, there is a way to be liberated from both and that way is the Eightfold Path. Eightfold Path encompasses: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration.
Dukkha is a Pali word is often translated as unhappiness, pain or suffering. Suffering is inevitable in our lives, it is part of our human condition. By learning to be still and coming face to face with our pain and disappointments we have the opportunity to transform ourselves.
An ancient tribal saying states it succinctly, ‚ÄúBefore we can see properly we must first shed our tears to clear the way.‚Äù
18/07/22, 8:17‚ÄØam
The World Listening Day on 18th of July is a reminder for us to take time and listen to the sounds of nature. It honours the birthday of Canadian environmentalist Murray Schafer one of the pioneers of the Acoustic Ecology movement. The theme this year is Listening Across Boundaries.
We are incessantly immersed in sounds of nature‚Ä¶whether it is the rustling of the leaves in the wind, the pitter patter of rain drops on the window pane or the natural orchestra of bird calls in the morning.
As our environment changes so too the sounds. Engrossed in the random cacophony of urban living, sitting at our computers or checking our mobiles, we are inattentive to the other sounds surrounding us.
The sounds of nature have long inspired artists be it in the realms of poetry or music. Beethoven found inspiration in nature. He loved to take walks in the countryside and take notes on the natural world he observed. The first movement of the Pastoral Symphony, ‚ÄòAwakening of cheerful feelings on arrival in the countryside,‚Äô immediately evokes a sense of relaxation. It's about seeing nature as a source of harmony. The second movement, ‚ÄòScene by the brook‚Äô evokes sounds of cuckoos and nightingales. In the third movement we hear the ‚ÄòMerry gathering of the country folk‚Äô and the next movement heralds the onset of the storm. As the storm slowly dies down, there is the cow waltz in the last movement. Interestingly cow waltz is still played on the alphorn in Switzerland to encourage cows to produce more milk! It is not surprising then that the Pastoral Symphony was played performed at the United Nations World Environment Day as a ‚Äúglobal statement for the preservation of nature‚Äù.
The health benefits of exposure to sounds of nature has been extensively documented. For instance, Stephen and Rachel Kaplan spent twenty years exploring the impact of natural sounds and in their Attention Restoration Theory, or ART, proposed that this can help us improve our focus and ability to concentrate.
Listening is a way of being in the world and feeling the vibrations of nature opens up an entirely new world of enriching experiences.
Next time you take a walk, listen deeply and immerse yourself in the serenity of the sonic landscape of nature. You might hear the melodic chirping of a lone bird sitting on a tree branch.
As the Chinese proverb states, ‚ÄúKeep a green tree in your heart and perhaps a singing bird will come‚Äù.
Listen
To the sounds of nature
The whispers of the wind
Waves lapping the shores
Chatter of the sparrows
Flutter of the birds
And the silence in between‚Ä¶
19/07/22, 10:36‚ÄØam
Hunter Thompson whose birthday is today was a hugely talented maverick.
He developed a style of journalism which is often referred to as gonzo journalism. It is a type of journalism where the writer becomes part of the story, portraying events through their own experience. His ‚ÄòFear and Loathing in Las Vegas: A Savage Journey to the Heart of the American Dream‚Äô is a compelling read.
He led a troubled life, often experiencing periods of low mood, articulating it in these poignant words‚Ä¶
22/07/22, 8:12‚ÄØam
Our brain is a mysterious jungle and there have been many remarkable people who have ventured into its enigmatic trails, providing us with valuable insights.
On the World Brain Day, let us remember Santiago Ramon y Cajal, the father of neuroscience who was also an aspiring artist. Armed with a rudimentary microscope which he bought with his savings, he set out to disentangle and catalogue the brain‚Äôs neuronal wildlife. He drew what he saw through the lens with delicate precision, offering tantalizing glimpses about the inner workings of the nervous system. His efforts were rewarded with the Nobel Prize along with Camillo Golgi. Where Golgi only saw an impenetrable jungle, Cajal was able to parse each tree with detail.
An interesting research revealed that Nobel Laureates were more likely to have arts and crafts hobbies than Royal Society and National Academy members. It may be that such activities offer endless opportunities for creative explorations both inside and outside the scientific realm. His work has often been compared to that of Andreas Vesalius, the Renaissance physician whose exquisite drawings of his own anatomical dissections revolutionized medicine. Cajal‚Äôs immense artistic skills similarly led him to profound insights into brain development and function, most of which have stood the test of time.
Cajal was also a prolific writer and wrote more than 200 books including science fiction!
His advice to young researchers was simple, ‚ÄúAny man could, if he were so inclined, be the sculptor of his own brain.‚Äù
22/07/22, 1:41‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for the glimpse into great researchers' works. Artistic bent of mind is a precursor for any kind of exploration into the unknown.
25/07/22, 9:09‚ÄØam
The landscape of Corbett is quite magical. One can spend hours amidst the vast grasslands, gently undulating hills, marshy depressions and riverine belts. It is the oldest national park in the country and is named after Jim Corbett whose birthday is today.
Corbett was a hunter with a heart. He tracked and killed 19 tigers and 14 leopards which were responsible for slaying around 1,200 people, without suffering even a scratch! He would mostly work alone, venturing into the jungles with his faithful dog Robin by his side. He also wrote six books which offer fascinating accounts of his trysts with the wildlife. His ‚ÄòMan eating leopard of Rudraprayag‚Äô is exciting narrative of a leopard that spread terror killing more than hundred people. Apart from being an account of the relentless pursuit of animal for more than a year, it also offers rich insights into lives in the Garhwal region. It is an ode to the people who inhabit the terrain and the resilience with which they face the hardships that assail them. On the highway to the town, there is a tree by the side of the road where one can find a notice which reads: ‚ÄúThis was the tree on which Jim Corbett sat and shot dead the Man Eating Leopard of Rudraprayag in 1926.‚Äù
Corbett died on April 19, 1955, days after finishing his sixth book, Tree Tops. A year later, the state of Uttarakhand renamed the national park he helped found as Jim Corbett National Park. In addition to the national park that bears his name, there‚Äôs a species of endangered Indochinese tiger, Panthera tigris corbetti, that bears his name.
In spite of his prowess as a hunter, Corbett was a naturalist at heart and voiced the need for wildlife conservation in India long before it became a popular refrain.
A child of the Kumaon region, its forests inspired his lifelong effort to protect animals and people alike.
In his own words, ‚ÄúThe book of nature has no beginning, as it has no end. Open this book where you will, and at any period of your life, and if you have the desire to acquire knowledge you will find it of intense interest, and no matter how long or how intently you study the pages, your interest will not flag, for in nature there is no finality.‚Äù
25/07/22, 8:51‚ÄØpm
So nice to read through but with a heavy heart as I feel we have come so far away from nature. Man is encroaching the natural habitat and believes he can thrive without wildlife and forests. In for trouble üòí Thanks Sir for the info.
27/07/22, 7:49‚ÄØam
Rajendra Chola I, one of the greatest rulers of Tamil Chola dynasty of India was born in the Tamil month of Aadi on Tiruvadirai day, which was yesterday. During his reign, he extended the influence of the already vast Chola empire up to the banks of the river Ganges in the north and across the ocean. He brought the waters of the Ganges to anoint his new capital and acquired the title ‚ÄòGangaikonda Cholan‚Äô (he who brought the Ganges). His navy was unmatched and sailed to kingdoms that are now Malaysia, Maldives, Indonesia and Cambodia. Through his naval victories he controlled the maritime trade in the Indian Ocean. During the course of his reign, he defeated Mahipala, the Pala king of Bengal and Bihar, and to commemorate his victory, built a new capital called Gangaikonda Cholapuram. It was to be the capital for about 250 years. Here, Rajendra built a majestic temple Gangaikonda Choleeswaram. It is a glorious representation of Chola architecture and is a rich repository of some of the most exquisite sculptures one can ever set eyes upon.
For instance, as one ascends a long flight of steps leading to the sanctum, on the right side, carved in a large niche is a beautifully carved sculpture of Siva, Parvathi and Chandesa. Siva is adorned with intricate jewels with his immense locks of hair resembling a crest. To his left is Parvathi, with a jewelled crown. Both have one leg folded up. Below them is the devotee Chandesa. Siva is in the process of winding a garland of flowers around Chandesa's head who, with folded hands accepts the honour. A striking feature of this panel is that the three main figures face different directions. As you walk up the stairs you realise that Chandesa is looking at you. Some scholars and historians have suggested that it could be Rajendra Chola himself who is represented here as Chandesa, sitting at the feet of Siva.
Rajendra Chola was not merely a fearsome warrior but also a connoisseur of arts, as can be seen in this gorgeous panel and the outstanding architecture of the temple.
Unfortunately, the legacy of Rajendra Chola remains buried in the annals of Indian history. It is only in the past few years that his legendary contributions have begun to receive the attention which they richly deserve. In honour of this pioneer maritime king, a portrait of Rajendra Chola was installed in the Mazgoan docks in 2016 and a training ship, TS Rajendra, has also been named after him.
27/07/22, 10:13‚ÄØpm
Such life like sculptures, what magic was there in their fingers! Thanks Sir for taking us into the past, for a change not the negative but something to cherish.
01/08/22, 5:39‚ÄØam
Moby Dick is a multi-layered novel in which Herman Melville (whose birthday is today) handles several themes. One salient refrain is the story of man's attempt to defeat nature. Nature itself is personified through the white whale, one of the sea‚Äôs greatest marvels. They are a part of nature themselves. Any act of violence against them becomes an act of violence against nature as well. If nature is a thing of wonder that should be treated with great respect, its creatures should be treated in the same manner.
Finally, the sea takes down the men aboard the ship and the elusive Moby Dick slips away. Nature continues to carry on as it has for the past several thousand years, regardless of those who attempt to control or destroy it and the final sentence of the novel resonates with this message: ‚ÄúNow small fowls flew screaming over the yet yawning gulf; a sullen white surf beat against its steep sides; then all collapsed, and the great shroud of the sea rolled on as it rolled five thousand years ago.‚Äù
William Turner was a sublime artist of the sea and painted a series of seascapes. Herman Melville was fascinated by his paintings. It is said that shortly before writing his maritime masterpiece, he travelled to England and saw some of Turner‚Äôs paintings. Aspects of Moby Dick are strikingly evocative of Turner‚Äôs style.
02/08/22, 11:04‚ÄØam
It was Aadi pooram yesterday which is considered to be the birthday of Andal. She is one of the most extraordinary personalities in religious history and is the only female among the 12 Alvars. Alvars were poet-saints of South India who expressed their devotion to Lord Vishnu in their songs resplendent with longing and bhakti.
Andal‚Äôs Nachiyar Thirmozhi matches and even surpasses Sangam love poetry.
For instance she writes‚Ä¶.
‡ÆÆ‡Æ¥‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Øá ‡ÆÆ‡Æ¥‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Øá ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ±‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÇ‡Æö‡Æø ‡Æâ‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æ≥‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ
‡ÆÆ‡ØÜ‡Æ¥‡ØÅ‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡Æä‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æ©‡Ææ‡Æ±‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æä‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æü‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æâ‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±
‡ÆÖ‡Æ¥‡Æï‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æ§‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡ÆÆ‡Øà ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ®‡ØÜ‡Æû‡Øç‡Æö‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æï‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æü‡Æ§‡Øç
‡Æ§‡Æ¥‡ØÅ‡Æµ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æ§‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æä‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æµ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Øá?
Rain, pouring rain
My dazzling lord
Lives encased in clay
Molten wax within.
Can you rain down
And wash away the clay?
To melt my heart
With his radiant embrace
(A rather ‚Äòamateurish‚Äô translation of the original!)
In Nachiyar Thirumozhi, Andal writes about her dream of holding the hands of Lord Vishnu under a pearl studded canopy. In this painting, musician S Rajam who was also painter extraordinary, has depicted the scene vividly with vibrant hues.
03/08/22, 8:43‚ÄØam
Once James Baldwin (whose birthday was yesterday) wrote ‚ÄúYou think your pain and your heartbreak are unprecedented in the history of the world, but then you read.‚Äù
Reading his book, The Fire Next Time, which was published more than five decades ago, widens our gaze and perspective about the dreadful legacy of racism. It is an intensely personal, passionate document.
He writes, "The White man's unadmitted - and apparently to him, unspeakable - private fears and longings are projected onto the Negro. The only way he can be released from the Negro's tyrannical power over him is to consent, in effect, to become black himself, to become part of the suffering and dancing country that he now watches wistfully from the heights of his lonely power and, armed with spiritual traveller's cheques, visits surreptitiously after dark‚Ä¶..try to remember that what they believe, as well as what they do and cause you to endure, does not testify to your inferiority but to their inhumanity and fear. " It is an insightful comment about understanding the lives and tribulations of the marginalized ‚Äòother‚Äô, who continue to face discrimination and oppression across various structural inequalities.
Words that are as relevant today as he wrote them more than fifty years ago.
That said, I often wonder why it is so difficult for us to recognize inhumanity and the pain of the ‚Äòother‚Äô. Perhaps as James Baldwin reflects, ‚ÄúI imagine one of the reasons people cling to their hates so stubbornly is because they sense, once hate is gone, they will be forced to deal with pain.‚Äù
04/08/22, 8:41‚ÄØam
Shelley whose birthday is today was not merely a talented poet. He was much ahead of the time in championing the cause of vegan diet for a sound mind and healthy body. He was also the man who first propounded the idea of massive, non-violent protest as the most appropriate and effective response to authoritarian oppression.
In his short life, he wrote some of the most dazzling lyrical poems. I am particularly fond of the poem, ‚ÄúTo a Skylark‚Äù. One day while walking in Italian countryside with his wife Mary, Shelley heard the melodious notes of the skylark. In the poem consisting of 24 stanzas, he describes the grace and beauty of the skylark's birdsong. He addresses the bird directly and praises the purity of its music, which is later contrasted with sad, hollow human communication. It is quintessentially an ode to the unmatched splendours of the natural world. Interestingly, Shelley uses the phrase "harmonious madness" referring to the beauty of the song of the skylark. He asks the bird to teach him ‚Äúhalf the gladness / That thy brain must know,‚Äù for then he would overflow with ‚Äúharmonious madness,‚Äù and his song would be so beautiful that the world would listen to him, even as he is now listening to the skylark.
This photograph is of a graceful Rufous Tailed Lark with a stanza from the poem.
06/08/22, 11:14‚ÄØam
Flowers have a habit of blooming in the most unexpected of places‚Ä¶which we may not even notice.
Sometimes a poet pauses, observes and reflects on it as Alfred Tennyson (whose birthday falls today) does in his poem ‚ÄòFlower In A Crannied Wall.‚Äô
It is a short six line poem in which he muses on the connection between man, god and the cosmos. He visualizes man as flower, god as the root of the flower and the wall as cosmos. He wonders whether by plucking the flower from the wall, one can fathom its roots and understand all of its deep connections.
The poet suggests that even the tiniest creations of the universe, those that could be found anywhere, are part of the whole of creation. Through honing the ability to understand every aspect of it, one can unravel the mystery of our connection to the divine and the cosmos.
Essentially anything , any object, no matter however mundane it may be, when truly and mindfully experienced, opens up a doorway to enlightenment.
07/08/22, 9:09‚ÄØam
Yesterday I had posted about Tennyson‚Äôs quest to ‚Äòunderstand‚Äô the connection between man, god and the cosmos through plucking a flower in the roadside and exploring its roots.
Can one experience that connectivity merely by ‚Äòlooking‚Äô at a flower?
Basho who is revered as the greatest of Japan‚Äôs haiku poets observes a nazuna flower (sheperd‚Äôs purse) blooming by the wayside on a hedge and writes:
When I look carefully
I see the nazuna blooming
By the hedge!
He is content merely to "look" to sense the deep mystery of the flower. Immersing oneself through contemplative observation of an ordinary flower and pondering over its beauty, one could unravel the mystery of creation. In the process, the distinction between ourselves and nature breaks down. We become one with the universe and a reassuring sense of harmony and connection with the world permeates our consciousness. A state often referred to Eutierria.
British naturalist and environmental writer Michael McCarthy wrote eloquently about such experiences, ‚ÄúThere can be occasions when we suddenly and involuntarily find ourselves loving the natural world with a startling intensity, in a burst of emotion which we may not fully understand, and the only word that seems to me to be appropriate for this feeling is Joy.‚Äù
Let us reclaim and discover our joyous belonging to the natural world . . .
08/08/22, 7:20‚ÄØam
Yes Sir. But man has created an artificial, pseodo lack of time and money after which he is chasing. Where is the patience to stop and look and listen. They think it is not their business to do and hence there is collective destruction of nature.
10/08/22, 1:39‚ÄØpm
World Lion Day, which is today is to create awareness about one of the most majestic species to walk the earth and celebrate the animal kingdom's most beautiful and fearsome creature.
Lions have been an important symbol in various kingdoms for thousands of years and appear as a theme in all cultures across the world. As the ‚ÄúKing of the beasts," it is a symbol of majesty, strength, courage, justice, and confidence.
Artists have been depicting lions for millennia and the list of lions in art is endless.
In temple architecture in India, lions figure all through history and prominently during the regime of the Pallavas.
The structural temples of the Pallavas belong to two groups: Rajasimha group (A.D. 690-c.800) and the Nandivarman group (800-c.900 A.D.). The famous ‚ÄòKailasanatha Temple‚Äô, considered as the largest sandstone temple in the world, is the best representation of the Rajasimha group of temples, while the ‚ÄòVaikuntha Perumal Temple‚Äô is an example of the Nandivarman group. Lion motifs started appearing under Rajasimha, marking the beginning of a pillar design in Kailasanatha temple and it reached the zenith in the Vaikuntha Perumal Temple in Kanchipuram. This temple is a masterpiece of Pallava architecture. Most impressive and unique feature of the temple are the pillars. Each one of them has a meticulously carved lion on it. They support the enclosed passage inside the temple which have a wealth of weathered but extremely detailed wall panels.
Lions have particularly caught the public attention of late, thanks to their representation over the new parliament building. The lion represents the Buddha, formerly Shakyamuni, a member of the Shakya (lion) clan. With their mouths open, the lions seem to convey the message of dharma and the Four Noble Truths.
A timely reminder in these times‚Ä¶
profraguram.com
10/08/22, 6:12‚ÄØpm
From King of the jungle to the fantastic sculpture on pillars to the noble truths! Thank you Sir for the detailed background history!
12/08/22, 8:01‚ÄØam
Elephants played a crucial role in military, political and cultural history of India.
On this World Elephant Day, let us recall their role in warfare.
The Mahabharata mentions the use of elephants in battle, though chariots were the preferred vehicle of the elite warriors. Almost every ruler in India had an army of elephants and used them effectively in battles. There are vivid descriptions of their role in the battle field. Arthashastra of Kautilya provides plenty of information on elephants, their training and conduct in wars.
With heavy armour to protect them, elephants were trained to trample the enemy and stab soldiers with their tusks which were armed with special blades, called elephant swords. Sometimes these elephant swords were coated with poison to make them even deadlier. During a charge, elephants would slash to pieces whomever they came in contact with. In some instances, the war elephants had an iron chain with an iron ball at the end attached to their trunk to kill enemy soldiers.
At one sweep elephants could get rid of enemy foot soldiers, scare away horses, and trample chariots. There was also the practice of intoxicating elephants as inebriated elephants could cause much more panic and break enemy formations with ease. The Chalukyas of Vatapi were well known for their use of drunken elephants to wreak destruction on the enemy troops. Only males, especially if they were sixty years old were used in the battle. The armies didn‚Äôt raise war elephants, they hunted them in the wild, tamed and trained them.
Innovative methods were employed to scare the elephants in the battle. It was found out that the elephants were afraid of the high-pitched squealing of the pigs. To make sure that they squealed louder, they were coated with tar, resin, or oil, set on fire and despatched towards the enemy elephants!
With the advent of artillery and muskets on a larger scale, the use of war elephants decreased over time. However, they continued to be used to carry the royalty and commanders into battle.
This mural in Thiruppudaimaruthur portrays war elephants in the 'Tamirabarani battle' which took place in 1532 at Aralvaimozhi Pass, near Thovalai in Kanyakumari district between the King of Travancore, Bhoothala Veera Udaya Marthanda Varma and Emperor of Vijayanagara, Achyutadeva Raya.
12/08/22, 6:42‚ÄØpm
The mural is so effective in depicting elephants waiting to pounce on the enemies. Thank you Sir for the history.
16/08/22, 1:32‚ÄØpm
As we celebrated 75 years of India‚Äôs independence yesterday, another exceptional event escaped our attention. It was also the 150th birth anniversary of Sri Aurobindo, the revolutionary turned mystic.
The decisive moment in his life was when he was incarcerated in the Alipore bomb case. Spending a year in solitary confinement, he experienced a series of spiritual awakenings. Deeply influenced by these, his life‚Äôs trajectory changed. On the strength of an 'Adesh' (Divine command) from above, he moved to Pondicherry. In his words, ‚ÄúPondicherry is my place of retreat, my cave of tapasya‚Äù. Yoga that strived for personal salvation was not for him. He sought the unity with the outer along with the exploration of the inner through his ‚Äòintegral yoga‚Äô
The core of Sri Aurobindo‚Äôs political philosophy is that the state exists for the individual and not the individual for the state. He commented, ‚ÄúThe government is for the people. It must provide for stability as well as progress. Stability may be achieved by unity and co-operative action, and progress by free individual growth. The government should be run by people who are selfless, unegoistic, scrupulously honest and capable. Their allegiance should be to the whole country; they should serve the interests of the whole country and not of any party.
A timely reminder!
17/08/22, 9:00‚ÄØam
Today is the birthday of Ted Hughes who was the Poet Laureate of England.
Ted Hughes has been fascinated with the forces of nature, the world of animals and wrote number of poems exploring them.
Notable among them is the ‚ÄòThe Hawk Roosting‚Äô. It is a powerful poem about a bird of prey as it sits overlooking its domain. The poem gives voice to a natural predator as it meditates on its innate nature, waiting fiercely for his prey.
I sit in the top of the wood, my eyes closed.
Inaction, no falsifying dream
Between my hooked head and hooked feet:
Or in sleep rehearse perfect kills and eat.
The convenience of the high trees!
The air's buoyancy and the sun's ray
Are of advantage to me;
And the earth's face upward for my inspection.
My feet are locked upon the rough bark.
It took the whole of Creation
To produce my foot, my each feather:
Now I hold Creation in my foot
Or fly up, and revolve it all slowly -
I kill where I please because it is all mine.
There is no sophistry in my body:
My manners are tearing off heads -
The allotment of death.
For the one path of my flight is direct
Through the bones of the living.
No arguments assert my right:
The sun is behind me.
Nothing has changed since I began.
My eye has permitted no change.
19/08/22, 9:27‚ÄØam
The Krishna Janmashtami marks the birth of Lord Krishna. Lord Krishna was the eighth incarnation of Lord Vishnu and was born as the eighth son of Vasudev and Yashoda on the on the eighth (ashtami) day in the month of Bhadrapada. The Vishnu Purana and Bhagavata Purana have lengthy descriptions of the story of his birth.
The life of Lord Krishna has been a source of perennial inspiration to the poets and the artists in India and he is portrayed in numerous paintings and sculptures in many parts of the country. Depictions of Lord Krishna vary greatly across time period, region as well as styles.
One of the most outstanding sculptural representation of events from Lord Krishna‚Äôs life can be seen in the Amruteshwara temple at Amruthapura in Karnataka. It is one of the oldest known Hoysala temple and is an outstanding representative of Hoysala architecture. Ruvari Mallitamma, the great architect of the Hoysala dynasty, is said to have started his career as a sculptor here. It is a small temple and the exterior wall of the mantapa has panel sculptures depicting scenes from Hindu epics and legends. If one walks in a clockwise direction, he can notice twenty-five small panels portraying various events in the life of Lord Krishna in meticulous detail. This one depicts baby Krishna being placed in a cradle.
Sri Tallapaka Annamacharya composed a lovely song Uyyala Balunuchedaru, describing gopikas placing the baby Krishna in the cradle.
19/08/22, 4:46‚ÄØpm
Today we are celebrating Krishna Janmashtami, son of Vasudeva and Devaki. A day when I reread Bhagavatha. The sculpture is so beautiful despite the weathered features of faces, depicting the celebration of Krishna Jayanthi which is tomorrow. üôèüèª

For me photography is an exploration as I immerse myself in observing the world around me, be it birds, landscapes, exquisite sculptures or even rain drops on a single leaf.
As I discover the world around me, I discover myself‚Ä¶
30/08/22, 5:35‚ÄØam
Among all the gods in the Hindu pantheon, Lord Ganesha is truly an exception. His iconographic representations span a large oeuvre. He ca be portrayed sitting, standing, dancing, with astounding variations. However, amidst the varied representations, his depiction with an elephant head and human body has remained consistent. Elephant head symbolises Jnana Shakti (knowledge, wisdom) and the human body is an icon of Kriya Shakti (creative energy in action).
Lord Ganesha urges us to make optimal use of these qualities in our everyday lives.
This sculpture of a joyous Ganesha is from a small corner of the gopuram at Arulmighu Azhagianambi Rayar Thirukovil at Thirukurungudi.

01/09/22, 7:12‚ÄØam
The way to truth lies through the destruction of the false.
To destroy the false,
you must question your most inveterate beliefs. Of these the idea that you are the body is the worst.
With the body comes the world,
with the world
-- God,
who is supposed to have created the world and thus it starts --
fears, religions, prayers, sacrifices, all sorts of systems --
all to protect and support the child-man, frightened out of his wits by monsters of his own making.
Realize that what you are cannot be born nor die, and with the fear gone,
all suffering ends.
- Sri Nisaraghatta Maharaj.

Krishna Janmashtami is closely followed two weeks later by the birthday of Radha, which is celebrated today.
The inseparable love and affection between Radha and Krishna is symbolic of the eternal striving of a devout mortal for the Divine.
‚ÄúAtma To Radhika Tasya‚Äù: She is the soul and energy that resides in Krishna.
The love between Radha and Krishna has been immortalised by poets, musicians, painters and writers.
Jayadeva‚Äôs Gita Govinda is an important text that describes their relationship in exquisite detail.
For instance in act seven song fourteen verse 17, he narrates the feeling of Radha when Krishna casts a glance on her:
dayita-vilokita-lajjita-hasit√§
bahu-vidha-k√ºjita-rati-rasa-rasit√§
k√§pi madhuripu√´√§
‚ÄúThe glance of her beloved incites a bashful laughter in her, Tasting the ambrosia of love, she murmurs like a cuckoo, voicing her pleasure with a sudden surge of ecstatic euphoria‚Äù.
Very many schools of painting have rendered such scenes with stylistic variations.
Thousand of Radhakrishna paintings adorn galleries and museums across the world.
Each one of them is sheer visual poetry.
This particular mural is from the Ram Gopal Poddar Chhatri in Ramgarh in the Shekhawati region of Rajasthan.
07/09/22, 12:34‚ÄØam
There are times in one‚Äôs life when the desire to know the essence of thing has an irresistible appeal. ‚ÄòZen And The Art Of Motorcycle Maintenance‚Äô fulfilled that need early in my life. It was the personal quest of the author, Pirsig in throes of intense suffering (he had 28 ECTs), to explore that realm through weaving together eastern and western philosophical thoughts in a fascinating manner. The motorcycle is a symbol of a soul in search. Reading the book is a transformational experience.
6th September was Pirsig‚Äôs birthday
13/09/22, 5:51‚ÄØpm
Today is Roald Dahl Day, a special day to remember the prolific author who wrote scores of children's books.
He was incredibly creative and came up with more than 500 new words such as Oompa-Loompas and scrumdiddlyumptious and the Oxford University Press even came up wit a special dictionary of his imaginary words!
I particularly like his book Matilda', which was later made into a movie. It is about an exceptionally talented, precocious little girl, who is, unfortunately, was never properly recognised by her parents. Amazingly self-motivated, she explores ways of quenching her thirst for knowledge. She was a voracious reader and a dreamer.
As the author remarks, ‚ÄúThe books transported her into new worlds and introduced her to amazing people who lived exciting lives. She went on sailing ships with Joseph Conrad. She went to Africa with Ernest Hemingway and to India with Rudyard Kipling. She travelled all over the world while sitting in her little room in an English village‚Äù.
The books conveyed a reassuring message to Matilda that she was not alone in a largely uncaring world.

When Ahalya and myself dedicated Disha, the learning resource center at the tribal school in Wayanad, we were keen to initiate training and skill building in the use of computers for the children there.
We‚Äôre happy to share that the Fragomen Immigration Services Ltd, based in Kochi has donated twenty laptops to take this initiative further. We gratefully acknowledge the Managing Director of Fragomen and Mr Kurian in particular for their generous gesture and support. We also thank Mr Antony Joseph, New Zealand for facilitating it.
NABARD Wayanad has expressed their interest to start the training program which will be mentored by Ms Pritha from our Enhanced Learning Environment program.

17/09/22, 8:10‚ÄØam
Today is Ken Kessey‚Äôs birthday. He was a maverick who was adept in donning various hats. He was a wrestler, a set designer, writer and an enthusiastic propagator of psychedelics.
His forays into the interior landscapes of the mind began when he volunteered at a hospital to be a subject of experiments with psychomimetic drugs. There was a dramatic change in his explorations when he took a job as a night attendant in a psychiatric ward of a big hospital. Watching the patients there convinced him that they were locked into a system that was the very opposite of therapeutic, and it provided the raw material for his magnum opus ,''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.''
It is a truly remarkable novel which offered insightful accounts of institutionalisation and its psychological impact. It was later made into a popular movie that won many Oscars. However Kessey was not happy with the production and refused to watch the film.
I am particularly drawn to this passage in the novel:
‚ÄúYou got to understand that as soon as a man goes to help someone, he leaves himself wide open.‚Äù
The encounter between a client and the therapist is not a one way process. Invariably the tumultuous emotional turmoil of the client leaves its footprints on the therapist too. In order not to feel overwhelmed and helpless, the therapist has to acknowledge and be aware of it as the impact might play out in their personal lives and in therapy too. In order to be helpful, the therapist must acquire the capacity to locate himself/herself in two parallel realities: the personal and the professional lives and their demands.
Therein lies the necessity and importance of personal supervision for the therapists‚Ä¶
21/09/22, 8:38‚ÄØam
Today is the birthday of Leonard Cohen, one of the most passionate songwriter and musicians.
His was an extraordinarily turbulent life. Depression was his lifelong nemesis. Treatments were of little help. After reading Balsekar‚Äôs book, ‚ÄòConsciousness Speaks‚Äô he came down to Bombay and stayed on for a year, meeting him everyday. At the end of his stay, the depression lifted miraculously and in his own words, ‚ÄúThere is a crack in everything. That‚Äôs how the light gets in‚Äù
Though I like many of his songs (who can forget Suzanne!‚Äù, ‚ÄòBird On The Wire‚Äô has a particular appeal for me. It was written during his early years, while he was staying on the Greek island of Hydra. During this period, he fell in love with Marianne Ihlen and theirs was a tempestuous relationship. It was not easy living and the town had no electricity amongst other problems. When the government finally installed the necessary infrastructure, the wires stretched across Leonard Cohen‚Äôs windows. As Marianne Ihlen recounted, ‚ÄúWhile we‚Äôre sitting there, birds were landing on the wire like notes on a music sheet.‚Äù She brought Cohen his guitar and he began to compose the song that became one of his greatest successes.
After they‚Äôd been together for eight years, the relationship came apart, bit by bit, ‚Äúlike falling ashes,‚Äù as Cohen put it. Later in her life Marianne was diagnosed to have cancer.
Hearing about it, Leonard Cohen wrote a poignant letter:
‚ÄúWell Marianne, it‚Äôs come to this time when we are really so old and our bodies are falling apart and I think I will follow you very soon. Know that I am so close behind you that if you stretch out your hand, I think you can reach mine. And you know that I‚Äôve always loved you for your beauty and your wisdom, but I don‚Äôt need to say anything more about that because you know all about that. But now, I just want to wish you a very good journey. Goodbye old friend. Endless love, see you down the road‚Äù.
In her last hour her friend held Marianne‚Äôs hand and hummed ‚ÄúBird on the Wire,‚Äù as her life slowly ebbed away‚Ä¶
23/09/22, 11:12‚ÄØpm
Artists and writers convey the message so beautifully, at the same time give razor's sharpness to their observation!
25/09/22, 8:12‚ÄØam
Colour is all around us and plays a crucial role in paintings. In figurative art where the subject matter is recognizable from the real world, they are employed to complement and enhance their representation. What if there‚Äôs no element of figures in a painting?
Decades ago when I was strolling through the National Gallery of Art in London, I walked into a room where there was a large painting of rectangles in brilliant hues, alternatingly radiant. A woman was sitting, totally engrossed in the painting with tears rolling from her eyes. I gingerly stepped out of the room without disturbing her.
Several days later, I went again to the museum and sat in front of the painting. The large canvas was suffused with a delicate yet powerful luminosity. Slowly my eyes soaked in the colours which seemed to percolate deeply within. It was an experience beyond words, beyond language. It was akin to a meditative state when the chatter of the mind quietens and there‚Äôs an inexplicable stillness.
In the words of Sogyal Rinpoche, ‚ÄúOur true nature could be compared to the sky, and the confusion of the ordinary mind to clouds. Some days the sky is completely obscured by clouds. When we are down on the ground, looking up, it is very difficult to believe there is anything else there but clouds. Yet we only have to fly in a plane to discover a limitless expanse of clear blue sky. From up there the clouds we assumed were everything seem so small and so far away down below‚Äù
Sharing a painting of Rothko on his birthday‚Ä¶
26/09/22, 7:28‚ÄØam
Our lives are long journeys of explorations, many of them in unexpected, uncharted territories. In our sojourns, we confront and negotiate the great imponderables like the meaning and purpose of life, the inevitable end of life and the mystery of what lies beyond. In each of these encounters we come close to ourselves and discover things anew.
TS Eliot, whose birthday falls today, expressed this succinctly in the poem, ‚ÄòLittle Gidding‚Äô, which forms part of the ‚ÄúFour Quartets‚Äù.
He wrote:
‚ÄúWe shall not cease from exploration
And the end of all our exploring
Will be to arrive where we started
And know the place for the first time.‚Äù
30/09/22, 7:29‚ÄØam
The poet WS Merwin whose birthday is today, had a spiritual connection with nature, especially in his later years. He went to Hawaii to study with the Zen master Robert Aitken and remained there, purchasing land on a place aptly called Haiku. He painstakingly restored depleted flora, including hundreds of species of palms, creating in the process one of the largest collections of palms in the world.
And the foliage started to bloom in his poems‚Ä¶
In the poem ‚ÄòPlace‚Äô he wrote:
On the last day of the world
I would want to plant a tree
what for
not the fruit
the tree that bears the fruit
is not the one that was planted
I want the tree that stands
in the earth for the first time
with the sun already
going down
and the water
touching its roots
in the earth full of the dead
and the clouds passing
one by one
over its leaves
When I was watching the migratory Bar Headed Geese which fly across several thousand miles to reach the lake Hadinaru Kere near Mysore, I was reminded of his poem, ‚ÄòMigration‚Äô:
Prayers of many summers come
to roost on a moment
until it sinks under them
and they resume their journey
flying by night
with the sound
of blood rushing in an ear

04/10/22, 6:08‚ÄØam
During Navarathri, Shakti is worshipped in her three manifestations. The first three days are for the worship of Mahakali (power of performing activities), Lakshmi is venerated during the next three days and the last three days are dedicated to Saraswathi, who symbolises the power of knowledge. Saraswathi, supreme icon of wisdom and the arts, is often depicted seated, holding a veena in her hands. Raja Ravi Varma‚Äôs painting of a seated Saraswathi can invariably be found in many Indian homes.
Sculptural representations of Saraswathi dancing are comparatively infrequent and are often found in the temples of the Hoysala period. This particular one is from Chennakesava temple at Somanathapura. Intricately chiseled, it exudes innate beauty and grace. The Goddess is seen dancing with one leg planted on the ground while raising the other one, bent at the knee. This is referred to as the urdhvajanuchari pose. She is holding an eka tantri veena in her hands and the ornamentation is detailed and exquisite. She is dancing to the beats of the drummer who can be seen in the lower right corner. Since the material used was soft chloritic schist stone, some of the details have been lost with vagaries of time, made worse by uncaring visitors who rub their hands over it with sheer disdain.
Dynamic, creative energy seems to flow from every inch of this visual interpretation of Goddess Saraswathi.
In the words of Mahakavi Bharathiyar‚Ä¶
‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ≤‡Æµ‡ØÅ ‡Æö‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øá‡Ææ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øá‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç
‡Æà‡Æ§‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æé‡Æ¥‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æø‡Æü‡Øà‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Ææ‡Æ≥‡Øç
‡Æá‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ™‡ÆÆ‡Øá ‡Æµ‡Æü‡Æø‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æü ‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Ææ‡Æ≥‡Øç
In beauteous paintings, temple towers
She manifests
As an epitome of joyful grace
05/10/22, 8:13‚ÄØam
The salient myth associated with Vijayadasami is that of the Goddess vanquishing the demon Mahishasura. It is interesting to note that Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva combined their powers to trounce the demon who had been granted his wish that he would not be annihilated by a male of any species. However he never thought that a woman would be capable of defeating him. But this underestimation of the power of women turned out to be his downfall.
This myth is a pointer to the inherent, underestimated and unacknowledged energy of the feminine spirit. Moreover it draws attention to the fact that the ‚Äòevil‚Äô often resides within us and it is imperative to address and annihilate it.
This sculpture is from the temple at Gangaikondacholapuram. In contrast to many fierce depictions of the Goddess, one can perceive the tranquil expression on her face after she subjugates and decimates the demon.
05/10/22, 5:00‚ÄØpm
Wonderful sculpture Sir. Yes. The energy to fight as well as the tender feelings to foster!
07/10/22, 7:56‚ÄØam
Considered as the ‚Äògreat voice of Victorian England,‚Äô Tennyson had a troubled legacy. He was subjected to trenchant denunciations by literary critics during his lifetime. It impacted his mental health and ailing from depression, he lamented:
‚ÄúWhen in my youth the growls!
In mine age the owls!
After death the ghouls!‚Äù
But his works had considerable public appeal. When he died on October 6th 1892, scores of people applied for tickets to his funeral in Westminster Abbey.
Tennyson built upon the foundations of Romantic poets and shared their reverence for nature. He commented ,‚ÄúWords, like nature, half reveal and half conceal the soul within.‚Äù
Artists often use Tennyson‚Äôs poetry to inspire their works. I found my muse in a corner of a garden which aptly embodies these words of his‚Ä¶
‚ÄúFlower in the crannied wall,
I pluck you out of the crannies,
I hold you here, root and all, in my hand,
Little flower‚Äîbut if I could understand
What you are, root and all, all in all,
I should know what God and man is.‚Äù
09/10/22, 7:04‚ÄØam
There is something magical about being in nature. You cannot put it in words, but you feel it deep within‚Ä¶it touches your spirit. Just a few minutes of being in nature can make us feel healed and restored. When we walk amidst the trees and reconnect with nature, an indescribable stillness will inescapably pervade within.
John Muir observed this perceptively, ‚ÄúNature‚Äôs peace will flow into you as sunshine flows into trees. The winds will blow their own freshness into you, and the storms their energy, while cares will drop away from you like the leaves of Autumn.‚Äù
As we usher in another World Mental Health Day, let us strive to discover the healing power of nature‚Ä¶
In Rache Carlson‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúThose who dwell among the beauties and mysteries of the earth are never alone or weary of life.‚Äù
10/10/22, 5:33‚ÄØpm

Whenever I saw Dr. Sigmund Freud's library filled with books I used to envy that! And opposition especially in the government the comment is not about the work but shaming the person and party.
12/10/22, 10:24‚ÄØam
Sometimes in the morning I sit on the deck, looking at this Buddha, listening to the sonorous rendering of Mahaparinibbana Sutta which describes the last days of Buddha. Though the recitation is in Pali, an all pervading sense of peace transcends the lyrics.
In his teachings Buddha emphasised the concept of NibbƒÅna, a Pali word for the extinguishing of a fire. A burning fire clings onto its fuel. When it extinguishes, it lets go of it, merging into the cosmos, reaching a state of unbounded freedom.
Buddha elaborated this analogy further in his Addittapariyaya Sutta, commonly known as the Fire Sermon, when he addressed his disciples:
‚ÄúAnd what is all that is burning? Bhikkhus, the eye is burning, visible forms are burning, visual consciousness is burning, visual impression is burning, also whatever sensation, pleasant or painful or neither-painful, nor pleasant, arises on account of the visual impression, that too is burning. Burning with what? Burning with the fire of craving, with the fire of hate, with the fire of delusion; I say it is burning with birth, ageing and death, with sorrows, with lamentations, with pains, with griefs, with despairs.‚Äù
Though the imagery is stark, Buddha draws attention to how suffering is caused by these sensory inputs which fill our minds and hearts with simmering fires of desire and hatred. The quest in life is to quell these fires and find peace within.
13/10/22, 7:47‚ÄØam
My tryst with Buddhist thought and teaching continues‚Ä¶
Over the years, I have been drawn to the teachings of Thich Nhat Hanh.
Caught in the throes of the Vietnam war, he was in a dilemma. Should he confine himself to the monastery and practice meditation or go out and help people? He decided to venture outside and assist people in distress and also be mindful in doing so. This transition from introspection to action laid the foundation for the practice of ‚ÄòEngaged Buddhism‚Äô.
He outlined fourteen precepts of Engaged Buddhism. Two of them in particular have made a deep impression on me. To begin with, truth has to be found in life and not through conceptual knowledge. It is important to engage and learn throughout life by observing within and becoming aware of oneself. The other one is to be cognizant of the existence of suffering in the world and explore ways of attending and redressing it. He articulated his thoughts about the reality of suffering perceptively in his book, No Mud No Lotus, ‚Äú‚ÄúIf you know how to make good use of the mud, you can grow beautiful lotuses.‚Äù
Thich Nhat Hanh also drew attention to how mindfulness can increase our awareness about Mother Earth. ‚ÄúPeople usually consider walking on water or in thin air a miracle. But I think the real miracle is not to walk either on water or in thin air, but to walk on earth. Every day we are engaged in a miracle which we don't even recognize: a blue sky, white clouds, green leaves, the black, curious eyes of a child‚Äîour own two eyes. All is a miracle.‚Äù
These words resonate within whenever I take a stroll and observe the beauty and mystery around me.
Thich Nhat Hanh (whose birthday was on 11th October), opened a vivid personal window of awareness for me‚Ä¶
14/10/22, 8:23‚ÄØam
It was an unusually cold afternoon in Bangalore (several years ago!) and when I entered the Select Bookshop, Mr Murthy‚Äôs warm smile dissipated the chillness instantaneously. Entering Select Bookshop is like stepping back in time. Every inch of the small interior was filled with old books. As I was rummaging through the crowded bookshelves filled with inky treasures, Mr Murthy picked out a book and asked me whether I‚Äôve read cummimngs. Taking up his suggestion, I bought the book.
Later on, when I went through it, I was struck by the innovative and idiosyncratic way he used form, grammar, and syntax in his poems. They were free-form poems mainly in lowercase with unconventional typographic detailing.
It was an uneven collection. But one particular poem titled, [somewhere i have never travelled,gladly beyond], caught my attention. In my MD exam written paper when there was a question on empathy, I took the liberty of quoting a few lines from the poem. During the viva, the examiner Dr Sarada Menon commented with a twinkle in her eyes to the other examiners, ‚Äúlook at this fellow quoting poetry in his exam paper!‚Äù These are those lines:
your slightest look easily will unclose me
though i have closed myself as fingers,
you open always petal by petal myself as Spring opens
(touching skilfully,mysteriously) her first rose
ee cummimngs wrote many poems in celebration of the natural world. I‚Äôve quoted some of his lines in this appended photograph of mine. ee cummings also dappled in painting. When I was looking through some of his works, I was struck by its similarity with my photograph!
Today is ee cumming‚Äôs birthday‚Ä¶
15/10/22, 8:04‚ÄØam
Hindi poet Suryakant Tripathi Nirala died on this day in 1961.
He gave voice to the marginalised sections of the society in his works. In a poem titled, ‚ÄúWah Todti Patthar‚Äù he narrated the torment of a woman breaking stones for a living. This has been translated into English by another poet, Arvind Krishna Mehrotra. There is also another version by the historian Romila Thapar.
BREAKING STONES
Beside a road in Allahabad,
I saw her
breaking stones.
No tree to give her shade,
A dark skin,
Firm, tightly-cupped breasts,
Eyes fixed on the ground,
Thoughts of the night before
Going through her mind,
She brought down the heavy hammer
Again and again, as though it was
A weapon in her hand.
Across the road‚Äî
A row of trees, high walls,
The mansions of the rich.
The sun climbed the sky.
The height of summer.
Blinding heat, and the loo blowing hard,
Scorching everything in its path.
The earth under the feet
Like burning cotton wool,
The air filled with dust and sparks.
It was almost noon,
And she was still breaking stones.
As I watched,
She looked at me once,
Then at the houses opposite,
Then at her ragged clothes.
Seeing there was no one around,
She met my eyes again
With eyes that spoke of painBut not defeat.
Suddenly, there came the notes of a sitar,
Such as I had not heard before.
The next moment her young body
Quivered and as sweat
Trickled down her face, she lifted
The hammer, resuming work,
As though to say,
I‚Äôm breaking stones.
(The photo is not mine and is from the net!)

20/10/22, 8:11‚ÄØam
Kurunthokai is the second of the Eight Anthologies in Sangam literature.
Composed between 100 CE and 300 CE, it contains works by 295 poets.
This particular verse No133 was written by the poet Uraiur Muthukannan Sathanar
‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æü‡Æµ‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æö‡Æø‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øà

‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æ£‡Øç‡ÆÆ‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡Æí‡Æ≤‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Ææ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ, ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç
‡Æâ‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç, ‡Æâ‡Æ≥‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡Øá ‡Æ§‡Øã‡Æ¥‡Æø, ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç
‡Æ®‡Æ≤‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æâ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ≤‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øá.
This commentary is by U Ve Swaminatha Iyer who is singularly responsible for bringing classical tamil poetry into the limelight.
‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ≥‡Æø ‡Æâ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ÆÆ‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ¥‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Ææ‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Æ≤‡ØÅ‡Æ£‡Øç‡ÆÆ‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æü‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤, ‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Øà‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ÆÆ‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æ≤‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ¥‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æâ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æ≥‡Øá‡Æ©‡Øç
In this verse, the heroine laments to her friend:
Hilly tribes plough the land and grow golden yellow millets. Parrots eat the grains and leave the stalks denuded.Yet, when it starts to rain the half eaten stalks sprout fresh leaves.
I am in a similar situation. I lost my maidenhood with him. Yet I live in the hope that he will come back as promised, like the rain reviving the half eaten stalks.
23/10/22, 10:30‚ÄØpm

25/10/22, 9:19‚ÄØam
Narakasura who figures prominently in the Deepavali legend has many stories associated with him. He was deemed to have been born from the union of Bhudevi and Varaha. This is a beautiful relief sculpture of Varaha and Bhudevi in the second cave at Badami.
According to the narratives from the North east of India, he was a king who ruled over Pragjyotishapura, which is modern day Assam. He was besotted with the beauty of Devi Kamakhya and wanted to marry her. The Goddess playfully put a condition on him that if he was able to build a staircase from the bottom of Nilachal hills to the temple within one night before the cock crowed to indicate dawn, then she would marry him. Narakasura accepted the condition and worked with all his might and was about to accomplish the task before dawn. When Kamakhya Devi got this news she made a cock to crow to convey the impression that it was already dawn. Angered by this, Narakasura chased the rooster, slew it and then entered into a battle with the Devi. During the course of the battle, Kamakhya Devi revealed herself as Maa Kali. Realising his mistake, Narakasura fell at her feet and requested that he be remembered as a devotee and not as a demon after his death. Maa Kamakhya granted the same and killed Narakasura with her trident on the Chaturdasi day. The incomplete staircase is known as the Mekhela Ujua Path and is used by devotees even today, to walk to the Kamakhya temple.
When I was reading about this, I was reminded of Led Zeppelin‚Äôs ‚ÄòStairway To Heaven‚Äô.
And as we wind on down the road
Our shadows taller than our soul
There walks a lady we all know
Who shines white light and wants to show
How everything still turns to gold
And if you listen very hard
The tune will come to you at last
When all are one and one is all, yeah‚Ä¶
25/10/22, 12:39‚ÄØpm
Such a beautiful sculpture clearly depicting Varaha, Bhudevi and Narakasura. And the write up. The wordings in Stairway to Heaven matches so well with the Naraka Chaturdashi. Thank you Sir.
27/10/22, 7:50‚ÄØam
During my Commonwealth fellowship (decades ago!)I used to explore various parts of the United Kingdom almost every weekend, thanks to the student's pass in the British Rail. The beautiful, untamed Welsh landscape had a special allure for me. During one such visit, I requested my student who was working in Carmarthen to take me to Dylan Thomas‚Äô writing shed. We made our way along Dylan's Walk to a simple, small structure perched on the edge of a cliff. When I peered through the window, I could see some cigarette butts, empty beer bottles and paper strewn on the floor in that sparsely furnished room. The setting sun cast its light through the window, which offered a lovely glimpse of the estuary. I could imagine Dylan sitting there, looking at the landscape which he loved dearly,writing his poems. It was the place where he completed his ‚ÄòUnder Milk Wood‚Äô.
Dylan died young at the age of 39 after a heavy drinking bout complicated by pneumonia. His life and works have had a lasting impact on many. Bob Dylan changed his last name from Zimmerman in homage to the poet. One can spot Dylan Thomas (just above Marlon Brando) on the iconic cover of the Beatles‚Äô album Sgt. Pepper‚Äôs Lonely Hearts Club Band.
Poetry opens our inner world and that is particularly true about Dylan‚Äôs powerfully articulated poem, ‚ÄòDo Not Go Gentle Into That Night‚Äô written on the background of his father‚Äôs ailment. It set off cascades of inner conversations within me when I was tending to the elderly in our family during their final days. I was caught in a conundrum: as a physician should I facilitate ‚Äòrage, rage against the dying of light‚Äô or quietly observe a life gently ebbing away. This is a predicament for everyone involved in end of life care.
On his birthday today I also wonder whether these lines have a larger canvas and ambit of impact. In the throes of unrelenting climate change, we realise that the earth we live in has a fragile existence and an uncertain future. Dylan was perhaps encouraging us to rage, rage against that dying light.
Of course there's a lot more to rage about, these days‚Ä¶
08/11/22, 9:04‚ÄØam
Today is Kartik Purnima. According to one of the legends (a lengthy one which I have summarised for sake of brevity), Vidyunmali, Tarakaksha and Viryavana were three rakshasa sons of Taraka. After getting a boon from Brahma they built three cities, Tripura. They also requested that the only way they could die was if somebody could destroy all three cities with a single arrow. Brahma granted their wish.On Kartik Purnima, Lord Shiva vanquished all of them with a single arrow, putting an end to their reign. This manifestation of Shiva is called Tripurantaka. ("Tri" means Three, "pura" means cities and "antaka" means destroyer.) When the Devatas heard this, they rejoiced and declared the day as Dev Diwali, Diwali for the gods.
This is an exquisite mural in the ceiling of the Rangamantapa of Virupaksha temple at Hampi, which depicts Tripuranataka. In it, four-armed Shiva is shown in a chariot with his right leg in front and the left leg behind and raised. The left hand is holding the bow string on which the arrow is set. The right hand is holding the arrow in horizontal position, which is about to be released. Shiva is sporting a blue dhoti and his body is adorned with jewels. Behind him is a Nagini holding an umbrella and above his shoulder is a kinnar (a celestial musician, half human and half horse) carrying a bell. The sun and the moon at the top of the picture represents twilight. The Tripuras are represented with three circles. When the wheel of the chariot got stuck in the sand, it could not come out even with Lord Shiva‚Äôs efforts. In the mural one can see Lord Vishnu in the form of a bull and digging the earth to bring the chariot out.
There is a temple devoted to Tripurantaka, built around 1070 by the Western Chalukyas in Balligave town of Shivamogga district, in Karnataka state.
Incidentally I also found out that there is a cicada in India naed as Meimuna Tripurasura!
11/11/22, 7:40‚ÄØam
Along with His Holiness the Dalai Lama, Thich Nhat Hanh has had a deep impact on me, personally as well as in my therapeutic work. I was also drawn to his teaching wherein he emphasized the interconnectedness of the Buddhist way of being and love of nature. According to him, even a simple act of walking mindfully can be a meditative practice. In his words:
Look again, you will see me in you and in every leaf and flower bud.
Walk and touch peace every moment.
Walk and touch happiness every moment.
Each step brings a fresh breeze.
Each step makes a flower bloom.
Kiss the Earth with your feet.
Bring the Earth your love and happiness.
The Earth will be safe
when we feel safe in ourselves.
(11th November was Thich Nhah Hanh‚Äôs birthday)

29/11/22, 7:25‚ÄØam
Both Ahalya and myself are Beatles aficionados. We have a good collection of their music (as LPs!) and listen to them often.
George Harrison was the most spiritual of all the Beatles. His tryst with Eastern music and religion was kindled by Ravi Shankar. The first time he used a sitar riff was in ‚ÄòNorwegian Wood‚Äô. He read extensively. In his own words, "I had read enough from the Vivekenandas and Yoganandas, to comprehend how to see God: by using the Yogic system of transcending through the relative states of consciousness to get to the most subtle level of pure consciousness. It is at that level that the individual experiences pure awareness, pure consciousness, the source of all being‚Ä¶‚Äù
His engagement and involvement in spiritual pursuits finds reflection in many of his songs. I particularly like ‚ÄòThe Inner Light‚Äô. The lyrics are inspired by a section of the Tao Te Ching, written by Lao Tsu, a contemporary of Confucius. There are 81 short chapters of Tao Te Ching. "Inner Light" is the title of Chapter 47, which in translation reads as:
Without going outside, you may know the whole world
Without looking through the window, you may see the ways of heaven
The farther you go, the less you know
Thus the sage knows without travelling
He sees without looking
He works without doing
Harrison's tweaked theses lines a bit, yet essentially conveying its inherent meaning:
Without going outside of your door
You can know all things on earth
Without looking out of your window
You could know the ways of heaven
The farther one travels
The less one knows
The less one really knows
Arrive without travelling
See all without looking
Do all without doing
When George died on 29th November 2001, Ravi Shankar was by his side as verses from the Bhagavad Gita were chanted. His ashes were later immersed in the Ganges as per his wish.
20/12/22, 8:20‚ÄØam
After birding around the Coyote hills, when we ventured into the Arastradero Preserve, in Santa Clara county, the call of the acorn woodpecker welcomed us. Its call was reportedly the inspiration for the cartoon character, Woody Woodpecker! The story goes that Walter Lantz, the creator of the cartoon character and his new bride, Grace, were on their honeymoon in a cabin in California. They were disturbed by a loud sound as if someone was laughing. When they went out to check, they spotted an Acorn Woodpecker, pounding away at the roof nonchalantly and Woody was born!
The terrain of the preserve was largely grassland with great old oak trees. When I saw this magnificent tree with its bare branches, I was struck by its resemblance to mysterious neural networks in our brain.
There is always something of an unknown presence embedded in such knotty tangles‚Ä¶
21/12/22, 10:49‚ÄØpm

26/01/22, 8:56‚ÄØam
India is no more a ‚Äòyoung‚Äô republic.
As we step into the 73rd year of the republic, it is a rather unsettling fact that India‚Äôs share of the world‚Äôs extreme poor is higher than its share of the world population.
The World Inequality Database developed by Thomas Piketty and colleagues reveals an alarming rise in both wealth and income inequality in India.
On this day, let us resolve to address this issue and attempt to narrow the yawning gap‚Ä¶
Plutarch, the Greek philosopher drew attention to it, aeons ago‚Ä¶

Today is the birthday of Roger Waters. His iconic song ‚ÄòAnother Brick In The Wall‚Äô is an incisive view on formal education and a protest against authority. The bricks are people, or events, which turns us inward, away from others and reality. It essentially draws attention to the process of thought control when concepts and ideas are imprinted on our minds through totalitarian means. Timeless‚Ä¶

15/11/22, 9:52‚ÄØam
As I was strolling across the garden this cup shaped flower in dazzling colour caught my eye. It was gently swaying in the wind. Its name sounded so appropriate when I read about it. The name of this flower comes from the Greek word anem≈çnƒì which means ‚Äòthe daughter of the wind‚Äô. It is a compound of the word √°nemos (‚Äòthe wind god‚Äô) and a feminine suffix ≈çnƒì (‚Äòdaughter‚Äô).
To paraphrase Victor Hugo, a garden to walk in and to dream in‚Ä¶what more could I ask for?
27/11/22, 8:10‚ÄØam
Jekyll island with its scenic seascapes is one of the charming places in Georgia.
One day while walking amidst tall oak trees dripping with fuzzy tendrils of moss, we chanced upon a building in ruins. A small plaque outside the house mentioned it as the Horton House and offered some details about it.
William Horton was one of the earliest settlers in Jekyll island and built the house in 1736. It was built of tabby, a unique material which was commonly used along the Georgia coast during the 18th and 19th centuries. Tabby was made by burning oyster shells to create lime, then mixing it with water, sand, ash and broken oyster shells. The mixture was then poured into moulds to form blocks with which the structure was built.
Though the house has survived the American revolution, war between the states and hurricane, it is in ruins now with time scarred mould laden walls.
There is something melancholic about an abandoned house in ruins.
As I stepped into a crumbling room with a broken window, the languid rays of the setting sun shone through the trees.
In that fleeting moment, I was transported into the world of those people, long forgotten, who would have looked through that window on many evenings.
And the place came alive‚Ä¶.
27/11/22, 10:19‚ÄØpm
Ecofriendly construction lasted so long! What a view through the broken window. Remnants reminding the past....

04/01/23, 9:24‚ÄØam
It was an incredible experience to usher in the New Year amidst the magical terrain of the Death Valley.
Desert landscapes are stunning to behold‚Ä¶
Their unique coloration creates a vivid visual experience.
Words fail to describe the dreamy environs coming alive at sunrise.
