06/01/23, 10:49‚ÄØam
On the occasion of Arudra Darisanam dedicated to the cosmic dance of Lord Siva, let me recall my visit to Banteay Srei, the jewel of Khmer Art. Each and every section of this small temple is exquisitely carved. This beautiful depiction of Aada Vallan or Dancing Siva is on the eastern side of the temple. Below him is Indira riding his Airavata, which is depicted as a monster-like figure with an elephant head. Indira (unfortunately his head is missing) is seen holding the elephant trunk on the right hand and the monster head on the left hand. The two other Airvatas are on the corners of the bas relief. On Siva‚Äôs left is a percussionist playing on the drum. On the right of Siva is a depiction of an emaciated woman, Karaikkal Ammaiyar. She was a Bhakti poet and one of the three women amongst the 63 Nayanmars, a group of saints devoted to Lord Siva.
Sekhizhar in his monumental work ‚ÄòPeriyapuranam‚Äô narrates the story of Karaikkal Ammaiyar. She began her life as Punithavathi and was married to Paramadattan. One day Paramadattan sent two mangoes to her telling her to keep them for his lunch. An hour or so later Lord Siva came as a mendicant, begging for alms. As food wasn‚Äôt ready, Punithavathi offered him one of the mangoes. When her husband returned, Punithavathi served him the other one. When he asked for the other one, she was desperate and prayed to Lord Siva and a ripe mango fell into her palm. Finding the fruit bigger and tastier, he asked her where she got it. When she related what had happened, Paramadattan was unconvinced and asked her to procure another such fruit. Punithavathi prayed again and received one more fruit but it vanished when her husband tried to touch it. Taken aback, Paramadattan realised that she had divine qualities and deserted her. Stung by this, she left home to pursue an ascetic path and prayed to Lord Siva to release her from the shackles of the physical body. Hence many iconographic depictions of her portray her in an emaciated form.
There is a small temple dedicated to her in Karaikkal. Every year Mangani (Mango) festival is celebrated commemorating this story. During this festival Lord Siva is taken in procession as Bikshadana with his begging bowl and people throw mangoes from the rooftops.
Karaikkal Ammaiyar composed beautiful verses in praise of Lord Siva:
‡Æá‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ§ ‡Æá‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ™ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç
‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øà ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡ÆÆ‡ØÄ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Øá‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Øà ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øà ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç
‡Æá‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ¥‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æü‡Æø
‡ÆÖ‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ®‡ØÄ ‡ÆÜ‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æâ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æü‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÄ‡Æ¥‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï.
I pray for the infinite happiness of Your love
I do not want to be born again
If I do, I do not want to forget You forever
If I do, I want to be happily singing in Your praise
Under Your feet as You are dancing‚Äù.
14/01/23, 10:48‚ÄØam
13th December is the last day of the Tamil month Margazhi which ushers in the Pongal festival. It occurs on the last day of Dakshinayana, a six month cycle of the Sun‚Äôs course moving south, which is followed by a six month cycle of the Sun‚Äôs course moving north called Uttarayana.
During Bhogi, people clean their houses, get rid of unwanted things, symbolically setting them on fire. Perhaps it reminds us that we need to give up all our negativities, and unwanted thoughts in the smouldering fire.
Mythologically it is an invocation to a divine force, Lord Indra, "the God of Clouds and Rains' ',seeking his benevolence to bring in good rains and help the farmers.
This is a beautifully carved sculpture of Lord Indra with Indrani on his vehicle Airavat, from the 13th century Chennakeshava temple at Somanathpua, near Mysore
15/01/23, 2:26‚ÄØpm
What a fantastic sculpture. So much of intricacyü§î Thank you Sir. Wish all of you the same.
16/01/23, 7:43‚ÄØam
The third day of Pongal is celebrated as Mattu Pongal to thank and revere the cattle which play an important role in the lives of the agricultural community. Their horns are painted in vibrant colours and decorated with bells and other ornaments.
This beautifully sculpted wooden figure (which is the size of a large postage stamp!) is from within the main temple tower at Thiruppudaimarthur, Tirunelveli district
29/01/23, 9:36‚ÄØam
When I was ambling along the corridors of the Durga temple at Aihole sometime ago, I noticed a sculpture of a serene, elegant, bejewelled person in a pillar. What caught my attention was a figure of a woman with legs of horse on his left. Unfortunately, her face was disfigured. At that time I was not sure of its iconographic importance.
Yesterday on the occasion of Ratha Saptami, when I was reading about the legends associated with Surya, I wondered whether this sculpture represents Surya and his wife.
According to the legends, Vishvakarma‚Äôs daughter, Sanjana was married to Surya. After bearing him three children, she found his brilliance too oppressive and the heat unbearable. Hence she took the form of a shadow, Chhaya to take her place. Chhaya did not disclose her identity to Surya and had two sons and two daughters from him. Later when Surya realized that Chhaya was not Sanjana he was extremely annoyed and banished Chhaya away. He went in search of Sanjana and enquired about her whereabouts with her father Vishvakarma who he told him that she was living in the forest. Surya went in search in the forest and found her in the form of a mare and united with her.
Chhaya who represents darkness was the manifestation of Sanjana who is deemed to be the source of all conscious thought. Ignorance is darkness which is dispelled by the light of awareness. Not surprisingly, the symbol associated with Sanjana is walnut which has a striking similarity with human brain!
There is plenty to ponder in mythology!
15/03/23, 7:01‚ÄØam
From the moment we are born, we begin our journey towards death. Understandably this prospect often evokes intense fear. It is suggested that one can negotiate this fear in three ways: through knowledge as epitomized by Nachiketa, by adopting a path of bhakti like Markandeya and by sheer power of love as symbolized by Savitri.
During Karadaiyan Nombu which is observed today, women offer prayers for the longevity and wellbeing of their husbands and celebrate great encounter of Savitri and Yama, the God of Death.
Savitri was the daughter of the King of Madradesha. She was exceedingly beautiful and when she reached marriageable age, though many princes admired her, none of them came forward to marry her, overawed by her beauty. Her father told her to go forth and select her own husband. Savitri visited many kingdoms but could not find the husband of her choice. On her way back home, she saw a young man in a forest serving an old couple with utter devotion. She was immediately drawn to him and informed her choice to her father. When Narada heard about it, he informed her that the young man she had chosen, Sathyavan, had a very short life and would die after a year. Savitri‚Äôs parents were shattered on hearing this and requested her to reconsider her choice. A determined Savitri married Sathyavan and went to the forest and assumed her new role with great joy. But deep within, she was afraid and could not forget Narada‚Äôs prophecy. As the day of death drew near, she began to fast and offer prayers with utmost piety. Finally, on the dreaded day, she decided to accompany her husband when he went into the forest as she did not want to be separated from him even for a short while. Yama made his appearance and starting pulling Sathyavan with his noose. To his astonishment he saw Savitri following him and asked her to return back. But Savitri said that it was her dharma to accompany her husband everywhere and she could not give it up. Pleased with her words he granted her many boons with which she restored the kingdom and eyesight of her father in law. But she still continued to follow him. Finally, impressed by her intense devotion, Yama restored the life of her husband and blessed them.
Interestingly festivals are associated with particular type of food. Karadaiyan Nombu is no exception. On this day, a special dish ‚ÄòKaradai‚Äô is prepared from rice flour, black eyed peas, jaggery and coconut and it is believed that Savitri prepared this special dish and offered it with butter to Lord Yama as a thanksgiving gesture for returning the life of Satyvan.
There are few representations of Yama in sculptural form. This image is from Khajuraho and depicts a four armed Yama. His vehicle, buffalo can be seen on the lower right hand corner. If one looks carefully, one can notice a cock in his right hand. There is an interesting story behind it. One day Yama attempted to kick his mother in a fit of rage. Incensed by this, Sanjana, his mother cursed that he would have a perennial wound infested with maggots which would never heal. Heeding to his request, Surya granted him a cock which ate all the vermin in his leg. And hence the cock in his hand!
23/03/23, 5:26‚ÄØpm
Sorry for the delay Sir. Was down with viral fever. Thank you and wish all of you the same.
14/04/23, 1:02‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir and wish you all the same.
22/04/23, 8:00‚ÄØam
Today is Akshaya Tritiya, a day when people throng the jewellery shops to buy gold. The word ‚ÄòAkshaya‚Äô means ‚Äònever diminishing‚Äô and hence the belief that buying the precious metal on this day guarantees endless wealth.
Like many festivals in India, Akshaya Tritiya has several legends connected with it. It is an important day in Jainism and is associated with Adinatha, the first of the 24 Tirthankaras. Rishabadeva, king of Ayodhya gave up all earthly pleasures (much like Gautam Buddha), to lead the life of a monk as Adinatha. In order to live as a Jain monk, one must not possess anything, not even a morsel of food. When he started begging for food, his subjects offered him their most prized possessions like precious stones, elephants, horses but not food or drink which they thought was too modest an offering for their dear king. The king refused all the fine gifts and went without food and water until, finally, his grandson Shreyansha Kumara understood his need and offered him some sugarcane juice. With this juice, Adinatha broke his fast that had lasted 400 days.
It was on Akshaya Tritiya day that Adinatha broke his fast. As a mark of reverence to Lord Adinatha and his strict penance, Jains celebrate this day as ‚ÄúParna Diwas‚Äù after the penance of Varshi Tap and end their year-long alternative-day fasting with sugarcane juice.
This photograph is from Cave 4 at Badamai. Carved into its wall is a beautiful, life-size relief of Adinatha. He is standing in Kayotsarga pose, with unbent knees and straight arms, which are held at the side and do not touch the body. It is representative of an ascetic practice characterised by detachment of the physical body. Adinatha has locks of hair cascading down his shoulders and this is one of the ways to identify his sculpture. There is an interesting story behind this. When he chose to become an ascetic, Rishbadeva started pulling out his long strands of hair. After four fistfuls, when he was pulling out the fifth fistful of hair Indra is said to have told him, " This strand of hair on the crown of your head and hanging down over your shoulders looks attractive. Kindly leave it as it is." Rishabadeva agreed. Due to this bunch of hair he got the popular name; Keshariya ji (one with hair).
As for myself, I am a miner for gold‚Ä¶in the hearts of peopleÔÅä
01/05/23, 9:00‚ÄØam
The purpose of celebrating May Day is to recognize and honour the enormous contributions made by the working class and inform them of their rights, to protect them against exploitation.
During the Industrial Revolution of the 1800s, the United States experienced great turmoil in the labour sector. There were very few protections in place for workers, so many men, women, and children worked long hours, doing excruciating labour, causing many to die. This unrest came to a head on May 1, 1886, as more than 300,000 workers walked out in protest of poor working conditions and in support of an eight-hour work day in the United States. This labour strike marked May 1 as International Workers‚Äô Day as well. It started the eight hour movement, promoting a schedule of eight hours for labour, eight hours for recreation, and eight hours for rest.
The first May Day celebrations took place on May 1st 1890 after its proclamation by the first international congress of socialist parties in Europe on July 14th 1889 in Paris, France, to dedicate May 1 every year as the "Workers Day of International Unity and Solidarity."
In India, the first May Day was celebrated on May 1, 1923, in Madras. It was organised by the Labour Kisan Party of Hindustan. It was during this day, the prominent Communist leader Malayapuram Singaravelu Chettiar hoisted the red flag in Chennai.
Over the years, we are witnessing increasing internal migration of people in search of work, wherever they can find one. They play a pivotal role in our country. Living away from home is never easy. Many of them work without any contract without regular, assured pay. Nor does this section receive any meaningful help from the state.
On this May Day, let us strive to strengthen their invisible hands‚Ä¶
(This panel from the Bayon temple, Krong Siem Reap, Cambodia depicts a group of workers actively engaged in their task)
12/05/23, 2:45‚ÄØpm
At 40, Franz Kafka (1883-1924), who never married and had no children, was walking through a park one day in Berlin when he met a girl who was crying because she had lost her favourite doll. She and Kafka searched for the doll unsuccessfully.
Kafka told her to meet him there the next day and they would come back to look for her.
The next day, when they had not yet found the doll, Kafka gave the girl a letter "written" by the doll saying "please don't cry. I took a trip to see the world. I will write to you about my adventures."
Thus began a story which continued until the end of Kafka's life.
During their meetings, Kafka read the letters of the doll carefully written with adventures and conversations that the girl found adorable.
Finally, Kafka brought back the doll (he bought one) that had returned to Berlin.
"It doesn't look like my doll at all," said the girl.
Kafka handed her another letter in which the doll wrote: "my travels have changed me." The little girl hugged the new doll and brought the doll with her to her happy home.
A year later Kafka died.
Many years later, the now-adult girl found a letter inside the doll. In the tiny letter signed by Kafka it was written:
"Everything you love will probably be lost, but in the end, love will return in another way."
Embrace change. It's inevitable for growth. Together we can shift pain into wonder and love, but it is up to us to consciously and intentionally create that connection.
24/05/23, 8:37‚ÄØam
World Turtle Day is an annual event (that was celebrated yesterday) aimed at increasing public awareness about the important need to protect the shrinking habitats of turtle and tortoises.
Hindu mythology is replete with references to animals, including tortoise. Prominent among them is the churning of the ocean (Samudra Manthan), which appears in several texts such as the Mahabharata, Vishnu Purana and Bhagavata Purana. To churn the primordial ocean, Mount Mandara was used as a churning rod and the snake, Vasuki as the churning rope. The Asuras held the head of the snake and the Devas held its tail and they pulled his body alternately, causing the mountain to rotate and the ocean to churn. In the process, slowly Mount Mandara began to sink. Vishnu, in his second avatar as the tortoise Kurma, came to the rescue and supported the mountain on his shell. Without Kurma avatar it would not have been possible for the ocean to be churned and the devas would not have received the fourteen gifts. The churning also resulted in the poison, ‚Äòhalahala‚Äô, which was imbibed by Lord Shiva to protect the universe from destruction.
The tortoise, as a symbol of the earth also figures in several vedic and puranic texts. According to these representation, the tortoise‚Äôs domed shell is heaven and the flat underside is the earth. Further, the kurmanivesha (tortoise abode) is central to Hindu astrology, wherein the body of the tortoise would be divided up into nakshatras (constellations) that influenced the regions occupying a certain body part. For instance, the head often represented the eastern region of the earth.
Turtle is considered very lucky in astrology and it is believed that Goddess Lakshmi, showers blessings on those who wear the ‚Äòturtle ring.‚Äô
There are three temples in India where Kurma is the main deity: Srikumaram near Srikakulam, Gavirangapura near Hosadurga and Kurma Varadaraja Swamy temple in Chittoor district. Prominent among them is Srikurmam, where the presiding Deity, Lord Kurma is self-manifest, or svayambhu. He is about 70 cm long, shaped like the shell of a turtle. The Deity‚Äôs tail is a saligram presented by Adi Sankara. In the temple‚Äôs premises, a tortoise park has also been built to conserve the adult and young star tortoises, which are found in the foothills and fields of Srikakulam. A stellar example of conservation which is in tune with the cultural and religious beliefs of people..
Let me conclude with this beautiful verse in the Sangam poetry, Kurunthokai, where the poet wrote:
‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ¥‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Øã‡Æ∞‡Øá,
‡Æ§‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡Øà ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤ ‡Æâ‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æü‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡Æö‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æé‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æü‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Øã,
‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©,
‡Æï‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Æ± ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øá?
Those who chide me, know not a thing
my passion is like a hatchling of tortoise
sustained by its mother;
if my lover forsakes me, it‚Äôll wither
like an unhatched egg, for what else can sustains it?
(This photograph of Kurma Avatar is from a pillar at the hundred pillar mandapam at Varadaraja Swamy temple, Kanchipuram. Each pillar, adorned with exquisite carvings, is a treasure to savour)
(Kindly do not share the post with due acknowledgement!)
01/06/23, 6:20‚ÄØam
Yesterday I had written about the role of chance and the throw of dice. The game of dice played a crucial role in the Mahabharata. The Kauravas (led by Duryodhana) challenged the Pa·πá·∏çavas to a game of dice and in the process robbed them of their kingdom, violated their queen Draupadi, and exiled them for thirteen years. As a consequence of these egregious acts, war between the two sets of cousins unfolded.
The dice game contained one of the most disturbing instances in the epic. When Draupadi underwent humiliation at the hands of the Kauravas, the elders who were present did nothing to stop the act. They chose to be passive witnesses to the horrendous act. Standing before her husbands and elders, humiliated and shamed, she questions Yudhi·π£·π≠hira, ‚ÄúWhom did you lose first, yourself or me?‚Äù This most poignant question was met with deafening silence. Draupadi comments, ‚ÄúIt is sad; in this vast assembly here, there are no elders in the true sense. The so called elders are unable say what is Dharma. There is neither Dharma nor Truth here‚Äù.
Why were the most eminent men in the hall blind to the immense suffering caused to Draupadi? The concept of dharma ruptured at that moment.
Pratibha Ray‚Äôs "Yajnaseni: The Story of Draupadi" is one of the most powerful narratives which unravels the dilemma and plight of Draupadi. The author gives voice to Draupadi‚Äôs angst, ‚ÄúFull of anguish and anger I was thinking: was woman merely man‚Äôs movable or immovable property? Being a woman did I not have the right even over myself, my own soul? If they had rights over this body of mine, did it mean they could do as they wished with me?‚Äù
The same question arises when one witnesses the plight and suffering of women wrestlers who brought glory to our country.
Wonder whether anything has changed at all? Draupadi continues to be slighted even today.
(This photograph which depicts the dice game from Mahabharata, is from a small panel in the Amruteshwara Temple at Amruthapura in Chikmagalur district)
06/06/23, 8:35‚ÄØam
Alexander Pushkin (whose birthday is today) is unquestionably Russia‚Äôs greatest writer and poet. Many consider him as the founder of modern Russian literature. In addition to being a master of the Russian language, he spoke ten other languages. His library in his St Petersburg apartment had over 4,500 books in 14 languages.
‚ÄòYevgeny Onegin‚Äô was his major work and a masterpiece. He completed the work during a course of three months when he was in forced quarantine during a major cholera outbreak. It is a story of love, loss, rejection and despair of Onegin, who wastes his life, allows the girl who loves him to marry another, and lets himself be drawn into a duel in which he kills his best friend. It is a novel in verse form and was the muse for Vikram Seth‚Äôs ‚ÄúGolden Gate‚Äô. Inspired by the novel, Tchaikovsky wrote a brilliant opera.
Throughout his life Pushkin took part in 90 duels and initiated 15 of them himself. One of those duels turned out to be his last when he was mortally wounded, defending his wife‚Äôs honour. He died with a substantial debt unpaid. Tsar Nicholas I, with whom Pushkin had a difficult relationship, ordered that the poet‚Äôs debt be paid off from the country‚Äôs treasury.
Pushkin‚Äôs oeuvre is unbelievably broad. He wrote classical odes, romantic poems, historical drama, novellas, short stories, fairy tales and travel journals. This poem titled, ‚ÄòA Little Bird‚Äô, is a favourite of mine:
In alien lands I keep the body
Of ancient native rites and things:
I gladly free a little birdie
At celebration of the spring.
I'm now free for consolation,
And thankful to almighty Lord:
At least, to one of his creations
I've given freedom in this world!
13/06/23, 8:44‚ÄØam
Long ago when I was on a Commonwealth Fellowship in London, I was staying on the outskirts of the city which involved lengthy commute by the tube. During all these travels, what kept me company were poems that were strategically placed on posters and billboards across the tube stations. I was introduced to many a poet and WB Yeats (whose birthday is today), was one among them. I particularly liked this poem of his:
HE WISHES FOR THE CLOTHS OF HEAVEN
Had I the heavens' embroidered cloths,
Enwrought with golden and silver light,
The blue and the dim and the dark cloths
Of night and light and the half-light,
I would spread the cloths under your feet:
But I, being poor, have only my dreams;
I have spread my dreams under your feet;
Tread softly because you tread on my dreams.
How can one forget these lines from his poem, ‚ÄòThe Second Coming‚Äô:
Turning and turning in the widening gyre
The falcon cannot hear the falconer;
Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold;
Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world,
The blood-dimmed tide is loosed, and everywhere
The ceremony of innocence is drowned;
The best lack all conviction, while the worst
Are full of passionate intensity.
The last two lines are unsettling true, even now‚Ä¶
30/06/23, 2:11‚ÄØpm
Today I lost one of my fellow travelers whom I had been treating for several decades. He was first admitted in NIMHANS with catatonia. He was in this state for a week and recovered with medication. Ever since that episode he has been in regular touch with me. Occasionally, he would slip into catatonia, but would recover quickly, to carry on his work as a teacher in a reputed residential school. Whenever I enquired about these episodes, there would be a lovely smile on his face, but he wouldn‚Äôt speak much about it. I was aware that there was a deep emotional substrate for his behavior, but made it a point not to force him, to ‚Äòelicit‚Äô psychopathology. It was a relationship built on compassion and empathy imbued with tacit trust. Being a fiercely independent person, he made the decision to live by himself and not return to his family home after retirement. He lived alone in a small house built entirely from his savings. He designed it in such a way so as to accommodate his vast collection of western music, which I would hear in the background during his calls, every month. Very regular with medication, he never skipped even a single dose.
A few years ago, on his own, he shared with me that he has been hearing voices which increased during these episodes and went on to offer a vivid description of them. He added as to how medications helped him to cope with them.
He was an aficionado of western classic music and used to send me YouTube links of the choicest recordings every morning. When I opened my computer this morning, there was none.
He would be the first person to wish me on ‚ÄòTeachers Day‚Äô. When I look back, I feel that he taught me many a thing about a chronic illness like schizophrenia. For people like him, it is a journey, often alone, in a strange country which as professionals we still strive to unravel. It continues to be an unsettling emotional terrain which patients negotiate with their own internal resources and remarkable resilience and he was a stellar example of that. He was alive even during the darkest moments in his life and the flame still glows.
Farewell my friend‚Ä¶
30/06/23, 5:14‚ÄØpm
A resilient person indeed. Music must have been his soul mate during the solitary journey. Wish he continues his journey peacefully.
11/07/23, 10:47‚ÄØam
This year, Ahalya reaches a milestone on 23rd July, when she turns 70! Yes indeed -- hard to believe, but it's true!
Rahul created a Facebook page for you to share your memories, anecdotes, wishes and anything else that you may like to, from knowing her all these years. She will treasure this as the best gift on this occasion. If you are not in Facebook, pen your thoughts with photos (if you have some!) and send it across to rahul.raguram@gmail.com

26/07/23, 11:33‚ÄØam
There is always a hidden side in each one of us. It is a part of our self which we do not like or acknowledge. It consists of everything that does not align with our conscious self. CG Jung whose birthday is today, termed it as the ‚Äòshadow‚Äô and emphasized that it offers a doorway to understand ourselves. The shadow is a cognitive blind spot of our psyche and Jung described it as ‚Äúthe thing a person has no wish to be‚Äù.
Often we identify and respond to the shadow of the others, with ease. It is a truism that what we dislike in others is an indication of what we dislike in ourselves. We hide our negative qualities, not only from others but from ourselves too.
The meeting with oneself is, at first, the meeting with one‚Äôs own shadow. Prising apart the doors of shadow offers us a glimpse of that part of our personality that conflicts with the ideal version of ourselves. It is the first step towards increasing our awareness about our self. As Jung commented, ‚Äúone must learn to know oneself in order to know who one is‚Ä¶ one does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light, but by making the darkness conscious‚Äù
Unravelling and working through the shadow is a crucial component in therapy. As Jung commented, ‚ÄúThere is no generally effective technique for assimilating the shadow. It is more like diplomacy or statesmanship and it is always an individual matter. First one has to accept and take seriously the existence of the shadow. Second, one has to become aware of its qualities and intentions. This happens through conscientious attention to moods, fantasies and impulses. Third, a long process of negotiation is unavoidable.‚Äù
Jung went on to add, ‚Äúthe task in life is not to become perfect, but to become whole. And as wholeness entails both good and evil, light and darkness, the achievement of wholeness in personality development requires we assimilate our shadow into our conscious personality.‚Äù
William Shakespeare articulated it perceptively, ‚ÄúThis thing of darkness I acknowledge mine.‚Äù
03/08/23, 12:54‚ÄØpm
Today is the festival of Aadi Perukku, which marks the beginning of agricultural activities in Tamil Nadu, when the river Kaveri is in full flow due to south west monsoon. Farmers start their sowing in the month of Aadi (July-August) so that they can harvest the crops after six months in January during Pongal Festival. On this day people gather on the banks of Kaveri and offer prayers to the river goddess.
River Kaveri fostered civilisations, kingdoms rose on her banks and majestic temples were built on the lands irrigated by it. Great Carnatic composers, scholars and writers lived and wrote in the towns and villages that flanked the river. Sangam poetry and tamil epics like Silappadikaram, celebrated her beauty.
In Pattina Palai, a Tamil poetic work belonging to the Sangam period, Kaveri is referred to as
‚ÄúCauvery, the river that never fails, even if the sky does‚Äù.
‚Äú‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡ÆØ‡Øç‡ÆØ‡Ææ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Øà‡ÆØ ‡Æï‡Æü‡Æ±‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æø‚Äù
An interesting verse in Purananooru, one of the eight books in the Sangam literature, draws attention to the maternal instincts of the river.
‚ÄúThe forceful waters of the river Cauvery
That can even uproot a tree,
Takes care of all the living beings of the world
As a woman feeding a child through her breast‚Äù
‚Äú‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ¥‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡Æá‡Æ≤‡Æø‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Æö‡Øç
‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æ∞‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Æø ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡Øç
‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æ§‡Øà ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‚Äù
Ilango Adigal wrote in a similar vein in Silappadigaram:
‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡ÆÖ‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æü‡ØÅ
‡ÆÆ‡Æï‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æï‡Æø
‡Æä‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡Æâ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Æµ‡Æø
‡Æí‡Æ¥‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ∞‡Æø
Long live this fertile country!
Long live Kaveri
That nurtures the country
Like a mother
05/09/23, 10:41‚ÄØpm

06/09/23, 8:14‚ÄØam
Hindu mythology is replete with many interesting stories and legends. Some of the fascinating ones are associated with Lord Krishna and his early childhood pranks. Among them Kaalinga Narthanam episode is quite fascinating.
Kaalinga was a serpent who was living in the Yamuna river in Vrindavan and had poisoned the entire river thus making it very difficult for people and animals to consume the water. He was hiding there from Garuda, his eternal enemy. Once Krishna jumped into the river to retrieve a ball and Kaalinga immediately tried to kill him. Krishna sprang on top of Kalinga‚Äôs head and started dancing on his hood. He spared Kaalinga at the behest of his wives and Kaalinga agreed to go back to his abode as he felt reassured that with the foot marks of Krishna on his hood Garuda would hesitate to harm him.
Many hymns and songs have been composed in celebration of this event.
Periyazhwar in his ‚ÄòPeriyazhwar Thirumozhi‚Äô wrote:
‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ≥‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æï‡Øà ‡Æï‡Æ≤‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ
‡ÆÖ‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ≥‡Øç‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æü‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Øà‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ≤‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡Æü‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æö‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡ÆÆ‡ØÄ‡Æ≥ ‡ÆÖ‡Æµ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æï‡Æ©‡Øç
‡Æ§‡Øã‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æµ‡Æ≤‡Æø ‡Æµ‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øá ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æ± ‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Æø ‡Æµ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æ±.
Another interesting song was composed by Oothukadu Venkata Subbaiyer. He was a devotee of Lord Krishna, and is believed to have composed over 400 compositions on Him. In the Kaalinga Narthana thillana, he describes the dance of the young Krishna on the hoods of the serpent. It contains many rhythmic words and intricate sequences that are fused with repetitive musical notes. He had even set the singing style in such a way that, at one place, a particular word is enunciated to resemble the hissing sound made by the great serpent!
Neela manohara jaala vibhooshana
Nirata chalanchala bhujanga nartana
Neeraja taDaaga adika mrudulapada
NikaTa taranga tunga tADanga
Nruttaka nruttaka taam tat taai
The beautiful blue-coloured one, embellished by his enchantment,
Is dancing on the tumultuously moving serpent
With footsteps softer than lotus petals
On the turbulent waves, adorned by drops of water
He dances and dances.
One of the most energetic rendering of this thillana is by Aruna Sayiram!
(This sculptural panel is from Lakshmi Narasimha Temple at Nuggehalli, Channarayapatna Talulk, Hassan District)
Dr Raguram
06/09/23, 10:39‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for the wonderful narration. Today is the festival Krishna Janmashtami for us. Thanks again for reviving nostalgia. Nuggehalli is my father's native place.
18/09/23, 9:58‚ÄØam
The Brahmapurisvara temple at Pullamangai, built in 10 century, is an extraordinary example of early Chola temple architecture. On this day, let me draw attention to an exquisite sculpture of Ganesha which is carved on the southern wall of the shrine. The god is seated on a throne with folded legs. His trunk hangs vertically and then curves to the left in the form of an inverted question mark. Ganesha is covered by a beautifully sculpted parasol with a central pendant. Two saluting figures are shown in flying posture on either side. Ganesha, ‚ÄòLord of the Ganas‚Äô, is flanked by joyous Ganas in three superimposed rows. One of them is holding Ganesha‚Äôs vahana (vehicle) Mushaka (Mouse). Right on top is the Makara Torana, with two Makaras carved on either side. Rows of Yalis, some of them with human riders, emerge from the mouth of the Makaras and form a canopy. Right in the middle of the canopy is a dancing figure (Siva?). Below it is another row of Ganas. In the midst of this elaborately carved canopy is a very small sculpture which depicts Siva, Parvati and Chandesa Nayanar. There is a large, beautifully carved sculpture of Chandesa Anugraha Murti in Gangaikondacholapuram. This one is a miniature depiction of it, much earlier! Kindly enlarge the image to see these intricate details!
May our lives be suffused with such beauty in its myriad forms!
(PS) Can I request that neither the image nor the post is shared?

24/09/23, 9:50‚ÄØam
When we were birding in the Point Reyes region CA, I heard a faint, warbling call. Curious to know the source of it, I scouted the vast land in front, but in vain. Suddenly, there was a flash of luminous blue and there it was, the Western Bluebird perched on the thorny bush! It was carrying the azure sky on its back. I spent a few minutes savouring this beauty. Bluebirds are friends to gardeners because they keep plant-damaging insects and other pests at bay and they can spot them from a distance of over 50 yards!
Bluebird is considered to be a harbinger of happiness. This notion was first held by the Chinese who saw the bird as immortal, a protector, and a symbol of the sun. Native Americans too were in deep awe of the bluebird. Navajos revered it as a spirit in animal form, and the Iroquois believed the bluebird‚Äôs song would make the harsh winters bearable. For the Russians, the bluebird represented hope.
Bluebirds figure in many lovely songs. In 1934, the song ‚ÄòBluebird of Happiness‚Äô was composed by Sandor Harmati and the words were written by Edward Heyman. By 1945, the song had become an international hit. Many other bluebird songs followed, including Judy Garland‚Äôs ‚ÄòHello, Bluebird‚Äô and Paul McCartney‚Äôs ‚ÄòBluebird.‚Äô Who can forget these lines from the song ‚ÄòOver The Rainbow‚Äô in the movie Wizard of Oz:
If happy little bluebirds fly
Beyond the rainbow
Why, oh why can't I?
23rd September is considered as the ‚ÄòBluebird of Happiness Day!‚Äô
Dr Raguram
30/09/23, 10:22‚ÄØam
I never get tired of reading Rumi, whose birthday is today. His insightful words and verses about life, love and unity of spirit touches me deeply. There is so much spiritual wisdom in his writings. He was an independent soul yearning for true freedom from dogma and hypocrisy and wrote about the abolishment of fear based religious orders. His prime message is that God is found in your own heart; ‚ÄúEvery moment I shape my destiny with a chisel. I am a carpenter of my own soul.‚Äù
He articulated a notion of a "religion of love," and wrote that "since we worship the one God/ Then all religions must be one." Remarkably at his funeral in Konya, Turkey, in 1273, the procession included not only singers and dancers, besides the traditional chanting from the Quran, but also there were Christian priests chanting the Gospel and Jewish rabbis reciting Psalms.
Just before his death, he recited one of his most inspirational words;
‚ÄúWhen I die; when my coffin is being taken out
you must never think I am missing this world.
Don't shed any tears, don't lament or feel sorry. I'm not falling into a monster's abyss.
When you see my corpse is being carried,
don‚Äôt cry for my leaving.
I'm not leaving; I'm arriving at eternal love.
When you leave me in the grave, don't say goodbye.
Remember a grave is only a curtain for the paradise behind.
You'll only see me descending into a grave, now watch me rise.
How can there be an end? When the sun sets
or the moon goes down, it looks like the end,
It seems like a sunset, but in reality, it is dawn.
When the grave locks you up, that is when your soul is freed.
Have you ever seen a seed fallen to earth not rise with a new life?
Why should you doubt the rise of a seed named man?. . .
When, for the last time, you close your mouth,
Your words and soul will belong to the world of no place, no time.‚Äù
And these words are inscribed in his tomb;
‚ÄúWhen we are dead, seek not our tomb in the earth, but find it in the hearts of men‚Äú.
Dr Raguram
15/10/23, 7:36‚ÄØpm
Three years ago, during Navaratri, I had posted images of sculptural representations of Mahishasura Mardini, with narratives, in Facebook.
Heeding to requests from many, I have now put them all together in a single pdf document and here it is!
Dr Raguram
22/10/23, 9:41‚ÄØam
The Brahmapuriswara temple is situated in the tiny hamlet of Pullamangai, on the outskirts of Pasupathikoyil in Thanjavur District. Dating back to 10th century, it is an outstanding example of early Chola temple architecture. Though comparatively smaller, it has some of the finest sculptures. Prominent among them is an exquisite depiction of Durga on the north wall of the temple.
Durga is depicted standing on the head of the buffalo. The goddess is tall and slender and stands in a tribhanga pose; tri meaning ‚Äúthree‚Äù and bhanga meaning ‚Äúposture‚Äù. It entails bending the body at three places, namely the knee, the hip and the shoulder. The flowing lines of the sculpture have an entrancing, sinuous quality. Rarely seen outside of Chola temples, is the umbrella (called the Venkotra Kudai) over Her head. On the right, above, is a small stylised lion and on the left a deer held by a bhuta. The presence of the deer is rather unusual. Thirugnanasambandar in Tevaram, Irandam Thirumurai, refers to Durga having a deer as ‚Äòkalaiyathurthi‚Äô.
Two kneeling figures are depicted in the wall on either side of the main niche, cutting parts of their body as a sacrificial gesture. The person on the left is seen holding his hair with his left hand and is attempting to cut off his head with his right hand. The one on the right is about the cut off his leg at the knee. A similar depiction can be found in the Draupathi Ratham at Mahabalipuram.
What struck me was the portrayal of Durga. Here the focus is not on the combat with Mahishasura but her triumphant visage after vanquishing him. There is sheer elegance in the depiction of Durga. Her face is very serene with a tranquil smile on her lips as described in the Devimahatmyam.
‡§à‡§∑‡§• ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞
‡§≠‡•Ä‡§¨‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡•ç
‚ÄúGently smiling, spotless resembling the full moon orb, beautiful as the choicest gold and lovely was thy face.‚Äù
One of the meanings of HER name is fortress. Durga reminds us of the fortress which we each carry within ourselves. As various challenges and chaos engulf us, SHE lends a helping hand to protect and fortify our spiritual wellbeing.
Dr Raguram
24/10/23, 8:12‚ÄØam
In sculptural depictions of Mahishasuramardini, the asura is portrayed either as a bull or a demon underneath the feet of the Goddess. There is an interesting sculpture in Chennakeshava Temple in Belur, in which the Mahishasura is actually seen emerging from the bull. Devi is pressing the bull with her right leg and one can see that the bull is buckling under the pressure. Mahishasura arises from the bull, with one leg still within it. The Goddess thrusts her weapon on Mahishasura‚Äôs chest, impaling and killing him in the process.
Today is Vijayadasami which is celebrated with much fanfare in Mysuru as the day Devi Chamundeshwari defeated and vanquished Mahishasura. Mysuru is deemed to be a corrupted version of ‚ÄúMysooru‚Äú, which is derived from the word ‚ÄúMahishooru‚Äù. According to the story, Mysuru was ruled by King Mahishasura who was a buffalo-headed monster. In response to the prayer by the Gods and Goddesses to save them from the demon, Goddess Parvathi, took birth as Chamundeshwari and killed the monster on top of the Chamundi hill near Mysuru. Bettada Chamaraja Wadiyar, the Raja of Mysuru rebuilt the fort and made it his headquarters and called the city ‚ÄòMahishura Nagara‚Äò, meaning the city of Mahishur. Many inscriptions done in the 17th century and later refer to Mysuru as ‚ÄòMahishuru‚Äò.
In recent times, Dalits and rationalists in the Mysuru region opine strongly that Mahishasura was not a monster but a Buddhist king, who fought against upper caste oppression and was killed by them. They argue that the demon story was fabricated to tarnish his legacy, claiming that Mahishasura was a historical figure sent by Maurya emperor Ashoka to promote Buddhism in the region. The proponents of this theory also point out that Mysuru derives its name after Mahishooru. Such an alternate narrative is not confined to Mysuru. A tribe named Asura who are living in some parts of Jharkhand claim that they are descendants of Mahishasura and for them, it is not a day of celebration, but a day of mourning.
These conflicting narratives are evidence of India‚Äôs incredible heterogeneity, which incorporates and accommodates differing beliefs within its fold, seamlessly.
Dr Raguram
31/10/23, 9:51‚ÄØam
John Keats was born on this day in 1795. During his short life, he published fifty-four poems using a wide range of poetic forms including odes and sonnets. Not happy with his earlier works he collected every piece of paper on which they had been written and burned them. While suffering from tuberculosis, he fell in love with Fanny Browne. Since he could not have any physical contact with her, he wrote her a series of letters. In one of them he wrote poignantly, ‚ÄúIllness is a long lane, but I see you at the end of it.‚Äù Later, in the same letter, he wondered, ‚ÄúIs there another life?
Shall I awake and find all this a dream?‚Äù He never recovered from his illness and died at the young age of 25.
Nature was one of the greatest sources of inspiration for Keats. He gazed with child-like delight at the rising sun, the moving cloud, the growing bud and the birds and turned them into beautiful poetic images. It was not the ‚Äòintellectual beauty‚Äô of Shelley, but one that emerged from the deepest reaches of his soul. As he wrote in the opening lines of Endymion: ‚ÄúA thing of beauty is a joy forever‚Äù.
During all my birding sojourns I seek beauty in the feathered friends as in this diminutive bird, Taiga Flycatcher. It gets its name from the habitat it uses, the Taiga forest, which refers to the coniferous forests of the sub polar region. A forest dwelling winter visitor to the Indian subcontinent, it is one of the most handsome birds I have ever seen. Its beauty is not confined to its visual aspects alone, but transcends it.
As Keats wrote in ‚ÄòOn A Grecian Urn‚Äô:
‚ÄúBeauty is truth, truth beauty,‚Äîthat is all
Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
03/11/23, 9:40‚ÄØam
It was late evening when we visited the cradle of Carnatic music, Thiruvaiyaru, a few months ago. We made our way to the samadhi of Tygaraja on the banks of the river Cauvery. It is a simple, single story building, shorn of any embellishment. Silence enveloped us as we stepped in as there was hardly anyone inside. The walls were inscribed with first two lines of krithis of the master composer. Tyagaraja‚Äôs idol is installed at a place where he attained samadhi. The idol was decorated with a garland of rudraksha and he was seen holding a sheaf of palm leaves in his left hand. The idol was personally designed and installed by a singer Nagarathnamma, often referred to as Bangalore Nagarathnamma, whose birthday is today.
Bangalore Nagarathnamma was an exceptional person. She was born in Nanjangud to a devadasi Puttu Lakshmi. Though she was initiated into the devadasi tradition at the age of five, she was a keen learner and became adept in many languages including Sanskrit. She developed an abiding interest in music and emerged as one of the finest carnatic singers of her time. Impressed by her talents, Maharaja Jayachamarajendra Wodeyar appointed her the Asthana Vidushi. She was probably the first woman to occupy such an exalted position in the royal court! She moved to Madras to consolidate her position as established herself as a popular concert artist. Her rendering of Tygaraja‚Äôs krithis enthralled huge audiences. She was the first female artist to pay income tax in Madras!
Tyagaraja occupied her mind in her waking hours as much as in her dreams. In one such dream, she saw an elderly person asking her to build a structure with her vast wealth. The dream came again after a few days and she described it to her mentor, Bidaram Krishnappa as to what it meant. He told her that the person she saw in her dream was none other than Tyagaraja himself and that she should build a memorial to him at Thiruvaiyaru. Tyagaraja‚Äôs samadhi at that time was desolate and forlorn. The place was filled with wild growth of plants and bushes with snakes crawling and wild animals roaming. Seeing it‚Äôs sad condition, she built a mandapam over the samadhi.
Tygaraja‚Äôs samadhi was also the place where annual music festival, Tyagaraja Aradhana, used to be held every year. Women artists were prohibited to perform in it. Nagarathnamma invited female artists and arranged for them to perform behind the mandapam. It was huge hit. Subsequently women artists started featuring in the annual Aradhana. She bequeathed her vast fortune and property to the Aradhana trust with a clear rider that‚Äù This property shall be allowed for the purpose of conducting the Tyagaraja Aradhana only as long as women artistes are allowed to perform in it.‚Äù When she died in 1952, she was laid to rest next to Tyagaraja. To this day, she remains the only woman to be buried there.
A true feminist, Nagarathnamma shattered glass ceilings wherever she went and contributed much to the inclusion of women and especially devadasis into carnatic music at a time when society was very much Victorian in its morals. She was much ahead of her time and established the first Association for Devadasis in Madras Presidency. As its president, she took several steps towards offering financial and social support to her fellow devadasis.
DV Gundappa wrote a moving tribute to this remarkable woman. When he met her towards the end of her life, she commented ‚ÄúI was Nagarathna (precious jewel on the snake‚Äôs head) by birth, then became bhogarathna (jewel of pleasure) and now I am rogarathna (jewel of disease)‚Äù DVG added that she should also be called ragarathna (jewel of musical ragas) and tyagarathna (jewel of sacrifice).
20/11/23, 8:52‚ÄØam
One of the most famous opening sentences in literature is from Leo Tolstoy's novel Anna Karenina: "All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way." Tolstoy's own marriage seems to have fallen into the second category. Though he and his wife, Sophia, had 13 children together, they were an unhappy couple in the later part of their lives. Tolstoy contemplated leaving his wife on many occasions and finally on the night of Nov. 10, 1910, he secretly fled, leaving a note to his wife, ‚ÄúI am doing what old men of my age usually do: leaving worldly life to spend the last days of my life in solitude and quiet.‚Äù Taking only a few things, he boarded a train with his personal physician Makovitsky. Taking a circuitous route, involving several train changes, they planned to travel further to Bulgaria. But on the way, Tolstoy caught a cold, which led to pneumonia and he was taken of the train at Astapovo. He declined any medical intervention as he wanted to "submit himself to God‚Äôs will." He passed away in the early morning of 20th November 1910.
Tolstoy‚Äôs final moments are a poignant reminder of what he wrote in The Death of Ivan Illyich; ‚ÄúWhat death? There was no fear, because there was no death. Instead of death there was light. So that‚Äôs it! He suddenly said aloud. ‚ÄúSuch joy!‚Äù
Dr Raguram

25/01/23, 9:07‚ÄØam
Virginia Woolf (whose birthday is today) had an enduring tryst with bipolar illness all through her life. In her fight against her hounding illness which she often referred to as ‚Äòwaves‚Äô, she held onto writing to prevent herself from sinking. In her own words, ‚ÄúOne ought to sink to the bottom of the sea, probably, and live alone with one‚Äôs words.‚Äù It was a prescient observation as years later, unable to cope with the devastating illness, she filled her overcoat with stones and drowned in the river Ouse.
TS Eliot, a close friend, persuaded her to write about her experiences with her ailments and the result was the contemplative essay, ‚ÄòOn Being Ill‚Äô. She wrote it in throes of yet another ravaging bout of illness. This has been reissued in 2012 with contributions from her mother and a friend. It is an insightful narrative about travails of illness and its impact on caregivers.
She voiced her profound loneliness in these evocative words, ‚ÄúWe do not know our own souls, let alone the souls of others. Human beings do not go hand in hand the whole stretch of the way. There is a virgin forest, tangled, pathless, in each; a snowfield where even the print of birds‚Äô feet is unknown. Here we go alone‚Ä¶‚Äù

14/02/23, 9:43‚ÄØam
Sanskrit literature is replete with beautiful verses celebrating love. Most notable among them is Chaurapanchasika , a compilation fifty short lyric poems written in the eleventh century A. D. by the poet Bilhana.
There are many versions about the origin of this work. One of them states that a king with a lovely daughter engages the famous poet Bilhana to educate his daughter. To prevent any romance blossoming between the two, he tells the princess that her guru is visually challenged and tells the guru that his student has deformities in her face. To ensure that they don‚Äôt see each other, he hangs a curtain between the two. One day while lessons were in progress, the poet is thrilled by the full moon on a cloudless sky. He breaks into a poem, and princess wonders how a blind man can sing about the moon with such brilliance. Excited, she pulls down the curtain and finds that Bilhana is a handsome young man while he finds he finds her to be a personification of female beauty. The two instantly fall in love and decide to marry, but the enraged king sentences them to death. As Bilhana is being led to his execution, he starts singing the fifty verses. Deeply moved by it, the king orders his release and formally gives his daughter in marriage.
Interestingly, in 1948, two producers made movies in Tamil based on this story of Bilhana. Unfortunately, the third version with the legendary MK Thyagaraja Bhagavathar as Bilhana was never completed as the actor was arrested.
Among many translations of this remarkable work, I find the one by Sir Edwin Arnold quite interesting. One of the verses reads:
Still when her eyes, as lotus petals long,
Like Fortune‚Äôs goddess lotus-born, I see,
And see her wearied by her bosom's load,
With both my arms clasping her close to me
As honey bee his darling lotus sips,
I would grow drunk on mead within her Iips.
These lines find a picturesque expression in this beautiful sculpture from Khajuraho.
15/02/23, 6:36‚ÄØpm
Exquisitely crafted sculpture and interesting narrative Sir.
16/02/23, 10:33‚ÄØpm

18/02/23, 8:35‚ÄØam
According to one of the legends, Lord Shiva and Devi Parvathi tied the nuptial knot on Mahashivaratri. Their union has a deeper connotation: Purusha (mindfulness) is represented by Shiva, while Prakriti (nature) is epitomized by Parvathi.
This classic Shiva Parvathi sculpture is from Hoysaleshwara temple in Halebeedu. It depicts Parvathi seated on Shiva‚Äôs lap which is referred to as atikarohana. They are bedecked with intricately carved jewellery and carry different weapons and ornaments in their arms. The details are so mesmerizing, providing a three dimensional perspective. What is interesting to note is the presence of mongoose, a vahana of Parvathi at her feet.
Composed by Adi Shankaracharya, Shiva Parvathi stotram holds a special importance amongst all Shiva Stotras. It extols the divine qualities of the god and goddess in 12 stanzas. On this Mahashivaratri day let us recall a verse from this:
‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç,
‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç,
‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç
Namah Shivabhyam pashupalakabhyam
Jagattrayee rakshana baddha hrudbhyam
Samastha Devaasura pujitabhyam
Namo namah Shankara Parvatibhyam
I bow to God Shiva and Goddess Parvathi, the protectors of all beings
Who are the divine guardians of all the three worlds
The divine pair worshipped by all the Devas and Asuras
I bow to you, again and again, God Shiva and Goddess Parvathi
18/02/23, 6:39‚ÄØpm
A beautiful sculpture Sirüôè The nuptial knot tied between mind and matter. Parvati through self discipline and determination won Shiva. Beyond idolising connecting to our lives really helps Sir. Thank you for the verse and its interpretation.
21/02/23, 10:23‚ÄØam
In all my forays into the library during my training days at NIMHANS, I was drawn into one particular journal, simply titled as Psychiatry. Tucked between its plain yellow covers were articles that opened up my perspective into the interpersonal context of psychological suffering. One of the founders of the journal was Harry Stack Sullivan, whose birthday is today. Sullivan through his framework of interpersonal psychotherapy articulated that one‚Äôs personality and behavior has to be viewed and examined on the background of close, intimate, relationships. He felt that descriptive psychiatry failed to look beyond diagnosis and view the whole person in his/her social context. He extended this orientation to understand what was often viewed as an incomprehensible disease process, schizophrenia. This laid the foundation of the Chestnut Lodge which pioneered intensive, individualized treatment of schizophrenia. Chestnut Lodge was also the locale of the book ‚ÄúI never promised you a rose garden‚Äô.
Enforced isolation during the Covid era, drew our attention to the unsettling fact that loneliness can be a severely distressing state. Yet it has eluded the attention of mental health professionals. Sullivan was among the very few who attempted to examine it. He regarded loneliness as one of the most intense and painful of human experiences and described people with schizophrenia as, ‚Äúthe loneliest of the lonely‚Äù.
Personally, the work of Sullivan widened my gaze beyond the veil of symptoms onto the real person shrouded behind them.
22/02/23, 10:20‚ÄØpm
Yes sir. Just labelling narrows our understanding of the person. We are a product of messy, intertwined relationships. Decades back had read the book.
23/02/23, 9:43‚ÄØam
When I joined NIMHANS, my teacher Dr RL Kapur told me to read Karl Jasper‚Äôs ‚ÄòGeneral Psychopathology‚Äô. I went over to the library to look for it. In those days, books in the library were all locked up securely in steel cupboards and the keys were with a strict looking female attender. When I requested her to look for it, she went straight to the pathology section and announced in a loud voice that there is no such book. I persuaded her to look for it in the psychiatry section and to my great relief it was there in a bottom shelf. It was the first edition, translated into English by Hoenig, who had spent a year at the All India Institute of Mental Health in 1955. It was a difficult book to read, but I gamely gave it a try over several weeks and re-read it during my training days. Later, I personally wanted to possess a copy of ‚ÄòGeneral Psychopathology‚Äô and finally got one in an old book shop. It has a pride of place in my collection. I was going through it today on Jasper‚Äôs birthday and was struck by its continuing relevance in the current climate of psychiatric practice.
The main emphasis of Jasper was on a phenomenological approach to psychiatric illnesses. It is essentially a form of qualitative enquiry that emphasized experiential, lived aspects of a particular phenomenon as described by the person. In Jasper‚Äôs own words ‚ÄúSince we never can perceive the psychic experiences of other in any direct fashion, as with physical phenomena, we can only make some kind of a representation of them. There has to be an act of empathy, of understanding ...which comes from the patient‚Äôs own self-descriptions, which can be evoked and tested out in the course of personal conversations.‚Äù In a Jaspersian sense, psychiatric diagnosis is not a ‚Äúsimple question-and-answer interrogation‚Äù but a ‚Äúparticular observation‚Äù in the context of an empathic interaction.
Unfortunately, with the advent of the Neo Kraeplinian frameworks of diagnosis, the emphasis has shifted to ‚Äòeliciting‚Äô symptoms which are then straight jacketed to fit into diagnostic criteria. This has led to a robotic checklist approach shorn of insights about the experiential terrain of symptoms. The person who ultimately knows his/her experiences is the patient himself/herself. The psychiatrist‚Äôs role is to facilitate expression of this experience through a compassionate, empathic stance tinged with an attitude of curiosity.
23/02/23, 10:55‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for sharing the above. Tha listening time we spend with the patients definitely helps in understanding, empathising with them. What I have observed is despite the same diagnostic label they get, each patient has her or his uniqueness, strengths and weaknesses. But time matters.....

06/03/23, 8:02‚ÄØam
During our training period at NIMHANS, after receiving our monthly pay, Ahalya and myself will invariably make our way to Premier Book Shop to stock up on books. During one such visit, Shanbhag guided us through the shelves overflowing with books, picked up one and said, ‚ÄúDoctor, you must read this!‚Äù
It was Gabrial Garcia Marquez‚Äôs ‚ÄòOne Hundred Years Of Solitude‚Äô.
When I started reading the novel, it was much akin to sojourns in dreamscapes. To borrow a phrase from Beatles, it was a Magical Mystery Tour! Every page was suffused with intricate details, intersecting history, mythology and tradition. The lives and tribulations of the Buendia family came alive in the author‚Äôs mesmerizing narrative.
In a memorable passage after the death of Jose Arcadio Buendia, Gabo‚Äôs writes, ‚ÄúWhen the carpenter was taking measurements for the coffin, through the window they saw a light rain of tiny yellow flowers falling. So many flowers fell from the sky that in the morning the streets were carpeted with a compact cushion and they had to clear them away with shovels and rakes so that the funeral procession could pass by.‚Äù
Yellow butterflies were one of his often used literary imagery and he used to comment that nothing awful would happen to him if there are yellow flowers around.
During his memorial service thousands of yellow butterflies made of paper were released to celebrate the life of this remarkable author.
Today is Gabo‚Äôs 96th birthday‚Ä¶
07/03/23, 8:12‚ÄØam
It was an unusually sultry morning and there was a long queue in front of St Peter‚Äôs Basilica in the Vatican City. Undeterred, I waited patiently behind a group of tourists from America who were chatting animatedly. As soon as I entered its hallowed precincts, I made my way straight to have a glimpse of Michelangelo‚Äôs Pieta. During his lifetime Michelangelo made three Pietas, of Virgin Mary mourning the dead body of Christ and this is the most beautiful of them all. Though Mary embracing her dead son is not explicitly mentioned in the holy book, the scene has proven to be a popular subject among artists for centuries.
Safely ensconced behind bullet proof glass, Virgin Mary was in a seated position, wrapped in robes and cradling the lifeless body of Jesus. His head was slumped back on her shoulder. When I looked at it closely, I felt that the sculpture was shaped like a pyramid, with the top of the head of Virgin Mary being its peak and the sculpture expanding to accommodate her seated legs. Her petite face with gentle demeanour exuded serene tranquillity. Michelangelo‚Äôs painstaking attention to detail and the unique treatment of the hair, the skin and the intricate folds in the fabric is a lasting testimony to his outstanding artistry.
Pieta was the only sculpture where Michelangelo inscribed his name. Unfortunately, with the crowd milling around, I couldn‚Äôt have a close look to locate it.
Michelangelo was a multi-talented individual who also wrote sonnets on variety of subjects. He produced hundreds of madrigals and sonnets, often putting down his chisel while at work to write down a line or two of verse.
These beautiful lines are from the sonnet titled The Model and the Statue:
When that which is divine in us doth try
To shape a face, both brain and hand unite
To give, from a mere model frail and slight
Life to the stone by Art‚Äôs free energy.
(Yesterday, 6th March was the birthday of this remarkable artist/poet)
08/03/23, 9:16‚ÄØam
International Women‚Äôs Day is observed to recognize and honor the achievements of women. On this day let us recall the life and works of a remarkable woman, Elizabeth Barrett Browning. Educated at home, she wrote an epic poem at the age of twelve. Her first major work was ‚ÄòAn Essay On Mind and Other Poems‚Äô which was published when she was twenty years old. These lines from it, offer a tantalizing glimpse of her talent:
So when the pilgrim sun is traveling o‚Äôer
The last blue hill, to gild a distant shore
He leaves a freshness in the evening scene
That tells the Creation where his steps have been
Unfortunately, much like Frida Kahlo she was beset with various ailments all through her life including a spinal fracture. This was not a dampener in her creative journey and she continued to immerse herself at work, producing some extraordinary verses.
Elizabeth was not just a talented poet, she was deeply involved in addressing many forms of social injustice, such as the slave trade in America, child labour in the mines and the mills of England and the restrictions forced upon women in 19th-century society. Standards of sexual conduct were so rigid at that period in time that any woman who bore a child out of wedlock, even if she had been a victim of male aggression, was shunned and scorned by the society. She urged that society should be more compassionate in its treatment of women who had been victims of sexual violence. Moved by the plight of children working in mines she wrote a long poem, ‚ÄòThe Cry of The Children‚Äô, with these poignant opening lines:
Do ye hear the children weeping, O my brothers,
Ere the sorrow comes with years ?
They are leaning their young heads against their mothers,
And that cannot stop their tears.
Elizabeth Barrett Browning was an extraordinary poet but she was also more than that. Hers was a voice for the oppressed and she had the courage to profess her views that went against the grains of society.
The theme of this year‚Äôs International Women‚Äôs Day is ‚ÄòEmbrace Equity‚Äô. Elizabeth Barrett Browning personified this all through her life and in her works.

21/03/23, 6:41‚ÄØam
‚ÄòPoetry is painting that speaks,‚Äô Plutarch observed.
Throughout history, poets have painted their canvas with lyrical and idyllic verses.
The landscape of poetry in India is vibrant and multihued and there is a treasure trove waiting to be unearthed across languages.
On this World Poetry Day, let me share a poem by Malathi Maithri which has been translated from Tamil by Lakshmi Holmstrom.
OBSERVE THE CRANE
The crane waits
at the verge of the river-bed,
fish swimming in its memory.
In search of its reflection, the moon
wanders, vanishes.
Swirls of roots tear into the earth,
with hunger.
The wind, sweeping up its troubles,
hurls the heat in all directions.
Pulverized, the heart swirls
like dust in a storm.
It is not just the earth
that overflows through its cracks
in heat and rage.
The crane
absorbs into itself all that heat
and boils within.
If only the crane would sink into
the water swirling in its memory
and beat its wings,
the river might gather its form once more
from the scattered drops,
and walk again.
River, watch.

24/03/23, 9:50‚ÄØpm

30/03/23, 7:33‚ÄØam
On the occasion of Sri Rama Navami let me offer you some glimpses from the Ramayana at the Amruteshwara temple in Amruthapura in Chikmagalur district. It is a small yet beautiful 12th century temple built by Amruteshwara Dandanayaka, during the reign of King Hoysala Veera Ballala II. On the south side of the parapet wall, the story of Ramayana is depicted in over seventy small panels.
This series of panels depict an episode from Kishkinda kandam which is the fourth book and one of the seven kandams in Valmiki's Ramayana. After Shabari tells Rama about Sugreeva, Rama goes in search of him and reaches Rishimukha mountain. Seeing Rama and Lakshmana, Sugreeva feels uneasy and wonders whether they were sent by Vali and asks Hanuman to meet them (Panel 1). Reassured that Rama and Lakshmana poses no danger, Sugreeva accompanies Hanuman and meets them. After listening to them, Rama promises Sugreeva that the wrong done to him would be redressed and that he would be reinstated as the king of the Vanaras (Panel 2). To imbue confidence in Sugreeva, Rama hurls his arrow which penetrates seven sala trees as well as the subterranean places of earth and returns to his quiver (Panel 3). Overcome with the immense prowess of Rama, Sugreeva submits himself to Rama, who urges him to challenge Vali for a duel. In their first encounter, Rama is unable to distinguish between the two and asks Sugreeva to wear a garland the next time, so that he could identify Vali. Rama then kills Vali (Panel 4). Rama reinstates Sugreeva on the throne as the king of Kishhkinda (Panel 5). Since the panels are quite small, zoom in to see the details!
Stories from Ramayana are an integral part of various art forms in India, whether it is music, dance or folktales. In Amruteshwara temple stories of Ramayana are imbedded in its architectural style. These intricately carved panels are like unfolding narratives which are sequentially depicted like chapters in a book before the advent of paper and print!
If you travel to Hampi, you can see a craggy hill on the south bank of the river Tungabadra, which is believed to be the Rishimukha Parvata where Hanuman is reported to have met Rama and Lakshmana.
30/03/23, 10:55‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for the repeat but with ornately carved sculpture üëåI read small portions of Ramayana every Tuesday and completed Sundara kanda today being Rama Navamiüôè
31/03/23, 6:33‚ÄØam
Vincent van Gogh whose birthday was yesterday, was admitted into the asylum at Saint-R√©my-de-Provence which was once a monastery. It originally held many patients, but by the time he was admitted, the male wing was almost empty and he was also given an extra room to use as a studio. This is the painting of the studio by van Gogh where he produced over 140 of his works, including the iconic "Starry Night". He also painted the view from his window, including the rolling hills 21 times but none of them show the bars on the window of his room! In a letter to his brother Theo, he wrote, "Through the iron-barred window I can make out a square of wheat in an enclosure, above which in the morning I see the sunrise in its glory."
01/04/23, 8:03‚ÄØam
I have been listening to piano concertos of late and have been besotted with Rachmaninoff‚Äôs Piano Concerto No 2. It unfolds effortlessly and one is drawn deeply into its fluid, melodic notes. Rhythmic tones from the piano seamlessly and subtly flow into the orchestra. The momentum builds up with several delicate touches. It is full of emotional intensity and has a hypnotic effect on me.
I started reading about Rachmaninoff (whose birthday is today) and found that he was mentored by none other than Tchaikovsky. After Tchaikovsky‚Äôs untimely death, Rachmaninoff faced a setback in his career. His first major work Piano Concerto 1 was savagely criticized and he went to meet Tolstoy for some succour. To his great dismay he found Tolstoy to be emotionally distant and dismissive of his work. In throes of deep depression, he sought the help of Dr Nikolai Dahl, an internist in neurology who had a deep interest in Jean-Martin Charcot‚Äôs work with hypnosis and was using it in therapy. After several months of therapy, Rachmaninoff recovered his creative urge and composed Piano Concerto 2, which he dedicated to Dr Nikolai Dah. Full of passion, melancholy, yearning, and ultimately triumph, it remains till today as one of the most influential classical works.
In his own words, ‚ÄúMusic is enough for a whole lifetime, but a lifetime is not enough for music.‚Äù
https://youtu.be/yJpJ8REjvqo
01/04/23, 10:54‚ÄØpm
Have to listen, thank you Sir.
02/04/23, 9:01‚ÄØpm
Once again, a blessed person who could translate his pain which I think was therapeutic. Nice to remember such great personalities through you Sir!
09/04/23, 8:09‚ÄØam
Easter commemorating the resurrection of Christ, was the earliest feast day decided upon by the ancient Christian church. One of the most beautiful depictions of Easter is by Raphael which he painted when he was just in his teens.
In this painting one can see Christ in the centre, hovering in the air above the tomb. Four guards are on either side with raised hands pointing out to him. In the left hand corner are Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and Salome who are on the way to anoint Christ. Two angels flank Christ on either side with their hands raised in blessing. Interestingly there are two symbolic representations in the painting; snake referring to the Satan and white crane indicating its strength and endurance during migration.
George Herbert, one of the great devotional poets in English, wrote couple of poems on Easter. In one of them, Easter Wings, he wrote:
O let me rise
As larks, harmoniously,
And sing this day thy victories:
Then shall the fall further the flight in me.
The poet suggests that those who stay close to God through religious devotion can ‚Äúfly" above, or find redemption from, their suffering.
Interestingly, he arranged these lines in print to resemble the shape of bird‚Äôs wings
09/04/23, 8:36‚ÄØam
What a painting and concept. Thanks Sir for the narrative and the poem.
11/04/23, 11:07‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for opening our eyes and knowing about these great thinkers.
13/04/23, 8:12‚ÄØam
Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar (whose birthday is tomorrow), was an amazing polymath. He was a politician, economist, anthropologist, jurist, theologian, historian, social reformer, lawyer, author, constitutionalist, sociologist, political scientist, feminist, environmentalist, educationist and a social scientist. This long list is a tribute to his thirst for knowledge across disciplines.
Ambedkar‚Äôs assiduous quest for equality, justice and the welfare of every human being, lead him to Buddhism. On 14 October 1956, he converted to Buddhism, along with 3,65,000 of his followers in Nagpur. Unfortunately he died two months after the event on December 6, 1956, three days after completing his final manuscript, ‚ÄòThe Buddha and His Dhamma‚Äô. He describes the appeal of Buddha quite eloquently: ‚ÄúAll prophets have promised salvation. The Buddha is the one teacher who did not make any such promise. He made a sharp distinction between a moksha data (Giver of Salvation) and a marga data (Way Finder), one who gives salvation and one who only shows the way. He was only a marga data. Salvation must be sought by each for himself by his own effort.‚Äù
Ambedkar continues to be the ‚Äòmarga data‚Äô for millions of oppressed for whom equality, social justice and an egalitarian livelihood is still a distant dream, even decades after independence.
‚ÄúMen are mortal. So are ideas. An idea needs as much propagation as a plant needs watering. Otherwise, both will wither and die.‚Äù
13/04/23, 11:15‚ÄØpm
What a write up Sir. Yes he was a fantastic blend of everything a society badly needs. And his Gurus. What a selection. Very true, those who guided and propagated the highest values.

Thank you Sir and wish you all the same.

18/04/23, 9:17‚ÄØam
April 18 is celebrated as World Heritage Day, also known as the International Day for Monuments and Sites. It is dedicated to highlighting the importance of cultural heritage and raising awareness about the need to preserve historical sites and monuments.
On this day, let me draw attention to Vaikuntha Perumal Kovil, one of the most unique temples which is visited by very few, in Kanchipuram. When we stepped into its precincts on a cold morning, we found the whole temple shorn of any visitor, which gave us ample opportunity to savour its architectural legacy at leisure. The priest in the main sanctum informed us that the main temple consists of three floors, each one with Vishnu murtis in different poses; sitting, sleeping, and standing. Unfortunately, it is difficult to access the top two floors. The priest also mentioned that there was a secret underground tunnel from this temple all the way to Mahabalipuram!
A distinctive aspect of the temple is the pillared corridor surrounding the sanctum. The walls of corridors are embellished with stories, carved into them. Many of the panels have eroded with time and it can be difficult to identify them. Thankfully, before visiting the place, I had downloaded a scholarly and informative monograph about it, authored by Dr Minakshi in 1936. Interestingly, many of the bas reliefs trace the life and history of Nandivarman II, who built the temple. There are vivid depictions of battle scenes with elephants and soldiers, much like scenes of warfare depicted on the outer walls of the Bayon temple, which was built five centuries later in Siem Reap, Cambodia. I understand that the chronological, historical, narrative depictions in bas reliefs in Vaikuntha Perumal shrine is the first such attempt in temple architecture in India. In front of the sculpted walls there is an array of beautifully chiselled pillars in the shape of sitting lions.
Vaikuntha Perumal Temple is also referred to as Parameswaravinnagaram. Nandivarman II‚Äôs original name before his coronation was Parameswara and he named this temple after himself. It is the 56th Divya Desam dedicated to Lord Vishnu. There is a small shrine dedicated to the famous saint poet, Thirumangai Alwar, who wrote hymns in praise of the Lord and the king who built it. In one of the hymns he wrote:
‡Æâ‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡ØÜ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æ£‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æ≥‡Æø ‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æí‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ ‡Æµ‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æü‡Æ≤‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Øç
‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Æø ‡Æµ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æü‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æü‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÇ‡Æ¥‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ¥‡Æï‡Ææ‡ÆØ ‡Æï‡Æö‡Øç‡Æö‡Æø
‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ®‡ØÜ‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Æö‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ© ‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æ≥‡Øç
‡Æ™‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øã‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ£‡Æø‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ™‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øá‡Æö‡Øç‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æ∞ ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Æï‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Øá-
In essence, the hymn states that Parameswaravinnagaram, the abode of the Lord is surrounded by mansions filled with precious gems and is in the capital of the beautiful Kanchipuram where the Pallava king who won many a battle and destroyed enemies, surrendered to the Lord.
Temples are not merely places of worship in India. Steeped in history, they are also sites of dazzling expressions of elegant art and architecture, which need to be cherished and conserved.
