22/04/23, 8:00‚ÄØam
Today is Akshaya Tritiya, a day when people throng the jewellery shops to buy gold. The word ‚ÄòAkshaya‚Äô means ‚Äònever diminishing‚Äô and hence the belief that buying the precious metal on this day guarantees endless wealth.
Like many festivals in India, Akshaya Tritiya has several legends connected with it. It is an important day in Jainism and is associated with Adinatha, the first of the 24 Tirthankaras. Rishabadeva, king of Ayodhya gave up all earthly pleasures (much like Gautam Buddha), to lead the life of a monk as Adinatha. In order to live as a Jain monk, one must not possess anything, not even a morsel of food. When he started begging for food, his subjects offered him their most prized possessions like precious stones, elephants, horses but not food or drink which they thought was too modest an offering for their dear king. The king refused all the fine gifts and went without food and water until, finally, his grandson Shreyansha Kumara understood his need and offered him some sugarcane juice. With this juice, Adinatha broke his fast that had lasted 400 days.
It was on Akshaya Tritiya day that Adinatha broke his fast. As a mark of reverence to Lord Adinatha and his strict penance, Jains celebrate this day as ‚ÄúParna Diwas‚Äù after the penance of Varshi Tap and end their year-long alternative-day fasting with sugarcane juice.
This photograph is from Cave 4 at Badamai. Carved into its wall is a beautiful, life-size relief of Adinatha. He is standing in Kayotsarga pose, with unbent knees and straight arms, which are held at the side and do not touch the body. It is representative of an ascetic practice characterised by detachment of the physical body. Adinatha has locks of hair cascading down his shoulders and this is one of the ways to identify his sculpture. There is an interesting story behind this. When he chose to become an ascetic, Rishbadeva started pulling out his long strands of hair. After four fistfuls, when he was pulling out the fifth fistful of hair Indra is said to have told him, " This strand of hair on the crown of your head and hanging down over your shoulders looks attractive. Kindly leave it as it is." Rishabadeva agreed. Due to this bunch of hair he got the popular name; Keshariya ji (one with hair).
As for myself, I am a miner for gold‚Ä¶in the hearts of peopleÔÅä

25/04/23, 7:41‚ÄØam
All forms of aesthetic expression, including poetry, spring from the deepest, personal, inner self. It is essentially an adventure in selfhood. That said, we are living in an era in which selfhood has become fluid. The boundary between the ‚Äòreal self‚Äô and the ‚Äòimagined, virtual self‚Äô has become rather porous in the cyber world in which we are increasingly immersed in.
Poet, novelist, Robert Penn Warren, whose birthday was yesterday, observed presciently years ago that, ‚ÄúThe ideal of understanding men and telling their story, noble or victorious, will be replaced by the study of statistics or non-ideographic units of an infinite series, and computers will dictate how such unites, which do breathe and move, can best be manipulated for their own good‚Ä¶.the self we have is more and more a fictive self.‚Äù He observed that poetry has an important role in the integration of self, ‚Äúin the face of increasingly disintegrative forces in our society, poetry may affirm and reinforce the notion of the self‚Äù. He argued for ‚Äúthe creation of a new body of attitudes and values, a new assessment of our expanding technological capacities in relation to the context of nature‚Äù. He wrote very few nature poems and his ‚ÄúEvening Hawk‚Äù, is truly exceptional. He wrote:
From plane of light to plane, wings dipping through
Geometries and orchids that the sunset builds,
Out of the peak's black angularity of shadow, riding
The last tumultuous avalanche of
Light above pines and the guttural gorge,
The hawk comes.
His wing
Scythes down another day, his motion
Is that of the honed steel-edge, we hear
The crashless fall of stalks of Time.
The head of each stalk is heavy with the gold of our error.
Look! Look! he is climbing the last light
Who knows neither Time nor error, and under
Whose eye, unforgiving, the world, unforgiven, swings
Into shadow.
Long now,
The last thrush is still, the last bat
Now cruises in his sharp hieroglyphics. His wisdom
Is ancient, too, and immense. The star
Is steady, like Plato, over the mountain.
If there were no wind we might, we think, hear
The earth grind on its axis, or history
Drip in darkness like a leaking pipe in the cellar.
The poem is laden with rich metaphors, but personally I feel that no one has described the flight of a bird of prey in these exquisitely inventive words, ‚ÄúNow cruises in his sharp hieroglyphics‚Äù!

17/05/23, 7:41‚ÄØam
Today is the birthday of Edward Jenner, the father of vaccination. It is a curious fact of history that he was elected as a Fellow of the Royal Society, not for his path breaking work with vaccination, but for his observation about the nesting habits of the cuckoo. The nesting habits of the cuckoo had intrigued philosophers and naturalists since the days of Aristotle. It was known that the cuckoo parasites on other species of birds and lays a single egg in the nest of a bird of another species. The foster-parents then feed and raise the young cuckoo as if it were their own. Only the young cuckoo survives. All eggs and fledglings belonging to the birds that built the nest disappear. Jenner determined to find out why only the cuckoo survives in each nest. He noticed that it was not the parent cuckoo that ejected the foster parents' eggs and chicks from the nest, as was previously believed, but the newly hatched cuckoo! In its first few days of life the fledgling bird worked its way backwards, up the side of the nest, pushing behind it an egg or young bird, until this could be thrown from the nest. It repeated this task until only it remained in the nest. Consequently, it took over the food supply provided tirelessly by the foster parents. Edward Jenner made several observations and experiments to support his hypothesis. His findings remained contentious until the naturalists were able to photograph the phenomenon.
Common hawk cuckoo, like many other cuckoos, is a brood parasite, preferring to lay the egg in the nest of jungle babblers. A single blue egg is laid in the nest. Once the egg is hatched, the hatchling usually evicts the eggs of its host and is reared to maturity by foster parents, much like what Jenner had observed. But it was also noticed that sometimes, it may not always evict the host and that young birds may be seen along with young babblers.
Shakespeare was an excellent observer of nature and gave vi. He mentions the cuckoo‚Äôs habit of laying its eggs in other birds‚Äô nests, in both The Rape of Lucrece, where ‚ÄúHateful cuckoos hatch in sparrows nests‚Äù and in King Lear:
The hedge-sparrow fed the cuckoo so long,
That it had its head bit off by its young
20/05/23, 4:04‚ÄØpm
Bright side of nature. Honey for the bee and beauty for the eyes of the beholder. Looks like a painting Sirüëå
21/05/23, 8:38‚ÄØam
The lure to get the brain to reveal its secrets is irresistible! Amongst those who made significant inroads into unravelling its secrets was Hans Berger, discoverer of electroencephalogram (EEG), whose birthday is today. There is an interesting background to his inclination to uncover secrets of the brain. In 1893, when he was 19, he fell off his horse during and was nearly trampled. On that same day, his sister, far away, got a bad feeling about him and she sent a telegram to her father asking if everything was all right. Berger felt that he had transmitted his thoughts to his sister somehow and called it as a case of ‚Äúspontaneous telepathy.‚Äù He strove to prove how telepathy worked, trying to measure mental activity through various means, but to no avail. He scrutinized blood flow and brain temperature before turning his attention to electrical output. His breakthrough finally came on July 6, 1924 when using a vacuum tube amplifier to enhance the electrical signals, he was finally able to spot a brain wave in a patient with skull injury. He took more than five years to report his findings in a complete form.
Hans Berger‚Äôs discovery of electroencephalography was a milestone in the advancement of neuroscience. Unfortunately, he gained neither acceptance nor recognition among his fellow contemporaries and there was also an uneasy relationship with the Nazi regime. His life took a dark turn when he was ousted from his research position at the university and forced into a non-research job at a nursing home. Convinced that he had a fatal heart disease and in throes of depression, Berger ended his life by hanging in 1941.
It is a daunting task for lonely pioneers who pursue their passion in the face of many obstacles. Often the inner loneliness and emotional turmoil is intricately interwoven with the creative impulse‚Ä¶
22/05/23, 10:21‚ÄØam
Arthur Conan Doyle, whose birthday is today, graduated from the University of Edinburgh Medical School and special interest in ophthalmology. It was no wonder then, that the main character in his works, Sherlock Holmes, was a very keen observer.
Careful attention to details is one of the important components of clinical medicine. Dr Shattner articulated the essential skills that a physician has to cultivate and summarized it in the acronym SOAPS:
S maintaining a Systematic approach
O using keen Observation
A Accessing relevant databases
P employing a Personal empathic attitude
S Shared decision-making
Sherlock Holmes‚Äôs famous deductions were based on his astute powers of observation. He often advised Watson that ‚ÄòIt is a capital mistake to draw conclusions without data.‚Äô He used to consult his meticulously compiled ‚ÄòIndex‚Äô and books from his library before arriving at conclusion. Though he is often portrayed as being detached, cold or remote, he was sensitive to his client‚Äôs circumstances and reached out to those in distress. All these form crucial components in clinical decision making. I often find myself quoting Holmes to my students to enhance their clinical acumen.
In the era of Evidence Based Medicine, we often rely on reliable sources of information to guide our clinical decisions. In the process, many a time we find ourselves bogged down in a morass of information. Unfortunately, we have to contend with limited storage space within ourselves. Arthur Conon Doyle employed an interesting metaphor ‚ÄòBrain Attic‚Äô, to highlight it. He wrote in the ‚Äò A Study At Scarlet‚Äô:
‚ÄúI consider that a man's brain originally is like a little empty attic, and you have to stock it with such furniture as you choose. A fool takes in all the lumber of every sort that he comes across, so that the knowledge which might be useful to him gets crowded out, or at best is jumbled up with a lot of other things, so that he has a difficulty in laying his hands upon it. Now the skilful workman is very careful indeed as to what he takes into his brain-attic. He will have nothing but the tools which may help him in doing his work, but of these he has a large assortment, and all in the most perfect order. It is a mistake to think that that little room has elastic walls and can distend to any extent. Depend upon it there comes a time when for every addition of knowledge, you forget something that you knew before. It is of the highest importance, therefore, not to have useless facts elbowing out the useful ones.‚Äù
A timely advice in the digital era!
23/05/23, 5:53‚ÄØpm
Fantastic Sir. So working memory gets affected. Such an useful observation for scattered brains and you tube addicts.
23/05/23, 5:58‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for this piece of information. I think the judges in courts should have this knowledge.
24/05/23, 8:37‚ÄØam
World Turtle Day is an annual event (that was celebrated yesterday) aimed at increasing public awareness about the important need to protect the shrinking habitats of turtle and tortoises.
Hindu mythology is replete with references to animals, including tortoise. Prominent among them is the churning of the ocean (Samudra Manthan), which appears in several texts such as the Mahabharata, Vishnu Purana and Bhagavata Purana. To churn the primordial ocean, Mount Mandara was used as a churning rod and the snake, Vasuki as the churning rope. The Asuras held the head of the snake and the Devas held its tail and they pulled his body alternately, causing the mountain to rotate and the ocean to churn. In the process, slowly Mount Mandara began to sink. Vishnu, in his second avatar as the tortoise Kurma, came to the rescue and supported the mountain on his shell. Without Kurma avatar it would not have been possible for the ocean to be churned and the devas would not have received the fourteen gifts. The churning also resulted in the poison, ‚Äòhalahala‚Äô, which was imbibed by Lord Shiva to protect the universe from destruction.
The tortoise, as a symbol of the earth also figures in several vedic and puranic texts. According to these representation, the tortoise‚Äôs domed shell is heaven and the flat underside is the earth. Further, the kurmanivesha (tortoise abode) is central to Hindu astrology, wherein the body of the tortoise would be divided up into nakshatras (constellations) that influenced the regions occupying a certain body part. For instance, the head often represented the eastern region of the earth.
Turtle is considered very lucky in astrology and it is believed that Goddess Lakshmi, showers blessings on those who wear the ‚Äòturtle ring.‚Äô
There are three temples in India where Kurma is the main deity: Srikumaram near Srikakulam, Gavirangapura near Hosadurga and Kurma Varadaraja Swamy temple in Chittoor district. Prominent among them is Srikurmam, where the presiding Deity, Lord Kurma is self-manifest, or svayambhu. He is about 70 cm long, shaped like the shell of a turtle. The Deity‚Äôs tail is a saligram presented by Adi Sankara. In the temple‚Äôs premises, a tortoise park has also been built to conserve the adult and young star tortoises, which are found in the foothills and fields of Srikakulam. A stellar example of conservation which is in tune with the cultural and religious beliefs of people..
Let me conclude with this beautiful verse in the Sangam poetry, Kurunthokai, where the poet wrote:
‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ¥‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Øã‡Æ∞‡Øá,
‡Æ§‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡Øà ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤ ‡Æâ‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æü‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡Æö‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æé‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æü‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Øã,
‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©,
‡Æï‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Æ± ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øá?
Those who chide me, know not a thing
my passion is like a hatchling of tortoise
sustained by its mother;
if my lover forsakes me, it‚Äôll wither
like an unhatched egg, for what else can sustains it?
(This photograph of Kurma Avatar is from a pillar at the hundred pillar mandapam at Varadaraja Swamy temple, Kanchipuram. Each pillar, adorned with exquisite carvings, is a treasure to savour)

25/05/23, 9:07‚ÄØam
Thank you Sir for the detailed narration, a recapitulation. Turtles are considered as bringing luck. Indian culture contributes to the preservation of trees and animals, nature worshipped as God.
27/05/23, 9:50‚ÄØam
Ahalya presented a book of collected short stories of John Cheever, sometime in the 80s. Cheever (whose birthday is today), was an insightful chronicler of suburban alienation, much like John Updike. He was truly the American Chekov! Among all the stories in the collection, I found The Swimmer, an exceptional one.
When the story begins, Neddy, who is described as being near the prime of his life, decides to affirm his vitality by swimming his way home. With a ‚Äòcartographer‚Äôs eye‚Äô, he plans his way through the swimming pools of the neighbours. At first his journey goes smoothly. He does, however, run into various obstacles, physical as well as emotional. The pools get colder and harder to swim through. The neighbours become critical and less friendly. Fatigue overtakes him and he starts feeling lonely. Towards the end, he finds it difficult to swim and plods across the pools. Tired and feeling miserable, when he finally reaches his house only to find that it has been abandoned, his wife and children are nowhere to be found. He pounds on the door, peeps through the window and notices the house to be completely empty. At the end of his surreal voyage, his house is bereft of life. It is a moment worthy of a Greek tragedy.
The metaphor of journey is one of the most widely used elements in literature. Quite often too in our lives we realize that our journey in life is nothing like what we thought it would be when we started. As Haruki Murakami observed perceptively, ‚ÄúWhatever it is you're seeking won't come in the form you're expecting.‚Äù
And at any time, there will always be people banging at the doors of their lost dreams‚Ä¶
Cheever was also a keen observer of nature and his stories are replete with wonderful descriptions like this one from his novel ‚ÄòBullet Park‚Äô, about the red winged blackbirds and the loss of their migratory instincts:
‚ÄúBelow the house, near the grove of dead elms, there was a swamp where a flock of red-winged blackbirds nested each spring. According to the law of their species they should have turned south in the autumn but the number of bird-feeding appliances in the neighbourhood, overflowing with provender, had rattled their migratory instincts and they now spent the autumn and winter in Bullet Park in utter confusion. Their song‚Äîtwo ascending notes and a harsh trill like a cicada‚Äîwas inalienably associated with the first long nights of summer but now one heard it in the autumn, one heard it in the snow.‚Äù
27/05/23, 10:49‚ÄØpm
Beautiful bird caught by you Sir unawares. The lines have hidden facts of life. A journey seeming long is spent in expectations, many a times too short to reach. But once we get into the path of looking at the journey from a different perspective things start falling into their places.
28/05/23, 9:45‚ÄØpm
Yes Sir.....
31/05/23, 7:44‚ÄØam
One day when I was a student at NIMHANS in late 1970s, my teacher and mentor, Dr RL Kapur asked me (which he often used to!) as to what book I was reading. I told him about an interesting book ‚ÄòDice Man‚Äô by Luke Rhinehart in which a man starts making decisions in his life, guided by chance, through the throw of the dice. He suggested that I read Jacques Monod‚Äôs ‚ÄòChance and Necessity‚Äô. Intrigued by the title, I set about searching for it. Not surprisingly, I found it in the Select Book Shop. When I mentioned the title, Mr Murthy walked over to an over stacked bookshelf and handed over the book to me. It was tough a reading at first. On subsequent, more careful reading I could discern the major themes of the book.
On ‚Äòchance‚Äô Jacques Monod comments, ‚ÄúIt necessarily follows that chance alone is at the source of every innovation, and of all creation in the biosphere. Pure chance, absolutely free but blind, at the very root of the stupendous edifice of evolution: this central concept of modern biology is no longer one among many other possible or even conceivable hypotheses. It is today the sole conceivable hypothesis, the only one that squares with observed and tested fact‚Äù. With regard to ‚Äònecessity‚Äô it refers to the fact that, ‚Äúthe enzyme must act as it does, catalysing a reaction with one substrate but not another, according to the constraints imposed by its structure‚Äù. He emphasizes that chance and necessity has to be subjected to scientific evaluation and that an objective stance, shorn of value judgements is an important requirement in the pursuit of knowledge. Pointing out to the crucial role of ethics of knowledge acquisition in modern science, the author makes an incisive comment that, ‚ÄúIn science, self-satisfaction is death. Personal self-satisfaction is the death of the scientist. Collective self-satisfaction is the death of research. It is the restlessness, anxiety, dissatisfaction, agony of mind that nourish Science‚Äù.
I read some more about the author and found out that he was a close associate of Albert Camus and that the book was the outcome of several hours of long discussions between the two.
Jacques Monod (whose birthday is today), was many things in his life: an aspiring orchestra conductor, hero of the French Resistance and was deeply involved in assisting scientists facing persecution in totalitarian regimes. He was often referred to as ‚ÄòCamus in a lab coat‚Äô.
Interestingly, chance played a significant part in his life. He was about to embark on a scientific expedition to Greenland when one of his colleagues from the faculty of natural sciences at the Sorbonne, convinced him to go to the California Institute of Technology in USA to study genetics on a Rockefeller scholarship. That chance decision saved his life, as the ship on which he was to travel with the expedition sank and there were no survivors!
01/06/23, 7:51‚ÄØpm
Chance, probably broadens the pursuit and does not narrow down to clear cut road. Food for thought Sir. How he escaped death by chance or destined to survive?
04/06/23, 12:46‚ÄØpm
The catastrophic train accident resulting in scores of deaths, is an unsurpassed human tragedy in recent time. Many more have been injured and the traumatic event will leave its footprints in their memory for long. Such terrifying experiences lurk deeply within, impacting emotional life and behaviour in myriad, unsettling ways. Coping with internalized trauma over time, is not an easy task.
WHR Rivers (whose death anniversary is today) in his pioneering work drew attention to the terrifying internalized experiences of traumatic memories, albeit in a different context, World War I.
River‚Äôs insightful observation was that traumatic memories were often repressed because there was a ‚Äúconflict between the mental tendencies of the individual and the traditional code of conduct prescribed by society‚Äù. He published an account of his work in the Lancet in 1918, stating: ‚ÄòNew symptoms often arise in hospital or at home which are not the immediate and necessary consequence of the war experience, but are due to repression of painful memories and thoughts, or of unpleasant affective states arising out of reflection concerning this experience.‚Äô
In dealing with these troublesome memories, Rivers emphasized the importance of a humanistic engagement with the traumatised patients, exploring the meaning of their experiences through ‚Äôtalking cure‚Äô. He employed what he termed as ‚Äòautognosis‚Äô, which was a two-part process. The first was focused on educating the patient and helping him to realize that the illness he was experiencing was neither ‚Äústrange‚Äù nor permanent. The second part was talk therapy, which involved discussing traumatic experiences at an in-depth level with patients and helping them to work through their painful experiences in more positive ways.
Notable amongst his patients the war poet Siegfried Sassoon, who wrote fondly of Rivers compassionate bedside manner in a poem which he sent to the poet Robert Graves:
But yesterday my reasoning Rivers ran solemnly in,
With peace in the pools of his spectacled eyes and a wisely omnipotent grin;
And I fished in that steady grey stream and decided that I
after all am no longer the Worm that refuses to die.
Pat Barker‚Äô ‚ÄòRegeneration Trilogy‚Äô gives a wonderful, fictionalized account of WHR Rivers and his monumental work with soldiers traumatized by the war

10/06/23, 6:37‚ÄØpm

11/06/23, 8:02‚ÄØam
Long back, I picked up a slim novel, ‚ÄòLie down in darkness‚Äô by William Styron. It was a deeply unsettling, poignant account of a family in the process of disintegration. It opens with the suicide of the daughter of the family and as the novel unfolds, we get to know her turbulent emotional background behind the act of self-destruction. As she narrates, ‚ÄúWhich is worse, past or future? Neither. I will fold up my mind like a leaf and drift on this stream over the brink. Which will be soon, and then the dark, and then be done with this ugliness...‚Äù
Many years late, William Styron found himself in throes of a similar overwhelming sadness. He went through a period of prolonged, severe, suicidal depression and wrote a harrowing account of his experience in ‚ÄòDarkness Visible: A Memoir of Madness‚Äô. Characterizing depression as ‚Äòthe howling tempest in the brain‚Äô, he described it as "a disorder of mood, so mysteriously painful and elusive in the way it becomes known to the self ‚Äì to the mediating intellect, as to verge close to being beyond description. It thus remains nearly incomprehensible to those who have not experienced it in its extreme mode.‚Äù
At the end of the book, the author comments, referring to Dante: ‚ÄúFor those who have dwelt in depression‚Äôs dark wood, and known its inexplicable agony, their return from the abyss is not unlike the ascent of the poet, trudging upward and upward out of hell‚Äôs black depths and at last emerging into what he saw as ‚Äòthe shining world.‚Äô There, whoever has been restored to health has almost always been restored to the capacity for serenity and joy, and this may be indemnity enough for having endured the despair beyond despair.‚Äù
The book is a moving vocabulary of depression that unlocks the unspoken, hidden suffering of many who are afflicted with it.
The title ‚ÄòDarkness Visible‚Äô, might sound a bit puzzling. It alludes to a poem in Milton‚Äôs ‚ÄòParadise Lost‚Äô:
‚ÄúNow the thought
Both of lost happiness and lasting pain
Torments him; round he throws his baleful eyes
That witnessed huge affliction and dismay
Mixed with obdurate pride and steadfast hate:
At once as far as angels ken he views
The dismal situation waste and wild,
A dungeon horrible, on all sides round
As one great furnace flamed, yet from those flames
No light, but rather darkness visible
Served only to discover sights of woe,
Regions of sorrow, doleful shades, where peace
And rest can never dwell, hope never comes
That comes to all; but torture without end
Still urges, and a fiery deluge, fed
With ever-burning sulfur unconsumed.‚Äù
In this book, William Styron (whose birthday is today) extends a reassuring hand to those suffering from depression by pointing out that it is possible to see and work through the darkness of depression and continue the journey in life, afresh.
12/06/23, 11:00‚ÄØpm
Simply gorgeous Sir!! Looks as though it is opening up the bright hope and automatically brings a smile on the onlooker....
14/06/23, 5:23‚ÄØam
Memory is an intrinsic part of our everyday lives. We are what we remember and what we forget too. Our brains are designed to forget things. Many a time when I try to recollect things, I can sense the chaos in my neuronal circuitry!
Is it possible for someone to remember everything in his life?
The first documented case of extraordinary memory was by the celebrated Russian psychologist Alexander Luria. Starting in the 1920s, the person whom he studied was able to remember long sequences of numbers and details many years after hearing them. After studying the person for more than 30 years, Luria confessed his inability to find a limit to his memory, a surprising statement considering that it came from one of the foremost psychologists of his time.
In the realm of literature, there is an interesting short story ‚ÄòFunes The Memorious‚Äô, by Jorge Luis Borges, who died on this day in 1986. It narrates the travails of Ireneo Funes, who after falling off a horse and hitting his head hard, recovers consciousness with the incredible ability or perhaps curse, of remembering absolutely everything. Borges suggests that this kind of extraordinary memory has its own pitfalls. Says Fune, ‚ÄúI alone have more memories than all men may have ever had since the world exists. My memory, sir, is like a rubbish heap.‚Äù
Borges goes on to write, ‚ÄúOf the magical compadrito of my story I can state that he is a precursor to supermen, a suburban, incomplete Zarathustra; what cannot be denied is that he is a monster.‚Äù
In the era of ChatGPT and AI, ‚ÄòFunes the Memorious,‚Äô the story about a man who remembers everything, but understands nothing seems so visionary!
Borges also wrote some captivating poems, like this one about the tiger:
THE OTHER TIGER
A tiger comes to mind. The twilight here
Exalts the vast and busy Library
And seems to set the bookshelves back in gloom;
Innocent, ruthless, bloodstained, sleek
It wanders through its forest and its day
Printing a track along the muddy banks
Of sluggish streams whose names it does not know
(In its world there are no names or past
Or time to come, only the vivid now)
And makes its way across wild distances
Sniffing the braided labyrinth of smells
And in the wind picking the smell of dawn
And tantalizing scent of grazing deer;
Among the bamboo's slanting stripes I glimpse
The tiger's stripes and sense the bony frame
Under the splendid, quivering cover of skin.
Curving oceans and the planet's wastes keep us
Apart in vain; from here in a house far off
In South America I dream of you,
Track you, O tiger of the Ganges' banks.
It strikes me now as evening fills my soul
That the tiger addressed in my poem
Is a shadowy beast, a tiger of symbols
And scraps picked up at random out of books,
A string of labored tropes that have no life,
And not the fated tiger, the deadly jewel
That under sun or stars or changing moon
Goes on in Bengal or Sumatra fulfilling
Its rounds of love and indolence and death.
To the tiger of symbols I hold opposed
The one that's real, the one whose blood runs hot
As it cuts down a herd of buffaloes,
And that today, this August third, nineteen
Fifty-nine, throws its shadow on the grass;
But by the act of giving it a name,
By trying to fix the limits of its world,
It becomes a fiction not a living beast,
Not a tiger out roaming the wilds of earth.
We'll hunt for a third tiger now, but like
The others this one too will be a form
Of what I dream, a structure of words, and not
The flesh and one tiger that beyond all myths
Paces the earth. I know these things quite well,
Yet nonetheless some force keeps driving me
In this vague, unreasonable, and ancient quest,
And I go on pursuing through the hours
Another tiger, the beast not found in verse.

19/06/23, 10:39‚ÄØam
Walking has a long history. Ever since our earliest hominids took the first bipedal steps, we have not stopped walking! Walking has served as a tool for political protests, affirmation of civil, human rights and in quest of the divine. The simple act of putting one step ahead of the other has also been medicalized over time. Physicians emphasize its health benefits and each and every smartphone has an app to count the number of steps taken during walking. One can often notice people with headphones striding briskly keeping pace with the magical number of healthy steps.
In 1862 David Thoreau‚Äôs wrote an interesting essay titled ‚ÄòWalking‚Äô. In it, he drew attention to the difference between walking and sauntering. When we walk, we concentrate on pace or getting somewhere, as quickly as possible. Sauntering is vastly different. When we saunter, we pause, look around, listen and immerse ourselves in the world outside. Thoreau observed that the word saunter might have originated with those who took pilgrimages to the Holy Land, the sainted land: ‚Äòsainte terre‚Äô. Or perhaps from the idea of being without land ownership, ‚Äòsans terre‚Äô, which, for him, meant having no particular home but being ‚Äúequally at home everywhere.‚Äù The trick, according to Thoreau, is not to take your inside life out but to go present and empty.
We often rush through our lives. How much better it would be to "saunter" along this trail of life, lingering hither and thither, pausing for a while in the company of trees, listening to the melodies of the wind as it courses through the leaves, keeping an ear for the songs of the birds and watch petite flowers growing?
In the words of Simon and Garfunkel:
Slow down, you move too fast
You got to make the morning last
Just kicking down the cobblestones
Looking for fun and feeling groovy
Ba da-da da-da da-da, feeling groovy
Hello lamppost, what'cha knowing
I've come to watch your flowers growin'
Ain't you got no rhymes for me?
Doo-ait-n-doo-doo, feeling groovy
Ba da-da da-da da-da, feeling groovy
I got no deeds to do, no promises to keep
I'm dappled and drowsy and ready to sleep
Let the morningtime drop all its petals on me
Life, I love you, all is groovy
(Notes on the World Sauntering Day!)
19/06/23, 7:39‚ÄØpm
Oh never knew there was some day called World Sauntering Day. In the maddening world, dependence on vehicles people have forgotten to walk let alone saunter! So important to slow down and look around not buildings but nature....photograph is wonderful Sir. Have to suffice with virtual saunteringüòî caption conveys the message of simple meaningful life.

22/06/23, 10:48‚ÄØam
There is something surreal about venturing into a rainforest. It was quite sunny when I entered the forest, but soon I was enveloped in darkness with sun peering through the tall trees occasionally. It was humid inside and the noisy cicadas showered me with their squirts of fluid, like raindrops. I made my way gingerly amongst the moist leaves and broken branches in the forest floor. Birds kept fluttering by but it was difficult to observe them clearly in the dense foliage. The Japanese have a wonderful word to describe the experience, ‚Äòshinrin-yoku‚Äô or ‚Äòforest bathing‚Äô. It refers to the contemplative experience of being immersed in the sights, sounds and smells of the forest.
Rainforests are cradles of biodiversity. Unfortunately, their loss continues, unabated at a blistering pace. As EO Wilson commented, ‚Äúdestroying rainforests for economic gains is like burning a renaissance painting to cook a meal‚Äù.
The rainforests hold answers for many of the question that besiege us in an era of escalating global warming. The problem is that we turn a deaf ear to them.
A world without rainforest is akin to a man without lungs.
Let us wander into the rainforest where the wifi is weak, discover its magic, feel and cherish the connection to Mother Earth.
(Today is the World Rainforest Day)

30/06/23, 2:11‚ÄØpm
Today I lost one of my fellow travelers whom I had been treating for several decades. He was first admitted in NIMHANS with catatonia. He was in this state for a week and recovered with medication. Ever since that episode he has been in regular touch with me. Occasionally, he would slip into catatonia, but would recover quickly, to carry on his work as a teacher in a reputed residential school. Whenever I enquired about these episodes, there would be a lovely smile on his face, but he wouldn‚Äôt speak much about it. I was aware that there was a deep emotional substrate for his behavior, but made it a point not to force him, to ‚Äòelicit‚Äô psychopathology. It was a relationship built on compassion and empathy imbued with tacit trust. Being a fiercely independent person, he made the decision to live by himself and not return to his family home after retirement. He lived alone in a small house built entirely from his savings. He designed it in such a way so as to accommodate his vast collection of western music, which I would hear in the background during his calls, every month. Very regular with medication, he never skipped even a single dose.
A few years ago, on his own, he shared with me that he has been hearing voices which increased during these episodes and went on to offer a vivid description of them. He added as to how medications helped him to cope with them.
He was an aficionado of western classic music and used to send me YouTube links of the choicest recordings every morning. When I opened my computer this morning, there was none.
He would be the first person to wish me on ‚ÄòTeachers Day‚Äô. When I look back, I feel that he taught me many a thing about a chronic illness like schizophrenia. For people like him, it is a journey, often alone, in a strange country which as professionals we still strive to unravel. It continues to be an unsettling emotional terrain which patients negotiate with their own internal resources and remarkable resilience and he was a stellar example of that. He was alive even during the darkest moments in his life and the flame still glows.
Farewell my friend‚Ä¶
02/07/23, 8:56‚ÄØam
What draws me to Hermann Hesse (whose birthday is today), is his emphasis on self-realization in his novels. The quest for authentic self is a continuing strand in most of his works. The greatest example of it is of course, his slender novel, Siddhartha. The protagonist wanders through ancient India, in pursuit of an enlightened way of life, during the course of which he experiments with both spartan asceticism and luxurious hedonism. In the book‚Äôs most important scene, Siddhartha actually encounters the Buddha, but spurns him as he perceives that any kind of religion is an obstacle to enlightenment. ‚ÄúNo one will ever attain redemption through doctrine! After all, the Buddha didn‚Äôt become the Buddha by following the Buddha!‚Äù Eventually, he finds spiritual wisdom by contemplating the flow of a great river and realizes that one can discover the true self only through wading alone in the waters of consciousness.
Hermann Hesse underwent two spells of therapy with Jung. In his diary, he recorded some advice that the renowned analyst gave him. ‚ÄúLife‚Äôs problems aren‚Äôt there to be cleanly solved, each of them is a pair of opposites, that between them produce a tension that is called life‚Äù.
Hermann Hesse was also a keen observer of nature, especially trees. He wrote:
‚ÄúFor me, trees have always been the most penetrating preachers‚Ä¶ in their highest boughs the world rustles, their roots rest in infinity; but they do not lose themselves there, they struggle with all the force of their lives for one thing only: to fulfil themselves according to their own laws, to build up their own form, to represent themselves. Nothing is holier, nothing is more exemplary than a beautiful, strong tree.‚Äù
03/07/23, 7:13‚ÄØpm
Very informative Sir and on Guru Poornima Day.
04/07/23, 9:01‚ÄØam
A few years ago, I visited Belur math and expressed a desire to see the room where Swami Vivekananda used to reside. The room was facing the Ganga and the river was flowing gently caressed by the morning sun. It was such a serene setting and I could imagine the Swami meditating, absorbed in the scenic beauty of the river. The room was full of various objects and artefacts used by him, including a pakhawaj and tanpura. There was a bed on the floor with a garlanded photograph of his.
This was the place where the Swami passed away on this day, at the age of thirty nine years, five months and twenty four days. He embraced death, free of any fear or apprehension. He remarked to his devotees, ‚ÄúI shall never see forty‚Ä¶ I delivered my message and I must go‚Ä¶ The shadow of a big tree will not let the smaller trees grow up. I must go to make room.‚Äù In one of his letters to his disciples, he commented, ‚ÄúComing and going is all pure delusion. The soul never comes nor goes. Where is the place to which it shall go, when all space is in the soul? When shall be the time for entering and departing, when all time is in the soul?‚Äù
One of the most popular saying of Swami Vivekananda is ‚ÄúArise, Awake, and stop not till the goal is reached.‚Äù This has its origin in Katha Upanishad. In Katha Upanishad, chapter 1.3.14, we see Yama suggesting Nachiketa‚Äî
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§§,
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§™‡§•: ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø |
Arise! Awake! Approach the great and learn.
Like the sharp edge of a razor is that path,
so the wise say‚àíhard to tread and difficult to cross.
As Swami observed, ‚ÄúSharp as the blade of a razor, long and difficult and hard to cross, is the way to liberation. The sages have declared this again and again. Yet do not let any weakness or failure bind you. The Upanishads have declared, ‚ÄòArise! Awake! and stop not until the goal is reached.‚Äô Cross the path, sharp as it is like the razor, however difficult it may be‚Äù.

12/07/23, 9:43‚ÄØam
Henry David Thoreau whose birthday is today, was enchanted by trees and they played a significant role in his inner life. They were his constant guides and companions in his spiritual quest. Trees emerge in his writings as special symbols and images of the divine. The forest was his cathedral, the woods his ‚Äúsanctum sanctorum.‚Äù
Thoreau immersed himself in observing the shape, colour, texture and stances of trees. For him, exploring such details was an act of contemplation. ‚ÄúA tree seen against other trees is a mere dark mass, but against the sky it has parts, has symmetry and expression.‚Äù
Trees revealed themselves poetically to Thoreau. They were ‚Äúliving poetry,‚Äù written by nature on the landscape. The shadows of trees on the ground at night were ‚Äúlike chandeliers of darkness.‚Äù
The writings of Thoreau helps me to see trees in new ways and they take on a deeper meaning in the process.
Trees were wordless poems to him and each time I immerse myself listening to their unspoken words, I discover something anew.
Unfortunately, we are losing the tree cover with an alarming rate in India. Around 2.3 million trees have been proposed to be cut to make way for mega infrastructure projects in the country. We are witnessing the biggest decline in deforestation in the past few years. Reports indicate that India lost 668400 hectares of forests in the past five years, second highest globally.
During Thoreau‚Äôs lifetime too, there was increasing deforestation in New England his comment was ‚ÄúThank God, they cannot cut down the clouds!‚Äù

17/07/23, 8:46‚ÄØam
When I joined NIMHANS, Dr RL Kapur gave us a few introductory classes on scientific method of enquiry in understanding human behaviour, which invariably, is complex. In the process, he introduced us to the writings of Henri Poincare, whose death anniversary is today. He quoted Poincare about the role of facts in science, ‚ÄúScience is built up of facts, as a house is with stones. But a collection of facts is no more a science than a heap of stones is a house.‚Äù Science is the process of determining which of the countless facts will be most useful in advancing knowledge.
According to Poincare, every scientific theory is a hypothesis that had to be tested. He emphasized that experience alone is inadequate to falsify a theory and the role of falsified hypothesis is very important in any scientific pursuit.
Poincare also drew attention to the role of intuition in science, ‚ÄúPure logic cannot give us this view of the whole; it is to intuition that we must look for it. It is with logic that one proves; it is with intuition that one invents.‚Äù
I find this particular reflection of his quite interesting: ‚ÄúLife is only a short episode between two eternities and in this episode, conscious thought has lasted and will last only a moment. Thought is only a gleam in the midst of a long night. But it is the gleam which is everything‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
17/07/23, 10:25‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for the glimpse of Poincare's reflections. I think we should develop that bent of mind to go beyond hard facts and that requires acumen. The emphasis on thought, impermanence but it's impact!
19/07/23, 10:22‚ÄØam
Today is the birth anniversary of a poet who was ahead of her times, Balamani Amma.
On this day, I want to share a poem of hers titled ‚ÄòThe Pen‚Äô which has been translated by her talented daughter, poet Kamala Das.
When I touch you, O pen,
you flow like blood in my veins.
You become my lover,
the one who knows my heart‚Äôs pain.
You are my companion,
the one who hears my silent cries.
With your ink, you write my story,
and my deepest desires arise.
You understand my words,
even before they are born.
You give life to my thoughts,
like the first light of morn.
You are my confidant,
the keeper of my secrets untold.
You hold my dreams and hopes,
more precious than silver or gold.
When I caress you, O pen,
I feel the pulse of life.
You become my voice,
in a world filled with strife.
You are my solace,
when darkness engulfs my soul.
With your gentle touch,
you make me feel whole.
When I hold you, O pen,
my spirit begins to soar.
You guide me through the realms,
where imagination and dreams explore.
You are my muse,
my source of inspiration divine.
With you by my side,
I can conquer mountains and cross every line.
O pen, you are my magic wand,
that brings forth a world unknown.
Through your ink, I find freedom,
and my true self is shown.
In your strokes and curves,
my heart finds solace and peace.
You are my silent companion,
in this journey that‚Äôll never cease.
(The attached photo of mine carries a few lines from her poem, ‚ÄòThe Temple‚Äô. It depicts a beautifully carved corridor at the Vanamamalai Perumal temple in Tirunelveli.)
26/07/23, 11:33‚ÄØam
There is always a hidden side in each one of us. It is a part of our self which we do not like or acknowledge. It consists of everything that does not align with our conscious self. CG Jung whose birthday is today, termed it as the ‚Äòshadow‚Äô and emphasized that it offers a doorway to understand ourselves. The shadow is a cognitive blind spot of our psyche and Jung described it as ‚Äúthe thing a person has no wish to be‚Äù.
Often we identify and respond to the shadow of the others, with ease. It is a truism that what we dislike in others is an indication of what we dislike in ourselves. We hide our negative qualities, not only from others but from ourselves too.
The meeting with oneself is, at first, the meeting with one‚Äôs own shadow. Prising apart the doors of shadow offers us a glimpse of that part of our personality that conflicts with the ideal version of ourselves. It is the first step towards increasing our awareness about our self. As Jung commented, ‚Äúone must learn to know oneself in order to know who one is‚Ä¶ one does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light, but by making the darkness conscious‚Äù
Unravelling and working through the shadow is a crucial component in therapy. As Jung commented, ‚ÄúThere is no generally effective technique for assimilating the shadow. It is more like diplomacy or statesmanship and it is always an individual matter. First one has to accept and take seriously the existence of the shadow. Second, one has to become aware of its qualities and intentions. This happens through conscientious attention to moods, fantasies and impulses. Third, a long process of negotiation is unavoidable.‚Äù
Jung went on to add, ‚Äúthe task in life is not to become perfect, but to become whole. And as wholeness entails both good and evil, light and darkness, the achievement of wholeness in personality development requires we assimilate our shadow into our conscious personality.‚Äù
William Shakespeare articulated it perceptively, ‚ÄúThis thing of darkness I acknowledge mine.‚Äù
27/07/23, 10:49‚ÄØpm
Wow what a photograph SirüëåAcceptance of oneself is a long process. But worth the effort as it loosens the knots.
30/07/23, 10:31‚ÄØpm
An enchanting photograph Sir. Yes, an eternal journey!!!
31/07/23, 10:36‚ÄØpm
Sure Sir.
03/08/23, 12:54‚ÄØpm
Today is the festival of Aadi Perukku, which marks the beginning of agricultural activities in Tamil Nadu, when the river Kaveri is in full flow due to south west monsoon. Farmers start their sowing in the month of Aadi (July-August) so that they can harvest the crops after six months in January during Pongal Festival. On this day people gather on the banks of Kaveri and offer prayers to the river goddess.
River Kaveri fostered civilisations, kingdoms rose on her banks and majestic temples were built on the lands irrigated by it. Great Carnatic composers, scholars and writers lived and wrote in the towns and villages that flanked the river. Sangam poetry and tamil epics like Silappadikaram, celebrated her beauty.
In Pattina Palai, a Tamil poetic work belonging to the Sangam period, Kaveri is referred to as
‚ÄúCauvery, the river that never fails, even if the sky does‚Äù.
‚Äú‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡ÆØ‡Øç‡ÆØ‡Ææ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Øà‡ÆØ ‡Æï‡Æü‡Æ±‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æø‚Äù
An interesting verse in Purananooru, one of the eight books in the Sangam literature, draws attention to the maternal instincts of the river.
‚ÄúThe forceful waters of the river Cauvery
That can even uproot a tree,
Takes care of all the living beings of the world
As a woman feeding a child through her breast‚Äù
‚Äú‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ¥‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡Æá‡Æ≤‡Æø‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Æö‡Øç
‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æ∞‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Æø ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡Øç
‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æ§‡Øà ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‚Äù
Ilango Adigal wrote in a similar vein in Silappadigaram:
‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡ÆÖ‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æü‡ØÅ
‡ÆÆ‡Æï‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æï‡Æø
‡Æä‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡Æâ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Æµ‡Æø
‡Æí‡Æ¥‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ∞‡Æø
Long live this fertile country!
Long live Kaveri
That nurtures the country
Like a mother
04/08/23, 10:47‚ÄØpm
What a serene scenery. Yes Sir she is not just a river. Talakaveri the origin of the river is in Coorg.
14/08/23, 12:03‚ÄØpm
Oriental garden lizards have been around with us for decades. They serve a very useful function as bioregulators of crop pests. One can spot them easily and it is fascinating to watch when they attack a prey. They will wait patiently, sitting on a branch, scanning around for a suitable prey. Once they spot them, they sprint fast to grasp the prey, in a flash. It is interesting to note that these reptiles are tetrachromats (having four cone cells) which allows them to see colours beyond the normal human visible range and this enhanced colour vision is a significant advantage when they hunt for a prey.
Lazing in the sun and chasing some insects, it is just another day in the life of the oriental garden lizard!
In its agility
We can feel inspired
To be nimble and agile
In our pursuits in life
15/08/23, 10:57‚ÄØpm
You have caught it from a wonderful angle Sir. True. It is important to keep up the spirits to be agile.

27/08/23, 9:06‚ÄØam
Today is the birthday of one of the most eminent psychiatrists that India ever produced, Dr Jaswant Singh Neki. As a fledgling young psychiatrist, I cherish the few interactions that I have had whenever he visited NIMHANS. Though I was overawed with his towering presence and intellectual proves, he interacted with youngsters like me with ease. In one such interaction, I asked him about the categorical classification on mental illness and I was bowled over by his response. He said, ‚ÄúYoung man, we try to capture the intangible in tangible way. Once we do that, we try to enumerate and quantify the tangible. Not content with it, we then try to measure it. In the process the essence and spirit of the intangible nature of human behaviour is lost.‚Äù
Dr JS Neki was a noted poet with several volumes of published work. On another occasion, I asked him about how science and poetry relate to each other. His answer was very apt, ‚ÄúA scientist is an empirical poet and a poet is a scientist of more imaginative and creative hypotheses."
His magnum opus is Koee Naon Na Jane Mera (Nobody Knows even my Name) which is his autobiography written in verse form. Unfortunately, this has not been translated into English. When I searched the net, I found a translation of one of the verses from the first section of the book:
My life is a journal, a diary, in it
I wrote one tale but another got writ.
My fancy built but castles of sand,
My effort drew but lines in brine.
Enrolling my name in destiny's scroll,
A spot I got on the slopes of Time.
27/08/23, 10:22‚ÄØpm
It is so True what he talks about classification. Though it may help for a rough understanding of the problem, for scientific study, very important to understand the unique nature of problems the person has... Thank you Sir for the glimpse especially the poetic side.
30/08/23, 10:31‚ÄØam
My grand uncle Dr RV Rajam was a well-known medical professional and a passionate bibliophile. Once when I visited him after joining the medical school, he handed over a slim book and asked me to read it. It was ‚ÄòDeath Be Not Proud‚Äô by John Gunther. Once I started reading it, I couldn‚Äôt put it down. Gunther‚Äôs memoir is a moving account of his son Johnny‚Äôs tryst with a fast growing brain tumour and his death.
The book's title comes from one of John Donne's Holy Sonnets, which he wrote after the death of his wife and three of his children. It opens with Gunther's fond, vivid portrait of his son: a young man of extraordinary intellectual promise and fun loving as well. It is a meticulous record of the diagnosis and the exhaustive hunt for various therapeutic options that he and his ex-wife pursued during their son's illness. The second section consists of Johnny‚Äôs letters and diaries which offer rich insights about his life before the onset of the tumour. The concluding part of the book by his mother, Frances is an intensely emotional account of a mother coping with the illness and demise of a beloved child. It ends with the moving last line, "And then like a thief, death stole him".
Death Be Not Proud is a poignantly interwoven account of the family‚Äôs suffering and loss. It is the forerunner of many others that followed, in articulating lived experiences of grief.
Inherent in personal narratives like Death Be Not Proud, is the immeasurable power of words to heal. The concept of bibliotherapy is not new. In ancient Greece, the phrase ‚Äúa healing place for the soul‚Äù was inscribed above the door to the library of Thebes. In the prescient words of the bard, ‚ÄúGive sorrow words, the grief that does not speak knits up the o‚Äôer wrought heart and bids it break.‚Äù
For people in throes of grief, poems do offer comfort and solace.
John Milton wrote in 1671:
‚Äúapt words have power to swage
The tumours of a troubled mind.
And are as balm to festered wound‚Äù
(Today is also the birthday of John Gunther)
Dr Raguram
31/08/23, 8:25‚ÄØpm
Thank you for sharing Sir. Ventilation through words and the way they heal...
01/09/23, 10:15‚ÄØam
Ahalya and myself finally caught up with the movie Oppenheimer and the story about the ‚Äòtrinity‚Äô test. The name is derived from a poem by John Donne and perhaps these lines from it ‚Äúyour force, to break, blow, burn and make me new‚Äù, were the inspiration behind choosing it. Watching the movie also brought back memories of passing by the testing site on our way to the White Sands National Park, New Mexico.
As a talented scientist, Oppenheimer ensured that the test was a success. Was he mindful about its radioactive fallout and its hazards? Though he famously remarked that he had blood on his hands, ostensibly, there was neither apology nor guilt about the human cost of the project that he led. During his visit to Japan later, he commented, ‚ÄúI do not think coming to Japan changed my sense of anguish about my part in this whole piece of history. Nor has it fully made me regret my responsibility for the technical success of the enterprise.‚Äù The horrendous effect of the bomb on Hiroshima is mentioned in the movie in bland statistical terms couched in numbers. One has to read John Hershey‚Äôs ‚ÄòHiroshima‚Äô to fathom the humongous human suffering inflicted by the act.
There were also others who had to endure the lasting effects of radiation around the test site. Often referred to as ‚Äòdownwinders‚Äô, these were thousands of families living in close proximity to the area. The bomb was packed with 13 pounds of weapons grade plutonium but only 3 pounds of the plutonium was fissioned. The remaining 10 pounds of plutonium found its way into the soil, sand, animal and plant life and on the skin of every living being. As a result of the overexposure to radiation, there was an increase in infant mortality in the months following the test. Heart disease, leukaemia, and other cancers appeared in families who had no prior history. Because of illness they were unable to work and access to health care remained unaffordable and elusive.
Though the US Government set up a fund to extend compensation and medical care through the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA), the downwinders in New Mexico have never been included or compensated although they were the first people to be exposed to radiation in the world.
The poet T≈çge Sankichi captured the horror and devastation unleashed by the atom bomb in the poem ‚ÄòAugust 6th‚Äô. Here are the first few lines from it:
‚Äúcan we forget that flash?
suddenly 30,000 in the streets disappeared
in the crushed depths of darkness
the shrieks of 50,000 died out ‚Äú
Dr Raguram
04/09/23, 10:23‚ÄØam
Decades ago during a visit to the Premier Bookshop, I picked up a book (attracted by its title!), ‚ÄòLimits to Medicine‚Äô by Ivan Illich. It blew me away when I read it. I was struck by its originality as well as by its audacity. Illich dared to question some of our deepest-held beliefs about medicine.
Those days, NIMHANS used to have a book review session and when my turn came, I chose this book without any hesitation. When I mentioned it to Dr RL Kapur, he asked me to meet the visiting professor Dr Morris Carstairs. He asked me the reason why I chose the book and said that he would chair the session. When I was about to leave, he told me that he had had a televised debate with Illich about the book! The session went off very well with me passionately articulating its strengths and drawbacks. After the session when we were walking out, Carstairs shook my hand and said, ‚ÄúYou are a wonderful rascal!‚Äù A typical British encomium!
One of the major themes in the book is iatrogenesis. Illich described three types of iatrogenesis: clinical, or the direct harm done by various medical treatments; social and the medicalisation of ordinary life; and cultural, meaning the loss of traditional ways of dealing with suffering and death. He coined the term ‚ÄòSisyphus syndrome‚Äô, meaning the more healthcare is given to a population, the greater is its demand. He cautioned that over-medicalisation often results in commodification of health and ‚Äòindustrialization‚Äô of medical practice.
Illich‚Äôs prediction of ever-increasing medicalisation has come true and unfortunately, doctors are as much victims of it as their patients. Health care is now on this conveyor belt, driven by ‚Äòtargets‚Äô set by ‚Äòmanagers‚Äô who have no background in medicine, solely driven by market forces. Doctors no longer hold the monopoly and they are ‚Äúaccomplices‚Äù in the ever expanding, large medical industry.
Illich was a visionary in the proper sense. He drew attention to disease mongering and the increasing pharmaceutical invasion. He emphasized the importance of evidence base in the practice of medicine and the crucial role of community and public involvement in medical care.
He mentioned that ‚Äúif you want to change society then you must tell an alternative story‚Äù and ‚ÄòLimits to Medicine‚Äô is a provocative one at that!
(Today is Ivan Illich‚Äôs birthday)
Dr Raguram

Thank you Sir for introducing a revolutionary thinker! I have always missed your judgment in medicating a patient. The erratic way patients are m medicated scares meüôÑ

17/09/23, 10:36‚ÄØam
Wild boars have been an integral part of the Indian ecosystem and have been mentioned in various folklores and mythologies. Among them, one of the most prominent reference to the wild boars is that of Varaha, the third avatar of Vishnu. It is a fascinating tale of how the earth goddess Bhudevi was captured by the demon Hiranayaksha and trapped in the cosmic waters. Vishnu then took the form of a divine boar and rescued her after battling the demon for a thousand years.
Varaha worship was significant in Central India during the Gupta period, particularly from the 4th to the 6th century CE. The worship of Varaha was also important in southern India, especially during the early Chalukyan period. They were the first dynasty to adopt boar as their symbol. Later the Vijayanagar dynasty also chose the boar as their royal emblem
In sculptural tradition, Varaha is usually depicted in two distinct ways: one is with the head of a boar and torso of a man, which is called the ‚ÄòNaravaraha‚Äô, and the other as a wild boar. Khajuraho has one of the best-known representations of Varaha in the wild boar form. One of the most beautiful depictions of Varaha as ‚ÄòNaravaraha‚Äô, is at the Mahakuta temple which dates back to 5th-6th centry.
Varaha avatar symbolizes the preservation and restoration of the world and the triumph of good over evil. Today, when our earth faces a serious threat from several modern demons, the chief of which is our own endless greed, it‚Äôs time to feel inspired by Varaha!
(Today is also celebrated as Varaha Jayanthi)
Dr Raguram
18/09/23, 3:35‚ÄØpm
Yes Sir. Will hear it again.

Thank you Sir for refreshing my memoryüôè

Thank you Sir for a detailed description of the beautifully sculpted figures. Your narration makes sense and we can truly enjoy the richness of our culture. Rubbishing everything is very easy and doesn't require brains. But to appreciate the intricate work done with knowledge needs an eye and cognitive capacity!!

23/09/23, 8:41‚ÄØam
During my tenure at NIMHANS, I used to conduct what was referred to as ‚ÄòBrain Storming Session‚Äô, on Saturdays. The idea was to broaden the ‚Äòclinical gaze‚Äô which the trainees are accustomed to and discuss issues of interest, whether it is a book/poem/film they have read/seen recently or explore an issue of concern. The unwritten rule was that no topic related to mental health will ever be the focus of discussion in the forum.
In one of the sessions, a visiting student from Sweden brought a book of poems by Pablo Neruda and recited some of them. I can distinctly recollect a few lines from one of the poems ‚ÄòKeeping Quiet.‚Äô:
‚ÄúFor once on the face of the earth
let‚Äôs not speak in any language,
let‚Äôs stop for one second,
and not move our arms so much.
It would be an exotic moment
without rush, without engines,
we would all be together
in a sudden strangeness‚Ä¶‚Äù
The session ended with some lively discussion about Neruda and his poems and I also urged the students to see the movie, ‚Äòil Postino (The Postman)‚Äô. It portrays an imagined a fictional friendship between Pablo Neruda and a shy impressionable young postman named Mario. Pablo Neruda has been exiled from his native Chile for political reasons, and has come to live in a small village. The entire village is illiterate and he‚Äôs the only one getting mail. After some hesitation, Mario summons up the courage to talk to Neruda. They talk about poetry, politics and women. Mario and Pablo develop a deep friendship as time passes. All these elements flow together seamlessly in a fascinating manner in the movie. More than anything else the movie is about the power of language. As Mario comments to Neruda, ‚ÄúYou gave me books to read, you taught me to use my tongue for more than licking stamps.‚Äù
(Today is Pablo Neruda‚Äôs 50th death anniversary)

07/10/23, 9:54‚ÄØam
Smile made its appearance first in sculptures during the Archaic Period in 6th -7th century BC. The characteristic smile on Greek statues was often referred to as the Archaic smile. It was believed that this kind of smile reflected a state of ideal health and well-being. The goddess Aphrodite, one of the 12 Greek Olympian gods, was called ‚Äúlover of smiles‚Äù.
Closer home, smiling visages started appearing in sculptures, especially that of Buddha during the Gupta period. Bharatha in Natyashashtra described two forms of smile.
ƒ´·π£advikasitair ga·πá·∏çai·∏• ka·π≠ƒÅk·π£ai·∏• sau·π£·π≠havƒÅnvitai·∏•
alak·π£itadvija·πÉ dhƒ´ram uttamƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ smita·πÉ bhavet || 54 |
‚ÄúWith cheeks slightly expanded, with glances of perfect qualities, not showing the teeth, stable, should be the smile (smita) of the highest characters.‚Äù 54
utphullƒÅnananetra·πÉ yad ga·πá·∏çair vikasitair atha
ki·πÉcillak·π£itadanta·πÉ ca hasita·πÉ tad vidhƒ´yate || 55 ||
‚ÄúThat which blooms the mouth and the eyes, expands the cheeks, shows the teeth slightly, is prescribed as smile (hasita).‚Äù 55
I was looking at my library of images to locate a sculpture which depicts ‚Äòsmita‚Äô and this particular one from Khajuraho seemed to represent the description of Bharatha, closely. The smile on the face of this alluring maiden is so well delineated with elongations of the ends of the line of joined lips, slightly swollen cheeks and enlarged nostril base. The almond-shaped eyes are almost on a level with the cheeks and brows, giving an expression of tenderness and bliss.
A smile
Though frozen in time
Still enchants
(Yesterday 6th October was the World Smile Day!)
Dr Raguram
08/10/23, 10:25‚ÄØam
Munshi Premchand (whose death anniversary is today), is often referred to as ‚Äòqalam ka sipahi‚Äô, soldier of the pen. His first collection of five short stories, Soz-e Watan was considered seditious and copies were burnt by the then government. Undeterred by this, he changed his name and continued to write. He wrote more than 300 short stories, plays, translations and14 novels.
Godaan is his magnum opus. It is the story of Hari, a poor farmer and his family‚Äôs struggle for survival and self-respect. Hari does everything he can to fulfil his life‚Äôs desire: to own a cow, as he believes that making the gift of a cow to a Brahman before he dies will help him achieve salvation. Premchand casts his glance beyond Hari to a far wider canvas with many interwoven stories. It is a deeply political novel which essays the lives and plights of the rural poor with much sensitivity. Almost everyone in the village is deep in debt ‚Äì which keeps growing. As one of the farmer laments:
‚ÄúOur parasitic existence has crippled us. (...) Sometimes I think the government would do us a big favour by confiscating our lands and making us work for a living. (...) We've fallen prey to the system, a system that's completely destroying us. Until we're freed from the chains of wealth, the curse will keep hanging over our heads and we'll never reach those heights of manhood which are life's ultimate goal‚Äù.
Even decades later, nothing seems to have changed in farmers‚Äô lives in India.
Godaan was the final work of Premchand. It was also the last book translated by my mother when she was in throes of a ravaging illness. It was a daunting task which she completed with unflinching resolve which is aptly summarized in these words in Godaan:
‚Äú‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§π ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ó ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§õ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó ‡§π‡•à, ‡§≤‡§ó‡§® ‡§π‡•à, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
‚ÄúThose people who write are those who have some pain, affection, dedication and thoughts‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
09/10/23, 6:55‚ÄØpm
Great to know about your mother Sir and the author of Godaan. They are those who are blessed with the skill to pen so wonderfully.
10/10/23, 9:56‚ÄØam
Can being around with birds improve mental health?
New research from King‚Äôs College London has found that seeing or hearing birds is associated with an improvement in mental well-being and this improvement was also evident in people with a diagnosis of depression, indicating the potential role of birdlife in helping those with mental health conditions. It was also noticed that people living in neighbourhoods with more birds are less likely to suffer from depression, anxiety and stress. By contrast, listening to more traffic noise worsened symptoms of depressive states.
Birds connect us to nature and the mere act of watching and listening to their calls can soothe our minds in a stressful world.
Go out and be amidst them. And even if they are hidden in trees or lurking in the underbrush, do revel in their songs. When they take to their wings, let your mind soar along with them‚Ä¶
(On World Mental Health Day!)
Dr Raguram

16/10/23, 10:57‚ÄØpm

19/10/23, 7:47‚ÄØam
Sometime back, I read the book, ‚ÄòTruth and Beauty: Aesthetics and Motivations In Science' by the Nobel laureate Dr S Chandrasekhar. It is a collection of speeches he delivered over 40 years on the questions of how scientists work and what motivates their quest. The most insightful lecture in the volume is the one in which he compares the work of Shakespeare, Beethoven and Newton. I was truly amazed at the depth and vastness of his erudition. CP Snow famously referred the relationship between the culture of sciences and that of the humanities as the ‚ÄòTwo Cultures‚Äô. Chandrasekhar engages both these worlds with seamless elegance.
He comments, ‚ÄúTo me, science is the search for truth, a definitive repetitive pattern in creation...Mozart looked for it in music, Monet saw it in a haystack he painted, Michelangelo found it in stone... Perhaps a scientist seeks it through a mathematical equation. But we can all see only a part of the pattern at a time. It is given only to a few to see the whole."
Writing on the quest of science, he comments, ‚ÄúThe pursuit of science has often been compared to the scaling of mountains, high and not so high. But who among us can hope, even in imagination, to scale Everest and reach its summit when the sky is blue and the air is still, and in the stillness of the air survey the entire Himalayan range in the dazzling white of the snow stretching to infinity? None of us can hope for a comparable vision of nature and of the universe around us. But there is nothing mean or lowly in standing in the valley below and awaiting the sun to rise over Kinchinjunga‚Äù.
Here was a scientist who spoke like a poet.
(On the occasion of the birthday of the Nobel Laureate Dr Chandrasekhar)

22/10/23, 9:41‚ÄØam
The Brahmapuriswara temple is situated in the tiny hamlet of Pullamangai, on the outskirts of Pasupathikoyil in Thanjavur District. Dating back to 10th century, it is an outstanding example of early Chola temple architecture. Though comparatively smaller, it has some of the finest sculptures. Prominent among them is an exquisite depiction of Durga on the north wall of the temple.
Durga is depicted standing on the head of the buffalo. The goddess is tall and slender and stands in a tribhanga pose; tri meaning ‚Äúthree‚Äù and bhanga meaning ‚Äúposture‚Äù. It entails bending the body at three places, namely the knee, the hip and the shoulder. The flowing lines of the sculpture have an entrancing, sinuous quality. Rarely seen outside of Chola temples, is the umbrella (called the Venkotra Kudai) over Her head. On the right, above, is a small stylised lion and on the left a deer held by a bhuta. The presence of the deer is rather unusual. Thirugnanasambandar in Tevaram, Irandam Thirumurai, refers to Durga having a deer as ‚Äòkalaiyathurthi‚Äô.
Two kneeling figures are depicted in the wall on either side of the main niche, cutting parts of their body as a sacrificial gesture. The person on the left is seen holding his hair with his left hand and is attempting to cut off his head with his right hand. The one on the right is about the cut off his leg at the knee. A similar depiction can be found in the Draupathi Ratham at Mahabalipuram.
What struck me was the portrayal of Durga. Here the focus is not on the combat with Mahishasura but her triumphant visage after vanquishing him. There is sheer elegance in the depiction of Durga. Her face is very serene with a tranquil smile on her lips as described in the Devimahatmyam.
‡§à‡§∑‡§• ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞
‡§≠‡•Ä‡§¨‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡•ç
‚ÄúGently smiling, spotless resembling the full moon orb, beautiful as the choicest gold and lovely was thy face.‚Äù
One of the meanings of HER name is fortress. Durga reminds us of the fortress which we each carry within ourselves. As various challenges and chaos engulf us, SHE lends a helping hand to protect and fortify our spiritual wellbeing.

23/10/23, 11:10‚ÄØpm
What a beautiful sculpture Sir. It is absolutely elegant and so slender. But more than that faith matters. I think that is what enhances the beauty. And thanks for the description of the intricate work.
24/10/23, 8:12‚ÄØam
In sculptural depictions of Mahishasuramardini, the asura is portrayed either as a bull or a demon underneath the feet of the Goddess. There is an interesting sculpture in Chennakeshava Temple in Belur, in which the Mahishasura is actually seen emerging from the bull. Devi is pressing the bull with her right leg and one can see that the bull is buckling under the pressure. Mahishasura arises from the bull, with one leg still within it. The Goddess thrusts her weapon on Mahishasura‚Äôs chest, impaling and killing him in the process.
Today is Vijayadasami which is celebrated with much fanfare in Mysuru as the day Devi Chamundeshwari defeated and vanquished Mahishasura. Mysuru is deemed to be a corrupted version of ‚ÄúMysooru‚Äú, which is derived from the word ‚ÄúMahishooru‚Äù. According to the story, Mysuru was ruled by King Mahishasura who was a buffalo-headed monster. In response to the prayer by the Gods and Goddesses to save them from the demon, Goddess Parvathi, took birth as Chamundeshwari and killed the monster on top of the Chamundi hill near Mysuru. Bettada Chamaraja Wadiyar, the Raja of Mysuru rebuilt the fort and made it his headquarters and called the city ‚ÄòMahishura Nagara‚Äò, meaning the city of Mahishur. Many inscriptions done in the 17th century and later refer to Mysuru as ‚ÄòMahishuru‚Äò.
In recent times, Dalits and rationalists in the Mysuru region opine strongly that Mahishasura was not a monster but a Buddhist king, who fought against upper caste oppression and was killed by them. They argue that the demon story was fabricated to tarnish his legacy, claiming that Mahishasura was a historical figure sent by Maurya emperor Ashoka to promote Buddhism in the region. The proponents of this theory also point out that Mysuru derives its name after Mahishooru. Such an alternate narrative is not confined to Mysuru. A tribe named Asura who are living in some parts of Jharkhand claim that they are descendants of Mahishasura and for them, it is not a day of celebration, but a day of mourning.
These conflicting narratives are evidence of India‚Äôs incredible heterogeneity, which incorporates and accommodates differing beliefs within its fold, seamlessly.
Dr Raguram
26/10/23, 8:26‚ÄØam
My first tryst with the butterflies was when I working as a tutor in the Department of Psychiatry at the Bagayam campus of Christian Medical College. I was given accommodation on a road called tantalizingly, the Mango Road and there were scores of butterflies to keep me company. It was always a pleasure to be in their midst after a busy working day.
As years rolled by, birds replaced the butterflies. And that‚Äôs another story‚Ä¶
No matter where we live, butterflies are always around us. Just observing them, we experience the colors and patterns of nature. Watching them opens up a window to appreciate the beauty around us. It is a wonderful sight to see them flitting around in the morning sun. Though I have been fascinated with butterflies, I had not gotten to know and learn about them in detail. I had been following the work of Arun Urs who has been documenting the butterfly species in and around Mysore and dropped him a line to enquire whether we could join him in one of his butterfly walks. He graciously heeded our request and invited us over. We met on a clear, sunny morning on the outskirts of the Lalitha Mahal Palace. We explored the region there, studded with tall trees and mixed vegetation over the next few hours. And what a discovery it was! Arun‚Äôs knowledge about the butterflies and their habitat is truly amazing and we learnt so much about them under his tutelage.
We have done a couple of walks with him thereafter and each one of them has been an eye opener to the butterflies and the rich biodiversity that sustains them. Arun‚Äôs dream is to transform the vast terrain into a vibrant conservation reserve and I earnestly hope that it becomes a reality. Every time I meet up with Arun, I feel inspired by his dedication and untiring involvement with butterfly conservation. He is truly the Butterfly Man of Mysore! I have been urging him to write and publish a book about his passion and work with the butterflies. It would indeed be a major contribution to increase awareness about these delicate, graceful, gossamer winged creatures and they will continue to entrance us even more!

31/10/23, 9:51‚ÄØam
John Keats was born on this day in 1795. During his short life, he published fifty-four poems using a wide range of poetic forms including odes and sonnets. Not happy with his earlier works he collected every piece of paper on which they had been written and burned them. While suffering from tuberculosis, he fell in love with Fanny Browne. Since he could not have any physical contact with her, he wrote her a series of letters. In one of them he wrote poignantly, ‚ÄúIllness is a long lane, but I see you at the end of it.‚Äù Later, in the same letter, he wondered, ‚ÄúIs there another life?
Shall I awake and find all this a dream?‚Äù He never recovered from his illness and died at the young age of 25.
Nature was one of the greatest sources of inspiration for Keats. He gazed with child-like delight at the rising sun, the moving cloud, the growing bud and the birds and turned them into beautiful poetic images. It was not the ‚Äòintellectual beauty‚Äô of Shelley, but one that emerged from the deepest reaches of his soul. As he wrote in the opening lines of Endymion: ‚ÄúA thing of beauty is a joy forever‚Äù.
During all my birding sojourns I seek beauty in the feathered friends as in this diminutive bird, Taiga Flycatcher. It gets its name from the habitat it uses, the Taiga forest, which refers to the coniferous forests of the sub polar region. A forest dwelling winter visitor to the Indian subcontinent, it is one of the most handsome birds I have ever seen. Its beauty is not confined to its visual aspects alone, but transcends it.
As Keats wrote in ‚ÄòOn A Grecian Urn‚Äô:
‚ÄúBeauty is truth, truth beauty,‚Äîthat is all
Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know‚Äù.

01/11/23, 7:28‚ÄØpm
