03/11/23, 9:40‚ÄØam
It was late evening when we visited the cradle of Carnatic music, Thiruvaiyaru, a few months ago. We made our way to the samadhi of Tygaraja on the banks of the river Cauvery. It is a simple, single story building, shorn of any embellishment. Silence enveloped us as we stepped in as there was hardly anyone inside. The walls were inscribed with first two lines of krithis of the master composer. Tyagaraja‚Äôs idol is installed at a place where he attained samadhi. The idol was decorated with a garland of rudraksha and he was seen holding a sheaf of palm leaves in his left hand. The idol was personally designed and installed by a singer Nagarathnamma, often referred to as Bangalore Nagarathnamma, whose birthday is today.
Bangalore Nagarathnamma was an exceptional person. She was born in Nanjangud to a devadasi Puttu Lakshmi. Though she was initiated into the devadasi tradition at the age of five, she was a keen learner and became adept in many languages including Sanskrit. She developed an abiding interest in music and emerged as one of the finest carnatic singers of her time. Impressed by her talents, Maharaja Jayachamarajendra Wodeyar appointed her the Asthana Vidushi. She was probably the first woman to occupy such an exalted position in the royal court! She moved to Madras to consolidate her position as established herself as a popular concert artist. Her rendering of Tygaraja‚Äôs krithis enthralled huge audiences. She was the first female artist to pay income tax in Madras!
Tyagaraja occupied her mind in her waking hours as much as in her dreams. In one such dream, she saw an elderly person asking her to build a structure with her vast wealth. The dream came again after a few days and she described it to her mentor, Bidaram Krishnappa as to what it meant. He told her that the person she saw in her dream was none other than Tyagaraja himself and that she should build a memorial to him at Thiruvaiyaru. Tyagaraja‚Äôs samadhi at that time was desolate and forlorn. The place was filled with wild growth of plants and bushes with snakes crawling and wild animals roaming. Seeing it‚Äôs sad condition, she built a mandapam over the samadhi.
Tygaraja‚Äôs samadhi was also the place where annual music festival, Tyagaraja Aradhana, used to be held every year. Women artists were prohibited to perform in it. Nagarathnamma invited female artists and arranged for them to perform behind the mandapam. It was huge hit. Subsequently women artists started featuring in the annual Aradhana. She bequeathed her vast fortune and property to the Aradhana trust with a clear rider that‚Äù This property shall be allowed for the purpose of conducting the Tyagaraja Aradhana only as long as women artistes are allowed to perform in it.‚Äù When she died in 1952, she was laid to rest next to Tyagaraja. To this day, she remains the only woman to be buried there.
A true feminist, Nagarathnamma shattered glass ceilings wherever she went and contributed much to the inclusion of women and especially devadasis into carnatic music at a time when society was very much Victorian in its morals. She was much ahead of her time and established the first Association for Devadasis in Madras Presidency. As its president, she took several steps towards offering financial and social support to her fellow devadasis.
DV Gundappa wrote a moving tribute to this remarkable woman. When he met her towards the end of her life, she commented ‚ÄúI was Nagarathna (precious jewel on the snake‚Äôs head) by birth, then became bhogarathna (jewel of pleasure) and now I am rogarathna (jewel of disease)‚Äù DVG added that she should also be called ragarathna (jewel of musical ragas) and tyagarathna (jewel of sacrifice).
05/11/23, 9:15‚ÄØam
Metaphors in therapy, as in life, are quite powerful and I often use them in therapy. They create a reflective space for the client and facilitate deeper level of understanding of issues that confront them. For instance, when clients are battling with anger issues (which is not so uncommon these days), I use this metaphor of Thich Hanh Nhat. I reframe it by saying, ‚ÄúImagine yourself relaxing alone in a boat. ‚Ä¶‚Äù

13/11/23, 7:09‚ÄØam
Last week Ahalya and myself were in Bandipur and it was the place where I discovered the pleasures of birding decades ago, thanks to a student during a trip. It has taken hold of me since then. Noticing it, Ahalya presented ‚ÄòThe Book of Indian Birds‚Äô by Salim Ali (whose birthday was on 12th November). It is a prized possession and has always been beside me since then. Ahalya didn‚Äôt forget to inscribe prominently in the first page of the book, ‚ÄúStay close to the feathered ones!‚Äù and I have been diligently following that diktat.
Birds wake us up in the morning with their dulcet serenades. Even in the midst of urban chaos we have to just look up and see them flying their sorties with sheer abandon. Just observing them, we experience colors and patterns of nature. It offers endless opportunities for discovery, all for free. Some kind of connection emerges in those encounters with nature and our inner selves.
For me watching birds is not about lists, BIG days but soaking in the experience and savoring moments of absolute calmness within.

15/11/23, 8:53‚ÄØam
Often people from different walks of life leave their imprint on us. Here was a person whom I had never met, but one who left a lasting impression on me through his commitment towards social justice and human rights. He is the only person who has been hailed as a ‚ÄúBhishma Pitamah‚Äù of the Indian judiciary. Today is the birthday of Krishna Iyer who made the judicial system more humane.
On this day, it is imperative to reflect on two of his perceptive observations on the role of judiciary:
‚Äúthe Gandhian diagnosis of offenders as patients and his conception of prisons as hospitals mental and moral ‚Äì is the key to the pathology of delinquency and therapeutic role of punishment. The whole man is a healthy man, and every man is born good. Criminality is curable deviance. If every saint has a past, every sinner has a future, and it is the role of law to remind both of this.‚Äù
‚ÄúLitigants are legal patients suffering from injustices seeking healing for their wounds. Would you tell a sufferer in the hospital that because he disclosed a certain symptom very late, therefore, he would be discharged without treatment for the sin of delayed disclosure? Humanism, which, at bottom sustains justice, cannot refuse relief unless, by entertaining the plea, another may sustain injury.‚Äù
It was Krishna Iyer‚Äôs abiding belief that the Supreme Court of India should perform as a Supreme Court for the people of India

17/11/23, 9:46‚ÄØam
Li Bai was one of the most prominent poets in Chinese literature, who had an abiding interest Daoism. He wrote more than thousand poems, replete with striking imagery, infused with Daoistic metaphors. The notion of ‚ÄòDao‚Äô, way or path, emphasizes that ideal world is to be found not by following an external route, but by a spiritual path, through state of mind, an attitude. In Daoism, a good life is a life that‚Äôs simple, spontaneous, in harmony with nature, unencumbered by societal regulation and free from the desire to achieve social ascendancy; a life lived in accordance with nature. Daoism doesn‚Äôt completely disregard the existence of the self, instead it acknowledges that the self exists, but it emphasizes that the person has to be ‚Äúselfless‚Äù. Instead of the ‚ÄúI‚Äù it‚Äôs ‚ÄúOthers‚Äù and the person should strive to live in harmony, in a balanced life with others and nature. It is wonderfully enunciated in this quote "The perfect man has no self; the spiritual man has no achievement; the true sage has no name".

20/11/23, 8:52‚ÄØam
One of the most famous opening sentences in literature is from Leo Tolstoy's novel Anna Karenina: "All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way." Tolstoy's own marriage seems to have fallen into the second category. Though he and his wife, Sophia, had 13 children together, they were an unhappy couple in the later part of their lives. Tolstoy contemplated leaving his wife on many occasions and finally on the night of Nov. 10, 1910, he secretly fled, leaving a note to his wife, ‚ÄúI am doing what old men of my age usually do: leaving worldly life to spend the last days of my life in solitude and quiet.‚Äù Taking only a few things, he boarded a train with his personal physician Makovitsky. Taking a circuitous route, involving several train changes, they planned to travel further to Bulgaria. But on the way, Tolstoy caught a cold, which led to pneumonia and he was taken of the train at Astapovo. He declined any medical intervention as he wanted to "submit himself to God‚Äôs will." He passed away in the early morning of 20th November 1910.
Tolstoy‚Äôs final moments are a poignant reminder of what he wrote in The Death of Ivan Illyich; ‚ÄúWhat death? There was no fear, because there was no death. Instead of death there was light. So that‚Äôs it! He suddenly said aloud. ‚ÄúSuch joy!‚Äù

03/12/23, 10:51‚ÄØam
When I was in the medical school, my grand uncle Dr RV Rajam asked me to read the book, ‚ÄôThe Lives of a Cell: Notes of a Biology Watcher‚Äô by Lewis Thomas. It was a collection of essays on varied topics ranging from medicine to music, written in a lively, light hearted, poetic way. It was said that he could write "as naturally as birds build a nest." In his own words, he let them ‚Äúloose . . . to fly around in the dark, bumping into each other, mating in crazy ways‚Äù. The book was full of fascinating nuggets of information. ‚Äúants are very much like humans. They farm fungi, raise aphids, as a livestock, launch armies into wars, use chemical sprays to alarm, and confused enemies, capture slaves‚Äù. He was prescient in his observation about the advent of the Internet in future. ‚ÄúWe are becoming a grid, a circuitry around the earth. If we keep at it, we will become a computer to end all computers, capable of fusing all the thoughts of the world into a syncytium.‚Äù The book opened my eyes to many things, our existence, our environment, social beings, our origin and a variety of interesting topics. ‚ÄòThe Lives of a Cell‚Äô is eleventh on the Modern Library‚Äôs list of the best 100 nonfiction books of the century. I started collecting his subsequent books and each one of them is a gem.
Lewis Thomas was a strong advocate of a scientific approach to understand and decode the mystery of biology and medicine. However, voicing a cautious note, he observed, ‚ÄúScience will...produce the data..., but never the full meaning. For perceiving real significance, we shall need...most of all the brains of poets, also those of artists, musicians, philosophers, historians, writers in general‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
04/12/23, 7:14‚ÄØam
Viktor Frankl‚Äôs ‚ÄòMan in search of meaning‚Äô, has had a profound impact on me. I came across the work of the poet Rainer Maria Rilke (whose birthday is today), for the first time when Frankl quoted from a poem by him, ‚ÄúHow much suffering there is to get through!‚Äù I started reading Rilke‚Äôs poetry and was struck by its lyricism and imagery like in these lines:
‚ÄúShe who reconciles the ill-matched threads
of her life, and weaves them gratefully
into a single cloth‚Ä¶ ‚Äù
We hold disparate threads in our life, some of them infused with pain and sorrow. Our task in life is how we reconcile the threads we‚Äôve been given and turn them into a personally meaningful cloth. A good life doesn‚Äôt come from having ‚Äúgood threads‚Äù. It comes from being an adept weaver, in knowing how to reconcile oneself the ill-matched parts of our life to each other.
And Rainer Maria Rilke observed:
‚ÄúBe patient toward all that is unsolved in your heart and try to love the questions themselves, like locked rooms and like books that are now written in a very foreign tongue. Do not now seek the answers, which cannot be given you because you would not be able to live them. And the point is, to live everything. Live the questions now. Perhaps you will then gradually, without noticing it, live along some distant day into the answer.‚Äù

05/12/23, 9:26‚ÄØam
Milton Erickson (whose birthday today) is an intriguing figure in the history of psychiatry. More so since most of his work was in the field of hypnosis, which was summarily dismissed by Freud. Erickson eschewed theories because he felt that they limit the way in which practitioners view the patient and the problem, ‚ÄúWe always translate the other person‚Äôs language into our own language‚Äù.
Many of Erickson's interventions ran counter to the theoretical postulates of major schools of therapy. He emphasized the need to incorporate the resources and abilities available to the patient, to assist them in problem resolution through a variety of innovative methods, including the use of metaphors and humour. In the 1940s, it was virtually unheard of for a psychiatrist to do family therapy as he often did and his strategic family interventions are still influential today. He was also not favour of extended therapy sessions and laid the foundation for the brief therapy movement.
He firmly believed that life is lived in the present and directed towards the future. He felt that one cannot change an unchangeable past, ‚ÄúIn order to ride a bicycle, you do not need to know physics. So too, individuals can achieve behavioural change without developing insight into the unconscious forces that may have determined the behaviour‚Äù.
His observation that, ‚ÄúEach person is a unique individual. Hence, psychotherapy should be formulated to meet the uniqueness of the individual's needs, rather than tailoring the person to fit the Procrustean bed of a hypothetical theory of human behaviour‚Äù, is a useful reminder in these times when we are immersed in a surfeit of schools of therapies, each one claiming greater effectiveness than the other.
Dr Raguram
06/12/23, 1:01‚ÄØpm
An extremely useful information Sir. It is important to look back at the greats, their practical approach and I have realised over time that patients can't suit our theoretical knowledge. It must have been a very difficult terrain for him to have an unconventional approach.
08/12/23, 11:32‚ÄØam
I was keen to reach the temple at Bodhgaya early, before the crowds start streaming in. When I entered the temple precincts there was hardly anyone except a group of Buddhist monks who were chanting melodiously. The ebb and flow of their chanting with sporadic chirping of birds set the tone for a reflective state of mind. I made my way to the Bodhi tree and sat down. Here was the place where Shakyamuni came after practising a lifestyle of severe asceticism for six years. After enduring many hardships, he realized that that a deeper understanding of life was still eluding him. He sat and meditated under this tree and became the Buddha, ‚Äúan awakened one.‚Äù Bodhi Day which is observed on 8th December marks this moment that took place 2500 years ago. In addition to its spiritual significance, the Bodhi Day reminds us of the importance of peace, compassion, and mindfulness in our everyday lives.
Within each of us is a tiny light, entangled in the fibres of our lives. As Ramana Maharishi observed, ‚ÄúYour own Self-Realization is the greatest service you can render the world.‚Äù
(If you look carefully at the photograph, you can have a glimpse of a covered slab at the foot of the Bodhi tree. It marks the exact position where Buddha sat in meditation. Traditionally, it is referred to as Buddha‚Äôs Vajrasana and is the oldest piece of architecture in Bodh Gaya)
Dr Raguram
09/12/23, 10:40‚ÄØpm

16/12/23, 10:18‚ÄØam
George Santayana (whose birthday is today), was a renowned philosopher, essayist, novelist and poet, known for his profound insights into human nature. He has become very well-known for his aphorisms. His most famous one "Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it" is inscribed on a plaque at the entrance of the Auschwitz concentration camp. I keep wondering whether we have drawn any lesson from it. In a lighter vein, Mark Twain famously commented, ‚ÄúHistory doesn‚Äôt repeat itself, but it does rhyme.‚Äù
Santayana wrote number of iconic poems like this one, titled ‚ÄòDecima‚Äô. A decima is a ten-line stanza of poetry. It is also referred to as decima espinela after the Spanish poet Vicente Espinel who used it extensively in his compositions.
DECIMA
Silent daisies out of reach,
Maidens of the starry grass,
Gazing on me as I pass
With a look too wise for speech,
Teach me resignation,‚Äîteach
Patience to the barren clod,
As, above your happier sod,
Bending to the wind's caress,
You‚Äîunplucked, alas!‚Äîno less
Sweetly manifest the god.

The sculptors are dead and gone but they are alive in their work. Like the sound of the bell resonating through flowers, the chiselling sound seems to be echoing in these sculpturesü§î

04/01/23, 9:24‚ÄØam
It was an incredible experience to usher in the New Year amidst the magical terrain of the Death Valley.
Desert landscapes are stunning to behold‚Ä¶
Their unique coloration creates a vivid visual experience.
Words fail to describe the dreamy environs coming alive at sunrise.

07/01/23, 10:24‚ÄØam
January 5th is celebrated as the National Bird Day in the USA to draw attention to the beauty and importance of birds in the ecosystem.
While birding in the Coyote Hills near San Francisco, I spotted a bird at a distance sallying in the air in a graceful way, much like a butterfly. When it settled down on a branch, I had a close look and it was Say‚Äôs Phoebe.
In Greek mythology, Phoebe was the goddess of the hunt and the moon, the daughter of Gaea and the twin sister of Apollo. I was wondering whether this petite flycatcher is called phoebe owing to its prowess in hunting insects. Instead, I gather that the name derives from the kind of sound it makes! American naturalist Thomas Sa was the first scientist to encounter the bird, at a site near Ca√±on City, Colorado, in 1819 and it was named after him by Charles Bonaparte, a nephew of Napoleon. They have been in the U.S. for a long time. Palaeontologists discovered Say‚Äôs Phoebe fossils in Arizona, California, New Mexico, and Texas dating back to about 400,000 years ago (the late Pleistocene).
08/01/23, 5:52‚ÄØpm
Wowww Sir. What a photograph ü§î you have caught the flycatcher from a fantastic angle. Its features are so vivid and can be feltüëåüèª
19/01/23, 9:58‚ÄØam
The Raven has featured in ancient stories from around the world and in almost every culture. In the book of Genesis, Noah first sent a raven from the ark to determine if the floodwaters had receded. They are perhaps one of the smartest of birds.
Ravens have fascinated people through history. Edgar Allan Poe, whose birthday is today, was no exception and wrote the poem The Raven in 1845. Who can forget these memorable lines‚Ä¶
‚ÄúDeep into that darkness peering, long I stood there wondering, fearing,
Doubting, dreaming dreams no mortals ever dared to dream before;
But the silence was unbroken, and the stillness gave no token,
And the only word there spoken was the whispered word, "Lenore?"
This I whispered, and an echo murmured back the word, "Lenore!" ‚Äî
Merely this, and nothing more‚Äù
This iconic poem launched him from a virtual nobody to an overnight success, but his newfound popularity wasn‚Äôt always easy for the writer. Children were known to follow him through the streets, flapping their arms and croaking like a raven. Poe‚Äôs response? Shouting ‚ÄúNevermore!‚Äù at them until they ran away.
Incidentally Edgar Allan Poe was a birder!
21/01/23, 10:52‚ÄØam
Any poet exists who is not inspired by nature? For people who have been caught up in the maddening crowd, such poems like the above is like a soothing breeze.
22/01/23, 9:36‚ÄØam
Lord Byron (whose birthday is today) expressed a sense of wonder and joy about nature in his poems. Born with a club foot, he was deeply uncomfortable with it and had to wear special boots to hide it. He was also a victim of childhood sexual abuse at the hands of a drunken nursemaid. For him nature was a healer; a refuge and place of shelter.
His love of nature finds expression in Childe Harold‚Äôs Pilgrimage:
‚ÄúI live not in myself, but I become
Portion of that around me; and to me,
High mountains are a feeling‚Ä¶
Are not the mountains, waves, and skies a part
Of me and of my soul, as I of them?
Is not the love of these deep in my heart
With a pure passion‚Äù
His own inner need for solitude finds expression in these perceptive lines‚Ä¶
‚ÄúThere is a pleasure in the pathless woods,
There is a rapture on the lonely shore,
There is society, where none intrudes,
By the deep sea, and music in its roar:‚Äù
22/01/23, 5:24‚ÄØpm
An enchanting photograph with Byron's lines.... It is only blessed few whose deep pain could find its outlet in lines like the above. Fame is so very secondary and immaterial. Thank you Sir for the beautiful photographs and for opening the treasure trove.
25/01/23, 9:07‚ÄØam
Virginia Woolf (whose birthday is today) had an enduring tryst with bipolar illness all through her life. In her fight against her hounding illness which she often referred to as ‚Äòwaves‚Äô, she held onto writing to prevent herself from sinking. In her own words, ‚ÄúOne ought to sink to the bottom of the sea, probably, and live alone with one‚Äôs words.‚Äù It was a prescient observation as years later, unable to cope with the devastating illness, she filled her overcoat with stones and drowned in the river Ouse.
TS Eliot, a close friend, persuaded her to write about her experiences with her ailments and the result was the contemplative essay, ‚ÄòOn Being Ill‚Äô. She wrote it in throes of yet another ravaging bout of illness. This has been reissued in 2012 with contributions from her mother and a friend. It is an insightful narrative about travails of illness and its impact on caregivers.
She voiced her profound loneliness in these evocative words, ‚ÄúWe do not know our own souls, let alone the souls of others. Human beings do not go hand in hand the whole stretch of the way. There is a virgin forest, tangled, pathless, in each; a snowfield where even the print of birds‚Äô feet is unknown. Here we go alone‚Ä¶‚Äù
29/01/23, 9:36‚ÄØam
When I was ambling along the corridors of the Durga temple at Aihole sometime ago, I noticed a sculpture of a serene, elegant, bejewelled person in a pillar. What caught my attention was a figure of a woman with legs of horse on his left. Unfortunately, her face was disfigured. At that time I was not sure of its iconographic importance.
Yesterday on the occasion of Ratha Saptami, when I was reading about the legends associated with Surya, I wondered whether this sculpture represents Surya and his wife.
According to the legends, Vishvakarma‚Äôs daughter, Sanjana was married to Surya. After bearing him three children, she found his brilliance too oppressive and the heat unbearable. Hence she took the form of a shadow, Chhaya to take her place. Chhaya did not disclose her identity to Surya and had two sons and two daughters from him. Later when Surya realized that Chhaya was not Sanjana he was extremely annoyed and banished Chhaya away. He went in search of Sanjana and enquired about her whereabouts with her father Vishvakarma who he told him that she was living in the forest. Surya went in search in the forest and found her in the form of a mare and united with her.
Chhaya who represents darkness was the manifestation of Sanjana who is deemed to be the source of all conscious thought. Ignorance is darkness which is dispelled by the light of awareness. Not surprisingly, the symbol associated with Sanjana is walnut which has a striking similarity with human brain!
There is plenty to ponder in mythology!
31/01/23, 8:26‚ÄØam
Da Ra Bendre‚Äôs (whose birthday is today) works are infused with a sense of divine unity. This is often expressed eloquently in his nature poems. For instance in Ba Bega (Come Soon) he conceives the clouds as a divine presence which can enliven the ‚Äòsleeping seed‚Äô within us‚Ä¶

Located in the beautiful Hudson Valley in Ghent, NY, Art Omi is a vast landscape untouched by landscapers or horticulturalists. Amidst the tranquil outdoor space dotted with wild flowers are large scale sculptures. Some works are so well camouflaged in the wooded trails that it is easy to miss them, while others reach out through the trees. When I ventured into a forest path, I chanced upon this wooden sculpture of a man in silent repose, silhouetted against the sky. As I spent a few minutes soaking up the experience, these words of the philosopher Martin Buber (whose birthday is today) resonated within me: "Solitude is the place of purification".
Solitude often unravels the richness within the self‚Ä¶

13/02/23, 10:16‚ÄØam
Sarojini Naidu, (whose birthday is today) was an exceptionally talented person right from young age. She was actively involved in the freedom struggle and yet found time to pen some exquisite poems. In particular, I am fascinated by the nature poems of the Nightingale of India, which are replete with entrancing, vibrant, imagery. In her poem the Autumn Song, she draws attention to the beauty and frailty of fall with a touch of poignancy. The first two lines are exquisitely eloquent‚Ä¶
Like a joy on the heart of a sorrow,
The sunset hangs on a cloud;
A golden storm of glittering sheaves,
Of fair and frail and fluttering leaves,
The wild wind blows in a cloud.
Hark to a voice that is calling
To my heart in the voice of the wind:
My heart is weary and sad and alone,
For its dreams like the fluttering leaves have gone,
And why should I stay behind?

14/02/23, 9:43‚ÄØam
Sanskrit literature is replete with beautiful verses celebrating love. Most notable among them is Chaurapanchasika , a compilation fifty short lyric poems written in the eleventh century A. D. by the poet Bilhana.
There are many versions about the origin of this work. One of them states that a king with a lovely daughter engages the famous poet Bilhana to educate his daughter. To prevent any romance blossoming between the two, he tells the princess that her guru is visually challenged and tells the guru that his student has deformities in her face. To ensure that they don‚Äôt see each other, he hangs a curtain between the two. One day while lessons were in progress, the poet is thrilled by the full moon on a cloudless sky. He breaks into a poem, and princess wonders how a blind man can sing about the moon with such brilliance. Excited, she pulls down the curtain and finds that Bilhana is a handsome young man while he finds he finds her to be a personification of female beauty. The two instantly fall in love and decide to marry, but the enraged king sentences them to death. As Bilhana is being led to his execution, he starts singing the fifty verses. Deeply moved by it, the king orders his release and formally gives his daughter in marriage.
Interestingly, in 1948, two producers made movies in Tamil based on this story of Bilhana. Unfortunately, the third version with the legendary MK Thyagaraja Bhagavathar as Bilhana was never completed as the actor was arrested.
Among many translations of this remarkable work, I find the one by Sir Edwin Arnold quite interesting. One of the verses reads:
Still when her eyes, as lotus petals long,
Like Fortune‚Äôs goddess lotus-born, I see,
And see her wearied by her bosom's load,
With both my arms clasping her close to me
As honey bee his darling lotus sips,
I would grow drunk on mead within her Iips.
These lines find a picturesque expression in this beautiful sculpture from Khajuraho.
16/02/23, 10:33‚ÄØpm
Glowing heart‚ù§Ô∏è Yes from within. Glittering photograph Sirüëå
18/02/23, 8:35‚ÄØam
According to one of the legends, Lord Shiva and Devi Parvathi tied the nuptial knot on Mahashivaratri. Their union has a deeper connotation: Purusha (mindfulness) is represented by Shiva, while Prakriti (nature) is epitomized by Parvathi.
This classic Shiva Parvathi sculpture is from Hoysaleshwara temple in Halebeedu. It depicts Parvathi seated on Shiva‚Äôs lap which is referred to as atikarohana. They are bedecked with intricately carved jewellery and carry different weapons and ornaments in their arms. The details are so mesmerizing, providing a three dimensional perspective. What is interesting to note is the presence of mongoose, a vahana of Parvathi at her feet.
Composed by Adi Shankaracharya, Shiva Parvathi stotram holds a special importance amongst all Shiva Stotras. It extols the divine qualities of the god and goddess in 12 stanzas. On this Mahashivaratri day let us recall a verse from this:
‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç,
‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç,
‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç
Namah Shivabhyam pashupalakabhyam
Jagattrayee rakshana baddha hrudbhyam
Samastha Devaasura pujitabhyam
Namo namah Shankara Parvatibhyam
I bow to God Shiva and Goddess Parvathi, the protectors of all beings
Who are the divine guardians of all the three worlds
The divine pair worshipped by all the Devas and Asuras
I bow to you, again and again, God Shiva and Goddess Parvathi
21/02/23, 10:23‚ÄØam
In all my forays into the library during my training days at NIMHANS, I was drawn into one particular journal, simply titled as Psychiatry. Tucked between its plain yellow covers were articles that opened up my perspective into the interpersonal context of psychological suffering. One of the founders of the journal was Harry Stack Sullivan, whose birthday is today. Sullivan through his framework of interpersonal psychotherapy articulated that one‚Äôs personality and behavior has to be viewed and examined on the background of close, intimate, relationships. He felt that descriptive psychiatry failed to look beyond diagnosis and view the whole person in his/her social context. He extended this orientation to understand what was often viewed as an incomprehensible disease process, schizophrenia. This laid the foundation of the Chestnut Lodge which pioneered intensive, individualized treatment of schizophrenia. Chestnut Lodge was also the locale of the book ‚ÄúI never promised you a rose garden‚Äô.
Enforced isolation during the Covid era, drew our attention to the unsettling fact that loneliness can be a severely distressing state. Yet it has eluded the attention of mental health professionals. Sullivan was among the very few who attempted to examine it. He regarded loneliness as one of the most intense and painful of human experiences and described people with schizophrenia as, ‚Äúthe loneliest of the lonely‚Äù.
Personally, the work of Sullivan widened my gaze beyond the veil of symptoms onto the real person shrouded behind them.
23/02/23, 9:43‚ÄØam
When I joined NIMHANS, my teacher Dr RL Kapur told me to read Karl Jasper‚Äôs ‚ÄòGeneral Psychopathology‚Äô. I went over to the library to look for it. In those days, books in the library were all locked up securely in steel cupboards and the keys were with a strict looking female attender. When I requested her to look for it, she went straight to the pathology section and announced in a loud voice that there is no such book. I persuaded her to look for it in the psychiatry section and to my great relief it was there in a bottom shelf. It was the first edition, translated into English by Hoenig, who had spent a year at the All India Institute of Mental Health in 1955. It was a difficult book to read, but I gamely gave it a try over several weeks and re-read it during my training days. Later, I personally wanted to possess a copy of ‚ÄòGeneral Psychopathology‚Äô and finally got one in an old book shop. It has a pride of place in my collection. I was going through it today on Jasper‚Äôs birthday and was struck by its continuing relevance in the current climate of psychiatric practice.
The main emphasis of Jasper was on a phenomenological approach to psychiatric illnesses. It is essentially a form of qualitative enquiry that emphasized experiential, lived aspects of a particular phenomenon as described by the person. In Jasper‚Äôs own words ‚ÄúSince we never can perceive the psychic experiences of other in any direct fashion, as with physical phenomena, we can only make some kind of a representation of them. There has to be an act of empathy, of understanding ...which comes from the patient‚Äôs own self-descriptions, which can be evoked and tested out in the course of personal conversations.‚Äù In a Jaspersian sense, psychiatric diagnosis is not a ‚Äúsimple question-and-answer interrogation‚Äù but a ‚Äúparticular observation‚Äù in the context of an empathic interaction.
Unfortunately, with the advent of the Neo Kraeplinian frameworks of diagnosis, the emphasis has shifted to ‚Äòeliciting‚Äô symptoms which are then straight jacketed to fit into diagnostic criteria. This has led to a robotic checklist approach shorn of insights about the experiential terrain of symptoms. The person who ultimately knows his/her experiences is the patient himself/herself. The psychiatrist‚Äôs role is to facilitate expression of this experience through a compassionate, empathic stance tinged with an attitude of curiosity.
03/03/23, 7:41‚ÄØam
On this World Wildlife Day, let us yield ourselves to the allure of the myriad winsome forms of wildlife and rededicate ourselves to their conservation.
Nature beckons and we must listen...
06/03/23, 8:02‚ÄØam
During our training period at NIMHANS, after receiving our monthly pay, Ahalya and myself will invariably make our way to Premier Book Shop to stock up on books. During one such visit, Shanbhag guided us through the shelves overflowing with books, picked up one and said, ‚ÄúDoctor, you must read this!‚Äù
It was Gabrial Garcia Marquez‚Äôs ‚ÄòOne Hundred Years Of Solitude‚Äô.
When I started reading the novel, it was much akin to sojourns in dreamscapes. To borrow a phrase from Beatles, it was a Magical Mystery Tour! Every page was suffused with intricate details, intersecting history, mythology and tradition. The lives and tribulations of the Buendia family came alive in the author‚Äôs mesmerizing narrative.
In a memorable passage after the death of Jose Arcadio Buendia, Gabo‚Äôs writes, ‚ÄúWhen the carpenter was taking measurements for the coffin, through the window they saw a light rain of tiny yellow flowers falling. So many flowers fell from the sky that in the morning the streets were carpeted with a compact cushion and they had to clear them away with shovels and rakes so that the funeral procession could pass by.‚Äù
Yellow butterflies were one of his often used literary imagery and he used to comment that nothing awful would happen to him if there are yellow flowers around.
During his memorial service thousands of yellow butterflies made of paper were released to celebrate the life of this remarkable author.
Today is Gabo‚Äôs 96th birthday‚Ä¶
07/03/23, 8:12‚ÄØam
It was an unusually sultry morning and there was a long queue in front of St Peter‚Äôs Basilica in the Vatican City. Undeterred, I waited patiently behind a group of tourists from America who were chatting animatedly. As soon as I entered its hallowed precincts, I made my way straight to have a glimpse of Michelangelo‚Äôs Pieta. During his lifetime Michelangelo made three Pietas, of Virgin Mary mourning the dead body of Christ and this is the most beautiful of them all. Though Mary embracing her dead son is not explicitly mentioned in the holy book, the scene has proven to be a popular subject among artists for centuries.
Safely ensconced behind bullet proof glass, Virgin Mary was in a seated position, wrapped in robes and cradling the lifeless body of Jesus. His head was slumped back on her shoulder. When I looked at it closely, I felt that the sculpture was shaped like a pyramid, with the top of the head of Virgin Mary being its peak and the sculpture expanding to accommodate her seated legs. Her petite face with gentle demeanour exuded serene tranquillity. Michelangelo‚Äôs painstaking attention to detail and the unique treatment of the hair, the skin and the intricate folds in the fabric is a lasting testimony to his outstanding artistry.
Pieta was the only sculpture where Michelangelo inscribed his name. Unfortunately, with the crowd milling around, I couldn‚Äôt have a close look to locate it.
Michelangelo was a multi-talented individual who also wrote sonnets on variety of subjects. He produced hundreds of madrigals and sonnets, often putting down his chisel while at work to write down a line or two of verse.
These beautiful lines are from the sonnet titled The Model and the Statue:
When that which is divine in us doth try
To shape a face, both brain and hand unite
To give, from a mere model frail and slight
Life to the stone by Art‚Äôs free energy.
(Yesterday, 6th March was the birthday of this remarkable artist/poet)
08/03/23, 9:16‚ÄØam
International Women‚Äôs Day is observed to recognize and honor the achievements of women. On this day let us recall the life and works of a remarkable woman, Elizabeth Barrett Browning. Educated at home, she wrote an epic poem at the age of twelve. Her first major work was ‚ÄòAn Essay On Mind and Other Poems‚Äô which was published when she was twenty years old. These lines from it, offer a tantalizing glimpse of her talent:
So when the pilgrim sun is traveling o‚Äôer
The last blue hill, to gild a distant shore
He leaves a freshness in the evening scene
That tells the Creation where his steps have been
Unfortunately, much like Frida Kahlo she was beset with various ailments all through her life including a spinal fracture. This was not a dampener in her creative journey and she continued to immerse herself at work, producing some extraordinary verses.
Elizabeth was not just a talented poet, she was deeply involved in addressing many forms of social injustice, such as the slave trade in America, child labour in the mines and the mills of England and the restrictions forced upon women in 19th-century society. Standards of sexual conduct were so rigid at that period in time that any woman who bore a child out of wedlock, even if she had been a victim of male aggression, was shunned and scorned by the society. She urged that society should be more compassionate in its treatment of women who had been victims of sexual violence. Moved by the plight of children working in mines she wrote a long poem, ‚ÄòThe Cry of The Children‚Äô, with these poignant opening lines:
Do ye hear the children weeping, O my brothers,
Ere the sorrow comes with years ?
They are leaning their young heads against their mothers,
And that cannot stop their tears.
Elizabeth Barrett Browning was an extraordinary poet but she was also more than that. Hers was a voice for the oppressed and she had the courage to profess her views that went against the grains of society.
The theme of this year‚Äôs International Women‚Äôs Day is ‚ÄòEmbrace Equity‚Äô. Elizabeth Barrett Browning personified this all through her life and in her works.
08/03/23, 1:17‚ÄØpm
Oh thank you Sir for shedding light on someone whom we don't talk aboutüëç
15/03/23, 7:01‚ÄØam
From the moment we are born, we begin our journey towards death. Understandably this prospect often evokes intense fear. It is suggested that one can negotiate this fear in three ways: through knowledge as epitomized by Nachiketa, by adopting a path of bhakti like Markandeya and by sheer power of love as symbolized by Savitri.
During Karadaiyan Nombu which is observed today, women offer prayers for the longevity and wellbeing of their husbands and celebrate great encounter of Savitri and Yama, the God of Death.
Savitri was the daughter of the King of Madradesha. She was exceedingly beautiful and when she reached marriageable age, though many princes admired her, none of them came forward to marry her, overawed by her beauty. Her father told her to go forth and select her own husband. Savitri visited many kingdoms but could not find the husband of her choice. On her way back home, she saw a young man in a forest serving an old couple with utter devotion. She was immediately drawn to him and informed her choice to her father. When Narada heard about it, he informed her that the young man she had chosen, Sathyavan, had a very short life and would die after a year. Savitri‚Äôs parents were shattered on hearing this and requested her to reconsider her choice. A determined Savitri married Sathyavan and went to the forest and assumed her new role with great joy. But deep within, she was afraid and could not forget Narada‚Äôs prophecy. As the day of death drew near, she began to fast and offer prayers with utmost piety. Finally, on the dreaded day, she decided to accompany her husband when he went into the forest as she did not want to be separated from him even for a short while. Yama made his appearance and starting pulling Sathyavan with his noose. To his astonishment he saw Savitri following him and asked her to return back. But Savitri said that it was her dharma to accompany her husband everywhere and she could not give it up. Pleased with her words he granted her many boons with which she restored the kingdom and eyesight of her father in law. But she still continued to follow him. Finally, impressed by her intense devotion, Yama restored the life of her husband and blessed them.
Interestingly festivals are associated with particular type of food. Karadaiyan Nombu is no exception. On this day, a special dish ‚ÄòKaradai‚Äô is prepared from rice flour, black eyed peas, jaggery and coconut and it is believed that Savitri prepared this special dish and offered it with butter to Lord Yama as a thanksgiving gesture for returning the life of Satyvan.
There are few representations of Yama in sculptural form. This image is from Khajuraho and depicts a four armed Yama. His vehicle, buffalo can be seen on the lower right hand corner. If one looks carefully, one can notice a cock in his right hand. There is an interesting story behind it. One day Yama attempted to kick his mother in a fit of rage. Incensed by this, Sanjana, his mother cursed that he would have a perennial wound infested with maggots which would never heal. Heeding to his request, Surya granted him a cock which ate all the vermin in his leg. And hence the cock in his hand!
20/03/23, 9:23‚ÄØam
White-crowned Sparrows are quite fascinating. They are extremely alert and they stay awake for up to two weeks during their migration. A migrating White-crowned Sparrow was once tracked moving 300 miles in a single night! It is a delightful sight to see them scuttling across the ground with their chirpy notes.
What do sparrows represent? They were associated with liberation in ancient Egypt. It was believed that they would catch the souls of the recently deceased and carry them to heaven. This was the inspiration for a while for sailors to get sparrow tattoos in the hope that the bird would catch their souls if they died at sea.
Sparrows often have a spiritual connotation. Mahakavi Bharathiyar wrote a couple of poems on this dainty bird. Here, he urges us to let go of the chains of bondages that hold us back and liberate ourselves from the fetters that bind us‚Ä¶like the sparrow
‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ±‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æö‡Øç
‡Æö‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Øá
May you escape from all shackles
And revel in freedom
Like this Sprightly Sparrow
(On the occasion of the World Sparrow Day)
20/03/23, 1:46‚ÄØpm
Heart warming photograph Sir and good to hear the belief about their soul catching tooüôÇSad we can only see sparrows in the photographs.
21/03/23, 6:41‚ÄØam
‚ÄòPoetry is painting that speaks,‚Äô Plutarch observed.
Throughout history, poets have painted their canvas with lyrical and idyllic verses.
The landscape of poetry in India is vibrant and multihued and there is a treasure trove waiting to be unearthed across languages.
On this World Poetry Day, let me share a poem by Malathi Maithri which has been translated from Tamil by Lakshmi Holmstrom.
OBSERVE THE CRANE
The crane waits
at the verge of the river-bed,
fish swimming in its memory.
In search of its reflection, the moon
wanders, vanishes.
Swirls of roots tear into the earth,
with hunger.
The wind, sweeping up its troubles,
hurls the heat in all directions.
Pulverized, the heart swirls
like dust in a storm.
It is not just the earth
that overflows through its cracks
in heat and rage.
The crane
absorbs into itself all that heat
and boils within.
If only the crane would sink into
the water swirling in its memory
and beat its wings,
the river might gather its form once more
from the scattered drops,
and walk again.
River, watch.
23/03/23, 6:23‚ÄØam
The World Poetry Day yesterday was also the birthday of a poet whom I admire deeply, Billy Collins.
He was the Poet Laureate of US and was instrumental in setting up a very interesting program, ‚ÄòPoetry 180‚Äô for high schools. He chose 180 poems for the program which are available online and are worth a look: https://www.loc.gov/programs/poetry-and-literature/poet-laureate/poet-laureate-projects/poetry-180/all-poems/
John Constable who described himself as, ‚ÄúI am man of the clouds‚Äù assiduously captured nature‚Äôs most ephemeral occurrence, clouds, in over fifty paintings. These are some of the most magnificent images of clouds ever painted. In this poem, Student of Clouds, Billy Collins reflects on Constable‚Äôs cloud paintings and populates the canvas with his beautiful words.
The emotion is to be found in the clouds,
not in the green solids of the sloping hills
or even in the gray signatures of rivers,
according to Constable, who was a student of clouds
and filled shelves of sketchbooks with their motion,
their lofty gesturing and sudden implication of weather.
Outdoors, he must have looked up thousands of times,
his pencil trying to keep pace with their high voyaging
and the silent commotion of their eddying and flow.
Clouds would move beyond the outlines he would draw
as they moved within themselves, tumbling into their centers
and swirling off at the burning edges in vapors
to dissipate into the universal blue of the sky.
In photographs we can stop all this movement now
long enough to tag them with their Latin names.
Cirrus, nimbus, stratocumulus
dizzying, romantic, authoritarian
they bear their titles over the schoolhouses below
where their shapes and meanings are memorized.
High on the soft blue canvases of Constable
they are stuck in pigment but his clouds appear
to be moving still in the wind of his brush
inching out of England and the nineteenth century
and sailing over these meadows where I am walking,
bareheaded beneath this cupola of motion,
my thoughts arranged like paint on a high blue ceiling.
24/03/23, 9:48‚ÄØpm
Sir I thought I share this with you. The poet has beautifully explained by using nature to be mindful and compassionate.
31/03/23, 6:33‚ÄØam
Vincent van Gogh whose birthday was yesterday, was admitted into the asylum at Saint-R√©my-de-Provence which was once a monastery. It originally held many patients, but by the time he was admitted, the male wing was almost empty and he was also given an extra room to use as a studio. This is the painting of the studio by van Gogh where he produced over 140 of his works, including the iconic "Starry Night". He also painted the view from his window, including the rolling hills 21 times but none of them show the bars on the window of his room! In a letter to his brother Theo, he wrote, "Through the iron-barred window I can make out a square of wheat in an enclosure, above which in the morning I see the sunrise in its glory."
07/04/23, 7:58‚ÄØam
It was late afternoon and as we were cruising through the Death Valley, a congregation of dark clouds rolled in over the blue sky. The sun peeped through the grey clouds caressing the mountains with swirls of golden hues. It was as if the rays were destined to create a great work of art on nature‚Äôs easel which poets often excel in expressing in words. I was reminded of Wordsworth‚Äôs poem, ‚ÄúComposed Upon An Evening of Extraordinary Splendor and Beauty‚Äù. He describes the magical sight of the glowing evening:
No sound is uttered,--but a deep
And solemn harmony pervades
The hollow vale from steep to steep,
And penetrates the glades.
Far-distant images draw nigh,
Called forth by wondrous potency
Of beamy radiance, that imbues,
Whate'er it strikes, with gem-like hues!
In the preface to his 1800 collection of poems, ‚ÄúLyrical Ballads,‚Äù he argued that men and women who live in close association with the natural environment are uniquely in tune with ‚Äúthe essential passions of the heart‚Äù because their very humanity is ‚Äúincorporated with the beautiful and permanent forms of nature.‚Äù He also lamented that this relationship has frayed over time and wrote in ‚ÄúThe World Is Too Much With Us,‚Äù
The world is too much with us; late and soon,
Getting and spending, we lay waste our powers;‚Äî
Little we see in Nature that is ours;
We have given our hearts away..
Lines to ponder on Wordsworth‚Äôs 253rd birthday today!
07/04/23, 1:49‚ÄØpm
Death Valley, what a name. But the way the colour is spread, very unusual effect. And so true that we are so far away from 'nature'. Ancient times even king's used to renounce everything and go into vanaprathashram so near to nature to understand themselves in that serene atmosphere!
08/04/23, 10:16‚ÄØam
The Wind in the Willows by Kenneth Grahame (whose birthday is today), is an enchanting narrative woven around the adventures of four woodland animals, the Mole, the Water Rat, the Badger and an often mischievous Mr Toad. Though each of them is different from the other, the bond between them becomes stronger over time. It is an inventive, imaginative tale which can be read and interpreted at many levels. There is also a hidden subtext which conveys a moral or two, like the importance of fidelity, fortitude, being honest and the power of friendship.
Beyond the idyllic tone of the book, there is a poignant tale. The Wind in the Willows evolved from the bedtime stories that Graham narrated to his son, Alastair. Alastair was born premature and was partially blind. Since he was small and squinty, he was nicknamed ‚ÄúMouse‚Äù and had to endure ridicule and bullying all through his life which unfortunately did not end happily. One day at Oxford, where he was studying, he downed a glass of port and took a late night stroll. The next morning, his decapitated body was found on the railways tracks near the university. An inquest determined his death to be suicide but out of respect for his father, it was recorded as an accident. Grahame never recovered from the loss of his only child and became increasingly reclusive, eventually abandoning writing altogether.
The descriptions of nature in the book are truly wonderful. The narration is imbued with a love of nature with lyrical passages, like this one:
‚ÄúWhen tired at last, he sat on the bank, while the river still chattered on to him, a babbling procession of the best stories in the world, sent from the heart of the earth to be told at last to the insatiable sea.‚Äù
Incidentally, Chapter 7, ‚ÄúThe Piper at the Gates of Dawn‚Äù, is also the name of Pink Floyd‚Äôs first album in 1967.
09/04/23, 8:09‚ÄØam
Easter commemorating the resurrection of Christ, was the earliest feast day decided upon by the ancient Christian church. One of the most beautiful depictions of Easter is by Raphael which he painted when he was just in his teens.
In this painting one can see Christ in the centre, hovering in the air above the tomb. Four guards are on either side with raised hands pointing out to him. In the left hand corner are Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and Salome who are on the way to anoint Christ. Two angels flank Christ on either side with their hands raised in blessing. Interestingly there are two symbolic representations in the painting; snake referring to the Satan and white crane indicating its strength and endurance during migration.
George Herbert, one of the great devotional poets in English, wrote couple of poems on Easter. In one of them, Easter Wings, he wrote:
O let me rise
As larks, harmoniously,
And sing this day thy victories:
Then shall the fall further the flight in me.
The poet suggests that those who stay close to God through religious devotion can ‚Äúfly" above, or find redemption from, their suffering.
Interestingly, he arranged these lines in print to resemble the shape of bird‚Äôs wings
09/04/23, 8:27‚ÄØam
A photograph or painting, simply enchanting. And what a tragedy. Sorrow deep within flows in the canvas of nature. And those lines.....
10/04/23, 7:25‚ÄØam
Madness has engaged the attention of writers and thinkers for long and Kahlil Gibran (whose death anniversary is today) was no exception. ‚ÄúThe Madman‚Äù was his first published work in English. It is an innovative collection of over 30 parables and poems exploring what occurs once we strip away our masks to look within and bare ourselves to God. Gibran describes this state as one of both freedom and vulnerability. In his words, ‚ÄúI have found both freedom and safety in my madness; the freedom of loneliness and the safety from being understood, for those who understand us enslave something in us.‚Äù
Khalil Gibran continued this path of enquiry in his best remembered publication ‚ÄòThe Prophet‚Äô. In this book, he reflects on subjects as varied as love, death, self-knowledge, joy and sorrow, reason and passion, in simple yet philosophical language. It has been translated into forty languages and has sold a million copies worldwide. ‚ÄúThe Madman‚Äù continues to be read and cherished for its timeless understanding of our shared humanity.
Gibran, in his writings, has touched upon almost all the important areas of human life in relation to God, nature, and others, in an elegant, inspiring style.
Ultimately, Gibran‚Äôs poems urge the reader to contemplate and reflect on the profound truths of human existence.
The imagery in these lines from his poem, ‚ÄòOut Of My Deeper Heart,‚Äô is particularly stunning:
Out of my deeper heart a bird rose and flew skyward.
Higher and higher did it rise,
yet larger and larger did it grow.
At first it was but like a swallow,
then a lark,
then an eagle,
then as vast as a spring cloud,
and then it filled the starry heavens.
Out of my heart a bird flew skyward.
And it waxed larger as it flew.
Yet it left not my heart.
12/04/23, 7:38‚ÄØam
Driving along the Big Sur where the winding road hugs the edge of cliffs that drop into an indigo blue ocean, is an incredible experience. One of the most amazing views is from the spectacular Bixby bridge, which soars above the cavernous Bixby creek. Down below, a rustic cabin in the Bixby canyon was the setting of an unusual book, Big Sur, by Jack Kerouac (whose birthday is today.) It is a biographical novel Kerouac wrote after the publication of ‚ÄòOn the Road‚Äô, when he was battling alcoholism and extreme depression. There are many lyrical passages like this in the book:
‚ÄúBut I remember seeing a mess of leaves suddenly go skittering in the wind and into the creek, then floating rapidly down the creek towards the sea, making me feel a nameless horror even then of 'Oh my God, we're all being swept away to sea no matter what we know or say or do‚Äù
Jack Kerouac along with his friends William Burroughs and Allen Ginsberg were considered to be part of the ‚ÄòBeat Generation‚Äô. Though the slang meaning of ‚Äòbeat‚Äô is one of being ‚Äòtired‚Äô, Kerouac gave a totally new interpretation and said that it is actually derived from the word ‚Äòbeatitude‚Äô, meaning ‚Äòblessedness‚Äô, something Kerouac searched for in vain all through his troubled life: ‚ÄúMaybe that's what life is... a wink of the eye and winking stars.‚Äù

15/04/23, 7:07‚ÄØam
A few years ago I got a book, the biography of Leonardo da Vinci by Walter Isaacson, as a gift. It is a magisterial account of the hugely talented, multitasker whose creative energy spanned many diverse domains. Leonardo (whose birthday is today), was a relentlessly curious observer of everything that was happening around him. In his words, there are three different kinds of people, ‚ÄúThose who see by themselves, those who see when someone has shown them and those who do not see.‚Äù His inquisitive mind wanted to know what causes people to yawn, how they walk on ice, what makes the aortic valves close and how light is processed in the eye. He even came up with the first description of arteriosclerosis as an outcome of the ageing process through dissecting the body of a hundred-year-old man. He made it a habit to record all his observations in thousands of notebook pages, known as codices.
There are two things that are distinctive in birds; their ability to fly and their song. As a birder, I am amazed at Leonardo‚Äôs keen observations of the flight of birds, which he recorded in detail in the Codex on the Flight of Birds. He made detailed drawings of birds as they soared, turned and manoeuvred in the wind. He wrote, "When a bird with a wide wingspan and short tail wants to take off, it will lift its wings with force and turn them to receive the wind beneath them." He was the first to document flight manoeuvres now called dynamic soaring. Birds use these manoeuvres to extract energy from the gradient of wind velocity for sustained flight. Leonardo described both horizontal and upward dynamic soaring as well as upward soaring in updrafts through detailed sketches. His description pre-dates by almost 400 years the first generally accepted explanation of the soaring technique by Lord Rayleigh in 1883.
No other figure in history was as creative in so many diverse fields as Leonardo. As Isaacson commented, ‚ÄúHis genius was of the type we can understand, even take lessons from. It was based on skills we can aspire to improve in ourselves, such as curiosity and intense observation. He had an imagination so excitable that it flirted with the edges of fantasy, which is also something we can try to preserve in ourselves and indulge in our children.‚Äù
Leonardo was a lifelong learner. In his words, ‚ÄúThe noblest pleasure is the joy of understanding.‚Äù
16/04/23, 8:42‚ÄØam
I had posted about Leonardo da Vinci on his birthday, yesterday. The day is also celebrated as World Art Day to draw attention to the contribution of artists and to recognize profound importance of arts in enriching our lives. Art encompasses painting, sculpture, dance, theatre and film among others.
Whenever I visit a temple in India, I am astounded by the sheer ingenuity and skill of artists who embellish its precincts but remain largely unknown.
For example, this suavely sculpted figure brimming with exuberance is from the Chennakeshava temple at Belur, Karnataka. Replete with intricate and opulent ornamentation, it portrays a beautiful, dextrously balanced, dancing woman. There is an interesting element in this aestheticized, graceful sculpture. When a drop of water is made to fall from the tip of her right hand above the head, it would pass through her nose, her left breast, the tip of her left hand and finally reach the toe of her left leg! It is truly an epitome of perfection.
As I kept looking at the sculpture, I was fascinated with the inventiveness and imaginative creativity of the artist who chiselled a block of stone and brought it alive.
Ephemeral beauty
Emanates from stone
And melts into a sculpture
17/04/23, 8:22‚ÄØam
Years ago, our friend Dr Stuart Schwartz, gave us a book, ‚ÄòI Am That‚Äô by Nisargadatta Maharaj and mentioned as to how deeply it influenced his spiritual quest. It is not a book in the conventional format and is an account of Maharaj‚Äôs dialogues with seekers. The book is arranged in a question and answer format and covers many topics such as god, the ego, living in the world, free will. I have been dipping into this interesting book on and off, over the years. Often I start with chapter ‚ÄòAwareness is Free‚Äô and then onto chapters which focus on his spiritual experiences. He speaks consistently on the direct experience of "I am".
In the sixth chapter of the ‚ÄúChandogya Upanishad,‚Äù the 24-year old Shvetaketu returns home, 12 years after his father has sent him to study the vedas. The first question that Svetaketu‚Äôs father Uddalaka Aruni asks his son is whether he has returned with the knowledge of that by which ‚Äúwe perceive what cannot be perceived, we know what cannot be known.‚Äù Svetaketu answers in the negative, asking his father what that actually is. His father explains, using the famous Advaita precept: ‚Äòtat tvam asi‚Äô. Maharaj delves on this and expands this concept through dialogue with the seekers. There is so much similarity between his teachings and that of Ramana Maharishi.
The book is studded with poetic descriptions. On Nisargatta Maharaj‚Äôs birthday today, let me recall some of his observations:
"My teacher told me to hold onto the sense ‚ÄòI am‚Äô tenaciously and not to swerve from it even for a moment. I did my best to follow his advice and in a comparatively short time I realized within myself the truth of his teaching. In the stillness of the mind I saw myself as I am un- bound."
‚ÄúGive up all questions except one, "Who am I?" After all the only fact you are sure of is that you "are". The "I am" is certain, the "I am this" is not. Struggle to find out what you are in reality.‚Äù
Among many of his comments, one that deeply resonates within me is in this attached photograph of mine!
18/04/23, 9:17‚ÄØam
April 18 is celebrated as World Heritage Day, also known as the International Day for Monuments and Sites. It is dedicated to highlighting the importance of cultural heritage and raising awareness about the need to preserve historical sites and monuments.
On this day, let me draw attention to Vaikuntha Perumal Kovil, one of the most unique temples which is visited by very few, in Kanchipuram. When we stepped into its precincts on a cold morning, we found the whole temple shorn of any visitor, which gave us ample opportunity to savour its architectural legacy at leisure. The priest in the main sanctum informed us that the main temple consists of three floors, each one with Vishnu murtis in different poses; sitting, sleeping, and standing. Unfortunately, it is difficult to access the top two floors. The priest also mentioned that there was a secret underground tunnel from this temple all the way to Mahabalipuram!
A distinctive aspect of the temple is the pillared corridor surrounding the sanctum. The walls of corridors are embellished with stories, carved into them. Many of the panels have eroded with time and it can be difficult to identify them. Thankfully, before visiting the place, I had downloaded a scholarly and informative monograph about it, authored by Dr Minakshi in 1936. Interestingly, many of the bas reliefs trace the life and history of Nandivarman II, who built the temple. There are vivid depictions of battle scenes with elephants and soldiers, much like scenes of warfare depicted on the outer walls of the Bayon temple, which was built five centuries later in Siem Reap, Cambodia. I understand that the chronological, historical, narrative depictions in bas reliefs in Vaikuntha Perumal shrine is the first such attempt in temple architecture in India. In front of the sculpted walls there is an array of beautifully chiselled pillars in the shape of sitting lions.
Vaikuntha Perumal Temple is also referred to as Parameswaravinnagaram. Nandivarman II‚Äôs original name before his coronation was Parameswara and he named this temple after himself. It is the 56th Divya Desam dedicated to Lord Vishnu. There is a small shrine dedicated to the famous saint poet, Thirumangai Alwar, who wrote hymns in praise of the Lord and the king who built it. In one of the hymns he wrote:
‡Æâ‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡ØÜ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æ£‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æ≥‡Æø ‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æí‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ ‡Æµ‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æü‡Æ≤‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Øç
‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Æø ‡Æµ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æü‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æü‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÇ‡Æ¥‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ¥‡Æï‡Ææ‡ÆØ ‡Æï‡Æö‡Øç‡Æö‡Æø
‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ®‡ØÜ‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Æö‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ© ‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æ≥‡Øç
‡Æ™‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øã‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ£‡Æø‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ™‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øá‡Æö‡Øç‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æ∞ ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Æï‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Øá-
In essence, the hymn states that Parameswaravinnagaram, the abode of the Lord is surrounded by mansions filled with precious gems and is in the capital of the beautiful Kanchipuram where the Pallava king who won many a battle and destroyed enemies, surrendered to the Lord.
Temples are not merely places of worship in India. Steeped in history, they are also sites of dazzling expressions of elegant art and architecture, which need to be cherished and conserved.
19/04/23, 8:48‚ÄØam
Poetry has touched the lives of countless people throughout history. James Gates Percival once commented that ‚ÄúThe world is full of poetry. The air is living with its spirit; and the waves dance to the music of its melodies, and sparkle in its brightness.‚Äù Poetry And The Creative Mind Day which is observed today draws attention to the creative minds of poets and their art. The magic is in poetry‚Äôs ability to be intensely personal, yet unfathomably imaginative at the same time, like this one by Srilata.
LINES OF POETRY
Lines of poetry
break
like sudden light
on a black-winged crow,
descend
like song birds
on bare trees,
arrange themselves
in so many
whimsical spines,
word by fast flying word,
light
with meaning,
new
like unseasonable rain.

19/04/23, 2:19‚ÄØpm

21/04/23, 9:26‚ÄØam
John Muir, whose birthday is today, was legendary naturalist and conservationist. He often spent months on end hiking in the Sierra Nevada, detailing his observations in journals and through books, letters, and poems. In 1868, Muir visited Yosemite for the first time and was overwhelmed and enthralled by the beauty he saw before him. ‚ÄúWe are now in the mountains and they are in us, kindling enthusiasm, making every nerve quiver, filling every pore and cell of us,‚Äù he wrote. He initiated measures to protect Yosemite from being threatened by commercial developments. After several legal battles, Congress established Yosemite National Park in 1890 in order to conserve thousands of acres of forest land from further destruction.
Yosemite is a magical place, with cascading waterfalls and soaring mountain peaks. It is a fascinating experience, especially, to have a glimpse of the iconic Half Dome.
There is an interesting story about it:
The Legend Of Tis-sa-ack:
Once an old Indian woman Tis-sa-ack and her husband arrived at the Yosemite Valley which they knew as Ahwahnee. The woman was carrying a heavy, cone shaped basket that was woven from reeds and the course grasses. Her husband walked alongside her unburdened except for his walking stick. It was a hot day and as the old couple continued on their journey they grew more and more thirsty. Tis-sa-ack arrived at the beautiful mountain lake first and she drank so deeply that when her husband arrived the lake was dry. Because the lake was dry there came a drought and the once beautiful green valley dried up. The man was enraged by this and he raised his walking stick to strike at his wife. She cried as she ran from him and her tears stained her face. She turned and threw her basket at her husband‚Ä¶.and as they faced one another The Great Spirit transformed them both to great stone structures. She and her husband now remain separated forever, as Half dome and Washington Column. To this day, her tears stain the face of the Half Dome.
As John Muir observed, ‚ÄúIn every walk with Nature one receives far more than he seeks.‚Äù
22/04/23, 8:00‚ÄØam
Today is Akshaya Tritiya, a day when people throng the jewellery shops to buy gold. The word ‚ÄòAkshaya‚Äô means ‚Äònever diminishing‚Äô and hence the belief that buying the precious metal on this day guarantees endless wealth.
Like many festivals in India, Akshaya Tritiya has several legends connected with it. It is an important day in Jainism and is associated with Adinatha, the first of the 24 Tirthankaras. Rishabadeva, king of Ayodhya gave up all earthly pleasures (much like Gautam Buddha), to lead the life of a monk as Adinatha. In order to live as a Jain monk, one must not possess anything, not even a morsel of food. When he started begging for food, his subjects offered him their most prized possessions like precious stones, elephants, horses but not food or drink which they thought was too modest an offering for their dear king. The king refused all the fine gifts and went without food and water until, finally, his grandson Shreyansha Kumara understood his need and offered him some sugarcane juice. With this juice, Adinatha broke his fast that had lasted 400 days.
It was on Akshaya Tritiya day that Adinatha broke his fast. As a mark of reverence to Lord Adinatha and his strict penance, Jains celebrate this day as ‚ÄúParna Diwas‚Äù after the penance of Varshi Tap and end their year-long alternative-day fasting with sugarcane juice.
This photograph is from Cave 4 at Badamai. Carved into its wall is a beautiful, life-size relief of Adinatha. He is standing in Kayotsarga pose, with unbent knees and straight arms, which are held at the side and do not touch the body. It is representative of an ascetic practice characterised by detachment of the physical body. Adinatha has locks of hair cascading down his shoulders and this is one of the ways to identify his sculpture. There is an interesting story behind this. When he chose to become an ascetic, Rishbadeva started pulling out his long strands of hair. After four fistfuls, when he was pulling out the fifth fistful of hair Indra is said to have told him, " This strand of hair on the crown of your head and hanging down over your shoulders looks attractive. Kindly leave it as it is." Rishabadeva agreed. Due to this bunch of hair he got the popular name; Keshariya ji (one with hair).
As for myself, I am a miner for gold‚Ä¶in the hearts of peopleÔÅä
25/04/23, 7:41‚ÄØam
All forms of aesthetic expression, including poetry, spring from the deepest, personal, inner self. It is essentially an adventure in selfhood. That said, we are living in an era in which selfhood has become fluid. The boundary between the ‚Äòreal self‚Äô and the ‚Äòimagined, virtual self‚Äô has become rather porous in the cyber world in which we are increasingly immersed in.
Poet, novelist, Robert Penn Warren, whose birthday was yesterday, observed presciently years ago that, ‚ÄúThe ideal of understanding men and telling their story, noble or victorious, will be replaced by the study of statistics or non-ideographic units of an infinite series, and computers will dictate how such unites, which do breathe and move, can best be manipulated for their own good‚Ä¶.the self we have is more and more a fictive self.‚Äù He observed that poetry has an important role in the integration of self, ‚Äúin the face of increasingly disintegrative forces in our society, poetry may affirm and reinforce the notion of the self‚Äù. He argued for ‚Äúthe creation of a new body of attitudes and values, a new assessment of our expanding technological capacities in relation to the context of nature‚Äù. He wrote very few nature poems and his ‚ÄúEvening Hawk‚Äù, is truly exceptional. He wrote:
From plane of light to plane, wings dipping through
Geometries and orchids that the sunset builds,
Out of the peak's black angularity of shadow, riding
The last tumultuous avalanche of
Light above pines and the guttural gorge,
The hawk comes.
His wing
Scythes down another day, his motion
Is that of the honed steel-edge, we hear
The crashless fall of stalks of Time.
The head of each stalk is heavy with the gold of our error.
Look! Look! he is climbing the last light
Who knows neither Time nor error, and under
Whose eye, unforgiving, the world, unforgiven, swings
Into shadow.
Long now,
The last thrush is still, the last bat
Now cruises in his sharp hieroglyphics. His wisdom
Is ancient, too, and immense. The star
Is steady, like Plato, over the mountain.
If there were no wind we might, we think, hear
The earth grind on its axis, or history
Drip in darkness like a leaking pipe in the cellar.
The poem is laden with rich metaphors, but personally I feel that no one has described the flight of a bird of prey in these exquisitely inventive words, ‚ÄúNow cruises in his sharp hieroglyphics‚Äù!
26/04/23, 8:37‚ÄØam
In 1836, Ralph Waldo Emerson (whose birthday is today) wrote an essay titled, "Nature". In it he recounted a mystical experience that he had while walking through the woods one afternoon. He experienced a deep kinship and communion with nature and wrote: ‚ÄúStanding on the bare ground, my head bathed by the blithe air, and uplifted into infinite space, all mean egotism vanishes. I become a transparent eyeball; I am nothing; I see all; the currents of the Universal Being circulate through me; I am part or particle of God.‚Äù For him nature is a spiritual experience that can be perceived intuitively. He observed, ‚ÄúThis transcendental experience is open to each one of us. It only requires that we spend time contemplating its meaning and significance in our lives‚Äù.
Emerson, along with Henry David Thoreau, belonged to the Transcendentalist movement which emphasized the need for an intuitive and ‚Äòpoetic‚Äô engagement with nature. In his words, ‚ÄúIn the presence of nature, a wild delight runs through the man, in spite of real sorrows. Nature says, he is my creature, and maugre all his impertinent griefs, he shall be glad with me‚Äù.
Emerson lead a very productive life and lived till 79. Travails of ageing and the prospects of end of life, did not deter him from penning these moving lines in his poem ‚ÄòTerminus‚Äô
As the bird trims her to the gale,
I trim myself to the storm of time,
I man the rudder, reef the sail,
Obey the voice at eve obeyed at prime:
‚ÄúLowly faithful, banish fear,
Right onward drive unharmed;
The port, well worth the cruise, is near,
And every wave is charmed.‚Äù
26/04/23, 11:18‚ÄØpm
Wonderful photograph Sir with those clouds which constantly change their hues and shape and the waters! And the words of Emerson. In tune with nature definitely helps us sync with the eternal, but we pretend to be busy and spare no time to dwell.

Beautiful flower vividly captured Sir. And profound presentation by Buddha, so simple but so deep!
07/05/23, 8:58‚ÄØpm
Fantastic photograph Sir and the lines selected very apt. Words are not mere words, one can really experience what they say...
11/05/23, 10:53‚ÄØpm
It is a beautiful photograph Sir. Very true....
13/05/23, 8:29‚ÄØam
