17/09/23, 10:36‚ÄØam
Wild boars have been an integral part of the Indian ecosystem and have been mentioned in various folklores and mythologies. Among them, one of the most prominent reference to the wild boars is that of Varaha, the third avatar of Vishnu. It is a fascinating tale of how the earth goddess Bhudevi was captured by the demon Hiranayaksha and trapped in the cosmic waters. Vishnu then took the form of a divine boar and rescued her after battling the demon for a thousand years.
Varaha worship was significant in Central India during the Gupta period, particularly from the 4th to the 6th century CE. The worship of Varaha was also important in southern India, especially during the early Chalukyan period. They were the first dynasty to adopt boar as their symbol. Later the Vijayanagar dynasty also chose the boar as their royal emblem
In sculptural tradition, Varaha is usually depicted in two distinct ways: one is with the head of a boar and torso of a man, which is called the ‚ÄòNaravaraha‚Äô, and the other as a wild boar. Khajuraho has one of the best-known representations of Varaha in the wild boar form. One of the most beautiful depictions of Varaha as ‚ÄòNaravaraha‚Äô, is at the Mahakuta temple which dates back to 5th-6th centry.
Varaha avatar symbolizes the preservation and restoration of the world and the triumph of good over evil. Today, when our earth faces a serious threat from several modern demons, the chief of which is our own endless greed, it‚Äôs time to feel inspired by Varaha!
(Today is also celebrated as Varaha Jayanthi)
Dr Raguram
18/09/23, 9:58‚ÄØam
The Brahmapurisvara temple at Pullamangai, built in 10 century, is an extraordinary example of early Chola temple architecture. On this day, let me draw attention to an exquisite sculpture of Ganesha which is carved on the southern wall of the shrine. The god is seated on a throne with folded legs. His trunk hangs vertically and then curves to the left in the form of an inverted question mark. Ganesha is covered by a beautifully sculpted parasol with a central pendant. Two saluting figures are shown in flying posture on either side. Ganesha, ‚ÄòLord of the Ganas‚Äô, is flanked by joyous Ganas in three superimposed rows. One of them is holding Ganesha‚Äôs vahana (vehicle) Mushaka (Mouse). Right on top is the Makara Torana, with two Makaras carved on either side. Rows of Yalis, some of them with human riders, emerge from the mouth of the Makaras and form a canopy. Right in the middle of the canopy is a dancing figure (Siva?). Below it is another row of Ganas. In the midst of this elaborately carved canopy is a very small sculpture which depicts Siva, Parvati and Chandesa Nayanar. There is a large, beautifully carved sculpture of Chandesa Anugraha Murti in Gangaikondacholapuram. This one is a miniature depiction of it, much earlier! Kindly enlarge the image to see these intricate details!
May our lives be suffused with such beauty in its myriad forms!
(PS) Can I request that neither the image nor the post is shared?
Dr Raguram
24/09/23, 9:50‚ÄØam
When we were birding in the Point Reyes region CA, I heard a faint, warbling call. Curious to know the source of it, I scouted the vast land in front, but in vain. Suddenly, there was a flash of luminous blue and there it was, the Western Bluebird perched on the thorny bush! It was carrying the azure sky on its back. I spent a few minutes savouring this beauty. Bluebirds are friends to gardeners because they keep plant-damaging insects and other pests at bay and they can spot them from a distance of over 50 yards!
Bluebird is considered to be a harbinger of happiness. This notion was first held by the Chinese who saw the bird as immortal, a protector, and a symbol of the sun. Native Americans too were in deep awe of the bluebird. Navajos revered it as a spirit in animal form, and the Iroquois believed the bluebird‚Äôs song would make the harsh winters bearable. For the Russians, the bluebird represented hope.
Bluebirds figure in many lovely songs. In 1934, the song ‚ÄòBluebird of Happiness‚Äô was composed by Sandor Harmati and the words were written by Edward Heyman. By 1945, the song had become an international hit. Many other bluebird songs followed, including Judy Garland‚Äôs ‚ÄòHello, Bluebird‚Äô and Paul McCartney‚Äôs ‚ÄòBluebird.‚Äô Who can forget these lines from the song ‚ÄòOver The Rainbow‚Äô in the movie Wizard of Oz:
If happy little bluebirds fly
Beyond the rainbow
Why, oh why can't I?
23rd September is considered as the ‚ÄòBluebird of Happiness Day!‚Äô
Dr Raguram
25/09/23, 10:30‚ÄØpm
It really looks like bluebird of happiness day. A small one yet so popular!!
25/09/23, 10:35‚ÄØpm
What a photograph Sir.. The very sight of it brings the cool breeze... And nature is the best teacher....
27/09/23, 10:11‚ÄØam
Our journey in life is ultimately about knowing ourselves. When we burrow deep within ourselves, the inner landscape unfolds, offering a glimpse of the potentials and challenges within. It may not be an easy task. As we diligently busy ourselves, like the crab shovelling each layer, the richness and depth of our self, unfolds.
Embrace the process of burrowing and discover yourself‚Ä¶it is like coming home.
Dr Raguram
30/09/23, 10:22‚ÄØam
I never get tired of reading Rumi, whose birthday is today. His insightful words and verses about life, love and unity of spirit touches me deeply. There is so much spiritual wisdom in his writings. He was an independent soul yearning for true freedom from dogma and hypocrisy and wrote about the abolishment of fear based religious orders. His prime message is that God is found in your own heart; ‚ÄúEvery moment I shape my destiny with a chisel. I am a carpenter of my own soul.‚Äù
He articulated a notion of a "religion of love," and wrote that "since we worship the one God/ Then all religions must be one." Remarkably at his funeral in Konya, Turkey, in 1273, the procession included not only singers and dancers, besides the traditional chanting from the Quran, but also there were Christian priests chanting the Gospel and Jewish rabbis reciting Psalms.
Just before his death, he recited one of his most inspirational words;
‚ÄúWhen I die; when my coffin is being taken out
you must never think I am missing this world.
Don't shed any tears, don't lament or feel sorry. I'm not falling into a monster's abyss.
When you see my corpse is being carried,
don‚Äôt cry for my leaving.
I'm not leaving; I'm arriving at eternal love.
When you leave me in the grave, don't say goodbye.
Remember a grave is only a curtain for the paradise behind.
You'll only see me descending into a grave, now watch me rise.
How can there be an end? When the sun sets
or the moon goes down, it looks like the end,
It seems like a sunset, but in reality, it is dawn.
When the grave locks you up, that is when your soul is freed.
Have you ever seen a seed fallen to earth not rise with a new life?
Why should you doubt the rise of a seed named man?. . .
When, for the last time, you close your mouth,
Your words and soul will belong to the world of no place, no time.‚Äù
And these words are inscribed in his tomb;
‚ÄúWhen we are dead, seek not our tomb in the earth, but find it in the hearts of men‚Äú.
Dr Raguram
01/10/23, 10:27‚ÄØam
On this World Elderly Day, let me recall Shakespeare‚Äôs evocative, lyrical verse on ageing.
Sonnet 73: That Time Of Year Thou Mayst In Me Behold
That time of year thou mayst in me behold
When yellow leaves, or none, or few, do hang
Upon those boughs which shake against the cold,
Bare ruined choirs, where late the sweet birds sang.
In me thou see‚Äôst the twilight of such day
As after sunset fadeth in the west;
Which by and by black night doth take away,
Death‚Äôs second self, that seals up all in rest.
In me thou see‚Äôst the glowing of such fire,
That on the ashes of his youth doth lie,
As the death-bed, whereon it must expire,
Consum‚Äôd with that which it was nourish‚Äôd by.
This thou perceiv‚Äôst, which makes thy love more strong,
To love that well, which thou must leave ere long.
The temple at Thiruppudaimaruthur is a treasure trove. Amidst beautiful murals that adorn the interior of the main gopuram, there are small, intricately carved wooden sculptures, like this one of an elderly person.
Dr Raguram
07/10/23, 9:54‚ÄØam
Smile made its appearance first in sculptures during the Archaic Period in 6th -7th century BC. The characteristic smile on Greek statues was often referred to as the Archaic smile. It was believed that this kind of smile reflected a state of ideal health and well-being. The goddess Aphrodite, one of the 12 Greek Olympian gods, was called ‚Äúlover of smiles‚Äù.
Closer home, smiling visages started appearing in sculptures, especially that of Buddha during the Gupta period. Bharatha in Natyashashtra described two forms of smile.
ƒ´·π£advikasitair ga·πá·∏çai·∏• ka·π≠ƒÅk·π£ai·∏• sau·π£·π≠havƒÅnvitai·∏•
alak·π£itadvija·πÉ dhƒ´ram uttamƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ smita·πÉ bhavet || 54 |
‚ÄúWith cheeks slightly expanded, with glances of perfect qualities, not showing the teeth, stable, should be the smile (smita) of the highest characters.‚Äù 54
utphullƒÅnananetra·πÉ yad ga·πá·∏çair vikasitair atha
ki·πÉcillak·π£itadanta·πÉ ca hasita·πÉ tad vidhƒ´yate || 55 ||
‚ÄúThat which blooms the mouth and the eyes, expands the cheeks, shows the teeth slightly, is prescribed as smile (hasita).‚Äù 55
I was looking at my library of images to locate a sculpture which depicts ‚Äòsmita‚Äô and this particular one from Khajuraho seemed to represent the description of Bharatha, closely. The smile on the face of this alluring maiden is so well delineated with elongations of the ends of the line of joined lips, slightly swollen cheeks and enlarged nostril base. The almond-shaped eyes are almost on a level with the cheeks and brows, giving an expression of tenderness and bliss.
A smile
Though frozen in time
Still enchants
(Yesterday 6th October was the World Smile Day!)

Such a beautiful photograph and apt lines of the poem which sounds like the magic played by a musical instrument, so lyrical yet so deep in it's meaning. Yes. Need to face and carry on as the final merge is nothing but blissüòå
08/10/23, 10:25‚ÄØam
Munshi Premchand (whose death anniversary is today), is often referred to as ‚Äòqalam ka sipahi‚Äô, soldier of the pen. His first collection of five short stories, Soz-e Watan was considered seditious and copies were burnt by the then government. Undeterred by this, he changed his name and continued to write. He wrote more than 300 short stories, plays, translations and14 novels.
Godaan is his magnum opus. It is the story of Hari, a poor farmer and his family‚Äôs struggle for survival and self-respect. Hari does everything he can to fulfil his life‚Äôs desire: to own a cow, as he believes that making the gift of a cow to a Brahman before he dies will help him achieve salvation. Premchand casts his glance beyond Hari to a far wider canvas with many interwoven stories. It is a deeply political novel which essays the lives and plights of the rural poor with much sensitivity. Almost everyone in the village is deep in debt ‚Äì which keeps growing. As one of the farmer laments:
‚ÄúOur parasitic existence has crippled us. (...) Sometimes I think the government would do us a big favour by confiscating our lands and making us work for a living. (...) We've fallen prey to the system, a system that's completely destroying us. Until we're freed from the chains of wealth, the curse will keep hanging over our heads and we'll never reach those heights of manhood which are life's ultimate goal‚Äù.
Even decades later, nothing seems to have changed in farmers‚Äô lives in India.
Godaan was the final work of Premchand. It was also the last book translated by my mother when she was in throes of a ravaging illness. It was a daunting task which she completed with unflinching resolve which is aptly summarized in these words in Godaan:
‚Äú‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§π ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ó ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§õ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§π‡•à, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó ‡§π‡•à, ‡§≤‡§ó‡§® ‡§π‡•à, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§π‡•à‡•§
‚ÄúThose people who write are those who have some pain, affection, dedication and thoughts‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
09/10/23, 8:08‚ÄØam
Beatles had a very productive sojourn in Rishikesh with Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, penning several beautiful songs. One day the Maharishi gave a lecture about the power of nature and the cycle of life comparing it to the cycle of human nature. Both John and Paul were inspired by his words. John wrote ‚ÄòChild of Nature‚Äô and Paul came up with ‚ÄòMother Nature‚Äôs Son‚Äô. When John heard Paul‚Äôs song he felt it captured what he wanted to say better and ‚ÄòChild of Nature‚Äô, did not figure in any of Beatles albums. It was released as part of the so called Esher demos. Much later, Lennon wrote a song ‚ÄòJealous Guy‚Äô, with exactly the same melody but with completely different lyrics.
Although not as well-known as Lennon‚Äôs other songs, it has a lingering beauty:
On the road to Rishikesh
I was dreaming more or less
And the dream I had was true
Yes, the dream I had was true
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
I don‚Äôt need much to set me free
I‚Äôm just child of nature
I‚Äôm one of nature‚Äôs children
Sunlight shining in your eyes
As I face the desert skies
And my thoughts return to home
Yes, my thoughts return to home
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
I don‚Äôt need much to set me free
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
I‚Äôm one nature‚Äôs children
Underneath the mountain ranges
Where the wind that never changes
Touch the windows of my soul
Touch the windows of my soul
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
I don‚Äôt need much to set me free
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
On John Lennon‚Äôs birthday, you can listen to the song here: https://youtu.be/cGAw_k3maXs?si=dxAZesV2--hLNfw6
Dr Raguram
10/10/23, 9:56‚ÄØam
Can being around with birds improve mental health?
New research from King‚Äôs College London has found that seeing or hearing birds is associated with an improvement in mental well-being and this improvement was also evident in people with a diagnosis of depression, indicating the potential role of birdlife in helping those with mental health conditions. It was also noticed that people living in neighbourhoods with more birds are less likely to suffer from depression, anxiety and stress. By contrast, listening to more traffic noise worsened symptoms of depressive states.
Birds connect us to nature and the mere act of watching and listening to their calls can soothe our minds in a stressful world.
Go out and be amidst them. And even if they are hidden in trees or lurking in the underbrush, do revel in their songs. When they take to their wings, let your mind soar along with them‚Ä¶
(On World Mental Health Day!)

11/10/23, 7:12‚ÄØam
Yesterday was the birthday of Kota Shivarama Karanth. He was a trendsetter in many areas and left an indelible mark in each of them. An unknown facet of his remarkable literary oeuvre is his interest in science fiction. He wrote a story ‚ÄòPashubala‚Äô in 1928, perhaps the science fiction in Kannada. The story revolves around two friends who are convinced that there is life in Mars and work on a manned mission with the help of a group of scientists. When they land in Mercury, they find humanoid aliens living in harmony with nature. Interestingly, one of the gadgets mentioned is, ‚Äòtejobhaashaka‚Äô which can communicate across light years. Truly a visionary!
You can find the only English translation of this intriguing story here: https://schrodingersbekku.blogspot.com/2020/10/pashubala-by-k-shivarama-karanth.html.
Do catch up with the engaging biography of Shivarama Karanth, ‚ÄúGrowing Up Karanth‚Äù written by his three children, each one of them talented in their own way.
Dr Raguram
15/10/23, 12:44‚ÄØpm
Poets often feel alienated and estranged which they express in their works which are deeply moving. Sylivia Plath was once such poet whose poems left a lasting impact on me. When I was reading the poems of Louise Gluck (who passed away a few days ago), I was struck by the similarity between her verses and that of Sylvia Plath (who is my favourite poet!). There is an unmistakable, intimate, autobiographical tone in her works much like Sylvia Plath. Like Plath, Louise Gl√ºck explores the deepest, innermost feelings in simple, straightforward language. In the poem ‚ÄòNostos‚Äô, she penned these memorable lines:
We look at the world once, in childhood.
The rest is memory..
In many of her poems, Lousie Gluck drew attention to the intimate association between humans and nature. For instance, in the poem, ‚ÄòOctober‚Äô, she wrote:
What others found in art
I found in nature.
What others found in human love
I found in nature.
Very simple.
These lines reiterate my belief that nature can assist and guide us in discovering our own inner selves...

Dr Raguram
18/10/23, 10:02‚ÄØam
Our lives seldom turn out to be the way that we want it to be. As Lao Tzu said 2500 years ago, ‚ÄúLife is a series of natural and spontaneous changes. Don‚Äôt resist them‚Äîthat only creates sorrow. Let things flow naturally forward in whatever way they like.‚Äù As we flow in the river of our lives there are fleeting moments when we come close to ourselves and feel at home. These experiences are incredibly intense and indescribable.
Such personal experiences form the core of Zen. The teachings of Zen focus on these moments. Zen has no God to worship, no ceremonial rites to observe. It does not attach any intrinsic importance to the sacred sutras or to their exegeses by the wise and learned.
The first book to cogently outline basic premises of Zen way of life, ‚ÄòIntroduction to Zen Buddhism‚Äô, was authored by D T Suzuki (whose birthday is today) in 1927. Carl Jung wrote a lucid foreword introducing the tenets of Zen and locating it in the larger framework of Buddhist thought.
As Suzuki writes in the book, ‚ÄúZen teaches nothing; it merely enables us to wake up and become aware. It does not teach, it points.‚Äù
There is so much wisdom in these words of Suzuki, ‚ÄúUnless it grows out of yourself no knowledge is really yours, it is only borrowed plumage.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
19/10/23, 7:47‚ÄØam
Sometime back, I read the book, ‚ÄòTruth and Beauty: Aesthetics and Motivations In Science' by the Nobel laureate Dr S Chandrasekhar. It is a collection of speeches he delivered over 40 years on the questions of how scientists work and what motivates their quest. The most insightful lecture in the volume is the one in which he compares the work of Shakespeare, Beethoven and Newton. I was truly amazed at the depth and vastness of his erudition. CP Snow famously referred the relationship between the culture of sciences and that of the humanities as the ‚ÄòTwo Cultures‚Äô. Chandrasekhar engages both these worlds with seamless elegance.
He comments, ‚ÄúTo me, science is the search for truth, a definitive repetitive pattern in creation...Mozart looked for it in music, Monet saw it in a haystack he painted, Michelangelo found it in stone... Perhaps a scientist seeks it through a mathematical equation. But we can all see only a part of the pattern at a time. It is given only to a few to see the whole."
Writing on the quest of science, he comments, ‚ÄúThe pursuit of science has often been compared to the scaling of mountains, high and not so high. But who among us can hope, even in imagination, to scale Everest and reach its summit when the sky is blue and the air is still, and in the stillness of the air survey the entire Himalayan range in the dazzling white of the snow stretching to infinity? None of us can hope for a comparable vision of nature and of the universe around us. But there is nothing mean or lowly in standing in the valley below and awaiting the sun to rise over Kinchinjunga‚Äù.
Here was a scientist who spoke like a poet.
(On the occasion of the birthday of the Nobel Laureate Dr Chandrasekhar)
Dr Raguram
20/10/23, 8:03‚ÄØam
Five-hundred children were killed during indiscriminate attacks on Gaza and many more were wounded. It is a brutal act of war crime and a blot on all our collective consciences.
Michael R. Burch wrote these poignant lines for us to reflect on this dastardly act:
Where does the butterfly go
when mothers cry
while children die
and politicians lie, politicians lie?
When the darkness of grief blots out all that we know:
when love and life are running low,
where does the butterfly go?
And how shall the spirit take wing
when life is harsh, too harsh to face,
and hope is flown without a trace?
Oh, when the light of life runs low,
where does the butterfly go,
where does the butterfly go?
(And the United States vetoed the draft resolution at the UN Security Council which called for a humanitarian pause in besieged Gaza)

26/10/23, 8:26‚ÄØam
My first tryst with the butterflies was when I working as a tutor in the Department of Psychiatry at the Bagayam campus of Christian Medical College. I was given accommodation on a road called tantalizingly, the Mango Road and there were scores of butterflies to keep me company. It was always a pleasure to be in their midst after a busy working day.
As years rolled by, birds replaced the butterflies. And that‚Äôs another story‚Ä¶
No matter where we live, butterflies are always around us. Just observing them, we experience the colors and patterns of nature. Watching them opens up a window to appreciate the beauty around us. It is a wonderful sight to see them flitting around in the morning sun. Though I have been fascinated with butterflies, I had not gotten to know and learn about them in detail. I had been following the work of Arun Urs who has been documenting the butterfly species in and around Mysore and dropped him a line to enquire whether we could join him in one of his butterfly walks. He graciously heeded our request and invited us over. We met on a clear, sunny morning on the outskirts of the Lalitha Mahal Palace. We explored the region there, studded with tall trees and mixed vegetation over the next few hours. And what a discovery it was! Arun‚Äôs knowledge about the butterflies and their habitat is truly amazing and we learnt so much about them under his tutelage.
We have done a couple of walks with him thereafter and each one of them has been an eye opener to the butterflies and the rich biodiversity that sustains them. Arun‚Äôs dream is to transform the vast terrain into a vibrant conservation reserve and I earnestly hope that it becomes a reality. Every time I meet up with Arun, I feel inspired by his dedication and untiring involvement with butterfly conservation. He is truly the Butterfly Man of Mysore! I have been urging him to write and publish a book about his passion and work with the butterflies. It would indeed be a major contribution to increase awareness about these delicate, graceful, gossamer winged creatures and they will continue to entrance us even more!
Dr Raguram
28/10/23, 8:55‚ÄØam
Ted Hughes (husband of Sylvia Plath) was a Poet Laureate of UK from 184 until his death on 28th October 1998. He was quite fascinated with animals and many of his poems are about nature and wildlife. Ted Hughes spent much of his time in Devon and Yorkshire countryside where hawks are often found. He wrote a wonderful poem, ‚ÄòHawk Roositng‚Äô, which was published in his second volume of poems titled, ‚ÄòLupercal‚Äô. Written in first person, it explores the mind of the hawk. As a bird of prey, it kills in order to survive. The hawk is a metaphor for the perennial human need for power and control through subjugation and conquest of the powerless, which we continue to witness all around us.
HAWK ROOSTING
I sit in the top of the wood, my eyes closed.
Inaction, no falsifying dream
Between my hooked head and hooked feet:
Or in sleep rehearse perfect kills and eat.
The convenience of the high trees!
The air's buoyancy and the sun's ray
Are of advantage to me;
And the earth's face upward for my inspection.
My feet are locked upon the rough bark.
It took the whole of Creation
To produce my foot, my each feather:
Now I hold Creation in my foot
Or fly up, and revolve it all slowly -
I kill where I please because it is all mine.
There is no sophistry in my body:
My manners are tearing off heads -
The allotment of death.
For the one path of my flight is direct
Through the bones of the living.
No arguments assert my right:
The sun is behind me.
Nothing has changed since I began.
My eye has permitted no change.
I am going to keep things like this.
Dr Raguram
28/10/23, 11:03‚ÄØpm
What a ruthless decree. Being higher animals we are worse than a hawk which is its nature to attack the prey. Thank you Sir for this wonderful poem and it reflects the happenings.
31/10/23, 9:51‚ÄØam
John Keats was born on this day in 1795. During his short life, he published fifty-four poems using a wide range of poetic forms including odes and sonnets. Not happy with his earlier works he collected every piece of paper on which they had been written and burned them. While suffering from tuberculosis, he fell in love with Fanny Browne. Since he could not have any physical contact with her, he wrote her a series of letters. In one of them he wrote poignantly, ‚ÄúIllness is a long lane, but I see you at the end of it.‚Äù Later, in the same letter, he wondered, ‚ÄúIs there another life?
Shall I awake and find all this a dream?‚Äù He never recovered from his illness and died at the young age of 25.
Nature was one of the greatest sources of inspiration for Keats. He gazed with child-like delight at the rising sun, the moving cloud, the growing bud and the birds and turned them into beautiful poetic images. It was not the ‚Äòintellectual beauty‚Äô of Shelley, but one that emerged from the deepest reaches of his soul. As he wrote in the opening lines of Endymion: ‚ÄúA thing of beauty is a joy forever‚Äù.
During all my birding sojourns I seek beauty in the feathered friends as in this diminutive bird, Taiga Flycatcher. It gets its name from the habitat it uses, the Taiga forest, which refers to the coniferous forests of the sub polar region. A forest dwelling winter visitor to the Indian subcontinent, it is one of the most handsome birds I have ever seen. Its beauty is not confined to its visual aspects alone, but transcends it.
As Keats wrote in ‚ÄòOn A Grecian Urn‚Äô:
‚ÄúBeauty is truth, truth beauty,‚Äîthat is all
Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know‚Äù.
Dr Raguram

Most drown in the suffering but select few are able to think beyond that and pen their thoughts. Such an young age, he sore into heights. What a beautiful photograph Sir, sparkling eyes and such a tiny cute bird.
01/11/23, 8:44‚ÄØam
‡≤π‡≤ï‡≥ç‡≤ï‡≤ø‡≤π‡≤∞‡≥Å‡≤§‡≤ø‡≤¶‡≥Ü ‡≤®‡≥ã‡≤°‡≤ø‡≤¶‡≤ø‡≤∞‡≤æ 'Have you seen a bird fly' by Dattatreya Ramachandra Bendre is a beautiful poem in Kannada. Birds are the metaphors of freedom and liberty. The poet urges us to soar high in our lives and feel free, unfettered. We gain in strength too, by flying with others in flocks.
In order to fly, we have to have faith in our wings.
Just spread your wings and soar . . .
(On the occasion of Karnataka Rajyotsava Day)

Metaphors in therapy, as in life, are quite powerful and I often use them in therapy. They create a reflective space for the client and facilitate deeper level of understanding of issues that confront them. For instance, when clients are battling with anger issues (which is not so uncommon these days), I use this metaphor of Thich Hanh Nhat. I reframe it by saying, ‚ÄúImagine yourself relaxing alone in a boat. ‚Ä¶‚Äù
13/11/23, 7:09‚ÄØam
Last week Ahalya and myself were in Bandipur and it was the place where I discovered the pleasures of birding decades ago, thanks to a student during a trip. It has taken hold of me since then. Noticing it, Ahalya presented ‚ÄòThe Book of Indian Birds‚Äô by Salim Ali (whose birthday was on 12th November). It is a prized possession and has always been beside me since then. Ahalya didn‚Äôt forget to inscribe prominently in the first page of the book, ‚ÄúStay close to the feathered ones!‚Äù and I have been diligently following that diktat.
Birds wake us up in the morning with their dulcet serenades. Even in the midst of urban chaos we have to just look up and see them flying their sorties with sheer abandon. Just observing them, we experience colors and patterns of nature. It offers endless opportunities for discovery, all for free. Some kind of connection emerges in those encounters with nature and our inner selves.
For me watching birds is not about lists, BIG days but soaking in the experience and savoring moments of absolute calmness within.

17/11/23, 9:46‚ÄØam
Li Bai was one of the most prominent poets in Chinese literature, who had an abiding interest Daoism. He wrote more than thousand poems, replete with striking imagery, infused with Daoistic metaphors. The notion of ‚ÄòDao‚Äô, way or path, emphasizes that ideal world is to be found not by following an external route, but by a spiritual path, through state of mind, an attitude. In Daoism, a good life is a life that‚Äôs simple, spontaneous, in harmony with nature, unencumbered by societal regulation and free from the desire to achieve social ascendancy; a life lived in accordance with nature. Daoism doesn‚Äôt completely disregard the existence of the self, instead it acknowledges that the self exists, but it emphasizes that the person has to be ‚Äúselfless‚Äù. Instead of the ‚ÄúI‚Äù it‚Äôs ‚ÄúOthers‚Äù and the person should strive to live in harmony, in a balanced life with others and nature. It is wonderfully enunciated in this quote "The perfect man has no self; the spiritual man has no achievement; the true sage has no name".
Dr Raguram
19/11/23, 9:52‚ÄØam
Margaret Atwood (whose birthday was yesterday), is a prolific, award winning writer with more than fifty books of fiction, poetry and critical essays. Beyond this remarkable oeuvre, she is a strong supporter of feminism, environmentalism and social justice. She was the first author to participate in a conceptual art project, the Future Library. The project envisioned that in the course of a hundred years, a hundred writers will contribute a manuscript to it. The manuscripts will remain unread except for their titles till 2114, when they will be printed on paper made from a thousand pine trees that have been planted.
I was quite surprised to find out that she is the honorary President of the Rare Bird Society!
Dr Raguram
19/11/23, 11:22‚ÄØam
Fantastic photograph Sir and befitting caption. It is so very True what the poet says but we have come so far away and deviated from the 'path'. Important to ponder and practise.
20/11/23, 8:52‚ÄØam
One of the most famous opening sentences in literature is from Leo Tolstoy's novel Anna Karenina: "All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way." Tolstoy's own marriage seems to have fallen into the second category. Though he and his wife, Sophia, had 13 children together, they were an unhappy couple in the later part of their lives. Tolstoy contemplated leaving his wife on many occasions and finally on the night of Nov. 10, 1910, he secretly fled, leaving a note to his wife, ‚ÄúI am doing what old men of my age usually do: leaving worldly life to spend the last days of my life in solitude and quiet.‚Äù Taking only a few things, he boarded a train with his personal physician Makovitsky. Taking a circuitous route, involving several train changes, they planned to travel further to Bulgaria. But on the way, Tolstoy caught a cold, which led to pneumonia and he was taken of the train at Astapovo. He declined any medical intervention as he wanted to "submit himself to God‚Äôs will." He passed away in the early morning of 20th November 1910.
Tolstoy‚Äôs final moments are a poignant reminder of what he wrote in The Death of Ivan Illyich; ‚ÄúWhat death? There was no fear, because there was no death. Instead of death there was light. So that‚Äôs it! He suddenly said aloud. ‚ÄúSuch joy!‚Äù
Dr Raguram
02/12/23, 7:43‚ÄØam
From a distance, the little grebe looks like an unremarkable small duck. When you observe it closely, the first thing that strikes one is its stunningly bright chestnut coloured throat. Its eyes are beady yellow with a tiny black pupil. It is fascinating to see it diving under the water, with ease, surfacing some distance away.
Its scientific name is Tachybaptus ruficollis. The genus Tachybaptus is from the Ancient Greek takhus which means fast, just like tachycardia is a fast heartbeat, and bapto which means ‚Äòto sink under‚Äô, similar to the word baptism. The specific name ruficollis is from the Latin rufus which means red and the Modern Latin collis, which means necked, which is originally from the Latin collum, or neck.
It has been named Switzerland‚Äôs Bird of The Year 2024.
Shakespeare in his Venus and Adonis gave a lovely description of this bird:
‚ÄúLike a dive-dapper peering through a wave
Who, being look‚Äôd on, ducks as quickly in.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
03/12/23, 10:51‚ÄØam
When I was in the medical school, my grand uncle Dr RV Rajam asked me to read the book, ‚ÄôThe Lives of a Cell: Notes of a Biology Watcher‚Äô by Lewis Thomas. It was a collection of essays on varied topics ranging from medicine to music, written in a lively, light hearted, poetic way. It was said that he could write "as naturally as birds build a nest." In his own words, he let them ‚Äúloose . . . to fly around in the dark, bumping into each other, mating in crazy ways‚Äù. The book was full of fascinating nuggets of information. ‚Äúants are very much like humans. They farm fungi, raise aphids, as a livestock, launch armies into wars, use chemical sprays to alarm, and confused enemies, capture slaves‚Äù. He was prescient in his observation about the advent of the Internet in future. ‚ÄúWe are becoming a grid, a circuitry around the earth. If we keep at it, we will become a computer to end all computers, capable of fusing all the thoughts of the world into a syncytium.‚Äù The book opened my eyes to many things, our existence, our environment, social beings, our origin and a variety of interesting topics. ‚ÄòThe Lives of a Cell‚Äô is eleventh on the Modern Library‚Äôs list of the best 100 nonfiction books of the century. I started collecting his subsequent books and each one of them is a gem.
Lewis Thomas was a strong advocate of a scientific approach to understand and decode the mystery of biology and medicine. However, voicing a cautious note, he observed, ‚ÄúScience will...produce the data..., but never the full meaning. For perceiving real significance, we shall need...most of all the brains of poets, also those of artists, musicians, philosophers, historians, writers in general‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
04/12/23, 7:14‚ÄØam
Viktor Frankl‚Äôs ‚ÄòMan in search of meaning‚Äô, has had a profound impact on me. I came across the work of the poet Rainer Maria Rilke (whose birthday is today), for the first time when Frankl quoted from a poem by him, ‚ÄúHow much suffering there is to get through!‚Äù I started reading Rilke‚Äôs poetry and was struck by its lyricism and imagery like in these lines:
‚ÄúShe who reconciles the ill-matched threads
of her life, and weaves them gratefully
into a single cloth‚Ä¶ ‚Äù
We hold disparate threads in our life, some of them infused with pain and sorrow. Our task in life is how we reconcile the threads we‚Äôve been given and turn them into a personally meaningful cloth. A good life doesn‚Äôt come from having ‚Äúgood threads‚Äù. It comes from being an adept weaver, in knowing how to reconcile oneself the ill-matched parts of our life to each other.
And Rainer Maria Rilke observed:
‚ÄúBe patient toward all that is unsolved in your heart and try to love the questions themselves, like locked rooms and like books that are now written in a very foreign tongue. Do not now seek the answers, which cannot be given you because you would not be able to live them. And the point is, to live everything. Live the questions now. Perhaps you will then gradually, without noticing it, live along some distant day into the answer.‚Äù

04/12/23, 10:18‚ÄØam
Thanks Sir for shedding light on the great works of such gems. But are we getting enmeshed in artificial aspects, fleeting attention and no eye for the details of the environment.
07/12/23, 8:25‚ÄØam
Yesterday was the death anniversary of Baba Saheb Ambedkar who fervently espoused the cause of the oppressed, exploited, deprives sections of the society. He was not merely a dalit icon, but someone who tirelessly worked towards emancipation of women. During the All India Depressed Classes Women‚Äôs Conference held in Nagpur in 1942, he remarked, ‚ÄúI measure the progress of a community by the degree of progress which women have achieved.‚Äù He strongly advocated the role of education in mitigating the discrimination faced by them. In this, he was carrying forward the legacy of Jyotiba and Savitribai Phule, who started the first school for girls at the historic Bhide Wada in Pune around 1932. It opened the gates for the emergence of a subculture wherein the oppressed women started giving expression about their struggles and lived experiences through the written word. They haven‚Äôt looked back since then. There is a growing body of writings from the dalits and the marginalized, brimming with vibrancy, especially in the past decade.
I particularly like the poems of Jacinta Kerketta, who belongs to the Adivasi community of West Singhbhum district. She essentially writes in Hindi and some of her poems have been translated into English recently. In her poems, Jacinta highlights the injustices committed on the Adivasi communities and particularly the struggles of women. Her poems, like this one, abounds with wonderful, poignant, imagery:
(‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Å‡§è ‡§§‡•ã‡§°‡§º‡•á ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•á‡§°‡§º ‡§∏‡•á? Kyon Mahue Tode Nahi Jate Ped Se?)
(Why the Mahua is not Plucked from the Tree?)
Mother, why do you wait all night
for the mahua to drop?
Why don‚Äôt you not
just pluck all the mahua from the tree?
Mother says ‚Äì
They live in the womb all night long.
When the time for their birth comes
They fall by themselves to the earth.
At dawn, when they‚Äôre soaked in the dew
We pick them up and bring them home.
When the tree is going through
Labour pains all night long
Tell me, how I can
shake the branch hard?
Say, how I can forcibly
pluck the mahua from a tree?
We just wait
Because we love them.
Dr Raguram
08/12/23, 11:32‚ÄØam
I was keen to reach the temple at Bodhgaya early, before the crowds start streaming in. When I entered the temple precincts there was hardly anyone except a group of Buddhist monks who were chanting melodiously. The ebb and flow of their chanting with sporadic chirping of birds set the tone for a reflective state of mind. I made my way to the Bodhi tree and sat down. Here was the place where Shakyamuni came after practising a lifestyle of severe asceticism for six years. After enduring many hardships, he realized that that a deeper understanding of life was still eluding him. He sat and meditated under this tree and became the Buddha, ‚Äúan awakened one.‚Äù Bodhi Day which is observed on 8th December marks this moment that took place 2500 years ago. In addition to its spiritual significance, the Bodhi Day reminds us of the importance of peace, compassion, and mindfulness in our everyday lives.
Within each of us is a tiny light, entangled in the fibres of our lives. As Ramana Maharishi observed, ‚ÄúYour own Self-Realization is the greatest service you can render the world.‚Äù
(If you look carefully at the photograph, you can have a glimpse of a covered slab at the foot of the Bodhi tree. It marks the exact position where Buddha sat in meditation. Traditionally, it is referred to as Buddha‚Äôs Vajrasana and is the oldest piece of architecture in Bodh Gaya)
Dr Raguram
10/12/23, 7:39‚ÄØam
‚ÄúIf we love Flowers, are we not ‚Äòborn again‚Äô every Day,‚Äù reflected Emily Dickinson whose birthday is today. She was better known in her hometown of Amherst, Massachusetts, as a gardener rather than a poet. She was often observed by neighbours on evenings, tending her flower beds. She identified herself strongly with flowers like the tiger lily, daisy, and rose and was particularly partial to wildflowers. Her first formal act of composition as a girl was not a poem but an herbarium.
The garden was the true inspiration for Emily Dickinson and flowers figured with richest symbolic language in her poems. As she wrote,
‚ÄúI hide myself within my flower
That fading from your Vase
You, unsuspecting, feel for me
Almost a loneliness‚Äù
For her, every single flower is a microcosm of complex ecological relationships between numerous organisms and their environment. She captured this understanding in an exquisite poem, in which the flower emerges not as the pretty object of admiration but as an enchanting, silent symphony of interconnected resilience.
BLOOM
‚ÄúBloom ‚Äî is Result ‚Äî to meet a Flower
And casually glance
Would cause one scarcely to suspect
The minor Circumstance
Assisting in the Bright Affair
So intricately done
Then offered as a Butterfly
To the Meridian ‚Äî
To pack the Bud ‚Äî oppose the Worm ‚Äî
Obtain its right of Dew ‚Äî
Adjust the Heat ‚Äî elude the Wind ‚Äî
Escape the prowling Bee
Great Nature not to disappoint
Awaiting Her that Day ‚Äî
To be a Flower, is profound
Responsibility‚Äù
Dr Raguram
10/12/23, 7:30‚ÄØpm
So beautiful both the photograph of flower and the poem. What a way of expressing the observation in detail and honour extended to a flower... So different from the casual look and one or two words of appreciation which we in general offer...
11/12/23, 7:47‚ÄØam
Mountains might not seem like they do much, but in reality, they are one of the most important creations of nature. To raise awareness about mountains, the United Nations signifies December 11 as International Mountain Day. They contain almost half of the total biodiversity hotspots on the planet. Mountains host a significant amount of flora and fauna, which are vulnerable and at risk of extinction. Unfortunately, they are being overexploited by humans and are torn apart to make way for buildings and cities.
Mountains are nature‚Äôs most beautiful gift to us and let us strive to take care of them.
William Wordsworth expressed the beauty and allure of mountains poetically in ‚ÄòLines composed a few miles above Tintern Abbey
‚ÄúTherefore am I still
A lover of the meadows and the woods
And mountains; and of all that we behold
From this green earth; of all the mighty world
Of eye and ear, both what they half create
And what perceive; well pleased to recognize
In nature and the language of the sense
The anchor of my purest thoughts, the nurse
The guide, the guardian of my heart, and soul
Of all my moral being.‚Äù

16/12/23, 10:18‚ÄØam
George Santayana (whose birthday is today), was a renowned philosopher, essayist, novelist and poet, known for his profound insights into human nature. He has become very well-known for his aphorisms. His most famous one "Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it" is inscribed on a plaque at the entrance of the Auschwitz concentration camp. I keep wondering whether we have drawn any lesson from it. In a lighter vein, Mark Twain famously commented, ‚ÄúHistory doesn‚Äôt repeat itself, but it does rhyme.‚Äù
Santayana wrote number of iconic poems like this one, titled ‚ÄòDecima‚Äô. A decima is a ten-line stanza of poetry. It is also referred to as decima espinela after the Spanish poet Vicente Espinel who used it extensively in his compositions.
DECIMA
Silent daisies out of reach,
Maidens of the starry grass,
Gazing on me as I pass
With a look too wise for speech,
Teach me resignation,‚Äîteach
Patience to the barren clod,
As, above your happier sod,
Bending to the wind's caress,
You‚Äîunplucked, alas!‚Äîno less
Sweetly manifest the god.
Dr Raguram
18/12/23, 9:18‚ÄØam
Today is the birth centenary of TS Satyan often considered as the ‚Äòfather of photojournalism‚Äô in India. His work was all about people, across various streams of life. One particular image that has made a deep impact in me was a photograph of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, showing Nehru walking in the corridor of the Parliament House with his back towards the camera. This was a period of time when Nehru was severely criticized for his policies regarding China which waged a war with an unprepared Indian army. The isolation and loneliness experienced by him has been artfully expressed in a simple frame.
Satyan had an unparalleled eye to capture the extraordinary in the ordinary. In his own words, ‚ÄúMy people are not the rich and the famous. They are the simple, ordinary folk. They do not hit the headlines, yet my people are people who matter. They were there when I picked up the camera six decades ago, and they have been there every time I have gone back to capture the interesting moments in their lives. In giving me privileged access at every step of my career as a photo journalist ‚Äì even in their moments of despair or drudgery ‚Äì they have never let me forget that photography is at once both an exquisite art-form and a means of communication. And that to lose sight of one aspect is to lose sight of both. Call it intimate intrusions, but it is these simple, ordinary people who dominate my oeuvre. Through a tiny aperture they allowed me to freeze-frame the cycle of life: birth, growth and death. In between, they showed me babies being born, babies being bathed, babies being suckled. They have let me in when children were learning, children were playing. They have allowed me to peep at adults at work, at worship, at recreation and adults at their everyday chores. And they have let me do so on the road, at the well, beside rivers, in crowds and in solitude. In the process, by making their private life public, they have enabled me to discover the extraordinary in the everyday."
I had a close association with him in the later part of his life and deeply cherish the interactions. I visited him a few years before his death. It was after a major retrospective of his work. He looked at the prints which were neatly stacked, turned to me and said, ‚ÄúI would like you to take these‚Äù. I was deeply moved, touched and requested him to just select a few for me to treasure. Every time I look at them, the magic of a creative genius keeps unfolding.‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram

Oh what a photograph Sir. Enchanting. No wonder the poets could spontaneously write poems when they deeply observed nature.... They have the patience to listen to their inner voice and translate it into words....
19/12/23, 8:36‚ÄØam
Paul Klee (whose birthday was yesterday), left an indelible mark on the world of visual arts with his unique style and innovative approach to painting. A great artist, he was also an inspiring teacher, fine musician, and persuasive writer. Klee was ambidextrous. He wrote with his right hand and painted with his left. Klee‚Äôs paintings often blur the line between reality and imagination. His famous dictum was that drawing is a matter of taking a line for a walk.
Reflecting on the artistic process, he wrote, ‚ÄúFrom the root, the sap rises up into the artist, flows through him, flows to his eye. Overwhelmed and activated by the force of the current, he conveys his vision into his work. And yet, standing at his appointed place as the trunk of the tree, he does nothing other than gather and pass on what rises from the depths. He neither serves nor commands he transmits. His position is humble. And the beauty at the crown is not his own; it has merely passed through him‚Äù.
Paul Klee felt that the study of nature was one of the central principles of artistic creation. Birds and fish assume a special place in his work. They exerted a particular fascination on him because unlike humans, who are bound to the earth by gravity, they can move completely freely in air or water. This gives them their own territories which are difficult for humans to access.
Antonin Artaud famously observed, ‚Äú ln Paul Klee, the objects of the world fall into order and it seems as if he was only writing down their dictation‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
20/12/23, 8:08‚ÄØam
Beau Taplin is a poet from Australia who has captured the essence of human emotions and experiences through eloquent words and enchanting themes. In his words, ‚ÄúI like to draw inspiration from wherever I can, so no river runs dry. The connections I have shared with people have always been a significant part of who I am, so a great deal of it comes directly from personal experiences‚Ä¶ As far back as I can remember, I have searched for the hidden magic in things, those moments that seem to glimmer and shine with their own inner light, and so my great hope and intention with my verses and volumes is to simply encourage you to do the same. To see how the rabbit hole, this deep magic, belongs not only to stories, but can be found right here beneath the soles of your feet; in the soft light of morning, amongst the woods and the streams, in dance, in music, or a lover‚Äôs kiss‚Äù.
Beau Taplin is among the new generation of poets like Rupi Kaur, who reach out to larger audiences through social media. His brief verses/notes in Instagram continue to enthral his devoted followers. He writes, ‚ÄúEveryone you meet has a part to play in your story. And while some may take a chapter, others a paragraph, and most will be no more than scribbled notes in the margins. Someday, you'll meet someone who will become so integral to your life, you'll put their name in the title.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
21/12/23, 8:59‚ÄØam
Kodo Sawaki is regarded by many as the greatest twentieth-century Zen master. He had a difficult start in life as his early life was full of travails of various kinds. He weathered them all and after receiving his ordination, spent many years living in an abandoned hermitage devoting himself to the practice of Zazen. He became famous throughout Japan for the sesshin (intensive meditation retreat) that he gave to people from all walks of life, without making any personal distinction or discrimination. Kodo Sawaki called his monastery a ‚Äúmoving monastery‚Äù. He gave Zen a new life and ‚Äúbrought fresh air to the decaying Zen‚Äù by staying away the frozen rituals. His tendency to travel alone and his refusal to settle down at any monastery in the classical sense earned him the nickname, ‚ÄúHomeless Kodo‚Äù.
Kodo Sawaki taught that the practice of zen is not about achieving enlightenment, but rather about living in the present moment and being mindful of our actions and thoughts. He emphasized the importance of zazen, or seated meditation to cultivate a sense of inner peace and clarity. Kodo encouraged people to live a life of simplicity and to find joy in the small moments of everyday life.
When he was 86, Kodo felt gravely ill and spent the last three months of his life at Antai-ji, a temple transformed by him into a place for a pure practice. From his bed, he spent a long time looking at the Takagamine mountain and, three days before his death, he told a nun: ‚ÄúLook at that. Nature is magnificent. In all my life, I have never encountered a person to whom I could have submitted and who I could have admired. But this Takagamine mountain looks upon me form the heights saying: ‚ÄòKodo, Kodo‚Äô‚Äù.
These were his last words. He passed away on the 21st of December, 1966
