The sculptors are dead and gone but they are alive in their work. Like the sound of the bell resonating through flowers, the chiselling sound seems to be echoing in these sculpturesü§î

Art & culture

06/01/23, 10:49‚ÄØam
On the occasion of Arudra Darisanam dedicated to the cosmic dance of Lord Siva, let me recall my visit to Banteay Srei, the jewel of Khmer Art. Each and every section of this small temple is exquisitely carved. This beautiful depiction of Aada Vallan or Dancing Siva is on the eastern side of the temple. Below him is Indira riding his Airavata, which is depicted as a monster-like figure with an elephant head. Indira (unfortunately his head is missing) is seen holding the elephant trunk on the right hand and the monster head on the left hand. The two other Airvatas are on the corners of the bas relief. On Siva‚Äôs left is a percussionist playing on the drum. On the right of Siva is a depiction of an emaciated woman, Karaikkal Ammaiyar. She was a Bhakti poet and one of the three women amongst the 63 Nayanmars, a group of saints devoted to Lord Siva.
Sekhizhar in his monumental work ‚ÄòPeriyapuranam‚Äô narrates the story of Karaikkal Ammaiyar. She began her life as Punithavathi and was married to Paramadattan. One day Paramadattan sent two mangoes to her telling her to keep them for his lunch. An hour or so later Lord Siva came as a mendicant, begging for alms. As food wasn‚Äôt ready, Punithavathi offered him one of the mangoes. When her husband returned, Punithavathi served him the other one. When he asked for the other one, she was desperate and prayed to Lord Siva and a ripe mango fell into her palm. Finding the fruit bigger and tastier, he asked her where she got it. When she related what had happened, Paramadattan was unconvinced and asked her to procure another such fruit. Punithavathi prayed again and received one more fruit but it vanished when her husband tried to touch it. Taken aback, Paramadattan realised that she had divine qualities and deserted her. Stung by this, she left home to pursue an ascetic path and prayed to Lord Siva to release her from the shackles of the physical body. Hence many iconographic depictions of her portray her in an emaciated form.
There is a small temple dedicated to her in Karaikkal. Every year Mangani (Mango) festival is celebrated commemorating this story. During this festival Lord Siva is taken in procession as Bikshadana with his begging bowl and people throw mangoes from the rooftops.
Karaikkal Ammaiyar composed beautiful verses in praise of Lord Siva:
‡Æá‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ§ ‡Æá‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ™ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç
‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øà ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡ÆÆ‡ØÄ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Øá‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Øà ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øà ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç
‡Æá‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ¥‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æü‡Æø
‡ÆÖ‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ®‡ØÄ ‡ÆÜ‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æâ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æü‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÄ‡Æ¥‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï.
I pray for the infinite happiness of Your love
I do not want to be born again
If I do, I do not want to forget You forever
If I do, I want to be happily singing in Your praise
Under Your feet as You are dancing‚Äù.
06/01/23, 11:01‚ÄØpm
So beautifully carved with so much of intricacy. Looks like a beautiful puzzle. Thank you Sir for the narration. I think Karaikkal Ammaiyar can be compared to Akkamahadevi and Andal amongst Azhwars.
07/01/23, 10:24‚ÄØam
January 5th is celebrated as the National Bird Day in the USA to draw attention to the beauty and importance of birds in the ecosystem.
While birding in the Coyote Hills near San Francisco, I spotted a bird at a distance sallying in the air in a graceful way, much like a butterfly. When it settled down on a branch, I had a close look and it was Say‚Äôs Phoebe.
In Greek mythology, Phoebe was the goddess of the hunt and the moon, the daughter of Gaea and the twin sister of Apollo. I was wondering whether this petite flycatcher is called phoebe owing to its prowess in hunting insects. Instead, I gather that the name derives from the kind of sound it makes! American naturalist Thomas Sa was the first scientist to encounter the bird, at a site near Ca√±on City, Colorado, in 1819 and it was named after him by Charles Bonaparte, a nephew of Napoleon. They have been in the U.S. for a long time. Palaeontologists discovered Say‚Äôs Phoebe fossils in Arizona, California, New Mexico, and Texas dating back to about 400,000 years ago (the late Pleistocene).
12/01/23, 7:50‚ÄØam
Haruki Murakami, one of my favourite writers, turns 74 today. His latest book Novelist as Vocation was published in English a few months ago. A collection of essays, it was first published in Japanese seven years ago. The narrative flows in the manner of many of his novels, which are usually written in the first-person. There are informative insights into his writings. I particularly liked his observation on the art/act of writing: ‚ÄúIf possible, I would like my readers to savour that same emotion when they read my books. I want to open a window in their souls and let the fresh air in. This is what I think of, and hope for, as I write‚Äîpurely and simply.‚Äù
14/01/23, 10:48‚ÄØam
13th December is the last day of the Tamil month Margazhi which ushers in the Pongal festival. It occurs on the last day of Dakshinayana, a six month cycle of the Sun‚Äôs course moving south, which is followed by a six month cycle of the Sun‚Äôs course moving north called Uttarayana.
During Bhogi, people clean their houses, get rid of unwanted things, symbolically setting them on fire. Perhaps it reminds us that we need to give up all our negativities, and unwanted thoughts in the smouldering fire.
Mythologically it is an invocation to a divine force, Lord Indra, "the God of Clouds and Rains' ',seeking his benevolence to bring in good rains and help the farmers.
This is a beautifully carved sculpture of Lord Indra with Indrani on his vehicle Airavat, from the 13th century Chennakeshava temple at Somanathpua, near Mysore
15/01/23, 2:26‚ÄØpm
What a fantastic sculpture. So much of intricacyü§î Thank you Sir. Wish all of you the same.
16/01/23, 7:43‚ÄØam
The third day of Pongal is celebrated as Mattu Pongal to thank and revere the cattle which play an important role in the lives of the agricultural community. Their horns are painted in vibrant colours and decorated with bells and other ornaments.
This beautifully sculpted wooden figure (which is the size of a large postage stamp!) is from within the main temple tower at Thiruppudaimarthur, Tirunelveli district
19/01/23, 9:58‚ÄØam
The Raven has featured in ancient stories from around the world and in almost every culture. In the book of Genesis, Noah first sent a raven from the ark to determine if the floodwaters had receded. They are perhaps one of the smartest of birds.
Ravens have fascinated people through history. Edgar Allan Poe, whose birthday is today, was no exception and wrote the poem The Raven in 1845. Who can forget these memorable lines‚Ä¶
‚ÄúDeep into that darkness peering, long I stood there wondering, fearing,
Doubting, dreaming dreams no mortals ever dared to dream before;
But the silence was unbroken, and the stillness gave no token,
And the only word there spoken was the whispered word, "Lenore?"
This I whispered, and an echo murmured back the word, "Lenore!" ‚Äî
Merely this, and nothing more‚Äù
This iconic poem launched him from a virtual nobody to an overnight success, but his newfound popularity wasn‚Äôt always easy for the writer. Children were known to follow him through the streets, flapping their arms and croaking like a raven. Poe‚Äôs response? Shouting ‚ÄúNevermore!‚Äù at them until they ran away.
Incidentally Edgar Allan Poe was a birder!
22/01/23, 9:36‚ÄØam
Lord Byron (whose birthday is today) expressed a sense of wonder and joy about nature in his poems. Born with a club foot, he was deeply uncomfortable with it and had to wear special boots to hide it. He was also a victim of childhood sexual abuse at the hands of a drunken nursemaid. For him nature was a healer; a refuge and place of shelter.
His love of nature finds expression in Childe Harold‚Äôs Pilgrimage:
‚ÄúI live not in myself, but I become
Portion of that around me; and to me,
High mountains are a feeling‚Ä¶
Are not the mountains, waves, and skies a part
Of me and of my soul, as I of them?
Is not the love of these deep in my heart
With a pure passion‚Äù
His own inner need for solitude finds expression in these perceptive lines‚Ä¶
‚ÄúThere is a pleasure in the pathless woods,
There is a rapture on the lonely shore,
There is society, where none intrudes,
By the deep sea, and music in its roar:‚Äù
29/01/23, 9:36‚ÄØam
When I was ambling along the corridors of the Durga temple at Aihole sometime ago, I noticed a sculpture of a serene, elegant, bejewelled person in a pillar. What caught my attention was a figure of a woman with legs of horse on his left. Unfortunately, her face was disfigured. At that time I was not sure of its iconographic importance.
Yesterday on the occasion of Ratha Saptami, when I was reading about the legends associated with Surya, I wondered whether this sculpture represents Surya and his wife.
According to the legends, Vishvakarma‚Äôs daughter, Sanjana was married to Surya. After bearing him three children, she found his brilliance too oppressive and the heat unbearable. Hence she took the form of a shadow, Chhaya to take her place. Chhaya did not disclose her identity to Surya and had two sons and two daughters from him. Later when Surya realized that Chhaya was not Sanjana he was extremely annoyed and banished Chhaya away. He went in search of Sanjana and enquired about her whereabouts with her father Vishvakarma who he told him that she was living in the forest. Surya went in search in the forest and found her in the form of a mare and united with her.
Chhaya who represents darkness was the manifestation of Sanjana who is deemed to be the source of all conscious thought. Ignorance is darkness which is dispelled by the light of awareness. Not surprisingly, the symbol associated with Sanjana is walnut which has a striking similarity with human brain!
There is plenty to ponder in mythology!
29/01/23, 10:48‚ÄØpm
Very informative Sir!! And what a sculpture
08/02/23, 8:18‚ÄØam
Located in the beautiful Hudson Valley in Ghent, NY, Art Omi is a vast landscape untouched by landscapers or horticulturalists. Amidst the tranquil outdoor space dotted with wild flowers are large scale sculptures. Some works are so well camouflaged in the wooded trails that it is easy to miss them, while others reach out through the trees. When I ventured into a forest path, I chanced upon this wooden sculpture of a man in silent repose, silhouetted against the sky. As I spent a few minutes soaking up the experience, these words of the philosopher Martin Buber (whose birthday is today) resonated within me: "Solitude is the place of purification".
Solitude often unravels the richness within the self‚Ä¶
13/02/23, 10:16‚ÄØam
Sarojini Naidu, (whose birthday is today) was an exceptionally talented person right from young age. She was actively involved in the freedom struggle and yet found time to pen some exquisite poems. In particular, I am fascinated by the nature poems of the Nightingale of India, which are replete with entrancing, vibrant, imagery. In her poem the Autumn Song, she draws attention to the beauty and frailty of fall with a touch of poignancy. The first two lines are exquisitely eloquent‚Ä¶
Like a joy on the heart of a sorrow,
The sunset hangs on a cloud;
A golden storm of glittering sheaves,
Of fair and frail and fluttering leaves,
The wild wind blows in a cloud.
Hark to a voice that is calling
To my heart in the voice of the wind:
My heart is weary and sad and alone,
For its dreams like the fluttering leaves have gone,
And why should I stay behind?
14/02/23, 9:43‚ÄØam
Sanskrit literature is replete with beautiful verses celebrating love. Most notable among them is Chaurapanchasika , a compilation fifty short lyric poems written in the eleventh century A. D. by the poet Bilhana.
There are many versions about the origin of this work. One of them states that a king with a lovely daughter engages the famous poet Bilhana to educate his daughter. To prevent any romance blossoming between the two, he tells the princess that her guru is visually challenged and tells the guru that his student has deformities in her face. To ensure that they don‚Äôt see each other, he hangs a curtain between the two. One day while lessons were in progress, the poet is thrilled by the full moon on a cloudless sky. He breaks into a poem, and princess wonders how a blind man can sing about the moon with such brilliance. Excited, she pulls down the curtain and finds that Bilhana is a handsome young man while he finds he finds her to be a personification of female beauty. The two instantly fall in love and decide to marry, but the enraged king sentences them to death. As Bilhana is being led to his execution, he starts singing the fifty verses. Deeply moved by it, the king orders his release and formally gives his daughter in marriage.
Interestingly, in 1948, two producers made movies in Tamil based on this story of Bilhana. Unfortunately, the third version with the legendary MK Thyagaraja Bhagavathar as Bilhana was never completed as the actor was arrested.
Among many translations of this remarkable work, I find the one by Sir Edwin Arnold quite interesting. One of the verses reads:
Still when her eyes, as lotus petals long,
Like Fortune‚Äôs goddess lotus-born, I see,
And see her wearied by her bosom's load,
With both my arms clasping her close to me
As honey bee his darling lotus sips,
I would grow drunk on mead within her Iips.
These lines find a picturesque expression in this beautiful sculpture from Khajuraho.
15/02/23, 6:36‚ÄØpm
Exquisitely crafted sculpture and interesting narrative Sir.
16/02/23, 10:33‚ÄØpm
Glowing heart‚ù§Ô∏è Yes from within. Glittering photograph Sirüëå
18/02/23, 8:35‚ÄØam
According to one of the legends, Lord Shiva and Devi Parvathi tied the nuptial knot on Mahashivaratri. Their union has a deeper connotation: Purusha (mindfulness) is represented by Shiva, while Prakriti (nature) is epitomized by Parvathi.
This classic Shiva Parvathi sculpture is from Hoysaleshwara temple in Halebeedu. It depicts Parvathi seated on Shiva‚Äôs lap which is referred to as atikarohana. They are bedecked with intricately carved jewellery and carry different weapons and ornaments in their arms. The details are so mesmerizing, providing a three dimensional perspective. What is interesting to note is the presence of mongoose, a vahana of Parvathi at her feet.
Composed by Adi Shankaracharya, Shiva Parvathi stotram holds a special importance amongst all Shiva Stotras. It extols the divine qualities of the god and goddess in 12 stanzas. On this Mahashivaratri day let us recall a verse from this:
‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç,
‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç,
‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç
Namah Shivabhyam pashupalakabhyam
Jagattrayee rakshana baddha hrudbhyam
Samastha Devaasura pujitabhyam
Namo namah Shankara Parvatibhyam
I bow to God Shiva and Goddess Parvathi, the protectors of all beings
Who are the divine guardians of all the three worlds
The divine pair worshipped by all the Devas and Asuras
I bow to you, again and again, God Shiva and Goddess Parvathi
18/02/23, 6:39‚ÄØpm
A beautiful sculpture Sirüôè The nuptial knot tied between mind and matter. Parvati through self discipline and determination won Shiva. Beyond idolising connecting to our lives really helps Sir. Thank you for the verse and its interpretation.
21/02/23, 10:23‚ÄØam
In all my forays into the library during my training days at NIMHANS, I was drawn into one particular journal, simply titled as Psychiatry. Tucked between its plain yellow covers were articles that opened up my perspective into the interpersonal context of psychological suffering. One of the founders of the journal was Harry Stack Sullivan, whose birthday is today. Sullivan through his framework of interpersonal psychotherapy articulated that one‚Äôs personality and behavior has to be viewed and examined on the background of close, intimate, relationships. He felt that descriptive psychiatry failed to look beyond diagnosis and view the whole person in his/her social context. He extended this orientation to understand what was often viewed as an incomprehensible disease process, schizophrenia. This laid the foundation of the Chestnut Lodge which pioneered intensive, individualized treatment of schizophrenia. Chestnut Lodge was also the locale of the book ‚ÄúI never promised you a rose garden‚Äô.
Enforced isolation during the Covid era, drew our attention to the unsettling fact that loneliness can be a severely distressing state. Yet it has eluded the attention of mental health professionals. Sullivan was among the very few who attempted to examine it. He regarded loneliness as one of the most intense and painful of human experiences and described people with schizophrenia as, ‚Äúthe loneliest of the lonely‚Äù.
Personally, the work of Sullivan widened my gaze beyond the veil of symptoms onto the real person shrouded behind them.
22/02/23, 8:54‚ÄØam
We are all drawn into the larger than life canvas of the Father of the Nation. Yet, we fail to notice the gentle brush strokes and fine textures that enhance its subject and the incredible person responsible for it, Kasturba Gandhi. Married at a very young age, she deftly juggled multiple roles: as a devoted wife to a demanding husband, a caring mother and a satyagrahi. It was not an easy task and its demands impacted her health significantly.
22nd February was the last day in the life of Kasturba Gandhi. She was imprisoned along with Mahatma Gandhi in the Aga Khan Palace, Poona and was not keeping good health for a while. When Kasturba realised that her end was near she said, "Do not sorrow after my death. It should be an occasion for rejoicing." Then she whispered a line from her favourite Gujarati hymn, ‚ÄòHari no marag che shoora no, nahi kayar nu kaam jone (The path to God is for the brave to tread, not for cowards). Then she slipped into an altered state of consciousness. When he was told about it, Bapu rushed to her room. took her hand in his and asked, ‚ÄòShun thay che, Kastur?‚Äô In a feeble, trembling voice, Kasturba replied, ‚ÄòShun thay che smajhatu nathi. Mare java no vakhat thai gayo.‚Äô She rested her head on Gandhi‚Äôs chest and soon her life ebbed away.
The next day she was cremated in the grounds of the Aga Khan Palace. Gandhi sat through the cremation till the pyre was extinguished. When someone suggested him to move away he replied, "This is the final parting, the end of 62 years of shared life. Let me stay here till the cremation is over."
When her children Devadas and Ramdas went to collect her ashes, they found to their great surprise, an intact a pair of red and green glass bangles worn by Kasturba since marriage.
22/02/23, 10:25‚ÄØpm
A brave heart and an inspiration to all the womenüëç
23/02/23, 9:43‚ÄØam
When I joined NIMHANS, my teacher Dr RL Kapur told me to read Karl Jasper‚Äôs ‚ÄòGeneral Psychopathology‚Äô. I went over to the library to look for it. In those days, books in the library were all locked up securely in steel cupboards and the keys were with a strict looking female attender. When I requested her to look for it, she went straight to the pathology section and announced in a loud voice that there is no such book. I persuaded her to look for it in the psychiatry section and to my great relief it was there in a bottom shelf. It was the first edition, translated into English by Hoenig, who had spent a year at the All India Institute of Mental Health in 1955. It was a difficult book to read, but I gamely gave it a try over several weeks and re-read it during my training days. Later, I personally wanted to possess a copy of ‚ÄòGeneral Psychopathology‚Äô and finally got one in an old book shop. It has a pride of place in my collection. I was going through it today on Jasper‚Äôs birthday and was struck by its continuing relevance in the current climate of psychiatric practice.
The main emphasis of Jasper was on a phenomenological approach to psychiatric illnesses. It is essentially a form of qualitative enquiry that emphasized experiential, lived aspects of a particular phenomenon as described by the person. In Jasper‚Äôs own words ‚ÄúSince we never can perceive the psychic experiences of other in any direct fashion, as with physical phenomena, we can only make some kind of a representation of them. There has to be an act of empathy, of understanding ...which comes from the patient‚Äôs own self-descriptions, which can be evoked and tested out in the course of personal conversations.‚Äù In a Jaspersian sense, psychiatric diagnosis is not a ‚Äúsimple question-and-answer interrogation‚Äù but a ‚Äúparticular observation‚Äù in the context of an empathic interaction.
Unfortunately, with the advent of the Neo Kraeplinian frameworks of diagnosis, the emphasis has shifted to ‚Äòeliciting‚Äô symptoms which are then straight jacketed to fit into diagnostic criteria. This has led to a robotic checklist approach shorn of insights about the experiential terrain of symptoms. The person who ultimately knows his/her experiences is the patient himself/herself. The psychiatrist‚Äôs role is to facilitate expression of this experience through a compassionate, empathic stance tinged with an attitude of curiosity.
06/03/23, 8:02‚ÄØam
During our training period at NIMHANS, after receiving our monthly pay, Ahalya and myself will invariably make our way to Premier Book Shop to stock up on books. During one such visit, Shanbhag guided us through the shelves overflowing with books, picked up one and said, ‚ÄúDoctor, you must read this!‚Äù
It was Gabrial Garcia Marquez‚Äôs ‚ÄòOne Hundred Years Of Solitude‚Äô.
When I started reading the novel, it was much akin to sojourns in dreamscapes. To borrow a phrase from Beatles, it was a Magical Mystery Tour! Every page was suffused with intricate details, intersecting history, mythology and tradition. The lives and tribulations of the Buendia family came alive in the author‚Äôs mesmerizing narrative.
In a memorable passage after the death of Jose Arcadio Buendia, Gabo‚Äôs writes, ‚ÄúWhen the carpenter was taking measurements for the coffin, through the window they saw a light rain of tiny yellow flowers falling. So many flowers fell from the sky that in the morning the streets were carpeted with a compact cushion and they had to clear them away with shovels and rakes so that the funeral procession could pass by.‚Äù
Yellow butterflies were one of his often used literary imagery and he used to comment that nothing awful would happen to him if there are yellow flowers around.
During his memorial service thousands of yellow butterflies made of paper were released to celebrate the life of this remarkable author.
Today is Gabo‚Äôs 96th birthday‚Ä¶
07/03/23, 8:12‚ÄØam
It was an unusually sultry morning and there was a long queue in front of St Peter‚Äôs Basilica in the Vatican City. Undeterred, I waited patiently behind a group of tourists from America who were chatting animatedly. As soon as I entered its hallowed precincts, I made my way straight to have a glimpse of Michelangelo‚Äôs Pieta. During his lifetime Michelangelo made three Pietas, of Virgin Mary mourning the dead body of Christ and this is the most beautiful of them all. Though Mary embracing her dead son is not explicitly mentioned in the holy book, the scene has proven to be a popular subject among artists for centuries.
Safely ensconced behind bullet proof glass, Virgin Mary was in a seated position, wrapped in robes and cradling the lifeless body of Jesus. His head was slumped back on her shoulder. When I looked at it closely, I felt that the sculpture was shaped like a pyramid, with the top of the head of Virgin Mary being its peak and the sculpture expanding to accommodate her seated legs. Her petite face with gentle demeanour exuded serene tranquillity. Michelangelo‚Äôs painstaking attention to detail and the unique treatment of the hair, the skin and the intricate folds in the fabric is a lasting testimony to his outstanding artistry.
Pieta was the only sculpture where Michelangelo inscribed his name. Unfortunately, with the crowd milling around, I couldn‚Äôt have a close look to locate it.
Michelangelo was a multi-talented individual who also wrote sonnets on variety of subjects. He produced hundreds of madrigals and sonnets, often putting down his chisel while at work to write down a line or two of verse.
These beautiful lines are from the sonnet titled The Model and the Statue:
When that which is divine in us doth try
To shape a face, both brain and hand unite
To give, from a mere model frail and slight
Life to the stone by Art‚Äôs free energy.
(Yesterday, 6th March was the birthday of this remarkable artist/poet)
08/03/23, 10:27‚ÄØam
Pen and chisel, both effective ways to touch heart. So beautifully and humbly put across- shadow of divine perfection. The artist has left to the eyes of the beholder to interpret the expression on Virgin Mary's face!!!
15/03/23, 7:01‚ÄØam
From the moment we are born, we begin our journey towards death. Understandably this prospect often evokes intense fear. It is suggested that one can negotiate this fear in three ways: through knowledge as epitomized by Nachiketa, by adopting a path of bhakti like Markandeya and by sheer power of love as symbolized by Savitri.
During Karadaiyan Nombu which is observed today, women offer prayers for the longevity and wellbeing of their husbands and celebrate great encounter of Savitri and Yama, the God of Death.
Savitri was the daughter of the King of Madradesha. She was exceedingly beautiful and when she reached marriageable age, though many princes admired her, none of them came forward to marry her, overawed by her beauty. Her father told her to go forth and select her own husband. Savitri visited many kingdoms but could not find the husband of her choice. On her way back home, she saw a young man in a forest serving an old couple with utter devotion. She was immediately drawn to him and informed her choice to her father. When Narada heard about it, he informed her that the young man she had chosen, Sathyavan, had a very short life and would die after a year. Savitri‚Äôs parents were shattered on hearing this and requested her to reconsider her choice. A determined Savitri married Sathyavan and went to the forest and assumed her new role with great joy. But deep within, she was afraid and could not forget Narada‚Äôs prophecy. As the day of death drew near, she began to fast and offer prayers with utmost piety. Finally, on the dreaded day, she decided to accompany her husband when he went into the forest as she did not want to be separated from him even for a short while. Yama made his appearance and starting pulling Sathyavan with his noose. To his astonishment he saw Savitri following him and asked her to return back. But Savitri said that it was her dharma to accompany her husband everywhere and she could not give it up. Pleased with her words he granted her many boons with which she restored the kingdom and eyesight of her father in law. But she still continued to follow him. Finally, impressed by her intense devotion, Yama restored the life of her husband and blessed them.
Interestingly festivals are associated with particular type of food. Karadaiyan Nombu is no exception. On this day, a special dish ‚ÄòKaradai‚Äô is prepared from rice flour, black eyed peas, jaggery and coconut and it is believed that Savitri prepared this special dish and offered it with butter to Lord Yama as a thanksgiving gesture for returning the life of Satyvan.
There are few representations of Yama in sculptural form. This image is from Khajuraho and depicts a four armed Yama. His vehicle, buffalo can be seen on the lower right hand corner. If one looks carefully, one can notice a cock in his right hand. There is an interesting story behind it. One day Yama attempted to kick his mother in a fit of rage. Incensed by this, Sanjana, his mother cursed that he would have a perennial wound infested with maggots which would never heal. Heeding to his request, Surya granted him a cock which ate all the vermin in his leg. And hence the cock in his hand!
17/03/23, 7:49‚ÄØam
Born to Palestinian immigrant parents, Naomi has published more than fifty books. I particularly like her poem 'Kindness'
Here are few lines from it....

21/03/23, 6:41‚ÄØam
‚ÄòPoetry is painting that speaks,‚Äô Plutarch observed.
Throughout history, poets have painted their canvas with lyrical and idyllic verses.
The landscape of poetry in India is vibrant and multihued and there is a treasure trove waiting to be unearthed across languages.
On this World Poetry Day, let me share a poem by Malathi Maithri which has been translated from Tamil by Lakshmi Holmstrom.
OBSERVE THE CRANE
The crane waits
at the verge of the river-bed,
fish swimming in its memory.
In search of its reflection, the moon
wanders, vanishes.
Swirls of roots tear into the earth,
with hunger.
The wind, sweeping up its troubles,
hurls the heat in all directions.
Pulverized, the heart swirls
like dust in a storm.
It is not just the earth
that overflows through its cracks
in heat and rage.
The crane
absorbs into itself all that heat
and boils within.
If only the crane would sink into
the water swirling in its memory
and beat its wings,
the river might gather its form once more
from the scattered drops,
and walk again.
River, watch.
30/03/23, 7:33‚ÄØam
On the occasion of Sri Rama Navami let me offer you some glimpses from the Ramayana at the Amruteshwara temple in Amruthapura in Chikmagalur district. It is a small yet beautiful 12th century temple built by Amruteshwara Dandanayaka, during the reign of King Hoysala Veera Ballala II. On the south side of the parapet wall, the story of Ramayana is depicted in over seventy small panels.
This series of panels depict an episode from Kishkinda kandam which is the fourth book and one of the seven kandams in Valmiki's Ramayana. After Shabari tells Rama about Sugreeva, Rama goes in search of him and reaches Rishimukha mountain. Seeing Rama and Lakshmana, Sugreeva feels uneasy and wonders whether they were sent by Vali and asks Hanuman to meet them (Panel 1). Reassured that Rama and Lakshmana poses no danger, Sugreeva accompanies Hanuman and meets them. After listening to them, Rama promises Sugreeva that the wrong done to him would be redressed and that he would be reinstated as the king of the Vanaras (Panel 2). To imbue confidence in Sugreeva, Rama hurls his arrow which penetrates seven sala trees as well as the subterranean places of earth and returns to his quiver (Panel 3). Overcome with the immense prowess of Rama, Sugreeva submits himself to Rama, who urges him to challenge Vali for a duel. In their first encounter, Rama is unable to distinguish between the two and asks Sugreeva to wear a garland the next time, so that he could identify Vali. Rama then kills Vali (Panel 4). Rama reinstates Sugreeva on the throne as the king of Kishhkinda (Panel 5). Since the panels are quite small, zoom in to see the details!
Stories from Ramayana are an integral part of various art forms in India, whether it is music, dance or folktales. In Amruteshwara temple stories of Ramayana are imbedded in its architectural style. These intricately carved panels are like unfolding narratives which are sequentially depicted like chapters in a book before the advent of paper and print!
If you travel to Hampi, you can see a craggy hill on the south bank of the river Tungabadra, which is believed to be the Rishimukha Parvata where Hanuman is reported to have met Rama and Lakshmana.
30/03/23, 10:55‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for the repeat but with ornately carved sculpture üëåI read small portions of Ramayana every Tuesday and completed Sundara kanda today being Rama Navamiüôè
01/04/23, 8:03‚ÄØam
I have been listening to piano concertos of late and have been besotted with Rachmaninoff‚Äôs Piano Concerto No 2. It unfolds effortlessly and one is drawn deeply into its fluid, melodic notes. Rhythmic tones from the piano seamlessly and subtly flow into the orchestra. The momentum builds up with several delicate touches. It is full of emotional intensity and has a hypnotic effect on me.
I started reading about Rachmaninoff (whose birthday is today) and found that he was mentored by none other than Tchaikovsky. After Tchaikovsky‚Äôs untimely death, Rachmaninoff faced a setback in his career. His first major work Piano Concerto 1 was savagely criticized and he went to meet Tolstoy for some succour. To his great dismay he found Tolstoy to be emotionally distant and dismissive of his work. In throes of deep depression, he sought the help of Dr Nikolai Dahl, an internist in neurology who had a deep interest in Jean-Martin Charcot‚Äôs work with hypnosis and was using it in therapy. After several months of therapy, Rachmaninoff recovered his creative urge and composed Piano Concerto 2, which he dedicated to Dr Nikolai Dah. Full of passion, melancholy, yearning, and ultimately triumph, it remains till today as one of the most influential classical works.
In his own words, ‚ÄúMusic is enough for a whole lifetime, but a lifetime is not enough for music.‚Äù
https://youtu.be/yJpJ8REjvqo
02/04/23, 11:32‚ÄØam
There is an interesting sculpture of Hans Christian Andersen in Central Park, New York. It depicts the author of Ugly Duckling, reading a book with a duckling at his feet. Quite often, children climb on top of him and sit on his lap! Countless generations of children (and adults alike!) have grown up relishing his fairy tales. The Danish word for fairy tale is Eventyr and Hans Christian Anderson authored hundreds of them which continue have a universal appeal. He is the eighth most-translated writer in the world, trailing right behind Vladimir Lenin and his works have been translated in more than 125 languages.
Raised in poverty and having lost his father early in life, he had to work in a factory as a child to support his mother. He endured many hardships and suffered from countless fears and phobias. His greatest fear was one of being buried alive, something which disturbed him so much that he made a note every night before bed to alert anyone who found him that he was merely sleeping and not dead. In spite of all the adversities in his life, he was able to transform his pain into art and as he reflected: "Most of what I have written is a reflection of myself. Every character is from life. I know and have known them all"
Hans Christian Andersen (whose birthday is today) was much more than a children‚Äôs writer and multiple layers of meanings are embedded in his stories. He founded a genre that has a unique and enduring appeal.
04/04/23, 9:44‚ÄØam
On the occasion of Mahavir Jayanti, let us recollect and embrace these words from the Uttaradhyayan Sutra which is revered as Bhagwan Mahavira's last sermon.
I particularly like these words of His,
‚ÄúJust as a threaded (sasutra) needle is secure from being lost,
in the same way a person given to self-study (sasutra) cannot be lost.‚Äù
(Uttaradhyayana, 29/59)
This exquisitely carved panel is from Ranakpur temple
