‚ÄúLord Ram gave Hanuman a quizzical look and said, "What are you, a monkey or a man?" Hanuman bowed his head reverently, folded his hands and said, "When I do not know who I am, I serve You and when I do know who I am, You and I are One.‚Äù
‚Äï Tulsidas, Ramcharitmanas
Hundred pillar mandapam in Varadaraja Perumal Temple in Kanchipuram is a treasure trove. Each and every pillar is adorned with beautifully sculpted figures, like this one of Hanuman
07/04/23, 7:58‚ÄØam
It was late afternoon and as we were cruising through the Death Valley, a congregation of dark clouds rolled in over the blue sky. The sun peeped through the grey clouds caressing the mountains with swirls of golden hues. It was as if the rays were destined to create a great work of art on nature‚Äôs easel which poets often excel in expressing in words. I was reminded of Wordsworth‚Äôs poem, ‚ÄúComposed Upon An Evening of Extraordinary Splendor and Beauty‚Äù. He describes the magical sight of the glowing evening:
No sound is uttered,--but a deep
And solemn harmony pervades
The hollow vale from steep to steep,
And penetrates the glades.
Far-distant images draw nigh,
Called forth by wondrous potency
Of beamy radiance, that imbues,
Whate'er it strikes, with gem-like hues!
In the preface to his 1800 collection of poems, ‚ÄúLyrical Ballads,‚Äù he argued that men and women who live in close association with the natural environment are uniquely in tune with ‚Äúthe essential passions of the heart‚Äù because their very humanity is ‚Äúincorporated with the beautiful and permanent forms of nature.‚Äù He also lamented that this relationship has frayed over time and wrote in ‚ÄúThe World Is Too Much With Us,‚Äù
The world is too much with us; late and soon,
Getting and spending, we lay waste our powers;‚Äî
Little we see in Nature that is ours;
We have given our hearts away..
Lines to ponder on Wordsworth‚Äôs 253rd birthday today!
08/04/23, 10:16‚ÄØam
The Wind in the Willows by Kenneth Grahame (whose birthday is today), is an enchanting narrative woven around the adventures of four woodland animals, the Mole, the Water Rat, the Badger and an often mischievous Mr Toad. Though each of them is different from the other, the bond between them becomes stronger over time. It is an inventive, imaginative tale which can be read and interpreted at many levels. There is also a hidden subtext which conveys a moral or two, like the importance of fidelity, fortitude, being honest and the power of friendship.
Beyond the idyllic tone of the book, there is a poignant tale. The Wind in the Willows evolved from the bedtime stories that Graham narrated to his son, Alastair. Alastair was born premature and was partially blind. Since he was small and squinty, he was nicknamed ‚ÄúMouse‚Äù and had to endure ridicule and bullying all through his life which unfortunately did not end happily. One day at Oxford, where he was studying, he downed a glass of port and took a late night stroll. The next morning, his decapitated body was found on the railways tracks near the university. An inquest determined his death to be suicide but out of respect for his father, it was recorded as an accident. Grahame never recovered from the loss of his only child and became increasingly reclusive, eventually abandoning writing altogether.
The descriptions of nature in the book are truly wonderful. The narration is imbued with a love of nature with lyrical passages, like this one:
‚ÄúWhen tired at last, he sat on the bank, while the river still chattered on to him, a babbling procession of the best stories in the world, sent from the heart of the earth to be told at last to the insatiable sea.‚Äù
Incidentally, Chapter 7, ‚ÄúThe Piper at the Gates of Dawn‚Äù, is also the name of Pink Floyd‚Äôs first album in 1967.
10/04/23, 7:25‚ÄØam
Madness has engaged the attention of writers and thinkers for long and Kahlil Gibran (whose death anniversary is today) was no exception. ‚ÄúThe Madman‚Äù was his first published work in English. It is an innovative collection of over 30 parables and poems exploring what occurs once we strip away our masks to look within and bare ourselves to God. Gibran describes this state as one of both freedom and vulnerability. In his words, ‚ÄúI have found both freedom and safety in my madness; the freedom of loneliness and the safety from being understood, for those who understand us enslave something in us.‚Äù
Khalil Gibran continued this path of enquiry in his best remembered publication ‚ÄòThe Prophet‚Äô. In this book, he reflects on subjects as varied as love, death, self-knowledge, joy and sorrow, reason and passion, in simple yet philosophical language. It has been translated into forty languages and has sold a million copies worldwide. ‚ÄúThe Madman‚Äù continues to be read and cherished for its timeless understanding of our shared humanity.
Gibran, in his writings, has touched upon almost all the important areas of human life in relation to God, nature, and others, in an elegant, inspiring style.
Ultimately, Gibran‚Äôs poems urge the reader to contemplate and reflect on the profound truths of human existence.
The imagery in these lines from his poem, ‚ÄòOut Of My Deeper Heart,‚Äô is particularly stunning:
Out of my deeper heart a bird rose and flew skyward.
Higher and higher did it rise,
yet larger and larger did it grow.
At first it was but like a swallow,
then a lark,
then an eagle,
then as vast as a spring cloud,
and then it filled the starry heavens.
Out of my heart a bird flew skyward.
And it waxed larger as it flew.
Yet it left not my heart.
11/04/23, 7:53‚ÄØam
In 1791, Thomas Paine published a pamphlet, ‚ÄúRights of Man‚Äù. His main thesis was that humans have inherent rights such as freedom of expression, religion and freedom from persecution, and these have to cherished and protected. He wrote, ‚ÄúMan did not enter into society to become worse than he was before, nor to have fewer rights than he had before, but to have those rights better secured.‚Äù Among those who were inspired by these words was Jyotirao Phule (whose birthday is today). He was a person much ahead of his time and along with his wife Savitribai Phule, dedicated his life for the betterment of oppressed groups, including women and the marginalized castes. He fought against caste and gender hierarchy and the ideological and social structures that naturalises and perpetuates their discrimination.
The contribution of the couple for the advancement of the underprivileged is truly remarkable. They set up the first orphanage and home for widows. They were pioneers of women‚Äôs education in India and started the first girls school in Bhidewada, Pune. It was the first step in the long list of initiatives they took for the empowerment of women. They set up a care center called ‚ÄòBalhatya Pratibandhak Griha,‚Äô where widows and rape victims could deliver their children in a safe and secure environment. They also adopted a child who was born there. I particularly like his concept of Satyashodhak marriage system which is simple, inexpensive and shorn of religious rituals, much akin to Kuvempu‚Äôs Mantra Mangalya.
On this day, let us recollect and reaffirm these words of his , ‚ÄúThere cannot be a ‚Äònation‚Äô worth the name until and unless all the people of the land, such as Shudras and Ati-shudras, tribals and fishermen etc, become truly educated and are able to think independently for themselves and are uniformly unified and emotionally integrated.‚Äù
11/04/23, 11:14‚ÄØpm
Oh yes. We are blessed to have had such reformers and binding on our part to work on those lines.
12/04/23, 7:38‚ÄØam
Driving along the Big Sur where the winding road hugs the edge of cliffs that drop into an indigo blue ocean, is an incredible experience. One of the most amazing views is from the spectacular Bixby bridge, which soars above the cavernous Bixby creek. Down below, a rustic cabin in the Bixby canyon was the setting of an unusual book, Big Sur, by Jack Kerouac (whose birthday is today.) It is a biographical novel Kerouac wrote after the publication of ‚ÄòOn the Road‚Äô, when he was battling alcoholism and extreme depression. There are many lyrical passages like this in the book:
‚ÄúBut I remember seeing a mess of leaves suddenly go skittering in the wind and into the creek, then floating rapidly down the creek towards the sea, making me feel a nameless horror even then of 'Oh my God, we're all being swept away to sea no matter what we know or say or do‚Äù
Jack Kerouac along with his friends William Burroughs and Allen Ginsberg were considered to be part of the ‚ÄòBeat Generation‚Äô. Though the slang meaning of ‚Äòbeat‚Äô is one of being ‚Äòtired‚Äô, Kerouac gave a totally new interpretation and said that it is actually derived from the word ‚Äòbeatitude‚Äô, meaning ‚Äòblessedness‚Äô, something Kerouac searched for in vain all through his troubled life: ‚ÄúMaybe that's what life is... a wink of the eye and winking stars.‚Äù
15/04/23, 7:07‚ÄØam
A few years ago I got a book, the biography of Leonardo da Vinci by Walter Isaacson, as a gift. It is a magisterial account of the hugely talented, multitasker whose creative energy spanned many diverse domains. Leonardo (whose birthday is today), was a relentlessly curious observer of everything that was happening around him. In his words, there are three different kinds of people, ‚ÄúThose who see by themselves, those who see when someone has shown them and those who do not see.‚Äù His inquisitive mind wanted to know what causes people to yawn, how they walk on ice, what makes the aortic valves close and how light is processed in the eye. He even came up with the first description of arteriosclerosis as an outcome of the ageing process through dissecting the body of a hundred-year-old man. He made it a habit to record all his observations in thousands of notebook pages, known as codices.
There are two things that are distinctive in birds; their ability to fly and their song. As a birder, I am amazed at Leonardo‚Äôs keen observations of the flight of birds, which he recorded in detail in the Codex on the Flight of Birds. He made detailed drawings of birds as they soared, turned and manoeuvred in the wind. He wrote, "When a bird with a wide wingspan and short tail wants to take off, it will lift its wings with force and turn them to receive the wind beneath them." He was the first to document flight manoeuvres now called dynamic soaring. Birds use these manoeuvres to extract energy from the gradient of wind velocity for sustained flight. Leonardo described both horizontal and upward dynamic soaring as well as upward soaring in updrafts through detailed sketches. His description pre-dates by almost 400 years the first generally accepted explanation of the soaring technique by Lord Rayleigh in 1883.
No other figure in history was as creative in so many diverse fields as Leonardo. As Isaacson commented, ‚ÄúHis genius was of the type we can understand, even take lessons from. It was based on skills we can aspire to improve in ourselves, such as curiosity and intense observation. He had an imagination so excitable that it flirted with the edges of fantasy, which is also something we can try to preserve in ourselves and indulge in our children.‚Äù
Leonardo was a lifelong learner. In his words, ‚ÄúThe noblest pleasure is the joy of understanding.‚Äù
15/04/23, 8:08‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for the fantastic details of one of my favorites. His basic intellectual potential and creativity, and God given gift to use all parts of his brain. Simply superb.
16/04/23, 8:42‚ÄØam
I had posted about Leonardo da Vinci on his birthday, yesterday. The day is also celebrated as World Art Day to draw attention to the contribution of artists and to recognize profound importance of arts in enriching our lives. Art encompasses painting, sculpture, dance, theatre and film among others.
Whenever I visit a temple in India, I am astounded by the sheer ingenuity and skill of artists who embellish its precincts but remain largely unknown.
For example, this suavely sculpted figure brimming with exuberance is from the Chennakeshava temple at Belur, Karnataka. Replete with intricate and opulent ornamentation, it portrays a beautiful, dextrously balanced, dancing woman. There is an interesting element in this aestheticized, graceful sculpture. When a drop of water is made to fall from the tip of her right hand above the head, it would pass through her nose, her left breast, the tip of her left hand and finally reach the toe of her left leg! It is truly an epitome of perfection.
As I kept looking at the sculpture, I was fascinated with the inventiveness and imaginative creativity of the artist who chiselled a block of stone and brought it alive.
Ephemeral beauty
Emanates from stone
And melts into a sculpture
17/04/23, 8:22‚ÄØam
Years ago, our friend Dr Stuart Schwartz, gave us a book, ‚ÄòI Am That‚Äô by Nisargadatta Maharaj and mentioned as to how deeply it influenced his spiritual quest. It is not a book in the conventional format and is an account of Maharaj‚Äôs dialogues with seekers. The book is arranged in a question and answer format and covers many topics such as god, the ego, living in the world, free will. I have been dipping into this interesting book on and off, over the years. Often I start with chapter ‚ÄòAwareness is Free‚Äô and then onto chapters which focus on his spiritual experiences. He speaks consistently on the direct experience of "I am".
In the sixth chapter of the ‚ÄúChandogya Upanishad,‚Äù the 24-year old Shvetaketu returns home, 12 years after his father has sent him to study the vedas. The first question that Svetaketu‚Äôs father Uddalaka Aruni asks his son is whether he has returned with the knowledge of that by which ‚Äúwe perceive what cannot be perceived, we know what cannot be known.‚Äù Svetaketu answers in the negative, asking his father what that actually is. His father explains, using the famous Advaita precept: ‚Äòtat tvam asi‚Äô. Maharaj delves on this and expands this concept through dialogue with the seekers. There is so much similarity between his teachings and that of Ramana Maharishi.
The book is studded with poetic descriptions. On Nisargatta Maharaj‚Äôs birthday today, let me recall some of his observations:
"My teacher told me to hold onto the sense ‚ÄòI am‚Äô tenaciously and not to swerve from it even for a moment. I did my best to follow his advice and in a comparatively short time I realized within myself the truth of his teaching. In the stillness of the mind I saw myself as I am un- bound."
‚ÄúGive up all questions except one, "Who am I?" After all the only fact you are sure of is that you "are". The "I am" is certain, the "I am this" is not. Struggle to find out what you are in reality.‚Äù
Among many of his comments, one that deeply resonates within me is in this attached photograph of mine!
18/04/23, 9:17‚ÄØam
April 18 is celebrated as World Heritage Day, also known as the International Day for Monuments and Sites. It is dedicated to highlighting the importance of cultural heritage and raising awareness about the need to preserve historical sites and monuments.
On this day, let me draw attention to Vaikuntha Perumal Kovil, one of the most unique temples which is visited by very few, in Kanchipuram. When we stepped into its precincts on a cold morning, we found the whole temple shorn of any visitor, which gave us ample opportunity to savour its architectural legacy at leisure. The priest in the main sanctum informed us that the main temple consists of three floors, each one with Vishnu murtis in different poses; sitting, sleeping, and standing. Unfortunately, it is difficult to access the top two floors. The priest also mentioned that there was a secret underground tunnel from this temple all the way to Mahabalipuram!
A distinctive aspect of the temple is the pillared corridor surrounding the sanctum. The walls of corridors are embellished with stories, carved into them. Many of the panels have eroded with time and it can be difficult to identify them. Thankfully, before visiting the place, I had downloaded a scholarly and informative monograph about it, authored by Dr Minakshi in 1936. Interestingly, many of the bas reliefs trace the life and history of Nandivarman II, who built the temple. There are vivid depictions of battle scenes with elephants and soldiers, much like scenes of warfare depicted on the outer walls of the Bayon temple, which was built five centuries later in Siem Reap, Cambodia. I understand that the chronological, historical, narrative depictions in bas reliefs in Vaikuntha Perumal shrine is the first such attempt in temple architecture in India. In front of the sculpted walls there is an array of beautifully chiselled pillars in the shape of sitting lions.
Vaikuntha Perumal Temple is also referred to as Parameswaravinnagaram. Nandivarman II‚Äôs original name before his coronation was Parameswara and he named this temple after himself. It is the 56th Divya Desam dedicated to Lord Vishnu. There is a small shrine dedicated to the famous saint poet, Thirumangai Alwar, who wrote hymns in praise of the Lord and the king who built it. In one of the hymns he wrote:
‡Æâ‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡ØÜ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æ£‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æ≥‡Æø ‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æí‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ ‡Æµ‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æü‡Æ≤‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Øç
‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Æø ‡Æµ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æü‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æü‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÇ‡Æ¥‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ¥‡Æï‡Ææ‡ÆØ ‡Æï‡Æö‡Øç‡Æö‡Æø
‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ®‡ØÜ‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Æö‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ© ‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æ≥‡Øç
‡Æ™‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øã‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ£‡Æø‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ™‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øá‡Æö‡Øç‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æ∞ ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Æï‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Øá-
In essence, the hymn states that Parameswaravinnagaram, the abode of the Lord is surrounded by mansions filled with precious gems and is in the capital of the beautiful Kanchipuram where the Pallava king who won many a battle and destroyed enemies, surrendered to the Lord.
Temples are not merely places of worship in India. Steeped in history, they are also sites of dazzling expressions of elegant art and architecture, which need to be cherished and conserved.
19/04/23, 8:48‚ÄØam
Poetry has touched the lives of countless people throughout history. James Gates Percival once commented that ‚ÄúThe world is full of poetry. The air is living with its spirit; and the waves dance to the music of its melodies, and sparkle in its brightness.‚Äù Poetry And The Creative Mind Day which is observed today draws attention to the creative minds of poets and their art. The magic is in poetry‚Äôs ability to be intensely personal, yet unfathomably imaginative at the same time, like this one by Srilata.
LINES OF POETRY
Lines of poetry
break
like sudden light
on a black-winged crow,
descend
like song birds
on bare trees,
arrange themselves
in so many
whimsical spines,
word by fast flying word,
light
with meaning,
new
like unseasonable rain.
21/04/23, 11:15‚ÄØpm
Earth is preserved by such great people whether it is west or east. Or else this planet wouldn't have survived this long. Future no idea with this terrible climate change thanks for the selfish, narrow minded people. Thank you Sir, can go to bed with gratitude.
22/04/23, 8:00‚ÄØam
Today is Akshaya Tritiya, a day when people throng the jewellery shops to buy gold. The word ‚ÄòAkshaya‚Äô means ‚Äònever diminishing‚Äô and hence the belief that buying the precious metal on this day guarantees endless wealth.
Like many festivals in India, Akshaya Tritiya has several legends connected with it. It is an important day in Jainism and is associated with Adinatha, the first of the 24 Tirthankaras. Rishabadeva, king of Ayodhya gave up all earthly pleasures (much like Gautam Buddha), to lead the life of a monk as Adinatha. In order to live as a Jain monk, one must not possess anything, not even a morsel of food. When he started begging for food, his subjects offered him their most prized possessions like precious stones, elephants, horses but not food or drink which they thought was too modest an offering for their dear king. The king refused all the fine gifts and went without food and water until, finally, his grandson Shreyansha Kumara understood his need and offered him some sugarcane juice. With this juice, Adinatha broke his fast that had lasted 400 days.
It was on Akshaya Tritiya day that Adinatha broke his fast. As a mark of reverence to Lord Adinatha and his strict penance, Jains celebrate this day as ‚ÄúParna Diwas‚Äù after the penance of Varshi Tap and end their year-long alternative-day fasting with sugarcane juice.
This photograph is from Cave 4 at Badamai. Carved into its wall is a beautiful, life-size relief of Adinatha. He is standing in Kayotsarga pose, with unbent knees and straight arms, which are held at the side and do not touch the body. It is representative of an ascetic practice characterised by detachment of the physical body. Adinatha has locks of hair cascading down his shoulders and this is one of the ways to identify his sculpture. There is an interesting story behind this. When he chose to become an ascetic, Rishbadeva started pulling out his long strands of hair. After four fistfuls, when he was pulling out the fifth fistful of hair Indra is said to have told him, " This strand of hair on the crown of your head and hanging down over your shoulders looks attractive. Kindly leave it as it is." Rishabadeva agreed. Due to this bunch of hair he got the popular name; Keshariya ji (one with hair).
As for myself, I am a miner for gold‚Ä¶in the hearts of peopleÔÅä
25/04/23, 7:41‚ÄØam
All forms of aesthetic expression, including poetry, spring from the deepest, personal, inner self. It is essentially an adventure in selfhood. That said, we are living in an era in which selfhood has become fluid. The boundary between the ‚Äòreal self‚Äô and the ‚Äòimagined, virtual self‚Äô has become rather porous in the cyber world in which we are increasingly immersed in.
Poet, novelist, Robert Penn Warren, whose birthday was yesterday, observed presciently years ago that, ‚ÄúThe ideal of understanding men and telling their story, noble or victorious, will be replaced by the study of statistics or non-ideographic units of an infinite series, and computers will dictate how such unites, which do breathe and move, can best be manipulated for their own good‚Ä¶.the self we have is more and more a fictive self.‚Äù He observed that poetry has an important role in the integration of self, ‚Äúin the face of increasingly disintegrative forces in our society, poetry may affirm and reinforce the notion of the self‚Äù. He argued for ‚Äúthe creation of a new body of attitudes and values, a new assessment of our expanding technological capacities in relation to the context of nature‚Äù. He wrote very few nature poems and his ‚ÄúEvening Hawk‚Äù, is truly exceptional. He wrote:
From plane of light to plane, wings dipping through
Geometries and orchids that the sunset builds,
Out of the peak's black angularity of shadow, riding
The last tumultuous avalanche of
Light above pines and the guttural gorge,
The hawk comes.
His wing
Scythes down another day, his motion
Is that of the honed steel-edge, we hear
The crashless fall of stalks of Time.
The head of each stalk is heavy with the gold of our error.
Look! Look! he is climbing the last light
Who knows neither Time nor error, and under
Whose eye, unforgiving, the world, unforgiven, swings
Into shadow.
Long now,
The last thrush is still, the last bat
Now cruises in his sharp hieroglyphics. His wisdom
Is ancient, too, and immense. The star
Is steady, like Plato, over the mountain.
If there were no wind we might, we think, hear
The earth grind on its axis, or history
Drip in darkness like a leaking pipe in the cellar.
The poem is laden with rich metaphors, but personally I feel that no one has described the flight of a bird of prey in these exquisitely inventive words, ‚ÄúNow cruises in his sharp hieroglyphics‚Äù!
26/04/23, 8:37‚ÄØam
In 1836, Ralph Waldo Emerson (whose birthday is today) wrote an essay titled, "Nature". In it he recounted a mystical experience that he had while walking through the woods one afternoon. He experienced a deep kinship and communion with nature and wrote: ‚ÄúStanding on the bare ground, my head bathed by the blithe air, and uplifted into infinite space, all mean egotism vanishes. I become a transparent eyeball; I am nothing; I see all; the currents of the Universal Being circulate through me; I am part or particle of God.‚Äù For him nature is a spiritual experience that can be perceived intuitively. He observed, ‚ÄúThis transcendental experience is open to each one of us. It only requires that we spend time contemplating its meaning and significance in our lives‚Äù.
Emerson, along with Henry David Thoreau, belonged to the Transcendentalist movement which emphasized the need for an intuitive and ‚Äòpoetic‚Äô engagement with nature. In his words, ‚ÄúIn the presence of nature, a wild delight runs through the man, in spite of real sorrows. Nature says, he is my creature, and maugre all his impertinent griefs, he shall be glad with me‚Äù.
Emerson lead a very productive life and lived till 79. Travails of ageing and the prospects of end of life, did not deter him from penning these moving lines in his poem ‚ÄòTerminus‚Äô
As the bird trims her to the gale,
I trim myself to the storm of time,
I man the rudder, reef the sail,
Obey the voice at eve obeyed at prime:
‚ÄúLowly faithful, banish fear,
Right onward drive unharmed;
The port, well worth the cruise, is near,
And every wave is charmed.‚Äù
29/04/23, 6:50‚ÄØam
On the occasion of the World Sculpture Day, it is important to recognize that the sculptural tradition in India is the oldest in the world. It dates back to the Indus Valley civilization, where people made statues and figurines in terracotta and bronze. The iconic ‚ÄòDancing Girl‚Äô which was cast in bronze is a stellar example of their skill. This tradition has been kept alive throughout history all across the country, especially in places of worship. Intricate sculptures of gods and goddesses with scenes from mythology adorn almost every temple. Wide range of sculptural idioms flourished under the patronage of rulers. A compelling aesthetic sensibility imbued with unsurpassed technical brilliance radiates from many of these sculptures.
Incidentally today is also World Dance Day. The art of dance in India has always been intertwined with sculpture. In Chidambaram, the abode of the celestial dancer, the walls of passageway in all four gopurams are decorated with exquisite representation of 108 karanas. In Natya Shastra, Bharata Muni defines a Karana as: ‚ÄòHastapaada Samaayogah Nrittasya Karanam bhavet‚Äô. Each Karana is a combination of a specific movement of the legs (Charis) and hands (Nritta Hastas) performed in a particular posture (Sthana). These carvings provide us with tantalizing glimpses into the hoary sculptural legacy of our country.
Looking at awe inspiring sculptures like this, I often struggle to express my emotional experience in words. It is an amazing, inexpressible feeling. That said, it is painful to see the abysmal way in which many of these artistic treasures are maintained in many. The sculptural legacy of our nation is a vital part of our identity and each and every one of us has a responsibility to protect, nurture, and conserve these valuable repositories of our rich cultural heritage.
Our future lies in preserving our past‚Ä¶
01/05/23, 9:00‚ÄØam
The purpose of celebrating May Day is to recognize and honour the enormous contributions made by the working class and inform them of their rights, to protect them against exploitation.
During the Industrial Revolution of the 1800s, the United States experienced great turmoil in the labour sector. There were very few protections in place for workers, so many men, women, and children worked long hours, doing excruciating labour, causing many to die. This unrest came to a head on May 1, 1886, as more than 300,000 workers walked out in protest of poor working conditions and in support of an eight-hour work day in the United States. This labour strike marked May 1 as International Workers‚Äô Day as well. It started the eight hour movement, promoting a schedule of eight hours for labour, eight hours for recreation, and eight hours for rest.
The first May Day celebrations took place on May 1st 1890 after its proclamation by the first international congress of socialist parties in Europe on July 14th 1889 in Paris, France, to dedicate May 1 every year as the "Workers Day of International Unity and Solidarity."
In India, the first May Day was celebrated on May 1, 1923, in Madras. It was organised by the Labour Kisan Party of Hindustan. It was during this day, the prominent Communist leader Malayapuram Singaravelu Chettiar hoisted the red flag in Chennai.
Over the years, we are witnessing increasing internal migration of people in search of work, wherever they can find one. They play a pivotal role in our country. Living away from home is never easy. Many of them work without any contract without regular, assured pay. Nor does this section receive any meaningful help from the state.
On this May Day, let us strive to strengthen their invisible hands‚Ä¶
(This panel from the Bayon temple, Krong Siem Reap, Cambodia depicts a group of workers actively engaged in their task)
05/05/23, 8:05‚ÄØam
On the occasion of Buddha Purnima, let me dwell on the only sermon given by Buddha, in which he didn‚Äôt utter a single word. When he held up a flower, the whole congregation was silent, not understanding it‚Äôs significance, except one. Mahakasyapa looked at it intently and smiled. Buddha handed over the flower to him and said, ‚ÄúI have said what can be said and what cannot be said.‚Äù From that day Mahakasyapa became his successor.
In this ‚ÄòFlower Sermon‚Äô, Buddha drew our attention to the importance of direct experience, shorn of intellectual analysis. Flowers embody both form and formlessness. They arise from the earth and return to it, drawing attention to the formless consciousness of Oneness.
The simple act of seeing a flower can usher in a meditative state of intense awareness
William Blake said it wonderfully:
To see a World in a Grain of Sand
And Heaven in a Wild Flower
Hold infinity in the palm of your hand
And eternity in an hour
07/05/23, 8:43‚ÄØam
‚ÄòThe Gardener‚Äô is a beautiful poem of Tagore. When I was re-reading it today, on his birthday, I particularly adored these lines from its final stanza:
‚ÄúWho are you, reader, reading my poems a hundred years hence?
I cannot send you one single flower from this wealth of the spring, one single streak of gold from yonder clouds.
Open your doors and look abroad.
From your blossoming garden gather fragrant memories of the vanished flowers of an hundred years before.
In the joy of your heart may you feel the living joy that sang one spring morning, sending its glad voice across an hundred years.‚Äù
08/05/23, 6:07‚ÄØam
Many a time in our lives, invariably we will find ourselves alone. These states differ from being lonely. Alone is a way of being-in- the -world, whereas loneliness is tinged with feelings of abandonment. Solitude is the state of being alone without feeling lonely. As May Sarton commented, ‚ÄúLoneliness is the poverty of self; solitude is richness of self.‚Äù It is a positive and constructive state of engagement with oneself.
As I was strolling in the temple precincts at Avani, this particular sculpture caught my attention. It portrayed a man in silent repose. There was a sense of inexplicable inner peacefulness stemming from it. Watching it, I was reminded of the words of Swami Chinmayananda, whose birthday is today, ‚ÄúThere is no companion like solitude. One who knows how to tune himself to the inner silence, even in the midst of the din and roar of the marketplace, enjoys a most recreative solitude.‚Äù
As Lord Byron wrote, ‚ÄúThere is a rapture on the lonely shore‚Äù.
10/05/23, 10:14‚ÄØam
A very thoughtful distinction between solitude and loneliness. It's very important to go into silent mode and not engage in chattering of thoughts or people. A very unusual posture and sculpture Sirüëç
14/05/23, 9:50‚ÄØam
The Cloisters, a branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a unique and lovely museum situated on top of a hill in the northern corner of Manhattan. Visiting it is like travel through time as it replete with wonderful collection of medieval art. The artworks are so beautiful and mesmerizing and are an enduring testimony to the skill of the medieval artists‚Äô skills.
On the Mother‚Äôs Day, let me share a beautiful sculpture which caught my attention as I was strolling through the museum. It was a life size, immaculately detailed wooden sculpture of Anne on the birthing bed with her child Mary, dating back to 1480. The legends state that Anne was married to Joachim and they shared a devout life at Nazareth. Anne was deeply grieved by her barrenness and promised God that she would dedicate her firstborn child to the Lord‚Äôs service. The couple then received a vision of the angel, who announced that Anne would conceive and bear a most wondrous child, Mary.
St. Anne is considered the patron saint of mothers and also of women in labour.
14/05/23, 10:44‚ÄØpm
Wonderful wooden sculpture Sir. A close look at the figure, faces of mother and baby look so real. Mother's face is so calm, satisfied and the gesture of her hand...and the smiling baby.
21/05/23, 8:38‚ÄØam
The lure to get the brain to reveal its secrets is irresistible! Amongst those who made significant inroads into unravelling its secrets was Hans Berger, discoverer of electroencephalogram (EEG), whose birthday is today. There is an interesting background to his inclination to uncover secrets of the brain. In 1893, when he was 19, he fell off his horse during and was nearly trampled. On that same day, his sister, far away, got a bad feeling about him and she sent a telegram to her father asking if everything was all right. Berger felt that he had transmitted his thoughts to his sister somehow and called it as a case of ‚Äúspontaneous telepathy.‚Äù He strove to prove how telepathy worked, trying to measure mental activity through various means, but to no avail. He scrutinized blood flow and brain temperature before turning his attention to electrical output. His breakthrough finally came on July 6, 1924 when using a vacuum tube amplifier to enhance the electrical signals, he was finally able to spot a brain wave in a patient with skull injury. He took more than five years to report his findings in a complete form.
Hans Berger‚Äôs discovery of electroencephalography was a milestone in the advancement of neuroscience. Unfortunately, he gained neither acceptance nor recognition among his fellow contemporaries and there was also an uneasy relationship with the Nazi regime. His life took a dark turn when he was ousted from his research position at the university and forced into a non-research job at a nursing home. Convinced that he had a fatal heart disease and in throes of depression, Berger ended his life by hanging in 1941.
It is a daunting task for lonely pioneers who pursue their passion in the face of many obstacles. Often the inner loneliness and emotional turmoil is intricately interwoven with the creative impulse‚Ä¶
22/05/23, 10:21‚ÄØam
Arthur Conan Doyle, whose birthday is today, graduated from the University of Edinburgh Medical School and special interest in ophthalmology. It was no wonder then, that the main character in his works, Sherlock Holmes, was a very keen observer.
Careful attention to details is one of the important components of clinical medicine. Dr Shattner articulated the essential skills that a physician has to cultivate and summarized it in the acronym SOAPS:
S maintaining a Systematic approach
O using keen Observation
A Accessing relevant databases
P employing a Personal empathic attitude
S Shared decision-making
Sherlock Holmes‚Äôs famous deductions were based on his astute powers of observation. He often advised Watson that ‚ÄòIt is a capital mistake to draw conclusions without data.‚Äô He used to consult his meticulously compiled ‚ÄòIndex‚Äô and books from his library before arriving at conclusion. Though he is often portrayed as being detached, cold or remote, he was sensitive to his client‚Äôs circumstances and reached out to those in distress. All these form crucial components in clinical decision making. I often find myself quoting Holmes to my students to enhance their clinical acumen.
In the era of Evidence Based Medicine, we often rely on reliable sources of information to guide our clinical decisions. In the process, many a time we find ourselves bogged down in a morass of information. Unfortunately, we have to contend with limited storage space within ourselves. Arthur Conon Doyle employed an interesting metaphor ‚ÄòBrain Attic‚Äô, to highlight it. He wrote in the ‚Äò A Study At Scarlet‚Äô:
‚ÄúI consider that a man's brain originally is like a little empty attic, and you have to stock it with such furniture as you choose. A fool takes in all the lumber of every sort that he comes across, so that the knowledge which might be useful to him gets crowded out, or at best is jumbled up with a lot of other things, so that he has a difficulty in laying his hands upon it. Now the skilful workman is very careful indeed as to what he takes into his brain-attic. He will have nothing but the tools which may help him in doing his work, but of these he has a large assortment, and all in the most perfect order. It is a mistake to think that that little room has elastic walls and can distend to any extent. Depend upon it there comes a time when for every addition of knowledge, you forget something that you knew before. It is of the highest importance, therefore, not to have useless facts elbowing out the useful ones.‚Äù
A timely advice in the digital era!
23/05/23, 8:57‚ÄØam
Who can forget A Doll‚Äôs House? Henrik Ibsen (whose birthday is today) wrote the play in 1879. It was much ahead of its time in terms of challenging traditional gender roles in marriage. Nora, the heroine, has been a domesticated person all through her life, striving to do the best for her family. She gets tangled in messy circumstances because of the money she borrowed from a man of ill repute for her husband. Both the men try to control and manipulate her in their own ways. Fed up with all this, she starts questioning the foundation of everything that she believed in. Feeling betrayed and disillusioned that she has always been treated like a doll in her life, she decides to leave. Her husband strongly criticizes her move, saying that by deserting her husband and children she is forsaking her "most sacred duties". Nora tells him that the duties that are most sacred to her now are the "duties to herself". The play ends with her exit as she walks out slamming the door. It is an act of bold self-assertion. ‚ÄúI must stand quite alone,‚Äù Nora declares, ‚Äúif I am to understand myself and everything about me.‚Äù After playing the role of a doll, Nora begins the journey of self-discovery afresh.
Through this ending, Ibsen is fundamentally questioning the institution of marriage, gender and societal roles of women in an "exclusively male society, with laws made by men and with prosecutors and judges who assess feminine conduct from a masculine standpoint."
Nora's journey keeps continuing all around us..
While primarily known for his dramatic works he also wrote poems and he was described as a ‚Äòprofound poetic dramatist‚Äô. Snippets from one his poem,
WITH A WATER LILY
Tis the flower with the white wings.
Buoyed upon the quiet stream
In the spring it lay adream.
24/05/23, 8:37‚ÄØam
World Turtle Day is an annual event (that was celebrated yesterday) aimed at increasing public awareness about the important need to protect the shrinking habitats of turtle and tortoises.
Hindu mythology is replete with references to animals, including tortoise. Prominent among them is the churning of the ocean (Samudra Manthan), which appears in several texts such as the Mahabharata, Vishnu Purana and Bhagavata Purana. To churn the primordial ocean, Mount Mandara was used as a churning rod and the snake, Vasuki as the churning rope. The Asuras held the head of the snake and the Devas held its tail and they pulled his body alternately, causing the mountain to rotate and the ocean to churn. In the process, slowly Mount Mandara began to sink. Vishnu, in his second avatar as the tortoise Kurma, came to the rescue and supported the mountain on his shell. Without Kurma avatar it would not have been possible for the ocean to be churned and the devas would not have received the fourteen gifts. The churning also resulted in the poison, ‚Äòhalahala‚Äô, which was imbibed by Lord Shiva to protect the universe from destruction.
The tortoise, as a symbol of the earth also figures in several vedic and puranic texts. According to these representation, the tortoise‚Äôs domed shell is heaven and the flat underside is the earth. Further, the kurmanivesha (tortoise abode) is central to Hindu astrology, wherein the body of the tortoise would be divided up into nakshatras (constellations) that influenced the regions occupying a certain body part. For instance, the head often represented the eastern region of the earth.
Turtle is considered very lucky in astrology and it is believed that Goddess Lakshmi, showers blessings on those who wear the ‚Äòturtle ring.‚Äô
There are three temples in India where Kurma is the main deity: Srikumaram near Srikakulam, Gavirangapura near Hosadurga and Kurma Varadaraja Swamy temple in Chittoor district. Prominent among them is Srikurmam, where the presiding Deity, Lord Kurma is self-manifest, or svayambhu. He is about 70 cm long, shaped like the shell of a turtle. The Deity‚Äôs tail is a saligram presented by Adi Sankara. In the temple‚Äôs premises, a tortoise park has also been built to conserve the adult and young star tortoises, which are found in the foothills and fields of Srikakulam. A stellar example of conservation which is in tune with the cultural and religious beliefs of people..
Let me conclude with this beautiful verse in the Sangam poetry, Kurunthokai, where the poet wrote:
‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ¥‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Øã‡Æ∞‡Øá,
‡Æ§‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡Øà ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤ ‡Æâ‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æü‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡Æö‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æé‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æü‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Øã,
‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©,
‡Æï‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Æ± ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øá?
Those who chide me, know not a thing
my passion is like a hatchling of tortoise
sustained by its mother;
if my lover forsakes me, it‚Äôll wither
like an unhatched egg, for what else can sustains it?
(This photograph of Kurma Avatar is from a pillar at the hundred pillar mandapam at Varadaraja Swamy temple, Kanchipuram. Each pillar, adorned with exquisite carvings, is a treasure to savour)
(Kindly do not share the post with due acknowledgement!)
27/05/23, 9:50‚ÄØam
Ahalya presented a book of collected short stories of John Cheever, sometime in the 80s. Cheever (whose birthday is today), was an insightful chronicler of suburban alienation, much like John Updike. He was truly the American Chekov! Among all the stories in the collection, I found The Swimmer, an exceptional one.
When the story begins, Neddy, who is described as being near the prime of his life, decides to affirm his vitality by swimming his way home. With a ‚Äòcartographer‚Äôs eye‚Äô, he plans his way through the swimming pools of the neighbours. At first his journey goes smoothly. He does, however, run into various obstacles, physical as well as emotional. The pools get colder and harder to swim through. The neighbours become critical and less friendly. Fatigue overtakes him and he starts feeling lonely. Towards the end, he finds it difficult to swim and plods across the pools. Tired and feeling miserable, when he finally reaches his house only to find that it has been abandoned, his wife and children are nowhere to be found. He pounds on the door, peeps through the window and notices the house to be completely empty. At the end of his surreal voyage, his house is bereft of life. It is a moment worthy of a Greek tragedy.
The metaphor of journey is one of the most widely used elements in literature. Quite often too in our lives we realize that our journey in life is nothing like what we thought it would be when we started. As Haruki Murakami observed perceptively, ‚ÄúWhatever it is you're seeking won't come in the form you're expecting.‚Äù
And at any time, there will always be people banging at the doors of their lost dreams‚Ä¶
Cheever was also a keen observer of nature and his stories are replete with wonderful descriptions like this one from his novel ‚ÄòBullet Park‚Äô, about the red winged blackbirds and the loss of their migratory instincts:
‚ÄúBelow the house, near the grove of dead elms, there was a swamp where a flock of red-winged blackbirds nested each spring. According to the law of their species they should have turned south in the autumn but the number of bird-feeding appliances in the neighbourhood, overflowing with provender, had rattled their migratory instincts and they now spent the autumn and winter in Bullet Park in utter confusion. Their song‚Äîtwo ascending notes and a harsh trill like a cicada‚Äîwas inalienably associated with the first long nights of summer but now one heard it in the autumn, one heard it in the snow.‚Äù
27/05/23, 10:49‚ÄØpm
Beautiful bird caught by you Sir unawares. The lines have hidden facts of life. A journey seeming long is spent in expectations, many a times too short to reach. But once we get into the path of looking at the journey from a different perspective things start falling into their places.
28/05/23, 9:42‚ÄØam
Yesterday I had posted about the journey of life and its travails. It is a conspicuous fact that more and more people have been journeying to different parts of the country in search of jobs. It is an overwhelming reality. Sadly, they were one of the most vulnerable groups during the lockdown, as their very livelihood came to a complete standstill. The lockdown culminated in a never-seen-before reverse migration as people started making often perilous journey to their villages and homes. While middle class Indians were busy banging utensils, scores of migrants were on the road, braving hostile conditions and an unempathic government. It was the largest migration in India after the partition. Though there was no major connection between the exodus and a spike in infection, they were treated as outcasts, socially distanced. The movie ‚ÄòBheed‚Äô, is a poignant reminder of this human tragedy.
On this day when the new parliament is being inaugurated, we mustn‚Äôt forget that more than sixty thousand workers, majority of them migrant labourers were involved in its construction which began in the middle of a brutal second wave of covid pandemic.
29/05/23, 8:28‚ÄØam
As the Sengol is safely ensconced in a glass case and the debates, discussions and drama about it settles down, let me draw attention to a poet (whose birthdays was yesterday), whom I admire deeply, K Satchidanandan. His poems are fascinating excursions embellished with a deeply reflective, gentle voice. In his own words, ‚ÄúI mark my passage with words that smell life‚Äù.
I particularly like his poem ‚ÄòGandhi and Poetry‚Äô, which I am quoting in full:
One day a lean poem
reached Gandhi‚Äôs ashram
to have a glimpse of the man.
Gandhi spinning away
his thread towards Ram
took no notice of the poem
waiting at his door,
ashamed at not being a bhajan.
The poem now cleared his throat
And Gandhi glanced at him sideways
through those glasses that had seen hell.
‚ÄúHave you ever spun thread?‚Äù he asked,
‚ÄúEver pulled a scavenger‚Äôs cart?
Ever stood in the smoke of
An early morning kitchen?
Have you ever starved?‚Äù
The poem said: ‚ÄúI was born in the woods,
in a hunter‚Äôs mouth.
A fisherman brought me up
in a cottage.
Yet I knew no work, I only sing.
First I sang in the courts:
then I was plump and handsome
but am on the streets now,
half-starved.‚Äù
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs better,‚Äù Gandhi said
with a sly smile. ‚ÄúBut you must give up this habit
of speaking in Sanskrit at times.
Go to the fields. Listen to
The peasants‚Äô speech.‚Äù
The poem turned into a grain
and lay waiting in the fields
for the tiller to come
and upturn the virgin soil
moist with new rain.
Kindled by thoughts, fuelled by ink, poems like this have a way of finding their home within us
31/05/23, 7:44‚ÄØam
One day when I was a student at NIMHANS in late 1970s, my teacher and mentor, Dr RL Kapur asked me (which he often used to!) as to what book I was reading. I told him about an interesting book ‚ÄòDice Man‚Äô by Luke Rhinehart in which a man starts making decisions in his life, guided by chance, through the throw of the dice. He suggested that I read Jacques Monod‚Äôs ‚ÄòChance and Necessity‚Äô. Intrigued by the title, I set about searching for it. Not surprisingly, I found it in the Select Book Shop. When I mentioned the title, Mr Murthy walked over to an over stacked bookshelf and handed over the book to me. It was tough a reading at first. On subsequent, more careful reading I could discern the major themes of the book.
On ‚Äòchance‚Äô Jacques Monod comments, ‚ÄúIt necessarily follows that chance alone is at the source of every innovation, and of all creation in the biosphere. Pure chance, absolutely free but blind, at the very root of the stupendous edifice of evolution: this central concept of modern biology is no longer one among many other possible or even conceivable hypotheses. It is today the sole conceivable hypothesis, the only one that squares with observed and tested fact‚Äù. With regard to ‚Äònecessity‚Äô it refers to the fact that, ‚Äúthe enzyme must act as it does, catalysing a reaction with one substrate but not another, according to the constraints imposed by its structure‚Äù. He emphasizes that chance and necessity has to be subjected to scientific evaluation and that an objective stance, shorn of value judgements is an important requirement in the pursuit of knowledge. Pointing out to the crucial role of ethics of knowledge acquisition in modern science, the author makes an incisive comment that, ‚ÄúIn science, self-satisfaction is death. Personal self-satisfaction is the death of the scientist. Collective self-satisfaction is the death of research. It is the restlessness, anxiety, dissatisfaction, agony of mind that nourish Science‚Äù.
I read some more about the author and found out that he was a close associate of Albert Camus and that the book was the outcome of several hours of long discussions between the two.
Jacques Monod (whose birthday is today), was many things in his life: an aspiring orchestra conductor, hero of the French Resistance and was deeply involved in assisting scientists facing persecution in totalitarian regimes. He was often referred to as ‚ÄòCamus in a lab coat‚Äô.
Interestingly, chance played a significant part in his life. He was about to embark on a scientific expedition to Greenland when one of his colleagues from the faculty of natural sciences at the Sorbonne, convinced him to go to the California Institute of Technology in USA to study genetics on a Rockefeller scholarship. That chance decision saved his life, as the ship on which he was to travel with the expedition sank and there were no survivors!
01/06/23, 6:20‚ÄØam
Yesterday I had written about the role of chance and the throw of dice. The game of dice played a crucial role in the Mahabharata. The Kauravas (led by Duryodhana) challenged the Pa·πá·∏çavas to a game of dice and in the process robbed them of their kingdom, violated their queen Draupadi, and exiled them for thirteen years. As a consequence of these egregious acts, war between the two sets of cousins unfolded.
The dice game contained one of the most disturbing instances in the epic. When Draupadi underwent humiliation at the hands of the Kauravas, the elders who were present did nothing to stop the act. They chose to be passive witnesses to the horrendous act. Standing before her husbands and elders, humiliated and shamed, she questions Yudhi·π£·π≠hira, ‚ÄúWhom did you lose first, yourself or me?‚Äù This most poignant question was met with deafening silence. Draupadi comments, ‚ÄúIt is sad; in this vast assembly here, there are no elders in the true sense. The so called elders are unable say what is Dharma. There is neither Dharma nor Truth here‚Äù.
Why were the most eminent men in the hall blind to the immense suffering caused to Draupadi? The concept of dharma ruptured at that moment.
Pratibha Ray‚Äôs "Yajnaseni: The Story of Draupadi" is one of the most powerful narratives which unravels the dilemma and plight of Draupadi. The author gives voice to Draupadi‚Äôs angst, ‚ÄúFull of anguish and anger I was thinking: was woman merely man‚Äôs movable or immovable property? Being a woman did I not have the right even over myself, my own soul? If they had rights over this body of mine, did it mean they could do as they wished with me?‚Äù
The same question arises when one witnesses the plight and suffering of women wrestlers who brought glory to our country.
Wonder whether anything has changed at all? Draupadi continues to be slighted even today.
(This photograph which depicts the dice game from Mahabharata, is from a small panel in the Amruteshwara Temple at Amruthapura in Chikmagalur district)
01/06/23, 8:01‚ÄØpm
Very shameful incidence and on top of it Arjuna laments about waging a war against so called elders. Such a beautiful sculpture depicting the game a root cause for the war.
03/06/23, 8:46‚ÄØam
The bicycle was an important invention in the history of mankind. It is the first mode of transport that was powered by nothing more than our physical bodies and the forerunner of eco-conscious vehicles. Each one of us would have ridden a cycle at least once in our lives, fallen down in the process of learning, enjoyed the fresh breath of air as we balanced ourselves delicately and pedalled to discover.
The bicycle has also been an inspiring metaphor in movies.
In ‚ÄòBicycle Thieves‚Äô, it is a means of sustenance from overriding, abject poverty. When the protagonist loses it, his world is shattered and in an attempt to overcome it, he steals another one and gets thoroughly bashed up and humiliated in the process. The movie ends with the father and son, reduced to tears, walking away from the crowd, holding hands.
There is a different and interesting perspective in the Marathi movie ‚ÄòCycle‚Äô. When the cycle is stolen from the main character Keshav, the entire village grieves with him. The thieves soon realize how the villagers are so affectionate about the person and his cycle, and ridden with guilt, they write a letter to Keshav and return the cycle. When he passes by a dilapidated house with no rooftop, he finds the owner quite composed. When Keshav asks him, the house owner says, ‚Äúlast year when I was going through difficult times, I came to you for guidance; I still remember what you said then, don‚Äôt get stuck with things.‚Äù It is a moment of revelation for Keshav and he gifts his cycle to a child. Both the movies portray the cycle from different perspectives. In one, it is a need and a necessity to steer through daunting circumstances in life. In the other, a source of attachment and its loss, which is negotiated through inherent goodness in people.
The bicycle has also inspired the muse in artists. One of the most creative interpretation of the cycle is in Picasso‚Äôs sculpture, ‚ÄòBull‚Äôs Head‚Äô, which was crafted from a discarded seat and handlebars of a cycle. An astonishing metamorphosis in the hands of a genius.
As Arthur Conan Doyle commented, ‚ÄúWhen the spirits are low, when the day appears dark, when work becomes monotonous, when hope hardly seems worth having, just mount a bicycle and go out for a spin down the road, without thought on anything but the ride you are taking.‚Äù
I am posting this in admiration of our dear friend and an ardent cyclist Dr Mohan Raj, on the occasion of the World Bicycle Day
04/06/23, 12:46‚ÄØpm
The catastrophic train accident resulting in scores of deaths, is an unsurpassed human tragedy in recent time. Many more have been injured and the traumatic event will leave its footprints in their memory for long. Such terrifying experiences lurk deeply within, impacting emotional life and behaviour in myriad, unsettling ways. Coping with internalized trauma over time, is not an easy task.
WHR Rivers (whose death anniversary is today) in his pioneering work drew attention to the terrifying internalized experiences of traumatic memories, albeit in a different context, World War I.
River‚Äôs insightful observation was that traumatic memories were often repressed because there was a ‚Äúconflict between the mental tendencies of the individual and the traditional code of conduct prescribed by society‚Äù. He published an account of his work in the Lancet in 1918, stating: ‚ÄòNew symptoms often arise in hospital or at home which are not the immediate and necessary consequence of the war experience, but are due to repression of painful memories and thoughts, or of unpleasant affective states arising out of reflection concerning this experience.‚Äô
In dealing with these troublesome memories, Rivers emphasized the importance of a humanistic engagement with the traumatised patients, exploring the meaning of their experiences through ‚Äôtalking cure‚Äô. He employed what he termed as ‚Äòautognosis‚Äô, which was a two-part process. The first was focused on educating the patient and helping him to realize that the illness he was experiencing was neither ‚Äústrange‚Äù nor permanent. The second part was talk therapy, which involved discussing traumatic experiences at an in-depth level with patients and helping them to work through their painful experiences in more positive ways.
Notable amongst his patients the war poet Siegfried Sassoon, who wrote fondly of Rivers compassionate bedside manner in a poem which he sent to the poet Robert Graves:
But yesterday my reasoning Rivers ran solemnly in,
With peace in the pools of his spectacled eyes and a wisely omnipotent grin;
And I fished in that steady grey stream and decided that I
after all am no longer the Worm that refuses to die.
Pat Barker‚Äô ‚ÄòRegeneration Trilogy‚Äô gives a wonderful, fictionalized account of WHR Rivers and his monumental work with soldiers traumatized by the war
04/06/23, 5:44‚ÄØpm
Yes Sir. Heartrending scenes. But how many of those survivors how many migrant laborers get the opportunity to talk to a professional. What has affected the body is treated but mind??
05/06/23, 7:21‚ÄØam
It is a sad and uncomfortable truth that we have become alienated from the environment we live in. Environmental degradation in the guise of development is occurring at an increasing, unsettling pace. Hardly do we realize that the environment within and outside of us are deeply interconnected. Every day of our lives, our breath connects us to the environment. We gasp for fresh air in the midst of clouds of pollutants that hold their unrelenting sway over us.
World environment day draws attention to the need for a deep communion and communication between us and the environment. As Thoreau commented, ‚ÄúWhat is the use of a house if you haven't got a tolerable planet to put it on?‚Äù
Let us heed to the sanely advice of Theodore Roosevelt, who was instrumental in establishing 150 national forests, 51 federal bird reserves, four national game preserves, five national parks and 18 national monuments on over 230 million acres of public land: ‚ÄúHere is your country. Cherish these natural wonders, cherish the natural resources, cherish the history and romance as a sacred heritage, for your children and your children's children. Do not let selfish men or greedy interests skin your country of its beauty, its riches or its romance.‚Äù
06/06/23, 8:35‚ÄØam
Alexander Pushkin (whose birthday is today) is unquestionably Russia‚Äôs greatest writer and poet. Many consider him as the founder of modern Russian literature. In addition to being a master of the Russian language, he spoke ten other languages. His library in his St Petersburg apartment had over 4,500 books in 14 languages.
‚ÄòYevgeny Onegin‚Äô was his major work and a masterpiece. He completed the work during a course of three months when he was in forced quarantine during a major cholera outbreak. It is a story of love, loss, rejection and despair of Onegin, who wastes his life, allows the girl who loves him to marry another, and lets himself be drawn into a duel in which he kills his best friend. It is a novel in verse form and was the muse for Vikram Seth‚Äôs ‚ÄúGolden Gate‚Äô. Inspired by the novel, Tchaikovsky wrote a brilliant opera.
Throughout his life Pushkin took part in 90 duels and initiated 15 of them himself. One of those duels turned out to be his last when he was mortally wounded, defending his wife‚Äôs honour. He died with a substantial debt unpaid. Tsar Nicholas I, with whom Pushkin had a difficult relationship, ordered that the poet‚Äôs debt be paid off from the country‚Äôs treasury.
Pushkin‚Äôs oeuvre is unbelievably broad. He wrote classical odes, romantic poems, historical drama, novellas, short stories, fairy tales and travel journals. This poem titled, ‚ÄòA Little Bird‚Äô, is a favourite of mine:
In alien lands I keep the body
Of ancient native rites and things:
I gladly free a little birdie
At celebration of the spring.
I'm now free for consolation,
And thankful to almighty Lord:
At least, to one of his creations
I've given freedom in this world!
07/06/23, 6:39‚ÄØam
As we journey in life, often we pose a question to ourselves: Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going? A question that has been in the realm of philosophers down the ages. It was also the title of a famous painting by Paul Gaugin (whose birthday is today). He started working on it when he was beset with multiple problems; his health was failing, he was estranged from his wife and his daughter to whom he was deeply attached, died of pneumonia. In throes of deep distress, he started wondering about the meaning and purpose of his life. This massive painting was an expression of this search.
After finishing the canvas in feverish frenzy, he put down the brush, walked up a hill near his home in Tahiti and swallowed a huge amount of arsenic. But the arsenic failed to kill him.
He wrote a detailed note about this work and mentioned, ‚ÄúI believe that this canvas not only surpasses all my previous work, but that I will never do anything better or even like it. Before dying I put into it all my energy, a passion so painful, in terrible circumstances, and a vision so clear, needing no correction, that the hastiness disappears and life surges up‚Ä¶I have finished a philosophical work on this theme, comparable to the Gospels‚Äù.
Often, while looking at paintings like this, I wonder, how does a painting begin in an artist‚Äôs mind, unravel itself in forms and colours, find its way within us and does this each and every time we look at it?
08/06/23, 7:40‚ÄØam
I have enjoyed watching Anthony Bourdain‚Äôs shows. His gastronomical pursuits often in exotic locales with his cocky commentaries were always fun to watch. Hence it was a surprise that he took his life on this day five years ago.
Every suicide is a mystery and tragedy unto itself. There is often a background against which the act is enacted. There were indications of simmering emotional distress which Bourdain himself acknowledged. ‚ÄòSpirals of depression‚Äô, left him lonely and exhausted. Only once he met up with a therapist in Buenos Aires, which was aired in a 2016 ‚ÄúParts Unknown‚Äù segment. ‚ÄúI can find myself in a spiral of depression that can last for days,‚Äù he tells the therapist and goes on to add, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an isolating feeling. I communicate for a living but I‚Äôm terrible at communicating with the people I care about.‚Äù He also shared with the therapist, a recurring dream he had been having that involved him being stuck inside a Victorian-style hotel with ‚Äúendless rooms and hallways, where he could never check out.‚Äù He recalled wanting to go home during the dream, but never being able to remember where his home actually was.
The dream is so poignant reflecting the travails of a media star who was wandering from place to place, shooting episodes in far off locations and haunted by crushing loneliness. He seemed to have lived an untethered existence.
It is tragic that even though he acknowledged his emotional distress, he never sought proper professional assistance and that too in a country where every source of help is was available. Media stars lead a double life. Their public image is often in stark contrast to their private lives. Once the gulf widens, they unfortunately get trapped within the image while their angst and distress remain in the realm of ‚ÄúParts Unknown‚Äù. This incidentally was the title of his popular show.
As Kay Redfield Jamison wrote in her book, ‚ÄòNight Falls Fast: Understanding Suicide‚Äô, ‚ÄúSuicide is not a blot on anyone‚Äôs name; it is a tragedy‚Ä¶.each way to suicide is its own: intensely private, unknowable, and terrible. Suicide will have seemed to its perpetrator the last and best of bad possibilities, and any attempt by the living to chart this final terrain of life can be only a sketch, maddeningly incomplete ‚Äù
08/06/23, 2:07‚ÄØpm
Wonderful artists but their own challenges. What they depict, the depth of their work and mind, probably is not something which everyone understands. The gap is so overwhelming for them. It is so sad that they end their lives but do they?
09/06/23, 7:52‚ÄØam
There is something magical about oceans. Sometimes it is calm and welcoming. It is a soothing experience to hear the sea water gently caressing the sandy shores. It has other moods too, when suddenly huge waves crash onto the shores with renewed vigor. It is playful when it catches you unaware, stroking your feet with a warm spray as you walk carefully along the edges, trying to keep your feet clean. Sometimes when I see plastic bottles and trash thrown carelessly on its shore, I wonder whether it is weeping silently, within. Whatever way I strive to describe it, there is always something that eludes me.
When its water touches me, I am aware that I am touching eternity.
The poet Nayyirah Waheed articulated this feeling beautifully:
‚Äúif
the ocean
can calm itself,
so can you.
we
are both
salt water
mixed with
air.‚Äù
(Yesterday was the World Ocean Day)
10/06/23, 8:45‚ÄØam
This post is about a diminutive, captivating temple. Since it is a bit long, I‚Äôve posted it in my website. Take time over the weekend, savour it and feel free to share your perceptions in the blog: https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/mesmerizing-melakadambur
12/06/23, 10:43‚ÄØam
National Red Rose Day is celebrated on June 12, to pay tribute to one of the most iconic symbols of love and romance throughout history.
In Greek myth, roses are closely linked with Adonis, the lover of Aphrodite. One day, Adonis was gored by a wild boar during a hunting trip and died in Aphrodite‚Äôs arms as she wept; the first red roses were said to have sprung up from his blood as it soaked into the earth, staining the nearby white roses a deep crimson. Red roses came to be inextricably linked to romantic love, highlighting that such love transcends death and lives on beyond the lovers‚Äô own short lives.
Interestingly, in three different languages, Spanish, Portuguese and French, the word ‚Äòrose‚Äô means ‚Äòred‚Äô!
12/06/23, 10:53‚ÄØpm
Though it is saddening to note the deep side of depression, very heartening to note how it can be worked through.
13/06/23, 8:44‚ÄØam
Long ago when I was on a Commonwealth Fellowship in London, I was staying on the outskirts of the city which involved lengthy commute by the tube. During all these travels, what kept me company were poems that were strategically placed on posters and billboards across the tube stations. I was introduced to many a poet and WB Yeats (whose birthday is today), was one among them. I particularly liked this poem of his:
HE WISHES FOR THE CLOTHS OF HEAVEN
Had I the heavens' embroidered cloths,
Enwrought with golden and silver light,
The blue and the dim and the dark cloths
Of night and light and the half-light,
I would spread the cloths under your feet:
But I, being poor, have only my dreams;
I have spread my dreams under your feet;
Tread softly because you tread on my dreams.
How can one forget these lines from his poem, ‚ÄòThe Second Coming‚Äô:
Turning and turning in the widening gyre
The falcon cannot hear the falconer;
Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold;
Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world,
The blood-dimmed tide is loosed, and everywhere
The ceremony of innocence is drowned;
The best lack all conviction, while the worst
Are full of passionate intensity.
The last two lines are unsettling true, even now‚Ä¶
14/06/23, 5:23‚ÄØam
Memory is an intrinsic part of our everyday lives. We are what we remember and what we forget too. Our brains are designed to forget things. Many a time when I try to recollect things, I can sense the chaos in my neuronal circuitry!
Is it possible for someone to remember everything in his life?
The first documented case of extraordinary memory was by the celebrated Russian psychologist Alexander Luria. Starting in the 1920s, the person whom he studied was able to remember long sequences of numbers and details many years after hearing them. After studying the person for more than 30 years, Luria confessed his inability to find a limit to his memory, a surprising statement considering that it came from one of the foremost psychologists of his time.
In the realm of literature, there is an interesting short story ‚ÄòFunes The Memorious‚Äô, by Jorge Luis Borges, who died on this day in 1986. It narrates the travails of Ireneo Funes, who after falling off a horse and hitting his head hard, recovers consciousness with the incredible ability or perhaps curse, of remembering absolutely everything. Borges suggests that this kind of extraordinary memory has its own pitfalls. Says Fune, ‚ÄúI alone have more memories than all men may have ever had since the world exists. My memory, sir, is like a rubbish heap.‚Äù
Borges goes on to write, ‚ÄúOf the magical compadrito of my story I can state that he is a precursor to supermen, a suburban, incomplete Zarathustra; what cannot be denied is that he is a monster.‚Äù
In the era of ChatGPT and AI, ‚ÄòFunes the Memorious,‚Äô the story about a man who remembers everything, but understands nothing seems so visionary!
Borges also wrote some captivating poems, like this one about the tiger:
THE OTHER TIGER
A tiger comes to mind. The twilight here
Exalts the vast and busy Library
And seems to set the bookshelves back in gloom;
Innocent, ruthless, bloodstained, sleek
It wanders through its forest and its day
Printing a track along the muddy banks
Of sluggish streams whose names it does not know
(In its world there are no names or past
Or time to come, only the vivid now)
And makes its way across wild distances
Sniffing the braided labyrinth of smells
And in the wind picking the smell of dawn
And tantalizing scent of grazing deer;
Among the bamboo's slanting stripes I glimpse
The tiger's stripes and sense the bony frame
Under the splendid, quivering cover of skin.
Curving oceans and the planet's wastes keep us
Apart in vain; from here in a house far off
In South America I dream of you,
Track you, O tiger of the Ganges' banks.
It strikes me now as evening fills my soul
That the tiger addressed in my poem
Is a shadowy beast, a tiger of symbols
And scraps picked up at random out of books,
A string of labored tropes that have no life,
And not the fated tiger, the deadly jewel
That under sun or stars or changing moon
Goes on in Bengal or Sumatra fulfilling
Its rounds of love and indolence and death.
To the tiger of symbols I hold opposed
The one that's real, the one whose blood runs hot
As it cuts down a herd of buffaloes,
And that today, this August third, nineteen
Fifty-nine, throws its shadow on the grass;
But by the act of giving it a name,
By trying to fix the limits of its world,
It becomes a fiction not a living beast,
Not a tiger out roaming the wilds of earth.
We'll hunt for a third tiger now, but like
The others this one too will be a form
Of what I dream, a structure of words, and not
The flesh and one tiger that beyond all myths
Paces the earth. I know these things quite well,
Yet nonetheless some force keeps driving me
In this vague, unreasonable, and ancient quest,
And I go on pursuing through the hours
Another tiger, the beast not found in verse.
16/06/23, 7:43‚ÄØam
For me nature is home. Being amidst it, soothes my soul. In the midst of tall trees, expansive grasslands, I feel suffused with an indescribable, subtle calmness and peace. It is a meditative experience.
Sometimes I translate what I experience through the camera , which incidentally, is not a high end one. Like all translations, often it may be a poor representation of what I see through my own lenses of perception. I have inscribed those moments within the coils of my neurons and cherish them deeply.
Nature can be very astounding. In the middle of a vast dry desert landscape strewn with barren hills, suddenly one comes face to face a burst of resplendent colours or rocky surfaces. This radiant, multihued mountain landscape is not surprisingly called, The Artist Palette!
(15th June was the National Nature Photography Day)
18/06/23, 11:47‚ÄØam
Such a beautiful sculpture feel like touching them. And what a statement....
19/06/23, 10:39‚ÄØam
Walking has a long history. Ever since our earliest hominids took the first bipedal steps, we have not stopped walking! Walking has served as a tool for political protests, affirmation of civil, human rights and in quest of the divine. The simple act of putting one step ahead of the other has also been medicalized over time. Physicians emphasize its health benefits and each and every smartphone has an app to count the number of steps taken during walking. One can often notice people with headphones striding briskly keeping pace with the magical number of healthy steps.
In 1862 David Thoreau‚Äôs wrote an interesting essay titled ‚ÄòWalking‚Äô. In it, he drew attention to the difference between walking and sauntering. When we walk, we concentrate on pace or getting somewhere, as quickly as possible. Sauntering is vastly different. When we saunter, we pause, look around, listen and immerse ourselves in the world outside. Thoreau observed that the word saunter might have originated with those who took pilgrimages to the Holy Land, the sainted land: ‚Äòsainte terre‚Äô. Or perhaps from the idea of being without land ownership, ‚Äòsans terre‚Äô, which, for him, meant having no particular home but being ‚Äúequally at home everywhere.‚Äù The trick, according to Thoreau, is not to take your inside life out but to go present and empty.
We often rush through our lives. How much better it would be to "saunter" along this trail of life, lingering hither and thither, pausing for a while in the company of trees, listening to the melodies of the wind as it courses through the leaves, keeping an ear for the songs of the birds and watch petite flowers growing?
In the words of Simon and Garfunkel:
Slow down, you move too fast
You got to make the morning last
Just kicking down the cobblestones
Looking for fun and feeling groovy
Ba da-da da-da da-da, feeling groovy
Hello lamppost, what'cha knowing
I've come to watch your flowers growin'
Ain't you got no rhymes for me?
Doo-ait-n-doo-doo, feeling groovy
Ba da-da da-da da-da, feeling groovy
I got no deeds to do, no promises to keep
I'm dappled and drowsy and ready to sleep
Let the morningtime drop all its petals on me
Life, I love you, all is groovy
(Notes on the World Sauntering Day!)
21/06/23, 8:53‚ÄØam
In Bhagavat Gita, Chapter 6, Dhyana Yoga, Sri Krishna outlines the processes of Ashtanga Yoga, lucidly, in verses 20-23
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ |

yatroparamate chitta·πÅ niruddha·πÅ yoga-sevayƒÅ
yatra chaivƒÅtmanƒÅtmƒÅna·πÅ pa≈õhyann ƒÅtmani tu·π£hyati
When the mind, restrained from material activities, becomes still by the practice of Yoga, then the yogi is able to behold the soul through the purified mind, and he rejoices in the inner joy.
‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
