sukhamƒÅtyantika·πÉ yattad buddhigrƒÅhyamatƒ´ndriyam
vetti yatra na caivƒÅya·πÉ sthita≈õcalati tattvata·∏•
When he (the Yogi) feels that Infinite bliss which can be grasped by the (pure) intellect and which transcends the senses he never moves from the Reality;
‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•¨-‡•®‡•®‡••
ya·πÉ labdhvƒÅ cƒÅpara·πÉ lƒÅbha·πÉ manyate nƒÅdhika·πÉ tata·∏•
yasminsthito na du·∏•khena guru·πáƒÅpi vicƒÅlyate
Which, having obtained, he thinks there is no other gain superior to it; wherein established, he is not moved even by heavy sorrow.
‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§æ ‡•• ‡•¨-‡•®‡•©‡••
ta·πÉ vidyƒÅd du·∏•khasa·πÉyogaviyoga·πÉ yogasa·πÉj√±itam
sa ni≈õcayena yoktavyo yogo‚Äônirvi·πá·πáacetasƒÅ
Let it be known: the severance from the union with pain is Yoga. This Yoga should be practised with determination and with a mind steady and undespairing.
(This small, exquisitely carved wooden panel is from Thirukkurungudi Temple, Tirunelveli)
22/06/23, 10:48‚ÄØam
There is something surreal about venturing into a rainforest. It was quite sunny when I entered the forest, but soon I was enveloped in darkness with sun peering through the tall trees occasionally. It was humid inside and the noisy cicadas showered me with their squirts of fluid, like raindrops. I made my way gingerly amongst the moist leaves and broken branches in the forest floor. Birds kept fluttering by but it was difficult to observe them clearly in the dense foliage. The Japanese have a wonderful word to describe the experience, ‚Äòshinrin-yoku‚Äô or ‚Äòforest bathing‚Äô. It refers to the contemplative experience of being immersed in the sights, sounds and smells of the forest.
Rainforests are cradles of biodiversity. Unfortunately, their loss continues, unabated at a blistering pace. As EO Wilson commented, ‚Äúdestroying rainforests for economic gains is like burning a renaissance painting to cook a meal‚Äù.
The rainforests hold answers for many of the question that besiege us in an era of escalating global warming. The problem is that we turn a deaf ear to them.
A world without rainforest is akin to a man without lungs.
Let us wander into the rainforest where the wifi is weak, discover its magic, feel and cherish the connection to Mother Earth.
(Today is the World Rainforest Day)
25/06/23, 11:50‚ÄØam
Today is the Global Beatles Day, which was created by a fan of the band, Faith Cohen. It was selected because on this date in 1967, the band participated in Our World, a program on the BBC that was broadcast to a global audience. They performed their song ‚ÄúAll You Need Is Love.‚Äù
It is remarkable how four dissimilar men came together to create music that is timeless. Whether raucous or reflective, there is immense beauty and enduring magic in their music. Ahalya and myself are unabashed aficionados of Beatles and listen to them often to revive our spirit and love of life.
26/06/23, 10:01‚ÄØam
Kailasanathar temple in Kanchipuram is replete with some of the most exquisite sculptures, each one of them deftly chiseled. As I was going around the temple, this figure caught my attention. Carved out of sandstone, it‚Äôs lower half has eroded over time. Sometimes brokenness has the power, unlike anything else, to bring forth the hidden loveliness. The serene face seems to emerge from the scarred surface with a delicate charm and beauty.
As we course through life, we invariably bear scars. In ‚ÄòThe Winter of Our Discontent‚Äô, John Steinbeck wrote ‚Äúto be alive at all is to have scars‚Äù. Seared with scars, we strive to weather the storms of life with renewed resilience. Scars sculpt us into what we can be.
28/06/23, 9:39‚ÄØam
Akkamahadevi was a poet, saint, wanderer, mystic and seeker and her vachanas are passionate dialogues expressing her spiritual quest to unite with her Lord Chennamallikarjuna. In her journey in search of the divine, she found her home in the lap of nature amidst the dense forests of Kadali in the Srisaila mountain ranges of Andhra Pradesh and merged into the infinite.
Many of her vachanas abound with vivid descriptions of nature in which she converses with chirping birds, dancing peacocks and butterflies, asking them whether they have seen her divine lover. The very word she used to address her beloved Shiva was Chennamallikarjuna, which AK Ramanujam translated as ‚ÄúLord, white as jasmine‚Äù.
Whenever I venture into a forest, this vachana of Akkamahadevi (which I have outlined in the photograph) wherein she experiences all of nature as a manifestation of the Lord Chennamallikarjuna, resonates deeply within me.
When the inner and outer world merge, we embrace the divine ‚ÄòOneness‚Äô.
29/06/23, 12:44‚ÄØpm
Very true Sir. She considered Lord Shiva as her consort and not a human like Andal, Meera. Her vachana Tanukaragadavaralli is my favorite song.
üëá I want you to listen to her perspective but is in Kanmada which appealed to me.
02/07/23, 8:56‚ÄØam
What draws me to Hermann Hesse (whose birthday is today), is his emphasis on self-realization in his novels. The quest for authentic self is a continuing strand in most of his works. The greatest example of it is of course, his slender novel, Siddhartha. The protagonist wanders through ancient India, in pursuit of an enlightened way of life, during the course of which he experiments with both spartan asceticism and luxurious hedonism. In the book‚Äôs most important scene, Siddhartha actually encounters the Buddha, but spurns him as he perceives that any kind of religion is an obstacle to enlightenment. ‚ÄúNo one will ever attain redemption through doctrine! After all, the Buddha didn‚Äôt become the Buddha by following the Buddha!‚Äù Eventually, he finds spiritual wisdom by contemplating the flow of a great river and realizes that one can discover the true self only through wading alone in the waters of consciousness.
Hermann Hesse underwent two spells of therapy with Jung. In his diary, he recorded some advice that the renowned analyst gave him. ‚ÄúLife‚Äôs problems aren‚Äôt there to be cleanly solved, each of them is a pair of opposites, that between them produce a tension that is called life‚Äù.
Hermann Hesse was also a keen observer of nature, especially trees. He wrote:
‚ÄúFor me, trees have always been the most penetrating preachers‚Ä¶ in their highest boughs the world rustles, their roots rest in infinity; but they do not lose themselves there, they struggle with all the force of their lives for one thing only: to fulfil themselves according to their own laws, to build up their own form, to represent themselves. Nothing is holier, nothing is more exemplary than a beautiful, strong tree.‚Äù
03/07/23, 11:58‚ÄØam
There are three kinds of teachers, in the context of spiritual education: Upadhyaya, Acharya, and Guru. Upadhyaya is one who teaches as a means of livelihood. Acharya is a preceptor who is a teacher and a guide. Guru is one who apart from imparting knowledge, guides the student to the path of liberation.
Advayataraka Upanishad which is one of the 19 Upanishads attached to the Shukla Yajurveda, gives a description of the Gure in verse 16:
‡§ó‡•Å‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•ß‡•¨‡••
The syllable Gu indicates darkness, the syllable Ru means its dispeller,
Because of the quality of dispelling darkness, the Guru is thus termed.
Four types of speech are described in ancient literature: verbal, mental, visual, and the transcendental. The verbal communication called as Vaikari. Higher than Vaikhari is Madhyama which is non-verbal communication through thoughts. Still advanced is Pashyanti which is communication through visual imagery, the person is made to ‚Äúsee‚Äù through the inner eye. The greatest form is ‚ÄúPara‚Äù which is ‚ÄúSilence,‚Äù where communication is without words, thoughts, or visions. It is kind of inner, intuitive, transcendental knowledge which is taught by Dakshinamurthy.
In every Siva temple the stone image of Dakshinamurthy is installed, facing south, on the southern circumambulatory path around the sanctum sanctorum. Perhaps, of all Hindu Gods, he is the only one sitting facing south.
This depiction of Dakshninamurthy is in the ceiling of Lokamahadevi temple at Pattadakkal. He is in a serene, meditative stance, yoga patta across him, with one leg on top of apasmara, flanked by two rishis and rishi patnis.
‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ú‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É
The one who is the abode of all the knowledge, who is the healer of the diseased
The Guru to all the lokas, Salutations to you, Lord Dakshinamurthy
Dr Raguram
04/07/23, 9:01‚ÄØam
A few years ago, I visited Belur math and expressed a desire to see the room where Swami Vivekananda used to reside. The room was facing the Ganga and the river was flowing gently caressed by the morning sun. It was such a serene setting and I could imagine the Swami meditating, absorbed in the scenic beauty of the river. The room was full of various objects and artefacts used by him, including a pakhawaj and tanpura. There was a bed on the floor with a garlanded photograph of his.
This was the place where the Swami passed away on this day, at the age of thirty nine years, five months and twenty four days. He embraced death, free of any fear or apprehension. He remarked to his devotees, ‚ÄúI shall never see forty‚Ä¶ I delivered my message and I must go‚Ä¶ The shadow of a big tree will not let the smaller trees grow up. I must go to make room.‚Äù In one of his letters to his disciples, he commented, ‚ÄúComing and going is all pure delusion. The soul never comes nor goes. Where is the place to which it shall go, when all space is in the soul? When shall be the time for entering and departing, when all time is in the soul?‚Äù
One of the most popular saying of Swami Vivekananda is ‚ÄúArise, Awake, and stop not till the goal is reached.‚Äù This has its origin in Katha Upanishad. In Katha Upanishad, chapter 1.3.14, we see Yama suggesting Nachiketa‚Äî
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§§,
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§™‡§•: ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø |
Arise! Awake! Approach the great and learn.
Like the sharp edge of a razor is that path,
so the wise say‚àíhard to tread and difficult to cross.
As Swami observed, ‚ÄúSharp as the blade of a razor, long and difficult and hard to cross, is the way to liberation. The sages have declared this again and again. Yet do not let any weakness or failure bind you. The Upanishads have declared, ‚ÄòArise! Awake! and stop not until the goal is reached.‚Äô Cross the path, sharp as it is like the razor, however difficult it may be‚Äù.
06/07/23, 9:15‚ÄØam
Years ago, I had the privilege of seeing a comprehensive retrospective of the paintings of Frida Kahlo at the Museum of Modern Art in San Francisco. Commemorating the centennial of the artist‚Äôs birth, it brought together paintings that spanned her entire career, along with a selection of her own collection of photographs, most of which have never been on public display. Both Ahalya and myself spent several hours going through the galleries and it was an experience to cherish.
Frida Kahlo (whose birthday is today) was a remarkable woman. When she was 18, she was nearly killed in an accident and an iron handrail went into her hip and came out the other side. On top of this, she also broke her spinal column, collarbone, ribs, pelvis, right leg in eleven places, and dislocated her shoulder. Although she did eventually recover, she had to have 35 operations over her life to help with her spinal injuries, and she lived with chronic pain. Sitting in her bed with a specially designed easel, she took recourse to painting and gave expression to her persistent suffering. Frida created 143 paintings including 55 self-portraits. She was perhaps the first artist to extensively portray haunting struggles with pain, injury and disability.
Filled with vivid imagery, her painting ‚ÄòThe Broken Column‚Äô is a literal depiction of her physical and psychological wounds. It portrays a crumbling ionic column shooting through her torso, representing the spinal injuries she suffered in a bus accident and the dozens of subsequent surgeries she had to undergo. She is encased in restrictive metal corsets which she had to wear all through her life. Nails are embedded throughout her body, connoting her enduring tryst with pain.
She died when she was just 47. A few days before her death, she wrote in her diary: ‚ÄúI hope the exit is joyful, and I hope never to return‚Äù.
When Ajit asked me to give a talk on ‚ÄòArts and the Mind‚Äô, some time ago, during the South Zone Conference of the Indian Psychiatric Society Frida was my obvious choice.
08/07/23, 9:18‚ÄØam
Manipur is burning and hearts have been singed. All our students who are from that region and currently staying outside are overwhelmed with deep distress and beset by a sense of helplessness. Many of them have reached out expressing their profound anguish. They are unable to reach their family and their loved ones.
The tangled web of violence has had a long imprint in our nation, right from the time of partition. Isn‚Äôt it imperative then, that as a nation we strive to address its recurrence with resolve and emotional commitment? Not a word from the head of our nation still. Mahatma Gandhi, if he was alive today would have taken the moral responsibility to quell the embers of violence, by actually being there.
As Buddha observed, ‚ÄúOur sorrows and wounds are healed only when we touch them with compassion.‚Äù
Unfortunately that seems to be in short supply these days as lives continue to slip through uncaring hands . . .
12/07/23, 9:43‚ÄØam
Henry David Thoreau whose birthday is today, was enchanted by trees and they played a significant role in his inner life. They were his constant guides and companions in his spiritual quest. Trees emerge in his writings as special symbols and images of the divine. The forest was his cathedral, the woods his ‚Äúsanctum sanctorum.‚Äù
Thoreau immersed himself in observing the shape, colour, texture and stances of trees. For him, exploring such details was an act of contemplation. ‚ÄúA tree seen against other trees is a mere dark mass, but against the sky it has parts, has symmetry and expression.‚Äù
Trees revealed themselves poetically to Thoreau. They were ‚Äúliving poetry,‚Äù written by nature on the landscape. The shadows of trees on the ground at night were ‚Äúlike chandeliers of darkness.‚Äù
The writings of Thoreau helps me to see trees in new ways and they take on a deeper meaning in the process.
Trees were wordless poems to him and each time I immerse myself listening to their unspoken words, I discover something anew.
Unfortunately, we are losing the tree cover with an alarming rate in India. Around 2.3 million trees have been proposed to be cut to make way for mega infrastructure projects in the country. We are witnessing the biggest decline in deforestation in the past few years. Reports indicate that India lost 668400 hectares of forests in the past five years, second highest globally.
During Thoreau‚Äôs lifetime too, there was increasing deforestation in New England his comment was ‚ÄúThank God, they cannot cut down the clouds!‚Äù
14/07/23, 12:26‚ÄØpm
Man is digging his own grave. The photograph of the tree looks like an x-ray with its background colour enhancing the parts.
14/07/23, 11:17‚ÄØam
One of the most beautiful experiences while walking through the woods is to listen to the sounds of the wind as it courses through the trees, caressing the leaves. Often it is a hypnotizing melody layered with descant notes. It is an enchanting experience to savor, especially when it is interspersed with bird songs. Sometimes while listening to these sounds, I wonder whether the trees and leaves are serenading each other.
Henry Wadsworth Longfellow described it evocatively in his poem "A Day of Sunshine":
I hear the wind among the trees
Playing celestial symphonies
I see the branches downward bent,
Like keys of some great instrument.
I kept wondering for a long while as to whether there is a term of this, till I accidentally found it! These sounds of wind in the trees and the rustling of leaves is called psithurism. Like many words that begin with "ps," the "p" at the beginning of psithurism is silent, and it is pronounced as sith-err-iz-um. It has its origins from the Greek word psithuros, which means whispering. So appropriate!.
Psithurism has inspired the muse in many. For instance Woody Guthrie (whose birthday is today), wrote a song ‚ÄòListening To The Wind That Blows‚Äô:
Blow, wind, blow, long low and lonesome
Blow, wind, blow, where no heart knows
I'm your lonesome-hearted listener
Listening to that lonesome wind that blows
It is easy to have a feel of psithurism. Keep the mouth closed, stick the tongue a bit and make hissing sound, then slowly withdraw the tongue till it touches the teeth, keep the lips closed and let out the air. Close your eyes and keep repeating it and you will be in the midst of a swaying forest!
17/07/23, 8:46‚ÄØam
When I joined NIMHANS, Dr RL Kapur gave us a few introductory classes on scientific method of enquiry in understanding human behaviour, which invariably, is complex. In the process, he introduced us to the writings of Henri Poincare, whose death anniversary is today. He quoted Poincare about the role of facts in science, ‚ÄúScience is built up of facts, as a house is with stones. But a collection of facts is no more a science than a heap of stones is a house.‚Äù Science is the process of determining which of the countless facts will be most useful in advancing knowledge.
According to Poincare, every scientific theory is a hypothesis that had to be tested. He emphasized that experience alone is inadequate to falsify a theory and the role of falsified hypothesis is very important in any scientific pursuit.
Poincare also drew attention to the role of intuition in science, ‚ÄúPure logic cannot give us this view of the whole; it is to intuition that we must look for it. It is with logic that one proves; it is with intuition that one invents.‚Äù
I find this particular reflection of his quite interesting: ‚ÄúLife is only a short episode between two eternities and in this episode, conscious thought has lasted and will last only a moment. Thought is only a gleam in the midst of a long night. But it is the gleam which is everything‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
19/07/23, 10:22‚ÄØam
Today is the birth anniversary of a poet who was ahead of her times, Balamani Amma.
On this day, I want to share a poem of hers titled ‚ÄòThe Pen‚Äô which has been translated by her talented daughter, poet Kamala Das.
When I touch you, O pen,
you flow like blood in my veins.
You become my lover,
the one who knows my heart‚Äôs pain.
You are my companion,
the one who hears my silent cries.
With your ink, you write my story,
and my deepest desires arise.
You understand my words,
even before they are born.
You give life to my thoughts,
like the first light of morn.
You are my confidant,
the keeper of my secrets untold.
You hold my dreams and hopes,
more precious than silver or gold.
When I caress you, O pen,
I feel the pulse of life.
You become my voice,
in a world filled with strife.
You are my solace,
when darkness engulfs my soul.
With your gentle touch,
you make me feel whole.
When I hold you, O pen,
my spirit begins to soar.
You guide me through the realms,
where imagination and dreams explore.
You are my muse,
my source of inspiration divine.
With you by my side,
I can conquer mountains and cross every line.
O pen, you are my magic wand,
that brings forth a world unknown.
Through your ink, I find freedom,
and my true self is shown.
In your strokes and curves,
my heart finds solace and peace.
You are my silent companion,
in this journey that‚Äôll never cease.
(The attached photo of mine carries a few lines from her poem, ‚ÄòThe Temple‚Äô. It depicts a beautifully carved corridor at the Vanamamalai Perumal temple in Tirunelveli.)
21/07/23, 7:51‚ÄØpm
To pen about a pen. So simple but so very effective. And such a nice old temple which carries its own ambience...
26/07/23, 11:33‚ÄØam
There is always a hidden side in each one of us. It is a part of our self which we do not like or acknowledge. It consists of everything that does not align with our conscious self. CG Jung whose birthday is today, termed it as the ‚Äòshadow‚Äô and emphasized that it offers a doorway to understand ourselves. The shadow is a cognitive blind spot of our psyche and Jung described it as ‚Äúthe thing a person has no wish to be‚Äù.
Often we identify and respond to the shadow of the others, with ease. It is a truism that what we dislike in others is an indication of what we dislike in ourselves. We hide our negative qualities, not only from others but from ourselves too.
The meeting with oneself is, at first, the meeting with one‚Äôs own shadow. Prising apart the doors of shadow offers us a glimpse of that part of our personality that conflicts with the ideal version of ourselves. It is the first step towards increasing our awareness about our self. As Jung commented, ‚Äúone must learn to know oneself in order to know who one is‚Ä¶ one does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light, but by making the darkness conscious‚Äù
Unravelling and working through the shadow is a crucial component in therapy. As Jung commented, ‚ÄúThere is no generally effective technique for assimilating the shadow. It is more like diplomacy or statesmanship and it is always an individual matter. First one has to accept and take seriously the existence of the shadow. Second, one has to become aware of its qualities and intentions. This happens through conscientious attention to moods, fantasies and impulses. Third, a long process of negotiation is unavoidable.‚Äù
Jung went on to add, ‚Äúthe task in life is not to become perfect, but to become whole. And as wholeness entails both good and evil, light and darkness, the achievement of wholeness in personality development requires we assimilate our shadow into our conscious personality.‚Äù
William Shakespeare articulated it perceptively, ‚ÄúThis thing of darkness I acknowledge mine.‚Äù
27/07/23, 8:13‚ÄØam
The sentence ‚ÄúA Rose is a rose is a rose is a rose‚Äù was written by Gertrude Stein (whose death anniversary is today), as part of a poem ‚ÄòSacred Emily‚Äô, which appeared in her 1922 book ‚ÄòGeography and Plays‚Äô. It is in similar vein to Shakespeare's ‚Äúa rose by any other name would smell as sweet.‚Äù Stein later used variations on the sentence in other writings, and ‚ÄúA rose is a rose is a rose‚Äù is among her most famous quotations, often interpreted as meaning ‚Äúthings are what they are.‚Äù
Puzzled by her writing about a rose, someone asked here, ‚ÄòWhy have you said this? We all know a rose is a rose is a rose. It makes no sense. It adds nothing to our knowledge.‚Äô Stein replied, ‚ÄòBecause poets have been talking about roses for millennia ‚Äì millions of poetries about roses, everybody has read them and sung them, and everybody has repeated ‚Äì the word ‚Äúrose‚Äù has lost its rosiness. It doesn‚Äôt say anything anymore. That‚Äôs why I had to repeat, ‚ÄúA rose is a rose is a rose‚Äù ‚Äì so that you are awakened out of your sleep, so that you are shaken a little: ‚ÄúWhat is this woman saying? the absurdity of it! ‚Äì a rose is a rose is a rose. Repeating this I have brought the redness to the rose again.‚Äù
03/08/23, 12:54‚ÄØpm
Today is the festival of Aadi Perukku, which marks the beginning of agricultural activities in Tamil Nadu, when the river Kaveri is in full flow due to south west monsoon. Farmers start their sowing in the month of Aadi (July-August) so that they can harvest the crops after six months in January during Pongal Festival. On this day people gather on the banks of Kaveri and offer prayers to the river goddess.
River Kaveri fostered civilisations, kingdoms rose on her banks and majestic temples were built on the lands irrigated by it. Great Carnatic composers, scholars and writers lived and wrote in the towns and villages that flanked the river. Sangam poetry and tamil epics like Silappadikaram, celebrated her beauty.
In Pattina Palai, a Tamil poetic work belonging to the Sangam period, Kaveri is referred to as
‚ÄúCauvery, the river that never fails, even if the sky does‚Äù.
‚Äú‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡ÆØ‡Øç‡ÆØ‡Ææ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Øà‡ÆØ ‡Æï‡Æü‡Æ±‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æø‚Äù
An interesting verse in Purananooru, one of the eight books in the Sangam literature, draws attention to the maternal instincts of the river.
‚ÄúThe forceful waters of the river Cauvery
That can even uproot a tree,
Takes care of all the living beings of the world
As a woman feeding a child through her breast‚Äù
‚Äú‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ¥‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡Æá‡Æ≤‡Æø‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Æö‡Øç
‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æ∞‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Æø ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡Øç
‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æ§‡Øà ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‚Äù
Ilango Adigal wrote in a similar vein in Silappadigaram:
‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡ÆÖ‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æü‡ØÅ
‡ÆÆ‡Æï‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æï‡Æø
‡Æä‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡Æâ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Æµ‡Æø
‡Æí‡Æ¥‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ∞‡Æø
Long live this fertile country!
Long live Kaveri
That nurtures the country
Like a mother
13/08/23, 7:23‚ÄØpm
Seychelles has a few endemic species. Prominent among them is the Aldabra giant tortoise. They are found in the Aldabra Atoll of Seychelles, in the western Indian Ocean and were introduced to the mainland, later. These giant tortoises are the largest living terrestrial species of tortoises.
We set our eyes on these incredible creatures when they were ambling along slowly, in the afternoon sun. Interestingly, the Aldabra giant tortoises are polygynandrous (promiscuous), with both males and females having multiple partners. One criterion for selection is a partner‚Äôs relatively bigger size. Like other tortoises, this species does not care for its young once the eggs are laid in a safe nest, with the young hatching and digging out of the nest by themselves. An Aldabra giant tortoise is a very slow-growing reptile and often does not reach maturity until 20-30 years old and live longer than most animals. One of them was brought from Seychelles by the British sailors to India as a gift to Robert Clive of the British East India Company. It was Robert Clive‚Äôs pet and was later kept in the Kolkata Zoo where it died after an estimated age of 255! Named ‚ÄòAdwaita‚Äô, it outlived its master, perhaps knowing all along that the sun would set on the British empire and it would be there to witness it!
16/08/23, 10:50‚ÄØam
On this day in 1886, during the early morning hours, Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa gave up his body. He has been ailing from throat cancer for a while and was in throes of immense pain. Even swallowing a small quantities of water was intensely painful. Seeing his suffering, his devotees urged him to seek some assistance to lessen the pain, Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa replied, ‚ÄúI have given my mind to the Divine Mother. How can I bring down my mind to this worthless cage of flesh? The body was born and it will die. But for the soul there is no death.‚Äù
As Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa observed in one of his earlier comments, ‚ÄúTake the case of the infinite ocean. There is no limit to its water. Suppose a pot is immersed in it: there is water both inside and outside the pot. What is this pot? It is 'I-consciousness'. Because of the pot the water appears to be divided into two parts; because of the pot you seem to perceive an inside and an outside. One feels that way as long as this pot of 'I' exists. When the 'I' disappears, what remains cannot be described in words.‚Äù
19/08/23, 9:39‚ÄØam
This is the first photograph I took, with a borrowed camera, way back when I was an undergraduate student in medicine at JIPMER. Auroville which was not far from our campus, was taking shape with some extraordinary architectural structures. Every weekend, I would cycle with my namesake TM Raghuram and during one such visit, spotted this circular opening in Bharat Nivas. I then asked TM to stand behind and raise his hand and this photo was the result.
Photography, like any other form of art is an act of self-expression. We reveal and unravel ourselves through the lens. Perhaps I was envisioning myself while framing the hand of my namesake, which occurred at the spur of the moment, without any forethought. I was both the subject as well as the object of observation.
As Rumi observed, ‚Äúthe real eye is the one that turns inwards‚Äù . . .
(On the occasion of the World Photography Day)

To be awake... Such a deep meaning. Never to get back to darkness.... The statue of Buddha depicts beautifully!
28/08/23, 8:20‚ÄØam
Bangalore hosted the Filmotsav in 1980 with a remarkable array of films. It marked the 25th anniversary of Satyajit Ray‚Äôs Pather Panchali and there was a complete retrospective of the master‚Äôs work. One of the films that left a deep impact on me was the documentary ‚ÄòKing‚Äô. When we entered the theatre where it was screened, there was a prominent notice which stated, ‚Äúno sex, no nudity and the film is 4hrs long!‚Äù Not surprisingly, there was hardly a dozen people in the auditorium. What we watched for the next four hours was the life story of Martin Luther King, his trials and tribulations, put together with real life footage. Prominent among them was his epochal speech ‚ÄòI have a dream‚Äô, delivered at the Lincoln Memorial, Washington.
Today marks the 60th anniversary of that poetic, prophetic, moving call to end segregation. The speech was written by his assistants and did not have the iconic line, ‚ÄòI have a dream‚Äô. As Martin Luther King was about to end his speech, Mahalia Jackson who was in the audience, shouted, ‚ÄúTell them about your dream Martin!‚Äù And history was made.
Although six decades have passed since the legendary speech, it still remains an inspirational call to work towards an equitable world. As he voiced in his speech, ‚ÄúLet us not seek to satisfy our thirst for freedom by drinking from the cup of bitterness and hatred.‚Äù
Though the dreamer laid down his life by an act of hatred, the dream lives on . . .
30/08/23, 10:31‚ÄØam
My grand uncle Dr RV Rajam was a well-known medical professional and a passionate bibliophile. Once when I visited him after joining the medical school, he handed over a slim book and asked me to read it. It was ‚ÄòDeath Be Not Proud‚Äô by John Gunther. Once I started reading it, I couldn‚Äôt put it down. Gunther‚Äôs memoir is a moving account of his son Johnny‚Äôs tryst with a fast growing brain tumour and his death.
The book's title comes from one of John Donne's Holy Sonnets, which he wrote after the death of his wife and three of his children. It opens with Gunther's fond, vivid portrait of his son: a young man of extraordinary intellectual promise and fun loving as well. It is a meticulous record of the diagnosis and the exhaustive hunt for various therapeutic options that he and his ex-wife pursued during their son's illness. The second section consists of Johnny‚Äôs letters and diaries which offer rich insights about his life before the onset of the tumour. The concluding part of the book by his mother, Frances is an intensely emotional account of a mother coping with the illness and demise of a beloved child. It ends with the moving last line, "And then like a thief, death stole him".
Death Be Not Proud is a poignantly interwoven account of the family‚Äôs suffering and loss. It is the forerunner of many others that followed, in articulating lived experiences of grief.
Inherent in personal narratives like Death Be Not Proud, is the immeasurable power of words to heal. The concept of bibliotherapy is not new. In ancient Greece, the phrase ‚Äúa healing place for the soul‚Äù was inscribed above the door to the library of Thebes. In the prescient words of the bard, ‚ÄúGive sorrow words, the grief that does not speak knits up the o‚Äôer wrought heart and bids it break.‚Äù
For people in throes of grief, poems do offer comfort and solace.
John Milton wrote in 1671:
‚Äúapt words have power to swage
The tumours of a troubled mind.
And are as balm to festered wound‚Äù
(Today is also the birthday of John Gunther)
Dr Raguram
01/09/23, 10:15‚ÄØam
Ahalya and myself finally caught up with the movie Oppenheimer and the story about the ‚Äòtrinity‚Äô test. The name is derived from a poem by John Donne and perhaps these lines from it ‚Äúyour force, to break, blow, burn and make me new‚Äù, were the inspiration behind choosing it. Watching the movie also brought back memories of passing by the testing site on our way to the White Sands National Park, New Mexico.
As a talented scientist, Oppenheimer ensured that the test was a success. Was he mindful about its radioactive fallout and its hazards? Though he famously remarked that he had blood on his hands, ostensibly, there was neither apology nor guilt about the human cost of the project that he led. During his visit to Japan later, he commented, ‚ÄúI do not think coming to Japan changed my sense of anguish about my part in this whole piece of history. Nor has it fully made me regret my responsibility for the technical success of the enterprise.‚Äù The horrendous effect of the bomb on Hiroshima is mentioned in the movie in bland statistical terms couched in numbers. One has to read John Hershey‚Äôs ‚ÄòHiroshima‚Äô to fathom the humongous human suffering inflicted by the act.
There were also others who had to endure the lasting effects of radiation around the test site. Often referred to as ‚Äòdownwinders‚Äô, these were thousands of families living in close proximity to the area. The bomb was packed with 13 pounds of weapons grade plutonium but only 3 pounds of the plutonium was fissioned. The remaining 10 pounds of plutonium found its way into the soil, sand, animal and plant life and on the skin of every living being. As a result of the overexposure to radiation, there was an increase in infant mortality in the months following the test. Heart disease, leukaemia, and other cancers appeared in families who had no prior history. Because of illness they were unable to work and access to health care remained unaffordable and elusive.
Though the US Government set up a fund to extend compensation and medical care through the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA), the downwinders in New Mexico have never been included or compensated although they were the first people to be exposed to radiation in the world.
The poet T≈çge Sankichi captured the horror and devastation unleashed by the atom bomb in the poem ‚ÄòAugust 6th‚Äô. Here are the first few lines from it:
‚Äúcan we forget that flash?
suddenly 30,000 in the streets disappeared
in the crushed depths of darkness
the shrieks of 50,000 died out ‚Äú
Dr Raguram
02/09/23, 8:23‚ÄØam
Vultures are majestic creatures, almost regal in their demeanour. Whenever I spot them, I think of Bharathidasan. Long ago during a birding sojourn, he spoke to us passionately about them and the importance of their conservation. In 2002, he founded Arulagam, a non-profit organisation dedicated towards their protection and conservation in the Nilagiri Biosphere. He began working with forest officials, persuading them not to bury the carcasses of elephants or gaur found in the forest but to leave them as feed for the vultures. He also started conducting workshops for cattle owners, vets and pharmacists to make them aware about the harmful effects of Diclofenac on vultures. He has been engaging the local communities in identifying and protecting vulture nesting areas. He is truly an inspiration and do have a look at the range of initiatives he is involved in at: https://www.arulagam.org/
(The first Saturday in September each year is celebrated as the International Vulture Awareness Day)
Dr Raguram
04/09/23, 10:23‚ÄØam
Decades ago during a visit to the Premier Bookshop, I picked up a book (attracted by its title!), ‚ÄòLimits to Medicine‚Äô by Ivan Illich. It blew me away when I read it. I was struck by its originality as well as by its audacity. Illich dared to question some of our deepest-held beliefs about medicine.
Those days, NIMHANS used to have a book review session and when my turn came, I chose this book without any hesitation. When I mentioned it to Dr RL Kapur, he asked me to meet the visiting professor Dr Morris Carstairs. He asked me the reason why I chose the book and said that he would chair the session. When I was about to leave, he told me that he had had a televised debate with Illich about the book! The session went off very well with me passionately articulating its strengths and drawbacks. After the session when we were walking out, Carstairs shook my hand and said, ‚ÄúYou are a wonderful rascal!‚Äù A typical British encomium!
One of the major themes in the book is iatrogenesis. Illich described three types of iatrogenesis: clinical, or the direct harm done by various medical treatments; social and the medicalisation of ordinary life; and cultural, meaning the loss of traditional ways of dealing with suffering and death. He coined the term ‚ÄòSisyphus syndrome‚Äô, meaning the more healthcare is given to a population, the greater is its demand. He cautioned that over-medicalisation often results in commodification of health and ‚Äòindustrialization‚Äô of medical practice.
Illich‚Äôs prediction of ever-increasing medicalisation has come true and unfortunately, doctors are as much victims of it as their patients. Health care is now on this conveyor belt, driven by ‚Äòtargets‚Äô set by ‚Äòmanagers‚Äô who have no background in medicine, solely driven by market forces. Doctors no longer hold the monopoly and they are ‚Äúaccomplices‚Äù in the ever expanding, large medical industry.
Illich was a visionary in the proper sense. He drew attention to disease mongering and the increasing pharmaceutical invasion. He emphasized the importance of evidence base in the practice of medicine and the crucial role of community and public involvement in medical care.
He mentioned that ‚Äúif you want to change society then you must tell an alternative story‚Äù and ‚ÄòLimits to Medicine‚Äô is a provocative one at that!
(Today is Ivan Illich‚Äôs birthday)
Dr Raguram
06/09/23, 8:14‚ÄØam
Hindu mythology is replete with many interesting stories and legends. Some of the fascinating ones are associated with Lord Krishna and his early childhood pranks. Among them Kaalinga Narthanam episode is quite fascinating.
Kaalinga was a serpent who was living in the Yamuna river in Vrindavan and had poisoned the entire river thus making it very difficult for people and animals to consume the water. He was hiding there from Garuda, his eternal enemy. Once Krishna jumped into the river to retrieve a ball and Kaalinga immediately tried to kill him. Krishna sprang on top of Kalinga‚Äôs head and started dancing on his hood. He spared Kaalinga at the behest of his wives and Kaalinga agreed to go back to his abode as he felt reassured that with the foot marks of Krishna on his hood Garuda would hesitate to harm him.
Many hymns and songs have been composed in celebration of this event.
Periyazhwar in his ‚ÄòPeriyazhwar Thirumozhi‚Äô wrote:
‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ≥‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æï‡Øà ‡Æï‡Æ≤‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ
‡ÆÖ‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ≥‡Øç‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æü‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Øà‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ≤‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡Æü‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æö‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡ÆÆ‡ØÄ‡Æ≥ ‡ÆÖ‡Æµ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æï‡Æ©‡Øç
‡Æ§‡Øã‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æµ‡Æ≤‡Æø ‡Æµ‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡ÆÆ‡Øá ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æ± ‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Æø ‡Æµ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æ±.
Another interesting song was composed by Oothukadu Venkata Subbaiyer. He was a devotee of Lord Krishna, and is believed to have composed over 400 compositions on Him. In the Kaalinga Narthana thillana, he describes the dance of the young Krishna on the hoods of the serpent. It contains many rhythmic words and intricate sequences that are fused with repetitive musical notes. He had even set the singing style in such a way that, at one place, a particular word is enunciated to resemble the hissing sound made by the great serpent!
Neela manohara jaala vibhooshana
Nirata chalanchala bhujanga nartana
Neeraja taDaaga adika mrudulapada
NikaTa taranga tunga tADanga
Nruttaka nruttaka taam tat taai
The beautiful blue-coloured one, embellished by his enchantment,
Is dancing on the tumultuously moving serpent
With footsteps softer than lotus petals
On the turbulent waves, adorned by drops of water
He dances and dances.
One of the most energetic rendering of this thillana is by Aruna Sayiram!
(This sculptural panel is from Lakshmi Narasimha Temple at Nuggehalli, Channarayapatna Talulk, Hassan District)
Dr Raguram
06/09/23, 10:39‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for the wonderful narration. Today is the festival Krishna Janmashtami for us. Thanks again for reviving nostalgia. Nuggehalli is my father's native place.
10/09/23, 10:31‚ÄØam
The beauty of the natural world has inspired people from the beginning of time, especially the poets. A tiny grain of sand inspired William Blake to pen these lines, ‚ÄúTo see the world in a grain of sand / And heaven in a wild flower / To hold infinity in the palm of your hand / And eternity in an hour‚Äù. Whether it is a grain of sand, alluring landscapes or changing seasons, the urge to describe the natural world has been an inescapable of poetry.
I am particularly drawn to the poems of Mary Oliver whose birthday is today. Through carefully chiselled words, she painted exquisite pictures of the natural world in her works. For her, nature was a source solace and wisdom. She wrote, ‚ÄúI could not be a poet without the natural world. Someone else could. But not me. For me, the door to the woods is the door to the temple.‚Äù
These eloquent lines from her poem ‚ÄòWild Geese‚Äô are truly exceptional:
Meanwhile the wild geese, high in the clean blue air
are heading home again
Whoever you are, no matter how lonely,
the world offers itself to your imagination,
calls to you like the wild geese, harsh and exciting
over and over announcing your place
in the family of things
Dr Raguram
12/09/23, 8:44‚ÄØam
The movie Pather Panchali has had an enduring impact on me. I have seen it at least half a dozen times and each and every scene is deeply etched in memory. The most endearing characters in the movie are drawn from the novel written by Bibhutibhushan Bandyopadhyay, whose birthday is today. Satyajit Ray went on to make more movies based on his work.
A not so well known novel of Bibhutibhushan Bandopadhyay is Aranyak. A newer translation was published by Penguin Modern Classics, two years ago. It is a heart-warming story of Satyacharan who gets a job as an estate manager in Bihar, and gradually falls in love with the beautiful and tranquil forest around him. It is a great environmental text celebrating the pristine beauty of nature, essaying the deep attachment of people who live close to mother earth. As one of the characters mentions, ‚ÄúThe forest you see here is very beautiful. The flowers have been blooming since a long time and the birds sing. Each with their own call; the gods themselves have merged with the wind and have left their mark on the earth. ..So whenever I pick up the cutter and the axe, the gods come and snatch away my tools. They whisper such thoughts into my ears that all thoughts of land and property are driven away from my mind‚Äù.
Living amongst them and listening to their stories, Satyacharan becomes a nature lover, ‚ÄúI had come here to settle new tenants in these forests. Having come to destroy the forestland, I have instead fallen in love with the beautiful forest maid‚Äù. He goes on to observe, ‚ÄúI shall try in vain to describe the beauty of a full-moon night in Phulkiya Baihar. Anybody who does not have the first-hand experience will never be able to imagine its beauty by merely listening or reading about it. Such a world of exquisite beauty can be manifested only in a place with such vastness of the sky, such quietude, such solitude, such dense vegetation spread up to the horizon. One should experience the beauty of such a place at least once in one‚Äôs lifetime; or else such a unique beauty of God‚Äôs creation will elude one forever.‚Äù
Feeling uneasy about the impending deforestation of the pristine land, Satyacharan laments, ‚ÄúPerhaps a time would come when men would no more be able to see forests: all they would see would be fields of crops, or the chimneys of jute and cotton mills. They would come then to this secluded forest-land, as though on a pilgrimage. For those people, yet to come, let the forest stay pristine, undisturbed.‚Äù
These words seem almost prophetic in light of the recent amendments to the Forest Act which opens up swathes of forests for ‚Äòdevelopmental‚Äô activities.
It is disheartening to note that we still have not paid heed to Satyacharan‚Äôs poignant words‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
13/09/23, 7:30‚ÄØpm
So True. By the time we start realising, there will be a change in the dream. Time to ponder on the self...
13/09/23, 8:45‚ÄØpm
Ahalya and myself were privileged to listen to Pandit Ravi Shankar's last concert in Inda, at Bangalore. Though he looked fragile, once he started playing, he was serenity personified. One our friends was the organizer and there was lots of concern about his health status. They had a team of doctors and an ambulance on standby. It was a magical evening. Found a part recording of it in FB: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VG5ds6R10rk
15/09/23, 8:10‚ÄØam
We have been planning to visit the newly opened Museum of Art and Photography (MAP) for a while and finally made it a few days ago.
It is a beautifully designed, aesthetically appealing structure and a welcome addition to the city. The main reason to visit the museum was to see the current exhibition, ‚ÄòWith Great Ease: The Photography of TS Satyan‚Äô. Satyan has been a very close friend and we cherish the photographs which he so graciously gifted to us. They have a special place in our home and in our hearts. The exhibition offers a tantalizing glimpse of his remarkable oeuvre. Satyan‚Äôs family has donated his vast archive of photographs, negatives, and writings to the Museum of Art & Photography and this exhibition draws from that collection. As Satyan remarked, ‚ÄúMy photography are slices of human life, gentle and personal‚Äù and I would urge people based in Bangalore to visit and have a glimpse of these wonderful images.
The other exhibition Visible/Invisible is a bit uneven, but has some interesting exhibits.
There is a very interesting hologram experience, wherein one can chat with MF Husain!
Two things bothered me about the museum‚Ä¶
Firstly there is no parking at all in the museum and one has to venture into the by lanes and search for one, which can be elusive. I wonder how the license was sanctioned for a new structure like this which will attract large footfall, without a dedicated parking space. That said, I noticed that a VIP visitor‚Äôs vehicle with the police escort was parked just in front of the museum which had a prominent board saying No Parking!
Secondly, why do the prices in the museum shop be so high?! I am personally in favour of ‚Äòaffordable‚Äô art which can kindle the aesthetic spirit among the visitors!
Dr Raguram
17/09/23, 10:36‚ÄØam
Wild boars have been an integral part of the Indian ecosystem and have been mentioned in various folklores and mythologies. Among them, one of the most prominent reference to the wild boars is that of Varaha, the third avatar of Vishnu. It is a fascinating tale of how the earth goddess Bhudevi was captured by the demon Hiranayaksha and trapped in the cosmic waters. Vishnu then took the form of a divine boar and rescued her after battling the demon for a thousand years.
Varaha worship was significant in Central India during the Gupta period, particularly from the 4th to the 6th century CE. The worship of Varaha was also important in southern India, especially during the early Chalukyan period. They were the first dynasty to adopt boar as their symbol. Later the Vijayanagar dynasty also chose the boar as their royal emblem
In sculptural tradition, Varaha is usually depicted in two distinct ways: one is with the head of a boar and torso of a man, which is called the ‚ÄòNaravaraha‚Äô, and the other as a wild boar. Khajuraho has one of the best-known representations of Varaha in the wild boar form. One of the most beautiful depictions of Varaha as ‚ÄòNaravaraha‚Äô, is at the Mahakuta temple which dates back to 5th-6th centry.
Varaha avatar symbolizes the preservation and restoration of the world and the triumph of good over evil. Today, when our earth faces a serious threat from several modern demons, the chief of which is our own endless greed, it‚Äôs time to feel inspired by Varaha!
(Today is also celebrated as Varaha Jayanthi)
Dr Raguram
18/09/23, 9:58‚ÄØam
The Brahmapurisvara temple at Pullamangai, built in 10 century, is an extraordinary example of early Chola temple architecture. On this day, let me draw attention to an exquisite sculpture of Ganesha which is carved on the southern wall of the shrine. The god is seated on a throne with folded legs. His trunk hangs vertically and then curves to the left in the form of an inverted question mark. Ganesha is covered by a beautifully sculpted parasol with a central pendant. Two saluting figures are shown in flying posture on either side. Ganesha, ‚ÄòLord of the Ganas‚Äô, is flanked by joyous Ganas in three superimposed rows. One of them is holding Ganesha‚Äôs vahana (vehicle) Mushaka (Mouse). Right on top is the Makara Torana, with two Makaras carved on either side. Rows of Yalis, some of them with human riders, emerge from the mouth of the Makaras and form a canopy. Right in the middle of the canopy is a dancing figure (Siva?). Below it is another row of Ganas. In the midst of this elaborately carved canopy is a very small sculpture which depicts Siva, Parvati and Chandesa Nayanar. There is a large, beautifully carved sculpture of Chandesa Anugraha Murti in Gangaikondacholapuram. This one is a miniature depiction of it, much earlier! Kindly enlarge the image to see these intricate details!
May our lives be suffused with such beauty in its myriad forms!
(PS) Can I request that neither the image nor the post is shared?
Dr Raguram
23/09/23, 8:41‚ÄØam
During my tenure at NIMHANS, I used to conduct what was referred to as ‚ÄòBrain Storming Session‚Äô, on Saturdays. The idea was to broaden the ‚Äòclinical gaze‚Äô which the trainees are accustomed to and discuss issues of interest, whether it is a book/poem/film they have read/seen recently or explore an issue of concern. The unwritten rule was that no topic related to mental health will ever be the focus of discussion in the forum.
In one of the sessions, a visiting student from Sweden brought a book of poems by Pablo Neruda and recited some of them. I can distinctly recollect a few lines from one of the poems ‚ÄòKeeping Quiet.‚Äô:
‚ÄúFor once on the face of the earth
let‚Äôs not speak in any language,
let‚Äôs stop for one second,
and not move our arms so much.
It would be an exotic moment
without rush, without engines,
we would all be together
in a sudden strangeness‚Ä¶‚Äù
The session ended with some lively discussion about Neruda and his poems and I also urged the students to see the movie, ‚Äòil Postino (The Postman)‚Äô. It portrays an imagined a fictional friendship between Pablo Neruda and a shy impressionable young postman named Mario. Pablo Neruda has been exiled from his native Chile for political reasons, and has come to live in a small village. The entire village is illiterate and he‚Äôs the only one getting mail. After some hesitation, Mario summons up the courage to talk to Neruda. They talk about poetry, politics and women. Mario and Pablo develop a deep friendship as time passes. All these elements flow together seamlessly in a fascinating manner in the movie. More than anything else the movie is about the power of language. As Mario comments to Neruda, ‚ÄúYou gave me books to read, you taught me to use my tongue for more than licking stamps.‚Äù
(Today is Pablo Neruda‚Äôs 50th death anniversary)
Dr Raguram
24/09/23, 9:50‚ÄØam
When we were birding in the Point Reyes region CA, I heard a faint, warbling call. Curious to know the source of it, I scouted the vast land in front, but in vain. Suddenly, there was a flash of luminous blue and there it was, the Western Bluebird perched on the thorny bush! It was carrying the azure sky on its back. I spent a few minutes savouring this beauty. Bluebirds are friends to gardeners because they keep plant-damaging insects and other pests at bay and they can spot them from a distance of over 50 yards!
Bluebird is considered to be a harbinger of happiness. This notion was first held by the Chinese who saw the bird as immortal, a protector, and a symbol of the sun. Native Americans too were in deep awe of the bluebird. Navajos revered it as a spirit in animal form, and the Iroquois believed the bluebird‚Äôs song would make the harsh winters bearable. For the Russians, the bluebird represented hope.
Bluebirds figure in many lovely songs. In 1934, the song ‚ÄòBluebird of Happiness‚Äô was composed by Sandor Harmati and the words were written by Edward Heyman. By 1945, the song had become an international hit. Many other bluebird songs followed, including Judy Garland‚Äôs ‚ÄòHello, Bluebird‚Äô and Paul McCartney‚Äôs ‚ÄòBluebird.‚Äô Who can forget these lines from the song ‚ÄòOver The Rainbow‚Äô in the movie Wizard of Oz:
If happy little bluebirds fly
Beyond the rainbow
Why, oh why can't I?
23rd September is considered as the ‚ÄòBluebird of Happiness Day!‚Äô
Dr Raguram
25/09/23, 8:47‚ÄØam
Equinox in the Northern Hemisphere heralds the advent of autumn. It is the time of the year when the trees that were once green explode into beautiful hues of gold, red, and orange. It is a beautiful sight to see the autumn leaves glide gently in the wind and fall as if they are falling in love with the earth.
Autumn teaches us that letting go is part of growing up. As Virginia Wolf wrote, "And all the lives we ever lived and all the lives to be are full of trees and changing leaves..."
30/09/23, 10:22‚ÄØam
I never get tired of reading Rumi, whose birthday is today. His insightful words and verses about life, love and unity of spirit touches me deeply. There is so much spiritual wisdom in his writings. He was an independent soul yearning for true freedom from dogma and hypocrisy and wrote about the abolishment of fear based religious orders. His prime message is that God is found in your own heart; ‚ÄúEvery moment I shape my destiny with a chisel. I am a carpenter of my own soul.‚Äù
He articulated a notion of a "religion of love," and wrote that "since we worship the one God/ Then all religions must be one." Remarkably at his funeral in Konya, Turkey, in 1273, the procession included not only singers and dancers, besides the traditional chanting from the Quran, but also there were Christian priests chanting the Gospel and Jewish rabbis reciting Psalms.
Just before his death, he recited one of his most inspirational words;
‚ÄúWhen I die; when my coffin is being taken out
you must never think I am missing this world.
Don't shed any tears, don't lament or feel sorry. I'm not falling into a monster's abyss.
When you see my corpse is being carried,
don‚Äôt cry for my leaving.
I'm not leaving; I'm arriving at eternal love.
When you leave me in the grave, don't say goodbye.
Remember a grave is only a curtain for the paradise behind.
You'll only see me descending into a grave, now watch me rise.
How can there be an end? When the sun sets
or the moon goes down, it looks like the end,
It seems like a sunset, but in reality, it is dawn.
When the grave locks you up, that is when your soul is freed.
Have you ever seen a seed fallen to earth not rise with a new life?
Why should you doubt the rise of a seed named man?. . .
When, for the last time, you close your mouth,
Your words and soul will belong to the world of no place, no time.‚Äù
And these words are inscribed in his tomb;
‚ÄúWhen we are dead, seek not our tomb in the earth, but find it in the hearts of men‚Äú.
Dr Raguram
01/10/23, 10:27‚ÄØam
On this World Elderly Day, let me recall Shakespeare‚Äôs evocative, lyrical verse on ageing.
Sonnet 73: That Time Of Year Thou Mayst In Me Behold
That time of year thou mayst in me behold
When yellow leaves, or none, or few, do hang
Upon those boughs which shake against the cold,
Bare ruined choirs, where late the sweet birds sang.
In me thou see‚Äôst the twilight of such day
As after sunset fadeth in the west;
Which by and by black night doth take away,
Death‚Äôs second self, that seals up all in rest.
In me thou see‚Äôst the glowing of such fire,
That on the ashes of his youth doth lie,
As the death-bed, whereon it must expire,
Consum‚Äôd with that which it was nourish‚Äôd by.
This thou perceiv‚Äôst, which makes thy love more strong,
To love that well, which thou must leave ere long.
The temple at Thiruppudaimaruthur is a treasure trove. Amidst beautiful murals that adorn the interior of the main gopuram, there are small, intricately carved wooden sculptures, like this one of an elderly person.

04/10/23, 11:09‚ÄØam
This is the link to the Mucukunda Murals in pdf format: https://www.transfernow.net/dl/20231003qMwYNT6I. It will be available till 10th October. Kindly do not share it. I would very much appreciate if you could get back to the blog after seeing them and post your comments there!
07/10/23, 9:54‚ÄØam
Smile made its appearance first in sculptures during the Archaic Period in 6th -7th century BC. The characteristic smile on Greek statues was often referred to as the Archaic smile. It was believed that this kind of smile reflected a state of ideal health and well-being. The goddess Aphrodite, one of the 12 Greek Olympian gods, was called ‚Äúlover of smiles‚Äù.
Closer home, smiling visages started appearing in sculptures, especially that of Buddha during the Gupta period. Bharatha in Natyashashtra described two forms of smile.
ƒ´·π£advikasitair ga·πá·∏çai·∏• ka·π≠ƒÅk·π£ai·∏• sau·π£·π≠havƒÅnvitai·∏•
alak·π£itadvija·πÉ dhƒ´ram uttamƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ smita·πÉ bhavet || 54 |
‚ÄúWith cheeks slightly expanded, with glances of perfect qualities, not showing the teeth, stable, should be the smile (smita) of the highest characters.‚Äù 54
utphullƒÅnananetra·πÉ yad ga·πá·∏çair vikasitair atha
ki·πÉcillak·π£itadanta·πÉ ca hasita·πÉ tad vidhƒ´yate || 55 ||
‚ÄúThat which blooms the mouth and the eyes, expands the cheeks, shows the teeth slightly, is prescribed as smile (hasita).‚Äù 55
I was looking at my library of images to locate a sculpture which depicts ‚Äòsmita‚Äô and this particular one from Khajuraho seemed to represent the description of Bharatha, closely. The smile on the face of this alluring maiden is so well delineated with elongations of the ends of the line of joined lips, slightly swollen cheeks and enlarged nostril base. The almond-shaped eyes are almost on a level with the cheeks and brows, giving an expression of tenderness and bliss.
A smile
Though frozen in time
Still enchants
(Yesterday 6th October was the World Smile Day!)
Dr Raguram
09/10/23, 8:08‚ÄØam
Beatles had a very productive sojourn in Rishikesh with Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, penning several beautiful songs. One day the Maharishi gave a lecture about the power of nature and the cycle of life comparing it to the cycle of human nature. Both John and Paul were inspired by his words. John wrote ‚ÄòChild of Nature‚Äô and Paul came up with ‚ÄòMother Nature‚Äôs Son‚Äô. When John heard Paul‚Äôs song he felt it captured what he wanted to say better and ‚ÄòChild of Nature‚Äô, did not figure in any of Beatles albums. It was released as part of the so called Esher demos. Much later, Lennon wrote a song ‚ÄòJealous Guy‚Äô, with exactly the same melody but with completely different lyrics.
Although not as well-known as Lennon‚Äôs other songs, it has a lingering beauty:
On the road to Rishikesh
I was dreaming more or less
And the dream I had was true
Yes, the dream I had was true
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
I don‚Äôt need much to set me free
I‚Äôm just child of nature
I‚Äôm one of nature‚Äôs children
Sunlight shining in your eyes
As I face the desert skies
And my thoughts return to home
Yes, my thoughts return to home
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
I don‚Äôt need much to set me free
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
I‚Äôm one nature‚Äôs children
Underneath the mountain ranges
Where the wind that never changes
Touch the windows of my soul
Touch the windows of my soul
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
I don‚Äôt need much to set me free
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
On John Lennon‚Äôs birthday, you can listen to the song here: https://youtu.be/cGAw_k3maXs?si=dxAZesV2--hLNfw6

11/10/23, 7:12‚ÄØam
Yesterday was the birthday of Kota Shivarama Karanth. He was a trendsetter in many areas and left an indelible mark in each of them. An unknown facet of his remarkable literary oeuvre is his interest in science fiction. He wrote a story ‚ÄòPashubala‚Äô in 1928, perhaps the science fiction in Kannada. The story revolves around two friends who are convinced that there is life in Mars and work on a manned mission with the help of a group of scientists. When they land in Mercury, they find humanoid aliens living in harmony with nature. Interestingly, one of the gadgets mentioned is, ‚Äòtejobhaashaka‚Äô which can communicate across light years. Truly a visionary!
You can find the only English translation of this intriguing story here: https://schrodingersbekku.blogspot.com/2020/10/pashubala-by-k-shivarama-karanth.html.
Do catch up with the engaging biography of Shivarama Karanth, ‚ÄúGrowing Up Karanth‚Äù written by his three children, each one of them talented in their own way.

15/10/23, 12:44‚ÄØpm
Poets often feel alienated and estranged which they express in their works which are deeply moving. Sylivia Plath was once such poet whose poems left a lasting impact on me. When I was reading the poems of Louise Gluck (who passed away a few days ago), I was struck by the similarity between her verses and that of Sylvia Plath (who is my favourite poet!). There is an unmistakable, intimate, autobiographical tone in her works much like Sylvia Plath. Like Plath, Louise Gl√ºck explores the deepest, innermost feelings in simple, straightforward language. In the poem ‚ÄòNostos‚Äô, she penned these memorable lines:
We look at the world once, in childhood.
The rest is memory..
In many of her poems, Lousie Gluck drew attention to the intimate association between humans and nature. For instance, in the poem, ‚ÄòOctober‚Äô, she wrote:
What others found in art
I found in nature.
What others found in human love
I found in nature.
Very simple.
These lines reiterate my belief that nature can assist and guide us in discovering our own inner selves...

19/10/23, 7:47‚ÄØam
Sometime back, I read the book, ‚ÄòTruth and Beauty: Aesthetics and Motivations In Science' by the Nobel laureate Dr S Chandrasekhar. It is a collection of speeches he delivered over 40 years on the questions of how scientists work and what motivates their quest. The most insightful lecture in the volume is the one in which he compares the work of Shakespeare, Beethoven and Newton. I was truly amazed at the depth and vastness of his erudition. CP Snow famously referred the relationship between the culture of sciences and that of the humanities as the ‚ÄòTwo Cultures‚Äô. Chandrasekhar engages both these worlds with seamless elegance.
He comments, ‚ÄúTo me, science is the search for truth, a definitive repetitive pattern in creation...Mozart looked for it in music, Monet saw it in a haystack he painted, Michelangelo found it in stone... Perhaps a scientist seeks it through a mathematical equation. But we can all see only a part of the pattern at a time. It is given only to a few to see the whole."
Writing on the quest of science, he comments, ‚ÄúThe pursuit of science has often been compared to the scaling of mountains, high and not so high. But who among us can hope, even in imagination, to scale Everest and reach its summit when the sky is blue and the air is still, and in the stillness of the air survey the entire Himalayan range in the dazzling white of the snow stretching to infinity? None of us can hope for a comparable vision of nature and of the universe around us. But there is nothing mean or lowly in standing in the valley below and awaiting the sun to rise over Kinchinjunga‚Äù.
Here was a scientist who spoke like a poet.
(On the occasion of the birthday of the Nobel Laureate Dr Chandrasekhar)

Thank you Sir for letting us know his valuable thoughts. I wonder if Science limits itself but arts goes vast and deep. But as he says the latter can positively influence the former....
22/10/23, 9:41‚ÄØam
The Brahmapuriswara temple is situated in the tiny hamlet of Pullamangai, on the outskirts of Pasupathikoyil in Thanjavur District. Dating back to 10th century, it is an outstanding example of early Chola temple architecture. Though comparatively smaller, it has some of the finest sculptures. Prominent among them is an exquisite depiction of Durga on the north wall of the temple.
Durga is depicted standing on the head of the buffalo. The goddess is tall and slender and stands in a tribhanga pose; tri meaning ‚Äúthree‚Äù and bhanga meaning ‚Äúposture‚Äù. It entails bending the body at three places, namely the knee, the hip and the shoulder. The flowing lines of the sculpture have an entrancing, sinuous quality. Rarely seen outside of Chola temples, is the umbrella (called the Venkotra Kudai) over Her head. On the right, above, is a small stylised lion and on the left a deer held by a bhuta. The presence of the deer is rather unusual. Thirugnanasambandar in Tevaram, Irandam Thirumurai, refers to Durga having a deer as ‚Äòkalaiyathurthi‚Äô.
Two kneeling figures are depicted in the wall on either side of the main niche, cutting parts of their body as a sacrificial gesture. The person on the left is seen holding his hair with his left hand and is attempting to cut off his head with his right hand. The one on the right is about the cut off his leg at the knee. A similar depiction can be found in the Draupathi Ratham at Mahabalipuram.
What struck me was the portrayal of Durga. Here the focus is not on the combat with Mahishasura but her triumphant visage after vanquishing him. There is sheer elegance in the depiction of Durga. Her face is very serene with a tranquil smile on her lips as described in the Devimahatmyam.
‡§à‡§∑‡§• ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞
‡§≠‡•Ä‡§¨‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡•ç
‚ÄúGently smiling, spotless resembling the full moon orb, beautiful as the choicest gold and lovely was thy face.‚Äù
One of the meanings of HER name is fortress. Durga reminds us of the fortress which we each carry within ourselves. As various challenges and chaos engulf us, SHE lends a helping hand to protect and fortify our spiritual wellbeing.
Dr Raguram
23/10/23, 8:51‚ÄØam
Almost all the households in south india would have a painting of Saraswati by Raja Ravi Varma. In it, Saraswati is usually depicted wearing a pure white saree sitting cross legged on the white lotus playing the Veena with peacock shown by her side.
In Halebeedu in Hassan district, Karnataka, one can find a different, vibrant, depiction of the Goddess as Natya Saraswati. Her left foot is planted firmly on the ground and her right leg is raised, bent at the knee. If one notices carefully even the heels are crafted carefully with attention to the instep. She is holding a palm leaf in her left hand and a japamala in the right hand. Observe the way she is holding the japamala with the thumb and index finger. She is wearing various ornaments which are intricately chiselled. The canopy overhead is ornate, richly carved with Keerthimukha on top. At the bottom is her vahana, swan. She is flanked on either side by a man and woman playing instruments. The man is playing the drum and the woman is playing the cymbals.
With every detail in its place, Saraswati dances into our hearts!
‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ
sarasvati nrityatu vachi me sada
Saraswati always dances in my words
(From Saraswati Stotram composed by Sage Agasthya)

23/10/23, 11:10‚ÄØpm

24/10/23, 8:12‚ÄØam
In sculptural depictions of Mahishasuramardini, the asura is portrayed either as a bull or a demon underneath the feet of the Goddess. There is an interesting sculpture in Chennakeshava Temple in Belur, in which the Mahishasura is actually seen emerging from the bull. Devi is pressing the bull with her right leg and one can see that the bull is buckling under the pressure. Mahishasura arises from the bull, with one leg still within it. The Goddess thrusts her weapon on Mahishasura‚Äôs chest, impaling and killing him in the process.
Today is Vijayadasami which is celebrated with much fanfare in Mysuru as the day Devi Chamundeshwari defeated and vanquished Mahishasura. Mysuru is deemed to be a corrupted version of ‚ÄúMysooru‚Äú, which is derived from the word ‚ÄúMahishooru‚Äù. According to the story, Mysuru was ruled by King Mahishasura who was a buffalo-headed monster. In response to the prayer by the Gods and Goddesses to save them from the demon, Goddess Parvathi, took birth as Chamundeshwari and killed the monster on top of the Chamundi hill near Mysuru. Bettada Chamaraja Wadiyar, the Raja of Mysuru rebuilt the fort and made it his headquarters and called the city ‚ÄòMahishura Nagara‚Äò, meaning the city of Mahishur. Many inscriptions done in the 17th century and later refer to Mysuru as ‚ÄòMahishuru‚Äò.
In recent times, Dalits and rationalists in the Mysuru region opine strongly that Mahishasura was not a monster but a Buddhist king, who fought against upper caste oppression and was killed by them. They argue that the demon story was fabricated to tarnish his legacy, claiming that Mahishasura was a historical figure sent by Maurya emperor Ashoka to promote Buddhism in the region. The proponents of this theory also point out that Mysuru derives its name after Mahishooru. Such an alternate narrative is not confined to Mysuru. A tribe named Asura who are living in some parts of Jharkhand claim that they are descendants of Mahishasura and for them, it is not a day of celebration, but a day of mourning.
These conflicting narratives are evidence of India‚Äôs incredible heterogeneity, which incorporates and accommodates differing beliefs within its fold, seamlessly.
Dr Raguram
26/10/23, 8:26‚ÄØam
My first tryst with the butterflies was when I working as a tutor in the Department of Psychiatry at the Bagayam campus of Christian Medical College. I was given accommodation on a road called tantalizingly, the Mango Road and there were scores of butterflies to keep me company. It was always a pleasure to be in their midst after a busy working day.
As years rolled by, birds replaced the butterflies. And that‚Äôs another story‚Ä¶
No matter where we live, butterflies are always around us. Just observing them, we experience the colors and patterns of nature. Watching them opens up a window to appreciate the beauty around us. It is a wonderful sight to see them flitting around in the morning sun. Though I have been fascinated with butterflies, I had not gotten to know and learn about them in detail. I had been following the work of Arun Urs who has been documenting the butterfly species in and around Mysore and dropped him a line to enquire whether we could join him in one of his butterfly walks. He graciously heeded our request and invited us over. We met on a clear, sunny morning on the outskirts of the Lalitha Mahal Palace. We explored the region there, studded with tall trees and mixed vegetation over the next few hours. And what a discovery it was! Arun‚Äôs knowledge about the butterflies and their habitat is truly amazing and we learnt so much about them under his tutelage.
We have done a couple of walks with him thereafter and each one of them has been an eye opener to the butterflies and the rich biodiversity that sustains them. Arun‚Äôs dream is to transform the vast terrain into a vibrant conservation reserve and I earnestly hope that it becomes a reality. Every time I meet up with Arun, I feel inspired by his dedication and untiring involvement with butterfly conservation. He is truly the Butterfly Man of Mysore! I have been urging him to write and publish a book about his passion and work with the butterflies. It would indeed be a major contribution to increase awareness about these delicate, graceful, gossamer winged creatures and they will continue to entrance us even more!
