28/10/23, 8:55‚ÄØam
Ted Hughes (husband of Sylvia Plath) was a Poet Laureate of UK from 184 until his death on 28th October 1998. He was quite fascinated with animals and many of his poems are about nature and wildlife. Ted Hughes spent much of his time in Devon and Yorkshire countryside where hawks are often found. He wrote a wonderful poem, ‚ÄòHawk Roositng‚Äô, which was published in his second volume of poems titled, ‚ÄòLupercal‚Äô. Written in first person, it explores the mind of the hawk. As a bird of prey, it kills in order to survive. The hawk is a metaphor for the perennial human need for power and control through subjugation and conquest of the powerless, which we continue to witness all around us.
HAWK ROOSTING
I sit in the top of the wood, my eyes closed.
Inaction, no falsifying dream
Between my hooked head and hooked feet:
Or in sleep rehearse perfect kills and eat.
The convenience of the high trees!
The air's buoyancy and the sun's ray
Are of advantage to me;
And the earth's face upward for my inspection.
My feet are locked upon the rough bark.
It took the whole of Creation
To produce my foot, my each feather:
Now I hold Creation in my foot
Or fly up, and revolve it all slowly -
I kill where I please because it is all mine.
There is no sophistry in my body:
My manners are tearing off heads -
The allotment of death.
For the one path of my flight is direct
Through the bones of the living.
No arguments assert my right:
The sun is behind me.
Nothing has changed since I began.
My eye has permitted no change.
I am going to keep things like this.
Dr Raguram
31/10/23, 9:51‚ÄØam
John Keats was born on this day in 1795. During his short life, he published fifty-four poems using a wide range of poetic forms including odes and sonnets. Not happy with his earlier works he collected every piece of paper on which they had been written and burned them. While suffering from tuberculosis, he fell in love with Fanny Browne. Since he could not have any physical contact with her, he wrote her a series of letters. In one of them he wrote poignantly, ‚ÄúIllness is a long lane, but I see you at the end of it.‚Äù Later, in the same letter, he wondered, ‚ÄúIs there another life?
Shall I awake and find all this a dream?‚Äù He never recovered from his illness and died at the young age of 25.
Nature was one of the greatest sources of inspiration for Keats. He gazed with child-like delight at the rising sun, the moving cloud, the growing bud and the birds and turned them into beautiful poetic images. It was not the ‚Äòintellectual beauty‚Äô of Shelley, but one that emerged from the deepest reaches of his soul. As he wrote in the opening lines of Endymion: ‚ÄúA thing of beauty is a joy forever‚Äù.
During all my birding sojourns I seek beauty in the feathered friends as in this diminutive bird, Taiga Flycatcher. It gets its name from the habitat it uses, the Taiga forest, which refers to the coniferous forests of the sub polar region. A forest dwelling winter visitor to the Indian subcontinent, it is one of the most handsome birds I have ever seen. Its beauty is not confined to its visual aspects alone, but transcends it.
As Keats wrote in ‚ÄòOn A Grecian Urn‚Äô:
‚ÄúBeauty is truth, truth beauty,‚Äîthat is all
Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
03/11/23, 9:40‚ÄØam
It was late evening when we visited the cradle of Carnatic music, Thiruvaiyaru, a few months ago. We made our way to the samadhi of Tygaraja on the banks of the river Cauvery. It is a simple, single story building, shorn of any embellishment. Silence enveloped us as we stepped in as there was hardly anyone inside. The walls were inscribed with first two lines of krithis of the master composer. Tyagaraja‚Äôs idol is installed at a place where he attained samadhi. The idol was decorated with a garland of rudraksha and he was seen holding a sheaf of palm leaves in his left hand. The idol was personally designed and installed by a singer Nagarathnamma, often referred to as Bangalore Nagarathnamma, whose birthday is today.
Bangalore Nagarathnamma was an exceptional person. She was born in Nanjangud to a devadasi Puttu Lakshmi. Though she was initiated into the devadasi tradition at the age of five, she was a keen learner and became adept in many languages including Sanskrit. She developed an abiding interest in music and emerged as one of the finest carnatic singers of her time. Impressed by her talents, Maharaja Jayachamarajendra Wodeyar appointed her the Asthana Vidushi. She was probably the first woman to occupy such an exalted position in the royal court! She moved to Madras to consolidate her position as established herself as a popular concert artist. Her rendering of Tygaraja‚Äôs krithis enthralled huge audiences. She was the first female artist to pay income tax in Madras!
Tyagaraja occupied her mind in her waking hours as much as in her dreams. In one such dream, she saw an elderly person asking her to build a structure with her vast wealth. The dream came again after a few days and she described it to her mentor, Bidaram Krishnappa as to what it meant. He told her that the person she saw in her dream was none other than Tyagaraja himself and that she should build a memorial to him at Thiruvaiyaru. Tyagaraja‚Äôs samadhi at that time was desolate and forlorn. The place was filled with wild growth of plants and bushes with snakes crawling and wild animals roaming. Seeing it‚Äôs sad condition, she built a mandapam over the samadhi.
Tygaraja‚Äôs samadhi was also the place where annual music festival, Tyagaraja Aradhana, used to be held every year. Women artists were prohibited to perform in it. Nagarathnamma invited female artists and arranged for them to perform behind the mandapam. It was huge hit. Subsequently women artists started featuring in the annual Aradhana. She bequeathed her vast fortune and property to the Aradhana trust with a clear rider that‚Äù This property shall be allowed for the purpose of conducting the Tyagaraja Aradhana only as long as women artistes are allowed to perform in it.‚Äù When she died in 1952, she was laid to rest next to Tyagaraja. To this day, she remains the only woman to be buried there.
A true feminist, Nagarathnamma shattered glass ceilings wherever she went and contributed much to the inclusion of women and especially devadasis into carnatic music at a time when society was very much Victorian in its morals. She was much ahead of her time and established the first Association for Devadasis in Madras Presidency. As its president, she took several steps towards offering financial and social support to her fellow devadasis.
DV Gundappa wrote a moving tribute to this remarkable woman. When he met her towards the end of her life, she commented ‚ÄúI was Nagarathna (precious jewel on the snake‚Äôs head) by birth, then became bhogarathna (jewel of pleasure) and now I am rogarathna (jewel of disease)‚Äù DVG added that she should also be called ragarathna (jewel of musical ragas) and tyagarathna (jewel of sacrifice).
10/11/23, 7:21‚ÄØpm
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/understanding-consciousness-goes-beyond-exploring-brain-chemistry/
15/11/23, 8:53‚ÄØam
Often people from different walks of life leave their imprint on us. Here was a person whom I had never met, but one who left a lasting impression on me through his commitment towards social justice and human rights. He is the only person who has been hailed as a ‚ÄúBhishma Pitamah‚Äù of the Indian judiciary. Today is the birthday of Krishna Iyer who made the judicial system more humane.
On this day, it is imperative to reflect on two of his perceptive observations on the role of judiciary:
‚Äúthe Gandhian diagnosis of offenders as patients and his conception of prisons as hospitals mental and moral ‚Äì is the key to the pathology of delinquency and therapeutic role of punishment. The whole man is a healthy man, and every man is born good. Criminality is curable deviance. If every saint has a past, every sinner has a future, and it is the role of law to remind both of this.‚Äù
‚ÄúLitigants are legal patients suffering from injustices seeking healing for their wounds. Would you tell a sufferer in the hospital that because he disclosed a certain symptom very late, therefore, he would be discharged without treatment for the sin of delayed disclosure? Humanism, which, at bottom sustains justice, cannot refuse relief unless, by entertaining the plea, another may sustain injury.‚Äù
It was Krishna Iyer‚Äôs abiding belief that the Supreme Court of India should perform as a Supreme Court for the people of India

19/11/23, 9:52‚ÄØam
Margaret Atwood (whose birthday was yesterday), is a prolific, award winning writer with more than fifty books of fiction, poetry and critical essays. Beyond this remarkable oeuvre, she is a strong supporter of feminism, environmentalism and social justice. She was the first author to participate in a conceptual art project, the Future Library. The project envisioned that in the course of a hundred years, a hundred writers will contribute a manuscript to it. The manuscripts will remain unread except for their titles till 2114, when they will be printed on paper made from a thousand pine trees that have been planted.
I was quite surprised to find out that she is the honorary President of the Rare Bird Society!

20/11/23, 8:52‚ÄØam
One of the most famous opening sentences in literature is from Leo Tolstoy's novel Anna Karenina: "All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way." Tolstoy's own marriage seems to have fallen into the second category. Though he and his wife, Sophia, had 13 children together, they were an unhappy couple in the later part of their lives. Tolstoy contemplated leaving his wife on many occasions and finally on the night of Nov. 10, 1910, he secretly fled, leaving a note to his wife, ‚ÄúI am doing what old men of my age usually do: leaving worldly life to spend the last days of my life in solitude and quiet.‚Äù Taking only a few things, he boarded a train with his personal physician Makovitsky. Taking a circuitous route, involving several train changes, they planned to travel further to Bulgaria. But on the way, Tolstoy caught a cold, which led to pneumonia and he was taken of the train at Astapovo. He declined any medical intervention as he wanted to "submit himself to God‚Äôs will." He passed away in the early morning of 20th November 1910.
Tolstoy‚Äôs final moments are a poignant reminder of what he wrote in The Death of Ivan Illyich; ‚ÄúWhat death? There was no fear, because there was no death. Instead of death there was light. So that‚Äôs it! He suddenly said aloud. ‚ÄúSuch joy!‚Äù
Dr Raguram
02/12/23, 7:43‚ÄØam
From a distance, the little grebe looks like an unremarkable small duck. When you observe it closely, the first thing that strikes one is its stunningly bright chestnut coloured throat. Its eyes are beady yellow with a tiny black pupil. It is fascinating to see it diving under the water, with ease, surfacing some distance away.
Its scientific name is Tachybaptus ruficollis. The genus Tachybaptus is from the Ancient Greek takhus which means fast, just like tachycardia is a fast heartbeat, and bapto which means ‚Äòto sink under‚Äô, similar to the word baptism. The specific name ruficollis is from the Latin rufus which means red and the Modern Latin collis, which means necked, which is originally from the Latin collum, or neck.
It has been named Switzerland‚Äôs Bird of The Year 2024.
Shakespeare in his Venus and Adonis gave a lovely description of this bird:
‚ÄúLike a dive-dapper peering through a wave
Who, being look‚Äôd on, ducks as quickly in.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
03/12/23, 10:51‚ÄØam
When I was in the medical school, my grand uncle Dr RV Rajam asked me to read the book, ‚ÄôThe Lives of a Cell: Notes of a Biology Watcher‚Äô by Lewis Thomas. It was a collection of essays on varied topics ranging from medicine to music, written in a lively, light hearted, poetic way. It was said that he could write "as naturally as birds build a nest." In his own words, he let them ‚Äúloose . . . to fly around in the dark, bumping into each other, mating in crazy ways‚Äù. The book was full of fascinating nuggets of information. ‚Äúants are very much like humans. They farm fungi, raise aphids, as a livestock, launch armies into wars, use chemical sprays to alarm, and confused enemies, capture slaves‚Äù. He was prescient in his observation about the advent of the Internet in future. ‚ÄúWe are becoming a grid, a circuitry around the earth. If we keep at it, we will become a computer to end all computers, capable of fusing all the thoughts of the world into a syncytium.‚Äù The book opened my eyes to many things, our existence, our environment, social beings, our origin and a variety of interesting topics. ‚ÄòThe Lives of a Cell‚Äô is eleventh on the Modern Library‚Äôs list of the best 100 nonfiction books of the century. I started collecting his subsequent books and each one of them is a gem.
Lewis Thomas was a strong advocate of a scientific approach to understand and decode the mystery of biology and medicine. However, voicing a cautious note, he observed, ‚ÄúScience will...produce the data..., but never the full meaning. For perceiving real significance, we shall need...most of all the brains of poets, also those of artists, musicians, philosophers, historians, writers in general‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
04/12/23, 7:14‚ÄØam
Viktor Frankl‚Äôs ‚ÄòMan in search of meaning‚Äô, has had a profound impact on me. I came across the work of the poet Rainer Maria Rilke (whose birthday is today), for the first time when Frankl quoted from a poem by him, ‚ÄúHow much suffering there is to get through!‚Äù I started reading Rilke‚Äôs poetry and was struck by its lyricism and imagery like in these lines:
‚ÄúShe who reconciles the ill-matched threads
of her life, and weaves them gratefully
into a single cloth‚Ä¶ ‚Äù
We hold disparate threads in our life, some of them infused with pain and sorrow. Our task in life is how we reconcile the threads we‚Äôve been given and turn them into a personally meaningful cloth. A good life doesn‚Äôt come from having ‚Äúgood threads‚Äù. It comes from being an adept weaver, in knowing how to reconcile oneself the ill-matched parts of our life to each other.
And Rainer Maria Rilke observed:
‚ÄúBe patient toward all that is unsolved in your heart and try to love the questions themselves, like locked rooms and like books that are now written in a very foreign tongue. Do not now seek the answers, which cannot be given you because you would not be able to live them. And the point is, to live everything. Live the questions now. Perhaps you will then gradually, without noticing it, live along some distant day into the answer.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
04/12/23, 10:18‚ÄØam
Thanks Sir for shedding light on the great works of such gems. But are we getting enmeshed in artificial aspects, fleeting attention and no eye for the details of the environment.
07/12/23, 8:25‚ÄØam
Yesterday was the death anniversary of Baba Saheb Ambedkar who fervently espoused the cause of the oppressed, exploited, deprives sections of the society. He was not merely a dalit icon, but someone who tirelessly worked towards emancipation of women. During the All India Depressed Classes Women‚Äôs Conference held in Nagpur in 1942, he remarked, ‚ÄúI measure the progress of a community by the degree of progress which women have achieved.‚Äù He strongly advocated the role of education in mitigating the discrimination faced by them. In this, he was carrying forward the legacy of Jyotiba and Savitribai Phule, who started the first school for girls at the historic Bhide Wada in Pune around 1932. It opened the gates for the emergence of a subculture wherein the oppressed women started giving expression about their struggles and lived experiences through the written word. They haven‚Äôt looked back since then. There is a growing body of writings from the dalits and the marginalized, brimming with vibrancy, especially in the past decade.
I particularly like the poems of Jacinta Kerketta, who belongs to the Adivasi community of West Singhbhum district. She essentially writes in Hindi and some of her poems have been translated into English recently. In her poems, Jacinta highlights the injustices committed on the Adivasi communities and particularly the struggles of women. Her poems, like this one, abounds with wonderful, poignant, imagery:
(‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Å‡§è ‡§§‡•ã‡§°‡§º‡•á ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•á‡§°‡§º ‡§∏‡•á? Kyon Mahue Tode Nahi Jate Ped Se?)
(Why the Mahua is not Plucked from the Tree?)
Mother, why do you wait all night
for the mahua to drop?
Why don‚Äôt you not
just pluck all the mahua from the tree?
Mother says ‚Äì
They live in the womb all night long.
When the time for their birth comes
They fall by themselves to the earth.
At dawn, when they‚Äôre soaked in the dew
We pick them up and bring them home.
When the tree is going through
Labour pains all night long
Tell me, how I can
shake the branch hard?
Say, how I can forcibly
pluck the mahua from a tree?
We just wait
Because we love them.
Dr Raguram
08/12/23, 11:32‚ÄØam
I was keen to reach the temple at Bodhgaya early, before the crowds start streaming in. When I entered the temple precincts there was hardly anyone except a group of Buddhist monks who were chanting melodiously. The ebb and flow of their chanting with sporadic chirping of birds set the tone for a reflective state of mind. I made my way to the Bodhi tree and sat down. Here was the place where Shakyamuni came after practising a lifestyle of severe asceticism for six years. After enduring many hardships, he realized that that a deeper understanding of life was still eluding him. He sat and meditated under this tree and became the Buddha, ‚Äúan awakened one.‚Äù Bodhi Day which is observed on 8th December marks this moment that took place 2500 years ago. In addition to its spiritual significance, the Bodhi Day reminds us of the importance of peace, compassion, and mindfulness in our everyday lives.
Within each of us is a tiny light, entangled in the fibres of our lives. As Ramana Maharishi observed, ‚ÄúYour own Self-Realization is the greatest service you can render the world.‚Äù
(If you look carefully at the photograph, you can have a glimpse of a covered slab at the foot of the Bodhi tree. It marks the exact position where Buddha sat in meditation. Traditionally, it is referred to as Buddha‚Äôs Vajrasana and is the oldest piece of architecture in Bodh Gaya)
Dr Raguram
10/12/23, 7:39‚ÄØam
‚ÄúIf we love Flowers, are we not ‚Äòborn again‚Äô every Day,‚Äù reflected Emily Dickinson whose birthday is today. She was better known in her hometown of Amherst, Massachusetts, as a gardener rather than a poet. She was often observed by neighbours on evenings, tending her flower beds. She identified herself strongly with flowers like the tiger lily, daisy, and rose and was particularly partial to wildflowers. Her first formal act of composition as a girl was not a poem but an herbarium.
The garden was the true inspiration for Emily Dickinson and flowers figured with richest symbolic language in her poems. As she wrote,
‚ÄúI hide myself within my flower
That fading from your Vase
You, unsuspecting, feel for me
Almost a loneliness‚Äù
For her, every single flower is a microcosm of complex ecological relationships between numerous organisms and their environment. She captured this understanding in an exquisite poem, in which the flower emerges not as the pretty object of admiration but as an enchanting, silent symphony of interconnected resilience.
BLOOM
‚ÄúBloom ‚Äî is Result ‚Äî to meet a Flower
And casually glance
Would cause one scarcely to suspect
The minor Circumstance
Assisting in the Bright Affair
So intricately done
Then offered as a Butterfly
To the Meridian ‚Äî
To pack the Bud ‚Äî oppose the Worm ‚Äî
Obtain its right of Dew ‚Äî
Adjust the Heat ‚Äî elude the Wind ‚Äî
Escape the prowling Bee
Great Nature not to disappoint
Awaiting Her that Day ‚Äî
To be a Flower, is profound
Responsibility‚Äù
Dr Raguram
11/12/23, 7:47‚ÄØam
Mountains might not seem like they do much, but in reality, they are one of the most important creations of nature. To raise awareness about mountains, the United Nations signifies December 11 as International Mountain Day. They contain almost half of the total biodiversity hotspots on the planet. Mountains host a significant amount of flora and fauna, which are vulnerable and at risk of extinction. Unfortunately, they are being overexploited by humans and are torn apart to make way for buildings and cities.
Mountains are nature‚Äôs most beautiful gift to us and let us strive to take care of them.
William Wordsworth expressed the beauty and allure of mountains poetically in ‚ÄòLines composed a few miles above Tintern Abbey
‚ÄúTherefore am I still
A lover of the meadows and the woods
And mountains; and of all that we behold
From this green earth; of all the mighty world
Of eye and ear, both what they half create
And what perceive; well pleased to recognize
In nature and the language of the sense
The anchor of my purest thoughts, the nurse
The guide, the guardian of my heart, and soul
Of all my moral being.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
18/12/23, 9:18‚ÄØam
Today is the birth centenary of TS Satyan often considered as the ‚Äòfather of photojournalism‚Äô in India. His work was all about people, across various streams of life. One particular image that has made a deep impact in me was a photograph of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, showing Nehru walking in the corridor of the Parliament House with his back towards the camera. This was a period of time when Nehru was severely criticized for his policies regarding China which waged a war with an unprepared Indian army. The isolation and loneliness experienced by him has been artfully expressed in a simple frame.
Satyan had an unparalleled eye to capture the extraordinary in the ordinary. In his own words, ‚ÄúMy people are not the rich and the famous. They are the simple, ordinary folk. They do not hit the headlines, yet my people are people who matter. They were there when I picked up the camera six decades ago, and they have been there every time I have gone back to capture the interesting moments in their lives. In giving me privileged access at every step of my career as a photo journalist ‚Äì even in their moments of despair or drudgery ‚Äì they have never let me forget that photography is at once both an exquisite art-form and a means of communication. And that to lose sight of one aspect is to lose sight of both. Call it intimate intrusions, but it is these simple, ordinary people who dominate my oeuvre. Through a tiny aperture they allowed me to freeze-frame the cycle of life: birth, growth and death. In between, they showed me babies being born, babies being bathed, babies being suckled. They have let me in when children were learning, children were playing. They have allowed me to peep at adults at work, at worship, at recreation and adults at their everyday chores. And they have let me do so on the road, at the well, beside rivers, in crowds and in solitude. In the process, by making their private life public, they have enabled me to discover the extraordinary in the everyday."
I had a close association with him in the later part of his life and deeply cherish the interactions. I visited him a few years before his death. It was after a major retrospective of his work. He looked at the prints which were neatly stacked, turned to me and said, ‚ÄúI would like you to take these‚Äù. I was deeply moved, touched and requested him to just select a few for me to treasure. Every time I look at them, the magic of a creative genius keeps unfolding.‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
19/12/23, 8:36‚ÄØam
Paul Klee (whose birthday was yesterday), left an indelible mark on the world of visual arts with his unique style and innovative approach to painting. A great artist, he was also an inspiring teacher, fine musician, and persuasive writer. Klee was ambidextrous. He wrote with his right hand and painted with his left. Klee‚Äôs paintings often blur the line between reality and imagination. His famous dictum was that drawing is a matter of taking a line for a walk.
Reflecting on the artistic process, he wrote, ‚ÄúFrom the root, the sap rises up into the artist, flows through him, flows to his eye. Overwhelmed and activated by the force of the current, he conveys his vision into his work. And yet, standing at his appointed place as the trunk of the tree, he does nothing other than gather and pass on what rises from the depths. He neither serves nor commands he transmits. His position is humble. And the beauty at the crown is not his own; it has merely passed through him‚Äù.
Paul Klee felt that the study of nature was one of the central principles of artistic creation. Birds and fish assume a special place in his work. They exerted a particular fascination on him because unlike humans, who are bound to the earth by gravity, they can move completely freely in air or water. This gives them their own territories which are difficult for humans to access.
Antonin Artaud famously observed, ‚Äú ln Paul Klee, the objects of the world fall into order and it seems as if he was only writing down their dictation‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
20/12/23, 8:08‚ÄØam
Beau Taplin is a poet from Australia who has captured the essence of human emotions and experiences through eloquent words and enchanting themes. In his words, ‚ÄúI like to draw inspiration from wherever I can, so no river runs dry. The connections I have shared with people have always been a significant part of who I am, so a great deal of it comes directly from personal experiences‚Ä¶ As far back as I can remember, I have searched for the hidden magic in things, those moments that seem to glimmer and shine with their own inner light, and so my great hope and intention with my verses and volumes is to simply encourage you to do the same. To see how the rabbit hole, this deep magic, belongs not only to stories, but can be found right here beneath the soles of your feet; in the soft light of morning, amongst the woods and the streams, in dance, in music, or a lover‚Äôs kiss‚Äù.
Beau Taplin is among the new generation of poets like Rupi Kaur, who reach out to larger audiences through social media. His brief verses/notes in Instagram continue to enthral his devoted followers. He writes, ‚ÄúEveryone you meet has a part to play in your story. And while some may take a chapter, others a paragraph, and most will be no more than scribbled notes in the margins. Someday, you'll meet someone who will become so integral to your life, you'll put their name in the title.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
21/12/23, 8:59‚ÄØam
Kodo Sawaki is regarded by many as the greatest twentieth-century Zen master. He had a difficult start in life as his early life was full of travails of various kinds. He weathered them all and after receiving his ordination, spent many years living in an abandoned hermitage devoting himself to the practice of Zazen. He became famous throughout Japan for the sesshin (intensive meditation retreat) that he gave to people from all walks of life, without making any personal distinction or discrimination. Kodo Sawaki called his monastery a ‚Äúmoving monastery‚Äù. He gave Zen a new life and ‚Äúbrought fresh air to the decaying Zen‚Äù by staying away the frozen rituals. His tendency to travel alone and his refusal to settle down at any monastery in the classical sense earned him the nickname, ‚ÄúHomeless Kodo‚Äù.
Kodo Sawaki taught that the practice of zen is not about achieving enlightenment, but rather about living in the present moment and being mindful of our actions and thoughts. He emphasized the importance of zazen, or seated meditation to cultivate a sense of inner peace and clarity. Kodo encouraged people to live a life of simplicity and to find joy in the small moments of everyday life.
When he was 86, Kodo felt gravely ill and spent the last three months of his life at Antai-ji, a temple transformed by him into a place for a pure practice. From his bed, he spent a long time looking at the Takagamine mountain and, three days before his death, he told a nun: ‚ÄúLook at that. Nature is magnificent. In all my life, I have never encountered a person to whom I could have submitted and who I could have admired. But this Takagamine mountain looks upon me form the heights saying: ‚ÄòKodo, Kodo‚Äô‚Äù.
These were his last words. He passed away on the 21st of December, 1966
Dr Raguram
22/12/23, 7:27‚ÄØam
Srinivasa Ramanjuan (whose birthday is today) is an enigma and continues to be one. To borrow a phrase from a radio address by Winston Churchill in 1939, to understand his creative process, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚ÄúThe enigma of Ramanujan‚Äôs creative process is still covered by a curtain that has barely been drawn,‚Äù observed the mathematician Bruce Berndt.
Like many geniuses, Srinivasa Ramanujan was a dreamer. Many of this profound insights were ‚Äòrevelations‚Äô unravelled in dreams. Recording one such dream, he wrote, ‚ÄúWhile asleep, I had an unusual experience. There was a red screen formed by flowing blood, as it were. I was observing it. Suddenly a hand began to write on the screen. I became all attention. That hand wrote a number of elliptic integrals. They stuck to my mind. As soon as I woke up, I committed them to writing.‚Äù Throughout his career, ‚Äúscrolls of the most complicated mathematics‚Äù would unfold before him in dreams. In a dream early in his life, the goddess Namagiri bestowed him with the gift of precociousness by writing on his tongue. Later, during a difficult period in his life, his abdomen appeared to him as an appendage of ‚Äúindefinable mathematical surges‚Äù
Revelatory dreams have been mentioned for many thousands of years, across cultures in the East and Near East. In Greek mythology, Oneiroi were the spirits, daimones, or gods of dreams in Greek mythology. Each night the Oneiroi would depart from Erebus, like a flock of bats leaving their caves. As the Oneiroi departed from Erebus they would pass between one of two gates. One gate was made of horn, and the Oneiroi who passed through this gate would bring to mortals truthful, prophetic god sent dreams. The second gate was made of ivory, and the Oneiroi who passed through this gate brought only false dreams, or those dreams without meaning. Virgil wrote in the epic poem Aeneid:
Two gates the silent house of Sleep adorn;
Of polish'd ivory this, that of transparent horn:
True visions thro' transparent horn arise;
Thro' polish'd ivory pass deluding lies.
Ramanjuan seems to have passed through the gates of horn to provide us with immense, intriguing mathematical insights.
In the garden of dreams
He wandered deeper
And an enchanted forest unfurled‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram

Ahalya joins me in converying our warmest wishes for the New Year. The theme of our calender is Madanika sculpltures at the Chennakesava temple at Belur. Let these images keep you company in the year to unfold!

The sculptors are dead and gone but they are alive in their work. Like the sound of the bell resonating through flowers, the chiselling sound seems to be echoing in these sculpturesü§î

06/01/23, 10:49‚ÄØam
On the occasion of Arudra Darisanam dedicated to the cosmic dance of Lord Siva, let me recall my visit to Banteay Srei, the jewel of Khmer Art. Each and every section of this small temple is exquisitely carved. This beautiful depiction of Aada Vallan or Dancing Siva is on the eastern side of the temple. Below him is Indira riding his Airavata, which is depicted as a monster-like figure with an elephant head. Indira (unfortunately his head is missing) is seen holding the elephant trunk on the right hand and the monster head on the left hand. The two other Airvatas are on the corners of the bas relief. On Siva‚Äôs left is a percussionist playing on the drum. On the right of Siva is a depiction of an emaciated woman, Karaikkal Ammaiyar. She was a Bhakti poet and one of the three women amongst the 63 Nayanmars, a group of saints devoted to Lord Siva.
Sekhizhar in his monumental work ‚ÄòPeriyapuranam‚Äô narrates the story of Karaikkal Ammaiyar. She began her life as Punithavathi and was married to Paramadattan. One day Paramadattan sent two mangoes to her telling her to keep them for his lunch. An hour or so later Lord Siva came as a mendicant, begging for alms. As food wasn‚Äôt ready, Punithavathi offered him one of the mangoes. When her husband returned, Punithavathi served him the other one. When he asked for the other one, she was desperate and prayed to Lord Siva and a ripe mango fell into her palm. Finding the fruit bigger and tastier, he asked her where she got it. When she related what had happened, Paramadattan was unconvinced and asked her to procure another such fruit. Punithavathi prayed again and received one more fruit but it vanished when her husband tried to touch it. Taken aback, Paramadattan realised that she had divine qualities and deserted her. Stung by this, she left home to pursue an ascetic path and prayed to Lord Siva to release her from the shackles of the physical body. Hence many iconographic depictions of her portray her in an emaciated form.
There is a small temple dedicated to her in Karaikkal. Every year Mangani (Mango) festival is celebrated commemorating this story. During this festival Lord Siva is taken in procession as Bikshadana with his begging bowl and people throw mangoes from the rooftops.
Karaikkal Ammaiyar composed beautiful verses in praise of Lord Siva:
‡Æá‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ§ ‡Æá‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ™ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç
‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øà ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡ÆÆ‡ØÄ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Øá‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Øà ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øà ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç
‡Æá‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ¥‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æü‡Æø
‡ÆÖ‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ®‡ØÄ ‡ÆÜ‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æâ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æü‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÄ‡Æ¥‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï.
I pray for the infinite happiness of Your love
I do not want to be born again
If I do, I do not want to forget You forever
If I do, I want to be happily singing in Your praise
Under Your feet as You are dancing‚Äù.
