12/01/23, 7:50‚ÄØam
Haruki Murakami, one of my favourite writers, turns 74 today. His latest book Novelist as Vocation was published in English a few months ago. A collection of essays, it was first published in Japanese seven years ago. The narrative flows in the manner of many of his novels, which are usually written in the first-person. There are informative insights into his writings. I particularly liked his observation on the art/act of writing: ‚ÄúIf possible, I would like my readers to savour that same emotion when they read my books. I want to open a window in their souls and let the fresh air in. This is what I think of, and hope for, as I write‚Äîpurely and simply.‚Äù
14/01/23, 10:48‚ÄØam
13th December is the last day of the Tamil month Margazhi which ushers in the Pongal festival. It occurs on the last day of Dakshinayana, a six month cycle of the Sun‚Äôs course moving south, which is followed by a six month cycle of the Sun‚Äôs course moving north called Uttarayana.
During Bhogi, people clean their houses, get rid of unwanted things, symbolically setting them on fire. Perhaps it reminds us that we need to give up all our negativities, and unwanted thoughts in the smouldering fire.
Mythologically it is an invocation to a divine force, Lord Indra, "the God of Clouds and Rains' ',seeking his benevolence to bring in good rains and help the farmers.
This is a beautifully carved sculpture of Lord Indra with Indrani on his vehicle Airavat, from the 13th century Chennakeshava temple at Somanathpua, near Mysore
16/01/23, 7:43‚ÄØam
The third day of Pongal is celebrated as Mattu Pongal to thank and revere the cattle which play an important role in the lives of the agricultural community. Their horns are painted in vibrant colours and decorated with bells and other ornaments.
This beautifully sculpted wooden figure (which is the size of a large postage stamp!) is from within the main temple tower at Thiruppudaimarthur, Tirunelveli district
22/01/23, 9:36‚ÄØam
Lord Byron (whose birthday is today) expressed a sense of wonder and joy about nature in his poems. Born with a club foot, he was deeply uncomfortable with it and had to wear special boots to hide it. He was also a victim of childhood sexual abuse at the hands of a drunken nursemaid. For him nature was a healer; a refuge and place of shelter.
His love of nature finds expression in Childe Harold‚Äôs Pilgrimage:
‚ÄúI live not in myself, but I become
Portion of that around me; and to me,
High mountains are a feeling‚Ä¶
Are not the mountains, waves, and skies a part
Of me and of my soul, as I of them?
Is not the love of these deep in my heart
With a pure passion‚Äù
His own inner need for solitude finds expression in these perceptive lines‚Ä¶
‚ÄúThere is a pleasure in the pathless woods,
There is a rapture on the lonely shore,
There is society, where none intrudes,
By the deep sea, and music in its roar:‚Äù
25/01/23, 9:07‚ÄØam
Virginia Woolf (whose birthday is today) had an enduring tryst with bipolar illness all through her life. In her fight against her hounding illness which she often referred to as ‚Äòwaves‚Äô, she held onto writing to prevent herself from sinking. In her own words, ‚ÄúOne ought to sink to the bottom of the sea, probably, and live alone with one‚Äôs words.‚Äù It was a prescient observation as years later, unable to cope with the devastating illness, she filled her overcoat with stones and drowned in the river Ouse.
TS Eliot, a close friend, persuaded her to write about her experiences with her ailments and the result was the contemplative essay, ‚ÄòOn Being Ill‚Äô. She wrote it in throes of yet another ravaging bout of illness. This has been reissued in 2012 with contributions from her mother and a friend. It is an insightful narrative about travails of illness and its impact on caregivers.
She voiced her profound loneliness in these evocative words, ‚ÄúWe do not know our own souls, let alone the souls of others. Human beings do not go hand in hand the whole stretch of the way. There is a virgin forest, tangled, pathless, in each; a snowfield where even the print of birds‚Äô feet is unknown. Here we go alone‚Ä¶‚Äù
31/01/23, 8:26‚ÄØam
Da Ra Bendre‚Äôs (whose birthday is today) works are infused with a sense of divine unity. This is often expressed eloquently in his nature poems. For instance in Ba Bega (Come Soon) he conceives the clouds as a divine presence which can enliven the ‚Äòsleeping seed‚Äô within us‚Ä¶
08/02/23, 8:18‚ÄØam
Located in the beautiful Hudson Valley in Ghent, NY, Art Omi is a vast landscape untouched by landscapers or horticulturalists. Amidst the tranquil outdoor space dotted with wild flowers are large scale sculptures. Some works are so well camouflaged in the wooded trails that it is easy to miss them, while others reach out through the trees. When I ventured into a forest path, I chanced upon this wooden sculpture of a man in silent repose, silhouetted against the sky. As I spent a few minutes soaking up the experience, these words of the philosopher Martin Buber (whose birthday is today) resonated within me: "Solitude is the place of purification".
Solitude often unravels the richness within the self‚Ä¶
14/02/23, 9:43‚ÄØam
Sanskrit literature is replete with beautiful verses celebrating love. Most notable among them is Chaurapanchasika , a compilation fifty short lyric poems written in the eleventh century A. D. by the poet Bilhana.
There are many versions about the origin of this work. One of them states that a king with a lovely daughter engages the famous poet Bilhana to educate his daughter. To prevent any romance blossoming between the two, he tells the princess that her guru is visually challenged and tells the guru that his student has deformities in her face. To ensure that they don‚Äôt see each other, he hangs a curtain between the two. One day while lessons were in progress, the poet is thrilled by the full moon on a cloudless sky. He breaks into a poem, and princess wonders how a blind man can sing about the moon with such brilliance. Excited, she pulls down the curtain and finds that Bilhana is a handsome young man while he finds he finds her to be a personification of female beauty. The two instantly fall in love and decide to marry, but the enraged king sentences them to death. As Bilhana is being led to his execution, he starts singing the fifty verses. Deeply moved by it, the king orders his release and formally gives his daughter in marriage.
Interestingly, in 1948, two producers made movies in Tamil based on this story of Bilhana. Unfortunately, the third version with the legendary MK Thyagaraja Bhagavathar as Bilhana was never completed as the actor was arrested.
Among many translations of this remarkable work, I find the one by Sir Edwin Arnold quite interesting. One of the verses reads:
Still when her eyes, as lotus petals long,
Like Fortune‚Äôs goddess lotus-born, I see,
And see her wearied by her bosom's load,
With both my arms clasping her close to me
As honey bee his darling lotus sips,
I would grow drunk on mead within her Iips.
These lines find a picturesque expression in this beautiful sculpture from Khajuraho.
16/02/23, 10:33‚ÄØpm
Glowing heart‚ù§Ô∏è Yes from within. Glittering photograph Sirüëå
18/02/23, 8:35‚ÄØam
According to one of the legends, Lord Shiva and Devi Parvathi tied the nuptial knot on Mahashivaratri. Their union has a deeper connotation: Purusha (mindfulness) is represented by Shiva, while Prakriti (nature) is epitomized by Parvathi.
This classic Shiva Parvathi sculpture is from Hoysaleshwara temple in Halebeedu. It depicts Parvathi seated on Shiva‚Äôs lap which is referred to as atikarohana. They are bedecked with intricately carved jewellery and carry different weapons and ornaments in their arms. The details are so mesmerizing, providing a three dimensional perspective. What is interesting to note is the presence of mongoose, a vahana of Parvathi at her feet.
Composed by Adi Shankaracharya, Shiva Parvathi stotram holds a special importance amongst all Shiva Stotras. It extols the divine qualities of the god and goddess in 12 stanzas. On this Mahashivaratri day let us recall a verse from this:
‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç,
‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç,
‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç
Namah Shivabhyam pashupalakabhyam
Jagattrayee rakshana baddha hrudbhyam
Samastha Devaasura pujitabhyam
Namo namah Shankara Parvatibhyam
I bow to God Shiva and Goddess Parvathi, the protectors of all beings
Who are the divine guardians of all the three worlds
The divine pair worshipped by all the Devas and Asuras
I bow to you, again and again, God Shiva and Goddess Parvathi
22/02/23, 8:54‚ÄØam
We are all drawn into the larger than life canvas of the Father of the Nation. Yet, we fail to notice the gentle brush strokes and fine textures that enhance its subject and the incredible person responsible for it, Kasturba Gandhi. Married at a very young age, she deftly juggled multiple roles: as a devoted wife to a demanding husband, a caring mother and a satyagrahi. It was not an easy task and its demands impacted her health significantly.
22nd February was the last day in the life of Kasturba Gandhi. She was imprisoned along with Mahatma Gandhi in the Aga Khan Palace, Poona and was not keeping good health for a while. When Kasturba realised that her end was near she said, "Do not sorrow after my death. It should be an occasion for rejoicing." Then she whispered a line from her favourite Gujarati hymn, ‚ÄòHari no marag che shoora no, nahi kayar nu kaam jone (The path to God is for the brave to tread, not for cowards). Then she slipped into an altered state of consciousness. When he was told about it, Bapu rushed to her room. took her hand in his and asked, ‚ÄòShun thay che, Kastur?‚Äô In a feeble, trembling voice, Kasturba replied, ‚ÄòShun thay che smajhatu nathi. Mare java no vakhat thai gayo.‚Äô She rested her head on Gandhi‚Äôs chest and soon her life ebbed away.
The next day she was cremated in the grounds of the Aga Khan Palace. Gandhi sat through the cremation till the pyre was extinguished. When someone suggested him to move away he replied, "This is the final parting, the end of 62 years of shared life. Let me stay here till the cremation is over."
When her children Devadas and Ramdas went to collect her ashes, they found to their great surprise, an intact a pair of red and green glass bangles worn by Kasturba since marriage.
07/03/23, 8:12‚ÄØam
It was an unusually sultry morning and there was a long queue in front of St Peter‚Äôs Basilica in the Vatican City. Undeterred, I waited patiently behind a group of tourists from America who were chatting animatedly. As soon as I entered its hallowed precincts, I made my way straight to have a glimpse of Michelangelo‚Äôs Pieta. During his lifetime Michelangelo made three Pietas, of Virgin Mary mourning the dead body of Christ and this is the most beautiful of them all. Though Mary embracing her dead son is not explicitly mentioned in the holy book, the scene has proven to be a popular subject among artists for centuries.
Safely ensconced behind bullet proof glass, Virgin Mary was in a seated position, wrapped in robes and cradling the lifeless body of Jesus. His head was slumped back on her shoulder. When I looked at it closely, I felt that the sculpture was shaped like a pyramid, with the top of the head of Virgin Mary being its peak and the sculpture expanding to accommodate her seated legs. Her petite face with gentle demeanour exuded serene tranquillity. Michelangelo‚Äôs painstaking attention to detail and the unique treatment of the hair, the skin and the intricate folds in the fabric is a lasting testimony to his outstanding artistry.
Pieta was the only sculpture where Michelangelo inscribed his name. Unfortunately, with the crowd milling around, I couldn‚Äôt have a close look to locate it.
Michelangelo was a multi-talented individual who also wrote sonnets on variety of subjects. He produced hundreds of madrigals and sonnets, often putting down his chisel while at work to write down a line or two of verse.
These beautiful lines are from the sonnet titled The Model and the Statue:
When that which is divine in us doth try
To shape a face, both brain and hand unite
To give, from a mere model frail and slight
Life to the stone by Art‚Äôs free energy.
(Yesterday, 6th March was the birthday of this remarkable artist/poet)
08/03/23, 10:27‚ÄØam
Pen and chisel, both effective ways to touch heart. So beautifully and humbly put across- shadow of divine perfection. The artist has left to the eyes of the beholder to interpret the expression on Virgin Mary's face!!!
09/03/23, 8:44‚ÄØam
On this day in 2015 Paul Kalanithi breathed his last after a valiant tryst with malignancy at a young age. Posting a review of his poignant deeply moving memoir which I wrote sometime ago: https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/stories-interrupted
15/03/23, 7:01‚ÄØam
From the moment we are born, we begin our journey towards death. Understandably this prospect often evokes intense fear. It is suggested that one can negotiate this fear in three ways: through knowledge as epitomized by Nachiketa, by adopting a path of bhakti like Markandeya and by sheer power of love as symbolized by Savitri.
During Karadaiyan Nombu which is observed today, women offer prayers for the longevity and wellbeing of their husbands and celebrate great encounter of Savitri and Yama, the God of Death.
Savitri was the daughter of the King of Madradesha. She was exceedingly beautiful and when she reached marriageable age, though many princes admired her, none of them came forward to marry her, overawed by her beauty. Her father told her to go forth and select her own husband. Savitri visited many kingdoms but could not find the husband of her choice. On her way back home, she saw a young man in a forest serving an old couple with utter devotion. She was immediately drawn to him and informed her choice to her father. When Narada heard about it, he informed her that the young man she had chosen, Sathyavan, had a very short life and would die after a year. Savitri‚Äôs parents were shattered on hearing this and requested her to reconsider her choice. A determined Savitri married Sathyavan and went to the forest and assumed her new role with great joy. But deep within, she was afraid and could not forget Narada‚Äôs prophecy. As the day of death drew near, she began to fast and offer prayers with utmost piety. Finally, on the dreaded day, she decided to accompany her husband when he went into the forest as she did not want to be separated from him even for a short while. Yama made his appearance and starting pulling Sathyavan with his noose. To his astonishment he saw Savitri following him and asked her to return back. But Savitri said that it was her dharma to accompany her husband everywhere and she could not give it up. Pleased with her words he granted her many boons with which she restored the kingdom and eyesight of her father in law. But she still continued to follow him. Finally, impressed by her intense devotion, Yama restored the life of her husband and blessed them.
Interestingly festivals are associated with particular type of food. Karadaiyan Nombu is no exception. On this day, a special dish ‚ÄòKaradai‚Äô is prepared from rice flour, black eyed peas, jaggery and coconut and it is believed that Savitri prepared this special dish and offered it with butter to Lord Yama as a thanksgiving gesture for returning the life of Satyvan.
There are few representations of Yama in sculptural form. This image is from Khajuraho and depicts a four armed Yama. His vehicle, buffalo can be seen on the lower right hand corner. If one looks carefully, one can notice a cock in his right hand. There is an interesting story behind it. One day Yama attempted to kick his mother in a fit of rage. Incensed by this, Sanjana, his mother cursed that he would have a perennial wound infested with maggots which would never heal. Heeding to his request, Surya granted him a cock which ate all the vermin in his leg. And hence the cock in his hand!
20/03/23, 9:23‚ÄØam
White-crowned Sparrows are quite fascinating. They are extremely alert and they stay awake for up to two weeks during their migration. A migrating White-crowned Sparrow was once tracked moving 300 miles in a single night! It is a delightful sight to see them scuttling across the ground with their chirpy notes.
What do sparrows represent? They were associated with liberation in ancient Egypt. It was believed that they would catch the souls of the recently deceased and carry them to heaven. This was the inspiration for a while for sailors to get sparrow tattoos in the hope that the bird would catch their souls if they died at sea.
Sparrows often have a spiritual connotation. Mahakavi Bharathiyar wrote a couple of poems on this dainty bird. Here, he urges us to let go of the chains of bondages that hold us back and liberate ourselves from the fetters that bind us‚Ä¶like the sparrow
‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ±‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æö‡Øç
‡Æö‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Øá
May you escape from all shackles
And revel in freedom
Like this Sprightly Sparrow
(On the occasion of the World Sparrow Day)
20/03/23, 1:46‚ÄØpm
Heart warming photograph Sir and good to hear the belief about their soul catching tooüôÇSad we can only see sparrows in the photographs.
21/03/23, 6:41‚ÄØam
‚ÄòPoetry is painting that speaks,‚Äô Plutarch observed.
Throughout history, poets have painted their canvas with lyrical and idyllic verses.
The landscape of poetry in India is vibrant and multihued and there is a treasure trove waiting to be unearthed across languages.
On this World Poetry Day, let me share a poem by Malathi Maithri which has been translated from Tamil by Lakshmi Holmstrom.
OBSERVE THE CRANE
The crane waits
at the verge of the river-bed,
fish swimming in its memory.
In search of its reflection, the moon
wanders, vanishes.
Swirls of roots tear into the earth,
with hunger.
The wind, sweeping up its troubles,
hurls the heat in all directions.
Pulverized, the heart swirls
like dust in a storm.
It is not just the earth
that overflows through its cracks
in heat and rage.
The crane
absorbs into itself all that heat
and boils within.
If only the crane would sink into
the water swirling in its memory
and beat its wings,
the river might gather its form once more
from the scattered drops,
and walk again.
River, watch.
23/03/23, 6:23‚ÄØam
The World Poetry Day yesterday was also the birthday of a poet whom I admire deeply, Billy Collins.
He was the Poet Laureate of US and was instrumental in setting up a very interesting program, ‚ÄòPoetry 180‚Äô for high schools. He chose 180 poems for the program which are available online and are worth a look: https://www.loc.gov/programs/poetry-and-literature/poet-laureate/poet-laureate-projects/poetry-180/all-poems/
John Constable who described himself as, ‚ÄúI am man of the clouds‚Äù assiduously captured nature‚Äôs most ephemeral occurrence, clouds, in over fifty paintings. These are some of the most magnificent images of clouds ever painted. In this poem, Student of Clouds, Billy Collins reflects on Constable‚Äôs cloud paintings and populates the canvas with his beautiful words.
The emotion is to be found in the clouds,
not in the green solids of the sloping hills
or even in the gray signatures of rivers,
according to Constable, who was a student of clouds
and filled shelves of sketchbooks with their motion,
their lofty gesturing and sudden implication of weather.
Outdoors, he must have looked up thousands of times,
his pencil trying to keep pace with their high voyaging
and the silent commotion of their eddying and flow.
Clouds would move beyond the outlines he would draw
as they moved within themselves, tumbling into their centers
and swirling off at the burning edges in vapors
to dissipate into the universal blue of the sky.
In photographs we can stop all this movement now
long enough to tag them with their Latin names.
Cirrus, nimbus, stratocumulus
dizzying, romantic, authoritarian
they bear their titles over the schoolhouses below
where their shapes and meanings are memorized.
High on the soft blue canvases of Constable
they are stuck in pigment but his clouds appear
to be moving still in the wind of his brush
inching out of England and the nineteenth century
and sailing over these meadows where I am walking,
bareheaded beneath this cupola of motion,
my thoughts arranged like paint on a high blue ceiling.
02/04/23, 11:32‚ÄØam
There is an interesting sculpture of Hans Christian Andersen in Central Park, New York. It depicts the author of Ugly Duckling, reading a book with a duckling at his feet. Quite often, children climb on top of him and sit on his lap! Countless generations of children (and adults alike!) have grown up relishing his fairy tales. The Danish word for fairy tale is Eventyr and Hans Christian Anderson authored hundreds of them which continue have a universal appeal. He is the eighth most-translated writer in the world, trailing right behind Vladimir Lenin and his works have been translated in more than 125 languages.
Raised in poverty and having lost his father early in life, he had to work in a factory as a child to support his mother. He endured many hardships and suffered from countless fears and phobias. His greatest fear was one of being buried alive, something which disturbed him so much that he made a note every night before bed to alert anyone who found him that he was merely sleeping and not dead. In spite of all the adversities in his life, he was able to transform his pain into art and as he reflected: "Most of what I have written is a reflection of myself. Every character is from life. I know and have known them all"
Hans Christian Andersen (whose birthday is today) was much more than a children‚Äôs writer and multiple layers of meanings are embedded in his stories. He founded a genre that has a unique and enduring appeal.
07/04/23, 1:31‚ÄØpm
Oh. Such a short answer, a blend of devotion and self realizationüôè
09/04/23, 8:09‚ÄØam
Easter commemorating the resurrection of Christ, was the earliest feast day decided upon by the ancient Christian church. One of the most beautiful depictions of Easter is by Raphael which he painted when he was just in his teens.
In this painting one can see Christ in the centre, hovering in the air above the tomb. Four guards are on either side with raised hands pointing out to him. In the left hand corner are Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and Salome who are on the way to anoint Christ. Two angels flank Christ on either side with their hands raised in blessing. Interestingly there are two symbolic representations in the painting; snake referring to the Satan and white crane indicating its strength and endurance during migration.
George Herbert, one of the great devotional poets in English, wrote couple of poems on Easter. In one of them, Easter Wings, he wrote:
O let me rise
As larks, harmoniously,
And sing this day thy victories:
Then shall the fall further the flight in me.
The poet suggests that those who stay close to God through religious devotion can ‚Äúfly" above, or find redemption from, their suffering.
Interestingly, he arranged these lines in print to resemble the shape of bird‚Äôs wings
09/04/23, 8:27‚ÄØam
A photograph or painting, simply enchanting. And what a tragedy. Sorrow deep within flows in the canvas of nature. And those lines.....
10/04/23, 7:25‚ÄØam
Madness has engaged the attention of writers and thinkers for long and Kahlil Gibran (whose death anniversary is today) was no exception. ‚ÄúThe Madman‚Äù was his first published work in English. It is an innovative collection of over 30 parables and poems exploring what occurs once we strip away our masks to look within and bare ourselves to God. Gibran describes this state as one of both freedom and vulnerability. In his words, ‚ÄúI have found both freedom and safety in my madness; the freedom of loneliness and the safety from being understood, for those who understand us enslave something in us.‚Äù
Khalil Gibran continued this path of enquiry in his best remembered publication ‚ÄòThe Prophet‚Äô. In this book, he reflects on subjects as varied as love, death, self-knowledge, joy and sorrow, reason and passion, in simple yet philosophical language. It has been translated into forty languages and has sold a million copies worldwide. ‚ÄúThe Madman‚Äù continues to be read and cherished for its timeless understanding of our shared humanity.
Gibran, in his writings, has touched upon almost all the important areas of human life in relation to God, nature, and others, in an elegant, inspiring style.
Ultimately, Gibran‚Äôs poems urge the reader to contemplate and reflect on the profound truths of human existence.
The imagery in these lines from his poem, ‚ÄòOut Of My Deeper Heart,‚Äô is particularly stunning:
Out of my deeper heart a bird rose and flew skyward.
Higher and higher did it rise,
yet larger and larger did it grow.
At first it was but like a swallow,
then a lark,
then an eagle,
then as vast as a spring cloud,
and then it filled the starry heavens.
Out of my heart a bird flew skyward.
And it waxed larger as it flew.
Yet it left not my heart.
13/04/23, 8:12‚ÄØam
Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar (whose birthday is tomorrow), was an amazing polymath. He was a politician, economist, anthropologist, jurist, theologian, historian, social reformer, lawyer, author, constitutionalist, sociologist, political scientist, feminist, environmentalist, educationist and a social scientist. This long list is a tribute to his thirst for knowledge across disciplines.
Ambedkar‚Äôs assiduous quest for equality, justice and the welfare of every human being, lead him to Buddhism. On 14 October 1956, he converted to Buddhism, along with 3,65,000 of his followers in Nagpur. Unfortunately he died two months after the event on December 6, 1956, three days after completing his final manuscript, ‚ÄòThe Buddha and His Dhamma‚Äô. He describes the appeal of Buddha quite eloquently: ‚ÄúAll prophets have promised salvation. The Buddha is the one teacher who did not make any such promise. He made a sharp distinction between a moksha data (Giver of Salvation) and a marga data (Way Finder), one who gives salvation and one who only shows the way. He was only a marga data. Salvation must be sought by each for himself by his own effort.‚Äù
Ambedkar continues to be the ‚Äòmarga data‚Äô for millions of oppressed for whom equality, social justice and an egalitarian livelihood is still a distant dream, even decades after independence.
‚ÄúMen are mortal. So are ideas. An idea needs as much propagation as a plant needs watering. Otherwise, both will wither and die.‚Äù
17/04/23, 8:22‚ÄØam
Years ago, our friend Dr Stuart Schwartz, gave us a book, ‚ÄòI Am That‚Äô by Nisargadatta Maharaj and mentioned as to how deeply it influenced his spiritual quest. It is not a book in the conventional format and is an account of Maharaj‚Äôs dialogues with seekers. The book is arranged in a question and answer format and covers many topics such as god, the ego, living in the world, free will. I have been dipping into this interesting book on and off, over the years. Often I start with chapter ‚ÄòAwareness is Free‚Äô and then onto chapters which focus on his spiritual experiences. He speaks consistently on the direct experience of "I am".
In the sixth chapter of the ‚ÄúChandogya Upanishad,‚Äù the 24-year old Shvetaketu returns home, 12 years after his father has sent him to study the vedas. The first question that Svetaketu‚Äôs father Uddalaka Aruni asks his son is whether he has returned with the knowledge of that by which ‚Äúwe perceive what cannot be perceived, we know what cannot be known.‚Äù Svetaketu answers in the negative, asking his father what that actually is. His father explains, using the famous Advaita precept: ‚Äòtat tvam asi‚Äô. Maharaj delves on this and expands this concept through dialogue with the seekers. There is so much similarity between his teachings and that of Ramana Maharishi.
The book is studded with poetic descriptions. On Nisargatta Maharaj‚Äôs birthday today, let me recall some of his observations:
"My teacher told me to hold onto the sense ‚ÄòI am‚Äô tenaciously and not to swerve from it even for a moment. I did my best to follow his advice and in a comparatively short time I realized within myself the truth of his teaching. In the stillness of the mind I saw myself as I am un- bound."
‚ÄúGive up all questions except one, "Who am I?" After all the only fact you are sure of is that you "are". The "I am" is certain, the "I am this" is not. Struggle to find out what you are in reality.‚Äù
Among many of his comments, one that deeply resonates within me is in this attached photograph of mine!
22/04/23, 8:00‚ÄØam
Today is Akshaya Tritiya, a day when people throng the jewellery shops to buy gold. The word ‚ÄòAkshaya‚Äô means ‚Äònever diminishing‚Äô and hence the belief that buying the precious metal on this day guarantees endless wealth.
Like many festivals in India, Akshaya Tritiya has several legends connected with it. It is an important day in Jainism and is associated with Adinatha, the first of the 24 Tirthankaras. Rishabadeva, king of Ayodhya gave up all earthly pleasures (much like Gautam Buddha), to lead the life of a monk as Adinatha. In order to live as a Jain monk, one must not possess anything, not even a morsel of food. When he started begging for food, his subjects offered him their most prized possessions like precious stones, elephants, horses but not food or drink which they thought was too modest an offering for their dear king. The king refused all the fine gifts and went without food and water until, finally, his grandson Shreyansha Kumara understood his need and offered him some sugarcane juice. With this juice, Adinatha broke his fast that had lasted 400 days.
It was on Akshaya Tritiya day that Adinatha broke his fast. As a mark of reverence to Lord Adinatha and his strict penance, Jains celebrate this day as ‚ÄúParna Diwas‚Äù after the penance of Varshi Tap and end their year-long alternative-day fasting with sugarcane juice.
This photograph is from Cave 4 at Badamai. Carved into its wall is a beautiful, life-size relief of Adinatha. He is standing in Kayotsarga pose, with unbent knees and straight arms, which are held at the side and do not touch the body. It is representative of an ascetic practice characterised by detachment of the physical body. Adinatha has locks of hair cascading down his shoulders and this is one of the ways to identify his sculpture. There is an interesting story behind this. When he chose to become an ascetic, Rishbadeva started pulling out his long strands of hair. After four fistfuls, when he was pulling out the fifth fistful of hair Indra is said to have told him, " This strand of hair on the crown of your head and hanging down over your shoulders looks attractive. Kindly leave it as it is." Rishabadeva agreed. Due to this bunch of hair he got the popular name; Keshariya ji (one with hair).
As for myself, I am a miner for gold‚Ä¶in the hearts of peopleÔÅä
26/04/23, 8:37‚ÄØam
In 1836, Ralph Waldo Emerson (whose birthday is today) wrote an essay titled, "Nature". In it he recounted a mystical experience that he had while walking through the woods one afternoon. He experienced a deep kinship and communion with nature and wrote: ‚ÄúStanding on the bare ground, my head bathed by the blithe air, and uplifted into infinite space, all mean egotism vanishes. I become a transparent eyeball; I am nothing; I see all; the currents of the Universal Being circulate through me; I am part or particle of God.‚Äù For him nature is a spiritual experience that can be perceived intuitively. He observed, ‚ÄúThis transcendental experience is open to each one of us. It only requires that we spend time contemplating its meaning and significance in our lives‚Äù.
Emerson, along with Henry David Thoreau, belonged to the Transcendentalist movement which emphasized the need for an intuitive and ‚Äòpoetic‚Äô engagement with nature. In his words, ‚ÄúIn the presence of nature, a wild delight runs through the man, in spite of real sorrows. Nature says, he is my creature, and maugre all his impertinent griefs, he shall be glad with me‚Äù.
Emerson lead a very productive life and lived till 79. Travails of ageing and the prospects of end of life, did not deter him from penning these moving lines in his poem ‚ÄòTerminus‚Äô
As the bird trims her to the gale,
I trim myself to the storm of time,
I man the rudder, reef the sail,
Obey the voice at eve obeyed at prime:
‚ÄúLowly faithful, banish fear,
Right onward drive unharmed;
The port, well worth the cruise, is near,
And every wave is charmed.‚Äù
05/05/23, 8:05‚ÄØam
On the occasion of Buddha Purnima, let me dwell on the only sermon given by Buddha, in which he didn‚Äôt utter a single word. When he held up a flower, the whole congregation was silent, not understanding it‚Äôs significance, except one. Mahakasyapa looked at it intently and smiled. Buddha handed over the flower to him and said, ‚ÄúI have said what can be said and what cannot be said.‚Äù From that day Mahakasyapa became his successor.
In this ‚ÄòFlower Sermon‚Äô, Buddha drew our attention to the importance of direct experience, shorn of intellectual analysis. Flowers embody both form and formlessness. They arise from the earth and return to it, drawing attention to the formless consciousness of Oneness.
The simple act of seeing a flower can usher in a meditative state of intense awareness
William Blake said it wonderfully:
To see a World in a Grain of Sand
And Heaven in a Wild Flower
Hold infinity in the palm of your hand
And eternity in an hour
06/05/23, 10:29‚ÄØpm
Beautiful flower vividly captured Sir. And profound presentation by Buddha, so simple but so deep!
08/05/23, 6:07‚ÄØam
Many a time in our lives, invariably we will find ourselves alone. These states differ from being lonely. Alone is a way of being-in- the -world, whereas loneliness is tinged with feelings of abandonment. Solitude is the state of being alone without feeling lonely. As May Sarton commented, ‚ÄúLoneliness is the poverty of self; solitude is richness of self.‚Äù It is a positive and constructive state of engagement with oneself.
As I was strolling in the temple precincts at Avani, this particular sculpture caught my attention. It portrayed a man in silent repose. There was a sense of inexplicable inner peacefulness stemming from it. Watching it, I was reminded of the words of Swami Chinmayananda, whose birthday is today, ‚ÄúThere is no companion like solitude. One who knows how to tune himself to the inner silence, even in the midst of the din and roar of the marketplace, enjoys a most recreative solitude.‚Äù
As Lord Byron wrote, ‚ÄúThere is a rapture on the lonely shore‚Äù.
13/05/23, 8:29‚ÄØam
On the occasion of the World Migratory Bird Day, a note on a petite, pretty migrant that graces the subcontinent. Read on at:
https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/an-avian-nomad
22/05/23, 10:21‚ÄØam
Arthur Conan Doyle, whose birthday is today, graduated from the University of Edinburgh Medical School and special interest in ophthalmology. It was no wonder then, that the main character in his works, Sherlock Holmes, was a very keen observer.
Careful attention to details is one of the important components of clinical medicine. Dr Shattner articulated the essential skills that a physician has to cultivate and summarized it in the acronym SOAPS:
S maintaining a Systematic approach
O using keen Observation
A Accessing relevant databases
P employing a Personal empathic attitude
S Shared decision-making
Sherlock Holmes‚Äôs famous deductions were based on his astute powers of observation. He often advised Watson that ‚ÄòIt is a capital mistake to draw conclusions without data.‚Äô He used to consult his meticulously compiled ‚ÄòIndex‚Äô and books from his library before arriving at conclusion. Though he is often portrayed as being detached, cold or remote, he was sensitive to his client‚Äôs circumstances and reached out to those in distress. All these form crucial components in clinical decision making. I often find myself quoting Holmes to my students to enhance their clinical acumen.
In the era of Evidence Based Medicine, we often rely on reliable sources of information to guide our clinical decisions. In the process, many a time we find ourselves bogged down in a morass of information. Unfortunately, we have to contend with limited storage space within ourselves. Arthur Conon Doyle employed an interesting metaphor ‚ÄòBrain Attic‚Äô, to highlight it. He wrote in the ‚Äò A Study At Scarlet‚Äô:
‚ÄúI consider that a man's brain originally is like a little empty attic, and you have to stock it with such furniture as you choose. A fool takes in all the lumber of every sort that he comes across, so that the knowledge which might be useful to him gets crowded out, or at best is jumbled up with a lot of other things, so that he has a difficulty in laying his hands upon it. Now the skilful workman is very careful indeed as to what he takes into his brain-attic. He will have nothing but the tools which may help him in doing his work, but of these he has a large assortment, and all in the most perfect order. It is a mistake to think that that little room has elastic walls and can distend to any extent. Depend upon it there comes a time when for every addition of knowledge, you forget something that you knew before. It is of the highest importance, therefore, not to have useless facts elbowing out the useful ones.‚Äù
A timely advice in the digital era!
23/05/23, 8:57‚ÄØam
Who can forget A Doll‚Äôs House? Henrik Ibsen (whose birthday is today) wrote the play in 1879. It was much ahead of its time in terms of challenging traditional gender roles in marriage. Nora, the heroine, has been a domesticated person all through her life, striving to do the best for her family. She gets tangled in messy circumstances because of the money she borrowed from a man of ill repute for her husband. Both the men try to control and manipulate her in their own ways. Fed up with all this, she starts questioning the foundation of everything that she believed in. Feeling betrayed and disillusioned that she has always been treated like a doll in her life, she decides to leave. Her husband strongly criticizes her move, saying that by deserting her husband and children she is forsaking her "most sacred duties". Nora tells him that the duties that are most sacred to her now are the "duties to herself". The play ends with her exit as she walks out slamming the door. It is an act of bold self-assertion. ‚ÄúI must stand quite alone,‚Äù Nora declares, ‚Äúif I am to understand myself and everything about me.‚Äù After playing the role of a doll, Nora begins the journey of self-discovery afresh.
Through this ending, Ibsen is fundamentally questioning the institution of marriage, gender and societal roles of women in an "exclusively male society, with laws made by men and with prosecutors and judges who assess feminine conduct from a masculine standpoint."
Nora's journey keeps continuing all around us..
While primarily known for his dramatic works he also wrote poems and he was described as a ‚Äòprofound poetic dramatist‚Äô. Snippets from one his poem,
WITH A WATER LILY
Tis the flower with the white wings.
Buoyed upon the quiet stream
In the spring it lay adream.
24/05/23, 8:37‚ÄØam
World Turtle Day is an annual event (that was celebrated yesterday) aimed at increasing public awareness about the important need to protect the shrinking habitats of turtle and tortoises.
Hindu mythology is replete with references to animals, including tortoise. Prominent among them is the churning of the ocean (Samudra Manthan), which appears in several texts such as the Mahabharata, Vishnu Purana and Bhagavata Purana. To churn the primordial ocean, Mount Mandara was used as a churning rod and the snake, Vasuki as the churning rope. The Asuras held the head of the snake and the Devas held its tail and they pulled his body alternately, causing the mountain to rotate and the ocean to churn. In the process, slowly Mount Mandara began to sink. Vishnu, in his second avatar as the tortoise Kurma, came to the rescue and supported the mountain on his shell. Without Kurma avatar it would not have been possible for the ocean to be churned and the devas would not have received the fourteen gifts. The churning also resulted in the poison, ‚Äòhalahala‚Äô, which was imbibed by Lord Shiva to protect the universe from destruction.
The tortoise, as a symbol of the earth also figures in several vedic and puranic texts. According to these representation, the tortoise‚Äôs domed shell is heaven and the flat underside is the earth. Further, the kurmanivesha (tortoise abode) is central to Hindu astrology, wherein the body of the tortoise would be divided up into nakshatras (constellations) that influenced the regions occupying a certain body part. For instance, the head often represented the eastern region of the earth.
Turtle is considered very lucky in astrology and it is believed that Goddess Lakshmi, showers blessings on those who wear the ‚Äòturtle ring.‚Äô
There are three temples in India where Kurma is the main deity: Srikumaram near Srikakulam, Gavirangapura near Hosadurga and Kurma Varadaraja Swamy temple in Chittoor district. Prominent among them is Srikurmam, where the presiding Deity, Lord Kurma is self-manifest, or svayambhu. He is about 70 cm long, shaped like the shell of a turtle. The Deity‚Äôs tail is a saligram presented by Adi Sankara. In the temple‚Äôs premises, a tortoise park has also been built to conserve the adult and young star tortoises, which are found in the foothills and fields of Srikakulam. A stellar example of conservation which is in tune with the cultural and religious beliefs of people..
Let me conclude with this beautiful verse in the Sangam poetry, Kurunthokai, where the poet wrote:
‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ¥‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Øã‡Æ∞‡Øá,
‡Æ§‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡Øà ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤ ‡Æâ‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æø‡Æü‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡Æö‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æé‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æü‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Øã,
‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©,
‡Æï‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Æ± ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øá?
Those who chide me, know not a thing
my passion is like a hatchling of tortoise
sustained by its mother;
if my lover forsakes me, it‚Äôll wither
like an unhatched egg, for what else can sustains it?
(This photograph of Kurma Avatar is from a pillar at the hundred pillar mandapam at Varadaraja Swamy temple, Kanchipuram. Each pillar, adorned with exquisite carvings, is a treasure to savour)
(Kindly do not share the post with due acknowledgement!)
29/05/23, 8:28‚ÄØam
As the Sengol is safely ensconced in a glass case and the debates, discussions and drama about it settles down, let me draw attention to a poet (whose birthdays was yesterday), whom I admire deeply, K Satchidanandan. His poems are fascinating excursions embellished with a deeply reflective, gentle voice. In his own words, ‚ÄúI mark my passage with words that smell life‚Äù.
I particularly like his poem ‚ÄòGandhi and Poetry‚Äô, which I am quoting in full:
One day a lean poem
reached Gandhi‚Äôs ashram
to have a glimpse of the man.
Gandhi spinning away
his thread towards Ram
took no notice of the poem
waiting at his door,
ashamed at not being a bhajan.
The poem now cleared his throat
And Gandhi glanced at him sideways
through those glasses that had seen hell.
‚ÄúHave you ever spun thread?‚Äù he asked,
‚ÄúEver pulled a scavenger‚Äôs cart?
Ever stood in the smoke of
An early morning kitchen?
Have you ever starved?‚Äù
The poem said: ‚ÄúI was born in the woods,
in a hunter‚Äôs mouth.
A fisherman brought me up
in a cottage.
Yet I knew no work, I only sing.
First I sang in the courts:
then I was plump and handsome
but am on the streets now,
half-starved.‚Äù
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs better,‚Äù Gandhi said
with a sly smile. ‚ÄúBut you must give up this habit
of speaking in Sanskrit at times.
Go to the fields. Listen to
The peasants‚Äô speech.‚Äù
The poem turned into a grain
and lay waiting in the fields
for the tiller to come
and upturn the virgin soil
moist with new rain.
Kindled by thoughts, fuelled by ink, poems like this have a way of finding their home within us
01/06/23, 6:20‚ÄØam
Yesterday I had written about the role of chance and the throw of dice. The game of dice played a crucial role in the Mahabharata. The Kauravas (led by Duryodhana) challenged the Pa·πá·∏çavas to a game of dice and in the process robbed them of their kingdom, violated their queen Draupadi, and exiled them for thirteen years. As a consequence of these egregious acts, war between the two sets of cousins unfolded.
The dice game contained one of the most disturbing instances in the epic. When Draupadi underwent humiliation at the hands of the Kauravas, the elders who were present did nothing to stop the act. They chose to be passive witnesses to the horrendous act. Standing before her husbands and elders, humiliated and shamed, she questions Yudhi·π£·π≠hira, ‚ÄúWhom did you lose first, yourself or me?‚Äù This most poignant question was met with deafening silence. Draupadi comments, ‚ÄúIt is sad; in this vast assembly here, there are no elders in the true sense. The so called elders are unable say what is Dharma. There is neither Dharma nor Truth here‚Äù.
Why were the most eminent men in the hall blind to the immense suffering caused to Draupadi? The concept of dharma ruptured at that moment.
Pratibha Ray‚Äôs "Yajnaseni: The Story of Draupadi" is one of the most powerful narratives which unravels the dilemma and plight of Draupadi. The author gives voice to Draupadi‚Äôs angst, ‚ÄúFull of anguish and anger I was thinking: was woman merely man‚Äôs movable or immovable property? Being a woman did I not have the right even over myself, my own soul? If they had rights over this body of mine, did it mean they could do as they wished with me?‚Äù
The same question arises when one witnesses the plight and suffering of women wrestlers who brought glory to our country.
Wonder whether anything has changed at all? Draupadi continues to be slighted even today.
(This photograph which depicts the dice game from Mahabharata, is from a small panel in the Amruteshwara Temple at Amruthapura in Chikmagalur district)
04/06/23, 12:46‚ÄØpm
The catastrophic train accident resulting in scores of deaths, is an unsurpassed human tragedy in recent time. Many more have been injured and the traumatic event will leave its footprints in their memory for long. Such terrifying experiences lurk deeply within, impacting emotional life and behaviour in myriad, unsettling ways. Coping with internalized trauma over time, is not an easy task.
WHR Rivers (whose death anniversary is today) in his pioneering work drew attention to the terrifying internalized experiences of traumatic memories, albeit in a different context, World War I.
River‚Äôs insightful observation was that traumatic memories were often repressed because there was a ‚Äúconflict between the mental tendencies of the individual and the traditional code of conduct prescribed by society‚Äù. He published an account of his work in the Lancet in 1918, stating: ‚ÄòNew symptoms often arise in hospital or at home which are not the immediate and necessary consequence of the war experience, but are due to repression of painful memories and thoughts, or of unpleasant affective states arising out of reflection concerning this experience.‚Äô
In dealing with these troublesome memories, Rivers emphasized the importance of a humanistic engagement with the traumatised patients, exploring the meaning of their experiences through ‚Äôtalking cure‚Äô. He employed what he termed as ‚Äòautognosis‚Äô, which was a two-part process. The first was focused on educating the patient and helping him to realize that the illness he was experiencing was neither ‚Äústrange‚Äù nor permanent. The second part was talk therapy, which involved discussing traumatic experiences at an in-depth level with patients and helping them to work through their painful experiences in more positive ways.
Notable amongst his patients the war poet Siegfried Sassoon, who wrote fondly of Rivers compassionate bedside manner in a poem which he sent to the poet Robert Graves:
But yesterday my reasoning Rivers ran solemnly in,
With peace in the pools of his spectacled eyes and a wisely omnipotent grin;
And I fished in that steady grey stream and decided that I
after all am no longer the Worm that refuses to die.
Pat Barker‚Äô ‚ÄòRegeneration Trilogy‚Äô gives a wonderful, fictionalized account of WHR Rivers and his monumental work with soldiers traumatized by the war
05/06/23, 7:21‚ÄØam
It is a sad and uncomfortable truth that we have become alienated from the environment we live in. Environmental degradation in the guise of development is occurring at an increasing, unsettling pace. Hardly do we realize that the environment within and outside of us are deeply interconnected. Every day of our lives, our breath connects us to the environment. We gasp for fresh air in the midst of clouds of pollutants that hold their unrelenting sway over us.
World environment day draws attention to the need for a deep communion and communication between us and the environment. As Thoreau commented, ‚ÄúWhat is the use of a house if you haven't got a tolerable planet to put it on?‚Äù
Let us heed to the sanely advice of Theodore Roosevelt, who was instrumental in establishing 150 national forests, 51 federal bird reserves, four national game preserves, five national parks and 18 national monuments on over 230 million acres of public land: ‚ÄúHere is your country. Cherish these natural wonders, cherish the natural resources, cherish the history and romance as a sacred heritage, for your children and your children's children. Do not let selfish men or greedy interests skin your country of its beauty, its riches or its romance.‚Äù
07/06/23, 6:39‚ÄØam
As we journey in life, often we pose a question to ourselves: Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going? A question that has been in the realm of philosophers down the ages. It was also the title of a famous painting by Paul Gaugin (whose birthday is today). He started working on it when he was beset with multiple problems; his health was failing, he was estranged from his wife and his daughter to whom he was deeply attached, died of pneumonia. In throes of deep distress, he started wondering about the meaning and purpose of his life. This massive painting was an expression of this search.
After finishing the canvas in feverish frenzy, he put down the brush, walked up a hill near his home in Tahiti and swallowed a huge amount of arsenic. But the arsenic failed to kill him.
He wrote a detailed note about this work and mentioned, ‚ÄúI believe that this canvas not only surpasses all my previous work, but that I will never do anything better or even like it. Before dying I put into it all my energy, a passion so painful, in terrible circumstances, and a vision so clear, needing no correction, that the hastiness disappears and life surges up‚Ä¶I have finished a philosophical work on this theme, comparable to the Gospels‚Äù.
Often, while looking at paintings like this, I wonder, how does a painting begin in an artist‚Äôs mind, unravel itself in forms and colours, find its way within us and does this each and every time we look at it?
08/06/23, 7:40‚ÄØam
I have enjoyed watching Anthony Bourdain‚Äôs shows. His gastronomical pursuits often in exotic locales with his cocky commentaries were always fun to watch. Hence it was a surprise that he took his life on this day five years ago.
Every suicide is a mystery and tragedy unto itself. There is often a background against which the act is enacted. There were indications of simmering emotional distress which Bourdain himself acknowledged. ‚ÄòSpirals of depression‚Äô, left him lonely and exhausted. Only once he met up with a therapist in Buenos Aires, which was aired in a 2016 ‚ÄúParts Unknown‚Äù segment. ‚ÄúI can find myself in a spiral of depression that can last for days,‚Äù he tells the therapist and goes on to add, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an isolating feeling. I communicate for a living but I‚Äôm terrible at communicating with the people I care about.‚Äù He also shared with the therapist, a recurring dream he had been having that involved him being stuck inside a Victorian-style hotel with ‚Äúendless rooms and hallways, where he could never check out.‚Äù He recalled wanting to go home during the dream, but never being able to remember where his home actually was.
The dream is so poignant reflecting the travails of a media star who was wandering from place to place, shooting episodes in far off locations and haunted by crushing loneliness. He seemed to have lived an untethered existence.
It is tragic that even though he acknowledged his emotional distress, he never sought proper professional assistance and that too in a country where every source of help is was available. Media stars lead a double life. Their public image is often in stark contrast to their private lives. Once the gulf widens, they unfortunately get trapped within the image while their angst and distress remain in the realm of ‚ÄúParts Unknown‚Äù. This incidentally was the title of his popular show.
As Kay Redfield Jamison wrote in her book, ‚ÄòNight Falls Fast: Understanding Suicide‚Äô, ‚ÄúSuicide is not a blot on anyone‚Äôs name; it is a tragedy‚Ä¶.each way to suicide is its own: intensely private, unknowable, and terrible. Suicide will have seemed to its perpetrator the last and best of bad possibilities, and any attempt by the living to chart this final terrain of life can be only a sketch, maddeningly incomplete ‚Äù
09/06/23, 7:52‚ÄØam
There is something magical about oceans. Sometimes it is calm and welcoming. It is a soothing experience to hear the sea water gently caressing the sandy shores. It has other moods too, when suddenly huge waves crash onto the shores with renewed vigor. It is playful when it catches you unaware, stroking your feet with a warm spray as you walk carefully along the edges, trying to keep your feet clean. Sometimes when I see plastic bottles and trash thrown carelessly on its shore, I wonder whether it is weeping silently, within. Whatever way I strive to describe it, there is always something that eludes me.
When its water touches me, I am aware that I am touching eternity.
The poet Nayyirah Waheed articulated this feeling beautifully:
‚Äúif
the ocean
can calm itself,
so can you.
we
are both
salt water
mixed with
air.‚Äù
(Yesterday was the World Ocean Day)
10/06/23, 8:45‚ÄØam
This post is about a diminutive, captivating temple. Since it is a bit long, I‚Äôve posted it in my website. Take time over the weekend, savour it and feel free to share your perceptions in the blog: https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/mesmerizing-melakadambur
11/06/23, 8:02‚ÄØam
Long back, I picked up a slim novel, ‚ÄòLie down in darkness‚Äô by William Styron. It was a deeply unsettling, poignant account of a family in the process of disintegration. It opens with the suicide of the daughter of the family and as the novel unfolds, we get to know her turbulent emotional background behind the act of self-destruction. As she narrates, ‚ÄúWhich is worse, past or future? Neither. I will fold up my mind like a leaf and drift on this stream over the brink. Which will be soon, and then the dark, and then be done with this ugliness...‚Äù
Many years late, William Styron found himself in throes of a similar overwhelming sadness. He went through a period of prolonged, severe, suicidal depression and wrote a harrowing account of his experience in ‚ÄòDarkness Visible: A Memoir of Madness‚Äô. Characterizing depression as ‚Äòthe howling tempest in the brain‚Äô, he described it as "a disorder of mood, so mysteriously painful and elusive in the way it becomes known to the self ‚Äì to the mediating intellect, as to verge close to being beyond description. It thus remains nearly incomprehensible to those who have not experienced it in its extreme mode.‚Äù
At the end of the book, the author comments, referring to Dante: ‚ÄúFor those who have dwelt in depression‚Äôs dark wood, and known its inexplicable agony, their return from the abyss is not unlike the ascent of the poet, trudging upward and upward out of hell‚Äôs black depths and at last emerging into what he saw as ‚Äòthe shining world.‚Äô There, whoever has been restored to health has almost always been restored to the capacity for serenity and joy, and this may be indemnity enough for having endured the despair beyond despair.‚Äù
The book is a moving vocabulary of depression that unlocks the unspoken, hidden suffering of many who are afflicted with it.
The title ‚ÄòDarkness Visible‚Äô, might sound a bit puzzling. It alludes to a poem in Milton‚Äôs ‚ÄòParadise Lost‚Äô:
‚ÄúNow the thought
Both of lost happiness and lasting pain
Torments him; round he throws his baleful eyes
That witnessed huge affliction and dismay
Mixed with obdurate pride and steadfast hate:
At once as far as angels ken he views
The dismal situation waste and wild,
A dungeon horrible, on all sides round
As one great furnace flamed, yet from those flames
No light, but rather darkness visible
Served only to discover sights of woe,
Regions of sorrow, doleful shades, where peace
And rest can never dwell, hope never comes
That comes to all; but torture without end
Still urges, and a fiery deluge, fed
With ever-burning sulfur unconsumed.‚Äù
In this book, William Styron (whose birthday is today) extends a reassuring hand to those suffering from depression by pointing out that it is possible to see and work through the darkness of depression and continue the journey in life, afresh.
12/06/23, 10:43‚ÄØam
National Red Rose Day is celebrated on June 12, to pay tribute to one of the most iconic symbols of love and romance throughout history.
In Greek myth, roses are closely linked with Adonis, the lover of Aphrodite. One day, Adonis was gored by a wild boar during a hunting trip and died in Aphrodite‚Äôs arms as she wept; the first red roses were said to have sprung up from his blood as it soaked into the earth, staining the nearby white roses a deep crimson. Red roses came to be inextricably linked to romantic love, highlighting that such love transcends death and lives on beyond the lovers‚Äô own short lives.
Interestingly, in three different languages, Spanish, Portuguese and French, the word ‚Äòrose‚Äô means ‚Äòred‚Äô!
14/06/23, 5:23‚ÄØam
Memory is an intrinsic part of our everyday lives. We are what we remember and what we forget too. Our brains are designed to forget things. Many a time when I try to recollect things, I can sense the chaos in my neuronal circuitry!
Is it possible for someone to remember everything in his life?
The first documented case of extraordinary memory was by the celebrated Russian psychologist Alexander Luria. Starting in the 1920s, the person whom he studied was able to remember long sequences of numbers and details many years after hearing them. After studying the person for more than 30 years, Luria confessed his inability to find a limit to his memory, a surprising statement considering that it came from one of the foremost psychologists of his time.
In the realm of literature, there is an interesting short story ‚ÄòFunes The Memorious‚Äô, by Jorge Luis Borges, who died on this day in 1986. It narrates the travails of Ireneo Funes, who after falling off a horse and hitting his head hard, recovers consciousness with the incredible ability or perhaps curse, of remembering absolutely everything. Borges suggests that this kind of extraordinary memory has its own pitfalls. Says Fune, ‚ÄúI alone have more memories than all men may have ever had since the world exists. My memory, sir, is like a rubbish heap.‚Äù
Borges goes on to write, ‚ÄúOf the magical compadrito of my story I can state that he is a precursor to supermen, a suburban, incomplete Zarathustra; what cannot be denied is that he is a monster.‚Äù
In the era of ChatGPT and AI, ‚ÄòFunes the Memorious,‚Äô the story about a man who remembers everything, but understands nothing seems so visionary!
Borges also wrote some captivating poems, like this one about the tiger:
THE OTHER TIGER
A tiger comes to mind. The twilight here
Exalts the vast and busy Library
And seems to set the bookshelves back in gloom;
Innocent, ruthless, bloodstained, sleek
It wanders through its forest and its day
Printing a track along the muddy banks
Of sluggish streams whose names it does not know
(In its world there are no names or past
Or time to come, only the vivid now)
And makes its way across wild distances
Sniffing the braided labyrinth of smells
And in the wind picking the smell of dawn
And tantalizing scent of grazing deer;
Among the bamboo's slanting stripes I glimpse
The tiger's stripes and sense the bony frame
Under the splendid, quivering cover of skin.
Curving oceans and the planet's wastes keep us
Apart in vain; from here in a house far off
In South America I dream of you,
Track you, O tiger of the Ganges' banks.
It strikes me now as evening fills my soul
That the tiger addressed in my poem
Is a shadowy beast, a tiger of symbols
And scraps picked up at random out of books,
A string of labored tropes that have no life,
And not the fated tiger, the deadly jewel
That under sun or stars or changing moon
Goes on in Bengal or Sumatra fulfilling
Its rounds of love and indolence and death.
To the tiger of symbols I hold opposed
The one that's real, the one whose blood runs hot
As it cuts down a herd of buffaloes,
And that today, this August third, nineteen
Fifty-nine, throws its shadow on the grass;
But by the act of giving it a name,
By trying to fix the limits of its world,
It becomes a fiction not a living beast,
Not a tiger out roaming the wilds of earth.
We'll hunt for a third tiger now, but like
The others this one too will be a form
Of what I dream, a structure of words, and not
The flesh and one tiger that beyond all myths
Paces the earth. I know these things quite well,
Yet nonetheless some force keeps driving me
In this vague, unreasonable, and ancient quest,
And I go on pursuing through the hours
Another tiger, the beast not found in verse.
16/06/23, 7:43‚ÄØam
For me nature is home. Being amidst it, soothes my soul. In the midst of tall trees, expansive grasslands, I feel suffused with an indescribable, subtle calmness and peace. It is a meditative experience.
Sometimes I translate what I experience through the camera , which incidentally, is not a high end one. Like all translations, often it may be a poor representation of what I see through my own lenses of perception. I have inscribed those moments within the coils of my neurons and cherish them deeply.
Nature can be very astounding. In the middle of a vast dry desert landscape strewn with barren hills, suddenly one comes face to face a burst of resplendent colours or rocky surfaces. This radiant, multihued mountain landscape is not surprisingly called, The Artist Palette!
(15th June was the National Nature Photography Day)
19/06/23, 10:39‚ÄØam
Walking has a long history. Ever since our earliest hominids took the first bipedal steps, we have not stopped walking! Walking has served as a tool for political protests, affirmation of civil, human rights and in quest of the divine. The simple act of putting one step ahead of the other has also been medicalized over time. Physicians emphasize its health benefits and each and every smartphone has an app to count the number of steps taken during walking. One can often notice people with headphones striding briskly keeping pace with the magical number of healthy steps.
In 1862 David Thoreau‚Äôs wrote an interesting essay titled ‚ÄòWalking‚Äô. In it, he drew attention to the difference between walking and sauntering. When we walk, we concentrate on pace or getting somewhere, as quickly as possible. Sauntering is vastly different. When we saunter, we pause, look around, listen and immerse ourselves in the world outside. Thoreau observed that the word saunter might have originated with those who took pilgrimages to the Holy Land, the sainted land: ‚Äòsainte terre‚Äô. Or perhaps from the idea of being without land ownership, ‚Äòsans terre‚Äô, which, for him, meant having no particular home but being ‚Äúequally at home everywhere.‚Äù The trick, according to Thoreau, is not to take your inside life out but to go present and empty.
We often rush through our lives. How much better it would be to "saunter" along this trail of life, lingering hither and thither, pausing for a while in the company of trees, listening to the melodies of the wind as it courses through the leaves, keeping an ear for the songs of the birds and watch petite flowers growing?
In the words of Simon and Garfunkel:
Slow down, you move too fast
You got to make the morning last
Just kicking down the cobblestones
Looking for fun and feeling groovy
Ba da-da da-da da-da, feeling groovy
Hello lamppost, what'cha knowing
I've come to watch your flowers growin'
Ain't you got no rhymes for me?
Doo-ait-n-doo-doo, feeling groovy
Ba da-da da-da da-da, feeling groovy
I got no deeds to do, no promises to keep
I'm dappled and drowsy and ready to sleep
Let the morningtime drop all its petals on me
Life, I love you, all is groovy
(Notes on the World Sauntering Day!)
21/06/23, 8:53‚ÄØam
In Bhagavat Gita, Chapter 6, Dhyana Yoga, Sri Krishna outlines the processes of Ashtanga Yoga, lucidly, in verses 20-23
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ |
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø || ‡•¨-‡•®‡•¶||
yatroparamate chitta·πÅ niruddha·πÅ yoga-sevayƒÅ
yatra chaivƒÅtmanƒÅtmƒÅna·πÅ pa≈õhyann ƒÅtmani tu·π£hyati
When the mind, restrained from material activities, becomes still by the practice of Yoga, then the yogi is able to behold the soul through the purified mind, and he rejoices in the inner joy.
‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡•¨-‡•®‡•ß‡••
sukhamƒÅtyantika·πÉ yattad buddhigrƒÅhyamatƒ´ndriyam
vetti yatra na caivƒÅya·πÉ sthita≈õcalati tattvata·∏•
When he (the Yogi) feels that Infinite bliss which can be grasped by the (pure) intellect and which transcends the senses he never moves from the Reality;
‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•¨-‡•®‡•®‡••
ya·πÉ labdhvƒÅ cƒÅpara·πÉ lƒÅbha·πÉ manyate nƒÅdhika·πÉ tata·∏•
yasminsthito na du·∏•khena guru·πáƒÅpi vicƒÅlyate
Which, having obtained, he thinks there is no other gain superior to it; wherein established, he is not moved even by heavy sorrow.
‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§æ ‡•• ‡•¨-‡•®‡•©‡••
ta·πÉ vidyƒÅd du·∏•khasa·πÉyogaviyoga·πÉ yogasa·πÉj√±itam
sa ni≈õcayena yoktavyo yogo‚Äônirvi·πá·πáacetasƒÅ
Let it be known: the severance from the union with pain is Yoga. This Yoga should be practised with determination and with a mind steady and undespairing.
(This small, exquisitely carved wooden panel is from Thirukkurungudi Temple, Tirunelveli)
22/06/23, 10:48‚ÄØam
There is something surreal about venturing into a rainforest. It was quite sunny when I entered the forest, but soon I was enveloped in darkness with sun peering through the tall trees occasionally. It was humid inside and the noisy cicadas showered me with their squirts of fluid, like raindrops. I made my way gingerly amongst the moist leaves and broken branches in the forest floor. Birds kept fluttering by but it was difficult to observe them clearly in the dense foliage. The Japanese have a wonderful word to describe the experience, ‚Äòshinrin-yoku‚Äô or ‚Äòforest bathing‚Äô. It refers to the contemplative experience of being immersed in the sights, sounds and smells of the forest.
Rainforests are cradles of biodiversity. Unfortunately, their loss continues, unabated at a blistering pace. As EO Wilson commented, ‚Äúdestroying rainforests for economic gains is like burning a renaissance painting to cook a meal‚Äù.
The rainforests hold answers for many of the question that besiege us in an era of escalating global warming. The problem is that we turn a deaf ear to them.
A world without rainforest is akin to a man without lungs.
Let us wander into the rainforest where the wifi is weak, discover its magic, feel and cherish the connection to Mother Earth.
(Today is the World Rainforest Day)
28/06/23, 9:39‚ÄØam
Akkamahadevi was a poet, saint, wanderer, mystic and seeker and her vachanas are passionate dialogues expressing her spiritual quest to unite with her Lord Chennamallikarjuna. In her journey in search of the divine, she found her home in the lap of nature amidst the dense forests of Kadali in the Srisaila mountain ranges of Andhra Pradesh and merged into the infinite.
Many of her vachanas abound with vivid descriptions of nature in which she converses with chirping birds, dancing peacocks and butterflies, asking them whether they have seen her divine lover. The very word she used to address her beloved Shiva was Chennamallikarjuna, which AK Ramanujam translated as ‚ÄúLord, white as jasmine‚Äù.
Whenever I venture into a forest, this vachana of Akkamahadevi (which I have outlined in the photograph) wherein she experiences all of nature as a manifestation of the Lord Chennamallikarjuna, resonates deeply within me.
When the inner and outer world merge, we embrace the divine ‚ÄòOneness‚Äô.
30/06/23, 5:14‚ÄØpm
A resilient person indeed. Music must have been his soul mate during the solitary journey. Wish he continues his journey peacefully.
02/07/23, 8:56‚ÄØam
What draws me to Hermann Hesse (whose birthday is today), is his emphasis on self-realization in his novels. The quest for authentic self is a continuing strand in most of his works. The greatest example of it is of course, his slender novel, Siddhartha. The protagonist wanders through ancient India, in pursuit of an enlightened way of life, during the course of which he experiments with both spartan asceticism and luxurious hedonism. In the book‚Äôs most important scene, Siddhartha actually encounters the Buddha, but spurns him as he perceives that any kind of religion is an obstacle to enlightenment. ‚ÄúNo one will ever attain redemption through doctrine! After all, the Buddha didn‚Äôt become the Buddha by following the Buddha!‚Äù Eventually, he finds spiritual wisdom by contemplating the flow of a great river and realizes that one can discover the true self only through wading alone in the waters of consciousness.
Hermann Hesse underwent two spells of therapy with Jung. In his diary, he recorded some advice that the renowned analyst gave him. ‚ÄúLife‚Äôs problems aren‚Äôt there to be cleanly solved, each of them is a pair of opposites, that between them produce a tension that is called life‚Äù.
Hermann Hesse was also a keen observer of nature, especially trees. He wrote:
‚ÄúFor me, trees have always been the most penetrating preachers‚Ä¶ in their highest boughs the world rustles, their roots rest in infinity; but they do not lose themselves there, they struggle with all the force of their lives for one thing only: to fulfil themselves according to their own laws, to build up their own form, to represent themselves. Nothing is holier, nothing is more exemplary than a beautiful, strong tree.‚Äù
03/07/23, 11:58‚ÄØam
There are three kinds of teachers, in the context of spiritual education: Upadhyaya, Acharya, and Guru. Upadhyaya is one who teaches as a means of livelihood. Acharya is a preceptor who is a teacher and a guide. Guru is one who apart from imparting knowledge, guides the student to the path of liberation.
Advayataraka Upanishad which is one of the 19 Upanishads attached to the Shukla Yajurveda, gives a description of the Gure in verse 16:
‡§ó‡•Å‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•ß‡•¨‡••
The syllable Gu indicates darkness, the syllable Ru means its dispeller,
Because of the quality of dispelling darkness, the Guru is thus termed.
Four types of speech are described in ancient literature: verbal, mental, visual, and the transcendental. The verbal communication called as Vaikari. Higher than Vaikhari is Madhyama which is non-verbal communication through thoughts. Still advanced is Pashyanti which is communication through visual imagery, the person is made to ‚Äúsee‚Äù through the inner eye. The greatest form is ‚ÄúPara‚Äù which is ‚ÄúSilence,‚Äù where communication is without words, thoughts, or visions. It is kind of inner, intuitive, transcendental knowledge which is taught by Dakshinamurthy.
In every Siva temple the stone image of Dakshinamurthy is installed, facing south, on the southern circumambulatory path around the sanctum sanctorum. Perhaps, of all Hindu Gods, he is the only one sitting facing south.
This depiction of Dakshninamurthy is in the ceiling of Lokamahadevi temple at Pattadakkal. He is in a serene, meditative stance, yoga patta across him, with one leg on top of apasmara, flanked by two rishis and rishi patnis.
‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ú‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É
The one who is the abode of all the knowledge, who is the healer of the diseased
The Guru to all the lokas, Salutations to you, Lord Dakshinamurthy
Dr Raguram
04/07/23, 9:01‚ÄØam
A few years ago, I visited Belur math and expressed a desire to see the room where Swami Vivekananda used to reside. The room was facing the Ganga and the river was flowing gently caressed by the morning sun. It was such a serene setting and I could imagine the Swami meditating, absorbed in the scenic beauty of the river. The room was full of various objects and artefacts used by him, including a pakhawaj and tanpura. There was a bed on the floor with a garlanded photograph of his.
This was the place where the Swami passed away on this day, at the age of thirty nine years, five months and twenty four days. He embraced death, free of any fear or apprehension. He remarked to his devotees, ‚ÄúI shall never see forty‚Ä¶ I delivered my message and I must go‚Ä¶ The shadow of a big tree will not let the smaller trees grow up. I must go to make room.‚Äù In one of his letters to his disciples, he commented, ‚ÄúComing and going is all pure delusion. The soul never comes nor goes. Where is the place to which it shall go, when all space is in the soul? When shall be the time for entering and departing, when all time is in the soul?‚Äù
One of the most popular saying of Swami Vivekananda is ‚ÄúArise, Awake, and stop not till the goal is reached.‚Äù This has its origin in Katha Upanishad. In Katha Upanishad, chapter 1.3.14, we see Yama suggesting Nachiketa‚Äî
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§§,
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§™‡§•: ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø |
Arise! Awake! Approach the great and learn.
Like the sharp edge of a razor is that path,
so the wise say‚àíhard to tread and difficult to cross.
As Swami observed, ‚ÄúSharp as the blade of a razor, long and difficult and hard to cross, is the way to liberation. The sages have declared this again and again. Yet do not let any weakness or failure bind you. The Upanishads have declared, ‚ÄòArise! Awake! and stop not until the goal is reached.‚Äô Cross the path, sharp as it is like the razor, however difficult it may be‚Äù.

I personally feel very strong within whenever I read or hear about Swami Vivekananda's words. They are so sharp, no mincing of words and ignites the strength within.
