08/07/23, 9:18‚ÄØam
Manipur is burning and hearts have been singed. All our students who are from that region and currently staying outside are overwhelmed with deep distress and beset by a sense of helplessness. Many of them have reached out expressing their profound anguish. They are unable to reach their family and their loved ones.
The tangled web of violence has had a long imprint in our nation, right from the time of partition. Isn‚Äôt it imperative then, that as a nation we strive to address its recurrence with resolve and emotional commitment? Not a word from the head of our nation still. Mahatma Gandhi, if he was alive today would have taken the moral responsibility to quell the embers of violence, by actually being there.
As Buddha observed, ‚ÄúOur sorrows and wounds are healed only when we touch them with compassion.‚Äù
Unfortunately that seems to be in short supply these days as lives continue to slip through uncaring hands . . .
11/07/23, 8:23‚ÄØam
Many of us grew up reading the piquant writings of Franz Kafka. On his birthday last week, I picked up his ‚ÄòMetamorphosis‚Äô and read it again. It is a very intriguing novel which opens with a most preposterous scenario. Gregor Samsa, awakes one morning to find himself ‚Äútransformed in his bed into a horrible vermin‚Äù. He was the primary breadwinner of the family which was beset with various problems: his father an invalid, his mother asthmatic and his sister a young, frivolous girl. We follow Gregor and his family as they navigate through their turmoil to reconcile with his transformation. As the family struggles to come to terms with this change, they increasingly ill-treat and neglect him. He becomes isolated from his family, who hide him away in his bedroom. Gregor spends his time listening through the wall to his family members talking. They often discuss the difficult financial situation they find themselves in now that Gregor can‚Äôt provide for them. There is never any talk of seeking help or attempts at understanding Gregor‚Äôs transformation. Once he even hears his sister, who was once his close friend, saying ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt carry on like this. Maybe you can‚Äôt see it, but I can. I don‚Äôt want to call this monster my brother, all I can say is: we have to try and get rid of it.‚Äù
Gregor‚Äôs end is quite poignant: ‚ÄúHe soon made the discovery that he was no longer capable of moving at all. He remained in this state of empty, peaceful reflection until the clock tower struck the third hour of morning. He watched as everything began to lighten outside his window. Then his head sank all the way to the floor without volition and from his nostrils his last breath faintly streamed.‚Äù The cleaning lady gets rid of his body.
Metamorphosis lends itself to variety of interpretations. For me it is symbolic of the manner people respond to disabling changes to a member of the family. People‚Äôs attitudes towards the disabled continue to be much like Grete‚Äôs. Taking care of them is often considered troublesome and they are treated as economic and emotional liabilities. His story mirrors the real world attitudes towards those who do not fit with the notions of accepted normality. Gregor is no longer a ‚Äòdear one‚Äô for the family, but a 'despicable creature' who has become a source of shame and embarrassment for them. Any person can metamorphose into an impaired being due to illness and changes that they have no control over. The novel outlines the dark side of dehumanization of a disabled person and the ostracism they have to endure. Although fictitious, Gregor‚Äôs situation echoes the anguish and pain experienced by bodily and emotionally challenged individuals even now.
Kafka himself experienced an overwhelming sense of estrangement from his family, ‚ÄúFaced with intolerance and the tyranny of my parents, I live with my family more as a stranger than a foreigner‚Äù. He lived in a state of anxious solitude, not at home with his family, never been able to find a woman with whom he could share his travails. Perhaps Kafka perceived himself as an odd, alienated outlier, like Gregor and he wrote in his diary, ‚ÄúI am a cage, in search of a bird.‚Äù
12/07/23, 9:43‚ÄØam
Henry David Thoreau whose birthday is today, was enchanted by trees and they played a significant role in his inner life. They were his constant guides and companions in his spiritual quest. Trees emerge in his writings as special symbols and images of the divine. The forest was his cathedral, the woods his ‚Äúsanctum sanctorum.‚Äù
Thoreau immersed himself in observing the shape, colour, texture and stances of trees. For him, exploring such details was an act of contemplation. ‚ÄúA tree seen against other trees is a mere dark mass, but against the sky it has parts, has symmetry and expression.‚Äù
Trees revealed themselves poetically to Thoreau. They were ‚Äúliving poetry,‚Äù written by nature on the landscape. The shadows of trees on the ground at night were ‚Äúlike chandeliers of darkness.‚Äù
The writings of Thoreau helps me to see trees in new ways and they take on a deeper meaning in the process.
Trees were wordless poems to him and each time I immerse myself listening to their unspoken words, I discover something anew.
Unfortunately, we are losing the tree cover with an alarming rate in India. Around 2.3 million trees have been proposed to be cut to make way for mega infrastructure projects in the country. We are witnessing the biggest decline in deforestation in the past few years. Reports indicate that India lost 668400 hectares of forests in the past five years, second highest globally.
During Thoreau‚Äôs lifetime too, there was increasing deforestation in New England his comment was ‚ÄúThank God, they cannot cut down the clouds!‚Äù
17/07/23, 8:46‚ÄØam
When I joined NIMHANS, Dr RL Kapur gave us a few introductory classes on scientific method of enquiry in understanding human behaviour, which invariably, is complex. In the process, he introduced us to the writings of Henri Poincare, whose death anniversary is today. He quoted Poincare about the role of facts in science, ‚ÄúScience is built up of facts, as a house is with stones. But a collection of facts is no more a science than a heap of stones is a house.‚Äù Science is the process of determining which of the countless facts will be most useful in advancing knowledge.
According to Poincare, every scientific theory is a hypothesis that had to be tested. He emphasized that experience alone is inadequate to falsify a theory and the role of falsified hypothesis is very important in any scientific pursuit.
Poincare also drew attention to the role of intuition in science, ‚ÄúPure logic cannot give us this view of the whole; it is to intuition that we must look for it. It is with logic that one proves; it is with intuition that one invents.‚Äù
I find this particular reflection of his quite interesting: ‚ÄúLife is only a short episode between two eternities and in this episode, conscious thought has lasted and will last only a moment. Thought is only a gleam in the midst of a long night. But it is the gleam which is everything‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
17/07/23, 10:25‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for the glimpse of Poincare's reflections. I think we should develop that bent of mind to go beyond hard facts and that requires acumen. The emphasis on thought, impermanence but it's impact!
19/07/23, 10:22‚ÄØam
Today is the birth anniversary of a poet who was ahead of her times, Balamani Amma.
On this day, I want to share a poem of hers titled ‚ÄòThe Pen‚Äô which has been translated by her talented daughter, poet Kamala Das.
When I touch you, O pen,
you flow like blood in my veins.
You become my lover,
the one who knows my heart‚Äôs pain.
You are my companion,
the one who hears my silent cries.
With your ink, you write my story,
and my deepest desires arise.
You understand my words,
even before they are born.
You give life to my thoughts,
like the first light of morn.
You are my confidant,
the keeper of my secrets untold.
You hold my dreams and hopes,
more precious than silver or gold.
When I caress you, O pen,
I feel the pulse of life.
You become my voice,
in a world filled with strife.
You are my solace,
when darkness engulfs my soul.
With your gentle touch,
you make me feel whole.
When I hold you, O pen,
my spirit begins to soar.
You guide me through the realms,
where imagination and dreams explore.
You are my muse,
my source of inspiration divine.
With you by my side,
I can conquer mountains and cross every line.
O pen, you are my magic wand,
that brings forth a world unknown.
Through your ink, I find freedom,
and my true self is shown.
In your strokes and curves,
my heart finds solace and peace.
You are my silent companion,
in this journey that‚Äôll never cease.
(The attached photo of mine carries a few lines from her poem, ‚ÄòThe Temple‚Äô. It depicts a beautifully carved corridor at the Vanamamalai Perumal temple in Tirunelveli.)
21/07/23, 8:36‚ÄØam
https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/the-joy-of-birding
27/07/23, 8:13‚ÄØam
The sentence ‚ÄúA Rose is a rose is a rose is a rose‚Äù was written by Gertrude Stein (whose death anniversary is today), as part of a poem ‚ÄòSacred Emily‚Äô, which appeared in her 1922 book ‚ÄòGeography and Plays‚Äô. It is in similar vein to Shakespeare's ‚Äúa rose by any other name would smell as sweet.‚Äù Stein later used variations on the sentence in other writings, and ‚ÄúA rose is a rose is a rose‚Äù is among her most famous quotations, often interpreted as meaning ‚Äúthings are what they are.‚Äù
Puzzled by her writing about a rose, someone asked here, ‚ÄòWhy have you said this? We all know a rose is a rose is a rose. It makes no sense. It adds nothing to our knowledge.‚Äô Stein replied, ‚ÄòBecause poets have been talking about roses for millennia ‚Äì millions of poetries about roses, everybody has read them and sung them, and everybody has repeated ‚Äì the word ‚Äúrose‚Äù has lost its rosiness. It doesn‚Äôt say anything anymore. That‚Äôs why I had to repeat, ‚ÄúA rose is a rose is a rose‚Äù ‚Äì so that you are awakened out of your sleep, so that you are shaken a little: ‚ÄúWhat is this woman saying? the absurdity of it! ‚Äì a rose is a rose is a rose. Repeating this I have brought the redness to the rose again.‚Äù
28/07/23, 8:59‚ÄØam
Matsuo Basho (1644-1694), was Japan's most famous poet, most renowned for his haikus. Born into a samurai family, he was deeply drawn into poetry and gave up his ambitions to be a samurai. He was a wanderer and made several long journeys, writing haikus on the way. The journeys were as much forays into interior as exterior, reflecting his abiding spiritual quest. In 1694, Basho set off on his last journey to his birthplace where he wrote his final poem:
Stricken while journeying
my dreams still wander about
but on withered fields
Dr Raguram
31/07/23, 7:58‚ÄØpm
Looking forward to your reflections in the blog!
https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/from-ignorance-to-enlightenment
03/08/23, 12:54‚ÄØpm
Today is the festival of Aadi Perukku, which marks the beginning of agricultural activities in Tamil Nadu, when the river Kaveri is in full flow due to south west monsoon. Farmers start their sowing in the month of Aadi (July-August) so that they can harvest the crops after six months in January during Pongal Festival. On this day people gather on the banks of Kaveri and offer prayers to the river goddess.
River Kaveri fostered civilisations, kingdoms rose on her banks and majestic temples were built on the lands irrigated by it. Great Carnatic composers, scholars and writers lived and wrote in the towns and villages that flanked the river. Sangam poetry and tamil epics like Silappadikaram, celebrated her beauty.
In Pattina Palai, a Tamil poetic work belonging to the Sangam period, Kaveri is referred to as
‚ÄúCauvery, the river that never fails, even if the sky does‚Äù.
‚Äú‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡ÆØ‡Øç‡ÆØ‡Ææ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Øà‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Øà‡ÆØ ‡Æï‡Æü‡Æ±‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æø‚Äù
An interesting verse in Purananooru, one of the eight books in the Sangam literature, draws attention to the maternal instincts of the river.
‚ÄúThe forceful waters of the river Cauvery
That can even uproot a tree,
Takes care of all the living beings of the world
As a woman feeding a child through her breast‚Äù
‚Äú‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ¥‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡Æá‡Æ≤‡Æø‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Æö‡Øç
‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æ∞‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Æø ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡Øç
‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æ§‡Øà ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‚Äù
Ilango Adigal wrote in a similar vein in Silappadigaram:
‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡ÆÖ‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æü‡ØÅ
‡ÆÆ‡Æï‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æï‡Æø
‡Æä‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡Æâ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Æµ‡Æø
‡Æí‡Æ¥‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ∞‡Æø
Long live this fertile country!
Long live Kaveri
That nurtures the country
Like a mother
16/08/23, 10:50‚ÄØam
On this day in 1886, during the early morning hours, Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa gave up his body. He has been ailing from throat cancer for a while and was in throes of immense pain. Even swallowing a small quantities of water was intensely painful. Seeing his suffering, his devotees urged him to seek some assistance to lessen the pain, Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa replied, ‚ÄúI have given my mind to the Divine Mother. How can I bring down my mind to this worthless cage of flesh? The body was born and it will die. But for the soul there is no death.‚Äù
As Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa observed in one of his earlier comments, ‚ÄúTake the case of the infinite ocean. There is no limit to its water. Suppose a pot is immersed in it: there is water both inside and outside the pot. What is this pot? It is 'I-consciousness'. Because of the pot the water appears to be divided into two parts; because of the pot you seem to perceive an inside and an outside. One feels that way as long as this pot of 'I' exists. When the 'I' disappears, what remains cannot be described in words.‚Äù
17/08/23, 7:57‚ÄØpm

17/08/23, 7:57‚ÄØpm
Do pen your reflections in the blog!
26/08/23, 11:56‚ÄØam
Buddha was sitting under the Bodhi tree for thirty days and his disciples were sitting all around him, watching. On about the thirtieth day he opened his eyes and he was shining, he was smiling. His disciples asked him, "Master, what happened to you, did you see God?" He said, "No," "Did you become self-realized?" "No," "Well what happened," and he simply exclaimed, "I am awake!"
26/08/23, 8:58‚ÄØpm
To be awake... Such a deep meaning. Never to get back to darkness.... The statue of Buddha depicts beautifully!
30/08/23, 10:31‚ÄØam
My grand uncle Dr RV Rajam was a well-known medical professional and a passionate bibliophile. Once when I visited him after joining the medical school, he handed over a slim book and asked me to read it. It was ‚ÄòDeath Be Not Proud‚Äô by John Gunther. Once I started reading it, I couldn‚Äôt put it down. Gunther‚Äôs memoir is a moving account of his son Johnny‚Äôs tryst with a fast growing brain tumour and his death.
The book's title comes from one of John Donne's Holy Sonnets, which he wrote after the death of his wife and three of his children. It opens with Gunther's fond, vivid portrait of his son: a young man of extraordinary intellectual promise and fun loving as well. It is a meticulous record of the diagnosis and the exhaustive hunt for various therapeutic options that he and his ex-wife pursued during their son's illness. The second section consists of Johnny‚Äôs letters and diaries which offer rich insights about his life before the onset of the tumour. The concluding part of the book by his mother, Frances is an intensely emotional account of a mother coping with the illness and demise of a beloved child. It ends with the moving last line, "And then like a thief, death stole him".
Death Be Not Proud is a poignantly interwoven account of the family‚Äôs suffering and loss. It is the forerunner of many others that followed, in articulating lived experiences of grief.
Inherent in personal narratives like Death Be Not Proud, is the immeasurable power of words to heal. The concept of bibliotherapy is not new. In ancient Greece, the phrase ‚Äúa healing place for the soul‚Äù was inscribed above the door to the library of Thebes. In the prescient words of the bard, ‚ÄúGive sorrow words, the grief that does not speak knits up the o‚Äôer wrought heart and bids it break.‚Äù
For people in throes of grief, poems do offer comfort and solace.
John Milton wrote in 1671:
‚Äúapt words have power to swage
The tumours of a troubled mind.
And are as balm to festered wound‚Äù
(Today is also the birthday of John Gunther)
Dr Raguram
09/09/23, 10:31‚ÄØpm
What a wonderful tree, Buddha, photograph and the apt caption! The 'root', True self and silence, nothing but bliss....
17/09/23, 10:36‚ÄØam
Wild boars have been an integral part of the Indian ecosystem and have been mentioned in various folklores and mythologies. Among them, one of the most prominent reference to the wild boars is that of Varaha, the third avatar of Vishnu. It is a fascinating tale of how the earth goddess Bhudevi was captured by the demon Hiranayaksha and trapped in the cosmic waters. Vishnu then took the form of a divine boar and rescued her after battling the demon for a thousand years.
Varaha worship was significant in Central India during the Gupta period, particularly from the 4th to the 6th century CE. The worship of Varaha was also important in southern India, especially during the early Chalukyan period. They were the first dynasty to adopt boar as their symbol. Later the Vijayanagar dynasty also chose the boar as their royal emblem
In sculptural tradition, Varaha is usually depicted in two distinct ways: one is with the head of a boar and torso of a man, which is called the ‚ÄòNaravaraha‚Äô, and the other as a wild boar. Khajuraho has one of the best-known representations of Varaha in the wild boar form. One of the most beautiful depictions of Varaha as ‚ÄòNaravaraha‚Äô, is at the Mahakuta temple which dates back to 5th-6th centry.
Varaha avatar symbolizes the preservation and restoration of the world and the triumph of good over evil. Today, when our earth faces a serious threat from several modern demons, the chief of which is our own endless greed, it‚Äôs time to feel inspired by Varaha!
(Today is also celebrated as Varaha Jayanthi)
Dr Raguram
27/09/23, 10:11‚ÄØam
Our journey in life is ultimately about knowing ourselves. When we burrow deep within ourselves, the inner landscape unfolds, offering a glimpse of the potentials and challenges within. It may not be an easy task. As we diligently busy ourselves, like the crab shovelling each layer, the richness and depth of our self, unfolds.
Embrace the process of burrowing and discover yourself‚Ä¶it is like coming home.

30/09/23, 10:22‚ÄØam
I never get tired of reading Rumi, whose birthday is today. His insightful words and verses about life, love and unity of spirit touches me deeply. There is so much spiritual wisdom in his writings. He was an independent soul yearning for true freedom from dogma and hypocrisy and wrote about the abolishment of fear based religious orders. His prime message is that God is found in your own heart; ‚ÄúEvery moment I shape my destiny with a chisel. I am a carpenter of my own soul.‚Äù
He articulated a notion of a "religion of love," and wrote that "since we worship the one God/ Then all religions must be one." Remarkably at his funeral in Konya, Turkey, in 1273, the procession included not only singers and dancers, besides the traditional chanting from the Quran, but also there were Christian priests chanting the Gospel and Jewish rabbis reciting Psalms.
Just before his death, he recited one of his most inspirational words;
‚ÄúWhen I die; when my coffin is being taken out
you must never think I am missing this world.
Don't shed any tears, don't lament or feel sorry. I'm not falling into a monster's abyss.
When you see my corpse is being carried,
don‚Äôt cry for my leaving.
I'm not leaving; I'm arriving at eternal love.
When you leave me in the grave, don't say goodbye.
Remember a grave is only a curtain for the paradise behind.
You'll only see me descending into a grave, now watch me rise.
How can there be an end? When the sun sets
or the moon goes down, it looks like the end,
It seems like a sunset, but in reality, it is dawn.
When the grave locks you up, that is when your soul is freed.
Have you ever seen a seed fallen to earth not rise with a new life?
Why should you doubt the rise of a seed named man?. . .
When, for the last time, you close your mouth,
Your words and soul will belong to the world of no place, no time.‚Äù
And these words are inscribed in his tomb;
‚ÄúWhen we are dead, seek not our tomb in the earth, but find it in the hearts of men‚Äú.
Dr Raguram
01/10/23, 9:16‚ÄØam
Fantastic Sir. It echoes what our spiritual texts talk about. Absolutely no contradiction about the absolute truth. Thank you Sir.
03/10/23, 7:31‚ÄØpm
https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/magnificent-mucukunda-murals
06/10/23, 9:05‚ÄØam
There is a mystery about rivers that inspires poets. Alfred Tennyson, (whose death anniversary is today), was no exception and wrote a wonderful poem, ‚ÄòThe Brook‚Äô. It was written six years before his death. The poem narrates the journey of a brook as it flows over hills and by villages, seeing various sights on its way, to ultimately join the river. The premise of the poem is that our lives are like rivers which are sometime peaceful, other times turbulent. We drift along, occasionally tossed over by the rapids. When we finally merge with the river and then the vast ocean, there is no end but a new beginning. The poem ends with these beautiful lines:
And out again I curve and flow
To join the brimming river,
For men may come and men may go,
But I go on for ever.
Dr Raguram
07/10/23, 9:54‚ÄØam
Smile made its appearance first in sculptures during the Archaic Period in 6th -7th century BC. The characteristic smile on Greek statues was often referred to as the Archaic smile. It was believed that this kind of smile reflected a state of ideal health and well-being. The goddess Aphrodite, one of the 12 Greek Olympian gods, was called ‚Äúlover of smiles‚Äù.
Closer home, smiling visages started appearing in sculptures, especially that of Buddha during the Gupta period. Bharatha in Natyashashtra described two forms of smile.
ƒ´·π£advikasitair ga·πá·∏çai·∏• ka·π≠ƒÅk·π£ai·∏• sau·π£·π≠havƒÅnvitai·∏•
alak·π£itadvija·πÉ dhƒ´ram uttamƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ smita·πÉ bhavet || 54 |
‚ÄúWith cheeks slightly expanded, with glances of perfect qualities, not showing the teeth, stable, should be the smile (smita) of the highest characters.‚Äù 54
utphullƒÅnananetra·πÉ yad ga·πá·∏çair vikasitair atha
ki·πÉcillak·π£itadanta·πÉ ca hasita·πÉ tad vidhƒ´yate || 55 ||
‚ÄúThat which blooms the mouth and the eyes, expands the cheeks, shows the teeth slightly, is prescribed as smile (hasita).‚Äù 55
I was looking at my library of images to locate a sculpture which depicts ‚Äòsmita‚Äô and this particular one from Khajuraho seemed to represent the description of Bharatha, closely. The smile on the face of this alluring maiden is so well delineated with elongations of the ends of the line of joined lips, slightly swollen cheeks and enlarged nostril base. The almond-shaped eyes are almost on a level with the cheeks and brows, giving an expression of tenderness and bliss.
A smile
Though frozen in time
Still enchants
(Yesterday 6th October was the World Smile Day!)
Dr Raguram
09/10/23, 8:08‚ÄØam
Beatles had a very productive sojourn in Rishikesh with Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, penning several beautiful songs. One day the Maharishi gave a lecture about the power of nature and the cycle of life comparing it to the cycle of human nature. Both John and Paul were inspired by his words. John wrote ‚ÄòChild of Nature‚Äô and Paul came up with ‚ÄòMother Nature‚Äôs Son‚Äô. When John heard Paul‚Äôs song he felt it captured what he wanted to say better and ‚ÄòChild of Nature‚Äô, did not figure in any of Beatles albums. It was released as part of the so called Esher demos. Much later, Lennon wrote a song ‚ÄòJealous Guy‚Äô, with exactly the same melody but with completely different lyrics.
Although not as well-known as Lennon‚Äôs other songs, it has a lingering beauty:
On the road to Rishikesh
I was dreaming more or less
And the dream I had was true
Yes, the dream I had was true
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
I don‚Äôt need much to set me free
I‚Äôm just child of nature
I‚Äôm one of nature‚Äôs children
Sunlight shining in your eyes
As I face the desert skies
And my thoughts return to home
Yes, my thoughts return to home
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
I don‚Äôt need much to set me free
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
I‚Äôm one nature‚Äôs children
Underneath the mountain ranges
Where the wind that never changes
Touch the windows of my soul
Touch the windows of my soul
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
I don‚Äôt need much to set me free
I‚Äôm just a child of nature
On John Lennon‚Äôs birthday, you can listen to the song here: https://youtu.be/cGAw_k3maXs?si=dxAZesV2--hLNfw6
Dr Raguram
18/10/23, 10:02‚ÄØam
Our lives seldom turn out to be the way that we want it to be. As Lao Tzu said 2500 years ago, ‚ÄúLife is a series of natural and spontaneous changes. Don‚Äôt resist them‚Äîthat only creates sorrow. Let things flow naturally forward in whatever way they like.‚Äù As we flow in the river of our lives there are fleeting moments when we come close to ourselves and feel at home. These experiences are incredibly intense and indescribable.
Such personal experiences form the core of Zen. The teachings of Zen focus on these moments. Zen has no God to worship, no ceremonial rites to observe. It does not attach any intrinsic importance to the sacred sutras or to their exegeses by the wise and learned.
The first book to cogently outline basic premises of Zen way of life, ‚ÄòIntroduction to Zen Buddhism‚Äô, was authored by D T Suzuki (whose birthday is today) in 1927. Carl Jung wrote a lucid foreword introducing the tenets of Zen and locating it in the larger framework of Buddhist thought.
As Suzuki writes in the book, ‚ÄúZen teaches nothing; it merely enables us to wake up and become aware. It does not teach, it points.‚Äù
There is so much wisdom in these words of Suzuki, ‚ÄúUnless it grows out of yourself no knowledge is really yours, it is only borrowed plumage.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
22/10/23, 9:41‚ÄØam
The Brahmapuriswara temple is situated in the tiny hamlet of Pullamangai, on the outskirts of Pasupathikoyil in Thanjavur District. Dating back to 10th century, it is an outstanding example of early Chola temple architecture. Though comparatively smaller, it has some of the finest sculptures. Prominent among them is an exquisite depiction of Durga on the north wall of the temple.
Durga is depicted standing on the head of the buffalo. The goddess is tall and slender and stands in a tribhanga pose; tri meaning ‚Äúthree‚Äù and bhanga meaning ‚Äúposture‚Äù. It entails bending the body at three places, namely the knee, the hip and the shoulder. The flowing lines of the sculpture have an entrancing, sinuous quality. Rarely seen outside of Chola temples, is the umbrella (called the Venkotra Kudai) over Her head. On the right, above, is a small stylised lion and on the left a deer held by a bhuta. The presence of the deer is rather unusual. Thirugnanasambandar in Tevaram, Irandam Thirumurai, refers to Durga having a deer as ‚Äòkalaiyathurthi‚Äô.
Two kneeling figures are depicted in the wall on either side of the main niche, cutting parts of their body as a sacrificial gesture. The person on the left is seen holding his hair with his left hand and is attempting to cut off his head with his right hand. The one on the right is about the cut off his leg at the knee. A similar depiction can be found in the Draupathi Ratham at Mahabalipuram.
What struck me was the portrayal of Durga. Here the focus is not on the combat with Mahishasura but her triumphant visage after vanquishing him. There is sheer elegance in the depiction of Durga. Her face is very serene with a tranquil smile on her lips as described in the Devimahatmyam.
‡§à‡§∑‡§• ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞
‡§≠‡•Ä‡§¨‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡•ç
‚ÄúGently smiling, spotless resembling the full moon orb, beautiful as the choicest gold and lovely was thy face.‚Äù
One of the meanings of HER name is fortress. Durga reminds us of the fortress which we each carry within ourselves. As various challenges and chaos engulf us, SHE lends a helping hand to protect and fortify our spiritual wellbeing.
Dr Raguram
24/10/23, 8:12‚ÄØam
In sculptural depictions of Mahishasuramardini, the asura is portrayed either as a bull or a demon underneath the feet of the Goddess. There is an interesting sculpture in Chennakeshava Temple in Belur, in which the Mahishasura is actually seen emerging from the bull. Devi is pressing the bull with her right leg and one can see that the bull is buckling under the pressure. Mahishasura arises from the bull, with one leg still within it. The Goddess thrusts her weapon on Mahishasura‚Äôs chest, impaling and killing him in the process.
Today is Vijayadasami which is celebrated with much fanfare in Mysuru as the day Devi Chamundeshwari defeated and vanquished Mahishasura. Mysuru is deemed to be a corrupted version of ‚ÄúMysooru‚Äú, which is derived from the word ‚ÄúMahishooru‚Äù. According to the story, Mysuru was ruled by King Mahishasura who was a buffalo-headed monster. In response to the prayer by the Gods and Goddesses to save them from the demon, Goddess Parvathi, took birth as Chamundeshwari and killed the monster on top of the Chamundi hill near Mysuru. Bettada Chamaraja Wadiyar, the Raja of Mysuru rebuilt the fort and made it his headquarters and called the city ‚ÄòMahishura Nagara‚Äò, meaning the city of Mahishur. Many inscriptions done in the 17th century and later refer to Mysuru as ‚ÄòMahishuru‚Äò.
In recent times, Dalits and rationalists in the Mysuru region opine strongly that Mahishasura was not a monster but a Buddhist king, who fought against upper caste oppression and was killed by them. They argue that the demon story was fabricated to tarnish his legacy, claiming that Mahishasura was a historical figure sent by Maurya emperor Ashoka to promote Buddhism in the region. The proponents of this theory also point out that Mysuru derives its name after Mahishooru. Such an alternate narrative is not confined to Mysuru. A tribe named Asura who are living in some parts of Jharkhand claim that they are descendants of Mahishasura and for them, it is not a day of celebration, but a day of mourning.
These conflicting narratives are evidence of India‚Äôs incredible heterogeneity, which incorporates and accommodates differing beliefs within its fold, seamlessly.
Dr Raguram
31/10/23, 9:51‚ÄØam
John Keats was born on this day in 1795. During his short life, he published fifty-four poems using a wide range of poetic forms including odes and sonnets. Not happy with his earlier works he collected every piece of paper on which they had been written and burned them. While suffering from tuberculosis, he fell in love with Fanny Browne. Since he could not have any physical contact with her, he wrote her a series of letters. In one of them he wrote poignantly, ‚ÄúIllness is a long lane, but I see you at the end of it.‚Äù Later, in the same letter, he wondered, ‚ÄúIs there another life?
Shall I awake and find all this a dream?‚Äù He never recovered from his illness and died at the young age of 25.
Nature was one of the greatest sources of inspiration for Keats. He gazed with child-like delight at the rising sun, the moving cloud, the growing bud and the birds and turned them into beautiful poetic images. It was not the ‚Äòintellectual beauty‚Äô of Shelley, but one that emerged from the deepest reaches of his soul. As he wrote in the opening lines of Endymion: ‚ÄúA thing of beauty is a joy forever‚Äù.
During all my birding sojourns I seek beauty in the feathered friends as in this diminutive bird, Taiga Flycatcher. It gets its name from the habitat it uses, the Taiga forest, which refers to the coniferous forests of the sub polar region. A forest dwelling winter visitor to the Indian subcontinent, it is one of the most handsome birds I have ever seen. Its beauty is not confined to its visual aspects alone, but transcends it.
As Keats wrote in ‚ÄòOn A Grecian Urn‚Äô:
‚ÄúBeauty is truth, truth beauty,‚Äîthat is all
Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
10/11/23, 7:21‚ÄØpm
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/understanding-consciousness-goes-beyond-exploring-brain-chemistry/
13/11/23, 7:09‚ÄØam
Last week Ahalya and myself were in Bandipur and it was the place where I discovered the pleasures of birding decades ago, thanks to a student during a trip. It has taken hold of me since then. Noticing it, Ahalya presented ‚ÄòThe Book of Indian Birds‚Äô by Salim Ali (whose birthday was on 12th November). It is a prized possession and has always been beside me since then. Ahalya didn‚Äôt forget to inscribe prominently in the first page of the book, ‚ÄúStay close to the feathered ones!‚Äù and I have been diligently following that diktat.
Birds wake us up in the morning with their dulcet serenades. Even in the midst of urban chaos we have to just look up and see them flying their sorties with sheer abandon. Just observing them, we experience colors and patterns of nature. It offers endless opportunities for discovery, all for free. Some kind of connection emerges in those encounters with nature and our inner selves.
For me watching birds is not about lists, BIG days but soaking in the experience and savoring moments of absolute calmness within.
Dr Raguram
17/11/23, 9:46‚ÄØam
Li Bai was one of the most prominent poets in Chinese literature, who had an abiding interest Daoism. He wrote more than thousand poems, replete with striking imagery, infused with Daoistic metaphors. The notion of ‚ÄòDao‚Äô, way or path, emphasizes that ideal world is to be found not by following an external route, but by a spiritual path, through state of mind, an attitude. In Daoism, a good life is a life that‚Äôs simple, spontaneous, in harmony with nature, unencumbered by societal regulation and free from the desire to achieve social ascendancy; a life lived in accordance with nature. Daoism doesn‚Äôt completely disregard the existence of the self, instead it acknowledges that the self exists, but it emphasizes that the person has to be ‚Äúselfless‚Äù. Instead of the ‚ÄúI‚Äù it‚Äôs ‚ÄúOthers‚Äù and the person should strive to live in harmony, in a balanced life with others and nature. It is wonderfully enunciated in this quote "The perfect man has no self; the spiritual man has no achievement; the true sage has no name".
Dr Raguram
20/11/23, 8:52‚ÄØam
One of the most famous opening sentences in literature is from Leo Tolstoy's novel Anna Karenina: "All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way." Tolstoy's own marriage seems to have fallen into the second category. Though he and his wife, Sophia, had 13 children together, they were an unhappy couple in the later part of their lives. Tolstoy contemplated leaving his wife on many occasions and finally on the night of Nov. 10, 1910, he secretly fled, leaving a note to his wife, ‚ÄúI am doing what old men of my age usually do: leaving worldly life to spend the last days of my life in solitude and quiet.‚Äù Taking only a few things, he boarded a train with his personal physician Makovitsky. Taking a circuitous route, involving several train changes, they planned to travel further to Bulgaria. But on the way, Tolstoy caught a cold, which led to pneumonia and he was taken of the train at Astapovo. He declined any medical intervention as he wanted to "submit himself to God‚Äôs will." He passed away in the early morning of 20th November 1910.
Tolstoy‚Äôs final moments are a poignant reminder of what he wrote in The Death of Ivan Illyich; ‚ÄúWhat death? There was no fear, because there was no death. Instead of death there was light. So that‚Äôs it! He suddenly said aloud. ‚ÄúSuch joy!‚Äù
Dr Raguram
08/12/23, 11:32‚ÄØam
I was keen to reach the temple at Bodhgaya early, before the crowds start streaming in. When I entered the temple precincts there was hardly anyone except a group of Buddhist monks who were chanting melodiously. The ebb and flow of their chanting with sporadic chirping of birds set the tone for a reflective state of mind. I made my way to the Bodhi tree and sat down. Here was the place where Shakyamuni came after practising a lifestyle of severe asceticism for six years. After enduring many hardships, he realized that that a deeper understanding of life was still eluding him. He sat and meditated under this tree and became the Buddha, ‚Äúan awakened one.‚Äù Bodhi Day which is observed on 8th December marks this moment that took place 2500 years ago. In addition to its spiritual significance, the Bodhi Day reminds us of the importance of peace, compassion, and mindfulness in our everyday lives.
Within each of us is a tiny light, entangled in the fibres of our lives. As Ramana Maharishi observed, ‚ÄúYour own Self-Realization is the greatest service you can render the world.‚Äù
(If you look carefully at the photograph, you can have a glimpse of a covered slab at the foot of the Bodhi tree. It marks the exact position where Buddha sat in meditation. Traditionally, it is referred to as Buddha‚Äôs Vajrasana and is the oldest piece of architecture in Bodh Gaya)
Dr Raguram
09/12/23, 10:40‚ÄØpm
Yes sir, to understand and manage the outside very much depends on our work within. We are so used to deal from the other way and complicate things for ourselves. A very auspicious day to remember and practice the teachings of Buddha.
10/12/23, 7:39‚ÄØam
‚ÄúIf we love Flowers, are we not ‚Äòborn again‚Äô every Day,‚Äù reflected Emily Dickinson whose birthday is today. She was better known in her hometown of Amherst, Massachusetts, as a gardener rather than a poet. She was often observed by neighbours on evenings, tending her flower beds. She identified herself strongly with flowers like the tiger lily, daisy, and rose and was particularly partial to wildflowers. Her first formal act of composition as a girl was not a poem but an herbarium.
The garden was the true inspiration for Emily Dickinson and flowers figured with richest symbolic language in her poems. As she wrote,
‚ÄúI hide myself within my flower
That fading from your Vase
You, unsuspecting, feel for me
Almost a loneliness‚Äù
For her, every single flower is a microcosm of complex ecological relationships between numerous organisms and their environment. She captured this understanding in an exquisite poem, in which the flower emerges not as the pretty object of admiration but as an enchanting, silent symphony of interconnected resilience.
BLOOM
‚ÄúBloom ‚Äî is Result ‚Äî to meet a Flower
And casually glance
Would cause one scarcely to suspect
The minor Circumstance
Assisting in the Bright Affair
So intricately done
Then offered as a Butterfly
To the Meridian ‚Äî
To pack the Bud ‚Äî oppose the Worm ‚Äî
Obtain its right of Dew ‚Äî
Adjust the Heat ‚Äî elude the Wind ‚Äî
Escape the prowling Bee
Great Nature not to disappoint
Awaiting Her that Day ‚Äî
To be a Flower, is profound
Responsibility‚Äù
Dr Raguram
11/12/23, 7:47‚ÄØam
Mountains might not seem like they do much, but in reality, they are one of the most important creations of nature. To raise awareness about mountains, the United Nations signifies December 11 as International Mountain Day. They contain almost half of the total biodiversity hotspots on the planet. Mountains host a significant amount of flora and fauna, which are vulnerable and at risk of extinction. Unfortunately, they are being overexploited by humans and are torn apart to make way for buildings and cities.
Mountains are nature‚Äôs most beautiful gift to us and let us strive to take care of them.
William Wordsworth expressed the beauty and allure of mountains poetically in ‚ÄòLines composed a few miles above Tintern Abbey
‚ÄúTherefore am I still
A lover of the meadows and the woods
And mountains; and of all that we behold
From this green earth; of all the mighty world
Of eye and ear, both what they half create
And what perceive; well pleased to recognize
In nature and the language of the sense
The anchor of my purest thoughts, the nurse
The guide, the guardian of my heart, and soul
Of all my moral being.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
21/12/23, 8:59‚ÄØam
Kodo Sawaki is regarded by many as the greatest twentieth-century Zen master. He had a difficult start in life as his early life was full of travails of various kinds. He weathered them all and after receiving his ordination, spent many years living in an abandoned hermitage devoting himself to the practice of Zazen. He became famous throughout Japan for the sesshin (intensive meditation retreat) that he gave to people from all walks of life, without making any personal distinction or discrimination. Kodo Sawaki called his monastery a ‚Äúmoving monastery‚Äù. He gave Zen a new life and ‚Äúbrought fresh air to the decaying Zen‚Äù by staying away the frozen rituals. His tendency to travel alone and his refusal to settle down at any monastery in the classical sense earned him the nickname, ‚ÄúHomeless Kodo‚Äù.
Kodo Sawaki taught that the practice of zen is not about achieving enlightenment, but rather about living in the present moment and being mindful of our actions and thoughts. He emphasized the importance of zazen, or seated meditation to cultivate a sense of inner peace and clarity. Kodo encouraged people to live a life of simplicity and to find joy in the small moments of everyday life.
When he was 86, Kodo felt gravely ill and spent the last three months of his life at Antai-ji, a temple transformed by him into a place for a pure practice. From his bed, he spent a long time looking at the Takagamine mountain and, three days before his death, he told a nun: ‚ÄúLook at that. Nature is magnificent. In all my life, I have never encountered a person to whom I could have submitted and who I could have admired. But this Takagamine mountain looks upon me form the heights saying: ‚ÄòKodo, Kodo‚Äô‚Äù.
These were his last words. He passed away on the 21st of December, 1966
Dr Raguram

03/02/23, 8:52‚ÄØam
World wetland day is celebrated every year all across the world to commemorate the Convention on Wetlands which was held on 2nd of February in 1971 in the city of Ramsar, Iran at the Caspian Sea coasts. The Ramsar Convention emphasizes the importance of conservation and sustainable management of wetlands. Wherever we live: city, town, village or country, we are surrounded by wetlands which are unfortunately in throes of decline due to excessive urbanisation, shrinking buffer zones and contamination. In an era of intense climate change, wetlands are like the River Styx which separated the world of the living from Hades, the world of the dead.
It is imperative to recognize the value that wetlands add to our lives and the joy of observing the beautiful flora and fauna that they nurse.
23/02/23, 11:02‚ÄØpm

19/03/23, 7:58‚ÄØam
Last week we were at Hadinaru Kere totally immersed in observing perhaps the last flock of the Bar Headed Geese before they head back. There are no idyllic conditions for them to make their long journey thought unforgiving climates.
To me they are icons of life affirming expressions of resilience.
As humans when we erect walls of beliefs and assumptions around us and fail to and rarely explore the vast horizon of possibilities of our lives, let us feel inspired by these alluring denizens of the air!

Who can forget the song ‚ÄòKaatrinile Varum Geetham‚Äô, (https://youtu.be/B7Z4ypRrFaA ), sung by MS Subbalakshmi in the movie Meera? It was written by Kalki Krishnamurthy and set to tune by S V Venkatraman.
There is an interesting story behind this song. I understand that it was inspired by a gramophone record ‚ÄòToot Gayi Man Bina‚Äô, sung by Sheela Sarkar and set to music by Kamal Dasgupta. You can listen to the song here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J2dqWwJYs6E.
Brimming with melody, the soothing notes of the songs are truly sempiternal‚Ä¶

27/10/23, 8:37‚ÄØam
I am totally aghast at this comment. In the IT sector, people are already working long hours, bracing endless commute, losing crucial hours of sleep working at UK/US hours. If one is working 70 hours a week across 5 days, which comes out to 14 hours per day and factoring an additional 2hrs of commuting, it will be 16hours which leaves the individual with just 8 hours to pay attention to his/her personal life and health. Extremely long working hours impact the mental health of the individual, interpersonal relations and family which is all too evident to mental health practitioners. This is a recipe for burnout. Employers should consider not only extracting more from employees but also care for their mental health and family lives.
Moreover, none of the IT companies follow the existing labor law of 48hrs per week
02/11/23, 9:51‚ÄØam
It was autumn and the trees in Taconic State Park were in full bloom. Prominent among them was the Silk Floss Tree. It was studded with spectacular five petaled flowers. It was a stunning experience to see them. In Brazil they call the floss-silk palo borracho ‚Äúdrunken tree‚Äù because each blossom opens like a provocative dancer and it was a wonderful sight to see them waltzing in the wind.
When I got back, I came across this wonderful poem by Natalia Andreeva:
A blustery autumn breeze
is playing with cotton wool clouds,
tossing cream puff pillows
across a cornflower sky;
gusts tease the pastel blooms
and make pink petals sigh
as they try hard to hold on
before they're rudely torn away.
Like the soft pink petals,
I will also let go someday,
it's then, unfettered, I too shall fly;
I'll float along tepid streams
of spiralling warm air
and dance as I'm lifted high,
twisting and tumbling in the squalls,
silent, unbound, without care.

2024

Festivals

01/01/24, 8:56‚ÄØam
Sir, Wish you and Madam a very Happy New Year 2024.
06/01/24, 9:46‚ÄØam
Among the many calls that I received this New Year, I was deeply touched by a particular one. It was from a lady whom I had known for the past few years. She rang up and said, ‚ÄúDoctor let this New Year be good for you and all those who help others‚Äù. What is distinctive about the caller is that she is a crematorium worker who handles all the paper work there.
I met her a few years ago, helping a friend who had lost a family member, to fill the forms. When I was about to leave, she asked me whether I was a doctor. Hearing the affirmative answer, she shared her psychological travails which were being attended to by a dear former student. I reassured her stating that she was in good hands while emphasizing the need to be regular with treatment. She profusely thanked me and thereafter kept in touch with me periodically.
Working in a crematorium can be a daunting task, more so being a woman. At a time when the term ‚Äòstress‚Äô is flaunted widely, I was keen to know more about her and how she coped with her situation. Her answer was simple, ‚ÄúI earn a livelihood doctor, for the sake of my children, for their better future‚Äù. I gathered that her husband was a drunkard without any regular work and she had to tend for two young children, with very little support from the extended family. She works six days a week with few breaks or any holiday. At the end of a busy working day, she gets back home, has a bath and starts cooking for the night. Her husband scolds and often beats her, if by chance the food is delayed. He is also sexually demanding and if she refuses, starts suspecting her. In spite of these ordeals when I chance to see her at work, I invariably find her attending to her task with a smile on her face.
By accepting the job, she has joined a cadre of Indian women who are entering arenas from which they have traditionally been excluded. That she has chosen to work in a space with significant stigma associated with it, where even men feel uneasy to be in, is a testament to her resilience.
A plant that can teach us resilience is the bamboo. It can withstand twice as much force bearing down on it while being stretched, pulled or bent. According to a Japanese proverb: ‚ÄúIn time, even the strongest wind tires itself out, but the bamboo remains standing tall and still.‚Äù
There is an interesting Zen parable, ‚ÄòBe like a bamboo‚Äô:
A Zen Master was walking through the forest down a narrow trail with one of his students along a steep incline. The student lost his footing and slipped; just as he began tumbling down the hill, the student reached out and grabbed a small bamboo tree. The bamboo bent nearly all the way over as the student continued to hold on tightly. He pulled himself up and brushed off the dirt with the Zen Masters help.
‚ÄúDid you notice that when you fell, you grabbed a hold of the bamboo and it bent nearly all the way over and still supported you.‚Äù the Zen Master asked.
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the student replied. The Zen Master gripped the bamboo and pulled the bamboo over.
‚ÄúBe like the bamboo,‚Äù the Zen Master said as he let go of the bamboo and it sprang back to its up-right position. ‚ÄúIt is pushed around by the wind and yet it always bounces back and grows upward, toward the sun, enlightenment. Have you ever felt as though you were going to snap? Have you ever felt as though you were at your breaking point, emotionally?‚Äù
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the student replied.
‚ÄúThen bend, do not break, such is the way with bamboo. It endures the stress and finds a way to bounce back!‚Äù the Zen Master stated. ‚ÄúThis is called resilience.‚Äù
Throughout our journey in life, we meet people along the way and we connect with the heart of a few from whom we draw inspiration. They become a poem or a story in my life to live by.
Dr Raguram
15/01/24, 8:08‚ÄØam
India with its diverse and rich cultural heritage celebrates multitudes of festivals throughout the year. The harvest festival holds a distinct place among them. The onset of harvest season is observed all across the country under various names based on the region where it is celebrated. It is essentially an act of thanksgiving to the farmers. Farmers who tend to the land with care and concern are the backbone of our society. We may need the help of a doctor or a lawyer sometime in our lives, but we need the farmer every day, three times a day to provide us with food.
Saint Poet Thiruvalluvar‚Äôs magnum opus Thirukkural consists of 133 chapters having 10 couplets each. Each one of them consisting of just one line and a half, like a short haiku. Thiruvalluvar devotes an entire chapter (104) wherein he extols the glory and greatness of agriculture and the important role of farmers.
‡Æá‡Æ∞‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ∞‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æà‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ∞‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡Æï‡Øà‡Æö‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡Æ£‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡ÆØ‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç.
Those who plough do not ask but give with both hands
To those that ask, the bounty they have tilled
On this festival day let us pay obeisance to our indefatigable farmers who are battling tremendous odds to keep us satiated.
As the Pongal brims over the pot
Let us pray to the lord
That joy bubbles in farmer‚Äôs heart
Forever
Dr Raguram
15/01/24, 10:18‚ÄØpm
Literally farmers are the backbone of our country. Hope nature doesn't play truant in their lives. Thank you for your wishes sir and wish you and madam the same.
16/01/24, 8:17‚ÄØam
Today is Mattu Pongal. On this day cattle are given a well-deserved day of rest and a pride of place. They are washed, their horns are painted and covered with shining metal caps. Multi-coloured beads, tinkling bells, sheaves of corn and flower garlands are tied around their necks. They look majestic in all their finery. It is essentially a day of thanksgiving to the cattle friends by the farmers. Cattle play important roles in different stages of cultivation. Even after the fields are harvested, they are used to separate the ear of the grains from the stalk by walking over the stalks. Besides their importance in ploughing fields, their manure also serves as natural fertilisers. While the practice of using cattle as farm labour has all but disappeared in Tamil Nadu today, there is still a thriving dung economy. For example, ‚ÄòThozhuvam Farmer Producer Organization‚Äô in Madurai directly sources cow dung and markets value-added products such incense sticks, dung handicrafts, and more. Their main agenda is to safeguard the traditional Pulikulam and Theni hill cattle breeds that are on the verge of extinction.
There are beautiful descriptions of cattle in Sangam poetry. For example, Orampokiyar wrote more than 100 poems and in one verse in Aiynkurunooru., he offers a beautiful description of a buffalo:
'‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æ±‡Øà ‡ÆÆ‡ØÄ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æ¥‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æï‡Øà,
‡ÆÖ‡Æ∞‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡ÆÜ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Øá‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ®‡ØÜ‡Æ±‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ
‡Æà‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æ£‡Øç ‡Æé‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øà‡Æö‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ,
‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡Æö‡Øá‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æ≥‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æû‡Øç‡Æö‡Æø, ‡Æ™‡Øä‡Æ¥‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Æü,
‡Æ™‡Øà‡Æ®‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ£ ‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Ææ‡ÆÖ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ±‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ,
‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡ØÇ‡Æâ‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øä‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æï‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Øà ‡Æö‡ØÇ‡Æü‡Æø, ‡ÆÆ‡ØÇ‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øç
‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡Æ±‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æ≥‡Æ∞‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æä‡Æ∞‡Æ©‡Øç
an old buffalo, his back wet and cool, his horns curved,
grazes on bright-flowered lilies
in a pond full of water and fish
sleeps all night in the oozing mud,
and then when dawn comes
walks out, crushing fish with their feet,
drapes himself with bright creepers,
and enters the ancient town like a warrior victorious in battle.
(The unique terracotta temples at Bishnupur, around 140kms from Kolkata, feature intricate carvings showcasing the skills of the artisans who created them).

17/01/24, 8:38‚ÄØam
Yes Sir yesterday was Mattu Pongal. We call it as Kanu (calf) pandigai. Celebrated by daughters in their mother's place. A day when we wish prosperity both for the family of origin and family a daughter enters after marriage. And the 'pidi' made of previous day rice, Dosa etc is fed to cows and prayed. I had never heard of a poem dedicated to buffalos. Very nice.
18/01/24, 8:28‚ÄØam
Most us would have read ‚ÄòWinnie the Pooh‚Äô by AA Milne (whose birthday is today). He wrote seven novels, five nonfiction books and 34 plays, along with numerous stories and articles. But ‚ÄòWinnie the Pooh‚Äô which was published in 1926, eclipsed and erased the memory of his other works. It featured characters based on his son, who was the inspiration for Pooh‚Äôs best friend, Christopher Robin and his stuffed animal toys. The Hundred Acre Woods, where Pooh‚Äôs adventures take place, was based on the 500 Acre Woods near Milne‚Äôs home.
A few years after Winnie-the-Pooh was published, Milne began to resent the fame that it brought on him and his family. He stated, ‚ÄúI feel that Christopher Robin has already had more publicity than I want for him. I do not want CR Milne to ever wish that his name was Charles Robert.‚Äù His son also disliked this attention, as the legacy of Christopher Robin and Pooh Bear followed him all throughout his life, making it difficult for him to make a name as his own person. In his memoir, ‚ÄòThe Enchanted Place‚Äô, he wrote, ‚ÄúIn pessimistic moments, when I was trudging London in search of an employer wanting to make use of such talents as I could offer, it seemed to me, almost, that my father had got to where he was by climbing upon my infant shoulders, that he had filched from me my good name and had left me with nothing but the empty fame of being his son.‚Äù
Strangely, there have been several attempts to ban the book. In 2009, Russian authorities banned it for being pro-Nazi, after an image of Pooh with a swastika was discovered amongst an extremist‚Äôs collection. In the United Kingdom, the book was banned from public schools, as the character Piglet might offend Muslim and Jewish students who abstain from pork for religious reasons. And in 2017, the Chinese government began censoring Winnie the Pooh on social media platforms after critics used the character to mock Xi Jinping and his policies.
What is more galling is the attempt to identify psychiatric disorders among the characters in the book. In 2000, paediatrician Sarah Shea and her team released a journal article titled ‚ÄúPathology in the Hundred Acre Wood: a neurodevelopmental perspective on A.A. Milne.‚Äù It proposed that each of the Winnie-the-Pooh characters displayed symptoms of a different mental disorder. Unfortunately this trend caught on and there have been several attempts in this vein over the years.
In spite of all this, ‚ÄòWinnie the Pooh‚Äô resonates with people of all ages due to its relatable characters and heart-warming stories, addressing themes such as friendship, love, and the pursuit of happiness.
"Sometimes, if you stand on the bottom rail of a bridge and lean over to watch the river slipping slowly away beneath you, you will suddenly know everything there is to be known" Pooh.
Dr Raguram
20/01/24, 7:01‚ÄØam
You cannot miss the European Robin when you take a stroll in the gardens of London. unlike its counterpart in America, it is a colourful bird with a striking orange breast. As you watch, it makes forays to the ground to catch insects and quickly flies back to its shady perch. The French naturalist Georges Cuvie gave the bird its current name Erithacus rubecula. The epithet rubecula is derived from the Latin, ruber ‚Äòred‚Äô.
The Victorian postmen used to be known as robins because part of their tunic was orange red. When Christmas cards first came into vogue they were brought by robins! And robins started featuring in the in the Christmas cards too.
There is a wealth of Christian mythology associated with it. The legend is that the robin was moved when it saw Christ on the cross and began to pluck the thorns out of the crown of thorns. The blood stained the robin and hence its orange red breast. According to an Irish tale, a robin flew in to see the infant Jesus in the manger. The infant reached out to touch the bird causing it to blush in deference and hence its colour!
Shakespeare refers to the charming song of the European Robin in Two Gentlemen of Verona.
Valentine: Why, how know you that I am in love?
Speed: Marry, by these special marks: first, you have learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms like a malcontent; to relish a love song like a robin redbreast; to walk alone like one that had the pestilence; to sigh like a schoolboy that had lost his ABC; to weep like a young wench that had buried her grandam; to fast like one that takes diet; to watch like one that fears robbing; to speak puling like a beggar at Hallowmas.
Emily Dickinson wrote a lovely small poem about it:
If I can stop one heart from breaking,
I shall not live in vain;
If I can ease one life the aching,
Or cool one pain,
Or help one fainting robin
Unto his nest again,
I shall not live in vain.
It is believed that when a robin appears, it is a sign that a loved one is near.
Dr Raguram
13/02/24, 8:35‚ÄØam
Sarojini Naidu, born on 13th February 1879, was one of the most outstanding figures of the independence movement. An equally talented poet in English, she was known as ‚ÄúThe Nightingale of India‚Äù. Her poetry brims with strong emotions expressed in lyrical verses. An ardent admirer of nature, she was also a great lover of birds.
I am particularly drawn (given my passion for them!) to her poem ‚ÄòBird of Time‚Äô, wherein she expresses the workings of time through the movements of a bird. Just as we don‚Äôt expect a bird to be still, time too is fleeting. Life and death, sorrow and hope, time encompasses them all in this poem.
BIRD OF TIME
O Bird of Time on your fruitful bough
What are the songs you sing? ‚Ä¶
Songs of the glory and gladness of life,
Of poignant sorrow and passionate strife,
And the lilting joy of the spring;
Of hope that sows for the years unborn,
And faith that dreams of a tarrying morn,
The fragrant peace of the twilight‚Äôs breath,
And the mystic silence that men call death.
O Bird of Time, say where did you learn
The changing measures you sing? ‚Ä¶
In blowing forests and breaking tides,
In the happy laughter of new-made brides,
And the nests of the new-born spring;
In the dawn that thrills to a mother‚Äôs prayer,
And the night that shelters a heart‚Äôs despair,
In the sigh of pity, the sob of hate,
And the pride of a soul that has conquered fate.
In one of last letters she wrote, ‚Äù While I live, it will always be the supreme desire of my Soul to write poetry ‚Äîone poem, one line of enduring verse even. Perhaps I shall die without realising that longing which is at once an exquisite joy and an unspeakable anguish to me‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
17/02/24, 7:57‚ÄØam
In the 60s Eshwari Lending Library in Chennai was my stomping ground. One day I picked up a book ‚ÄòThe Chosen‚Äô by Chaim Potok, sheerly by chance. When I started reading it, I was put off initially by an extensive description of a baseball match in the first 30 pages of the book. I persisted nevertheless and couldn‚Äôt put the book down after that. The novel opened me up to another time and another world which I was not familiar with,till then.
It is a story about two Jewish teens from different backgrounds; Reuven Malter, hailing from an Orthodox family and Danny Sanders from a Hasidic background. It details the bond between the two and the relationship each has with his father. Relationships between fathers and sons figure prominently in ‚ÄòThe Chosen‚Äô, especially in the choices of the sons' careers. Danny's father expects him to become a rabbi and leader of his Hasidic sect, following the tradition of generations, while Reuven's father lets him choose his own path. Daniel has decided not to become a Tzaddik, but to follow his heart, attend graduate school and become a psychologist. Reuven has made up his mind to become a Rabbi, despite his great talent for logic and mathematics. Reuven and Danny both have one thing in common, trying to decide on whether they should be something that was chosen for them or something they want to be.
I had just finished PUC at the time I read the book and was drawn to the main theme of the book, ‚ÄòChoosing and Being Chosen‚Äô. Hailing from a family wherein my grandfather was a well known doctor, the implicit expectation was that I should follow his path. I wasn‚Äôt so sure at that time as I was drawn more to liberal arts. Perhaps I was ‚Äòchosen‚Äô to become a doctor and that too a psychiatrist!
When I read this book again, I was particularly drawn to this passage in the book, ‚ÄúHuman beings do not live forever‚Ä¶ We live less than the time it takes to blink an eye, if we measure against eternity. So it may be asked what value is there to a human life. There is so much pain in the world. What does it mean to suffer so much if our lives are nothing more than the blink of an eye?‚Ä¶ I learned a long time ago ‚Ä¶ that a blink of an eye in itself is nothing. But the eye that blinks, that is something. A span of life is nothing. But the man who lives that span, he is something. He can fill that tiny span with meaning, so its quality is immeasurable though its quantity may be insignificant. ‚Ä¶ A man must fill his life with meaning, meaning is not automatically given to life‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
18/02/24, 8:26‚ÄØam
Another book I had picked up those days at Easwari lending library was the novel ‚ÄòZorba the Greek‚Äô. Much like ‚ÄòThe Chosen‚Äô, it is the story of two men: Zorba, a Greek working man and a wealthy, young narrator and their incredible friendship. The two of them couldn‚Äôt be further apart. The narrator is cerebral, modest, and reserved; Zorba is unfettered and spirited.The younger man reads all day. He‚Äôs an aficionado of Buddhist philosophy, the exact opposite world view of Zorba who has such lust for life. These two characters represent two distinct ways of life. The implicit question throughout the book: which is better? Being a ‚Äústable‚Äù person and being accepted and respected in society, or being an indulgent person living his life full. Both are searching for answers. The Narrator has a desire to change, but he adamantly resists Zorba‚Äôs philosophy, despite admitting to admiring it and wishing he could assimilate it with his own. The relationship between these two characters symbolizes the conversation between the head and the heart, the mind and the spirit, what Nietzsche referred to as the Apollonian and the Dionysian impulses. Kazantzakis masterfully interweaves these dual perspectives of human nature. The book is also an important reminder to embrace the transience of life, to seize the moments that bring us joy, unfettered by intellectual curiosity. A passage in the book by the narrator illustrates this perspective:
‚ÄúI remember one morning when I discovered a cocoon in the back of a tree just as a butterfly was making a hole in its case and preparing to come out. I waited a while, but it was too long appearing and I was impatient. I bent over it and breathed on it to warm it. I warmed it as quickly as I could and the miracle began to happen before my eyes faster than life. The case opened; the butterfly started slowly crawling out, and I shall never forget my horror when I saw how its wings were folded back and crumpled; the wretched butterfly tried with its whole trembling body to unfold them. Bending over it, I tried to help it with my breath, in vain. It needed to be hatched out patiently and the unfolding of the wings should be a gradual process in the sun. Now it was too late. My breath had forced the butterfly to appear all crumpled, before its time. It struggled desperately and, a few seconds later, died in the palm of my hand. That little body is, I do believe, the greatest weight I have on my conscience. For, I realize today that it is a mortal sin to violate great laws of nature. We should not hurry, we should not be impatient, but we should confidently obey the external rhythm‚Äù.
A viewpoint summarized in the gravestone of the author, Nikos Kazantzakis,"I hope for nothing. I fear nothing. I am free."
(And who can forget Anthony Quinn bringing the most life-affirming character of Zorba alive in the movie version of the book with the Zorba the Greek song brimming with life?)
Dr Raguram
27/02/24, 8:07‚ÄØam
A good poem opens up a new world and takes you on a memorable journey. Henry Wadswoth Longfellow‚Äôs, ‚ÄòNature‚Äô is one such.
The simple, unpretentious opening lines of the poem portray a familiar scene that happens in most of our homes; a mother trying to put her child to sleep. The child‚Äôs ‚Äòbroken playthings‚Äô are scattered on the floor, and he is ‚Äúhalf willing" to abandon the play and retire for the night. He lingers, staring longingly at the toys he has left behind.
The next few lines venture into a new territory all together. The poet compares the mother whom he just described eloquently, to mother nature. Both are essentially caretakers of all of us. Nature is to man, what a mother is to her child. As we advance in years, nature gradually takes away all our earthly possessions and gently guides us to the world beyond. Since often we are greatly attached to our earthly life and our belongings, we are never too willing to proceed towards that goal. But nature leads us just like the mother leading the child to sleep,taking away our "playthings" one at a time. The poet suggests that our earthly desires and attachments are like playthings that we must eventually relinquish to discover the unknown mysteries of life..
Why did this poem appeal to me? I was drawn (and still continue to be!) by the simple imagery of a mother putting a reluctant child to sleep, which slowly blends itself into a very powerful metaphor of a nurturing nature that prepares us for our journey beyond this world. There is much wisdom in these lines;
NATURE
As a fond mother, when the day is o'er,
Leads by the hand her little child to bed,
Half willing, half reluctant to be led,
And leave his broken playthings on the floor,
Still gazing at them through the open door,
Nor wholly reassured and comforted
By promises of others in their stead,
Which, though more splendid, may not please him more;
So Nature deals with us, and takes away
Our playthings one by one, and by the hand
Leads us to rest so gently, that we go
Scarce knowing if we wish to go or stay,
Being too full of sleep to understand
How far the unknown transcends the what we know.
(Henry Wadswoth Longfellow born on this day on 1807)
Dr Raguram
08/03/24, 9:28‚ÄØpm
There are many legends associated with Mahashivaratri which is being celebrated today. According to one, it was the day when Shiva drank the poison that emerged from the ocean during Amritmanthan, to protect the world. He drank it but held it in his throat instead of swallowing it. Thus, his throat changed to a blue colour and he was then given the name, Nilkantha. According to another legend, when Ganga was descended from heaven after the request of Bhagirath, it was enormous and uncontrollable, so Lord Brahma requested Shiva to control her fall. Shiva agreed to it and he held the rapid flow of Ganga by tying it up in his hair. According to yet another legend, this was the night when Shiva and Parvati got married, an amalgamation of Purusha (mindfulness) and Prakriti (nature).
I have a particular interest in the mural tradition of south India and went over to the Virupaksha temple sometime back to have a look at the murals that adorn the ranga mantapa. It was fascinating to see the ceiling resplendent with murals depicting scenes from the purana and various narrative episodes from history. Prominent among them is a large panel depicting the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. In the attached photo, starting from the left, one can find Narada, a horse headed Tumburu.. Vishnu and Lakshmi are in the next section. The middle portion depicts the marriage of Shiva and Parvati in exquisite detail.. Brahma is officiating the marriage of Shiva and Parvati with Himavat performing Kanyadan. Three bejewelled women are seen on their right. In the last section on the right, one can notice the three legged Bhringi. The attention to detail, especially the designs in the textiles is quite striking. I was wondering as to how these murals would have looked in their heyday. Temples are not merely places of worship; embellished with magnificent sculptures and paintings, they are repositories of a rich aesthetic tradition which needs to be preserved and protected. I was happy to note that an innovative attempt has been made to digitise these murals. There is an overwhelming need for similar initiatives to conserve many such artistic treasures across the country, which are unfortunately in various stages of neglect.
Dr Raguram
10/03/24, 8:49‚ÄØam
MEDITATION ON THE AUTUMN LEAF
Thich Nhat Hanh
"I asked the leaf whether it was frightened because it was Autumn and the other leaves were falling.
The leaf told me, ‚ÄúNo. During the whole Spring and Summer I was completely alive. I worked hard to help nourish the tree, and now much of me is in the tree. I am not limited by this form. I am also the whole tree, and when I go back to the soil, I will continue to nourish the tree. So I don‚Äôt worry at all. As I leave this branch and float to the ground, I will wave to the tree and tell her, ‚ÄòI will see you again very soon.‚Äù
That day there was a wind blowing and, after a while, I saw the leaf leave the branch and float down to the soil, dancing joyfully, because as it floated it saw itself already there in the tree. It was so happy. I bowed my head, knowing that I have a lot to learn from the leaf.‚Äù
‚Äù ‚Ä¶ So please continue to look back and you will see that you have always been here. Let us look together and penetrate into the life of a leaf, so we may be one with the leaf. Let us penetrate and be one with the cloud or with the wave, to realize our own nature as water and be free from our fear. If we look very deeply, we will transcend birth and death.
Tomorrow, I will continue to be. But you will have to be very attentive to see me. I will be a flower, or a leaf. I will be in these forms and I will say hello to you. If you are attentive enough, you will recognize me, and you may greet me. I will be very happy."
Dr Raguram
23/03/24, 6:50‚ÄØam
Saigyo was a 12th century Japanese poet who became a Buddhist monk very early in his life. The most popular form of Japanese poetry is the haiku, the 17-syllable poem whicht reached the height of its development in the seventeenth century. But the haiku is derived from an older poetic form, the waka, which had been around for a thousand years before the haiku. The word waka means "Japanese poem," and it is a form so basic to Japanese literature that Japanese still study and write it today. It encompases five principal forms; tanka, ch≈çk,a bussokusekika, sedoka, and katauta. The last three fell into disuse over time and wanka is now identified principally with the tanka. Saigyo was one of the greatest masters of tanka which is described as, ‚Äúsomething which takes root in the soil of the heart and blossoms forth in a forest of words.‚Äù
Saigyo travelled all over Japan, living as a hermit in the mountains and writing poems which expressed his Buddhist principles and love of nature. Peering out through the window of his hut or sitting on a rock, he portrayed nature and the universe around him, as he saw them. For example, alone in his hut, he compares himself to the reclusive bird, warbler in a poem titled ‚ÄòThe Bush Warbler Idling,‚Äô
‚ÄúSeeping through the haze,
the voice
of the bush warbler‚Äî
few people passing,
mountain village in spring‚Äù.
Saigyo was deeply attracted to cherry blossoms and wrote many poems about it. In his final days, he moved to a hermitage in the mountains near Kyoto, which was surrounded by cherry blossom trees. He wished to die under the cherry blossom tree and wrote:
‚Äúlet me die in spring
under the cherry blossoms
on that day
in the Second Month
when the moon is full‚Äù
Saigyo eventually accomplished his wish, and died peacefully in the year 1190 on 23rd March at the age of 73, beneath a blossoming cherry tree
Dr Raguram
25/03/24, 10:21‚ÄØpm
Oh looks like decked up for the colourful holiüòä Thank you and wish you all the same.
09/04/24, 6:25‚ÄØam
Ugadi, derived from the words yug (era) and adi (new), marks the start of a new era according to the lunar calendar. It is believed that Lord Brahma created the world on this day. According to a mythological story, a demon named Somakasura stole the Vedas from Lord Brahma. Somakasura later hid the Vedas in the sea. When Lord Vishnu came to know of this situation, he took the Avatar of a fish, the Matsya Avatar, to fight Somakasura under the sea. Lord Vishnu killed Somakasura and returned the Vedas to Brahma. After receiving the Vedas back, Lord Brahma started creating the world on this day. Ugadi is perhaps the only festival that exalts Lord Brahma.
There is an extraordinarily beautiful tall,long limbed, Brahma sculpture in the Brahmpureeswarar temple near Thanjavur, which is one of earliest Chola temples, constructed under the joint reign of Aditya-I and Parantaka-I Chola. According to ancient temple iconometry, sculptures are carved on the basis of the Tala system. Each Tala is equal to 12 Angulas.This particular sculpture of Brahma has been carved according to the Dasa (ten)tala system. On either side of Brahma are two Rishis writing down the Vedas chanted by him, on palm leafs. Curiously, in the midst of the makara torana on top was a small figure of Aalilai Kannan!
Dr Raguram
