22/04/24, 7:35‚ÄØam
On this World Earth Day, let me share a letter written by Thich Nhah Hanh.
Dear Mother Earth,
Every time I step upon the Earth, I will train myself to see that I am walking on you, my Mother. Every time I place my feet on the Earth I have a chance to be in touch with you and with all your wonders. With every step I can touch the fact that you aren‚Äôt just beneath me, dear Mother, but you are also within me. Each mindful and gentle step can nourish me, heal me, and bring me into contact with myself and with you in the present moment.
Walking in mindfulness I can express my love, respect, and care for you, our precious Earth. I will touch the truth that mind and body are not two separate entities. I will train myself to look deeply to see your true nature: you are my loving mother, a living being, a great being‚Äîan immense, beautiful, and precious wonder. You are not only matter, you are also mind, you are also consciousness. Just as the beautiful pine or tender grain of corn possess an innate sense of knowing, so, too, do you. Within you, dear Mother Earth, there are the elements of Earth, water, air and fire; and there is also time, space, and consciousness. Our nature is your nature, which is also the nature of the cosmos.
I want to walk gently, with steps of love and with great respect. I shall walk with my own body and mind united in oneness. I know I can walk in such a way that every step is a pleasure, every step is nourishing, and every step is healing‚Äînot only for my body and mind, but also for you, dear Mother Earth. You are the most beautiful planet in our entire solar system. I do not want to run away from you, dear Mother, nor to hurry. I know I can find happiness right here with you. I do not need to rush to find more conditions for happiness in the future. At every step I can take refuge in you. At every step I can enjoy your beauties, your delicate veil of atmosphere and the miracle of gravity. I can stop my thinking. I can walk relaxingly and effortlessly. Walking in this spirit I can experience awakening. I can awaken to the fact that I am alive, and that life is a precious miracle. I can awaken to the fact that I am never alone and can never die. You are always there within me and around me at every step, nourishing me, embracing me, and carrying me far into the future.
Dear Mother, you wish that we live with more awareness and gratitude, and we can do this by generating the energies of mindfulness, peace, stability, and compassion in our daily lives. Therefore I make the promise today to return your love and fulfil this wish by investing every step I take on you with love and tenderness. I am walking not merely on matter, but on spirit.
23/04/24, 10:31‚ÄØpm
The photograph brings smile automatically. And what to say about mindfulness walking... It is an ode to mother earth... It contains the essence of spirituality... Who can ever even imagine harming the mother if we take it seriously. I wish this becomes the early morning prayer and practise for the generation.
03/05/24, 7:25‚ÄØam
According to Greek mythology, orchids were made from the remains of a young man named Orchis. He was the son of a nymph and a satyr, and while attending a festival of the wine god Bacchus, he became drunk. He abused the priestess Bacchantes and was torn apart by the other guests at the party. When his sorrowful father asked Zeus to make him whole again, he refused but allowed flowers to grow from his remains. These were the first orchids. It should be noted that there are many variations of this story, but all do end with the creation of orchids from his remains.
Orchids exude undeniable charm and are symbolic of everything from life, love and happiness. As Eckhart Tolle, in his book A New Earth commented,‚ÄùHumans would increasingly be drawn to and fascinated by them [orchids]....They provided inspiration to countless artists, poets, and mystics..more fleeting, more ethereal, and more delicate, they are like messengers from another realm, like a bridge between the world of physical forms and the formless."
I am enamoured of the ephemeral beauty of the orchids and when I looked closely at the heart of this moth orchid,
‚ÄúWould I could bury my soul
Deep in its bosom
Listening to its
Hidden secrets‚Äù
Dr Tsguram
12/05/24, 5:54‚ÄØpm
I wish it was carried out in a peaceful manner. Things are happening the way it happened in the end of Dwapara yuga.
20/05/24, 6:50‚ÄØpm
Bees have been around for long. In Ancient Egypt, tears of the Sun God Ra turned into bees upon touching the ground.and in Ancient Greece, bee was a cult symbol for Artemis, goddess of wild nature. In Indian mythology, Honeybees form the string of Kama‚Äôs bowmade of sugarcane. In the words of the poet Kalidasa, Kama, ‚Äúbears the bow of Love; and on that bow, the lustrous string is made of bees‚Ä¶.Weaves a string of Bees with deft invention, To speed the missile when the bow is bent.‚Äù
It is believed that Brahma resides as a bee of Vishnu‚Äôs navel-lotus, humming vedic texts. There is also a mention about a goddess, Brahmari in Srimad Devi Bhagavatam;book 10, chapter 13. Bhramari, who slayed the demon Arunasura, is considered as the goddess of bees. Lakshmi tantra (9,41-43), also mentions her, ‚ÄúDuring the sixtieth era there will be one demon, called Aru·πáa who will do much harm to men and sages. Then I shall appear in bee-form incorporating innumerable bees, and I shall slay the mighty demon and rescue the three worlds. From then on people will praise me forever and address me as BhrƒÅmarƒ´.‚Äù Iconographically she is portrayed with scores of bees emanating from her hands. Brahmari is worshipped on the eighth night of the Navarathri festival. There is a temple for her in Kasauni. It is said that Adi Guru Shankaracharya spent sometime in the temple, which is situated at the top of a mount enclosed by a fort. Bhramari Pranayama is a yogic technique that consists of concentrating on the sound emulating a bee along with breath control. The vibration of sound produced is said to enhance the level of consciousness. So the next time you hear the hum of a bee, do not panic!
(Penned on the occasion of the World Bee Day, 20th May)
Dr Raguram
26/06/24, 9:28‚ÄØam
As we were birding around the Stow Lake in Golden Gate Park few months ago, the unmissable melodious note of the Song Sparrow drew our attention. Thoreau described it as ‚ÄúMaids! Maids! Maids! hang up your teakettle-ettle-ettle.‚Äù Some others compared it the opening notes of Beethoven‚Äôs Fifth Symphony! It was flitting through low branches, occasionally moving onto open ground in search of food, pumping its tail up. It was foraging on the ground kicking away debris by hopping forward while sweeping both feet quickly back along the ground, a move often described as ‚Äòsong sparrow samba‚Äô! Soon, it perched on a stump and started singing.
Most of what we know about the song sparrow emerges from the work of one amateur ornithologist, Margaret Morse Nice. She shifted the focus away from collection, description of bird specimens and emphasized on close observation on bird behaviour in their natural setting. She observed and compiled a detailed study of the song sparrow in her own backyard. She marked each bird with a coloured band and managed to follow and study 336 individual birds in detail. And one of them, which she named 4M, remained in her study area for seven years. She described her technique as a ‚Äúphenomenogical method.‚Äù Interestingly, it is through the phenomenological approach as mental health professionals, we explore and understand the lived experience of people in throes of psychological distress. Her study, which spanned eight years, detailed the daily activities and territorial behaviour of several generations of song sparrows. Though she lacked a professional position and funding, she published 250 articles, five monographs and single-handedly initiated a new era in American ornithology.
In the words of Margaret Morse, ‚Äúthe study of nature is a limitless field, the most fascinating adventure in the world.‚Äù There are plenty of birds like the song sparrow right in our backyards/environs and her work should inspire us that we can learn a lot about them through careful observation.
With tongue in cheek, she observed, ‚ÄúI decided it would be better to be a bird. Birds are very busy at one period each year caring for babies, but this lasts only a few weeks with many of them, and then their babies are grown and gone. Best of all, they leave their houses forever and take to camping for the rest of the year. No wonder they are happy.‚Äù
(Margaret Morse Nice 6th December 1983 ‚Äì 26th June 1974)
Dr Raguram
29/06/24, 12:02‚ÄØpm
Antoine de Saint-Exup√©ry was born on this day in 1900. He was a precocious, talented child, who attached wings to his bicycle, to fulfil his dreams of becoming a pilot. He wrote only one children‚Äôs book, ‚ÄòThe Little Prince‚Äô, in his lifetime and it is one of those rare gems. The strength of any great work of literature is that it can be read and reflected upon at many levels. The book is both an engaging children‚Äôs fantasy and yet at the same time a philosophical fable on various aspects of life.
For me personally, there are two important inspirational dimensions embedded in this timeless tale.
The first theme is about the power of enduring love. The Little Prince has many encounters, one of which is with a Rose. She is delicate, vulnerable, needs watering and protection. She has only four thorns to protect herself and Little Prince dutifully cares for her. But then he must move on. Accepting his departure, the Rose comments, ‚ÄúWell, I must endure the presence of a few caterpillars if I wish to become acquainted with the butterflies.‚Äù A message as important as in any great philosophical tome. The little prince then encounters the fox who tells him that love is when you care enough to tend to someone who needs care.
The second theme is one of separation from a loved one, of loving someone with the inevitability of losing that friend. In a beautiful, poignant passage, the writer reflects, ‚ÄúBit by bit‚Ä¶ it comes over us that we shall never again hear the laughter of our friend, that this one garden is forever locked against us. And at that moment begins our true mourning, which, though it may not be rending, is yet a little bitter. For nothing, in truth, can replace that companion. Old friends cannot be created out of hand. Nothing can match the treasure of common memories, of trials endured together, of quarrels and reconciliations and generous emotions. It is idle, having planted an acorn in the morning, to expect that afternoon to sit in the shade of the oak. So life goes on. For years we plant the seed, we feel ourselves rich; and then come other years when time does its work and our plantation is made sparse and thin. One by one, our comrades slip away, deprive us of their shade.‚Äù
And I keep reflecting on these timeless words of the author, ‚ÄúWhat is essential is invisible to the eye.‚Äù It emphasizes the importance of looking beyond the surface and relying on intuition, empathy, and emotions to truly understand and appreciate what is essential in life.
Dr Raguram
05/07/24, 8:28‚ÄØam
On the 4th of July in 1855, Walt Whitman self-published his first edition of Leaves of Grass, a volume of twelve poems. He pronounced that ‚ÄúThis is no book, / Who touches this touches a man.‚Äù It had a lengthy preface in which he reflected on various aspects of life ‚ÄúLove the earth and sun and the animals, despise riches, give alms to everyone that asks, stand up for the stupid and crazy, devote your income and labour to others, hate tyrants, argue not concerning God, have patience and indulgence toward the people, take off your hat to nothing known or unknown or to any man or number of men, go freely with powerful uneducated persons and with the young and with the mothers of families, read these leaves in the open air every season of every year of your life, re-examine all you have been told at school or church or in any book, dismiss whatever insults your own soul, and your very flesh shall be a great poem and have the richest fluency not only in its words but in the silent lines of its lips and face and between the lashes of your eyes and in every motion and joint of your body.‚Äù
The initial print run of the first edition was modest and the book did not sell well. It did receive a number of rave reviews in New York newspapers and some of them were written by Whitman himself. Whitman was undeterred and continued to add poems to ‚ÄòLeaves of Grass‚Äô in four different editions and finished the last revision on his deathbed in 1892.
The poems in the ‚ÄòLeaves of Grass‚Äò represent Whitman's celebration of his philosophy of life and nature. Throughout the book, Whitman emphasizes the importance of connecting with nature and finding solace, inspiration, and spiritual fulfilment in the natural world. He sees nature as a source of wisdom and renewal, and encourages readers to forge a deeper connection with the environment around them.
‚ÄúSmile O voluptuous coolbreathed earth!
Earth of the slumbering and liquid trees!
Earth of departed sunset! Earth of the mountains misty-top!
Earth of vitreous pour of the full moon just tinged with blue!
Earth of shine and dark mottling the tide of the river!
Earth of the limpid gray of clouds brighter and clearer for my sake!
Far-swooping elbowed earth! Rich apple-blossomed earth!
Smile, for your lover comes!
Dr Raguram
25/07/24, 9:00‚ÄØam
Birds are nature‚Äôs original poems. Once you start to hear birds, notice them, learn their habits, the world around you opens up in beautiful ways. Our lives would be charmless without them. Their songs give solace to the weary soul. There are thousands of beautiful poems written about birds by poets all over the world. Many turned to them for inspiration at various points in their writing as birds provide boundless metaphors. For example, the singing of the nightingale becomes a metaphor for writing poetry in Shelley‚Äôs works, ‚ÄúA poet is a nightingale, who sits in darkness and sings to cheer its own solitude with sweet sounds; his auditors are as men entranced by the melody of an unseen musician, who feel that they are moved and softened, yet know not whence or why.‚Äù
The nightingale is a recurrent theme in poetry. Samuel Taylor Coleridge (21 October 177 - 25 July 1834), famed author of ‚ÄòRime of the Ancient Mariner‚Äô lived in the Chanters House which had a Victorian bird house with an aviary. He wrote about the nightingale too;
‚ÄúMany a nightingale perch giddily
On blossomy twig still swinging from the breeze,
And to that motion tune his wanton song
Like tipsy Joy that reels with tossing head.‚Äù
Poetry for Coleridge, ‚Äúhas been to me its own exceeding great reward; it has given me the habit of wishing to discover the good and beautiful in all that meets and surrounds me.‚Äù
(The accompanying image is that of the Northern Mockingbird which is commonly called the ‚ÄúAmerican Nightingale.‚Äù It lives up to its nickname, singing during the day and sometimes at night, varying its songs from spring to fall. The Northern Mockingbird can sing up to 30 differing bird songs)
Dr Raguram
07/08/24, 10:21‚ÄØam
India is a land of festivals. Traditions and rituals associated with it vary across the vast cultural landscape of India. For instance, today is celebrated as Hariyali Teej in many states in Northern India to commemorate the union of Shiva and Parvati.
Triyuginarayan temple is situated at the confluence of Mandakini and Son-Ganga river in Rudraprayag district of Uttarakhand. It is a much sought after wedding destination as it is said to be the place where the celestial marriage of Shiva and Parvati took place. Parvati, daughter to Himavat was keen to marry Shiva and undertook rigorous penance to prove her love and dedication to Shiva at Gauri Kund, which is not very far from Triyuginarayan. Gauri Kund temple, which dedicated to Parvati, is also the base camp for trekking to Kedarnath Temple. Mythology states that Shiva proposed to Parvati at Guptakashi and got married in the Triyuginarayan temple. A holy fire still burns perpetually in front of the temple and the ashes from this fire are supposed to promote conjugal bliss.
There are many sculptural depictions of the celestial event of the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. Perhaps one of most beautiful one is at the 10th century Bhoganandishwara temple near Bangalore. In this relief one can see Lord Brahma on the extreme right and next to him is Vishnu who is blessing the couple. In the middle are the couple, Shiva and Parvati. Next to the couple is the father of Parvati offering Kanyadan and adjoining him is Parvati‚Äôs mother.
Embedded in rich mythological tapestry, the marriage of Shiva and Parvati is a tale that resonates with devotion, perseverance, and the enduring power of love.
Dr Raguram
08/08/24, 10:15‚ÄØam
A movie that left a deep impression on me was ‚ÄòCharly‚Äô directed by Ralph Nelson. Based on the novel ‚ÄòFlowers for Algermon‚Äô by Daniel Keyes, It had a beautiful musical score by Pandit Ravi Shankar. It‚Äôs a timeless story that explores the experiences of Charlie Gordon, a 32-year-old man with a learning disability who undergoes surgery in an effort to make him ‚Äúsmarter‚Äù and more ‚Äúnormal.‚Äù Since the same procedure worked well on Algernon, a lab mouse, the scientists have high hopes for Charlie‚Äôs transformation. After the operation, Charlie‚Äôs intelligence begins to steadily increase and he is functionally a genius after a few months. As his intelligence grows, he finds it increasingly difficult to connect with others at an emotional level and realizes that he is losing touch with his own emotional needs and desires, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs worse; to not know what you are and be happy, or to become what you‚Äôve always wanted to be, and feel alone.‚Äù The researchers present Charlie and their findings at a scientific convention. Meanwhile Charly comes to know that Algernon has lost its enhanced intelligence and died, facts that the research team kept away from him. He starts wondering whether he will undergo a similar decline and reflects, ‚ÄúThe problem, dear professor, is that you wanted someone who could be made intelligent but still be kept in a cage and displayed when necessary to reap the honours you seek. The hitch is that I'm a person.‚Äù Soon Charly regresses to his previous level of intelligence, but finally feels himself at home, happier than before.
The story explores themes that are still relevant today, including intelligence, empathy, and the ethical implications of scientific advancement. More importantly, it seeks out the unflinchingly honest message that our humanity is not measured by how smart we are, but rather by our kindness, love and interaction with others.
In the era of Neurolink, the daunting question is ‚ÄúDoes intelligence alone makes us better people?‚Äù
Charly reminds us that, ‚ÄúIntelligence is one of the greatest human gifts. But all too often a search for knowledge drives out the search for love. This is something else I've discovered for myself very recently. I present it to you as a hypothesis: Intelligence without the ability to give and receive affection leads to mental and moral breakdown, to neurosis, and possibly even psychosis. And I say that the mind absorbed in and involved in itself as a self-centered end, to the exclusion of human relationships, can only lead to violence and pain.‚Äù
(Daniel Keyes: 9 August 1927 - 15 June 2014)
Dr Raguram
16/08/24, 10:27‚ÄØam
Varalakshmi Puja is celebrated mostly in South India. Goddess Varalakshmi represents prosperity and divine grace. The name 'Varalakshmi' itself signifies her nature; 'Vara' meaning boon or blessing, and 'Lakshmi' referring to the goddess of wealth. This form of the goddess is particularly revered for her role in granting wishes and bringing prosperity. It is believed that worshipping the Goddess Varalakshmi on this day is equivalent to worshipping Ashtalakshmis; the eight goddesses of Wealth, Earth, Wisdom, Love, Fame, Peace, Contentment, and Strength.
There are iconographic variations in depiction of the Goddess. In this sculpture from Nuggehalli, Karnataka, she is found seated and has four arms. The four arms are symbolic of the four goals of humanity: dharma (pursuit of ethical, moral life), artha (pursuit of wealth, means of life), kama (pursuit of love, emotional fulfillment), and moksha (pursuit of self-knowledge, liberation). Her front right hand is held up in the abhaya mudra while her left hand is in the varada mudra giving boons to her devotees.
Muthuswami Dishidhar composed a beautiful song ‚ÄòSri Varalakshmi Nama Sthubhyam‚Äô in praise of the Goddess. Most appropriately it is set in the raga Sri (one of the names of Lakshmi). It starts with the pallavi
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏ ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§∞‡§∏ ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§∏‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§™‡§¶‡•á
Interestingly the pallavi starting from sArasa is in form of Gopuccha Yati which begins with a set of syllables and gets one syllable smaller with each repetition. The syllables are arranged similar to a cow‚Äôs tail, which is broad at the beginning gradually tapering to the bottom.
The pallavi translates as;
I bow down to you, O eminent Goddess Lakshmi, the giver of boons!
O bestower of fortunes! O Sri with feet as soft as a lotus, you are the bestower of affection, be my companion at every step.
Dr Raguram
26/08/24, 9:14‚ÄØam
Krishna Janmashtami, celebrates the birth of Krishna. Stories of Krishna's childhood are illustrated in numerous paintings and sculptures. This small sculpture at Amrutheshwara temple at Amruthapura in Karnataka depicts an interesting episode during his childhood.
The village that Krishna lived in, Gokula, was a land of cow herders. Hence, not surprisingly, there was an abundance of milk, curds, and butter in the village. Krishna was very fond of butter and would make use of every opportunity to steal butter from his mother or from any of the place in the village. Many of them started tying pots of butter to the ceiling so that Krishna or his friends couldn‚Äôt reach them. Undeterred by this, Krishna would team up with his friends to reach these pots by climbing on the shoulders of his friends. People found out that Krishna was the prime culprit for these acts and complained to Yashoda. One day, Yashoda lost her patience and tied him up in a heavy grindstone in the courtyard and went inside to attend to her domestic chores. Left alone, Krishna happily and effortlessly dragged the grindstone and passed through the gap between two Arjuna trees. But the grindstone got stuck in between and when Krishna pulled the mortar with all his strength the roots of the two trees get uprooted and they fell to the ground with a loud crash. The twin trees were, in fact, the two sons of Kubera, the god of wealth, Nalakubara and Manigriva. They were cursed by the sage Narada to be born as two Arjuna trees in Gokula. When Krishna pulled down the two trees they got liberated from the curse.
Since Yashoda tied him to the mortar with a rope, Krishna is also called as Damodara (dam + udara = rope + stomach). Sri Damodarastakam is a poem written by Sri Satyavrata Muni that describes his love for Sri Damodara. The poem is made up of eight verses and is found in the Padma Purana by Krishna Dwaipayana Vyasa. In the poem, Satyavrata Muni prays to Sri Damodara to appear to him in his eternal form as a young cowherd-boy and bestow his blessings. The 7th verse states:
‡§ï‡•Å‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•å ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß-‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç
‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•å ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø-‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡•å ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•å ‡§ö
‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ-‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ
‡§® ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§π ‡•• ‡•≠‡••
O Lord Damodara, in Your form as a baby, Mother Yasoda bound You to a grinding stone with a rope. You then freed the sons of Kuvera, Manigriva and Nalakuvara, who were cursed to stand as trees and You gave them the chance to become Your devotees. Please bless me in this same way. I only long for this and have no desire for any kind of liberation.

05/09/24, 6:29‚ÄØpm
Oh nice to hear about your experience with a 'teacher' in the real sense. Wish you a very happy teachers day sir. I have learnt a lot and continue to learn with your spotlights.
07/09/24, 7:56‚ÄØam
Nritya Ganapati is the 15th among the 32 forms of Ganesha. This exquisitely carved sculpture of Nritya Ganapati (Dancing Ganesha) is from Chennakeshava temple at Somanathapura. A significant aspect of Nritya Ganapati‚Äôs imagery is the setting of his dance, beneath the Kalpavriksha, or the wish-fulfilling tree. This choice of location is not arbitrary. The Kalpavriksha in Hindu mythology is known to grant all wishes. Nritya Ganapati‚Äôs dance under this tree thus becomes a metaphor for the joyous and bountiful nature of the cosmos. He is depicted with four hands. His left foot is firmly placed on the ground whereas the right one is lifted up and bent sideways at the knee. He is bejewelled and intricate ornaments decorate various parts of his body. Despite his bulky disposition, there is a lightness in his stance.
Oothukadu Venkata Subba Iyer, popularly known as Venkata Kavi, was a brilliant composer of the 18th Century who made immense contributions to the Carnatic Music repertoire. One of his memorable composition is on Nritya Ganapati, titled ‚ÄòAnandha Narthana Ganapathim‚Äô in the raga Naatai, which begins with these lines:
‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§® ‡§ó‡§£‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á ‚Äì (‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç / ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ )
‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡•ê ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§ú‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶)
Ananda nartana gaNapatim bhAvayE
chidAkAra mUlAdhAra OmkAra gajavadanam paramam param (Ananda)
I meditate on the joyous dancing Ganapati always
Whose form is pure consciousness, who lives in the muladhara chakra and who is the form of Om, the elephant faced one, the supreme one.
Though we recognize Ganesha in various forms, in Adi Shankara‚Äôs words, he is formless Supreme Brahman. 'Ajam Nirvikalpam Niraakaaramekam,' Ganesha is Ajam (unborn), Nirvikalpa (attributeless), Niraakaar (formless) and he symbolizes Brahman, the absolute consciousness.
Dr Raguram
14/09/24, 9:18‚ÄØam
One of the temples not often visited in Khajuraho is the Vamana temple. Set amidst a verdant, green landscape, it is a sight to behold with its spire reaching up like a beautiful mountain. Like rest of the temples in Khajuraho, the outer walls of the sanctum are adorned with intricate carvings depicting scenes from Hindu mythology. In the sanctum is a striking idol of Vamana, the fifth incarnation of Lord Vishnu. Vamana is the first incarnation whem Lord Vishnu appeared in a full human form, as a dwarf.
The legend of the Vamana avatar is narrated in the Rigveda and other scriptures. Mahabali, son of Virochan and grandson of Prahlad, was a generous, mighty monarch who was adored by his subjects. He was granted the boon of immortality by Lord Brahma and he continued to expand the frontiers of his empire. He conquered all the three realms: Heaven, Earth and the Underworld. Immensely troubled by growing powers, the Devas appealed to Lord Vishnu to intervene and restore the balance of power. Responding to their prayers, Lord Vishnu incarnated as Vamana, the dwarf and went to the Yaga that was being performed by Mahabali. During the Yaga, people could ask Mahabali for and receive anything they wanted. Mahabali bade Vamana to ask for anything that he wanted, like jewels, land, forests etc, without hesitation. Vamana denied all these politely and asked merely for three paces of land. Looking at Vamana‚Äôs diminutive stature, Bali said, ‚ÄòSo be it; pace and take it.‚Äô The dwarf Vamana suddenly grew in size into a giant and with one step measured the Earth and with another the entire Heaven. As there was no room left for the third step that had been granted, Mahabali humbly knelt under Vamana‚Äôs foot and offered his head. As Bali sank deep into the underworld, he heard his subjects wailing in grief for their much loved king. Seeing this, Vamana granted Mahabali one last boon. The boon was the permission to visit his subjects on Earth once a year. Thus, Mahabali returns every year to visit his people and the land that he had once ruled. Onam commemorates the annual visit of this legendary king from the underworld to his former kingdom, the land of Kerala.
Parsva Ekadashi which is observed today is also associated with the legend of Mahabali and Vamana Avatar of Lord Vishnu and is also referred to as Vamana Ekadashi. It is fascinating to note that the Onam festival follows the same legend and takes place around the same time of year.
Dr Raguram
23/09/24, 9:14‚ÄØam
On September 21, Max Schur, Freud‚Äôs personal physician visited him and was aghast to see him looking pale and quite wasted. Freud took his doctor‚Äôs hand and said, ‚ÄúMy dear Schur, you certainly remember our first talk. You promised me then not to forsake me when the time comes. Now it is nothing but torture and makes no sense anymore.‚Äù Schur responded stating that he had not forgotten the promise he made. Freud thanked him and told Schur to ‚Äútalk it over with Anna, and if she thinks it‚Äôs right, make an end of it.‚Äù Schur spoke to Anna and she sorrowfully concurred with her father‚Äôs wish. Then Schur gave Freud an injection of three centigrams of morphine, a dose much stronger than he would have used if the objective had only been to relieve pain. He was now assisting him to die a peaceful death. He gave Freud another injection that day, then a third on September 22. Freud lapsed into a coma, but he held on to life. At 3AM in the morning on Saturday, September 23, 1939, Sigmund Freud breathed his last. Three days later, his body was cremated and his ashes placed in an ancient Greek urn, originally gifted to him by his friend Marie Bonaparte.
Many years before, Freud had made it abundantly clear as to how he wanted to die as he never wanted to live without his mental capacities intact. He wrote to his friend Oskar Pfister, ‚ÄúWith all the resignation before destiny that suits an honest man, I have one wholly secret entreaty: only no invalidism, no paralysis of one‚Äôs powers through bodily misery. Let us die in harness, as King Macbeth says.‚Äù
Freud left the world with a certain degree of composure. In Nietzsche‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúThe most fortunate author is one who is able to say as an old man that all he had of life giving, invigorating, uplifting enlightening thoughts and feelings still lives on in his writings, and that he himself is only the gray ash, while the fire has been rescued and carried forth everywhere.‚Äù
The last book Freud read was Balzac‚Äôs La Peau de Chagrin (The Wild Ass‚Äôs Skin). The protagonist, Rapheal de Valentin, gains possession of a wild donkey‚Äôs skin and is granted all he wishes. The magical object has the power to fulfil its owner's every wish but carries a heavy price: With every wish the owner's remaining time in life is reduced. On finishing the book, Freud told Schur, ‚ÄúThis was the proper book for me to read.‚Äù
Mark Edmundson has written a very perceptive book on Freud‚Äôs last days, ‚ÄòThe Death Of Sigmund Freud.‚Äô The book ends with these words ‚ÄúToward the person who has died we adopt a special attitude: something like admiration for someone who has accomplished a very difficult task.‚Äù
In the words of Sheena Blackhall
‚ÄúIt was Saturday, under the sign of Libra
When he crossed, with the aid of morphine,
(that child of Morpheus, Greek God of Dreams)
Into the world of the dead.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
29/09/24, 9:47‚ÄØam
Today is the World Heart Day‚Ä¶
Sharing a poem by Dr Viswanathan Venkatachalam
An interventional cardiologist based in Sydney, Australia
THE INFARCT PARTY
Today I wish to write a solemn poetry
On poor little coronary artery
With an infarction, it‚Äôs lumen totally seals
Gosh! The pain that the patient feels!
In comes the cardiologist from a party
All gadgets to make it hale and hearty
We need to get a catheter in first,
For the clot in the artery to be burst!
In comes the wire and on it a balloon
In saving the life, this really is a boon!
Now the stenosis has just got to vent
In comes to cure the majestic stent!
With all drugs on board is served cocktail
This the happy ending of the cardiac tale!
Dr Raguram
01/10/24, 6:54‚ÄØam
I don't mind being older. I'm proud of my age. Being a ‚Äòsenior citizen‚Äô has its own advantages! In the crowded mayhem of security checks in the airport, one is gently guided ahead of the queue and people offer their seat in the airport shuttle. As they say, ‚ÄúAge is a question of mind over matter. If you don't mind, it doesn't matter.‚Äù I follow Walt Disney‚Äôs dictum ‚ÄúImagination has no age. And dreams are forever.‚Äù
Thought of sharing a lovely poem by Mary Oliver on the occasion of ‚ÄúInternational Day for ‚ÄòOlder‚Äô Persons.‚Äù
HALLELUIAH by Mary Oliver
Everyone should be born into this world happy
and loving everything.
But in truth it rarely works that way.
For myself, I have spent my life clamoring toward it.
Halleluiah, anyway I‚Äôm not where I started!
And have you too been trudging like that, sometimes
almost forgetting how wondrous the world is
and how miraculously kind some people can be?
And have you too decided that probably nothing important
is ever easy?
Not, say, for the first sixty years.
Halleluiah, I‚Äôm sixty now, and even a little more,
and some days I feel I have wings.
Dr Raguram
08/10/24, 9:10‚ÄØam
Navratri is devoted to the worship of Goddess Durga in her various forms. Katyayani is one among the Navadurgas, the nine forms of the Goddess, who is worshipped on the sixth fay of Navratri. She is a fierce manifestation of Shakti, the divine female power.
In the Devi Bhagavata Purana, it is mentioned that Rishi Katyayana was a great devotee of Mother Shakti. He wished for the goddess to be born in his household in the form of his daughter. For this, Sage Katyayana did severe penance for years. Meanwhile, the malevolent Mahishasura was wreaking havoc, tormenting the gods relentlessly. Seeking a solution, the divine trinity of Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma emitted flames that coalesced into the formidable form of Goddess Katyayani. Each of them gifted her a weapon to vanquish Mahishasura. She then embarked on a mission, engaged Mahishasura in a fearsome battle, defeated and vanquished him. Hence, she is also referred to as Mahishasura Mardhini.
This delicately sculpted panel in the inner wall of the Chidambaram temple depicts Katyayani with eighteen hands, her leg firmly entrenched on the neck of Mahishasura.
The legend of Katyayani is not merely a relic of a bygone era but an inspiring metaphor of resilience and empowerment, which women can draw upon in their daily lives even now. In a world beset with discrimination, inequality, and injustice faced by women, her story illustrates that courage, coupled with an unshakable resolve, can be a continuing source of motivation to conquer adversities and challenge norms even in the face of seemingly insurmountable odds.
Dr Raguram
11/10/24, 8:48‚ÄØam
This is a beautiful sculpture of Vishnu Durga at the Melakadambur temple which dates back to 12th century, constructed during the reign of Kulottunga Chola. She is four-armed and carries conch and discus in her upper handd. Her right hand is in ‚Äòabhaya posture‚Äô. She is standing in samabhanga pose, which means she is resting her weight equally on both feet. Vishnu Durga is usually depicted in a peaceful form (Saumya Vadana).
Dr Raguram
02/11/24, 8:50‚ÄØam
Balipadyami is observed the day after Diwali in Karnataka. On this day let us recall the story of Mahabali. According to the legend, once upon a time, there was an asura called Bali, also known as Mahabali, who conquered three worlds and was famous for his generosity. Over the course of time he annexed the celestial world too. Unhappy with it, Indra, king of the celestial regions, requested Vishnu to deal with Bali. Vishnu took the form of a dwarf, Vamana, and asked Mahabali for three paces of land. Mahabali granted it without a second thought. The dwarf then suddenly transformed into a giant, and with two paces, he claimed the sky, the earth, and all possessions that Mahabali had. Vamana then asked him where should he take the third step. The only thing Mahabali had left was his body. So he told Vamana to step on his head. Vamana did so and pushed Bali underground into Patal. Mahabali, however, was granted a wish to visit the earth once a year to meet the people who loved him very much.
One of the most beautiful depictions of this myth is in Cave II in Badami: the Vamana-Trivikrama sculpture is carved on the western wall of the mukhamandapa. In the centre of the panel Vishnu is portrayed as Trivikrama. Eight-armed, his right leg is placed firmly on the ground, while the left leg is raised up to the level of chest, with Mahabali underneath it. Of the eight hands, seven hold khadga, bana, gada, chakra, sankha, khetaka and chapa. The remaining left hand is stretched out parallel to the raised leg. A soldier with a sword is shown falling upside down, failing in his attempt to attack Vishnu. A dwarfish person who is portrayed in a royal outfit holds the right leg of Trivikrama firmly, to obstruct his measuring the paces; he is identified as Namuchi, the son of Bali. On the lower left part of this panel, Vamana‚Äôs figure has been unfortunately defaced and he can be identified only by his umbrella. Sukracharya is shown by his side pouring water into the hand of Vamana while Bali stands behind with his wife Vindhyavali. Strangely Shukracharya has a Buddha like demeanour.
What does the story of Balipadyami inform us? Mahabali was caught in the trappings of his ego, craving for more power and perceiving himself as invulnerable. When Trivikrama asked him ‚Äúwhere can I place the third step?‚Äù he broke free from the fetters of ego and surrendered himself to the divine, cosmic power. When we light the lamp on Balipadyami, let us strive to renew our deeper connection with the divine through transcending the trappings of our ego. It is a path to tread in a period of time when narcissistic patterns are so salient and on the rise.
Dr Raguram
04/11/24, 8:31‚ÄØam
One has to take the electric buggy or walks some distance to reach Cave 29. The location of the cave is the most picturesque of all the caves with a large waterfall plunging into the gorge next to it. This cave is planned in the shape of a cross and has massive friezes of Shiva & Parvati adorning the walls. Prominent among them is this large sculptural depiction of the marriage of Shiva and Parvati, officiated by Lord Brahma. Many poets have described this scene in the verse form. I am particularly drawn to this poem titled ‚ÄòMahadev-ji ka Byah‚Äô (Wedding ceremony of Lord Mahadev ) written by Nazeer Akbarabadi. A Muslim by birth, Nazeer Akbarabadi, predates Ghalib. He wrote on a wide variety of subjects and on religious subjects ranging from Islam, Hinduism to Budhism. Nazeer strongly opposed religious orthodoxy and was a strong advocate of the syncretic culture of the land. Here is the wonderful poem about the marriage of Shiva and Parvati.
‚Äú‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§Å‡§µ ‡§ó‡§£‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∏ ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§è
‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ú ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§π‡•ã‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ç‡§∞‡§§ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§è
‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§ö‡§® ‡§Ü‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§π
‡§∏‡•Å‡§® ‡§≤‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã, ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® ‡§ß‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π
‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§æ, ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®
‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§æ, ‡§â‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£
‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§π‡§Å‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡§º‡•Å‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§ø‡§® ‡§∞‡•à‡§®
‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡§¢‡§º‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡§∞, ‡§â‡§® ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§ö‡•à‡§®
‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏ ‡§®‡•á ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§ï‡•Ä, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§è
‡§â‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§π‡§∞ ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ-‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§è
‡§ñ‡§º‡•Å‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§¶‡§ø‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§ ‡§µ‡•ã, ‡§ï‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§® ‡§π‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤-‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∞
‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§â‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ '‡§®‡§ú‡§º‡•Ä‡§∞'‚Äù
‚ÄúBefore you begin, honour Ganesh and bow with grace
so your tasks are completed and good fortune you embrace
Utter the words of joy, love, affection and attachment
My friends, attentively listen to the story of the wedding of Mahadev
Those who listened from hermits narrated it
And those who listened as the story also certify
Those who listen remain cheerful day and nigh
Those who read and memorize are also happy
Whoever narrates the glory of this wedding
Lord Shiva remains happy with him
This exercise brings the happiness that one doesn‚Äôt feel sad
Glory to the narrator whose name is ‚ÄòNazeer‚Äô‚Äù
Our worldview often becomes restricted by our personal beliefs, religious values and political orientations. The strength of poems like this lies in its ability to transport us beyond these confines especially in times when inclusive principles and pluralistic perspectives are under strain.
In Kavi Pradeep‚Äôs words from the movie Nastik, ‚ÄúDekh tere sansar ki halat kya ho gayi bhagwaan kitna badal gaya insaan...‚Äù (Look at what has happened to your world, O god. Man has changed so much).
Dr Raguram
04/12/24, 9:34‚ÄØam
Kandariya Mahadeva Temple is the largest and most ornate temple at Khajuraho. Every inch of its exterior walls is adorned with a mesmerizing profusion of sculptures. Deities from the Hindu pantheon like Brahma, Vishnu, and Ganesha grace the walls, their expressions radiating serenity and power. Geometric patterns and floral motifs add a touch of elegance, while friezes depicting scenes from mythology offer a glimpse into ancient Hindu epics. Interspersed with these are the celestial nymphs (apsaras) in their flowing attire adorned with intricate jewellery. They are shown in various poses, such as playing instruments, dancing, beautifying themselves, or removing a thorn from the foot.
I was totally bewitched on seeing the depiction of a voluptuous apsara with a scorpion sculpted on her left thigh. Intricately carved, it seems to be traveling up. It doesn‚Äôt appear to be a decorative motif and seemed to be associated uniquely with the celestial beauty. Strangely, there is no fear or apprehension on the apsara‚Äôs face. What could be the association of a sensuous beauty with a scorpion? In Indian mythology, Vrischika has multiple and diverse symbolic meanings, ranging from fear to allure. In Vedic astrology Vruschika Rashi embodies intensity, passion, and transformation. Could the scorpion be a metaphor for female arousal? Al-Biruni, in his book written in 1029 A.D. just around the time that the Kandariya Mahadeva temple was constructed and shortly after his own trip to India, states that in India, scorpions were associated with the genitals, fertility, progeny.
I searched far and wide to understand and unravel the iconographic background of the association of scorpion with sensuality and it still remains an unfathomable mystery to me!
Dr Raguram
14/12/24, 10:02‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir and wish you all the same.
23/12/24, 7:49‚ÄØpm
Sending across the calendar to keep you company in the New Year. Do feel free to print itüôÇ

Professional

01/01/24, 8:56‚ÄØam

01/01/24, 1:32‚ÄØpm
If not in the vicinity of nature, at least we are lucky to look at the wonderful photographs, fill our eyes and mind with colours. Thank you Sir.
05/01/24, 10:09‚ÄØam
It was a bright morning and as we were making our way in the Coyote Hills Regional Park, we heard a loud, rattling sound. And when we looked around, a bird with bright colours under its wings caught our eyes. It perched on the outer branches of a tree, feasting on the berries. It was the Northern Flicker. As we were watching, it, hopped down onto the ground, foraging for insects. Its scientific name is Colaptes auratus. Colaptes means ‚Äúto peck.‚Äù Northern Flickers are often referred to as the ‚Äúanteaters of the sky.‚Äù Unlike other woodpeckers, which usually remain high in the treetops, Northern Flickers venture down to ground level to search for their favourite meal, ants. They are ably assisted in this task by their slightly curved bill. Their dusky brow plumage helps them to blend with the colours of the forest floor. Most woodpeckers in North America have black white stripped plumage, which helps them to blend in with tree bark. Northern Flickers stand apart and are considered the ‚Äòblack sheep‚Äô of the woodpecker family because they have brown feathers and forage for food on the ground. The Northern Flicker is one of the few North American woodpeckers that is strongly migratory.
(On the occasion of the National Birds Day which is observed on January 5 in USA to raise awareness about the role of birds in our ecosystem)
Dr Raguram
05/01/24, 1:24‚ÄØpm
Enlightening info Sir....
06/01/24, 9:46‚ÄØam
Among the many calls that I received this New Year, I was deeply touched by a particular one. It was from a lady whom I had known for the past few years. She rang up and said, ‚ÄúDoctor let this New Year be good for you and all those who help others‚Äù. What is distinctive about the caller is that she is a crematorium worker who handles all the paper work there.
I met her a few years ago, helping a friend who had lost a family member, to fill the forms. When I was about to leave, she asked me whether I was a doctor. Hearing the affirmative answer, she shared her psychological travails which were being attended to by a dear former student. I reassured her stating that she was in good hands while emphasizing the need to be regular with treatment. She profusely thanked me and thereafter kept in touch with me periodically.
Working in a crematorium can be a daunting task, more so being a woman. At a time when the term ‚Äòstress‚Äô is flaunted widely, I was keen to know more about her and how she coped with her situation. Her answer was simple, ‚ÄúI earn a livelihood doctor, for the sake of my children, for their better future‚Äù. I gathered that her husband was a drunkard without any regular work and she had to tend for two young children, with very little support from the extended family. She works six days a week with few breaks or any holiday. At the end of a busy working day, she gets back home, has a bath and starts cooking for the night. Her husband scolds and often beats her, if by chance the food is delayed. He is also sexually demanding and if she refuses, starts suspecting her. In spite of these ordeals when I chance to see her at work, I invariably find her attending to her task with a smile on her face.
By accepting the job, she has joined a cadre of Indian women who are entering arenas from which they have traditionally been excluded. That she has chosen to work in a space with significant stigma associated with it, where even men feel uneasy to be in, is a testament to her resilience.
A plant that can teach us resilience is the bamboo. It can withstand twice as much force bearing down on it while being stretched, pulled or bent. According to a Japanese proverb: ‚ÄúIn time, even the strongest wind tires itself out, but the bamboo remains standing tall and still.‚Äù
There is an interesting Zen parable, ‚ÄòBe like a bamboo‚Äô:
A Zen Master was walking through the forest down a narrow trail with one of his students along a steep incline. The student lost his footing and slipped; just as he began tumbling down the hill, the student reached out and grabbed a small bamboo tree. The bamboo bent nearly all the way over as the student continued to hold on tightly. He pulled himself up and brushed off the dirt with the Zen Masters help.
‚ÄúDid you notice that when you fell, you grabbed a hold of the bamboo and it bent nearly all the way over and still supported you.‚Äù the Zen Master asked.
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the student replied. The Zen Master gripped the bamboo and pulled the bamboo over.
‚ÄúBe like the bamboo,‚Äù the Zen Master said as he let go of the bamboo and it sprang back to its up-right position. ‚ÄúIt is pushed around by the wind and yet it always bounces back and grows upward, toward the sun, enlightenment. Have you ever felt as though you were going to snap? Have you ever felt as though you were at your breaking point, emotionally?‚Äù
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the student replied.
‚ÄúThen bend, do not break, such is the way with bamboo. It endures the stress and finds a way to bounce back!‚Äù the Zen Master stated. ‚ÄúThis is called resilience.‚Äù
Throughout our journey in life, we meet people along the way and we connect with the heart of a few from whom we draw inspiration. They become a poem or a story in my life to live by.
Dr Raguram
09/01/24, 8:55‚ÄØam
I have a time worn book of ‚ÄòSecond Sex‚Äô by Simone de Beauvoir (whose birthday is today) and it is incredible as to how it is so relevant today, decades after its publication. Weaving together perspectives from biology, psychoanalysis, anthropology, sociology, psychology, history she narrates as to how gender demarcation came into being and women lead a life as the ‚ÄòSecond Sex‚Äô; ‚ÄúHumanity is male, and man defines woman, not in herself, but in relation to himself.‚Äù She theorizes about every phase of a woman's life, from infancy to old age, and the events outlining each phase with insight and erudition. No woman before her had written with such candour about the most intimate aspects of women. Adopting an existentialist framework, she emphasizes on the social construction of femininity. Women are not born knowing what it means to be a woman, how to behave, what jobs to do, how to feel, but are rather socialized into the role of ‚Äòwoman,‚Äô often by men; ‚ÄúOne is not born, but rather becomes, a woman.‚Äù
She concludes ‚ÄòSecond Sex‚Äô with optimistic undertones, hoping that either gender will eventually see eye to eye and accept each other as subjects and equals.
‚ÄúOn the day when it will be possible for woman to love not in her weakness but in her strength, not to escape herself but to find herself, not to abase herself but to assert herself on that day love will become for her, as for man, a source of life and not of mortal danger.‚Äù
It is an important read in these times when there is an attempt to define the role of women according to staid ideologies.
Dr Raguram
10/01/24, 9:05‚ÄØam
I had posted yesterday about Simone de Beauvoir‚Äôs ‚ÄòSecond Sex‚Äô, wherein she urges women to
have the freedom to escape from prescribed social roles and seek their own identity. This perspective has been articulated well in many works of fiction. Daisy Rockwell's translation of Geetanjali Shree's Hindi novel ‚ÄòRet Samadhi‚Äô ‚Äò‚Äô‡§∞‡•á‡§§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‚Äô which I read some time ago, is one such engaging narrative. It traces the life trajectory of a woman who is recently bereaved and her journey to discover aspects of self that were deeply buried within her.
The strength of any work of fiction is that it can be read at different layers, each with its own attendant meaning. Grief after a loss of a partner has been essayed in many novels. Usually it follows a predictable path, focusing on the loss and its emotional impact within the individual. What is different in this work is the broader narration of separation and loss in the historical context of partition and the quest of the protagonist to seek her personal identity embedded in it.
The novel is tale of transformative powers of crossing the ‚Äòborders‚Äô, of geography, gender and prescriptive roles, reaffirming that the inner landscape has no borders. ‚ÄúAnything worth doing transcends borders‚Äù.
The protagonist‚Äôs travel is also a journey into her own self, opening doors of discovery. In her words, ‚ÄúAlways, at least once, every woman, whether this one or that one, whether small or big, finds herself at the door, one foot poised in the air, like a dancer striking a mudra, a pose, in order to re-enter the home or that door which she has renounced and already left far behind, asking herself in that moment, Is this my world in which I‚Äôm setting foot, or is it that which is receding behind me, where I had gone, or whence I‚Äôve come?‚Äù
As for the story, ‚ÄúOnce you‚Äôve got women and a border, a story can write itself. Even women on their own are enough. Women are stories in themselves, full of stirrings and whisperings that float on the wind, that bend with each blade of grass.‚Äù
There is extensive use of metaphors like doors and windows. ‚Äúthere was a painter, Bhupen Khakkar. He told stories with brush‚Ä¶He knew that a story cannot be locked into a box, or a canvas, or a gaze. So he never tried. On the contrary, he always left a small window, an empty space, so the story could move on at will and take another path if it so desired. Because stories never end. They jump through windows and cracks‚Ä¶or create them by shaking, causing the earth to quake"
The novel is replete with lyrical passages, like this one, ‚ÄúMa sips her morning tea as though drinking in a bird‚Äôs song‚Äù.
All together a fascinating read!
Dr Raguram
10/01/24, 10:33‚ÄØpm
Truly interesting sir. 'Will' to find one's own path matters. Scenario is changing....
11/01/24, 10:23‚ÄØam
William James (whose birthday is today), is most famous for his psychology textbook,‚Äô Principles of Psychology‚Äô which was published in 1890. It consisted of two volumes with over 1400 pages and took him 12 years to write. He did not produce any original research, did not perform any experiment, yet he became the driving force behind psychology.
Of the many topics he addressed during his life time, he is most famous for his theories about emotions and consciousness. Concerning emotions, James believed that a person is exposed to a stimulus, has a physiological reaction, and then interprets that reaction as emotion. So, first comes physiological arousal, then the subjective interpretation of those processes as emotion. An independent researcher in Denmark, Carl Lange, developed a similar theory of emotion at roughly the same time as James did. Their view of emotion came to be known as the James-Lange theory of emotion. Though it was later thought not to be an accurate theory of how emotions work, its framework was quite influential in drawing attention to the interaction between physiological processes and emotion.
William James also conceptualized consciousness as a river or a stream, constantly changing and never the same. He had an abiding interest in religion and faith. He believed that divine existence can be justified by the emotional benefits it brings to one‚Äôs life. His book ‚ÄòThe Varieties of Religious Experience: a study in human nature‚Äô, examines varied forms of religious experiences such as mystical experiences, conversion, saintliness, and spirituality from a psychological perspective. I was quite surprised to learn that the emphasis given in Alcoholic Anonymous is largely due to the influence of this book. It seems that when Bill, a co-founder of AA, was trying to fight his way back to sobriety, chanced upon a copy of the book and was deeply impressed by James' "great wisdom." It also helped Bill to finally achieve sobriety and the impact of the book can be seen in the formulation of AA's basic ideas.
James was an inspiring teacher. His students included such luminaries as Theodore Roosevelt, author and philosopher George Santayana and Gertrude Stein.
I particularly like this observation of his, ‚ÄúA great many people think they are thinking when they are merely rearranging their prejudices.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
13/01/24, 10:01‚ÄØam
In my forays into the Zen landscape, I discovered the poetry of Ryokan. His poems are direct and unpretentious, infused with profound insights. For example, he wrote:
The rain has stopped, the clouds have drifted away,
and the weather is clear again.
If your heart is pure, then all things in your world are pure.
Abandon this fleeting world, abandon yourself,
Then the moon and flowers will guide you along the Way.
He is reported to have led a live of extreme simplicity. He showed love for all living things to the extent of placing lice under his robes to keep them warm, allowing thieves to take freely from his possessions, and letting one leg protrude from his mosquito net at night to give the mosquitos food. As a Zen priest, he never established his own temple, and lived by alms. Instead of preaching, he enjoyed companionship and conversation with many ordinary people. His practice consisted of sitting in zazen meditation, walking in the woods, playing with children, making his daily begging rounds, reading, writing poetry and on occasion drinking sake with friends. He was adept in calligraphy and was also known as one of Japan's great calligraphers.
He was deeply influenced by the teachings of Dogen, the 13th century monk, about whom I wrote sometime back. Ryokan never published a collection of verse while he was alive. One of his last verses reads;
Life is like a dewdrop,
Empty and fleeting;
My years are gone
And now, quivering and frail,
I must fade away.
As Rabindranath Tagore wrote, ‚ÄúLet your life lightly dance on the edges of Time like dew on the tip of a life.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
15/01/24, 10:18‚ÄØpm
Literally farmers are the backbone of our country. Hope nature doesn't play truant in their lives. Thank you for your wishes sir and wish you and madam the same.
17/01/24, 8:38‚ÄØam
Yes Sir yesterday was Mattu Pongal. We call it as Kanu (calf) pandigai. Celebrated by daughters in their mother's place. A day when we wish prosperity both for the family of origin and family a daughter enters after marriage. And the 'pidi' made of previous day rice, Dosa etc is fed to cows and prayed. I had never heard of a poem dedicated to buffalos. Very nice.
20/01/24, 7:01‚ÄØam
You cannot miss the European Robin when you take a stroll in the gardens of London. unlike its counterpart in America, it is a colourful bird with a striking orange breast. As you watch, it makes forays to the ground to catch insects and quickly flies back to its shady perch. The French naturalist Georges Cuvie gave the bird its current name Erithacus rubecula. The epithet rubecula is derived from the Latin, ruber ‚Äòred‚Äô.
The Victorian postmen used to be known as robins because part of their tunic was orange red. When Christmas cards first came into vogue they were brought by robins! And robins started featuring in the in the Christmas cards too.
There is a wealth of Christian mythology associated with it. The legend is that the robin was moved when it saw Christ on the cross and began to pluck the thorns out of the crown of thorns. The blood stained the robin and hence its orange red breast. According to an Irish tale, a robin flew in to see the infant Jesus in the manger. The infant reached out to touch the bird causing it to blush in deference and hence its colour!
Shakespeare refers to the charming song of the European Robin in Two Gentlemen of Verona.
Valentine: Why, how know you that I am in love?
Speed: Marry, by these special marks: first, you have learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms like a malcontent; to relish a love song like a robin redbreast; to walk alone like one that had the pestilence; to sigh like a schoolboy that had lost his ABC; to weep like a young wench that had buried her grandam; to fast like one that takes diet; to watch like one that fears robbing; to speak puling like a beggar at Hallowmas.
Emily Dickinson wrote a lovely small poem about it:
If I can stop one heart from breaking,
I shall not live in vain;
If I can ease one life the aching,
Or cool one pain,
Or help one fainting robin
Unto his nest again,
I shall not live in vain.
It is believed that when a robin appears, it is a sign that a loved one is near.
Dr Raguram
21/01/24, 8:55‚ÄØam
It is always so wonderful to see the Malabar Giant Squirrel prancing from one tree branch to another. It will pause for a while to eat fruits with its tiny hands and scramble to the upper reaches of the canopy in a flash of a second. The multi-coloured magician is adept in nimbly disappearing without a trace. They build their nests, called dreys, in close proximity to each other and use them as decoys to fool predators. The joy of observing them up close is truly memorable.
I had my first glimpse of it several decades ago in Bandipur. I had gone with a group of students and when we ventured into the forest, I heard a very unusual call. As I was scouting to locate its source with the binocular, I was delighted to find to find the Malabar Giant Squirrel in the upper reaches of a tree a few hundred feet away. Overjoyed to sight it, I passed the binoculars around so that others could see it. While they were engrossed watching it, I turned back and was shocked to find a lone tusker not too far away. I gently tapped them and whispered, ‚ÄúHey, there is a tusker here‚Äù, only to be meet with a response, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt joke Sir‚Äù. Their reaction soon turned into alarm when they turned around and saw the tusker. Overwhelmed with increasing fright, we all gave a loud shout and ran for our lives. Catching up with my breath after some time, when I looked back, I saw the tusker turning its back and making its way into the forest.
Oblivious to this drama, the Giant Squirrel was foraging amongst the branches of tree with sheer abandon at a distance.
(Incidentally 21st January, is a Squirrel Appreciation Day!)
Dr Raguram
05/02/24, 8:41‚ÄØpm
During those times it must have been a radical attitude. Absolute freedom of the absolute.... The angle from which the photograph is clicked is fantastic sir.
11/02/24, 8:50‚ÄØam
London is full of blue plaques. They dot the walls of buildings throughout London, marking the places where scientists, artists, politicians and activists who lived and worked there. When I was on a Commonwealth Fellowship, I made it a point to visit as many of them. One address I was keen to locate was No 1, Fitzroy Road where WB Yeats lived for a while. It was also the building where Sylvia Plath, a poet whom I admire deeply, spent her last days before ending her life on February 11th 1963.
Poets die young and not so often by suicide. Perhaps the act of writing poetry fascinates the wounded and in the process also opens up fresh wounds. Syvia Plath was no exception. In her thinly veiled autobiographical novel, ‚ÄòBell Jar‚Äô, she wrote, ‚ÄúDeath must be so beautiful. To lie in the soft brown earth, with the grasses waving above one's head, and listen to silence. To have no yesterday, and no to-morrow. To forget time, to forgive life, to be at peace‚Äù. Pensive by disposition, she kept ruminating about it, which found expression in these lines which she wrote ten days before ending her life:
‚ÄúThe blood jet is poetry,
There is no stopping it‚Äù.
There are a multitude of ways in which Sylvia Plath‚Äôs life and her final act has been analyzed and debated. Beyond these lenses of scrutiny her existential angst was enmeshed in a troubled past and a tumultuous relationship with her husband Ted Hughes. Perhaps the most insightful and poignant account about Syliva Plath‚Äôs suicide was by her friend A Alvarez in his book, ‚ÄòThe Savage God‚Äô, which we reviewed in NIMHANS in the late 70s. In the first page of the book, there is a quote by Cesare Pavese, regarded as one of Italy's most important twentieth-century poets, which says it all:"No one ever lacks a good reason for suicide."
Dr Raguram
12/02/24, 8:08‚ÄØam
In a series of groundbreaking studies conducted in the late 1930s, psychologist Kurt Lewin (who was born on this day), identified three core styles of leadership; Authoritarian (autocratic) leadership. Participative (democratic) leadership and Delegative (laissez-faire) leadership.
Over the past decade we are witnessing the rise of populist, authoritarian, strong-man politicians across the globe. Its seductive appeal necessitates a detailed sociological enquiry! However, a political leadership that rules on the basis of fear, threat, intimidation, and advocating one worldview as superior while silencing diversity of opinions and dissent is in my opinion will lead to fragmentation of society. Unfortunately an authoritarian world view is not confined to the political arena. It seeps into and influences people's attitudes, impacts institutional ethos in centres of learning and more importantly, festers lack of trust. The more we portray the ‚Äòothers‚Äô as threat, the greater the harm to the fabric that binds and holds us all together.
The harmful impact of authoritarian attitude in a leader is accentuated once it is tinged with narcissistic traits, resulting in an overwhelming need for control with an inflated sense of self-worth. They strongly adhere to the belief that they should be in charge and expect others to conform to their views and desires, often holding people with differing viewpoints in contempt. These leaders insist on strict conformity to their beliefs and tend to view the world in binary terms; you are either with them or against them. This black-and-white perspective creates a hostile environment where individuals are categorized as friends or foes based on their willingness to conform. Such a rigid stance stifles open dialogue and learning from others.
As George Orwell observed presciently in 1984, it leads to ‚Äúprocessions, meetings, military parades, lectures, waxwork displays, film shows, telescreen programs all had to be organized; stands had to be erected, effigies built, slogans coined, songs written, rumours circulated, photographs faked.‚Äù
13/02/24, 8:35‚ÄØam
Sarojini Naidu, born on 13th February 1879, was one of the most outstanding figures of the independence movement. An equally talented poet in English, she was known as ‚ÄúThe Nightingale of India‚Äù. Her poetry brims with strong emotions expressed in lyrical verses. An ardent admirer of nature, she was also a great lover of birds.
I am particularly drawn (given my passion for them!) to her poem ‚ÄòBird of Time‚Äô, wherein she expresses the workings of time through the movements of a bird. Just as we don‚Äôt expect a bird to be still, time too is fleeting. Life and death, sorrow and hope, time encompasses them all in this poem.
BIRD OF TIME
O Bird of Time on your fruitful bough
What are the songs you sing? ‚Ä¶
Songs of the glory and gladness of life,
Of poignant sorrow and passionate strife,
And the lilting joy of the spring;
Of hope that sows for the years unborn,
And faith that dreams of a tarrying morn,
The fragrant peace of the twilight‚Äôs breath,
And the mystic silence that men call death.
O Bird of Time, say where did you learn
The changing measures you sing? ‚Ä¶
In blowing forests and breaking tides,
In the happy laughter of new-made brides,
And the nests of the new-born spring;
In the dawn that thrills to a mother‚Äôs prayer,
And the night that shelters a heart‚Äôs despair,
In the sigh of pity, the sob of hate,
And the pride of a soul that has conquered fate.
In one of last letters she wrote, ‚Äù While I live, it will always be the supreme desire of my Soul to write poetry ‚Äîone poem, one line of enduring verse even. Perhaps I shall die without realising that longing which is at once an exquisite joy and an unspeakable anguish to me‚Äù.

18/02/24, 8:26‚ÄØam
Another book I had picked up those days at Easwari lending library was the novel ‚ÄòZorba the Greek‚Äô. Much like ‚ÄòThe Chosen‚Äô, it is the story of two men: Zorba, a Greek working man and a wealthy, young narrator and their incredible friendship. The two of them couldn‚Äôt be further apart. The narrator is cerebral, modest, and reserved; Zorba is unfettered and spirited.The younger man reads all day. He‚Äôs an aficionado of Buddhist philosophy, the exact opposite world view of Zorba who has such lust for life. These two characters represent two distinct ways of life. The implicit question throughout the book: which is better? Being a ‚Äústable‚Äù person and being accepted and respected in society, or being an indulgent person living his life full. Both are searching for answers. The Narrator has a desire to change, but he adamantly resists Zorba‚Äôs philosophy, despite admitting to admiring it and wishing he could assimilate it with his own. The relationship between these two characters symbolizes the conversation between the head and the heart, the mind and the spirit, what Nietzsche referred to as the Apollonian and the Dionysian impulses. Kazantzakis masterfully interweaves these dual perspectives of human nature. The book is also an important reminder to embrace the transience of life, to seize the moments that bring us joy, unfettered by intellectual curiosity. A passage in the book by the narrator illustrates this perspective:
‚ÄúI remember one morning when I discovered a cocoon in the back of a tree just as a butterfly was making a hole in its case and preparing to come out. I waited a while, but it was too long appearing and I was impatient. I bent over it and breathed on it to warm it. I warmed it as quickly as I could and the miracle began to happen before my eyes faster than life. The case opened; the butterfly started slowly crawling out, and I shall never forget my horror when I saw how its wings were folded back and crumpled; the wretched butterfly tried with its whole trembling body to unfold them. Bending over it, I tried to help it with my breath, in vain. It needed to be hatched out patiently and the unfolding of the wings should be a gradual process in the sun. Now it was too late. My breath had forced the butterfly to appear all crumpled, before its time. It struggled desperately and, a few seconds later, died in the palm of my hand. That little body is, I do believe, the greatest weight I have on my conscience. For, I realize today that it is a mortal sin to violate great laws of nature. We should not hurry, we should not be impatient, but we should confidently obey the external rhythm‚Äù.
A viewpoint summarized in the gravestone of the author, Nikos Kazantzakis,"I hope for nothing. I fear nothing. I am free."
(And who can forget Anthony Quinn bringing the most life-affirming character of Zorba alive in the movie version of the book with the Zorba the Greek song brimming with life?)
Dr Raguram

She will learn the lesson and wait patiently for the second who is Vainatheya very powerful and releases his mother from curse!!
24/02/24, 8:05‚ÄØam
Sometime ago I had posted about the intriguing interface between the private and the public self.
Jorge Luis Borges, whom I admire deeply, wrote the shortest of short stories, ‚ÄòBorges and I‚Äô. It is a fascinating read, raising an interesting question, ‚ÄúIs Borges the man or Borges the writer‚Äù? When a writer articulates his experiences and expresses them on paper,does he assume a different persona? In an essay which he wrote in 1919, TS Eliot wondered whether, ‚Äúthe more perfect the artist, the more completely separate in him will be the man who suffers and the mind which creates‚Äù. Borges is a lover of paradox and doesn‚Äôt attempt to ‚Äòresolve‚Äô this question. His story ends tantalizingly with these words, ‚ÄúI do not know which of us has written this page‚Äù.
BORGES and I
The other one, the one called Borges], is the one things happen to. I walk through the streets of Buenos Aires and stop for a moment, perhaps mechanically now, to look at the arch of an entrance hall and the grillwork on the gate; I know of Borges from the mail and see his name on a list of professors or in a biographical dictionary. I like hourglasses, maps, eighteenth-century typography, the taste of coffee and the prose of Stevenson; he shares these preferences, but in a vain way that turns them into the attributes of an actor. It would be an exaggeration to say that ours is a hostile relationship; I live, let myself go on living, so that Borges may contrive his literature, and this literature justifies me. It is no effort for me to confess that he has achieved some valid pages, but those pages cannot save me], perhaps because what is good belongs to no one, not even to him, but rather to the language and to tradition. Besides, I am destined to perish,definitely and only some instant of myself can survive in him. Little by little, I am giving over everything to him, though I am quite aware of his perverse custom of falsifying and magnifying things].
Spinoza knew that all things long to persist in their being; the stone eternally wants to be a stone and the tiger a tiger. I shall remain in Borges, not in myself (if it is true that I am someone), but I recognize myself less in his books than in many others or in the laborious strumming of a guitar. Years ago I tried to free myself from him and went from the mythologies of the suburbs to the games with time and infinity, but those games belong to Borges now and I shall have to imagine other things. Thus my life is a flight and I lose everything and everything belongs to oblivion, or to him.
I do not know which of us has written this page.
(From Labyrinths: ‚ÄòSelected Stories and Other Writings‚Äô)
This final sentence of the story entices the reader to venture into the labyrinth of labyrinths to explore who is ‚Äòreally‚Äô fictional in this mirror world!!
Dr Raguram

26/02/24, 1:30‚ÄØpm
