27/02/24, 8:07‚ÄØam
A good poem opens up a new world and takes you on a memorable journey. Henry Wadswoth Longfellow‚Äôs, ‚ÄòNature‚Äô is one such.
The simple, unpretentious opening lines of the poem portray a familiar scene that happens in most of our homes; a mother trying to put her child to sleep. The child‚Äôs ‚Äòbroken playthings‚Äô are scattered on the floor, and he is ‚Äúhalf willing" to abandon the play and retire for the night. He lingers, staring longingly at the toys he has left behind.
The next few lines venture into a new territory all together. The poet compares the mother whom he just described eloquently, to mother nature. Both are essentially caretakers of all of us. Nature is to man, what a mother is to her child. As we advance in years, nature gradually takes away all our earthly possessions and gently guides us to the world beyond. Since often we are greatly attached to our earthly life and our belongings, we are never too willing to proceed towards that goal. But nature leads us just like the mother leading the child to sleep,taking away our "playthings" one at a time. The poet suggests that our earthly desires and attachments are like playthings that we must eventually relinquish to discover the unknown mysteries of life..
Why did this poem appeal to me? I was drawn (and still continue to be!) by the simple imagery of a mother putting a reluctant child to sleep, which slowly blends itself into a very powerful metaphor of a nurturing nature that prepares us for our journey beyond this world. There is much wisdom in these lines;
NATURE
As a fond mother, when the day is o'er,
Leads by the hand her little child to bed,
Half willing, half reluctant to be led,
And leave his broken playthings on the floor,
Still gazing at them through the open door,
Nor wholly reassured and comforted
By promises of others in their stead,
Which, though more splendid, may not please him more;
So Nature deals with us, and takes away
Our playthings one by one, and by the hand
Leads us to rest so gently, that we go
Scarce knowing if we wish to go or stay,
Being too full of sleep to understand
How far the unknown transcends the what we know.
(Henry Wadswoth Longfellow born on this day on 1807)
Dr Raguram
01/03/24, 9:04‚ÄØam
Rhythmic highs and lows of life can spark the creative urge within ourselves. But when the intensity of the swings are severe, it causes immense suffering to those in the midst of it. Rober Lowell, whose birthday is today, suffered from a severe form of bipolar illness which started early in his life. Mental illness ran deep in his family and his life was laden with instability; for thirty years he was in and out of mental hospitals. The manic episodes were extremely disruptive with florid psychotic symptoms, requiring hospitalization, which were invariably followed by periods of depression.
Fire is a central image in Lowell‚Äôs works. His manic episodes were akin to a blaze of fire which took some effect to be quelled. He wrote, ‚ÄúBy the time I reached the hospital I was completely out of my head‚Äîstrange physical sensations‚ÄîI was a prophet and everything was a symbol; then in the hospital: shouting, singing, tearing things up‚Äîreligion and antics. Then depression (extreme) aching, self-enclosed, fearful of everyone and everything anyone could do, feeling I was nothing and could do nothing‚Äù He termed his manic phase as the ‚Äúholocaust of irrationality‚Äù and depression as the ‚Äúlong, burdensome dull period‚Äù with months of ‚Äúwading in the muck and weeds and backwash of a depression. Depression is an illness for oneself, mania an illness for one‚Äôs friends‚Äù.
Above all, he was a poet and during one of his admissions, he wrote:
The resident doctor said,
‚ÄúWe are not deep in ideas, imagination, or enthusiasm‚Äî
how can we help you?‚Äù
I asked,
‚ÄúThese days of only poems and depression‚Äî
what can I do with them?
Will they help me notice
what I cannot bear to look at?‚Äù
Lowell wrote brilliantly about the embers of his illness in an autobiographical piece, ‚ÄúNear the Unbalanced Aquarium‚Äù, which is included in his book ‚ÄòMemoirs‚Äô. The effect of the medication was ‚Äúlike the slowing and ache of a medium fever. One‚Äôs thoughts are not directly changed and healed, but the terrible, over-riding restlessness of one‚Äôs system is halted so that the mind can see life as it is‚Äù. He was given Lithium much later in his life, once it was available for use. Among all the medications and ECTs that were given to him, Lowell found that Lithium was the most effective one. Reflecting about it, hw wondered to his friend, ‚ÄúIt's terrible, Bob, to think that all I‚Äôve suffered, and all the suffering I‚Äôve caused, might have arisen from the lack of a little salt in my brain‚Äù
What is remarkable is that Lowell continued writing despite the immense suffering due to his mood disorder which wreaked on his life. His courage and determination enabled him to channel the creative fire within, which unfortunately consumed him.
(There have been many biographies of Robert Lowell, my personal favourite is the exceptional,l ‚ÄòSetting the River on Fire‚Äô, by Kay Redfeld Jamison)
Dr Raguram
01/03/24, 10:30‚ÄØpm
Yes Sir... The wings of the bee and flower that you have caught forces us to be in the present moment and appreciate.
03/03/24, 8:02‚ÄØam
Humans and wildlife have interacted closely for millions of years, especially during the prehistoric era. The habitat of the prehistoric people were caves. Dwelling there, they embellished the caves with paintings imbued with natural colours. A common theme in their paintings was wildlife, which was not surprising since they lived in close proximity with them. Wildlife was an integral part of their daily lives.
I had the first glimpse of the richness of the prehistoric cave paintings ranging from the Upper Paleolithic period (around 30,000 years ago) to the mediaeval period, in Bhimbetka. It is one of the most densely painted rock shelters in India. As I walked into its vast terrain, one particular rock shelter caught my attention, which is often referred to as the Zoo Rock. A vast array of various wild animals, painted in profile, covered its rock face. Deers, elephants, leopards, wild buffaloes, bears and boars were galloping on its aged backdrop. The primary colour was white, which dates back to the Mesolithic period, while a few from later periods were mostly in red. Though the colours had faded with time, the entire scene was brimming with energy, showcasing the close relationship between these ancient painters and the wildlife around them.
Unfortunately this relationship has frayed over time. The global loss of wildlife is significantly alrarming. According to a 2022 World Wildlife Fund report, global wildlife populations have declined by 69% since 1970.
I am reminded of the story, ‚ÄòThe Epic of Gilgamesh‚Äô, which narrates the great city builder Gilgamesh‚Äôs friendship with a ‚Äúwild man,‚Äù Enkidu. Enkidu leads a contented life without human contact, ‚Äúcoated in hair like the god of the animals,‚Äù grazing at the water hole with a herd of gazelles, ‚Äúhis heart delighting with the beasts in the water.‚Äù Gilgamesh forcibly humanizes Enkidu by sending Shamhat, a priestess, to seduce him. After many days of lovemaking, Enkidu is spurned by the wild animals. He gets a haircut, eats bread, drinks ale and returns with Shamhat to the city.
As modern city dwellers, we are much like the alienated Enkidu, estranged from the rich wildlife around us, making occasional forays to have a glimpse of them amidst the declining forest covers. On the occasion of World Wildlife day and on the background of increasing man-animal conflicts, can we cultivate a more mindful interaction with wild animals at a both personal and public level and commit ourselves towards sustained conservation and peaceful coexistence?
(And of course, you can see them all at ‚ÄòVantara‚Äô‚Ä¶relocated and displaced from their natural habitat. Is that the future of wildlife in India?!)
Dr Raguram
04/03/24, 8:37‚ÄØam
I went for the interview in JIPMER, preparing myself for all kinds of questions that could be asked in the ‚Äòsubjects‚Äô. When I stepped in with much trepidation into the room, I was overwhelmed by the presence of half a dozen serious looking gentlemen. An imposing man seated in the centre looked at me and asked, ‚ÄúYoung man, why do you want to study medicine?‚Äù Without hesitation, I blurted ‚Äúbecause I love literature‚Äù. The response was on the spur of the moment, totally unrehearsed. My answer must have surprised him and he asked me to mention physicians who were also writers. I spoke for a few minutes about Anton Chekov, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and William Carlos William, amongst others. It was much later that I discovered that the gentleman who asked me the question was the venerable writer GK Gokak who later became President of the Sahithya Academy.
There is always an interesting tryst between the professional call and the personal passion and sometimes they converge. A long list of physician-writers down the ages right from the mediaeval physician, Maimonides, down to Abraham Verghese in recent times, will bear testimony to this.
William Carlos Williams was a pediatrician and general practitioner. He "worked harder at being a writer than he did at being a physician," His enormous output ranges across short stories, poems, plays, novels, critical essays and an autobiography. In his ‚ÄòDoctor Stories‚Äô, he gave a glimpse of work; hysterical mothers, obstinate children and poor families with nine kids unable to spare a few dollars for his services. There is an unflinching, straightforward tone in his stories. All the while, he was diligently mining his material for his true call, poetry.
His poems are simple, spare, with striking imagery. For instance, his lengthy poem, ‚ÄòBirds and Flowers‚Äô ends with these beautiful words;
‚ÄúThough the eye
turns inward, the mind
has spread its embrace ‚Äî in
a wind that
roughs the stiff petals ‚Äî
More! the particular flower is
blossoming . . ‚Äú.
Dr Raguram
05/03/24, 8:06‚ÄØam
London has the world‚Äôs first underground railway system and it is always busy with hordes of busy commuters. It is also the most efficient way to travel in the city, provided there are no strikes or unplanned closures.
For me, one of the pleasures of travelling by the tube was to read the poems that used to adorn the stations. Simply called, ‚ÄòPoems from the underground‚Äô, it was a veritable collection of verses from across the world. It was also a wonderful introduction to poets whom I neve heard of before. One such poet was Anise Koltz, often referred to as ‚Äúthe great lady of Luxembourg literature.‚Äù These particular lines of her, which I had made a note of, were particularly striking.
THE BIRDS WILL STILL SING
‚ÄúBreak my branches
saw me into bits
the birds will still sing
in my roots‚Äù
Birds inhabit the same world we do, and yet, they seem capable of transcending it. Though many of them lead lives on the brink of ruin, they still sing. These sparse, powerful, words in the poem convey that even in the midst of destruction unleashed by humans, spirited voices will emerge, rooted in resilience.
This is the anthem for Gaza too‚Ä¶

30/03/24, 7:12‚ÄØam
Bipolar disorder is a difficult illness. Journeying across its varied emotional landscape can be a daunting task as one is caught up in eddies of unpredictable swings of mood that can vary across a spectrum. It starts pervading one's whole being and often a person becomes an amalgamation of wounds in various stages of healing.
Textbooks offer impassioned descriptions of the illness with signs and symptoms to detect and categorize. The lived experience of the illness lurks beyond the pages of academic tomes. It is a welcome augury that many have authored insightful books about their experiences of living through the illness. Sometimes poetry captures these embodied experiences with remarkable poignancy. The constant battle between extreme highs and lows is often depicted through vivid imagery in poems, conveying the intense emotions that come with the disorder and the overwhelming feeling of being out of control. Once, a patient of mine with bipolar illness brought a piece of paper in which she had penned a few lines about it.
IN MY LIFE
In my life
I ride
On the rainbow
Sometimes.
Colours
Flow through
My veins.
Surging eddies
Of energy
Soon fade away.
Colours lurk behind
Dark clouds.
All that is left
Is inky blackness.
It draws me
In a vicious swamp
Till my breath
Becomes a mist
And I lose myself
Trying to find
My way
Amidst the dark clouds
In search
Of a ray of light..
As we usher in another World Bipolar Day, it is imperative to lend an ear and listen deeply to the lived experiences of people afflicted by it.
Dr Raguram
03/04/24, 4:52‚ÄØpm
So very True Sir. I have heard patients saying this just after one session. A step toward healing themselves!!!
06/04/24, 7:45‚ÄØam
Once when I was birding in the Bhoramdeo Wildlife Sanctuary, I noticed this bird landing on a delicate, frail branch of a tree. The branch was swaying in the early morning breeze. Suddenly there was a gust of wind and I wondered whether the brittle branch would break. At that moment, the bird took off, finding strength in its wings.
As I watched, I kept wondering whether it was akin to a phase in the journey of recovery of patients with psychiatric illnesses. Recovery from ‚Äòmajor‚Äô psychiatric illnesses can be a challenging plight. Often, it is a daunting task as the patient travels along the uneven, unsettling social landscape,negotiating demands, expectations and most importantly social stigma. It is almost a Sisyphean task.
My MD thesis was on First Rank Symptoms of Schneider and since I worked in the same unit for over three decades, I was in a position to follow up many of the patients and be a participatory witness in their journey. Contrary to the often touted ‚Äòfavourable‚Äô recovery of schizophrenia in ‚Äòdeveloping‚Äô countries like India, I have rarely seen a complete recovery in most of them. It is not the ‚Äòpsychotic‚Äô symptoms that impair their recovery, but a host of emotional turmoils that are embedded in unsettling ‚Äòreal‚Äô social contexts. Since the illness starts during the early adult period in their lives, which disrupts their academic and vocational pursuits, finding employment can be a difficult issue. It is also an unenviable task to manage their sexual strivings, which largely remains unaddressed by professionals. They can negotiate these demands to some extent, if there are safe, nurturing, supportive, immediate relationships. In the midst of it all, as their therapist, I strive to kindle and sustain hope in them to unravel their innate strength to cope with these formidable situations. In the words of Victor Hugo,
Be like the bird
Who, pausing in her flight
Awhile on boughs too slight
Feels them give way
Beneath her and yet sings,
Knowing that she hath wings.
Dr Raguram
07/04/24, 10:04‚ÄØam
What to say about the photograph Sir. I don't have a large repertoire of words to praise. Any deviance from normalcy is suffering for the patients as well as for the family. There is absolutely no tolerance. I think you remember Keshav Bharadwaj. He completed his Ph. D. And working for Infosys. Reinforcing their strengths matters so much in their difficult journey.
08/04/24, 7:55‚ÄØam
Yet another solar eclipse‚Ä¶this time a total one is visible along a narrow track stretching from Texas to Maine in the USA and crowds of people are flocking to watch this celestial event. Unfortunately I will miss it this time. The first time I had a glimpse of it was in 1980. Few of us from NIMHANS who were keen not to miss the event, hopped onto a bus and travelled to Karwar as it was touted to afford the best view. We positioned ourselves on a small hillock overlooking the sea. There was lots of activity on the beach below with children and adults enjoying a stroll in the evening. The sea gulls were squawking noisily and merrily. A few had brought special glasses to view it. I was merely watching the light passing through tree leaves. To my fascination, the eclipse was projected onto the ground as the light passed through gaps in the leaves and I was able to track the progress of the eclipse. As the eclipse advanced, the activity on the beach faded away and the gulls were suddenly quiet. Without a prelude, the sun disappeared totally, a black disc covering it like a lens cap. There was an eerie silence and the entire landscape was bathed in surreal colours. Slowly light peeped through like a thin golden ring around the sun. Though it lasted for just a few minutes, it was an enthralling experience during which I felt an intense sense of connectivity to another realm, a vast uncharted universe. In that brief moment when the all life- giving sun disappeared behind a black veil and re-emerged, it was a reminder that all things have an end and a new beginning. Navigating through life's valleys, we may experience a phase of darkness, till the ray of light illuminates and rejuvenates us. Embracing the inevitable cycle of darkness and light provides us an opportunity to reflect and expand our awareness towards a more meaningful existence.
Amidst one of the most tumultuous periods in his life, Mahatma Gandhi wrote, "In the midst of darkness, light persists.‚Äù
(photo from the net!)
Dr Raguram
09/04/24, 10:12‚ÄØpm
Very nice Sir.

12/04/24, 8:36‚ÄØam
Waterfowl employ a variety of "feeding modes" to satisfy their daily energy needs. It is interesting to see the mallards feeding in shallow waters. They prefer water that is less than three feet deep, and which has plenty of aquatic vegetation to feed on. They forage by dabbling, dipping their heads and necks underwater to grab shallow plants, while their tails and feathers stay above the water. Mallards are considered the generalists of the waterfowl world and they forage on a wide variety of food, seeds, waste grain, vegetation, and just about anything they can swallow. This is helped to a large extent by its broad and relatively unspecialized bill. They are incredible survivors, and can adapt to a wide range of habitats.
In Ogden Nash‚Äôs words:
Behold the duck.
It does not cluck.
A cluck it lacks.
It quacks.
It is specially fond
Of a puddle or pond.
When it dines or sups,
It bottoms ups.
Dr Raguram
15/04/24, 7:02‚ÄØam
I was in the eighth standard when I first heard about Guru Nanak. Our school had a moral education session on the last Saturday of every month.Students were called upon to speak on various religious/spiritual traditions which was followed up by a talk by a leading figure from that background. I was given the opportunity twice: the first time to speak on the ‚ÄòSermon on the mount‚Äô and the second time on ‚ÄòGuru Nanak‚Äô. I went to the school library to read about him and was attracted by the three pillars of Sikhism he outlined; Kirat Karni (honest living), Vand Chakna (sharing with others) and Naam Japna (focus on God). At that time I didn‚Äôt know much about God but honest living and the spirit of sharing and giving appealed to my young mind and left a lasting impact. Perhaps it also laid the foundation for my interest in serving the needy, in later part of my life.
I cannot claim to have read all his works and shabads but I am drawn to his message of 'Ik Onkar': "Ik Onkar, Satnam, Karta Purakh, Nirbhau, Nirvair, Akal Murat, Ajuni Sae Bham, Guru Prasad." There's only one God, his name is the only truth, he is the only creator, he is fearless, he is without hate, he is immortal, he is beyond birth and death, and only by his grace one can chant his name.
‚Äú·∏éasƒó ·∏ùisƒù ravi¬≠ƒù parab·∫ñ ƒók. ·∏é·∫ñaran akƒùs sab·∫ñ meh parab·∫ñ pƒók·∫ñ. Jal thal ban parba·πØ pƒù·πØƒùl.‚Äù ‚ÄúHe can be found in all the ten directions, on land, in water, in the forests and mountains‚Äù
Guru Nanak died when he was seventy. In accordance with the Sikh tradition, on the day of his death, as he was sinking the community gathered around Nanak. Those of Hindu background insisted they should cremate his body, while Muslims wanted to bury him as a great saint. Nanak said, ‚ÄúPlace flowers on both sides of my body‚Äîflowers from the Hindus on the right side and flowers from the Muslims on the left. If tomorrow the flowers of the Hindus are still fresh let my body be burned, and if the flowers of the Muslims are still fresh, let it be buried.‚Äù He requested that those present to place a sheet over his head and body, and instructed everyone to leave him.The Sikh, Hindu and Muslim devotees returned the following morning on September 22, 1539 A.D. They carefully lifted and removed the sheet and they were astonished to discover that there was no trace of Guru Nanak Dev Ji's mortal body. Only fresh flowers remained and not a single bud had wilted of any of the blossoms which had been left by either Sikhs Hindus or Muslims, the night before.
‡®∏‡®≠ ‡®Æ‡®π‡®ø ‡®∞‡®µ‡®ø ‡®∞‡®π‡®ø‡®Ü ‡®™‡©ç‡®∞‡®≠‡©Å ‡®è‡®ï‡©à ‡®™‡©á‡®ñ‡®ø ‡®™‡©á‡®ñ‡®ø ‡®®‡®æ‡®®‡®ï ‡®¨‡®ø‡®ó‡®∏‡®æ‡®à
The One God is pervading in all. Gazing upon Him, beholding Him, Nanak blossoms forth in happiness
(Guru Nanak Jayanti 15th April)

19/04/24, 7:52‚ÄØam
Lord Byron, whose death anniversary is today, passionately espoused the cause of Greek independence. In his epic work Don Juan, which included the poem The Isles of Greece, he pleaded with the Greeks to remember their heritage and unite to fight for their freedom.
‚ÄúTrust not for freedom to the Frank
They have a king who buys and sells;
In native swords and native ranks
The only hope of courage dwells‚Äù
On December 29, 1823 Byron sailed to join Prince Al√©xandros Mavrokord√°tos, the leader of the rebel forces in western Greece, to join their struggle for freedom and also trained troops. He was staying in the town of Missolonghi where he died of fever on April 19, 1824. His last words were reportedly , ‚ÄúCome, come, no weakness. Let‚Äôs be a man to the last. Shall I sue for mercy? I must sleep now‚Äù. The body was shipped to England and was buried on 16th July 1824, at Hucknall Torkard.
When I re-read his poem, ‚ÄòDarkness‚Äô today, I wondered whether he was prescient in holding up the mirror for us to the ecological impact of climate change. In 1816 Europe, amongst other places in the world, experienced a drastic climate shift that produced famine, riots and mass death because of a large disease outbreak. All these were as a result of the eruption of Mt. Tambora in Indonesia. As a result, 1816 was called ‚ÄòThe Year without Summer‚Äô, as temperatures dropped so much that there were some local recording drops of 3-5 degrees Fahrenheit on average, as was the case in New England. Byron wrote the poem ‚ÄòDarkness‚Äô, in the aftermath of this catastrophic changes of weather and the long poem ends with these apocalyptic lines:
It is a long poem and ends with these words:
They slept on the abyss without a surge‚Äî
The waves were dead; the tides were in their grave,
The moon, their mistress, had expir'd before;
The winds were wither'd in the stagnant air,
And the clouds perish'd; Darkness had no need
Of aid from them‚ÄîShe was the Universe.
Dr Raguram
23/04/24, 7:43‚ÄØam
On this World Book Day, let me pen a few words about a book that I read yesterday; ‚ÄòThe Rumi Prescription: How an Ancient Mystic Poet Changed My Modern Manic Life‚Äô by Melody Moezzi. Diagnosed to have Bipolar Disorder, she experienced severe bouts of depression, mania and had to be hospitalized on occasions. Medications helped her to balance her moods, but merely keeping the disorder in check did not satisfy her. She decided to channel her energy into writing and published her experiences of the illness in a powerful book, ‚ÄòHaldol and Hyacinths‚Äô. Much like the hyacinth flower, which rarely grows perfectly straight, Moezzi urged the need to embrace the disorder and rely on the support from loved ones to keep afloat. The book was very well received. After many interviews in the media and countless promotional events, she felt utterly drained, not just physically and emotionally, but spiritually. In her words, ‚ÄúConsumed by an insatiable longing for more and bigger and better successes down the line, I lost track of the
present and grew so addicted to affirmation that I had no energy left for creation‚Äù.
It was at this stage that she rediscovered the timeless teachings of Rumi, with the help of her surgeon father. The book is organized in an innovative way with chapters titled as diagnosis and prescription, dealing with many of the tribulations the author underwent; wanting, isolation, haste, depression, distraction, anxiety, anger, fear, disappointment, and pride. These are all inherent aspects of each of our lives and the author deftly uses Rumi‚Äôs poems as ‚Äòprescriptions‚Äô that we can imbibe. Let me outline some of these prescriptions:
On Haste and the need to Slow Down:
‚ÄúYou went out in search of gold far and wide
But all along you were gold on the inside‚Äù
On Depression:
‚ÄúWhere there are roses, thorns abound.
In the grand bazaar of life, joy without sorrow cannot be found‚Äù
On Anxiety:
‚ÄúForget your plans and embrace uncertainty.
Only then will you find stability‚Äù
On Disappointment
‚ÄúBread on your head and knee-deep in a river,
How are you so starved and withered?
You already own all the sustenance you seek.
If only you‚Äôd wake up and take a peek‚Äù
These verses of Rumi must be read in the context of the personal narratives of the author in the book. I strongly recommend it!
Let me end with this verse of Rumi:
‚ÄúOn the road to enlightenment, wise and mad are one.
In the way of Love, self and other are one.
For those who drink of the wine that connects souls,
In their religion, the Kaaba and the house of idols are one‚Äù
Dr Raguram
30/04/24, 7:11‚ÄØam
Every time I spot a blackbuck I am amazed by its graceful elegance as it saunters across the grassland. They figure prominently in Hindu mythology. In Sanskrit texts, blackbucks are called ‚ÄúKrushna Mrug‚Äù (black deer). They are also considered the vehicles of Vayu (the wind god) and Chandra (the moon god).
Sangam poetry has vivid, wonderful descriptions of nature and animals. I was wondering whether there is a reference to the blackbuck. Finally I located one in verse 317 in Kurunthogai, which was penned by Madurai Kandarathnanar, In it, a close friend of a lady, consoles her that the man whom she loves deeply will return soon from his travels.
‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æü ‡ÆÆ‡Æ∞‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡Æ∞‡Øà ‡Æ®‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æè‡Æ±‡ØÅ
‡Æ§‡ØÄ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Æø ‡Æ®‡ØÜ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø, ‡ÆÖ‡ÆØ‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡Æ§‡Øá‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï ‡Æµ‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æâ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ,
‡Æì‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øà‡Æû‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Øà ‡Æ™‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æü‡Æ©‡Øç
‡Æ®‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡ÆÆ‡Øà ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡ÆÆ‡Øà‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øã ‡ÆÆ‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Øá-‡Æï‡Øà‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡ÆÆ‡Æø‡Æï
‡Æµ‡Æü ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ≤ ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æü‡Øà‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æ¥‡Øày
‡Æ§‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ≤‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æü‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æ£‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ©‡Æø ‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æ≥‡Øá?
The context is that the man and the lady were deeply in love when the he parted away to gather wealth for their wedding. The lady languishes and loses her health in his absence. Observing her friend‚Äôs anxiety, the confidante says to her, ‚ÄúThe fine, dark male with white patches, mate of the alluring and innocent female black buck, eats the sweet and sour gooseberry, and then, making the nearby honey-dripping huge flowers shiver with its hot breath, it drinks from the fresh springs in the soaring mountains of the lord. How can he stay away from you, in those moist and cold days, when the excessively strong northern winds scatter the rain clouds, making them move south?‚Äù. With these words, the confidante assures the lady that the man would return before the commencement of the rainy season.
What a wonderful expression to soothe and calm an anxious, aspiring, loving, heart!
‚ÄùThe blackbuck stops
Our eyes meet
Tranquil stillness‚Äù
(In my amateurish verse!)

02/05/24, 8:23‚ÄØam
Sometimes by sheer chance, one discovers an interesting book. This time it was ‚ÄòIn The Shade Of The Spring Leaves‚Äô,a biography of a Japanese author, Ichiyo Higuchi, containing nine stories and extracts from her diary. It was a revelation.
After finishing the book, I discovered that Ichigo Higuchi was a very important writer of the Meiji period and Japan‚Äôs first modern female writer. She was born in 1872 and died in 1896 at the tender age of 24. Born into a peasant family, her mother was not keen for her to be educated. Finally at the age of 14 she was allowed to attend poetry school as a concession. That marked the beginning of an illustrious literary career. Higuchi picked the pen name ‚ÄúIchiy≈ç‚Äù, meaning ‚Äúone leaf,‚Äù which has a deeper references to a specific form of Zen meditation. In her short life, wrote four thousand classical poems, many short stories, and kept a detailed, 60-volume diary. In one of the entries in the diary, quoted in the book, she writes;
‚ÄúThe rain stopped, green and fresh new leaves rise above the eaves. Pointless it is to wait for someone in my quiet house. I hear the voice of the vendor. And delve into reading a collection of Tang poems.‚Äù
Her stories are replete with lyrical passages like this one from‚ÄòSnowy Day‚Äô, ‚Äú Silver sprinkles the earth. Softly, snowflakes fall like dancing butterflies; wings flutter, but there is no sound. Six-petalled crystals come to rest on withered trees, spring‚Äôs first flowering‚Äù.
Ichiyo Higuchi took me on a compelling journey and I travelled on the wings of her writings to discover an entirely new creative landscape.
Dr Raguram
06/05/24, 8:43‚ÄØam
Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote a memorable poem, ‚ÄòHamatreya‚Äô in 1847. It is based on a passage of the Vishnu Purana. The title of the poem is a shortened form of ‚ÄúHail Maitraya‚Äù. Here, the poet records what the sage named Parashara taught his disciple Maitreya in response to the disciple‚Äôs query regarding the real worth of earthly possessions. Emerson guides us to be aware of the futility of our boasting and pride and points towards an awareness of earth‚Äôs living relationship to each one of us. According to him, earth laughs at the boastful attitude of people who feel that they possess her. None can possess her and ultimately all of us are possessed by her.
The flower in the image I‚Äôve posted today is called by various names; Shiv Kamal, Kailaspati and Nagalingam. Imbued with cultural and religious significance, it has petals resembling the hood of a Naga or serpent around its stamen which is considered as Shiva Linga. The tree, often referred to as cannonball tree has important medicinal properties.
In my growing years there was a huge nagalinga tree in front of our house. Every morning, hundreds of flowers would be strewn all over the ground and there would be a contest amongst the children as to who could pick up the most. We spent many hours playing cricket under its vast canopy and when the ball went near its trunk, we would retrieve it with some trepidation as we were told that snakes might be lurking around the tree.
One fine day, the owners of the property decided to cut it down to build new housing. All of us watched with dismay as the magnificent tree fell on the ground. We lost our much loved companion as also the birds and the squirrels, who lost a sturdy, reliable place to nest and rest. In the ensuing years the owners too had to undergo various shades of tribulations.
For me personally it was a kind of grief and an unsettling reminder of our disconnect from the non-human world, which has only gotten worse over the years.
Perhaps it‚Äôs time to read and reconnect with these timeless lines of ‚ÄòHamatreya‚Äô.
‚ÄúWhere are these men? Asleep beneath their grounds:
And strangers, fond as they, their furrows plough.
Earth laughs in flowers, to see her boastful boy‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
07/05/24, 1:16‚ÄØpm
A wonderful photograph to depict spring season. And such a short lived spark, whose short poem conveys so much. Thank you Sir for the glimpse of a hidden treasure.
11/05/24, 7:18‚ÄØam
While birding in Seychelles last year, I noticed a fairly large sized bird hidden amongst the tree tops. From a distance, it looked like a dove. However, on close observation, it looked distinctive with a beautiful blend of browns, purplish-reds, and blueish-grays, with a brown eye with a red circle around it. At the end of the day, I checked my observations online and found out that it is referred to as Malagasy turtle dove.
There are only six doves that bear the name ‚ÄúTurtle Dove‚Äù. They belong to two groups, the Nesoenas and the Streptopelia. The Malagasy Turtle Dove (Nesoenas picturata) is the only one in the Nesoenas. Its closest relative is the Pink Pigeon and together they form a lineage apart from both the typical pigeons and the other turtle doves.
Madagascar turtle doves produce a liquid called "crop milk" in their upper digestive tract that they regurgitate and feed to their young. While it is called milk, it does not contain lactose and is a blend of water, protein, fat, minerals and amino acids. I was told by the locals that it is quite adept in stealing copras that are left in the open to dry!
Often in the processe of glimpsing something anew, nature unveils itself and enthralls you!
Dr Raguram
19/05/24, 6:48‚ÄØam
It is an enchanting experience to watch birds. A new window opens up to unravel alluring secrets from another world. In that absorbing moment I become one with them.
Let me recollect an interesting poem about birding from Ogden Nash whose death anniversary is today.
‚ÄúBird watchers top my honours list.
I aimed to be one, but I missed.
Since I'm both myopic and astigmatic,
My aim turned out to be erratic,
And I, bespectacled and binocular,
Exposed myself to comment jocular.
We don't need too much birdlore, do we,
To tell a flamingo from a towhee:
Yet I cannot, and never will,
Unless the silly birds stand still.
And there's no enlightenment in a tour
Of ornithological literature.
Is yon strange creature a common chickadee,
Or a migrant alouette from Picardy?
You can rush to consult your Nature guide
And inspect the gallery inside,
But a bird in the open never looks
Like its picture in the birdie books-
Or if it once did, it has changed its plumage,
And plunges you back into ignorant gloomage.
That is why I sit here growing old by inches,
Watching a clock instead of finches,
But I sometimes visualize in my gin
The Audubon that I audubin‚Äù.

15/06/24, 9:33‚ÄØam
The stories of Jorge Luis Borges can be read in a matter of minutes, yet the impact upon the reader is profound. Take for instance the story, ‚ÄòThe Book of Sand‚Äô: the three pages long story is a deeply engaging narrative about a mysterious book which appears to have an infinite number of pages. It was sold to him by a bookseller who bought it in India, from a low caste man. When the narrator opens the surprisingly heavy book, he finds the script to be unfamiliar, laid out in double columns, with page numbers. which do not run in any sequential order. It also contains clumsily drawn illustrations on some pages of the book. The narrator is unable to find either the first or last page of the book and as he browses through it, more and more pages appear. Overwhelmed by curiosity, he becomes obsessed with the book over time. He also notices that he can never find the same page twice in the book. He comes to view the book as ‚Äòmonstrous‚Äô, and wants to destroy it, but fears that if he tries to burn the book, it might result in an infinite fire whose flames would engulf the whole world. He feels that ‚Äúthe best place to hide a leaf is in a forest‚Äù and disposes of the book by taking it to the Argentine National Library and hiding it in one of the musty shelves in the library‚Äôs basement.
The beauty of the story is that every time I read it, a new perspective emerges. Is the writer alluding to the hold of curiosity in human imagination or is it a meditation on the nature of infinity? Perhaps it refers to our deepest strivings to probe, understand, and make sense of the vast, unfathomable essence that is woven into the grand cosmic tapestry.
The infinite has always been of interest to people, mathematicians, physicists and philosophers. But very few can decode and render it in magical words like Borges!
(Jorge Luis Borges August 24, 1899 - June 14, 1986)
Dr Raguram
17/06/24, 10:11‚ÄØam
Such a 'Wonderful' guidance to a son. It is not hoards of money and property but wise words. Fantastic Sir and this is the best message a father can give for the son to ponder and follow!!!
20/06/24, 11:05‚ÄØpm
Thank you for the information Sir. But reading habit is vanishing in youngsters thought I do come across some families which restrict the use of gadgets and instill the value of reading.
24/06/24, 11:49‚ÄØam
Ambrose Bierce who was born on this day in 1842 is largely known as the author of the interesting, ‚ÄòThe Devil‚Äôs Dictionary‚Äô. He also wrote several trenching stories about the harsh realities of war. Bierce was a Union soldier during the Civil War and he gave expression to his traumatic memories in his stories, in a collection titled, ‚ÄòCivil War Stories‚Äô.
‚ÄòThe Mocking Bird‚Äô, is particularly poignant short story from this collection. Private William Grayrock is posted on picket duty and on hearing the approach of someone he cannot see, he shoots blindly into the night and is certain he has hit a man in the darkness. He is lauded for protecting the regiment from intruders, but Grayrock is beset with guilt and goes in search and to his great dismay finds that he has shot his long last twin brother. Overcome with intense grief, he doesn‚Äôt return to the camp and wanders off.
The story juxtaposes the harsh realities of war with memories fond family relationships. As he goes in search of the person he had shot, Grayrock dreams about his childhood friendship with his brother and their attachment to their most precious possession, a mockingbird. ‚ÄúThrough all the golden days floated one unceasing sound-- the rich, thrilling melody of a mocking-bird in a cage by the cottage door. It pervaded and possessed all the spiritual intervals of the dream, like a musical benediction. The joyous bird was always in song; its infinitely various notes seemed to flow from its throat, effortless, in bubbles and rills at each heart-beat, like the waters of a pulsing spring‚Äù. As ‚Äúhe was passing a thicket of laurel, a bird rose from the midst of it and perching on the branch of a tree above, poured from its joyous breast so inexhaustible floods of song as but one of all God's creatures can utter in His praise. There was little in that--it was only to open the bill and breathe; yet the man stopped as if struck --stopped and let fall his rifle, looked upward at the bird, covered his eyes with his hands and wept like a child‚Äù. When he finally notices the dead body of his twin brother, ‚Äúthe shrilling bird upon the bough overhead stilled her song and, flushed with sunset's crimson glory, glided silently away through the solemn spaces of the wood‚Äù.
The mocking bird is a crucial metaphor in this haunting story. The bird is reportedly quite caring when it comes to protecting its family from predators and sadly witnesses an avoidable tragedy involving two brothers whose memories are entwined with it.
The story is also about the futility of war. The American Civil War created deep divisions between the North and South and also divided many families. Some family members fought for the Union, while others sided with the Confederacy. It ripped the country apart and in many of those deadly battles, brothers fought against their own brothers, at times killing each other.
As Fran√ßois de Salignac de la Mothe-F√©nelon, a French theologian, poet and writer, commented perceptively, ‚ÄúAll wars are civil wars because all men are brothers... Each one owes infinitely more to the human race than to the particular country in which he was born.‚Äù
Traumatic memories of war linger on for long in the psyche of the individual and often remains unresolved. Ambrose Bierce‚Äôs death remains an unsolved mystery. Did he commit suicide, or pneumonia took a toll on him or was he killed by Mexican federal forces? In his last known communication, he wrote, ‚ÄúAs to me, I leave here tomorrow for an unknown destination.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
02/07/24, 10:54‚ÄØpm
The depth of the poet's train of thoughts gets manifested while describing nature. We identify so much with our body and mind that we have ceased to be like the grain of sand.... The photograph and its link to the poem, very nice Sir.
04/07/24, 9:48‚ÄØam
Van Mahotsav is an annual ritual, diligently observed by the state between July 1st and 7th, every year. The occasion is heralded with planting of trees. Unfortunately most of the saplings remain largely unattended thereafter and wither till it is time for the next Van Mahotsav.
The sad fact beyond these ceremonial occasions is that the forest cover in India is dwindling at an alarming rate. . According to the India State of Forest Report (ISFR) 2021, India has lost 2.33 million hectares of tree cover since 2000, with the highest loss in 2017 at 189,000 hectares. In 2023, the country lost 144,000 hectares, the highest in the last six years. In addition, the quality of India's forests has also deteriorated, with 9,117 square kilometres of forest turning into barren lands and scrubs between 2019 and 2021. Fixing the forest cover by planting a new one is an endlessly impossible task, as the life of the forest takes its own time.
Forests are critical to reduce and sequester carbon dioxide, protect habitats for millions of species, and ensure the health and wellbeing of people. As we search for a route to a sustainable future, we need to halt deforestation. Keeping forests standing is the most cost-effective of celebrating Van Mahotsav
Gieve Patel, a poet and artist whom I admire immensely, describes the cruelty of man in killing/destroying the tree with a touch of irony in this poem;
ON KILLING A TREE
It takes much time to kill a tree,
Not a simple jab of the knife
Will do it. It has grown
Slowly consuming the earth,
Rising out of it, feeding
Upon its crust, absorbing
Years of sunlight, air, water,
And out of its leperous hide
Sprouting leaves.
So hack and chop
But this alone wont do it.
Not so much pain will do it.
The bleeding bark will heal
And from close to the ground
Will rise curled green twigs,
Miniature boughs
Which if unchecked will expand again
To former size.
No,
The root is to be pulled out -
Out of the anchoring earth;
It is to be roped, tied,
And pulled out - snapped out
Or pulled out entirely,
Out from the earth-cave,
And the strength of the tree exposed,
The source, white and wet,
The most sensitive, hidden
For years inside the earth.
Then the matter
Of scorching and choking
In sun and air,
Browning, hardening,
Twisting, withering,
And then it is done.

08/07/24, 9:04‚ÄØam
With advances in health care, dying is increasingly becoming lonely, mechanical and dehumanized. To assist and help people cope with a demanding end of life process, one has to listen to them. This is what Elisabeth Kubler-Ross did. Along with four of her students she conducted a series of interviews with the terminally ill which resulted in her path breaking book, ‚ÄòOn Death and Dying.‚Äô The book outlined five stages of grief, popularly referred to as DABDA: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, Acceptance.
Though her work brought death and dying out of the closet, Elisabeth Kubler-Ross‚Äôs legacy has been a mixed one. There has been critical re-examination of the stages she has outlined and whether these stages apply to everyone who is grieving, since her research focused only on those who were terminally ill. Empirical evidence for these stages was also scanty. The well conducted Yale Bereavement Study did not find support for K√ºbler-Ross‚Äôs five stage theory. The findings indicated that acceptance was the most commonly reported reaction from the start, and yearning was the most common negative feature for the first two years. The other variables, such as disbelief, depression and anger were typically absent or minimal. Moreover, her model described how people with terminal illness face their imminent death. But strangely, it was soon adapted as a way of thinking about grief in general. The process of death and dying is not purely enacted within the individual and is impacted by a host of social, religious and cultural factors which is noticeably absent in her work. Perhaps the abiding appeal of her work is in its simplicity.
Her later years were mired in scandals. She began to embrace spiritualism, claiming she had communicated with spirits of the dead with names like ‚ÄúMario,‚Äù ‚ÄúAnka,‚Äù ‚ÄúSalem,‚Äù and ‚ÄúWillie.‚Äù She started believing in reincarnation, and told listeners she had lived during the time of Jesus, when she had been named Isabel. She involved herself in a cult-like retreat with a psychic called Jay Barham. and conducted s√©ances which involved the widows/widowers ‚Äòengaging‚Äô with the departed. It was revealed that Barham molested female participants during s√©ances, while pretending to be an "afterlife entity". Her professional reputation began to decline and she also became largely confined to bed due to a series of strokes.
In the final stages of her life she observed, ‚ÄúI now know that the purpose of my life is more than these stages. I have been married, had kids, then grandkids, written books, and travelled. I have loved and lost, and I am so much more than five stages. And so are you.‚Äù
(Elisabeth Kubler Ross 8th July 1926 ‚Äì 24th August 2004)
Dr Raguram
09/07/24, 9:28‚ÄØam
I am besotted with gardens. When I walk through a garden I am enveloped in a symphony of colors, rustling leaves, bird and insect sounds wafting through the air. It is an immersive experience imbued with a sense of tranquillity. As Bacon commented, ‚Äúit is the purest of human pleasure.‚Äù Gardens are often seen as a refuge, a place to forget the "real" life that lies outside. But they are also quintessential healing spaces.
Oliver Sacks, the famed neurologist and author, whose birthday falls today, wrote a small, wonderful essay ‚ÄúWhy We Need Gardens,‚Äù in his book ‚ÄúEverything in Its Place: First Loves and Last Tales,‚Äù which was published posthumously. Since his place of work was just across the road from the New York Botanical Garden, he noticed how patients who were unable to function inside a hospital setting seemed to come alive in the garden. An elderly lady with Parkinson‚Äôs disease, often frozen, unable to initiate movement was more mobile in the garden and even climbed the rocks up and down many times, unattended. Patients with very advanced dementia who had difficulty in even tying their shoe laces, when put in front of a flower bed with some seedlings knew exactly what to do. He described such deep bonds people have with gardens as ‚Äúhortophilia.‚Äù In his words, ‚ÄúI cannot say exactly how nature exerts its calming and organizing effects on our brains, but I have seen in my patients the restorative and healing powers of nature and gardens, even for those who are deeply disabled neurologically. In many cases, gardens and nature are more powerful than any medication‚Äù. He went on to add, ‚ÄúIn forty years of medical practice, I have found only two types of non-pharmaceutical ‚Äòtherapy‚Äô to be vitally important for patients with chronic neurological diseases: music and gardens.‚Äù
Gardens saturate our awareness and the boundary between our self and the world fuses and we feel more alive and flourish in that moment. It leaves a lasting trace in the innards of our minds.
For Thich Nhat Hanh, garden was a metaphor for the mind. He wrote, ‚ÄúFirst, you have to take care of your own garden and master the art of gardening. In each one of us there are flowers and there is also garbage. The garbage is the anger, fear, discrimination, and jealousy within us. If you water the garbage, you will strengthen the negative seeds. If you water the flowers of compassion, understanding, and love, you will strengthen the positive seeds. What you grow is up to you.‚Äù

19/07/24, 10:34‚ÄØam
After completing PUC, I had quite a bit of time before venturing into a professional course and I spent most of this time cycling to Eswari Lending Library in Chennai. One day when I was browsing, I noticed AJ Cronin‚Äôs ‚ÄòThe Citadel‚Äô, in one of the shelves. I‚Äôve never heard of him before. I brought it back home and finished reading it in one setting.
‚ÄòCitadel‚Äô tells the story of Andrew Manson, a young, idealistic doctor, who moves to a small mining town. He soon finds that he is dealing with more than what he‚Äôd bargained for. There is a lot of poverty in the town, many miners suffering from lung diseases. He begins to notice how doctors often lack clinical competence and are part of the system which really doesn‚Äôt help the people the way it should. He carefully studies the lung afflictions of the miners and completes his thesis detailing it. The research gains him a post with the "Mines Fatigue Board" in London, but he resigns after six months to set up a private practice. Seduced by the thought of making easy money from wealthy clients, he drifts away from the principles he started with and is estranged from his wife. When he notices the death of a patient because of a surgeon's ineptitude, he abandons his practice and returns to his wife to begin his life afresh. Tragically she is run over by a bus and dies.
In this novel, Cronin draws attention to the moral dilemmas that beset the doctors and the conflicts between the demands of private medicine as a business and of medicine as a Platonic ideal. He deftly identifies many of the issues in clinical practice which needs to be tackled like adequate training of doctors to prepare them for the reality of practice in the community, better supervision of young doctors, importance of team based care and the crucial role of ethics in medicine. As Cronin commented, ‚ÄúI have written in ‚ÄòThe Citadel‚Äô all I feel about the medical profession, its injustices, its hide-bound unscientific stubbornness, its humbug‚Ä¶ The horrors and inequities detailed in the story I have personally witnessed. This is not an attack against individuals, but against a system.‚Äù
In choosing the title for the novel, I wonder whether Cronin is prescient in alluding that modern health care system has become an impenetrable citadel where doctors ensconce and fortify themselves in defensive practices, highlighting in the process, the importance of opening the doors of the fortress.
Reading, for me is like stepping into worlds that I am not aware of. As a youngster, ‚ÄòCitadel‚Äô opened my eyes to the varied landscapes of the practice of medicine and perhaps also played a role in my choice of the profession.
Stories can change lives‚Ä¶
(AJ Cronin Born On 19th July 1896)

26/07/24, 9:41‚ÄØam
There are two books of CG Jung which I treasure and value deeply. One is Volume 16 of his Collected Works which explores psychotherapy and the other one is the autobiographical ‚ÄòMemories, Dreams and Reflections.‚Äô The latter book offers fascinating glimpses about his evolution as a mental health professional.
Jung spent some time at the famous ‚ÄòBurgholzi‚Äô. He describes his experiences there with extraordinary candour: ‚ÄúPsychiatry teachers were not interested in what the patient had to say, but rather in how to make a diagnosis or how to describe symptoms and to compile statistics. From the clinical point of view which then prevailed, the human personality of the patient, his individuality, did not matter at all. Rather, the doctor was confronted with Patient X, with a long list of cut-and-dried diagnoses and a detailing of symptoms. Patients were labelled, rubber-stamped with a diagnosis, and, for the most part, that settled the matter. The psychology of the patient played no role whatsoever.‚Äù
There is also a vivid account of an extraordinary encounter with a patient. A young woman was admitted with the diagnosis of ‚Äòdementia praecox.‚Äô Jung felt that it was a case of depression but did not voice his opinion, fearing rebuke from seniors. He sat with the patient over many days, gently exploring the background to her distress and it revealed a dark story. Before her current marriage, she was keen to marry the son of a wealthy industrialist. Five years later, an old friend visited her and he said to her, "When you got married it was quite a shock to your Mr. X.‚Äù She started brooding about the loss of her love. She lived in a place where the water supply was not perfectly hygienic; there was pure spring water for drinking, and impure water from the river for bathing and washing. While she was bathing her young daughter, she saw the child sucking at the impure water but did not stop her as she was quite preoccupied. A short time later the girl came down with typhoid fever and died. She was tremendously distressed and was admitted in Burgholzi. Jung started speaking to her over the next few weeks and she was able to acknowledge and work through her distress and guilt. She got better and was discharged.
In Jung‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúIn many cases in psychiatry, the patient who comes to us has a story that is not told, and which as a rule no one knows of. To my mind, therapy only really begins after the investigation of that wholly personal story. It is the patient's secret, the rock against which he is shattered. If I know his secret story, I have a key to the treatment. The doctor's task is to find out how to gain that knowledge. In therapy the problem is always the whole person, never the symptom alone.‚Äù
This facet of Jung, not so well known, draws attention to importance of the transformative power of narration in psychotherapy. Stories that are told in therapy are the stories that cannot be told in everyday life. The role of the therapist is to offer a space to share such stories and facilitate emergence of alternate versions and make them feel confident to try them out in their lives.
Dr Raguram
26/07/24, 1:06‚ÄØpm

27/07/24, 9:24‚ÄØam
Mangroves are enchanting places. Our sojourn amidst the mangroves of the Zuari river remains deeply etched in memory. Zuari River is the largest river in Goa which divides the state into two parts; North Goa and South Goa. It‚Äôs a tidal river, which sustains this important ecosystem. We boarded the boat at the Courtalim ferry pier and as we slowly coursed along the wide swatches of mangroves, a wide array of birds kept us company. Numerous species of water birds were foraging the shallow marshy banks for food. One of the birds that caught our attention was the black capped kingfisher which was perched on a swaying branch. As we were leaving an Indian Mugger Crocodile cast a lazy glance at us from its muddy abode.
Mangrove forests are among the planet‚Äôs most complex ecosystems. The word "mangrove" comes from the Portuguese word mangue, which means "tree", and the English word "grove", which refers to trees and shrubs in sandy, muddy, or shallow areas. Mangroves are survivors flourishing in environmental conditions that would swiftly kill most other types of vegetation. Known as the dancing trees, mangroves are regularly battered by cyclonic winds, especially along the coasts of India, but their intertwined breathing root system anchors them firm on the soil. They play a crucial role in protecting coastal areas from tsunamis. Mangroves are critical ecosystems sustaining a wide array of biodiversity.
Let me end this post paying obeisance to a remarkable man who was instrumental in developing and conserving mangroves in Kerala. Pokkudan, who grew by the lap of the estuaries and the rich rivers of Ezhom recognized the importance of mangroves. With remarkable determination, he would set out on his country boat everyday along the waters to plant saplings of mangroves in the marshes. He not only planted acres of mangrove saplings but ensured their protection against tremendous odds, until they emerged as teeming mangrove forests. Over a span of two and a half decades, Pokkudan had planted over hundreds of thousands of mangrove saplings along the banks of the Pazhayangadi River in the Kannur district, which earned him the sobriquet as ‚ÄòKandal Pokkudan‚Äô (Kandal is mangrove in Malayalam). Pokkudan describes his efforts poetically in his autobiography, ‚ÄòKandalkadukalkidayil Ente Jeevitham‚Äô (My Life Among the Mangrove Forests) ‚ÄúI began by planting 300 mangrove plants to prevent the sea from eroding the coast and to shield the children walking to the school from the gusts of wind. And to soak in their beauty when they grew up.‚Äù He passed away in 2015 leaving behind a great legacy.
(26th July, International Day for the Conservation of the Mangrove Ecosystem).
Dr Raguram
01/08/24, 4:30‚ÄØpm
Very True Sir.
06/08/24, 8:11‚ÄØam
When we were in Bandipur some months ago, I noticed this little bird peeping out of its nest and I was reminded of a simple, beautiful poem by Alfred Tennyson whose birthday is today.
WHAT DOES THAT LITTLE BIRDIE SAY
‚ÄúWhat does little birdie say,
In her nest at peep of day?
‚ÄúLet me fly,‚Äù says little birdie‚Äî
‚ÄúMother, let me fly away.‚Äù
‚ÄúBirdie, rest a little longer,
Till the little wings are stronger.‚Äù
So she rests a little longer,
Then she flies away.
What does little baby say
In her bed at peep of day?
Baby says, like little birdie,
‚ÄúLet me rise and fly away.‚Äù
‚ÄúBaby, sleep a little longer,
Till the little limbs are stronger.
If she sleeps a little longer,
Baby, too, shall fly away.‚Äù
It is a touching poem about a bird's desire to leave the nest and experience the world. The mother, gently advises the young bird to stay and rest, as its wings are not yet strong enough to fly. The poem ends by hinting that eventually the little bird will soon fly away. All of us aspire for independence and exploration, but need the guidance and protection of our parents till we find the metier to be on our own.
All of us are born to fly. As the master strategist Napoleon Bonaparte is said to have commented, ‚ÄúUntil you spread your wings, you‚Äôll have no idea how far you can fly.‚Äù
(I scrupulously avoid nest photography and this was taken from a distance with utmost care that the bird doesn‚Äôt sense my presence!)
Dr Raguram
08/08/24, 10:15‚ÄØam
A movie that left a deep impression on me was ‚ÄòCharly‚Äô directed by Ralph Nelson. Based on the novel ‚ÄòFlowers for Algermon‚Äô by Daniel Keyes, It had a beautiful musical score by Pandit Ravi Shankar. It‚Äôs a timeless story that explores the experiences of Charlie Gordon, a 32-year-old man with a learning disability who undergoes surgery in an effort to make him ‚Äúsmarter‚Äù and more ‚Äúnormal.‚Äù Since the same procedure worked well on Algernon, a lab mouse, the scientists have high hopes for Charlie‚Äôs transformation. After the operation, Charlie‚Äôs intelligence begins to steadily increase and he is functionally a genius after a few months. As his intelligence grows, he finds it increasingly difficult to connect with others at an emotional level and realizes that he is losing touch with his own emotional needs and desires, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs worse; to not know what you are and be happy, or to become what you‚Äôve always wanted to be, and feel alone.‚Äù The researchers present Charlie and their findings at a scientific convention. Meanwhile Charly comes to know that Algernon has lost its enhanced intelligence and died, facts that the research team kept away from him. He starts wondering whether he will undergo a similar decline and reflects, ‚ÄúThe problem, dear professor, is that you wanted someone who could be made intelligent but still be kept in a cage and displayed when necessary to reap the honours you seek. The hitch is that I'm a person.‚Äù Soon Charly regresses to his previous level of intelligence, but finally feels himself at home, happier than before.
The story explores themes that are still relevant today, including intelligence, empathy, and the ethical implications of scientific advancement. More importantly, it seeks out the unflinchingly honest message that our humanity is not measured by how smart we are, but rather by our kindness, love and interaction with others.
In the era of Neurolink, the daunting question is ‚ÄúDoes intelligence alone makes us better people?‚Äù
Charly reminds us that, ‚ÄúIntelligence is one of the greatest human gifts. But all too often a search for knowledge drives out the search for love. This is something else I've discovered for myself very recently. I present it to you as a hypothesis: Intelligence without the ability to give and receive affection leads to mental and moral breakdown, to neurosis, and possibly even psychosis. And I say that the mind absorbed in and involved in itself as a self-centered end, to the exclusion of human relationships, can only lead to violence and pain.‚Äù
(Daniel Keyes: 9 August 1927 - 15 June 2014)

13/08/24, 8:56‚ÄØam
Otters are some of the most adorable aquatic animals. One can spend endless hours watching their energetic play as they wrestle, play and slide down the slippery rocks. ‚ÄòTarka the Otter‚Äô, by Henry Williamson is a lovely novel about them. When the novel was published, otters were declining in numbers and by the 1960s it seemed possible that they would become extinct in England. Their recovery was much assisted by an increase in public awareness, facilitated in part by the popular success of Williamson‚Äôs novel. He describes the hunting behaviour of the otters like a trained naturalist, ‚ÄúFilling her lungs with new air, she slipped into the water and swam to the other end of the islet, where a scour had been formed by the flood-rains of the last south-westerly wind. Here the grown family of the moorhen was paddling. When almost under them, the otter saw the legs and the images of legs joined to them, black in silhouette against the less dark surface. She seized one of the moorhens and drew it under, releasing it to bite it in her jaws, and carried it back to her cubs, swimming with her nose, whiskers, eyes and part of the dead fowl out of the water.‚Äù
Williamson was quite productive with over fifty novels and essays. A keen observer of the landscape around him, his forte was writing about nature in its myriad expressions, ‚ÄúWhen the bees‚Äô feet shake the bells of the heather, and the ruddy strings of the sap-stealing dodder are twined about the green spikes of the furze, it is summertime on the commons.‚Äù
Though there was a darker side in his life, Williamson is still considered by many as a pioneer in the genre of nature writing. Even a simple description of an icicle is imbued with lyricism, ‚ÄúMusic comes from an icicle as it melts, to live again as spring water.‚Äù
(Henry Williamson 1 December 1895 - 13 August 1977)

16/08/24, 10:27‚ÄØam
Varalakshmi Puja is celebrated mostly in South India. Goddess Varalakshmi represents prosperity and divine grace. The name 'Varalakshmi' itself signifies her nature; 'Vara' meaning boon or blessing, and 'Lakshmi' referring to the goddess of wealth. This form of the goddess is particularly revered for her role in granting wishes and bringing prosperity. It is believed that worshipping the Goddess Varalakshmi on this day is equivalent to worshipping Ashtalakshmis; the eight goddesses of Wealth, Earth, Wisdom, Love, Fame, Peace, Contentment, and Strength.
There are iconographic variations in depiction of the Goddess. In this sculpture from Nuggehalli, Karnataka, she is found seated and has four arms. The four arms are symbolic of the four goals of humanity: dharma (pursuit of ethical, moral life), artha (pursuit of wealth, means of life), kama (pursuit of love, emotional fulfillment), and moksha (pursuit of self-knowledge, liberation). Her front right hand is held up in the abhaya mudra while her left hand is in the varada mudra giving boons to her devotees.
Muthuswami Dishidhar composed a beautiful song ‚ÄòSri Varalakshmi Nama Sthubhyam‚Äô in praise of the Goddess. Most appropriately it is set in the raga Sri (one of the names of Lakshmi). It starts with the pallavi
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏ ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§∞‡§∏ ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§∏‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§™‡§¶‡•á
Interestingly the pallavi starting from sArasa is in form of Gopuccha Yati which begins with a set of syllables and gets one syllable smaller with each repetition. The syllables are arranged similar to a cow‚Äôs tail, which is broad at the beginning gradually tapering to the bottom.
The pallavi translates as;
I bow down to you, O eminent Goddess Lakshmi, the giver of boons!
O bestower of fortunes! O Sri with feet as soft as a lotus, you are the bestower of affection, be my companion at every step.
Dr Raguram
17/08/24, 9:24‚ÄØam
During my earlier days at NIMHANS, I was shocked by an incident that happened not very far away from the campus. One evening when a woman was walking along the busy Double Road, she was forcefully taken away and raped. She was a married working woman who was walking home after the day‚Äôs work. I was troubled and wondered about the mind-set of the person who did the dastardly act. Wanting to understand more about rape, I went over to the Select Bookshop and asked Mr Murthy whether he could suggest a book that could offer me a broader perspective about this inhuman act. He rummaged through the crowded bookshelves and handed over a copy of Susan Brownmiller‚Äôs ‚ÄòAgainst Our Will‚Äô which was published in 1975.
It is not an easy read as it is filled with incidents and details of rape through0ut history. Susan Brownmiller outlines the history, politics, and sociology of rape and the and how it continues to profoundly affect women‚Äôs lives. What was profoundly insightful was reframing rape as an act of power, fundamental to the patriarchal domination of women. The chapter ‚ÄòPower: Institution and Authority‚Äô best expresses the main thesis of the book that rape is the primeval and the ultimate act of subjugation. Surveys show that a vast majority of rapes are planned. This goes to disprove the theory that the rapist is usually ‚Äòprovoked‚Äô by the flimsy clothing worn by the victim, and is overcome by an overpowering physical urge. In fact, the rapist is asserting his power and urge to dominate, ‚ÄúMan‚Äôs discovery that his genitalia could serve as a weapon to generate fear must rank as one of the most important discoveries in prehistoric times, along with the use of fire and the first crude stone axe. From prehistoric times to the present, rape has played a crucial function. It is nothing more or less than a conscious process of intimidation by which all men keep all women in a state of fear. ...That some men rape provides a sufficient threat to keep all women in a constant state of intimidation...‚Äù
She goes on to comment, ‚ÄúA world without rape would be a world in which women moved freely without fear of men. That some men rape provides a sufficient threat to keep all women in a constant state of intimidation, forever conscious of the knowledge that the biological tool must be held in awe for it may turn to weapon with sudden swiftness borne of harmful intent.‚Äù
In light of the recent event in Kolkata her observation is quite prescient, ‚ÄúAll rape is an exercise in power, but some rapists have an edge that is more than physical. They operate within an institutionalized setting that works to their advantage and in which a victim has little chance to redress her grievance.‚Äù
Even though there have been some criticisms of her perspective on rape, I agree with her that ‚ÄúOppression thrives on silence. In order to resist, we must break the silence and speak out against injustice.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
20/08/24, 7:37‚ÄØam
Yesterday was the birthday of one of my favourite poets, Ogden Nash. He wrote a lot of poems about birds and as a birdwatcher, I find his take on the twitchers delightfully playful!
UP FROM THE EGG
‚ÄúBird watchers top my honors list.
I aimed to be one, but I missed.
Since I‚Äôm both myopic and astigmatic,
My aim turned out to be erratic,
And I, bespectacled and binocular,
Exposed myself to comment jocular.
We don‚Äôt need too much birdlore, do we,
To tell a flamingo from a towhee;
Yet I cannot, and never will,
Unless the silly birds stand still.
And there‚Äôs no enlightenment in a tour
Of ornithological literature.
Is yon strange creature a common chickadee,
Or a migrant alouette from Picardy?
You can rush to consult your Nature guide
And inspect the gallery inside,
But a bird in the open never looks
Like its picture in the birdie books ‚Äì
Or if it once did, it has changed its plumage,
And plunges you back into ignorant gloomage.
That is why I sit here growing old by inches,
Watching a clock instead of finches,
But I sometimes visualize in my gin
The Audubon that I audubin.‚Äù

Thank you Sir for the enumeration. I also have a beautiful bronze dancing Nataraja presented to me decades back. Adi Shankara's Advaitha Philosophy gist in three lines. And the essay which describes the essence of the form...
26/08/24, 9:14‚ÄØam
Krishna Janmashtami, celebrates the birth of Krishna. Stories of Krishna's childhood are illustrated in numerous paintings and sculptures. This small sculpture at Amrutheshwara temple at Amruthapura in Karnataka depicts an interesting episode during his childhood.
The village that Krishna lived in, Gokula, was a land of cow herders. Hence, not surprisingly, there was an abundance of milk, curds, and butter in the village. Krishna was very fond of butter and would make use of every opportunity to steal butter from his mother or from any of the place in the village. Many of them started tying pots of butter to the ceiling so that Krishna or his friends couldn‚Äôt reach them. Undeterred by this, Krishna would team up with his friends to reach these pots by climbing on the shoulders of his friends. People found out that Krishna was the prime culprit for these acts and complained to Yashoda. One day, Yashoda lost her patience and tied him up in a heavy grindstone in the courtyard and went inside to attend to her domestic chores. Left alone, Krishna happily and effortlessly dragged the grindstone and passed through the gap between two Arjuna trees. But the grindstone got stuck in between and when Krishna pulled the mortar with all his strength the roots of the two trees get uprooted and they fell to the ground with a loud crash. The twin trees were, in fact, the two sons of Kubera, the god of wealth, Nalakubara and Manigriva. They were cursed by the sage Narada to be born as two Arjuna trees in Gokula. When Krishna pulled down the two trees they got liberated from the curse.
Since Yashoda tied him to the mortar with a rope, Krishna is also called as Damodara (dam + udara = rope + stomach). Sri Damodarastakam is a poem written by Sri Satyavrata Muni that describes his love for Sri Damodara. The poem is made up of eight verses and is found in the Padma Purana by Krishna Dwaipayana Vyasa. In the poem, Satyavrata Muni prays to Sri Damodara to appear to him in his eternal form as a young cowherd-boy and bestow his blessings. The 7th verse states:
‡§ï‡•Å‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•å ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß-‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç
‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•å ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø-‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡•å ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•å ‡§ö
‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ-‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ
‡§® ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§π ‡•• ‡•≠‡••
O Lord Damodara, in Your form as a baby, Mother Yasoda bound You to a grinding stone with a rope. You then freed the sons of Kuvera, Manigriva and Nalakuvara, who were cursed to stand as trees and You gave them the chance to become Your devotees. Please bless me in this same way. I only long for this and have no desire for any kind of liberation.

28/08/24, 9:14‚ÄØam
