28/08/24, 9:22‚ÄØam
Yes. A familiar story but needs to be applied in our lives. Resilience develops when the perspective changes. Thank you Sir for the highlight of the aspects we need to inculcate in our lives.
28/08/24, 7:51‚ÄØam
You cannot miss the Dark Eyed Junco. They have a charm all of their own, with their black hood and unusual metallic chipping song, For the most part, they seem quite content to forage on the ground, kicking up the leaves to garner whatever morsels are hidden below. The flash of their characteristic white outer tail feather is unmistakable when they take to flight. They are quite handsome looking with their black heads and white plumage, like the old saying ‚Äúdark skies above, snow below.‚Äù In some parts of North America, they are strongly associated with winter and are often referred to as snowbirds.
Junco attracted the attention of poets like William Stafford (17 January 1914 - 28 August 1993). Stafford‚Äôs poems are characterized by simple language, unadorned imagery and a conversational tone. He was deeply attached to nature, as he mentioned in one of his works.
‚ÄúI like to live in the sound of water,
in the feel of mountain air. A sharp
reminder hits me: this world still is alive;
it stretches out there shivering toward its own
creation, and I‚Äôm part of it.‚Äù
He wrote a small, beautiful poem about the Junco:
‚ÄúThey operate from elsewhere,
some hall in the mountains ‚Äì
quick visit, gone.
Specialists on branch ends,
craft union. I like their
clean little coveralls.‚Äù
Canadian singer Anne Murray wrote a song about it, which won the 1971 Juno Award (the Canadian music award) for Best Produced Single. The song ends with these lines:
‚ÄúSpread your tiny wings and fly away
And take the snow back with you
Where it came from on that day
The one I love forever is untrue
And if I could you know
that I would fly away with you
yah if I could, you know that I would fly away with you.‚Äù
There is always an unmeasurable joy in watching birds and reading what the poets say about them!
Dr Raguram
29/08/24, 8:19‚ÄØam
Eyes, often referred to as the windows to the soul, have captivated artists throughout history. Eyes convey a wide range of emotions powerfully. In any work of art, especially paintings, eyes nudge us to connect with the subjects at an intimate level. In the hands of a skilled artist, eyes capture and convey the individual personality of the subject, with much ease. The gaze of a subject in an artwork can be quite captivating. One such painting which illustrates this is the ‚ÄòLaughing Cavalier‚Äô, painted by Franz Hal. I haven‚Äôt seen this painting in any gallery (so far!). But whenever I see it in the net, I keep wondering whether he is actually laughing or is it a smirk? Is that a mischievous smile we are seeing? His eyes seem to follow us from whichever direction we view the painting. It appears as if he is observing us intently. His gaze engages us in mysterious ways!
Every time I look at this painting, I am reminded of Ralph Waldo Emerson‚Äôs observation that eyes "speak all languages."
(Franz Hal 1581 - 29th August 1666)
Dr Raguram
30/08/24, 7:06‚ÄØam
An author whom I admire deeply is Oliver Sacks, who eloquently explored the interface between mind and brain in his works. I am captivated by Dr Sacks‚Äô beautiful stories and his loving portrayals of his patients. Referred to as the ‚Äòpoet laureate of modern medicine‚Äô, he died from ocular cancer on August 30, 2015, at the age of 82. We lead a finite existence and letting go can often be hard. It is an arduous task to negotiate the irreversible trajectory of impending death.
An anonymous scholar writing in the 15th century wrote a poignant tract on how to prepare oneself for a good death, entitled Ars Moriendi (Latin for ‚Äòthe art of dying‚Äô). The work instructs as to how one can prepare for their final hours on this earth. It emphasizes the importance of allowing a dying person to experience the emotions they feel without pathologizing those emotions. The possibility of being overwhelmed with existential despair is lessened by allowing a dying person to grieve in their own way, allowing them to focus on the things and people that matter to them most. As the text suggests, most importantly, death is about coming to terms with our transcendental nature.
After learning of his terminal diagnosis, Sacks reflected on these aspects with remarkable candour which was condensed into a book, ‚ÄòGratitude‚Äô. He wrote:
‚ÄúOver the last few days, I have been able to see my life as from a great altitude, as a sort of landscape, and with a deepening sense of the connection of all its parts. This does not mean I am finished with life. On the contrary, I feel intensely alive, and I want and hope in the time that remains to deepen my friendships, to say farewell to those I love, to write more, to travel if I have the strength, to achieve new levels of understanding and insight. This will involve audacity, clarity and plain speaking; trying to straighten my accounts with the world. But there will be time, too, for some fun (and even some silliness, as well). ..And now, weak, short of breath, my once-firm muscles melted away by cancer . . . I find my thoughts drifting to the Sabbath, the day of rest, the seventh day of the week, and perhaps the seventh day of one‚Äôs life as well, when one can feel that one‚Äôs work is done, and one may, in good conscience, rest.‚Äù
In these writings, Oliver Sacks reminds us that we are visitors here, passing through the great mystery of life. Every moment of life including the final ones is a gift and one can face death with poise and equanimity.
In his interesting book, ‚ÄòMusicophilia‚Äô, Oliver Sacks wrote, ‚ÄúIt really is a very odd business that all of us, to varying degrees, have music in our heads.‚Äù That music never dies‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
30/08/24, 1:43‚ÄØpm
A necessary diet for thought. How we live, learn to handle oddities, remind ourselves of the impermanence I think will help in the last moments. It is a practice. Thank you Sir for throwing light on the unknown (for me) authors...
01/09/24, 11:41‚ÄØam
Gibbons may be the most endangered groups of primates on Earth. Hoolock Gibbon is the only ape species in India. Ahalya and myself were keen to have a glimpse of this rare species and we headed to The Hollongapar Gibbon Sanctuary, a habitat of the endangered Western hoolock gibbon in Assam. After finishing the formalities in the office at the entrance of the sanctuary, we made our way, accompanied by a forest guard. The only way to explore the forest is by walk. The sun was playing hide and seek through the thick trees covered with lush green foliage. As we were walking, we heard an unusual loud call. The guard whispered that it is the call of the gibbon. We walked further for an hour, but couldn‚Äôt spot any. Suddenly the guard noticed some activity in the higher reaches of the trees. We stood there for a while, keenly looking for its presence. Slowly a huge, glossy, black figure emerged, hanging from a branch in the tree with its long arm. It swung from one branch to another, adeptly, with sinuous movements. Soon several others joined and they were darting from one tree to another like skilled acrobats. It was so wonderful to watch their graceful movements. With their short torso, long legs, they almost looked like us!
The gibbons are arboreal animals, preferring to stay in the higher reaches of tall Hollong trees. They barely come down to the forest floor. As they are canopy dwellers, it is difficult to have a good look at them. One has to keep craning the neck all the time to spot them. It is also difficult to photograph them amidst the dark green cover. With some effort and lots of luck, I was able to freeze the experience through the lens!
Life is a collection of moments and our tryst with the Hoolock Gibbon was one of the most memorable experience in our sojourns into the wild. As Oscar Wilde commented, ‚Äúmemories are the diary we all carry with us‚Äù and our visit to the Hoollongapar Sanctuary will remain as a cherished entry in it.
(It is so apt to pen these reminiscences on the International Primate Day, especially when the theme this year is ‚ÄúConnecting with Wild Primates.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
02/09/24, 7:45‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for the virtual journey..
02/09/24, 7:57‚ÄØpm
People nowadays want a short cut answer for everything. We need to slow down, ponder to find meaning in life. It can't be barrowed from others. Thank you sir for the revisit to the contribution of Viktor Frankl.
03/09/24, 9:11‚ÄØam
One of the spiritual seekers I listened to very early in life, left a lasting impression on me. It was a discourse delivered by Swami Chinmayananda in a playground near our house. I listened in silence to his booming voice as he outlined aspects of the Bhagavat Gita. Much of it was well over my cognitive grasp at that age. But there was an unmistakable pull in the way he addressed the vast audience with clarity and ease.
Much later, I rediscovered him and some of his observations are worth reflecting and I felt like sharing them, on his death anniversary:
‚ÄúMore important than what is behind you and what is ahead of you is what is in you. Seek it. Centred in it, act and live.‚Äù
‚ÄúTo see the one in the many
Is the casual vision of knowledge.
To see the many in the one,
Is the mission wisdom.‚Äù
‚ÄúBe strict and intelligently critical about yourself and your own weakness and follies. But, cushion your words and attitudes with Love. Love is the greatest persuasive power we know in life.‚Äù
In throes of adversities in life, I invariably seek succour in these words of his:
‚ÄúTo be patient means to suffer something that hinders or hurts us, and still retain our self-composure. How many difficulties, with their consequent unpleasantness and discord, could be smoothed over and almost entirely eliminated by patience. Patience always elevates and strengthens our character. We need it not only with others but also with ourselves.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
04/09/24, 8:28‚ÄØam
Auroville came into existence when I was doing medicine at JIPMER. I used to cycle there on most weekends to have a look at the emerging settlement which was dotted with very imaginative structures. During one such visit I walked into the ‚ÄòLast School‚Äô. It was a very unusual, creative building, with no resemblance to any school structure I was familiar with. There was a small stream flowing inside and children were making paper boats and floating them in the water. There was a person who was telling them about boats and how they are carried further in waterways. I was attracted to its imaginative and inventive concept. I came to know that Mother called it the ‚ÄòLast School‚Äô, to emphasize that once the community took shape, learning would continue outside of formal schools.
A couple of years later, I was introduced to the work of Ivan Illich by Prof Moris Carstairs who was a visiting professor at NIMHANS. I reviewed Illich‚Äôs ‚ÄòLimits to Medicine‚Äô, which was chaired by him (I wrote about it two years ago). He urged me to read Illich‚Äôs other book, ‚ÄòDeschooling Society‚Äô. In this most unusual book, he articulated ideas which mapped onto the vision of the Mother. Deschooling is not about abolishing education altogether, but rather about reimagining and restructuring the way we learn. It emphasized the importance of self-directed learning, individual autonomy, and community-based education. To quote Illich, ‚ÄúWhat is a child, what is a teacher, what is education? Why, in particular, do we tend to think of learning primarily in the context of the school ‚Äì a particular kind of institution, with a very specific form and organisational structure? What, indeed, are schools actually for? Most learning is not the result of instruction. It is rather the result of unhampered participation in a meaningful setting. Teaching, it is true, may contribute to certain kinds of learning under certain circumstances. But most people acquire most of their knowledge outside school.‚Äù
Illich offered a passionate critique of a formalized, institutionalized educational system and its limitations. It may not be an easy exercise to reshape schools as places of informal, guided, learning habitats focussed on individual skill building. There have been many innovative attempts to create such spaces. The dilemma has always been what happens after such schooling? How do the children from these learning spaces negotiate their lives in the demanding job market outside which is not attuned to such orientations? Many don‚Äôt want to be just ‚Äúanother brick in the wall‚Äô and some perhaps find new imaginative paths to explore in their lives.
Unfortunately education has become an industry and there is an urgent need to think creatively about the role and purpose of schools. Illich‚Äôs book may be a catalyst in that direction.
As Margaret Mead commented, ‚ÄúChildren must be taught how to think, not what to think.‚Äù
(Ivan Illich 4th September 1926 - 2 December 2002)
Dr Raguram
05/09/24, 7:31‚ÄØam
Teacher‚Äôs Day is about paying tribute with an abiding sense of gratitude to teachers who have shaped our journey in learning.
Our formal education starts within the premises of a school. I was fortunate to be a student in the Ramakrishna Mission School, North Branch, Chennai. Among all the teachers who taught us, the one who left a deep impact on me was Sri TS Ranganathan Sir, referred to TSR. He had a commanding presence and when he entered the classroom we were over awed with his demeanor. He was a science teacher but he could also teach us about English literature, geography and human anatomy with ease and √©lan. He was a polymath. He shared with us anecdotes from forgotten pages of history and opened our minds to explore unknown landscapes of learning. I was learning tennis and one day he called to ask me whether I would like to join him on the tennis court. The school had a tennis court not far away from his home. When I reached the place, I found him dressed in his usual attire, an immaculate panchakacham. Panchakacham is not a regular dhoti and has five pleats delicately tucked in, much akin to a nine yards‚Äô saree worn by women in traditional attire. It took me a while to register that he was going to play tennis in this rather complicated outfit. My reservations were put to rest however when he started to serve. It was a booming service that would be the envy of any seasoned tennis player. I struggled to return it. He didn‚Äôt make it easy but egged me on to respond to it. At the end of an hour I was sweating profusely! He patted me and said, ‚ÄúGood start!‚Äù. Sometimes he would ask me to tabulate the results of the exam papers in his home and on completion of the task, I would be enthralled listening to him playing the harmonium.
TSR lit the fire to awaken the joy of learning which was not just confined to the classroom. Borrowing a saying from Robert Frost, he was ‚Äúnot a teacher, but an awakener.‚Äù

14/09/24, 9:18‚ÄØam
One of the temples not often visited in Khajuraho is the Vamana temple. Set amidst a verdant, green landscape, it is a sight to behold with its spire reaching up like a beautiful mountain. Like rest of the temples in Khajuraho, the outer walls of the sanctum are adorned with intricate carvings depicting scenes from Hindu mythology. In the sanctum is a striking idol of Vamana, the fifth incarnation of Lord Vishnu. Vamana is the first incarnation whem Lord Vishnu appeared in a full human form, as a dwarf.
The legend of the Vamana avatar is narrated in the Rigveda and other scriptures. Mahabali, son of Virochan and grandson of Prahlad, was a generous, mighty monarch who was adored by his subjects. He was granted the boon of immortality by Lord Brahma and he continued to expand the frontiers of his empire. He conquered all the three realms: Heaven, Earth and the Underworld. Immensely troubled by growing powers, the Devas appealed to Lord Vishnu to intervene and restore the balance of power. Responding to their prayers, Lord Vishnu incarnated as Vamana, the dwarf and went to the Yaga that was being performed by Mahabali. During the Yaga, people could ask Mahabali for and receive anything they wanted. Mahabali bade Vamana to ask for anything that he wanted, like jewels, land, forests etc, without hesitation. Vamana denied all these politely and asked merely for three paces of land. Looking at Vamana‚Äôs diminutive stature, Bali said, ‚ÄòSo be it; pace and take it.‚Äô The dwarf Vamana suddenly grew in size into a giant and with one step measured the Earth and with another the entire Heaven. As there was no room left for the third step that had been granted, Mahabali humbly knelt under Vamana‚Äôs foot and offered his head. As Bali sank deep into the underworld, he heard his subjects wailing in grief for their much loved king. Seeing this, Vamana granted Mahabali one last boon. The boon was the permission to visit his subjects on Earth once a year. Thus, Mahabali returns every year to visit his people and the land that he had once ruled. Onam commemorates the annual visit of this legendary king from the underworld to his former kingdom, the land of Kerala.
Parsva Ekadashi which is observed today is also associated with the legend of Mahabali and Vamana Avatar of Lord Vishnu and is also referred to as Vamana Ekadashi. It is fascinating to note that the Onam festival follows the same legend and takes place around the same time of year.
Dr Raguram
14/09/24, 7:19‚ÄØpm
Yes Sir. Tomorrow is Vamana Jayanthi...
16/09/24, 6:58‚ÄØpm
Will listen Sir
18/09/24, 7:54‚ÄØam
William Carlos Williams was a full-time practicing physicians who was also a prolific writer across many literary genres. He regarded art and medicine as ‚Äútwo parts of a whole.‚Äù Williams rejected traditional conventions of rhyme and meter, masterfully blending colloquial idioms which lent a conversational tone to his poems. Often referred to as the ‚ÄúMaster of the glimpse,‚Äù Williams painted verbal pictures with crisp, vivid word images in poems like, ‚ÄúThe Red Wheelbarrow.‚Äù The subject of Williams‚Äôs poetry is quite varied; crowds attending baseball games, trains pulling into station, wheelbarrows, fire trucks, and a host of everyday subjects. He drew inspiration from grounded images from any source, in unexpected places.
Even though he was incapacitated by a stroke, he continued to type with his non dominant hand and completed his and Pulitzer Prize-winning ‚ÄúPictures from Brueghel.‚Äù Additional small strokes resulted in more deficits, but he kept on writing.
I particularly like his poem ‚ÄúThe Fool‚Äôs Song‚Äù
I tried to put a bird in a cage.
O fool that I am!
For the bird was Truth.
Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put
Truth in a cage!
And when I had the bird in the cage,
O fool that I am!
Why, it broke my pretty cage.
Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put
Truth in a cage!
And when the bird was flown from the cage,
O fool that I am!
Why, I had nor bird nor cage.
Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put
Truth in a cage!
Heigh-ho! Truth in a cage.
Much like the bird in the poem, each of us tussle with some deep secret or truth which we want to hide from others. But truth is hard to reveal and often cannot be hidden. As Leo Tolstoy observed, ‚ÄúVery often, all the activity of the human mind is directed not in revealing the truth, but in hiding the truth.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
20/09/24, 1:16‚ÄØpm
Yes Sir. We have to learn to handle constant chattering.
22/09/24, 9:22‚ÄØam
Like William Carlos William, Dannie Abse (22 September 1923 - 28 September 2014), was a physician poet. Unlike the former, who largely kept medicine out of his poetry, Abse wanted to ‚Äúhear the heartbeat of words‚Äù and wrote about patients and the diseases they had, with tenderness. Even a stethoscope is infused with poetic insights, transmitting sounds ‚Äúover young women‚Äôs tense abdomens . . . of creation and in a dead man‚Äôs chest, the silence before creation began.‚Äù
His poem, ‚ÄòPortrait of an Old Doctor‚Äù begins with these beautiful, reflective lines:
‚ÄúLover of music more than his textbooks‚Äô
arrythmic prose and dated, almost dangerous
his Conybeare and his Boyd‚Äôs Pathology.
(Notes in the margin by the student he was)
What was it all about? Blunderbuss drugs
prescribed to ease the patient. And moonbeams.
A composer‚Äîa Beethoven, a Smetana‚Äîit seemed, could be deaf, but not a doctor.
He had been a conÔ¨Ådence man for the patient.
That‚Äôs how it was in the Theatre of Disease
and, at the Ô¨Ånal act, he had lifted
his stethoscope to listen
as if to Mozart.
Then, silently, relatives and friends Ô¨Åled out.
No applause. None for Hippocrates‚Äô art.‚Äù
Let me end this post with this poignant poem of Abse
‚ÄòMoonbright‚Äô
Afterwards, late, walking home from hospital,
that December hour too blatantly moonbright
- such an unworldly moon so widely round,
an orifice of scintillating arctic light -
I thought how the effrontery of a similar moon,
a Pirandello moon that would make men howl,
would, in future, bring back the eidolon
of you, father, propped high on pillow
your mouth ajar, your nerveless hand in mine.
At home, feeling hollow, I shamelessly wept
- whether for you or myself I do not know.
Tonight a bracing wind makes my eyes cry
while a cloud dociles an impudent moon
that is and was, and is again, and was.
Men become mortal the night their fathers die.‚Äù
Lastly, at this stage in my life, these lines from his poem ‚ÄòTalking to Myself‚Äô ‚ÄúIn the mildew of age/all pavements slope uphill‚Äô touch a deep chord within‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
23/09/24, 9:14‚ÄØam
On September 21, Max Schur, Freud‚Äôs personal physician visited him and was aghast to see him looking pale and quite wasted. Freud took his doctor‚Äôs hand and said, ‚ÄúMy dear Schur, you certainly remember our first talk. You promised me then not to forsake me when the time comes. Now it is nothing but torture and makes no sense anymore.‚Äù Schur responded stating that he had not forgotten the promise he made. Freud thanked him and told Schur to ‚Äútalk it over with Anna, and if she thinks it‚Äôs right, make an end of it.‚Äù Schur spoke to Anna and she sorrowfully concurred with her father‚Äôs wish. Then Schur gave Freud an injection of three centigrams of morphine, a dose much stronger than he would have used if the objective had only been to relieve pain. He was now assisting him to die a peaceful death. He gave Freud another injection that day, then a third on September 22. Freud lapsed into a coma, but he held on to life. At 3AM in the morning on Saturday, September 23, 1939, Sigmund Freud breathed his last. Three days later, his body was cremated and his ashes placed in an ancient Greek urn, originally gifted to him by his friend Marie Bonaparte.
Many years before, Freud had made it abundantly clear as to how he wanted to die as he never wanted to live without his mental capacities intact. He wrote to his friend Oskar Pfister, ‚ÄúWith all the resignation before destiny that suits an honest man, I have one wholly secret entreaty: only no invalidism, no paralysis of one‚Äôs powers through bodily misery. Let us die in harness, as King Macbeth says.‚Äù
Freud left the world with a certain degree of composure. In Nietzsche‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúThe most fortunate author is one who is able to say as an old man that all he had of life giving, invigorating, uplifting enlightening thoughts and feelings still lives on in his writings, and that he himself is only the gray ash, while the fire has been rescued and carried forth everywhere.‚Äù
The last book Freud read was Balzac‚Äôs La Peau de Chagrin (The Wild Ass‚Äôs Skin). The protagonist, Rapheal de Valentin, gains possession of a wild donkey‚Äôs skin and is granted all he wishes. The magical object has the power to fulfil its owner's every wish but carries a heavy price: With every wish the owner's remaining time in life is reduced. On finishing the book, Freud told Schur, ‚ÄúThis was the proper book for me to read.‚Äù
Mark Edmundson has written a very perceptive book on Freud‚Äôs last days, ‚ÄòThe Death Of Sigmund Freud.‚Äô The book ends with these words ‚ÄúToward the person who has died we adopt a special attitude: something like admiration for someone who has accomplished a very difficult task.‚Äù
In the words of Sheena Blackhall
‚ÄúIt was Saturday, under the sign of Libra
When he crossed, with the aid of morphine,
(that child of Morpheus, Greek God of Dreams)
Into the world of the dead.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
24/09/24, 3:43‚ÄØpm
Such a graceful end but a chosen one. So determined till the last. Thank you Sir for letting us know about his last days. I have always kept Freud on a pedestal and he deserves to be, considering the time of his contribution.
29/09/24, 9:47‚ÄØam
Today is the World Heart Day‚Ä¶
Sharing a poem by Dr Viswanathan Venkatachalam
An interventional cardiologist based in Sydney, Australia
THE INFARCT PARTY
Today I wish to write a solemn poetry
On poor little coronary artery
With an infarction, it‚Äôs lumen totally seals
Gosh! The pain that the patient feels!
In comes the cardiologist from a party
All gadgets to make it hale and hearty
We need to get a catheter in first,
For the clot in the artery to be burst!
In comes the wire and on it a balloon
In saving the life, this really is a boon!
Now the stenosis has just got to vent
In comes to cure the majestic stent!
With all drugs on board is served cocktail
This the happy ending of the cardiac tale!
Dr Raguram
30/09/24, 8:49‚ÄØam
Today is the birthday of Rumi whose works continue to have a deep impact on me. His poems encompass a rich and complex tapestry of themes and ideas, all deftly woven together. Personally they have been inspiring signposts which gently guided me to discover myself anew.
Last week I spoke about the travails of the survivors of suicide in a CME. Suicide destroys the fabric of existence of the survivors and their lives become frayed at the edges. Embracing the reality of loss is not an easy task. It is an extremely poignant journey.
In this particular poem, Rumi explores the nature of grief and loss, suggesting that it can be a catalyst for self-discovery and growth.
‚ÄúYour grief for what you‚Äôve lost lifts a mirror
up to where you are bravely working.
Expecting the worst, you look, and instead,
here‚Äôs the joyful face you‚Äôve been wanting to see.
Your hand opens and closes, and opens and closes.
If it were always a fist or always stretched open,
you would be paralyzed.
Your deepest presence is in every small contracting and expanding,
the two as beautifully balanced
and coordinated
as birds' wings.‚Äù
Often the survivor‚Äôs world becomes constricted in the absence of the person and they withdraw into themselves. Through the evocative use of the metaphor of bird‚Äôs wings, Rumi extols the virtue of spreading the wings open, ‚Äòcontracting and expanding‚Äô them, to experience the transformative power of loss.
I have observed in my clinical work that the person whom the survivors think that they have lost, continues to live amidst their own feathers of memory and I strive to urge them to find strength in them, balance themselves and soar again.
Dr Raguram
03/10/24, 10:28‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for posting Rumi's poems and even I look forward to reading them. It is very true that the loss, grief should enable a person to search deeper meaning of our 'self', progress not succumb. The simile, a very simple mechanical act, when given a second thought holds so much of significance.
08/10/24, 9:10‚ÄØam
Navratri is devoted to the worship of Goddess Durga in her various forms. Katyayani is one among the Navadurgas, the nine forms of the Goddess, who is worshipped on the sixth fay of Navratri. She is a fierce manifestation of Shakti, the divine female power.
In the Devi Bhagavata Purana, it is mentioned that Rishi Katyayana was a great devotee of Mother Shakti. He wished for the goddess to be born in his household in the form of his daughter. For this, Sage Katyayana did severe penance for years. Meanwhile, the malevolent Mahishasura was wreaking havoc, tormenting the gods relentlessly. Seeking a solution, the divine trinity of Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma emitted flames that coalesced into the formidable form of Goddess Katyayani. Each of them gifted her a weapon to vanquish Mahishasura. She then embarked on a mission, engaged Mahishasura in a fearsome battle, defeated and vanquished him. Hence, she is also referred to as Mahishasura Mardhini.
This delicately sculpted panel in the inner wall of the Chidambaram temple depicts Katyayani with eighteen hands, her leg firmly entrenched on the neck of Mahishasura.
The legend of Katyayani is not merely a relic of a bygone era but an inspiring metaphor of resilience and empowerment, which women can draw upon in their daily lives even now. In a world beset with discrimination, inequality, and injustice faced by women, her story illustrates that courage, coupled with an unshakable resolve, can be a continuing source of motivation to conquer adversities and challenge norms even in the face of seemingly insurmountable odds.
Dr Raguram
10/10/24, 10:17‚ÄØam
On this World Mental Health Day, let me draw attention to Dorothea Buck, an inspiring figure who espoused the cause of the mentally ill with extraordinary zeal and commitment.
When Dorothea was just 19 years old, she was emotionally distraught at the prospect of yet another war and the attendant suffering. She was diagnosed as schizophrenic and was confined to an asylum for nine months where she was subjected to a range of harsh physical treatments. Under the Nazi-era ‚Äúhereditary health law‚Äù protocols, which had been imposed to prevent so-called genetic impurities from being transmitted to future generations, she was also sterilized. When she was released, she was barred from marrying and denied a career as a teacher. She continued to have periods of psychotic episodes which were poorly treated. Undeterred by these adversities, she started writing about mental health, giving lectures, holding seminars and helping to start organizations to protect the rights of mentally ill persons.
In her talks and writings, Dorothea continuously emphasized that mental health professionals should provide a safe space and hear the stories of personal suffering, rather than seeing them as soulless objects of study. She drew attention to the importance of a three-way discourse in clinical settings involving the patients, their key relatives and their doctors. She called this process as a ‚Äútrialogue.‚Äù
Dorothea trained herself to be a sculptor and this work of hers is called, ‚ÄúMother and Child.‚Äù Speaking about, it she remarked that such kind of intimate personal relationship between doctors and psychotic patients is ‚Äúmissing in today‚Äôs psychiatry‚Ä¶ the unrelatedness of psychiatrists to their patients contradicted everything human.‚Äù
Dorothea died on Oct. 9, 2019, at the age of 102.
Dorothea‚Äôs autobiography ‚ÄúOn the Trail of the Morning Star: Psychosis as Self-Discovery‚Äù, was originally published in German. Translated into English in 2024, it is available as a free download in Research Gate. It is one of the most moving accounts of her lived experiences and tryst with mental illness and I would urge every mental health professional to read it.
Advocacy about mental health is not merely in the realm of professionals. There is an urgent need to provide spaces, where the voice of people who enter and pas through the gates of immense emotional suffering can be heard.
Dr Raguram
11/10/24, 10:35‚ÄØpm
Such a wonderful sculpture which shows the impact of her treatment which devoided her of innate desire to have a child. Very moving account but I think society is turning out to be a larger asylum when we get to hear about the work place atmosphere.
15/10/24, 1:23‚ÄØpm
I understand that today is World Students‚Äô Day to commemorate Dr Abdul Kalam‚Äôs birthday. He was a great motivator of students and always encouraged them to ask questions in his interactions with them. He also had a website wherein students could raise question on a wide variety of subjects. He even dedicated his book ‚ÄòIgnited Minds‚Äô to a class XII student, Snehal Thakkar. According to him, ‚Äú a very important characteristic of a student is to question.‚Äù
During our training period in NIMHANS, we were enveloped in an ambiance of open discussion that encouraged questioning. Seminars, case conferences were active crucibles replete with thoughtful and engaging questioning by trainees. On many occasions, these would spill over to the hostel mess for more animated exchanges!
Questioning lies at the heart of active learning. It is like planting seeds of thought. They can create spaces to reflect on new ideas and perceptions. Unfortunately, the trend to question seems to be declining. In many academic presentations across various settings, I invariably notice that students are reticent to ask questions. Is it because as a culture, we overvalue speaking and privilege it over questioning? Or is it because we are educated in a system that implicitly silences questioning and assigns value only to ‚Äòcorrect answers‚Äô? Perhaps teachers and ‚Äògurus‚Äô feel uneasy being challenged and implicitly discourage questioning?
Historically, the art of questioning was valorised as an important avenue of learning especially in the spiritual realm, across all cultures. For instance, Prashna Upanishad consists of a series philosophical poems presented as questions (prashna) posed by various seekers and responded to by Sage Pippalada. Perhaps it is time to revitalize the ‚ÄòArt of Questioning‚Äô!
In the words of Naguib Mahfouz, the Nobel Laureate, ‚ÄúYou can tell whether a man is clever by his answers. You can tell whether a man is wise by his questions.‚Äù
Dr Raguram

19/10/24, 12:39‚ÄØpm
Sir Thomas Browne (October 19, 1605 - October 19, 1682), was a physician and philosopher, who wrote on a wide array of subjects, including science, medicine, religion, and the esoteric. One particular work that I personally find fascinating to read is ‚ÄòReligio Medici‚Äô, a book of his reflections. Translated as "The Religion of a Doctor," it offers an interesting perspective of views on various scientific and religious subjects; ‚ÄúNot picked from the leaves of any author, but bred amongst the weeds and tares of mine own brain.‚Äù William Osler, who is credited as "the father of modern medicine," considered ‚ÄòReligio Medici‚Äô so influential to his career that he reportedly memorized it by heart.
I would like to draw attention to two of his reflections that made an impact on me. Cleaving a boundary between the personal attitudes and beliefs and professional responsibilities can often be a daunting task especially in clinical work. Browne urges that there needs to be a clear separation between the spheres of religion and that of science, especially in the field of medicine. He underscores the importance that a doctor must not only tolerate but also respect individual patients' religious beliefs, even if they conflict with his own. Physicians personal, religious beliefs should not impact the way he treats his patients. This stems largely from Browne's own belief that individual churches and sects should not "usurp the gates of heaven, and turn the key against each other; and thus we go to heaven against each other‚Äôs' wills, conceits, and, with as much uncharity as arrogance, do err."
In a period where the moral aspects of medical practice are under strain, Browne draws attention to the fact that a strong moral component is at the core in the practice of medicine. To him, medicine is more than a trade, it is a moral pursuit built on a foundation of service to others. "For by compassion," Browne writes, "we make others' misery our own, and so, by relieving them, we relieve ourselves also." When a disease was beyond Browne's capacity to cure, he felt uneasy and was reluctant to charge the patient any fee, calling this "scarce honest gain."
‚ÄúWho in the world am I? Ah, that's the great puzzle‚Äù pondered Alice in Wonderland. Often, our ideas, beliefs and perspectives about life become clear when we introspect and ‚ÄòReligio Medici‚Äô is one such example. Sir Thomas Browne is like a person who is sitting on the edge of a stream, looking at his reflection in the ripples of water, plunging himself in the process into the depths of self-introspection, articulating them with clarity and insight in this small book of memoirs.
As Browne observes in this book, we must ‚ÄúBe able to be alone. Lose not the advantage of solitude. and the society of thyself.‚Äù Often the privacy of aloneness provides a space for deep, perceptive reflections.
( When I was typing these lines, my attention was drawn to this small terracotta figure on the desk and I thought that this image adeptly epitomizes Browne‚Äôs observations)

23/10/24, 9:06‚ÄØam
Robert Bridges was another physician poet who was also the Poet Laureate of England for over a decade from 1913. He was a conscientious doctor and often found it difficult to use the stethoscope because of the noise in the overcrowded hospital. He described the vivid soundscape of a Victorian hospital ward, poetically: ‚Äò‚Ä¶the rattle of carts in the street, the hum of voices inside, the slamming of doors, the noise of people walking about, the coughings of all kinds, the crying of babies, the scraping of impatient feet, the stamping of cold ones, the chinking of the bottles and zinc tickets, and, after eleven o‚Äôclock, the hammering, sawing, and tinkering of the carpenters and blacksmiths who came not unfrequently at that hour to set things generally to rights.‚Äù Unfortunately, he contracted a serious lung infection at the age of 38 and retired from the medical profession, immersing himself fully in literary pursuits.
Bridges had a deep love for all things in nature; ‚ÄúI love all beauteous things, I seek and adore them..‚Äù I particularly like his shorter poems, especially this one:
I WOULD BE A BIRD, AND STRAIGHT ON WINGS I ARISE
I would be a bird, and straight on wings I arise
I would be a bird, and straight on wings I arise,
And carry purpose up to the ends of the air:
In calm and storm my sails I feather, and where
By freezing cliffs the unransom'd wreckage lies:
Or, strutting on hot meridian banks, surprise
The silence: over plains in the moonlight bare
I chase my shadow, and perch where no bird dare
In treetops torn by fiercest winds of the skies.
Poor simple birds, foolish birds! then I cry,
Ye pretty pictures of delight, unstir'd
By the only joy of knowing that ye fly;
Ye are not what ye are, but rather, sum'd in a word,
The alphabet of a god's idea, and I
Who master it, I am the only bird.
(Robert Bridges born on 23rd October, 1844)
Dr Raguram
29/10/24, 8:54‚ÄØam
The first cave one comes across in Ajanta is cave 1. It is not the first one built chronologically and perhaps the last one to be completed. It is the first cave one encounters when approaching the complex from the north side of the horseshoe-shaped cliff. The construction of the cave started around 466 CE and there were several disruptions. Emperor Harisena of the Vakataka dynasty played a crucial role in executing it.
As we entered the cool, dark interior of the cave, our attention was drawn to the colossal sculpture of the Buddha in the sanctum. He is seated on a throne in the padmasana, with his hands in the Dharmachakra Mudra. Dharmachakra in Sanskrit means the 'Wheel of Dharma'. This mudra symbolizes one of the most important moments in the life of Buddha, the occasion when he delivered his first sermon after his Enlightenment in the Deer Park at Sarnath.
On the left wall adjoining the sanctum is the painting of Padmapani. It is perhaps one of most iconic paintings of Ajanta and has adorned the walls of many houses. I stood in front of it, totally transfixed, devouring as much as I could of its stately elegance. Padmapani, the bearer of the lotus is portrayed holding the flower in his right hand. There is an unbroken flow of the body which is gracefully inclined slightly to the right side. The left-arm is tied with a ribbon. A high crown adorns his head and around his neck is a pearl necklace. There is a long string of jewellery over the left shoulder, falling across the chest. The long, sharp nose, highlighted with warm colours and inward shading, enhances the serene beauty of his face.
I closed my eyes for a moment and then looked at the deeply introspective, lotus-shaped, half-closed eyes. This is often referred to as the ‚Äòadamantine‚Äô gaze. I wonder whether through his half closed eyes, Padmapani is urging us to withdraw our awareness from the distractions of the outside world and look within, indicating that all the answers we seek are inside us. I was immersed in the overwhelming aura of boundless compassion radiating from Padmapani‚Äôs visage and it was difficult to prise myself away from the celestial painting. As I was leaving the cave, I was reminded of Rumi‚Äôs counsel, ‚ÄúListen with ears of tolerance. See through the eyes of compassion. Speak with the language of love‚Äù
Dr Raguram

02/11/24, 8:50‚ÄØam
Balipadyami is observed the day after Diwali in Karnataka. On this day let us recall the story of Mahabali. According to the legend, once upon a time, there was an asura called Bali, also known as Mahabali, who conquered three worlds and was famous for his generosity. Over the course of time he annexed the celestial world too. Unhappy with it, Indra, king of the celestial regions, requested Vishnu to deal with Bali. Vishnu took the form of a dwarf, Vamana, and asked Mahabali for three paces of land. Mahabali granted it without a second thought. The dwarf then suddenly transformed into a giant, and with two paces, he claimed the sky, the earth, and all possessions that Mahabali had. Vamana then asked him where should he take the third step. The only thing Mahabali had left was his body. So he told Vamana to step on his head. Vamana did so and pushed Bali underground into Patal. Mahabali, however, was granted a wish to visit the earth once a year to meet the people who loved him very much.
One of the most beautiful depictions of this myth is in Cave II in Badami: the Vamana-Trivikrama sculpture is carved on the western wall of the mukhamandapa. In the centre of the panel Vishnu is portrayed as Trivikrama. Eight-armed, his right leg is placed firmly on the ground, while the left leg is raised up to the level of chest, with Mahabali underneath it. Of the eight hands, seven hold khadga, bana, gada, chakra, sankha, khetaka and chapa. The remaining left hand is stretched out parallel to the raised leg. A soldier with a sword is shown falling upside down, failing in his attempt to attack Vishnu. A dwarfish person who is portrayed in a royal outfit holds the right leg of Trivikrama firmly, to obstruct his measuring the paces; he is identified as Namuchi, the son of Bali. On the lower left part of this panel, Vamana‚Äôs figure has been unfortunately defaced and he can be identified only by his umbrella. Sukracharya is shown by his side pouring water into the hand of Vamana while Bali stands behind with his wife Vindhyavali. Strangely Shukracharya has a Buddha like demeanour.
What does the story of Balipadyami inform us? Mahabali was caught in the trappings of his ego, craving for more power and perceiving himself as invulnerable. When Trivikrama asked him ‚Äúwhere can I place the third step?‚Äù he broke free from the fetters of ego and surrendered himself to the divine, cosmic power. When we light the lamp on Balipadyami, let us strive to renew our deeper connection with the divine through transcending the trappings of our ego. It is a path to tread in a period of time when narcissistic patterns are so salient and on the rise.
Dr Raguram
02/11/24, 10:13‚ÄØpm
Today we celebrated Balipadyami. They have sculpted all details so well and clearly though some portions are disfigured. I wonder why Shukracharya is pouring water. As far as I know Bali will pour the arghya (as he was well known for his charity) when Vamana the Brahmana asks for it. His Guru Shukracharya wants to prevent in doing so as he knows who the dwarf is. He will enter the container and block the hole when Vamana takes a blade of grass and pokes due to which he loses an eye. Bali is supposed to have been pushed down as he went against his Guru 's instructions! Thank you Sir for the wonderful sculpture, a treasure we still possess.
06/11/24, 8:14‚ÄØam
Decades ago, in the busy outpatient wing of NIMHANS, I noticed an elderly man who was drumming his hands vigorously on his head. I called him inside and asked him as to why he was doing so. He turned to me and said, ‚ÄúI was listening to music.‚Äù It was the first case of musical hallucinations I had ever seen and I reported it as a case study in a journal. There have been many reports of such phenomenon with varied hypotheses as to its causation. It left me wondering as to what would happen if a musician were to have musical hallucinations? Will it be an inspiration, finding its way to his/her musical creations, or will it be a curse?
These questions resonated within me for long, till I chanced upon a wonderful 1958 recording of Robert Schumann‚Äôs Symphony No 2, by the Cleveland Orchestra conducted by George Szell. It‚Äôs deeply affective sombre opening notes, slowly flow into brighter phase with repartees between strings and winds, ending with a hymn like finale. I must have listened to it many times and was curious to find out more about its composer. I was surprised to read about the inspiration for this symphony. It was a piece of auditory musical hallucination that Schumann experienced. In his words, ‚ÄúFor several days, drums and trumpets in the key of C have been sounding in my mind. I have no idea what will come of it‚Äù: they found their place in Symphony No 2.
Schumann battled various physical and psychiatric illnesses all through his life, prominent among them being syphilis. He wrote that his illness, ‚Äúhearing problems, depression, dizziness, rheumatism is inscribed in the fabric of the piece. I would say that my resistant spirit had a visible influence on it and it is through that that I sought to fight my condition. The first movement is full of this combativeness, is very moody and rebellious in character."
During his final days when he was incarcerated in a mental asylum, he was hearing a musical pitch or an entire orchestra. As his wife recorded in a note, Schumann experienced ‚Äúvery strong and painful auditory disturbances‚Äù during this time period. The music sounded in his head, day and night, and sometimes went on for days.
Though the melodic hallucinations formed a kernel of this inspiring composition, Symphony No 2, Schumann was drowned in a sea of musical hallucinations at the end of his life, probably related to the final stages of the syphilitic infection. That raises a question: Are musical hallucinations a ‚Äòroyal road‚Äô to a person‚Äôs unconscious creative mind or are they merely discordant notes from a disharmonious brain in disarray?

16/12/24, 9:48‚ÄØam
Confronting mortality is not an easy task. Very few musicians have ventured into this landscape and prominent among them is Mahler. He explored the vicissitudes of life and death in his masterly Second Symphony. It is a work that explores mortality and inevitably of death and ends with an affirmation of a transcendent, everlasting life. The first eight lines from the final movement were taken from the poem, ‚ÄòDie Auferstehung‚Äô, by Friedrich Gottlieb Klopstock and Mahler wrote the rest himself;
‚ÄúRise again, yes, rise again,
Will you, my dust, after a brief rest!
Immortal life! Immortal life
Will he who called you, give you.
You are sown to bloom again!
The lord of the harvest goes
And gathers sheaves,
Us, who have died.
O believe, my heart, O believe:
Nothing is lost to you!
Yours, yes yours, is what you desired
Yours, what you have loved
What you have fought for!
O believe,
You were not born for nothing!
Have not lived for nothing,
Nor suffered!
What was created
Must perish;
What perished, rise again!
Cease from trembling!
Prepare yourself to live!
O Pain, you piercer of all things,
From you, I have been wrested!
O Death, you conqueror of all things,
Now, are you conquered!
With wings which I have won for myself,
In love‚Äôs fierce striving,
I shall soar upwards
To the light which no eye has penetrated!
I shall die in order to live.
Rise again, yes, rise again,
Will you, my heart, in an instant!
That for which you suffered,
To God shall it carry you!‚Äù
(Dedicated to Ustad Zakir Hussain, whose dancing fingers on the tabla will continue to entrance us)
Do close your eyes and listen to this exceptional recording of Mahler‚Äôs 2nd symphony by Otto Klemperer.
Dr Raguram
17/12/24, 8:27‚ÄØam
I first came across the name of Kirkbride in a book tantalizingly titled, ‚ÄúMadhouses, Mad doctors and Madmen.‚Äù Kirkbride (July 31, 1809 - December 16,1883), was one of the thirteen founders of the Association of Medical Superintendents of American Asylums for the Insane (now the American Psychiatric Association), and was its president from 1862 to 1870. He was a passionate advocate of ‚Äòmoral treatment‚Äô of the insane and argued that the place where the mentally ill are placed, must further this cause. Towards this end he spent considerable amount of time to develop an architectural plan for these buildings which is often referred to as a the ‚ÄòKirkbride Plan.‚Äô
When I had a look at the ‚ÄòKirkbride Plan‚Äô I was struck by its similarity to wings of a bird! From the central administrative block two wings extend out in a staggered fashion. The idea behind was that the living quarters of the patients should have maximum light and ventilation, with high ceilings. Each ward would be a self-contained unit with all facilities under one roof. Kirkbride paid meticulous attention to each aspect of the design, including the design and placement of the windows, plan of the bathrooms and even recommending particular building materials and colours of paint. He specially emphasized that the living quarters should open into large outdoor landscape and foliage, so that all the patients could be part of it. Patients were segregated by their condition; those who were quite disturbed were kept in the pavilions furthest from the centre.
‚ÄòKirkbride Plan‚Äô was adopted in several asylums in US. Except for a few which have been declared as heritage structures, the rest have been pulled down and demolished in the era of deinstitutionalization.
Even though no mental hospitals are being built now, ‚ÄòKirkbride Plan‚Äô is a remarkable document from a certain time in history of care of the mentally ill, which emphasizes the important role of architecture in facilitating a healing environment.
Dr Raguram

Father talks about social stigma which is still rampant.
20/12/24, 9:29‚ÄØam
Cintio Vitier was a Cuban poet, essayist, and novelist, often referred to as "one of the most important writers of his generation". His abundant love of the ordinary people and his firm conviction that without roots in those people, nothing can be created, finds expression in his poems. He wrote, ‚ÄúSoul of the nation lived in the quiet suffering of the poor or middle-class family, in its capacity for resistance and hope, in its irrepressible popular laugh, in its unbeatable music, in the lamp of the intellectual, in poetry.‚Äù
‚ÄúMy words verge on silence
like great birds that disappear
into the early evening: their
strenuous white wings
carry off the intense sweetness
of dusk, visible then
in starlight.
My words turn toward the night
with no look back
at what is lost or won, or
what is missing, like those workers,
who, utterly fatigued
by a long day, return home
so the household once again can rest
and the strength that comes
with morning be restored.‚Äù
Here, the poet wonderfully transposes the metaphor of the birds with that of workers who toil tirelessly. I always feel that there are birds lurking within us, resting and finding a moment to recoup the strength to fly again and again in the vast sky of life.

Yes Sir. Thank you.

Photography

01/01/24, 1:32‚ÄØpm

03/01/24, 9:19‚ÄØam
Rudaki was a poet, singer, and musician who is regarded as the first major poet to write in New Persian. He wrote several thousand poems and unfortunately only a few survive. In Iran, Rudaki is acknowledged as the "founder of New Persian poetry" and in Tajikistan as the "father of Tajik literature". Rudaki was also an innovator of poetic form. Aside from writing in forms inherited from Arabic poetry, he is thought to be the first poet to have written in the rubaiyat form, which is a quatrain consisting of two couplets.
Interestingly he translated Panchatantra stories which gained popularity in the medieval Europe as, 'The Fables of Bidpai'. The Persian version by Rudaki is known as ‚ÄòKalileh o Demneh‚Äô.
His poetry is replete with interesting imagery and vivid description of nature. Observing the clouds one day, he wrote:
Look at that cloud,
how it cries like a grieving man,
Thunder moans like a lover with a broken heart.
Now and then the sun peeks from behind the clouds
Like a prisoner hiding from the guard.
This particular poem is about the Hoopoe. Hoopoe has had an important status in Persian literature and often considered as a guide that directs the mystics toward God. Rudaki wrote:
I saw a hoopoe near Sarakhs
Whose little song reached the clouds.
She was wearing a little cloak Of many different colors.
I stand before you in awe.
Dr Raguram
05/01/24, 10:09‚ÄØam
It was a bright morning and as we were making our way in the Coyote Hills Regional Park, we heard a loud, rattling sound. And when we looked around, a bird with bright colours under its wings caught our eyes. It perched on the outer branches of a tree, feasting on the berries. It was the Northern Flicker. As we were watching, it, hopped down onto the ground, foraging for insects. Its scientific name is Colaptes auratus. Colaptes means ‚Äúto peck.‚Äù Northern Flickers are often referred to as the ‚Äúanteaters of the sky.‚Äù Unlike other woodpeckers, which usually remain high in the treetops, Northern Flickers venture down to ground level to search for their favourite meal, ants. They are ably assisted in this task by their slightly curved bill. Their dusky brow plumage helps them to blend with the colours of the forest floor. Most woodpeckers in North America have black white stripped plumage, which helps them to blend in with tree bark. Northern Flickers stand apart and are considered the ‚Äòblack sheep‚Äô of the woodpecker family because they have brown feathers and forage for food on the ground. The Northern Flicker is one of the few North American woodpeckers that is strongly migratory.
(On the occasion of the National Birds Day which is observed on January 5 in USA to raise awareness about the role of birds in our ecosystem)
Dr Raguram
05/01/24, 1:23‚ÄØpm
Photo depicts what Rudaki observesüëå
05/01/24, 1:24‚ÄØpm
Enlightening info Sir....
06/01/24, 9:46‚ÄØam
Among the many calls that I received this New Year, I was deeply touched by a particular one. It was from a lady whom I had known for the past few years. She rang up and said, ‚ÄúDoctor let this New Year be good for you and all those who help others‚Äù. What is distinctive about the caller is that she is a crematorium worker who handles all the paper work there.
I met her a few years ago, helping a friend who had lost a family member, to fill the forms. When I was about to leave, she asked me whether I was a doctor. Hearing the affirmative answer, she shared her psychological travails which were being attended to by a dear former student. I reassured her stating that she was in good hands while emphasizing the need to be regular with treatment. She profusely thanked me and thereafter kept in touch with me periodically.
Working in a crematorium can be a daunting task, more so being a woman. At a time when the term ‚Äòstress‚Äô is flaunted widely, I was keen to know more about her and how she coped with her situation. Her answer was simple, ‚ÄúI earn a livelihood doctor, for the sake of my children, for their better future‚Äù. I gathered that her husband was a drunkard without any regular work and she had to tend for two young children, with very little support from the extended family. She works six days a week with few breaks or any holiday. At the end of a busy working day, she gets back home, has a bath and starts cooking for the night. Her husband scolds and often beats her, if by chance the food is delayed. He is also sexually demanding and if she refuses, starts suspecting her. In spite of these ordeals when I chance to see her at work, I invariably find her attending to her task with a smile on her face.
By accepting the job, she has joined a cadre of Indian women who are entering arenas from which they have traditionally been excluded. That she has chosen to work in a space with significant stigma associated with it, where even men feel uneasy to be in, is a testament to her resilience.
A plant that can teach us resilience is the bamboo. It can withstand twice as much force bearing down on it while being stretched, pulled or bent. According to a Japanese proverb: ‚ÄúIn time, even the strongest wind tires itself out, but the bamboo remains standing tall and still.‚Äù
There is an interesting Zen parable, ‚ÄòBe like a bamboo‚Äô:
A Zen Master was walking through the forest down a narrow trail with one of his students along a steep incline. The student lost his footing and slipped; just as he began tumbling down the hill, the student reached out and grabbed a small bamboo tree. The bamboo bent nearly all the way over as the student continued to hold on tightly. He pulled himself up and brushed off the dirt with the Zen Masters help.
‚ÄúDid you notice that when you fell, you grabbed a hold of the bamboo and it bent nearly all the way over and still supported you.‚Äù the Zen Master asked.
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the student replied. The Zen Master gripped the bamboo and pulled the bamboo over.
‚ÄúBe like the bamboo,‚Äù the Zen Master said as he let go of the bamboo and it sprang back to its up-right position. ‚ÄúIt is pushed around by the wind and yet it always bounces back and grows upward, toward the sun, enlightenment. Have you ever felt as though you were going to snap? Have you ever felt as though you were at your breaking point, emotionally?‚Äù
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the student replied.
‚ÄúThen bend, do not break, such is the way with bamboo. It endures the stress and finds a way to bounce back!‚Äù the Zen Master stated. ‚ÄúThis is called resilience.‚Äù
Throughout our journey in life, we meet people along the way and we connect with the heart of a few from whom we draw inspiration. They become a poem or a story in my life to live by.
Dr Raguram
09/01/24, 8:55‚ÄØam
I have a time worn book of ‚ÄòSecond Sex‚Äô by Simone de Beauvoir (whose birthday is today) and it is incredible as to how it is so relevant today, decades after its publication. Weaving together perspectives from biology, psychoanalysis, anthropology, sociology, psychology, history she narrates as to how gender demarcation came into being and women lead a life as the ‚ÄòSecond Sex‚Äô; ‚ÄúHumanity is male, and man defines woman, not in herself, but in relation to himself.‚Äù She theorizes about every phase of a woman's life, from infancy to old age, and the events outlining each phase with insight and erudition. No woman before her had written with such candour about the most intimate aspects of women. Adopting an existentialist framework, she emphasizes on the social construction of femininity. Women are not born knowing what it means to be a woman, how to behave, what jobs to do, how to feel, but are rather socialized into the role of ‚Äòwoman,‚Äô often by men; ‚ÄúOne is not born, but rather becomes, a woman.‚Äù
She concludes ‚ÄòSecond Sex‚Äô with optimistic undertones, hoping that either gender will eventually see eye to eye and accept each other as subjects and equals.
‚ÄúOn the day when it will be possible for woman to love not in her weakness but in her strength, not to escape herself but to find herself, not to abase herself but to assert herself on that day love will become for her, as for man, a source of life and not of mortal danger.‚Äù
It is an important read in these times when there is an attempt to define the role of women according to staid ideologies.
Dr Raguram
10/01/24, 9:05‚ÄØam
I had posted yesterday about Simone de Beauvoir‚Äôs ‚ÄòSecond Sex‚Äô, wherein she urges women to
have the freedom to escape from prescribed social roles and seek their own identity. This perspective has been articulated well in many works of fiction. Daisy Rockwell's translation of Geetanjali Shree's Hindi novel ‚ÄòRet Samadhi‚Äô ‚Äò‚Äô‡§∞‡•á‡§§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‚Äô which I read some time ago, is one such engaging narrative. It traces the life trajectory of a woman who is recently bereaved and her journey to discover aspects of self that were deeply buried within her.
The strength of any work of fiction is that it can be read at different layers, each with its own attendant meaning. Grief after a loss of a partner has been essayed in many novels. Usually it follows a predictable path, focusing on the loss and its emotional impact within the individual. What is different in this work is the broader narration of separation and loss in the historical context of partition and the quest of the protagonist to seek her personal identity embedded in it.
The novel is tale of transformative powers of crossing the ‚Äòborders‚Äô, of geography, gender and prescriptive roles, reaffirming that the inner landscape has no borders. ‚ÄúAnything worth doing transcends borders‚Äù.
The protagonist‚Äôs travel is also a journey into her own self, opening doors of discovery. In her words, ‚ÄúAlways, at least once, every woman, whether this one or that one, whether small or big, finds herself at the door, one foot poised in the air, like a dancer striking a mudra, a pose, in order to re-enter the home or that door which she has renounced and already left far behind, asking herself in that moment, Is this my world in which I‚Äôm setting foot, or is it that which is receding behind me, where I had gone, or whence I‚Äôve come?‚Äù
As for the story, ‚ÄúOnce you‚Äôve got women and a border, a story can write itself. Even women on their own are enough. Women are stories in themselves, full of stirrings and whisperings that float on the wind, that bend with each blade of grass.‚Äù
There is extensive use of metaphors like doors and windows. ‚Äúthere was a painter, Bhupen Khakkar. He told stories with brush‚Ä¶He knew that a story cannot be locked into a box, or a canvas, or a gaze. So he never tried. On the contrary, he always left a small window, an empty space, so the story could move on at will and take another path if it so desired. Because stories never end. They jump through windows and cracks‚Ä¶or create them by shaking, causing the earth to quake"
The novel is replete with lyrical passages, like this one, ‚ÄúMa sips her morning tea as though drinking in a bird‚Äôs song‚Äù.
All together a fascinating read!
Dr Raguram
11/01/24, 10:23‚ÄØam
William James (whose birthday is today), is most famous for his psychology textbook,‚Äô Principles of Psychology‚Äô which was published in 1890. It consisted of two volumes with over 1400 pages and took him 12 years to write. He did not produce any original research, did not perform any experiment, yet he became the driving force behind psychology.
Of the many topics he addressed during his life time, he is most famous for his theories about emotions and consciousness. Concerning emotions, James believed that a person is exposed to a stimulus, has a physiological reaction, and then interprets that reaction as emotion. So, first comes physiological arousal, then the subjective interpretation of those processes as emotion. An independent researcher in Denmark, Carl Lange, developed a similar theory of emotion at roughly the same time as James did. Their view of emotion came to be known as the James-Lange theory of emotion. Though it was later thought not to be an accurate theory of how emotions work, its framework was quite influential in drawing attention to the interaction between physiological processes and emotion.
William James also conceptualized consciousness as a river or a stream, constantly changing and never the same. He had an abiding interest in religion and faith. He believed that divine existence can be justified by the emotional benefits it brings to one‚Äôs life. His book ‚ÄòThe Varieties of Religious Experience: a study in human nature‚Äô, examines varied forms of religious experiences such as mystical experiences, conversion, saintliness, and spirituality from a psychological perspective. I was quite surprised to learn that the emphasis given in Alcoholic Anonymous is largely due to the influence of this book. It seems that when Bill, a co-founder of AA, was trying to fight his way back to sobriety, chanced upon a copy of the book and was deeply impressed by James' "great wisdom." It also helped Bill to finally achieve sobriety and the impact of the book can be seen in the formulation of AA's basic ideas.
James was an inspiring teacher. His students included such luminaries as Theodore Roosevelt, author and philosopher George Santayana and Gertrude Stein.
I particularly like this observation of his, ‚ÄúA great many people think they are thinking when they are merely rearranging their prejudices.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
11/01/24, 10:46‚ÄØpm
Wonderful photograph with apt caption. It is so much like what advaita says. The last statement is so very true, rearranging their prejudices....
13/01/24, 10:01‚ÄØam
In my forays into the Zen landscape, I discovered the poetry of Ryokan. His poems are direct and unpretentious, infused with profound insights. For example, he wrote:
The rain has stopped, the clouds have drifted away,
and the weather is clear again.
If your heart is pure, then all things in your world are pure.
Abandon this fleeting world, abandon yourself,
Then the moon and flowers will guide you along the Way.
He is reported to have led a live of extreme simplicity. He showed love for all living things to the extent of placing lice under his robes to keep them warm, allowing thieves to take freely from his possessions, and letting one leg protrude from his mosquito net at night to give the mosquitos food. As a Zen priest, he never established his own temple, and lived by alms. Instead of preaching, he enjoyed companionship and conversation with many ordinary people. His practice consisted of sitting in zazen meditation, walking in the woods, playing with children, making his daily begging rounds, reading, writing poetry and on occasion drinking sake with friends. He was adept in calligraphy and was also known as one of Japan's great calligraphers.
He was deeply influenced by the teachings of Dogen, the 13th century monk, about whom I wrote sometime back. Ryokan never published a collection of verse while he was alive. One of his last verses reads;
Life is like a dewdrop,
Empty and fleeting;
My years are gone
And now, quivering and frail,
I must fade away.
As Rabindranath Tagore wrote, ‚ÄúLet your life lightly dance on the edges of Time like dew on the tip of a life.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
13/01/24, 11:04‚ÄØpm
One can literally smell the fragrance in nature in this photographüëå And he himself appears to be a realised soul. Life is so fragile but we don't want to acknowledge that.
15/01/24, 10:18‚ÄØpm

18/01/24, 8:28‚ÄØam
Most us would have read ‚ÄòWinnie the Pooh‚Äô by AA Milne (whose birthday is today). He wrote seven novels, five nonfiction books and 34 plays, along with numerous stories and articles. But ‚ÄòWinnie the Pooh‚Äô which was published in 1926, eclipsed and erased the memory of his other works. It featured characters based on his son, who was the inspiration for Pooh‚Äôs best friend, Christopher Robin and his stuffed animal toys. The Hundred Acre Woods, where Pooh‚Äôs adventures take place, was based on the 500 Acre Woods near Milne‚Äôs home.
A few years after Winnie-the-Pooh was published, Milne began to resent the fame that it brought on him and his family. He stated, ‚ÄúI feel that Christopher Robin has already had more publicity than I want for him. I do not want CR Milne to ever wish that his name was Charles Robert.‚Äù His son also disliked this attention, as the legacy of Christopher Robin and Pooh Bear followed him all throughout his life, making it difficult for him to make a name as his own person. In his memoir, ‚ÄòThe Enchanted Place‚Äô, he wrote, ‚ÄúIn pessimistic moments, when I was trudging London in search of an employer wanting to make use of such talents as I could offer, it seemed to me, almost, that my father had got to where he was by climbing upon my infant shoulders, that he had filched from me my good name and had left me with nothing but the empty fame of being his son.‚Äù
Strangely, there have been several attempts to ban the book. In 2009, Russian authorities banned it for being pro-Nazi, after an image of Pooh with a swastika was discovered amongst an extremist‚Äôs collection. In the United Kingdom, the book was banned from public schools, as the character Piglet might offend Muslim and Jewish students who abstain from pork for religious reasons. And in 2017, the Chinese government began censoring Winnie the Pooh on social media platforms after critics used the character to mock Xi Jinping and his policies.
What is more galling is the attempt to identify psychiatric disorders among the characters in the book. In 2000, paediatrician Sarah Shea and her team released a journal article titled ‚ÄúPathology in the Hundred Acre Wood: a neurodevelopmental perspective on A.A. Milne.‚Äù It proposed that each of the Winnie-the-Pooh characters displayed symptoms of a different mental disorder. Unfortunately this trend caught on and there have been several attempts in this vein over the years.
In spite of all this, ‚ÄòWinnie the Pooh‚Äô resonates with people of all ages due to its relatable characters and heart-warming stories, addressing themes such as friendship, love, and the pursuit of happiness.
"Sometimes, if you stand on the bottom rail of a bridge and lean over to watch the river slipping slowly away beneath you, you will suddenly know everything there is to be known" Pooh.
Dr Raguram
19/01/24, 7:53‚ÄØam
When I look at a painting by Paul Cezanne (whose birthday is today), I am attracted to his innovative use of colour, particularly its relationship with form. His visual language is uniquely personal. There is a magical quality in his canvases which are replete with use of multitude of colours and distinctive brush strokes. He explored an amazing range of subjects throughout his career: landscape, portraiture, figures and still life. I am particularly fond of his still life paintings. In the hands of an unimaginative artist, still life can be quite stilted, but not in Cezanne‚Äôs hands. He was particularly drawn into painting fruits, particularly apples which take on an inexplicable lustrous luminosity in his paintings. He confided to a friend that "they [fruits] love having their portraits done. They exhale their message with their scent. They reach you with all their smells and tell you about the fields they‚Äôve left, the rain that made them grow, the dawns they watched. When I‚Äôm outlining the skin of a lovely peach with soft touches of paint, or a sad old apple, I catch a glimpse in the reflections they exchange of . . . the same love of the sun, the same recollection of the dew, a freshness."
How should one look at his paintings? In his own words, ‚ÄúShut your eyes, wait, and think of nothing. Now, open them ‚Ä¶ one sees nothing but a great coloured undulation. What then? An irradiation and glory of colour. This is what a picture should give us ‚Ä¶ an abyss in which the eye is lost, a secret germination, a coloured state of grace ‚Ä¶ loose consciousness. Descend with the painter into the dim tangled roots of things, and rise again from them in colours, be steeped in the light of them.‚Äù
Now look at Cezanne‚Äôs apples and see them come alive!
Dr Raguram
20/01/24, 7:01‚ÄØam
You cannot miss the European Robin when you take a stroll in the gardens of London. unlike its counterpart in America, it is a colourful bird with a striking orange breast. As you watch, it makes forays to the ground to catch insects and quickly flies back to its shady perch. The French naturalist Georges Cuvie gave the bird its current name Erithacus rubecula. The epithet rubecula is derived from the Latin, ruber ‚Äòred‚Äô.
The Victorian postmen used to be known as robins because part of their tunic was orange red. When Christmas cards first came into vogue they were brought by robins! And robins started featuring in the in the Christmas cards too.
There is a wealth of Christian mythology associated with it. The legend is that the robin was moved when it saw Christ on the cross and began to pluck the thorns out of the crown of thorns. The blood stained the robin and hence its orange red breast. According to an Irish tale, a robin flew in to see the infant Jesus in the manger. The infant reached out to touch the bird causing it to blush in deference and hence its colour!
Shakespeare refers to the charming song of the European Robin in Two Gentlemen of Verona.
Valentine: Why, how know you that I am in love?
Speed: Marry, by these special marks: first, you have learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms like a malcontent; to relish a love song like a robin redbreast; to walk alone like one that had the pestilence; to sigh like a schoolboy that had lost his ABC; to weep like a young wench that had buried her grandam; to fast like one that takes diet; to watch like one that fears robbing; to speak puling like a beggar at Hallowmas.
Emily Dickinson wrote a lovely small poem about it:
If I can stop one heart from breaking,
I shall not live in vain;
If I can ease one life the aching,
Or cool one pain,
Or help one fainting robin
Unto his nest again,
I shall not live in vain.
It is believed that when a robin appears, it is a sign that a loved one is near.
Dr Raguram
21/01/24, 8:55‚ÄØam
It is always so wonderful to see the Malabar Giant Squirrel prancing from one tree branch to another. It will pause for a while to eat fruits with its tiny hands and scramble to the upper reaches of the canopy in a flash of a second. The multi-coloured magician is adept in nimbly disappearing without a trace. They build their nests, called dreys, in close proximity to each other and use them as decoys to fool predators. The joy of observing them up close is truly memorable.
I had my first glimpse of it several decades ago in Bandipur. I had gone with a group of students and when we ventured into the forest, I heard a very unusual call. As I was scouting to locate its source with the binocular, I was delighted to find to find the Malabar Giant Squirrel in the upper reaches of a tree a few hundred feet away. Overjoyed to sight it, I passed the binoculars around so that others could see it. While they were engrossed watching it, I turned back and was shocked to find a lone tusker not too far away. I gently tapped them and whispered, ‚ÄúHey, there is a tusker here‚Äù, only to be meet with a response, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt joke Sir‚Äù. Their reaction soon turned into alarm when they turned around and saw the tusker. Overwhelmed with increasing fright, we all gave a loud shout and ran for our lives. Catching up with my breath after some time, when I looked back, I saw the tusker turning its back and making its way into the forest.
Oblivious to this drama, the Giant Squirrel was foraging amongst the branches of tree with sheer abandon at a distance.
(Incidentally 21st January, is a Squirrel Appreciation Day!)
Dr Raguram
23/01/24, 9:11‚ÄØam
Sometime back we visited Avani in Kolar district (a detailed description is at: (https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/avani). Avani attained prominence due to myriad legends associated with it. Most importantly, it is said to be the site of Uttara Ramayana. There is a small beautiful, Ramalingeshwara temple which dates back to 10th century. A hillock strewn with boulders forms an interesting backdrop to this ancient temple. It is believed that Sita retreated to this hill after her trial by fire and gave birth to Lava and Kusha who grew up in the hermitage of Valmiki. There are several caves; one of them is considered to be Valmiki‚Äôs ashram and another one where Sita lived and cooked for her children.
I was keen to find out whether there are other places identified as Sita‚Äôs Kitchen. To my great surprise, I discovered that there are several Sita‚Äôs Rasoi (kitchen) dotted across the subcontinent. At least two of Sita‚Äôs kitchens have been documented in Ayodhya, but only one survived the demolition of the Babri Masjid. I understand that within the complex on the Ramkot in Ayodhya, there is a building bearing the painted phrase ‚ÄúJanmasthana Sita Rasoi‚Äù (Birthplace Sita‚Äôs Kitchen). The garbhagriha contains a rolling board, rolling pin, chulha and an image of Sita.
When I searched for other ‚ÄòSita‚Äôs Rasois‚Äô, I found documentation of several others: Lalapur near Allahabad, Chitrakoot, Brahmavarta in UP and Nasik in Maharashtra amongst others. Each one of them is adjacent to Valmiki‚Äôs ashram and similarly contain a rolling pin, board and a chulha.
I also looked for mention of Sita and her kitchen in many of the Ramayanas. There were none. An array of localized narratives and memories associated with Sita and her kitchen seemed to have evolved over time across the country. It would be a fascinating exercise to explore how these memories of the past have been constructed, celebrated and sometimes politically appropriated too.
While Rama is valorised and huge temples are built to honour him, for some inexplicable reason, Sita has been relegated and confined to the kitchen. Is her power and authority confined to the kitchen alone? Cooking, to a large extent has been embedded in the patriarchal construction of femininity. If the kitchen is a feminine abode, it might also be a site of resistance.
In the animated film, ‚ÄòSita Sings The Blues‚Äô, Nina Paley relocates her as a woman who retells her own story in her own voice in an altogether different context. Sita‚Äôs songs not only give her a voice.
Perhaps it is time to retell the Ramayana from the perspective of Sita.
Dr Raguram

Such a chubby bird! And so many nice tales about it!
