I didn't know Lava and Kusha were born in Karnataka! Valmiki didn't stay in one place but the place where they were born is in the north. In Valmiki Ramayana there are many situations where her strengths, importance, judgment are highlighted. Actually Laksmana was the one who took the responsibility of looking after the welfare like constructing ashrams, getting fruits etc. May be cooking she did as part of her dutyüòä
28/01/24, 10:12‚ÄØam
One of the birds I closely observed during my forays in the vast, arid lands of Rann of Kutch was the sleek, powerful, fast flying Peregrine Falcon. I observed it making sorties with tremendous speed, caressing the wind with an agile grace. It was exploring the boundless sky with unfettered freedom.
After my return, I read WB Yeats famous poem, ‚ÄòThe Second Coming‚Äô. Yeats wrote this poem after World War I, a global catastrophe that killed millions of people. The First World War unleashed humanity‚Äôs power to harm and kill, a trend that has gotten worse with the advent of the nuclear power. The poem is replete with lots of Biblical allusions. Beyond this, to me personally, the first stanza of the poem with its potent images, perceptively describes the plight of our civilization. The ‚Äúfalconer,‚Äù representing our attempt to control the natural world, has lost its ‚Äúfalcon‚Äù in the ever expanding ‚Äúgyre‚Äù (of progress?). The poet alludes to an evolving situation when "Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold."
‚ÄúThe falcon cannot hear the falconer;
Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold;
Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world,
The blood-dimmed tide is loosed, and everywhere
The ceremony of innocence is drowned;
The best lack all conviction, while the worst
Are full of passionate intensity.‚Äù
Though written decades ago, these lines, imbued with timeless allegory, resonate even now,

A fantastic photograph so serene unlike the ups and downs of life. So True life is but a dream but we don't seem to be aware that it is....
01/02/24, 8:04‚ÄØam
Every time I step into the bronze gallery of the Chennai museum, I am overwhelmed by the sheer beauty of the priceless exhibits encompassed in its glass display cases. The most impressive pieces are that of Siva as the cosmic dancer, Nataraja.
Whenever I look at them, I recollect the words of Fritjof Capra, (whose birthday is today),in ‚ÄòThe Tao of Physics‚Äô, relating the Nataraja‚Äôs dance with modern physics:
‚ÄúEvery subatomic particle not only performs an energy dance, but also is an energy dance; a pulsating process of creation and destruction‚Ä¶without end‚Ä¶For the modern physicists then, Shiva‚Äôs dance is the dance of subatomic matter. As in Hindu mythology, it is a continual dance of creation and destruction involving the whole cosmos; the basis of all existence and of all natural phenomena...the metaphor of the cosmic dance thus unifies ancient mythology, religious art and modern physics.‚Äù
He went on to comment, ‚ÄúThe mystic and the physicist arrive at the same conclusion; one starting from the inner realm, the other from the outer world. The harmony between their views confirms the ancient Indian wisdom that Brahman, the ultimate reality without, is identical to Atman, the reality within.‚Äù
In the words of Appar, the seventh century Shaivaite poet saint, who went to Chidambaram to see the cosmic dance of Siva,
‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øä‡Æµ‡Øç‡Æµ‡Øà‡Æö‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡Æµ‡Øç‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Æø‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æö‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æø‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç
‡Æ™‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æö‡Æü‡Øà‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Øá‡Æ©‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æµ‡ØÜ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡ØÄ‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç
‡Æá‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æü‡Øà‡ÆØ ‡Æé‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ™‡Øä‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ§‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ£‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç
‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Æø‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æ§‡Øá ‡Æá‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Øá
‚ÄúIf you could see
the arch of his brow
the budding smile
on his lips red as the kovvai fruit
cool matted hair
the milk-white ash on coral skin
and the golden foot raised up in dance
our birth on this earth is fulfilled‚Äù
In sculptures, paintings and verses, Nataraja continues to dance...beyond time.
Dr Raguram
02/02/24, 8:19‚ÄØam
It was a breezy early morning and I was standing on the banks of a large swathes of wetland. The air resonated with myriad calls of birds that inhabited the vast terrain. I was totally amazed at the wide variety of birds in front of me. Suddenly, I noticed a flash of light and it was the bronze winged jacana. The early morning sun was caressing its beautiful plumage with lustrous hues. It was foraging on the aquatic vegetation, daintily balancing itself on the water with its long feet and toes, with the elegance of a ballerina.These wetlands provide crucial breeding, nesting and feeding habitats for countless numbers of birds.
Wetlands and human beings are all part of a delicate and interconnected ecosystem.They play a vital role in treating and detoxifying a variety of waste products and are often described as earth‚Äôs kidneys. In addition, through sequestering and releasing a major portion of fixed carbon they are important regulators of global climate change.
February 2nd of each year is observed globally as World Wetlands Day to raise awareness about the value of wetlands for nature and society. The theme this year is ‚Äòwetlands and human wellbeing.‚Äô It emphasizes how all aspects of human well-being are linked to the health of the world‚Äôs wetlands and calls on each of us to value their importance.
While it is heartening to notice that three new wetlands are added to the Ramsar sites in Karnatka, it is equally saddening to witness increasing habitat fragmentation, polluting runoff and invasive species that plague the wetlands especially in rapidly urbanizing areas, like Bangalore.
As Sandra Postel, a renowned expert on freshwater ecosystems cautioned, ‚ÄúFor many of us, water simply flows from a faucet, and we think little about it beyond this point of contact. We have lost a sense of respect for the wild river, for the complex workings of a wetland, for the intricate web of life that water supports‚Äù
Dr Raguram.
04/02/24, 9:45‚ÄØam
One of the earliest writings of J Krishnamurti was 'The Song of Life' which was published in 1931. It is a profound, thought provoking work, offering deep insights about JK as a seeker and a poet. The final lines of the poem are in this photograph and I have taken the liberty to quote it in its entirety;
I have no name;
I am as the fresh breeze of the mountains.
I have no shelter;
I am as the wandering waters.
I have no sanctuary, like the dark gods;
Nor am I in the shadow of deep temples.
I have no sacred books;
Nor am I well-seasoned in tradition.
I am not in the incense burning upon the high altars;
Nor in the pomp of ceremonies.
I am neither in the graven image;
Nor in the rich chant of a melodious voice.
I am not bound by theories;
Nor corrupted by beliefs.
I am not held in the bondage of religions;
Nor in the pious agony of their priests.
I am not entrapped by philosophies;
Nor held in the power of their sects.
I am neither low nor high;
I am the worshipper and the worshipped.
I am free.
My song is the song of the river calling for the open seas;
Wandering, wandering;

06/02/24, 8:59‚ÄØam
Farid ud-Din Attar was considered by Rumi to be ‚Äúthe master of sufi poetry‚Äù. The ‚ÄúConference of the Birds‚Äù by him is an engaging parable about the mystical quest for the Truth. It features a host of birds led by the hoopoe, who acts as their spiritual guide in their quest. In their journey, the birds travel through the seven valleys of the quest, love, understanding, independence and detachment, unity, astonishment, and finally to a state of nothingness. In this allegorical text, many of us can locate ourselves amidst these different valleys.
Let us strive to head to the words of the Hoopoe;
‚ÄúThe ocean can be yours; why should you stop
Beguiled by dreams of evanescent dew?‚Äù
Dr Raguram
07/02/24, 10:24‚ÄØam
Ursula Le Guin‚Äôs poem LEAVES is a deeply reflective poem about ageing..
LEAVES
Years do odd things to identity.
What does it mean to say
I am that child in the photograph
at Kishamish in 1935?
Might as well say I am the shadow
of a leaf of the acacia tree
felled seventy years ago
moving on the page the child reads.
Might as well say I am the words she read
or the words I wrote in other years,
flicker of shade and sunlight
as the wind moves through the leaves.

11/02/24, 8:50‚ÄØam
London is full of blue plaques. They dot the walls of buildings throughout London, marking the places where scientists, artists, politicians and activists who lived and worked there. When I was on a Commonwealth Fellowship, I made it a point to visit as many of them. One address I was keen to locate was No 1, Fitzroy Road where WB Yeats lived for a while. It was also the building where Sylvia Plath, a poet whom I admire deeply, spent her last days before ending her life on February 11th 1963.
Poets die young and not so often by suicide. Perhaps the act of writing poetry fascinates the wounded and in the process also opens up fresh wounds. Syvia Plath was no exception. In her thinly veiled autobiographical novel, ‚ÄòBell Jar‚Äô, she wrote, ‚ÄúDeath must be so beautiful. To lie in the soft brown earth, with the grasses waving above one's head, and listen to silence. To have no yesterday, and no to-morrow. To forget time, to forgive life, to be at peace‚Äù. Pensive by disposition, she kept ruminating about it, which found expression in these lines which she wrote ten days before ending her life:
‚ÄúThe blood jet is poetry,
There is no stopping it‚Äù.
There are a multitude of ways in which Sylvia Plath‚Äôs life and her final act has been analyzed and debated. Beyond these lenses of scrutiny her existential angst was enmeshed in a troubled past and a tumultuous relationship with her husband Ted Hughes. Perhaps the most insightful and poignant account about Syliva Plath‚Äôs suicide was by her friend A Alvarez in his book, ‚ÄòThe Savage God‚Äô, which we reviewed in NIMHANS in the late 70s. In the first page of the book, there is a quote by Cesare Pavese, regarded as one of Italy's most important twentieth-century poets, which says it all:"No one ever lacks a good reason for suicide."
Dr Raguram
12/02/24, 8:08‚ÄØam
In a series of groundbreaking studies conducted in the late 1930s, psychologist Kurt Lewin (who was born on this day), identified three core styles of leadership; Authoritarian (autocratic) leadership. Participative (democratic) leadership and Delegative (laissez-faire) leadership.
Over the past decade we are witnessing the rise of populist, authoritarian, strong-man politicians across the globe. Its seductive appeal necessitates a detailed sociological enquiry! However, a political leadership that rules on the basis of fear, threat, intimidation, and advocating one worldview as superior while silencing diversity of opinions and dissent is in my opinion will lead to fragmentation of society. Unfortunately an authoritarian world view is not confined to the political arena. It seeps into and influences people's attitudes, impacts institutional ethos in centres of learning and more importantly, festers lack of trust. The more we portray the ‚Äòothers‚Äô as threat, the greater the harm to the fabric that binds and holds us all together.
The harmful impact of authoritarian attitude in a leader is accentuated once it is tinged with narcissistic traits, resulting in an overwhelming need for control with an inflated sense of self-worth. They strongly adhere to the belief that they should be in charge and expect others to conform to their views and desires, often holding people with differing viewpoints in contempt. These leaders insist on strict conformity to their beliefs and tend to view the world in binary terms; you are either with them or against them. This black-and-white perspective creates a hostile environment where individuals are categorized as friends or foes based on their willingness to conform. Such a rigid stance stifles open dialogue and learning from others.
As George Orwell observed presciently in 1984, it leads to ‚Äúprocessions, meetings, military parades, lectures, waxwork displays, film shows, telescreen programs all had to be organized; stands had to be erected, effigies built, slogans coined, songs written, rumours circulated, photographs faked.‚Äù
13/02/24, 8:35‚ÄØam
Sarojini Naidu, born on 13th February 1879, was one of the most outstanding figures of the independence movement. An equally talented poet in English, she was known as ‚ÄúThe Nightingale of India‚Äù. Her poetry brims with strong emotions expressed in lyrical verses. An ardent admirer of nature, she was also a great lover of birds.
I am particularly drawn (given my passion for them!) to her poem ‚ÄòBird of Time‚Äô, wherein she expresses the workings of time through the movements of a bird. Just as we don‚Äôt expect a bird to be still, time too is fleeting. Life and death, sorrow and hope, time encompasses them all in this poem.
BIRD OF TIME
O Bird of Time on your fruitful bough
What are the songs you sing? ‚Ä¶
Songs of the glory and gladness of life,
Of poignant sorrow and passionate strife,
And the lilting joy of the spring;
Of hope that sows for the years unborn,
And faith that dreams of a tarrying morn,
The fragrant peace of the twilight‚Äôs breath,
And the mystic silence that men call death.
O Bird of Time, say where did you learn
The changing measures you sing? ‚Ä¶
In blowing forests and breaking tides,
In the happy laughter of new-made brides,
And the nests of the new-born spring;
In the dawn that thrills to a mother‚Äôs prayer,
And the night that shelters a heart‚Äôs despair,
In the sigh of pity, the sob of hate,
And the pride of a soul that has conquered fate.
In one of last letters she wrote, ‚Äù While I live, it will always be the supreme desire of my Soul to write poetry ‚Äîone poem, one line of enduring verse even. Perhaps I shall die without realising that longing which is at once an exquisite joy and an unspeakable anguish to me‚Äù.

Thank you Sir for sharing the life and work of so many poets. It is really a feast, like the fantastic bird which you have caught enjoying the bead like fruits!!
15/02/24, 8:58‚ÄØam

16/02/24, 8:39‚ÄØam
Nicheren (February 16, 1222 - November 14, 1282) was one of the most influential Japanese priests who preached tenets of Mahayana Buddhism. An important sutra of Mahayana Buddhism is the ‚ÄòLotus Sutra‚Äô which was written between 100 B.C. and 200 A.D. Already well known in India, it became one of the important sutras of Chinese Buddhism and later in Japan..
It is named the ‚ÄòLotus Sutra‚Äô because the lotus symbolises the oneness of cause and effect since the lotus is a flower that blooms and seeds at the same time. Moreover, it also signifies the purity of Buddhahood, blooming in the midst of our ordinary lives just as the lotus blossoms in muddy pond water. What the ‚ÄòLotus Sutra‚Äô essentially emphasizes is that all living beings, whether they realize it or not, have the capacity to become enlightened. Everyone, without exception, can unlock the perfect wisdom and great compassion that reside in the depths of life.
Nichiren established the practice of reciting the ‚ÄòLotus Sutra's‚Äô title,‚Äù Nam-myoho-renge-kyo‚Äù, to make the path to enlightenment accessible to all. It is no ordinary phrase and is the essence of the entire ‚ÄòLotus Sutra‚Äô. The phrase "Namu-myoho-renge-kyo" literally translates to "I take refuge in the Lotus of the Wonderful Law". Nam: Comes from the Sanskrit word namas, which means to devote or dedicate oneself. Myo: is usually translated as wonderful. Ho: Means law. Renge, meaning lotus blossom. The lotus flower is pure and fragrant, unsullied by the muddy water in which it grows. Similarly, the beauty and dignity of our humanity is brought forth amidst the sufferings of daily lives. Kyo literally means sutra. Chanting the mantra is called daimoku. The purpose of chanting daimoku is to attain perfect and complete awakening. It is an expression of determination, to embrace and realize our Buddha nature. Nichiren taught that to chant ‚ÄúNam-myoho-renge-kyo‚Äù is to bring forth the Buddhahood that exists inherently within all of us.
Dr Raguram
18/02/24, 8:26‚ÄØam
Another book I had picked up those days at Easwari lending library was the novel ‚ÄòZorba the Greek‚Äô. Much like ‚ÄòThe Chosen‚Äô, it is the story of two men: Zorba, a Greek working man and a wealthy, young narrator and their incredible friendship. The two of them couldn‚Äôt be further apart. The narrator is cerebral, modest, and reserved; Zorba is unfettered and spirited.The younger man reads all day. He‚Äôs an aficionado of Buddhist philosophy, the exact opposite world view of Zorba who has such lust for life. These two characters represent two distinct ways of life. The implicit question throughout the book: which is better? Being a ‚Äústable‚Äù person and being accepted and respected in society, or being an indulgent person living his life full. Both are searching for answers. The Narrator has a desire to change, but he adamantly resists Zorba‚Äôs philosophy, despite admitting to admiring it and wishing he could assimilate it with his own. The relationship between these two characters symbolizes the conversation between the head and the heart, the mind and the spirit, what Nietzsche referred to as the Apollonian and the Dionysian impulses. Kazantzakis masterfully interweaves these dual perspectives of human nature. The book is also an important reminder to embrace the transience of life, to seize the moments that bring us joy, unfettered by intellectual curiosity. A passage in the book by the narrator illustrates this perspective:
‚ÄúI remember one morning when I discovered a cocoon in the back of a tree just as a butterfly was making a hole in its case and preparing to come out. I waited a while, but it was too long appearing and I was impatient. I bent over it and breathed on it to warm it. I warmed it as quickly as I could and the miracle began to happen before my eyes faster than life. The case opened; the butterfly started slowly crawling out, and I shall never forget my horror when I saw how its wings were folded back and crumpled; the wretched butterfly tried with its whole trembling body to unfold them. Bending over it, I tried to help it with my breath, in vain. It needed to be hatched out patiently and the unfolding of the wings should be a gradual process in the sun. Now it was too late. My breath had forced the butterfly to appear all crumpled, before its time. It struggled desperately and, a few seconds later, died in the palm of my hand. That little body is, I do believe, the greatest weight I have on my conscience. For, I realize today that it is a mortal sin to violate great laws of nature. We should not hurry, we should not be impatient, but we should confidently obey the external rhythm‚Äù.
A viewpoint summarized in the gravestone of the author, Nikos Kazantzakis,"I hope for nothing. I fear nothing. I am free."
(And who can forget Anthony Quinn bringing the most life-affirming character of Zorba alive in the movie version of the book with the Zorba the Greek song brimming with life?)
Dr Raguram
20/02/24, 8:28‚ÄØam
When I visited Yosemite sometime ago, I felt overwhelmed with the enormous expanse of its enchanting landscape. It was much like losing myself in a vast heritage temple which was built aeons ago. I felt humbled in the presence of its towering granite cliffs, lush meadows, forested valleys and dramatic seasonal waterfalls. It was a mystical experience.
One person who brought out its magical realm in tangible ways for us to relish was Anselm Adams, whose birthday is today. Yosemite was Ansel Adam‚Äôs muse.When he looked through his camera lens, he saw more than it's rocks, trees, and rivers. He saw art. Adams explored and recorded the grandeur of nature in stunning black and white photographs,conveying its beauty in lyrical ways. His elegant compositions with tantalizing play of light across its incredible terrain exude a certain sense of calmness.
As Adams observed, ‚ÄúThe whole world is, to me, very much alive, all the little growing things, even the rocks‚Ä¶I can‚Äôt look at a swell bit of grass and earth, for instance, without feeling the essential life, the things going on, within them‚Äù.
I put myself in Adam‚Äôs shoes, when I stood in front of the half dome, where he has taken many of his stunning photographs and froze that moment in this frame

22/02/24, 8:06‚ÄØam
Takahama Kyoshi (born on 22nd February1874) was a great haiku poet in the history of modern Japanese haiku literature. He wrote more than two hundred thousand haikus in his lifetime.
He defined haiku as the poetry of ‚Äòka-cho-fuhei‚Äô, literally meaning ‚Äúan elegant way of describing bird and flower‚Äù. Not surprisingly then, nature in all manifestations figure prominently in his haikus.
One day Kyoshi was sweeping his garden, trying to get rid of cobwebs. To his great dismay, when he returned later, he found another spider had spun a new web. Though annoyed for a second, he realized that it is the natural behaviour of the spider to keep spinning webs. In a moment, he identified with the spider. He himself has to keep creating haiku as long as he lives, much like the spider. That's the call and beauty of life.
And he sat down and wrote this beautiful haiku:
‚ÄúBorn as a spider
No choice but to spin
His spider web‚Äù
The spider is aware that the web it spins will not last long. Yet it doesn‚Äôt tire itself in spinning one. The cadence of our existence is in lending an ear to the melody of life‚Äôs ephemeral quality and embracing it.
In the timeless words of Gulzar:
‚Äú‡§Ü‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§™‡§≤ , ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§π‡•à
‡§π‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡•ã ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç
‡§ú‡§º‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ã
‡§™‡§≤ ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‚Äù
Dr Raguram
23/02/24, 8:44‚ÄØam
For a long time I shied away reading, ‚ÄòThe Rise and Fall of the Third Reich‚Äô, as the very thought of reading about a misanthropic, racist, megalomaniac ruler who caused so much human misery, was sheer anathema for me.
I dipped into the book several years later. Usually I read books at a stretch, but not with this voluminous one spread over a thousand pages.
Once I finished reading it, my first thought was one of appreciation about the author, William Shirer, whose birthday is today. A talented journalist, he had interviewed Mahatma Gandhi several times and wrote an interesting book about these encounters.
But nothing prepared him for the demonic, spellbinding charisma he witnessed when he took up residence in Berlin in 1934 where he began to chronicle the rise of the Third Reich under Adolf Hitler. His contempt is not for Hitler so much as for the ‚Äúlittle men of German‚Äù, for the culture that acceded to Hitler and Nazism so readily
Charlemagne is often considered as Germany‚Äôs First Reich. He was followed by the Second Reich, Bismarck who felt betrayed by the supposed treachery of Jews. When all of Germany was awaiting the Third Reich as a saviour, Adolf Hitler stepped in.
Shirer is mainly concerned with charting the rise to power of this ruthless man, how he bullied and threatened his way to convince a large population, which was unreflectively taken by his promise of a ‚ÄòThousand Year Reich‚Äô, which only lasted a total of 12 years, 4 months, and 8 days. But during that brief span it wrought havoc and destruction on a scale never witnessed before, that resulted in their own ruin.
Shirer is no historian. As he observed, ‚ÄúJournalism is the first draft of history‚Äù, His scrutinizing lens is that of an observant journalist. There is no overarching historical explanation of the Third Reich, but a rich account of its rise and fall.
The book is a reminder that there is danger in giving up our sense of selfhood for the illusory unity of a frenzied mass movement, championed by a narcissistic, charismatic leader.
Couple of quotes to reflect upon from the book:
‚ÄúThe broad masses of a population are more amenable to the appeal of rhetoric than to any other force‚Äù.
‚ÄúWith a shrewdness that never deserted him Hitler carefully calculated the precipitation of one crisis upon another so that he was always moving in the driver's seat at the center of the stage‚Äù.
‚ÄúThe most dangerous people in the world are not those who carry guns and bombs, but those who carry blind hatred in their hearts‚Äù.
And lastly:
‚ÄúDoubt is the beginning of wisdom‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
24/02/24, 8:05‚ÄØam
Sometime ago I had posted about the intriguing interface between the private and the public self.
Jorge Luis Borges, whom I admire deeply, wrote the shortest of short stories, ‚ÄòBorges and I‚Äô. It is a fascinating read, raising an interesting question, ‚ÄúIs Borges the man or Borges the writer‚Äù? When a writer articulates his experiences and expresses them on paper,does he assume a different persona? In an essay which he wrote in 1919, TS Eliot wondered whether, ‚Äúthe more perfect the artist, the more completely separate in him will be the man who suffers and the mind which creates‚Äù. Borges is a lover of paradox and doesn‚Äôt attempt to ‚Äòresolve‚Äô this question. His story ends tantalizingly with these words, ‚ÄúI do not know which of us has written this page‚Äù.
BORGES and I
The other one, the one called Borges], is the one things happen to. I walk through the streets of Buenos Aires and stop for a moment, perhaps mechanically now, to look at the arch of an entrance hall and the grillwork on the gate; I know of Borges from the mail and see his name on a list of professors or in a biographical dictionary. I like hourglasses, maps, eighteenth-century typography, the taste of coffee and the prose of Stevenson; he shares these preferences, but in a vain way that turns them into the attributes of an actor. It would be an exaggeration to say that ours is a hostile relationship; I live, let myself go on living, so that Borges may contrive his literature, and this literature justifies me. It is no effort for me to confess that he has achieved some valid pages, but those pages cannot save me], perhaps because what is good belongs to no one, not even to him, but rather to the language and to tradition. Besides, I am destined to perish,definitely and only some instant of myself can survive in him. Little by little, I am giving over everything to him, though I am quite aware of his perverse custom of falsifying and magnifying things].
Spinoza knew that all things long to persist in their being; the stone eternally wants to be a stone and the tiger a tiger. I shall remain in Borges, not in myself (if it is true that I am someone), but I recognize myself less in his books than in many others or in the laborious strumming of a guitar. Years ago I tried to free myself from him and went from the mythologies of the suburbs to the games with time and infinity, but those games belong to Borges now and I shall have to imagine other things. Thus my life is a flight and I lose everything and everything belongs to oblivion, or to him.
I do not know which of us has written this page.
(From Labyrinths: ‚ÄòSelected Stories and Other Writings‚Äô)
This final sentence of the story entices the reader to venture into the labyrinth of labyrinths to explore who is ‚Äòreally‚Äô fictional in this mirror world!!
Dr Raguram
27/02/24, 8:07‚ÄØam
A good poem opens up a new world and takes you on a memorable journey. Henry Wadswoth Longfellow‚Äôs, ‚ÄòNature‚Äô is one such.
The simple, unpretentious opening lines of the poem portray a familiar scene that happens in most of our homes; a mother trying to put her child to sleep. The child‚Äôs ‚Äòbroken playthings‚Äô are scattered on the floor, and he is ‚Äúhalf willing" to abandon the play and retire for the night. He lingers, staring longingly at the toys he has left behind.
The next few lines venture into a new territory all together. The poet compares the mother whom he just described eloquently, to mother nature. Both are essentially caretakers of all of us. Nature is to man, what a mother is to her child. As we advance in years, nature gradually takes away all our earthly possessions and gently guides us to the world beyond. Since often we are greatly attached to our earthly life and our belongings, we are never too willing to proceed towards that goal. But nature leads us just like the mother leading the child to sleep,taking away our "playthings" one at a time. The poet suggests that our earthly desires and attachments are like playthings that we must eventually relinquish to discover the unknown mysteries of life..
Why did this poem appeal to me? I was drawn (and still continue to be!) by the simple imagery of a mother putting a reluctant child to sleep, which slowly blends itself into a very powerful metaphor of a nurturing nature that prepares us for our journey beyond this world. There is much wisdom in these lines;
NATURE
As a fond mother, when the day is o'er,
Leads by the hand her little child to bed,
Half willing, half reluctant to be led,
And leave his broken playthings on the floor,
Still gazing at them through the open door,
Nor wholly reassured and comforted
By promises of others in their stead,
Which, though more splendid, may not please him more;
So Nature deals with us, and takes away
Our playthings one by one, and by the hand
Leads us to rest so gently, that we go
Scarce knowing if we wish to go or stay,
Being too full of sleep to understand
How far the unknown transcends the what we know.
(Henry Wadswoth Longfellow born on this day on 1807)
Dr Raguram
29/02/24, 8:03‚ÄØam
Tore √òrjas√¶ter (March 3rd,1886 - February 29th1968) was a Norwegian poet who was rooted in the folk tradition and wrote many lyrical poems about nature. Unfortunately only very few of them have been translated into English. Cries of Gulls is one such gem:
CRIES OF GULLS
Sheer rock and steep faces of Lofot,
bird-cliff and thousands
of seagulls that circle round mast and hull.
Let themselves glide on powerful wings
towards the open sea, - it breathes towards them
and receives like an open mind.
Soon after the storm has abated,
the sea‚Äôs bosom still goes on heaving.
The swell lifts the heavy sea
closer up to the horizon
that constantly escapes and dies out quietly
to new heights on the skyline
that once more breathes out and escapes
like time dies out within the age.
Oh these free cries of gulls
towards the open sea! It is like breathing
out one‚Äôs longings and never landing.
Dr Raguram
01/03/24, 9:04‚ÄØam
Rhythmic highs and lows of life can spark the creative urge within ourselves. But when the intensity of the swings are severe, it causes immense suffering to those in the midst of it. Rober Lowell, whose birthday is today, suffered from a severe form of bipolar illness which started early in his life. Mental illness ran deep in his family and his life was laden with instability; for thirty years he was in and out of mental hospitals. The manic episodes were extremely disruptive with florid psychotic symptoms, requiring hospitalization, which were invariably followed by periods of depression.
Fire is a central image in Lowell‚Äôs works. His manic episodes were akin to a blaze of fire which took some effect to be quelled. He wrote, ‚ÄúBy the time I reached the hospital I was completely out of my head‚Äîstrange physical sensations‚ÄîI was a prophet and everything was a symbol; then in the hospital: shouting, singing, tearing things up‚Äîreligion and antics. Then depression (extreme) aching, self-enclosed, fearful of everyone and everything anyone could do, feeling I was nothing and could do nothing‚Äù He termed his manic phase as the ‚Äúholocaust of irrationality‚Äù and depression as the ‚Äúlong, burdensome dull period‚Äù with months of ‚Äúwading in the muck and weeds and backwash of a depression. Depression is an illness for oneself, mania an illness for one‚Äôs friends‚Äù.
Above all, he was a poet and during one of his admissions, he wrote:
The resident doctor said,
‚ÄúWe are not deep in ideas, imagination, or enthusiasm‚Äî
how can we help you?‚Äù
I asked,
‚ÄúThese days of only poems and depression‚Äî
what can I do with them?
Will they help me notice
what I cannot bear to look at?‚Äù
Lowell wrote brilliantly about the embers of his illness in an autobiographical piece, ‚ÄúNear the Unbalanced Aquarium‚Äù, which is included in his book ‚ÄòMemoirs‚Äô. The effect of the medication was ‚Äúlike the slowing and ache of a medium fever. One‚Äôs thoughts are not directly changed and healed, but the terrible, over-riding restlessness of one‚Äôs system is halted so that the mind can see life as it is‚Äù. He was given Lithium much later in his life, once it was available for use. Among all the medications and ECTs that were given to him, Lowell found that Lithium was the most effective one. Reflecting about it, hw wondered to his friend, ‚ÄúIt's terrible, Bob, to think that all I‚Äôve suffered, and all the suffering I‚Äôve caused, might have arisen from the lack of a little salt in my brain‚Äù
What is remarkable is that Lowell continued writing despite the immense suffering due to his mood disorder which wreaked on his life. His courage and determination enabled him to channel the creative fire within, which unfortunately consumed him.
(There have been many biographies of Robert Lowell, my personal favourite is the exceptional,l ‚ÄòSetting the River on Fire‚Äô, by Kay Redfeld Jamison)
Dr Raguram
03/03/24, 8:02‚ÄØam
Humans and wildlife have interacted closely for millions of years, especially during the prehistoric era. The habitat of the prehistoric people were caves. Dwelling there, they embellished the caves with paintings imbued with natural colours. A common theme in their paintings was wildlife, which was not surprising since they lived in close proximity with them. Wildlife was an integral part of their daily lives.
I had the first glimpse of the richness of the prehistoric cave paintings ranging from the Upper Paleolithic period (around 30,000 years ago) to the mediaeval period, in Bhimbetka. It is one of the most densely painted rock shelters in India. As I walked into its vast terrain, one particular rock shelter caught my attention, which is often referred to as the Zoo Rock. A vast array of various wild animals, painted in profile, covered its rock face. Deers, elephants, leopards, wild buffaloes, bears and boars were galloping on its aged backdrop. The primary colour was white, which dates back to the Mesolithic period, while a few from later periods were mostly in red. Though the colours had faded with time, the entire scene was brimming with energy, showcasing the close relationship between these ancient painters and the wildlife around them.
Unfortunately this relationship has frayed over time. The global loss of wildlife is significantly alrarming. According to a 2022 World Wildlife Fund report, global wildlife populations have declined by 69% since 1970.
I am reminded of the story, ‚ÄòThe Epic of Gilgamesh‚Äô, which narrates the great city builder Gilgamesh‚Äôs friendship with a ‚Äúwild man,‚Äù Enkidu. Enkidu leads a contented life without human contact, ‚Äúcoated in hair like the god of the animals,‚Äù grazing at the water hole with a herd of gazelles, ‚Äúhis heart delighting with the beasts in the water.‚Äù Gilgamesh forcibly humanizes Enkidu by sending Shamhat, a priestess, to seduce him. After many days of lovemaking, Enkidu is spurned by the wild animals. He gets a haircut, eats bread, drinks ale and returns with Shamhat to the city.
As modern city dwellers, we are much like the alienated Enkidu, estranged from the rich wildlife around us, making occasional forays to have a glimpse of them amidst the declining forest covers. On the occasion of World Wildlife day and on the background of increasing man-animal conflicts, can we cultivate a more mindful interaction with wild animals at a both personal and public level and commit ourselves towards sustained conservation and peaceful coexistence?
(And of course, you can see them all at ‚ÄòVantara‚Äô‚Ä¶relocated and displaced from their natural habitat. Is that the future of wildlife in India?!)
Dr Raguram
04/03/24, 8:37‚ÄØam
I went for the interview in JIPMER, preparing myself for all kinds of questions that could be asked in the ‚Äòsubjects‚Äô. When I stepped in with much trepidation into the room, I was overwhelmed by the presence of half a dozen serious looking gentlemen. An imposing man seated in the centre looked at me and asked, ‚ÄúYoung man, why do you want to study medicine?‚Äù Without hesitation, I blurted ‚Äúbecause I love literature‚Äù. The response was on the spur of the moment, totally unrehearsed. My answer must have surprised him and he asked me to mention physicians who were also writers. I spoke for a few minutes about Anton Chekov, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and William Carlos William, amongst others. It was much later that I discovered that the gentleman who asked me the question was the venerable writer GK Gokak who later became President of the Sahithya Academy.
There is always an interesting tryst between the professional call and the personal passion and sometimes they converge. A long list of physician-writers down the ages right from the mediaeval physician, Maimonides, down to Abraham Verghese in recent times, will bear testimony to this.
William Carlos Williams was a pediatrician and general practitioner. He "worked harder at being a writer than he did at being a physician," His enormous output ranges across short stories, poems, plays, novels, critical essays and an autobiography. In his ‚ÄòDoctor Stories‚Äô, he gave a glimpse of work; hysterical mothers, obstinate children and poor families with nine kids unable to spare a few dollars for his services. There is an unflinching, straightforward tone in his stories. All the while, he was diligently mining his material for his true call, poetry.
His poems are simple, spare, with striking imagery. For instance, his lengthy poem, ‚ÄòBirds and Flowers‚Äô ends with these beautiful words;
‚ÄúThough the eye
turns inward, the mind
has spread its embrace ‚Äî in
a wind that
roughs the stiff petals ‚Äî
More! the particular flower is
blossoming . . ‚Äú.
Dr Raguram
05/03/24, 8:06‚ÄØam
London has the world‚Äôs first underground railway system and it is always busy with hordes of busy commuters. It is also the most efficient way to travel in the city, provided there are no strikes or unplanned closures.
For me, one of the pleasures of travelling by the tube was to read the poems that used to adorn the stations. Simply called, ‚ÄòPoems from the underground‚Äô, it was a veritable collection of verses from across the world. It was also a wonderful introduction to poets whom I neve heard of before. One such poet was Anise Koltz, often referred to as ‚Äúthe great lady of Luxembourg literature.‚Äù These particular lines of her, which I had made a note of, were particularly striking.
THE BIRDS WILL STILL SING
‚ÄúBreak my branches
saw me into bits
the birds will still sing
in my roots‚Äù
Birds inhabit the same world we do, and yet, they seem capable of transcending it. Though many of them lead lives on the brink of ruin, they still sing. These sparse, powerful, words in the poem convey that even in the midst of destruction unleashed by humans, spirited voices will emerge, rooted in resilience.
This is the anthem for Gaza too‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
06/03/24, 8:43‚ÄØam
Georgia O'Keeffe was one of the first female painters to achieve worldwide acclaim.She struggled with depression and anxiety throughout her life. In the midst of it all, she connected with several others who were going through similar psychological tribulations and also got in touch with Frida Kahlo. These connections helped her immensely in her healing process. She also found solace and inspiration in nature. Over the course of her illustrious career she painted around 200 images of flowers, focusing on their innards. Many critics, largely males, claimed that these images were replete with sexual symbolism,which O‚ÄôKeefee denied vehemently stating that she had only painted the blooms she saw. It is hard to say exactly what O‚ÄôKeeffe intended to symbolise in her flower paintings. Nevertheless, they are the most iconic images imbued with undulating forms and soft gradations of tones, exuding a mystical quality.
In O‚ÄôKeeffe‚Äôs own words: ‚ÄúWhen you take a flower in your hand and really look at it, it‚Äôs your world for the moment. Most people in the city rush around so they have no time to look at a flower. I want them to see it whether they want to or not.‚Äù

08/03/24, 9:28‚ÄØpm
There are many legends associated with Mahashivaratri which is being celebrated today. According to one, it was the day when Shiva drank the poison that emerged from the ocean during Amritmanthan, to protect the world. He drank it but held it in his throat instead of swallowing it. Thus, his throat changed to a blue colour and he was then given the name, Nilkantha. According to another legend, when Ganga was descended from heaven after the request of Bhagirath, it was enormous and uncontrollable, so Lord Brahma requested Shiva to control her fall. Shiva agreed to it and he held the rapid flow of Ganga by tying it up in his hair. According to yet another legend, this was the night when Shiva and Parvati got married, an amalgamation of Purusha (mindfulness) and Prakriti (nature).
I have a particular interest in the mural tradition of south India and went over to the Virupaksha temple sometime back to have a look at the murals that adorn the ranga mantapa. It was fascinating to see the ceiling resplendent with murals depicting scenes from the purana and various narrative episodes from history. Prominent among them is a large panel depicting the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. In the attached photo, starting from the left, one can find Narada, a horse headed Tumburu.. Vishnu and Lakshmi are in the next section. The middle portion depicts the marriage of Shiva and Parvati in exquisite detail.. Brahma is officiating the marriage of Shiva and Parvati with Himavat performing Kanyadan. Three bejewelled women are seen on their right. In the last section on the right, one can notice the three legged Bhringi. The attention to detail, especially the designs in the textiles is quite striking. I was wondering as to how these murals would have looked in their heyday. Temples are not merely places of worship; embellished with magnificent sculptures and paintings, they are repositories of a rich aesthetic tradition which needs to be preserved and protected. I was happy to note that an innovative attempt has been made to digitise these murals. There is an overwhelming need for similar initiatives to conserve many such artistic treasures across the country, which are unfortunately in various stages of neglect.
Dr Raguram
09/03/24, 8:55‚ÄØam
There have been many fictionalized accounts of child abuse. Almost all of them are very unsettling to read as they deal with one of the most harrowing aspects of human behaviour.
Keri Hulme‚Äôs ‚ÄòThe Bone People‚Äô, is one such. It was the first work of fiction from New Zealand to win the Booker Prize.
There are three main characters in the novel: a person modelled after the author, a widower who finds and adopts a young mute boy and, finally, the child. It becomes clear quite early that the child suffered abuse even before he was found with no memory on a beach. Unfortunately, he is also abused by his adoptive father. The novel deals with guilt vs impulse for violence of the father, the trauma of the child and the woman's debate over the acceptability of this behaviour. The novel offers a moving, intimate insight into the lives of these three flawed, struggling people. The descriptions of child abuse are quite gut renching.
Ker Hulme took twelve years to write it and it was rejected by many before it was published by a women‚Äôs collective. It has a rambling style, switching between first persona and third person narratives, interspersed with poetry.
It is not a perfect novel, much like the flawed characters it portrays, but there is an unmistakable originality in narration. Some of the imagery in this novel is absolutely breathtaking and there are poetic, evocative descriptions of the New Zealand coastline :
‚ÄúThe color has faded out of the sky. It is grey, becoming darker as the world turns herself round a little more. The clouds are long and black and ragged, like the wings of storm battered dragons.‚Äù
(Born on 9th March, 1947, the author died after a prolonged struggle with dementia on 2021)
Dr Raguram
10/03/24, 8:49‚ÄØam
MEDITATION ON THE AUTUMN LEAF
Thich Nhat Hanh
"I asked the leaf whether it was frightened because it was Autumn and the other leaves were falling.
The leaf told me, ‚ÄúNo. During the whole Spring and Summer I was completely alive. I worked hard to help nourish the tree, and now much of me is in the tree. I am not limited by this form. I am also the whole tree, and when I go back to the soil, I will continue to nourish the tree. So I don‚Äôt worry at all. As I leave this branch and float to the ground, I will wave to the tree and tell her, ‚ÄòI will see you again very soon.‚Äù
That day there was a wind blowing and, after a while, I saw the leaf leave the branch and float down to the soil, dancing joyfully, because as it floated it saw itself already there in the tree. It was so happy. I bowed my head, knowing that I have a lot to learn from the leaf.‚Äù
‚Äù ‚Ä¶ So please continue to look back and you will see that you have always been here. Let us look together and penetrate into the life of a leaf, so we may be one with the leaf. Let us penetrate and be one with the cloud or with the wave, to realize our own nature as water and be free from our fear. If we look very deeply, we will transcend birth and death.
Tomorrow, I will continue to be. But you will have to be very attentive to see me. I will be a flower, or a leaf. I will be in these forms and I will say hello to you. If you are attentive enough, you will recognize me, and you may greet me. I will be very happy."
Dr Raguram
15/03/24, 8:02‚ÄØam
WS Merwin was a widely celebrated poet, winner of two Pulitzers and the poet laureate of America. He wrote 26 books of poetry, eight books of prose and translated 22 more, including Neruda's love poems, He was a practising Buddhist and a passionate proponent of deep ecology. Merwin lived on an old pineapple plantation in Hawaii which he painstakingly restored to its original rainforest state and died there on 15th March 2019.
Merwin‚Äôs poems may seem to be simple. As you read them, the words take hold of you. The sentences come alive, with beautiful imagery of the world around us. ‚ÄúI don't like using the word environment," he commented. "I don't like the word nature. I don't like using them because they make it seem as though we're not nature. Anything we do to the rest of the world we're doing to ourselves."
Sometimes while birding, when I hear the song of a bird which I haven‚Äôt heard before I keep wondering as to what it could be. It lingers on as a mystery in my memory. Merwin uses this imagery evocatively in this poem, drawing attention to the wonder and mystery of the ‚Äòunknown‚Äô.
THE UNKNOWN BIRD
Out of the dry days
through the dusty leaves
far across the valley
those few notes never
heard here before
one fluted phrase
floating over its
wandering secret
all at once wells up
somewhere else
and is gone before it
goes on fallen into
its own echo leaving
a hollow through the air
that is dry as before
where is it from
hardly anyone
seems to have noticed it
so far but who now
would have been listening
it is not native here
that may be the one
thing we are sure of
it came from somewhere
else perhaps alone
so keeps on calling for
no one who is here
hoping to be heard
by another of its own
unlikely origin
trying once more the same few
notes that began the song
of an oriole last heard
years ago in another
existence there
it goes again tell
no one it is here
foreign as we are
who are filling the days
with a sound of our own
(Dr Raguram)
20/03/24, 7:59‚ÄØam
As I watch through my window, the snowflakes are whirling and falling on the ground with fluffy lightness. Soon, they cover the ground, forming a dainty, white blanket.
I feel oneness with these gyrating crystals. Immersed in the experience, I become aware of my own thoughts that arise and fall within myself. They are the visual hieroglyphic representations of multitudes of thoughts swirling within my mind. In these moments I am not just an observer of the world outside my window, but an explorer of my internal landscape.The falling snow becomes a companion in my journey, like a wandering minstrel.
Dr Raguram
21/03/24, 8:33‚ÄØam
20th March is celebrated as World Sparrow Day. On this day I would like to share a story about the Pine tree and the Sparrow from the Cherokee folklore.
Back when the world was young and all of the animals and trees could talk to each other, winter was on the anvil. The Sparrow was injured and was not strong enough to fly away, so he sent his family on to the Southern regions and decided to stay behind and heal. Since he was injured he knew he would not survive the winter without shelter. So he asked various trees for help.
Sparrow went from tree to tree asking them to shelter him in the cold months. One by one they gave him excuses and refused to give him shelter. There was only one tree left, the lowly Pine tree. So with no hope left Sparrow made his plea to the Pine tree. Sparrow said "Pine, I am injured and not able to fly south, would you let me shelter in your branches until my family returns?"
Pine was a humble tree and thought to himself "What can I do?" but his heart heard the plight of Sparrow and said "My branches are small and my leaves are more like needles but you are welcome to be with me." And so Sparrow spent the cold winter with Pine tree.
Spring came and when the Creator saw what had happened he called a council of the trees and said to them. "You who have so much and would not share with Sparrow will now lose your leaves in the cold time. But Pine, because you gave so much you shall keep your leaves in the coldtime.‚Äù
And that is why the Pine tree keeps its green cover throughout the year.
It is a reminder that in our professional lives we come across many who are like the injured Sparrow, in search of a shelter to heal. It behoves us to offer them space to recoup and recover so that they can bring their journey afresh, with renewed hope.
Dr Raguram
22/03/24, 6:47‚ÄØam
Poems are like flowers, stemming from the heart and blossoming in delicate petals of words. We all use words, we all want to communicate and poetry does it seamlessly. It is a very powerful art form. In the words of William Wordsworth ‚Äúpoetry is the breath and finer spirit of all knowledge.‚Äù Expanding on this aspect, Ursula Le Guin commented, ‚ÄúScience describes accurately from outside, poetry describes accurately from inside. Science explicates, poetry implicates. Both celebrate what they describe. We need the languages of both science and poetry to save us from merely stockpiling endless ‚Äòinformation‚Äô that fails to inform our ignorance or our irresponsibility.‚Äù
Le Guin‚Äôs poems offer glimpses of her deep and abiding love of the natural world; ‚ÄùI guess I‚Äôm trying to subjectify the universe, because look where objectifying it has gotten us. One way to stop seeing trees, or river, or hills, only as ‚Äònatural resources,‚Äô is to class them as fellow beings,as kinfolk.‚Äù
In this poem titled, ‚ÄòKinship‚Äô, she explores the primordial ties that connect all life forms.
Very slowly burning, the big forest tree
stands in the slight hollow of the snow
melted around it by the mild, long
heat of its being and its will to be
root, trunk, branch, leaf, and know
earth dark, sun light, wind touch, bird song.
Rootless and restless and warmblooded, we
blaze in the flare that blinds us to that slow,
tall, fraternal fire of life as strong
now as in the seedling two centuries ago.
(Reflections on the World Poetry Day, 21st March)

23/03/24, 6:50‚ÄØam
Saigyo was a 12th century Japanese poet who became a Buddhist monk very early in his life. The most popular form of Japanese poetry is the haiku, the 17-syllable poem whicht reached the height of its development in the seventeenth century. But the haiku is derived from an older poetic form, the waka, which had been around for a thousand years before the haiku. The word waka means "Japanese poem," and it is a form so basic to Japanese literature that Japanese still study and write it today. It encompases five principal forms; tanka, ch≈çk,a bussokusekika, sedoka, and katauta. The last three fell into disuse over time and wanka is now identified principally with the tanka. Saigyo was one of the greatest masters of tanka which is described as, ‚Äúsomething which takes root in the soil of the heart and blossoms forth in a forest of words.‚Äù
Saigyo travelled all over Japan, living as a hermit in the mountains and writing poems which expressed his Buddhist principles and love of nature. Peering out through the window of his hut or sitting on a rock, he portrayed nature and the universe around him, as he saw them. For example, alone in his hut, he compares himself to the reclusive bird, warbler in a poem titled ‚ÄòThe Bush Warbler Idling,‚Äô
‚ÄúSeeping through the haze,
the voice
of the bush warbler‚Äî
few people passing,
mountain village in spring‚Äù.
Saigyo was deeply attracted to cherry blossoms and wrote many poems about it. In his final days, he moved to a hermitage in the mountains near Kyoto, which was surrounded by cherry blossom trees. He wished to die under the cherry blossom tree and wrote:
‚Äúlet me die in spring
under the cherry blossoms
on that day
in the Second Month
when the moon is full‚Äù
Saigyo eventually accomplished his wish, and died peacefully in the year 1190 on 23rd March at the age of 73, beneath a blossoming cherry tree
Dr Raguram
24/03/24, 9:53‚ÄØam
With the advent of online book collectives like the Amazon, scores of independent bookstores have pulled down their shutters. Yet there are a few that have survived this onslaught. The experience that envelops you when you step into such a brick and mortar bookstore is unsurpassable. As you walk through the aisles brimming with books, inhaling the inimitable smells emitted by them, the noise of the world outside slowly fades away and you are transported into the dreamy realm of the written word. Premier book shop in Bangalore was one such oasis.
I cannot resist visiting bookstores on my travels. The Strand at New York is a gargantuan cave with a huge collection of the old and new. The Green Apple in San Francisco comes a close second. Both have endless rows of books closely stacked together and one can spend hours getting lost amongst them! By comparison, the City Lights bookstore in the heart of North Beach, San Francisco is tiny. Named after the Charles Chaplin movie, it was founded by poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti in 1953 and was the first all paperback bookstore in the United States. It specializes in publishing and selling avant garde literature which one may not find in any other bookstore. City Lights was the first to publish Allen Ginsberg‚Äôs ‚ÄòHowl‚Äô and has a wide selection of Jack Kerouac‚Äôs works. One can pick a book, sit in the steps of the basement and spend hours browsing a book with no one looking over your shoulders. Interestingly, when you step out of the store, you walk into Jack Kerouac alley whose walls come alive with colourful murals.
Ferlinghetti was also a poet and I thought of sharing one of his poems on his birthday which sounds so relevant now.
PITY THE NATION (After Khalil Gibran) 2007
Pity the nation whose people are sheep
And whose shepherds mislead them
Pity the nation whose leaders are liars
Whose sages are silenced
And whose bigots haunt the airwaves
Pity the nation that raises not its voice
Except to praise conquerors
And acclaim the bully as hero
And aims to rule the world
By force and by torture
Pity the nation that knows
No other language but its own
And no other culture but its own
Pity the nation whose breath is money
And sleeps the sleep of the too well fed
Pity the nation oh pity the people
who allow their rights to erode
and their freedoms to be washed away
My country, tears of thee
Sweet land of liberty!

24/03/24, 4:56‚ÄØpm
A beautiful photograph of blossoming flowers! And the poem so crisp but so deep.. Good to get attached to nature...
26/03/24, 7:40‚ÄØam
The woods are lovely, dark and deep,
But I have promises to keep,
And miles to go before I sleep,
And miles to go before I sleep.
These lines of Robert Frost are firmly etched in the memory of most of us. Jawaharlal Nehru kept them by his bedside. They inspire us to take a ‚Äòturn‚Äô through enchanting, deep woods in our life and continue our quest with renewed vigour. Perhaps it also indicates that our final destination can be one of eternal sleep, death. By embracing the unpredictability of our last breath, it urges us to savour every moment in the journey of our lives.
The notion of woods as ‚Äòdark and deep‚Äô alludes to the fact that our experiences in life can be touched by ‚Äòdarkness‚Äô. Robert Frost‚Äôs poems emerged from the dark, deep depression that engulfed him for most of his life. He lost both his parents early and had a difficult early childhood. Both his mother and wife suffered from depression. Only two of his children survived. His son died by suicide and his daughter was committed to psychiatric facility.
Robert Frost gave expression to his sense of isolation, sorrow and despair in this poignant poem:
ACQUAINTED WITH THE NIGHT
‚ÄúI have been one acquainted with the night.
I have walked out in rain‚Äîand back in rain.
I have outwalked the furthest city light.
I have looked down the saddest city lane.
I have passed by the watchman on his beat
And dropped my eyes, unwilling to explain.
I have stood still and stopped the sound of feet
When far away an interrupted cry
Came over houses from another street,
But not to call me back or say good-bye;
And further still at an unearthly height,
One luminary clock against the sky
Proclaimed the time was neither wrong nor right.
I have been one acquainted with the night.‚Äù
Each of us may experience a touch of ‚Äòdarkness‚Äô sometime in our lives. Only poets like Frost can alchemize those experiences into glittering verses.
(Penned on the birthday of Robert Frost)
Dr Raguram
26/03/24, 10:45‚ÄØpm
Oh. What famous poets have gone through in their lives. Don't we exaggerate our pain... Theory of relativity. What matters is how we ventilate, in a constructive way... And as you have time and again spoken about resilience. The photograph is simply wonderful and heavenly Sir!!
27/03/24, 7:53‚ÄØam
I haven‚Äôt read much Chinese poetry. Sheerly by chance, I came up with the work Ai Qing. He was a notable poet during the Mao Zedong era in China. He spent more than twenty years in a hard labour camp, emptying latrines as a punishment for criticizing the government and for his ‚Äòwrong mental condition‚Äô. What was his crime? During the brief ''hundred flowers'' period, he had written four fables pleading the party to show more understanding and respect for writers. In one of them, titled ''The Gardener's Dream,'' he wrote about a gardener who cultivated only roses. One night he dreamt that scores of different flowers pleaded to be let into his garden. When he awoke, the gardener thought to himself , ''Because I have shown favouritism to one type of flower only, I have caused discontent among all the other types of flowers. I am becoming more and more convinced that my world is too narrow.''
Breaking with traditional forms of Chinese poetry, Ai Qing innovatively adapted free verse, writing with simple, clear lines that could be understood by all readers. His poems flow like a sparkling stream‚Ä¶ like this one:
What kind of bird is that
In that forest
Singing, singing, singing,
As though it is calling for someone,
As though it is recounting something,
It does not stop though it is raining,
Even its voice is wet
Ai Qing compares himself to a bird that reaches out to the listeners, undeterred by the rain, pouring out songs. These lines derive and are anchored in myriad tribulations that he underwent in his life, writing poems amidst adverse circumstances.
His poem ‚ÄòTrees‚Äô which I have attached with this note, opens with the line, ‚Äòone tree, another tree‚Äô, rather than two trees, emphasizing how separate they are. Yet, they are united by the earth through their roots. It is a beautiful way of stating that no matter how isolated we appear on the surface, we are linked to each other through our roots.
Dr Raguram
28/03/24, 10:32‚ÄØpm
Oh what a simile! So beautifully she has worded.... And the photograph which suits the wordings....
30/03/24, 7:12‚ÄØam
Bipolar disorder is a difficult illness. Journeying across its varied emotional landscape can be a daunting task as one is caught up in eddies of unpredictable swings of mood that can vary across a spectrum. It starts pervading one's whole being and often a person becomes an amalgamation of wounds in various stages of healing.
Textbooks offer impassioned descriptions of the illness with signs and symptoms to detect and categorize. The lived experience of the illness lurks beyond the pages of academic tomes. It is a welcome augury that many have authored insightful books about their experiences of living through the illness. Sometimes poetry captures these embodied experiences with remarkable poignancy. The constant battle between extreme highs and lows is often depicted through vivid imagery in poems, conveying the intense emotions that come with the disorder and the overwhelming feeling of being out of control. Once, a patient of mine with bipolar illness brought a piece of paper in which she had penned a few lines about it.
IN MY LIFE
In my life
I ride
On the rainbow
Sometimes.
Colours
Flow through
My veins.
Surging eddies
Of energy
Soon fade away.
Colours lurk behind
Dark clouds.
All that is left
Is inky blackness.
It draws me
In a vicious swamp
Till my breath
Becomes a mist
And I lose myself
Trying to find
My way
Amidst the dark clouds
In search
Of a ray of light..
As we usher in another World Bipolar Day, it is imperative to lend an ear and listen deeply to the lived experiences of people afflicted by it.
Dr Raguram
31/03/24, 1:13‚ÄØpm
Looking at nature always brings in positive thoughts...
01/04/24, 7:24‚ÄØam
Beauty comes in all colours. Black can be even more beautiful. Often birds are besotted with colourful birds. But with its striking black plumage and bright orange-yellow bill, the blackbird is an unmistakably bewitching bird today. I first saw it in the forests of BR Hills and it was a fascinating experience to hear its fluting, musical call too.
Blackbirds have been around for long. It has played a significant role in folklore and mythology in many cultures. There is a lovely folktale from Zambia, which has also been translated into an award winning childrens‚Äô book..
Long ago, in the forests of Zambia, the blackbird was voted as the most beautiful bird,ever. The other birds, who were coloured red, yellow, blue, and green, were so enamoured with the blackbird‚Äôs colour that they begged it to paint their feathers black so that they could be beautiful too. The blackbird warned them "Colour on the outside is not what's on the inside. You don't act like me. You don't eat like me. You don't get down in the groove and move your feet like me." The other birds were insistent that they be painted black so that they can look beautiful too. Bowing to their demands the blackbird said "We'll see the difference a touch of black can make. Just remember, whatever I do, I'll be me and you'll be you‚Äù. Rather than painting them all black, it gave them a touch of black on their feathers, which is noticeable in birds to this day. Thus they embraced each other‚Äôs differences while maintaining their own distinctive individuality.
There is a lovely poem, ‚ÄòA Blackbird Singing‚Äô by the talented Welsh poet RS Thomas,who was born on 29th March, 1913.
A BLACKBIRD SINGING
It seems wrong that out of this bird,
Black, bold, a suggestion of dark
Places about it, there yet should come
Such rich music, as though the notes'
Ore were changed to a rare metal
At one touch of that bright bill.
You have heard it often, alone at your desk
In a green April, your mind drawn
Away from its work by sweet disturbance
Of the mild evening outside your room.
A slow singer, but loading each phrase
With history's overtones, love, joy
And grief learned by his dark tribe
In other orchards and passed on
Instinctively as they are now,
But fresh always with new tears.
The poet was perhaps using the blackbird as a metaphor of black Africans.In spite of various travails endured by them, they keep their memories afresh through their music, imbued with a tinge of tears.
Dr Raguram
01/04/24, 10:48‚ÄØpm
Just like black bird there are so many wonderful talented singers from Africa.. The photograph catches the colours so well. With a tinge of blue and a coloured beak...
02/04/24, 7:47‚ÄØam
I have an abiding interest in temple architecture and have been photographing and documenting ancient sculptures and mural paintings. There is something distinctive about sculptures that adorn Hindu temples. I was searching for a befitting description of these aesthetic creations and found it in the words of Octavio Paz, ‚ÄúGothic architecture is the music turned to stone; one could say that Hindu architecture is sculpted dance.‚Äù No one could have said it better. Though steeped in history, these sculptures come alive (in spite of years of neglect and deterioration) and cast a lingering spell on the viewer. A notable example is the depiction of 108 Karanas from the Natya Shastra of Bharata Muni which adorn the passages of all the four gopurams in Chidambaram..
Ocatavio Paz, poet, Nobel laureate and diplomat, spent several years in India and wrote a small, engaging book, ‚ÄòIn Light of India‚Äô, reflecting on the history and ethos of the nation. Observing the sculptures of Elephanta Caves, he wrote, ‚ÄúI entered a world made of shadows and sudden brightness. The play of the light, the vastness of the space and its irregular form, the figures carved on the walls: all of it gave the place a sacred character, sacred in the deepest meaning of the word.‚Äù
In addition, Paz explored themes of identity, cultural heritage, and the complexities of India in this book. It is an insightful account, weaving together the intricate layers of its cultural tapestry and the impact they have on shaping individual identities and the collective consciousness of the nation. His observation was quite prescient, ‚ÄúWe are witnessing now, at the end of the century, the resurrection of ethnic and psychic passions, beliefs, ideas, and realities that seemed to have been long buried. The return of religious passion and nationalist fervour hides an ambiguous meaning: Is it the return of ghosts and demons that reason had exorcised, or is it the revelation of profound truths and realities that had been ignored by our proud intellectual constructs?‚Äù
Paz was an outstanding poet (more of it later!) and a glimpse of it in this short poem about the hummingbird which almost sounds like a Haiku.
Stillness
not on the branch
in the air
Not in the air
in the moment
Hummingbird
(Octavio Paz March 31st 1914 - April 19th 1998)
Dr Raguram
03/04/24, 4:49‚ÄØpm
You have caught the humming bird in the right position if the poem is taken in a literal sense! Yes hope it is the revelation of profound truths as the intellectualisation does not help in the long run....
06/04/24, 7:45‚ÄØam
Once when I was birding in the Bhoramdeo Wildlife Sanctuary, I noticed this bird landing on a delicate, frail branch of a tree. The branch was swaying in the early morning breeze. Suddenly there was a gust of wind and I wondered whether the brittle branch would break. At that moment, the bird took off, finding strength in its wings.
As I watched, I kept wondering whether it was akin to a phase in the journey of recovery of patients with psychiatric illnesses. Recovery from ‚Äòmajor‚Äô psychiatric illnesses can be a challenging plight. Often, it is a daunting task as the patient travels along the uneven, unsettling social landscape,negotiating demands, expectations and most importantly social stigma. It is almost a Sisyphean task.
My MD thesis was on First Rank Symptoms of Schneider and since I worked in the same unit for over three decades, I was in a position to follow up many of the patients and be a participatory witness in their journey. Contrary to the often touted ‚Äòfavourable‚Äô recovery of schizophrenia in ‚Äòdeveloping‚Äô countries like India, I have rarely seen a complete recovery in most of them. It is not the ‚Äòpsychotic‚Äô symptoms that impair their recovery, but a host of emotional turmoils that are embedded in unsettling ‚Äòreal‚Äô social contexts. Since the illness starts during the early adult period in their lives, which disrupts their academic and vocational pursuits, finding employment can be a difficult issue. It is also an unenviable task to manage their sexual strivings, which largely remains unaddressed by professionals. They can negotiate these demands to some extent, if there are safe, nurturing, supportive, immediate relationships. In the midst of it all, as their therapist, I strive to kindle and sustain hope in them to unravel their innate strength to cope with these formidable situations. In the words of Victor Hugo,
Be like the bird
Who, pausing in her flight
Awhile on boughs too slight
Feels them give way
Beneath her and yet sings,
Knowing that she hath wings.
Dr Raguram
07/04/24, 10:04‚ÄØam
What to say about the photograph Sir. I don't have a large repertoire of words to praise. Any deviance from normalcy is suffering for the patients as well as for the family. There is absolutely no tolerance. I think you remember Keshav Bharadwaj. He completed his Ph. D. And working for Infosys. Reinforcing their strengths matters so much in their difficult journey.
08/04/24, 7:55‚ÄØam
Yet another solar eclipse‚Ä¶this time a total one is visible along a narrow track stretching from Texas to Maine in the USA and crowds of people are flocking to watch this celestial event. Unfortunately I will miss it this time. The first time I had a glimpse of it was in 1980. Few of us from NIMHANS who were keen not to miss the event, hopped onto a bus and travelled to Karwar as it was touted to afford the best view. We positioned ourselves on a small hillock overlooking the sea. There was lots of activity on the beach below with children and adults enjoying a stroll in the evening. The sea gulls were squawking noisily and merrily. A few had brought special glasses to view it. I was merely watching the light passing through tree leaves. To my fascination, the eclipse was projected onto the ground as the light passed through gaps in the leaves and I was able to track the progress of the eclipse. As the eclipse advanced, the activity on the beach faded away and the gulls were suddenly quiet. Without a prelude, the sun disappeared totally, a black disc covering it like a lens cap. There was an eerie silence and the entire landscape was bathed in surreal colours. Slowly light peeped through like a thin golden ring around the sun. Though it lasted for just a few minutes, it was an enthralling experience during which I felt an intense sense of connectivity to another realm, a vast uncharted universe. In that brief moment when the all life- giving sun disappeared behind a black veil and re-emerged, it was a reminder that all things have an end and a new beginning. Navigating through life's valleys, we may experience a phase of darkness, till the ray of light illuminates and rejuvenates us. Embracing the inevitable cycle of darkness and light provides us an opportunity to reflect and expand our awareness towards a more meaningful existence.
Amidst one of the most tumultuous periods in his life, Mahatma Gandhi wrote, "In the midst of darkness, light persists.‚Äù
(photo from the net!)

09/04/24, 8:18‚ÄØam
If you scroll up in the photo you will see a depiction of Aalilai Kannan. I was totally surprised to see it! This is an iconic represenation of infant Krishna on a banyan leaf. The story behind this is described in detail in Bhagavata Purana. One day Sage Markendeya say a beautiful sight of an infant sleeping on a banyan leaf. It was infant Krishna. He was drawn inside the baby and witnessed the celestial sight of the entire universe. Thirumangai Azhwar described it in 4000 Divyaprabandam: ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æµ‡Øä‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æµ‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æµ‡ØÅ ‡Æá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æü‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç
‡Æâ‡Æ≤‡Æï‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æâ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æï‡Æ≥‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æí‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç
‡Æï‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡Æ§‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ¥‡Æµ‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øà ‡ÆÜ‡ÆØ‡Øç
‡ÆÖ‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡Æï‡Æü‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÜ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øá
‡ÆÜ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æì‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Øç ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Øá‡Æ≤‡Øç
‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Øá‡Æ©‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Øà‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ¥‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Øà-‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Æï‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Øá‡ÆØ‡Æµ‡Æ©‡Øá (
In the form of a baby, you swallowed the world, the sun , the moon & all the life-forms and slumbered on a banyan leaf. I no longer seek the fleeting pleasures of this mortal world. Lord of Vinnagaram, all I ask for is the honor of worshipping you!
16/04/24, 7:49‚ÄØam
Nature has always been a great source of inspiration to artists, right from the times of petroglyphs. As one of the most inspiring muses known to man, it provides endless inspiration to artists and has become a central theme in many famous artists' artworks. Artists not only recreate the natural world but also create new ways of perceiving it.
The theme of the World Art Day on 15th April this year is ‚ÄòA Garden of Expression. Claude Monet, arguably the most important painter of gardens in the history of art, organized his garden at Giverny as though it were a huge painting. Inspired by Japanese prints, he diverted the water from river Epte into the gardens and developed an extensive pond and planted lilies. But fearing the effect the water lilies might have on their livestock, the farmers wrote to local officials to block his plans. Fortunately, Monet was able to obtain permission to proceed after facing lots of difficulties. He painted hundred of lilies and titled the series as
The Nymph√©as. The word nymph√©a comes from the Greek word numph√©, meaning nymph, which takes its name from the classical myth that attributes the birth of the flower to a nymph who was dying of love for Hercules. In fact, it is also a scientific term for a water lily. In all these paintings he focused solely on the surface of the pond, with its cluster of vegetation Ô¨Çoating amid the lilies. Painted on the backdrop of World War 1, these tranquil paintings perhaps provided ‚Äùa refuge of peaceful mediation‚Äù in turbulent times. Much like the Starry Nights of Vincent van Gogh, these are the most iconic images of the impressionist era of paintings.
I was privileged to see the recreation of Monet‚Äô garden in the New York Botanical Garden,several years ago. It was like walking amidst the canvases of Monet. There was the iconic Japanese footbridge, an amazing range of flowers of myriad hues and a lovely pond with floating lilies. I was totally immersed in watching the reflection of light on the shimmering waters of the pond, studded with beautiful lilies. Mone‚Äôt paintings of the lilies came alive at that moment.
If William Blake saw the world ‚Äúin a grain of sand‚Äù, Monet viewed the water lilies as an extension of his life, ‚Äúwithout the water the lilies cannot live, as I am without art.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
