22/04/24, 7:35‚ÄØam
On this World Earth Day, let me share a letter written by Thich Nhah Hanh.
Dear Mother Earth,
Every time I step upon the Earth, I will train myself to see that I am walking on you, my Mother. Every time I place my feet on the Earth I have a chance to be in touch with you and with all your wonders. With every step I can touch the fact that you aren‚Äôt just beneath me, dear Mother, but you are also within me. Each mindful and gentle step can nourish me, heal me, and bring me into contact with myself and with you in the present moment.
Walking in mindfulness I can express my love, respect, and care for you, our precious Earth. I will touch the truth that mind and body are not two separate entities. I will train myself to look deeply to see your true nature: you are my loving mother, a living being, a great being‚Äîan immense, beautiful, and precious wonder. You are not only matter, you are also mind, you are also consciousness. Just as the beautiful pine or tender grain of corn possess an innate sense of knowing, so, too, do you. Within you, dear Mother Earth, there are the elements of Earth, water, air and fire; and there is also time, space, and consciousness. Our nature is your nature, which is also the nature of the cosmos.
I want to walk gently, with steps of love and with great respect. I shall walk with my own body and mind united in oneness. I know I can walk in such a way that every step is a pleasure, every step is nourishing, and every step is healing‚Äînot only for my body and mind, but also for you, dear Mother Earth. You are the most beautiful planet in our entire solar system. I do not want to run away from you, dear Mother, nor to hurry. I know I can find happiness right here with you. I do not need to rush to find more conditions for happiness in the future. At every step I can take refuge in you. At every step I can enjoy your beauties, your delicate veil of atmosphere and the miracle of gravity. I can stop my thinking. I can walk relaxingly and effortlessly. Walking in this spirit I can experience awakening. I can awaken to the fact that I am alive, and that life is a precious miracle. I can awaken to the fact that I am never alone and can never die. You are always there within me and around me at every step, nourishing me, embracing me, and carrying me far into the future.
Dear Mother, you wish that we live with more awareness and gratitude, and we can do this by generating the energies of mindfulness, peace, stability, and compassion in our daily lives. Therefore I make the promise today to return your love and fulfil this wish by investing every step I take on you with love and tenderness. I am walking not merely on matter, but on spirit.
23/04/24, 7:43‚ÄØam
On this World Book Day, let me pen a few words about a book that I read yesterday; ‚ÄòThe Rumi Prescription: How an Ancient Mystic Poet Changed My Modern Manic Life‚Äô by Melody Moezzi. Diagnosed to have Bipolar Disorder, she experienced severe bouts of depression, mania and had to be hospitalized on occasions. Medications helped her to balance her moods, but merely keeping the disorder in check did not satisfy her. She decided to channel her energy into writing and published her experiences of the illness in a powerful book, ‚ÄòHaldol and Hyacinths‚Äô. Much like the hyacinth flower, which rarely grows perfectly straight, Moezzi urged the need to embrace the disorder and rely on the support from loved ones to keep afloat. The book was very well received. After many interviews in the media and countless promotional events, she felt utterly drained, not just physically and emotionally, but spiritually. In her words, ‚ÄúConsumed by an insatiable longing for more and bigger and better successes down the line, I lost track of the
present and grew so addicted to affirmation that I had no energy left for creation‚Äù.
It was at this stage that she rediscovered the timeless teachings of Rumi, with the help of her surgeon father. The book is organized in an innovative way with chapters titled as diagnosis and prescription, dealing with many of the tribulations the author underwent; wanting, isolation, haste, depression, distraction, anxiety, anger, fear, disappointment, and pride. These are all inherent aspects of each of our lives and the author deftly uses Rumi‚Äôs poems as ‚Äòprescriptions‚Äô that we can imbibe. Let me outline some of these prescriptions:
On Haste and the need to Slow Down:
‚ÄúYou went out in search of gold far and wide
But all along you were gold on the inside‚Äù
On Depression:
‚ÄúWhere there are roses, thorns abound.
In the grand bazaar of life, joy without sorrow cannot be found‚Äù
On Anxiety:
‚ÄúForget your plans and embrace uncertainty.
Only then will you find stability‚Äù
On Disappointment
‚ÄúBread on your head and knee-deep in a river,
How are you so starved and withered?
You already own all the sustenance you seek.
If only you‚Äôd wake up and take a peek‚Äù
These verses of Rumi must be read in the context of the personal narratives of the author in the book. I strongly recommend it!
Let me end with this verse of Rumi:
‚ÄúOn the road to enlightenment, wise and mad are one.
In the way of Love, self and other are one.
For those who drink of the wine that connects souls,
In their religion, the Kaaba and the house of idols are one‚Äù

Who can ever even imagine harming the mother if we take it seriously. I wish this becomes the early morning prayer and practise for the generation.
25/04/24, 7:41‚ÄØam
In light of the recent deeply divisive, agonising , electoral comments, it is perhaps time to read and reflect about Kabir and his writings.
Kabir‚Äôs poetry urges us to rise above identity politics and to seek an essence that transcends notions of selfhood. In his works, he draws attention to multiple manifestations of this ‚Äòessence‚Äô and encourages us to celebrate them.
‚ÄúChaahe Gita bachiye ya padhiye Quran
Tera mera pyaar hai har pustak ka gyan‚Äù
‚ÄúIt matters not if you read the Gita or the Quran
All holy texts preach love.‚Äù
More importantly, he emphasized how the process of ‚Äòothering‚Äô, in whatever way we view them as being ‚Äòdifferent‚Äô from ‚Äòour‚Äô ways of knowing and being, keeps us locked up in firm, unempathetic stances. As mental health professionals we are deeply aware of the impact of ‚Äòothering‚Äô in stigmatising, marginalising and devaluing those who are considered and responded to as being ‚Äòdifferent‚Äô.
Hence it is appropriate to recall Kabir‚Äôs words
‚ÄúBura dekhan main chala, bura na milya koye
Jo mann khoya aapna toh mujhsa buran na koye‚Äù
‚ÄúI set out to find bad men, but couldn‚Äôt find any
When l looked within myself, l found there was no one worse than me.‚Äù
In Kabir's worldview, hatred has no place and one needs to look within oneself before directing fingers at others.
In the words of Kabir, I reiterate:
‚ÄúAisi Baani boliye | Mann ka aapa khoye ||
Auran ko sheetal kare | Aaphu sheetal hoye ||‚Äù
‚ÄúLet your speech be such that the ego of ‚ÄòI‚Äô and ‚Äòmine‚Äô dissolves.
That the words you speak soothe everyone, and soothe you as well‚Äù
It hasn‚Äôt been easy to post this.
Dr Raguram
30/04/24, 7:11‚ÄØam
Every time I spot a blackbuck I am amazed by its graceful elegance as it saunters across the grassland. They figure prominently in Hindu mythology. In Sanskrit texts, blackbucks are called ‚ÄúKrushna Mrug‚Äù (black deer). They are also considered the vehicles of Vayu (the wind god) and Chandra (the moon god).
Sangam poetry has vivid, wonderful descriptions of nature and animals. I was wondering whether there is a reference to the blackbuck. Finally I located one in verse 317 in Kurunthogai, which was penned by Madurai Kandarathnanar, In it, a close friend of a lady, consoles her that the man whom she loves deeply will return soon from his travels.
‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æü ‡ÆÆ‡Æ∞‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡Æ∞‡Øà ‡Æ®‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æè‡Æ±‡ØÅ
‡Æ§‡ØÄ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ≥‡Æø ‡Æ®‡ØÜ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø, ‡ÆÖ‡ÆØ‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡Æ§‡Øá‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï ‡Æµ‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æâ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ,
‡Æì‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Øà‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øà‡Æû‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Øà ‡Æ™‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æü‡Æ©‡Øç
‡Æ®‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡ÆÆ‡Øà ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æü‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡ÆÆ‡Øà‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øã ‡ÆÆ‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Øá-‡Æï‡Øà‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡ÆÆ‡Æø‡Æï
‡Æµ‡Æü ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ≤ ‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æü‡Øà‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ¥‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æ¥‡Øày
‡Æ§‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ≤‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æü‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æ£‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æ©‡Æø ‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æ≥‡Øá?
The context is that the man and the lady were deeply in love when the he parted away to gather wealth for their wedding. The lady languishes and loses her health in his absence. Observing her friend‚Äôs anxiety, the confidante says to her, ‚ÄúThe fine, dark male with white patches, mate of the alluring and innocent female black buck, eats the sweet and sour gooseberry, and then, making the nearby honey-dripping huge flowers shiver with its hot breath, it drinks from the fresh springs in the soaring mountains of the lord. How can he stay away from you, in those moist and cold days, when the excessively strong northern winds scatter the rain clouds, making them move south?‚Äù. With these words, the confidante assures the lady that the man would return before the commencement of the rainy season.
What a wonderful expression to soothe and calm an anxious, aspiring, loving, heart!
‚ÄùThe blackbuck stops
Our eyes meet
Tranquil stillness‚Äù
(In my amateurish verse!)
Dr Raguram
30/04/24, 10:18‚ÄØpm
I love to read and listen doha of Kabirdas. The essence of spirituality is conveyed in couple of lines.
30/04/24, 10:36‚ÄØpm
Wonderful photograph Sir. And thanks for the detailed information about the blackbuck...
01/05/24, 6:52‚ÄØam
On this Labor Day let us acknowledge the incredible efforts of someone who toils tirelessly, the worker bee. It is the smallest amongst the three (queen, worker and drone) in the honey bee colony The characteristic feature of the worker bee is its prominent proboscis which helps in collecting nectar from the flowers.
The worker bee has a very busy schedule. Depending on her age, she has many different roles to perform in the hive. When she is young, she is a nurse bee, feeding bee larvae. She also takes on the job of processing incoming nectar, feeding the queen, as well as making and capping the honey. Older worker bees leave the hive to collect the necessary resources from which the colony survives. Collecting nectar and pollen can be a dangerous task, due to risks from predators and pesticides. Their search expeditions and forays can take them four to five miles from their hive. When they return, they play an important role in maintaining the temperature and ensuring adequate ventilation of the hive.
The lifespan of the worker bee is short. The time comes when it has to decide whether the hive is better off without her. It then make one last flight and often she does not have enough energy left to fly back and dies From the moment they‚Äôre born, the worker bees are actively involved in executing various tasks for the collective good of the hive, which they fulfil with remarkable dedication till their end.
With a brain the size of a sesame seed, the worker bee is a source of inspiration. The work they do is not confined to the hive. They play a crucial role through their efforts in pollination in sustaining the ecosystem and life on earth. What they take from the landscape, they give back generously. We, as humans with much larger brains, have a lot to learn from them!
Dr Raguram
02/05/24, 8:23‚ÄØam
Sometimes by sheer chance, one discovers an interesting book. This time it was ‚ÄòIn The Shade Of The Spring Leaves‚Äô,a biography of a Japanese author, Ichiyo Higuchi, containing nine stories and extracts from her diary. It was a revelation.
After finishing the book, I discovered that Ichigo Higuchi was a very important writer of the Meiji period and Japan‚Äôs first modern female writer. She was born in 1872 and died in 1896 at the tender age of 24. Born into a peasant family, her mother was not keen for her to be educated. Finally at the age of 14 she was allowed to attend poetry school as a concession. That marked the beginning of an illustrious literary career. Higuchi picked the pen name ‚ÄúIchiy≈ç‚Äù, meaning ‚Äúone leaf,‚Äù which has a deeper references to a specific form of Zen meditation. In her short life, wrote four thousand classical poems, many short stories, and kept a detailed, 60-volume diary. In one of the entries in the diary, quoted in the book, she writes;
‚ÄúThe rain stopped, green and fresh new leaves rise above the eaves. Pointless it is to wait for someone in my quiet house. I hear the voice of the vendor. And delve into reading a collection of Tang poems.‚Äù
Her stories are replete with lyrical passages like this one from‚ÄòSnowy Day‚Äô, ‚Äú Silver sprinkles the earth. Softly, snowflakes fall like dancing butterflies; wings flutter, but there is no sound. Six-petalled crystals come to rest on withered trees, spring‚Äôs first flowering‚Äù.
Ichiyo Higuchi took me on a compelling journey and I travelled on the wings of her writings to discover an entirely new creative landscape.
Dr Raguram
03/05/24, 7:25‚ÄØam
According to Greek mythology, orchids were made from the remains of a young man named Orchis. He was the son of a nymph and a satyr, and while attending a festival of the wine god Bacchus, he became drunk. He abused the priestess Bacchantes and was torn apart by the other guests at the party. When his sorrowful father asked Zeus to make him whole again, he refused but allowed flowers to grow from his remains. These were the first orchids. It should be noted that there are many variations of this story, but all do end with the creation of orchids from his remains.
Orchids exude undeniable charm and are symbolic of everything from life, love and happiness. As Eckhart Tolle, in his book A New Earth commented,‚ÄùHumans would increasingly be drawn to and fascinated by them [orchids]....They provided inspiration to countless artists, poets, and mystics..more fleeting, more ethereal, and more delicate, they are like messengers from another realm, like a bridge between the world of physical forms and the formless."
I am enamoured of the ephemeral beauty of the orchids and when I looked closely at the heart of this moth orchid,
‚ÄúWould I could bury my soul
Deep in its bosom
Listening to its
Hidden secrets‚Äù
Dr Tsguram
06/05/24, 8:43‚ÄØam
Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote a memorable poem, ‚ÄòHamatreya‚Äô in 1847. It is based on a passage of the Vishnu Purana. The title of the poem is a shortened form of ‚ÄúHail Maitraya‚Äù. Here, the poet records what the sage named Parashara taught his disciple Maitreya in response to the disciple‚Äôs query regarding the real worth of earthly possessions. Emerson guides us to be aware of the futility of our boasting and pride and points towards an awareness of earth‚Äôs living relationship to each one of us. According to him, earth laughs at the boastful attitude of people who feel that they possess her. None can possess her and ultimately all of us are possessed by her.
The flower in the image I‚Äôve posted today is called by various names; Shiv Kamal, Kailaspati and Nagalingam. Imbued with cultural and religious significance, it has petals resembling the hood of a Naga or serpent around its stamen which is considered as Shiva Linga. The tree, often referred to as cannonball tree has important medicinal properties.
In my growing years there was a huge nagalinga tree in front of our house. Every morning, hundreds of flowers would be strewn all over the ground and there would be a contest amongst the children as to who could pick up the most. We spent many hours playing cricket under its vast canopy and when the ball went near its trunk, we would retrieve it with some trepidation as we were told that snakes might be lurking around the tree.
One fine day, the owners of the property decided to cut it down to build new housing. All of us watched with dismay as the magnificent tree fell on the ground. We lost our much loved companion as also the birds and the squirrels, who lost a sturdy, reliable place to nest and rest. In the ensuing years the owners too had to undergo various shades of tribulations.
For me personally it was a kind of grief and an unsettling reminder of our disconnect from the non-human world, which has only gotten worse over the years.
Perhaps it‚Äôs time to read and reconnect with these timeless lines of ‚ÄòHamatreya‚Äô.
‚ÄúWhere are these men? Asleep beneath their grounds:
And strangers, fond as they, their furrows plough.
Earth laughs in flowers, to see her boastful boy‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
07/05/24, 1:16‚ÄØpm
A wonderful photograph to depict spring season. And such a short lived spark, whose short poem conveys so much. Thank you Sir for the glimpse of a hidden treasure.
07/05/24, 7:38‚ÄØam
I became aware of the teachings of Rennyo on reading the book ‚ÄúRennyo:The Second Founder of Shin Buddhism‚Äù. Various Buddhist sects celebrate and follow Buddha‚Äôs teachings through different practices, rituals, with emphasis on different aspects of his teachings. While other schools of Buddhism seek to ‚Äúattain‚Äù or ‚Äúrealize‚Äù enlightenment, the Shin Buddhist path focuses on simply listening and opening one‚Äôs heart to receiving it. ‚ÄúThe pursuit of enlightenment can become something like chasing after a mirage in the desert: You think you have arrived, only to find it disappear ‚Äú. Shin Buddhism emphasizes that one doesn‚Äôt have to become a monk or sit for hours in meditation and can experience this in everyday life through tuning the ears and the heart to listen to life unfolding around oneself.
Rennyo wrote 85 letters to convey his teachings. Let me draw attention to two excepts from it which made an impact on me. The first one is‚ÄùWhite Ashes‚Äù in which he urges us to reflect on life‚Äôs impermanence:
‚ÄúThe people we leave behind and the people who go before us, are more numerous than dewdrops that rest briefly on leaves and branches. Hence, I may have a radiant face in the morning, but in the evening, become no more than white ashes.‚Äù
In the second one on awareness, he comments:
‚ÄúAs the sun shines upon the earth, awakening into growth the seeds that lie dormant in the soil, may the Light of Wisdom shine into our minds and truly awaken us to our ignorance and by this insight stir us to strive for a life of deeper understanding and enlightenment.‚Äù
An observation much in tune with that of Sri Ramana Maharishi, ‚ÄúYour own Self-Realization is the greatest service you can render the world‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
08/05/24, 6:21‚ÄØpm
The photograph and the caption amazing.
11/05/24, 7:18‚ÄØam
While birding in Seychelles last year, I noticed a fairly large sized bird hidden amongst the tree tops. From a distance, it looked like a dove. However, on close observation, it looked distinctive with a beautiful blend of browns, purplish-reds, and blueish-grays, with a brown eye with a red circle around it. At the end of the day, I checked my observations online and found out that it is referred to as Malagasy turtle dove.
There are only six doves that bear the name ‚ÄúTurtle Dove‚Äù. They belong to two groups, the Nesoenas and the Streptopelia. The Malagasy Turtle Dove (Nesoenas picturata) is the only one in the Nesoenas. Its closest relative is the Pink Pigeon and together they form a lineage apart from both the typical pigeons and the other turtle doves.
Madagascar turtle doves produce a liquid called "crop milk" in their upper digestive tract that they regurgitate and feed to their young. While it is called milk, it does not contain lactose and is a blend of water, protein, fat, minerals and amino acids. I was told by the locals that it is quite adept in stealing copras that are left in the open to dry!
Often in the processe of glimpsing something anew, nature unveils itself and enthralls you!
Dr Raguram
12/05/24, 5:57‚ÄØpm
Both the bird and the caption are beautiful and meaningful!
16/05/24, 7:19‚ÄØam
A few years ago I read a very perceptive story about ageing and declining memory,‚ÄùIn Sight of the Lake‚Äù, by Alice Munro, who passed away yesterday.. It is a non-linear story that goes back and forth about an old, widowed woman. She decides to visit a gerontologist to get help for her memory loss and drives to the village only to find that the doctor is not there. More distressingly, it‚Äôs the doctor‚Äôs day off. She also realizes that she has forgotten the piece of paper with the directions and has got the dates.wrong. She wanders around the town and finds out that the doctor works in a nursing home nearby. When she reaches the place, she feels trapped inside. She is now aware that it's the place she has already been in. She narrates her experience of being lost in search of the doctor to the nursing attendant. The story ends with the attendant‚Äôs response, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the same thing you tell me every time.‚Äù
Growing old is like a trip through a difficult, unfamiliar country and there have been many accounts of it in the literature. What is particularly poignant about this short story is that it was written in a period of time when the author herself was in the throes of early dementia. It was among other reasons why she couldn‚Äôt travel to accept the Nobel prize in person.
Works of art often emerge from a slew of experiences, sometimes deeply personal. In the process, the tenuous border between the artist and the character she essays, becomes blurred. Deeply enmeshed internal stories of the author get transformed as powerful, poignant narratives in the literary landscape. It is not an easy task. In Murakami‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúSometimes I can't even remember what I was trying to say in the first place. It's like my body's split in two and one of me is chasing the other me around a big pillar. We're running circles around it. The other me has the right words, but I can never catch her.‚Äù
Alice Munro seems to have bridged this gap with ease in this harrowing story about declining memory and loss of self hood.
Dr Raguram
17/05/24, 6:13‚ÄØam
Endangered Species Day on the third Friday of May was created to increase awareness as to how fragile the existence of some animals,plants and insects is. According to the IUCN, at least 40% of animals, insects and plants are at risk of extinction across the world. On this day, let me draw attention to an endangered bird, the Steppe Eagle..
Little Rann of Kutch is a magical landscape. Ahalya and myself spent several days exploring and savouring the immense biodiversity of the region in the company of Mr Jugal Kishor Tiwari, famed ornithologist and ecologist. One of our first sightings was the Steppe Eagle. Perched on a sandy mound, it was surveying the vast territory for suitable prey. It looked stunning with its rich brown plumage. Steppe eagles migrate to India from their breeding grounds in Central Asia and Eastern Europe. They play an important role in nature by helping to control populations of prey animals and maintain a balance in the ecosystems. It is categorized as an endangered species, because of major declines in their populations over the past few decades. Reasons for this are varied; environmental changes, overhunting by predators, poaching, the changing or destruction of habits by humans, or natural disasters, to name a few.
There‚Äôs a tremendous need for a worldwide conservation effort to prevent such species from being lost forever. No species has ever had such wholesale control over everything on earth, living or dead, as we now have. It is our responsibility to initiate measures at conserving species that are endangered.
In the words of EO Wilson, ‚ÄúLook closely at nature. Every species is a masterpiece, exquisitely adapted to the particular environment in which it has survived. Who are we to destroy or even diminish biodiversity?‚Äù
Dr Raguram
18/05/24, 7:20‚ÄØam
When I first laid hands on Edward Fitzerald‚Äôs translation of Omar Khayyam‚Äôs ‚ÄòRubaiyat‚Äô I was mesmerised by its haunting beauty. In just four lines, the poems explored themes of love, fate, mortality, and the transient nature of life with elegance and simplicity. The verses offered a contemplative perspective on life, urging us to seize the moment and find joy in the face of life‚Äôs uncertainties. He alludes to the temporality of life in these deeply reflective words:
‚ÄúI saw the potter in the market yesterday
Pounding and pounding upon a piece of clay
‚ÄúBehold,‚Äù said the clay to the potter
Treat me gently for once like you, now I am clay.‚Äù
The tapestry of our lives is woven with diverse threads, some of them bleak and dark. Khayyam urges us to dance in the present and relish the beauty of each moment, embracing the ephemeral lives we lead, wholeheartedly and with joy.
‚ÄúSince neither truth nor certitude is at hand
Do not waste your life in doubt for a fairyland
O let us not refuse the goblet of wine
For, sober or drunken, in ignorance we stand‚Äù.
Khayyam‚Äôs verses are like delicate blossoms that bloom with timeless beauty and endless charm. It is hard to resist their irresistible allure.
‚ÄúCome, fill the Cup, and in the Fire of Spring
The Winter Garment of Repentance fling:
The Bird of Time has but a little time to flutter
And the bird is on the wing‚Äù.
It is a reminder to seize the moment, while we still have the wings and to soar!
(Omar Khayyam was born on this day, 18th May, in Nishapur, northern Persia)

19/05/24, 6:48‚ÄØam
It is an enchanting experience to watch birds. A new window opens up to unravel alluring secrets from another world. In that absorbing moment I become one with them.
Let me recollect an interesting poem about birding from Ogden Nash whose death anniversary is today.
‚ÄúBird watchers top my honours list.
I aimed to be one, but I missed.
Since I'm both myopic and astigmatic,
My aim turned out to be erratic,
And I, bespectacled and binocular,
Exposed myself to comment jocular.
We don't need too much birdlore, do we,
To tell a flamingo from a towhee:
Yet I cannot, and never will,
Unless the silly birds stand still.
And there's no enlightenment in a tour
Of ornithological literature.
Is yon strange creature a common chickadee,
Or a migrant alouette from Picardy?
You can rush to consult your Nature guide
And inspect the gallery inside,
But a bird in the open never looks
Like its picture in the birdie books-
Or if it once did, it has changed its plumage,
And plunges you back into ignorant gloomage.
That is why I sit here growing old by inches,
Watching a clock instead of finches,
But I sometimes visualize in my gin
The Audubon that I audubin‚Äù.

20/05/24, 6:50‚ÄØpm
Bees have been around for long. In Ancient Egypt, tears of the Sun God Ra turned into bees upon touching the ground.and in Ancient Greece, bee was a cult symbol for Artemis, goddess of wild nature. In Indian mythology, Honeybees form the string of Kama‚Äôs bowmade of sugarcane. In the words of the poet Kalidasa, Kama, ‚Äúbears the bow of Love; and on that bow, the lustrous string is made of bees‚Ä¶.Weaves a string of Bees with deft invention, To speed the missile when the bow is bent.‚Äù
It is believed that Brahma resides as a bee of Vishnu‚Äôs navel-lotus, humming vedic texts. There is also a mention about a goddess, Brahmari in Srimad Devi Bhagavatam;book 10, chapter 13. Bhramari, who slayed the demon Arunasura, is considered as the goddess of bees. Lakshmi tantra (9,41-43), also mentions her, ‚ÄúDuring the sixtieth era there will be one demon, called Aru·πáa who will do much harm to men and sages. Then I shall appear in bee-form incorporating innumerable bees, and I shall slay the mighty demon and rescue the three worlds. From then on people will praise me forever and address me as BhrƒÅmarƒ´.‚Äù Iconographically she is portrayed with scores of bees emanating from her hands. Brahmari is worshipped on the eighth night of the Navarathri festival. There is a temple for her in Kasauni. It is said that Adi Guru Shankaracharya spent sometime in the temple, which is situated at the top of a mount enclosed by a fort. Bhramari Pranayama is a yogic technique that consists of concentrating on the sound emulating a bee along with breath control. The vibration of sound produced is said to enhance the level of consciousness. So the next time you hear the hum of a bee, do not panic!
(Penned on the occasion of the World Bee Day, 20th May)

23/05/24, 7:13‚ÄØam
Buddha‚Äôs followers never officially celebrated his birthday, till it was formalized in May 1950, at the first conference of the World Fellowship of Buddhists in Colombo, Sri Lanka. It was agreed upon that the day of the full moon in May would be auspicious, due to Buddha attaining nirvana on a full moon day.
The natural world was ubiquitous in the Buddha‚Äôs life and teachings. Forests and woodland parks were the most common setting where people met the Buddha and listened to his teachings. Nature provided the backdrop and the context for his teachings and the natural settings played an important role in his awakening and his teachings. The important connection he saw between nature and the practices he taught is encapsulated in some of his utterances like this one;
‚ÄúIf we could see the miracle of a single flower clearly our whole life would change. ‚Äù
On this Buddha Purima day, it would be wonderful to become aware that sources of immense awareness is all around us in our everyday lives‚Ä¶let us pause and reflect.

02/06/24, 8:56‚ÄØam
All of us are curious about the outcome of the elections and are besieged with countless exit polls which vary in their calculations which are at best astrological. Talking of curiosity, no other feathered creature has aroused interest owing to its uncanny nature, like the owl, in literature, across ages. They are perhaps the most commonly mentioned birds in literature. Watching the endless discussions about electoral trends, I am reminded of a tale from Aesop Fables, ‚ÄòThe Owl and the Birds‚Äô. It narrates how the ordinary birds ignore the warnings of the wise owl. Later when they are proved wrong and the owl is proved to have been right, they turn to it for pearls of wisdom, but the owl is now silent and ‚Äòno longer gives them advice, but in solitude laments their past folly‚Äô.
There is another interesting story in the eighteenth century English author John Gay‚Äôs, ‚ÄòFifty-one Fables in Verse‚Äô. In one of them a grumpy owl laments that he is not being paid sufficient attention. Overhearing it, a sparrow comments that the birds have now learned that looks can be misleading and that just because the owls happen to appear wise and venerable does not necessarily mean that they are so. It goes on to say that if the owl concentrates on what it is good at, namely catching mice, the farmers will applaud and respect its work, rather than looking for false respect for its looks.
A group of owls is called a ‚Äòparliament‚Äô. It has its origins in the 1950s children's classic ‚ÄòThe Chronicles of Narnia‚Äô by CS Lewis. Lewis adopted the title of the Chaucer‚Äôs allegorical poem "The Parliament of Fowls to describe a council of owls who meet at night to discuss the affairs of Narnia.
Will we have wise owls in the new parliament or like the one in ‚ÄòWinnie the Pooh‚Äô, where the character named Owl presents himself as wise and knowledgeable but is really a scatterbrain who even spells his own name incorrectly as ‚ÄúWol‚Äù

07/06/24, 10:34‚ÄØam
Sometimes, a small, unobserved detail in a painting can be an object of intense scrutiny. Take for instance the painting, ‚ÄòThe Sorcerer of Hiva Oa‚Äô, by Paul Gaugin. It was painted by him during his sojourn in 1902 on the small Pacific island of Hiva Oa in French Polynesia's Marquesas. The main focus in the painting is that of the sorcerer who is adorned with a dramatic red cape. If one looks at the bottom right, there is a dog holding a bird in its jaws. Over the years, the identity of this bird has been an object of intense curiosity and speculation. One suggestion was that it could be a large flightless New Zealand bird, ‚ÄòTakahe‚Äô. The problem with this surmise is that Hiva Oa is far away from New Zealand and couldn‚Äôt have travelled that far. Moreover, it was pointed out the Takahe‚Äôs head is dark blue, whereas in the painting the head of the bird is green. Much later, in 1937 Norwegian voyager Thor Heyerdahl spotted a strange bird while visiting Hiva Oa. He saw a hen-sized flightless bird scurrying rapidly between tall ferns and was told by the islanders that this was the Koao. Could it be the now extinct Marquesas Swamp Hen? Or was it the Takahe, one of the rarest birds native to New Zealand? Finally, in 1988, 600-year-old bones of a bird was found in Marquesas which was identical to the description of Koao, but unfortunately there was no way to find out the colouration, which could have solved the riddle!
Artists are endowed with keen powers of observation. Did Gaugin notice the bird and painted it? It is interesting that a small detail from a painting by a great artist kindled an ornithological mystery, which remains unsolved till now!
(Penned on the birthday of Paul Gaugin, 7th June 1848)
Dr Raguram
15/06/24, 9:33‚ÄØam
The stories of Jorge Luis Borges can be read in a matter of minutes, yet the impact upon the reader is profound. Take for instance the story, ‚ÄòThe Book of Sand‚Äô: the three pages long story is a deeply engaging narrative about a mysterious book which appears to have an infinite number of pages. It was sold to him by a bookseller who bought it in India, from a low caste man. When the narrator opens the surprisingly heavy book, he finds the script to be unfamiliar, laid out in double columns, with page numbers. which do not run in any sequential order. It also contains clumsily drawn illustrations on some pages of the book. The narrator is unable to find either the first or last page of the book and as he browses through it, more and more pages appear. Overwhelmed by curiosity, he becomes obsessed with the book over time. He also notices that he can never find the same page twice in the book. He comes to view the book as ‚Äòmonstrous‚Äô, and wants to destroy it, but fears that if he tries to burn the book, it might result in an infinite fire whose flames would engulf the whole world. He feels that ‚Äúthe best place to hide a leaf is in a forest‚Äù and disposes of the book by taking it to the Argentine National Library and hiding it in one of the musty shelves in the library‚Äôs basement.
The beauty of the story is that every time I read it, a new perspective emerges. Is the writer alluding to the hold of curiosity in human imagination or is it a meditation on the nature of infinity? Perhaps it refers to our deepest strivings to probe, understand, and make sense of the vast, unfathomable essence that is woven into the grand cosmic tapestry.
The infinite has always been of interest to people, mathematicians, physicists and philosophers. But very few can decode and render it in magical words like Borges!
(Jorge Luis Borges August 24, 1899 - June 14, 1986)
Dr Raguram
16/06/24, 9:25‚ÄØam
Gordon Parks, Sr. was a hugely talented polymath. He was a photographer, filmmaker, composer, writer, journalist, novelist and a poet. On Father‚Äôs Day I thought of sharing one of his beautiful poem ‚ÄòThe Parting‚Äô, wherein the father prepares his son to find his own life path amid signposts signalling devious directions and roads "paved with roses and thorns." Success, the father concludes, will be determined by whether the son, in the autumn of his own life, can thankfully manage a smile.
THE PARTING
Two roads passed my father‚Äôs house,
paved with roses and thorns.
They went everywhere, with tolls
unfixed on unmarked distances,
paved with roses and thorns.
Papa said a few things when I was packed to go:
The feel of your feet will reconcile the differences in which road you take.
Signposts along the way will give devious directions.
It is your right to question, but don‚Äôt ignore them.
Each one is meant for something.
Summer grass underfoot will be kinder than weeds.
Yet during winter storms, it will be the taller stalks, leaning above the snow, that will catch your eye. And you will learn that all things are not the same.
You must select your friends with the same care I gave to selecting your mother.
Avoid things that die too easy, and get your soul ready to die well.
As you grow older, you will pray more and worry less.
Well, what I‚Äôve told you might amount to everything, or maybe nothing.
Just be thankful if, in autumn, you can still manage a smile.
Dr Raguram
17/06/24, 7:31‚ÄØam
The Norman Rockwell Museum is located in Stockbridge, Berkshire County amidst carefully tended, lush gardens overlooking the picturesque Housatonic River Valley. It is home to the largest collection of his original works. When I was looking today at some of the photographs I took of the displays in the collection, one particular canvas titled, ‚ÄòNew in the neighbourhood‚Äô stood out. It portrayed a family moving into a new locality. Five kids are portrayed in the painting and noticeably, there is a distance between the white kids who are looking at the two black children with some curiosity. If one looks closely, an adult is seen peering from behind the window curtain. The entire painting draws attention to issues in assimilation of people viewed as being ‚Äòdifferent‚Äô.
In his 1903 book, ‚ÄòThe Souls of Black Folk‚Äô, DuBois wrote about the social philosophy of ‚Äòdouble consciousness‚Äô: ‚ÄúIt is a sense of always looking at one's self through the eyes of others, of measuring one's soul by the tape of a world that looks on in amused contempt and pity‚Ä¶ two unreconciled strivings; two warring ideals‚Äù. During the period of segregation, African Americans essentially lived in segregated communities not by choice, but forced into these places by racial prejudice and led parallel lives.
Sometime I wonder whether we are also slowly and steadily moving into such situation in India. A recent news that residents in a housing complex in Ahmedabad were preventing a person from a minority community from moving into her allotted unit raises concerns. Out of an unseen and ever-lingering fear and mistrust, people belonging to the minority community will gradually move into separate, demarcated areas. This will result in an unfortunate situation of ghettoization of both communities. Secularism and comradeship will soon vanish in these spaces.
‚ÄúAll good people agree,
And all good people say,
All nice people, like Us, are We
And everyone else is They:
But if you cross over the sea,
Instead of over the way,
You may end by (think of it!) looking on We
As only a sort of They!‚Äù
Rudyard Kipling in ‚ÄòDebits and Credits‚Äô
Dr Raguram
20/06/24, 9:04‚ÄØam
In a world bristling with distractions the simple act of picking up a book, opens up doors of enlightenment, knowledge, and personal transformation. It is a catalyst for personal growth and self-discovery. The person who unveiled the power of the written word to uplift, educate, and empower was PN Panicker.
Puthuvayil Narayana Panicker is known as the Father of the Library Movement in Kerala. The activities of the Kerala Grandhasala Sangham that he initiated triggered a popular cultural movement in Kerala which contributed to the universal literacy in the state in the 1990s. Panicker led the formation of Thiruvithaamkoor Granthasala Sangham (Travancore Library Association) in 1945 with 47 rural libraries. The slogan of the organization was 'Read and Grow '. Later on, with the formation of Kerala State in 1956, it became Kerala Granthasala Sangham (KGS). He travelled across Kerala proclaiming the value of reading. He succeeded in bringing some 6,000 libraries into this network. He founded the Kerala Association for Nonformal Education and Development (KANFED) in 1977. KANFED was instrumental in starting the Kerala State Literacy Mission, which led Kerala to its universal literacy movement. Kerala became the first state which achieved universal literacy.
Panicker died on 19 June 1995, at the age of 86. His death anniversary, is observed in Kerala as Vayanadinam (Reading Day) since 1996. The Department of Education in Kerala also observes Vayana varam (Reading Week) for a week from June 19 to 25. In 2017, Govt of India declared June 19th as National Reading Day.
As Victor Hugo commented perceptively, "To learn to read is to light a fire; every syllable that is spelled out is a spark."
Dr Raguram
21/06/24, 11:27‚ÄØam
Historically, both yoga and Indian classical dance traditions share Vedic roots in the ancient texts of Patanjali Yogasutra and Natyashastra, respectively. For both, the body is a temple and the dance/asana is one‚Äôs prayer. The emphasis on stilling the mind through concentration on the inner and outer bodies, moving the practitioner toward an experience of freedom.
Natya yoga is the name given to a type of yoga that combines yoga and dance-like movements as a spiritual practice. It has similarities to Hatha yoga, but it has a different approach in that it also integrates elements of dance and mime, rather than static asanas. Quite a number of asanas of Hatha Yoga are in parallel with some of the 108 karanas of the Natyashastra. Karanas are basically yogic poses in rhythm. The karanas are dance counterparts of asanas and like the alignment of asanas, the karanas focus on the center line of the body in relation to gravity paying attention to the pathways of energies that flow through the body.
Thillai Nataraja Temple in Chidambaram is one of very few temples that have all 108 karanas from the Natya Shastra. They are depicted in the stone carvings on the passage walls in the gopurams of the temple. Most of the dance poses in this temple resemble various yoga poses. The karanas arise from fundamental yogic postures. Many of the 108 karanas employ various yogic postures like Garudasana, Natarajasana etc. When yoga is used with stylistic expression it becomes an instrument to evoke Rasa.
The photograph depicts LalƒÅ·π≠atilaka, which is 50th Karana, where the left leg is placed on the ground with the feet flat in and the knee bent. The right leg is lifted up and bent and the toes virtually touching the forehead. The hand is held in Anjali mudra and the face and the head are tilted back.
‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§∞‡•å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É ‡•• 111-112 ‡••
p·πõ·π£·π≠hata·∏• ku√±cita·πÉ k·πõtvƒÅ vyatikrƒÅntakrama·πÉ tata·∏• ||4-111||
ƒÅk·π£iptau ca karau kƒÅryau krƒÅntake kara·πáe dvijƒÅ·∏• |
Natya Yoga conceives body as a temple and dance as an offering
Dr Raguram
24/06/24, 11:49‚ÄØam
Ambrose Bierce who was born on this day in 1842 is largely known as the author of the interesting, ‚ÄòThe Devil‚Äôs Dictionary‚Äô. He also wrote several trenching stories about the harsh realities of war. Bierce was a Union soldier during the Civil War and he gave expression to his traumatic memories in his stories, in a collection titled, ‚ÄòCivil War Stories‚Äô.
‚ÄòThe Mocking Bird‚Äô, is particularly poignant short story from this collection. Private William Grayrock is posted on picket duty and on hearing the approach of someone he cannot see, he shoots blindly into the night and is certain he has hit a man in the darkness. He is lauded for protecting the regiment from intruders, but Grayrock is beset with guilt and goes in search and to his great dismay finds that he has shot his long last twin brother. Overcome with intense grief, he doesn‚Äôt return to the camp and wanders off.
The story juxtaposes the harsh realities of war with memories fond family relationships. As he goes in search of the person he had shot, Grayrock dreams about his childhood friendship with his brother and their attachment to their most precious possession, a mockingbird. ‚ÄúThrough all the golden days floated one unceasing sound-- the rich, thrilling melody of a mocking-bird in a cage by the cottage door. It pervaded and possessed all the spiritual intervals of the dream, like a musical benediction. The joyous bird was always in song; its infinitely various notes seemed to flow from its throat, effortless, in bubbles and rills at each heart-beat, like the waters of a pulsing spring‚Äù. As ‚Äúhe was passing a thicket of laurel, a bird rose from the midst of it and perching on the branch of a tree above, poured from its joyous breast so inexhaustible floods of song as but one of all God's creatures can utter in His praise. There was little in that--it was only to open the bill and breathe; yet the man stopped as if struck --stopped and let fall his rifle, looked upward at the bird, covered his eyes with his hands and wept like a child‚Äù. When he finally notices the dead body of his twin brother, ‚Äúthe shrilling bird upon the bough overhead stilled her song and, flushed with sunset's crimson glory, glided silently away through the solemn spaces of the wood‚Äù.
The mocking bird is a crucial metaphor in this haunting story. The bird is reportedly quite caring when it comes to protecting its family from predators and sadly witnesses an avoidable tragedy involving two brothers whose memories are entwined with it.
The story is also about the futility of war. The American Civil War created deep divisions between the North and South and also divided many families. Some family members fought for the Union, while others sided with the Confederacy. It ripped the country apart and in many of those deadly battles, brothers fought against their own brothers, at times killing each other.
As Fran√ßois de Salignac de la Mothe-F√©nelon, a French theologian, poet and writer, commented perceptively, ‚ÄúAll wars are civil wars because all men are brothers... Each one owes infinitely more to the human race than to the particular country in which he was born.‚Äù
Traumatic memories of war linger on for long in the psyche of the individual and often remains unresolved. Ambrose Bierce‚Äôs death remains an unsolved mystery. Did he commit suicide, or pneumonia took a toll on him or was he killed by Mexican federal forces? In his last known communication, he wrote, ‚ÄúAs to me, I leave here tomorrow for an unknown destination.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
25/06/24, 8:39‚ÄØam
Judith Wright was a prolific Australian poet, critic and short-story writer, who published more than 50 books. She was also an uncompromising environmentalist and social activist campaigning for Aboriginal land rights. Late in life, she settled to a remote property near the heritage town of Braidwood, south of Canberra, where she wrote many of her nature poems. Judith was one of Australia‚Äôs most celebrated poets and one of the two to be considered for the Nobel prize. Her book ‚ÄòBirds‚Äô was first published in 1962 and one of the poems is about the Magpie:
Along the road the magpies walk
with hands in pockets, left and right.
They tilt their heads, and stroll and talk.
In their well-fitted black and white.
They look like certain gentlemen
who seem most nonchalant and wise
until their meal is served ‚Äì and then
what clashing beaks, what greedy eyes!
But not one man that I have heard
throws back his head in such a song
of grace and praise ‚Äì no man nor bird.
Their greed is brief; their joy is long.
For each is born with such a throat
as thanks his God with every note.
When we were birding in Australia, we spotted the Australian Magpie on many occasions. When I read this poem I was struck as to how beautifully she has described the bird‚Äôs behaviour, especially in the first four lines. She then compares the bird to ‚Äúcertain gentlemen‚Äù who are greedy to just fulfil their need. Finally, she alludes to the magpies' remarkable singing abilities, which surpass even those of human beings. The poem ends with her thoughtful reflection that the magpie‚Äôs ‚Äúgreed is brief, their joy is long‚Äù and they ‚Äúthank his God with every note.‚Äù
Judith died of heart attack in Canberra on June 26 at the age of 85. Her ashes were scattered around the mountain cemetery of Tamborine Mountain. Wright had owned a strip of rainforest nearby, which she donated to the state so it could be preserved as a national park.

Such a beautiful bird with piercing eyes. A very sad story and so very True, man against his own species. Mankind is just shredding into pieces because of hatred, power and greed...
25/06/24, 10:44‚ÄØpm
You are enlightening us with so many varieties of birds. What a creation and the poets are blessed with their ability to describe them and compare and contrast with humans. Greed is brief and joy is long which is the opposite for our man'kind'?
26/06/24, 9:28‚ÄØam
As we were birding around the Stow Lake in Golden Gate Park few months ago, the unmissable melodious note of the Song Sparrow drew our attention. Thoreau described it as ‚ÄúMaids! Maids! Maids! hang up your teakettle-ettle-ettle.‚Äù Some others compared it the opening notes of Beethoven‚Äôs Fifth Symphony! It was flitting through low branches, occasionally moving onto open ground in search of food, pumping its tail up. It was foraging on the ground kicking away debris by hopping forward while sweeping both feet quickly back along the ground, a move often described as ‚Äòsong sparrow samba‚Äô! Soon, it perched on a stump and started singing.
Most of what we know about the song sparrow emerges from the work of one amateur ornithologist, Margaret Morse Nice. She shifted the focus away from collection, description of bird specimens and emphasized on close observation on bird behaviour in their natural setting. She observed and compiled a detailed study of the song sparrow in her own backyard. She marked each bird with a coloured band and managed to follow and study 336 individual birds in detail. And one of them, which she named 4M, remained in her study area for seven years. She described her technique as a ‚Äúphenomenogical method.‚Äù Interestingly, it is through the phenomenological approach as mental health professionals, we explore and understand the lived experience of people in throes of psychological distress. Her study, which spanned eight years, detailed the daily activities and territorial behaviour of several generations of song sparrows. Though she lacked a professional position and funding, she published 250 articles, five monographs and single-handedly initiated a new era in American ornithology.
In the words of Margaret Morse, ‚Äúthe study of nature is a limitless field, the most fascinating adventure in the world.‚Äù There are plenty of birds like the song sparrow right in our backyards/environs and her work should inspire us that we can learn a lot about them through careful observation.
With tongue in cheek, she observed, ‚ÄúI decided it would be better to be a bird. Birds are very busy at one period each year caring for babies, but this lasts only a few weeks with many of them, and then their babies are grown and gone. Best of all, they leave their houses forever and take to camping for the rest of the year. No wonder they are happy.‚Äù
(Margaret Morse Nice 6th December 1983 ‚Äì 26th June 1974)
Dr Raguram
27/06/24, 9:13‚ÄØam
Another bird that caught my attention down under, because of it gruesome ways of having food was the butcherbird. When it caught a prey, it hung it on a branch and scythed the meat away, just like a butcher. It kept any uneaten bits of food between the twigs in a tree and came back to eat the leftovers, later. Though aggressive in its behaviour, I was quite surprised to see the bird visit the kitchen window in a friend‚Äôs house regularly and savoring the cooked rice!
Many works of fiction have been woven around the butcher bird, often in the genre of fantasy and horror. It also figured in the poems of Charles Causley, the Cornish poet, who was profoundly influenced and impacted by the World War I. His father returned from the war as an invalid. As an only child, Causley spent his first seven years watching his father slowly die. He also witnessed the suffering shell-shocked soldiers who walked aimlessly around the town. These experiences found expression in his poems. In a poem titled ‚ÄúRecruiting Drive,‚Äù bristling with images of violence and deception, he uses the metaphor of the butcher bird as someone who lures young men to their deaths in battle.
RECRUITING DRIVE
‚ÄúUnder the willow
I heard the butcher-bird sing,
Come out you fine young fellow
From under your mother‚Äôs wing.
I‚Äôll show you the magic garden
That hangs in the beamy air,
The way of the lynx and the angry Sphinx
And the fun of the freezing fair.
Lie down lie down with my daughter
Beneath the Arabian tree,
Gaze on your face in the water
Forget the scribbling sea.
Your pillow the nine bright shiners
Your bed the spilling sand,
But the terrible toy of my lily-white boy
Is the gun in his innocent hand.‚Äù

29/06/24, 11:21‚ÄØpm
Oh what a poem... And the photograph looking like the couple in an old cinema, black and white!
02/07/24, 8:09‚ÄØam
When poets write about nature, it is not merely about the landscape around them, but on how they perceive it. Wislawa Szymborska, the Polish Nobel Laureate‚Äôs poem, ‚ÄòView with a Grain of Sand‚Äô, is a poem painted with an engaging palette of words. The poet makes us think differently about objects and things we see and name. The objects we see do not know their names or their purposes. Likewise, sand does not know that it is sand. We give it an identity and call it sand within the frameworks of our language. Wislawa Szymborska draws our attention not just to the sand, but how we understand, comprehend and construct a sense of identity about objects around us.
A few lines from the poem;
‚ÄúWe call it a grain of sand,
but it calls itself neither grain nor sand.
It does just fine without a name,
whether general, particular,
permanent, passing,
incorrect, or apt.
Our glance, our touch mean nothing to it.
It doesn't feel itself seen and touched.
And that it fell on the windowsill
is only our experience, not its.
For it, it is no different from falling on anything else
with no assurance that it has finished falling
or that it is falling still‚Äù.
The tapestry of words that she weaves, is intricate and magical.
And I keep reading, re-reading and reflecting on these lines from another of her poem, ‚ÄòWater‚Äô
‚ÄúThere are not enough mouths to utter
all your fleeting names, O water.
Emerson said it succinctly ‚ÄúThe world is emblematic. Parts of speech are metaphors, because the whole of nature is a metaphor of the human mind‚Äù.
Wis≈Çawa Szymborska (2 July 1923 - 1 February 2012 )

The depth of the poet's train of thoughts gets manifested while describing nature. We identify so much with our body and mind that we have ceased to be like the grain of sand.... The photograph and its link to the poem, very nice Sir.
03/07/24, 10:11‚ÄØam
Kafka wrote a series of aphorisms, each one of them deeply meaningful. I have penned a few thoughts on one of them. Do have a look and pen your thoughts on my reflections and the aphorism too: https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/a-cage-went-in-search-of-a-bird
04/07/24, 9:48‚ÄØam
Van Mahotsav is an annual ritual, diligently observed by the state between July 1st and 7th, every year. The occasion is heralded with planting of trees. Unfortunately most of the saplings remain largely unattended thereafter and wither till it is time for the next Van Mahotsav.
The sad fact beyond these ceremonial occasions is that the forest cover in India is dwindling at an alarming rate. . According to the India State of Forest Report (ISFR) 2021, India has lost 2.33 million hectares of tree cover since 2000, with the highest loss in 2017 at 189,000 hectares. In 2023, the country lost 144,000 hectares, the highest in the last six years. In addition, the quality of India's forests has also deteriorated, with 9,117 square kilometres of forest turning into barren lands and scrubs between 2019 and 2021. Fixing the forest cover by planting a new one is an endlessly impossible task, as the life of the forest takes its own time.
Forests are critical to reduce and sequester carbon dioxide, protect habitats for millions of species, and ensure the health and wellbeing of people. As we search for a route to a sustainable future, we need to halt deforestation. Keeping forests standing is the most cost-effective of celebrating Van Mahotsav
Gieve Patel, a poet and artist whom I admire immensely, describes the cruelty of man in killing/destroying the tree with a touch of irony in this poem;
ON KILLING A TREE
It takes much time to kill a tree,
Not a simple jab of the knife
Will do it. It has grown
Slowly consuming the earth,
Rising out of it, feeding
Upon its crust, absorbing
Years of sunlight, air, water,
And out of its leperous hide
Sprouting leaves.
So hack and chop
But this alone wont do it.
Not so much pain will do it.
The bleeding bark will heal
And from close to the ground
Will rise curled green twigs,
Miniature boughs
Which if unchecked will expand again
To former size.
No,
The root is to be pulled out -
Out of the anchoring earth;
It is to be roped, tied,
And pulled out - snapped out
Or pulled out entirely,
Out from the earth-cave,
And the strength of the tree exposed,
The source, white and wet,
The most sensitive, hidden
For years inside the earth.
Then the matter
Of scorching and choking
In sun and air,
Browning, hardening,
Twisting, withering,
And then it is done.
Dr Raguram
05/07/24, 8:28‚ÄØam
On the 4th of July in 1855, Walt Whitman self-published his first edition of Leaves of Grass, a volume of twelve poems. He pronounced that ‚ÄúThis is no book, / Who touches this touches a man.‚Äù It had a lengthy preface in which he reflected on various aspects of life ‚ÄúLove the earth and sun and the animals, despise riches, give alms to everyone that asks, stand up for the stupid and crazy, devote your income and labour to others, hate tyrants, argue not concerning God, have patience and indulgence toward the people, take off your hat to nothing known or unknown or to any man or number of men, go freely with powerful uneducated persons and with the young and with the mothers of families, read these leaves in the open air every season of every year of your life, re-examine all you have been told at school or church or in any book, dismiss whatever insults your own soul, and your very flesh shall be a great poem and have the richest fluency not only in its words but in the silent lines of its lips and face and between the lashes of your eyes and in every motion and joint of your body.‚Äù
The initial print run of the first edition was modest and the book did not sell well. It did receive a number of rave reviews in New York newspapers and some of them were written by Whitman himself. Whitman was undeterred and continued to add poems to ‚ÄòLeaves of Grass‚Äô in four different editions and finished the last revision on his deathbed in 1892.
The poems in the ‚ÄòLeaves of Grass‚Äò represent Whitman's celebration of his philosophy of life and nature. Throughout the book, Whitman emphasizes the importance of connecting with nature and finding solace, inspiration, and spiritual fulfilment in the natural world. He sees nature as a source of wisdom and renewal, and encourages readers to forge a deeper connection with the environment around them.
‚ÄúSmile O voluptuous coolbreathed earth!
Earth of the slumbering and liquid trees!
Earth of departed sunset! Earth of the mountains misty-top!
Earth of vitreous pour of the full moon just tinged with blue!
Earth of shine and dark mottling the tide of the river!
Earth of the limpid gray of clouds brighter and clearer for my sake!
Far-swooping elbowed earth! Rich apple-blossomed earth!
Smile, for your lover comes!
