22/08/24, 10:37‚ÄØam
Every time I visit the Bronze Gallery in the Chennai Museum I am totally entranced by the depictions of the dancing Siva in sculptural forms. Each one of them is so alive, and yet so balanced, so powerful and yet so effortlessly graceful. One can spend hours just looking at their transcendental beauty. It is a difficult task to portray the infinite divine in finite forms. Sankaracharya articulated it perceptively, ‚ÄúO Lord, pardon my three sins: I have in contemplation clothed in form Thyself that hast no form; I have in praise described Thee who dost transcend all qualities; and in visiting shrines I have ignored Thine omnipresence.‚Äù
It is indeed an extremely challenging undertaking to portray and convey the manifestation of the Divine in tangible forms, especially the ‚ÄòDance of Shiva‚Äô in his avatar as Nataraja. The primal rhythmic energy of the dancing Shiva found its ultimate expression in the bronzes of the Chola period. Shiva's dance is set within a flaming halo. The god holds in his upper right hand the damaru (hand drum that made the first sounds of creation). His upper left hand holds agni (the fire that will destroy the universe). With his lower right hand, he makes abhayamudra (the gesture that allays fear). The dwarflike figure being trampled by his right foot represents apasmara purusha (illusion, which leads mankind astray). Shiva's front left hand, pointing to his raised left foot, signifies refuge for the troubled soul. The energy of his dance makes his hair fly to the sides.
There have been many interpretations of the Dance of Shiva. Ananda Coomaraswamy (who was born on 22nd August in 1877) wrote a brilliant essay detailing it, in the book ‚ÄòThe Dance of Shiva‚Äô, which was published in 1918. He offers a detailed analysis of the five types of dance Shiva does, with extensive and fascinating quotes from mythical literature. Coomaraswamy sees the dance of Shiva as an interplay of Prakriti and Purusha, ‚ÄúThe Essential Significance of Shiva‚Äôs Dance is threefold: First, it is the image of his Rhythmic Play as the Source of all Movement within the Cosmos, which is Represented by the Arch: Secondly, the Purpose of his Dance is to Release the Countless souls of men from the Snare of Illusion: Thirdly the Place of the Dance, Chidambaram, the Centre of the Universe, is within the Heart. He rises from His rapture, and dancing sends through inert matter pulsing waves of awakening sound, and lo! matter also dances appearing as a glory round about Him. Dancing, He sustains its manifold phenomena. In the fullness of time, still dancing, he destroys all forms and names by fire and gives new rest. By these means, our Father scatters the darkness of illusion (maya), burns the thread of causality (karma}, stamps down evil (mala, anava, avidyfi), showers Grace, and lovingly plunges the soul in the ocean of Bliss (ananda).‚Äù
Coomaraswamy concludes by saying, ‚ÄúThe image of Shiva as Nataraja is indelibly stitched into the Indian imagination‚Ä¶Whatever the origins of Shiva's dance, it became in time the clearest image of the activity of God which any art or religion can boast of.‚Äù
As Thirumular describes in Thirumanthiram;
‚ÄúThe dancing foot, the sound of the tinkling bells,
The songs that are sung and the varying steps,
The form assumed by our Dancing Gurupara ‚Äî
Find out these within yourself, then shall your fetters fall away.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
22/08/24, 10:41‚ÄØpm
Nature so divine.. Photograph has captured the divinity...
25/08/24, 9:11‚ÄØam
Ahalya and myself went for a ‚ÄòTree Walk‚Äô organized by ATREE yesterday morning at Lalbagh. Mr Ganesan with decades of experience gently guided us to identify different tree crown shapes, leaf patterns and details of the trunks, which helps to differentiate the species. ‚ÄòTree Walk‚Äô encourages us to slow down and gaze upwards to unravel how the species have adapted over the years and support a enormous range of birds and insects.
Lalbagh is home to a vast variety of trees from different parts of the world and it is fascinating to observe their details. There are about fifteen silk cotton trees spread around the garden and I am particularly drawn to a white silk cotton tree near the west gate. It is immensely huge, sprawling majestically across a vast space. The board near the tree informs that it is over two centuries old and it is not clear as to who would have planted it, though the folk lore suggests that it may be Tipu Sultan. To prevent the tree from falling during gusty storms, the tree has huge buttresses which extend for several feet around the trunk. These buttresses are akin to a mother rearing and supporting a child as it grows, develops and matures over the years. Whenever I look at them, I keep wondering about what kinds stories would be hidden within its withered, wrinkled, folds.
As Herman Hesse wrote in ‚ÄòWanderings; Notes & Sketches‚Äô, ‚ÄúTrees are sanctuaries. Whoever knows how to speak to them, whoever knows how to listen to them, can learn the truth. They do not preach learning and precepts, they preach, undeterred by particulars, the ancient law of life.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
27/08/24, 10:27‚ÄØam
Many of us might have grown up savouring every page of Chandamama comics with enchanting tales of mythology, folklore, and adventure. I was recollecting today about one particular story of Krishna and the sparrow.
Kurukshetra was being prepared for the big battle with elephants being used to uproot the trees and clear the space. When one such tree was uprooted, it disturbed a family of sparrows and all of them fell down along with their nest which ensured that they were unharmed. The mother sparrow looked around for some help as she feared that the young ones would be crushed in the ensuing battle. She noticed Krishna and pleaded that he save them all. Krishna responded saying that the law of nature would take its own course, he could not interfere with it and advised that she stock food for the next three weeks. The mother sparrow responded that she trusted Krishna and that the fate of her family rests in his hands and flew away.
When the battle commenced, Krishna asked Arjuna for his bow and arrow and took aim at an elephant. The arrow hit the massive bell around its neck which then fell down. When Krishna told Arjuna that the elephant was the one which brought down the sparrow‚Äôs nest, Arjuna wondered why Krishna did not kill it.
The Pandavas won the ensuing war in which numerous lives were lost. Krishna asked Arjuna to steer the chariot through the battleground which was littered with scores of bodies. He stopped at one place and asked Arjuna to lift an elephant bell which lay on the ground. Arjuna was puzzled as to why Krishna asked him to lift the bell when so many other things needed clearing. When he got down and lifted the bell all the young sparrows flew out with their mother. A single bell brought down by Krishna had saved the lives of the family of sparrows.
When I read it as a child, I was struck by the fact that Krishna found time amidst the great battle, to save a group of helpless sparrows. Its significance expands when I reflect on it now. We are much like the sparrows caught in the battlefield of life, over which we have little control. It is faith in ourselves and trust in a greater force that often helps us to navigate through the tribulations of life. It is the choices we make which define and guide us.
Dr Raguram
28/08/24, 9:22‚ÄØam
Yes. A familiar story but needs to be applied in our lives. Resilience develops when the perspective changes. Thank you Sir for the highlight of the aspects we need to inculcate in our lives.
28/08/24, 7:51‚ÄØam
You cannot miss the Dark Eyed Junco. They have a charm all of their own, with their black hood and unusual metallic chipping song, For the most part, they seem quite content to forage on the ground, kicking up the leaves to garner whatever morsels are hidden below. The flash of their characteristic white outer tail feather is unmistakable when they take to flight. They are quite handsome looking with their black heads and white plumage, like the old saying ‚Äúdark skies above, snow below.‚Äù In some parts of North America, they are strongly associated with winter and are often referred to as snowbirds.
Junco attracted the attention of poets like William Stafford (17 January 1914 - 28 August 1993). Stafford‚Äôs poems are characterized by simple language, unadorned imagery and a conversational tone. He was deeply attached to nature, as he mentioned in one of his works.
‚ÄúI like to live in the sound of water,
in the feel of mountain air. A sharp
reminder hits me: this world still is alive;
it stretches out there shivering toward its own
creation, and I‚Äôm part of it.‚Äù
He wrote a small, beautiful poem about the Junco:
‚ÄúThey operate from elsewhere,
some hall in the mountains ‚Äì
quick visit, gone.
Specialists on branch ends,
craft union. I like their
clean little coveralls.‚Äù
Canadian singer Anne Murray wrote a song about it, which won the 1971 Juno Award (the Canadian music award) for Best Produced Single. The song ends with these lines:
‚ÄúSpread your tiny wings and fly away
And take the snow back with you
Where it came from on that day
The one I love forever is untrue
And if I could you know
that I would fly away with you
yah if I could, you know that I would fly away with you.‚Äù
There is always an unmeasurable joy in watching birds and reading what the poets say about them!
Dr Raguram
30/08/24, 7:06‚ÄØam
An author whom I admire deeply is Oliver Sacks, who eloquently explored the interface between mind and brain in his works. I am captivated by Dr Sacks‚Äô beautiful stories and his loving portrayals of his patients. Referred to as the ‚Äòpoet laureate of modern medicine‚Äô, he died from ocular cancer on August 30, 2015, at the age of 82. We lead a finite existence and letting go can often be hard. It is an arduous task to negotiate the irreversible trajectory of impending death.
An anonymous scholar writing in the 15th century wrote a poignant tract on how to prepare oneself for a good death, entitled Ars Moriendi (Latin for ‚Äòthe art of dying‚Äô). The work instructs as to how one can prepare for their final hours on this earth. It emphasizes the importance of allowing a dying person to experience the emotions they feel without pathologizing those emotions. The possibility of being overwhelmed with existential despair is lessened by allowing a dying person to grieve in their own way, allowing them to focus on the things and people that matter to them most. As the text suggests, most importantly, death is about coming to terms with our transcendental nature.
After learning of his terminal diagnosis, Sacks reflected on these aspects with remarkable candour which was condensed into a book, ‚ÄòGratitude‚Äô. He wrote:
‚ÄúOver the last few days, I have been able to see my life as from a great altitude, as a sort of landscape, and with a deepening sense of the connection of all its parts. This does not mean I am finished with life. On the contrary, I feel intensely alive, and I want and hope in the time that remains to deepen my friendships, to say farewell to those I love, to write more, to travel if I have the strength, to achieve new levels of understanding and insight. This will involve audacity, clarity and plain speaking; trying to straighten my accounts with the world. But there will be time, too, for some fun (and even some silliness, as well). ..And now, weak, short of breath, my once-firm muscles melted away by cancer . . . I find my thoughts drifting to the Sabbath, the day of rest, the seventh day of the week, and perhaps the seventh day of one‚Äôs life as well, when one can feel that one‚Äôs work is done, and one may, in good conscience, rest.‚Äù
In these writings, Oliver Sacks reminds us that we are visitors here, passing through the great mystery of life. Every moment of life including the final ones is a gift and one can face death with poise and equanimity.
In his interesting book, ‚ÄòMusicophilia‚Äô, Oliver Sacks wrote, ‚ÄúIt really is a very odd business that all of us, to varying degrees, have music in our heads.‚Äù That music never dies‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
30/08/24, 1:43‚ÄØpm
A necessary diet for thought. How we live, learn to handle oddities, remind ourselves of the impermanence I think will help in the last moments. It is a practice. Thank you Sir for throwing light on the unknown (for me) authors...
31/08/24, 7:22‚ÄØam
It has been cloudy on most evenings in Bangalore, with an occasional rain drenching the parched earth. Clouds appearing in a vast array of shapes have been fascinating to watch. Slowly the fluffy white clouds give way to dark clouds, foreboding the arrival of rain. Poets and writers feel inspired to use them as metaphors of human emotions ranging from the joyous to the melancholic. Poems about clouds capture their ethereal beauty, ever-changing nature, and their symbolic significance. Shelley‚Äôs joyful poem, ‚ÄòThe Cloud‚Äô, starts with the beautiful line, ‚ÄúI bring fresh showers for the thirsting flowers‚Äù. Wordsworth conveyed a sense of loneliness describing clouds floating over fluttering daffodils in his poem, ‚ÄúI wandered lonely as a cloud.‚Äù In Rabindranath Tagore‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúClouds come floating into my life, no longer to carry rain or usher storm, but to add color to my sunset sky.‚Äù Mark Strand evocatively described clouds as being ‚Äúdrawn by invisible birds‚Äô and ‚ÄúIf a parrot is lost in a cloud, it turns into a rainbow.‚Äù
Clouds are moving poetry. As Thich Nhat Hanh commented. ‚ÄúIf you are a poet, you will see clearly that there is a cloud floating in this sheet of paper.‚Äù
They teased my imagination too!
Rainclouds
Caress gently
The boundless sky.
Dr Raguram
01/09/24, 11:41‚ÄØam
Gibbons may be the most endangered groups of primates on Earth. Hoolock Gibbon is the only ape species in India. Ahalya and myself were keen to have a glimpse of this rare species and we headed to The Hollongapar Gibbon Sanctuary, a habitat of the endangered Western hoolock gibbon in Assam. After finishing the formalities in the office at the entrance of the sanctuary, we made our way, accompanied by a forest guard. The only way to explore the forest is by walk. The sun was playing hide and seek through the thick trees covered with lush green foliage. As we were walking, we heard an unusual loud call. The guard whispered that it is the call of the gibbon. We walked further for an hour, but couldn‚Äôt spot any. Suddenly the guard noticed some activity in the higher reaches of the trees. We stood there for a while, keenly looking for its presence. Slowly a huge, glossy, black figure emerged, hanging from a branch in the tree with its long arm. It swung from one branch to another, adeptly, with sinuous movements. Soon several others joined and they were darting from one tree to another like skilled acrobats. It was so wonderful to watch their graceful movements. With their short torso, long legs, they almost looked like us!
The gibbons are arboreal animals, preferring to stay in the higher reaches of tall Hollong trees. They barely come down to the forest floor. As they are canopy dwellers, it is difficult to have a good look at them. One has to keep craning the neck all the time to spot them. It is also difficult to photograph them amidst the dark green cover. With some effort and lots of luck, I was able to freeze the experience through the lens!
Life is a collection of moments and our tryst with the Hoolock Gibbon was one of the most memorable experience in our sojourns into the wild. As Oscar Wilde commented, ‚Äúmemories are the diary we all carry with us‚Äù and our visit to the Hoollongapar Sanctuary will remain as a cherished entry in it.
(It is so apt to pen these reminiscences on the International Primate Day, especially when the theme this year is ‚ÄúConnecting with Wild Primates.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
05/09/24, 7:31‚ÄØam
Teacher‚Äôs Day is about paying tribute with an abiding sense of gratitude to teachers who have shaped our journey in learning.
Our formal education starts within the premises of a school. I was fortunate to be a student in the Ramakrishna Mission School, North Branch, Chennai. Among all the teachers who taught us, the one who left a deep impact on me was Sri TS Ranganathan Sir, referred to TSR. He had a commanding presence and when he entered the classroom we were over awed with his demeanor. He was a science teacher but he could also teach us about English literature, geography and human anatomy with ease and √©lan. He was a polymath. He shared with us anecdotes from forgotten pages of history and opened our minds to explore unknown landscapes of learning. I was learning tennis and one day he called to ask me whether I would like to join him on the tennis court. The school had a tennis court not far away from his home. When I reached the place, I found him dressed in his usual attire, an immaculate panchakacham. Panchakacham is not a regular dhoti and has five pleats delicately tucked in, much akin to a nine yards‚Äô saree worn by women in traditional attire. It took me a while to register that he was going to play tennis in this rather complicated outfit. My reservations were put to rest however when he started to serve. It was a booming service that would be the envy of any seasoned tennis player. I struggled to return it. He didn‚Äôt make it easy but egged me on to respond to it. At the end of an hour I was sweating profusely! He patted me and said, ‚ÄúGood start!‚Äù. Sometimes he would ask me to tabulate the results of the exam papers in his home and on completion of the task, I would be enthralled listening to him playing the harmonium.
TSR lit the fire to awaken the joy of learning which was not just confined to the classroom. Borrowing a saying from Robert Frost, he was ‚Äúnot a teacher, but an awakener.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
05/09/24, 6:29‚ÄØpm
Oh nice to hear about your experience with a 'teacher' in the real sense. Wish you a very happy teachers day sir. I have learnt a lot and continue to learn with your spotlights.
07/09/24, 7:56‚ÄØam
Nritya Ganapati is the 15th among the 32 forms of Ganesha. This exquisitely carved sculpture of Nritya Ganapati (Dancing Ganesha) is from Chennakeshava temple at Somanathapura. A significant aspect of Nritya Ganapati‚Äôs imagery is the setting of his dance, beneath the Kalpavriksha, or the wish-fulfilling tree. This choice of location is not arbitrary. The Kalpavriksha in Hindu mythology is known to grant all wishes. Nritya Ganapati‚Äôs dance under this tree thus becomes a metaphor for the joyous and bountiful nature of the cosmos. He is depicted with four hands. His left foot is firmly placed on the ground whereas the right one is lifted up and bent sideways at the knee. He is bejewelled and intricate ornaments decorate various parts of his body. Despite his bulky disposition, there is a lightness in his stance.
Oothukadu Venkata Subba Iyer, popularly known as Venkata Kavi, was a brilliant composer of the 18th Century who made immense contributions to the Carnatic Music repertoire. One of his memorable composition is on Nritya Ganapati, titled ‚ÄòAnandha Narthana Ganapathim‚Äô in the raga Naatai, which begins with these lines:
‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§® ‡§ó‡§£‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á ‚Äì (‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç / ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ )
‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡•ê ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§ú‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶)
Ananda nartana gaNapatim bhAvayE
chidAkAra mUlAdhAra OmkAra gajavadanam paramam param (Ananda)
I meditate on the joyous dancing Ganapati always
Whose form is pure consciousness, who lives in the muladhara chakra and who is the form of Om, the elephant faced one, the supreme one.
Though we recognize Ganesha in various forms, in Adi Shankara‚Äôs words, he is formless Supreme Brahman. 'Ajam Nirvikalpam Niraakaaramekam,' Ganesha is Ajam (unborn), Nirvikalpa (attributeless), Niraakaar (formless) and he symbolizes Brahman, the absolute consciousness.
Dr Raguram
13/09/24, 10:26‚ÄØam
Both Ahalya and myself are in the midst of looking closely at our collection of books and deciding which ones to hold onto and which ones to give away. In the process we discover that it is not as easy as it appears. When I pick up a book, weathered with ages, a flood of memories ensues. Most of the books we have bought are from the iconic ‚ÄòPremier Book Shop‚Äô. It was our usual haunt in the first week of the moth, once we got our stipends. Shanbhag would lift his head up from a pile of books, greet us and point out to the ones that we should have a look. Now, when I browse those books, making the choice to ‚Äòlet them go‚Äô is a daunting task. It is not merely a physical process of giving away the books, but also letting of the memories associated with them. Like the books, emotionally too we cling to myriad stories in our lives, often encompassing resentments, anger and a range of other negative feelings. Letting go is loosening those knots, freeing our energies to flow in the sea of life. It creates newer spaces for fresh beginnings. We have to open the cages of our mind and free the birds that are not meant to be caged.
As Herman Hesse remarked, ‚ÄúSome of us think holding on makes us strong, but sometimes it is letting go.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
14/09/24, 9:18‚ÄØam
One of the temples not often visited in Khajuraho is the Vamana temple. Set amidst a verdant, green landscape, it is a sight to behold with its spire reaching up like a beautiful mountain. Like rest of the temples in Khajuraho, the outer walls of the sanctum are adorned with intricate carvings depicting scenes from Hindu mythology. In the sanctum is a striking idol of Vamana, the fifth incarnation of Lord Vishnu. Vamana is the first incarnation whem Lord Vishnu appeared in a full human form, as a dwarf.
The legend of the Vamana avatar is narrated in the Rigveda and other scriptures. Mahabali, son of Virochan and grandson of Prahlad, was a generous, mighty monarch who was adored by his subjects. He was granted the boon of immortality by Lord Brahma and he continued to expand the frontiers of his empire. He conquered all the three realms: Heaven, Earth and the Underworld. Immensely troubled by growing powers, the Devas appealed to Lord Vishnu to intervene and restore the balance of power. Responding to their prayers, Lord Vishnu incarnated as Vamana, the dwarf and went to the Yaga that was being performed by Mahabali. During the Yaga, people could ask Mahabali for and receive anything they wanted. Mahabali bade Vamana to ask for anything that he wanted, like jewels, land, forests etc, without hesitation. Vamana denied all these politely and asked merely for three paces of land. Looking at Vamana‚Äôs diminutive stature, Bali said, ‚ÄòSo be it; pace and take it.‚Äô The dwarf Vamana suddenly grew in size into a giant and with one step measured the Earth and with another the entire Heaven. As there was no room left for the third step that had been granted, Mahabali humbly knelt under Vamana‚Äôs foot and offered his head. As Bali sank deep into the underworld, he heard his subjects wailing in grief for their much loved king. Seeing this, Vamana granted Mahabali one last boon. The boon was the permission to visit his subjects on Earth once a year. Thus, Mahabali returns every year to visit his people and the land that he had once ruled. Onam commemorates the annual visit of this legendary king from the underworld to his former kingdom, the land of Kerala.
Parsva Ekadashi which is observed today is also associated with the legend of Mahabali and Vamana Avatar of Lord Vishnu and is also referred to as Vamana Ekadashi. It is fascinating to note that the Onam festival follows the same legend and takes place around the same time of year.
Dr Raguram
18/09/24, 7:54‚ÄØam
William Carlos Williams was a full-time practicing physicians who was also a prolific writer across many literary genres. He regarded art and medicine as ‚Äútwo parts of a whole.‚Äù Williams rejected traditional conventions of rhyme and meter, masterfully blending colloquial idioms which lent a conversational tone to his poems. Often referred to as the ‚ÄúMaster of the glimpse,‚Äù Williams painted verbal pictures with crisp, vivid word images in poems like, ‚ÄúThe Red Wheelbarrow.‚Äù The subject of Williams‚Äôs poetry is quite varied; crowds attending baseball games, trains pulling into station, wheelbarrows, fire trucks, and a host of everyday subjects. He drew inspiration from grounded images from any source, in unexpected places.
Even though he was incapacitated by a stroke, he continued to type with his non dominant hand and completed his and Pulitzer Prize-winning ‚ÄúPictures from Brueghel.‚Äù Additional small strokes resulted in more deficits, but he kept on writing.
I particularly like his poem ‚ÄúThe Fool‚Äôs Song‚Äù
I tried to put a bird in a cage.
O fool that I am!
For the bird was Truth.
Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put
Truth in a cage!
And when I had the bird in the cage,
O fool that I am!
Why, it broke my pretty cage.
Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put
Truth in a cage!
And when the bird was flown from the cage,
O fool that I am!
Why, I had nor bird nor cage.
Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put
Truth in a cage!
Heigh-ho! Truth in a cage.
Much like the bird in the poem, each of us tussle with some deep secret or truth which we want to hide from others. But truth is hard to reveal and often cannot be hidden. As Leo Tolstoy observed, ‚ÄúVery often, all the activity of the human mind is directed not in revealing the truth, but in hiding the truth.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
21/09/24, 9:53‚ÄØam
As a birder, I am appalled at the sight of birds being confined to cages. Nature had assigned them the open sky and they do not deserve to be in such confined, claustrophobic spaces. When captured and put into cages, these birds become depressed and withdrawn. Their frustration at being restrained often leads to a form of self-mutilation called ‚Äòfeather-plucking‚Äô. As an Italian proverb states, ‚ÄúThe bird in its cage sings not for joy but in rage.‚Äù Sometimes we struggle like a caged bird battling enforced isolation in our lives.
Stevie Smith, a talented, but largely unknown poet, gave expression to these experiences in her poems, like this one titled, ‚ÄòThe Parrot‚Äô.
‚ÄúThe old sick green parrot
High in a dingy cage
Sick with malevolent rage
Beadily glutted his furious eye
On the old dark
Chimneys of Noel Park
Far from his jungle green
Over the seas he came
To the yellow skies, to the dripping rain,
To the night of his despair
And the pavement of his street
Are shining beneath the lamp
With a beauty that's not for one
Born under a tropic sun
He has croup. His feathered chest
Know no minute of rest
High on his perch he sits
And coughs and spits,
Waiting for death to come.
Pray heaven it won't be long.‚Äù
The parrot's helpless rage parallels the poet‚Äôs existential angst as she continuously feels caged in her personal life. Stevie Smith lived a largely secluded and celibate life and it was an unceasing saga of illness, abandonment and confinement. Beset with depression, she was preoccupied with the thought of death. The caged parrot is a metaphor for her life constrained by despair and depression, conveying the feeling of death as a release.
There is always the perennial question whether creativity occurs in spite of illness or because of it. Karl Jaspers in his ‚ÄòGeneral Psychopathology‚Äô, commented, ‚ÄúWas the morbid event only destructive or was it an ally in positive creation? Many more examples could be quoted and they cannot be subject to a single, common and exhaustive interpretation. But it is certain that some hidden correlation often stood in the background between the fact of illness and the profoundest of human possibilities, between human folly and wisdom."
I also wonder whether in battling her sadness Stevie Smith also draws attention to our confined, isolated urban existence in these times‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
22/09/24, 9:22‚ÄØam
Like William Carlos William, Dannie Abse (22 September 1923 - 28 September 2014), was a physician poet. Unlike the former, who largely kept medicine out of his poetry, Abse wanted to ‚Äúhear the heartbeat of words‚Äù and wrote about patients and the diseases they had, with tenderness. Even a stethoscope is infused with poetic insights, transmitting sounds ‚Äúover young women‚Äôs tense abdomens . . . of creation and in a dead man‚Äôs chest, the silence before creation began.‚Äù
His poem, ‚ÄòPortrait of an Old Doctor‚Äù begins with these beautiful, reflective lines:
‚ÄúLover of music more than his textbooks‚Äô
arrythmic prose and dated, almost dangerous
his Conybeare and his Boyd‚Äôs Pathology.
(Notes in the margin by the student he was)
What was it all about? Blunderbuss drugs
prescribed to ease the patient. And moonbeams.
A composer‚Äîa Beethoven, a Smetana‚Äîit seemed, could be deaf, but not a doctor.
He had been a conÔ¨Ådence man for the patient.
That‚Äôs how it was in the Theatre of Disease
and, at the Ô¨Ånal act, he had lifted
his stethoscope to listen
as if to Mozart.
Then, silently, relatives and friends Ô¨Åled out.
No applause. None for Hippocrates‚Äô art.‚Äù
Let me end this post with this poignant poem of Abse
‚ÄòMoonbright‚Äô
Afterwards, late, walking home from hospital,
that December hour too blatantly moonbright
- such an unworldly moon so widely round,
an orifice of scintillating arctic light -
I thought how the effrontery of a similar moon,
a Pirandello moon that would make men howl,
would, in future, bring back the eidolon
of you, father, propped high on pillow
your mouth ajar, your nerveless hand in mine.
At home, feeling hollow, I shamelessly wept
- whether for you or myself I do not know.
Tonight a bracing wind makes my eyes cry
while a cloud dociles an impudent moon
that is and was, and is again, and was.
Men become mortal the night their fathers die.‚Äù
Lastly, at this stage in my life, these lines from his poem ‚ÄòTalking to Myself‚Äô ‚ÄúIn the mildew of age/all pavements slope uphill‚Äô touch a deep chord within‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
23/09/24, 9:14‚ÄØam
On September 21, Max Schur, Freud‚Äôs personal physician visited him and was aghast to see him looking pale and quite wasted. Freud took his doctor‚Äôs hand and said, ‚ÄúMy dear Schur, you certainly remember our first talk. You promised me then not to forsake me when the time comes. Now it is nothing but torture and makes no sense anymore.‚Äù Schur responded stating that he had not forgotten the promise he made. Freud thanked him and told Schur to ‚Äútalk it over with Anna, and if she thinks it‚Äôs right, make an end of it.‚Äù Schur spoke to Anna and she sorrowfully concurred with her father‚Äôs wish. Then Schur gave Freud an injection of three centigrams of morphine, a dose much stronger than he would have used if the objective had only been to relieve pain. He was now assisting him to die a peaceful death. He gave Freud another injection that day, then a third on September 22. Freud lapsed into a coma, but he held on to life. At 3AM in the morning on Saturday, September 23, 1939, Sigmund Freud breathed his last. Three days later, his body was cremated and his ashes placed in an ancient Greek urn, originally gifted to him by his friend Marie Bonaparte.
Many years before, Freud had made it abundantly clear as to how he wanted to die as he never wanted to live without his mental capacities intact. He wrote to his friend Oskar Pfister, ‚ÄúWith all the resignation before destiny that suits an honest man, I have one wholly secret entreaty: only no invalidism, no paralysis of one‚Äôs powers through bodily misery. Let us die in harness, as King Macbeth says.‚Äù
Freud left the world with a certain degree of composure. In Nietzsche‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúThe most fortunate author is one who is able to say as an old man that all he had of life giving, invigorating, uplifting enlightening thoughts and feelings still lives on in his writings, and that he himself is only the gray ash, while the fire has been rescued and carried forth everywhere.‚Äù
The last book Freud read was Balzac‚Äôs La Peau de Chagrin (The Wild Ass‚Äôs Skin). The protagonist, Rapheal de Valentin, gains possession of a wild donkey‚Äôs skin and is granted all he wishes. The magical object has the power to fulfil its owner's every wish but carries a heavy price: With every wish the owner's remaining time in life is reduced. On finishing the book, Freud told Schur, ‚ÄúThis was the proper book for me to read.‚Äù
Mark Edmundson has written a very perceptive book on Freud‚Äôs last days, ‚ÄòThe Death Of Sigmund Freud.‚Äô The book ends with these words ‚ÄúToward the person who has died we adopt a special attitude: something like admiration for someone who has accomplished a very difficult task.‚Äù
In the words of Sheena Blackhall
‚ÄúIt was Saturday, under the sign of Libra
When he crossed, with the aid of morphine,
(that child of Morpheus, Greek God of Dreams)
Into the world of the dead.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
25/09/24, 9:17‚ÄØam
Internet is an immense ocean swirling with humongous amount of information. Sometimes by sheer coincidence an unknown pearl emerges from its depth. A few days ago, I was typing the word luminous in the search box and by mistake typed ‚Äòn‚Äô instead of ‚Äòl‚Äô and a mysterious word ‚Äònuminous‚Äô emerged. Curious to know further I googled about the word and found that it is credited to Rudolf Otto who was an eminent German theologian in the early part of twentieth century. Rudolf is regarded as one of the most influential scholars of comparative religion. He travelled to India twice, mastered Sanskrit and translated many ancient Hindu texts into German.
I also came across an interesting book summarizing his work, ‚ÄòIndia's Religion of Grace and Christianity Compared and Contrasted‚Äô which was dedicated to Sri Krishnaraja Wadiyar. When I was reading the book, I got to know more about his concept of the ‚ÄòNuminous‚Äô, an experience that, in his view, underlies all spiritual quests. According to him, it has three components, each designated with a Latin phrase: mysterium tremendum et fascinans. As mysterium, the numinous is entirely different from anything we experience in ordinary life. It evokes a reaction of transcendental silence. But the numinous is also a mysterium tremendum. Initially it provokes terror because of its overwhelming power. Finally, the numinous presents itself as fascinans, as merciful and gracious. Rudolf emphasized that it is essentially nonrational, subjective, and cannot be expressed in language. In his opinion, the numinous is a universal aspect of human spirituality and is at the core of all spiritual experience across various cultures and religions. His notion of the numinous remains an important framework for understanding the deeply transformative and awe-inspiring aspects of human spirituality.
I found his concept of ‚ÄòNuminous‚Äô, quite interesting as it is reflective of the perennial human quest to explore the deeper aspects of individual consciousness and seek its connection to something vast and infinite. For me I often have a glimpse of that state in my sojourns in nature. We only have to lift our accustomed veils to experience it.
(Rudolf Otto; September 25th 1869 - March 6th 1937)
Dr Raguram
27/09/24, 9:36‚ÄØam
Kay Ryan, the 16th Poet Laureate of USA has a distinctive, original voice. Her poems are short, not more than twenty lines, some even shorter, replete with intricate wordplay. I found the rich, imaginative nature of her poems quite alluring. She has written several poems about birds and this particular one is permanently installed at the Central Park.
How Birds Sing
‚ÄúOne is not taxed;
one need not practice;
one simply tips
the throat back
over the spine axis
and asserts the chest.
The wings and the rest
compress a musical
squeeze which floats
a series of notes
upon the breeze.‚Äù
There are many entrancing sounds in nature. Listening to the symphonic serenade emerging from the fragile throats of birds is a magical experience. I often immerse myself in that moment, swaying with their haunting, melodic airwaves. In the words of the poet Maria Rainer Rilke, ‚ÄúA birdsong can even for a moment, make the whole world into a sky within us.‚Äù

30/09/24, 8:49‚ÄØam
Today is the birthday of Rumi whose works continue to have a deep impact on me. His poems encompass a rich and complex tapestry of themes and ideas, all deftly woven together. Personally they have been inspiring signposts which gently guided me to discover myself anew.
Last week I spoke about the travails of the survivors of suicide in a CME. Suicide destroys the fabric of existence of the survivors and their lives become frayed at the edges. Embracing the reality of loss is not an easy task. It is an extremely poignant journey.
In this particular poem, Rumi explores the nature of grief and loss, suggesting that it can be a catalyst for self-discovery and growth.
‚ÄúYour grief for what you‚Äôve lost lifts a mirror
up to where you are bravely working.
Expecting the worst, you look, and instead,
here‚Äôs the joyful face you‚Äôve been wanting to see.
Your hand opens and closes, and opens and closes.
If it were always a fist or always stretched open,
you would be paralyzed.
Your deepest presence is in every small contracting and expanding,
the two as beautifully balanced
and coordinated
as birds' wings.‚Äù
Often the survivor‚Äôs world becomes constricted in the absence of the person and they withdraw into themselves. Through the evocative use of the metaphor of bird‚Äôs wings, Rumi extols the virtue of spreading the wings open, ‚Äòcontracting and expanding‚Äô them, to experience the transformative power of loss.
I have observed in my clinical work that the person whom the survivors think that they have lost, continues to live amidst their own feathers of memory and I strive to urge them to find strength in them, balance themselves and soar again.
Dr Raguram
05/10/24, 8:53‚ÄØam
On some days, the azure blue sky in Bangalore transforms itself in a moment to a painter‚Äôs palette. Gazing at the sky dappled with myriad colours inspires a sense of wonder. Sometime I imagine myself to be a bird drifting amidst the vast firmament and my imagination takes wings in its metaphorical wings. I wonder whether Flaubert alluded to this when he wrote, "If one always looked at the skies, one would end up with wings."
Our imagination is boundless and its transcendental power energizes and unfetters us.
‚ÄúImagination takes flight
On wings afloat
Poems unfold
In nature‚Äôs embrace‚Äù
Dr Raguram
06/10/24, 8:20‚ÄØam
There was quite a heavy downpour in Bengaluru last evening and the meteorologists predicted that more will be on the anvil. Forecasting weather can be quite dicey, even with machine learning techniques which are making steady inroads to predict rainfall, more accurately.
Sometimes an experienced farmer can foresee the onset of rain more accurately than any algorithm. Once we went in search of the most elusive bird in India, the Great Indian Bustard, in the Desert National Park. We got the permission with some difficulty and proceeded to a little village Khuri where we stayed with a farmer in his simple homestay. We spent a night in the midst of the desert with his assistance and it was an experience to cherish. Next morning we were to proceed to the national park. As we were taking leave from the farmer, he looked up in the sky (which incidentally was totally clear), and said, much to our dismay that it will rain in the park area in an hour or two. True to his words, as we neared the national park, it started raining, gathering strength in few minutes. We waited for a while, hoping that it will abate and after some time, rain stopped. But unfortunately we couldn‚Äôt enter the park as the tracks inside were muddy and not suitable for the only vehicle that is allowed inside, camel drawn cart, to venture in. Needless to say, it was a huge disappointment. But till this day it amazes me as to how the farmer forecasted the rains so accurately, by just looking at the sky! (I did catch up with the elusive bird, year later and that‚Äôs another story!)

Such a serene sight even if one sees in a photograph! Nature works wonders!
