Art & culture

03/01/24, 9:19‚ÄØam
Rudaki was a poet, singer, and musician who is regarded as the first major poet to write in New Persian. He wrote several thousand poems and unfortunately only a few survive. In Iran, Rudaki is acknowledged as the "founder of New Persian poetry" and in Tajikistan as the "father of Tajik literature". Rudaki was also an innovator of poetic form. Aside from writing in forms inherited from Arabic poetry, he is thought to be the first poet to have written in the rubaiyat form, which is a quatrain consisting of two couplets.
Interestingly he translated Panchatantra stories which gained popularity in the medieval Europe as, 'The Fables of Bidpai'. The Persian version by Rudaki is known as ‚ÄòKalileh o Demneh‚Äô.
His poetry is replete with interesting imagery and vivid description of nature. Observing the clouds one day, he wrote:
Look at that cloud,
how it cries like a grieving man,
Thunder moans like a lover with a broken heart.
Now and then the sun peeks from behind the clouds
Like a prisoner hiding from the guard.
This particular poem is about the Hoopoe. Hoopoe has had an important status in Persian literature and often considered as a guide that directs the mystics toward God. Rudaki wrote:
I saw a hoopoe near Sarakhs
Whose little song reached the clouds.
She was wearing a little cloak Of many different colors.
I stand before you in awe.
Dr Raguram
04/01/24, 8:53‚ÄØam
All of us are accustomed to seeing with our eyes and also communicate with the written word. When blindness sets in and one cannot see, one has to rely on the sense of touch. It is such a poignant and inspiring sight in our cities to see the blind negotiate the travails of travel with the touch of the white wand. Can the sense of exquisite touch help them also to read and communicate?
This was the quest of Louis Braille (whose birthday is today), who lost his vision early in life. When he was 12, a French soldier by the name of Charles Barbier introduced him to ‚Äúnight writing,‚Äù a system he had invented that used patterns of 12 raised dots to simulate letters so soldiers could communicate across battles in secret. Braille‚Äôs magic wand was a group of six dots in which the vertical line consists of three dots, and the horizontal of two. The combination of these dots produces characters to each of which a particular meaning is assigned, just as the seeing does to the alphabets in print. It is amazing how six dots can be so combined to represent so many things. Braille refined this by the time he was 15 and published his Braille Code in 1829. Unfortunately, it did not receive international attention until 1868, a full 16 years after Braille‚Äôs death.
The Braille Code liberated the ‚ÄúPeople of the Night‚Äù, who had resigned to the dark abyss of blindness. It opened doors of learning and was instrumental in weaving bonds of companionship between those who could not see.
What is remarkable about Braille is that he was only a child when he developed his revolutionary invention. He had no training, no funding, no public or institutional support, no commercial motive or business plan and only the dream to open the doors of knowledge to the blind.
As John Lee Clark, a blind poet wrote about Braille:
The world rests on my lap.
If my finger is the sky,
Then under it the fields prosper.
Row after perfect row of buds
Bid me gather all I can.
The harvest is food for thought
Dr Raguram
05/01/24, 10:09‚ÄØam
It was a bright morning and as we were making our way in the Coyote Hills Regional Park, we heard a loud, rattling sound. And when we looked around, a bird with bright colours under its wings caught our eyes. It perched on the outer branches of a tree, feasting on the berries. It was the Northern Flicker. As we were watching, it, hopped down onto the ground, foraging for insects. Its scientific name is Colaptes auratus. Colaptes means ‚Äúto peck.‚Äù Northern Flickers are often referred to as the ‚Äúanteaters of the sky.‚Äù Unlike other woodpeckers, which usually remain high in the treetops, Northern Flickers venture down to ground level to search for their favourite meal, ants. They are ably assisted in this task by their slightly curved bill. Their dusky brow plumage helps them to blend with the colours of the forest floor. Most woodpeckers in North America have black white stripped plumage, which helps them to blend in with tree bark. Northern Flickers stand apart and are considered the ‚Äòblack sheep‚Äô of the woodpecker family because they have brown feathers and forage for food on the ground. The Northern Flicker is one of the few North American woodpeckers that is strongly migratory.
(On the occasion of the National Birds Day which is observed on January 5 in USA to raise awareness about the role of birds in our ecosystem)
Dr Raguram
06/01/24, 9:46‚ÄØam
Among the many calls that I received this New Year, I was deeply touched by a particular one. It was from a lady whom I had known for the past few years. She rang up and said, ‚ÄúDoctor let this New Year be good for you and all those who help others‚Äù. What is distinctive about the caller is that she is a crematorium worker who handles all the paper work there.
I met her a few years ago, helping a friend who had lost a family member, to fill the forms. When I was about to leave, she asked me whether I was a doctor. Hearing the affirmative answer, she shared her psychological travails which were being attended to by a dear former student. I reassured her stating that she was in good hands while emphasizing the need to be regular with treatment. She profusely thanked me and thereafter kept in touch with me periodically.
Working in a crematorium can be a daunting task, more so being a woman. At a time when the term ‚Äòstress‚Äô is flaunted widely, I was keen to know more about her and how she coped with her situation. Her answer was simple, ‚ÄúI earn a livelihood doctor, for the sake of my children, for their better future‚Äù. I gathered that her husband was a drunkard without any regular work and she had to tend for two young children, with very little support from the extended family. She works six days a week with few breaks or any holiday. At the end of a busy working day, she gets back home, has a bath and starts cooking for the night. Her husband scolds and often beats her, if by chance the food is delayed. He is also sexually demanding and if she refuses, starts suspecting her. In spite of these ordeals when I chance to see her at work, I invariably find her attending to her task with a smile on her face.
By accepting the job, she has joined a cadre of Indian women who are entering arenas from which they have traditionally been excluded. That she has chosen to work in a space with significant stigma associated with it, where even men feel uneasy to be in, is a testament to her resilience.
A plant that can teach us resilience is the bamboo. It can withstand twice as much force bearing down on it while being stretched, pulled or bent. According to a Japanese proverb: ‚ÄúIn time, even the strongest wind tires itself out, but the bamboo remains standing tall and still.‚Äù
There is an interesting Zen parable, ‚ÄòBe like a bamboo‚Äô:
A Zen Master was walking through the forest down a narrow trail with one of his students along a steep incline. The student lost his footing and slipped; just as he began tumbling down the hill, the student reached out and grabbed a small bamboo tree. The bamboo bent nearly all the way over as the student continued to hold on tightly. He pulled himself up and brushed off the dirt with the Zen Masters help.
‚ÄúDid you notice that when you fell, you grabbed a hold of the bamboo and it bent nearly all the way over and still supported you.‚Äù the Zen Master asked.
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the student replied. The Zen Master gripped the bamboo and pulled the bamboo over.
‚ÄúBe like the bamboo,‚Äù the Zen Master said as he let go of the bamboo and it sprang back to its up-right position. ‚ÄúIt is pushed around by the wind and yet it always bounces back and grows upward, toward the sun, enlightenment. Have you ever felt as though you were going to snap? Have you ever felt as though you were at your breaking point, emotionally?‚Äù
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the student replied.
‚ÄúThen bend, do not break, such is the way with bamboo. It endures the stress and finds a way to bounce back!‚Äù the Zen Master stated. ‚ÄúThis is called resilience.‚Äù
Throughout our journey in life, we meet people along the way and we connect with the heart of a few from whom we draw inspiration. They become a poem or a story in my life to live by.
Dr Raguram
10/01/24, 9:05‚ÄØam
I had posted yesterday about Simone de Beauvoir‚Äôs ‚ÄòSecond Sex‚Äô, wherein she urges women to
have the freedom to escape from prescribed social roles and seek their own identity. This perspective has been articulated well in many works of fiction. Daisy Rockwell's translation of Geetanjali Shree's Hindi novel ‚ÄòRet Samadhi‚Äô ‚Äò‚Äô‡§∞‡•á‡§§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‚Äô which I read some time ago, is one such engaging narrative. It traces the life trajectory of a woman who is recently bereaved and her journey to discover aspects of self that were deeply buried within her.
The strength of any work of fiction is that it can be read at different layers, each with its own attendant meaning. Grief after a loss of a partner has been essayed in many novels. Usually it follows a predictable path, focusing on the loss and its emotional impact within the individual. What is different in this work is the broader narration of separation and loss in the historical context of partition and the quest of the protagonist to seek her personal identity embedded in it.
The novel is tale of transformative powers of crossing the ‚Äòborders‚Äô, of geography, gender and prescriptive roles, reaffirming that the inner landscape has no borders. ‚ÄúAnything worth doing transcends borders‚Äù.
The protagonist‚Äôs travel is also a journey into her own self, opening doors of discovery. In her words, ‚ÄúAlways, at least once, every woman, whether this one or that one, whether small or big, finds herself at the door, one foot poised in the air, like a dancer striking a mudra, a pose, in order to re-enter the home or that door which she has renounced and already left far behind, asking herself in that moment, Is this my world in which I‚Äôm setting foot, or is it that which is receding behind me, where I had gone, or whence I‚Äôve come?‚Äù
As for the story, ‚ÄúOnce you‚Äôve got women and a border, a story can write itself. Even women on their own are enough. Women are stories in themselves, full of stirrings and whisperings that float on the wind, that bend with each blade of grass.‚Äù
There is extensive use of metaphors like doors and windows. ‚Äúthere was a painter, Bhupen Khakkar. He told stories with brush‚Ä¶He knew that a story cannot be locked into a box, or a canvas, or a gaze. So he never tried. On the contrary, he always left a small window, an empty space, so the story could move on at will and take another path if it so desired. Because stories never end. They jump through windows and cracks‚Ä¶or create them by shaking, causing the earth to quake"
The novel is replete with lyrical passages, like this one, ‚ÄúMa sips her morning tea as though drinking in a bird‚Äôs song‚Äù.
All together a fascinating read!
Dr Raguram
11/01/24, 10:23‚ÄØam
William James (whose birthday is today), is most famous for his psychology textbook,‚Äô Principles of Psychology‚Äô which was published in 1890. It consisted of two volumes with over 1400 pages and took him 12 years to write. He did not produce any original research, did not perform any experiment, yet he became the driving force behind psychology.
Of the many topics he addressed during his life time, he is most famous for his theories about emotions and consciousness. Concerning emotions, James believed that a person is exposed to a stimulus, has a physiological reaction, and then interprets that reaction as emotion. So, first comes physiological arousal, then the subjective interpretation of those processes as emotion. An independent researcher in Denmark, Carl Lange, developed a similar theory of emotion at roughly the same time as James did. Their view of emotion came to be known as the James-Lange theory of emotion. Though it was later thought not to be an accurate theory of how emotions work, its framework was quite influential in drawing attention to the interaction between physiological processes and emotion.
William James also conceptualized consciousness as a river or a stream, constantly changing and never the same. He had an abiding interest in religion and faith. He believed that divine existence can be justified by the emotional benefits it brings to one‚Äôs life. His book ‚ÄòThe Varieties of Religious Experience: a study in human nature‚Äô, examines varied forms of religious experiences such as mystical experiences, conversion, saintliness, and spirituality from a psychological perspective. I was quite surprised to learn that the emphasis given in Alcoholic Anonymous is largely due to the influence of this book. It seems that when Bill, a co-founder of AA, was trying to fight his way back to sobriety, chanced upon a copy of the book and was deeply impressed by James' "great wisdom." It also helped Bill to finally achieve sobriety and the impact of the book can be seen in the formulation of AA's basic ideas.
James was an inspiring teacher. His students included such luminaries as Theodore Roosevelt, author and philosopher George Santayana and Gertrude Stein.
I particularly like this observation of his, ‚ÄúA great many people think they are thinking when they are merely rearranging their prejudices.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
13/01/24, 10:01‚ÄØam
In my forays into the Zen landscape, I discovered the poetry of Ryokan. His poems are direct and unpretentious, infused with profound insights. For example, he wrote:
The rain has stopped, the clouds have drifted away,
and the weather is clear again.
If your heart is pure, then all things in your world are pure.
Abandon this fleeting world, abandon yourself,
Then the moon and flowers will guide you along the Way.
He is reported to have led a live of extreme simplicity. He showed love for all living things to the extent of placing lice under his robes to keep them warm, allowing thieves to take freely from his possessions, and letting one leg protrude from his mosquito net at night to give the mosquitos food. As a Zen priest, he never established his own temple, and lived by alms. Instead of preaching, he enjoyed companionship and conversation with many ordinary people. His practice consisted of sitting in zazen meditation, walking in the woods, playing with children, making his daily begging rounds, reading, writing poetry and on occasion drinking sake with friends. He was adept in calligraphy and was also known as one of Japan's great calligraphers.
He was deeply influenced by the teachings of Dogen, the 13th century monk, about whom I wrote sometime back. Ryokan never published a collection of verse while he was alive. One of his last verses reads;
Life is like a dewdrop,
Empty and fleeting;
My years are gone
And now, quivering and frail,
I must fade away.
As Rabindranath Tagore wrote, ‚ÄúLet your life lightly dance on the edges of Time like dew on the tip of a life.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
15/01/24, 8:08‚ÄØam
India with its diverse and rich cultural heritage celebrates multitudes of festivals throughout the year. The harvest festival holds a distinct place among them. The onset of harvest season is observed all across the country under various names based on the region where it is celebrated. It is essentially an act of thanksgiving to the farmers. Farmers who tend to the land with care and concern are the backbone of our society. We may need the help of a doctor or a lawyer sometime in our lives, but we need the farmer every day, three times a day to provide us with food.
Saint Poet Thiruvalluvar‚Äôs magnum opus Thirukkural consists of 133 chapters having 10 couplets each. Each one of them consisting of just one line and a half, like a short haiku. Thiruvalluvar devotes an entire chapter (104) wherein he extols the glory and greatness of agriculture and the important role of farmers.
‡Æá‡Æ∞‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ∞‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æà‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ∞‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡Æï‡Øà‡Æö‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡Æ£‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡ÆØ‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç.
Those who plough do not ask but give with both hands
To those that ask, the bounty they have tilled
On this festival day let us pay obeisance to our indefatigable farmers who are battling tremendous odds to keep us satiated.
As the Pongal brims over the pot
Let us pray to the lord
That joy bubbles in farmer‚Äôs heart
Forever
Dr Raguram
16/01/24, 8:17‚ÄØam
Today is Mattu Pongal. On this day cattle are given a well-deserved day of rest and a pride of place. They are washed, their horns are painted and covered with shining metal caps. Multi-coloured beads, tinkling bells, sheaves of corn and flower garlands are tied around their necks. They look majestic in all their finery. It is essentially a day of thanksgiving to the cattle friends by the farmers. Cattle play important roles in different stages of cultivation. Even after the fields are harvested, they are used to separate the ear of the grains from the stalk by walking over the stalks. Besides their importance in ploughing fields, their manure also serves as natural fertilisers. While the practice of using cattle as farm labour has all but disappeared in Tamil Nadu today, there is still a thriving dung economy. For example, ‚ÄòThozhuvam Farmer Producer Organization‚Äô in Madurai directly sources cow dung and markets value-added products such incense sticks, dung handicrafts, and more. Their main agenda is to safeguard the traditional Pulikulam and Theni hill cattle breeds that are on the verge of extinction.
There are beautiful descriptions of cattle in Sangam poetry. For example, Orampokiyar wrote more than 100 poems and in one verse in Aiynkurunooru., he offers a beautiful description of a buffalo:
'‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æ±‡Øà ‡ÆÆ‡ØÄ‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æ¥‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øä‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æï‡Øà,
‡ÆÖ‡Æ∞‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡ÆÜ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Øá‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ®‡ØÜ‡Æ±‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ
‡Æà‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æ£‡Øç ‡Æé‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øà‡Æö‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ,
‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡Æö‡Øá‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æ≥‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æû‡Øç‡Æö‡Æø, ‡Æ™‡Øä‡Æ¥‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Æü,
‡Æ™‡Øà‡Æ®‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ£ ‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Ææ‡ÆÖ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ±‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ,
‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡ØÇ‡Æâ‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øä‡Æü‡Æø‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æï‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Øà ‡Æö‡ØÇ‡Æü‡Æø, ‡ÆÆ‡ØÇ‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øç
‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡Æ±‡Æø ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æ≥‡Æ∞‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æä‡Æ∞‡Æ©‡Øç
an old buffalo, his back wet and cool, his horns curved,
grazes on bright-flowered lilies
in a pond full of water and fish
sleeps all night in the oozing mud,
and then when dawn comes
walks out, crushing fish with their feet,
drapes himself with bright creepers,
and enters the ancient town like a warrior victorious in battle.
(The unique terracotta temples at Bishnupur, around 140kms from Kolkata, feature intricate carvings showcasing the skills of the artisans who created them).
Dr Raguram
18/01/24, 8:28‚ÄØam
Most us would have read ‚ÄòWinnie the Pooh‚Äô by AA Milne (whose birthday is today). He wrote seven novels, five nonfiction books and 34 plays, along with numerous stories and articles. But ‚ÄòWinnie the Pooh‚Äô which was published in 1926, eclipsed and erased the memory of his other works. It featured characters based on his son, who was the inspiration for Pooh‚Äôs best friend, Christopher Robin and his stuffed animal toys. The Hundred Acre Woods, where Pooh‚Äôs adventures take place, was based on the 500 Acre Woods near Milne‚Äôs home.
A few years after Winnie-the-Pooh was published, Milne began to resent the fame that it brought on him and his family. He stated, ‚ÄúI feel that Christopher Robin has already had more publicity than I want for him. I do not want CR Milne to ever wish that his name was Charles Robert.‚Äù His son also disliked this attention, as the legacy of Christopher Robin and Pooh Bear followed him all throughout his life, making it difficult for him to make a name as his own person. In his memoir, ‚ÄòThe Enchanted Place‚Äô, he wrote, ‚ÄúIn pessimistic moments, when I was trudging London in search of an employer wanting to make use of such talents as I could offer, it seemed to me, almost, that my father had got to where he was by climbing upon my infant shoulders, that he had filched from me my good name and had left me with nothing but the empty fame of being his son.‚Äù
Strangely, there have been several attempts to ban the book. In 2009, Russian authorities banned it for being pro-Nazi, after an image of Pooh with a swastika was discovered amongst an extremist‚Äôs collection. In the United Kingdom, the book was banned from public schools, as the character Piglet might offend Muslim and Jewish students who abstain from pork for religious reasons. And in 2017, the Chinese government began censoring Winnie the Pooh on social media platforms after critics used the character to mock Xi Jinping and his policies.
What is more galling is the attempt to identify psychiatric disorders among the characters in the book. In 2000, paediatrician Sarah Shea and her team released a journal article titled ‚ÄúPathology in the Hundred Acre Wood: a neurodevelopmental perspective on A.A. Milne.‚Äù It proposed that each of the Winnie-the-Pooh characters displayed symptoms of a different mental disorder. Unfortunately this trend caught on and there have been several attempts in this vein over the years.
In spite of all this, ‚ÄòWinnie the Pooh‚Äô resonates with people of all ages due to its relatable characters and heart-warming stories, addressing themes such as friendship, love, and the pursuit of happiness.
"Sometimes, if you stand on the bottom rail of a bridge and lean over to watch the river slipping slowly away beneath you, you will suddenly know everything there is to be known" Pooh.
Dr Raguram
19/01/24, 7:53‚ÄØam
When I look at a painting by Paul Cezanne (whose birthday is today), I am attracted to his innovative use of colour, particularly its relationship with form. His visual language is uniquely personal. There is a magical quality in his canvases which are replete with use of multitude of colours and distinctive brush strokes. He explored an amazing range of subjects throughout his career: landscape, portraiture, figures and still life. I am particularly fond of his still life paintings. In the hands of an unimaginative artist, still life can be quite stilted, but not in Cezanne‚Äôs hands. He was particularly drawn into painting fruits, particularly apples which take on an inexplicable lustrous luminosity in his paintings. He confided to a friend that "they [fruits] love having their portraits done. They exhale their message with their scent. They reach you with all their smells and tell you about the fields they‚Äôve left, the rain that made them grow, the dawns they watched. When I‚Äôm outlining the skin of a lovely peach with soft touches of paint, or a sad old apple, I catch a glimpse in the reflections they exchange of . . . the same love of the sun, the same recollection of the dew, a freshness."
How should one look at his paintings? In his own words, ‚ÄúShut your eyes, wait, and think of nothing. Now, open them ‚Ä¶ one sees nothing but a great coloured undulation. What then? An irradiation and glory of colour. This is what a picture should give us ‚Ä¶ an abyss in which the eye is lost, a secret germination, a coloured state of grace ‚Ä¶ loose consciousness. Descend with the painter into the dim tangled roots of things, and rise again from them in colours, be steeped in the light of them.‚Äù
Now look at Cezanne‚Äôs apples and see them come alive!
Dr Raguram
20/01/24, 7:01‚ÄØam
You cannot miss the European Robin when you take a stroll in the gardens of London. unlike its counterpart in America, it is a colourful bird with a striking orange breast. As you watch, it makes forays to the ground to catch insects and quickly flies back to its shady perch. The French naturalist Georges Cuvie gave the bird its current name Erithacus rubecula. The epithet rubecula is derived from the Latin, ruber ‚Äòred‚Äô.
The Victorian postmen used to be known as robins because part of their tunic was orange red. When Christmas cards first came into vogue they were brought by robins! And robins started featuring in the in the Christmas cards too.
There is a wealth of Christian mythology associated with it. The legend is that the robin was moved when it saw Christ on the cross and began to pluck the thorns out of the crown of thorns. The blood stained the robin and hence its orange red breast. According to an Irish tale, a robin flew in to see the infant Jesus in the manger. The infant reached out to touch the bird causing it to blush in deference and hence its colour!
Shakespeare refers to the charming song of the European Robin in Two Gentlemen of Verona.
Valentine: Why, how know you that I am in love?
Speed: Marry, by these special marks: first, you have learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms like a malcontent; to relish a love song like a robin redbreast; to walk alone like one that had the pestilence; to sigh like a schoolboy that had lost his ABC; to weep like a young wench that had buried her grandam; to fast like one that takes diet; to watch like one that fears robbing; to speak puling like a beggar at Hallowmas.
Emily Dickinson wrote a lovely small poem about it:
If I can stop one heart from breaking,
I shall not live in vain;
If I can ease one life the aching,
Or cool one pain,
Or help one fainting robin
Unto his nest again,
I shall not live in vain.
It is believed that when a robin appears, it is a sign that a loved one is near.
Dr Raguram
23/01/24, 9:11‚ÄØam
Sometime back we visited Avani in Kolar district (a detailed description is at: (https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/avani). Avani attained prominence due to myriad legends associated with it. Most importantly, it is said to be the site of Uttara Ramayana. There is a small beautiful, Ramalingeshwara temple which dates back to 10th century. A hillock strewn with boulders forms an interesting backdrop to this ancient temple. It is believed that Sita retreated to this hill after her trial by fire and gave birth to Lava and Kusha who grew up in the hermitage of Valmiki. There are several caves; one of them is considered to be Valmiki‚Äôs ashram and another one where Sita lived and cooked for her children.
I was keen to find out whether there are other places identified as Sita‚Äôs Kitchen. To my great surprise, I discovered that there are several Sita‚Äôs Rasoi (kitchen) dotted across the subcontinent. At least two of Sita‚Äôs kitchens have been documented in Ayodhya, but only one survived the demolition of the Babri Masjid. I understand that within the complex on the Ramkot in Ayodhya, there is a building bearing the painted phrase ‚ÄúJanmasthana Sita Rasoi‚Äù (Birthplace Sita‚Äôs Kitchen). The garbhagriha contains a rolling board, rolling pin, chulha and an image of Sita.
When I searched for other ‚ÄòSita‚Äôs Rasois‚Äô, I found documentation of several others: Lalapur near Allahabad, Chitrakoot, Brahmavarta in UP and Nasik in Maharashtra amongst others. Each one of them is adjacent to Valmiki‚Äôs ashram and similarly contain a rolling pin, board and a chulha.
I also looked for mention of Sita and her kitchen in many of the Ramayanas. There were none. An array of localized narratives and memories associated with Sita and her kitchen seemed to have evolved over time across the country. It would be a fascinating exercise to explore how these memories of the past have been constructed, celebrated and sometimes politically appropriated too.
While Rama is valorised and huge temples are built to honour him, for some inexplicable reason, Sita has been relegated and confined to the kitchen. Is her power and authority confined to the kitchen alone? Cooking, to a large extent has been embedded in the patriarchal construction of femininity. If the kitchen is a feminine abode, it might also be a site of resistance.
In the animated film, ‚ÄòSita Sings The Blues‚Äô, Nina Paley relocates her as a woman who retells her own story in her own voice in an altogether different context. Sita‚Äôs songs not only give her a voice.
Perhaps it is time to retell the Ramayana from the perspective of Sita.
Dr Raguram
24/01/24, 1:15‚ÄØpm
Deep sense of gratitude to all our donors who donated computers, laptops and furniture to realize our initiative to start training in computers for tribal children at Disha Learning Resource Centre at the tribal school in Wayanad
24/01/24, 4:45‚ÄØpm
I didn't know Lava and Kusha were born in Karnataka! Valmiki didn't stay in one place but the place where they were born is in the north. In Valmiki Ramayana there are many situations where her strengths, importance, judgment are highlighted. Actually Laksmana was the one who took the responsibility of looking after the welfare like constructing ashrams, getting fruits etc. May be cooking she did as part of her dutyüòä
25/01/24, 9:32‚ÄØam
Nambinarayana temple is at Thirukurungudi, a serene village in Tirunelveli district. It is a beautiful temple with hundreds of sculptures and carvings. Of the several lovely ones in the main gopuram, an interesting one depicts a seated Rama contemplating as to how he can journey across the sea to reach Lanka. For three days he fasted and meditated, praying to the God of the sea, Varuna, to appear and to help him find a way to cross to Lanka. There was no response, nothing but the endless, repetitive sound of the waves. Rama, infuriated by this unbearable silence picked up his bow and began to shoot arrows into the sea. The creatures of the sea began to die, and the waters began to burn. The army of monkeys who had come to help Rama were aghast and alarmed at this display of violence against the sea and her innocent creatures and tried to dissuade him to stop the onslaught. Just as Rama was about to unleash the all-powerful weapon, Brahmastra, Varuna appeared out of the sea. He bowed to Rama and calmly explained that there was nothing to be so upset about and that he would ensure that the waves would remain still while a way was found for Rama‚Äôs forces to cross the sea, and that they would remain calm until they had completed their crossing. Then, Hanuman came up with a solution and assured Rama that he along with other monkeys would build a bridge.
In this small carving you can see Rama and in front of him is Varuna. Lakshmana is standing behind him. He is surrounded by the army of monkeys. Hanuman at his feet and another one by Rama‚Äôs side are trying to dissuade him from taking any drastic action.
The bridge as a metaphor, conveys multifaceted meanings. It symbolizes a sense of connectedness and union, both physically and psychologically. Even the process of building the structure is not merely an individual act, but a collective one driven by a common cause to link and join together that which is disparate and separate. Something to ponder and reflect on‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
28/01/24, 10:12‚ÄØam
One of the birds I closely observed during my forays in the vast, arid lands of Rann of Kutch was the sleek, powerful, fast flying Peregrine Falcon. I observed it making sorties with tremendous speed, caressing the wind with an agile grace. It was exploring the boundless sky with unfettered freedom.
After my return, I read WB Yeats famous poem, ‚ÄòThe Second Coming‚Äô. Yeats wrote this poem after World War I, a global catastrophe that killed millions of people. The First World War unleashed humanity‚Äôs power to harm and kill, a trend that has gotten worse with the advent of the nuclear power. The poem is replete with lots of Biblical allusions. Beyond this, to me personally, the first stanza of the poem with its potent images, perceptively describes the plight of our civilization. The ‚Äúfalconer,‚Äù representing our attempt to control the natural world, has lost its ‚Äúfalcon‚Äù in the ever expanding ‚Äúgyre‚Äù (of progress?). The poet alludes to an evolving situation when "Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold."
‚ÄúThe falcon cannot hear the falconer;
Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold;
Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world,
The blood-dimmed tide is loosed, and everywhere
The ceremony of innocence is drowned;
The best lack all conviction, while the worst
Are full of passionate intensity.‚Äù
Though written decades ago, these lines, imbued with timeless allegory, resonate even now,

01/02/24, 8:04‚ÄØam
Every time I step into the bronze gallery of the Chennai museum, I am overwhelmed by the sheer beauty of the priceless exhibits encompassed in its glass display cases. The most impressive pieces are that of Siva as the cosmic dancer, Nataraja.
Whenever I look at them, I recollect the words of Fritjof Capra, (whose birthday is today),in ‚ÄòThe Tao of Physics‚Äô, relating the Nataraja‚Äôs dance with modern physics:
‚ÄúEvery subatomic particle not only performs an energy dance, but also is an energy dance; a pulsating process of creation and destruction‚Ä¶without end‚Ä¶For the modern physicists then, Shiva‚Äôs dance is the dance of subatomic matter. As in Hindu mythology, it is a continual dance of creation and destruction involving the whole cosmos; the basis of all existence and of all natural phenomena...the metaphor of the cosmic dance thus unifies ancient mythology, religious art and modern physics.‚Äù
He went on to comment, ‚ÄúThe mystic and the physicist arrive at the same conclusion; one starting from the inner realm, the other from the outer world. The harmony between their views confirms the ancient Indian wisdom that Brahman, the ultimate reality without, is identical to Atman, the reality within.‚Äù
In the words of Appar, the seventh century Shaivaite poet saint, who went to Chidambaram to see the cosmic dance of Siva,
‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øä‡Æµ‡Øç‡Æµ‡Øà‡Æö‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡Æµ‡Øç‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Æø‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æö‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æø‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç
‡Æ™‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æö‡Æü‡Øà‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Øá‡Æ©‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æµ‡ØÜ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡ØÄ‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç
‡Æá‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æü‡Øà‡ÆØ ‡Æé‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ™‡Øä‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ§‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ£‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç
‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Æø‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æ§‡Øá ‡Æá‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Øá
‚ÄúIf you could see
the arch of his brow
the budding smile
on his lips red as the kovvai fruit
cool matted hair
the milk-white ash on coral skin
and the golden foot raised up in dance
our birth on this earth is fulfilled‚Äù
In sculptures, paintings and verses, Nataraja continues to dance...beyond time.
Dr Raguram
02/02/24, 8:19‚ÄØam
It was a breezy early morning and I was standing on the banks of a large swathes of wetland. The air resonated with myriad calls of birds that inhabited the vast terrain. I was totally amazed at the wide variety of birds in front of me. Suddenly, I noticed a flash of light and it was the bronze winged jacana. The early morning sun was caressing its beautiful plumage with lustrous hues. It was foraging on the aquatic vegetation, daintily balancing itself on the water with its long feet and toes, with the elegance of a ballerina.These wetlands provide crucial breeding, nesting and feeding habitats for countless numbers of birds.
Wetlands and human beings are all part of a delicate and interconnected ecosystem.They play a vital role in treating and detoxifying a variety of waste products and are often described as earth‚Äôs kidneys. In addition, through sequestering and releasing a major portion of fixed carbon they are important regulators of global climate change.
February 2nd of each year is observed globally as World Wetlands Day to raise awareness about the value of wetlands for nature and society. The theme this year is ‚Äòwetlands and human wellbeing.‚Äô It emphasizes how all aspects of human well-being are linked to the health of the world‚Äôs wetlands and calls on each of us to value their importance.
While it is heartening to notice that three new wetlands are added to the Ramsar sites in Karnatka, it is equally saddening to witness increasing habitat fragmentation, polluting runoff and invasive species that plague the wetlands especially in rapidly urbanizing areas, like Bangalore.
As Sandra Postel, a renowned expert on freshwater ecosystems cautioned, ‚ÄúFor many of us, water simply flows from a faucet, and we think little about it beyond this point of contact. We have lost a sense of respect for the wild river, for the complex workings of a wetland, for the intricate web of life that water supports‚Äù
Dr Raguram.
03/02/24, 3:43‚ÄØpm
Feast for the eyes. Man is fooling himself that life will go on but the heat of climate change has already started burning....
04/02/24, 9:45‚ÄØam
One of the earliest writings of J Krishnamurti was 'The Song of Life' which was published in 1931. It is a profound, thought provoking work, offering deep insights about JK as a seeker and a poet. The final lines of the poem are in this photograph and I have taken the liberty to quote it in its entirety;
I have no name;
I am as the fresh breeze of the mountains.
I have no shelter;
I am as the wandering waters.
I have no sanctuary, like the dark gods;
Nor am I in the shadow of deep temples.
I have no sacred books;
Nor am I well-seasoned in tradition.
I am not in the incense burning upon the high altars;
Nor in the pomp of ceremonies.
I am neither in the graven image;
Nor in the rich chant of a melodious voice.
I am not bound by theories;
Nor corrupted by beliefs.
I am not held in the bondage of religions;
Nor in the pious agony of their priests.
I am not entrapped by philosophies;
Nor held in the power of their sects.
I am neither low nor high;
I am the worshipper and the worshipped.
I am free.
My song is the song of the river calling for the open seas;
Wandering, wandering;
Dr Raguram
08/02/24, 8:53‚ÄØam
In one of the safaris in Kanha, the driver took us on a dirt track, away from other vehicles. As I was soaking in the soothing ambiance of the forest, I noticed a tiger just ahead of us. He kept us company for over the next fifteen minutes. Suddenly he stopped right in front of us. He was looking at me and our eyes locked. His stunning eyes never wavered. I experienced a profound connection through that intense gaze. I was immersed in listening to the unspoken language of his eyes. At that moment I understood what Martin Buber (whose birthday is today) meant when he commented that "An animal's eyes have the power to speak a great language." It is a powerful reminder that the most fulfilling and genuine moments in life are found through the act of connecting deeply with another being.
Dr Raguram
11/02/24, 8:50‚ÄØam
London is full of blue plaques. They dot the walls of buildings throughout London, marking the places where scientists, artists, politicians and activists who lived and worked there. When I was on a Commonwealth Fellowship, I made it a point to visit as many of them. One address I was keen to locate was No 1, Fitzroy Road where WB Yeats lived for a while. It was also the building where Sylvia Plath, a poet whom I admire deeply, spent her last days before ending her life on February 11th 1963.
Poets die young and not so often by suicide. Perhaps the act of writing poetry fascinates the wounded and in the process also opens up fresh wounds. Syvia Plath was no exception. In her thinly veiled autobiographical novel, ‚ÄòBell Jar‚Äô, she wrote, ‚ÄúDeath must be so beautiful. To lie in the soft brown earth, with the grasses waving above one's head, and listen to silence. To have no yesterday, and no to-morrow. To forget time, to forgive life, to be at peace‚Äù. Pensive by disposition, she kept ruminating about it, which found expression in these lines which she wrote ten days before ending her life:
‚ÄúThe blood jet is poetry,
There is no stopping it‚Äù.
There are a multitude of ways in which Sylvia Plath‚Äôs life and her final act has been analyzed and debated. Beyond these lenses of scrutiny her existential angst was enmeshed in a troubled past and a tumultuous relationship with her husband Ted Hughes. Perhaps the most insightful and poignant account about Syliva Plath‚Äôs suicide was by her friend A Alvarez in his book, ‚ÄòThe Savage God‚Äô, which we reviewed in NIMHANS in the late 70s. In the first page of the book, there is a quote by Cesare Pavese, regarded as one of Italy's most important twentieth-century poets, which says it all:"No one ever lacks a good reason for suicide."
Dr Raguram
12/02/24, 8:08‚ÄØam
In a series of groundbreaking studies conducted in the late 1930s, psychologist Kurt Lewin (who was born on this day), identified three core styles of leadership; Authoritarian (autocratic) leadership. Participative (democratic) leadership and Delegative (laissez-faire) leadership.
Over the past decade we are witnessing the rise of populist, authoritarian, strong-man politicians across the globe. Its seductive appeal necessitates a detailed sociological enquiry! However, a political leadership that rules on the basis of fear, threat, intimidation, and advocating one worldview as superior while silencing diversity of opinions and dissent is in my opinion will lead to fragmentation of society. Unfortunately an authoritarian world view is not confined to the political arena. It seeps into and influences people's attitudes, impacts institutional ethos in centres of learning and more importantly, festers lack of trust. The more we portray the ‚Äòothers‚Äô as threat, the greater the harm to the fabric that binds and holds us all together.
The harmful impact of authoritarian attitude in a leader is accentuated once it is tinged with narcissistic traits, resulting in an overwhelming need for control with an inflated sense of self-worth. They strongly adhere to the belief that they should be in charge and expect others to conform to their views and desires, often holding people with differing viewpoints in contempt. These leaders insist on strict conformity to their beliefs and tend to view the world in binary terms; you are either with them or against them. This black-and-white perspective creates a hostile environment where individuals are categorized as friends or foes based on their willingness to conform. Such a rigid stance stifles open dialogue and learning from others.
As George Orwell observed presciently in 1984, it leads to ‚Äúprocessions, meetings, military parades, lectures, waxwork displays, film shows, telescreen programs all had to be organized; stands had to be erected, effigies built, slogans coined, songs written, rumours circulated, photographs faked.‚Äù
13/02/24, 8:35‚ÄØam
Sarojini Naidu, born on 13th February 1879, was one of the most outstanding figures of the independence movement. An equally talented poet in English, she was known as ‚ÄúThe Nightingale of India‚Äù. Her poetry brims with strong emotions expressed in lyrical verses. An ardent admirer of nature, she was also a great lover of birds.
I am particularly drawn (given my passion for them!) to her poem ‚ÄòBird of Time‚Äô, wherein she expresses the workings of time through the movements of a bird. Just as we don‚Äôt expect a bird to be still, time too is fleeting. Life and death, sorrow and hope, time encompasses them all in this poem.
BIRD OF TIME
O Bird of Time on your fruitful bough
What are the songs you sing? ‚Ä¶
Songs of the glory and gladness of life,
Of poignant sorrow and passionate strife,
And the lilting joy of the spring;
Of hope that sows for the years unborn,
And faith that dreams of a tarrying morn,
The fragrant peace of the twilight‚Äôs breath,
And the mystic silence that men call death.
O Bird of Time, say where did you learn
The changing measures you sing? ‚Ä¶
In blowing forests and breaking tides,
In the happy laughter of new-made brides,
And the nests of the new-born spring;
In the dawn that thrills to a mother‚Äôs prayer,
And the night that shelters a heart‚Äôs despair,
In the sigh of pity, the sob of hate,
And the pride of a soul that has conquered fate.
In one of last letters she wrote, ‚Äù While I live, it will always be the supreme desire of my Soul to write poetry ‚Äîone poem, one line of enduring verse even. Perhaps I shall die without realising that longing which is at once an exquisite joy and an unspeakable anguish to me‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
15/02/24, 8:58‚ÄØam
A brief write up about an exquisite early Chola temple with images. Do have a look and pen your thoughts in the website: https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/bewitching-brahmapureeswarar-temple
17/02/24, 7:57‚ÄØam
In the 60s Eshwari Lending Library in Chennai was my stomping ground. One day I picked up a book ‚ÄòThe Chosen‚Äô by Chaim Potok, sheerly by chance. When I started reading it, I was put off initially by an extensive description of a baseball match in the first 30 pages of the book. I persisted nevertheless and couldn‚Äôt put the book down after that. The novel opened me up to another time and another world which I was not familiar with,till then.
It is a story about two Jewish teens from different backgrounds; Reuven Malter, hailing from an Orthodox family and Danny Sanders from a Hasidic background. It details the bond between the two and the relationship each has with his father. Relationships between fathers and sons figure prominently in ‚ÄòThe Chosen‚Äô, especially in the choices of the sons' careers. Danny's father expects him to become a rabbi and leader of his Hasidic sect, following the tradition of generations, while Reuven's father lets him choose his own path. Daniel has decided not to become a Tzaddik, but to follow his heart, attend graduate school and become a psychologist. Reuven has made up his mind to become a Rabbi, despite his great talent for logic and mathematics. Reuven and Danny both have one thing in common, trying to decide on whether they should be something that was chosen for them or something they want to be.
I had just finished PUC at the time I read the book and was drawn to the main theme of the book, ‚ÄòChoosing and Being Chosen‚Äô. Hailing from a family wherein my grandfather was a well known doctor, the implicit expectation was that I should follow his path. I wasn‚Äôt so sure at that time as I was drawn more to liberal arts. Perhaps I was ‚Äòchosen‚Äô to become a doctor and that too a psychiatrist!
When I read this book again, I was particularly drawn to this passage in the book, ‚ÄúHuman beings do not live forever‚Ä¶ We live less than the time it takes to blink an eye, if we measure against eternity. So it may be asked what value is there to a human life. There is so much pain in the world. What does it mean to suffer so much if our lives are nothing more than the blink of an eye?‚Ä¶ I learned a long time ago ‚Ä¶ that a blink of an eye in itself is nothing. But the eye that blinks, that is something. A span of life is nothing. But the man who lives that span, he is something. He can fill that tiny span with meaning, so its quality is immeasurable though its quantity may be insignificant. ‚Ä¶ A man must fill his life with meaning, meaning is not automatically given to life‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
18/02/24, 8:26‚ÄØam
Another book I had picked up those days at Easwari lending library was the novel ‚ÄòZorba the Greek‚Äô. Much like ‚ÄòThe Chosen‚Äô, it is the story of two men: Zorba, a Greek working man and a wealthy, young narrator and their incredible friendship. The two of them couldn‚Äôt be further apart. The narrator is cerebral, modest, and reserved; Zorba is unfettered and spirited.The younger man reads all day. He‚Äôs an aficionado of Buddhist philosophy, the exact opposite world view of Zorba who has such lust for life. These two characters represent two distinct ways of life. The implicit question throughout the book: which is better? Being a ‚Äústable‚Äù person and being accepted and respected in society, or being an indulgent person living his life full. Both are searching for answers. The Narrator has a desire to change, but he adamantly resists Zorba‚Äôs philosophy, despite admitting to admiring it and wishing he could assimilate it with his own. The relationship between these two characters symbolizes the conversation between the head and the heart, the mind and the spirit, what Nietzsche referred to as the Apollonian and the Dionysian impulses. Kazantzakis masterfully interweaves these dual perspectives of human nature. The book is also an important reminder to embrace the transience of life, to seize the moments that bring us joy, unfettered by intellectual curiosity. A passage in the book by the narrator illustrates this perspective:
‚ÄúI remember one morning when I discovered a cocoon in the back of a tree just as a butterfly was making a hole in its case and preparing to come out. I waited a while, but it was too long appearing and I was impatient. I bent over it and breathed on it to warm it. I warmed it as quickly as I could and the miracle began to happen before my eyes faster than life. The case opened; the butterfly started slowly crawling out, and I shall never forget my horror when I saw how its wings were folded back and crumpled; the wretched butterfly tried with its whole trembling body to unfold them. Bending over it, I tried to help it with my breath, in vain. It needed to be hatched out patiently and the unfolding of the wings should be a gradual process in the sun. Now it was too late. My breath had forced the butterfly to appear all crumpled, before its time. It struggled desperately and, a few seconds later, died in the palm of my hand. That little body is, I do believe, the greatest weight I have on my conscience. For, I realize today that it is a mortal sin to violate great laws of nature. We should not hurry, we should not be impatient, but we should confidently obey the external rhythm‚Äù.
A viewpoint summarized in the gravestone of the author, Nikos Kazantzakis,"I hope for nothing. I fear nothing. I am free."
(And who can forget Anthony Quinn bringing the most life-affirming character of Zorba alive in the movie version of the book with the Zorba the Greek song brimming with life?)
Dr Raguram
20/02/24, 8:28‚ÄØam
When I visited Yosemite sometime ago, I felt overwhelmed with the enormous expanse of its enchanting landscape. It was much like losing myself in a vast heritage temple which was built aeons ago. I felt humbled in the presence of its towering granite cliffs, lush meadows, forested valleys and dramatic seasonal waterfalls. It was a mystical experience.
One person who brought out its magical realm in tangible ways for us to relish was Anselm Adams, whose birthday is today. Yosemite was Ansel Adam‚Äôs muse.When he looked through his camera lens, he saw more than it's rocks, trees, and rivers. He saw art. Adams explored and recorded the grandeur of nature in stunning black and white photographs,conveying its beauty in lyrical ways. His elegant compositions with tantalizing play of light across its incredible terrain exude a certain sense of calmness.
As Adams observed, ‚ÄúThe whole world is, to me, very much alive, all the little growing things, even the rocks‚Ä¶I can‚Äôt look at a swell bit of grass and earth, for instance, without feeling the essential life, the things going on, within them‚Äù.
I put myself in Adam‚Äôs shoes, when I stood in front of the half dome, where he has taken many of his stunning photographs and froze that moment in this frame
Dr Raguram
23/02/24, 8:44‚ÄØam
For a long time I shied away reading, ‚ÄòThe Rise and Fall of the Third Reich‚Äô, as the very thought of reading about a misanthropic, racist, megalomaniac ruler who caused so much human misery, was sheer anathema for me.
I dipped into the book several years later. Usually I read books at a stretch, but not with this voluminous one spread over a thousand pages.
Once I finished reading it, my first thought was one of appreciation about the author, William Shirer, whose birthday is today. A talented journalist, he had interviewed Mahatma Gandhi several times and wrote an interesting book about these encounters.
But nothing prepared him for the demonic, spellbinding charisma he witnessed when he took up residence in Berlin in 1934 where he began to chronicle the rise of the Third Reich under Adolf Hitler. His contempt is not for Hitler so much as for the ‚Äúlittle men of German‚Äù, for the culture that acceded to Hitler and Nazism so readily
Charlemagne is often considered as Germany‚Äôs First Reich. He was followed by the Second Reich, Bismarck who felt betrayed by the supposed treachery of Jews. When all of Germany was awaiting the Third Reich as a saviour, Adolf Hitler stepped in.
Shirer is mainly concerned with charting the rise to power of this ruthless man, how he bullied and threatened his way to convince a large population, which was unreflectively taken by his promise of a ‚ÄòThousand Year Reich‚Äô, which only lasted a total of 12 years, 4 months, and 8 days. But during that brief span it wrought havoc and destruction on a scale never witnessed before, that resulted in their own ruin.
Shirer is no historian. As he observed, ‚ÄúJournalism is the first draft of history‚Äù, His scrutinizing lens is that of an observant journalist. There is no overarching historical explanation of the Third Reich, but a rich account of its rise and fall.
The book is a reminder that there is danger in giving up our sense of selfhood for the illusory unity of a frenzied mass movement, championed by a narcissistic, charismatic leader.
Couple of quotes to reflect upon from the book:
‚ÄúThe broad masses of a population are more amenable to the appeal of rhetoric than to any other force‚Äù.
‚ÄúWith a shrewdness that never deserted him Hitler carefully calculated the precipitation of one crisis upon another so that he was always moving in the driver's seat at the center of the stage‚Äù.
‚ÄúThe most dangerous people in the world are not those who carry guns and bombs, but those who carry blind hatred in their hearts‚Äù.
And lastly:
‚ÄúDoubt is the beginning of wisdom‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
24/02/24, 8:05‚ÄØam
Sometime ago I had posted about the intriguing interface between the private and the public self.
Jorge Luis Borges, whom I admire deeply, wrote the shortest of short stories, ‚ÄòBorges and I‚Äô. It is a fascinating read, raising an interesting question, ‚ÄúIs Borges the man or Borges the writer‚Äù? When a writer articulates his experiences and expresses them on paper,does he assume a different persona? In an essay which he wrote in 1919, TS Eliot wondered whether, ‚Äúthe more perfect the artist, the more completely separate in him will be the man who suffers and the mind which creates‚Äù. Borges is a lover of paradox and doesn‚Äôt attempt to ‚Äòresolve‚Äô this question. His story ends tantalizingly with these words, ‚ÄúI do not know which of us has written this page‚Äù.
BORGES and I
The other one, the one called Borges], is the one things happen to. I walk through the streets of Buenos Aires and stop for a moment, perhaps mechanically now, to look at the arch of an entrance hall and the grillwork on the gate; I know of Borges from the mail and see his name on a list of professors or in a biographical dictionary. I like hourglasses, maps, eighteenth-century typography, the taste of coffee and the prose of Stevenson; he shares these preferences, but in a vain way that turns them into the attributes of an actor. It would be an exaggeration to say that ours is a hostile relationship; I live, let myself go on living, so that Borges may contrive his literature, and this literature justifies me. It is no effort for me to confess that he has achieved some valid pages, but those pages cannot save me], perhaps because what is good belongs to no one, not even to him, but rather to the language and to tradition. Besides, I am destined to perish,definitely and only some instant of myself can survive in him. Little by little, I am giving over everything to him, though I am quite aware of his perverse custom of falsifying and magnifying things].
Spinoza knew that all things long to persist in their being; the stone eternally wants to be a stone and the tiger a tiger. I shall remain in Borges, not in myself (if it is true that I am someone), but I recognize myself less in his books than in many others or in the laborious strumming of a guitar. Years ago I tried to free myself from him and went from the mythologies of the suburbs to the games with time and infinity, but those games belong to Borges now and I shall have to imagine other things. Thus my life is a flight and I lose everything and everything belongs to oblivion, or to him.
I do not know which of us has written this page.
(From Labyrinths: ‚ÄòSelected Stories and Other Writings‚Äô)
This final sentence of the story entices the reader to venture into the labyrinth of labyrinths to explore who is ‚Äòreally‚Äô fictional in this mirror world!!
Dr Raguram
25/02/24, 8:59‚ÄØam
Both Ahalya and myself are ardent Beatles aficionados. We must have listened to ‚ÄòSgt.Peppers Lonely Heart Club‚Äô umpteen number of times. Each time it is a revelation of the group‚Äôs immense talents and originality. Each and every song in it is a gem, Amidst them, the ‚ÄòWithin and Without You‚Äô, stands out for its melodious tones inspired by Indian music.George Harrison (whose birthday is today) was learning sitar from Pandit Ravi Shankar at that time and used it in the song beautifully. The tune was partially based on a lengthy suite Shankar had written for All-India Radio.It has a sinuous quality and its sweeping tunes cast a spell.
One can consider this song as the most philosophical in the entire album. George was quite influenced by the book, ‚ÄòAutobiography of a Yogi‚Äô, by Paramahamsa Yogananda. Its underlying theme is the importance of self knowledge. in order for a person to freely love and realize self-knowledge, he/she must become less attached to the things of the world which might deter him from reaching such a state. Harrison is encouraging the listener to go ‚Äúwithin‚Äù themselves. And at the same time, in order to successfully do so one has to be ‚Äúwithout‚Äù himself. And to be ‚Äúwithout‚Äù himself involves casting aside one‚Äôs worldly concerns. In essence, this is one of the well-recognized aspects for effective meditative practice.
When you've seen beyond yourself
Then you may find peace of mind is waiting there
And the time will come when you see we're all one
And life flows on within you and without you

But man keeps on spinning thoughts around people, instances not letting go which is the sad part. Not able to accept embrace the fleeting existence of life. Such a beautiful very short yet very deep haiku!
27/02/24, 8:07‚ÄØam
A good poem opens up a new world and takes you on a memorable journey. Henry Wadswoth Longfellow‚Äôs, ‚ÄòNature‚Äô is one such.
The simple, unpretentious opening lines of the poem portray a familiar scene that happens in most of our homes; a mother trying to put her child to sleep. The child‚Äôs ‚Äòbroken playthings‚Äô are scattered on the floor, and he is ‚Äúhalf willing" to abandon the play and retire for the night. He lingers, staring longingly at the toys he has left behind.
The next few lines venture into a new territory all together. The poet compares the mother whom he just described eloquently, to mother nature. Both are essentially caretakers of all of us. Nature is to man, what a mother is to her child. As we advance in years, nature gradually takes away all our earthly possessions and gently guides us to the world beyond. Since often we are greatly attached to our earthly life and our belongings, we are never too willing to proceed towards that goal. But nature leads us just like the mother leading the child to sleep,taking away our "playthings" one at a time. The poet suggests that our earthly desires and attachments are like playthings that we must eventually relinquish to discover the unknown mysteries of life..
Why did this poem appeal to me? I was drawn (and still continue to be!) by the simple imagery of a mother putting a reluctant child to sleep, which slowly blends itself into a very powerful metaphor of a nurturing nature that prepares us for our journey beyond this world. There is much wisdom in these lines;
NATURE
As a fond mother, when the day is o'er,
Leads by the hand her little child to bed,
Half willing, half reluctant to be led,
And leave his broken playthings on the floor,
Still gazing at them through the open door,
Nor wholly reassured and comforted
By promises of others in their stead,
Which, though more splendid, may not please him more;
So Nature deals with us, and takes away
Our playthings one by one, and by the hand
Leads us to rest so gently, that we go
Scarce knowing if we wish to go or stay,
Being too full of sleep to understand
How far the unknown transcends the what we know.
(Henry Wadswoth Longfellow born on this day on 1807)
Dr Raguram
01/03/24, 9:04‚ÄØam
Rhythmic highs and lows of life can spark the creative urge within ourselves. But when the intensity of the swings are severe, it causes immense suffering to those in the midst of it. Rober Lowell, whose birthday is today, suffered from a severe form of bipolar illness which started early in his life. Mental illness ran deep in his family and his life was laden with instability; for thirty years he was in and out of mental hospitals. The manic episodes were extremely disruptive with florid psychotic symptoms, requiring hospitalization, which were invariably followed by periods of depression.
Fire is a central image in Lowell‚Äôs works. His manic episodes were akin to a blaze of fire which took some effect to be quelled. He wrote, ‚ÄúBy the time I reached the hospital I was completely out of my head‚Äîstrange physical sensations‚ÄîI was a prophet and everything was a symbol; then in the hospital: shouting, singing, tearing things up‚Äîreligion and antics. Then depression (extreme) aching, self-enclosed, fearful of everyone and everything anyone could do, feeling I was nothing and could do nothing‚Äù He termed his manic phase as the ‚Äúholocaust of irrationality‚Äù and depression as the ‚Äúlong, burdensome dull period‚Äù with months of ‚Äúwading in the muck and weeds and backwash of a depression. Depression is an illness for oneself, mania an illness for one‚Äôs friends‚Äù.
Above all, he was a poet and during one of his admissions, he wrote:
The resident doctor said,
‚ÄúWe are not deep in ideas, imagination, or enthusiasm‚Äî
how can we help you?‚Äù
I asked,
‚ÄúThese days of only poems and depression‚Äî
what can I do with them?
Will they help me notice
what I cannot bear to look at?‚Äù
Lowell wrote brilliantly about the embers of his illness in an autobiographical piece, ‚ÄúNear the Unbalanced Aquarium‚Äù, which is included in his book ‚ÄòMemoirs‚Äô. The effect of the medication was ‚Äúlike the slowing and ache of a medium fever. One‚Äôs thoughts are not directly changed and healed, but the terrible, over-riding restlessness of one‚Äôs system is halted so that the mind can see life as it is‚Äù. He was given Lithium much later in his life, once it was available for use. Among all the medications and ECTs that were given to him, Lowell found that Lithium was the most effective one. Reflecting about it, hw wondered to his friend, ‚ÄúIt's terrible, Bob, to think that all I‚Äôve suffered, and all the suffering I‚Äôve caused, might have arisen from the lack of a little salt in my brain‚Äù
What is remarkable is that Lowell continued writing despite the immense suffering due to his mood disorder which wreaked on his life. His courage and determination enabled him to channel the creative fire within, which unfortunately consumed him.
(There have been many biographies of Robert Lowell, my personal favourite is the exceptional,l ‚ÄòSetting the River on Fire‚Äô, by Kay Redfeld Jamison)
Dr Raguram
03/03/24, 8:02‚ÄØam
Humans and wildlife have interacted closely for millions of years, especially during the prehistoric era. The habitat of the prehistoric people were caves. Dwelling there, they embellished the caves with paintings imbued with natural colours. A common theme in their paintings was wildlife, which was not surprising since they lived in close proximity with them. Wildlife was an integral part of their daily lives.
I had the first glimpse of the richness of the prehistoric cave paintings ranging from the Upper Paleolithic period (around 30,000 years ago) to the mediaeval period, in Bhimbetka. It is one of the most densely painted rock shelters in India. As I walked into its vast terrain, one particular rock shelter caught my attention, which is often referred to as the Zoo Rock. A vast array of various wild animals, painted in profile, covered its rock face. Deers, elephants, leopards, wild buffaloes, bears and boars were galloping on its aged backdrop. The primary colour was white, which dates back to the Mesolithic period, while a few from later periods were mostly in red. Though the colours had faded with time, the entire scene was brimming with energy, showcasing the close relationship between these ancient painters and the wildlife around them.
Unfortunately this relationship has frayed over time. The global loss of wildlife is significantly alrarming. According to a 2022 World Wildlife Fund report, global wildlife populations have declined by 69% since 1970.
I am reminded of the story, ‚ÄòThe Epic of Gilgamesh‚Äô, which narrates the great city builder Gilgamesh‚Äôs friendship with a ‚Äúwild man,‚Äù Enkidu. Enkidu leads a contented life without human contact, ‚Äúcoated in hair like the god of the animals,‚Äù grazing at the water hole with a herd of gazelles, ‚Äúhis heart delighting with the beasts in the water.‚Äù Gilgamesh forcibly humanizes Enkidu by sending Shamhat, a priestess, to seduce him. After many days of lovemaking, Enkidu is spurned by the wild animals. He gets a haircut, eats bread, drinks ale and returns with Shamhat to the city.
As modern city dwellers, we are much like the alienated Enkidu, estranged from the rich wildlife around us, making occasional forays to have a glimpse of them amidst the declining forest covers. On the occasion of World Wildlife day and on the background of increasing man-animal conflicts, can we cultivate a more mindful interaction with wild animals at a both personal and public level and commit ourselves towards sustained conservation and peaceful coexistence?
(And of course, you can see them all at ‚ÄòVantara‚Äô‚Ä¶relocated and displaced from their natural habitat. Is that the future of wildlife in India?!)
Dr Raguram
04/03/24, 8:37‚ÄØam
I went for the interview in JIPMER, preparing myself for all kinds of questions that could be asked in the ‚Äòsubjects‚Äô. When I stepped in with much trepidation into the room, I was overwhelmed by the presence of half a dozen serious looking gentlemen. An imposing man seated in the centre looked at me and asked, ‚ÄúYoung man, why do you want to study medicine?‚Äù Without hesitation, I blurted ‚Äúbecause I love literature‚Äù. The response was on the spur of the moment, totally unrehearsed. My answer must have surprised him and he asked me to mention physicians who were also writers. I spoke for a few minutes about Anton Chekov, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and William Carlos William, amongst others. It was much later that I discovered that the gentleman who asked me the question was the venerable writer GK Gokak who later became President of the Sahithya Academy.
There is always an interesting tryst between the professional call and the personal passion and sometimes they converge. A long list of physician-writers down the ages right from the mediaeval physician, Maimonides, down to Abraham Verghese in recent times, will bear testimony to this.
William Carlos Williams was a pediatrician and general practitioner. He "worked harder at being a writer than he did at being a physician," His enormous output ranges across short stories, poems, plays, novels, critical essays and an autobiography. In his ‚ÄòDoctor Stories‚Äô, he gave a glimpse of work; hysterical mothers, obstinate children and poor families with nine kids unable to spare a few dollars for his services. There is an unflinching, straightforward tone in his stories. All the while, he was diligently mining his material for his true call, poetry.
His poems are simple, spare, with striking imagery. For instance, his lengthy poem, ‚ÄòBirds and Flowers‚Äô ends with these beautiful words;
‚ÄúThough the eye
turns inward, the mind
has spread its embrace ‚Äî in
a wind that
roughs the stiff petals ‚Äî
More! the particular flower is
blossoming . . ‚Äú.
Dr Raguram
05/03/24, 8:06‚ÄØam
London has the world‚Äôs first underground railway system and it is always busy with hordes of busy commuters. It is also the most efficient way to travel in the city, provided there are no strikes or unplanned closures.
For me, one of the pleasures of travelling by the tube was to read the poems that used to adorn the stations. Simply called, ‚ÄòPoems from the underground‚Äô, it was a veritable collection of verses from across the world. It was also a wonderful introduction to poets whom I neve heard of before. One such poet was Anise Koltz, often referred to as ‚Äúthe great lady of Luxembourg literature.‚Äù These particular lines of her, which I had made a note of, were particularly striking.
THE BIRDS WILL STILL SING
‚ÄúBreak my branches
saw me into bits
the birds will still sing
in my roots‚Äù
Birds inhabit the same world we do, and yet, they seem capable of transcending it. Though many of them lead lives on the brink of ruin, they still sing. These sparse, powerful, words in the poem convey that even in the midst of destruction unleashed by humans, spirited voices will emerge, rooted in resilience.
This is the anthem for Gaza too‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
08/03/24, 9:28‚ÄØpm
There are many legends associated with Mahashivaratri which is being celebrated today. According to one, it was the day when Shiva drank the poison that emerged from the ocean during Amritmanthan, to protect the world. He drank it but held it in his throat instead of swallowing it. Thus, his throat changed to a blue colour and he was then given the name, Nilkantha. According to another legend, when Ganga was descended from heaven after the request of Bhagirath, it was enormous and uncontrollable, so Lord Brahma requested Shiva to control her fall. Shiva agreed to it and he held the rapid flow of Ganga by tying it up in his hair. According to yet another legend, this was the night when Shiva and Parvati got married, an amalgamation of Purusha (mindfulness) and Prakriti (nature).
I have a particular interest in the mural tradition of south India and went over to the Virupaksha temple sometime back to have a look at the murals that adorn the ranga mantapa. It was fascinating to see the ceiling resplendent with murals depicting scenes from the purana and various narrative episodes from history. Prominent among them is a large panel depicting the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. In the attached photo, starting from the left, one can find Narada, a horse headed Tumburu.. Vishnu and Lakshmi are in the next section. The middle portion depicts the marriage of Shiva and Parvati in exquisite detail.. Brahma is officiating the marriage of Shiva and Parvati with Himavat performing Kanyadan. Three bejewelled women are seen on their right. In the last section on the right, one can notice the three legged Bhringi. The attention to detail, especially the designs in the textiles is quite striking. I was wondering as to how these murals would have looked in their heyday. Temples are not merely places of worship; embellished with magnificent sculptures and paintings, they are repositories of a rich aesthetic tradition which needs to be preserved and protected. I was happy to note that an innovative attempt has been made to digitise these murals. There is an overwhelming need for similar initiatives to conserve many such artistic treasures across the country, which are unfortunately in various stages of neglect.
Dr Raguram
09/03/24, 12:08‚ÄØam
Art and divinity went hand in hand in our culture unlike the present day commercialisation. Such a beautiful depiction of the marriage.
