He pronounced that ‚ÄúThis is no book, / Who touches this touches a man.‚Äù It had a lengthy preface in which he reflected on various aspects of life ‚ÄúLove the earth and sun and the animals, despise riches, give alms to everyone that asks, stand up for the stupid and crazy, devote your income and labour to others, hate tyrants, argue not concerning God, have patience and indulgence toward the people, take off your hat to nothing known or unknown or to any man or number of men, go freely with powerful uneducated persons and with the young and with the mothers of families, read these leaves in the open air every season of every year of your life, re-examine all you have been told at school or church or in any book, dismiss whatever insults your own soul, and your very flesh shall be a great poem and have the richest fluency not only in its words but in the silent lines of its lips and face and between the lashes of your eyes and in every motion and joint of your body.‚Äù
The initial print run of the first edition was modest and the book did not sell well. It did receive a number of rave reviews in New York newspapers and some of them were written by Whitman himself. Whitman was undeterred and continued to add poems to ‚ÄòLeaves of Grass‚Äô in four different editions and finished the last revision on his deathbed in 1892.
The poems in the ‚ÄòLeaves of Grass‚Äò represent Whitman's celebration of his philosophy of life and nature. Throughout the book, Whitman emphasizes the importance of connecting with nature and finding solace, inspiration, and spiritual fulfilment in the natural world. He sees nature as a source of wisdom and renewal, and encourages readers to forge a deeper connection with the environment around them.
‚ÄúSmile O voluptuous coolbreathed earth!
Earth of the slumbering and liquid trees!
Earth of departed sunset! Earth of the mountains misty-top!
Earth of vitreous pour of the full moon just tinged with blue!
Earth of shine and dark mottling the tide of the river!
Earth of the limpid gray of clouds brighter and clearer for my sake!
Far-swooping elbowed earth! Rich apple-blossomed earth!
Smile, for your lover comes!
Dr Raguram
07/07/24, 8:55‚ÄØam
I was listening to Mahler‚Äôs ‚ÄòThe Song of the Earth‚Äô symphony the other day. It is interspersed with six songs. I couldn‚Äôt follow the lyrics and checked for them in the net. It was an interesting discovery! The songs are based on a set of poems, ‚ÄòThe Chinese Flute‚Äô, dating back to the Tang dynasty. Curious to know further, I searched for their translation and found that each one of them was so meaningful. For instance, Mahler employed two poems; Mong Kao-Yen ‚ÄúStaying at a Teacher‚Äôs Mountain retreat and Awaiting a Friend in Vain‚Äù and Wang Wei‚Äôs ‚ÄúFarewell‚Äù. The final lines are:
‚ÄúI shall no longer seek the far horizon
Still is my heart and awaits its hour‚Ä¶.
The lovely earth everywhere blossoms and grows anew
Everywhere and forever the luminous blue of distant space‚Ä¶.Forever‚Ä¶forever‚Ä¶‚Äù
The word forever is repeated nine times indication that forever there will be beauty, sadness, tears and happiness in all our life experiences.
Listening to ‚ÄòThe Song of the Earth‚Äô was a revelation as to how poetry can be combined seamlessly with beautiful orchestration to create a magical listening experience.
I read further about Mahler and found that he experienced a slew of losses in his life; the death of his closest brother at the age of 13; his sister at the age of 26; and the suicide of another brother and the loss of his elder daughter. In addition, Mahler himself had serious health problems, sometimes life-threatening, throughout his life.
This draws attention to the significant interface between adversity and creativity. Often a crucible of challenges is a fertile ground for the seeds of creativity to emerge and flourish. Creativity also serves as a coping mechanism in the face of adversity, providing individuals with an avenue for self-expression and can be a therapeutic outlet too.
As the life of Gustav Mahler informs us, in the face of adversity creativity is a guiding light.
(Gustav Mahler 7th July 1860 ‚Äì 18th May 1911)
Dr Raguram
08/07/24, 9:04‚ÄØam
With advances in health care, dying is increasingly becoming lonely, mechanical and dehumanized. To assist and help people cope with a demanding end of life process, one has to listen to them. This is what Elisabeth Kubler-Ross did. Along with four of her students she conducted a series of interviews with the terminally ill which resulted in her path breaking book, ‚ÄòOn Death and Dying.‚Äô The book outlined five stages of grief, popularly referred to as DABDA: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, Acceptance.
Though her work brought death and dying out of the closet, Elisabeth Kubler-Ross‚Äôs legacy has been a mixed one. There has been critical re-examination of the stages she has outlined and whether these stages apply to everyone who is grieving, since her research focused only on those who were terminally ill. Empirical evidence for these stages was also scanty. The well conducted Yale Bereavement Study did not find support for K√ºbler-Ross‚Äôs five stage theory. The findings indicated that acceptance was the most commonly reported reaction from the start, and yearning was the most common negative feature for the first two years. The other variables, such as disbelief, depression and anger were typically absent or minimal. Moreover, her model described how people with terminal illness face their imminent death. But strangely, it was soon adapted as a way of thinking about grief in general. The process of death and dying is not purely enacted within the individual and is impacted by a host of social, religious and cultural factors which is noticeably absent in her work. Perhaps the abiding appeal of her work is in its simplicity.
Her later years were mired in scandals. She began to embrace spiritualism, claiming she had communicated with spirits of the dead with names like ‚ÄúMario,‚Äù ‚ÄúAnka,‚Äù ‚ÄúSalem,‚Äù and ‚ÄúWillie.‚Äù She started believing in reincarnation, and told listeners she had lived during the time of Jesus, when she had been named Isabel. She involved herself in a cult-like retreat with a psychic called Jay Barham. and conducted s√©ances which involved the widows/widowers ‚Äòengaging‚Äô with the departed. It was revealed that Barham molested female participants during s√©ances, while pretending to be an "afterlife entity". Her professional reputation began to decline and she also became largely confined to bed due to a series of strokes.
In the final stages of her life she observed, ‚ÄúI now know that the purpose of my life is more than these stages. I have been married, had kids, then grandkids, written books, and travelled. I have loved and lost, and I am so much more than five stages. And so are you.‚Äù
(Elisabeth Kubler Ross 8th July 1926 ‚Äì 24th August 2004)
Dr Raguram
09/07/24, 9:28‚ÄØam
I am besotted with gardens. When I walk through a garden I am enveloped in a symphony of colors, rustling leaves, bird and insect sounds wafting through the air. It is an immersive experience imbued with a sense of tranquillity. As Bacon commented, ‚Äúit is the purest of human pleasure.‚Äù Gardens are often seen as a refuge, a place to forget the "real" life that lies outside. But they are also quintessential healing spaces.
Oliver Sacks, the famed neurologist and author, whose birthday falls today, wrote a small, wonderful essay ‚ÄúWhy We Need Gardens,‚Äù in his book ‚ÄúEverything in Its Place: First Loves and Last Tales,‚Äù which was published posthumously. Since his place of work was just across the road from the New York Botanical Garden, he noticed how patients who were unable to function inside a hospital setting seemed to come alive in the garden. An elderly lady with Parkinson‚Äôs disease, often frozen, unable to initiate movement was more mobile in the garden and even climbed the rocks up and down many times, unattended. Patients with very advanced dementia who had difficulty in even tying their shoe laces, when put in front of a flower bed with some seedlings knew exactly what to do. He described such deep bonds people have with gardens as ‚Äúhortophilia.‚Äù In his words, ‚ÄúI cannot say exactly how nature exerts its calming and organizing effects on our brains, but I have seen in my patients the restorative and healing powers of nature and gardens, even for those who are deeply disabled neurologically. In many cases, gardens and nature are more powerful than any medication‚Äù. He went on to add, ‚ÄúIn forty years of medical practice, I have found only two types of non-pharmaceutical ‚Äòtherapy‚Äô to be vitally important for patients with chronic neurological diseases: music and gardens.‚Äù
Gardens saturate our awareness and the boundary between our self and the world fuses and we feel more alive and flourish in that moment. It leaves a lasting trace in the innards of our minds.
For Thich Nhat Hanh, garden was a metaphor for the mind. He wrote, ‚ÄúFirst, you have to take care of your own garden and master the art of gardening. In each one of us there are flowers and there is also garbage. The garbage is the anger, fear, discrimination, and jealousy within us. If you water the garbage, you will strengthen the negative seeds. If you water the flowers of compassion, understanding, and love, you will strengthen the positive seeds. What you grow is up to you.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
11/07/24, 8:45‚ÄØam
People have been drawing and painting flowers for a very long time. In contrast to botanical illustration, botanical artwork emphasizes the aesthetic value of the plant or flower but without much of the details illustrated in the former. The artist tries to capture the essence of the dainty plant form in all its inherent beauty.
One of the most celebrated flower painter in the entire history of botanical art was Pierre-Joseph RedouteÃÅ. Nicknamed ‚Äúthe Raphael of flowers,‚Äù he was one of the most talented botanical artists ever known. He was also arguably the most popular botanical artist in history. Redout√© was patronized by the kings of France from Louis XVI to Louis-Philippe and their wives. In his lifetime, he produced over 2,100 paintings, depicting over 1,800 different species, many of which had never been rendered before. Even now, each of his paintings fetch incredible prices at auction. Fortunately many of his original works are available in the digital world for us to savour.
In the accompanying image, Redoute‚Äôs painting of a tulip is on the left and on the right is one of my photographs of the flower. What I captured through my lens is a pale image of the flower lusciously portrayed in exquisite detail by the talented Redoute.
As Edvard Munch commented, ‚ÄúNature is not only all that is visible to the eye‚Ä¶ it also includes the inner pictures of the soul.‚Äù And a flower seen through a painter‚Äôs eyes has a transcendental quality which a photograph can rarely match.
(Pierre-Joseph RedouteÃÅ July 10, 1759 - June 20, 1840)
Dr Raguram
12/07/24, 9:53‚ÄØam
I've read DT Suzuki‚Äôs book on Zen Buddhism long time ago. I am not sure what led me to pull the book out of the shelf a few days ago. And on the page I randomly picked, there was this comment, ‚ÄúOutwardly, be open; inwardly, be deep.‚Äù And it resonated with me in an inexplicable way.
I consider Zen to be the best source of guidance for people like me who do not strictly adhere to any religious camp but drawn by a spiritual quest. I especially like that Zen has no need for God or any other supernatural entity. The quirky Zen tales and anecdotes fascinate me, even though I have trouble grasping them, sometime.
DT Suzuki is responsible for a clear and simple introduction to the essentials of Zen Buddhism. Carl Jung wrote a remarkable foreword to Suzuki's Introduction to Zen Buddhism. Zen is an experience not confined to the intellect. As Jung wrote in the introduction, ‚ÄúA monk once went to Gensha, and wanted to learn where the entrance to the path of truth was. Gensha asked him, "Do you hear the murmuring of the brook?" "Yes, I hear it," answered the monk. "There is the entrance," the master instructed him.
Zen Buddhism aspires to seek meaning without insisting upon belief. As Suzuki wrote perceptively, ‚ÄúThe idea of Zen is to catch life as it flows. There is nothing extraordinary or mysterious about Zen. I raise my hand; I take a book from the other side of the desk; I hear the boys playing ball outside my window; I see the clouds blown away beyond the neighbouring wood: ‚Äî in all these I am practising Zen, I am living Zen. No wordy discussion is necessary, nor any explanation. I do not know why and there is no need of explaining, but when the sun rises the whole world dances with joy and everybody‚Äôs heart is filled with bliss. If Zen is at all conceivable, it must be taken hold of here.‚Äù
As for me, all of us live our lives on the edge of the vast sea of consciousness, sometimes caressed by waves of awareness and it is a zen moment.
(DT Suzuki 18th October 1870 ‚Äì 12th July 1966)
Dr Raguram
12/07/24, 12:55‚ÄØpm
What a contrast. An artist's inner self defines the beauty of the painting. The suppleness, veins, natural texture everything is so visible in a painting. But as you have pointed out it is par excellence.
16/07/24, 9:50‚ÄØam
Goddess Kali is the first of the Dasa Mahavidyas, the ten aspects or forms of Shakti. She is the quintessential embodiment of Shakti embodying the power of creation and destruction in one entity. She is perceived as Mother Nature, primordial, nurturing, creating, and devouring all at once. In Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa‚Äôs words she is ‚Äúthe benign all-loving Mother.‚Äù He felt in her breath ‚Äúthe soothing touch of tender love and saw in her the seed of immortality.‚Äù
There is a carefully chiselled sculpture of her in the Hoysaleshewara temple at Halebidu. She is seen holding a trident, damaru, knife and a severed head in her four hands. A garland of severed heads adorns her. Around her are corpses and one of them is seen dancing too.
Looking at her, I wonder whether the severed head is indicative that we should severe the human ego in order to exit from the cycle of life and rebirth.
Mary Starton was a gifted writer and she was best known and most highly regarded as a poet. In a collection of her poetry ‚ÄòA Grain of Mustard Seed‚Äô, she wrote an evocative poem about Goddess Kali.
INVOCATION TO KALI
‚ÄúKali, be with us.
Violence, destruction, receive our homage.
Help us to bring darkness into the light,
To lift out the pain, the anger,
Where it can be seen for what it is‚Äî
The balance-wheel for our vulnerable, aching love.
Put the wild hunger where it belongs,
Within the act of creation,
Crude power that forges a balance
Between hate and love.
Help us to be the always hopeful
Gardeners of the spirit
Who know that without darkness
Nothing comes to birth
As without light
Nothing flowers.
Bear the roots in mind,
You, the dark one, Kali,
Awesome power.‚Äù
(Mary Starton May 3, 1912 - July 16, 1995)
Dr Raguram
18/07/24, 9:41‚ÄØam
Why are people so besotted with the weddings of the ‚Äúrich and famous?‚Äù I am a strong advocate of Kuvempu, one of the greatest poets of Kannada, who propounded the idea of a distinctly different kind of marriage which he called, ‚ÄòMantra Mangalya‚Äô. It is a revolutionary approach to bring back marriage to the folds of personal Dharma freed from the clutches of hedonism and ritualistic customs. It is a simple marriage ceremony devoid of pomp to teach couples the seriousness and sacredness of marriage, encouraging them to adopt the values inherent in this method throughout their lives.
Mantra Mangalya is available as a manual. It has three sections. The first one explains what Mantra Mangalya is, ‚ÄúIt is a type of marriage in which the bride and the groom invoke the power symbolising all the values worshipped by Indians since times immemorial‚Äù. It goes on to add, ‚ÄúThe objective of Mantra Mangalya is to liberate Indians from the rituals which are indirectly responsible for evils of caste system, gender inequality and untouchability. As this mode of marriage has to be simple, no part of the wedding shall be expensive or ostentatious. No one shall receive dowry in any form.‚Äù
The next section has meticulous instructions on the conduct of the ceremony. The total number of invitees including parents and relations should not exceed 200. Gifts are prohibited. No particular time is auspicious or inauspicious. Mantra Mangalya believes that the whole life of man is auspicious for making life fruitful. Photographs of four Mahapurushas such as Ramakrishna Parmahamsa and Sharada Devi or of any ideal couple shall be placed as spiritual witnesses.
The third section is titled ‚ÄúMarriage Code‚Äù. It is an extra-ordinary set of statements meant to be administered to the bride and groom. It reiterates that the wife is equal to the husband, enjoying the same freedom and emphasizes the crucial role of affective bond between the spouses as an important aspect to sustain relationship. It ends by stating that ‚Äúthe bride and groom who are now unfettered from all religions, rituals, and ignorance, should continue this sacred duty of unfettering humanity. There is no need to belong to any religion. There is no need to belong to any sect. There is no need to follow any rituals. The aforementioned oaths are the guiding lights in your life.‚Äù
(Mantra Mangalya is available in amazon)
Dr Raguram
19/07/24, 10:34‚ÄØam
After completing PUC, I had quite a bit of time before venturing into a professional course and I spent most of this time cycling to Eswari Lending Library in Chennai. One day when I was browsing, I noticed AJ Cronin‚Äôs ‚ÄòThe Citadel‚Äô, in one of the shelves. I‚Äôve never heard of him before. I brought it back home and finished reading it in one setting.
‚ÄòCitadel‚Äô tells the story of Andrew Manson, a young, idealistic doctor, who moves to a small mining town. He soon finds that he is dealing with more than what he‚Äôd bargained for. There is a lot of poverty in the town, many miners suffering from lung diseases. He begins to notice how doctors often lack clinical competence and are part of the system which really doesn‚Äôt help the people the way it should. He carefully studies the lung afflictions of the miners and completes his thesis detailing it. The research gains him a post with the "Mines Fatigue Board" in London, but he resigns after six months to set up a private practice. Seduced by the thought of making easy money from wealthy clients, he drifts away from the principles he started with and is estranged from his wife. When he notices the death of a patient because of a surgeon's ineptitude, he abandons his practice and returns to his wife to begin his life afresh. Tragically she is run over by a bus and dies.
In this novel, Cronin draws attention to the moral dilemmas that beset the doctors and the conflicts between the demands of private medicine as a business and of medicine as a Platonic ideal. He deftly identifies many of the issues in clinical practice which needs to be tackled like adequate training of doctors to prepare them for the reality of practice in the community, better supervision of young doctors, importance of team based care and the crucial role of ethics in medicine. As Cronin commented, ‚ÄúI have written in ‚ÄòThe Citadel‚Äô all I feel about the medical profession, its injustices, its hide-bound unscientific stubbornness, its humbug‚Ä¶ The horrors and inequities detailed in the story I have personally witnessed. This is not an attack against individuals, but against a system.‚Äù
In choosing the title for the novel, I wonder whether Cronin is prescient in alluding that modern health care system has become an impenetrable citadel where doctors ensconce and fortify themselves in defensive practices, highlighting in the process, the importance of opening the doors of the fortress.
Reading, for me is like stepping into worlds that I am not aware of. As a youngster, ‚ÄòCitadel‚Äô opened my eyes to the varied landscapes of the practice of medicine and perhaps also played a role in my choice of the profession.
Stories can change lives‚Ä¶
(AJ Cronin Born On 19th July 1896)
Dr Raguram
20/07/24, 8:06‚ÄØam
Literature is replete with evocative portraits of romantic love in its many facets. The Greeks had three expressions to designate love: Eros, Philos and Agape. Eros is love between two persons that perpetuates the human race. Philos is the sentiment that we dedicate to our friends. Finally, Agape, which contains both Eros and Philos, is total love; the love that we give spontaneously to others, regardless of reciprocation, which devours those who feel it.
One of the most endearing expression of love in literature is that of Petrarch. He was an Italian scholar and poet and is considered as one of the founders of the Renaissance movement in arts and literature. His most famous work is his ‚ÄòCanzoniere‚Äô, a collection of love poems written in the vernacular which revolve around an unknown and unobtainable woman called Laura.
In sonnet 353, titled ‚ÄòThe Wandering Bird‚Äô he articulates poignantly, his love for Laura and the unbearable loss after her demise.
‚ÄúSweet wandering bird that singest on thy way,
Or mournest yet the time for ever past,
Watching night come and spring receding fast,
Day‚Äôs bliss behind thee and the seasons gay,‚Äî
If thou my griefs against thine own couldst weigh,
Thou couldst not guess how long my sorrows last;
Yet thou mightst hide thee from the wintry blast
Within my breast, and thus my pains allay.
Yet may not all thy woes be named with mine,
Since she whom thou dost mourn may live, yet live,
But death and heaven still hold my spirit‚Äôs bride;
And all those long past days of sad decline
With all the joys remembered years can give
Still bid me ask ‚ÄúSweet bird! with me abide!‚Äù
Petrarch is so consumed by grief following the death of the woman he loves that he begins to see sorrow in the world around him. He hears the song of the bird and imagines that every note is stricken with grief. The bird is a symbol of the deep pain and suffering Petrarch endures after the death of Laura. He talks to the bird and hopes that the bird can sympathize with his pain because there is no one else to talk with.
When poets dip their pen in emotions deeply entrenched in the innermost recesses of their hearts, love, longing and loss comes alive‚Ä¶
( Petrarch. July 20, 1304 - July 19, 1374)
Dr Raguram
21/07/24, 6:48‚ÄØam
Today is dedicated to expressing gratitude and reverence to teachers. The term Guru is derived from the Sanskrit, ‚ÄòGu‚Äô meaning darkness and ‚Äòru‚Äô signifying light.
Guru Paduka Stotram is a hymn which draws attention to the importance and influence of a Guru in one‚Äôs life. One day, Adi Shankaracharya was travelling across the country in search of his Master, Govind Bhagavatpada when he came upon a cave on the banks of River Narmada. He saw a pair of padukas or sandals outside the cave and immediately recognized them as that of his Master. Filled with abundant joy, he penned the ‚ÄòGuru Paduka Stotram.‚Äô Padukas are symbolically representative of the ‚Äòthe boat to help cross the endless ocean of life‚Äô. It is a beautiful hymn which ends with these verses.
‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§°‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡••
That which is the Garuda which drives off the serpents of passion,
That which provides one with the treasure of wisdom and renunciation,
That which blesses one with refined wisdom,
And that which blesses the aspirant with speedy salvation,
Salutations to such sacred sandals of my revered Guru.
Sri Dakshinamurthy is regarded as the quintessential guru, an embodiment of knowledge and the destroyer of ignorance. These images of Sri Dakshinamurthy are from Brahmapureeswarar temple at Pullamangai. In the Koshtam on the southern side, there is an entrancing idol of Sri Dakshinamurthy with two more depictions of the Lord, above, in the Vimana.
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§Æ ‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á
Salutations to Him, the Personification of Our Inner Guru Who Awakens Knowledge through His Profound Silence; Salutation to Sri Dakshinamurthy.
Dr Raguram
22/07/24, 10:26‚ÄØpm
Yes. Yesterday was Guru Poornima. Thank you Sir for the glimpse of the fantastic sculpture. Looks like an ornament where they chisel minute designs especially the vimana. I love to hear Shankaracharya's Guru Ashtakam 'thathah kim'.
24/07/24, 9:05‚ÄØam
Hermits have been around in every historical era, across all geographical locales. In nearly all cultures of the world, we find people who chose to live differently, often in solitary existence. Japan has a long tradition of hermits and Kamo no Chomei was a famous recluse during the medieval times. After living through calamitous time, at the age of fifty, Chomei renounced the world, became a hermit and built a small hut for himself in the mountains. In this retreat, he spent his time, observing signs of change in the seasons: wisteria blossoms in spring, summer cuckoos, autumns insect chirping, and snow in winter and meditating. Chomei was a poet and he wrote about his experiences in a book, ‚ÄòHojoki.‚Äô It‚Äôs opening phrases are lyrical,
‚ÄúThe flowing river
never stops
and yet the water
never stays
the same.
Foam floats
upon the pools
scattering, re-forming
never lingering long.
So it is with man
and all his dwelling places
here on earth.‚Äù
Writing about life spent in quietude, he observes:
‚ÄúFish do not hate the water.
But then, none can know
the happiness of the fish
unless he is one.
Birds love the woods.
If you are not a bird
you will not know its truths.
A quiet life is much the same.
How would anyone know it
without living it?‚Äù
Having spent his life in seclusion, Chomei is profoundly reflective in the final passages of the ‚ÄòHojoki‚Äô wondering whether he has adhered to the essential teaching of the Buddha.
‚ÄúThe moon of my life is setting.
The life now left me sinks into the hills.
Any time now I may descend
to the darkness of the river below.
To what end do I pour this out?
Buddha taught we must not be attached.
Yet the way I love this hut is itself attachment.
To be attached to the quiet and serene
must likewise be a burden‚Äù
(Kamo no Chomei died on July 24, 1216)
Dr Raguram
25/07/24, 9:00‚ÄØam
Birds are nature‚Äôs original poems. Once you start to hear birds, notice them, learn their habits, the world around you opens up in beautiful ways. Our lives would be charmless without them. Their songs give solace to the weary soul. There are thousands of beautiful poems written about birds by poets all over the world. Many turned to them for inspiration at various points in their writing as birds provide boundless metaphors. For example, the singing of the nightingale becomes a metaphor for writing poetry in Shelley‚Äôs works, ‚ÄúA poet is a nightingale, who sits in darkness and sings to cheer its own solitude with sweet sounds; his auditors are as men entranced by the melody of an unseen musician, who feel that they are moved and softened, yet know not whence or why.‚Äù
The nightingale is a recurrent theme in poetry. Samuel Taylor Coleridge (21 October 177 - 25 July 1834), famed author of ‚ÄòRime of the Ancient Mariner‚Äô lived in the Chanters House which had a Victorian bird house with an aviary. He wrote about the nightingale too;
‚ÄúMany a nightingale perch giddily
On blossomy twig still swinging from the breeze,
And to that motion tune his wanton song
Like tipsy Joy that reels with tossing head.‚Äù
Poetry for Coleridge, ‚Äúhas been to me its own exceeding great reward; it has given me the habit of wishing to discover the good and beautiful in all that meets and surrounds me.‚Äù
(The accompanying image is that of the Northern Mockingbird which is commonly called the ‚ÄúAmerican Nightingale.‚Äù It lives up to its nickname, singing during the day and sometimes at night, varying its songs from spring to fall. The Northern Mockingbird can sing up to 30 differing bird songs)
Dr Raguram
26/07/24, 9:41‚ÄØam
There are two books of CG Jung which I treasure and value deeply. One is Volume 16 of his Collected Works which explores psychotherapy and the other one is the autobiographical ‚ÄòMemories, Dreams and Reflections.‚Äô The latter book offers fascinating glimpses about his evolution as a mental health professional.
Jung spent some time at the famous ‚ÄòBurgholzi‚Äô. He describes his experiences there with extraordinary candour: ‚ÄúPsychiatry teachers were not interested in what the patient had to say, but rather in how to make a diagnosis or how to describe symptoms and to compile statistics. From the clinical point of view which then prevailed, the human personality of the patient, his individuality, did not matter at all. Rather, the doctor was confronted with Patient X, with a long list of cut-and-dried diagnoses and a detailing of symptoms. Patients were labelled, rubber-stamped with a diagnosis, and, for the most part, that settled the matter. The psychology of the patient played no role whatsoever.‚Äù
There is also a vivid account of an extraordinary encounter with a patient. A young woman was admitted with the diagnosis of ‚Äòdementia praecox.‚Äô Jung felt that it was a case of depression but did not voice his opinion, fearing rebuke from seniors. He sat with the patient over many days, gently exploring the background to her distress and it revealed a dark story. Before her current marriage, she was keen to marry the son of a wealthy industrialist. Five years later, an old friend visited her and he said to her, "When you got married it was quite a shock to your Mr. X.‚Äù She started brooding about the loss of her love. She lived in a place where the water supply was not perfectly hygienic; there was pure spring water for drinking, and impure water from the river for bathing and washing. While she was bathing her young daughter, she saw the child sucking at the impure water but did not stop her as she was quite preoccupied. A short time later the girl came down with typhoid fever and died. She was tremendously distressed and was admitted in Burgholzi. Jung started speaking to her over the next few weeks and she was able to acknowledge and work through her distress and guilt. She got better and was discharged.
In Jung‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúIn many cases in psychiatry, the patient who comes to us has a story that is not told, and which as a rule no one knows of. To my mind, therapy only really begins after the investigation of that wholly personal story. It is the patient's secret, the rock against which he is shattered. If I know his secret story, I have a key to the treatment. The doctor's task is to find out how to gain that knowledge. In therapy the problem is always the whole person, never the symptom alone.‚Äù
This facet of Jung, not so well known, draws attention to importance of the transformative power of narration in psychotherapy. Stories that are told in therapy are the stories that cannot be told in everyday life. The role of the therapist is to offer a space to share such stories and facilitate emergence of alternate versions and make them feel confident to try them out in their lives.
Dr Raguram
27/07/24, 9:24‚ÄØam
Mangroves are enchanting places. Our sojourn amidst the mangroves of the Zuari river remains deeply etched in memory. Zuari River is the largest river in Goa which divides the state into two parts; North Goa and South Goa. It‚Äôs a tidal river, which sustains this important ecosystem. We boarded the boat at the Courtalim ferry pier and as we slowly coursed along the wide swatches of mangroves, a wide array of birds kept us company. Numerous species of water birds were foraging the shallow marshy banks for food. One of the birds that caught our attention was the black capped kingfisher which was perched on a swaying branch. As we were leaving an Indian Mugger Crocodile cast a lazy glance at us from its muddy abode.
Mangrove forests are among the planet‚Äôs most complex ecosystems. The word "mangrove" comes from the Portuguese word mangue, which means "tree", and the English word "grove", which refers to trees and shrubs in sandy, muddy, or shallow areas. Mangroves are survivors flourishing in environmental conditions that would swiftly kill most other types of vegetation. Known as the dancing trees, mangroves are regularly battered by cyclonic winds, especially along the coasts of India, but their intertwined breathing root system anchors them firm on the soil. They play a crucial role in protecting coastal areas from tsunamis. Mangroves are critical ecosystems sustaining a wide array of biodiversity.
Let me end this post paying obeisance to a remarkable man who was instrumental in developing and conserving mangroves in Kerala. Pokkudan, who grew by the lap of the estuaries and the rich rivers of Ezhom recognized the importance of mangroves. With remarkable determination, he would set out on his country boat everyday along the waters to plant saplings of mangroves in the marshes. He not only planted acres of mangrove saplings but ensured their protection against tremendous odds, until they emerged as teeming mangrove forests. Over a span of two and a half decades, Pokkudan had planted over hundreds of thousands of mangrove saplings along the banks of the Pazhayangadi River in the Kannur district, which earned him the sobriquet as ‚ÄòKandal Pokkudan‚Äô (Kandal is mangrove in Malayalam). Pokkudan describes his efforts poetically in his autobiography, ‚ÄòKandalkadukalkidayil Ente Jeevitham‚Äô (My Life Among the Mangrove Forests) ‚ÄúI began by planting 300 mangrove plants to prevent the sea from eroding the coast and to shield the children walking to the school from the gusts of wind. And to soak in their beauty when they grew up.‚Äù He passed away in 2015 leaving behind a great legacy.
(26th July, International Day for the Conservation of the Mangrove Ecosystem).
Dr Raguram
28/07/24, 6:17‚ÄØpm
Grandmothers are endless sources of engaging stories and delectable food. When we were young, there was no concept of an evening ‚Äòtiffin‚Äô. Instead of tea and biscuits, the leftover food from the morning will take a new mouth-watering avatar in the evening. All the kids of the house will sit around the grandmother as she placed a dollop of delicious, recycled food in our hands while narrating a story. It was always a very special moment for all of us.
I travelled back in time reminiscing about these moments when I read the poem ‚ÄúButterfly Laughter" by Katherine Mansfield.
‚ÄúIn the middle of our porridge plates
There was a blue butterfly painted
And each morning we tried who should reach the
butterfly first.
Then the Grandmother said: "Do not eat the poor
butterfly."
That made us laugh.
Always she said it and always it started us laughing.
It seemed such a sweet little joke.
I was certain that one fine morning
The butterfly would fly out of our plates,
Laughing the teeniest laugh in the world,
And perch on the Grandmother's lap.‚Äù
The grandmother has made a porridge for the children and she painted a blue butterfly on top of it to make the food attractive. There is a competition among all the children as to who will eat that butterfly first. When the grandmother remarks, "Do not eat the poor butterfly", they start laughing. The poet wonders what the grandmother‚Äôs reaction would be if the butterfly comes alive and sits on her lap!
‚ÄúThat butterfly
Will land on us
One day
When wrinkles arrive
And we get old‚Äù
(28th July is World Grandparent‚Äôs Day)
Dr Raguram
05/08/24, 8:51‚ÄØam
Hyde Park was a favourite haunt of mine during my fellowship years in London, decades ago. It is an urban oasis in the midst of busy, bustling London. The park is dotted with monuments and statues and on one occasion I came across an intriguing relief, which I couldn‚Äôt figure out. Later, I discovered that it depicts a mysterious girl, ‚ÄòRima‚Äô from the book ‚ÄòGreen Mansions‚Äô written by WH Hudson. Curious to find out more about the author, I learnt that he was a founder-member of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB), in 1889. RSPB had 20,000 members at that time, majority of them women. Hudson was a meticulous observer of nature and during a sojourn to Patagonia, he identified a flycatcher which is named after him. He also authored a series of ornithological studies.
Hudson‚Äôs writings are quite lyrical, ‚ÄùThe blue sky, the brown soil beneath, the grass, the trees, the animals, the wind, and rain, and stars are never strange to me; for I am in and of and am one with them; and my flesh and the soil are one, and the heat in my blood and in the sunshine are one, and the winds and the tempests and my passions are one.‚Äù
I particularly like his observation about the humming bird, ‚ÄúHave you ever observed a humming-bird moving about in an aerial dance among the flowers--a living prismatic gem that changes its colour with every change of position.‚Äù
Hudson was ahead of his time and believed in studying his subjects in the field, not just in the laboratory. He would spend long hours quietly watching, listening, and being with nature. ‚Äúwhen walking there one day, the loveliness of that green leafy world, its silence and its melody and the divine sunlight, so wrought on me that for a few precious moments it produced a mystical state, that rare condition of beautiful illusions when the feet are off the ground, when, on some occasions, we appear to be one with nature, unbodied like the poet's bird, floating, diffused in it.‚Äù
He was admired by Virginia Woolf and Joseph Conrad, who declared that he wrote ‚Äòas the good God makes the grass grow‚Äô.
(W H Hudson. Born on 4 August 1841)
Dr Raguram
06/08/24, 10:32‚ÄØam
Such wonderful souls. It is very easy to slide into the slippery temporary world but to have an eye and heart to become one with nature.....
06/08/24, 8:11‚ÄØam
When we were in Bandipur some months ago, I noticed this little bird peeping out of its nest and I was reminded of a simple, beautiful poem by Alfred Tennyson whose birthday is today.
WHAT DOES THAT LITTLE BIRDIE SAY
‚ÄúWhat does little birdie say,
In her nest at peep of day?
‚ÄúLet me fly,‚Äù says little birdie‚Äî
‚ÄúMother, let me fly away.‚Äù
‚ÄúBirdie, rest a little longer,
Till the little wings are stronger.‚Äù
So she rests a little longer,
Then she flies away.
What does little baby say
In her bed at peep of day?
Baby says, like little birdie,
‚ÄúLet me rise and fly away.‚Äù
‚ÄúBaby, sleep a little longer,
Till the little limbs are stronger.
If she sleeps a little longer,
Baby, too, shall fly away.‚Äù
It is a touching poem about a bird's desire to leave the nest and experience the world. The mother, gently advises the young bird to stay and rest, as its wings are not yet strong enough to fly. The poem ends by hinting that eventually the little bird will soon fly away. All of us aspire for independence and exploration, but need the guidance and protection of our parents till we find the metier to be on our own.
All of us are born to fly. As the master strategist Napoleon Bonaparte is said to have commented, ‚ÄúUntil you spread your wings, you‚Äôll have no idea how far you can fly.‚Äù
(I scrupulously avoid nest photography and this was taken from a distance with utmost care that the bird doesn‚Äôt sense my presence!)
Dr Raguram
07/08/24, 10:21‚ÄØam
India is a land of festivals. Traditions and rituals associated with it vary across the vast cultural landscape of India. For instance, today is celebrated as Hariyali Teej in many states in Northern India to commemorate the union of Shiva and Parvati.
Triyuginarayan temple is situated at the confluence of Mandakini and Son-Ganga river in Rudraprayag district of Uttarakhand. It is a much sought after wedding destination as it is said to be the place where the celestial marriage of Shiva and Parvati took place. Parvati, daughter to Himavat was keen to marry Shiva and undertook rigorous penance to prove her love and dedication to Shiva at Gauri Kund, which is not very far from Triyuginarayan. Gauri Kund temple, which dedicated to Parvati, is also the base camp for trekking to Kedarnath Temple. Mythology states that Shiva proposed to Parvati at Guptakashi and got married in the Triyuginarayan temple. A holy fire still burns perpetually in front of the temple and the ashes from this fire are supposed to promote conjugal bliss.
There are many sculptural depictions of the celestial event of the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. Perhaps one of most beautiful one is at the 10th century Bhoganandishwara temple near Bangalore. In this relief one can see Lord Brahma on the extreme right and next to him is Vishnu who is blessing the couple. In the middle are the couple, Shiva and Parvati. Next to the couple is the father of Parvati offering Kanyadan and adjoining him is Parvati‚Äôs mother.
Embedded in rich mythological tapestry, the marriage of Shiva and Parvati is a tale that resonates with devotion, perseverance, and the enduring power of love.
Dr Raguram
08/08/24, 10:15‚ÄØam
A movie that left a deep impression on me was ‚ÄòCharly‚Äô directed by Ralph Nelson. Based on the novel ‚ÄòFlowers for Algermon‚Äô by Daniel Keyes, It had a beautiful musical score by Pandit Ravi Shankar. It‚Äôs a timeless story that explores the experiences of Charlie Gordon, a 32-year-old man with a learning disability who undergoes surgery in an effort to make him ‚Äúsmarter‚Äù and more ‚Äúnormal.‚Äù Since the same procedure worked well on Algernon, a lab mouse, the scientists have high hopes for Charlie‚Äôs transformation. After the operation, Charlie‚Äôs intelligence begins to steadily increase and he is functionally a genius after a few months. As his intelligence grows, he finds it increasingly difficult to connect with others at an emotional level and realizes that he is losing touch with his own emotional needs and desires, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs worse; to not know what you are and be happy, or to become what you‚Äôve always wanted to be, and feel alone.‚Äù The researchers present Charlie and their findings at a scientific convention. Meanwhile Charly comes to know that Algernon has lost its enhanced intelligence and died, facts that the research team kept away from him. He starts wondering whether he will undergo a similar decline and reflects, ‚ÄúThe problem, dear professor, is that you wanted someone who could be made intelligent but still be kept in a cage and displayed when necessary to reap the honours you seek. The hitch is that I'm a person.‚Äù Soon Charly regresses to his previous level of intelligence, but finally feels himself at home, happier than before.
The story explores themes that are still relevant today, including intelligence, empathy, and the ethical implications of scientific advancement. More importantly, it seeks out the unflinchingly honest message that our humanity is not measured by how smart we are, but rather by our kindness, love and interaction with others.
In the era of Neurolink, the daunting question is ‚ÄúDoes intelligence alone makes us better people?‚Äù
Charly reminds us that, ‚ÄúIntelligence is one of the greatest human gifts. But all too often a search for knowledge drives out the search for love. This is something else I've discovered for myself very recently. I present it to you as a hypothesis: Intelligence without the ability to give and receive affection leads to mental and moral breakdown, to neurosis, and possibly even psychosis. And I say that the mind absorbed in and involved in itself as a self-centered end, to the exclusion of human relationships, can only lead to violence and pain.‚Äù
(Daniel Keyes: 9 August 1927 - 15 June 2014)
Dr Raguram
10/08/24, 8:54‚ÄØam
Just finished reading Rachel Aviv‚Äôs ‚ÄúStrangers to Ourselves‚Äù, a moving account of five people who were in throes of various kinds of psychological distress. The book begins with Rachel‚Äôs account of her own tryst with Anorexia Nervosa when she was young. Her disinclination to eat occurred on the background of her parents‚Äô divorce and her role as a pawn in their custody battle. The anorexia resolved within the year, and her doctors ended up seeing it as a coping mechanism during a demanding phase in her life. Rachel reflects, ‚ÄúFor a child, solipsistic by nature, there are limits to the ways that despair can be communicated. Culture shapes the scripts that expressions of distress will follow. In both anorexia and resignation syndrome, children embody anger and a sense of powerlessness by refusing food, one of the few methods of protest available to them. Experts tell these children that they are behaving in a recognisable way that has a label. The children then make adjustments, conscious and unconscious, to the way that they've been classified. Over time, a willed pattern of behaviour becomes increasingly involuntary and ingrained.‚Äù As the poet Louise Gluck who was anorexic, wrote, ‚ÄúThe tragedy of anorexia seems to me that its intent is not self-destructive, though its outcome so often is. Its intent is to construct, in the only way possible when means are so limited, a plausible self.‚Äù
All five people Rachel writes about are products of their life stories, circumstances over which they had little control. She richly documents each of their journeys in the ‚Äúpsychic hinterlands, the outer edges of human experience, where language tends to fail.‚Äù
I was particularly moved by the narrative about Bapu. Her rich parents married Bapu to a man who was more keen on her money. She had to endure much abuse in the new household and sought solace in religion. She believed Lord Krishna to be her true husband who would offer unconditional love and wrote poems about him. As she merged her life with that of Lord Krishna, she abandoned the household duties, became uncommunicative, attempted multiple times to run away. She was found living on the street with other pilgrims and later confined to a mental health facility. She was taken care by her son and daughter in law. Sometime later she had a stroke, slipped into coma and died a few days later at home. After her demise, her daughter Bhargavi (whom I had known) started the Bapu Trust in Pune focusing on developing community based programs facilitating the autonomy and independence of persons living with a mental health issues
Rachel comments perceptively, ‚ÄúMental illnesses are often seen as chronic and intractable forces that take over our lives, but I wonder how much the stories we tell about them, especially in the beginning, can shape their course. People can feel freed by these stories, but they can also get stuck in them.‚Äù
In the words of Paulo Coelho, ‚ÄúSometimes, we need to be strangers to ourselves. Then the hidden light in our soul will illuminate what we need to see.‚Äù
It is a deeply moving and insightful narrative of lived experiences of people with psychological distress and needs to be widely read by all mental health professionals.
Dr Raguram
12/08/24, 9:44‚ÄØam
Elephants have the longest gestation period compared to any other animal. Usually a female gives birth to a single calf, occasionally two. Calves nurse for the first six months of life, drinking about 10 litters of milk per day. Elephant milk is high in fat and protein, hundred times more than cow's milk. Calves are weaned slowly and may continue to nurse until they reach puberty or the mother gives birth again. The young ones begin to experiment with their trunks around four to six months and start picking leaves and grasses to supplement their diet. They follow their mothers' responses to learn who is a friend or relative, and who might be a threat. The bond between a mother elephant and her calf is special because it's very strong and nurturing. The mother elephant takes care of her calf with a lot of love and protection, ensuring its safety and teaching it essential skills for survival.
Interestingly, Priyanka Sharma wrote an article, ‚ÄúBeing an Elephant Mom in the time of the Tiger Mother.‚Äù She observed that compared to the ‚ÄòTiger Mums‚Äô who push their children to make choices, behave like adults and minimize relying on parents, an ‚ÄòElephant Mom‚Äô parenting style is flexible; it allows children to reach out for help providing comfort and warmth to the young. This parenting style is filled with encouragement and protection. While Tiger moms prepare their children for independence and the harsh realities of life from a young age, Elephant moms strive to support their children emotionally, and create a warm and loving environment for their kids to grow. They will nurture and protect their little ones through hard time, compared to a tiger mom style, which is a parenting style that is formed on the basis of tough love.
Watching a young calf gently ambling along the mother in the wild is a sight to behold!
(12th August is World Elephant Day)
Dr Raguram
13/08/24, 8:56‚ÄØam
Otters are some of the most adorable aquatic animals. One can spend endless hours watching their energetic play as they wrestle, play and slide down the slippery rocks. ‚ÄòTarka the Otter‚Äô, by Henry Williamson is a lovely novel about them. When the novel was published, otters were declining in numbers and by the 1960s it seemed possible that they would become extinct in England. Their recovery was much assisted by an increase in public awareness, facilitated in part by the popular success of Williamson‚Äôs novel. He describes the hunting behaviour of the otters like a trained naturalist, ‚ÄúFilling her lungs with new air, she slipped into the water and swam to the other end of the islet, where a scour had been formed by the flood-rains of the last south-westerly wind. Here the grown family of the moorhen was paddling. When almost under them, the otter saw the legs and the images of legs joined to them, black in silhouette against the less dark surface. She seized one of the moorhens and drew it under, releasing it to bite it in her jaws, and carried it back to her cubs, swimming with her nose, whiskers, eyes and part of the dead fowl out of the water.‚Äù
Williamson was quite productive with over fifty novels and essays. A keen observer of the landscape around him, his forte was writing about nature in its myriad expressions, ‚ÄúWhen the bees‚Äô feet shake the bells of the heather, and the ruddy strings of the sap-stealing dodder are twined about the green spikes of the furze, it is summertime on the commons.‚Äù
Though there was a darker side in his life, Williamson is still considered by many as a pioneer in the genre of nature writing. Even a simple description of an icicle is imbued with lyricism, ‚ÄúMusic comes from an icicle as it melts, to live again as spring water.‚Äù
(Henry Williamson 1 December 1895 - 13 August 1977)
16/08/24, 10:27‚ÄØam
Varalakshmi Puja is celebrated mostly in South India. Goddess Varalakshmi represents prosperity and divine grace. The name 'Varalakshmi' itself signifies her nature; 'Vara' meaning boon or blessing, and 'Lakshmi' referring to the goddess of wealth. This form of the goddess is particularly revered for her role in granting wishes and bringing prosperity. It is believed that worshipping the Goddess Varalakshmi on this day is equivalent to worshipping Ashtalakshmis; the eight goddesses of Wealth, Earth, Wisdom, Love, Fame, Peace, Contentment, and Strength.
There are iconographic variations in depiction of the Goddess. In this sculpture from Nuggehalli, Karnataka, she is found seated and has four arms. The four arms are symbolic of the four goals of humanity: dharma (pursuit of ethical, moral life), artha (pursuit of wealth, means of life), kama (pursuit of love, emotional fulfillment), and moksha (pursuit of self-knowledge, liberation). Her front right hand is held up in the abhaya mudra while her left hand is in the varada mudra giving boons to her devotees.
Muthuswami Dishidhar composed a beautiful song ‚ÄòSri Varalakshmi Nama Sthubhyam‚Äô in praise of the Goddess. Most appropriately it is set in the raga Sri (one of the names of Lakshmi). It starts with the pallavi
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏ ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§∞‡§∏ ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§∏‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§™‡§¶‡•á
Interestingly the pallavi starting from sArasa is in form of Gopuccha Yati which begins with a set of syllables and gets one syllable smaller with each repetition. The syllables are arranged similar to a cow‚Äôs tail, which is broad at the beginning gradually tapering to the bottom.
The pallavi translates as;
I bow down to you, O eminent Goddess Lakshmi, the giver of boons!
O bestower of fortunes! O Sri with feet as soft as a lotus, you are the bestower of affection, be my companion at every step.
Dr Raguram
19/08/24, 9:57‚ÄØam
Trees are the living energy of earth. With their roots deeply entrenched in the earth, they struggle with all the forces of nature to represent and express themselves. In the forest no two trees are alike. Each one has a distinctive presence. During an early morning walk amongst the wooded terrain of the Golden Gate Park, I saw this gnarled tree with a contorted trunk and twisted branches. It communicated something that a perfectly grown tree will never convey.
As Tom Waits observed, ‚ÄúIn the forest, there was a crooked tree and a straight tree. Every day, the straight tree would say to the crooked tree, "Look at me...I'm tall, and I'm straight, and I'm handsome. Look at you...you're all crooked and bent over. No one wants to look at you." And they grew up in that forest together. And then one day the loggers came, and they saw the crooked tree and the straight tree, and they said, "Just cut the straight trees and leave the rest." So the loggers turned all the straight trees into lumber and toothpicks and paper. And the crooked tree is still there, growing stronger and stranger every day.‚Äù
Photography is not about capturing the perfect but embracing the imperfect to see the world differently.
(Penned on the World Photography Day)
Dr Raguram
20/08/24, 10:33‚ÄØpm
Yes. I think I remember you had sent this sometime back. Still it is a great read and no wonder the plumage looks like a modern art...
22/08/24, 10:37‚ÄØam
Every time I visit the Bronze Gallery in the Chennai Museum I am totally entranced by the depictions of the dancing Siva in sculptural forms. Each one of them is so alive, and yet so balanced, so powerful and yet so effortlessly graceful. One can spend hours just looking at their transcendental beauty. It is a difficult task to portray the infinite divine in finite forms. Sankaracharya articulated it perceptively, ‚ÄúO Lord, pardon my three sins: I have in contemplation clothed in form Thyself that hast no form; I have in praise described Thee who dost transcend all qualities; and in visiting shrines I have ignored Thine omnipresence.‚Äù
It is indeed an extremely challenging undertaking to portray and convey the manifestation of the Divine in tangible forms, especially the ‚ÄòDance of Shiva‚Äô in his avatar as Nataraja. The primal rhythmic energy of the dancing Shiva found its ultimate expression in the bronzes of the Chola period. Shiva's dance is set within a flaming halo. The god holds in his upper right hand the damaru (hand drum that made the first sounds of creation). His upper left hand holds agni (the fire that will destroy the universe). With his lower right hand, he makes abhayamudra (the gesture that allays fear). The dwarflike figure being trampled by his right foot represents apasmara purusha (illusion, which leads mankind astray). Shiva's front left hand, pointing to his raised left foot, signifies refuge for the troubled soul. The energy of his dance makes his hair fly to the sides.
There have been many interpretations of the Dance of Shiva. Ananda Coomaraswamy (who was born on 22nd August in 1877) wrote a brilliant essay detailing it, in the book ‚ÄòThe Dance of Shiva‚Äô, which was published in 1918. He offers a detailed analysis of the five types of dance Shiva does, with extensive and fascinating quotes from mythical literature. Coomaraswamy sees the dance of Shiva as an interplay of Prakriti and Purusha, ‚ÄúThe Essential Significance of Shiva‚Äôs Dance is threefold: First, it is the image of his Rhythmic Play as the Source of all Movement within the Cosmos, which is Represented by the Arch: Secondly, the Purpose of his Dance is to Release the Countless souls of men from the Snare of Illusion: Thirdly the Place of the Dance, Chidambaram, the Centre of the Universe, is within the Heart. He rises from His rapture, and dancing sends through inert matter pulsing waves of awakening sound, and lo! matter also dances appearing as a glory round about Him. Dancing, He sustains its manifold phenomena. In the fullness of time, still dancing, he destroys all forms and names by fire and gives new rest. By these means, our Father scatters the darkness of illusion (maya), burns the thread of causality (karma}, stamps down evil (mala, anava, avidyfi), showers Grace, and lovingly plunges the soul in the ocean of Bliss (ananda).‚Äù
Coomaraswamy concludes by saying, ‚ÄúThe image of Shiva as Nataraja is indelibly stitched into the Indian imagination‚Ä¶Whatever the origins of Shiva's dance, it became in time the clearest image of the activity of God which any art or religion can boast of.‚Äù
As Thirumular describes in Thirumanthiram;
‚ÄúThe dancing foot, the sound of the tinkling bells,
The songs that are sung and the varying steps,
The form assumed by our Dancing Gurupara ‚Äî
Find out these within yourself, then shall your fetters fall away.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
25/08/24, 9:11‚ÄØam
Ahalya and myself went for a ‚ÄòTree Walk‚Äô organized by ATREE yesterday morning at Lalbagh. Mr Ganesan with decades of experience gently guided us to identify different tree crown shapes, leaf patterns and details of the trunks, which helps to differentiate the species. ‚ÄòTree Walk‚Äô encourages us to slow down and gaze upwards to unravel how the species have adapted over the years and support a enormous range of birds and insects.
Lalbagh is home to a vast variety of trees from different parts of the world and it is fascinating to observe their details. There are about fifteen silk cotton trees spread around the garden and I am particularly drawn to a white silk cotton tree near the west gate. It is immensely huge, sprawling majestically across a vast space. The board near the tree informs that it is over two centuries old and it is not clear as to who would have planted it, though the folk lore suggests that it may be Tipu Sultan. To prevent the tree from falling during gusty storms, the tree has huge buttresses which extend for several feet around the trunk. These buttresses are akin to a mother rearing and supporting a child as it grows, develops and matures over the years. Whenever I look at them, I keep wondering about what kinds stories would be hidden within its withered, wrinkled, folds.
As Herman Hesse wrote in ‚ÄòWanderings; Notes & Sketches‚Äô, ‚ÄúTrees are sanctuaries. Whoever knows how to speak to them, whoever knows how to listen to them, can learn the truth. They do not preach learning and precepts, they preach, undeterred by particulars, the ancient law of life.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
26/08/24, 9:14‚ÄØam
Krishna Janmashtami, celebrates the birth of Krishna. Stories of Krishna's childhood are illustrated in numerous paintings and sculptures. This small sculpture at Amrutheshwara temple at Amruthapura in Karnataka depicts an interesting episode during his childhood.
The village that Krishna lived in, Gokula, was a land of cow herders. Hence, not surprisingly, there was an abundance of milk, curds, and butter in the village. Krishna was very fond of butter and would make use of every opportunity to steal butter from his mother or from any of the place in the village. Many of them started tying pots of butter to the ceiling so that Krishna or his friends couldn‚Äôt reach them. Undeterred by this, Krishna would team up with his friends to reach these pots by climbing on the shoulders of his friends. People found out that Krishna was the prime culprit for these acts and complained to Yashoda. One day, Yashoda lost her patience and tied him up in a heavy grindstone in the courtyard and went inside to attend to her domestic chores. Left alone, Krishna happily and effortlessly dragged the grindstone and passed through the gap between two Arjuna trees. But the grindstone got stuck in between and when Krishna pulled the mortar with all his strength the roots of the two trees get uprooted and they fell to the ground with a loud crash. The twin trees were, in fact, the two sons of Kubera, the god of wealth, Nalakubara and Manigriva. They were cursed by the sage Narada to be born as two Arjuna trees in Gokula. When Krishna pulled down the two trees they got liberated from the curse.
Since Yashoda tied him to the mortar with a rope, Krishna is also called as Damodara (dam + udara = rope + stomach). Sri Damodarastakam is a poem written by Sri Satyavrata Muni that describes his love for Sri Damodara. The poem is made up of eight verses and is found in the Padma Purana by Krishna Dwaipayana Vyasa. In the poem, Satyavrata Muni prays to Sri Damodara to appear to him in his eternal form as a young cowherd-boy and bestow his blessings. The 7th verse states:
‡§ï‡•Å‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•å ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß-‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç
‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•å ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø-‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡•å ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•å ‡§ö
‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ-‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ
‡§® ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§π ‡•• ‡•≠‡••
O Lord Damodara, in Your form as a baby, Mother Yasoda bound You to a grinding stone with a rope. You then freed the sons of Kuvera, Manigriva and Nalakuvara, who were cursed to stand as trees and You gave them the chance to become Your devotees. Please bless me in this same way. I only long for this and have no desire for any kind of liberation.
Dr Raguram
27/08/24, 10:27‚ÄØam
Many of us might have grown up savouring every page of Chandamama comics with enchanting tales of mythology, folklore, and adventure. I was recollecting today about one particular story of Krishna and the sparrow.
Kurukshetra was being prepared for the big battle with elephants being used to uproot the trees and clear the space. When one such tree was uprooted, it disturbed a family of sparrows and all of them fell down along with their nest which ensured that they were unharmed. The mother sparrow looked around for some help as she feared that the young ones would be crushed in the ensuing battle. She noticed Krishna and pleaded that he save them all. Krishna responded saying that the law of nature would take its own course, he could not interfere with it and advised that she stock food for the next three weeks. The mother sparrow responded that she trusted Krishna and that the fate of her family rests in his hands and flew away.
When the battle commenced, Krishna asked Arjuna for his bow and arrow and took aim at an elephant. The arrow hit the massive bell around its neck which then fell down. When Krishna told Arjuna that the elephant was the one which brought down the sparrow‚Äôs nest, Arjuna wondered why Krishna did not kill it.
The Pandavas won the ensuing war in which numerous lives were lost. Krishna asked Arjuna to steer the chariot through the battleground which was littered with scores of bodies. He stopped at one place and asked Arjuna to lift an elephant bell which lay on the ground. Arjuna was puzzled as to why Krishna asked him to lift the bell when so many other things needed clearing. When he got down and lifted the bell all the young sparrows flew out with their mother. A single bell brought down by Krishna had saved the lives of the family of sparrows.
When I read it as a child, I was struck by the fact that Krishna found time amidst the great battle, to save a group of helpless sparrows. Its significance expands when I reflect on it now. We are much like the sparrows caught in the battlefield of life, over which we have little control. It is faith in ourselves and trust in a greater force that often helps us to navigate through the tribulations of life. It is the choices we make which define and guide us.
Dr Raguram
28/08/24, 9:14‚ÄØam
A wonderful sculpture and thanks Sir for giving a detailed description of the leela of Lord Krishna.
28/08/24, 7:51‚ÄØam
You cannot miss the Dark Eyed Junco. They have a charm all of their own, with their black hood and unusual metallic chipping song, For the most part, they seem quite content to forage on the ground, kicking up the leaves to garner whatever morsels are hidden below. The flash of their characteristic white outer tail feather is unmistakable when they take to flight. They are quite handsome looking with their black heads and white plumage, like the old saying ‚Äúdark skies above, snow below.‚Äù In some parts of North America, they are strongly associated with winter and are often referred to as snowbirds.
Junco attracted the attention of poets like William Stafford (17 January 1914 - 28 August 1993). Stafford‚Äôs poems are characterized by simple language, unadorned imagery and a conversational tone. He was deeply attached to nature, as he mentioned in one of his works.
‚ÄúI like to live in the sound of water,
in the feel of mountain air. A sharp
reminder hits me: this world still is alive;
it stretches out there shivering toward its own
creation, and I‚Äôm part of it.‚Äù
He wrote a small, beautiful poem about the Junco:
‚ÄúThey operate from elsewhere,
some hall in the mountains ‚Äì
quick visit, gone.
Specialists on branch ends,
craft union. I like their
clean little coveralls.‚Äù
Canadian singer Anne Murray wrote a song about it, which won the 1971 Juno Award (the Canadian music award) for Best Produced Single. The song ends with these lines:
‚ÄúSpread your tiny wings and fly away
And take the snow back with you
Where it came from on that day
The one I love forever is untrue
And if I could you know
that I would fly away with you
yah if I could, you know that I would fly away with you.‚Äù
There is always an unmeasurable joy in watching birds and reading what the poets say about them!
Dr Raguram
29/08/24, 8:19‚ÄØam
Eyes, often referred to as the windows to the soul, have captivated artists throughout history. Eyes convey a wide range of emotions powerfully. In any work of art, especially paintings, eyes nudge us to connect with the subjects at an intimate level. In the hands of a skilled artist, eyes capture and convey the individual personality of the subject, with much ease. The gaze of a subject in an artwork can be quite captivating. One such painting which illustrates this is the ‚ÄòLaughing Cavalier‚Äô, painted by Franz Hal. I haven‚Äôt seen this painting in any gallery (so far!). But whenever I see it in the net, I keep wondering whether he is actually laughing or is it a smirk? Is that a mischievous smile we are seeing? His eyes seem to follow us from whichever direction we view the painting. It appears as if he is observing us intently. His gaze engages us in mysterious ways!
Every time I look at this painting, I am reminded of Ralph Waldo Emerson‚Äôs observation that eyes "speak all languages."
(Franz Hal 1581 - 29th August 1666)
Dr Raguram
30/08/24, 7:06‚ÄØam
An author whom I admire deeply is Oliver Sacks, who eloquently explored the interface between mind and brain in his works. I am captivated by Dr Sacks‚Äô beautiful stories and his loving portrayals of his patients. Referred to as the ‚Äòpoet laureate of modern medicine‚Äô, he died from ocular cancer on August 30, 2015, at the age of 82. We lead a finite existence and letting go can often be hard. It is an arduous task to negotiate the irreversible trajectory of impending death.
An anonymous scholar writing in the 15th century wrote a poignant tract on how to prepare oneself for a good death, entitled Ars Moriendi (Latin for ‚Äòthe art of dying‚Äô). The work instructs as to how one can prepare for their final hours on this earth. It emphasizes the importance of allowing a dying person to experience the emotions they feel without pathologizing those emotions. The possibility of being overwhelmed with existential despair is lessened by allowing a dying person to grieve in their own way, allowing them to focus on the things and people that matter to them most. As the text suggests, most importantly, death is about coming to terms with our transcendental nature.
After learning of his terminal diagnosis, Sacks reflected on these aspects with remarkable candour which was condensed into a book, ‚ÄòGratitude‚Äô. He wrote:
‚ÄúOver the last few days, I have been able to see my life as from a great altitude, as a sort of landscape, and with a deepening sense of the connection of all its parts. This does not mean I am finished with life. On the contrary, I feel intensely alive, and I want and hope in the time that remains to deepen my friendships, to say farewell to those I love, to write more, to travel if I have the strength, to achieve new levels of understanding and insight. This will involve audacity, clarity and plain speaking; trying to straighten my accounts with the world. But there will be time, too, for some fun (and even some silliness, as well). ..And now, weak, short of breath, my once-firm muscles melted away by cancer . . . I find my thoughts drifting to the Sabbath, the day of rest, the seventh day of the week, and perhaps the seventh day of one‚Äôs life as well, when one can feel that one‚Äôs work is done, and one may, in good conscience, rest.‚Äù
In these writings, Oliver Sacks reminds us that we are visitors here, passing through the great mystery of life. Every moment of life including the final ones is a gift and one can face death with poise and equanimity.
In his interesting book, ‚ÄòMusicophilia‚Äô, Oliver Sacks wrote, ‚ÄúIt really is a very odd business that all of us, to varying degrees, have music in our heads.‚Äù That music never dies‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
31/08/24, 7:22‚ÄØam
It has been cloudy on most evenings in Bangalore, with an occasional rain drenching the parched earth. Clouds appearing in a vast array of shapes have been fascinating to watch. Slowly the fluffy white clouds give way to dark clouds, foreboding the arrival of rain. Poets and writers feel inspired to use them as metaphors of human emotions ranging from the joyous to the melancholic. Poems about clouds capture their ethereal beauty, ever-changing nature, and their symbolic significance. Shelley‚Äôs joyful poem, ‚ÄòThe Cloud‚Äô, starts with the beautiful line, ‚ÄúI bring fresh showers for the thirsting flowers‚Äù. Wordsworth conveyed a sense of loneliness describing clouds floating over fluttering daffodils in his poem, ‚ÄúI wandered lonely as a cloud.‚Äù In Rabindranath Tagore‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúClouds come floating into my life, no longer to carry rain or usher storm, but to add color to my sunset sky.‚Äù Mark Strand evocatively described clouds as being ‚Äúdrawn by invisible birds‚Äô and ‚ÄúIf a parrot is lost in a cloud, it turns into a rainbow.‚Äù
Clouds are moving poetry. As Thich Nhat Hanh commented. ‚ÄúIf you are a poet, you will see clearly that there is a cloud floating in this sheet of paper.‚Äù
They teased my imagination too!
Rainclouds
Caress gently
The boundless sky.
Dr Raguram
01/09/24, 11:41‚ÄØam
Gibbons may be the most endangered groups of primates on Earth. Hoolock Gibbon is the only ape species in India. Ahalya and myself were keen to have a glimpse of this rare species and we headed to The Hollongapar Gibbon Sanctuary, a habitat of the endangered Western hoolock gibbon in Assam. After finishing the formalities in the office at the entrance of the sanctuary, we made our way, accompanied by a forest guard. The only way to explore the forest is by walk. The sun was playing hide and seek through the thick trees covered with lush green foliage. As we were walking, we heard an unusual loud call. The guard whispered that it is the call of the gibbon. We walked further for an hour, but couldn‚Äôt spot any. Suddenly the guard noticed some activity in the higher reaches of the trees. We stood there for a while, keenly looking for its presence. Slowly a huge, glossy, black figure emerged, hanging from a branch in the tree with its long arm. It swung from one branch to another, adeptly, with sinuous movements. Soon several others joined and they were darting from one tree to another like skilled acrobats. It was so wonderful to watch their graceful movements. With their short torso, long legs, they almost looked like us!
The gibbons are arboreal animals, preferring to stay in the higher reaches of tall Hollong trees. They barely come down to the forest floor. As they are canopy dwellers, it is difficult to have a good look at them. One has to keep craning the neck all the time to spot them. It is also difficult to photograph them amidst the dark green cover. With some effort and lots of luck, I was able to freeze the experience through the lens!
Life is a collection of moments and our tryst with the Hoolock Gibbon was one of the most memorable experience in our sojourns into the wild. As Oscar Wilde commented, ‚Äúmemories are the diary we all carry with us‚Äù and our visit to the Hoollongapar Sanctuary will remain as a cherished entry in it.
(It is so apt to pen these reminiscences on the International Primate Day, especially when the theme this year is ‚ÄúConnecting with Wild Primates.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
04/09/24, 8:28‚ÄØam
Auroville came into existence when I was doing medicine at JIPMER. I used to cycle there on most weekends to have a look at the emerging settlement which was dotted with very imaginative structures. During one such visit I walked into the ‚ÄòLast School‚Äô. It was a very unusual, creative building, with no resemblance to any school structure I was familiar with. There was a small stream flowing inside and children were making paper boats and floating them in the water. There was a person who was telling them about boats and how they are carried further in waterways. I was attracted to its imaginative and inventive concept. I came to know that Mother called it the ‚ÄòLast School‚Äô, to emphasize that once the community took shape, learning would continue outside of formal schools.
A couple of years later, I was introduced to the work of Ivan Illich by Prof Moris Carstairs who was a visiting professor at NIMHANS. I reviewed Illich‚Äôs ‚ÄòLimits to Medicine‚Äô, which was chaired by him (I wrote about it two years ago). He urged me to read Illich‚Äôs other book, ‚ÄòDeschooling Society‚Äô. In this most unusual book, he articulated ideas which mapped onto the vision of the Mother. Deschooling is not about abolishing education altogether, but rather about reimagining and restructuring the way we learn. It emphasized the importance of self-directed learning, individual autonomy, and community-based education. To quote Illich, ‚ÄúWhat is a child, what is a teacher, what is education? Why, in particular, do we tend to think of learning primarily in the context of the school ‚Äì a particular kind of institution, with a very specific form and organisational structure? What, indeed, are schools actually for? Most learning is not the result of instruction. It is rather the result of unhampered participation in a meaningful setting. Teaching, it is true, may contribute to certain kinds of learning under certain circumstances. But most people acquire most of their knowledge outside school.‚Äù
Illich offered a passionate critique of a formalized, institutionalized educational system and its limitations. It may not be an easy exercise to reshape schools as places of informal, guided, learning habitats focussed on individual skill building. There have been many innovative attempts to create such spaces. The dilemma has always been what happens after such schooling? How do the children from these learning spaces negotiate their lives in the demanding job market outside which is not attuned to such orientations? Many don‚Äôt want to be just ‚Äúanother brick in the wall‚Äô and some perhaps find new imaginative paths to explore in their lives.
Unfortunately education has become an industry and there is an urgent need to think creatively about the role and purpose of schools. Illich‚Äôs book may be a catalyst in that direction.
As Margaret Mead commented, ‚ÄúChildren must be taught how to think, not what to think.‚Äù
(Ivan Illich 4th September 1926 - 2 December 2002)
Dr Raguram
05/09/24, 7:31‚ÄØam
Teacher‚Äôs Day is about paying tribute with an abiding sense of gratitude to teachers who have shaped our journey in learning.
Our formal education starts within the premises of a school. I was fortunate to be a student in the Ramakrishna Mission School, North Branch, Chennai. Among all the teachers who taught us, the one who left a deep impact on me was Sri TS Ranganathan Sir, referred to TSR. He had a commanding presence and when he entered the classroom we were over awed with his demeanor. He was a science teacher but he could also teach us about English literature, geography and human anatomy with ease and √©lan. He was a polymath. He shared with us anecdotes from forgotten pages of history and opened our minds to explore unknown landscapes of learning. I was learning tennis and one day he called to ask me whether I would like to join him on the tennis court. The school had a tennis court not far away from his home. When I reached the place, I found him dressed in his usual attire, an immaculate panchakacham. Panchakacham is not a regular dhoti and has five pleats delicately tucked in, much akin to a nine yards‚Äô saree worn by women in traditional attire. It took me a while to register that he was going to play tennis in this rather complicated outfit. My reservations were put to rest however when he started to serve. It was a booming service that would be the envy of any seasoned tennis player. I struggled to return it. He didn‚Äôt make it easy but egged me on to respond to it. At the end of an hour I was sweating profusely! He patted me and said, ‚ÄúGood start!‚Äù. Sometimes he would ask me to tabulate the results of the exam papers in his home and on completion of the task, I would be enthralled listening to him playing the harmonium.
TSR lit the fire to awaken the joy of learning which was not just confined to the classroom. Borrowing a saying from Robert Frost, he was ‚Äúnot a teacher, but an awakener.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
05/09/24, 6:19‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for touching upon the most important matter. Nowadays schools have turned into commercial establishments with very few committed teachers. You can't be a square peg in a round hole. What can be expected from a demand to just vomit what is taught? The learning place is really pathetic and children who are bright start to burn out and get disillusioned.
06/09/24, 8:10‚ÄØam
Mahakuta, an important centre of Chalukya art and architecture is nestled amidst a grove of kadamba trees in a peaceful village, not very far away from Badami. Within the temple complex there are a number of temples, situated around an ancient water tank. Unfortunately, most of the sculptures in the temples have eroded with time.
