When I walked over to the small Sangameshwara temple, I found a few delicately carved sculptures on its outer wall. The most striking one among them was that of Bhu Varaha. There are three common depictions of Varaha: Bhu Varaha is usually represented standing while that of Pralaya Varaha and Yajna Varaha are in sitting forms. In this stunning sculpture, Bhu Varaha is shown with the head of a boar and the body of a man with four hands. Two hands are holding the shankha and chakra. He is lifting the goddess of earth, Bhudevi, who is safely ensconced in his folded elbow of his left upper hand. The right lower hand rests on his leg. At the bottom are the naga and nagini, with hands folded in devotion. The ornamentation, though delicate, is quite sparse. The graceful, kinetic energy in this depiction has a lasting allure.
There are several versions of the Varaha legend right from the Shatapatha Brahmana. The most commonly associated legend is that of Varaha lifting the earth, personified as the goddess Bhudevi, out of the cosmic ocean. When the demon Hiranyaksha stole the earth and hid her in the primordial waters, Lord Vishnu appeared as Varaha to rescue her. Varaha slew the demon and retrieved the Earth from the ocean and restored Bhudevi to her place in the universe.
What is interesting is how geological events and processes become part of thos narration. Varaha as an avatar of God Vishnu saved the Earth by lifting it out of the cosmic ocean and restoring it back. While the legend symbolizes the triumph of good over evil it also emphasizes the need to protect and restore the environment, especially on the background of increasing climate change now. With 70 percent of the planet being covered in water, the oceans are important drivers of the global climate. Increasing greenhouse gases from human activities are altering the oceans before our eyes. Greenhouse gases trap energy from the sun, which the oceans absorb, causing them to warm. As the excessive heat and energy warms the ocean, the change in temperature leads to unparalleled cascading effects, including rise in sea levels.
Today as our earth faces serious threats from climate change, we should draw inspiration from the legend of Varaha to be proactive in saving the planet.
(Penned on the occasion of Varaha Jayanthi, which is observed on 6th September 2024)
Dr Raguram
07/09/24, 7:56‚ÄØam
Nritya Ganapati is the 15th among the 32 forms of Ganesha. This exquisitely carved sculpture of Nritya Ganapati (Dancing Ganesha) is from Chennakeshava temple at Somanathapura. A significant aspect of Nritya Ganapati‚Äôs imagery is the setting of his dance, beneath the Kalpavriksha, or the wish-fulfilling tree. This choice of location is not arbitrary. The Kalpavriksha in Hindu mythology is known to grant all wishes. Nritya Ganapati‚Äôs dance under this tree thus becomes a metaphor for the joyous and bountiful nature of the cosmos. He is depicted with four hands. His left foot is firmly placed on the ground whereas the right one is lifted up and bent sideways at the knee. He is bejewelled and intricate ornaments decorate various parts of his body. Despite his bulky disposition, there is a lightness in his stance.
Oothukadu Venkata Subba Iyer, popularly known as Venkata Kavi, was a brilliant composer of the 18th Century who made immense contributions to the Carnatic Music repertoire. One of his memorable composition is on Nritya Ganapati, titled ‚ÄòAnandha Narthana Ganapathim‚Äô in the raga Naatai, which begins with these lines:
‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§® ‡§ó‡§£‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á ‚Äì (‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç / ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ )
‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡•ê ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§ú‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶)
Ananda nartana gaNapatim bhAvayE
chidAkAra mUlAdhAra OmkAra gajavadanam paramam param (Ananda)
I meditate on the joyous dancing Ganapati always
Whose form is pure consciousness, who lives in the muladhara chakra and who is the form of Om, the elephant faced one, the supreme one.
Though we recognize Ganesha in various forms, in Adi Shankara‚Äôs words, he is formless Supreme Brahman. 'Ajam Nirvikalpam Niraakaaramekam,' Ganesha is Ajam (unborn), Nirvikalpa (attributeless), Niraakaar (formless) and he symbolizes Brahman, the absolute consciousness.

07/09/24, 6:19‚ÄØpm
Sculpture so ornamental. Form to channelize our thoughts to understand the formless Brahman....
09/09/24, 10:33‚ÄØam
Literacy is more than just reading and writing. At its simplest, it is a tool for meaningful engagement with society. It shapes and enhances our experience of the world.
Kerala had 49.5% literacy rate before independence. This has scaled up in the ensuing years and now Kerala has the highest literacy rate among the states of India. Kerala's literacy success can be attributed to a number of factors, including its history, social reform, and the Kerala Education Act of 1958. As of March 2023, the literacy rate in Kerala was 94%. In spite of this remarkable achievement there are pockets where literacy hasn‚Äôt made inroads as anticipated. For instance, in Wayanad which has 36 per cent of the state's tribal population, the literacy rate amongst tribals is lower than the district's average literacy rate and the literacy rate of the general population.
It is on this background that we got involved with the education of tribal children in the region. Wayanad Girijana Seva Trust was initiated by two youngsters who have been committed to this cause and we started working with them. The need was for a secure, hospitable environment where these children could stay and learn. Hence, in the initial phases the focus was on infrastructure, furnished class rooms, hostel, kitchen etc. With the help of volunteers and committed teachers, the educational input has also scaled up over the years. A few years back we added a learning resource centre, fully equipped with laptops to advance their learning.
What I have noticed in the past two decades, is the cascading impact of formal education among the children. Children, especially the girls, have become more assured, confident while keeping alive their tribal identity. Literacy has expanded their ambit of learning and capabilities.
It has been a journey of learning for us too and there are continuing challenges in maintaining and sustaining the process. We have built bridges of learning for these marginalized children with the fond hope that it kindles the spirit of enquiry to discover and realize the potentials within.
And the spirit flows on‚Ä¶
(8th September was the International Literacy Day)
Dr Raguram
11/09/24, 10:19‚ÄØam
Mahadevi Varma was one of the four pillars of Chhayavaad, the neo-romantic movement of Hindi literature. She wrote a series of eleven radical essays titled Shrinkhala Ki Kadiyan (Links In My Chain) which is often compared to Beauvoir‚Äôs seminal text, ‚ÄòThe Second Sex‚Äô. Married off at an early age, she chose to lead an ascetic life, later on in her life. She was deeply influenced by Buddhism and even wanted to become a monk. There is an interesting anecdote about a particular meeting with her Buddhist guru, when she noticed that he was hiding his face from her with a palm leaf. Shocked by this, she walked out and later said that someone who could not trust himself with a woman had nothing to teach her.
Mahadevi Varma took an active part in the freedom movement and also wrote eloquently about women‚Äôs issues and social reform. A strong believer in gender equality, she was among the first Indian poets to delve into the subject of women rights and their place in society. She powerfully emphasized in her writings, that women deserved every opportunity to flourish in a world that had suppressed their freedom and potential.
In an essay, ‚Äò‡§Ö‡§§‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‚Äô she wrote;
‚Äú‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡§π‡§®‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§è ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§° ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ü ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§‚Äù
‚ÄúFor ages, men have been punishing women not for their strength but for their endurance.‚Äù
Her works are a living testament to the power of the written word to drive social change.
Dr Raguram
12/09/24, 8:43‚ÄØam
Mahakavi Bharathiyar was a champion of women‚Äôs rights, much like Mahadevi Varma, about whom I had posted yesterday. As a poet, mystic, and visionary, his advocacy of women reached unique heights. His poems, songs, and essays on freedom, feminism, social and gender equality are pertinent to date, despite being written more than a hundred year ago. One of his famous poems is "Pudhumai Penn", which translates to "Modern Woman." It celebrates the empowerment and independence of women. He writes:
‡Æ®‡Æø‡ÆÆ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ®‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Æü‡Øà ‡Æ®‡Øá‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æµ‡Øà‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æû‡Øç‡Æö‡Ææ‡Æ§ ‡Æ®‡ØÜ‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æï‡Æ≥‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡Æ§‡Æø‡ÆÆ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æû‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Æö‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æ§‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç
‡Æö‡ØÜ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡ÆÆ‡Øà ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æ§‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ±‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æµ ‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øç;
Her head held high, she walks while looking everyone in the eye
She is a fearless possessor of integrity
She is a proud possessor of wisdom born out of conviction
The resolute woman does not falter or feel inferior
Bharathiyar was a strong advocate of gender parity:
‡ÆÜ‡Æ£‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æï‡Æ∞‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡Æï‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æµ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç
‡ÆÖ‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æµ‡Æø ‡Æ≤‡Øã‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø ‡Æá‡Æµ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øà‡ÆØ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æ¥‡Øà‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡ÆÆ‡Øç
Recognizing men and women as equals
Will result in empowered knowledge and sustain the world
These powerful words are still deeply relevant today and will continue to inspire people to strive for a society that is free from fear, oppression, and discrimination on the basis of gender.
Dr Raguram
14/09/24, 9:18‚ÄØam
One of the temples not often visited in Khajuraho is the Vamana temple. Set amidst a verdant, green landscape, it is a sight to behold with its spire reaching up like a beautiful mountain. Like rest of the temples in Khajuraho, the outer walls of the sanctum are adorned with intricate carvings depicting scenes from Hindu mythology. In the sanctum is a striking idol of Vamana, the fifth incarnation of Lord Vishnu. Vamana is the first incarnation whem Lord Vishnu appeared in a full human form, as a dwarf.
The legend of the Vamana avatar is narrated in the Rigveda and other scriptures. Mahabali, son of Virochan and grandson of Prahlad, was a generous, mighty monarch who was adored by his subjects. He was granted the boon of immortality by Lord Brahma and he continued to expand the frontiers of his empire. He conquered all the three realms: Heaven, Earth and the Underworld. Immensely troubled by growing powers, the Devas appealed to Lord Vishnu to intervene and restore the balance of power. Responding to their prayers, Lord Vishnu incarnated as Vamana, the dwarf and went to the Yaga that was being performed by Mahabali. During the Yaga, people could ask Mahabali for and receive anything they wanted. Mahabali bade Vamana to ask for anything that he wanted, like jewels, land, forests etc, without hesitation. Vamana denied all these politely and asked merely for three paces of land. Looking at Vamana‚Äôs diminutive stature, Bali said, ‚ÄòSo be it; pace and take it.‚Äô The dwarf Vamana suddenly grew in size into a giant and with one step measured the Earth and with another the entire Heaven. As there was no room left for the third step that had been granted, Mahabali humbly knelt under Vamana‚Äôs foot and offered his head. As Bali sank deep into the underworld, he heard his subjects wailing in grief for their much loved king. Seeing this, Vamana granted Mahabali one last boon. The boon was the permission to visit his subjects on Earth once a year. Thus, Mahabali returns every year to visit his people and the land that he had once ruled. Onam commemorates the annual visit of this legendary king from the underworld to his former kingdom, the land of Kerala.
Parsva Ekadashi which is observed today is also associated with the legend of Mahabali and Vamana Avatar of Lord Vishnu and is also referred to as Vamana Ekadashi. It is fascinating to note that the Onam festival follows the same legend and takes place around the same time of year.
Dr Raguram
14/09/24, 6:53‚ÄØpm
Words like a razor. So powerful and so very True. Even today it exists and no wonder women have started revolting!
14/09/24, 7:21‚ÄØpm
An unusual sculpture. In fact he goes to Bali Chakravarthi after his parents do the thread ceremony and the sacred thread is so well sculpted!
18/09/24, 7:54‚ÄØam
William Carlos Williams was a full-time practicing physicians who was also a prolific writer across many literary genres. He regarded art and medicine as ‚Äútwo parts of a whole.‚Äù Williams rejected traditional conventions of rhyme and meter, masterfully blending colloquial idioms which lent a conversational tone to his poems. Often referred to as the ‚ÄúMaster of the glimpse,‚Äù Williams painted verbal pictures with crisp, vivid word images in poems like, ‚ÄúThe Red Wheelbarrow.‚Äù The subject of Williams‚Äôs poetry is quite varied; crowds attending baseball games, trains pulling into station, wheelbarrows, fire trucks, and a host of everyday subjects. He drew inspiration from grounded images from any source, in unexpected places.
Even though he was incapacitated by a stroke, he continued to type with his non dominant hand and completed his and Pulitzer Prize-winning ‚ÄúPictures from Brueghel.‚Äù Additional small strokes resulted in more deficits, but he kept on writing.
I particularly like his poem ‚ÄúThe Fool‚Äôs Song‚Äù
I tried to put a bird in a cage.
O fool that I am!
For the bird was Truth.
Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put
Truth in a cage!
And when I had the bird in the cage,
O fool that I am!
Why, it broke my pretty cage.
Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put
Truth in a cage!
And when the bird was flown from the cage,
O fool that I am!
Why, I had nor bird nor cage.
Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put
Truth in a cage!
Heigh-ho! Truth in a cage.
Much like the bird in the poem, each of us tussle with some deep secret or truth which we want to hide from others. But truth is hard to reveal and often cannot be hidden. As Leo Tolstoy observed, ‚ÄúVery often, all the activity of the human mind is directed not in revealing the truth, but in hiding the truth.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
22/09/24, 9:22‚ÄØam
Like William Carlos William, Dannie Abse (22 September 1923 - 28 September 2014), was a physician poet. Unlike the former, who largely kept medicine out of his poetry, Abse wanted to ‚Äúhear the heartbeat of words‚Äù and wrote about patients and the diseases they had, with tenderness. Even a stethoscope is infused with poetic insights, transmitting sounds ‚Äúover young women‚Äôs tense abdomens . . . of creation and in a dead man‚Äôs chest, the silence before creation began.‚Äù
His poem, ‚ÄòPortrait of an Old Doctor‚Äù begins with these beautiful, reflective lines:
‚ÄúLover of music more than his textbooks‚Äô
arrythmic prose and dated, almost dangerous
his Conybeare and his Boyd‚Äôs Pathology.
(Notes in the margin by the student he was)
What was it all about? Blunderbuss drugs
prescribed to ease the patient. And moonbeams.
A composer‚Äîa Beethoven, a Smetana‚Äîit seemed, could be deaf, but not a doctor.
He had been a conÔ¨Ådence man for the patient.
That‚Äôs how it was in the Theatre of Disease
and, at the Ô¨Ånal act, he had lifted
his stethoscope to listen
as if to Mozart.
Then, silently, relatives and friends Ô¨Åled out.
No applause. None for Hippocrates‚Äô art.‚Äù
Let me end this post with this poignant poem of Abse
‚ÄòMoonbright‚Äô
Afterwards, late, walking home from hospital,
that December hour too blatantly moonbright
- such an unworldly moon so widely round,
an orifice of scintillating arctic light -
I thought how the effrontery of a similar moon,
a Pirandello moon that would make men howl,
would, in future, bring back the eidolon
of you, father, propped high on pillow
your mouth ajar, your nerveless hand in mine.
At home, feeling hollow, I shamelessly wept
- whether for you or myself I do not know.
Tonight a bracing wind makes my eyes cry
while a cloud dociles an impudent moon
that is and was, and is again, and was.
Men become mortal the night their fathers die.‚Äù
Lastly, at this stage in my life, these lines from his poem ‚ÄòTalking to Myself‚Äô ‚ÄúIn the mildew of age/all pavements slope uphill‚Äô touch a deep chord within‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
23/09/24, 9:14‚ÄØam
On September 21, Max Schur, Freud‚Äôs personal physician visited him and was aghast to see him looking pale and quite wasted. Freud took his doctor‚Äôs hand and said, ‚ÄúMy dear Schur, you certainly remember our first talk. You promised me then not to forsake me when the time comes. Now it is nothing but torture and makes no sense anymore.‚Äù Schur responded stating that he had not forgotten the promise he made. Freud thanked him and told Schur to ‚Äútalk it over with Anna, and if she thinks it‚Äôs right, make an end of it.‚Äù Schur spoke to Anna and she sorrowfully concurred with her father‚Äôs wish. Then Schur gave Freud an injection of three centigrams of morphine, a dose much stronger than he would have used if the objective had only been to relieve pain. He was now assisting him to die a peaceful death. He gave Freud another injection that day, then a third on September 22. Freud lapsed into a coma, but he held on to life. At 3AM in the morning on Saturday, September 23, 1939, Sigmund Freud breathed his last. Three days later, his body was cremated and his ashes placed in an ancient Greek urn, originally gifted to him by his friend Marie Bonaparte.
Many years before, Freud had made it abundantly clear as to how he wanted to die as he never wanted to live without his mental capacities intact. He wrote to his friend Oskar Pfister, ‚ÄúWith all the resignation before destiny that suits an honest man, I have one wholly secret entreaty: only no invalidism, no paralysis of one‚Äôs powers through bodily misery. Let us die in harness, as King Macbeth says.‚Äù
Freud left the world with a certain degree of composure. In Nietzsche‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúThe most fortunate author is one who is able to say as an old man that all he had of life giving, invigorating, uplifting enlightening thoughts and feelings still lives on in his writings, and that he himself is only the gray ash, while the fire has been rescued and carried forth everywhere.‚Äù
The last book Freud read was Balzac‚Äôs La Peau de Chagrin (The Wild Ass‚Äôs Skin). The protagonist, Rapheal de Valentin, gains possession of a wild donkey‚Äôs skin and is granted all he wishes. The magical object has the power to fulfil its owner's every wish but carries a heavy price: With every wish the owner's remaining time in life is reduced. On finishing the book, Freud told Schur, ‚ÄúThis was the proper book for me to read.‚Äù
Mark Edmundson has written a very perceptive book on Freud‚Äôs last days, ‚ÄòThe Death Of Sigmund Freud.‚Äô The book ends with these words ‚ÄúToward the person who has died we adopt a special attitude: something like admiration for someone who has accomplished a very difficult task.‚Äù
In the words of Sheena Blackhall
‚ÄúIt was Saturday, under the sign of Libra
When he crossed, with the aid of morphine,
(that child of Morpheus, Greek God of Dreams)
Into the world of the dead.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
24/09/24, 4:33‚ÄØpm
Adam Schmalholz, an American songwriter and National Poetry Slam champion from Los Angeles, California. Schmalholz describes his poetry as a reflection of his own experiences and life lessons.
24/09/24, 4:34‚ÄØpm
Adam Schmalholz, an American songwriter and National Poetry Slam champion from Los Angeles, California. Schmalholz describes his poetry as a reflection of his own experiences and life lessons.
25/09/24, 9:17‚ÄØam
Internet is an immense ocean swirling with humongous amount of information. Sometimes by sheer coincidence an unknown pearl emerges from its depth. A few days ago, I was typing the word luminous in the search box and by mistake typed ‚Äòn‚Äô instead of ‚Äòl‚Äô and a mysterious word ‚Äònuminous‚Äô emerged. Curious to know further I googled about the word and found that it is credited to Rudolf Otto who was an eminent German theologian in the early part of twentieth century. Rudolf is regarded as one of the most influential scholars of comparative religion. He travelled to India twice, mastered Sanskrit and translated many ancient Hindu texts into German.
I also came across an interesting book summarizing his work, ‚ÄòIndia's Religion of Grace and Christianity Compared and Contrasted‚Äô which was dedicated to Sri Krishnaraja Wadiyar. When I was reading the book, I got to know more about his concept of the ‚ÄòNuminous‚Äô, an experience that, in his view, underlies all spiritual quests. According to him, it has three components, each designated with a Latin phrase: mysterium tremendum et fascinans. As mysterium, the numinous is entirely different from anything we experience in ordinary life. It evokes a reaction of transcendental silence. But the numinous is also a mysterium tremendum. Initially it provokes terror because of its overwhelming power. Finally, the numinous presents itself as fascinans, as merciful and gracious. Rudolf emphasized that it is essentially nonrational, subjective, and cannot be expressed in language. In his opinion, the numinous is a universal aspect of human spirituality and is at the core of all spiritual experience across various cultures and religions. His notion of the numinous remains an important framework for understanding the deeply transformative and awe-inspiring aspects of human spirituality.
I found his concept of ‚ÄòNuminous‚Äô, quite interesting as it is reflective of the perennial human quest to explore the deeper aspects of individual consciousness and seek its connection to something vast and infinite. For me I often have a glimpse of that state in my sojourns in nature. We only have to lift our accustomed veils to experience it.
(Rudolf Otto; September 25th 1869 - March 6th 1937)
Dr Raguram
27/09/24, 9:36‚ÄØam
Kay Ryan, the 16th Poet Laureate of USA has a distinctive, original voice. Her poems are short, not more than twenty lines, some even shorter, replete with intricate wordplay. I found the rich, imaginative nature of her poems quite alluring. She has written several poems about birds and this particular one is permanently installed at the Central Park.
How Birds Sing
‚ÄúOne is not taxed;
one need not practice;
one simply tips
the throat back
over the spine axis
and asserts the chest.
The wings and the rest
compress a musical
squeeze which floats
a series of notes
upon the breeze.‚Äù
There are many entrancing sounds in nature. Listening to the symphonic serenade emerging from the fragile throats of birds is a magical experience. I often immerse myself in that moment, swaying with their haunting, melodic airwaves. In the words of the poet Maria Rainer Rilke, ‚ÄúA birdsong can even for a moment, make the whole world into a sky within us.‚Äù

29/09/24, 9:47‚ÄØam
Today is the World Heart Day‚Ä¶
Sharing a poem by Dr Viswanathan Venkatachalam
An interventional cardiologist based in Sydney, Australia
THE INFARCT PARTY
Today I wish to write a solemn poetry
On poor little coronary artery
With an infarction, it‚Äôs lumen totally seals
Gosh! The pain that the patient feels!
In comes the cardiologist from a party
All gadgets to make it hale and hearty
We need to get a catheter in first,
For the clot in the artery to be burst!
In comes the wire and on it a balloon
In saving the life, this really is a boon!
Now the stenosis has just got to vent
In comes to cure the majestic stent!
With all drugs on board is served cocktail
This the happy ending of the cardiac tale!

30/09/24, 8:49‚ÄØam
Today is the birthday of Rumi whose works continue to have a deep impact on me. His poems encompass a rich and complex tapestry of themes and ideas, all deftly woven together. Personally they have been inspiring signposts which gently guided me to discover myself anew.
Last week I spoke about the travails of the survivors of suicide in a CME. Suicide destroys the fabric of existence of the survivors and their lives become frayed at the edges. Embracing the reality of loss is not an easy task. It is an extremely poignant journey.
In this particular poem, Rumi explores the nature of grief and loss, suggesting that it can be a catalyst for self-discovery and growth.
‚ÄúYour grief for what you‚Äôve lost lifts a mirror
up to where you are bravely working.
Expecting the worst, you look, and instead,
here‚Äôs the joyful face you‚Äôve been wanting to see.
Your hand opens and closes, and opens and closes.
If it were always a fist or always stretched open,
you would be paralyzed.
Your deepest presence is in every small contracting and expanding,
the two as beautifully balanced
and coordinated
as birds' wings.‚Äù
Often the survivor‚Äôs world becomes constricted in the absence of the person and they withdraw into themselves. Through the evocative use of the metaphor of bird‚Äôs wings, Rumi extols the virtue of spreading the wings open, ‚Äòcontracting and expanding‚Äô them, to experience the transformative power of loss.
I have observed in my clinical work that the person whom the survivors think that they have lost, continues to live amidst their own feathers of memory and I strive to urge them to find strength in them, balance themselves and soar again.

01/10/24, 6:54‚ÄØam
I don't mind being older. I'm proud of my age. Being a ‚Äòsenior citizen‚Äô has its own advantages! In the crowded mayhem of security checks in the airport, one is gently guided ahead of the queue and people offer their seat in the airport shuttle. As they say, ‚ÄúAge is a question of mind over matter. If you don't mind, it doesn't matter.‚Äù I follow Walt Disney‚Äôs dictum ‚ÄúImagination has no age. And dreams are forever.‚Äù
Thought of sharing a lovely poem by Mary Oliver on the occasion of ‚ÄúInternational Day for ‚ÄòOlder‚Äô Persons.‚Äù
HALLELUIAH by Mary Oliver
Everyone should be born into this world happy
and loving everything.
But in truth it rarely works that way.
For myself, I have spent my life clamoring toward it.
Halleluiah, anyway I‚Äôm not where I started!
And have you too been trudging like that, sometimes
almost forgetting how wondrous the world is
and how miraculously kind some people can be?
And have you too decided that probably nothing important
is ever easy?
Not, say, for the first sixty years.
Halleluiah, I‚Äôm sixty now, and even a little more,
and some days I feel I have wings.
Dr Raguram
03/10/24, 10:53‚ÄØam
Yet another Gandhi Jayanti has passed by with ritual obeisance and hollow homilies uttered by politicians. An epitome of humility, compassion, forgiveness and tolerance, Mahatma Gandhi brought morality into the forefront of political life. There have been very few in public life who have embodied these values. It was my privilege to have met one such person, Sri HS Doreswamy. My first meeting is deeply entrenched in my memory. He was dressed in a simple khadi dhoti and jubba with a towel strung around his neck. Though bent with age, he was deceptively frail looking and the sparkle in his eyes told a different story. After that initial encounter, we met on several occasions. He faced scores of tribulations in life and shared many of the most poignant moments in life freely with me. His innate resilience in the face of hosts of adversities in his life, never dampened his remarkable resolve to serve the people. He was deeply concerned about the malignant influence of money power over the electoral process and the fragmentation of the society across caste and religious divides.
Sri Doreswamy never held any political position and his power came from his unwavering commitment to social harmony, environmental protection, safeguarding of the constitution and serving the downtrodden. He led a very simple, spartan life and remarked once that ‚Äúa social worker should live in voluntary poverty.‚Äù
This eminent Gandhian who battled many odds in his life, including Covid infection, died of cardiac problems at the age of 103, a few years ago.
As a mental health professional I like listening rather than talking. In the process, invariably I tune into the life stories and connect with the heart of people whom I meet. I take a moment today to acknowledge the impact of this special person whose unparalleled resilience and courage of conviction, continues to inspire me.

06/10/24, 8:20‚ÄØam
There was quite a heavy downpour in Bengaluru last evening and the meteorologists predicted that more will be on the anvil. Forecasting weather can be quite dicey, even with machine learning techniques which are making steady inroads to predict rainfall, more accurately.
Sometimes an experienced farmer can foresee the onset of rain more accurately than any algorithm. Once we went in search of the most elusive bird in India, the Great Indian Bustard, in the Desert National Park. We got the permission with some difficulty and proceeded to a little village Khuri where we stayed with a farmer in his simple homestay. We spent a night in the midst of the desert with his assistance and it was an experience to cherish. Next morning we were to proceed to the national park. As we were taking leave from the farmer, he looked up in the sky (which incidentally was totally clear), and said, much to our dismay that it will rain in the park area in an hour or two. True to his words, as we neared the national park, it started raining, gathering strength in few minutes. We waited for a while, hoping that it will abate and after some time, rain stopped. But unfortunately we couldn‚Äôt enter the park as the tracks inside were muddy and not suitable for the only vehicle that is allowed inside, camel drawn cart, to venture in. Needless to say, it was a huge disappointment. But till this day it amazes me as to how the farmer forecasted the rains so accurately, by just looking at the sky! (I did catch up with the elusive bird, year later and that‚Äôs another story!)
Dr Raguram
08/10/24, 9:10‚ÄØam
Navratri is devoted to the worship of Goddess Durga in her various forms. Katyayani is one among the Navadurgas, the nine forms of the Goddess, who is worshipped on the sixth fay of Navratri. She is a fierce manifestation of Shakti, the divine female power.
In the Devi Bhagavata Purana, it is mentioned that Rishi Katyayana was a great devotee of Mother Shakti. He wished for the goddess to be born in his household in the form of his daughter. For this, Sage Katyayana did severe penance for years. Meanwhile, the malevolent Mahishasura was wreaking havoc, tormenting the gods relentlessly. Seeking a solution, the divine trinity of Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma emitted flames that coalesced into the formidable form of Goddess Katyayani. Each of them gifted her a weapon to vanquish Mahishasura. She then embarked on a mission, engaged Mahishasura in a fearsome battle, defeated and vanquished him. Hence, she is also referred to as Mahishasura Mardhini.
This delicately sculpted panel in the inner wall of the Chidambaram temple depicts Katyayani with eighteen hands, her leg firmly entrenched on the neck of Mahishasura.
The legend of Katyayani is not merely a relic of a bygone era but an inspiring metaphor of resilience and empowerment, which women can draw upon in their daily lives even now. In a world beset with discrimination, inequality, and injustice faced by women, her story illustrates that courage, coupled with an unshakable resolve, can be a continuing source of motivation to conquer adversities and challenge norms even in the face of seemingly insurmountable odds.
Dr Raguram
09/10/24, 10:13‚ÄØam
This leaf, gnarled and frayed at the edges, will soon plummet gently to the earth at any moment. It‚Äôs limitedness, makes me aware of our own impermanence. As Robert Frost wrote;
‚ÄúNature's first green is gold,
Her hardest hue to hold.
Her early leaf's a flower;
But only so an hour.
Then leaf subsides to leaf.
So Eden sank to grief,
So dawn goes down to day.
Nothing gold can stay.‚Äù
Impermanence is the essence of life. We build castles on the shifting sands of life hardly realizing their ephemeral nature. It when we recognize the ever changing tides of life, however painful they may be and flow with them, we can truly appreciate the beauty of our temporary existence. In Jimi Hendrix‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúCastles made of sand, slip into the sea, eventually.‚Äù
Just as this branch will soon release these leaves without resistance, won‚Äôt it be wonderful to adapt to the impermanence of our lives with grace?
Dr Raguram
09/10/24, 10:55‚ÄØpm
Sculpture full of energy and it is important to draw inspiration to fight the evils withinüôè
10/10/24, 10:17‚ÄØam
On this World Mental Health Day, let me draw attention to Dorothea Buck, an inspiring figure who espoused the cause of the mentally ill with extraordinary zeal and commitment.
When Dorothea was just 19 years old, she was emotionally distraught at the prospect of yet another war and the attendant suffering. She was diagnosed as schizophrenic and was confined to an asylum for nine months where she was subjected to a range of harsh physical treatments. Under the Nazi-era ‚Äúhereditary health law‚Äù protocols, which had been imposed to prevent so-called genetic impurities from being transmitted to future generations, she was also sterilized. When she was released, she was barred from marrying and denied a career as a teacher. She continued to have periods of psychotic episodes which were poorly treated. Undeterred by these adversities, she started writing about mental health, giving lectures, holding seminars and helping to start organizations to protect the rights of mentally ill persons.
In her talks and writings, Dorothea continuously emphasized that mental health professionals should provide a safe space and hear the stories of personal suffering, rather than seeing them as soulless objects of study. She drew attention to the importance of a three-way discourse in clinical settings involving the patients, their key relatives and their doctors. She called this process as a ‚Äútrialogue.‚Äù
Dorothea trained herself to be a sculptor and this work of hers is called, ‚ÄúMother and Child.‚Äù Speaking about, it she remarked that such kind of intimate personal relationship between doctors and psychotic patients is ‚Äúmissing in today‚Äôs psychiatry‚Ä¶ the unrelatedness of psychiatrists to their patients contradicted everything human.‚Äù
Dorothea died on Oct. 9, 2019, at the age of 102.
Dorothea‚Äôs autobiography ‚ÄúOn the Trail of the Morning Star: Psychosis as Self-Discovery‚Äù, was originally published in German. Translated into English in 2024, it is available as a free download in Research Gate. It is one of the most moving accounts of her lived experiences and tryst with mental illness and I would urge every mental health professional to read it.
Advocacy about mental health is not merely in the realm of professionals. There is an urgent need to provide spaces, where the voice of people who enter and pas through the gates of immense emotional suffering can be heard.
Dr Raguram
11/10/24, 8:48‚ÄØam
This is a beautiful sculpture of Vishnu Durga at the Melakadambur temple which dates back to 12th century, constructed during the reign of Kulottunga Chola. She is four-armed and carries conch and discus in her upper handd. Her right hand is in ‚Äòabhaya posture‚Äô. She is standing in samabhanga pose, which means she is resting her weight equally on both feet. Vishnu Durga is usually depicted in a peaceful form (Saumya Vadana).
