12/10/24, 9:06‚ÄØam
Vijayadashami commemorates the triumph of Lord Rama over Ravana. The Yudh Kanda section of the Ramayana is replete with details of the fierce battle which lasted for nearly seven days. The duel was so intense that both the armies stood watching the ferocious exchanges. Ravana fought valiantly and fired his arrows in the direction of the flagstaff fixed on Rama's chariot. But none of his arrows could reach the Indra's chariot that Rama rode on. All of Ravana's arrows fell to the ground. Rama's arrows, however, tore asunder Ravana's flag-staff which fell and entered the earth. Overcome with rage, Ravana showered a stream of arrows aiming them at the horses that pulled Rama's chariot. But they had no impact on the horses. This enraged Ravana further and he rained a number of objects in the direction of Rama's chariot. That included gadaa (maces), hathora (iron bludgeons), chakras (discs), mountains and uprooted trees, axes etc. When even that failed, Ravana covered the sky with his missiles. Ravana then tried to attack Matali, Indra‚Äôs charioteer. This angered Rama and he aimed the arrows at Ravana's heads. The heads fell down one by one, but they grew back. Finally, Matali, suggested that "To kill Ravana you must use the dreaded arrow of Brahma, given to you by Agastya Muni, which never misses its target". Heeding to his advice, Rama shot the divine arrow, which found its mark and pierced Ravana in the heart, finally killing him.
Amruteshwara Temple in the Chikkamagalur district of Karnataka is embellished with some of the most beautiful carvings of scenes from Ramayana and Mahabharatha. These friezes are quite small in size and showcase the extraordinary skill and craftsmanship of the sculptors. This particular one depicts the battle scene between Rama and Ravana. I have merged two adjacent panels together to form a composite image. The size of the actual panel is as depicted in the photograph!
Dr Raguram
13/10/24, 11:53‚ÄØam
Migratory birds are a mesmerizing and astonishing aspect of nature that never ceases to amaze me. These remarkable creatures embark on incredible odysseys, spanning thousands of miles annually, between their breeding grounds in the north and wintering grounds in the south. Their epic migrations are a testament to their remarkable adaptations and the formidable obstacles they overcome in an ever-changing world. Their movements are an indispensable part of numerous ecosystems worldwide.
Ruffs are migratory birds that travel to India from their breeding grounds in northern Europe and Asia. They breed in wetlands and marshes across a vast range that extends from Scandinavia and Russia to eastern Siberia. During the autumn migration, ruffs undertake a long journey, flying southwards to reach their wintering grounds in Africa and South Asia. During their migration, ruffs face a range of threats, including habitat loss and degradation, hunting, and climate change.
Mangalajodi is a magical bird paradise and Ruffs migrate to its wetlands during winter. It is a wonderful sight to see scores of them amidst the marshes and reed beds. Ruffs generally leave India in the months of March and April, as they begin their return journey to their breeding grounds in northern Europe and Asia.
Here is a beautiful poem about migratory birds like Ruff by Nehal;
‚ÄúThese days
My thoughts are like
Migratory birds
Visiting me from
Far far away, unknown regions
Fill the sky of my mind
With their
Beauty, sounds and movements
of their wings
And when they leave
They leave without a trace
Can't keep them even in my memory
And I start waiting
For
One more winter!
( 12th October is the World Migratory Day)
Dr Raguram
14/10/24, 10:16‚ÄØam
Jos√© Emilio Pacheco, revered as one of Mexico‚Äôs literary giants, deftly wove the rich tapestry of Mexican culture and its landscapes in his works. His poems offer vivid descriptions of Mexico‚Äôs diverse ecosystems. These landscapes are not mere settings but are intertwined with his deep reflections about their ecosystem. This particular poem is a living testimony to the transformative power of his words;
INSISTENCE
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs talk about snow once more let‚Äôs say
its cardinal virtue is that it‚Äôs quiet
It knows how to be born with impeccable smoothness in the night
and when we wake we see it has claimed
the earth and the trees
The snow is all around you today, where will it go?
The snow that spins interminably around the city
and the house
will take off into thin air
again be cloud and water
then snow once more
You don‚Äôt have its easy adaptable nature
You‚Äôll go on and die and be buried
You will be the clod of earth the snow settles on‚Äù
When we read a poem like this, we enter the imaginative world of the author. It is a kind of conversation, a sharing of experiences. As Pacheco commented, "I like poetry to be the interior voice, the voice no one hears, the voice of the person reading it. That is how the 'I' becomes 'you', the 'you' becomes 'I', and in the act of reading is born the 'we' that only exists in that intimate, full moment of reading."
Dr Raguram
15/10/24, 1:23‚ÄØpm
I understand that today is World Students‚Äô Day to commemorate Dr Abdul Kalam‚Äôs birthday. He was a great motivator of students and always encouraged them to ask questions in his interactions with them. He also had a website wherein students could raise question on a wide variety of subjects. He even dedicated his book ‚ÄòIgnited Minds‚Äô to a class XII student, Snehal Thakkar. According to him, ‚Äú a very important characteristic of a student is to question.‚Äù
During our training period in NIMHANS, we were enveloped in an ambiance of open discussion that encouraged questioning. Seminars, case conferences were active crucibles replete with thoughtful and engaging questioning by trainees. On many occasions, these would spill over to the hostel mess for more animated exchanges!
Questioning lies at the heart of active learning. It is like planting seeds of thought. They can create spaces to reflect on new ideas and perceptions. Unfortunately, the trend to question seems to be declining. In many academic presentations across various settings, I invariably notice that students are reticent to ask questions. Is it because as a culture, we overvalue speaking and privilege it over questioning? Or is it because we are educated in a system that implicitly silences questioning and assigns value only to ‚Äòcorrect answers‚Äô? Perhaps teachers and ‚Äògurus‚Äô feel uneasy being challenged and implicitly discourage questioning?
Historically, the art of questioning was valorised as an important avenue of learning especially in the spiritual realm, across all cultures. For instance, Prashna Upanishad consists of a series philosophical poems presented as questions (prashna) posed by various seekers and responded to by Sage Pippalada. Perhaps it is time to revitalize the ‚ÄòArt of Questioning‚Äô!
In the words of Naguib Mahfouz, the Nobel Laureate, ‚ÄúYou can tell whether a man is clever by his answers. You can tell whether a man is wise by his questions.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
19/10/24, 12:39‚ÄØpm
Sir Thomas Browne (October 19, 1605 - October 19, 1682), was a physician and philosopher, who wrote on a wide array of subjects, including science, medicine, religion, and the esoteric. One particular work that I personally find fascinating to read is ‚ÄòReligio Medici‚Äô, a book of his reflections. Translated as "The Religion of a Doctor," it offers an interesting perspective of views on various scientific and religious subjects; ‚ÄúNot picked from the leaves of any author, but bred amongst the weeds and tares of mine own brain.‚Äù William Osler, who is credited as "the father of modern medicine," considered ‚ÄòReligio Medici‚Äô so influential to his career that he reportedly memorized it by heart.
I would like to draw attention to two of his reflections that made an impact on me. Cleaving a boundary between the personal attitudes and beliefs and professional responsibilities can often be a daunting task especially in clinical work. Browne urges that there needs to be a clear separation between the spheres of religion and that of science, especially in the field of medicine. He underscores the importance that a doctor must not only tolerate but also respect individual patients' religious beliefs, even if they conflict with his own. Physicians personal, religious beliefs should not impact the way he treats his patients. This stems largely from Browne's own belief that individual churches and sects should not "usurp the gates of heaven, and turn the key against each other; and thus we go to heaven against each other‚Äôs' wills, conceits, and, with as much uncharity as arrogance, do err."
In a period where the moral aspects of medical practice are under strain, Browne draws attention to the fact that a strong moral component is at the core in the practice of medicine. To him, medicine is more than a trade, it is a moral pursuit built on a foundation of service to others. "For by compassion," Browne writes, "we make others' misery our own, and so, by relieving them, we relieve ourselves also." When a disease was beyond Browne's capacity to cure, he felt uneasy and was reluctant to charge the patient any fee, calling this "scarce honest gain."
‚ÄúWho in the world am I? Ah, that's the great puzzle‚Äù pondered Alice in Wonderland. Often, our ideas, beliefs and perspectives about life become clear when we introspect and ‚ÄòReligio Medici‚Äô is one such example. Sir Thomas Browne is like a person who is sitting on the edge of a stream, looking at his reflection in the ripples of water, plunging himself in the process into the depths of self-introspection, articulating them with clarity and insight in this small book of memoirs.
As Browne observes in this book, we must ‚ÄúBe able to be alone. Lose not the advantage of solitude. and the society of thyself.‚Äù Often the privacy of aloneness provides a space for deep, perceptive reflections.
( When I was typing these lines, my attention was drawn to this small terracotta figure on the desk and I thought that this image adeptly epitomizes Browne‚Äôs observations)
Dr Raguram
22/10/24, 8:44‚ÄØam
It has been raining continuously over the past few days in Bangalore and the sun is finally up today. Rains are an abiding source of inspiration for poets. It is used as a metaphor for a wide range of emotions: renewal, cleansing, melancholy amongst others. This particular poem ‚ÄòThe Rainy Day‚Äô by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow was written after the death of his first wife. It is a contemplative poem representing the feelings of sadness and isolation of the poet on a gloomy, rainy day. The sun peeking from behind the clouds offers a glimmer of hope. The poem ends with the evocative line "Into each life some rain must fall‚Äù, meaning that anyone of us might feel despondent (some days must be dark and dreary), at some time in our life, but the ‚Äúthe shining sun‚Äù will always be around to dispel the dark clouds within.
THE RAINY DAY
The day is cold, and dark, and dreary;
It rains, and the wind is never weary;
The vine still clings to the mouldering wall,
But at every gust the dead leaves fall,
And the day is dark and dreary.
My life is cold, and dark, and dreary;
It rains, and the wind is never weary;
My thoughts still cling to the mouldering past,
But the hopes of youth fall thick in the blast,
And the days are dark and dreary.
Be still, sad heart, and cease repining;
Behind the clouds is the sun still shining;
Thy fate is the common fate of all,
Into each life some rain must fall,
Some days must be dark and dreary.
Dr Raguram
23/10/24, 9:06‚ÄØam
Robert Bridges was another physician poet who was also the Poet Laureate of England for over a decade from 1913. He was a conscientious doctor and often found it difficult to use the stethoscope because of the noise in the overcrowded hospital. He described the vivid soundscape of a Victorian hospital ward, poetically: ‚Äò‚Ä¶the rattle of carts in the street, the hum of voices inside, the slamming of doors, the noise of people walking about, the coughings of all kinds, the crying of babies, the scraping of impatient feet, the stamping of cold ones, the chinking of the bottles and zinc tickets, and, after eleven o‚Äôclock, the hammering, sawing, and tinkering of the carpenters and blacksmiths who came not unfrequently at that hour to set things generally to rights.‚Äù Unfortunately, he contracted a serious lung infection at the age of 38 and retired from the medical profession, immersing himself fully in literary pursuits.
Bridges had a deep love for all things in nature; ‚ÄúI love all beauteous things, I seek and adore them..‚Äù I particularly like his shorter poems, especially this one:
I WOULD BE A BIRD, AND STRAIGHT ON WINGS I ARISE
I would be a bird, and straight on wings I arise
I would be a bird, and straight on wings I arise,
And carry purpose up to the ends of the air:
In calm and storm my sails I feather, and where
By freezing cliffs the unransom'd wreckage lies:
Or, strutting on hot meridian banks, surprise
The silence: over plains in the moonlight bare
I chase my shadow, and perch where no bird dare
In treetops torn by fiercest winds of the skies.
Poor simple birds, foolish birds! then I cry,
Ye pretty pictures of delight, unstir'd
By the only joy of knowing that ye fly;
Ye are not what ye are, but rather, sum'd in a word,
The alphabet of a god's idea, and I
Who master it, I am the only bird.
(Robert Bridges born on 23rd October, 1844)
Dr Raguram
28/10/24, 8:57‚ÄØam
Just came back after an enthralling sojourn at Ellora and Ajanta. After spending more than two hours savouring the majestic Kailasa temple, we made our way to other caves. Amongst them Cave 10 stands out an enchanting edifice. It is also called The Vishwakarma Cave and is locally known as the Sutar-ka-jhopra (Carpenter's hut). Constructed around 7th century AD, this is the only chaitya in these series of caves in Ellora.
Once we entered the massive cave, we were overwhelmed by its sheer architectural beauty. The apsidal hall is quite long and at the far end of the cave was a huge stupa with a simple circular base, hemispherical dome and a square structure on top. In front of it is a colossal Buddha seated with the Dharmachakra mudra. Dharmachakra mudra holds deep metaphysical significance in Buddhism. It embodies the union of method (Upaya) and wisdom (Prajna), which are essential in pursuing enlightenment. By positioning the hands in front of the heart or the left side of the chest, the mudra signifies teachings emanating directly from Buddha's compassionate heart. A large Bodhi tree is carved at the back and on both sides are the attendants. The outstanding feature of the chaitya is it‚Äôs a vaulted roof in which ribs (known as triforium) have been carved in the rock imitating the wooden beams. Even the wooden pins at the joints of beams and lintels have been carefully sculpted in stone.
There was hardly anyone around and the guide asked us to stand with our back aligned to the stone pillars. He then stood in a corned are slowly started chanting, ‚ÄúBuddham Charanam Gachchami‚Äù in a soft, low voice. The rhythmic, repetitive chanting reverberated in a magical way in the vast hall and we were immersed in that hypnotizing soundscape. We could feel the vibration of the mellifluous chants cruising through the stone pillars, energizing us. It was not merely a vibrant realm of sacred sounds but a sonic journey that unlocked the doors within.
Dr Raguram
29/10/24, 8:54‚ÄØam
The first cave one comes across in Ajanta is cave 1. It is not the first one built chronologically and perhaps the last one to be completed. It is the first cave one encounters when approaching the complex from the north side of the horseshoe-shaped cliff. The construction of the cave started around 466 CE and there were several disruptions. Emperor Harisena of the Vakataka dynasty played a crucial role in executing it.
As we entered the cool, dark interior of the cave, our attention was drawn to the colossal sculpture of the Buddha in the sanctum. He is seated on a throne in the padmasana, with his hands in the Dharmachakra Mudra. Dharmachakra in Sanskrit means the 'Wheel of Dharma'. This mudra symbolizes one of the most important moments in the life of Buddha, the occasion when he delivered his first sermon after his Enlightenment in the Deer Park at Sarnath.
On the left wall adjoining the sanctum is the painting of Padmapani. It is perhaps one of most iconic paintings of Ajanta and has adorned the walls of many houses. I stood in front of it, totally transfixed, devouring as much as I could of its stately elegance. Padmapani, the bearer of the lotus is portrayed holding the flower in his right hand. There is an unbroken flow of the body which is gracefully inclined slightly to the right side. The left-arm is tied with a ribbon. A high crown adorns his head and around his neck is a pearl necklace. There is a long string of jewellery over the left shoulder, falling across the chest. The long, sharp nose, highlighted with warm colours and inward shading, enhances the serene beauty of his face.
I closed my eyes for a moment and then looked at the deeply introspective, lotus-shaped, half-closed eyes. This is often referred to as the ‚Äòadamantine‚Äô gaze. I wonder whether through his half closed eyes, Padmapani is urging us to withdraw our awareness from the distractions of the outside world and look within, indicating that all the answers we seek are inside us. I was immersed in the overwhelming aura of boundless compassion radiating from Padmapani‚Äôs visage and it was difficult to prise myself away from the celestial painting. As I was leaving the cave, I was reminded of Rumi‚Äôs counsel, ‚ÄúListen with ears of tolerance. See through the eyes of compassion. Speak with the language of love‚Äù
Dr Raguram
30/10/24, 10:53‚ÄØpm
What a beautiful sculpture no words can describe. I have seen Ajantha caves but could not go to Ellora. Thank you Sir for this feast to the eyes. Buddha's teachings I feel has the essence of spirituality.
02/11/24, 8:50‚ÄØam
Balipadyami is observed the day after Diwali in Karnataka. On this day let us recall the story of Mahabali. According to the legend, once upon a time, there was an asura called Bali, also known as Mahabali, who conquered three worlds and was famous for his generosity. Over the course of time he annexed the celestial world too. Unhappy with it, Indra, king of the celestial regions, requested Vishnu to deal with Bali. Vishnu took the form of a dwarf, Vamana, and asked Mahabali for three paces of land. Mahabali granted it without a second thought. The dwarf then suddenly transformed into a giant, and with two paces, he claimed the sky, the earth, and all possessions that Mahabali had. Vamana then asked him where should he take the third step. The only thing Mahabali had left was his body. So he told Vamana to step on his head. Vamana did so and pushed Bali underground into Patal. Mahabali, however, was granted a wish to visit the earth once a year to meet the people who loved him very much.
One of the most beautiful depictions of this myth is in Cave II in Badami: the Vamana-Trivikrama sculpture is carved on the western wall of the mukhamandapa. In the centre of the panel Vishnu is portrayed as Trivikrama. Eight-armed, his right leg is placed firmly on the ground, while the left leg is raised up to the level of chest, with Mahabali underneath it. Of the eight hands, seven hold khadga, bana, gada, chakra, sankha, khetaka and chapa. The remaining left hand is stretched out parallel to the raised leg. A soldier with a sword is shown falling upside down, failing in his attempt to attack Vishnu. A dwarfish person who is portrayed in a royal outfit holds the right leg of Trivikrama firmly, to obstruct his measuring the paces; he is identified as Namuchi, the son of Bali. On the lower left part of this panel, Vamana‚Äôs figure has been unfortunately defaced and he can be identified only by his umbrella. Sukracharya is shown by his side pouring water into the hand of Vamana while Bali stands behind with his wife Vindhyavali. Strangely Shukracharya has a Buddha like demeanour.
What does the story of Balipadyami inform us? Mahabali was caught in the trappings of his ego, craving for more power and perceiving himself as invulnerable. When Trivikrama asked him ‚Äúwhere can I place the third step?‚Äù he broke free from the fetters of ego and surrendered himself to the divine, cosmic power. When we light the lamp on Balipadyami, let us strive to renew our deeper connection with the divine through transcending the trappings of our ego. It is a path to tread in a period of time when narcissistic patterns are so salient and on the rise.
Dr Raguram
02/11/24, 10:13‚ÄØpm
Today we celebrated Balipadyami. They have sculpted all details so well and clearly though some portions are disfigured. I wonder why Shukracharya is pouring water. As far as I know Bali will pour the arghya (as he was well known for his charity) when Vamana the Brahmana asks for it. His Guru Shukracharya wants to prevent in doing so as he knows who the dwarf is. He will enter the container and block the hole when Vamana takes a blade of grass and pokes due to which he loses an eye. Bali is supposed to have been pushed down as he went against his Guru 's instructions! Thank you Sir for the wonderful sculpture, a treasure we still possess.
04/11/24, 8:31‚ÄØam
One has to take the electric buggy or walks some distance to reach Cave 29. The location of the cave is the most picturesque of all the caves with a large waterfall plunging into the gorge next to it. This cave is planned in the shape of a cross and has massive friezes of Shiva & Parvati adorning the walls. Prominent among them is this large sculptural depiction of the marriage of Shiva and Parvati, officiated by Lord Brahma. Many poets have described this scene in the verse form. I am particularly drawn to this poem titled ‚ÄòMahadev-ji ka Byah‚Äô (Wedding ceremony of Lord Mahadev ) written by Nazeer Akbarabadi. A Muslim by birth, Nazeer Akbarabadi, predates Ghalib. He wrote on a wide variety of subjects and on religious subjects ranging from Islam, Hinduism to Budhism. Nazeer strongly opposed religious orthodoxy and was a strong advocate of the syncretic culture of the land. Here is the wonderful poem about the marriage of Shiva and Parvati.
‚Äú‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§Å‡§µ ‡§ó‡§£‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§è ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∏ ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§è
‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ú ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§π‡•ã‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ç‡§∞‡§§ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§è
‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§ö‡§® ‡§Ü‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§π
‡§∏‡•Å‡§® ‡§≤‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã, ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® ‡§ß‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π
‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§æ, ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®
‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§æ, ‡§â‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£
‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§π‡§Å‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡§º‡•Å‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§ø‡§® ‡§∞‡•à‡§®
‡§î‡§∞ ‡§™‡§¢‡§º‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ï‡§∞, ‡§â‡§® ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§ö‡•à‡§®
‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏ ‡§®‡•á ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§ï‡•Ä, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§è
‡§â‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§π‡§∞ ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ-‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§è
‡§ñ‡§º‡•Å‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§¶‡§ø‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§ ‡§µ‡•ã, ‡§ï‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§® ‡§π‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤-‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∞
‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§â‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ '‡§®‡§ú‡§º‡•Ä‡§∞'‚Äù
‚ÄúBefore you begin, honour Ganesh and bow with grace
so your tasks are completed and good fortune you embrace
Utter the words of joy, love, affection and attachment
My friends, attentively listen to the story of the wedding of Mahadev
Those who listened from hermits narrated it
And those who listened as the story also certify
Those who listen remain cheerful day and nigh
Those who read and memorize are also happy
Whoever narrates the glory of this wedding
Lord Shiva remains happy with him
This exercise brings the happiness that one doesn‚Äôt feel sad
Glory to the narrator whose name is ‚ÄòNazeer‚Äô‚Äù
Our worldview often becomes restricted by our personal beliefs, religious values and political orientations. The strength of poems like this lies in its ability to transport us beyond these confines especially in times when inclusive principles and pluralistic perspectives are under strain.
In Kavi Pradeep‚Äôs words from the movie Nastik, ‚ÄúDekh tere sansar ki halat kya ho gayi bhagwaan kitna badal gaya insaan...‚Äù (Look at what has happened to your world, O god. Man has changed so much).
Dr Raguram
06/11/24, 8:14‚ÄØam
Decades ago, in the busy outpatient wing of NIMHANS, I noticed an elderly man who was drumming his hands vigorously on his head. I called him inside and asked him as to why he was doing so. He turned to me and said, ‚ÄúI was listening to music.‚Äù It was the first case of musical hallucinations I had ever seen and I reported it as a case study in a journal. There have been many reports of such phenomenon with varied hypotheses as to its causation. It left me wondering as to what would happen if a musician were to have musical hallucinations? Will it be an inspiration, finding its way to his/her musical creations, or will it be a curse?
These questions resonated within me for long, till I chanced upon a wonderful 1958 recording of Robert Schumann‚Äôs Symphony No 2, by the Cleveland Orchestra conducted by George Szell. It‚Äôs deeply affective sombre opening notes, slowly flow into brighter phase with repartees between strings and winds, ending with a hymn like finale. I must have listened to it many times and was curious to find out more about its composer. I was surprised to read about the inspiration for this symphony. It was a piece of auditory musical hallucination that Schumann experienced. In his words, ‚ÄúFor several days, drums and trumpets in the key of C have been sounding in my mind. I have no idea what will come of it‚Äù: they found their place in Symphony No 2.
Schumann battled various physical and psychiatric illnesses all through his life, prominent among them being syphilis. He wrote that his illness, ‚Äúhearing problems, depression, dizziness, rheumatism is inscribed in the fabric of the piece. I would say that my resistant spirit had a visible influence on it and it is through that that I sought to fight my condition. The first movement is full of this combativeness, is very moody and rebellious in character."
During his final days when he was incarcerated in a mental asylum, he was hearing a musical pitch or an entire orchestra. As his wife recorded in a note, Schumann experienced ‚Äúvery strong and painful auditory disturbances‚Äù during this time period. The music sounded in his head, day and night, and sometimes went on for days.
Though the melodic hallucinations formed a kernel of this inspiring composition, Symphony No 2, Schumann was drowned in a sea of musical hallucinations at the end of his life, probably related to the final stages of the syphilitic infection. That raises a question: Are musical hallucinations a ‚Äòroyal road‚Äô to a person‚Äôs unconscious creative mind or are they merely discordant notes from a disharmonious brain in disarray?
Dr Raguram
08/11/24, 9:03‚ÄØam
Sometimes even a desolate landscape can kindle the creative spirit in a poet. An example is this poem, ‚ÄúNo Birds in Sight, The Forest Withers Slowly‚Äù by Ivan Bunin. Ivan was the first Russian author to be awarded the Nobel Prize in 1930. He wrote this poem when he was just 19 years old.
NO BIRDS IN SIGHT, THE FOREST WITHERS SLOWLY
No birds in sight. The forest withers slowly,
Resigned to utter emptiness and chill.
No mushrooms, but there comes from out a gully
Of mushroom damp the strong and tangy smell.
The scrub is lighter and less tall, the greying
Grass near the bushes droops, seems trampled down;
Beneath the autumn rain the leaves, decaying,
In mouldy heaps lie of a darkish brown.
But in the fields the wind is fresh and biting.
I lead my stallion out and ride from home,
And, in the freedom of the steppe delighting,
Far from the villages till nightfall roam.
Lulled by my mount's slow, easy pace, I listen
With joy-tinged, quiet sadness to the hum
Of wind as it invades with singsong whistle
And drawn-out moan the barrels of my gun.
As the poet makes his way through the forest, he is surrounded by barren trees that have shed their foliage. There an overwhelming silence as the woods are shorn of bird calls. The mouldering leaves form a crumbling pile on the moist undergrowth of the woods. There is a touch of melancholic beauty around him. Absence of any human or animal activity around him enhances his perceived isolation. But as he rides with his mount across the landscape the wind serenading through the trees buoys up his spirit.
The inner and outer landscape merge and blend seamlessly in this enchanting little poem. As Thoreau reflected, ‚ÄúAm I not partly leaves and vegetable mounds myself?‚Äù
Ivan Bunin (October 22, 1870 - November 8, 1953)
Dr Raguram
11/11/24, 9:17‚ÄØam
Banteay Srei is a small temple near Angkor Thom in Cambodia and is considered to be the ‚Äújewel of Khmer art.‚Äù Exquisitely carved in the mid-10th century, it is the first temple in Angkor to depict mythological scenes, each one of them superbly carved.
This particular panel depicts the story of Lord Krishna slaying Kamsa. Kamsa was the tyrannical ruler who took over the kingdom of Mathura after overthrowing his father, Ugrasena. Narada Muni had prophesized that Kamsa‚Äôs sister Devaki's eighth child would kill him. Kamsa imprisoned Devaki and Vasudev, and killed seven of the children that Devaki gave birth. When the eighth child, Lord Krishna was born, Vasudev took the child out of the prison safely to Gokul, his friend Nanda‚Äôs home. Nanda‚Äôs wife Yashoda had also given birth to a girl and Vasudev took the girl child back to the prison. When Kamsa came to know about the birth, he rushed to the prison and tried to kill the baby. But the baby slipped from his hand and was transformed into the goddess Yogamaya, who told Kamsa: ‚ÄúO foolish! What will you get by killing me? Your nemesis is already born somewhere else.‚Äù After hearing that Lord Krishna was alive, Kamsa sent many Rakshas to kill him but they all met their demise. Frustrated with this, he came up with a masterplan to kill his nephew in his kingdom. He announced a wrestling match with demon brothers Mushtika and Chanura. Hearing of this, Lord Krishna went over to Mathura with Balarama. When they reached the arena, Kamsa ridiculed them and sent the demon brothers to the arena. After a fierce fight, Lord Krishna and Balrama slew the wrestler demons. Seeing this and filled with rage, Kamsa stormed to the arena himself. Lord Krishna grabbed him, threw him down on the ground and beheaded Kamsa.
The final battle between Lord Krishna and Kamsa is depicted with much detail in this particular panel in Banteay Srei. The event takes place in Kamsa‚Äôs beautifully carved palace. Large number of women witness the event and one can notice the agitation on their faces. At the bottom of the panel, Lord Krishna and Balarama arrive at the palace in their horse drawn carriage. The entire episode is intricately sculpted with much attention to detail.
Kamsa Vadh is celebrated today in Mathura, primarily by the Chaturvedi community. On the next day of Kamsa Vadh, ‚ÄòTeen Van Parikrama‚Äô is performed in Braj region. It covers three towns namely Mathura, Vrindavan and Garun Govind. It is believed that Lord Krishna performed this Parikrama to absolve the sins of killing Kamsa.
Dr Raguram
12/11/24, 11:06‚ÄØpm
No wonder it is called as "jewel of Khmer art". Such a beautiful carving and thank you Sir for the detailed narration of Kamsa vadh.
19/11/24, 9:40‚ÄØam
One of the major factor impacting access to and utilisation of mental health services is stigma. Overcome with shame and isolation, people with mental illness feel discriminated from the rest. It has a cascading effect on their social relationships, wellbeing and quality of life.
Erving Goffman was perhaps the first sociologist to dwell into it in his book, ‚ÄòStigma, Notes on the Management of Spoiled Identity.‚Äô According to him, stigma essentially conveys a devalued stereotype, an ‚Äúattribute that is deeply discrediting.‚Äù The discredited attributes can include race, religion, ethnicity, physical deformity and mental illnesses. Stigmatized people feel stigmatized in relation to a group of people who are deemed to be normal, and normal people consider themselves normal in relation to people who viewed as less than normal and stigmatized. According to him stigma exists in a relationship between an attribute and frames of understanding and society which views that attribute as representative of a deviance from social norms. In his words, ‚ÄúBy definition, of course, we believe the person with a stigma is not quite human. On this assumption we exercise varieties of discrimination, through which we effectively, if unthinkingly, reduce his life chances. We construct a stigma-theory, an ideology to explain his inferiority.‚Äù
I was wondering whether there is a biographical context to Goffman‚Äôs explorations into aspects of stigma. Was it the anti-Semitic discrimination which he experienced early in his life as an immigrant Jew or his lived experience of tending to his life who had a lifelong mental illness and died by suicide.
Perhaps much of our efforts to understand human behaviour and the social world around us often emerges from our own personal experiences.
Erving Goffman (born June 11, 1922 - died Nov. 19, 1982)
Dr Raguram
20/11/24, 9:01‚ÄØam
Ajanta has a series of Buddhist caves. As I step into one of its dark interiors, silence enveloped me like a comforting blanket. In the vast cavernous space, I felt alive, with the soft breeze from the valley below caressing me. At the far end of the cave was a striking sculpture of Buddha, softly lit; its beauty accentuated by a colourful painting in the ceiling. When I continued to gaze on the Buddha, the sounds from the transitory world outside slowly faded away and I was transported into an inexplicably serene realm. It was a strange feeling and quite indescribable too.
As I made my way outside of the dark cave, my heart was filled with an ineffable light.
Dr Raguram
26/11/24, 9:14‚ÄØam
Trees are being felled at alarming rate in Bengaluru. The iconic tree lined avenues have faded away, and linger only in memory. Sometimes what we glimpse through eyes can find their way through a poet‚Äôs heart and find expression in haunting words, like in this poem ‚ÄòThe Poplar Field‚Äô by William Cowper.
‚ÄúThe Poplars are fell‚Äôd, farewell to the shade
And the whispering sound of the cool colonnade
The winds play no longer and sing in the leaves,
Nor Ouse on his bosom their image receives.
Twelve years have elapsed since I last took a view
Of my favourite field and the bank where they grew,
And now in the grass behold they are laid,
And the tree is my seat that once lent me a shade.
The black-bird has fled to another retreat
Where the hazels afford him a screen from the heat,
And the scene where his melody charm‚Äôd me before,
Resounds with his sweet-flowing ditty no more.
My fugitive years are all hasting away,
And I must e‚Äôer long lie as lowly as they,
With a turf on my breast and a stone at my head
E‚Äôer another such grove shall arise in its stead.
‚ÄôTis a sight to engage me if anything can
To muse on the perishing pleasures of Man;
Though his life be a dream, his enjoyments, I see,
Have a Being less durable even than he‚Äù
The poet describes the destruction of a field of poplar trees which no longer offer him shade. The birds too have flown away. Reflecting on the passage of time, the poet wonders with a touch of melancholy, whether he too will return to earth soon. The degradation of the outer landscape and its liminality is symbolic of the tribulations that Cowper went through all his life. His life was one long tryst with pain as he suffered from recurrent attacks of severe depression, ‚Äúlying down in horror, and rising up in despair‚Äù resulting in several suicidal attempts. He found succour in the company of John Milton who wrote the ‚ÄòAmazing Grace‚Äô.
Cowper died from dropsy on April 25th 1800. He summed up his life in these words;
‚ÄúI, who scribble rhyme
To catch the triflers of the time,
And tell them truths divine and clear
Which, couched in prose, they would not hear.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
29/11/24, 9:37‚ÄØam
Elephants are magical. Their footprints are deeply imprinted in the cultural, collective consciousness and in individual memories of each one of us.
Mythical stories narrated in the PurƒÅ·πáas mention that the weight of the world rested on divine elephants. Hence not surprisingly, the giant pachyderms figure prominently in temple architecture all around the country. In Hindu temples, they are found primarily in the Adhisthana, the base of the structure on which the superstructure of the temple rests and on Upapitha (sub-base or plinth) of the shrine.
There are two ways in which elephants figure in these structures. Gajapitha, consists of a row of standing elephants holding the pitha. The most wonderful example is in the Kailasa temple at Ellora. Rising from the middle of the rock-cut courtyard, the monolithic temple conveys the impression of being borne aloft on the backs of dozens of life-sized elephants. Beautifully sculpted from the black basalt, they seem to hold the temple up with consummate ease. Though many of them have borne the vagaries of time, there is an unmistakable grace and power in them. (Photograph on top is from Kailasa temple).
A different way in which elephants figure in temple structure is that of Gajathara. It consists of a horizontal frieze of elephants, generally in the lowermost portion of the Adhisthana. The adhisthana usually comprises a remarkable array of horizontal bands depicting at the base, a row of elephants, symbolizing stability. Over this, scrollwork containing delicately carved figures of birds, animals and mythical animals and over these another row of miniature pillars, with a row of miniature temple vimanas. At the highest level are figures of dancers and musicians. The whole adhisthana enclosing the temple is thus transformed into a gallery of intricate sculptural art with miniature carving at its best. The elephants in the bottom layer are usually rendered in profile, marching in procession or in war and hunting scenes. An outstanding example is in the Hoysala temples, especially in Belur and Halebid. (Glimpses of this in the bottom photo from Halebid)
The symbolism of the elephant in Hindu mythology and temple architecture encompasses wisdom, dignity and strength. Its portrayal in these sculptural forms reflects these qualities while also serving as a reminder for us to strive for these virtues in our own lives.
Dr Raguram
30/11/24, 9:01‚ÄØam
Often writers choose pseudonyms in their writings, to conceal their true identities and they use them for a variety of reasons. For instance, Isaac Asimov used the fictitious name of Paul French to publish a series of science fiction books early in his career. Fernando Pessoa, the famous Portuguese writer ventured in the opposite direction, using heteronyms. In his own words, ‚ÄúA pseudonymous work is, except for the name with which it is signed, the work of an author writing as himself; a heteronymic work is by an author writing outside his own personality: it is the work of a complete individuality made up by him, just as the utterances of some character in a drama would be‚Ä¶ I break my soul into pieces, and into different persons.‚Äù More than 72 heteronyms have been identified in Fernando Pessoa‚Äôs writing! Sometimes he even thought that, at times, he could see and hear the heteronyms he had created.
Basically a heteronym is an imaginary character created by a writer to write in a different style. The writer becomes a virtual subject, who starts inhabiting the character's life first-personally. As a consequence, the characters in heteronym have their own individual identity, which is expressed in writing. Viewed this way I was wondering whether heteronym is a precursor to Avatar!
Pessoa‚Äôs famous work is the ‚ÄòBook of Disquiet‚Äô which has an unusual structure. It is totally nonlinear and a fusion of poetry and prose in which the author reflects on various aspects of life. In an interesting comment, the author states, ‚ÄúMy soul is a hidden orchestra; I know not what instruments, what fiddlestrings and harps, drums and tamboura I sound and clash inside myself. All I hear is the symphony.‚Äù
(Fernando Pessoa: June 13 1888 ‚Äì November 30 1935)
Dr Raguram
02/12/24, 9:34‚ÄØam
‚ÄòCome to the Edge‚Äô is a poem often attributed to Guillaume Apollinaire but actually written by poet, activist, Christopher Logue (23rd November 1926 ‚Äì 2nd December 2011). Whenever I read this poem, a series of images and meanings keep swirling through my mind. Quite often we feel contented, settling into our own comfort zones. Life is often a delicate dance between the possible and the impossible. Logue urges us to venture further and discover uncharted territories that we feel hesitant to explore.
Years ago I went along with my friend to explore the caves in the Antaragange hill near Kolar. It was the first time I attempted to climb a hill. The guide reassured me that it shouldn‚Äôt be too difficult. Encouraged by his reassurance I started the climb. The first few ascents were a bit difficult but when we entered the caves on the top, the cool morning breeze was quite refreshing. The difficulty started when I started to climb down. I felt that the rocks might give way and was overcome with intense fear that I would tumble down the hill. It was at that time, the guide came over and whispered in my ears, ‚ÄúDoctor, the mountain is in the mind.‚Äù I felt energized by that comment and made my way down with much greater ease. The dreadful consequences I had anticipated vanished into thin air. Crossing the threshold of fear opened my mind to lurking possibilities within. To this day, these words resonate deeply within and swell to contain the anxiety whenever I face uncertainties in life.
Often the most profound experiences lie beyond the familiar and have a way of keeping us afloat.
COME TO THE EDGE
Come to the edge.
We might fall.
Come to the edge.
It's too high!
COME TO THE EDGE!
And they came,
and he pushed,
And they flew.
Dr Raguram
02/12/24, 7:35‚ÄØpm
A wonderful sculpture of the elephants! A legacy to be proud of...
04/12/24, 9:34‚ÄØam
Kandariya Mahadeva Temple is the largest and most ornate temple at Khajuraho. Every inch of its exterior walls is adorned with a mesmerizing profusion of sculptures. Deities from the Hindu pantheon like Brahma, Vishnu, and Ganesha grace the walls, their expressions radiating serenity and power. Geometric patterns and floral motifs add a touch of elegance, while friezes depicting scenes from mythology offer a glimpse into ancient Hindu epics. Interspersed with these are the celestial nymphs (apsaras) in their flowing attire adorned with intricate jewellery. They are shown in various poses, such as playing instruments, dancing, beautifying themselves, or removing a thorn from the foot.
I was totally bewitched on seeing the depiction of a voluptuous apsara with a scorpion sculpted on her left thigh. Intricately carved, it seems to be traveling up. It doesn‚Äôt appear to be a decorative motif and seemed to be associated uniquely with the celestial beauty. Strangely, there is no fear or apprehension on the apsara‚Äôs face. What could be the association of a sensuous beauty with a scorpion? In Indian mythology, Vrischika has multiple and diverse symbolic meanings, ranging from fear to allure. In Vedic astrology Vruschika Rashi embodies intensity, passion, and transformation. Could the scorpion be a metaphor for female arousal? Al-Biruni, in his book written in 1029 A.D. just around the time that the Kandariya Mahadeva temple was constructed and shortly after his own trip to India, states that in India, scorpions were associated with the genitals, fertility, progeny.
I searched far and wide to understand and unravel the iconographic background of the association of scorpion with sensuality and it still remains an unfathomable mystery to me!
Dr Raguram
05/12/24, 9:41‚ÄØam
Yesterday was the World Wildlife Conservation Day. It is celebrated to raise awareness about the importance of protecting the earth's endangered species and ecosystems. It‚Äôs main aim is to encourage people to conserve wildlife and their natural habitats.
Vultures figure prominently among the endangered species in India. Though they play a crucial role in the ecosystem, they are one step away from total extinction. In an earlier post, I had drawn attention to the silent, committed work by Sri Bharathidasan and his colleagues at Arulagam, an environmental organization based in Coimbatore. Bharathi and his colleagues have been working actively over the past decade to protect and increase the critically endangered vulture population in Tamil Nadu. They educate the local communities through awareness campaigns about the importance of vultures in the ecosystem, advocating for the elimination of harmful veterinary drugs that are poisoning vulture food sources.
When we went along with them in the Satyamangalam Tiger Reserve recently, we sighted around 120 white-rumped, long-billed, and red-headed vultures. More than sighting a large flock, it was the age group of vultures that was remarkable; there were juveniles, sub adults and adults, many of them perched on trees. Bharathi was moved by the sight as it was the first time that such large number of vultures were sighted in Tamil Nadu.
India, owes much of its natural splendour to the selfless efforts of group of remarkable individuals like Bharathi and his dedicated team. These unsung heroes have dedicated their lives to the cause of protecting and preserving the nation's precious wildlife like vultures. Their efforts are a living testimony that it is feasible to transform potential conflicts into collaborative solutions ensuring the conservation of precious species in the ecosystem.
As Margaret Mead commented, ‚ÄúNever doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
06/12/24, 7:46‚ÄØam
Rumi is not merely a poet; he is also a spiritual guide. I dip into his works often and the ‚Äòdoors of perception‚Äô start opening. If I have to choose just one poem to illustrate this, it is this one.
‚ÄúOut beyond ideas of wrongdoing and rightdoing,
there is a field. I‚Äôll meet you there.
When the soul lies down in that grass,
the world is too full to talk about.
Ideas, language, even the phrase ‚Äúeach other‚Äù
doesn‚Äôt make any sense.
The breeze at dawn has secrets to tell you.
Don‚Äôt go back to sleep.
You must ask for what you really want.
Don‚Äôt go back to sleep.
People are going back and forth across the doorsill
where the two worlds touch.
The door is round and open.
Don‚Äôt go back to sleep.‚Äù
Often we get enmeshed in binaries in our lives: good/bad, right/wrong, proper/improper, valid/invalid etc. Such a position often results in a judgmental stance and we start viewing the world around us through these prisms. Basically a sense of duality shapes our worldviews. Rumi wonders whether there is a realm of experience beyond this. Is it possible for us to be in a more unified space where we can aspire to free ourselves and savour a more unified reality? In that mind space void of labels and judgements, duality dissolves and we can realize our ‚Äòoneness‚Äô.
Thanks to Rumi, whenever I find myself quick to judge, I pause and reflect.

No one in the neighborhood are bothered but I had to tell Uma who said she will contact Social Work department. How many people we are going to bring under the list of 'not in the name of human'?
10/12/24, 9:47‚ÄØam
I just finished reading a deeply moving book, ‚ÄúWhy do you fear my way so much?‚Äù by GN Saibaba. He was 90% paralysed and had spent over 10 years in jail, till the Division Bench of the Bombay High Court acquitted him of all charges. Saibaba died on October 12, 2024.
This particular passage from the book is heart rendering;
‚ÄúI have lived all my conscious life on the campuses of learning and teaching in search of knowledge, love and freedom. In the course of this search, I learnt that freedom for a few was no freedom. I began to study histories, philosophies and literatures with more eagerness and critical engagement. That led me to look around myself closely. I travelled across and met people living in sub-human conditions. I realised that they never tasted freedom very much like me. I understood that castes and freedom can never co-exist. I began to speak to myself. Then I slowly started to speak to my fellow beings on my journey. I grasped of a great void of silence around me. I saw a society of silence. I dashed myself against the boulders of silence. I brutally wounded myself‚Äù‚Ä¶.
‚ÄúI reel under excruciating relentless pain. One after the other, my organs started bursting. The closure of my voice within me explodes into shooting pain. My vocal chords acquired lesions making my voice a thin and inaudible squeak. My heart broke with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. My brain has started having blackouts with a condition called syncope. My kidneys are silted with pebbles; my gallbladder gathered stones and pancreas grew a tail of pain called pancreatitis. Nerve lines in my left shoulder broke under the conditions of my arrest, known as brachial plexopathy. More and more organs of silence replaced the original. I have been living with explosive and shooting pain day in and day out. I am living on the margins of life.‚Äù
And he quotes a verse from Faiz Ahmad Faiz
‚ÄúMy pain, a voiceless song,
my being a nameless mote.
If only my pain could speak,
I‚Äôd know who I am.
And if myself could find its essence,
I‚Äôd unravel the mystery of this world.
If I could seize this hidden mystery,
my silence would find expression.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
13/12/24, 9:40‚ÄØam
Separation is a poignant theme across all creative oeuvres. It encompasses a range of emotions involving intense longing as well extreme sadness. The anguish and emotional turmoil of separation is particularly well expressed in the realm of poetry. Often described as ‚Äòviraha‚Äô, where lovers experience intense pain due to physical separation, evocative descriptions are aplenty in works like Kalidasa's ‚ÄòMeghaduta‚Äô, Jayadeva's ‚ÄòGitagovinda‚Äô and in Tamil Sangam poetry. In the latter, where different landscapes are associated with specific emotions, separation is described on the background of ‚Äòneithal‚Äô, where the separation of lovers is associated with the vastness and loneliness of the sea and in exquisite detail in the ‚Äòpaalai‚Äô landscape which symbolizes complete separation and the harshness in a desolate, barren environment.
The torment of separation plays out powerfully in the palette of Expressionist painters like Edvard Munch (12 December 1863 - 23 January 1944), who is often remembered for his iconic painting ‚ÄòThe Scream‚Äô. In a painting titled ‚ÄòSeparation‚Äô he portrayed a man and a woman in the process of parting. Our eyes are drawn to the striking colour contrast between the two. The man, ostensibly overwhelmed with emotions of sadness and despair is painted in black. On the other hand, the woman is painted with a brighter yellow colour, symbolic of happiness and optimism. While the man is static, the woman seems as though she is ready to move on from him and cross the black line of separation. While the man is still caught in the web of the past, suffering from the memories of what they once had together, the woman looks far across the line, awaiting the future. What is also interesting is that the man‚Äôs right hand is painted with the colours of the woman, indicating how the man fails to let go of the woman from his heart which seems to be bleeding. Colours are not merely aesthetic choices in art; they hold the power to evoke powerful feelings. Edvard Munch utilizes intense hues as a powerful tool in this painting to convey emotional tribulations lurking within the individuals in throes of separation, so effectively.
Only Pablo Neruda can voice these in verse,
‚Äú..Tonight I can write the saddest lines.
To think that I do not have her. To feel that I have lost her.
To hear the immense night, still more immense without her.
And the verse falls to the soul like dew to the pasture.
What does it matter that my love could not keep her.
The night is shattered and she is not with me.
This is all‚Ä¶‚Äù
Dr Raguram
16/12/24, 9:48‚ÄØam
Confronting mortality is not an easy task. Very few musicians have ventured into this landscape and prominent among them is Mahler. He explored the vicissitudes of life and death in his masterly Second Symphony. It is a work that explores mortality and inevitably of death and ends with an affirmation of a transcendent, everlasting life. The first eight lines from the final movement were taken from the poem, ‚ÄòDie Auferstehung‚Äô, by Friedrich Gottlieb Klopstock and Mahler wrote the rest himself;
‚ÄúRise again, yes, rise again,
Will you, my dust, after a brief rest!
Immortal life! Immortal life
Will he who called you, give you.
You are sown to bloom again!
The lord of the harvest goes
And gathers sheaves,
Us, who have died.
O believe, my heart, O believe:
Nothing is lost to you!
Yours, yes yours, is what you desired
Yours, what you have loved
What you have fought for!
O believe,
You were not born for nothing!
Have not lived for nothing,
Nor suffered!
What was created
Must perish;
What perished, rise again!
Cease from trembling!
Prepare yourself to live!
O Pain, you piercer of all things,
From you, I have been wrested!
O Death, you conqueror of all things,
Now, are you conquered!
With wings which I have won for myself,
In love‚Äôs fierce striving,
I shall soar upwards
To the light which no eye has penetrated!
I shall die in order to live.
Rise again, yes, rise again,
Will you, my heart, in an instant!
That for which you suffered,
To God shall it carry you!‚Äù
(Dedicated to Ustad Zakir Hussain, whose dancing fingers on the tabla will continue to entrance us)
Do close your eyes and listen to this exceptional recording of Mahler‚Äôs 2nd symphony by Otto Klemperer.
Dr Raguram
17/12/24, 8:27‚ÄØam
I first came across the name of Kirkbride in a book tantalizingly titled, ‚ÄúMadhouses, Mad doctors and Madmen.‚Äù Kirkbride (July 31, 1809 - December 16,1883), was one of the thirteen founders of the Association of Medical Superintendents of American Asylums for the Insane (now the American Psychiatric Association), and was its president from 1862 to 1870. He was a passionate advocate of ‚Äòmoral treatment‚Äô of the insane and argued that the place where the mentally ill are placed, must further this cause. Towards this end he spent considerable amount of time to develop an architectural plan for these buildings which is often referred to as a the ‚ÄòKirkbride Plan.‚Äô
When I had a look at the ‚ÄòKirkbride Plan‚Äô I was struck by its similarity to wings of a bird! From the central administrative block two wings extend out in a staggered fashion. The idea behind was that the living quarters of the patients should have maximum light and ventilation, with high ceilings. Each ward would be a self-contained unit with all facilities under one roof. Kirkbride paid meticulous attention to each aspect of the design, including the design and placement of the windows, plan of the bathrooms and even recommending particular building materials and colours of paint. He specially emphasized that the living quarters should open into large outdoor landscape and foliage, so that all the patients could be part of it. Patients were segregated by their condition; those who were quite disturbed were kept in the pavilions furthest from the centre.
‚ÄòKirkbride Plan‚Äô was adopted in several asylums in US. Except for a few which have been declared as heritage structures, the rest have been pulled down and demolished in the era of deinstitutionalization.
Even though no mental hospitals are being built now, ‚ÄòKirkbride Plan‚Äô is a remarkable document from a certain time in history of care of the mentally ill, which emphasizes the important role of architecture in facilitating a healing environment.

Which has superficially changed but has not accepted or ready to tolerate and extend help. Father talks about social stigma which is still rampant.
19/12/24, 8:19‚ÄØam
Emotions come through stronger in black and white photography and touches the heart of the viewer. The greatest example of it is in the works of TS Satyan. Almost all his works are in exquisite shades of black and white wherein the light gently caresses the subjects. He freezes the moment with loving subtlety and images linger on in our memory.
I was privileged and deeply touched when he gifted some of his photographs, which I treasure and value profoundly. Fondly recollecting my memorable association with this legendary lens man on his 101st birthday.

‚ÄúThe bee emerging
from deep within the peony
departs reluctantly‚Äù

06/01/24, 9:46‚ÄØam
Among the many calls that I received this New Year, I was deeply touched by a particular one. It was from a lady whom I had known for the past few years. She rang up and said, ‚ÄúDoctor let this New Year be good for you and all those who help others‚Äù. What is distinctive about the caller is that she is a crematorium worker who handles all the paper work there.
I met her a few years ago, helping a friend who had lost a family member, to fill the forms. When I was about to leave, she asked me whether I was a doctor. Hearing the affirmative answer, she shared her psychological travails which were being attended to by a dear former student. I reassured her stating that she was in good hands while emphasizing the need to be regular with treatment. She profusely thanked me and thereafter kept in touch with me periodically.
Working in a crematorium can be a daunting task, more so being a woman. At a time when the term ‚Äòstress‚Äô is flaunted widely, I was keen to know more about her and how she coped with her situation. Her answer was simple, ‚ÄúI earn a livelihood doctor, for the sake of my children, for their better future‚Äù. I gathered that her husband was a drunkard without any regular work and she had to tend for two young children, with very little support from the extended family. She works six days a week with few breaks or any holiday. At the end of a busy working day, she gets back home, has a bath and starts cooking for the night. Her husband scolds and often beats her, if by chance the food is delayed. He is also sexually demanding and if she refuses, starts suspecting her. In spite of these ordeals when I chance to see her at work, I invariably find her attending to her task with a smile on her face.
By accepting the job, she has joined a cadre of Indian women who are entering arenas from which they have traditionally been excluded. That she has chosen to work in a space with significant stigma associated with it, where even men feel uneasy to be in, is a testament to her resilience.
A plant that can teach us resilience is the bamboo. It can withstand twice as much force bearing down on it while being stretched, pulled or bent. According to a Japanese proverb: ‚ÄúIn time, even the strongest wind tires itself out, but the bamboo remains standing tall and still.‚Äù
There is an interesting Zen parable, ‚ÄòBe like a bamboo‚Äô:
A Zen Master was walking through the forest down a narrow trail with one of his students along a steep incline. The student lost his footing and slipped; just as he began tumbling down the hill, the student reached out and grabbed a small bamboo tree. The bamboo bent nearly all the way over as the student continued to hold on tightly. He pulled himself up and brushed off the dirt with the Zen Masters help.
‚ÄúDid you notice that when you fell, you grabbed a hold of the bamboo and it bent nearly all the way over and still supported you.‚Äù the Zen Master asked.
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the student replied. The Zen Master gripped the bamboo and pulled the bamboo over.
‚ÄúBe like the bamboo,‚Äù the Zen Master said as he let go of the bamboo and it sprang back to its up-right position. ‚ÄúIt is pushed around by the wind and yet it always bounces back and grows upward, toward the sun, enlightenment. Have you ever felt as though you were going to snap? Have you ever felt as though you were at your breaking point, emotionally?‚Äù
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the student replied.
‚ÄúThen bend, do not break, such is the way with bamboo. It endures the stress and finds a way to bounce back!‚Äù the Zen Master stated. ‚ÄúThis is called resilience.‚Äù
Throughout our journey in life, we meet people along the way and we connect with the heart of a few from whom we draw inspiration. They become a poem or a story in my life to live by.
Dr Raguram
10/01/24, 9:05‚ÄØam
I had posted yesterday about Simone de Beauvoir‚Äôs ‚ÄòSecond Sex‚Äô, wherein she urges women to
have the freedom to escape from prescribed social roles and seek their own identity. This perspective has been articulated well in many works of fiction. Daisy Rockwell's translation of Geetanjali Shree's Hindi novel ‚ÄòRet Samadhi‚Äô ‚Äò‚Äô‡§∞‡•á‡§§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‚Äô which I read some time ago, is one such engaging narrative. It traces the life trajectory of a woman who is recently bereaved and her journey to discover aspects of self that were deeply buried within her.
The strength of any work of fiction is that it can be read at different layers, each with its own attendant meaning. Grief after a loss of a partner has been essayed in many novels. Usually it follows a predictable path, focusing on the loss and its emotional impact within the individual. What is different in this work is the broader narration of separation and loss in the historical context of partition and the quest of the protagonist to seek her personal identity embedded in it.
The novel is tale of transformative powers of crossing the ‚Äòborders‚Äô, of geography, gender and prescriptive roles, reaffirming that the inner landscape has no borders. ‚ÄúAnything worth doing transcends borders‚Äù.
The protagonist‚Äôs travel is also a journey into her own self, opening doors of discovery. In her words, ‚ÄúAlways, at least once, every woman, whether this one or that one, whether small or big, finds herself at the door, one foot poised in the air, like a dancer striking a mudra, a pose, in order to re-enter the home or that door which she has renounced and already left far behind, asking herself in that moment, Is this my world in which I‚Äôm setting foot, or is it that which is receding behind me, where I had gone, or whence I‚Äôve come?‚Äù
As for the story, ‚ÄúOnce you‚Äôve got women and a border, a story can write itself. Even women on their own are enough. Women are stories in themselves, full of stirrings and whisperings that float on the wind, that bend with each blade of grass.‚Äù
There is extensive use of metaphors like doors and windows. ‚Äúthere was a painter, Bhupen Khakkar. He told stories with brush‚Ä¶He knew that a story cannot be locked into a box, or a canvas, or a gaze. So he never tried. On the contrary, he always left a small window, an empty space, so the story could move on at will and take another path if it so desired. Because stories never end. They jump through windows and cracks‚Ä¶or create them by shaking, causing the earth to quake"
The novel is replete with lyrical passages, like this one, ‚ÄúMa sips her morning tea as though drinking in a bird‚Äôs song‚Äù.
All together a fascinating read!
Dr Raguram
11/01/24, 10:23‚ÄØam
William James (whose birthday is today), is most famous for his psychology textbook,‚Äô Principles of Psychology‚Äô which was published in 1890. It consisted of two volumes with over 1400 pages and took him 12 years to write. He did not produce any original research, did not perform any experiment, yet he became the driving force behind psychology.
Of the many topics he addressed during his life time, he is most famous for his theories about emotions and consciousness. Concerning emotions, James believed that a person is exposed to a stimulus, has a physiological reaction, and then interprets that reaction as emotion. So, first comes physiological arousal, then the subjective interpretation of those processes as emotion. An independent researcher in Denmark, Carl Lange, developed a similar theory of emotion at roughly the same time as James did. Their view of emotion came to be known as the James-Lange theory of emotion. Though it was later thought not to be an accurate theory of how emotions work, its framework was quite influential in drawing attention to the interaction between physiological processes and emotion.
William James also conceptualized consciousness as a river or a stream, constantly changing and never the same. He had an abiding interest in religion and faith. He believed that divine existence can be justified by the emotional benefits it brings to one‚Äôs life. His book ‚ÄòThe Varieties of Religious Experience: a study in human nature‚Äô, examines varied forms of religious experiences such as mystical experiences, conversion, saintliness, and spirituality from a psychological perspective. I was quite surprised to learn that the emphasis given in Alcoholic Anonymous is largely due to the influence of this book. It seems that when Bill, a co-founder of AA, was trying to fight his way back to sobriety, chanced upon a copy of the book and was deeply impressed by James' "great wisdom." It also helped Bill to finally achieve sobriety and the impact of the book can be seen in the formulation of AA's basic ideas.
James was an inspiring teacher. His students included such luminaries as Theodore Roosevelt, author and philosopher George Santayana and Gertrude Stein.
I particularly like this observation of his, ‚ÄúA great many people think they are thinking when they are merely rearranging their prejudices.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
13/01/24, 10:01‚ÄØam
In my forays into the Zen landscape, I discovered the poetry of Ryokan. His poems are direct and unpretentious, infused with profound insights. For example, he wrote:
The rain has stopped, the clouds have drifted away,
and the weather is clear again.
If your heart is pure, then all things in your world are pure.
Abandon this fleeting world, abandon yourself,
Then the moon and flowers will guide you along the Way.
He is reported to have led a live of extreme simplicity. He showed love for all living things to the extent of placing lice under his robes to keep them warm, allowing thieves to take freely from his possessions, and letting one leg protrude from his mosquito net at night to give the mosquitos food. As a Zen priest, he never established his own temple, and lived by alms. Instead of preaching, he enjoyed companionship and conversation with many ordinary people. His practice consisted of sitting in zazen meditation, walking in the woods, playing with children, making his daily begging rounds, reading, writing poetry and on occasion drinking sake with friends. He was adept in calligraphy and was also known as one of Japan's great calligraphers.
He was deeply influenced by the teachings of Dogen, the 13th century monk, about whom I wrote sometime back. Ryokan never published a collection of verse while he was alive. One of his last verses reads;
Life is like a dewdrop,
Empty and fleeting;
My years are gone
And now, quivering and frail,
I must fade away.
As Rabindranath Tagore wrote, ‚ÄúLet your life lightly dance on the edges of Time like dew on the tip of a life.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
13/01/24, 11:04‚ÄØpm
One can literally smell the fragrance in nature in this photographüëå And he himself appears to be a realised soul. Life is so fragile but we don't want to acknowledge that.
15/01/24, 8:08‚ÄØam
India with its diverse and rich cultural heritage celebrates multitudes of festivals throughout the year. The harvest festival holds a distinct place among them. The onset of harvest season is observed all across the country under various names based on the region where it is celebrated. It is essentially an act of thanksgiving to the farmers. Farmers who tend to the land with care and concern are the backbone of our society. We may need the help of a doctor or a lawyer sometime in our lives, but we need the farmer every day, three times a day to provide us with food.
Saint Poet Thiruvalluvar‚Äôs magnum opus Thirukkural consists of 133 chapters having 10 couplets each. Each one of them consisting of just one line and a half, like a short haiku. Thiruvalluvar devotes an entire chapter (104) wherein he extols the glory and greatness of agriculture and the important role of farmers.
‡Æá‡Æ∞‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æá‡Æ∞‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Øä‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡ØÅ ‡Æà‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æï‡Æ∞‡Æµ‡Ææ‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡Æï‡Øà‡Æö‡ØÜ‡ÆØ‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡Æ£‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡ÆØ‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç.
Those who plough do not ask but give with both hands
To those that ask, the bounty they have tilled
On this festival day let us pay obeisance to our indefatigable farmers who are battling tremendous odds to keep us satiated.
As the Pongal brims over the pot
Let us pray to the lord
That joy bubbles in farmer‚Äôs heart
Forever
Dr Raguram
19/01/24, 7:53‚ÄØam
When I look at a painting by Paul Cezanne (whose birthday is today), I am attracted to his innovative use of colour, particularly its relationship with form. His visual language is uniquely personal. There is a magical quality in his canvases which are replete with use of multitude of colours and distinctive brush strokes. He explored an amazing range of subjects throughout his career: landscape, portraiture, figures and still life. I am particularly fond of his still life paintings. In the hands of an unimaginative artist, still life can be quite stilted, but not in Cezanne‚Äôs hands. He was particularly drawn into painting fruits, particularly apples which take on an inexplicable lustrous luminosity in his paintings. He confided to a friend that "they [fruits] love having their portraits done. They exhale their message with their scent. They reach you with all their smells and tell you about the fields they‚Äôve left, the rain that made them grow, the dawns they watched. When I‚Äôm outlining the skin of a lovely peach with soft touches of paint, or a sad old apple, I catch a glimpse in the reflections they exchange of . . . the same love of the sun, the same recollection of the dew, a freshness."
How should one look at his paintings? In his own words, ‚ÄúShut your eyes, wait, and think of nothing. Now, open them ‚Ä¶ one sees nothing but a great coloured undulation. What then? An irradiation and glory of colour. This is what a picture should give us ‚Ä¶ an abyss in which the eye is lost, a secret germination, a coloured state of grace ‚Ä¶ loose consciousness. Descend with the painter into the dim tangled roots of things, and rise again from them in colours, be steeped in the light of them.‚Äù
Now look at Cezanne‚Äôs apples and see them come alive!
Dr Raguram
23/01/24, 9:11‚ÄØam
Sometime back we visited Avani in Kolar district (a detailed description is at: (https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/avani). Avani attained prominence due to myriad legends associated with it. Most importantly, it is said to be the site of Uttara Ramayana. There is a small beautiful, Ramalingeshwara temple which dates back to 10th century. A hillock strewn with boulders forms an interesting backdrop to this ancient temple. It is believed that Sita retreated to this hill after her trial by fire and gave birth to Lava and Kusha who grew up in the hermitage of Valmiki. There are several caves; one of them is considered to be Valmiki‚Äôs ashram and another one where Sita lived and cooked for her children.
I was keen to find out whether there are other places identified as Sita‚Äôs Kitchen. To my great surprise, I discovered that there are several Sita‚Äôs Rasoi (kitchen) dotted across the subcontinent. At least two of Sita‚Äôs kitchens have been documented in Ayodhya, but only one survived the demolition of the Babri Masjid. I understand that within the complex on the Ramkot in Ayodhya, there is a building bearing the painted phrase ‚ÄúJanmasthana Sita Rasoi‚Äù (Birthplace Sita‚Äôs Kitchen). The garbhagriha contains a rolling board, rolling pin, chulha and an image of Sita.
When I searched for other ‚ÄòSita‚Äôs Rasois‚Äô, I found documentation of several others: Lalapur near Allahabad, Chitrakoot, Brahmavarta in UP and Nasik in Maharashtra amongst others. Each one of them is adjacent to Valmiki‚Äôs ashram and similarly contain a rolling pin, board and a chulha.
I also looked for mention of Sita and her kitchen in many of the Ramayanas. There were none. An array of localized narratives and memories associated with Sita and her kitchen seemed to have evolved over time across the country. It would be a fascinating exercise to explore how these memories of the past have been constructed, celebrated and sometimes politically appropriated too.
While Rama is valorised and huge temples are built to honour him, for some inexplicable reason, Sita has been relegated and confined to the kitchen. Is her power and authority confined to the kitchen alone? Cooking, to a large extent has been embedded in the patriarchal construction of femininity. If the kitchen is a feminine abode, it might also be a site of resistance.
In the animated film, ‚ÄòSita Sings The Blues‚Äô, Nina Paley relocates her as a woman who retells her own story in her own voice in an altogether different context. Sita‚Äôs songs not only give her a voice.
Perhaps it is time to retell the Ramayana from the perspective of Sita.
Dr Raguram
25/01/24, 9:32‚ÄØam
Nambinarayana temple is at Thirukurungudi, a serene village in Tirunelveli district. It is a beautiful temple with hundreds of sculptures and carvings. Of the several lovely ones in the main gopuram, an interesting one depicts a seated Rama contemplating as to how he can journey across the sea to reach Lanka. For three days he fasted and meditated, praying to the God of the sea, Varuna, to appear and to help him find a way to cross to Lanka. There was no response, nothing but the endless, repetitive sound of the waves. Rama, infuriated by this unbearable silence picked up his bow and began to shoot arrows into the sea. The creatures of the sea began to die, and the waters began to burn. The army of monkeys who had come to help Rama were aghast and alarmed at this display of violence against the sea and her innocent creatures and tried to dissuade him to stop the onslaught. Just as Rama was about to unleash the all-powerful weapon, Brahmastra, Varuna appeared out of the sea. He bowed to Rama and calmly explained that there was nothing to be so upset about and that he would ensure that the waves would remain still while a way was found for Rama‚Äôs forces to cross the sea, and that they would remain calm until they had completed their crossing. Then, Hanuman came up with a solution and assured Rama that he along with other monkeys would build a bridge.
In this small carving you can see Rama and in front of him is Varuna. Lakshmana is standing behind him. He is surrounded by the army of monkeys. Hanuman at his feet and another one by Rama‚Äôs side are trying to dissuade him from taking any drastic action.
The bridge as a metaphor, conveys multifaceted meanings. It symbolizes a sense of connectedness and union, both physically and psychologically. Even the process of building the structure is not merely an individual act, but a collective one driven by a common cause to link and join together that which is disparate and separate. Something to ponder and reflect on‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
01/02/24, 8:04‚ÄØam
Every time I step into the bronze gallery of the Chennai museum, I am overwhelmed by the sheer beauty of the priceless exhibits encompassed in its glass display cases. The most impressive pieces are that of Siva as the cosmic dancer, Nataraja.
Whenever I look at them, I recollect the words of Fritjof Capra, (whose birthday is today),in ‚ÄòThe Tao of Physics‚Äô, relating the Nataraja‚Äôs dance with modern physics:
‚ÄúEvery subatomic particle not only performs an energy dance, but also is an energy dance; a pulsating process of creation and destruction‚Ä¶without end‚Ä¶For the modern physicists then, Shiva‚Äôs dance is the dance of subatomic matter. As in Hindu mythology, it is a continual dance of creation and destruction involving the whole cosmos; the basis of all existence and of all natural phenomena...the metaphor of the cosmic dance thus unifies ancient mythology, religious art and modern physics.‚Äù
He went on to comment, ‚ÄúThe mystic and the physicist arrive at the same conclusion; one starting from the inner realm, the other from the outer world. The harmony between their views confirms the ancient Indian wisdom that Brahman, the ultimate reality without, is identical to Atman, the reality within.‚Äù
In the words of Appar, the seventh century Shaivaite poet saint, who went to Chidambaram to see the cosmic dance of Siva,
‡Æï‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øä‡Æµ‡Øç‡Æµ‡Øà‡Æö‡Øç ‡Æö‡ØÜ‡Æµ‡Øç‡Æµ‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æï‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Æø‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æö‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Æø‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç
‡Æ™‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æö‡Æü‡Øà‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Øá‡Æ©‡Æø‡ÆØ‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æµ‡ØÜ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡ØÄ‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç
‡Æá‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æü‡Øà‡ÆØ ‡Æé‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ™‡Øä‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ§‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ£‡Æ™‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Ææ‡Æ≤‡Øç
‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ™‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ±‡Æµ‡Æø‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Øá‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æ§‡Øá ‡Æá‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Øá
‚ÄúIf you could see
the arch of his brow
the budding smile
on his lips red as the kovvai fruit
cool matted hair
the milk-white ash on coral skin
and the golden foot raised up in dance
our birth on this earth is fulfilled‚Äù
In sculptures, paintings and verses, Nataraja continues to dance...beyond time.
