It is so divine. And the more and more we delve deeper into the actual reality, it helps us to integrate and easier to comprehend.
04/02/24, 9:45‚ÄØam
One of the earliest writings of J Krishnamurti was 'The Song of Life' which was published in 1931. It is a profound, thought provoking work, offering deep insights about JK as a seeker and a poet. The final lines of the poem are in this photograph and I have taken the liberty to quote it in its entirety;
I have no name;
I am as the fresh breeze of the mountains.
I have no shelter;
I am as the wandering waters.
I have no sanctuary, like the dark gods;
Nor am I in the shadow of deep temples.
I have no sacred books;
Nor am I well-seasoned in tradition.
I am not in the incense burning upon the high altars;
Nor in the pomp of ceremonies.
I am neither in the graven image;
Nor in the rich chant of a melodious voice.
I am not bound by theories;
Nor corrupted by beliefs.
I am not held in the bondage of religions;
Nor in the pious agony of their priests.
I am not entrapped by philosophies;
Nor held in the power of their sects.
I am neither low nor high;
I am the worshipper and the worshipped.
I am free.
My song is the song of the river calling for the open seas;
Wandering, wandering;
Dr Raguram
06/02/24, 8:59‚ÄØam
Farid ud-Din Attar was considered by Rumi to be ‚Äúthe master of sufi poetry‚Äù. The ‚ÄúConference of the Birds‚Äù by him is an engaging parable about the mystical quest for the Truth. It features a host of birds led by the hoopoe, who acts as their spiritual guide in their quest. In their journey, the birds travel through the seven valleys of the quest, love, understanding, independence and detachment, unity, astonishment, and finally to a state of nothingness. In this allegorical text, many of us can locate ourselves amidst these different valleys.
Let us strive to head to the words of the Hoopoe;
‚ÄúThe ocean can be yours; why should you stop
Beguiled by dreams of evanescent dew?‚Äù
Dr Raguram

11/02/24, 8:50‚ÄØam
London is full of blue plaques. They dot the walls of buildings throughout London, marking the places where scientists, artists, politicians and activists who lived and worked there. When I was on a Commonwealth Fellowship, I made it a point to visit as many of them. One address I was keen to locate was No 1, Fitzroy Road where WB Yeats lived for a while. It was also the building where Sylvia Plath, a poet whom I admire deeply, spent her last days before ending her life on February 11th 1963.
Poets die young and not so often by suicide. Perhaps the act of writing poetry fascinates the wounded and in the process also opens up fresh wounds. Syvia Plath was no exception. In her thinly veiled autobiographical novel, ‚ÄòBell Jar‚Äô, she wrote, ‚ÄúDeath must be so beautiful. To lie in the soft brown earth, with the grasses waving above one's head, and listen to silence. To have no yesterday, and no to-morrow. To forget time, to forgive life, to be at peace‚Äù. Pensive by disposition, she kept ruminating about it, which found expression in these lines which she wrote ten days before ending her life:
‚ÄúThe blood jet is poetry,
There is no stopping it‚Äù.
There are a multitude of ways in which Sylvia Plath‚Äôs life and her final act has been analyzed and debated. Beyond these lenses of scrutiny her existential angst was enmeshed in a troubled past and a tumultuous relationship with her husband Ted Hughes. Perhaps the most insightful and poignant account about Syliva Plath‚Äôs suicide was by her friend A Alvarez in his book, ‚ÄòThe Savage God‚Äô, which we reviewed in NIMHANS in the late 70s. In the first page of the book, there is a quote by Cesare Pavese, regarded as one of Italy's most important twentieth-century poets, which says it all:"No one ever lacks a good reason for suicide."
Dr Raguram
13/02/24, 8:35‚ÄØam
Sarojini Naidu, born on 13th February 1879, was one of the most outstanding figures of the independence movement. An equally talented poet in English, she was known as ‚ÄúThe Nightingale of India‚Äù. Her poetry brims with strong emotions expressed in lyrical verses. An ardent admirer of nature, she was also a great lover of birds.
I am particularly drawn (given my passion for them!) to her poem ‚ÄòBird of Time‚Äô, wherein she expresses the workings of time through the movements of a bird. Just as we don‚Äôt expect a bird to be still, time too is fleeting. Life and death, sorrow and hope, time encompasses them all in this poem.
BIRD OF TIME
O Bird of Time on your fruitful bough
What are the songs you sing? ‚Ä¶
Songs of the glory and gladness of life,
Of poignant sorrow and passionate strife,
And the lilting joy of the spring;
Of hope that sows for the years unborn,
And faith that dreams of a tarrying morn,
The fragrant peace of the twilight‚Äôs breath,
And the mystic silence that men call death.
O Bird of Time, say where did you learn
The changing measures you sing? ‚Ä¶
In blowing forests and breaking tides,
In the happy laughter of new-made brides,
And the nests of the new-born spring;
In the dawn that thrills to a mother‚Äôs prayer,
And the night that shelters a heart‚Äôs despair,
In the sigh of pity, the sob of hate,
And the pride of a soul that has conquered fate.
In one of last letters she wrote, ‚Äù While I live, it will always be the supreme desire of my Soul to write poetry ‚Äîone poem, one line of enduring verse even. Perhaps I shall die without realising that longing which is at once an exquisite joy and an unspeakable anguish to me‚Äù.
Dr Raguram
15/02/24, 8:58‚ÄØam
A brief write up about an exquisite early Chola temple with images. Do have a look and pen your thoughts in the website: https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/bewitching-brahmapureeswarar-temple
16/02/24, 8:39‚ÄØam
Nicheren (February 16, 1222 - November 14, 1282) was one of the most influential Japanese priests who preached tenets of Mahayana Buddhism. An important sutra of Mahayana Buddhism is the ‚ÄòLotus Sutra‚Äô which was written between 100 B.C. and 200 A.D. Already well known in India, it became one of the important sutras of Chinese Buddhism and later in Japan..
It is named the ‚ÄòLotus Sutra‚Äô because the lotus symbolises the oneness of cause and effect since the lotus is a flower that blooms and seeds at the same time. Moreover, it also signifies the purity of Buddhahood, blooming in the midst of our ordinary lives just as the lotus blossoms in muddy pond water. What the ‚ÄòLotus Sutra‚Äô essentially emphasizes is that all living beings, whether they realize it or not, have the capacity to become enlightened. Everyone, without exception, can unlock the perfect wisdom and great compassion that reside in the depths of life.
Nichiren established the practice of reciting the ‚ÄòLotus Sutra's‚Äô title,‚Äù Nam-myoho-renge-kyo‚Äù, to make the path to enlightenment accessible to all. It is no ordinary phrase and is the essence of the entire ‚ÄòLotus Sutra‚Äô. The phrase "Namu-myoho-renge-kyo" literally translates to "I take refuge in the Lotus of the Wonderful Law". Nam: Comes from the Sanskrit word namas, which means to devote or dedicate oneself. Myo: is usually translated as wonderful. Ho: Means law. Renge, meaning lotus blossom. The lotus flower is pure and fragrant, unsullied by the muddy water in which it grows. Similarly, the beauty and dignity of our humanity is brought forth amidst the sufferings of daily lives. Kyo literally means sutra. Chanting the mantra is called daimoku. The purpose of chanting daimoku is to attain perfect and complete awakening. It is an expression of determination, to embrace and realize our Buddha nature. Nichiren taught that to chant ‚ÄúNam-myoho-renge-kyo‚Äù is to bring forth the Buddhahood that exists inherently within all of us.
Dr Raguram
18/02/24, 8:26‚ÄØam
Another book I had picked up those days at Easwari lending library was the novel ‚ÄòZorba the Greek‚Äô. Much like ‚ÄòThe Chosen‚Äô, it is the story of two men: Zorba, a Greek working man and a wealthy, young narrator and their incredible friendship. The two of them couldn‚Äôt be further apart. The narrator is cerebral, modest, and reserved; Zorba is unfettered and spirited.The younger man reads all day. He‚Äôs an aficionado of Buddhist philosophy, the exact opposite world view of Zorba who has such lust for life. These two characters represent two distinct ways of life. The implicit question throughout the book: which is better? Being a ‚Äústable‚Äù person and being accepted and respected in society, or being an indulgent person living his life full. Both are searching for answers. The Narrator has a desire to change, but he adamantly resists Zorba‚Äôs philosophy, despite admitting to admiring it and wishing he could assimilate it with his own. The relationship between these two characters symbolizes the conversation between the head and the heart, the mind and the spirit, what Nietzsche referred to as the Apollonian and the Dionysian impulses. Kazantzakis masterfully interweaves these dual perspectives of human nature. The book is also an important reminder to embrace the transience of life, to seize the moments that bring us joy, unfettered by intellectual curiosity. A passage in the book by the narrator illustrates this perspective:
‚ÄúI remember one morning when I discovered a cocoon in the back of a tree just as a butterfly was making a hole in its case and preparing to come out. I waited a while, but it was too long appearing and I was impatient. I bent over it and breathed on it to warm it. I warmed it as quickly as I could and the miracle began to happen before my eyes faster than life. The case opened; the butterfly started slowly crawling out, and I shall never forget my horror when I saw how its wings were folded back and crumpled; the wretched butterfly tried with its whole trembling body to unfold them. Bending over it, I tried to help it with my breath, in vain. It needed to be hatched out patiently and the unfolding of the wings should be a gradual process in the sun. Now it was too late. My breath had forced the butterfly to appear all crumpled, before its time. It struggled desperately and, a few seconds later, died in the palm of my hand. That little body is, I do believe, the greatest weight I have on my conscience. For, I realize today that it is a mortal sin to violate great laws of nature. We should not hurry, we should not be impatient, but we should confidently obey the external rhythm‚Äù.
A viewpoint summarized in the gravestone of the author, Nikos Kazantzakis,"I hope for nothing. I fear nothing. I am free."
(And who can forget Anthony Quinn bringing the most life-affirming character of Zorba alive in the movie version of the book with the Zorba the Greek song brimming with life?)
Dr Raguram
20/02/24, 8:28‚ÄØam
When I visited Yosemite sometime ago, I felt overwhelmed with the enormous expanse of its enchanting landscape. It was much like losing myself in a vast heritage temple which was built aeons ago. I felt humbled in the presence of its towering granite cliffs, lush meadows, forested valleys and dramatic seasonal waterfalls. It was a mystical experience.
One person who brought out its magical realm in tangible ways for us to relish was Anselm Adams, whose birthday is today. Yosemite was Ansel Adam‚Äôs muse.When he looked through his camera lens, he saw more than it's rocks, trees, and rivers. He saw art. Adams explored and recorded the grandeur of nature in stunning black and white photographs,conveying its beauty in lyrical ways. His elegant compositions with tantalizing play of light across its incredible terrain exude a certain sense of calmness.
As Adams observed, ‚ÄúThe whole world is, to me, very much alive, all the little growing things, even the rocks‚Ä¶I can‚Äôt look at a swell bit of grass and earth, for instance, without feeling the essential life, the things going on, within them‚Äù.
I put myself in Adam‚Äôs shoes, when I stood in front of the half dome, where he has taken many of his stunning photographs and froze that moment in this frame

At least we are capable of appreciating someone else's perspective. What else should give 'peace of mind' for such people who can see life everywhere including rocks?
22/02/24, 8:06‚ÄØam
Takahama Kyoshi (born on 22nd February1874) was a great haiku poet in the history of modern Japanese haiku literature. He wrote more than two hundred thousand haikus in his lifetime.
He defined haiku as the poetry of ‚Äòka-cho-fuhei‚Äô, literally meaning ‚Äúan elegant way of describing bird and flower‚Äù. Not surprisingly then, nature in all manifestations figure prominently in his haikus.
One day Kyoshi was sweeping his garden, trying to get rid of cobwebs. To his great dismay, when he returned later, he found another spider had spun a new web. Though annoyed for a second, he realized that it is the natural behaviour of the spider to keep spinning webs. In a moment, he identified with the spider. He himself has to keep creating haiku as long as he lives, much like the spider. That's the call and beauty of life.
And he sat down and wrote this beautiful haiku:
‚ÄúBorn as a spider
No choice but to spin
His spider web‚Äù
The spider is aware that the web it spins will not last long. Yet it doesn‚Äôt tire itself in spinning one. The cadence of our existence is in lending an ear to the melody of life‚Äôs ephemeral quality and embracing it.
In the timeless words of Gulzar:
‚Äú‡§Ü‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§™‡§≤ , ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§π‡•à
‡§π‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡•ã ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç
‡§ú‡§º‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ã
‡§™‡§≤ ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‚Äù
Dr Raguram
25/02/24, 8:59‚ÄØam
Both Ahalya and myself are ardent Beatles aficionados. We must have listened to ‚ÄòSgt.Peppers Lonely Heart Club‚Äô umpteen number of times. Each time it is a revelation of the group‚Äôs immense talents and originality. Each and every song in it is a gem, Amidst them, the ‚ÄòWithin and Without You‚Äô, stands out for its melodious tones inspired by Indian music.George Harrison (whose birthday is today) was learning sitar from Pandit Ravi Shankar at that time and used it in the song beautifully. The tune was partially based on a lengthy suite Shankar had written for All-India Radio.It has a sinuous quality and its sweeping tunes cast a spell.
One can consider this song as the most philosophical in the entire album. George was quite influenced by the book, ‚ÄòAutobiography of a Yogi‚Äô, by Paramahamsa Yogananda. Its underlying theme is the importance of self knowledge. in order for a person to freely love and realize self-knowledge, he/she must become less attached to the things of the world which might deter him from reaching such a state. Harrison is encouraging the listener to go ‚Äúwithin‚Äù themselves. And at the same time, in order to successfully do so one has to be ‚Äúwithout‚Äù himself. And to be ‚Äúwithout‚Äù himself involves casting aside one‚Äôs worldly concerns. In essence, this is one of the well-recognized aspects for effective meditative practice.
When you've seen beyond yourself
Then you may find peace of mind is waiting there
And the time will come when you see we're all one
And life flows on within you and without you
Dr Raguram
26/02/24, 1:07‚ÄØpm
But man keeps on spinning thoughts around people, instances not letting go which is the sad part. Not able to accept embrace the fleeting existence of life. Such a beautiful very short yet very deep haiku!
27/02/24, 8:07‚ÄØam
A good poem opens up a new world and takes you on a memorable journey. Henry Wadswoth Longfellow‚Äôs, ‚ÄòNature‚Äô is one such.
The simple, unpretentious opening lines of the poem portray a familiar scene that happens in most of our homes; a mother trying to put her child to sleep. The child‚Äôs ‚Äòbroken playthings‚Äô are scattered on the floor, and he is ‚Äúhalf willing" to abandon the play and retire for the night. He lingers, staring longingly at the toys he has left behind.
The next few lines venture into a new territory all together. The poet compares the mother whom he just described eloquently, to mother nature. Both are essentially caretakers of all of us. Nature is to man, what a mother is to her child. As we advance in years, nature gradually takes away all our earthly possessions and gently guides us to the world beyond. Since often we are greatly attached to our earthly life and our belongings, we are never too willing to proceed towards that goal. But nature leads us just like the mother leading the child to sleep,taking away our "playthings" one at a time. The poet suggests that our earthly desires and attachments are like playthings that we must eventually relinquish to discover the unknown mysteries of life..
Why did this poem appeal to me? I was drawn (and still continue to be!) by the simple imagery of a mother putting a reluctant child to sleep, which slowly blends itself into a very powerful metaphor of a nurturing nature that prepares us for our journey beyond this world. There is much wisdom in these lines;
NATURE
As a fond mother, when the day is o'er,
Leads by the hand her little child to bed,
Half willing, half reluctant to be led,
And leave his broken playthings on the floor,
Still gazing at them through the open door,
Nor wholly reassured and comforted
By promises of others in their stead,
Which, though more splendid, may not please him more;
So Nature deals with us, and takes away
Our playthings one by one, and by the hand
Leads us to rest so gently, that we go
Scarce knowing if we wish to go or stay,
Being too full of sleep to understand
How far the unknown transcends the what we know.
(Henry Wadswoth Longfellow born on this day on 1807)
Dr Raguram
29/02/24, 8:03‚ÄØam
Tore √òrjas√¶ter (March 3rd,1886 - February 29th1968) was a Norwegian poet who was rooted in the folk tradition and wrote many lyrical poems about nature. Unfortunately only very few of them have been translated into English. Cries of Gulls is one such gem:
CRIES OF GULLS
Sheer rock and steep faces of Lofot,
bird-cliff and thousands
of seagulls that circle round mast and hull.
Let themselves glide on powerful wings
towards the open sea, - it breathes towards them
and receives like an open mind.
Soon after the storm has abated,
the sea‚Äôs bosom still goes on heaving.
The swell lifts the heavy sea
closer up to the horizon
that constantly escapes and dies out quietly
to new heights on the skyline
that once more breathes out and escapes
like time dies out within the age.
Oh these free cries of gulls
towards the open sea! It is like breathing
out one‚Äôs longings and never landing.
Dr Raguram
01/03/24, 9:04‚ÄØam
Rhythmic highs and lows of life can spark the creative urge within ourselves. But when the intensity of the swings are severe, it causes immense suffering to those in the midst of it. Rober Lowell, whose birthday is today, suffered from a severe form of bipolar illness which started early in his life. Mental illness ran deep in his family and his life was laden with instability; for thirty years he was in and out of mental hospitals. The manic episodes were extremely disruptive with florid psychotic symptoms, requiring hospitalization, which were invariably followed by periods of depression.
Fire is a central image in Lowell‚Äôs works. His manic episodes were akin to a blaze of fire which took some effect to be quelled. He wrote, ‚ÄúBy the time I reached the hospital I was completely out of my head‚Äîstrange physical sensations‚ÄîI was a prophet and everything was a symbol; then in the hospital: shouting, singing, tearing things up‚Äîreligion and antics. Then depression (extreme) aching, self-enclosed, fearful of everyone and everything anyone could do, feeling I was nothing and could do nothing‚Äù He termed his manic phase as the ‚Äúholocaust of irrationality‚Äù and depression as the ‚Äúlong, burdensome dull period‚Äù with months of ‚Äúwading in the muck and weeds and backwash of a depression. Depression is an illness for oneself, mania an illness for one‚Äôs friends‚Äù.
Above all, he was a poet and during one of his admissions, he wrote:
The resident doctor said,
‚ÄúWe are not deep in ideas, imagination, or enthusiasm‚Äî
how can we help you?‚Äù
I asked,
‚ÄúThese days of only poems and depression‚Äî
what can I do with them?
Will they help me notice
what I cannot bear to look at?‚Äù
Lowell wrote brilliantly about the embers of his illness in an autobiographical piece, ‚ÄúNear the Unbalanced Aquarium‚Äù, which is included in his book ‚ÄòMemoirs‚Äô. The effect of the medication was ‚Äúlike the slowing and ache of a medium fever. One‚Äôs thoughts are not directly changed and healed, but the terrible, over-riding restlessness of one‚Äôs system is halted so that the mind can see life as it is‚Äù. He was given Lithium much later in his life, once it was available for use. Among all the medications and ECTs that were given to him, Lowell found that Lithium was the most effective one. Reflecting about it, hw wondered to his friend, ‚ÄúIt's terrible, Bob, to think that all I‚Äôve suffered, and all the suffering I‚Äôve caused, might have arisen from the lack of a little salt in my brain‚Äù
What is remarkable is that Lowell continued writing despite the immense suffering due to his mood disorder which wreaked on his life. His courage and determination enabled him to channel the creative fire within, which unfortunately consumed him.
(There have been many biographies of Robert Lowell, my personal favourite is the exceptional,l ‚ÄòSetting the River on Fire‚Äô, by Kay Redfeld Jamison)
Dr Raguram
03/03/24, 8:02‚ÄØam
Humans and wildlife have interacted closely for millions of years, especially during the prehistoric era. The habitat of the prehistoric people were caves. Dwelling there, they embellished the caves with paintings imbued with natural colours. A common theme in their paintings was wildlife, which was not surprising since they lived in close proximity with them. Wildlife was an integral part of their daily lives.
I had the first glimpse of the richness of the prehistoric cave paintings ranging from the Upper Paleolithic period (around 30,000 years ago) to the mediaeval period, in Bhimbetka. It is one of the most densely painted rock shelters in India. As I walked into its vast terrain, one particular rock shelter caught my attention, which is often referred to as the Zoo Rock. A vast array of various wild animals, painted in profile, covered its rock face. Deers, elephants, leopards, wild buffaloes, bears and boars were galloping on its aged backdrop. The primary colour was white, which dates back to the Mesolithic period, while a few from later periods were mostly in red. Though the colours had faded with time, the entire scene was brimming with energy, showcasing the close relationship between these ancient painters and the wildlife around them.
Unfortunately this relationship has frayed over time. The global loss of wildlife is significantly alrarming. According to a 2022 World Wildlife Fund report, global wildlife populations have declined by 69% since 1970.
I am reminded of the story, ‚ÄòThe Epic of Gilgamesh‚Äô, which narrates the great city builder Gilgamesh‚Äôs friendship with a ‚Äúwild man,‚Äù Enkidu. Enkidu leads a contented life without human contact, ‚Äúcoated in hair like the god of the animals,‚Äù grazing at the water hole with a herd of gazelles, ‚Äúhis heart delighting with the beasts in the water.‚Äù Gilgamesh forcibly humanizes Enkidu by sending Shamhat, a priestess, to seduce him. After many days of lovemaking, Enkidu is spurned by the wild animals. He gets a haircut, eats bread, drinks ale and returns with Shamhat to the city.
As modern city dwellers, we are much like the alienated Enkidu, estranged from the rich wildlife around us, making occasional forays to have a glimpse of them amidst the declining forest covers. On the occasion of World Wildlife day and on the background of increasing man-animal conflicts, can we cultivate a more mindful interaction with wild animals at a both personal and public level and commit ourselves towards sustained conservation and peaceful coexistence?
(And of course, you can see them all at ‚ÄòVantara‚Äô‚Ä¶relocated and displaced from their natural habitat. Is that the future of wildlife in India?!)
Dr Raguram
05/03/24, 8:06‚ÄØam
London has the world‚Äôs first underground railway system and it is always busy with hordes of busy commuters. It is also the most efficient way to travel in the city, provided there are no strikes or unplanned closures.
For me, one of the pleasures of travelling by the tube was to read the poems that used to adorn the stations. Simply called, ‚ÄòPoems from the underground‚Äô, it was a veritable collection of verses from across the world. It was also a wonderful introduction to poets whom I neve heard of before. One such poet was Anise Koltz, often referred to as ‚Äúthe great lady of Luxembourg literature.‚Äù These particular lines of her, which I had made a note of, were particularly striking.
THE BIRDS WILL STILL SING
‚ÄúBreak my branches
saw me into bits
the birds will still sing
in my roots‚Äù
Birds inhabit the same world we do, and yet, they seem capable of transcending it. Though many of them lead lives on the brink of ruin, they still sing. These sparse, powerful, words in the poem convey that even in the midst of destruction unleashed by humans, spirited voices will emerge, rooted in resilience.
This is the anthem for Gaza too‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
08/03/24, 9:28‚ÄØpm
There are many legends associated with Mahashivaratri which is being celebrated today. According to one, it was the day when Shiva drank the poison that emerged from the ocean during Amritmanthan, to protect the world. He drank it but held it in his throat instead of swallowing it. Thus, his throat changed to a blue colour and he was then given the name, Nilkantha. According to another legend, when Ganga was descended from heaven after the request of Bhagirath, it was enormous and uncontrollable, so Lord Brahma requested Shiva to control her fall. Shiva agreed to it and he held the rapid flow of Ganga by tying it up in his hair. According to yet another legend, this was the night when Shiva and Parvati got married, an amalgamation of Purusha (mindfulness) and Prakriti (nature).
I have a particular interest in the mural tradition of south India and went over to the Virupaksha temple sometime back to have a look at the murals that adorn the ranga mantapa. It was fascinating to see the ceiling resplendent with murals depicting scenes from the purana and various narrative episodes from history. Prominent among them is a large panel depicting the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. In the attached photo, starting from the left, one can find Narada, a horse headed Tumburu.. Vishnu and Lakshmi are in the next section. The middle portion depicts the marriage of Shiva and Parvati in exquisite detail.. Brahma is officiating the marriage of Shiva and Parvati with Himavat performing Kanyadan. Three bejewelled women are seen on their right. In the last section on the right, one can notice the three legged Bhringi. The attention to detail, especially the designs in the textiles is quite striking. I was wondering as to how these murals would have looked in their heyday. Temples are not merely places of worship; embellished with magnificent sculptures and paintings, they are repositories of a rich aesthetic tradition which needs to be preserved and protected. I was happy to note that an innovative attempt has been made to digitise these murals. There is an overwhelming need for similar initiatives to conserve many such artistic treasures across the country, which are unfortunately in various stages of neglect.
Dr Raguram
10/03/24, 8:49‚ÄØam
MEDITATION ON THE AUTUMN LEAF
Thich Nhat Hanh
"I asked the leaf whether it was frightened because it was Autumn and the other leaves were falling.
The leaf told me, ‚ÄúNo. During the whole Spring and Summer I was completely alive. I worked hard to help nourish the tree, and now much of me is in the tree. I am not limited by this form. I am also the whole tree, and when I go back to the soil, I will continue to nourish the tree. So I don‚Äôt worry at all. As I leave this branch and float to the ground, I will wave to the tree and tell her, ‚ÄòI will see you again very soon.‚Äù
That day there was a wind blowing and, after a while, I saw the leaf leave the branch and float down to the soil, dancing joyfully, because as it floated it saw itself already there in the tree. It was so happy. I bowed my head, knowing that I have a lot to learn from the leaf.‚Äù
‚Äù ‚Ä¶ So please continue to look back and you will see that you have always been here. Let us look together and penetrate into the life of a leaf, so we may be one with the leaf. Let us penetrate and be one with the cloud or with the wave, to realize our own nature as water and be free from our fear. If we look very deeply, we will transcend birth and death.
Tomorrow, I will continue to be. But you will have to be very attentive to see me. I will be a flower, or a leaf. I will be in these forms and I will say hello to you. If you are attentive enough, you will recognize me, and you may greet me. I will be very happy."

Nijinsky was an extraordinarily talented ballet dancer. Unfortunately he had to weather the storm of schizophrenia during a major part of his life. I have penned a few thoughts on his birthday at: https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/vaslav-nijisnsky-and-his-tryst-with-schizophrenia.

20/03/24, 7:59‚ÄØam
As I watch through my window, the snowflakes are whirling and falling on the ground with fluffy lightness. Soon, they cover the ground, forming a dainty, white blanket.
I feel oneness with these gyrating crystals. Immersed in the experience, I become aware of my own thoughts that arise and fall within myself. They are the visual hieroglyphic representations of multitudes of thoughts swirling within my mind. In these moments I am not just an observer of the world outside my window, but an explorer of my internal landscape.The falling snow becomes a companion in my journey, like a wandering minstrel.
Dr Raguram
22/03/24, 6:47‚ÄØam
Poems are like flowers, stemming from the heart and blossoming in delicate petals of words. We all use words, we all want to communicate and poetry does it seamlessly. It is a very powerful art form. In the words of William Wordsworth ‚Äúpoetry is the breath and finer spirit of all knowledge.‚Äù Expanding on this aspect, Ursula Le Guin commented, ‚ÄúScience describes accurately from outside, poetry describes accurately from inside. Science explicates, poetry implicates. Both celebrate what they describe. We need the languages of both science and poetry to save us from merely stockpiling endless ‚Äòinformation‚Äô that fails to inform our ignorance or our irresponsibility.‚Äù
Le Guin‚Äôs poems offer glimpses of her deep and abiding love of the natural world; ‚ÄùI guess I‚Äôm trying to subjectify the universe, because look where objectifying it has gotten us. One way to stop seeing trees, or river, or hills, only as ‚Äònatural resources,‚Äô is to class them as fellow beings,as kinfolk.‚Äù
In this poem titled, ‚ÄòKinship‚Äô, she explores the primordial ties that connect all life forms.
Very slowly burning, the big forest tree
stands in the slight hollow of the snow
melted around it by the mild, long
heat of its being and its will to be
root, trunk, branch, leaf, and know
earth dark, sun light, wind touch, bird song.
Rootless and restless and warmblooded, we
blaze in the flare that blinds us to that slow,
tall, fraternal fire of life as strong
now as in the seedling two centuries ago.
(Reflections on the World Poetry Day, 21st March)
Dr Raguram
23/03/24, 6:50‚ÄØam
Saigyo was a 12th century Japanese poet who became a Buddhist monk very early in his life. The most popular form of Japanese poetry is the haiku, the 17-syllable poem whicht reached the height of its development in the seventeenth century. But the haiku is derived from an older poetic form, the waka, which had been around for a thousand years before the haiku. The word waka means "Japanese poem," and it is a form so basic to Japanese literature that Japanese still study and write it today. It encompases five principal forms; tanka, ch≈çk,a bussokusekika, sedoka, and katauta. The last three fell into disuse over time and wanka is now identified principally with the tanka. Saigyo was one of the greatest masters of tanka which is described as, ‚Äúsomething which takes root in the soil of the heart and blossoms forth in a forest of words.‚Äù
Saigyo travelled all over Japan, living as a hermit in the mountains and writing poems which expressed his Buddhist principles and love of nature. Peering out through the window of his hut or sitting on a rock, he portrayed nature and the universe around him, as he saw them. For example, alone in his hut, he compares himself to the reclusive bird, warbler in a poem titled ‚ÄòThe Bush Warbler Idling,‚Äô
‚ÄúSeeping through the haze,
the voice
of the bush warbler‚Äî
few people passing,
mountain village in spring‚Äù.
Saigyo was deeply attracted to cherry blossoms and wrote many poems about it. In his final days, he moved to a hermitage in the mountains near Kyoto, which was surrounded by cherry blossom trees. He wished to die under the cherry blossom tree and wrote:
‚Äúlet me die in spring
under the cherry blossoms
on that day
in the Second Month
when the moon is full‚Äù
Saigyo eventually accomplished his wish, and died peacefully in the year 1190 on 23rd March at the age of 73, beneath a blossoming cherry tree

27/03/24, 9:07‚ÄØpm
The poem has the essence of spiritual truth. Tyranny could not mute his words....
29/03/24, 10:18‚ÄØpm
All great souls say the same.
02/04/24, 7:47‚ÄØam
I have an abiding interest in temple architecture and have been photographing and documenting ancient sculptures and mural paintings. There is something distinctive about sculptures that adorn Hindu temples. I was searching for a befitting description of these aesthetic creations and found it in the words of Octavio Paz, ‚ÄúGothic architecture is the music turned to stone; one could say that Hindu architecture is sculpted dance.‚Äù No one could have said it better. Though steeped in history, these sculptures come alive (in spite of years of neglect and deterioration) and cast a lingering spell on the viewer. A notable example is the depiction of 108 Karanas from the Natya Shastra of Bharata Muni which adorn the passages of all the four gopurams in Chidambaram..
Ocatavio Paz, poet, Nobel laureate and diplomat, spent several years in India and wrote a small, engaging book, ‚ÄòIn Light of India‚Äô, reflecting on the history and ethos of the nation. Observing the sculptures of Elephanta Caves, he wrote, ‚ÄúI entered a world made of shadows and sudden brightness. The play of the light, the vastness of the space and its irregular form, the figures carved on the walls: all of it gave the place a sacred character, sacred in the deepest meaning of the word.‚Äù
In addition, Paz explored themes of identity, cultural heritage, and the complexities of India in this book. It is an insightful account, weaving together the intricate layers of its cultural tapestry and the impact they have on shaping individual identities and the collective consciousness of the nation. His observation was quite prescient, ‚ÄúWe are witnessing now, at the end of the century, the resurrection of ethnic and psychic passions, beliefs, ideas, and realities that seemed to have been long buried. The return of religious passion and nationalist fervour hides an ambiguous meaning: Is it the return of ghosts and demons that reason had exorcised, or is it the revelation of profound truths and realities that had been ignored by our proud intellectual constructs?‚Äù
Paz was an outstanding poet (more of it later!) and a glimpse of it in this short poem about the hummingbird which almost sounds like a Haiku.
Stillness
not on the branch
in the air
Not in the air
in the moment
Hummingbird
(Octavio Paz March 31st 1914 - April 19th 1998)

15/04/24, 7:02‚ÄØam
I was in the eighth standard when I first heard about Guru Nanak. Our school had a moral education session on the last Saturday of every month.Students were called upon to speak on various religious/spiritual traditions which was followed up by a talk by a leading figure from that background. I was given the opportunity twice: the first time to speak on the ‚ÄòSermon on the mount‚Äô and the second time on ‚ÄòGuru Nanak‚Äô. I went to the school library to read about him and was attracted by the three pillars of Sikhism he outlined; Kirat Karni (honest living), Vand Chakna (sharing with others) and Naam Japna (focus on God). At that time I didn‚Äôt know much about God but honest living and the spirit of sharing and giving appealed to my young mind and left a lasting impact. Perhaps it also laid the foundation for my interest in serving the needy, in later part of my life.
I cannot claim to have read all his works and shabads but I am drawn to his message of 'Ik Onkar': "Ik Onkar, Satnam, Karta Purakh, Nirbhau, Nirvair, Akal Murat, Ajuni Sae Bham, Guru Prasad." There's only one God, his name is the only truth, he is the only creator, he is fearless, he is without hate, he is immortal, he is beyond birth and death, and only by his grace one can chant his name.
‚Äú·∏éasƒó ·∏ùisƒù ravi¬≠ƒù parab·∫ñ ƒók. ·∏é·∫ñaran akƒùs sab·∫ñ meh parab·∫ñ pƒók·∫ñ. Jal thal ban parba·πØ pƒù·πØƒùl.‚Äù ‚ÄúHe can be found in all the ten directions, on land, in water, in the forests and mountains‚Äù
Guru Nanak died when he was seventy. In accordance with the Sikh tradition, on the day of his death, as he was sinking the community gathered around Nanak. Those of Hindu background insisted they should cremate his body, while Muslims wanted to bury him as a great saint. Nanak said, ‚ÄúPlace flowers on both sides of my body‚Äîflowers from the Hindus on the right side and flowers from the Muslims on the left. If tomorrow the flowers of the Hindus are still fresh let my body be burned, and if the flowers of the Muslims are still fresh, let it be buried.‚Äù He requested that those present to place a sheet over his head and body, and instructed everyone to leave him.The Sikh, Hindu and Muslim devotees returned the following morning on September 22, 1539 A.D. They carefully lifted and removed the sheet and they were astonished to discover that there was no trace of Guru Nanak Dev Ji's mortal body. Only fresh flowers remained and not a single bud had wilted of any of the blossoms which had been left by either Sikhs Hindus or Muslims, the night before.
‡®∏‡®≠ ‡®Æ‡®π‡®ø ‡®∞‡®µ‡®ø ‡®∞‡®π‡®ø‡®Ü ‡®™‡©ç‡®∞‡®≠‡©Å ‡®è‡®ï‡©à ‡®™‡©á‡®ñ‡®ø ‡®™‡©á‡®ñ‡®ø ‡®®‡®æ‡®®‡®ï ‡®¨‡®ø‡®ó‡®∏‡®æ‡®à
The One God is pervading in all. Gazing upon Him, beholding Him, Nanak blossoms forth in happiness
(Guru Nanak Jayanti 15th April)
Dr Raguram
16/04/24, 7:49‚ÄØam
Nature has always been a great source of inspiration to artists, right from the times of petroglyphs. As one of the most inspiring muses known to man, it provides endless inspiration to artists and has become a central theme in many famous artists' artworks. Artists not only recreate the natural world but also create new ways of perceiving it.
The theme of the World Art Day on 15th April this year is ‚ÄòA Garden of Expression. Claude Monet, arguably the most important painter of gardens in the history of art, organized his garden at Giverny as though it were a huge painting. Inspired by Japanese prints, he diverted the water from river Epte into the gardens and developed an extensive pond and planted lilies. But fearing the effect the water lilies might have on their livestock, the farmers wrote to local officials to block his plans. Fortunately, Monet was able to obtain permission to proceed after facing lots of difficulties. He painted hundred of lilies and titled the series as
The Nymph√©as. The word nymph√©a comes from the Greek word numph√©, meaning nymph, which takes its name from the classical myth that attributes the birth of the flower to a nymph who was dying of love for Hercules. In fact, it is also a scientific term for a water lily. In all these paintings he focused solely on the surface of the pond, with its cluster of vegetation Ô¨Çoating amid the lilies. Painted on the backdrop of World War 1, these tranquil paintings perhaps provided ‚Äùa refuge of peaceful mediation‚Äù in turbulent times. Much like the Starry Nights of Vincent van Gogh, these are the most iconic images of the impressionist era of paintings.
I was privileged to see the recreation of Monet‚Äô garden in the New York Botanical Garden,several years ago. It was like walking amidst the canvases of Monet. There was the iconic Japanese footbridge, an amazing range of flowers of myriad hues and a lovely pond with floating lilies. I was totally immersed in watching the reflection of light on the shimmering waters of the pond, studded with beautiful lilies. Mone‚Äôt paintings of the lilies came alive at that moment.
If William Blake saw the world ‚Äúin a grain of sand‚Äù, Monet viewed the water lilies as an extension of his life, ‚Äúwithout the water the lilies cannot live, as I am without art.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
17/04/24, 7:39‚ÄØam
When Lakshmana fell unconscious during the battle with Meghnad, Jambavan suggested that only a herb with healing powers, sanjeevini, can revive him. Hanuman immediately flew in search of the mountain where the herb was to be found. In spite of his best efforts he couldn‚Äôt identify the herb and uprooted the whole mountain and flew back.
This particular episode from Ramayana teeming with exquisite details is depicted in this beautiful painting, which is part of the first illustrated version of Valmiki Ramayana. The project was commissioned by the great Mughal Akbar and text of the great epic was translated into Persian. Abdul Qadir Badaoni was deputed by the emperor as the chief translator in partnership with Naqib Khan under the direction of a learned Hindu scholar, Deva Misra. It involved several layers of translation. Brahmins at the court first translated the verses from Sanskrit into Awadhi. Court translators then rendered their transliteration into Persian verse, and court painters added their interpretations of the various scenes.
It was profusely illustrated with a vivid and sophisticated colour palette blending Indo-Persian aesthetic principles adroitly. It contained one hundred and seventy-six miniatures within three hundred and sixty-five finely calligraphed folios. The imperial copy of the Ramayana is now in Maharaja Sawai Man Singh II Museum in Jaipur. Several copies of the original were made, one especially for Akbar‚Äôs mother, Hamida Banu Begum. This copy is preserved at Doha‚Äôs Museum of Islamic Art. One of the sub imperial copies is at the Freer Gallery of Art in Washington,which is remarkably congruent to the imperial copy. This has been digitized and available for viewing. It is a lasting testimony of the religious tolerance and all-inclusive spiritual world view of Akbar. He envisioned his initiatives such as translation of the Ramayana not merely as an aesthetic exercise, but also as an efficient tool for dissemination of knowledge and spirituality, promoting religious tolerance and harmony.
(Penned on the occasion of Rama Navami)
Dr Raguram

22/04/24, 7:35‚ÄØam
On this World Earth Day, let me share a letter written by Thich Nhah Hanh.
Dear Mother Earth,
Every time I step upon the Earth, I will train myself to see that I am walking on you, my Mother. Every time I place my feet on the Earth I have a chance to be in touch with you and with all your wonders. With every step I can touch the fact that you aren‚Äôt just beneath me, dear Mother, but you are also within me. Each mindful and gentle step can nourish me, heal me, and bring me into contact with myself and with you in the present moment.
Walking in mindfulness I can express my love, respect, and care for you, our precious Earth. I will touch the truth that mind and body are not two separate entities. I will train myself to look deeply to see your true nature: you are my loving mother, a living being, a great being‚Äîan immense, beautiful, and precious wonder. You are not only matter, you are also mind, you are also consciousness. Just as the beautiful pine or tender grain of corn possess an innate sense of knowing, so, too, do you. Within you, dear Mother Earth, there are the elements of Earth, water, air and fire; and there is also time, space, and consciousness. Our nature is your nature, which is also the nature of the cosmos.
I want to walk gently, with steps of love and with great respect. I shall walk with my own body and mind united in oneness. I know I can walk in such a way that every step is a pleasure, every step is nourishing, and every step is healing‚Äînot only for my body and mind, but also for you, dear Mother Earth. You are the most beautiful planet in our entire solar system. I do not want to run away from you, dear Mother, nor to hurry. I know I can find happiness right here with you. I do not need to rush to find more conditions for happiness in the future. At every step I can take refuge in you. At every step I can enjoy your beauties, your delicate veil of atmosphere and the miracle of gravity. I can stop my thinking. I can walk relaxingly and effortlessly. Walking in this spirit I can experience awakening. I can awaken to the fact that I am alive, and that life is a precious miracle. I can awaken to the fact that I am never alone and can never die. You are always there within me and around me at every step, nourishing me, embracing me, and carrying me far into the future.
Dear Mother, you wish that we live with more awareness and gratitude, and we can do this by generating the energies of mindfulness, peace, stability, and compassion in our daily lives. Therefore I make the promise today to return your love and fulfil this wish by investing every step I take on you with love and tenderness. I am walking not merely on matter, but on spirit.
23/04/24, 7:43‚ÄØam
On this World Book Day, let me pen a few words about a book that I read yesterday; ‚ÄòThe Rumi Prescription: How an Ancient Mystic Poet Changed My Modern Manic Life‚Äô by Melody Moezzi. Diagnosed to have Bipolar Disorder, she experienced severe bouts of depression, mania and had to be hospitalized on occasions. Medications helped her to balance her moods, but merely keeping the disorder in check did not satisfy her. She decided to channel her energy into writing and published her experiences of the illness in a powerful book, ‚ÄòHaldol and Hyacinths‚Äô. Much like the hyacinth flower, which rarely grows perfectly straight, Moezzi urged the need to embrace the disorder and rely on the support from loved ones to keep afloat. The book was very well received. After many interviews in the media and countless promotional events, she felt utterly drained, not just physically and emotionally, but spiritually. In her words, ‚ÄúConsumed by an insatiable longing for more and bigger and better successes down the line, I lost track of the
present and grew so addicted to affirmation that I had no energy left for creation‚Äù.
It was at this stage that she rediscovered the timeless teachings of Rumi, with the help of her surgeon father. The book is organized in an innovative way with chapters titled as diagnosis and prescription, dealing with many of the tribulations the author underwent; wanting, isolation, haste, depression, distraction, anxiety, anger, fear, disappointment, and pride. These are all inherent aspects of each of our lives and the author deftly uses Rumi‚Äôs poems as ‚Äòprescriptions‚Äô that we can imbibe. Let me outline some of these prescriptions:
On Haste and the need to Slow Down:
‚ÄúYou went out in search of gold far and wide
But all along you were gold on the inside‚Äù
On Depression:
‚ÄúWhere there are roses, thorns abound.
In the grand bazaar of life, joy without sorrow cannot be found‚Äù
On Anxiety:
‚ÄúForget your plans and embrace uncertainty.
Only then will you find stability‚Äù
On Disappointment
‚ÄúBread on your head and knee-deep in a river,
How are you so starved and withered?
You already own all the sustenance you seek.
If only you‚Äôd wake up and take a peek‚Äù
These verses of Rumi must be read in the context of the personal narratives of the author in the book. I strongly recommend it!
Let me end with this verse of Rumi:
‚ÄúOn the road to enlightenment, wise and mad are one.
In the way of Love, self and other are one.
For those who drink of the wine that connects souls,
In their religion, the Kaaba and the house of idols are one‚Äù
Dr Raguram
23/04/24, 10:31‚ÄØpm
The photograph brings smile automatically. And what to say about mindfulness walking... It is an ode to mother earth... It contains the essence of spirituality... Who can ever even imagine harming the mother if we take it seriously. I wish this becomes the early morning prayer and practise for the generation.
25/04/24, 7:41‚ÄØam
In light of the recent deeply divisive, agonising , electoral comments, it is perhaps time to read and reflect about Kabir and his writings.
Kabir‚Äôs poetry urges us to rise above identity politics and to seek an essence that transcends notions of selfhood. In his works, he draws attention to multiple manifestations of this ‚Äòessence‚Äô and encourages us to celebrate them.
‚ÄúChaahe Gita bachiye ya padhiye Quran
Tera mera pyaar hai har pustak ka gyan‚Äù
‚ÄúIt matters not if you read the Gita or the Quran
All holy texts preach love.‚Äù
More importantly, he emphasized how the process of ‚Äòothering‚Äô, in whatever way we view them as being ‚Äòdifferent‚Äô from ‚Äòour‚Äô ways of knowing and being, keeps us locked up in firm, unempathetic stances. As mental health professionals we are deeply aware of the impact of ‚Äòothering‚Äô in stigmatising, marginalising and devaluing those who are considered and responded to as being ‚Äòdifferent‚Äô.
Hence it is appropriate to recall Kabir‚Äôs words
‚ÄúBura dekhan main chala, bura na milya koye
Jo mann khoya aapna toh mujhsa buran na koye‚Äù
‚ÄúI set out to find bad men, but couldn‚Äôt find any
When l looked within myself, l found there was no one worse than me.‚Äù
In Kabir's worldview, hatred has no place and one needs to look within oneself before directing fingers at others.
In the words of Kabir, I reiterate:
‚ÄúAisi Baani boliye | Mann ka aapa khoye ||
Auran ko sheetal kare | Aaphu sheetal hoye ||‚Äù
‚ÄúLet your speech be such that the ego of ‚ÄòI‚Äô and ‚Äòmine‚Äô dissolves.
That the words you speak soothe everyone, and soothe you as well‚Äù
It hasn‚Äôt been easy to post this.

30/04/24, 10:18‚ÄØpm
I love to read and listen doha of Kabirdas. The essence of spirituality is conveyed in couple of lines.
02/05/24, 8:23‚ÄØam
Sometimes by sheer chance, one discovers an interesting book. This time it was ‚ÄòIn The Shade Of The Spring Leaves‚Äô,a biography of a Japanese author, Ichiyo Higuchi, containing nine stories and extracts from her diary. It was a revelation.
After finishing the book, I discovered that Ichigo Higuchi was a very important writer of the Meiji period and Japan‚Äôs first modern female writer. She was born in 1872 and died in 1896 at the tender age of 24. Born into a peasant family, her mother was not keen for her to be educated. Finally at the age of 14 she was allowed to attend poetry school as a concession. That marked the beginning of an illustrious literary career. Higuchi picked the pen name ‚ÄúIchiy≈ç‚Äù, meaning ‚Äúone leaf,‚Äù which has a deeper references to a specific form of Zen meditation. In her short life, wrote four thousand classical poems, many short stories, and kept a detailed, 60-volume diary. In one of the entries in the diary, quoted in the book, she writes;
‚ÄúThe rain stopped, green and fresh new leaves rise above the eaves. Pointless it is to wait for someone in my quiet house. I hear the voice of the vendor. And delve into reading a collection of Tang poems.‚Äù
Her stories are replete with lyrical passages like this one from‚ÄòSnowy Day‚Äô, ‚Äú Silver sprinkles the earth. Softly, snowflakes fall like dancing butterflies; wings flutter, but there is no sound. Six-petalled crystals come to rest on withered trees, spring‚Äôs first flowering‚Äù.
Ichiyo Higuchi took me on a compelling journey and I travelled on the wings of her writings to discover an entirely new creative landscape.
Dr Raguram
03/05/24, 7:25‚ÄØam
According to Greek mythology, orchids were made from the remains of a young man named Orchis. He was the son of a nymph and a satyr, and while attending a festival of the wine god Bacchus, he became drunk. He abused the priestess Bacchantes and was torn apart by the other guests at the party. When his sorrowful father asked Zeus to make him whole again, he refused but allowed flowers to grow from his remains. These were the first orchids. It should be noted that there are many variations of this story, but all do end with the creation of orchids from his remains.
Orchids exude undeniable charm and are symbolic of everything from life, love and happiness. As Eckhart Tolle, in his book A New Earth commented,‚ÄùHumans would increasingly be drawn to and fascinated by them [orchids]....They provided inspiration to countless artists, poets, and mystics..more fleeting, more ethereal, and more delicate, they are like messengers from another realm, like a bridge between the world of physical forms and the formless."
I am enamoured of the ephemeral beauty of the orchids and when I looked closely at the heart of this moth orchid,
‚ÄúWould I could bury my soul
Deep in its bosom
Listening to its
Hidden secrets‚Äù
Dr Tsguram
07/05/24, 1:31‚ÄØpm
Spirituality hidden in few lines... Yes, as a child even I used to come across many trees on the broad road in Mysore and loved to collect the flowers and used to be amazed at the shapes much like linga and naga.
07/05/24, 7:38‚ÄØam
I became aware of the teachings of Rennyo on reading the book ‚ÄúRennyo:The Second Founder of Shin Buddhism‚Äù. Various Buddhist sects celebrate and follow Buddha‚Äôs teachings through different practices, rituals, with emphasis on different aspects of his teachings. While other schools of Buddhism seek to ‚Äúattain‚Äù or ‚Äúrealize‚Äù enlightenment, the Shin Buddhist path focuses on simply listening and opening one‚Äôs heart to receiving it. ‚ÄúThe pursuit of enlightenment can become something like chasing after a mirage in the desert: You think you have arrived, only to find it disappear ‚Äú. Shin Buddhism emphasizes that one doesn‚Äôt have to become a monk or sit for hours in meditation and can experience this in everyday life through tuning the ears and the heart to listen to life unfolding around oneself.
Rennyo wrote 85 letters to convey his teachings. Let me draw attention to two excepts from it which made an impact on me. The first one is‚ÄùWhite Ashes‚Äù in which he urges us to reflect on life‚Äôs impermanence:
‚ÄúThe people we leave behind and the people who go before us, are more numerous than dewdrops that rest briefly on leaves and branches. Hence, I may have a radiant face in the morning, but in the evening, become no more than white ashes.‚Äù
In the second one on awareness, he comments:
‚ÄúAs the sun shines upon the earth, awakening into growth the seeds that lie dormant in the soil, may the Light of Wisdom shine into our minds and truly awaken us to our ignorance and by this insight stir us to strive for a life of deeper understanding and enlightenment.‚Äù
An observation much in tune with that of Sri Ramana Maharishi, ‚ÄúYour own Self-Realization is the greatest service you can render the world‚Äù.

18/05/24, 7:20‚ÄØam
When I first laid hands on Edward Fitzerald‚Äôs translation of Omar Khayyam‚Äôs ‚ÄòRubaiyat‚Äô I was mesmerised by its haunting beauty. In just four lines, the poems explored themes of love, fate, mortality, and the transient nature of life with elegance and simplicity. The verses offered a contemplative perspective on life, urging us to seize the moment and find joy in the face of life‚Äôs uncertainties. He alludes to the temporality of life in these deeply reflective words:
‚ÄúI saw the potter in the market yesterday
Pounding and pounding upon a piece of clay
‚ÄúBehold,‚Äù said the clay to the potter
Treat me gently for once like you, now I am clay.‚Äù
The tapestry of our lives is woven with diverse threads, some of them bleak and dark. Khayyam urges us to dance in the present and relish the beauty of each moment, embracing the ephemeral lives we lead, wholeheartedly and with joy.
‚ÄúSince neither truth nor certitude is at hand
Do not waste your life in doubt for a fairyland
O let us not refuse the goblet of wine
For, sober or drunken, in ignorance we stand‚Äù.
Khayyam‚Äôs verses are like delicate blossoms that bloom with timeless beauty and endless charm. It is hard to resist their irresistible allure.
‚ÄúCome, fill the Cup, and in the Fire of Spring
The Winter Garment of Repentance fling:
The Bird of Time has but a little time to flutter
And the bird is on the wing‚Äù.
It is a reminder to seize the moment, while we still have the wings and to soar!
(Omar Khayyam was born on this day, 18th May, in Nishapur, northern Persia)
Dr Raguram
19/05/24, 6:48‚ÄØam
It is an enchanting experience to watch birds. A new window opens up to unravel alluring secrets from another world. In that absorbing moment I become one with them.
Let me recollect an interesting poem about birding from Ogden Nash whose death anniversary is today.
‚ÄúBird watchers top my honours list.
I aimed to be one, but I missed.
Since I'm both myopic and astigmatic,
My aim turned out to be erratic,
And I, bespectacled and binocular,
Exposed myself to comment jocular.
We don't need too much birdlore, do we,
To tell a flamingo from a towhee:
Yet I cannot, and never will,
Unless the silly birds stand still.
And there's no enlightenment in a tour
Of ornithological literature.
Is yon strange creature a common chickadee,
Or a migrant alouette from Picardy?
You can rush to consult your Nature guide
And inspect the gallery inside,
But a bird in the open never looks
Like its picture in the birdie books-
Or if it once did, it has changed its plumage,
And plunges you back into ignorant gloomage.
That is why I sit here growing old by inches,
Watching a clock instead of finches,
But I sometimes visualize in my gin
The Audubon that I audubin‚Äù.

20/05/24, 6:50‚ÄØpm
Bees have been around for long. In Ancient Egypt, tears of the Sun God Ra turned into bees upon touching the ground.and in Ancient Greece, bee was a cult symbol for Artemis, goddess of wild nature. In Indian mythology, Honeybees form the string of Kama‚Äôs bowmade of sugarcane. In the words of the poet Kalidasa, Kama, ‚Äúbears the bow of Love; and on that bow, the lustrous string is made of bees‚Ä¶.Weaves a string of Bees with deft invention, To speed the missile when the bow is bent.‚Äù
It is believed that Brahma resides as a bee of Vishnu‚Äôs navel-lotus, humming vedic texts. There is also a mention about a goddess, Brahmari in Srimad Devi Bhagavatam;book 10, chapter 13. Bhramari, who slayed the demon Arunasura, is considered as the goddess of bees. Lakshmi tantra (9,41-43), also mentions her, ‚ÄúDuring the sixtieth era there will be one demon, called Aru·πáa who will do much harm to men and sages. Then I shall appear in bee-form incorporating innumerable bees, and I shall slay the mighty demon and rescue the three worlds. From then on people will praise me forever and address me as BhrƒÅmarƒ´.‚Äù Iconographically she is portrayed with scores of bees emanating from her hands. Brahmari is worshipped on the eighth night of the Navarathri festival. There is a temple for her in Kasauni. It is said that Adi Guru Shankaracharya spent sometime in the temple, which is situated at the top of a mount enclosed by a fort. Bhramari Pranayama is a yogic technique that consists of concentrating on the sound emulating a bee along with breath control. The vibration of sound produced is said to enhance the level of consciousness. So the next time you hear the hum of a bee, do not panic!
(Penned on the occasion of the World Bee Day, 20th May)
Dr Raguram
23/05/24, 7:13‚ÄØam
Buddha‚Äôs followers never officially celebrated his birthday, till it was formalized in May 1950, at the first conference of the World Fellowship of Buddhists in Colombo, Sri Lanka. It was agreed upon that the day of the full moon in May would be auspicious, due to Buddha attaining nirvana on a full moon day.
The natural world was ubiquitous in the Buddha‚Äôs life and teachings. Forests and woodland parks were the most common setting where people met the Buddha and listened to his teachings. Nature provided the backdrop and the context for his teachings and the natural settings played an important role in his awakening and his teachings. The important connection he saw between nature and the practices he taught is encapsulated in some of his utterances like this one;
‚ÄúIf we could see the miracle of a single flower clearly our whole life would change. ‚Äù
On this Buddha Purima day, it would be wonderful to become aware that sources of immense awareness is all around us in our everyday lives‚Ä¶let us pause and reflect.
