03/09/24, 10:10‚ÄØpm
I have heard his talks and very authentic are his words. How he was drawn to spirituality from journalism is very interesting. We used to listen to a series of lectures on Kathopanishad by Swami Tejomayanada of Chinmaya mission during COVID!
05/09/24, 7:31‚ÄØam
Teacher‚Äôs Day is about paying tribute with an abiding sense of gratitude to teachers who have shaped our journey in learning.
Our formal education starts within the premises of a school. I was fortunate to be a student in the Ramakrishna Mission School, North Branch, Chennai. Among all the teachers who taught us, the one who left a deep impact on me was Sri TS Ranganathan Sir, referred to TSR. He had a commanding presence and when he entered the classroom we were over awed with his demeanor. He was a science teacher but he could also teach us about English literature, geography and human anatomy with ease and √©lan. He was a polymath. He shared with us anecdotes from forgotten pages of history and opened our minds to explore unknown landscapes of learning. I was learning tennis and one day he called to ask me whether I would like to join him on the tennis court. The school had a tennis court not far away from his home. When I reached the place, I found him dressed in his usual attire, an immaculate panchakacham. Panchakacham is not a regular dhoti and has five pleats delicately tucked in, much akin to a nine yards‚Äô saree worn by women in traditional attire. It took me a while to register that he was going to play tennis in this rather complicated outfit. My reservations were put to rest however when he started to serve. It was a booming service that would be the envy of any seasoned tennis player. I struggled to return it. He didn‚Äôt make it easy but egged me on to respond to it. At the end of an hour I was sweating profusely! He patted me and said, ‚ÄúGood start!‚Äù. Sometimes he would ask me to tabulate the results of the exam papers in his home and on completion of the task, I would be enthralled listening to him playing the harmonium.
TSR lit the fire to awaken the joy of learning which was not just confined to the classroom. Borrowing a saying from Robert Frost, he was ‚Äúnot a teacher, but an awakener.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
06/09/24, 8:10‚ÄØam
Mahakuta, an important centre of Chalukya art and architecture is nestled amidst a grove of kadamba trees in a peaceful village, not very far away from Badami. Within the temple complex there are a number of temples, situated around an ancient water tank. Unfortunately, most of the sculptures in the temples have eroded with time. When I walked over to the small Sangameshwara temple, I found a few delicately carved sculptures on its outer wall. The most striking one among them was that of Bhu Varaha. There are three common depictions of Varaha: Bhu Varaha is usually represented standing while that of Pralaya Varaha and Yajna Varaha are in sitting forms. In this stunning sculpture, Bhu Varaha is shown with the head of a boar and the body of a man with four hands. Two hands are holding the shankha and chakra. He is lifting the goddess of earth, Bhudevi, who is safely ensconced in his folded elbow of his left upper hand. The right lower hand rests on his leg. At the bottom are the naga and nagini, with hands folded in devotion. The ornamentation, though delicate, is quite sparse. The graceful, kinetic energy in this depiction has a lasting allure.
There are several versions of the Varaha legend right from the Shatapatha Brahmana. The most commonly associated legend is that of Varaha lifting the earth, personified as the goddess Bhudevi, out of the cosmic ocean. When the demon Hiranyaksha stole the earth and hid her in the primordial waters, Lord Vishnu appeared as Varaha to rescue her. Varaha slew the demon and retrieved the Earth from the ocean and restored Bhudevi to her place in the universe.
What is interesting is how geological events and processes become part of thos narration. Varaha as an avatar of God Vishnu saved the Earth by lifting it out of the cosmic ocean and restoring it back. While the legend symbolizes the triumph of good over evil it also emphasizes the need to protect and restore the environment, especially on the background of increasing climate change now. With 70 percent of the planet being covered in water, the oceans are important drivers of the global climate. Increasing greenhouse gases from human activities are altering the oceans before our eyes. Greenhouse gases trap energy from the sun, which the oceans absorb, causing them to warm. As the excessive heat and energy warms the ocean, the change in temperature leads to unparalleled cascading effects, including rise in sea levels.
Today as our earth faces serious threats from climate change, we should draw inspiration from the legend of Varaha to be proactive in saving the planet.
(Penned on the occasion of Varaha Jayanthi, which is observed on 6th September 2024)
Dr Raguram
07/09/24, 7:56‚ÄØam
Nritya Ganapati is the 15th among the 32 forms of Ganesha. This exquisitely carved sculpture of Nritya Ganapati (Dancing Ganesha) is from Chennakeshava temple at Somanathapura. A significant aspect of Nritya Ganapati‚Äôs imagery is the setting of his dance, beneath the Kalpavriksha, or the wish-fulfilling tree. This choice of location is not arbitrary. The Kalpavriksha in Hindu mythology is known to grant all wishes. Nritya Ganapati‚Äôs dance under this tree thus becomes a metaphor for the joyous and bountiful nature of the cosmos. He is depicted with four hands. His left foot is firmly placed on the ground whereas the right one is lifted up and bent sideways at the knee. He is bejewelled and intricate ornaments decorate various parts of his body. Despite his bulky disposition, there is a lightness in his stance.
Oothukadu Venkata Subba Iyer, popularly known as Venkata Kavi, was a brilliant composer of the 18th Century who made immense contributions to the Carnatic Music repertoire. One of his memorable composition is on Nritya Ganapati, titled ‚ÄòAnandha Narthana Ganapathim‚Äô in the raga Naatai, which begins with these lines:
‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§® ‡§ó‡§£‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á ‚Äì (‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç / ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ )
‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡•ê ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§ú‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶)
Ananda nartana gaNapatim bhAvayE
chidAkAra mUlAdhAra OmkAra gajavadanam paramam param (Ananda)
I meditate on the joyous dancing Ganapati always
Whose form is pure consciousness, who lives in the muladhara chakra and who is the form of Om, the elephant faced one, the supreme one.
Though we recognize Ganesha in various forms, in Adi Shankara‚Äôs words, he is formless Supreme Brahman. 'Ajam Nirvikalpam Niraakaaramekam,' Ganesha is Ajam (unborn), Nirvikalpa (attributeless), Niraakaar (formless) and he symbolizes Brahman, the absolute consciousness.
Dr Raguram
09/09/24, 10:33‚ÄØam
Literacy is more than just reading and writing. At its simplest, it is a tool for meaningful engagement with society. It shapes and enhances our experience of the world.
Kerala had 49.5% literacy rate before independence. This has scaled up in the ensuing years and now Kerala has the highest literacy rate among the states of India. Kerala's literacy success can be attributed to a number of factors, including its history, social reform, and the Kerala Education Act of 1958. As of March 2023, the literacy rate in Kerala was 94%. In spite of this remarkable achievement there are pockets where literacy hasn‚Äôt made inroads as anticipated. For instance, in Wayanad which has 36 per cent of the state's tribal population, the literacy rate amongst tribals is lower than the district's average literacy rate and the literacy rate of the general population.
It is on this background that we got involved with the education of tribal children in the region. Wayanad Girijana Seva Trust was initiated by two youngsters who have been committed to this cause and we started working with them. The need was for a secure, hospitable environment where these children could stay and learn. Hence, in the initial phases the focus was on infrastructure, furnished class rooms, hostel, kitchen etc. With the help of volunteers and committed teachers, the educational input has also scaled up over the years. A few years back we added a learning resource centre, fully equipped with laptops to advance their learning.
What I have noticed in the past two decades, is the cascading impact of formal education among the children. Children, especially the girls, have become more assured, confident while keeping alive their tribal identity. Literacy has expanded their ambit of learning and capabilities.
It has been a journey of learning for us too and there are continuing challenges in maintaining and sustaining the process. We have built bridges of learning for these marginalized children with the fond hope that it kindles the spirit of enquiry to discover and realize the potentials within.
And the spirit flows on‚Ä¶
(8th September was the International Literacy Day)
Dr Raguram
14/09/24, 9:18‚ÄØam
One of the temples not often visited in Khajuraho is the Vamana temple. Set amidst a verdant, green landscape, it is a sight to behold with its spire reaching up like a beautiful mountain. Like rest of the temples in Khajuraho, the outer walls of the sanctum are adorned with intricate carvings depicting scenes from Hindu mythology. In the sanctum is a striking idol of Vamana, the fifth incarnation of Lord Vishnu. Vamana is the first incarnation whem Lord Vishnu appeared in a full human form, as a dwarf.
The legend of the Vamana avatar is narrated in the Rigveda and other scriptures. Mahabali, son of Virochan and grandson of Prahlad, was a generous, mighty monarch who was adored by his subjects. He was granted the boon of immortality by Lord Brahma and he continued to expand the frontiers of his empire. He conquered all the three realms: Heaven, Earth and the Underworld. Immensely troubled by growing powers, the Devas appealed to Lord Vishnu to intervene and restore the balance of power. Responding to their prayers, Lord Vishnu incarnated as Vamana, the dwarf and went to the Yaga that was being performed by Mahabali. During the Yaga, people could ask Mahabali for and receive anything they wanted. Mahabali bade Vamana to ask for anything that he wanted, like jewels, land, forests etc, without hesitation. Vamana denied all these politely and asked merely for three paces of land. Looking at Vamana‚Äôs diminutive stature, Bali said, ‚ÄòSo be it; pace and take it.‚Äô The dwarf Vamana suddenly grew in size into a giant and with one step measured the Earth and with another the entire Heaven. As there was no room left for the third step that had been granted, Mahabali humbly knelt under Vamana‚Äôs foot and offered his head. As Bali sank deep into the underworld, he heard his subjects wailing in grief for their much loved king. Seeing this, Vamana granted Mahabali one last boon. The boon was the permission to visit his subjects on Earth once a year. Thus, Mahabali returns every year to visit his people and the land that he had once ruled. Onam commemorates the annual visit of this legendary king from the underworld to his former kingdom, the land of Kerala.
Parsva Ekadashi which is observed today is also associated with the legend of Mahabali and Vamana Avatar of Lord Vishnu and is also referred to as Vamana Ekadashi. It is fascinating to note that the Onam festival follows the same legend and takes place around the same time of year.
Dr Raguram
14/09/24, 7:04‚ÄØpm
Such a beautiful way of putting across the basic tenet of life. Absolutely true.. To let go means freedom... It helps us to grow, mature spiritually...
14/09/24, 7:21‚ÄØpm
An unusual sculpture. In fact he goes to Bali Chakravarthi after his parents do the thread ceremony and the sacred thread is so well sculpted!
22/09/24, 9:22‚ÄØam
Like William Carlos William, Dannie Abse (22 September 1923 - 28 September 2014), was a physician poet. Unlike the former, who largely kept medicine out of his poetry, Abse wanted to ‚Äúhear the heartbeat of words‚Äù and wrote about patients and the diseases they had, with tenderness. Even a stethoscope is infused with poetic insights, transmitting sounds ‚Äúover young women‚Äôs tense abdomens . . . of creation and in a dead man‚Äôs chest, the silence before creation began.‚Äù
His poem, ‚ÄòPortrait of an Old Doctor‚Äù begins with these beautiful, reflective lines:
‚ÄúLover of music more than his textbooks‚Äô
arrythmic prose and dated, almost dangerous
his Conybeare and his Boyd‚Äôs Pathology.
(Notes in the margin by the student he was)
What was it all about? Blunderbuss drugs
prescribed to ease the patient. And moonbeams.
A composer‚Äîa Beethoven, a Smetana‚Äîit seemed, could be deaf, but not a doctor.
He had been a conÔ¨Ådence man for the patient.
That‚Äôs how it was in the Theatre of Disease
and, at the Ô¨Ånal act, he had lifted
his stethoscope to listen
as if to Mozart.
Then, silently, relatives and friends Ô¨Åled out.
No applause. None for Hippocrates‚Äô art.‚Äù
Let me end this post with this poignant poem of Abse
‚ÄòMoonbright‚Äô
Afterwards, late, walking home from hospital,
that December hour too blatantly moonbright
- such an unworldly moon so widely round,
an orifice of scintillating arctic light -
I thought how the effrontery of a similar moon,
a Pirandello moon that would make men howl,
would, in future, bring back the eidolon
of you, father, propped high on pillow
your mouth ajar, your nerveless hand in mine.
At home, feeling hollow, I shamelessly wept
- whether for you or myself I do not know.
Tonight a bracing wind makes my eyes cry
while a cloud dociles an impudent moon
that is and was, and is again, and was.
Men become mortal the night their fathers die.‚Äù
Lastly, at this stage in my life, these lines from his poem ‚ÄòTalking to Myself‚Äô ‚ÄúIn the mildew of age/all pavements slope uphill‚Äô touch a deep chord within‚Ä¶
Dr Raguram
23/09/24, 9:14‚ÄØam
On September 21, Max Schur, Freud‚Äôs personal physician visited him and was aghast to see him looking pale and quite wasted. Freud took his doctor‚Äôs hand and said, ‚ÄúMy dear Schur, you certainly remember our first talk. You promised me then not to forsake me when the time comes. Now it is nothing but torture and makes no sense anymore.‚Äù Schur responded stating that he had not forgotten the promise he made. Freud thanked him and told Schur to ‚Äútalk it over with Anna, and if she thinks it‚Äôs right, make an end of it.‚Äù Schur spoke to Anna and she sorrowfully concurred with her father‚Äôs wish. Then Schur gave Freud an injection of three centigrams of morphine, a dose much stronger than he would have used if the objective had only been to relieve pain. He was now assisting him to die a peaceful death. He gave Freud another injection that day, then a third on September 22. Freud lapsed into a coma, but he held on to life. At 3AM in the morning on Saturday, September 23, 1939, Sigmund Freud breathed his last. Three days later, his body was cremated and his ashes placed in an ancient Greek urn, originally gifted to him by his friend Marie Bonaparte.
Many years before, Freud had made it abundantly clear as to how he wanted to die as he never wanted to live without his mental capacities intact. He wrote to his friend Oskar Pfister, ‚ÄúWith all the resignation before destiny that suits an honest man, I have one wholly secret entreaty: only no invalidism, no paralysis of one‚Äôs powers through bodily misery. Let us die in harness, as King Macbeth says.‚Äù
Freud left the world with a certain degree of composure. In Nietzsche‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúThe most fortunate author is one who is able to say as an old man that all he had of life giving, invigorating, uplifting enlightening thoughts and feelings still lives on in his writings, and that he himself is only the gray ash, while the fire has been rescued and carried forth everywhere.‚Äù
The last book Freud read was Balzac‚Äôs La Peau de Chagrin (The Wild Ass‚Äôs Skin). The protagonist, Rapheal de Valentin, gains possession of a wild donkey‚Äôs skin and is granted all he wishes. The magical object has the power to fulfil its owner's every wish but carries a heavy price: With every wish the owner's remaining time in life is reduced. On finishing the book, Freud told Schur, ‚ÄúThis was the proper book for me to read.‚Äù
Mark Edmundson has written a very perceptive book on Freud‚Äôs last days, ‚ÄòThe Death Of Sigmund Freud.‚Äô The book ends with these words ‚ÄúToward the person who has died we adopt a special attitude: something like admiration for someone who has accomplished a very difficult task.‚Äù
In the words of Sheena Blackhall
‚ÄúIt was Saturday, under the sign of Libra
When he crossed, with the aid of morphine,
(that child of Morpheus, Greek God of Dreams)
Into the world of the dead.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
24/09/24, 4:33‚ÄØpm
Adam Schmalholz, an American songwriter and National Poetry Slam champion from Los Angeles, California. Schmalholz describes his poetry as a reflection of his own experiences and life lessons.
24/09/24, 4:34‚ÄØpm
Adam Schmalholz, an American songwriter and National Poetry Slam champion from Los Angeles, California. Schmalholz describes his poetry as a reflection of his own experiences and life lessons.
25/09/24, 9:17‚ÄØam
Internet is an immense ocean swirling with humongous amount of information. Sometimes by sheer coincidence an unknown pearl emerges from its depth. A few days ago, I was typing the word luminous in the search box and by mistake typed ‚Äòn‚Äô instead of ‚Äòl‚Äô and a mysterious word ‚Äònuminous‚Äô emerged. Curious to know further I googled about the word and found that it is credited to Rudolf Otto who was an eminent German theologian in the early part of twentieth century. Rudolf is regarded as one of the most influential scholars of comparative religion. He travelled to India twice, mastered Sanskrit and translated many ancient Hindu texts into German.
I also came across an interesting book summarizing his work, ‚ÄòIndia's Religion of Grace and Christianity Compared and Contrasted‚Äô which was dedicated to Sri Krishnaraja Wadiyar. When I was reading the book, I got to know more about his concept of the ‚ÄòNuminous‚Äô, an experience that, in his view, underlies all spiritual quests. According to him, it has three components, each designated with a Latin phrase: mysterium tremendum et fascinans. As mysterium, the numinous is entirely different from anything we experience in ordinary life. It evokes a reaction of transcendental silence. But the numinous is also a mysterium tremendum. Initially it provokes terror because of its overwhelming power. Finally, the numinous presents itself as fascinans, as merciful and gracious. Rudolf emphasized that it is essentially nonrational, subjective, and cannot be expressed in language. In his opinion, the numinous is a universal aspect of human spirituality and is at the core of all spiritual experience across various cultures and religions. His notion of the numinous remains an important framework for understanding the deeply transformative and awe-inspiring aspects of human spirituality.
I found his concept of ‚ÄòNuminous‚Äô, quite interesting as it is reflective of the perennial human quest to explore the deeper aspects of individual consciousness and seek its connection to something vast and infinite. For me I often have a glimpse of that state in my sojourns in nature. We only have to lift our accustomed veils to experience it.
(Rudolf Otto; September 25th 1869 - March 6th 1937)
Dr Raguram
25/09/24, 6:01‚ÄØpm
Very interesting...What he says appears to be True in the case of highly spritualised souls and it is something one can experience as you said if we unmask.
27/09/24, 9:36‚ÄØam
Kay Ryan, the 16th Poet Laureate of USA has a distinctive, original voice. Her poems are short, not more than twenty lines, some even shorter, replete with intricate wordplay. I found the rich, imaginative nature of her poems quite alluring. She has written several poems about birds and this particular one is permanently installed at the Central Park.
How Birds Sing
‚ÄúOne is not taxed;
one need not practice;
one simply tips
the throat back
over the spine axis
and asserts the chest.
The wings and the rest
compress a musical
squeeze which floats
a series of notes
upon the breeze.‚Äù
There are many entrancing sounds in nature. Listening to the symphonic serenade emerging from the fragile throats of birds is a magical experience. I often immerse myself in that moment, swaying with their haunting, melodic airwaves. In the words of the poet Maria Rainer Rilke, ‚ÄúA birdsong can even for a moment, make the whole world into a sky within us.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
05/10/24, 8:53‚ÄØam
On some days, the azure blue sky in Bangalore transforms itself in a moment to a painter‚Äôs palette. Gazing at the sky dappled with myriad colours inspires a sense of wonder. Sometime I imagine myself to be a bird drifting amidst the vast firmament and my imagination takes wings in its metaphorical wings. I wonder whether Flaubert alluded to this when he wrote, "If one always looked at the skies, one would end up with wings."
Our imagination is boundless and its transcendental power energizes and unfetters us.
‚ÄúImagination takes flight
On wings afloat
Poems unfold
In nature‚Äôs embrace‚Äù
Dr Raguram
08/10/24, 9:10‚ÄØam
Navratri is devoted to the worship of Goddess Durga in her various forms. Katyayani is one among the Navadurgas, the nine forms of the Goddess, who is worshipped on the sixth fay of Navratri. She is a fierce manifestation of Shakti, the divine female power.
In the Devi Bhagavata Purana, it is mentioned that Rishi Katyayana was a great devotee of Mother Shakti. He wished for the goddess to be born in his household in the form of his daughter. For this, Sage Katyayana did severe penance for years. Meanwhile, the malevolent Mahishasura was wreaking havoc, tormenting the gods relentlessly. Seeking a solution, the divine trinity of Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma emitted flames that coalesced into the formidable form of Goddess Katyayani. Each of them gifted her a weapon to vanquish Mahishasura. She then embarked on a mission, engaged Mahishasura in a fearsome battle, defeated and vanquished him. Hence, she is also referred to as Mahishasura Mardhini.
This delicately sculpted panel in the inner wall of the Chidambaram temple depicts Katyayani with eighteen hands, her leg firmly entrenched on the neck of Mahishasura.
The legend of Katyayani is not merely a relic of a bygone era but an inspiring metaphor of resilience and empowerment, which women can draw upon in their daily lives even now. In a world beset with discrimination, inequality, and injustice faced by women, her story illustrates that courage, coupled with an unshakable resolve, can be a continuing source of motivation to conquer adversities and challenge norms even in the face of seemingly insurmountable odds.
Dr Raguram
09/10/24, 10:55‚ÄØpm
Sculpture full of energy and it is important to draw inspiration to fight the evils withinüôè
10/10/24, 10:17‚ÄØam
On this World Mental Health Day, let me draw attention to Dorothea Buck, an inspiring figure who espoused the cause of the mentally ill with extraordinary zeal and commitment.
When Dorothea was just 19 years old, she was emotionally distraught at the prospect of yet another war and the attendant suffering. She was diagnosed as schizophrenic and was confined to an asylum for nine months where she was subjected to a range of harsh physical treatments. Under the Nazi-era ‚Äúhereditary health law‚Äù protocols, which had been imposed to prevent so-called genetic impurities from being transmitted to future generations, she was also sterilized. When she was released, she was barred from marrying and denied a career as a teacher. She continued to have periods of psychotic episodes which were poorly treated. Undeterred by these adversities, she started writing about mental health, giving lectures, holding seminars and helping to start organizations to protect the rights of mentally ill persons.
In her talks and writings, Dorothea continuously emphasized that mental health professionals should provide a safe space and hear the stories of personal suffering, rather than seeing them as soulless objects of study. She drew attention to the importance of a three-way discourse in clinical settings involving the patients, their key relatives and their doctors. She called this process as a ‚Äútrialogue.‚Äù
Dorothea trained herself to be a sculptor and this work of hers is called, ‚ÄúMother and Child.‚Äù Speaking about, it she remarked that such kind of intimate personal relationship between doctors and psychotic patients is ‚Äúmissing in today‚Äôs psychiatry‚Ä¶ the unrelatedness of psychiatrists to their patients contradicted everything human.‚Äù
Dorothea died on Oct. 9, 2019, at the age of 102.
Dorothea‚Äôs autobiography ‚ÄúOn the Trail of the Morning Star: Psychosis as Self-Discovery‚Äù, was originally published in German. Translated into English in 2024, it is available as a free download in Research Gate. It is one of the most moving accounts of her lived experiences and tryst with mental illness and I would urge every mental health professional to read it.
Advocacy about mental health is not merely in the realm of professionals. There is an urgent need to provide spaces, where the voice of people who enter and pas through the gates of immense emotional suffering can be heard.
Dr Raguram
11/10/24, 8:48‚ÄØam
This is a beautiful sculpture of Vishnu Durga at the Melakadambur temple which dates back to 12th century, constructed during the reign of Kulottunga Chola. She is four-armed and carries conch and discus in her upper handd. Her right hand is in ‚Äòabhaya posture‚Äô. She is standing in samabhanga pose, which means she is resting her weight equally on both feet. Vishnu Durga is usually depicted in a peaceful form (Saumya Vadana).
Dr Raguram
12/10/24, 9:06‚ÄØam
Vijayadashami commemorates the triumph of Lord Rama over Ravana. The Yudh Kanda section of the Ramayana is replete with details of the fierce battle which lasted for nearly seven days. The duel was so intense that both the armies stood watching the ferocious exchanges. Ravana fought valiantly and fired his arrows in the direction of the flagstaff fixed on Rama's chariot. But none of his arrows could reach the Indra's chariot that Rama rode on. All of Ravana's arrows fell to the ground. Rama's arrows, however, tore asunder Ravana's flag-staff which fell and entered the earth. Overcome with rage, Ravana showered a stream of arrows aiming them at the horses that pulled Rama's chariot. But they had no impact on the horses. This enraged Ravana further and he rained a number of objects in the direction of Rama's chariot. That included gadaa (maces), hathora (iron bludgeons), chakras (discs), mountains and uprooted trees, axes etc. When even that failed, Ravana covered the sky with his missiles. Ravana then tried to attack Matali, Indra‚Äôs charioteer. This angered Rama and he aimed the arrows at Ravana's heads. The heads fell down one by one, but they grew back. Finally, Matali, suggested that "To kill Ravana you must use the dreaded arrow of Brahma, given to you by Agastya Muni, which never misses its target". Heeding to his advice, Rama shot the divine arrow, which found its mark and pierced Ravana in the heart, finally killing him.
Amruteshwara Temple in the Chikkamagalur district of Karnataka is embellished with some of the most beautiful carvings of scenes from Ramayana and Mahabharatha. These friezes are quite small in size and showcase the extraordinary skill and craftsmanship of the sculptors. This particular one depicts the battle scene between Rama and Ravana. I have merged two adjacent panels together to form a composite image. The size of the actual panel is as depicted in the photograph!
Dr Raguram
14/10/24, 10:16‚ÄØam
Jos√© Emilio Pacheco, revered as one of Mexico‚Äôs literary giants, deftly wove the rich tapestry of Mexican culture and its landscapes in his works. His poems offer vivid descriptions of Mexico‚Äôs diverse ecosystems. These landscapes are not mere settings but are intertwined with his deep reflections about their ecosystem. This particular poem is a living testimony to the transformative power of his words;
INSISTENCE
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs talk about snow once more let‚Äôs say
its cardinal virtue is that it‚Äôs quiet
It knows how to be born with impeccable smoothness in the night
and when we wake we see it has claimed
the earth and the trees
The snow is all around you today, where will it go?
The snow that spins interminably around the city
and the house
will take off into thin air
again be cloud and water
then snow once more
You don‚Äôt have its easy adaptable nature
You‚Äôll go on and die and be buried
You will be the clod of earth the snow settles on‚Äù
When we read a poem like this, we enter the imaginative world of the author. It is a kind of conversation, a sharing of experiences. As Pacheco commented, "I like poetry to be the interior voice, the voice no one hears, the voice of the person reading it. That is how the 'I' becomes 'you', the 'you' becomes 'I', and in the act of reading is born the 'we' that only exists in that intimate, full moment of reading."
Dr Raguram
15/10/24, 1:23‚ÄØpm
I understand that today is World Students‚Äô Day to commemorate Dr Abdul Kalam‚Äôs birthday. He was a great motivator of students and always encouraged them to ask questions in his interactions with them. He also had a website wherein students could raise question on a wide variety of subjects. He even dedicated his book ‚ÄòIgnited Minds‚Äô to a class XII student, Snehal Thakkar. According to him, ‚Äú a very important characteristic of a student is to question.‚Äù
During our training period in NIMHANS, we were enveloped in an ambiance of open discussion that encouraged questioning. Seminars, case conferences were active crucibles replete with thoughtful and engaging questioning by trainees. On many occasions, these would spill over to the hostel mess for more animated exchanges!
Questioning lies at the heart of active learning. It is like planting seeds of thought. They can create spaces to reflect on new ideas and perceptions. Unfortunately, the trend to question seems to be declining. In many academic presentations across various settings, I invariably notice that students are reticent to ask questions. Is it because as a culture, we overvalue speaking and privilege it over questioning? Or is it because we are educated in a system that implicitly silences questioning and assigns value only to ‚Äòcorrect answers‚Äô? Perhaps teachers and ‚Äògurus‚Äô feel uneasy being challenged and implicitly discourage questioning?
Historically, the art of questioning was valorised as an important avenue of learning especially in the spiritual realm, across all cultures. For instance, Prashna Upanishad consists of a series philosophical poems presented as questions (prashna) posed by various seekers and responded to by Sage Pippalada. Perhaps it is time to revitalize the ‚ÄòArt of Questioning‚Äô!
In the words of Naguib Mahfouz, the Nobel Laureate, ‚ÄúYou can tell whether a man is clever by his answers. You can tell whether a man is wise by his questions.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
19/10/24, 12:39‚ÄØpm
Sir Thomas Browne (October 19, 1605 - October 19, 1682), was a physician and philosopher, who wrote on a wide array of subjects, including science, medicine, religion, and the esoteric. One particular work that I personally find fascinating to read is ‚ÄòReligio Medici‚Äô, a book of his reflections. Translated as "The Religion of a Doctor," it offers an interesting perspective of views on various scientific and religious subjects; ‚ÄúNot picked from the leaves of any author, but bred amongst the weeds and tares of mine own brain.‚Äù William Osler, who is credited as "the father of modern medicine," considered ‚ÄòReligio Medici‚Äô so influential to his career that he reportedly memorized it by heart.
I would like to draw attention to two of his reflections that made an impact on me. Cleaving a boundary between the personal attitudes and beliefs and professional responsibilities can often be a daunting task especially in clinical work. Browne urges that there needs to be a clear separation between the spheres of religion and that of science, especially in the field of medicine. He underscores the importance that a doctor must not only tolerate but also respect individual patients' religious beliefs, even if they conflict with his own. Physicians personal, religious beliefs should not impact the way he treats his patients. This stems largely from Browne's own belief that individual churches and sects should not "usurp the gates of heaven, and turn the key against each other; and thus we go to heaven against each other‚Äôs' wills, conceits, and, with as much uncharity as arrogance, do err."
In a period where the moral aspects of medical practice are under strain, Browne draws attention to the fact that a strong moral component is at the core in the practice of medicine. To him, medicine is more than a trade, it is a moral pursuit built on a foundation of service to others. "For by compassion," Browne writes, "we make others' misery our own, and so, by relieving them, we relieve ourselves also." When a disease was beyond Browne's capacity to cure, he felt uneasy and was reluctant to charge the patient any fee, calling this "scarce honest gain."
‚ÄúWho in the world am I? Ah, that's the great puzzle‚Äù pondered Alice in Wonderland. Often, our ideas, beliefs and perspectives about life become clear when we introspect and ‚ÄòReligio Medici‚Äô is one such example. Sir Thomas Browne is like a person who is sitting on the edge of a stream, looking at his reflection in the ripples of water, plunging himself in the process into the depths of self-introspection, articulating them with clarity and insight in this small book of memoirs.
As Browne observes in this book, we must ‚ÄúBe able to be alone. Lose not the advantage of solitude. and the society of thyself.‚Äù Often the privacy of aloneness provides a space for deep, perceptive reflections.
( When I was typing these lines, my attention was drawn to this small terracotta figure on the desk and I thought that this image adeptly epitomizes Browne‚Äôs observations)
Dr Raguram
22/10/24, 8:44‚ÄØam
It has been raining continuously over the past few days in Bangalore and the sun is finally up today. Rains are an abiding source of inspiration for poets. It is used as a metaphor for a wide range of emotions: renewal, cleansing, melancholy amongst others. This particular poem ‚ÄòThe Rainy Day‚Äô by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow was written after the death of his first wife. It is a contemplative poem representing the feelings of sadness and isolation of the poet on a gloomy, rainy day. The sun peeking from behind the clouds offers a glimmer of hope. The poem ends with the evocative line "Into each life some rain must fall‚Äù, meaning that anyone of us might feel despondent (some days must be dark and dreary), at some time in our life, but the ‚Äúthe shining sun‚Äù will always be around to dispel the dark clouds within.
THE RAINY DAY
The day is cold, and dark, and dreary;
It rains, and the wind is never weary;
The vine still clings to the mouldering wall,
But at every gust the dead leaves fall,
And the day is dark and dreary.
My life is cold, and dark, and dreary;
It rains, and the wind is never weary;
My thoughts still cling to the mouldering past,
But the hopes of youth fall thick in the blast,
And the days are dark and dreary.
Be still, sad heart, and cease repining;
Behind the clouds is the sun still shining;
Thy fate is the common fate of all,
Into each life some rain must fall,
Some days must be dark and dreary.
Dr Raguram
28/10/24, 8:57‚ÄØam
Just came back after an enthralling sojourn at Ellora and Ajanta. After spending more than two hours savouring the majestic Kailasa temple, we made our way to other caves. Amongst them Cave 10 stands out an enchanting edifice. It is also called The Vishwakarma Cave and is locally known as the Sutar-ka-jhopra (Carpenter's hut). Constructed around 7th century AD, this is the only chaitya in these series of caves in Ellora.
Once we entered the massive cave, we were overwhelmed by its sheer architectural beauty. The apsidal hall is quite long and at the far end of the cave was a huge stupa with a simple circular base, hemispherical dome and a square structure on top. In front of it is a colossal Buddha seated with the Dharmachakra mudra. Dharmachakra mudra holds deep metaphysical significance in Buddhism. It embodies the union of method (Upaya) and wisdom (Prajna), which are essential in pursuing enlightenment. By positioning the hands in front of the heart or the left side of the chest, the mudra signifies teachings emanating directly from Buddha's compassionate heart. A large Bodhi tree is carved at the back and on both sides are the attendants. The outstanding feature of the chaitya is it‚Äôs a vaulted roof in which ribs (known as triforium) have been carved in the rock imitating the wooden beams. Even the wooden pins at the joints of beams and lintels have been carefully sculpted in stone.
There was hardly anyone around and the guide asked us to stand with our back aligned to the stone pillars. He then stood in a corned are slowly started chanting, ‚ÄúBuddham Charanam Gachchami‚Äù in a soft, low voice. The rhythmic, repetitive chanting reverberated in a magical way in the vast hall and we were immersed in that hypnotizing soundscape. We could feel the vibration of the mellifluous chants cruising through the stone pillars, energizing us. It was not merely a vibrant realm of sacred sounds but a sonic journey that unlocked the doors within.
Dr Raguram
29/10/24, 8:54‚ÄØam
The first cave one comes across in Ajanta is cave 1. It is not the first one built chronologically and perhaps the last one to be completed. It is the first cave one encounters when approaching the complex from the north side of the horseshoe-shaped cliff. The construction of the cave started around 466 CE and there were several disruptions. Emperor Harisena of the Vakataka dynasty played a crucial role in executing it.
As we entered the cool, dark interior of the cave, our attention was drawn to the colossal sculpture of the Buddha in the sanctum. He is seated on a throne in the padmasana, with his hands in the Dharmachakra Mudra. Dharmachakra in Sanskrit means the 'Wheel of Dharma'. This mudra symbolizes one of the most important moments in the life of Buddha, the occasion when he delivered his first sermon after his Enlightenment in the Deer Park at Sarnath.
On the left wall adjoining the sanctum is the painting of Padmapani. It is perhaps one of most iconic paintings of Ajanta and has adorned the walls of many houses. I stood in front of it, totally transfixed, devouring as much as I could of its stately elegance. Padmapani, the bearer of the lotus is portrayed holding the flower in his right hand. There is an unbroken flow of the body which is gracefully inclined slightly to the right side. The left-arm is tied with a ribbon. A high crown adorns his head and around his neck is a pearl necklace. There is a long string of jewellery over the left shoulder, falling across the chest. The long, sharp nose, highlighted with warm colours and inward shading, enhances the serene beauty of his face.
I closed my eyes for a moment and then looked at the deeply introspective, lotus-shaped, half-closed eyes. This is often referred to as the ‚Äòadamantine‚Äô gaze. I wonder whether through his half closed eyes, Padmapani is urging us to withdraw our awareness from the distractions of the outside world and look within, indicating that all the answers we seek are inside us. I was immersed in the overwhelming aura of boundless compassion radiating from Padmapani‚Äôs visage and it was difficult to prise myself away from the celestial painting. As I was leaving the cave, I was reminded of Rumi‚Äôs counsel, ‚ÄúListen with ears of tolerance. See through the eyes of compassion. Speak with the language of love‚Äù
Dr Raguram
30/10/24, 8:51‚ÄØam
In the adjoining wall to the right of the main sanctum in Cave 1 is an interesting painting of Vajrapani, one of the earliest bodhisattvas in Mahayana Buddhism. He is the protector of Buddha and symbolizes the Buddha's power. Padmapani manifests Buddha's compassion and Vajrapani establishes Buddha‚Äôs power as well as the power of all five Tathagatas. It is interesting to note tht Indra and BrahmƒÅ, are recast as Vajrapa·πái and Padmapa·πái, bearers of the vajra and lotus respectively.
In this painting, Vajrapani is bejewelled, regally attired with an elaborate crown. There is an understated aura of a stately presence. Despite his power, Vajrapani has a peaceful countenance.
Vajra Vidarana Sutra, explains Vajrapani‚Äôs nature thus;
‚ÄúCondensed within you alone,
Is the power and strength of all the Buddhas.
Manifesting in the form of the enlightened Vajra,
I pay homage to you Vajra Vidarana, the Subduer.‚Äù
Vajrapani‚Äôs energy is not mere force, not even power in any sense. It is what the Buddhist tradition calls Virya: ‚Äúenergy in pursuit of the good.‚Äù Most of this energy remains dormant within us. In Vajrayana meditation, visualizing Vajrapani and chanting the mantra, ‚ÄúOm Vajrapani Hum‚Äù ushers a vajra-like enlightened awareness to negotiate the inner and outer fears with a sense of spiritual empowerment.

30/10/24, 10:53‚ÄØpm
What a beautiful sculpture no words can describe. I have seen Ajantha caves but could not go to Ellora. Thank you Sir for this feast to the eyes. Buddha's teachings I feel has the essence of spirituality.
02/11/24, 8:50‚ÄØam
Balipadyami is observed the day after Diwali in Karnataka. On this day let us recall the story of Mahabali. According to the legend, once upon a time, there was an asura called Bali, also known as Mahabali, who conquered three worlds and was famous for his generosity. Over the course of time he annexed the celestial world too. Unhappy with it, Indra, king of the celestial regions, requested Vishnu to deal with Bali. Vishnu took the form of a dwarf, Vamana, and asked Mahabali for three paces of land. Mahabali granted it without a second thought. The dwarf then suddenly transformed into a giant, and with two paces, he claimed the sky, the earth, and all possessions that Mahabali had. Vamana then asked him where should he take the third step. The only thing Mahabali had left was his body. So he told Vamana to step on his head. Vamana did so and pushed Bali underground into Patal. Mahabali, however, was granted a wish to visit the earth once a year to meet the people who loved him very much.
One of the most beautiful depictions of this myth is in Cave II in Badami: the Vamana-Trivikrama sculpture is carved on the western wall of the mukhamandapa. In the centre of the panel Vishnu is portrayed as Trivikrama. Eight-armed, his right leg is placed firmly on the ground, while the left leg is raised up to the level of chest, with Mahabali underneath it. Of the eight hands, seven hold khadga, bana, gada, chakra, sankha, khetaka and chapa. The remaining left hand is stretched out parallel to the raised leg. A soldier with a sword is shown falling upside down, failing in his attempt to attack Vishnu. A dwarfish person who is portrayed in a royal outfit holds the right leg of Trivikrama firmly, to obstruct his measuring the paces; he is identified as Namuchi, the son of Bali. On the lower left part of this panel, Vamana‚Äôs figure has been unfortunately defaced and he can be identified only by his umbrella. Sukracharya is shown by his side pouring water into the hand of Vamana while Bali stands behind with his wife Vindhyavali. Strangely Shukracharya has a Buddha like demeanour.
What does the story of Balipadyami inform us? Mahabali was caught in the trappings of his ego, craving for more power and perceiving himself as invulnerable. When Trivikrama asked him ‚Äúwhere can I place the third step?‚Äù he broke free from the fetters of ego and surrendered himself to the divine, cosmic power. When we light the lamp on Balipadyami, let us strive to renew our deeper connection with the divine through transcending the trappings of our ego. It is a path to tread in a period of time when narcissistic patterns are so salient and on the rise.
Dr Raguram
06/11/24, 8:14‚ÄØam
Decades ago, in the busy outpatient wing of NIMHANS, I noticed an elderly man who was drumming his hands vigorously on his head. I called him inside and asked him as to why he was doing so. He turned to me and said, ‚ÄúI was listening to music.‚Äù It was the first case of musical hallucinations I had ever seen and I reported it as a case study in a journal. There have been many reports of such phenomenon with varied hypotheses as to its causation. It left me wondering as to what would happen if a musician were to have musical hallucinations? Will it be an inspiration, finding its way to his/her musical creations, or will it be a curse?
These questions resonated within me for long, till I chanced upon a wonderful 1958 recording of Robert Schumann‚Äôs Symphony No 2, by the Cleveland Orchestra conducted by George Szell. It‚Äôs deeply affective sombre opening notes, slowly flow into brighter phase with repartees between strings and winds, ending with a hymn like finale. I must have listened to it many times and was curious to find out more about its composer. I was surprised to read about the inspiration for this symphony. It was a piece of auditory musical hallucination that Schumann experienced. In his words, ‚ÄúFor several days, drums and trumpets in the key of C have been sounding in my mind. I have no idea what will come of it‚Äù: they found their place in Symphony No 2.
Schumann battled various physical and psychiatric illnesses all through his life, prominent among them being syphilis. He wrote that his illness, ‚Äúhearing problems, depression, dizziness, rheumatism is inscribed in the fabric of the piece. I would say that my resistant spirit had a visible influence on it and it is through that that I sought to fight my condition. The first movement is full of this combativeness, is very moody and rebellious in character."
During his final days when he was incarcerated in a mental asylum, he was hearing a musical pitch or an entire orchestra. As his wife recorded in a note, Schumann experienced ‚Äúvery strong and painful auditory disturbances‚Äù during this time period. The music sounded in his head, day and night, and sometimes went on for days.
Though the melodic hallucinations formed a kernel of this inspiring composition, Symphony No 2, Schumann was drowned in a sea of musical hallucinations at the end of his life, probably related to the final stages of the syphilitic infection. That raises a question: Are musical hallucinations a ‚Äòroyal road‚Äô to a person‚Äôs unconscious creative mind or are they merely discordant notes from a disharmonious brain in disarray?
Dr Raguram
13/11/24, 9:35‚ÄØam
D≈çgen Zenji is considered as one of the great philosophers who was responsible for outlining the principles of S≈çt≈ç Zen. The S≈çt≈ç Zen school he founded is one of the important Buddhist traditions in Japan. The essence of Soto Zen is the practice of meditation without objects, anchors, or content, known as Shikantaza. The goal is to be aware of the stream of thoughts and allow them to arise and pass away without interference. In Dogen‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúForgetting oneself is opening oneself.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
20/11/24, 9:01‚ÄØam
Ajanta has a series of Buddhist caves. As I step into one of its dark interiors, silence enveloped me like a comforting blanket. In the vast cavernous space, I felt alive, with the soft breeze from the valley below caressing me. At the far end of the cave was a striking sculpture of Buddha, softly lit; its beauty accentuated by a colourful painting in the ceiling. When I continued to gaze on the Buddha, the sounds from the transitory world outside slowly faded away and I was transported into an inexplicably serene realm. It was a strange feeling and quite indescribable too.
As I made my way outside of the dark cave, my heart was filled with an ineffable light.
Dr Raguram
26/11/24, 9:14‚ÄØam
Trees are being felled at alarming rate in Bengaluru. The iconic tree lined avenues have faded away, and linger only in memory. Sometimes what we glimpse through eyes can find their way through a poet‚Äôs heart and find expression in haunting words, like in this poem ‚ÄòThe Poplar Field‚Äô by William Cowper.
‚ÄúThe Poplars are fell‚Äôd, farewell to the shade
And the whispering sound of the cool colonnade
The winds play no longer and sing in the leaves,
Nor Ouse on his bosom their image receives.
Twelve years have elapsed since I last took a view
Of my favourite field and the bank where they grew,
And now in the grass behold they are laid,
And the tree is my seat that once lent me a shade.
The black-bird has fled to another retreat
Where the hazels afford him a screen from the heat,
And the scene where his melody charm‚Äôd me before,
Resounds with his sweet-flowing ditty no more.
My fugitive years are all hasting away,
And I must e‚Äôer long lie as lowly as they,
With a turf on my breast and a stone at my head
E‚Äôer another such grove shall arise in its stead.
‚ÄôTis a sight to engage me if anything can
To muse on the perishing pleasures of Man;
Though his life be a dream, his enjoyments, I see,
Have a Being less durable even than he‚Äù
The poet describes the destruction of a field of poplar trees which no longer offer him shade. The birds too have flown away. Reflecting on the passage of time, the poet wonders with a touch of melancholy, whether he too will return to earth soon. The degradation of the outer landscape and its liminality is symbolic of the tribulations that Cowper went through all his life. His life was one long tryst with pain as he suffered from recurrent attacks of severe depression, ‚Äúlying down in horror, and rising up in despair‚Äù resulting in several suicidal attempts. He found succour in the company of John Milton who wrote the ‚ÄòAmazing Grace‚Äô.
Cowper died from dropsy on April 25th 1800. He summed up his life in these words;
‚ÄúI, who scribble rhyme
To catch the triflers of the time,
And tell them truths divine and clear
Which, couched in prose, they would not hear.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
27/11/24, 9:51‚ÄØam
https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/forays-into-the-land-of-the-vultures
29/11/24, 9:37‚ÄØam
Elephants are magical. Their footprints are deeply imprinted in the cultural, collective consciousness and in individual memories of each one of us.
Mythical stories narrated in the PurƒÅ·πáas mention that the weight of the world rested on divine elephants. Hence not surprisingly, the giant pachyderms figure prominently in temple architecture all around the country. In Hindu temples, they are found primarily in the Adhisthana, the base of the structure on which the superstructure of the temple rests and on Upapitha (sub-base or plinth) of the shrine.
There are two ways in which elephants figure in these structures. Gajapitha, consists of a row of standing elephants holding the pitha. The most wonderful example is in the Kailasa temple at Ellora. Rising from the middle of the rock-cut courtyard, the monolithic temple conveys the impression of being borne aloft on the backs of dozens of life-sized elephants. Beautifully sculpted from the black basalt, they seem to hold the temple up with consummate ease. Though many of them have borne the vagaries of time, there is an unmistakable grace and power in them. (Photograph on top is from Kailasa temple).
A different way in which elephants figure in temple structure is that of Gajathara. It consists of a horizontal frieze of elephants, generally in the lowermost portion of the Adhisthana. The adhisthana usually comprises a remarkable array of horizontal bands depicting at the base, a row of elephants, symbolizing stability. Over this, scrollwork containing delicately carved figures of birds, animals and mythical animals and over these another row of miniature pillars, with a row of miniature temple vimanas. At the highest level are figures of dancers and musicians. The whole adhisthana enclosing the temple is thus transformed into a gallery of intricate sculptural art with miniature carving at its best. The elephants in the bottom layer are usually rendered in profile, marching in procession or in war and hunting scenes. An outstanding example is in the Hoysala temples, especially in Belur and Halebid. (Glimpses of this in the bottom photo from Halebid)
The symbolism of the elephant in Hindu mythology and temple architecture encompasses wisdom, dignity and strength. Its portrayal in these sculptural forms reflects these qualities while also serving as a reminder for us to strive for these virtues in our own lives.
Dr Raguram
30/11/24, 9:01‚ÄØam
Often writers choose pseudonyms in their writings, to conceal their true identities and they use them for a variety of reasons. For instance, Isaac Asimov used the fictitious name of Paul French to publish a series of science fiction books early in his career. Fernando Pessoa, the famous Portuguese writer ventured in the opposite direction, using heteronyms. In his own words, ‚ÄúA pseudonymous work is, except for the name with which it is signed, the work of an author writing as himself; a heteronymic work is by an author writing outside his own personality: it is the work of a complete individuality made up by him, just as the utterances of some character in a drama would be‚Ä¶ I break my soul into pieces, and into different persons.‚Äù More than 72 heteronyms have been identified in Fernando Pessoa‚Äôs writing! Sometimes he even thought that, at times, he could see and hear the heteronyms he had created.
Basically a heteronym is an imaginary character created by a writer to write in a different style. The writer becomes a virtual subject, who starts inhabiting the character's life first-personally. As a consequence, the characters in heteronym have their own individual identity, which is expressed in writing. Viewed this way I was wondering whether heteronym is a precursor to Avatar!
Pessoa‚Äôs famous work is the ‚ÄòBook of Disquiet‚Äô which has an unusual structure. It is totally nonlinear and a fusion of poetry and prose in which the author reflects on various aspects of life. In an interesting comment, the author states, ‚ÄúMy soul is a hidden orchestra; I know not what instruments, what fiddlestrings and harps, drums and tamboura I sound and clash inside myself. All I hear is the symphony.‚Äù
(Fernando Pessoa: June 13 1888 ‚Äì November 30 1935)
Dr Raguram
02/12/24, 9:34‚ÄØam
‚ÄòCome to the Edge‚Äô is a poem often attributed to Guillaume Apollinaire but actually written by poet, activist, Christopher Logue (23rd November 1926 ‚Äì 2nd December 2011). Whenever I read this poem, a series of images and meanings keep swirling through my mind. Quite often we feel contented, settling into our own comfort zones. Life is often a delicate dance between the possible and the impossible. Logue urges us to venture further and discover uncharted territories that we feel hesitant to explore.
Years ago I went along with my friend to explore the caves in the Antaragange hill near Kolar. It was the first time I attempted to climb a hill. The guide reassured me that it shouldn‚Äôt be too difficult. Encouraged by his reassurance I started the climb. The first few ascents were a bit difficult but when we entered the caves on the top, the cool morning breeze was quite refreshing. The difficulty started when I started to climb down. I felt that the rocks might give way and was overcome with intense fear that I would tumble down the hill. It was at that time, the guide came over and whispered in my ears, ‚ÄúDoctor, the mountain is in the mind.‚Äù I felt energized by that comment and made my way down with much greater ease. The dreadful consequences I had anticipated vanished into thin air. Crossing the threshold of fear opened my mind to lurking possibilities within. To this day, these words resonate deeply within and swell to contain the anxiety whenever I face uncertainties in life.
Often the most profound experiences lie beyond the familiar and have a way of keeping us afloat.
COME TO THE EDGE
Come to the edge.
We might fall.
Come to the edge.
It's too high!
COME TO THE EDGE!
And they came,
and he pushed,
And they flew.
Dr Raguram
06/12/24, 7:46‚ÄØam
Rumi is not merely a poet; he is also a spiritual guide. I dip into his works often and the ‚Äòdoors of perception‚Äô start opening. If I have to choose just one poem to illustrate this, it is this one.
‚ÄúOut beyond ideas of wrongdoing and rightdoing,
there is a field. I‚Äôll meet you there.
When the soul lies down in that grass,
the world is too full to talk about.
Ideas, language, even the phrase ‚Äúeach other‚Äù
doesn‚Äôt make any sense.
The breeze at dawn has secrets to tell you.
Don‚Äôt go back to sleep.
You must ask for what you really want.
Don‚Äôt go back to sleep.
People are going back and forth across the doorsill
where the two worlds touch.
The door is round and open.
Don‚Äôt go back to sleep.‚Äù
Often we get enmeshed in binaries in our lives: good/bad, right/wrong, proper/improper, valid/invalid etc. Such a position often results in a judgmental stance and we start viewing the world around us through these prisms. Basically a sense of duality shapes our worldviews. Rumi wonders whether there is a realm of experience beyond this. Is it possible for us to be in a more unified space where we can aspire to free ourselves and savour a more unified reality? In that mind space void of labels and judgements, duality dissolves and we can realize our ‚Äòoneness‚Äô.
Thanks to Rumi, whenever I find myself quick to judge, I pause and reflect.
Dr Raguram
06/12/24, 12:55‚ÄØpm
Thank you Sir for the wonderful and very thoughtful poem. He is a realized soul and we should indeed be thankful for lighting the path when otherwise seems so dark.
09/12/24, 9:50‚ÄØam
Despite being an acclaimed poet in Persian, Sadi Shirraj or Sa‚Äôdi, felt that he had written nothing of consequence and resolved to spend rest of his life in silence. One day, he broke his vow at the insistence of his close friend when both of them went for a stroll in the garden. Sadi noticed that that his friend was gathering rose petals and putting them into his robes. Sadi wondered why his friend was collecting and storing them carefully when they would dry very soon and will not be of much use. He told his friend that, instead, he would write a book called the Gulistan, (Garden of Roses), whose folios would last forever. The Gulistan remains one of the most beloved works of Persian literature. It consists of parables interspersed with short poems. In one of his most beautiful poems in the book, he wrote;
‚ÄúHuman beings are members of a whole
In creation of one essence and soul
If one member is afflicted with pain
Other members uneasy will remain
If you have no sympathy for human pain
The name of human you cannot retain‚Äù
The flowers of Gulistan's poems are still fresh today and can be savoured in a wonderful translation by Richard Burton.
Dr Raguram
10/12/24, 9:47‚ÄØam
I just finished reading a deeply moving book, ‚ÄúWhy do you fear my way so much?‚Äù by GN Saibaba. He was 90% paralysed and had spent over 10 years in jail, till the Division Bench of the Bombay High Court acquitted him of all charges. Saibaba died on October 12, 2024.
This particular passage from the book is heart rendering;
‚ÄúI have lived all my conscious life on the campuses of learning and teaching in search of knowledge, love and freedom. In the course of this search, I learnt that freedom for a few was no freedom. I began to study histories, philosophies and literatures with more eagerness and critical engagement. That led me to look around myself closely. I travelled across and met people living in sub-human conditions. I realised that they never tasted freedom very much like me. I understood that castes and freedom can never co-exist. I began to speak to myself. Then I slowly started to speak to my fellow beings on my journey. I grasped of a great void of silence around me. I saw a society of silence. I dashed myself against the boulders of silence. I brutally wounded myself‚Äù‚Ä¶.
‚ÄúI reel under excruciating relentless pain. One after the other, my organs started bursting. The closure of my voice within me explodes into shooting pain. My vocal chords acquired lesions making my voice a thin and inaudible squeak. My heart broke with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. My brain has started having blackouts with a condition called syncope. My kidneys are silted with pebbles; my gallbladder gathered stones and pancreas grew a tail of pain called pancreatitis. Nerve lines in my left shoulder broke under the conditions of my arrest, known as brachial plexopathy. More and more organs of silence replaced the original. I have been living with explosive and shooting pain day in and day out. I am living on the margins of life.‚Äù
And he quotes a verse from Faiz Ahmad Faiz
‚ÄúMy pain, a voiceless song,
my being a nameless mote.
If only my pain could speak,
I‚Äôd know who I am.
And if myself could find its essence,
I‚Äôd unravel the mystery of this world.
If I could seize this hidden mystery,
my silence would find expression.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
13/12/24, 9:40‚ÄØam
Separation is a poignant theme across all creative oeuvres. It encompasses a range of emotions involving intense longing as well extreme sadness. The anguish and emotional turmoil of separation is particularly well expressed in the realm of poetry. Often described as ‚Äòviraha‚Äô, where lovers experience intense pain due to physical separation, evocative descriptions are aplenty in works like Kalidasa's ‚ÄòMeghaduta‚Äô, Jayadeva's ‚ÄòGitagovinda‚Äô and in Tamil Sangam poetry. In the latter, where different landscapes are associated with specific emotions, separation is described on the background of ‚Äòneithal‚Äô, where the separation of lovers is associated with the vastness and loneliness of the sea and in exquisite detail in the ‚Äòpaalai‚Äô landscape which symbolizes complete separation and the harshness in a desolate, barren environment.
The torment of separation plays out powerfully in the palette of Expressionist painters like Edvard Munch (12 December 1863 - 23 January 1944), who is often remembered for his iconic painting ‚ÄòThe Scream‚Äô. In a painting titled ‚ÄòSeparation‚Äô he portrayed a man and a woman in the process of parting. Our eyes are drawn to the striking colour contrast between the two. The man, ostensibly overwhelmed with emotions of sadness and despair is painted in black. On the other hand, the woman is painted with a brighter yellow colour, symbolic of happiness and optimism. While the man is static, the woman seems as though she is ready to move on from him and cross the black line of separation. While the man is still caught in the web of the past, suffering from the memories of what they once had together, the woman looks far across the line, awaiting the future. What is also interesting is that the man‚Äôs right hand is painted with the colours of the woman, indicating how the man fails to let go of the woman from his heart which seems to be bleeding. Colours are not merely aesthetic choices in art; they hold the power to evoke powerful feelings. Edvard Munch utilizes intense hues as a powerful tool in this painting to convey emotional tribulations lurking within the individuals in throes of separation, so effectively.
Only Pablo Neruda can voice these in verse,
‚Äú..Tonight I can write the saddest lines.
To think that I do not have her. To feel that I have lost her.
To hear the immense night, still more immense without her.
And the verse falls to the soul like dew to the pasture.
What does it matter that my love could not keep her.
The night is shattered and she is not with me.
This is all‚Ä¶‚Äù
Dr Raguram
16/12/24, 9:48‚ÄØam
Confronting mortality is not an easy task. Very few musicians have ventured into this landscape and prominent among them is Mahler. He explored the vicissitudes of life and death in his masterly Second Symphony. It is a work that explores mortality and inevitably of death and ends with an affirmation of a transcendent, everlasting life. The first eight lines from the final movement were taken from the poem, ‚ÄòDie Auferstehung‚Äô, by Friedrich Gottlieb Klopstock and Mahler wrote the rest himself;
‚ÄúRise again, yes, rise again,
Will you, my dust, after a brief rest!
Immortal life! Immortal life
Will he who called you, give you.
You are sown to bloom again!
The lord of the harvest goes
And gathers sheaves,
Us, who have died.
O believe, my heart, O believe:
Nothing is lost to you!
Yours, yes yours, is what you desired
Yours, what you have loved
What you have fought for!
O believe,
You were not born for nothing!
Have not lived for nothing,
Nor suffered!
What was created
Must perish;
What perished, rise again!
Cease from trembling!
Prepare yourself to live!
O Pain, you piercer of all things,
From you, I have been wrested!
O Death, you conqueror of all things,
Now, are you conquered!
With wings which I have won for myself,
In love‚Äôs fierce striving,
I shall soar upwards
To the light which no eye has penetrated!
I shall die in order to live.
Rise again, yes, rise again,
Will you, my heart, in an instant!
That for which you suffered,
To God shall it carry you!‚Äù
(Dedicated to Ustad Zakir Hussain, whose dancing fingers on the tabla will continue to entrance us)
Do close your eyes and listen to this exceptional recording of Mahler‚Äôs 2nd symphony by Otto Klemperer.
Dr Raguram
20/12/24, 9:29‚ÄØam
Cintio Vitier was a Cuban poet, essayist, and novelist, often referred to as "one of the most important writers of his generation". His abundant love of the ordinary people and his firm conviction that without roots in those people, nothing can be created, finds expression in his poems. He wrote, ‚ÄúSoul of the nation lived in the quiet suffering of the poor or middle-class family, in its capacity for resistance and hope, in its irrepressible popular laugh, in its unbeatable music, in the lamp of the intellectual, in poetry.‚Äù
‚ÄúMy words verge on silence
like great birds that disappear
into the early evening: their
strenuous white wings
carry off the intense sweetness
of dusk, visible then
in starlight.
My words turn toward the night
with no look back
at what is lost or won, or
what is missing, like those workers,
who, utterly fatigued
by a long day, return home
so the household once again can rest
and the strength that comes
with morning be restored.‚Äù
Here, the poet wonderfully transposes the metaphor of the birds with that of workers who toil tirelessly. I always feel that there are birds lurking within us, resting and finding a moment to recoup the strength to fly again and again in the vast sky of life.
Dr Raguram
21/12/24, 10:05‚ÄØam
As I was watching this honey bee on the garden rose, I was reminded of a poem by the 17th-century Japanese haiku master, Basho:
‚ÄúThe bee emerging
from deep within the peony
departs reluctantly‚Äù
Dr Raguram

Blog & posts

23/01/24, 9:11‚ÄØam
Sometime back we visited Avani in Kolar district (a detailed description is at: (https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/avani). Avani attained prominence due to myriad legends associated with it. Most importantly, it is said to be the site of Uttara Ramayana. There is a small beautiful, Ramalingeshwara temple which dates back to 10th century. A hillock strewn with boulders forms an interesting backdrop to this ancient temple. It is believed that Sita retreated to this hill after her trial by fire and gave birth to Lava and Kusha who grew up in the hermitage of Valmiki. There are several caves; one of them is considered to be Valmiki‚Äôs ashram and another one where Sita lived and cooked for her children.
I was keen to find out whether there are other places identified as Sita‚Äôs Kitchen. To my great surprise, I discovered that there are several Sita‚Äôs Rasoi (kitchen) dotted across the subcontinent. At least two of Sita‚Äôs kitchens have been documented in Ayodhya, but only one survived the demolition of the Babri Masjid. I understand that within the complex on the Ramkot in Ayodhya, there is a building bearing the painted phrase ‚ÄúJanmasthana Sita Rasoi‚Äù (Birthplace Sita‚Äôs Kitchen). The garbhagriha contains a rolling board, rolling pin, chulha and an image of Sita.
When I searched for other ‚ÄòSita‚Äôs Rasois‚Äô, I found documentation of several others: Lalapur near Allahabad, Chitrakoot, Brahmavarta in UP and Nasik in Maharashtra amongst others. Each one of them is adjacent to Valmiki‚Äôs ashram and similarly contain a rolling pin, board and a chulha.
I also looked for mention of Sita and her kitchen in many of the Ramayanas. There were none. An array of localized narratives and memories associated with Sita and her kitchen seemed to have evolved over time across the country. It would be a fascinating exercise to explore how these memories of the past have been constructed, celebrated and sometimes politically appropriated too.
While Rama is valorised and huge temples are built to honour him, for some inexplicable reason, Sita has been relegated and confined to the kitchen. Is her power and authority confined to the kitchen alone? Cooking, to a large extent has been embedded in the patriarchal construction of femininity. If the kitchen is a feminine abode, it might also be a site of resistance.
In the animated film, ‚ÄòSita Sings The Blues‚Äô, Nina Paley relocates her as a woman who retells her own story in her own voice in an altogether different context. Sita‚Äôs songs not only give her a voice.
Perhaps it is time to retell the Ramayana from the perspective of Sita.

Manas National Park, is a key elephant habitat and is known for its large herds of wild elephants. It was a pleasure to see a large group of them on our morning safari. We spent several minutes just observing them and then they crossed over to the other side, led by the matriarch. As we were watching (from a safe distance!), a tusker advanced quite close towards us. The guard said ‚Äòhat, hat‚Äô and it stopped in its tracks, thankfully. Later on he mentioned that if the elephant‚Äôs ears are waving and the trunk is loose, it most probably indicates a fake charge.

01/06/25, 10:32‚ÄØam
A friend asked a question this morning as to why I didn‚Äôt post anything on the World Milk Day! In the process of getting to know about the history of milk production in India, I discovered that the history of dairy in the Indian subcontinent goes back roughly 8,000 years to the first domestication of zebu cattle, which is thought to have originated in India. By the beginning of the Indus Valley civilisation (c. 3300 ‚Äì c. 1300 BCE), zebu cattle had been fully domesticated and used for their milk. They were known to produce dairy products, including milk. This is evidenced by the analysis of lipid residues on pottery shards from the Kotada Bhadli archaeological site in Gujarat. These analyses revealed the presence of milk-related lipids, suggesting the earliest direct evidence of dairy processing in the Indus Valley Civilization. The study also suggested that milk may have been boiled before consumption. There is also a suggestion that milk production may have been in surplus, potentially leading to trade and exchange between settlements. The majestic zebu bull, with its heavy dewlap and wide curving horns is perhaps the most impressive motif found on the Indus seals.
Dr Raguram

06/01/25, 8:19‚ÄØam
5th January is celebrated as National Bird Day in USA. Every time when we are there, we manage to do some bit of birding. Last year we visited Lake Placid, which is nestled in the heart of New York state's scenic Adirondack Mountains. One morning when I was sitting on the deck, I heard a very unusual bird call. It was like a guttural squeak, ending with a long whistle. Curious to locate it, I saw a bird sitting on the tree ahead which was emitting the call. It had a glossy-iridescent body, with purplish-blue head, neck and breast. Its eyes were like intense little black beads that seemed to look at me sideways. Quickly I searched the net and found that it was a grackle. I sat for a while observing it closely as it was joined by scores of its ilk, it was sheer grackophony!
Once I was back in the room, I was curious to know whether this bird has caught the attention of poets. In a short poem published in 1958, Lisel Mueller described what I witnessed a few minutes ago.
‚ÄúWatching the black grackle
come out of the gray shade
into the sun, I am dazzled
by an unexpected sheen,
yellow, purple, and green,
where the comb of light silkens
unspectacular wings ‚Äî
until he, unaware
of what he means at this one
peculiar angle of sun,
hops back to his modest dark
and leaves the shining part
of himself behind, as though
brightness must outgrow
its fluttering worldly dress
and enter the mind outright
as vision, as pure light.‚Äù
When the poets dips their pen in ornithology, the results can be quite enchanting!
Dr Raguram
10/01/25, 11:24‚ÄØam
The Padma Purana narrates the history of Vaikunta Ekadasi through the episode of the asura Muran, who secures Vishnu‚Äôs blessings but abuses his power. Vishnu Himself engages him in a combat. When Vishnu rests briefly in a cave, the asura tries to ambush Him at which point, a female form springs from Vishnu‚Äôs chest and kills Muran on the 11th day of Margazhi sukla paksham. Vishnu names her as Ekadasi. She seeks Moksha for Muran and anyone who prays to Vishnu on this day. It is believed that Vishnu opens the north gate of heaven, Vaikunta vaasal for those who pray to him on this day. Vaishnavite temples replicate this practice by opening the Sorga Vaasal.
Lord Vishnu has five states. Param, Vyuham, Vibhavam, Antaryami and Archam. The first state Param is the state known as Paramapadam, Vaikuntam or Moksam, which is located in a space beyond all worlds. This is a sculptural depiction of Para-Vasudeva from cave 3 at Badami. He is shown here with four arms, seating on Sheshanaga (serpent), also known as Ananta, who symbolises primordial principle of time. Vishnu is seated on the coils of Ananta, in a relaxed manner with his left leg folded over the coils and right leg resting down. His upper two hands hold shankha and chakra while his lower-right hand is placed on the coils and lower-left hand rests on the left leg. The five hoods of Ananta serve as a parasol over his head. The sculpture is exquisitely carved with fine ornamentation and eye for detail.
Dr Raguram
11/01/25, 2:12‚ÄØpm
I knew about Ekadashi but what a sculpture to describe Vishnu with Shanka and Chakra, ornaments, posture and more than that the expression may be yoga nidra. The sculptor has become immortal in his work...
13/01/25, 8:12‚ÄØam
Music and dance are not merely aesthetic forms but also serve as conduits for realizing the divine presence. For instance, Arudra Darisanam which is observed today, celebrates the cosmic dance of Lord Shiva as Nataraja. Nataraja‚Äôs dance is not just a physical expression but signifies the underlying vibrations that sustain the universe, embodying creation, preservation, destruction, release, and embodiment, often referred to as Panchakrityas.
One of the beautiful expression of Nataraja‚Äôs dance is in the form of Alidhanrita Shiva. This sculpture is from Kailasanathar Kovil in Kancheepuram. Here he is depicted in a Swastika Mudra. On the right side is Parvathi with an adoring expression relishing the dance, with a Nandi below her. On the left is a musician playing the drums. The animated Shiva Ganas are dancing with sheer abandon at the bottom. Right on top is a small, exquisitely carved Ganesha.
Kaviyogi Sri Suddhananda Bharathi composed a beautiful song about the dancing Shiva, ‚Äò‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æü‡Æø' ‚ÄútUkkiya tiruvaDi‚Äô in raga Shankarabharanam. He pays obeisance to the Lord in the opening line;
‚Äú‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æü‡Æø ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æ£‡Øà ‡Æé‡Æ© ‡Æ®‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øá‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æ®‡Æü‡Æ∞‡Ææ‡Æú‡Æ©‡Øá‚Äù
‚ÄúI seek salvation in your raised foot, Oh Supreme Lord, Nataraja.‚Äù
This particular verse in Thevaram by Tirunavukkarasar, beautifully articulates our abiding quest for salvation from the Lord;
‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡ÆÆ‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡Æ®‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Øã‡Æ£‡Æø ‡Æ™‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æø
‡ÆÆ‡Æ§‡Æø‡ÆØ‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡Æô‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡ÆØ‡ØÇ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æö‡Øç
‡Æö‡Æø‡Æ©‡ÆÆ‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡Æû‡Øç ‡Æö‡Æ∞‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Øà ‡Æè‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æö‡Øç
‡Æö‡ØÜ‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æï‡Æü ‡Æ≤‡Øã‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡ÆÆ‡Æ§‡Æ©‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ±‡Øà ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø
‡ÆÆ‡Æ±‡Æø‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øã ‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ±‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æµ‡Øä‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Ææ(‡Æ§‡ØÅ)
‡Æâ‡Æ©‡Øà‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æ£‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æµ‡Øà ‡Æ®‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æï‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç
‡Æí‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æø‡ÆØ‡ØÇ ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æü‡Øà‡ÆØ ‡Æï‡Øã‡Æµ‡Øá.
