Saw this happen.
Countrymen! Here's the implicit meaning.
The gods will enter us
And guard us from all ills
If we transcend our pride.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
19/04/25, 9:08‚ÄØam
Yet another World Heritage Day (18th April), has passed on. It raises an uncomfortable question, have we really taken care of the plethora of ancient gems which crave for attention all over the country? In our travels we found that many of these historically invaluable monuments are in a severe stage of neglect.
For instance, when we were travelling in Tirunelveli district we were keen to visit the Sathya Vageeswarar Temple in Kalakad. In addition to beautiful sculptures it is said to have more than 200 mural paintings, which are 400 years old. With great effort we got the necessary permission and when we visited it, there was no one around. We went around the temple savouring all the wonderful sculptures and after an hour, an official arrived. These murals are on the inner walls of each of the nine tiers of the temple‚Äôs gopuram. We climbed the inside of the gopuram in darkness. The steps were quite high and narrow. The official led the way with a torch with an intimidating stick. I wondered why he was carrying it. Our doubts were answered when we arrived at the first tier of the gopuram. Countless bats were hovering around us and there were resident monkeys who were making threating sounds. Fortunately, the official kept them at bay with the stick. The floor was littered with bat droppings and we gingerly made our way around them. There was no light inside and we started scanning the walls with the light from our mobile phones. Every inch of the wall was covered with murals depicting scenes from the Ramayana, the Mahabharata and episodes from the life of Saivite saints of Tamil Nadu. We were deeply saddened to see their derelict condition. Even though the paint had worn off due to years of neglect their innate beauty shone through layers of the murals. We climbed all the nine tiers and seeing the murals on each tier, was like watching a moving gallery of fading images which glowed in the light from our mobiles.
We slowly climbed down with a deep sense of disquiet. These priceless repositories of the past crave for attention and careful restoration. It is a sad story of monumental neglect. Without concentrated efforts at conservation these murals will just fade away. If we create awareness about these treasures and integrate their histories into our educational systems, perhaps there might be a greater urgency to preserve them. It is also important not to leave this responsibility to governmental agencies with are already functioning on a shoe string budget. Involvement of the local community is extremely crucial to conserve these sublime remains of the past.
Unfortunately, it is the same story in many monuments of interest. When our son Rahul was young we had taken him to the Chennakesava Temple at Somanathapura, near Mysore. There were two beautifully carved elephants flanking the steps and we had taken a photo of him with them. When we visited years later both of them were missing. I called the ASI person and asked him and he staunchly defended that no such sculpture ever existed there!
It is a sad fact that we have failed in our moral responsibility to take care and preserve many of the beautiful monuments across the country.
Hope we are able to break this circle of neglect‚Ä¶at some time!
(The attached mural is one among the few which are relatively in good condition. The rest are not!)
Dr Raguram
20/04/25, 6:58‚ÄØpm
Such beautiful mural art, women with all the jewellery and dress and wonderfully adjusted in the available space. And the details you have given has enhanced the beauty of it.
22/04/25, 12:42‚ÄØpm
The phrase "Earth laughs in flowers" comes from the poem "Hamatreya" by Ralph Waldo Emerson, wherein flowers are presented as a symbol of the earth's resilience and joy, often interpreted as a mockery of human attempts to dominate nature. Emerson believed that humans are ultimately transient and will return to the earth. The origin of the poem's title is unclear, because there is no Hindu word or name "Hamatreya." Perhaps it is an adaptation of "Maitreya," one of the characters in the Hindu text ‚ÄúVishnu Purana‚Äù, who is engaged in a dialogue with the Vishnu. Vishnu tells Maitreya about the Hindu kings who mistakenly believed themselves as the possessors of the Earth. But the kings have disappeared, while the Earth endures. Vishnu recites the chant of the Earth and pities the egotistical kings and their blindness to their mortality. Human efforts to build empires and leave their mark on the earth will ultimately be futile. The earth, on the other hand, with its natural cycles of rejuvenation will always be alive, communicating joy and happiness through its flowers.
(Penned on the Earth Day 22nd April 2025)
Dr Raguram
23/04/25, 9:26‚ÄØam
I grew up with books. On every birthday there was no cake to cut, but books to savour. I devoured them so fast that I needed glasses at a young age. That did not deter my quest to unravel secrets tucked into inked pages. The smell of books was so irresistible that I surrounded myself with scores of them. Libraries were my sanctuary where I retreated to find succour and company. I couldn‚Äôt afford to buy them till I started earning. The salary as a young psychiatry resident opened the doors of Premier and Select Book Shops. Mr Shanbhag and Mr Murthy guided my forays and fuelled my quest further. I started buying books and slowly the collection increased. Aware of my interest, the gifts my friends gave were mostly books. They were all piled in all available spaces in the quarters we lived in. When we moved to our new abode, our first task was to house them all in a bedroom which metamorphosed into a library. Sometimes I have to cautiously step onto a ladder to locate a book on ceiling high shelves. When I start my day ensconced amidst them, it's like all my friends sitting on shelves are waving their pages at me. They then begin talking and I start a conversation with them afloat on a magic carpet gliding through imagined landscapes. Each book is like a stepping stone offering a new perspective and a fresh lens to view the world and oneself. As I venture further, I start feeling at home in that inward journey.
‚ÄúWhen the book unfurls
The journey starts
On paper wings‚Äù
(Penned On The World Book Day 23rd April)
Dr Raguram
26/04/25, 8:34‚ÄØam
Situated besides the Nambi river and against the backdrop of the Western Ghats (Mahendragiri) in Tirunelveli district is the Azhagiya Nambi Rayar temple at Thirukkurungudi. Nindra Nambi or Azhagiya Nambi is also called as ‚ÄúSundara Paripoornam‚Äù, meaning ‚ÄúPerfect and complete beauty‚Äù. It is one of the most beautiful temple I had ever visited. Every corner of the temple premises is decorated with exquisite sculptures. Some of the most delicate carving are in the Chitra Gopuram.
This particular panel illustrates the story of Gajendra Moksham. It is a small rectangular panel. Dominant figure is that of eight armed Vishnu, seated on Garuda, who is depicted with human face and body and wings. Garuda has infinite strength, so he comfortably bears Vishnu. Vishnu‚Äôs kirita makuta is a fascinating contrast to the jatamakutas which adorn Siva. Gajendra is beseeching Vishnu to deliver him from the clutches of the crocodile which has as strangle hold on its legs. On the top are munis, hands in worship who are witnessing this event.
Gajendra Moksha, meaning "the liberation of the elephant," is a story from the Bhagavata Purana about a king named Indradyumna, who was cursed in a past life to be born as an elephant named Gajendra. In his present life, Gajendra is attacked by a crocodile while at a lake, and he prays to Lord Vishnu for help. Vishnu, upon hearing Gajendra's prayer, intervenes and frees Gajendra from the crocodile's grasp, granting him liberation.
The Gajendra Moksha story, highlights the importance of surrendering to Lord Vishnu for liberation from suffering and the cycle of rebirth. Gajendra, the elephant, is rescued by Vishnu after being captured by a crocodile, symbolizing the release from ignorance and material attachments. The story emphasizes the power of devotion and the importance of seeking refuge in the divine during times of distress. The water symbolises our material world or samsara. The crocodile is maya which forever tries to pull the soul into samsara and its bondage.
The Gajendra Moksha Stotra, a prayer within the Srimad Bhagavatam, captures this dialogue between the devoted soul and the divine. The hymn highlights the transformative power of unwavering devotion, which offers liberation.
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø
O Lord of great compassion, liberated from the shackles of surrendered animals like me, I offer my obeisance to You.
(Penned on the International Sculpture Day)
Dr Raguram
28/04/25, 7:39‚ÄØam
It must have been a beautiful morning when scores of people made their way to Baisaran which is often referred to as "Mini-Switzerland". Reportedly it is one of the most scenic places near Pahalgam. When people settled down in the lovely large green meadow with the grand backdrop of pine trees and mountains they would have hardly anticipated the turn of events. Suddenly, bullets rained down on unsuspecting people, mostly men, who were shot at very close range. Horror and terror must have engulfed their companions who ran to safety. In that moment their lives changed for ever. The emotional trauma they experienced will leave a lasting impact among the survivors.
Even on reading about the incident and the experiences of the survivors, one is overwhelmed with a deep sense of anguish. Often it is difficult to express that pain in words. Sometimes, creative artists unmask that feeling in paintings. I recall the iconic painting of Edward Munch, ‚ÄòThe Scream‚Äô. It features a figure with a terrified expression, surrounded by a swirling, vibrant landscape that reflects the emotional intensity of the moment. Munch used a distorted form and intense colours to unveil that moment of intense dread. In his words, ‚ÄúI felt tired and ill. I stopped and looked out over the fjord ‚Äî the sun was setting, and the clouds turning blood red. I sensed a scream passing through nature; it seemed to me that I heard the scream. I painted this picture, painted the clouds as actual blood. The color shrieked.‚Äù
‚ÄòThe Scream‚Äô stands as a timeless reminder of the existential dread that can make inroads into our lives and overwhelm us at the most unanticipated moments in our lives. The painting‚Äôs shriek, echoes deeply within our hearts. It unites us all in collective empathy and determination to respond to the anguish and pain with renewed resilience.
Sometimes the most painful tears are not the ones that fall from our eyes. They're the ones that tumble from our hearts and find their way to those in throes of unbearable anguish.
Dr Raguram
29/04/25, 8:51‚ÄØam
As I was ambling through the vast Angkor Wat temple complex, savouring myriad sculptures that adorn it‚Äôs walls, I was particularly drawn to thousands of intricate stone carving that depict the dance of the Apsaras. The term "Apsara" refers to celestial nymphs or divine dancers in Hindu and Buddhist traditions, and are believed to be supernatural beings who entertain gods and kings with their graceful movements. The Apsara dance is a traditional Cambodian (Khmer) classical dance deeply rooted in Hindu and Buddhist mythology. It dates back to at least the 7th century and flourished during the Angkorian era (9th‚Äì15th centuries), particularly under King Jayavarman VII (12th century), whose court reportedly included over 3,000 Apsara dancers. The dance was performed at royal courts for ceremonies, festivals, and religious rituals, symbolizing a connection between the divine and human realms. The dance nearly vanished during the Khmer Rouge regime (1975‚Äì1979), when many artists were killed. It was revived in the mid-20th century and one can watch its performance at Siem Reap. Unfortunately, we know very little about the meanings and gestures of dance in ancient Cambodia. While a Sanskrit dance treatise, the Natyasastra, sheds light on ancient dance in India, no such text has survived in Cambodia. While the legacy of dance was transmitted orally and bodily, the Apsara dance performed today is often a modern reinvention. This particular dance form was created in the late 1950s by Queen Kossamak. The frontal focus, the twisted movement of bodies, and the flexible hand gestures seen in contemporary Apsara dance are derived from and inspired by the different poses depicted on Angkorian stone reliefs.
The Apsara dancers of Angkor Wat are more than just exquisite carvings on temple walls; they are symbols of Cambodia‚Äôs enduring spirituality, artistry, and cultural identity. Rooted in Hindu mythology yet shaped by Cambodian creativity, these Apsaras embody ideals of grace, beauty, and spirituality in a dance form that resonate across generations.
As Martha Graham commented, ‚ÄúDance is the hidden language of the soul.‚Äù
The attached image from Bayon temple is just a small sampler!
(Penned on the International Dance Day 29th April)
Dr Raguram
01/05/25, 8:36‚ÄØam
Today is International Workers' Day, which honours the contributions of the workforces globally. Worker bees, though small, are nature‚Äôs ultimate labourers. A worker bee is a female honey bee that performs various tasks to maintain the hive. Unable to lay eggs, she takes on roles like foraging for nectar and pollen, cleaning the hive, feeding larvae, producing wax, and guarding the entrance. Their work shift with age: younger bees handle hive duties, while older one‚Äôs forage. Each hive has thousands of workers, forming the backbone of the colony's survival. Worker bees are vital pollinators, supporting 75% of global food crops through pollination, ensuring food security and biodiversity. This critical role is much akin to the indispensable contributions made by human workers in various walks of life. Like human workers facing exploitation or poor conditions, worker bees too endure threats like pesticides, habitat loss, and climate change, which shorten their lives. Worker bees embody the essence of labour.
Like the worker bees labouring selflessly, let us work for common good in the hive of our lives.
Dr Raguram
02/05/25, 8:51‚ÄØam
Kalabhairava is a fearsome, yet revered, form of Lord Shiva. He is known as the destroyer of time, a protector, and a guardian against negative forces. He is also considered a deity who removes fear and protects devotees from enemies like greed, anger, and lust.
This beautifully chiselled Kalabhairava sculpture is at Halebidu's Hoysaleshwara Temple. He is depicted with multiple arms holding various weapons. There is a dog licking the blood from a decapitated head on the bottom right. The sculpture also features Kali, the Goddess of time and destruction, dancing on Bhairava's side, symbolizing the cosmic dance of creation, preservation, and dissolution. The KalaBhairava sculpture in Halebidu is a powerful representation of Bhairava's role as a destroyer, a guardian, and a symbol of the transformative power of time and nature. The sculpture's intricate details and symbolic elements make it a captivating work of art and a testament to the rich artistic traditions of the Hoysala period.
The Kalabhairava Ashtakam, was composed by the revered Adi Shankaracharya, in 8th Century CE. It is a powerful prayer to Lord Kalabhairava, and consists of eight stanzas (Ashtakam) that praise the attributes of Kalabhairava and seek his grace and protection. The Ashtakam is believed to offer protection from negativity, enhance courage, and promote spiritual growth. One of the ashtakam states;
‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ü‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç
‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç
‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§≠‡•à‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡•á ‡••
I worship Lord Kalabhairava. Who holds (in His hands) the trident, the axe, the noose and the rod and who, is the Primal Cause of the Universe, who the Primeval God has a blue body, and who, is imperishable and pure, and the Lord of terrific prowess, fond of the wonderful dance.
(May 2 is observed as Adi Shankaracharya Jayanti 2, marking the 1237th birth anniversary of the revered philosopher and spiritual reformer.)
Dr Raguram
03/05/25, 7:15‚ÄØam
Vietnam war culminated on April 30, in 1975. It remains an outstanding example of squandered military valour. But more than that it was a vast preventable tragedy. The death toll is estimated to be around 1 to 3.8 million. Not all of these were military personnel; nearly half of the deaths of the Vietnam War were the deaths of civilians caught in the fighting.
There have been many literary accounts of the futility of war. For me personally Joseph Heller‚Äôs ‚ÄòCatch 22‚Äô was a very incisive fictionalized narration of the realities and absurdities of war. Set on an island off the coast of Italy during World War II, it tells the story of Yossarian, an American bomber who is coming to grips with the dehumanizing impact of war on people. It is a unique fusion of satire, surrealism, and black humour to illustrate the terrible psychological effects of war. Heller reveals the brutalizing effects of combat, the deterioration of morals, and the loss of personal agency suffered by those caught up in war. It is a satirical and anti-war masterpiece. The phrase ‚ÄòCatch-22‚Äô is used in the novel to describe a bureaucratic paradox that Yossarian and his fellow soldiers are trapped in. It often creates a situation where a soldier is caught in a catch-22 position: he can‚Äôt be grounded if he‚Äôs sane, but asking to be grounded is evidence of his sanity. Basically it draws attention to a plight when one is damned if they do and damned if they don‚Äôt, and the futility of trying to escape a situation that is inherently contradictory.
As Heller observes "Outside the hospital the war was still going on. Men went mad and were rewarded with medals. All over the world, boys on every side of the bomb line were laying down their lives for what they had been told was their country, and no one seemed to mind, least of all the boys who were laying down their young lives‚Ä¶..It doesn't make a damned bit of difference who wins the war to someone who's dead."
(Joseph Heller 1 May 1923 - 12 December 1999)
Dr Raguram
08/05/25, 8:52‚ÄØam
Rabindranath Tagore was an ardent lover of nature. For him the wide-open skies and tranquillity of the countryside symbolised freedom. Not surprisingly, he envisioned education as a holistic process with close linkages with nature, fostering creativity and personal growth. Tagore saw the traditional formal education system as overtly focused on rote memorization and exams, which stifled creativity, alienating students from their cultural roots and the natural world around them.
Tagore articulated his perspective about education through a short story "The Parrot's Training," It is a powerful satire that exposes the flaws of an inflexible educational system. The story depicts a king who orders his nephew to "educate" a parrot by forcing it to learn from books. The parrot initially considered "illiterate," is confined to a golden cage and subjected to rote memorization. With text-book in one hand and baton in the other, the pundits forced the bird to learn the lessons. It ultimately loses its natural singing voice and becomes a sad mimic. Unable to cope up with this forced tutelage, the parrot finally dies. The king orders the bird to be brought to him and when he pokes its lifeless body, he finds that its innards are stuffed with books: ‚Äúonly its inner stuffing of book-leaves rustled.‚Äù
Tagore uses the parrot as a metaphor of a child in the formal education system. The parrot represents a child who is forced to conform to a rigid system that stifles creativity, natural learning, and individual needs, leading to a loss of natural abilities. In his view, ‚Äúeducation is not the filling of a pail but the lighting of a fire.‚Äù
I wonder whether we have heeded to the prescient message of Tagore. The learning spaces of today have metamorphosed into commodified, shiny concrete cages that are adoringly fitted with modern gadgets with a draconian emphasis on ‚Äòperforming well‚Äô that sucks away the vibrant spirit of learning.
Dr Raguram
10/05/25, 9:15‚ÄØam
During our sojourn in the Rann of Kutch we were keen to have a glimpse of the Grey Hypocolius. We drove around on an early morning and spotted it, perched on the higher branches of ‚ÄòSalvadora Persica‚Äô, also known as the Miswak tree. Its twigs and roots are used to clean teeth due to their antibacterial properties. Prophet Muhammad reportedly recommended its use to maintain oral hygiene.
Hypocolius are generally shy birds and it so wonderful to see it. It was oblivious to our presence and was savouring the berries in a leisurely fashion. Hypocolius migrates from West Asia to Western India during winter, with the Greater Rann of Kachchh being a major wintering ground. They breed in areas like Iraq, Iran, Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Turkmenistan, and winter in the Arabian Peninsula, Pakistan, and Western India.
War significantly impacts bird migration. The sounds of blazing guns and flashing lights from the bombs often frighten the birds, forcing them to search out new migratory routes and some of them might perish during the journey. In spite of it, they make the journey with hope tucked in their feathers.
These migratory birds connect people, ecosystems and nations. They are symbols of peace in a world in throes of turmoil.
(Penned on the occasion of World Migratory Bird Day)
Dr Raguram
11/05/25, 11:10‚ÄØam
Hoysala art is known for its intricate and detailed carvings, and Narasimha sculptures are no exception. Narasimha, the man-lion incarnation of Vishnu, whose advent is celebrated today, is prominently featured in many Hoysala temples throughout Karnataka. There are two representations of Narasimha; Ugra (fierce) and Yoga (meditative). The former is much more common.
The Kedareshwara Temple is just a kilometre away from the main Hoysaleswara Temple in Halebidu, but it is not as well known. Many people who visit Hoysaleswara Temple miss out on seeing this beautiful temple. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, it is a brilliant example of medieval Indian temple design. This particular panel depicts Ugra Narasimha as a fearsome form with a lion head, a human torso, and a powerful physique, with multiple arms. Two of his hands are holding Hiranyakashipu, the demon king, firmly on his lap. With two other hands he is opening the abdomen of Hiranyakashipu and one can see the intestines coming out, which Ugra Narasimha is wearing as a garland around him.
Ugra means "ferocious" and this image of Ugra Narasimha devouring Hiranyakashipu symbolizes the destruction of negative forces and the triumph of good over evil. By vanquishing the demon, Ugra Narasimha re-establishes order and harmony in the cosmos, restoring the balance that was disrupted by the evil forces. Ugra Narasimha transcends mere visual representation. He urges us to stand up for what‚Äôs right and embrace our own inner strength in the face of injustice.
12/05/25, 9:28‚ÄØam
Buddha Jayanti honours three major events in the Buddha's life: his birth in Lumbini, his attainment of enlightenment under the Bodhi tree in Bodhgaya, and his Mahaparinirvana in Kusinaga. When Buddha is meditating under the Bodhi tree, Mara tries to tempt and distract him. Buddha's encounter with Mara is a pivotal moment in Buddhist history, encapsulating the core of his spiritual journey, facing and transcending obstacles on the path to enlightenment.
In cave number 26 at Ajanta, there is an elaborate relief panel which depicts how Mara confronts and disturbs Buddha who is in deep meditation. In the centre of the panel, Buddha is in the varada (bestowing gifts) mudra and sits under the Bodhi tree. In the upper left half of the panel, the evil demon Mara is seen sitting astride a large elephant. His fearsome forces are shown all around, trying to defeat the Buddha before he achieves enlightenment. Mara‚Äôs three daughters Rati (lust), Trishna (thirst), and Arati (delight) dance at the Buddha‚Äôs feet, with hopes of breaking his meditation with lustful advances. In the bottom right hand corner, a dejected and defeated Mara is portrayed with his hand to his head beside his daughters.
The tale of the Buddha's victory over Mara is a timeless narrative that captures the core of the Buddhist journey to enlightenment. In Buddhist teachings, Mara's temptation symbolizes the obstacles and distractions that hinder spiritual progress. It teaches that the quest for truth and liberation demands unwavering determination, the capacity to conquer desire, fear, and doubt, and the readiness to turn adversity into spiritual growth.
Buddhacarita, is the poetic narrative of the life of the Buddha by the Sanskrit poet Ashvaghosha, and is one of the finest examples of Buddhist literature. Chapter 13 details the defeat of Mara and ends with this sloka;
‚ÄútathƒÅpi pƒÅpƒ´yasi nirjite gate di≈õa·∏• prasedu·∏• prababhau ni≈õƒÅkara·∏• |
divo nipeturbhuvi pu·π£pav·πõ·π£·π≠ayo rarƒÅja yo·π£eva vikalma·π£ƒÅ ni≈õƒÅ‚Äù
‚ÄúWhen the wicked one thus fled vanquished, the different regions of the sky grew clear, the moon shone forth, showers of flowers fell down from the sky upon the earth, and the night gleamed out like a spotless maiden.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
18/05/25, 8:17‚ÄØam
Endangered Species Day is observed annually on the third Friday of May, and is dedicated to raising awareness about threatened species and the importance of conserving these species. At least 900 species are already extinct till date, while at least 28,5000 others are listed as endangered or critically endangered by the IUCN, the International Union for Conservation of Nature, which is the global wildlife conservation authority. It classifies species into one of nine Red List Categories: Extinct, Extinct in the Wild, Critically Endangered, Endangered, Vulnerable, Near Threatened, Least Concern, Data Deficient and Not Evaluated.
The red-headed vulture is listed as being Critically Endangered on the IUCN Red List. This classification reflects the species' precarious population status and high risk of extinction. This is one of the 9 species of vulture which are found in India. It is also called the Asian King vulture or Pondicherry Vulture. The red-headed vulture is one of the few species of large vultures that does not live in big groups and is usually found alone or as a breeding pair. With its wingspan of over two metres the red-headed vulture is truly impressive especially when it is flying. Like most vultures their diet consists of carrion and they have been observed feeding on the carcasses of cattle. They play a crucial role in the ecosystem by cleaning up animal remains. This species has experienced a dramatic decline in both population size and distribution. In India it has been estimated that the population decreased by over 90% in just 10 years. This decline has been largely attributed to the use of the drug Diclofenac by veterinarians.
Mr Bharatidasan through his NGO ‚ÄòArulagam‚Äô has played a stellar role in drawing attention to the importance of conserving this species through consistent, dedicated, efforts in the field. He along with his team has been educating the villagers about the consequences of usage of diclofenac through conducting village meetings, programs in the schools and involving senior members of the community in the conservation efforts. I had known him for over a decade and he is truly an inspiration. It was a privilege to accompany him to his field area and observe the tangible impact of his efforts. I will never forget the experience of seeing at least a hundred of various vultures, including the Red headed vulture, which are considered to be critically endangered.
In the Ramayana, there are references to two vultures, Jatayu and Sampati. While the tale of the former is rather well known, the role of Sampati, remains largely overlooked. Sampati sacrifices his wings to shield Jatayu from the sun's heat, leading to his own loss of ability to fly. Later, with his exceptional eyesight, he spots Sita in Lanka and guides Hanuman and the Vanara army towards her location. Though Jatayu and Sampati are key figures in the epic which is read widely, vultures have had a negative reputation in the minds of people as they feed on carcases. Often referred to demeaningly as "nature's garbage collectors", it fails to acknowledge the crucial importance of vultures in sustaining our environment.
Vultures like the Red headed ones are the unsung heroes of our ecosystem and saving them should be our responsibility and a top priority.
‚ÄúSoaring high above
They scan the ground with ancient skill
Clean the earth with quite will
Yet remain unloved and misjudged‚Äù
Dr Raguram
20/05/25, 9:23‚ÄØam
Every time I watch the bees, I am amazed how seamlessly and effectively they seem to carry out their job. They flit from blossom to blossom and when they had gathered enough, they take off and fly, heading to their hive. Bees, whose brains only have about 1 million neurons compared to the 86 billion or so in the human brain, navigate the world, avoid collisions and escape danger while accomplishing a task. I am sure that they have an accurate conceptual mental map of the space they have to negotiate. I wonder whether they have been the inspiration for robotic drones which are being used in many different ways‚Ä¶from warfare to agriculture.
More importantly, bees draw attention to the importance of collaborative existence. Each bee has a specific role; worker, drone, or queen and they function as a cohesive unit for the colony's survival. Grounded in millions of years of evolutionary experience, bees highlight the power of working as a unified whole while respecting individual differences and valuing varied contributions.
Perhaps, it is an important reminder on the World Bee Day for our leaders to adopt a "queen bee" mind set, which is not authoritarian, but inspiring and unifying purposeful co-existence for common good.
Dr Raguram
21/05/25, 9:10‚ÄØam
Last week we were in the Nagarhole forest on an early morning safari. It was quite misty and in the dapple light streaming through towering trees, the forest came alive with the hum of life. The fleeting glimpse of the dholes, graceful chitals frolicking amidst the tall grass and the whispers of birds waking up was a mesmerizing experience. The forest pulls us in, it is an irresistible pull that reconnects us with something primeval within ourselves.
The raw, untamed beauty of the forests has kindled the creative spirit in many artists. For me the dreamlike paintings of Henri Rousseau have a special appeal. His unconventional canvases brim with vivid colours depicting lush vegetation, exotic animals, like this one titled ‚ÄòExotic Landscape.‚Äô The leaves, grass, the trees of the jungle are all painted in opulent shades of green. Monkeys are picking up oranges hanging from the trees and on the ground.
Rousseau's paintings like this one, are not realistic depictions but rather creative, ingenious renderings of the jungles, which succeeds in creating a sense of wonder. He was not trained in any formal art school and his paintings are reflective of his fascination with nature and his imaginative world. They are almost like a childlike view of the forest landscapes.
‚ÄúIt is a world of vibrant hues
Where dreams take flight
Drawing us in.‚Äù
(Henri Rousseau born on 21 May 1844)
Dr Raguram
22/05/25, 8:53‚ÄØam
While birding in Munnar, I suddenly heard a distinctive, repetitive clicking sound and I knew that the Malabar Giant Squirrel was somewhere in the midst of the canopy. As I was trying to locate the where the sound was coming from, I saw a flurry of activity. And there it was, scurrying up the trunk of the tree. It suddenly hurtled itself across to another tree, soaring for several meters before grabbing hold a branch in the adjacent tree. It was like watching an agile, trained athlete making a final dash to touch the finishing line. I was keen to have a closer look at it, but it was tirelessly scurrying across the trees. I gave up the search and to my great surprise, after a few minutes, it landed up a few feet away from where I was, peering at me closely. Our eyes locked for a minute before it slithered away.
At that moment I was reminded of Rumi‚Äôs timeless words, ‚ÄúWhat you seek is seeking you.‚Äù
The poem reads;
‚ÄúOut beyond ideas of wrongdoing
and right doing, there is a field.
I‚Äôll meet you there.
When the soul lies down in that grass
the world is too full to talk about.
What you seek, is seeking you.‚Äù
22/05/25, 8:39‚ÄØpm
There is so much of clarity in the photograph. Humans have ulterior motives and very self centered. We have drifted too much from the concept of co-existence.
23/05/25, 9:26‚ÄØam
I am besotted with the hornbills, particularly the Great Indian Hornbill. My first sighting of this majestic bird was in Karian Shola in Anamalai Tiger Reserve, near Coimbatore. The stately bird with a commanding presence flew in to feed the chick in the nesting hole, high up in the tree. Over the years many more sightings ensued, almost all of them alone or in pairs. It was different when we went birding recently in the Royal Manas National Park. There were scores of them flying around and perching on trees. I have never seen so many of them together in my life. The forest came alive in their colourful presence.
The Great Indian Hornbill plays a crucial role in sustaining biodiversity by acting as a key agent in seed dispersal, which is crucial for forest regeneration and the overall health of the ecosystem. They are referred to as "farmers of the forest" or "engineers of the forests" because they play a vital role in dispersing seeds of various tropical trees. They consume a wide variety of fruits, including figs, and then disperse the seeds through their droppings in different locations, away from the parent plant. This helps in preventing competition among seedlings and aids in forest regeneration. By dispersing seeds, they help establish new tree populations and ensure the diversity of plant life in the jungle. Their presence and activity contribute to a healthy ecosystem by supporting the growth and diversity of plant life, which in turn supports other wildlife.
In India we are blessed with a wide variety of biomes ranging from driest deserts to the moist rain forests, which harbour an astounding variety of flora and fauna. It is a sad fact that we have lost 90% of them which are biodiversity hotspots. Ravaging the biosphere in the guise of ‚Äòdevelopment‚Äô will leave lasting impact on the health of the planet and our wellbeing too.
The life around us is an intricate, diverse, beautiful web. On this day let us commit ourselves not to fray it further.
(Penned on the occasion of International Day of Biodiversity, 22nd May)
Dr Raguram
24/05/25, 9:30‚ÄØam
Among this year‚Äôs Pulitzer Prize winner is Marie Howe, for her poetry collection, ‚ÄòNew and Selected Poems‚Äô. When I was reading it, I was drawn into a diverse world of experiences. Howe seamlessly transforms everyday observations into profound meditations on the human condition. One of the perennial questions that daunts each one of us is what is the meaning and purpose of life. Personally I have found answers to this when I immerse myself in the natural world; whether it is observing birds or just being in the midst of a silent forest, embracing stillness. Jiddu Krishnamurti drew attention to the importance of observing nature without judgment or attachment, viewing it as a path to understanding oneself and one's relationship with the world. Marie Howe articulates this perspective beautifully in this poem, ‚ÄòThe Maples.‚Äô She suggests that through embracing stillness, and being present in the ordinary moments mindfully is the key to a meaningful life.
THE MAPLES
‚ÄúI asked the stand of maples behind the house,
How should I live my life?
They said, shhh shhh shhh‚Ä¶
How should I live, I asked, and the leaves seemed to ripple and gleam.
A bird called from a branch in its own tongue,
And from a branch, across the yard, another bird answered.
A squirrel scrambled up a trunk
then along the length of a branch.
Stand still, I thought,
See how long you can bear that.
Try to stand still, if only for a few moments,
drinking light breathing.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
25/05/25, 6:53‚ÄØpm
Such a huge beak! They are so useful to our nature but we are here to destroy.
25/05/25, 7:18‚ÄØpm
The photograph üçÅ looks so real with light falling on it and the poem is so inspiring to be mindful of the tiny happenings in nature. But for people living amidst concrete buildings, can do the above only in imagination.
27/05/25, 9:40‚ÄØam
On her birthday today, 27th May, let us recall Rachel Carson whose work profoundly shaped the environmental movement. In her most influential work ‚ÄòSilent Spring‚Äô, Carson‚Äôs drew attention to the devastating effects of pesticides, particularly DDT, on ecosystems, wildlife, and human health. The book documented how indiscriminate pesticide use harmed birds, fish, and other organisms, disrupting food chains and causing widespread ecological damage. Its evocative title referred to a future where birdsong might vanish due to pesticide-induced deaths. The book‚Äôs impact was monumental. It sparked national debate and led to the eventual U.S. ban on DDT in 1972. It also drew attention to the fact that we are part of an interconnected ecosystem and how indifferent actions can have a rippling effect endangering it.
Insecticide use is a double-edged sword. While they offer benefits like increased crop yields and disease control, they also pose risks to human health and the environment. Unfortunately, pesticide use in India has significantly increased, especially in recent decades, driven by factors like climate change, the need for increased agricultural output, and the adoption of high-yielding crop varieties. There is growing concern about their impact on human health and the environment, including potential contamination of soil and water.
On this background, the stellar contributions of Rachel Carson are all the more relevant now. If we don‚Äôt pay heed to her observations, we will end up in a world where ‚Äúthe sedge has withered from the lake/ And no birds sing.‚Äù These lines are from John Keats' poem "La Belle Dame Sans Merci". It describes the withering of the sedge (a type of grass) at the lake, signifying a sense of desolation and decay in a barren and bleak landscape devoid of the rejuvenating songs of the birds.
In every brilliantly veined leaf, in every grain of food that we partake, there is a beautiful story of the earth which we have to attune ourselves to.
Dr Raguram
28/05/25, 9:06‚ÄØam
We reached Elkhorn Slough early in the morning to have a good glimpse of its rich aquatic life. We got into the boat and made our way through its tidal flats, creeks and marshes, all teeming with amazing variety of aquatic plants and animals.
It was a beautiful clear blue sky and we saw scores of pelicans, herons. As we were busy training our binoculars on them, I spotted a southern sea otter who was leisurely cruising on its back. Soon we saw several of them swimming together, rolling around in the water playfully and watching us right back. One of them was using a stone to crack open some shelled prey and devouring it, using its tummy as a dinner plate. Once it finished eating, it spent a few minutes rigorously cleaning its dense coat with its teeth and paws. Sea otters have the thickest fur of any animal and were hunted extensively for it. Elkhorn Slough has one of the largest resident colony of southern sea otters.
Southern sea otters are considered as keystone species, as they play a crucial role in maintaining the health and balance of the marine ecosystems, particularly kelp forests. They help regulate the population of sea urchins, which can overgraze and destroy kelp forests, by preying on them. This helps to maintain the biodiversity of kelp forests and supports a wide variety of other marine life that rely on them.
It was fascinating to watch the otters dipping, diving playfully. Seamus Heaney offers a wonderful description of them, in his poem ‚ÄòThe Otter‚Äô:
‚ÄúTurning to swim on your back,
Each silent, thigh-shaking kick
Re-tilting the light,
Heaving the cool at your neck.
And suddenly you're out,
Back again, intent as ever,
Heavy and frisky in your freshened pelt‚Äù
(28th May is World Otter Day)
Dr Raguram
29/05/25, 9:23‚ÄØam
Whenever I read Paul Lawrence Dunbar‚Äôs poem, "Sympathy", it leaves me deeply moved. The poet uses the symbol of a caged bird to voice his angst against societal oppression. The bird suffers from the ‚Äúold, old scars‚Äù of past and it beats itself against its cage until its ‚Äúblood is red on the cruel bars.‚Äù But in spite of it, it keeps singing. It is a song of pain.
No wonder this poem was the inspiration to Maya Angelou, to title her poignant autobiography, ‚ÄòI know why the caged bird sings.‚Äô Among others, it is a searing account of her abuse and rape very early in life and ensuing trauma which cast a long shadow in her life. Angelou gave voice to countless survivors of sexual assault who, like her, endured years of trauma and silence. ‚ÄúWrite so that perhaps people who hadn‚Äôt raped anybody yet might be discouraged, people who had might be informed, people who have not been raped might understand something, and people who have been raped might forgive themselves.‚Äù Her memoir powerfully conveys a message of resilience and revival, which she poetically refers as, ‚Äúthe honeycomb of determination‚Äù. Angelou also movingly describes the trials and tribulations of growing up as a black adolescent in a crushing climate of overt racism and inherent discrimination.
The publication of this book paved way for countless women to feel inspired to narrate and share aspects of their lives that had long been shrouded in euphemism, secrecy, and shame.
Angelou summarizes her perspective succinctly, ‚ÄúMy mission in life is not merely to survive, but to thrive; and to do so with some passion, some compassion, some humour, and some style.‚Äù
(Maya Angelou 4 April 1928 - 28 May 2014)

Such a beautiful photograph. Its look reminds of a an old man who is gazing at a younger person!
02/06/25, 4:54‚ÄØpm
The photograph looks like a very colourful painting. The feathers look like rich green lawns with shades of yellow colours.
02/06/25, 6:47‚ÄØpm

04/06/25, 9:22‚ÄØam
During my early adolescent years, my uncle presented me with a BSA bicycle. I didn‚Äôt know how to ride one at that time. The task then, was to learn to ride it and in the process I fell down many a time and finally found the right balance to steer it. I often use this analogy in therapy to address the trauma and pain due to unfortunate tribulations in life which dawn upon us. These can unsettle us, but if we choose to, only briefly. The task is to unearth the emotional balance within, to navigate through the situation. The seeds for this perspective were sown through a painting of Claude Bernard outside our lecture theatre in JIPMER. Claude Bernard's concept of "milieu int√©rieur" meaning "internal environment" is a fundamental principle in physiology and medicine. It describes the body's ability to maintain a stable internal environment (homeostasis) despite external changes. Our task is to harness it, sometimes through external support and help.
Another important learning curve for me when I started cycling was that the bicycle becomes a part of you. It merges with the rhythm of pedalling and the diktats of the driver. Personally it broadened my urban and inner landscape, much as outlined in ‚ÄòZen and the art of motorcycle maintenance‚Äô. Cycling is as close to flying, you feel free, your mind feels free and your spirits take flight. It was through cycling I discovered the nooks and corners of the city and its people. I took great pride in cleaning it meticulously and taking care of it, till I handed it over to my nephew.
There is a lovely quote attributed to Mehmet Murat ildan:
Four wheels move the body, Two wheels move the soul.
Every time you miss your childhood, ride on a bicycle!
( Reflections on my cycling days, on 3rd June, the World Bicycle Day)
Dr Raguram
05/06/25, 10:22‚ÄØam
The Tamil Sangam poetry (circa 1st to 4th century CE) is a unique literary tradition among various streams of Indian literature. Devoid of mythological and religious allusions. It focused more on the environment and its impact on the individual. While the broad Sangam literature is generally categorized into akam (inner) and puram (outer), what is of great importance is that these two categories of poetry were painted on the ecological canvas of ‚Äútinais‚Äù. Tinais refer to five different environments; kurinji (mountainous regions), mullai (pastoral regions), marutham (riverine agricultural regions), neidhal (coastal regions) and palai (arid, desert regions). Sights and sounds of the environment is manifested in different locations like the mysterious mountain peaks, murmuring cool ponds and rivers, noisy sea shore, dry soulless desert land and rich agricultural pastures.
In PuranƒÅn≈´ru 2, Poet Muranjiyur MudinƒÅkanƒÅr writes;
‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ£‡Æø‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æè‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æö‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æö‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ ‡Æ§‡Øà‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æø‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Øà‡Æá‡ÆØ ‡Æ§‡ØÄ‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡Æ§‡ØÄ ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æ£‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç, ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Ææ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ
‡Æê‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÇ‡Æ§‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æá‡ÆØ‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æï‡Øà ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤
These verses describe a king by comparing his nature to the five elements, ‚ÄúYour nature is like the five elements ‚Äì the earth filled with sand,
the sky raised above the earth, wind that blows in the sky, fire that
sweeps up the wind, and water that contrasts from that fire.‚Äù
The poem draws attention to the intricate relationship between us and the environment we live in. It is imperative then to value and cherish this association.
(Penned on 5th June, World Environment Day)
Dr Raguram
05/06/25, 8:09‚ÄØpm
A very unusual photograph clicked from an angle, light falling like falls and lush greenery. We have forgotten our 'Nature' made of panchabhutas and disregarded nature that is visible.
08/06/25, 10:05‚ÄØam
Point Lobos State National Reserve in California is dramatically situated at the edge of the Pacific Ocean. It is often referred to as the ‚Äúgreatest meeting of land and water in the world‚Äù. Its rocky coastline offers a superb habitat for a huge diversity of plants animals and birds. Every time we visit the place, we feel mesmerized by its dramatic landscape. This enchanting landscape is a haven of tranquillity. At times one can hear the ocean's voice as a chorus of deafening roars when its powerful waves crash upon the rocks. But soon the waves start lapping gently against the rocks as if they are in a whispered conversation.
As I was scanning the oceanscape, I noticed a groups of Brandt‚Äôs cormorants perched on the craggy surface of the rocks. They are the largest cormorants on the Pacific Coast. Brandt's cormorants are fascinating seabirds with unique diving abilities and can often dive deep to catch fish. They roost together as groups on rocks and forage in flocks. It was a fascinating sight when they suddenly took to the sky, flying in long lines over the rippling waters of the ocean.
The Pacific Ocean in Point Lobos is a vast expanse mirroring the endless blue sky above, its surface a restless expanse of waves shimmering in sunlight. Watching it, I was reminded of a poem ‚ÄòOnce By The Pacific‚Äô by Robert Frost.
‚ÄúThe shattered water made a misty din.
Great waves looked over others coming in,
And thought of doing something to the shore
That water never did to land before.
The clouds were low and hairy in the skies,
Like locks blown forward in the gleam of eyes.
You could not tell, and yet it looked as if
The shore was lucky in being backed by cliff,
The cliff in being backed by continent;
It looked as if a night of dark intent
Was coming, and not only a night, an age.
Someone had better be prepared for rage.
There would be more than ocean-water broken
Before God's last Put out the light was spoken.‚Äù
(8th June is World Oceans Day)
Dr Raguram
08/06/25, 9:03‚ÄØpm
A good photograph can tell tales and also help us to virtually experience the sound of waves, the smell of waters and sight of birds and ocean and words of the poet describing so beautifully.
09/06/25, 9:15‚ÄØam
All through history there have been narcissistic leaders., characterized by being unduly vain and conceited with an overwhelming sense of false pride. With their insatiable need for adoration, they seek attention and constant validation, often resorting to manipulation to maintain their image. One of the greatest example of it is the Roman emperor, Nero, who died on this date of suicide. Nero surrounded himself with sycophants who only told him what he wanted to hear. This environment stifled honest feedback, preventing him from confronting unpleasant truths. As a result, Nero's leadership became increasingly erratic, culminating in a series of disastrous decisions. His response to the Great Fire of Rome exemplifies his incompetence. Instead of uniting the people, he scapegoated Christians, initiating a wave of persecution that would last for centuries.
More importantly, narcissistic leaders like Nero destabilize institutions, prioritizing personal ego over the common good. Throughout history many political leaders have traversed this territory with disastrous consequences in governance. There is an urgent need of leaders who embody virtue, courage and wisdom. Only then can we safeguard the institutions and freedoms we hold dear.
Perhaps our leaders need to look back at people like Nero, learn and unlearn important lessons from history, to govern us with sensitivity and equanimity.
Dr Raguram
11/06/25, 9:02‚ÄØam
We are all dreamers of dreams. Though it is a part of our real world experience, dream is also a window into our subconscious mind. Sometimes, our minds teeter on the edge of two worlds; the reality outside of us and the dreamscape within. In that state, we are neither fully immersed in the dreamscapes of our subconscious nor fully anchored in the rationality of waking life. Often it is a fertile breeding ground for deep reflection.
Zhuangzi, a foundational figure in Daoist philosophy, is famous for his parable of the butterfly dream. The story blurs the boundary between self and other. Zhuangzi wonders if he can truly know whether he is the dreamer or the dreamed, highlighting the limits of human understanding and the need to embrace uncertainty. He implies that life is a series of transformations, a constant flux of existence, wherein the distinction between the self and the other dissolves, leading to a newer level of awareness. Zhuangzi‚Äôs uncertainty about whether he is the dreamer or the dreamed also draws our attention to the perennial question, what defines the self?
In her travels in the wonderland, Alice had to confront this perennial question. She comes across a Caterpillar that is resting on top of a giant mushroom and smoking a hookah pipe. The two stare at each other in silence for a while before the Caterpillar asks Alice, ‚ÄúWho are you? This was not an encouraging opening for a conversation. Alice replied, rather shyly, ‚ÄúI--I hardly know, sir, just at present-- at least I know who I WAS when I got up this morning, but I think I must have been changed several times since then.‚Äù
Both Zhuangzi and Lewis Carroll indicate that the concept of self is often fluid and dynamic.
As Carl Rogers commented, "A person is a fluid process, not a fixed and static entity; a flowing river of change‚Ä¶continually changing constellation of potentialities".

I took time to go through Doist philosophy and the butterfly fable. It was an interesting read though the words used 'self' and 'consciousness' are not the same as it is used in our philosophy. But change which is constant, simple life to align with nature, being mindful are to be followed. We complicate our lives by being highly materialistic, the ideal and real selves at logger heads leads to a huge gap in understanding ourselves....
16/06/25, 8:36‚ÄØam
When we were in Wayanad a month ago, there was a prediction that the monsoon will arrive soon. Once we entered the Nagarhole forest, we were greeted with thousands of butterflies on their annual seasonal journey during pre-monsoon period. It was so wonderful to see them fluttering around in hordes. The raucous call of the peahen resonated across the forest. I recalled that the word "Mylapore" in Chennai is derived from the Tamil phrase "Mayil ƒÅrpparikkum ≈´r," which translates to "land of the peacock scream." As we ventured further, a peacock flew in front of us, looked around for a while, and then began its elegant, dazzling dance. Slowly, it lifted its tail to form a semi-circular fan, which rippled in iridescent colours. I noticed that when they strum and flicker the feathers, strangely, the eyespots at the end seemed to remain relatively still.
It is a commonly held belief that peacocks respond to the change of seasons and their dance heralds the arrival of monsoon. This has been one of the favourite subjects in Indian poetry.
In the poetry of the Sangam era (300BCE-300CE), peacocks and the monsoon are often associated, with peacocks symbolizing the joy and vibrancy of the monsoon season. The monsoon is a time of renewal and abundance, and peacocks, known for their beauty and flamboyant display, are seen as messengers of its arrival. A lovely poem in Ainkurunooru; 492, states;
‚Äú‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Øá ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡Æû‡Øç‡Æû‡Øà ‡ÆÜ‡Æ≤ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç
‡Æ®‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æ±‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡ÆÆ‡Æ≤‡Æ∞
‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Øá ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤ ‡ÆÆ‡Ææ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æ®‡Øã‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï
‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Øá ‡Æâ‡Æ≥‡Øç‡Æ≥‡Æø ‡Æµ‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æ©‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡Øç
‡Æ®‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡ÆÖ‡Æ∞‡Æø‡Æµ‡Øà ‡Æï‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Æø‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ∞‡Øà‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Øá‚Äù
‚ÄúWhen a peacock dances like you,
And fragrant jasmine blooms
like the scent of your forehead,
When a doe gazes timidly like you,
I rush home thinking of you,
Swifter than a monsoon cloud.‚Äù
In a 16th century poetic work, Mayurasandesa (The Peacock‚Äôs Message) written by Udaya in Malayalam, the poet writes, ‚ÄúIn order to bring joy to the world, you dance, creating happiness. You, the descendant of Indira, offer solace to those in woe and brighten their world, much like the sun casting its rays on the lotus to bloom‚Äù.
In a beautiful poem, ‚ÄòNew Rain‚Äô, Rabindranath Tagore writes;
‚ÄúMy heart dances today ‚Äî dances like a peacock.
Like the shimmer of its plumes,
My heart glistens with rapturous colours.
When I see the sky, my longing loses itself in euphoria.
My heart dances today ‚Äî dances like a peacock.‚Äù
The peacock‚Äôs brilliant hues as it dances does not merely reside in the pigment of its feathers but is due to refraction of light streaming through its plumage. As I watched it, I wondered as to how important it will be for us to let the light of awareness permeate and transform our inner selves and set it aglow.
Dr Raguram
19/06/25, 8:29‚ÄØam
We are in throes of yet another war. As missiles soar in the sky, screams fill the air and blood wets the ground, will the futility of war ever descend upon us all? I wonder.
One of the most unsettling portrayal of war and its aftermath is a painting, ‚ÄòThe Face of War‚Äô by Salvador Dali. Dali was profoundly impacted by the events of the Spanish Civil War and World War II and he gave expression to his personal angst in his own unique way in this painting. It is a surrealistic portrayal of the impact of war on the human psyche. In this painting there is a disembodied, withered face, resembling a corpse, on the background of a barren, desert landscape. There is an unmistakable expression of fear, misery and agony on the face. The sockets of the eyes and mouth contain smaller faces which in turn have more faces within them, suggesting the infinite number of people who suffer the tragedy of war. Swarming around the face are serpents, representing relentless attacks by malevolent forces. Dali left his handprint in the lower right corner of the canvas to convey that this painting came from his own deep agony about the impact of war.
Whenever I see this painting, I can‚Äôt take my eyes off the haunting forms which are manifestations of the dread spawned by war. It is a chilling portrayal of the psychological trauma inflicted by the harshness of war. The wounds of battles are not merely physical. They leave behind craters smouldering with intense pain, unfathomable anguish and deep despair. As the world crumbles all around, the minds of people left behind after the war crumble too.
As Aldous Huxley observed, "The most shocking fact about war is that its victims and its instruments are individual human beings, and that these individual beings are condemned by the monstrous conventions of politics to murder or be murdered in quarrels not their own."
Amy Patterson, whose son returned from the war, deeply traumatized wrote these poignant lines in her poem, ‚ÄòA Mother‚Äôs Tear.‚Äô
‚ÄúHe screams in the night,
for the battle still roars,
as he lays in his bed,
he re-lives all the horror.
Nobody heard the fight,
he still fights,
except for his Mama,
who comforts him every night.
He never will be,
the son I once knew,
the war killed that part,
for freedom, for you.
Great Nation, Great Leaders,
and all those who will hear,
Freedom began
On a mother‚Äôs first tear.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
20/06/25, 8:41‚ÄØam
When I think of the current war scenario, I am reminded of an Aesop fable, ‚ÄòBirds, The Beasts and The Bat.‚Äù
The fable reads, ‚ÄúThe Birds and the Beasts declared war against each other. No compromise was possible, and so they went at it tooth and claw. It is said the quarrel grew out of the persecution the race of Geese suffered at the teeth of the Fox family. The Beasts, too, had cause for fight. The Eagle was constantly pouncing on the Hare, and the Owl dined daily on Mice. It was a terrible battle. Many a Hare and many a Mouse died. Chickens and Geese fell by the score‚Äîand the victor always stopped for a feast. Now the Bat family had not openly joined either side. They were a very politic race. So when they saw the Birds getting the better of it, they were Birds for all there was in it. But when the tide of battle turned, they immediately sided with the Beasts. When the battle was over, the conduct of the Bats was discussed at the peace conference. Such deceit was unpardonable, and Birds and Beasts made common cause to drive out the Bats. And since then the Bat family hides in dark towers and deserted ruins, flying out only in the night.‚Äù
The fable highlights the problems associated with trying to remain neutral in a conflict. If one constantly switches allegiances, it can lead to losing the trust and support from either side. The bat's attempts to benefit from both sides ultimately results in him having no friends or allies."
‚ÄúA Beast he would be, or a bird,
As might suit, thought the Bat: but he erred.
When the battle was done,
He found that no one
Would take him for friend at his word.‚Äù

25/06/25, 10:53‚ÄØam
I first heard the Beatles way back in 1975: it was the album, ‚ÄòSgt Pepper‚Äôs Lonely Hearts Club Band.‚Äô I had never heard anything like it before. I was mesmerized by its unique instrumentation, the harmonic tones and the lovely vocals. I‚Äôve heard this album so many times and find something new every time I hear the songs. The album left a lasting impression on me and I was hooked to the Beatles. Over a course of time, Ahalya and myself started collecting their albums and these vinyl records have a special place in our home. Their repertoire is vast and stunning, from love songs to deeply reflective, introspective lyrics which explore themes of loneliness like in ‚ÄòEleanor Rigby.‚Äô To me their songs are sheer poetry. For instance, the song, ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs Leaving Home‚Äù stands out as one of their loveliest and saddest songs. It is like a short story in a musical form, narrating the plight of a young girl who feels unloved at home: ‚ÄòShe‚Äôs leaving home after living alone for so many years‚Äô, to embark on a journey to find solace with her new companion. Each of their albums is a creative gem to cherish.
Like me, Murakami also seems to have had an abiding love for the Beatles. It seeps through many of his works. There is a short story titled ‚ÄòYesterday‚Äô and another one titled, ‚ÄòWith The Beatles‚Äô, in which narrator's fondest memories is of a girl he encounters in the school corridor, clutching an LP of ‚ÄúWith The Beatles‚Äù. I am particularly fond of his novel whose title is based on a Beatle song, ‚ÄòNorwegian Wood‚Äô from the album ‚ÄòRubber Soul.‚Äô The novel begins with the main protagonist, Toru Watanabe, arriving at Hamburg Airport while the Beatles‚Äô song ‚ÄúNorwegian Wood‚Äù is playing on the speakers. The song‚Äôs opening line (‚ÄúI once had a girl, or should I say she once had me.‚Äù) succinctly captures the melancholic tone in the relationship of the two main characters Toru and Naoko. There is beautiful part in the novel when Toru asks, ‚ÄúWhat happens when people open their hearts?‚Äù and Reiko responds, ‚ÄúThey get better.‚Äù And the Beatles achieve this seamlessly in their songs.
(It was on 25th June that the Beatles participated in the BBC show ‚ÄòOur World‚Äô in 1967, performing, ‚ÄúAll You Need Is Love‚Äù to an international audience which is now commemorated as the World Beatles Day).

07/07/25, 9:46‚ÄØam
Whenever I course along the Big Sur, I am reminded of authors, artists and spiritual seekers who had made this pristine stretch their creative abode. I had written sometime back about Jack Kerouac who wrote his novel, ‚ÄòBig Sur‚Äô in a cabin under the picturesque Bixby Creek Bridge. Another author who found a sanctuary there was Henry Miller. I have read many of his novels, including his controversial novel, ‚ÄòThe Tropic of Cancer.‚Äô But one work of his which left a lasting impression on me is the ‚ÄòThe Air-Conditioned Nightmare.‚Äô
The book is a travelogue of his journey across US in the 40s. When I re-read it now many of his observations ring so true about the nation. He finds USA, vapid and soulless, a nation of people who are a ‚Äúvulgar, pushing mob whose passions are easily mobilized by demagogues, newspaper men, religious quacks, agitators and such like. To call this a society of free peoples is blasphemous. What have we to offer the world beside the superabundant loot which we recklessly plunder from the earth under the maniacal delusion that this insane activity represents progress and enlightenment?‚Äù
At times he may sound like a grumpy old man, feeling a deep sense of disquiet observing a nation where giant industries which pollute the environment and are impervious to the lives of their workers, and a population entrapped in a fast web of material comforts and relentless mass consumerism. He finds the people totally unaware of the world outside who, ‚Äúbludgeon one another with facts and theories gleaned from cursory readings of newspapers, magazines, and digests.‚Äù He observes the giant, corporate American who is ‚Äúseated in a comfortable chair in New York, Chicago or San Francisco, a man surrounded by every luxury and yet paralyzed with fear and anxiety, controls the lives and destinies of thousands of men and women whom he has never seen, whom he never wishes to see and whose fate he is thoroughly uninterested in.‚Äù Writing in 1940s, he laments, ‚ÄòThe world meanwhile looks to us with a desperation such as it has never known before. Where is the democratic spirit? Where are the leaders?‚Äù
Even though his narration might sound bleak, he notices a nation ‚Äústill intact, like a piece of music which goes on being played forever. The instruments wear out, and the players too, but the notes are eternal, and you are made of nothing but invisible notes which even the faintest zephyr can shake a tune out of.‚Äù

Philosophy

10/01/25, 11:24‚ÄØam
The Padma Purana narrates the history of Vaikunta Ekadasi through the episode of the asura Muran, who secures Vishnu‚Äôs blessings but abuses his power. Vishnu Himself engages him in a combat. When Vishnu rests briefly in a cave, the asura tries to ambush Him at which point, a female form springs from Vishnu‚Äôs chest and kills Muran on the 11th day of Margazhi sukla paksham. Vishnu names her as Ekadasi. She seeks Moksha for Muran and anyone who prays to Vishnu on this day. It is believed that Vishnu opens the north gate of heaven, Vaikunta vaasal for those who pray to him on this day. Vaishnavite temples replicate this practice by opening the Sorga Vaasal.
Lord Vishnu has five states. Param, Vyuham, Vibhavam, Antaryami and Archam. The first state Param is the state known as Paramapadam, Vaikuntam or Moksam, which is located in a space beyond all worlds. This is a sculptural depiction of Para-Vasudeva from cave 3 at Badami. He is shown here with four arms, seating on Sheshanaga (serpent), also known as Ananta, who symbolises primordial principle of time. Vishnu is seated on the coils of Ananta, in a relaxed manner with his left leg folded over the coils and right leg resting down. His upper two hands hold shankha and chakra while his lower-right hand is placed on the coils and lower-left hand rests on the left leg. The five hoods of Ananta serve as a parasol over his head. The sculpture is exquisitely carved with fine ornamentation and eye for detail.
Dr Raguram
13/01/25, 8:12‚ÄØam
Music and dance are not merely aesthetic forms but also serve as conduits for realizing the divine presence. For instance, Arudra Darisanam which is observed today, celebrates the cosmic dance of Lord Shiva as Nataraja. Nataraja‚Äôs dance is not just a physical expression but signifies the underlying vibrations that sustain the universe, embodying creation, preservation, destruction, release, and embodiment, often referred to as Panchakrityas.
One of the beautiful expression of Nataraja‚Äôs dance is in the form of Alidhanrita Shiva. This sculpture is from Kailasanathar Kovil in Kancheepuram. Here he is depicted in a Swastika Mudra. On the right side is Parvathi with an adoring expression relishing the dance, with a Nandi below her. On the left is a musician playing the drums. The animated Shiva Ganas are dancing with sheer abandon at the bottom. Right on top is a small, exquisitely carved Ganesha.
Kaviyogi Sri Suddhananda Bharathi composed a beautiful song about the dancing Shiva, ‚Äò‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æü‡Æø' ‚ÄútUkkiya tiruvaDi‚Äô in raga Shankarabharanam. He pays obeisance to the Lord in the opening line;
‚Äú‡Æ§‡ØÇ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æü‡Æø ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æ£‡Øà ‡Æé‡Æ© ‡Æ®‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Æø‡Æ©‡Øá‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æ®‡Æü‡Æ∞‡Ææ‡Æú‡Æ©‡Øá‚Äù
‚ÄúI seek salvation in your raised foot, Oh Supreme Lord, Nataraja.‚Äù
This particular verse in Thevaram by Tirunavukkarasar, beautifully articulates our abiding quest for salvation from the Lord;
‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡ÆÆ‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡Æ®‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Øã‡Æ£‡Æø ‡Æ™‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æø
‡ÆÆ‡Æ§‡Æø‡ÆØ‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡Æô‡Øç ‡Æï‡Øã‡Æ≤‡Øà ‡ÆØ‡ØÇ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æö‡Øç
‡Æö‡Æø‡Æ©‡ÆÆ‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡Æû‡Øç ‡Æö‡Æ∞‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Øà ‡Æè‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æö‡Øç
‡Æö‡ØÜ‡Æ±‡Æø‡Æï‡Æü ‡Æ≤‡Øã‡Æü‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ§‡ØÅ
‡ÆÆ‡Æ§‡Æ©‡ØÜ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æ±‡Øà ‡Æ§‡Ææ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø
‡ÆÆ‡Æ±‡Æø‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡Øã ‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡ÆÖ‡Æ±‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æµ‡Øä‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æ£‡Ææ(‡Æ§‡ØÅ)
‡Æâ‡Æ©‡Øà‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æâ‡Æ£‡Æ∞‡Øç‡Æµ‡Øà ‡Æ®‡Æ≤‡Øç‡Æï‡Ææ‡ÆØ‡Øç
‡Æí‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æ±‡Æø‡ÆØ‡ØÇ ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡Æü‡Øà‡ÆØ ‡Æï‡Øã‡Æµ‡Øá.
