14/02/25, 8:00‚ÄØam
Love is in the air once again and let us cast our glance beyond red roses and chocolates and delve deeper to unearth its roots in the vast and vibrant tapestry of Indian culture.
Rig Veda in Nasadiya Sukta comments on the origin of the universe, wherein desire is recognized as the primal source:
‡§§‡§Æ‡•ë ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡•í‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ë‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Ç‡•í‡§≥‡•ç‡§π‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡•ë‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á‡•í‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ë‡§≤‡§ø‡•í‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ë‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§á‡•í‡§¶‡§Ç‡•§
‡§§‡•Å‡•í‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡•í‡§≠‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø‡•ë‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç‡•í ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡•í‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ë‡§∏‡•í‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ë‡§π‡§ø‡•í‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡•ë‡§Ø‡•í‡§§‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç‡•ë
‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•í‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡•í ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ë‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•í‡§§‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡•í ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ë‡§∏‡•ã‡•í ‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ë: ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡•í‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡•ë‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•í‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡•í‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ë‡§§‡§ø‡•í ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ë‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç ‡§π‡•É‡•í‡§¶‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•í‡§§‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡•ë ‡§ï‡•í‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡•ë ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä‡•í‡§∑‡§æ‡••‡•™‡••
There are numerous, often varying interpretations of these verses. In essence it states that ‚Äúin the beginning, darkness was hidden by darkness with no distinguishing sign; all of this was water. The life force that was covered with emptiness arose through the power of heat. Desire (kama) arose in it in the beginning; that was the first seed of the mind. Wise sages seeking in their hearts, with wisdom, found it to be the bond that connects existence with non-existence.‚Äù
It is a phenomenally perceptive way to describe the origin of desire and its influence.
The formless desire had to find a form and the Hindu pantheon found its own cupid, Kamadeva.
Kamadeva and Rati weave a tale beyond mere desire. It's a passionate love story, defying death and destiny. Kamadeva is an alluring deity, wielding a bow and arrow adorned with flowers and bees, capable of kindling the flames of love in any heart. In one notable tale, the gods, seeking to preserve the cosmic equilibrium, wished for Shiva, the Destroyer, to rediscover love. Engrossed in profound meditation, Shiva remained oblivious to such desires. To provoke him, Kamadeva took action, striking the meditative god with an arrow of love. The repercussions of this act were unexpected. Shiva, disturbed from his deep meditation, became enraged. He activated the formidable power of his third eye, reducing Kama to ashes. Overwhelmed with grief, Rati fell at the feet of the Lord and beseeched him to spare her husband. Touched by her desperate pleas, Shiva revoked his actions and brought Kamadeva back to life, with a rider that he would be formless from that day onwards. Though remaining unseen, he wields his arrow bursting with blossoming flowers and bees to kindle and awaken the spirit of love in humans.
In verse 6 of Saundarya Lahari, Adi Shankaracharya writes:
‡§ß‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§É
‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å-‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§®-‡§∞‡§•‡§É ‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç
‡§Ö‡§™‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶-‡§Æ‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•á
‚ÄúOh ,daughter of the mountain of ice,
With a bow made of flowers,
Bow string made of honey bees,
Five arrows made of only tender flowers,
With spring as his minister,
And riding on the chariot of breeze from Malaya mountains
The god of love who does not have a body,
Gets the sideways glance of your holy eyes,
And is able to win all the world alone.‚Äù
This sculpture from Khajuraho has beautifully captured the rapturous expression of love in Kamadeva and Rati.
Dr Raguram
15/02/25, 6:34‚ÄØpm
It is really joyful to see the sunset caught by your camera Sir. Yes. But they are blessed with the talent to convey in a such a touching manner!
18/02/25, 8:34‚ÄØam
Saints and seers have drawn inspiration and spiritual knowledge from objects of nature. Often our spiritual journey has been described by mystics as the flight of a bird.
Birds played a crucial role in Sri Ramakrishna‚Äôs life. When he was a six-year-old, he was walking along the fields and suddenly the sky was overcast with thick black clouds. A flock of white birds flew across the clouds. When Sri Ramakrishna saw this, (his name was Gadadhar then), he was totally absorbed in the sight, was motionless and he became unconscious. Later on he said, ‚ÄúThat was my first ecstasy.‚Äù It was his first spiritual, mystic experience which caste its impact in many of his sayings & teachings.
In one of the prayer meetings, he narrated a story, ‚ÄúA bird sat on the mast of a ship. When the ship sailed through the mouth of the Ganges into the 'black waters' of the ocean, the bird failed to notice the fact. When it finally became aware of the ocean, it left the mast and flew north in search of land. But it found no limit to the water and so returned. After resting a while it flew south. There too it found no limit to the water. Panting for breath the bird returned to the mast. Again, after resting a while, it flew east and then west. Finding no limit to the water in any direction, at last it settled down on the mast of the ship. What a man seeks is very near him. Still he wanders about from place to place. As long as a man feels that God is 'there', he is ignorant. But he attains knowledge when he feels that God is 'here'.‚Äù
There was an interesting incident when Sri Ramakrishna mentioned that a devotee is like a ‚Äòchataka‚Äô bird. This bird will drink only rainwater, as it falls from the clouds. So it is always watching the sky. As the bird watches the sky, so the devotees always look to God to appease the thirst of learning. Naren, (Swami Vivekananda) was listening and he exclaimed: "Sir, though it is the common belief that the ‚Äòchataka‚Äô bird drinks only rainwater, it is not a fact that it does not take other kinds of water. I have seen these birds drink water from rivers and ponds." Sri Ramakrishna said: "Is that so? Do they drink like other birds? Then I am mistaken. If you have seen it, then there is no doubt about it." But Sri Ramakrishna, was a little disturbed, "If I am mistaken in this, then I may also be mistaken in other ways too." After a few days Naren called Sri Ramakrishna and said: "Sir, see a ‚Äòchataka‚Äô bird is drinking Ganga water." Sri Ramakrishna rushed out of the room and said: "Where? Where?" When they came near the spot, what they saw was just a small bat. Sri Ramakrishna laughed and said: "You rogue; it is a bat. You have given me so much trouble for nothing. Now I shall be wiser and not believe everything you say!‚Äù
Sri Ramakrishna also used the analogy of the mythical ‚ÄòHoma Bird‚Äô to explain the intense renunciation and spiritual aspiration of the seeker. The bird lives quite high up in the sky and lays egg at that height. Because of the height the egg keeps falling for many days. While falling, it hatches and the chick continues to fall. This goes on for many days. One day the chick opens its eyes and realizes about the impending death if it hits the ground. Then it gives a shrill cry and shoots up towards its mother. It keeps going in the upward direction and does not look behind. Sri Ramakrishna used to call Naren who later became Swami Vivekananda as a ‚ÄòHoma Bird.‚Äô
When I looked at the logo of Ramakrisha Math (which was designed by Swami Vivekananda), I was struck with its striking similarity with the logo of my alma mater, NIMHANS, except for the serpent encircling it. It is believed that when milk diluted with water is given to the swan, it sips only the milk, leaving the water behind. Water represents ignorance and the milk symbolizes knowledge. The image of the swan signifies the discerning mind that is in pursuit of the Real.
According to the ancient tradition, ascetics who strive to gain liberation are classified into four classes. They are ku·π≠ƒ´cakas, bah≈´dakas, ha·πÉsas and paramaha·πÉsas. Paramahamsa refers to the highest level of spiritual development of an enlightened, exalted soul.
(Penned on the birthday of Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa)
Dr Raguram
19/02/25, 3:52‚ÄØpm
Thank you very much Sir for the recollection of the teachings of Sri Ramakrishna. A realised soul who blended Advaita and Bhakti. He has narrated many stories to hone in on the essence by taking animals and birds as examples.
21/02/25, 1:51‚ÄØpm
Very true Sir..
24/02/25, 10:13‚ÄØam
Ibn Battuta was a medieval Muslim explorer, scholar and an intrepid traveller. He began his travels in the 14th century when he was just 20 years old and over the course of the next 29 years he travelled about 75,000 miles, visiting 44 countries. Near the end of Ibn Battuta's life, the Sultan of Morocco insisted that he dictate the story of his travels and today we can read translations of that account, which is generally referred to as Ibn Battuta‚Äôs ‚ÄòRihla‚Äô, or journey. It is available online and makes a fascinating read.
Ibn Battuta‚Äôs travels in India were mostly in the north and towards the end of his stay, he came down to the Malabar coast. When I was reading about the accounts of his sojourn in the Malabar coast, I was astonished by his keen sense of observation about people and places. He gives an accurate description of the most important produce of the region, pepper.
‚ÄúThe pepper-bushes look like vines. The natives plant them opposite the coco-nut trees around which the pepper-bushes climb like vines; but they have no tendrils ('asl≈´j) as in the case of vines. The leaves of the bush look like leaves of asafoetida and also like the leaves of the blackberry bush. The pepper-bush bears small bunches of fruit, the grains of which resemble those of ab≈´qinnina as long as they are green. When autumn comes the pepper is plucked and exposed on reed-mats to the sun just as is done with grapes when they are turned into raisins. It is continually turned round until it is completely dry and becomes black; then it is sold to the merchants. The common people in our country think that it is roasted by the fire, whence the wrinkles on the pepper-grains come. But it is not so, since the wrinkles are caused by the sun. I saw the pepper grains in the city of Calicut (QƒÅlƒ±q√ºl) emptied out into bushels as is done with the millet in our country.‚Äù
Reading ‚ÄòRihla‚Äô I felt as if I was following the footsteps of this peripatetic traveller who remarked, ‚Äútraveling, it leaves you speechless, then turns you into a storyteller‚Äù
(Ibun Battuta born on 24 February 1304, Tangier, Morocco)
Dr Raguram
27/02/25, 8:42‚ÄØam
We all long for the home. It is less a physical space than a place filled with enduring memories. Those memories never fade completely and have the power to catapult us back through time. Its centripetal force has an irresistible allure.
Sometimes, home can be elusive. Particularly when one is living far away and keeps longing to return to a land which is in throes of conflict. Often there is a deep yearning for that familiar, comforting place, especially when the situation doesn‚Äôt fulfil the need to return. There is a beautiful Welsh word ‚ÄòHiraeth‚Äô that has no direct English translation. It refers to a homesickness tinged with grief and sadness. A poet who gave expression to that feeling most powerfully in modern times was Mahmoud Darwish, a Palestinian author. He spent most of his time as a refugee and spent his final days in the US. Mahmoud Darwish died on 9 August 2008 and his mortal remains were buried next to the Palace of Culture at Ramallah.
Mahmoud Darwish‚Äôs ‚ÄúTo My Mother‚Äù is one of the most poignant poems I have ever read and the following lines resonate deeply within.
‚ÄúI am old
Give me back the stars of childhood
That I may chart the homeward quest
Back with the migrant birds,
Back to your awaiting nest.‚Äù
I was reminded of these lines when I saw a sunbird making frequent sorties to feed and nurture it‚Äôs chick. The chick would be quiet most of the time and the moment she heard the fluttering wings of the mother, would start making a low pitched chirping noises. In a few days, as its wings grow stronger, it will fly away from the nest but memories of the nest would remain deeply etched in its being.
Dr Raguram
04/03/25, 9:34‚ÄØam
I was not aware of the teachings of Baba Shaikh Farid till I read the book about him edited by Prof Gurbachan Singh Talib. Baba Farid was a great Sufi mystic, teacher and poet. He was born in the month of Ramadan in the year 1173 CE at a place near Multan called Kotheval. He was named after the Sufi poet Fariduddin Attar. Farid in Arabic language means 'Unique'. He came to be known also as Shakarganj or Ganj-i-Shakar (Treasury of Sugar). There is an interesting story behind this nickname. Farid‚Äôs mother Qarsum Bibi, used to place a small packet of sugar under the prayer mat as a reward for the child to say his prayers regularly. Once she forgot to put it under the mat. To her great surprise a packet of sugar appeared in the usual place. Following this miracle, he came to be known as ‚ÄòShakarganj.‚Äô Another explanation attributes the title 'Shakarganj' to the blessing which Farid received from his spiritual teacher, Khwaja Qutubuddin Bakhtiyar Kaki (the famous Qutb Minar in Delhi was built in his name) who praised the sweetness of Farid‚Äôs disposition and remarked; "You shall be sweet like sugar."
There is a beautiful story attributed to Baba Farid;
‚ÄúOnce a king came to see him. He had brought a present for Farid. It was a beautiful pair of scissors, golden, studded with diamonds. It was very valuable, rare and unique. He touched Farid‚Äôs feet and gave him the scissors. Farid looked at it and gave it back to the king, and said, ‚ÄúSir, many many thanks for the present that you have brought. It is a beautiful thing, but utterly useless for me. It will be better if you can give me a needle. Scissors I don‚Äôt need: a needle will do.‚Äù The king said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand. If you need a needle, you will need scissors too.‚Äù Farid said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need scissors because scissors cut things apart. I need a needle because it can put things together. My whole teaching is based on love, bringing people together. I need a needle so that I can stitch them together. The scissors are useless; they cut, they disconnect. Next time when you come, just an ordinary needle will be enough‚Äù.
These lines are so pertinent now in a world brimming with growing distrust. Too often we underestimate the power of compassion that can bind us together. Let us untether the love deeply buried in our hearts and heal ourselves and the ‚Äòothers‚Äô.
In Rumi‚Äôs eloquent words;
‚ÄúI will soothe and heal you,
I will bring you roses.
I too have been covered with thorns.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
06/03/25, 9:57‚ÄØam
Michelangelo famously observed that "Every block of stone has a statue inside it and it is the task of the sculptor to discover it." For him, the process of sculpting involved bringing out the ideal form lurking inside. Each one of us has an ideal self and our aspiration in life is to actualize it. Relationships, especially close, intimate ones like in marriage have an important role in facilitating the emergence of the ideal self in each other. The process would involve identifying qualities in our partners that already exist within them, but remain latent. Like sculpting a statue from marble, couples can gently chip away at each other‚Äôs rough edges to reveal their inner beauty. This is often referred to as the ‚ÄòMichelangelo Phenomenon.‚Äô Just as Michelangelo saw the process of sculpting as releasing the ideal forms hidden in the marble, close partners sculpt one another to bring out the best in each other. Like the sculptor, the partner doesn't create something out of nothing, he or she brings out qualities that inherently exist.
We all hold visions of our ‚Äúideal selves‚Äù that long to be realized. Our partners can be the chisels and mallets that gently unveil our inner potential through affirmation and support over the course of a relationship. In this way partners can affirm and empower each other‚Äôs growth.
However, wielding the chisel is a delicate process. When one partner imposes his/her vision of the ‚Äòideal self‚Äô onto the other, it can lead to deep resentment in the partner, leading onto tremendous strain and distress. There is also the possibility that one might subjugate the real, aspiring self to meet the partner‚Äôs expectations.
We are all capable of breaking free from the limitations that hold us back to discover the beauty that is confined inside of us. A caring, sensitive partner can play a catalysing role in facilitating that process.
In the words of Michelangelo, ‚ÄúI saw the angel in the marble and carved until I set him free‚Äù

28/03/25, 11:25‚ÄØam
One of the most vital tenet of mysticism is its call for self-annihilation as an important prerequisite for the ultimate union with the Divine. It emerged in life and writings of two women who lived far apart and could not possibly have known of each other; St Teresa of Avila and Akka Mahadevi.
St. Teresa of Avila, was a 16th-century Spanish mystic and a Catholic saint, who was born on this date in 1515. She wrote a book, the "Interior Castle" to describe the individual soul's journey towards its unification with God. Reading through it, I was struck by her use of the metaphor that the castle has seven mansions, each representing a different stage of spiritual development. I thought that these seven mansions are akin to transiting through seven planes of consciousness to realize the Divine. St Teresa of Avila provides practical advice and insights as to how prayer, meditation further the path towards the ultimate merger with God. The final stage is one intense ecstasy of realisation of the deepest amalgamation with the Divine. St. Teresa of Avila emphasized that it is only through complete renunciation and total surrender to God, one can experience the Divine.
Like her, Akka Mahadevi relinquished all worldly possessions, including her clothing, in a radical act of spiritual devotion. This decision was not merely an act of defiance against societal expectations but emerged from profound spiritual convictions. She believed that true devotion to God necessitated annihilation of self and complete detachment from materialistic trappings. Her Vachanas are replete with her deep desire to merge with her beloved Chennamallikarjuna. She writes;
‚ÄúHow can milk swallow ghee and remain separate?
Who can separate fire from the sun‚Äôs radiance?
Chennamallikarjuna,
Great One without bounds
seeing how you are hidden within me not separated
I opened my eyes.‚Äù
Both St Teresa of Avila and Akka Mahadevi forged an inseparable bond with the God spirit through unflinching devotion and a life of ultimate renunciation, summarized eloquently in a Vachana by Akka Mahadevi;
‚ÄúLike treasure hidden in the ground,
like flavour in the fruit,
like gold in the rock
and oil in the seed,
the Absolute is hidden in the heart.‚Äù

02/04/25, 9:11‚ÄØam
Literature has provided us with rich insights into the landscape of mental health Through the written word, authors have been able to delve into the depths of the human psyche, providing insights into the inner struggles, triumphs, and vulnerabilities of individuals grappling with mental illness.
I was reading Nikolai Gogol‚Äôs powerful story ‚ÄòMemoirs of a Madman‚Äô, which was published in 1835. The story follows the descent into insanity of Poprishchin, a low-level civil servant who becomes convinced that he is the rightful heir to the Spanish throne; ‚ÄúSpain has a king. He has been found. I am that king. Only this very day did I learn of it. I confess, it came to me suddenly in a flash of lightning. I don‚Äôt understand how I could have thought and imagined that I was a titular councillor‚Äù. He starts hearing dogs speak to one another. More interestingly, he hears them discussing letters they have written to each other; ‚ÄúI confess, lately I had begun sometimes to hear and see things no one had ever seen or heard before. Ah, you pup! I was very surprised to hear her speak in human language. But later, when I‚Äôd thought it over properly, I at once ceased to be surprised‚Äù. The hallucinations and delusions became more frequent, he was taken to the hospital; ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm safe in hazarding a guess that I‚Äôve fallen into the hands of the Inquisition, and the person I thought was a minister of state was really the Grand Inquisitor‚Äù. His stay in the hospital was not too pleasant as he was subjected to various kinds of physical treatments; ‚Äúthey began dripping cold water on my head. I‚Äôve never experienced such hell before‚Ä¶ Judging by all probabilities, I guess I may have fallen into the hands of the Inquisition‚Äù.
The story ends on a poignant note; ‚ÄúO mother, mother, save your unhappy son! Let a tear fall on his aching head! See how they torture him! Press the poor orphan to your bosom! He has no rest in this world; they hunt him from place to place. Mother, mother, have pity on your sick child!‚Äù
The story is a moving portrayal of Poprishchin‚Äôs delusions of grandeur, hallucinations, and finally his complete break with reality. As Ben Okri commented, ‚ÄúThe fact of storytelling hints at a fundamental human unease, hints at human imperfection. Where there is perfection there is no story to tell.‚Äù
(Nikolai Gogol born on 1st April 1809)
Dr Raguram
12/04/25, 10:04‚ÄØam
Parasrampura is a nondescript village in Jhunjhunu district, near Nawalgarh in the Shekhawati region of Rajasthan. We were keen to see the Chhatri (cenotaph) erected in 1750 in memory of Thakur Shardul Singh which is said to house some of the oldest frescoes of the region. When we reached the place we found it to be overgrown with weeds and poorly maintained. But once we cast our glance inside the dome, we were transported into a magical realm, the likes of which we had never set our eyes on before. Miniature paintings adorned the entire ceiling. Each and every inch was decorated with intricate paintings done in ochre tones. They depicted events in the life of Thakur Shardul Singh, interspersed with episodes of Hindu mythology, especially the penultimate battle of the Ramayana.
During the battle of Lanka, Lakshman was grievously wounded by Indrajit, son of Ravana. Seeing Lakshman was close to death, Jambavan commanded Hanuman to fetch immediately ‚ÄòSanjivani booti‚Äô, a powerful medicinal herb that has the power to revive the dead found only on the Dronagiri mountain. Hanuman leapt up and soared through the skies across a great distance to Dronagiri to fetch the life-saving herb. But having reached Dronagiri mountain Hanuman could not identify the plant Sanjivani. As he could not afford to waste time searching for the herb, he quickly tore up part of the whole mountain The villagers of the tiny hamlet of Dronagiri in Uttarakhand, identify a nearby mountain as the mythical Dronagiri mountain mentioned in the Ramayana. But they have a totally different take on this tale. They are angry and refuse to forgive Hanuman for mutilating the right flank of their precious mountain. As per the local beliefs, when Hanuman flew into the region in search of the Sanjivani plant to revive Lakshman, the villagers of Dronagiri did not reveal the identity of the magical mountain to him as it was sacred to them. But time was running out and Lakshman was near death, so Hanuman disguised himself as an old sage and begged an elderly woman in the village to help him identify the magical mountain where the herb grew. The woman took pity on the sage and pointed out the mountain which was thickly populated by various shrubs and trees. Hanuman then proceeded to uproot half of the mountain and carried it away along with the magic herb. The villagers were furious and punished the old woman. Reportedly, since Hanuman destroyed a part of their sacred mountain, the villagers of Dronagiri village do not keep an idol of Hanuman in their homes even today.
This section of the fresco depicts Hanuman carrying the Sanjeevi Parvatha with portrayal of the Thakur Shardul Singh‚Äôs court on the left side of the panel.

28/04/25, 7:39‚ÄØam
It must have been a beautiful morning when scores of people made their way to Baisaran which is often referred to as "Mini-Switzerland". Reportedly it is one of the most scenic places near Pahalgam. When people settled down in the lovely large green meadow with the grand backdrop of pine trees and mountains they would have hardly anticipated the turn of events. Suddenly, bullets rained down on unsuspecting people, mostly men, who were shot at very close range. Horror and terror must have engulfed their companions who ran to safety. In that moment their lives changed for ever. The emotional trauma they experienced will leave a lasting impact among the survivors.
Even on reading about the incident and the experiences of the survivors, one is overwhelmed with a deep sense of anguish. Often it is difficult to express that pain in words. Sometimes, creative artists unmask that feeling in paintings. I recall the iconic painting of Edward Munch, ‚ÄòThe Scream‚Äô. It features a figure with a terrified expression, surrounded by a swirling, vibrant landscape that reflects the emotional intensity of the moment. Munch used a distorted form and intense colours to unveil that moment of intense dread. In his words, ‚ÄúI felt tired and ill. I stopped and looked out over the fjord ‚Äî the sun was setting, and the clouds turning blood red. I sensed a scream passing through nature; it seemed to me that I heard the scream. I painted this picture, painted the clouds as actual blood. The color shrieked.‚Äù
‚ÄòThe Scream‚Äô stands as a timeless reminder of the existential dread that can make inroads into our lives and overwhelm us at the most unanticipated moments in our lives. The painting‚Äôs shriek, echoes deeply within our hearts. It unites us all in collective empathy and determination to respond to the anguish and pain with renewed resilience.
Sometimes the most painful tears are not the ones that fall from our eyes. They're the ones that tumble from our hearts and find their way to those in throes of unbearable anguish.

Yes Sir it is no doubt a horrifying experience, most unexpected unlike a natural disaster which has left behind the near and dear ones in inconsolable distress. It was truly overwhelming when I heard that many of the men were stripped to confirm they were not their bloody clan. I had seen this painting and aptly describes the feelings.
29/04/25, 8:51‚ÄØam
As I was ambling through the vast Angkor Wat temple complex, savouring myriad sculptures that adorn it‚Äôs walls, I was particularly drawn to thousands of intricate stone carving that depict the dance of the Apsaras. The term "Apsara" refers to celestial nymphs or divine dancers in Hindu and Buddhist traditions, and are believed to be supernatural beings who entertain gods and kings with their graceful movements. The Apsara dance is a traditional Cambodian (Khmer) classical dance deeply rooted in Hindu and Buddhist mythology. It dates back to at least the 7th century and flourished during the Angkorian era (9th‚Äì15th centuries), particularly under King Jayavarman VII (12th century), whose court reportedly included over 3,000 Apsara dancers. The dance was performed at royal courts for ceremonies, festivals, and religious rituals, symbolizing a connection between the divine and human realms. The dance nearly vanished during the Khmer Rouge regime (1975‚Äì1979), when many artists were killed. It was revived in the mid-20th century and one can watch its performance at Siem Reap. Unfortunately, we know very little about the meanings and gestures of dance in ancient Cambodia. While a Sanskrit dance treatise, the Natyasastra, sheds light on ancient dance in India, no such text has survived in Cambodia. While the legacy of dance was transmitted orally and bodily, the Apsara dance performed today is often a modern reinvention. This particular dance form was created in the late 1950s by Queen Kossamak. The frontal focus, the twisted movement of bodies, and the flexible hand gestures seen in contemporary Apsara dance are derived from and inspired by the different poses depicted on Angkorian stone reliefs.
The Apsara dancers of Angkor Wat are more than just exquisite carvings on temple walls; they are symbols of Cambodia‚Äôs enduring spirituality, artistry, and cultural identity. Rooted in Hindu mythology yet shaped by Cambodian creativity, these Apsaras embody ideals of grace, beauty, and spirituality in a dance form that resonate across generations.
As Martha Graham commented, ‚ÄúDance is the hidden language of the soul.‚Äù
The attached image from Bayon temple is just a small sampler!
(Penned on the International Dance Day 29th April)

He wants to complain to the government and comment on twitter!! Which falls on deaf ears.
10/05/25, 9:15‚ÄØam
During our sojourn in the Rann of Kutch we were keen to have a glimpse of the Grey Hypocolius. We drove around on an early morning and spotted it, perched on the higher branches of ‚ÄòSalvadora Persica‚Äô, also known as the Miswak tree. Its twigs and roots are used to clean teeth due to their antibacterial properties. Prophet Muhammad reportedly recommended its use to maintain oral hygiene.
Hypocolius are generally shy birds and it so wonderful to see it. It was oblivious to our presence and was savouring the berries in a leisurely fashion. Hypocolius migrates from West Asia to Western India during winter, with the Greater Rann of Kachchh being a major wintering ground. They breed in areas like Iraq, Iran, Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Turkmenistan, and winter in the Arabian Peninsula, Pakistan, and Western India.
War significantly impacts bird migration. The sounds of blazing guns and flashing lights from the bombs often frighten the birds, forcing them to search out new migratory routes and some of them might perish during the journey. In spite of it, they make the journey with hope tucked in their feathers.
These migratory birds connect people, ecosystems and nations. They are symbols of peace in a world in throes of turmoil.
(Penned on the occasion of World Migratory Bird Day)
Dr Raguram
12/05/25, 9:28‚ÄØam
Buddha Jayanti honours three major events in the Buddha's life: his birth in Lumbini, his attainment of enlightenment under the Bodhi tree in Bodhgaya, and his Mahaparinirvana in Kusinaga. When Buddha is meditating under the Bodhi tree, Mara tries to tempt and distract him. Buddha's encounter with Mara is a pivotal moment in Buddhist history, encapsulating the core of his spiritual journey, facing and transcending obstacles on the path to enlightenment.
In cave number 26 at Ajanta, there is an elaborate relief panel which depicts how Mara confronts and disturbs Buddha who is in deep meditation. In the centre of the panel, Buddha is in the varada (bestowing gifts) mudra and sits under the Bodhi tree. In the upper left half of the panel, the evil demon Mara is seen sitting astride a large elephant. His fearsome forces are shown all around, trying to defeat the Buddha before he achieves enlightenment. Mara‚Äôs three daughters Rati (lust), Trishna (thirst), and Arati (delight) dance at the Buddha‚Äôs feet, with hopes of breaking his meditation with lustful advances. In the bottom right hand corner, a dejected and defeated Mara is portrayed with his hand to his head beside his daughters.
The tale of the Buddha's victory over Mara is a timeless narrative that captures the core of the Buddhist journey to enlightenment. In Buddhist teachings, Mara's temptation symbolizes the obstacles and distractions that hinder spiritual progress. It teaches that the quest for truth and liberation demands unwavering determination, the capacity to conquer desire, fear, and doubt, and the readiness to turn adversity into spiritual growth.
Buddhacarita, is the poetic narrative of the life of the Buddha by the Sanskrit poet Ashvaghosha, and is one of the finest examples of Buddhist literature. Chapter 13 details the defeat of Mara and ends with this sloka;
‚ÄútathƒÅpi pƒÅpƒ´yasi nirjite gate di≈õa·∏• prasedu·∏• prababhau ni≈õƒÅkara·∏• |
divo nipeturbhuvi pu·π£pav·πõ·π£·π≠ayo rarƒÅja yo·π£eva vikalma·π£ƒÅ ni≈õƒÅ‚Äù
‚ÄúWhen the wicked one thus fled vanquished, the different regions of the sky grew clear, the moon shone forth, showers of flowers fell down from the sky upon the earth, and the night gleamed out like a spotless maiden.‚Äù
Dr Raguram
14/05/25, 6:26‚ÄØpm
Oh definitely Sir. I would love to. Thank you for the invite.
18/05/25, 8:17‚ÄØam
Endangered Species Day is observed annually on the third Friday of May, and is dedicated to raising awareness about threatened species and the importance of conserving these species. At least 900 species are already extinct till date, while at least 28,5000 others are listed as endangered or critically endangered by the IUCN, the International Union for Conservation of Nature, which is the global wildlife conservation authority. It classifies species into one of nine Red List Categories: Extinct, Extinct in the Wild, Critically Endangered, Endangered, Vulnerable, Near Threatened, Least Concern, Data Deficient and Not Evaluated.
The red-headed vulture is listed as being Critically Endangered on the IUCN Red List. This classification reflects the species' precarious population status and high risk of extinction. This is one of the 9 species of vulture which are found in India. It is also called the Asian King vulture or Pondicherry Vulture. The red-headed vulture is one of the few species of large vultures that does not live in big groups and is usually found alone or as a breeding pair. With its wingspan of over two metres the red-headed vulture is truly impressive especially when it is flying. Like most vultures their diet consists of carrion and they have been observed feeding on the carcasses of cattle. They play a crucial role in the ecosystem by cleaning up animal remains. This species has experienced a dramatic decline in both population size and distribution. In India it has been estimated that the population decreased by over 90% in just 10 years. This decline has been largely attributed to the use of the drug Diclofenac by veterinarians.
Mr Bharatidasan through his NGO ‚ÄòArulagam‚Äô has played a stellar role in drawing attention to the importance of conserving this species through consistent, dedicated, efforts in the field. He along with his team has been educating the villagers about the consequences of usage of diclofenac through conducting village meetings, programs in the schools and involving senior members of the community in the conservation efforts. I had known him for over a decade and he is truly an inspiration. It was a privilege to accompany him to his field area and observe the tangible impact of his efforts. I will never forget the experience of seeing at least a hundred of various vultures, including the Red headed vulture, which are considered to be critically endangered.
In the Ramayana, there are references to two vultures, Jatayu and Sampati. While the tale of the former is rather well known, the role of Sampati, remains largely overlooked. Sampati sacrifices his wings to shield Jatayu from the sun's heat, leading to his own loss of ability to fly. Later, with his exceptional eyesight, he spots Sita in Lanka and guides Hanuman and the Vanara army towards her location. Though Jatayu and Sampati are key figures in the epic which is read widely, vultures have had a negative reputation in the minds of people as they feed on carcases. Often referred to demeaningly as "nature's garbage collectors", it fails to acknowledge the crucial importance of vultures in sustaining our environment.
Vultures like the Red headed ones are the unsung heroes of our ecosystem and saving them should be our responsibility and a top priority.
‚ÄúSoaring high above
They scan the ground with ancient skill
Clean the earth with quite will
Yet remain unloved and misjudged‚Äù
Dr Raguram
23/05/25, 9:26‚ÄØam
I am besotted with the hornbills, particularly the Great Indian Hornbill. My first sighting of this majestic bird was in Karian Shola in Anamalai Tiger Reserve, near Coimbatore. The stately bird with a commanding presence flew in to feed the chick in the nesting hole, high up in the tree. Over the years many more sightings ensued, almost all of them alone or in pairs. It was different when we went birding recently in the Royal Manas National Park. There were scores of them flying around and perching on trees. I have never seen so many of them together in my life. The forest came alive in their colourful presence.
The Great Indian Hornbill plays a crucial role in sustaining biodiversity by acting as a key agent in seed dispersal, which is crucial for forest regeneration and the overall health of the ecosystem. They are referred to as "farmers of the forest" or "engineers of the forests" because they play a vital role in dispersing seeds of various tropical trees. They consume a wide variety of fruits, including figs, and then disperse the seeds through their droppings in different locations, away from the parent plant. This helps in preventing competition among seedlings and aids in forest regeneration. By dispersing seeds, they help establish new tree populations and ensure the diversity of plant life in the jungle. Their presence and activity contribute to a healthy ecosystem by supporting the growth and diversity of plant life, which in turn supports other wildlife.
In India we are blessed with a wide variety of biomes ranging from driest deserts to the moist rain forests, which harbour an astounding variety of flora and fauna. It is a sad fact that we have lost 90% of them which are biodiversity hotspots. Ravaging the biosphere in the guise of ‚Äòdevelopment‚Äô will leave lasting impact on the health of the planet and our wellbeing too.
The life around us is an intricate, diverse, beautiful web. On this day let us commit ourselves not to fray it further.
(Penned on the occasion of International Day of Biodiversity, 22nd May)
Dr Raguram
27/05/25, 9:40‚ÄØam
On her birthday today, 27th May, let us recall Rachel Carson whose work profoundly shaped the environmental movement. In her most influential work ‚ÄòSilent Spring‚Äô, Carson‚Äôs drew attention to the devastating effects of pesticides, particularly DDT, on ecosystems, wildlife, and human health. The book documented how indiscriminate pesticide use harmed birds, fish, and other organisms, disrupting food chains and causing widespread ecological damage. Its evocative title referred to a future where birdsong might vanish due to pesticide-induced deaths. The book‚Äôs impact was monumental. It sparked national debate and led to the eventual U.S. ban on DDT in 1972. It also drew attention to the fact that we are part of an interconnected ecosystem and how indifferent actions can have a rippling effect endangering it.
Insecticide use is a double-edged sword. While they offer benefits like increased crop yields and disease control, they also pose risks to human health and the environment. Unfortunately, pesticide use in India has significantly increased, especially in recent decades, driven by factors like climate change, the need for increased agricultural output, and the adoption of high-yielding crop varieties. There is growing concern about their impact on human health and the environment, including potential contamination of soil and water.
On this background, the stellar contributions of Rachel Carson are all the more relevant now. If we don‚Äôt pay heed to her observations, we will end up in a world where ‚Äúthe sedge has withered from the lake/ And no birds sing.‚Äù These lines are from John Keats' poem "La Belle Dame Sans Merci". It describes the withering of the sedge (a type of grass) at the lake, signifying a sense of desolation and decay in a barren and bleak landscape devoid of the rejuvenating songs of the birds.
In every brilliantly veined leaf, in every grain of food that we partake, there is a beautiful story of the earth which we have to attune ourselves to.
Dr Raguram
28/05/25, 9:06‚ÄØam
We reached Elkhorn Slough early in the morning to have a good glimpse of its rich aquatic life. We got into the boat and made our way through its tidal flats, creeks and marshes, all teeming with amazing variety of aquatic plants and animals.
It was a beautiful clear blue sky and we saw scores of pelicans, herons. As we were busy training our binoculars on them, I spotted a southern sea otter who was leisurely cruising on its back. Soon we saw several of them swimming together, rolling around in the water playfully and watching us right back. One of them was using a stone to crack open some shelled prey and devouring it, using its tummy as a dinner plate. Once it finished eating, it spent a few minutes rigorously cleaning its dense coat with its teeth and paws. Sea otters have the thickest fur of any animal and were hunted extensively for it. Elkhorn Slough has one of the largest resident colony of southern sea otters.
Southern sea otters are considered as keystone species, as they play a crucial role in maintaining the health and balance of the marine ecosystems, particularly kelp forests. They help regulate the population of sea urchins, which can overgraze and destroy kelp forests, by preying on them. This helps to maintain the biodiversity of kelp forests and supports a wide variety of other marine life that rely on them.
It was fascinating to watch the otters dipping, diving playfully. Seamus Heaney offers a wonderful description of them, in his poem ‚ÄòThe Otter‚Äô:
‚ÄúTurning to swim on your back,
Each silent, thigh-shaking kick
Re-tilting the light,
Heaving the cool at your neck.
And suddenly you're out,
Back again, intent as ever,
Heavy and frisky in your freshened pelt‚Äù
(28th May is World Otter Day)
Dr Raguram
29/05/25, 9:23‚ÄØam
Whenever I read Paul Lawrence Dunbar‚Äôs poem, "Sympathy", it leaves me deeply moved. The poet uses the symbol of a caged bird to voice his angst against societal oppression. The bird suffers from the ‚Äúold, old scars‚Äù of past and it beats itself against its cage until its ‚Äúblood is red on the cruel bars.‚Äù But in spite of it, it keeps singing. It is a song of pain.
No wonder this poem was the inspiration to Maya Angelou, to title her poignant autobiography, ‚ÄòI know why the caged bird sings.‚Äô Among others, it is a searing account of her abuse and rape very early in life and ensuing trauma which cast a long shadow in her life. Angelou gave voice to countless survivors of sexual assault who, like her, endured years of trauma and silence. ‚ÄúWrite so that perhaps people who hadn‚Äôt raped anybody yet might be discouraged, people who had might be informed, people who have not been raped might understand something, and people who have been raped might forgive themselves.‚Äù Her memoir powerfully conveys a message of resilience and revival, which she poetically refers as, ‚Äúthe honeycomb of determination‚Äù. Angelou also movingly describes the trials and tribulations of growing up as a black adolescent in a crushing climate of overt racism and inherent discrimination.
The publication of this book paved way for countless women to feel inspired to narrate and share aspects of their lives that had long been shrouded in euphemism, secrecy, and shame.
Angelou summarizes her perspective succinctly, ‚ÄúMy mission in life is not merely to survive, but to thrive; and to do so with some passion, some compassion, some humour, and some style.‚Äù
(Maya Angelou 4 April 1928 - 28 May 2014)

04/06/25, 9:22‚ÄØam
During my early adolescent years, my uncle presented me with a BSA bicycle. I didn‚Äôt know how to ride one at that time. The task then, was to learn to ride it and in the process I fell down many a time and finally found the right balance to steer it. I often use this analogy in therapy to address the trauma and pain due to unfortunate tribulations in life which dawn upon us. These can unsettle us, but if we choose to, only briefly. The task is to unearth the emotional balance within, to navigate through the situation. The seeds for this perspective were sown through a painting of Claude Bernard outside our lecture theatre in JIPMER. Claude Bernard's concept of "milieu int√©rieur" meaning "internal environment" is a fundamental principle in physiology and medicine. It describes the body's ability to maintain a stable internal environment (homeostasis) despite external changes. Our task is to harness it, sometimes through external support and help.
Another important learning curve for me when I started cycling was that the bicycle becomes a part of you. It merges with the rhythm of pedalling and the diktats of the driver. Personally it broadened my urban and inner landscape, much as outlined in ‚ÄòZen and the art of motorcycle maintenance‚Äô. Cycling is as close to flying, you feel free, your mind feels free and your spirits take flight. It was through cycling I discovered the nooks and corners of the city and its people. I took great pride in cleaning it meticulously and taking care of it, till I handed it over to my nephew.
There is a lovely quote attributed to Mehmet Murat ildan:
Four wheels move the body, Two wheels move the soul.
Every time you miss your childhood, ride on a bicycle!
( Reflections on my cycling days, on 3rd June, the World Bicycle Day)
Dr Raguram

Thank you Sir, though it is a very familiar area for me!
05/06/25, 10:22‚ÄØam
The Tamil Sangam poetry (circa 1st to 4th century CE) is a unique literary tradition among various streams of Indian literature. Devoid of mythological and religious allusions. It focused more on the environment and its impact on the individual. While the broad Sangam literature is generally categorized into akam (inner) and puram (outer), what is of great importance is that these two categories of poetry were painted on the ecological canvas of ‚Äútinais‚Äù. Tinais refer to five different environments; kurinji (mountainous regions), mullai (pastoral regions), marutham (riverine agricultural regions), neidhal (coastal regions) and palai (arid, desert regions). Sights and sounds of the environment is manifested in different locations like the mysterious mountain peaks, murmuring cool ponds and rivers, noisy sea shore, dry soulless desert land and rich agricultural pastures.
In PuranƒÅn≈´ru 2, Poet Muranjiyur MudinƒÅkanƒÅr writes;
‡ÆÆ‡Æ£‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ£‡Æø‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§ ‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ©‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡Æ®‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ©‡Øç ‡Æè‡Æ®‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æö‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æö‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç‡Æ™‡ØÅ ‡Æ§‡Øà‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ ‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æø‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡Æµ‡Æ≥‡Æø‡Æ§‡Øç ‡Æ§‡Æ≤‡Øà‡Æá‡ÆØ ‡Æ§‡ØÄ‡ÆØ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç,
‡Æ§‡ØÄ ‡ÆÆ‡ØÅ‡Æ∞‡Æ£‡Æø‡ÆØ ‡Æ®‡ØÄ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç, ‡Æé‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ±‡Ææ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ
‡Æê‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÜ‡Æ∞‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç ‡Æ™‡ØÇ‡Æ§‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡ØÅ ‡Æá‡ÆØ‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æï‡Øà ‡Æ™‡Øã‡Æ≤
These verses describe a king by comparing his nature to the five elements, ‚ÄúYour nature is like the five elements ‚Äì the earth filled with sand,
the sky raised above the earth, wind that blows in the sky, fire that
sweeps up the wind, and water that contrasts from that fire.‚Äù
The poem draws attention to the intricate relationship between us and the environment we live in. It is imperative then to value and cherish this association.
(Penned on 5th June, World Environment Day)
Dr Raguram

08/06/25, 10:05‚ÄØam
Point Lobos State National Reserve in California is dramatically situated at the edge of the Pacific Ocean. It is often referred to as the ‚Äúgreatest meeting of land and water in the world‚Äù. Its rocky coastline offers a superb habitat for a huge diversity of plants animals and birds. Every time we visit the place, we feel mesmerized by its dramatic landscape. This enchanting landscape is a haven of tranquillity. At times one can hear the ocean's voice as a chorus of deafening roars when its powerful waves crash upon the rocks. But soon the waves start lapping gently against the rocks as if they are in a whispered conversation.
As I was scanning the oceanscape, I noticed a groups of Brandt‚Äôs cormorants perched on the craggy surface of the rocks. They are the largest cormorants on the Pacific Coast. Brandt's cormorants are fascinating seabirds with unique diving abilities and can often dive deep to catch fish. They roost together as groups on rocks and forage in flocks. It was a fascinating sight when they suddenly took to the sky, flying in long lines over the rippling waters of the ocean.
The Pacific Ocean in Point Lobos is a vast expanse mirroring the endless blue sky above, its surface a restless expanse of waves shimmering in sunlight. Watching it, I was reminded of a poem ‚ÄòOnce By The Pacific‚Äô by Robert Frost.
‚ÄúThe shattered water made a misty din.
Great waves looked over others coming in,
And thought of doing something to the shore
That water never did to land before.
The clouds were low and hairy in the skies,
Like locks blown forward in the gleam of eyes.
You could not tell, and yet it looked as if
The shore was lucky in being backed by cliff,
The cliff in being backed by continent;
It looked as if a night of dark intent
Was coming, and not only a night, an age.
Someone had better be prepared for rage.
There would be more than ocean-water broken
Before God's last Put out the light was spoken.‚Äù
(8th June is World Oceans Day)
Dr Raguram
11/06/25, 9:02‚ÄØam
We are all dreamers of dreams. Though it is a part of our real world experience, dream is also a window into our subconscious mind. Sometimes, our minds teeter on the edge of two worlds; the reality outside of us and the dreamscape within. In that state, we are neither fully immersed in the dreamscapes of our subconscious nor fully anchored in the rationality of waking life. Often it is a fertile breeding ground for deep reflection.
Zhuangzi, a foundational figure in Daoist philosophy, is famous for his parable of the butterfly dream. The story blurs the boundary between self and other. Zhuangzi wonders if he can truly know whether he is the dreamer or the dreamed, highlighting the limits of human understanding and the need to embrace uncertainty. He implies that life is a series of transformations, a constant flux of existence, wherein the distinction between the self and the other dissolves, leading to a newer level of awareness. Zhuangzi‚Äôs uncertainty about whether he is the dreamer or the dreamed also draws our attention to the perennial question, what defines the self?
In her travels in the wonderland, Alice had to confront this perennial question. She comes across a Caterpillar that is resting on top of a giant mushroom and smoking a hookah pipe. The two stare at each other in silence for a while before the Caterpillar asks Alice, ‚ÄúWho are you? This was not an encouraging opening for a conversation. Alice replied, rather shyly, ‚ÄúI--I hardly know, sir, just at present-- at least I know who I WAS when I got up this morning, but I think I must have been changed several times since then.‚Äù
Both Zhuangzi and Lewis Carroll indicate that the concept of self is often fluid and dynamic.
As Carl Rogers commented, "A person is a fluid process, not a fixed and static entity; a flowing river of change‚Ä¶continually changing constellation of potentialities".
Dr Raguram
17/06/25, 10:01‚ÄØam
The crocodile has had a strange relationship with the people of India. It has been both revered and feared, considered a protector and a menace. It figures in puranas and in various mythological accounts. The most well-known mention about the crocodile is in Bhagavat Purana, as the legend of Gajendra Moksha. Gajendra, in his previous life as King Indradyumna, had neglected his duties and was cursed by Agastya to become an elephant. While fetching lotus flowers, he was seized by a crocodile and struggled to free himself, even trying to escape with his own strength for 1000 years. His friends and family also tried to help, but were unsuccessful. Finally, realizing his limitations, Gajendra prayed to Vishnu for help, offering a lotus flower as a symbol of devotion. Lord Vishnu, pleased with his prayer, appeared on Garuda and killed the crocodile, liberating Gajendra.
There is an extraordinary depiction of this legend in Hoysaleshwar temple, Halebidu. Perhaps this is one of the most detailed depiction of the Gajendra Moksham. Vishnu is seated in Lalitasana and is holding an arrow, mace, and is Sudarshan Chakra. Garuda is carrying Vishnu and is covered with various ornaments. One can also see his wings on both sides. Bellow him, is the elephant struggling to survive. He is holding a lotus and presenting it to Vishnu. Under the right knee of Garuda, is the crocodile holding down the elephant in his killer jaws.
The overarching message of Gajendra Moksham is a spiritual one, reminding us to prioritize the eternal connection with the divine over transient material pursuits. It encourages a deeper reflection on the impermanence of life and the importance of turning towards a higher power for solace and liberation from the cycle of suffering.
As Srimat Bhagavatam states in verse 8.3.25
‡§ú‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø-
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•á‡§≠‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§
‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ-
‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç
I do not wish to live anymore after I am released from the attack of the crocodile. What is the use of an elephant‚Äôs body covered externally and internally by ignorance? I simply desire eternal liberation from the covering of ignorance.
(June 17th is celebrated as the World Crocodile Day)
